column2: NAPLES, Dec. 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- An American officer searching for some ordinary gravel has uncovered what two Italian scientists described today as one of the most important archaeological discoveries ever made in Italy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Thirteen thousand cases of reported sabotage have been investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the two years the country has been at war and one in ten has been found to be actual, Fred Hallford, special agent in charge of the Springfield office of the FBI, fold the convention of the Illinois State's Attorneys' Association today.

Formation of an American Association for an International Office for Education, consisting of leaders in industry, labor, religion and education, to serve as "an essential instrument for an enduring peace," was announced yesterday.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Dec. 28 -- Freemen, Inc., an organization of West River Valley residents fighting the proposed Federal dam at West Dummerston, sent broadcast today "an alarm and an appeal to save the homes and to maintain the sovereignty of Vermont against invasion by Federal bureaucracy."
LONDON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The link and contrast between Versailles in 1919 and the still unknown place and time of the next peace conference were dramatized yesterday when Field Marshal Smuts received the Woodrow Wilson Award on the eighty-seventh anniversary of Mr. Wilson's birth. Of Versailles and the League Mr. Smuts felt compelled to admit that "we failed, and our failure is writ large in the vast tragedy of today."

Sir Godfrey Haggard, British Consul General here since 1938, will retire in February, it was announced yesterday by the British Information Services, and will be succeeded by Francis Edward Evans, who came here four months ago from the Foreign Office in London to serve as senior consul in the Consulate General until Sir Godfrey reaches the retirement age of 60 on Feb. 6.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Dec. 29 -- Dropping all pretense of further collaboration with Vichy, which will henceforth accept "orders," Otto Abetz, the German Ambassador to the French Government, had a lengthy interview with Chief of State Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain late yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Bolivian Embassy announced today, upon the basis of advices from La Paz, that the revolutionary government there was prepared to take "first steps" toward assuring greater economic cooperation with the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- War production reached in December the all-time record rate af $80,000,000,000 a year, which, if maintained would be more than enough to meet Schedules for 1944, Lawrence A. Appley, executive director tor of the War Manpower Commission said today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 28 -- For the first time in six years of periodic sampling of public opinion on the issue of amending the Constitution to limit the Presidency to two terms, a majority of American voters are today in favor of such a plan.

The current break-even point for a large independent steel company is very close to 80 per cent, according to the corporation's records of costs and prices. This means that if operations are at 90 per cent, or 85 per cent of capacity, something will be earned for the stocks, whereas a drop in operations to 75 per cent or lower would bring losses.

Textile officials from the Washington headquarters of the War Production Board will arrive in New York next week to help clear up confusion created in the cotton textile and garment industries by the agency's new program designed to channel civilian output of scarce fabrics into essential garments for infants and children, it was reported yesterday by Worth Street suppliers.

Women's organizations are preparing to descend on Albany when the Legislature opens a week from today. They will bear various bills, some continuing campaigns waged for years, others dealing with conditions arising out of the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The voices of "profiteers, chiselers, lobbyists and pressure groups have been altogether too loud and too insistent" for the good of a nation at war, Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, said tonight.

Borodin's "Prince Igor" was presented by Michel Kachouk's Russian Opera Company last night in Carnegie Hall. At this performance an orchestra, conducted by Zinovy Kogan, replaced the two-piano support previously employed in the company's offerings, and the opera was acted out in costume, instead of being given in concert form.

The stock market underwent yesterday a further dipping spell under the pressure of renewed year-end tax selling. Many issues which had not received any attention recently appeared on the reporting tape as activity embraced the largest number of individual stocks since early November.

Common sense must be the guide when landlords and tenants disagree about how essential a doorman is these days, according to Louis H. Pink, Area Rent Director for the Office of Price Administration. In a letter to a tenant, made public yesterday, he provided some helpful reflections on the subject.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 29 -- A panic rush by stokers and men from the lower decks marked the last minutes of the German battleship Scharnhorst, according to a survivor whose story was printed in this afternoon's Allehanda in Stockholm.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the re-capitalization plan of the Florida Power and Light Company, involving sale at competitive bidding of $45,000,000 of first mortgage bonds and $10,000,000 of sinking fund debentures and sale to banks of $5,000,000 of special notes.

ALGIERS, Dec. 29 -- In debating next week on plans for the post- war elections in France, the Consultative Assembly recently established here in conjunction with the French Committee of National Liberation expects to show it is not hand picked and its role is not that of a rubber stamp.

The very best New Year's resolution that one can recommend for persons in responsible public positions connected with the war is not to tell the American people what things mean but to tell the people what the things are. The people will then determine the meaning for themselves.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The country's railroads asked today for immediate examination of public safety possibilities in the proposed use of radio telephones on moving trains.

The first last-minute fight cancelation in his ten years as America's leading boxing promoter overtook Mike Jacobs, president of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, last night and was directly attributable to the war.

CHANGTEH, China, Dec. 21 (Delayed) -- On a charred roof timber of a demolished store building a crow looked off at Changteh with saturnine satisfaction. He was looking at a city that had been blasted off the face of the earth.

Through eleven "action" and advisory committees, experts in manufacturing, marketing, sales, finance, management and engineering have organized to make available to American business during 1944 the latest practical knowledge needed to achieve expansion of post-war production and employment to unprecedented peacetime levels, Marion B. Folsom, treasurer of the Eastman Kodak Company and chairman of the field development division of the committee for economic development, said in an interview here yesterday.

A drastic shortage of chocolate candy for civilians, caused by an unprecedented holiday demand and a mounting combination of shortages, was reported yesterday by manufacturers and distributors. To meet the situation retail stores have cut down their already curtailed business hours.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 30 -- Russian troops, advancing west and southwest of Kiev on a broadening front, yesterday captured the rail center of Korosten and swept five miles beyond it to within forty-eight miles of the pre-war Polish border, while in the Dnieper bend they opened a third winter offensive that plunged nine miles west of Zaporozhye.

Mrs. Paula Mona Wolfe, 27 years old, was found beaten to death at 12:15 o'clock this morning in her room on the ninth floor of the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, after a telephone call to Brooklyn headquarters had informed the police: "Send someone here, I just killed my wife."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Finns, like the Germans, were charged by Soviet Russia today, through the medium of the Information Bulletin issued by the Russian Embassy here, with the commission of "terrible crimes" in occupied Russian territory.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Buying of May wheat attributed to millers and of September by a house with cash and Southwestern connections gave that market a firm undertone in the face of easiness in other grains. Prices held within narrow limits until near the close, when a renewal of buying developed and the close was at the top with gains on the Board of Trade of 3/8 to 1/2 cent.

George Grey Barnard's old Cloisters, museum, home and studio where many of the late sculptor's works were executed and where he painstakingly assembled his outstanding collections of Romanesque and early Gothic art treasures, have been sold to a corporation which expects to utilize the big site at 698-700 Fort Washington Avenue for a large six-story apartment building after the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Postmaster General Frank C. Walker, as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, expressed confidence today that Congress would work out an absentee voting program which would enable service men and women, in this country and abroad, to participate in maximum numbers in the election of the President, Vice President and the Seventy-ninth Congress in 1944.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (AP) -- United States District Judge Guy K. Bard approved today a revised plan of the Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company for the payment of "bonuses" to 160 executives in the form of options to buy 300,000 shares of the company's authorized but unissued common stock.

Members of Tammany expressed interest yesterday in the attempt of Edward V. Loughlin, leader of the Fourteenth Assembly District, to bring about a meeting of the Tammany executive committee for the purpose of ousting Michael J. Kennedy as leader.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Barring a severe drought or some unforeseen disaster, War Food Administration officials predicted today a food supply for civilians in 1944 approximating that for 1943, although some existing tight spots will probably get tighter, they said.

Consumer cooperatives in this country set a new record in 1943 for trade and membership volume, it was made known yesterday by Wallace J. Campbell of the Cooperative League of the U.S.A. He estimated retail sales of co-ops at close to $750,000,000, while memberships passed the 2,500,000 mark.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- The induction into the Army of a 29-year-old father of seven children, who expects an eighth child soon, was reported today by Draft Board 748 of this city. The board said this induction marked a trend here that has gained momentum since the board drafted its first father in October and has now resulted in fifty-six fathers being sent into the services.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Dec. 30 -- Flame-throwers blasted Japanese pill boxes as United States Marines fought their way half a mile forward through the jungle to within a mile of the Cape Gloucester, New Britain, airfields, it was announced today.
Gifts from Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands were presented yesterday to the thirteen members of the Pan-American Clipper who flew her from Canada to Europe last July.
The Japanese said yesterday that their forces in China had "returned to their original base of operations" after a plunge into the "rice bowl" area of northern Hunan Province.

Wives of thousands of service men are flocking here to spend the New Year week-end with their husbands on holiday leave, Army Emergency Relief headquarters at 165 Broadway revealed yesterday. - record influx "far exceeding the Christmas week-end rush" was predicted at the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The amount of material necessary to supply the invasion forces in western Europe will be so tremendous that it will dwarf the quantity of supplies shipped for the offensives in North Africa and Italy, Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, told a meeting of executives of the board's reorganized Office of Operations today.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
Waste paper now ranks with steel, iron, aluminum and rubber as a No. 1 war essential.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Proposals made in some Democratic and Republican quarters for a unified declaration of foreign policy in the major party platforms took a new form today in a suggestion by Representative Bloom of New York, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, that the Presidential candidates themselves agree on this question.

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank has sold to an investing client of Julius Krefetz, lawyer, the vacant land at 113-23 West Fifty-first Street, through to 112-18 West Fifty-second Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, now used for automobile parking.
Communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The six-story apartment house, containing forty-three suites, on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 1104 Manor Avenue, corner of Watson Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Aaron Rabinowitz, James L. Clare and Adrian P. Burke, as trustees of Mortgage Series F-1, to a client of Louis Bierfass, attorney.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Dec. 29 -- Miss Ruth Harvey, 25, a practical nurse, died today in Bryn Mawr Hospital of burns suffered two weeks ago when she disregarded her own safety to protect an infant from flames.

LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- With the hour of the Allied invasion of Hitler's Europe approaching, the Germans reported tonight a series of British commando thrusts on the Channel islands within twenty-two miles of French Normandy.

On both the European and the Pacific fronts the policy of fluid design, constantly improved to incorporate lessons learned from battle, is proving its great value. This policy has made possible the production of a new first team of combat planes in the very midst of the battle. It is a complete answer to the policy of frozen designs and overstandardization which both the Germans and the Japanese have adopted.
New York State's most abundant fur-bearer, the muskrat, may be taken in traps starting New Year's Day, according to an announcement yesterday from the Conservation Department in Albany.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday its program of State legislation on civil service matters. Included in the program is a proposal for legislation to prohibit payment of pension benefits out of public funds to officials or employes who misappropriate public funds or property or are guilty of other corrupt practices.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Plans for an eight-engined airliner designed for performance higher than that of any aircraft now in use have been submitted to the Ministry of Aircraft Production by F.G. Miles, famous British designer.

After early irregularity caused by liquidation and hedging the cotton futures market recovered yesterday under moderate commission-house demand and mill price-fixing in the near-by March position. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures ended the session near the day's best levels and with net gains of 1 to 6 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The War Production Board today announced that a new branch, known as the copper recovery inventory branch, has been organized within its copper division and will have headquarters on the forty-third floor of the Empire State Building in New York City.

The annual report of the Beech Aircraft Corporation for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, disclosed that without adding any substantial new facilities during the year, the value of deliveries was more than double that of the preceding year and more than fifteen times the value of deliveries in the fiscal year ended in 1941.

Greatly enlarged promotional and advertising campaigns on behalf of the Certified Performance Program for gas ranges are seen as effective answers to the threat of post-war competition of electric ranges by Arthur P. Hirose, promotion and market research director of McCall's and Redbook magazines.

As the Russian armies, driving west on winter's winds in a renewal of their great offensive, rout the German forces beyond Kiev and approach the pre-war borders of Poland, a situation threatens to arise which will test the statesmanship of the United Nations. Of all the political problems which this war has raised, the potential conflict between Polish nationalism and Russian strategy is admittedly the most difficult and the most explosive.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Admiral Sir Bertram Ramsay and Air Chief Marshal Trafford L. Leigh-Mallory, British commanders tested in four years of war, have been named as sea and air chiefs under Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Commander in Chief in the coming invasion of northwest Europe.

Merchant seamen gave a Christmas party yesterday afternoon for 100 children of torpedoed mariners at the Andrew Furuseth Club of the United Seamen's Service, 30 East Thirty-seventh Street. Each youngster received a game as a gift, as well as refreshments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Asserting that President Roosevelt was obviously "using every strategy at his command to build a fourth and perhaps continual term in the White House," Senator Robertson, Republican, of Wyoming, called on the President today to state his political intentions.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 29 -- Drastic changes in the Wagner-Murray-Dingell bill to provide national health insurance were recommended today by the Committee of Physicians for the Improvement of Medical Care, Inc., composed of leading members of the medical faculties of Harvard, Yale, Columbia, Johns Hopkins and other leading medical schools throughout the country.

IT always is pleasant to receive mail, particularly at Christmas time. There is the moment of anticipation before opening an envelope, possibly even a preliminary exploration of the handwriting to try and guess the sender, and then the delights of getting messages from old friends, new friends and sometimes even forgotten friends.

The regional War Labor Board approved yesterday a general increase of $1.25 a week for 1,900 employes of Bloomingdale's department store, it was announced by Theodore W. Kheel, board chairman. The increase is retroactive to Feb. 28, 1943.

A statement by Dr. Tewfik Rushdu Aras, former Turkish Foreign Minister, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Dec. 26, contains the assertion that "it is safe to say that the largest majority of Poles never heard of Mikolajczyk," the Polish Prime Minister in exile.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- The magazine Railway Age catalogued tonight 1943 as "the greatest year in the history of American railroading since the first rail was laid." It offered these statistics:

LONDON, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans have crossed the Italian-Yugoslav border to a depth of twenty-five miles and attacked two German garrisons in a resurgence of guerrilla activity in northeastern Italy, Marshal Tito's (Josip Broz) communique announced today.
OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 29 -- Champagne splashed against the prow, bands played and several hundred guests cheered, but the ship failed to budge.
" There is an old, old custom of 'blessing' a gift which, skeptics to the contrary, often brings surprising results in its wake. This money I send you has been blest. May God go with it."

An internal fight for control of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company (Mokan), which in turn controls the rich Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, developed yesterday with the formation of a stockholders' committee whose announced intention is to oust William G. Maguire as president of Mokan.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a series of transactions leading to dissolution of the Walnut Electric and Gas Corporation, a holding company.

A plan for the return to manufacturers of used shipping containers from the stores has been worked out by the Toilet Goods Association to forestall possible major difficulties arising from the acute shortage of such containers. S.L. Mayham, executive secretary of the association, said yesterday the plan is not practicable on a national scale, but will be tried out in the metropolitan area of New York near-by New Jersey and Connecticut.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Prime Minister Churchill wrote a "thank you letter" to the world tonight, reassuring his countrymen and his Allies that he had recovered from his illness, but conceded that he still needed "a few more weeks in the sunshine" to recover his full strength.

An important site of antiquity that has come into prominence lately as the scene of bitter fighting in Italy by American and British troops was discussed yesterday afternoon at a symposium of the New York Society of the Archaeological Institute of America in the lecture hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- The Circuit Court of Appeals upheld today a Federal court decision that the caisson marching song had not been copyrighted by its composer, the late Brig. Gen. Edmund L. Gruber.
Sol Rubinow, City College champion, won the Intercollegiate Chess League individual title in the tourney that ended at the Marshall Chess Club last night. Rubinow swept seven matches.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Thursday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- American warships, bent on hastening the withdrawal of the Japanese from their last big Solomons base on Bougainville, ventured into waters Monday where they had not been before to shell the important enemy air and shipping point of Kieta for an hour and a half.

" Madame Curie," the Greer Garson-Walter Pidgeon starring vehicle at the Radio City Music Hall, today starts its third week. . . . "For Whom the Bell Tolls" has entered its twenty-fifth week at the Rivoli. . . . "Iran, Where the Big Three Met," a Soviet importation described as "the first comprehensive film of Iran," will open at the Victoria late in January as an added attraction with the Russian feature, "No Greater Love."

In this newspaper yesterday Frank Kluckhohn, our correspondent in New Guinea, related his experiences and those of a fellow correspondent. They were to report the landing of the Marines at Cape Gloucester. In the early morning of their first day they flew over the Stanley Mountains in an overloaded plane.

A supplementary allocation of coal to New York City appeared in prospect last night, promising a measure of relief in the fuel crisis facing the metropolitan area. The understanding among dealers and officials is that the extra supply will consist chiefly of bituminous with only a small portion of anthracite.

MADRID, Dec. 28 (Delayed) -- The first official figures on political prisoners of the present Spanish regime as a result of the civil war were disclosed today by Angel Sanz, Director General of Prisons, in an interview published in Arriba, Falange party organ. The number on Jan. 7, 1940, said Senior Sanz, was 270,719.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- The first formal step to enter the name of Gen. Douglas MacArthur in the Illinois Presidential preference primary was taken today by the MacArthur-for-President Club.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- The twenty-third annual College Week of winter sports of the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds had a gap in its program today because of a mix-up in travel reservations which prevented the arrival of the hockey teams. The officials and competitors on hand devoted the day to preparations for the start tomorrow of the skiing events. The cross-country is now scheduled for 10 o'clock in the morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Less than nine and a half hours before a strike vote deadline was to have become effective the railway firemen, conductors and switchmen's brotherhoods canceled their strike call tonight, according to an announcement made by Harry W. Fraser, Chief of the Order of Railway Conductors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Experts from the Army Signal Corps, aided by the Army Air Forces, have just accomplished a great feat in defeating the aurora borealis and other magnetic disturbances so that the task of ferrying aircraft across the North Atlantic has been greatly expedited.

For a year the principal efforts of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms have been devoted to the Wall Street salary problem, now on the road to solution. In 1944, according to John L. Clark, president, the association will spend more time in the field that it was reorganized to exploit: Public relations.

Individuals and firms reported yesterday as having taken new commercial quarters included the Newtex Steamship Corporation, through Cushman Wakefield, Inc., in 19 Rector Street and the Moran Towing and Transportation Company in 21 West Street.

BOUGAINVILLE ISLAND, Dec. 22 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- The marines consolidated positions on "Helizapoppin Ridge" today -- a ridge named by a lone grenade-throwing gunnery sergeant who helped break the most severe Japanese resistance of the entire Bougainville campaign.
Dutton announces publication of "The Siege of Leningrad" on Jan. 18, the first anniversary of the lifting of the city's siege. The authors are Boris Skomorovsky and E.G. Morris.

A report has just been received from Hearn's of the arrival from Minnesota of 1,300 turkeys, which are scheduled to go on sale today in the store, 20 West Fourteenth Street. The birds form half of a carload shipment received by this establishment, the other half consisting of fryers, broilers, roasters and fowl.
ALGIERS, Dec. 29 -- Heavy bombers of the Fifteenth Air Force roared back into action over Italy yesterday with powerful strategic blows at railway yards at Vicenza and Rimini, far north of the front.

A large cooperative apartment in the building at 1120 Fifth Avenue has been purchased by Van Rensselaer Lansingh of the Molybdenum Corporation of America through N.A. Berwin Co. and Douglas L. Elliman Co.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- British sea power struck another shattering blow at Germany on Monday and yesterday in the Bay of Biscay when a fast blockade runner believed to be nearing the end of its long journey from Japan, was sunk and three out of a strong force of eleven enemy destroyers were sent to the bottom, the British Admiralty and Air Ministry announced tonight in a joint communique.
GLADSTONE, N.J., Dec. 29 -- A British merchant seaman held up the half-finished furlough bag he was making.

The clear cold weather of the last few days has had a tendency to curb respiratory ailments, and the absentee rate, based upon a sample poll of the population, has dropped to half of what it was a fortnight ago, the Health Department reported yesterday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- Soviet military experts reported today that the situation on the general Soviet-German front "greatly resembles that which prevailed a month and a half ago," with the added advantage for the Russians that the Germans have expended large reserves, especially in tank forces, in the six-week drive for territory that has been largely retaken in a few days during the new Soviet offensive.
American pilots for the first time are flying Britain's crack night-fighter aircraft, the Beaufighter, the British Information Services revealed yesterday.

Sixteen housing authorities in various parts of the country awarded yesterday new issues of temporary loan notes aggregating $43,467,000. A syndicate headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company won the award of $31,538,000; Salomon Brothers Hutzler, $7,626,000; R.W. Pressprich Co., $1,840,000; the United States Trust Company, $915,000; Harvey Fisk Sons, Inc., $778,000, and the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, $770,000.

Murray Goldman, whose conviction of first-degree rape was set aside by Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz after Goldman had submitted to a lie-detector test, will be tried again on the original charge, Thomas Cradock Hughes, Acting District Attorney, announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 29 -- Bombers and fighters of the United States and British Air Forces in this theatre continue to expand their main effort in preventing the enemy from supplying the Dodecanese and other Aegean Islands under his control.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- A communique:
Ingenious hair ornaments will be a prominent fashion feature this New Year's Eve.

A contribution of 16,508,075 pounds of waste paper was made by 20,000 of the city's industrial plants to the paper salvage drive here between Nov. 20 and Dec. 20, it was announced yesterday by P.S. Anderson, War Production Board regional chief for industrial salvage.

There is but one pale touch of purple in what the British Admiralty has to say about the Scharnhorst action. It opened, says the Admiralty, "in the half-light of the Arctic dawn." After that things happened in bleak, precise English. The cruiser squadron "made contact" with the German battleship -- just that.

Substantial discharge payments to service men and dismissal or layoff wages to war workers, both for as long as six months if necessary, were advocated yesterday by Prof. Harold M. Somers of the School of Business Administration, University of Buffalo, as "the first requisite in preventing a depression which threatens either immediately after or soon after the war."

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. James Roosevelt told a radio audience today that changes made by the Japanese on Makin Island in the fifteen months between the two American attacks on that atoll had demonstrated that the Japanese were an enemy to be reckoned with.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Little business was done today on the stock markets here, but the tone remained firm. Industrial shares were a good feature. Among the textiles, British Celanese continued to do well after yesterday's strong start. Among the stores, Woolworth gained a few pence.

A man who had identified himself as James Monahan, 32 years old, was a most indignant witness before the grand jury yesterday when he accused two Harlem residents of holding him up. But when he had finished his testimony, he was turned over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a draft dodger who had been sought for more than two years.

A complete reorganization of present methods of teaching English to foreign adults has been necessitated by the flow of educated foreigners into our country, Frank W. Thomas, instructor in English at New York University's School of Education, said yesterday at a meeting of the National Association of Teachers of Speech at the Hotel Commodore.

Describing the 5,000,000 owners, executives and employes of the nation's retail stores as "among the Treasury's best salesmen in our war bond campaigns," Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. appealed yesterday to retailers to support the Fourth War Loan Drive, which starts Jan. 18.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 29 -- A ninety-minute engagement by the United States Marine Corps was described today by a paratroop raider, Corp. Max May of Blue Mountain, Miss., who was one of a daring band that carried out a diversionary operation on Choiseul as the Bougainville punch swung through the air.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The War Food Administration today ordered all existing freezer stocks of chicken and fowls set aside so that they would be available to the armed forces, and as a result the Office of Price Administration set ceiling prices which the Government and its agencies would pay when requisitioning or buying poultry in storage from producers, processors, wholesalers, hotel supply houses, restaurants, railroad dining cars, night clubs and retailers.

ALGIERS, Dec. 29 -- Canadian units of the British Eighth Army were driving up the Adriatic coastal road toward Francavilla and Pescara yesterday after the occupation of ruined and desolate Ortona at the end of nine days of the most brutal house-to-house fighting in the entire Italian campaign.

" Nothing in our post-war plans is so full of dynamite as the small item of rehabilitating European education," the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, said yesterday at the ninety-ninth Commencement of Fordham College and the Fordham College of Pharmacy in the gymnasium on the campus.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Allied air blows against the hard-pressed Japanese forces on all sectors of the Southwest Pacific battlefront continued to smash the enemy, it was announced today.

For the first time a band is to play a return engagement in the New York Stock Exchange. There have been many bands there, almost always at the last business session of the year, but the Salvation Army Staff Band under the baton of Major George Granger is the first to be asked to do it again.

The third of the holiday season basketball double-headers will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight when St. John's University opposes the University of Kentucky and Long Island University clashes with De Paul of Chicago. The St. John's-Kentucky encounter will be the feature on the program, which gets under way at 8:15.
I read with interest your editorial of Dec. 23 on renegotiation. I trust that you will bear with me if I set forth the War Department's position.
May I report with respect to the Latvian Minister and with sympathy for the difficult position of his people at this time the technical position between Britain and Latvia as it is explained to me?

Disclosure of the basis used by war contractors in determing the amount of renegotiation refunds or of the status of pending discussions is essential in the reports of industrial corporations if the stockholders or other interested parties are to be informed fairly on these points, according to a bulletin of the American Institute of Accountants mailed yesterday to members of the accounting profession and to financial executives of war production companies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration points to its record in the courts as the best answer to charges in Congress that it has operated without proper regard for the rights of citizens.

The winners of the All-American Jazz Band Poll have been announced by the Esquire committee of judges. They will receive $10,000 in war bond awards at the jazz concert and jam session they are to give at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night, Jan. 18, in connection with the opening of the Fourth War Bond Drive.

Gilbert Dodds was named yesterday by the Amateur Athletic Union as winner of the Sullivan Memorial Trophy in a poll of 600 sports leaders. This honor, bestowed annually on the athlete who does most to advance the cause of sportsmanship, represents the greatest distinction in a distinguished competitive career for the Boston divinity student.

A sprained ankle brought about an upset in the boys' singles of the Eastern junior and boys indoor tennis championships in progress at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday. MacDonald Mathey of Princeton, N.J., seeded No. 2, was defeated in the quarter-final round by Peter Lemon, New York, when young Mathey turned an ankle midway in the second set. Lemon triumphed, 7 -- 5 and 6 -- 4.

Striking back at the city firemen who had rejected his offer of a "cost of living" increase of $420 in their annual salary for 24 hours of extra work every 20 days, Mayor La Guardia issued two orders yesterday which have the joint effect of making uniformed members of the Fire Department subject to unlimited overtime without extra pay.

An industry meeting to protest the new OPA regulation rolling back prices of synthetic sole footwear will be held Jan. 5 in the Hotel McAlpin, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin Seligman of Seligman Seligman, counsel for the National Association of Playshoe and Slipper Manufacturers.
Two fine town houses on the East Side passed to new control in transactions reported yesterday.

Simultaneous announcements have been made by the Metropolitan Museum and the Whitney Museum of purchases from the current Whitney Museum annual exhibition of contemporary American art. When the show opened -- the first annual since the amalgamation of the two institutions -- it was stated that each organization was setting aside $10,000 for the purpose.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 -- Paramount has opened negotiations with Greta Garbo seeking her return to the screen for the starring role in an adaptation of Ferenc Molnar's play, "Olympia." Miss Garbo has not appeared in a picture since "Two Faced Woman" at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer two years ago.

Trained leaders with vision are needed urgently today, Dean Harry J. Carman of Columbia College told the Alumni Federation of Columbia University at its annual luncheon yesterday. Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, was unable to attend because of illness.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- A joint Admiralty and Air Ministry communique:
Jewish synagogues will observe New Year's Day as the National Day of Prayer as proclaimed by President Roosevelt.

The President's belief that "Win the War" is a better slogan for the times than "New Deal" will be shared by everyone who fully understands that we are fighting, and have been fighting for two years, for our very existence as a nation. It is the survival of our free institutions that is the great question now.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 29 -- Speculation over Allied invasion plans is accelerating the war of nerves in Germany. Public reaction to recent undertakings by the Anglo-American High Command indicates that the masses sense the early months of the new year will witness decisive events in the European theatre.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A proposal that the Senate act speedily to draw a line between executive agreements and treaties was made today by Senator Wallace H. White of Maine as a result of a Belgian leader's suggestion that peace be declared without a treaty.

A series of statements and affidavits detailing numerous acts of Anti-Semitism and desecration of Protestant churches and Jewish Synagogues in Washington Heights, was issued yesterday by the Eastern regional office of the Anti-Defamation League of the B'nai B'rith.

It is a matter of record and of much interest to this observer that a very large audience applauded often and enthusiastically, in the middle of scenes as well as at the ends thereof, at the revival of Bellini's "Norma" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 29 -- Columbia rallied in the final six minutes tonight to defeat Yale at basketball, 49 -- 42. The score was tied six times and the lead changed ten times.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Jacob Drucker, alleged "finger man" for the Brooklyn murder syndicate, arrested Monday in Wilmington, Del., has been released by Federal authorities to Delware police for extradition to New York, Attorney General Francis Biddle announced today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- The "folly" of considering Japan a permanent outcast from the family of nations was pictured by Joseph C. Grew, formerly Ambassador to Japan, in a speech at the annual banquet tonight of the Illinois Education Association.
LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Further slight improvement generally was made in the oil supply situation along the Atlantic seaboard last week. At the close of the period the index of the American Petroleum Institute covering gasoline stood at 43.2 against 42.4 at the end of the preceding week.

Representatives of American Distilling Company and transfer agents for its shares, Bank of the Manhattan Company, met yesterday, with an official of the New York Stock Exchange present, to work out the procedure to be followed for the stamping of shares to denote the sale of sixteen cases of whisky that the holder of each share may purchase.

Joseph A. Esquirol, who served as a State Senator from the Eighth Brooklyn District for ten years, was suspended yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn from the practice of law for five years.

From the standpoint of business not much separates the Wednesday matinee between Christmas and New Year's and the one of Washington's Birthday, generally conceded the best theatre afternoon of the year. Yesterday proved the point when two dozen of the thirty-one current Broadway offerings gave afternoon performances.

With the danger of air raids on New York believed greatly lessened, fifty paintings and busts that were taken from City College's halls and corridors to bomb-proof shelters immediately after Pearl Harbor will be restored to their former niches, President Harry N. Wright said yesterday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 29 -- Walker Gullatt's Navy, third to C.W. Anderson's Kanlast on Christmas Day, gained revenge at Tropical Park today when he dominated the running for the entire mile and a sixteenth and won the Lake City Purse by four lengths. Kanlast was second, three lengths better than Mrs. E.D. Jacobs' Sir Alfred.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 30 -- A strong force of Royal Air Force heavy bombers returned to the assault on Berlin last night, hammering the German capital so heavily a pall of smoke arose over the city soon after completion of the attack.

Without question, "South Pacific" has many good qualities. In the first place, Howard Rigsby and Dorothy Heyward, who wrote it, have brought to the play a sincerity which is not usual along Broadway, and they are not afraid to use the name for a spade when they see it.

Discontent is not always a protest against intolerable conditions. Discontent may be a sign that things are getting better, but not fast enough to meet heightened expectations. Growing resentment against race discrimination does not mean that discrimination is growing.

Publication of the tenth and final volume of the Universal Jewish Encyclopedia, with offices at 130 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, was announced yesterday by Dr. Isaac Landman, editor-in-chief. Louis Rittenberg is executive and literary editor.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A Fourteen Air Force communique:
A "state of emergency" for the Fire Department of this city was declared last night by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh after a brief conference with Mayor La Guardia at 4:30 P.M.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Indications that Premier Hideki Tojo of Japan has fallen into disgrace because he failed to maintain the unbroken string of victories piled up by Japan at the start of the war were seen today by Ta Kung Pao, Chungking's leading newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A House Naval subcommittee, reporting on an investigation into critical housing, health, food, transportation and other conditions in the congested Los Angeles-Long Beach sector, criticized the Joint Chiefs of Staff today as having failed to tell that West Coast production center what additional loads it must take on when the war program shifted to the Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Reflecting an easier supply situation in several of the products which have been critically short in the past, the War Production Board today removed delivery and sale restrictions on vanadium, cobalt, tungsten and molybdenum.
Yesterday's Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Local bow and arrow hunters may find food for thought in this, even though food of a more substantial sort eluded them during the deer season here.

The first prosecution of a New York landlord on charges of violating the Office of Price Administration's rent control regulations was reported yesterday with the filing of "criminal informations" by United States Attorney James B. McNally in Federal court against a Bronx apartment-house owner.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Government operation of the railroads for an indefinite period seemed likely tonight as President Roosevelt and eighteen railway unions prepared for a show-down fight on wages.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday to the best levels of the day at the close and 8 to 16 points over Wednesday's final quotations. Aggressive trade price-fixing in the near positions, year-end covering and scattered demand influenced largely by the firmness in grains and securities accounted for the market's strength.
Dr. George Wilfred Hartmann, chairman of the Peace Now Movement, asserted last night that the organization he heads was for a negotiated peace and opposed to any policy of unconditional surrender.

New Yorkers, planning what is predicted will be the biggest and gayest New Year's Eve celebration seen here in a long time, have made certain that the men and women serving the nation will be in on the hearty welcome to 1944.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Thomas Burke, chief of the Division of International Communications of the State Department, has resigned to return to private business. The State Department made public today a letter from Secretary Hull which said:

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 30 -- Army and Navy bombers met stiff opposition in three encounters at separate Japanese bases in the Marshall Islands Tuesday, losing three Liberators and shooting down at least five and possibly fifteen enemy fighter planes, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet and Pacific Ocean areas, announced today.

At midnight tonight Gen. Thomas Holcomb, commander of the Marines, retires from active service with four well-earned stars on his shoulder. For more than forty years he has served his country in peace and war. He now turns over to General Vandegrift one of the finest fighting forces in the world.

LONDON, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans asserted today that they had driven German punitive forces from the Croat provinces of Banija and Kordun, and had routed a Bulgarian unit on the Belgrade-Nish-Salonika rail line, German north-south supply route through the Balkans.

The invasion of the continent of Europe must be a "combined operation" in every sense. If it is to succeed -- and who dares contemplate failure -- all the forces the Allies can muster, on land, at sea and in the air, whatever their nationality, must function as a single unit with one purpose, to complement and assist each other to attain the common goal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The War Labor Board "will always refuse" to act on any case while a strike is in progress, William H. Davis, WLB chairman, declared tonight during a "March of Time" broadcast over the National Broadcasting Company network.

The post-war committee of the National Association of Manufacturers, according to The Associated Press, estimated yesterday that deferred consumer demand for things now unavailable because of war restrictions is equal to $22,500,000,000 worth of goods, including 10,000,000 automobiles and 20,000,000 radios.

TED MEREDITH stopped by the other day and that immediately pushed back the clock more than thirty years to the time when Ted, then only a Mercersburg schoolboy, was one of the idols of the athletic universe. He had just won the Olympic 800-meter championship in world record time, defeating Peerless Mel Sheppard, the seemingly invincible one.

The Metropolitan Opera has requested and received first performance rights outside of the Soviet Union to the new Russian opera, Sergei Prokofieff's setting of Tolstoy's "War and Peace," it became known yesterday. The work, like the novel from which it is drawn, deals with Napoleon's invasion of Russia, and it is written to cast new light and place in historical perspective the struggle of Russians today against another invading host.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 30 -- South and southeast Berlin were hit in last night's Royal Air Force blow, according to eyewitnesses arriving in Stockholm by this afternoon's passenger plane.

The barring by the Navy of John T. McManus, motion picture critic of the newspaper PM, from the submarine base at New London, Conn., on Dec. 22 resulted yesterday in a protest being sent to Navy Secretary Frank Knox by officers of the Newspaper Guild of New York.

In a quarter-final round upset yesterday in the Eastern junior indoor tennis tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Herbert Tilles of the Naval Academy eliminated Glenn Shively of Phillips Exeter, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4. Tilles was unseeded in the championship while Snively was rated No. 2.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, Dec. 31 -- United States marines have captured the Cape Gloucester airdrome, their objective, just four days after their landing on the northwestern tip of New Britain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Charges that the Finns had committed "terrible crimes" in occupied Russian territory were denied today by Hjalmar J. Procope, the Finnish Minister. The charges were made in the Information Bulletin issued by the Soviet Embassy here.

Art Young, who died in this city Wednesday night at the age of 77, wouldn't have liked to have it said that he was a lovable soul in spite of his sometimes heterodox opinions. He valued his opinions. He had worked them out for himself, and for them he had sacrificed the chance to accumulated a fair share of this world's goods.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30 -- Two ships were launched today at the Richmond yards of the Henry J. Kaiser organization in spite of a stalemate in a dispute between the Maritime Commission and the Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, AFL, over wage payments to the launching crews of vessels built for the commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- American education has made an Arab middle class which has been helpful to the Allies in the war, according to Miss Freya Stark, English author and photographer, who has written a colorful chapter for the British Information Services in the Near East.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- By midnight tomorrow the Federal Government will have spent more money in the 365 days of 1943 than it did in all the first 150 years of this country's existence.
In a recent letter to THE TIMES William Stix Wasserman expresses alarm over the possibility of post-war economic nationalism in the United States.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- About 2,000 women engineers in a Scottish war factory have just been joined in their strike for equal pay by 3,000 of their male colleagues. Another 6,000 women, working at a large Lancaster bomber factory, are reported to be threatening another strike on the same issue.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The largest crowd since opening day, 5,205 fans, watched Jake Freedman's Sir War speed to a length-and-a-half victory in the Daytona Purse, today's feature event at Tropical Park. Claire Critchfield piloted the 4-year-old over the six furlongs in 1:11 2-5. Sir War paid $17.90 for $2.

Starting tonight and continuing through Sunday night (four performances in all), the team of Paul Draper and Larry Adler will hold forth at the City Center, 135 West Fifty-fifth Street, in a program featuring their specialized type of entertainment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- On the heels of President Roosevelt's adoption of the slogan "Win the War" in place of "New Deal," the United Mine Workers Journal, official organ for John L. Lewis' miners' union, says that the New Deal died more than six years ago.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 30 -- The existence of dog fights that are waged "to the death" in Bergen County and on whose outcome "high stakes" are wagered was bared today in an official report filed in the State Library in Trenton by Governor Edison.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- In an apparent effort to dispel suspicion that it has Axis leanings the new Bolivian Government instructed its representative here today to initiate Bolivian recognition of the Soviet Union through the United States.

The News Agency of Democratic Yugoslavia, in a message to Constantin Fotitch, Yugoslav Ambassador in Washington yesterday, challenged statements attributed to a military expert of the London radio that Yugoslav Partisan armies number 200,000 men while Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch commands only 15,000.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- The tremendous break-through along a 186-mile front found the Germans throwing away their arms in their haste to escape as General Vatutin's First Ukranian Army swept into Kazatin, one of the two key junctions on the Nazi's last double-tracked railroad leading out of the Dnieper bend.

The procurement division of the Treasury Department will supply the materials for the production of apparel items shortly to be purchased for the Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations of the Foreign Economic Administration, members were advised yesterday by the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board. Thus the bids to be made will be on a cut, make and trim basis.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- The Japanese who survived the battle for the airdrome fled into the hills behind Cape Gloucester.

Coal dealers in the New York area were under pressure last night from the Solid Fuels Administration to refuse anthracite to those of their customers who can use bituminous. A special emergency reserve of 8,000 tons of hard coal was ordered set up also yesterday to take care of distress cases in which the Health Department certifies that buildings are without fuel.

WITH THE TWELFTH AIR SUPPORT COMMAND, Italy, Dec. 22 (Delayed) -- A Missouri college professor spent ten days and nights, much of the time under artillery and machine-gun fire from both sides, digging fifty-seven graves for American and German soldiers in a wild No Man's Land beyond the American lines here.

Suggestions for improving the teaching of American history in schools and colleges were presented yesterday by leading historians attending the annual sessions of the American Historical Association at Barnard College. The speakers declared that while enough history courses were being offered in the elementary and high schools, the quality of teaching should be raised.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 30 -- If the Germans were to evacuate Greece and her islands now, the United Nations' manifold and varied organizations set up for the rehabilitation of stricken populations would be strained to give effective immediate aid.

HENRY BELLAMANN, author of the enormously popular "King's Row" and of the less popular "The Floods of Spring," is a specialist in psychological melodrama. Monomanias, destructive obsessions, the evil fascinations of the abnormal and the Gothic horrors of minds diseased are his delight. Out of such grisly materials he fashions his sinister bedtime stories for grown-ups who like to be shocked and enjoy the cold grue caused by nameless and impalpable terrors.

The five-story walk-up apartment house on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 1363-65 Plimpton Avenue, near Boscobel Avenue, the Bronx, was purchased b Paul S. Hitlin, builder and operator, from the Primstone Realty Corporation.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Winston Churchill was a bad boy.

Therese Bonney's photographic study, "Europe's Children," which she published in a limited edition, will be brought out in a large trade printing by Duell, Sloan Pearce on Jan. 20. The new edition will have some additional photographs.

Army and Navy commissions were awarded to sixty-nine of the ninety-one medical students who were graduated from the Long Island College of Medicine last night at commencement exercises at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The graduation exercises were the second held during the last nine months under the accelerated wartime studying program now in effect at the college.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Manufacture of 2,000,000 electric irons and 50,000 bathtubs in 1944 was authorized today by the War Production Board, this being the first important resumption of civilian manufacture since the war started.

Bad news for the Axis came yesterday from three airplane companies in the metropolitan area, from Wright Aeronautical in Paterson, N.J., and Republic Aviation in Farmingdale, L.I., and Grumman Aircraft in Bethpage, L.I.

Horse racing enjoyed its span of greatest success in the year ending today, according to the annual report of Chairman Herbert Bayard Swope of the New York State Racing Commission, submitted this week to the Secretary of State at Albany.

At a recent meeting of the New York Federation of Postoffice Clerks attention was called to a letter from Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, printed in your columns on Nov. 16 in reply to your editorial of Nov. 14. Miss Perkins stated that Federal employes are being paid after forty hours a week at the rate of time and one-half.

That the defensive skill of the Reds played a major part last summer in enabling Bill McKechnie's club to slip ahead of the Dodgers and finish second is strikingly revealed in the National League's official fielding averages announced yesterday.
The steel industry exceeded in 1943 all previous production records for the fourth consecutive time, according to Walter S. Tower, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Both the New York City member banks and those of the Federal Reserve System as a whole showed increases in excess reserves during the week ended Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

" Destination Tokyo," a Warner Brothers drama telling of the exploits of a United States submarine in the Pacific, will have its premiere this morning at the Strand. Cary Grant, John Garfield, Dane Clark, John Ridgely and Alan Hale head the cast.

Twenty-two "peacemaking blunders" by President Wilson "that have resulted in the most far-reaching consequences" were outlined yesterday before the annual meeting of the American Historical Association at Barnard College, Columbia University, by Prof. Thomas A. Bailey, Stanford University historian, now at Harvard, as danger signs to avoid in the peacemaking to come."

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- "Investment bankers see ahead an era of tremendous activity and urgent demand for their services," John Clifford Folger, president of the Investment Bankers Association, said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Trams-Oceanic Air Lines, Inc., a company composed of air crews now in war service, obtained today from the Securities and Exchange Commission exemption from all provisions of the Investment Company Act except one requiring it to file a balance sheet, income and expense statement and surplus account statement at the close of each fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- To make up the coal shortages which are assuming crisis proportions along the Eastern seaboard, Secretary Ickes said today that from New Year's Day until April 1 shipments of anthracite to points west of the Pennsylvania-Ohio line will be prohibited.

The Brooklyn Law School, which for forty years has been under the jurisdiction of St. Lawrence University, has "bought its freedom" for $167,000 and in future will confer its own degrees and act as an autonomous non-profit educational institution, it was announced yesterday by Dean William Payson Richardson.

A constantly recurring feature of the war in China is a Japanese advance beyond the lines on rivers and railways that they customarily hold. After a few days or weeks they retire again. The Chinese say that they have been driven back. The Japanese reply that they have withdrawn after fulfilling their mission.

Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, writing in the latest issue of the Reich, declared that 1944 would be a "dangerous year" containing "riddles upon riddles," and then urged the German people to have "faith," the Transocean, Germany news agency, said in a wireless dispatch to the United States yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Representative Sparkman of Alabama said today that the Army Air Forces have laid down rigid new safety rules to prevent such tragedies as the one-night series of crashes which, he reported, killed eight cadet pilots from Courtland Field, Ala..
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY NEAR SAN VITTORE, Dec. 29 (Delayed) (AP) -- Another Italian town died today beneath terrible crashing explosions of American artillery.

Fire raging unchecked through two tenement dwellings took the lives of three women and two children yesterday in densely populated sections of Brooklyn and Harlem. The dead were overcome by smoke. Four additional children suffered smoke poisoning.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The traffic death toll in the United States for 1943 was estimated at 23,000 by the National Safety Council today, a drop of 20 per cent from 1942 and about 40 per cent from 1941.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- Despite pleas for leniency from friends and public officials, Victor P. Materne, Supervisor of Mount Pleasant Township until his arrest last July, was sentenced here today by County Judge Frank H. Coyne to serve two to four years in Sing Sing Prison for embezzling $12,213 tax money from Mount Pleasant.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 30 -- With the addition of the Italian paintings, sculptures and tapestries bequeathed to Yale University by Maitland F. Griggs of the class of 1896, the Yale Art Gallery now contains one of the finest teaching collections in this country of Italian painters of the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries.
Stores were unable to meet the demand here yesterday for scotch, rye and bourbon, much of it wanted to help usher in 1944.

Boleslav Martinu, whose fertility extraordinary, was present to envy the success of his Second symphony, heard for the first time in New York at the concert of Dr. Rodzinski and the Philharmonic-symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

Tax Selling Brokerage house analysts feel that the tax law may be responsible for a considerable volume of tax selling in the last two days of 1943. The law requires that an investor taking a profit do it by cash sale but allows an investor taking a loss to sell and then settle the transaction in normal course.

Defeat caught up with the St. John's basketball team last night in an exciting struggle with Kentucky, 44 -- 38. This setback, first of the season for the Brooklyn Redmen, followed a 59-38 trouncing handed to Long Island University by De Paul of Chicago before 18,179 persons, the biggest turnout of the campaign at Madison Square Garden.

ALGIERS, Dec. 30 -- The British Eighth Army has pushed a mile beyond Ortona along the direct coastal route to Pescara and is now barely eleven miles from the Adriatic terminus of the trans-peninsular road to Rome.

LONDON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Circulation of fiduciary notes increased 7,660,000 to the new high mark of 1,088,682,000 in the week ended yesterday, according to the weekly statement of the Bank of England. Outstanding notes were 165,252,000 more than were in circulation a year ago.
Skiing conditions of a limited variety appear to be in store for enthusiasts intending to spend the holiday period in the north unless the elements cooperate and deliver more snow real soon.

The exigencies of war yesterday dealt the world champion Yankees their heaviest blow since the enlistment of Joe DiMaggio a year ago when word was received at the club's Forty-second Street offices that Charlie Keller, key man of Joe McCarthy's attacking force last summer, had entered service.

Thirty-five Brooklyn consumer groups have taken their first big step to reinforce the Government's price control program. They have compiled a pocketbook-size chart listing price ceilings of fifty staple foods and have arranged for the borough's schools and libraries to distribute mimeographed copies "by the thousands" beginning next week.

The caption "Orchards Without Friends" in Topics of The Times arouses an automatic protest in an old-timer. Orchards without commercial status; orchards with no financial backers, perhaps. But orchards without friends! That is impossible.

This month marks the one hundredth anniversary of the birth of Josephine Shaw Lowell, distinguished crusader, whose life was devoted to the cause of human betterment. Her story is, in a sense, a war story, steeped in personal tragedy, yet filled with great victories for the needy, the neglected, the homeless and the mentally sick.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- Under bright blue skies and with a rise in temperature that made conditions ideal for spectators, the twenty-third annual College Week invitation ski tournament of the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds got under way today with the staging of the cross-country race.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The statement by Admiral King today marked the second time since August that he answered questions on progress of the war at an interview at which, contrary to standard practice at on-the-record conferences with Navy officials, only representatives of press associations were present.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Friday, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Today's communique:

A pamphlet was recently released by the Government Printing Office entitled "Hearings before the Committee on Foreign Affairs, House of Representatives * * * on * * * resolutions providing for the establishment by the Executive of a commission to effectuate the rescue of the Jewish people of Europe."

Good wishes were conveyed yesterday from President Roosevelt and all other living former Governors of New York and from Governor Dewey to former Gov. Alfred E. Smith at a reception in honor of his seventieth birthday at the Empire State Club.

Contributors who give year after year to the Neediest Cases Fund cherish the privilege of voluntary giving to help those in need that is an American tradition. For them the fund is their way of holding out a friendly, helping hand to the less fortunate.
Sales of housing and business properties by banks formed the bulk of property deals in Manhattan reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade ruled today that individuals who had gone short in December oats and have found it impossible to make delivery of the grain itself must settle their contracts at the OPA ceiling of 82 cents a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Washington Evening Star said editorially today that the proposed publication of a definitive edition of the writings of Thomas Jefferson by Princeton University and THE NEW YORK TIMES was "something important to the average American in a measure and to a degree that perhaps may not be apparent to every citizen at first glance."

The Trent Theatre property at 594-600 Main Street, New Rochelle, Westchester County, was sold by the 600 Main Street Corporation, Joseph G. Abramson, attorney, to the Trent Theatre Corporation, represented by Levy, Gutman and Goldberg, attorneys.
Waste paper now ranks with steel, iron, aluminum and rubber as a No. 1 war essential.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Commodity prices in primary markets continued generally steady during the week ended on Dec. 25. The Bureau of Labor Statistics all-commodity index remained unchanged for the third consecutive week at 102.9 per cent of the 1926 average.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Esquire Magazine, in which the Varga girl drawings and other material offended the Postoffice Department's sense of modesty, was ordered deprived of its second-class mailing privileges tonight.

The Navy is seriously considering the leasing of the Manhattan Towers Hotel, 2166 Broadway, near Seventy-sixth Street, for Waves on duty in the metropolitan area, the Third Naval District Headquarters announced yesterday.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Details of the final hours of the battle for the Cape Gloucester airdrome were meager, but Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique announcing the victory said that, "following an intense air preparation, our ground forces took the positions by assault."

The commercial research division of the Curtis Publishing Company has issued a series of charts containing statistics relative to the number of marriages and births during the war and predictions of post-war trends. These charts were compiled, according to the company, because of widespread interest in business circles in the anticipated huge post-war market for household appliances, homefurnishings and related products.

Egg receipts in this city are running from approximately 20 to 25 per cent higher than last year, according to a spokesman for a Manhattan market-reporting concern. This increase, which is abnormal for this season, is attributed largely to the fact that Government needs for dried eggs are much less than they were twelve months ago, requiring the operation of only a fraction of the 125 plants that were being used at that time.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Appointment of Rear Admiral George D. Murray as chief of the new naval air training command was announced tonight.

CHANGTEH, China, Dec. 22 (Delayed) -- During the time the Japanese occupied Changteh, from Dec. 3 to Dec. 9, 120 Chinese soldiers never left the city. Two of those who remained hidden inside the city in that period turned up today, healthy and smiling and ready to talk about their experiences.

LONDON, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Pierre Laval, openly anxious over the growing strength and activities of French patriots, who are ready to rise against him when Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's invasion army lands in France, named three men today to try to suppress the underground.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Lumber production this year, estimated at 32,500,000,000 feet, will be 10 per cent below 1942 output, the Lumber Survey Committee said tonight in a quarterly report describing the lumber economy as "tight."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Foreign Economic Administration today announced a further move in its program to modify decentralization procedure, so far as exports to Latin America are concerned. Beginning Jan. 1, applications for licenses to export certain commodities to fifteen American republics need no longer be accompanied by import recommendations from officials of the country of destination.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Department store sales in the week ended Dec. 25 were 22 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight.

A meeting of Protestant, Catholic and Jewish leaders has been called for next week by the National Conference of Christians and Jews in a move designed to get at the roots of anti-Semitism in the city.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The War Food Administration reported today that increased receipts of hogs in the North Central States had slowed up trade and that few hogs will be needed tomorrow in view of the holiday on Saturday when slaughter will be suspended. Holdovers of 8,000 head were reported locally and producers were urged to communicate with their agents before shipping supplies to market. The WFA's report of today's livestock markets here follows:

The stock market reverted yesterday to type, and with a rebirth of the time-honored year-end rally prices pushed forward with considerable zest in one of the best drives in many weeks. Driven by the release of a reinvestment demand that carried business above the million-share mark, values on the Stock Exchange were enlarged generally from 1 to 2 points, with peak gains of 7 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- A group of distinguished scholars is working at the Library of Congress, answering questions from Congressmen, Government agencies and plain citizens on subjects ranging from Chinese philosophy and Scandinavian law to the eating habits of Koreans.

MOSCOW, Friday, Dec. 31 -- Premier Joseph Stalin revealed yesterday in an order of the day that the seven-day-old counter-offensive of Gen. Nikolai F. Vatutin had sent twenty-two of Hitler's divisions reeling in flight along a 186-mile front north, west and south of Zhitomir.

" Since social considerations will probably make it necessary to demobilize the armed forces rapidly and terminate war production immediately" after the war, Prof. Harold M. Somers of the University of Buffalo believes that "the best solution is to provide substantial discharge payments to service men and dismissal or lay-off wages to war workers, both spread over, say, a six-month period, if necessary.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The Allies have achieved air superiority in every theatre of the war and sent planes on the offensive all around the world, the Royal Air Force announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Federal Communications Commission has deferred for further consideration, and possibly revision, a tentative ruling on newspaper ownership of radio stations the effect of which would be to limit if not prevent larger newspaper participation in the broadcasting field.

Mr. Churchill's letter of thanks to those who have helped or written him during his second attack of pneumonia is characteristically Churchillian, full of his fresh and vital spirit. In spite of his high temperature he didn't feel so ill in his second bout with the disease as he did with the first.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Sharp cuts in the green-stamp cost of canned snap beans, peas, tomatoes and frozen fruits and vegetables will become effective Monday, the Office of Price Administration said today in announcing January point values for rationed foods.

ALGIERS, Dec. 30 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Allied Commander for the invasion of northwestern Europe, today called on Gen. Charles de Gaulle, with whom he talked for half an hour. He was accompanied by Col. Lawrence Higgins, American liaison officer with the French Army.
LONDON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

FIFTEENTH UNITED STATES AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Dec. 29 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Germany, under threat of a twin-edged aerial assault from Italy and England, has shifted considerable Luftwaffe strength, at the cost of defenses in northern Europe, to meet attacks from the south, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- An estimate catch of $4,000,000,000 pounds of fish and shell fish for 1944 from United States and Alaska fisheries was made today by Secretary Ickes on the basis of a promised addition of 528 vessels to the fishing fleet.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 -Teresa Wright will be lent by Samuel Goldwyn for the feminine lead with Gary Cooper in "Casanova Q. Brown." The film, Nunnally Johnson's first production for International Pictures, will start on Feb. 10.

WASHINGTON, Dec., 30 -- During the week ended Dec. 29, member bank reserve balances increased $92,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $203,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks and $9,000,000 in Treasury cash, offset in part by a decrease of $29,000,000 in reserve bank credit and increases of $46,000,000 in money in circulation and $45,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Plans will have to be prepared to make a greater use of the scant fabric supply for absolutely necessary clothing, in the opinion of Albert A. Kaplan, price executive of the manufactured articles branch of the Office of Price Administration.

Senator Gillette predicted yesterday in Washington that when Congress reconvenes a subcommittee of the Senate will begin consideration of four possible substitutes for the present constitutional requirement for a two-thirds Senate majority on the ratification of treaties.

A large suite of offices in the Lincoln Building, 60 East Forty-second Street, has been rented to the Bethlehem Steel Company through R. Bruce Estelle, broker, one of the commercial leases reported yesterday disclosed.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 31 -- More than thirteen hundred American heavy bombers and fighters, the largest force ever dispatched by the United States Army Air Forces in any theatre, blasted targets in southwest Germany yesterday to bring to a climax an offensive that involved more than 2,000 Allied planes, including strong formations of American and British medium bombers and hundreds of fighters.

LONDON, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- The German High Command, in a special communique seeking to offset the effect of two stinging naval defeats, reported today that five British destroyers and probably six had been sunk in the Bay of Biscay battle on which the British Admiralty and Air Ministry reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Wheat prices advanced 1 1/4 cents a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade to new seasonal highs on all deliveries with May leading. Brokers who frequently act for mills or distillers were aggressive buyers of May and despite some selling attributed to the Northwest the close was about the top.

Visitors to New York who discovered yesterday that the basement exhibition hall of Madison Square Garden had been turned into "a vast barnyard" for the remainder of this week, saw new types of fowl which are suitable for the amateur breeder as well as those outstanding in the poultry industry.

The American Jewish Conference yesterday assailed the Emergency Committee to Save the Jewish People of Europe as one of a "series of fronts" whose leaders had "constantly assumed to speak for the Jewish people in this country without having or endeavoring to secure a mandate from any constituency" and whose activities had caused "discord, resulting frequently in a disservice to the cause they had assumed to represent."
LONDON, Friday, Dec. 31 (UP) -- The Russian Thursday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

The new year of 1944 -- if she may be considered as a lady -- will dance into existence in trailing skirts. Such, at least, is the opinion of hotel and night-club men and other students of Manhattan night life. Elegant, decollete evening gowns -- though no longer obligatory in even the most sophisticated retreats -- are expected to appear for one final, formal fling.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Chiefs of the three hold-out operating railroad brotherhoods issued a statement tonight declaring that, had the Administration permitted the National Mediation Board to proceed as it had planned to adjust their wage dispute under the Railway Labor Act, a satisfactory adjustment would have been made.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed an increase of $63,498,000 in holdings of United States Government securities to a new high record. Note circulation for the entire system showed an increase of $66,079,000.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Lieut. Gen. Jacob L. Devers said today that the coming year would be one of deliverance for Europe. Now commander of American troops in the European Theatre of Operations he will soon take up similar duties in the Mediterranean area.

Guy Vaughan, president of the Curtis-Wright Corporation, announced yesterday that an increase of 2,500 per cent in 1943 production of warplanes, engines and propellers over the 1939 volume represented the company's share in a war program which "will virtually overwhelm the enemy" in 1944.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Governor Dewey again deferred today the execution of Louis Buchalter (Lepke), Louis Capone and Emanuel Weiss, calling attention to the failure of the Federal Government to surrender Buchalter to the State.

Offenbach's "The Tales of Hoffmann" received its second performance of the season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, being given as a benefit for the Near East Colleges before an enthusiastic large audience. Except that Eleanor Steber replaced Jarmila Novotna as Antonia, the cast remained identical with that of the previous presentation.
