Patrice Munsel was again the Olympia, Lily Djanel the Giulietta, Raoul Jobin the Hoffmann.

Net profit of the American Distilling Company for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 was $1,333,384, equal to $5.01 a share on 250,000 common shares after preferred dividends. The entire outstanding preferred stock was called for redemption on Dec. 20.

Makers of military insignia holding certificates of authority for such output which were valid on March 1, 1943, and which on their face are still valid, may now resume operation, the Military Suppliers Association of America, Inc., declared yesterday in commenting on the signing by President Roosevelt of legislation passed by Congress which forbids enforcement of restrictions imposed earlier by the Army.

The Conesus Milk Producers Cooperative Association, Inc., second largest operating cooperative in the New York milkshed, notified the New York City Health Department yesterday that it would cease shipping milk to the New York market effective as of midnight tonight.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Ranging from central China to central Burma, American fliers have struck telling blows against Japanese rail and river communications in the past three days, sinking at least four ships and destroying rolling stock, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.
LONDON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A special German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Football players of the East and West, ranging from college freshmen to men in the armed forces, will clash here tomorrow in the nineteenth annual All-Star charity game. The Western team, manned by older and more experienced players, is the favorite.

With reference to a recent article in THE NEW YORK TIMES, I would like to commend Mrs. Anna Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, for the leadership she has assumed in applying for funds to care for children of service men's wives who must work to supplement their allotments.

All markets and exchanges in the United States will be closed today, except a few livestock markets. Banks will be closed in every State in the Union except Kentucky and will be closed in all United States possessions except Hawaii and the Panama Canal zone.

JUST a minute, folks. There is no need to rush into this business in headlong fashion. It is very bewildering to discuss the various bowl contestants this year because in many instances it seems that the main requisite for an invitation was to have a football team.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The ceiling charts compiled by Brooklyn consumer groups are a jump ahead of a country-wide plan to place such charts in the hands of consumers, as described today by Dr. J. Paul Leonard, director of the consumer division of the Office of Price Administration.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Johnny Adams, champion jockey, finished the year with two victories today at Tropical Park, boosting his 1943 total to 228 winning mounts.

U.S. ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Central Pacific, Dec. 29 (Delayed) -- The nature of the coming war in the Pacific has been brought into clear focus in 1943, and the weight of our military and naval might is shifted like that of a boxer who alters strategy to fit his opponent's style.

Our voluntary and municipal hospitals have never discriminated against nationalities, creeds and races in treating the sick. On the other hand, their boards of trustees and their medical staffs have been restricted. By admitting Negroes to its board and its medical staff Sydenham Hospital becomes the first important institution of its kind to sweep away anachronistic barriers.

Having had a regular show shot out from under it, the New York City Center last evening celebrated New Year's in the next best way -- by offering the first of four performances by Paul Draper and Larry Adler, tap and harmonica specialists.

In connection with the proposed use of radio telephones on moving trains to increase safety of travel, I note that in today's NEW YORK TIMES veteran railway signal technicians question its feasibility on the ground that if a train were wrecked its radio probably would be wrecked with it.

Turkeys, geese and a few special displays of water fowl and rabbits were added to the larger numbers of poultry and pigeons at yesterday's session of the Madison Square Garden Poultry Show, Inc., which occupies the basement exhibition hall.

The rocky road along which most of the local college basketball quintets have been traveling of late holds small promise for smoother going tonight as Long Island University meets Duke in the opener and New York University clashes with Colgate in another double-header at Madison Square Garden.

William McFee's new novel, postponed from the Random House lists of last year, will be brought out this spring. The publishers announce the book's title as "Ship to Shore." His best-known earlier work is "Casuals of the Sea."

It's strange how two men can look into the same crystal ball and see entirely different pictures. This being the open season for crystal gazing, two gentlemen, ardent fishermen both, were peering into the relatively small orb that holds 1944's fishing destiny after luncheon at the Anglers Club the other day.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- It'll take more than a New Year's Eve celebration to lift the spirits of Homer Norton.

In order to permit a few script revisions, George Brandt has postponed the Broadway premiere of his production, "A Lady Comes Home," from next Tuesday to Wednesday at the Playhouse. One of the problems confronting Mr. Brandt's directorial staff is to find an actor for a new character that has just been written into the melodrama's third act.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Japanese troops have attacked Allied forces guarding the new "Burma Road" being built to China in northern Burma, but have been thrown back, headquarters of Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten announced today.

The fact that the January chart of consumer point values for processed foods -- it becomes effective Monday -- lists several quick-frozen fruits and vegetables as unrationed facilitates cookery enormously. For it puts a number of time and labor savers at the disposal of the many women whose hours in the kitchen are limited nowadays.

A New Year's message from Premier Hideki Tojo to the Japanese people, quoted yesterday by the Japanese Domei news agency, said that Allied attacks had put their nation "to a crucial test" and that it was "the sublime duty of everyone now to sacrifice body and soul without a single atom of self-interest."

The Zenith Radio Corporation and its subsidiaries, in a report for the six months ended on Oct. 31, estimated the profit at $3,372,908 after depreciation, reserves for voluntary price reduction on war contracts and renegotiation, but before the provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Today's communique :...

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Dec. 31 -- General MacArthur flew today over Australian positions in the Ramu Valley along the coast of New Guinea and conferred at a new advanced Allied command base with Lieut. Gen. Walter Krueger, commander of the Sixth United States Army.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Adolf Hitler, in a grim New Year's massage to the German people today, offered them only hope of dogged resistance for their very lives and, anticipating invasion from the west, boasted that wherever they landed the Allies would receive an appropriate welcome.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- It was learned authoritatively today that a firm belief is held in some high Givernment circles that the threatened railroad strike, which culminated in the Army's taking over the railroads, has set hack the end of the war by giving the Nazis a propaganda weapon with which to stave off internal collapse in Europe.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 31 (AP) -- An Allied Southeast Asia communique:

Mayor La Guardia signed yesterday, after a public hearing at City Hall, a local law making it a misdemeanor for individuals or business concerns to charge more than $1 as a premium for supplying tickets or other accommodations for railroad, bus or airplane transportation.

John T. McManus, president of the Newspaper Guild of New York and motion-picture critic of the newspaper PM, received a letter yesterday from Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox expressing regret that he had been embarrassed by his exclusion from the submarine base at New London recently and explaining the reasons for the Navy's action.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Jan. 1 -- Russia's festive mood was enhanced yesterday by the announcement of the capture of the heavily defended railroad center of Zhitomir by the armies of Gen. Nikolai F. Vatutin.

Due to the close result of the November election for the office of County Judge of Richmond County and further court actions on the part of both candidates, Staten Island today, for the first time in more than fifty years, is without a County Judge.

" The Song of Bernadette" and "Lifeboat," two of Twentieth Century-Fox's more important releases of the new year, will have their premieres here within the next three weeks, it was learned yesterday. According to present plans, "The Song of Bernadette" will open at the Rivoli on Thursday, Jan. 20, while "Lifeboat" will arrive at the Astor on Tuesday, Jan. 11.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The feasibility of expanding old-age and survivors' insurance protection to include smaller business men throughout the country, as is proposed in the cradle-to-grave "American Beveridge Plan" given Congress in legislative form last June, will be investigated early in the new year by the Social Security Board.

Leading creators of fashion are making a distinguished contribution to New York as a design center. Their spring collections will be described in a series of articles which will appear on this page during the coming weeks.
Charles L. Benesch has been placed in charge of the institutional and syndicate department of Ernst Co. Nathan Abell is the new head of the arbitrage department.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Transportation has reinforced its proposal that both major political parties hold their 1944 conventions in Chicago with a statement that more than three times as many sleeping cars arrive daily at the Illinois city than at any other Midwest point.

Business in 1943 on the New York Stock Exchange was the best in from five to seven years, with the turnover of 278,741,765 shares, the largest since 1938, and dealings of $3,254,716,525 in bonds, the heaviest of any year since 1936. The biggest day in stocks was 2,805,294 shares on May 4, while in bonds it was $32,172,000, on March 3.
MOSCOW, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The people of the Soviet Union celebrated tonight their greatest, happiest New Year's Eve of the war to date.

The flood of liquor of all sorts that moved across package store counters yesterday was matched by the flood poured down throats in neighborhood bars. The drinking at bars began on a large scale at the unusually early hour of 8 A.M. and reached a record high tide during the day.

The Rev. Dr. Waiter M. Howlett will celebrate the New Year today by "'hanging out a shingle" and taking up his duties as executive director of the Division of Christian Education of the newly formed Protestant Council of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 25 were 641,368 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 117,020 cars, or 15.5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 49,897 cars, or 8.4 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 34,866 cars, or 5.7 per cent more, than during the corresponding week two years ago.

In the wake of scale-down trade support with a flurry of liquidation and New Orleans hedge selling that developed toward the close, prices of futures in the cotton market sagged yesterday. At the close the list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange registered net losses of 8 to 12 points.
Running contrary to expectations in some quarters, returns and exchanges of gift merchandise this week by customers have been fairly light, a survey of leading stores here yesterday indicated.

Sagging tendencies returned yesterday to the stock market and produced a mixed closing on the final session of 1943. Prices ended the old year about midway between the highs and lows of the last twelve months but at an improvement over the day prior to Pearl Harbor and with the largest annual volume since 1938.

Military Police patrols afoot and in jeeps scoured the metropolitan district all through the last day of 1943, from pre-dawn hours into the new year, trying to round up an undisclosed number of enlisted men who walked out of a near-by Army camp, apparently to celebrate the New Year.

" Universal Week of Prayer" will be observed by the churches next week, as is customary during the first week in the New Year. In addition to prayers for missions there will be supplications for victory in 1944 and for our men in the war theatre.

The State Attorney General's office moved yesterday to override the recent decision by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in dismissing a seventy-one count indictment charging officials of Local 324, Independent Laundry Drivers of Greater New York, a Congress of Industrial Organizations' affiliate, with obtaining $90,000 from union members through extortion and blackmail.

George Santayana, at one point in the memoirs of his early life, speaks with contempt of certain Spanish politicians who set out at the turn of the century to bring Spain into line with modern "progress." Santayana thinks the idea was ignoble and fantastic.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 31 -- A decree issued today dissolves "all political parties existing in the whole territory of the nation." The Minister of the Interior at the same time was instructed to take all necessary measures to see that the decree was enforced.

Payments to American exporters on long-outstanding commercial indebtedness by Spanish accounts amounting to several million dollars have now begun, it was announced yesterday by Eugene P. Thomas, president of the National Foreign Trade Council.

One section of the Allied raiding force occupied the village of Ponte Fiume while another section wiped out German machine-gun posts and cut its way through barbed-wire as it advanced on German headquarters, located in an amphitheatre on the road to Rome, the London radio said last night.

Reversing an earlier opinion of the Supreme Court, the Appellate Division of Brooklyn ruled yesterday that the Board of Education need not pay custodians extra salaries for keeping the school buildings open during the summer. This decision, if upheld by the Court of Appeals, will save the city as much as $1,000,000 a year, it was estimated.

Alfred E. Smith was 70 yesterday, though hopelessly unable to look it. Just about forty years ago he was an obscure freshman member of the Assembly. For two or three years he was a queer legislator. He kept his mouth shut. It was his singular habit never to talk about anything until he knew all about it.
GUADALCANAL, Dec. 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Cheered by 7,500 service men, twenty-four young fighters battled for the boxing championships of the South Pacific Christmas night.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 31 -- A note of distress was struck in the official Yugoslav Information Office's communique tonight. In a discouraged manner, the communique suggests that Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch's forces at present find themselves fighting under exceptionally difficult circumstances.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 31 -- President Getulio Vargas promised today that naval, land and air forces would form part of an expeditionary force to fight overseas. He made the pledge during a New Year's Eve talk at a luncheon given by the armed forces.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Dec. 31 (AP) - The Manor Real Estate and Trust Company, a subsidiary of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, completed today the purchase of 2,669 acres of coal land in Croyle and Summerhill Townships, Cambria County, at a cost of about $515,000.

Some time ago THE NEW YORK TIMES advocated additional appointments of regular teachers to the New York school system as a measure to stem the rising tide of juvenile delinquency. The Mayor's office pleaded poverty. Controller McGoldrick's annual report as it appeared in THE TIMES indicated that tax returns reached a twenty-year peak and that there is a surplus of over $7,000,000, to say nothing of many more millions doubtlessly concealed in departmental accrual funds.

The year 1944 will be a year of decision and a year of test. General Eisenhower predicts that it will see the end of the European war, and this means that Britain, Russia and the United States will have won from Hitler the power he aspired to when he threw down the gantlet in 1939.

Despite the $57,132 allowed for her support and incidentals last year, Mrs. Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt Di Cicco found it necessary to borrow $1,500 as evidenced by the redemption of jewelry for which she paid $1,810 in principal and interest, it was shown in an annual accounting filed by her general guardian, Thomas B. Gilchrist of Yonkers, N.Y.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 31 -- A minimum annual wage for industrial workers, to be paid and guaranteed by employers, is being built up by the Congress of Industrial Organizations as a major issue for the 1944 elections, Philip Murray, CIO president, disclosed here.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Without fanfare or speeches, Senator Joe R. Hanley took the oath of office as Lieutenant Governor this afternoon. The former minister was sworn in the Senate chamber, where he had served since 1939 as majority leader and president pro tempore, in the presence of his family, Governor and Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey and about a hundred friends.

The volume of 71,374,283 shares for the New York Curb Exchange in 1943 was the largest since the 104,000,000 recorded in 1937. Last year, as a matter of fact, recorded more than three times the 1942 volume of 22,000,000 shares and twice the 1941 volume of 35,000,000 shares.

LITTLE SILVER, N.J., Dec. 31 -- Charles Sivell Lee, formerly a six-goal polo player, and his wife, Elizabeth, each 58 years old, were found dead of illuminating gas poisoning late yesterday in their apartment adjoining the stables of the Holly Tree Farm, where Mr. Lee had been employed as superintendent of the stables.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 31 -- The Argentine Government decided yesterday to recognize the new Bolivian regime. An official communique announcing recognition had been prepared and was to have been issued in the evening. But a last-minute change in plans caused a delay.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur in his New Year's Day communique reported today that all Japanese counter attacks against newly-won Marine holdings at Cape Gloucester, New Britain, had been beaten off.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would swear in a group of city officials, including two justices, in connection with his annual New Year's reception at noon today in his office at City Hall.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 31 -- The war in the Pacific was rated the toughest war theatre in which they have served by New Zealand veterans of the Middle East who returned here today after battle experience against the Japanese.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- New high prices for the season were established for wheat futures today on the Board of Trade. Heavy buying attributed to mills combined with an upturn of 1 cent in the national parity price last month, and announcement that the Government subsidy to be paid to mills on January sales of flour had been raised 5 1/2 to 6 cents a bushel were the dominating influences.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Two wishes for women workers were given in a New Year's message issued today by Miss Mary Anderson, director of the Women's Bureau, one that they will surpass their 1943 work record in 1944 and two, that they will receive "the same recognition as a rightful and vital part of the labor force in the reconstruction period as in the war years."

Americans bought everything they could lay their hands on in 1943 -- from paper-soled shoes to wooden springed mattresses -- and pushed up the sales of all retail stores to a record-smashing estimate of $63,000,000,000, according to The Associated Press yesterday.

The five-story store and apartment building at 300-304 Grove Street near City Hall, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by the Alberta Realty Company, Bertha Rosenberger, president, to Harry Goldlang. This structure is on a plot 65 by 80 feet and contains two stores and twenty-eight apartments.

Bethlehem Steel Corporation more than lived up to its pledge of a ship a day, every day, for 1943, by producing 380 large vessels of all types last year, Eugene G. Grace, president, said yesterday. "Never before in the world's history has any company carried out a shipbuilding program of such magnitude and diversity," he said.

Although Brooklyn City Prison, better known as Raymond Street jail, has been denounced as "antiquated'' by many Kings County grand juries in the last two decades, the December panel yesterday handed up a presentment to Kings County Judge Nathan R. Sobel praising the present accommodations in the penal institution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Thomas Holcomb will be retired as commandant of the United States Marine Corps tomorrow with the rank of full general, the first Marine ever to hold that rank, the Navy Department annonunced tonight.

As milder weather eased the coal shortage crisis in the New York metropolitan area, Mayor George E. Brunner of Camden, N.J., yesterday declared a state of emergency in that city -- one of the most active war-production centers of the Eastern Seaboard.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- The German Junkers 88 twin-engined bomber which two American officers recently flew across the Atlantic had a press button marked "Rudder Salvo."
LONDON, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- New York City felt effects of the first move in what War Production Board officials conceded would be a sharp cut-back in the aluminum production program. Two "pot lines" plants which produce aluminum from alumina, the raw material and which employ about 300 persons, were ordered shut down as of tonight, although the workers will be paid for an additional week.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Despite active buying, packers were unable to absorb the fresh supply of hogs on hand today, and 2,000 head remained unsold at the end of the session. In view of the possibility that marketings next week might be heavier than could be processed readily, the War Food Administration urged farmers to withhold shipments until they are assured of a market for their hogs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- There will be a total eclipse of the sun next month. The total blackout will be observable only in parts of South America and West Africa and there are no known plans for expeditions by scientists from this country.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Six Appellate Division appointments and reappointments, including two in the First Department, were announced today by Governor Dewey.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Washington and Southern California were physically fit tonight and ready for their New Year's Rose Bowl battle that is to settle the Pacific Coast Conference football championship.

LONDON, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Nazi Propaganda Minister, today agreed with Hitler that 1943 was the heaviest year of the war, "for in it we have had to pass a great moral and material test."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 - "No government ever before borrowed so much from so many" was one pregnant sentence in a review of fiscal activities during the year issued by the Treasury Department tonight.

To start the New Year, many warm-hearted persons, out of gratitude for their own good fortune, gave generously to the Neediest Cases Fund to help the most distressed families, men and Women and children known to eight leading private family welfare organizations in the city.

ALGIERS, Dec. 31 -- Allied troops at the Tyrrhenian end of the trans-Italian front have carried out "a large raid" on German positions across the Garigliano River. It was made two days after the Germans, presumably anticipating a move of some kind, launched a strong thrust at Pontefiume, on the south bank of the recently flooded river.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- Dartmouth and Middlebury skiers dominated the crusty slopes of Mount Whitney today as the twenty-third annual Lake Placid Club College Week invitation ski tourney moved through its second day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The United States is approaching the most critical period of the war, Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, said tonight in an address over the NBC network.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31 -- Universal is reviving its "Invisible Man" picture as an addition to its horror program and will start with The Invisible Man's Revenge." The picture, based on a story by Clyde Bruckman, will be put into production within three weeks with Ford Beebe producing and directing.
PRESSMEN'S HOME, Tenn., Dec. 31 -- George L. Berry has been re-elected president of the International Printing Pressmen and Assistants' Union of North America, it was announced today.

Retail trade here this week ranged from slight gains to declines under the comparative week last year, with indications that the average of department store sales dropped by about 3 per cent or more. Estimates were that December trade as a whole was off by 5 to 7 per cent, which was more than offset, however, by the 20 per cent rise in November.

Despite the seasonal peak of the demand for currency, and large movements of funds, related chiefly to quarterly income tax collections and other governmental receipts and expenditures, the money market remained on an even keel during December, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York states in the Jan. 1 issue of its monthly review of credit and business conditions.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Minnesota Supreme Court today held that purchasers of unregistered stock sold in Minnesota during 1928, 1929 and 1930 by two New York corporations can recover the purchase price.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Tulsa's Golden Hurricane and the Ramblin' Wreck of Georgia Tech will start the tenth annual Sugar Bowl football classic here tomorrow "without an alibi."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- An estimated 10,000,000 pairs of women's shoes will be removed from rationing for two weeks beginning Jan. 17 under an Office of Price Administration order permitting retailers to sell 15 per cent of their Sept. 30 stocks ration-free at $3 or less a pair.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Jan. 1 -- New Yorkers and other Easterners played an important part in a savage attack on the Japanese bivouac area the night before the capture of the Cape Gloucester airdrome.
CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- After more than two years and forty-five consecutive defeats, the University of Chicago finally won a basketball game tonight.
Mr. and Mrs. J. Douglas Auchincloss are expected to come to Hampshire House today from Norwalk, Conn.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- Twenty-six young women were presented to society in a victory bow tonight at the sixty-fourth annual charity ball and debutante cotillion at the Bellevue-Stratford.

Adolf Hitler was quoted last night as having told the German people in a New Year's proclamation for 1944 that "in this war there will be no victors and losers." That is not the way the German people heard it from Hitler in his previous New Year's proclamations, according to the Office of War Information.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- Smashing through tottering German defenses west and southwest of Kiev on a front broadened to 200 miles, Soviet forces scored gains as high as sixteen miles to complete a year in which the Russians drove more than 700 miles westward from Stalingrad.

There is no good reason why New Year's Day should be today. Nor has it always been Jan. 1. Until 1582 in all European countries and until 1753 in England it was March 25. Some ancient peoples put it at Sept. 21. The ancient Jewish calendar has a civil New Year's in the fall and a religious one in March.
Following is the text of Adolf Hitler's New Year's proclamation to the German people, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by United States Government monitors:

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The young Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlvi, told The Associated Press at the royal palace today that "I would like to see my Army cooperating much more with the Allies," and described the recent Teheran Declaration concerning Iran as the "first application of the principles of the Atlantic Charter."
A veritable avalanche of eggs has struck the New York City market and prices are tumbling. This condition became apparent yesterday when the Federal Government announced its purchase support program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, said in a year-end statement today that he thought keeping a hold on prices, and even tightening that grip in 1944 depended on these two factors:

Despite the shortage of equipment and scarcity of labor, together with adverse climatic conditions last winter, the Canadian railroads met all war-time requirements and the ordinary business of the Dominion did not suffer by reason of the unprecedented traffic that the railways were called upon to shoulder, D.C. Coleman, chairman and president of the Canadian Pacific Railway, says in his annual review.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Every hour of daylight in the last day of the year 1943 saw American aircraft -- Flying Fortresses, Liberators, Marauders, Thunderbolts and Lightnings -- pressing home their fast-mounting offensive against Adolf Hitler.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world offers a partial list of free amusements available today. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets 4, 5:30, 6:30 and 7:30 P.M.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 31 -- Only a seven-day production week and draft exemption of all workers in the industry can avert a more serious shortage of anthracite during this winter than that experienced in 1942 and 1943, in the view of top-ranking State officials in Pennsylvania, where hard coal is mined.

Wherever the English tongue is known the words of the Ayrshire plowman were sung last night. They were heard in the wardrooms of ships in dangerous waters, in quarters within sound of the front line, and probably in prison camps. Like Burns himself, the old song had a humble origin.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 31 -- For the second time within ten days Premier Emmanuel Tsouderos addressed the Greek people over the Cairo radio station tonight, beseeching them to compose their political differences and combine in the common struggle against the invaders.

As commanding general of the Eighth Air Force in Britain and former head of its Bomber Command, Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker demonstrated that mass air attacks could be made in daylight against heavily defended enemy territory effectively and economically, after the Germans and British had given up the attempt as hopeless.

Family life insurance coverage rose $8,700,000,000 last year, the largest gain in this class of insurance ever recorded, according to Holgar J. Johnson, president of the Institute of Life Insurance. There are now, he said yesterday, 68,000,000 policyholders in the United States, with an aggregate of $139,000,000,000 in life insurance.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Rewards for political services reappeared on the King's New Year's Honor List today for the first time since the outbreak of the war. Otherwise it was a document containing few surprises and, like all such wartime lists, emphasized the good deeds of thousands of men and women high and low in civilian and military life.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- An arrangement has been made between the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration and the Combined Boards which govern the allocation of raw metals and finished goods to the non-Axis world, assuring those countries unable to pay for relief an even break as against those able to pay.

New issues of bonds offered here for public subscription in December aggregated $86,152,000 for ten flotations, compared with $57,865,000 for fourteen offerings in the preceding month and $28,649,000 for ten issues in December, 1942. The total last month was the largest for any December since 1941, when $114,589,000 in thirty-three issues reached the market.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 31 -- The police reorganization in Vichy, announced yesterday, was considered here today as representing another of those slick moves that have enabled Pierre Laval to remain in the saddle in face of innumerable difficulties.

This city continues to be one of the safest and healthiest in the world, Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, Health Commissioner, said in the annual report of his department submitted late yesterday to Mayor La Guardia.

The Advertising Research Foundation has issued the sixty-sixth report of its Study of Newspaper Reading covering the Nov. 3 issue of The St. Paul Dispatch. A full page insertion by United Aircraft describing the combat roles of various company planes and equipment was the most widely read advertisement by men questioned by the foundation.

Wearing zoot suits and brandishing pistols, two thugs walked into the B S Dress Company, on the second floor of 340 West Thirty-ninth Street at noon yesterday and shouted "This is a stick-up!" The two wearing handkerchiefs across their faces, herded twenty-five employes of the dress company into a dressing room and robbed them of $300.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The last day of 1943 saw the stock markets here cheerful and generally firm in tone.

Today's events: "La Traviata," 2 P.M., and "Boris Godunoff," 8, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Leah Effenbach, piano, and Gabor Rejto, 'cello, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; "La Boheme," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

DALLAS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Randolph Field disputes mighty Texas tomorrow in the eighth annual Cotton Bowl game, laughing lustily at bettings odds that make the Longhorns 1-to-2 favorites over the gridiron battlers of the air corps.

ALGIERS, Dec. 31 -- French Communists, as represented by five former members of the French Chamber and delegates to the Consultative Assembly here, today called upon the French Committee of National Liberation to transform itself into a provisional government for France by admitting representatives of the General Federation of Labor and the Communist party and then presenting to the Assembly here a war program.

Basic English is inadequate to meet the demands of daily conversation and is in many instances neither "basic" nor "English," speakers said yesterday at a regional meeting of the American Dialect Society at the Men's Faculty Club, Columbia University.
Friday's Soviet communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 31 -- A new kind of strong paper, an unusual method of refrigerating trucks which carry perishables, a new synthetic hormone and a remarkable new drug valuable in surgery were the subjects of patents among the 547 listed as issued during the past week in the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The world battlefront in 1943 "felt the full impact of ten years of unified resources development in the Tennessee Valley," the Tennessee Valley Authority reported to the President and Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- President Roosevelt removed one obstacle to settling the wage disputes affecting eighteen railway unions today by making known that he had no intention of freezing the wages of railroad employes for the duration of the war.

NAPLES, Saturday, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- A wholesale policy for the removal of Italian Fascists from public office by categories rather than individually was announced today by Allied Military Government officials for the Campagna region, in the southwest part of the country.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- A spokesman for Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced that the Navy's Seabees already have moved into the Cape Gloucester area to begin rebuilding the bomb-blasted airdrome.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Axis broadcasts to the effect that Spain has recognized the puppet regime of Benito Mussolini have been denounced as "flagrant lies" by a high official of the Spanish Foreign Office, according to a report received by the State Department today from Carlton J.H. Hayes, the American Ambassador in Madrid.

Charles W. Oliver of Perth Amboy High School and Herbert Tilles of the Naval Academy in Annapolis yesterday gained the final round of the junior singles in the Eastern indoor tennis championship tourney in the Seventh Regiment Armory.

The birthday present Lester Patrick wanted most was denied him last night by the Maple Leafs. The coach of the New York Rangers, born sixty years ago yesterday, had hoped that his resurgent team would honor the anniversary with its fourth straight National Hockey League triumph on the Madison Square Garden surface, but try as hard as they might, his skaters failed to come through for him.

The climax to which the Government had been building during the eleven weeks of the trial of five Chicago gangsters, a Newark labor leader and a young man who had left Hollywood for the Army, was reached yesterday in Federal court. Taking full advantage of it, Judge John Bright imposed maximum penalties of ten years' imprisonment and $10,000 fines on all but the union man, Louis Kaufman.

For 123 years prior to 1919, at the annual diplomatic reception of the Sublime Porte the Sultan never failed to ask for the Polish Ambassador, and invariably the Grand Vizier replied that the Polish Ambassador had been detained. This to draw attention to the fact that Turkey, like the Holy See, had never recognized the partition of Poland.

Adolf Hitler showed a good judgment of news values yesterday when he made "the Bolshevist danger" the main theme of his New Year's diatribe. The Russian advance, now resumed at a great pace west and southwest of Kiev and in the Dnieper bend, is the outstanding military event of the year, just as the surrender of Italy was the outstanding political event.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- An increase in the milk subsidy program is likely in the near future, it was said tonight, as the result of a conference in the office of Fred M. Vinson, Stabilization Director, in which Office of Price Administration and War Food Administration officials participated.

Retirements from member firms of the New York Stock Exchange include Walter W. Price from Abbott, Proctor Paine, Robert A. McCord and Elizabeth B. Laundon (limited partner) from Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane and Edwin H. Herzog from Shields Co. Irving P. Jacobs will retire from Sutro Co.

The Uniformed Firemen's Association, representing the 6,590 members of the Fire Department now on active duty, announced yesterday that it would take early court action to set aside the emergency order issued on Wednesday by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh, imposing three additional eight-hour tours of duty in every twenty-day cycle.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTH PACIFIC, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- Adm. William F. Halsey predicted in a New Year's Day statement today that 1944 would be a year of great and decisive victories for the cause of Pacific freedom.

Inasmuch as the discontinuance of scrap rubber purchases by the Rubber Reserve Company will force dealers to sell at the lower prices set by the Office of Price Administration, collections of scrap rubber will decline in the coming year, dealers asserted yesterday.

ALGIERS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Edward Kennedy of The Associated Press, in a Thursday dispatch from the front, descried bitter fighting through the rubble-strewn streets of San Vittore, which American infantry entered the previous day after an artillery barrage virtually had leveled the village.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Here the new year, A. D. 1944, begins with Kip Fadiman departed from the book pages of The New Yorker. The Gentleman Down in Front asks the sixty-four-dollar question, What's he going to do when he wants to read Fadiman on books?

One of the finest town houses on the West Side figured in the news yesterday when Lieut. Col. Gordon S. P. Kleeberg purchased the building at 3 Riverside Drive which was erected by his father in 1896 and had passed from the family control in 1908.

Times Square crowds moved into the New Year last night with the same spirit that moved the Allied world everywhere -- with singing hearts and with hope that the New Year may bring victory in Europe, increased pressure against the enemy in the Pacific, as Allied military leaders predict.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today to the General Gas and Electric Company a re-argument in the case of the Virginia Public Service Company, whose plan of recapitalization has been approved.
New State and municipal financing in 1943 amounted to $809,201,536, Daily Bond Buyer reported yesterday on the basis of preliminary compilations. This was a weekly average of $15,561,568.
Waste paper now ranks with steel, iron, aluminum and rubber as a No. 1 war essential

Winning the individual batting championship of the National League as well as being named the most valuable player in his circuit were still not the only honors to fall to Stan Musial, star outfielder of the Cardinals, during the 1943 campaign.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Jan. 1 -- Although the United States is supplying Russia and Great Britain with large quantities of munitions and providing the bulk of the ground forces for the major invasion of Hitler's Europe, there have been sufficient men and supplies, particularly airplanes, for the Pacific theatre, so that the perpetrators of the Pearl Harbor attack are worried at last.

The year 1943 was the most momentous in the history of American industry from the viewpoint of production and earnings. With the program of conversion of plants for war work virtually completed during the year, production of military materials reached the highest level in this or any other nation.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 1 -- Daniel J. Juliano, one of three Democratic members of Hartford's bi-partisan board of six police commissioners, was held in $200 bail in the Police Court today for a hearing on Jan. 7 on charges of appropriating city property, consisting of two desks, a chair and a locker.

The national Government alone can cope with price control, wage control and inflationary trends in our economic system. Yet precisely because we are committed to a national regulation of commerce, we must not ignore the fact that as centralized Government acquires more authority there must be a better and quicker check on the abuse of power by such a centralized Government.

MOSCOW, Jan. 1 -- A brilliant Russian maneuver north of Zhitomir forced units of three panzer divisions that were fighting to hold the city to retreat northwestward away from Berdichev. This was accomplished, it was revealed today, by a smashing blow across the Zhitomir-Berdichev highway similar in conception and execution to that which came within a few miles of cutting the Zhitomir-Novograd Volynski road two days before Zhitomir was stormed.

A sharp increase in public utility retirements raised the total of] bonds called before maturity for payment in December to $161,687,000, the largest amount since October, when $168,294,000 was retired. The total compared with $31,063,000 in the preceding month and $99,778,000 in December, 1942.

SHRUBS which have brightly colored twigs, and trees whose bark is unusually interesting, seem to be particularly admirable when the rest of the winter garden is somber and dull. Their color becomes especially noticeable during the dormant season after the leaves have fallen.

ALGIERS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The status of ruined San Vittore remained in doubt and Allied headquarters had no confirmation of the capture of the heavily fortified position at the base of Mount Samucro, although the Bari radio, controlled by the government of Marshal Pietro Badoglio, announced yesterday it had been taken by the Americans.

THE third annual exhibition of the Audubon Artists Group will be held at the Norlyst Gallery from Feb. 15 to 29. It will include oils, water-colors, black-and-whites and small sculpture. Two prizes of $50 each will be awarded, one for oil and one for water-color.

Low-priced stocks, rather than the pivotal industrial favorites of other years, were the most active issues dealt in on the New York Stock Exchange in 1943. Of the twenty most active stocks only one closed above $25 a share. Radio Corporation was the year's leader in volume, closing at 9 1/2, up 4 5/8 points, on a total turnover of 4,244,300 shares.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Dartmouth took a commanding lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight by defeating Pennsylvania, 54 -- 48, before a crowd of 10,982.

To meet the nursing shortage in private and city hospitals in Manhattan and the Bronx, a drive for this month to recruit 500 Red Cross nurse's aides will be started tomorrow by the local chapter of the American Red Cross, Maj. Gen. Robert C. Davis, chapter executive director, announced yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 1 -- Revolutions are nothing new in Bolivia. Indeed, revolutions, coups d'etat and violent methods of all kinds have been used so often in recent years to remove one President and put another in his place that they may well be regarded as the rule rather than the exception.

BY coincidence, I have just seen, on consecutive days, the first public performances in England of two plays dealing with precisely the same subject, one by a leading American, the other by a leading English dramatist.

DALLAS, Tex., Jan. 1 -- The nation's No. 1 pass offensive and the season's top pass defense fought to a muddy 7-7 stalemate today in the eighth annual Cotton Bowl football game, Texas staving off repeated Randolph Field drives deep into Longhorn territory by timely interceptions.

Determined to start the year in much better fashion than they did 1943, the Rangers will seek to make it two straight over the Bruins in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. Last January the New Yorkers found the going exceedingly tough, and the setbacks suffered in that month were more than enough to keep them out of the post-season play-offs.

OTTAWA, Jan. 1 -- There are so many uncertainties ahead in this new year that the tendency has been among all classes of Canadians to welcome it soberly and with the same realism as they have faced these four years of war.
HERE is a tidy armful of books which, for the equally tidy sum of $7.50, will pleasurably consolidate whatever confusion you may be enjoying about the farm, food and nutrition situation.

RICHARD SULLIVAN's second novel will undoubtedly come as a considerable surprise to those who have read his first, "Summer After Summer." Where that was a more or less sober study of average people under fairly normal circumstances, "The Dark Continent" is breezy in manner from the outset and quick to invoke the improbable, if not the fantastic.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 1 -- Under conditions about as difficult as ever encountered since winter sailing was started twelve years ago, the anniversary regatta of frostbite racing began today off the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 1 -- Gov. Raymond E. Baldwin named a committee of five clergymen today to carrry out his program for the unity and amity of all citizens in Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Foreign food purchasing activities of the War Food Administration and of the Commodity Credit Corporation have been transferred, effective today, to the Foreign Economic Administration's Foodstuffs Division and the agency's United States Commercial Corporation, it was learned here today.

News of a general strike in Mar del Plata, Argentina's leading seaside resort, stirs up wistful thoughts that have nothing to do with labor. . . . It is January there. Swimmers are sporting in the surf, happy families picnic in the shade of the boardwalk, bathing beauties loll on the sunny sand, and the dulcet song of the salt-water taffy vendor mingles with the joyous barking of the hot-dog merchant. . . .

THE winter sports season is under way, and with it appears a host of beauty problems. The skier on snowy slopes or the skater in New York demands double service on her grooming aids. They must help her appearance both during and after her activity.
NORTHEASTERN BOUGAINVILLE, Dec. 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- Lieut. Comdr. Gene Tunney, now a trim 210-pounder at 46 years of age, still is "champ" so far as one front-line expedition from here is concerned.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 1 -- Flights of Army aircraft warmed over three different atolls of the Marshall Islands, attacking enemy installations and bombing and strafing against ineffectual opposition, it was announced here today.

ARCHIBALD MacLEISH, poet and Librarian of Congress, who once was one of the more active artisans along Radio Row, is going to interrupt his Washington chores for a singularly ambitious project on the airwaves. As part of the curricula of the Hational Broadcasting Cornpany's Inter-American University of the Air he is about to offer a history of the literature of the Americas.

MOSCOW, Jan 1 -- War and the Working Class, the Soviet journal of international relations, declared today that Japan and Germany were losing confidence in each other but must stick together, hoping for a long war, thus minimizing the effects of inevitable defeat.

"The Power of Plants" is the subject of a talk by Dr. E.E. Naylor, assistant curator of the New York Botanical Garden, to be given at the monthly member's day meeting in the Museum Building, Bronx Park, on Jan. 5 at 3:30 P.M.

Clearance events stimulated shopping in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles last week, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.
New Year's Day was observed by Jewish congregations as the National Day of Prayer in accordance with President Roosevelt's proclamation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Stiffened laws to make wartime strikes a crime were talked of at the capitol today in swift aftermath to an assertion from a figure high in the councils of the United States and the United Nations that recent labor disputes might delay victory over Germany.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 1 -- Samhar, flying the Red and Black silks of Charles S. Bromley and an entry with Walker Gullatt's Navy, scored a popular, hard-earned triumph in the $2,500 Orange Bowl Handicap of a mile and a sixteenth before Florida's earliest racing crowd at Tropical Park this morning.

EVERY so often it happens on Broadway. An understudy goes on for the principal and for a night or a week enjoys the warm thrill of applause and a fat check from the producer. For a young actor it is heady wine. Between encores he may murmur to himself, "This is it; now I'll get a play of my own."

IN an atmosphere surprisingly pacific for such a usually tempestuous affair, the New York Film Critics came together for their annual palmsgiving last week. In times past, these sober get-togethers, at which the "year's best" selections are made, have been the occasions of such dissensions as have out-run discreet reports.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Prices of the staple items which families buy in retail markets rose about 3 1/2 per cent in 1943, the smallest advance in any year since 1940, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, stated today in making public results of a survey by her department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Although all strike orders affecting railroad workers have been called off, and although 150,000 striking steel workers have returned to their posts, industrial peace on the railroads and in the steel mills is still not assured.

HOME-GROWN radishes are a convenience during the garden season, but when they can be pulled at will from a box on the window sill in midwinter their usefulness as a salad relish or garnish is doubly appreciated.

WITH THE MARINES AT CAPE GLOUCESTER, Dec. 30 (Delayed) -- From the minute our cruisers and destroyers began their predawn bombardment the day after Christmas, the enemy in the Cape Gloucester area was disorganized and never fully recovered.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- The War Food Administration continued the dairy subsidy program tonight, with increases in minimum rates to be paid to producers during January.
ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- News of an accumulated State surplus of $100,000,000 will greet members of the Legislature when they gather for the opening of the 167th regular session on Wednesday.

QUEBEC -- Two ski events are listed for winter sportsmen for next Sunday, with a senior downhill invitation tournament on the tortuous slopes of Mont St. Castin so for the grown-ups, and schoolboys from Quebec competing in an interscholastic relay race in the other.

Electrical manufacturers reached an all-time record in production of both electrical and non-electrical goods last year, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by W.J. Donald, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- Secretary Stimson called 1944 tonight "the year of our struggle for the decision" and urged a unification and intensification of effort to enable the Allies to win.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Poland wants to maintain her freedom and wants "respect for our undoubted right to that which belonged to us as a state before the war," the Polish President, Wladislaw Raczkiewicz, declared today during a New Year ceremony at the Polish Embassy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- The Washington Times-Herald today replied sharply to Elmer Davis' criticism of that paper and The New York Daily News last night by charging that Mr. Davis' statement was "an effort to retrieve his prestige as OWI director * * * which he has never acquired."

To further Canadian-American relations, Canadians of national distinction are to be brought to St. Lawrence University every semester to speak before classes and to make public addresses. Invitations have been accepted by Dr. Diamond Jenness, curator of the National Museum of Canada at Ottawa, and a noted anthropologist, who will visit St. Lawrence Jan. 5 through 8, and Georges Bouehard, Canadian assistant Deputy Minister of Agriculture, who will visit the university Feb. 2 through 5.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Germany will be knocked out between the spring and summer of this year, Sun Fo, president of the Legislative Yuan, declared in a New Year's message today, and "we believe that when the time comes our ally, the Soviet Union, will turn her forces to the east and participate in the war against Japan!"

DURING the year which ended Friday 121 different governments issued 1,443 postage stamps as thus far reported. This seems on the surface a small number, as the average across the five years of 1938 through 1942 was about 2,100 varieties.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Just over three weeks ago Field Marshal Smuts gave a weighty and statesmanlike address at the Houses of Parliament which was rightly received with appreciation and interest. I have deliberately deferred any comment on the one vulnerable point, since I do not wish to be captious but rather to correct an unintentional misapprehension.

As the New Year looms ahead, this department's thoughts have turned to some books as yet unwritten which it would be pleasant to think of as fruit which the coming months might bear. Most of us who are much concerned with books have a few cherished wishes in that respect, expectations which have not thus far been realized.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts laid down today a Republican campaign blueprint for the new year which cautioned the party to:

"AIN'T you seen the new Army textbook on English grammar, Joe? It's out of this world. It's English with jive to it, what I mean. It'll learn you to talk right even if you didn't never wanta. All you gotta do is be able to read, and if you can't read just look at the pictures; they're better than a college education and twice as funny.

WITH promise of victory in Europe this year, business in 1944 tackles the problems of conversion to peace as it emerges only now from the completed task of conversion to war. The business outlook, therefore, depends largely on how well the new program is meshed into the reduced needs of the war effort.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 1 (Reuter) -- King Michael of Rumania, Premier Ion Antonescu and Vice Premier Michael Antonescu are directly responsible for activities of the "syndicate" that is filling its pockets at the expense of Rumania's misery, according to a diplomatic source.

THE great conferences held in recent months, at Moscow, Cairo and Teheran, have opened up new hopes on all continents. Especially here in America, where our people have been so overwhelmingly in favor of a new international outlook, the conferences have given encouragement to those who have worked and fought in this cause for years.

When the Legislature reconvenes in Albany on Wednesday it will have before it the Board of Regents' recommendations for a gigantic State-wide post-war educational program embracing every phase of education from kindergarten through college. The plan, estimated to cost $65,000,000, is the result of two years of work and study by school leaders of this State.

USUALLY the first thing doctors say when the subject of penicillin is brought up is, "Please don't call it a 'wonder drug.'" But then they proceed to grow enthusiastic in spite of themselves: "A remarkably effective antibacterial agent" . . . "better than the sulfa drugs" . . . "a few months ago in a case like this we'd have been helpless."

ALGIERS, Jan. 1 -- Driving toward Pescara over the coastal highway, troops of the British Eighth Army progressed another mile yesterday to within four miles of Francavilla and to within the Adriatic terminus of the vital transpeninsular highway to Rome.

ORAN, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Breaking a one-touchdown deadlock in the last ten seconds of play, the Army eleven today defeated the Navy, 10 -- 7, before 15,000 gridiron-hungry generals and G.I.'s in the first Arab Bowl game in football history.

At least two distillers are planning to issue "dividends in kind" to their shareholders of whiskies upward of six years in age, as a direct result of the recent "rollback" order of the Office of Price Administration on whisky brands, it was learned yesterday.

Seven thousand visitors witnessed yesterday the judging of various poultry entries and the completion of the selection of champions in the pigeon classes at the Madison Square Garden Poultry Show in the basement exhibition halls.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The destroyer Perkins was sunk in a collision off New Guinea on Nov. 29, the Navy announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Norwegian Embassy in Washington has disclosed that one of Norway's best known underground newspapers, V Posten, recently celebrated the publication of its 100th edition and the beginning of its third year of existence. The paper has appeared regularly each week.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Theodore W. Kheel, chairman of the Second Regional War Labor Board in New York, was appointed today executive director of the national board here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- While asserting that this year would undoubtedly see reduction of output in some lines of munitions, two key officials of the War Labor Board gave assurances today that the necessary changes in schedules, cutbacks and contract terminations would bring a minimum of hardship to workers.

Failure of the Congress to pass the "Revenue Act of 1943" before the close of the year will be the first violation of the intent of the "Current Tax Payment Act of 1943," signed by President Roosevelt on June 9. To what extent the new measure will be made retrospective in its application will depend upon the promptness of its adoption after the present recess of the Congress.

With a record year for both sales and profits behind them, retailers enter 1944 faced with more acute merchandise shortages during the months directly ahead but encouraged by the probability of increasing supplies of civilian goods for next summer and fall, according to a telegraphic and local survey made last week by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The arrival in London of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, most consistently successful Allied commander, will give form and direction to the vast organization now preparing for invasion of northwest Europe from Britain.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- A shade of envy, a murmur of regret, crept into the voice of Alfred E. Smith when a few days ago as a guest of Thomas E. Dewey he made an unheralded tour of the executive offices he had occupied for ten years.

IT is not often that a house plant is thought of as a source of cutting material. If a plant or two of Asparagus sprengeri (known as Asparagus Fern, or simply sprengeri among florists) is included in such a collection, additional green will be available for mixing with cut flowers during the winter.

THE twentieth, and final, part of the monumental "Dictionary of American English," which the University of Chicago Press has been issuing to subscribers, part by part, since the project was undertaken in 1925, will be ready for delivery on Jan. 25.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by United States Government monitors:

IN many ways Henry Bellamann's new novel, "Victoria Grandolet," is reminiscent of Daphne du Maurier's "Rebecca." Like the latter, it is mainly concerned with the spirit of a house and its influence upon a new mistress.

The Red Army last week scored one of the most smashing successes of the war. In the upper Ukraine it unleashed a tremendous new drive that crashed through Nazi defenses on a front of 185 miles. Roaring into high gear, the Soviet juggernaut swept the wrecks of twenty-two German divisions before it toward the borders of Poland and Rumania.

If we can look forward confidently in 1944 to a full-scale frontal assault upon Hitler's European fortress, while at the same time maintaining our pressure upon the Japanese in the Pacific, it is to a very large degree due to the resurgence of Anglo-American seapower.

THE controversy between the Screen Actors Guild and Warner Brothers over talent for "The Hollywood Canteen," which resulted in the abandonment of that picture, is believed to have killed for all time the multiple-star film for which, in the past, name players have consented to waive established salaries to work for a short period on a pro-rata basis.

ANOTHER cycle begins. And augurs point to the strong likelihood that 1944 will prove a momentous year in many respects. While, in the art world, seasons are traditionally dated from early autumn to the quietus that summer brings, there comes always, midway, a lull -- an intermission, as it were, between the two acts of a drama.

MOSCOW, Jan. 1 -- In fifty Moscow churches tonight the Russian Orthodox Christmas season is beginning. Though Christmas is traditionally of less importance in Russia proper than in the Ukraine, this year special circumstances are causing the occasion to be observed here with unusual solemnity and devotion.

The Neediest Cases Fund for 1943 has reached a total of $265,306.47 today, the final Sunday of the thirty-second annual Christmas appeal on behalf of the most distressed families and individuals in the city known to eight leading private family welfare organizations. This total includes yesterday's 104 contributions, amounting to $3,060.25.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- New Yorkers and Midwesterners as well as New Englanders are the current victims, through fishless days all the week, of a feud between striking Boston and New Bedford fishermen and the Office of Price Administration in Washington.

Governmental invasion of the industrial fields has created the danger of post-war political control of technology, Professor James Kip Finch, acting dean of Columbia University's School of Engineering, warned yesterday in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- With fresh pork supplies continuing to pile up because of the exceptionally heavy run of hogs to market, the OPA announced today that it will continue for two weeks the present special pork ration point allowance to consumers.

IN 1944 babies may have to get along with tapes instead of safety pins, and otherwise make out with substitutes. But there are no priorities on love and understanding, and "nothing we can do or provide for a baby is more important," Dr. Dorothy V. Whipple said in an interview the other day.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS IN THE CENTRAL PACIFIC, Dec. 29 (Delayed) -- New methods and weapons, the nature of which cannot now be disclosed, have been developed as a result of lessons learned in the Gilbert Islands invasion last month and are being tested at central Pacific bases by Army forces now rehearsing for future assaults.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 2 -- Red Army troops, capitalizing on the greatest German military debacle since Stalingrad, plunged ahead to within twenty-seven miles of the Polish border yesterday in pursuit of demoralized German troops, Moscow announced early today.

The American merchant marine last year attained a new high point in its history by its performance in delivering men and war materials to battlefronts and bases scattered all over the world, but these achievements will be overshadowed, Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- President Roosevelt's order that materials be made available for more war plant cafeterias and rest rooms is regarded as a major move toward industrial feeding and generally improved plant services by Miss Rhea Radin, Chief of the Plant and Community Services Section of the War Manpower Commission, back this week from a month's inspection trip to the Pacific Coast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- R.F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, told the general chairmen of the brotherhood when they met in Chicago and authorized strike action, which has since been called off, that a strike might prove "suicidal" not only for the brotherhood but for the whole American labor movement and democracy itself in this country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- President Roosevelt, in a New Year's statement today, declared it fitting "that we direct our thoughts to the concept of the United Nations" and urged the need to continue when peace comes "the mutually beneficial cooperation we have achieved in war."
LONDON, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- A joint British Air Ministry and United States Army, European Theatre of Operations communique:

LONDON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- King Peter, youthful exiled monarch of Yugoslavia who has been disavowed by the Partisans, was reported to have left Cairo for a "secret destination" today, and reports arose immediately that some Balkan development was imminent.

AS these columns looked toward the press, more than 5,000 radio listeners from forty States had responded to the plea of the Metropolitan Opera for funds during the first three weeks of its money-raising campaign -- which would seem to prove once more, if proof were needed, that fine music is still radio's most effective ambassador to the listening public.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Artur Rodzinski, will give a concert tomorrow at 7 P.M., in Halloran Hospital, S.I., for wounded men of the armed forces. On the program, presented under the auspices of the Red Cross, Dr. Rodzinski has placed Weber's overture to "Oberon," Beethoven's Fifth symphony, the third movement from Tchaikovsky's Fourth symphony and Gershwin's "An American in Paris."

MOSCOW, Jan. 1 -- Swiftly advancing Soviet troops, heavily supported by tanks and mobile artillery, this week smashed eight German tank and fourteen infantry divisions, severed numerous major rail and road communication lines and appeared on the verge of inflicting a disastrous blow on the entire German army remaining in the Ukraine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The motion picture industry must be prepared to present a united front at the peace table if it is to recapture the free access which American films had to world markets before the war, Harold Hopper, chief of the Motion Picture Section of the War Production Board, said today.

Thousands of worshipers attended New Year's Day devotions yesterday for Protestants and Roman Catholics conducted at the city's churches and cathedrals. Principally they heard prayers for a victorious peace. The President's proclamation setting the day aside as one of prayer, with emphasis upon the nation's needs in time of peril, was read at some services and published in many parish bulletins.

Looking back yesterday over the last ten years, Mayor La Guardia found them, as the city's Chief Executive, "just hard labor." He was non-commital on whether he would try for a fourth term at the "heart-breaking work" of being Mayor again.

SINCE November, 1942, Dwight D. Eisenhower has been directing the gigantic task of kicking in the southern door to Germany. Now he is about to shift his approach to "other points of the compass," as President Roosevelt put it. But his primary objective will remain the same -- to kill Germans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered reopening of the proceedings for the reorganization of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company, the case having been referred back to it by the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri.

A new education bill, called the most comprehensive measure in the history of British education, is to get its second reading soon after Parliament reassembles in 1944. Based on the White Paper published last July, the bill will supersede all existing education acts, and includes all of the reforms proposed in that paper.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 -- Overcoming shortages that ranged from material to boypower, Philadelphia's Mummers rolled up Broad Street today to welcome the New Year with all the spirit of other and better years.

Illinois Institute of Technology freshman engineers, required to take a course in American history for the first time during the September term, are finding that, although they cannot solve history problems with a slide rule, they like the subject. Illinois Tech added United States history to its required list in July and is now teaching it to civilian, Navy V-12 and Army Specialized Training Program freshmen.

The new year dawns in the glow of a hope which, if fulfilled, will make this the most memorable year in the history of our times. Victory in Europe in 1944 -- provided all of us do our part -- has been pledged by many Allied spokesmen, most particularly by the man chosen to achieve it, General Eisenhower.

The seventeenth annual Debutantes New Year's Ball, a holiday party for debutantes of this city, surrounding communities and other cities in the eastern States, was given last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Many of the several hundred debutantes attending the ball were formally introduced to society on the occasion.

ANTHONY EDEN is superficially as much unlike Winston Churchill as any man bred in the same system could be; but deep down they have the same essential beliefs. Perhaps that is the reason why political sqothsayers believe the Foreign Secretary is in direct line for Mr. Churchill's position as First Minister of the Crown.

SWIFT, small and maneuverable, the modern destroyer is unquestionably, gun for gun and ton for ton, "the fightingest thing afloat." Unarmored to the point of fragility, narrow of beam, cramped, a destroyer rides rough.

SINCE glamour girls seldom start out already equipped with beach houses, gowns by Adrian, swimming pools and station wagons, a low-slung Y.W.C.A. called the Hollywood Studio Club continues -- after twenty- seven years -- to rake in most of the high ambition, the clear eyes, the pure souls, and, consequently, the smallest rents in town.

"I WOULD just as soon buy the blue sky as an acre of Panhandle land!" So spoke George Washington Littlefield, Texan, in 1879, when it was suggested that he buy a mere 16,800 acres of the millions over which his L I T cattle ranged.

SEATTLE, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Senator Mon C. Wallgren of Washington has disclosed that he will call for an immediate halt in conversion of Liberty ships to troop carriers pending investigation by the Truman committee into alleged faults that have caused some of the vessels to break.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Congress may be asked to rewrite the Communications Act to require that opponents of President Roosevelt receive equal time on the radio to answer any political statements he may broadcast.

MOLLIE PANTER-DOWNES, whose "London Letter" in The New Yorker has done as much as anything in print to make wartime life in England vivid to readers on this side of the Atlantic, has now written a story for boys and girls that pleases by its naturalness, its good humor and its spontaneous, easy style.

National safety and prosperity would cease for the United States if isolationism were adopted by this country as a post-war policy, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University and the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, predicted yesterday in a New Year's message.

The new year opened yesterday on a note of great expectations. In the East German armies, their lines of retreat into Poland endangered, were reeling back under the hammerblows of the Russians. Allied air fleets -- more than 3,000 planes strong on one day -- roared through German skies, battering at German cities.

THESE two books possess the common denominator of being concerned with Russia. But they are quite different as regards style and contents. The first is a collection of war reports and short stories by a well known Russian poet and war correspondent.

IN recent years the stately and magnificent Amaryllis has begun to attain the popularity that it so richly deserves. Those who have not yet tried it might see for themselves how satisfactory and fascinating can be the growing of one of these majestic and inspiringly beautiful flowering plants.

IN this exciting tale of the Montana gold rush will be found such surprising happenings a could best occur in the wake of Ellen Jerusha Posey, called Jerry. The Posey family made the river journey up the muddy Missouri in the Sixties, and thence by stage to the raw new mining settlement of Helena.

HERBERT WEINSTOCK'S new biography of Tchaikovsky, which appears fifty years after the composer's death, is the most thorough and detailed that we have in English. The author has gone to a fund of source material made available in recent years by Soviet Russia.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 1 -- Princeton University held today its first graduation exercises for members of its Army Specialized Training Program unit, with 204 soldier trainees receiving certificates for the successful completion of nine months of college work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Protestations that householders in the East Coast region are allergic to the fumes of burning bituminous are said to account for a critical situation which existed in New York and neighboring cities this week.
LONDON, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Extension of the International Rubber Regulation Agreement to facilitate establishment of a non-regulatory committee embracing all important producers and consumers of the commodity was accepted last week by United States rubber manufacturers as an indication that British and Dutch interests believe demand for rubber will be heavy enough "for some time after the cessation of hostilities" to support both natural and synthetic rubber production.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The British and United States Governments have been discussing with the Netherlands, Norwegian and Belgian Governments and the French Committee of National Liberation the ways in which civil affairs will be controlled in these countries after the Allied armies land in Europe.

RUTH GORDON was talking to Max Gordon about her play, "Over Twenty-One," when the producer, impressed by her firm stand on certain phases of the production, suddenly turned to her and exclaimed, "Miss Gordon, you are a determined woman."

THE dance bands swept across the country; listeners in Tacoma, Wash., heard what New Year's Eve sounded like in Times Square, in case they cared, which seems doubtful; another radio year was under way. Along Radio Row people were talking, naturally, of what 1944 would bring, and what you heard depended on the people with whom you conversed.

THE War Production Board has made it clear that many months will elapse before new household equipment can be released to the public. In the meantime it is entreating householders to redouble their efforts to conserve appliances now on hand.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 2 -- Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, commander of the United States Eighth Air Force, who is relinquishing his post in this theatre to take command of the Allied air forces in the Mediterranean area, in a transatlantic broadcast early today gave a dramatic outline of the swiftly rising power of American bombers and fighters.

Richard K. Law, British Minister of State and son of the late Prime Minister Bonar Law, speaking from London at yesterday afternoon's Victory Rally at the Metropolitan Opera House, declared that peace will depend on the common understanding of the nations and on their partnership.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Surgeon General Thomas Parran of the Public Health Service appealed to young women today to enroll in the classes of nursing schools now being organized for opening in the spring.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 -- Paced by three college freshman backfield stars who stole the show from their older teammates, East and West battled to a 13-13 tie on a rain-drenched field today, in the nineteenth annual charity football game for the Shriners Crippled Children's Hospital played before a capacity crowd of nearly 60,000.

PALM BEACH COUNTY sprawls away into Florida from the coast -- into a wilderness of savannah and jungle hammock that once oozed into the deeper wilderness of the Everglades. Much of the ooze is gone today -- drained off by WPA canals.

For the third time at Hunter College, a National Discussion Contest on Inter-American Affairs, organized by the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs in cooperation with the National Council on Education, is being sponsored by the Departments of Economics, Geography and Geology, History, Political Science, Romance Languages and Speech and Dramatics.
