LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The strongest bid for the support of its own people yet issued by the government of an occupied country functioning in exile since May, 1940, was addressed to the Belgians today by Hubert Pierlot, their Prime Minister, broadcasting from London.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, Jan. 2 -- United States Marines, pushing a mile and a half beyond the airdrome in expanding their hold on Cape Gloucester, New Britain, have counted more than 1,000 Japanese dead, and General MacArthur's headquarters said "the total (enemy) casualties are estimated at many times this figure."

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- Cooperation of college and university students in the Fourth War Loan and the principles upon which a lasting peace may be founded were among topics discussed today by delegates to the annual convention of the National Federation of Catholic College Students at Loyola University.

A year passes and a new year begins, and neither sun nor moon alters its cycle by a tenth of a second. Ships shudder and sink in the winter sea. Planes roar through the sky. Bombs burst and guns bellow. Men die. Time runs out, we say. Yet water flows beneath the ice and the winds sweep down the valley.
CHANGES are being announced in the Four Aces system of bidding, the first changes since it was published in 1935.

In the first broadcast of its kind, Mayor La Guardia, through the medium of a recording of his voice, sent a New Year's message to the people of Italy yesterday afternoon declaring that victory over the Germans was more certain this year than it was at the beginning of the new year in 1918.

MATTHEW FONTAINE MAURY is one of the great names in the maritime history of this country. This naval officer of our Civil War period did more than any other one man to chart the routes of the ocean winds and currents.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- British warships opened fire on the enemy in the first light of the Arctic dawn last Sunday. That engagement came to a dramatic close long after darkness had returned to veil the sinking of the powerful German battle cruiser Scharnhorst.

Major Karl Hetz, vice president of the Free Germany National Committee in Moscow, an organization of imprisoned German officers and men, uttered some blunt truths about "secret weapons" in camp recently during the course of an address. According to him all the "secret" German weapons of the past have been failures in the sense that they did not bring victory and that they were easily copied and even improved by the enemy.

IN this little book a former Social-Democratic Reichstag Deputy and a one-time Professor of Breslau University -- exiles both because of opposition to Hitler -- discuss the fate of Germany in the hour of her anticipated defeat.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A call for gradual paying off of the war-swollen public debt and a shifting of emphasis by pressure groups in the coming year from increasing rates of compensation to the pressing problem of how to make jobs and markets in the immediate post-war period came in New Year's Day statements today from two members of Congress.

From the official Hansard reports of Dec. 1, just received, I gather that the Colonial Secretary, Oliver Stanley, made a statement in Parliament, in reply to a question of the Conservative Member Samuel Hammersley, to the effect that the present Mufti of Jerusalem, Hadj Amin al-Husseini, is "technically still Mufti" (of Jerusalem), because "no legal machinery exists for the formal deposition of the holder" of that office.

Charles Oliver, tall, bespectacled honor student from Perth Amboy High School, lived up to his No. 1 rating yesterday when he breezed to a straight-set triumph in the Eastern indoor junior singles tennis championship final at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

WILL canned foods remain rationed in 1944? Will butter continue to be as scarce as French olive oil? Will there be enough evaporated milk for babies' formulas? Will a good thick steak be any easier to buy? These were some of the questions this department put to Government officials and to leaders of the food trade in an effort to find out what kind of meals civilians will be savoring in the forthcoming year.

WHILE 1944 is not likely to see the resumption of pleasure travel on a very extensive scale, travel circles checking recent statistics offer hope to the future tourist. The inveterate traveler, at present absorbed in war work, may take heart, for travel lanes of the world are being rapidly extended as war supplies are delivered to stations once mere dots on the map.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Uncertainty over the amount of coal the mine workers will dig every week under the 1944 wages and hours agreement is complicating the coal-mine manpower problem.
The German-controlled Italian radio reported yesterday that Benito Mussolini and Adolf Hitler had exchanged New Year's greetings and that Hitler had signed his message, "Yours, Adolf Hitler."

All Japanese ships that operated in Chinese domestic trade will be replaced after the war by a Chinese owned and operated merchant marine, and China then may bed customer for as many as 500 surplus American ships of all classes, Dr. Lin Lin, economist on the staff of the Chinese News Service, asserted last week.

Col. and Mrs. H. Murray-Jacoby gave an old-fashioned New Year's Day reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 1165 Fifth Avenue, to introduce their younger daughter, Miss Beatrice Murray-Jacoby, to older friends of the family. Autumn flowers were used in the decorations.
LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 2 -- The Russian Saturday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

WHEN we were young our composition teachers never forgot to warn us: "Write about things you know. Don't try to think up plots, just tell about the people and life familiar to you." And they would point to Proust of the "temps perdu" and, of course, to Jane Austen.
EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 1 (AP) -- A final-quarter forward pass gave Southwestern of Texas a 7-to-0 victory over the University of New Mexico in the Sun Bowl today.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1 -- The swivel-hipped Steve Van Buren today gave the Louisiana State Tigers an upset 19-to-14 victory over the Texas Aggies in the colorful Orange Bowl before an overflow crowd of 28,000.

In the wake of three disappointments to the fistic schedule he had planned for the end of 1943, Promoter Mike Jacobs yesterday could hardly be expected to look with substantial optimism on the year that is budding in so far as it relates to his extravaganzas.

In a recent speech former Ambassador Joseph Grew criticized "armchair statesmen" who would put a fence around a defeated Japan and let her stew forever in her own juice. Such a policy of vindictiveness, he feared, would create a festering sore with permanent explosive tendencies.

THE Metropolitan Opera Association's projected production of Prokofieff's recently completed opera, "War and Peace," after the great epic of Tolstoy, is certain to be an American premiere of exceptional interest.

Harlan Major, of whom you may have heard before, dropped into the office intent on beating the drum for his favorite campaign -- supplying fishing tackle to our soldiers and sailors on the world's outposts.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- The German battleship Scharnhorst's first offensive foray at sea, which led to her destruction last Sunday, occurred when she teamed with the huge Tirpitz and several destroyers to attack the Allied island of Spitsbergen more than three months ago, the Norwegian Government-in-Exile said today.

IN a bountiful mood, perhaps induced by the lucrative returns of the recent holiday period, the cafe impresarios are offering a superior assortment of events this week for the benefit of the night club habitues. The first item of consequence takes place tomorrow evening when Jimmy Savo, the darling of the pantomimists, opens a return engagement at Barney Josephson's Cafe Society Uptown.
In a recent editorial you cited the words of Justice Story in support of the view that Cabinet members should be permitted to appear before Congress and participate in debate.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 1 -- Many builders of the future hope to have done forever with the whole conception of spheres of influence. They disapprove of what it implies, which is a more or less constant, though perhaps veiled, intrusion into the political, economic and military affairs of small countries by large ones.

TURNING from painting and the teaching of painting at the Kansas City Art Institute, Fletcher Martin went to North Africa as a war art correspondent for Life. In his current show at the Midtown Gallery both phases of his existence are vividly represented.
Paradoxically enough war both checks and stimulates research. It checks the exploration of fundamentals; it stimulates the improvement of weapons and industrial processes.

HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 1 -- Southwestern Louisiana Institute's powerhouse offensive, clicking smartly through the air and on the ground in rain and mud, blasted Arkansas A. and M., 24 to 7, today before 12,000 spectators to inaugurate the Oil Bowl football game.
Waste paper now ranks with steel, iron, aluminum and rubber as a No. 1 war essential.

Activity was light in the wholesale markets here last week, but preparations were under way to take care of the January buying rush, the settling of spring and summer allotments in many lines, and sizing up the available merchandise in the market in relation to the anticipated needs of out-of-town buyers, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

VLADIMIR DUKELSKY, who has just received an honorable discharge from the Coast Guard, has written a Coast Guard fighting song, "The Silver Shield," to words by Howard Dietz, who was a seaman in the first World War.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Germans presented a summary of 1943 naval action today in which they claimed, without Allied confirmation, to have sunk 607 Allied merchant ships, an aircraft carrier, six cruisers, sixty-three destroyers, eighteen submarines, three corvettes, fifty-six motor torpedo-boats and several midget submarines.

American breeders and exhibitors of pure-bred dogs face the new year in an optimistic mood, feeling reasonably certain of at least an average period and with the possibility of the best twelve month since this country entered the war.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- Answering Royal Yugoslav Government reports from Cairo that the Partisans were disintegrating, the Partisan communique asserted today that numerous officers, non-commissioned officers and men of the former Yugoslav Army had deserted General Makhailovitch to join Marshal Tito's army.

ALGIERS, Jan. 1 -- At his beautiful Villa les Oliviers, which, as the name implies, stands among trees on a hillside overlooking the Mediterranean, Gen. Charles de Gaulle today held, for the first time, a New Year's diplomatic reception, such as is customary for the heads of States.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 1 -- With breaks figuring in most of the scoring, the Tuskegee Institute Tigers defeated the Clark College Panthers, 12 to 7, today in the third annual Vulcan Bowl game.

THE second term of the Broadway theatre season now is open for registration, with classes scheduled to begin tomorrow. WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Alexander Archer Vandegrift, who led the marines into Guadalcanal in the first penetration of Japan's stolen empire, formally assumed his new duties as Marine Corps commandant today.

A little nurse moves softly down an aisle armed with her thermometers, going from patient to patient.
The nation greeted the dawn of the new year yesterday with a record markedly milder, less costly in lives and property than that of a normal, peacetime morning after.

MOSCOW, Jan. 1 -- Immediate steps for the creation of an effective and active guerrilla movement in Czechoslovakia to hasten the war's end was urged today by War and the Working Class which expressed full confidence that the Russians would bring full victory over Germany in 1944 and further strengthen the friendship between Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union.

A small white-shingled playhouse with green shutters on the seventh floor terrace playground of the Hunter College Elementary School has been decorated by the children. No sooner had the school carpenters set together and installed the structure than the pupils of the "School for Gifted Children" began to add their personal decorative touches.

The city's intensified drive to salvage wastepaper will see trucks and trailers of various welfare agencies and the War Production Board-Civilian Defense Volunteer Office begin rolling through the streets at dawn tomorrow on their rounds of collection of what has become a No. 1 war essential, it was announced yesterday by the New York Newspaper Assocation Wastepaper Salvage Committee.

Whenever this column has occasion to look back through the files it usually finds the record sadly manhandled by time. All the more gratifying is the rare exception which manages to stand up under the wear and tear of the years.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 -- Georgia Tech's Ramblin' Wreck discarded its famed razzle-dazzle offensive long enough to smash to a 20-to-18 last-quarter victory over Tulsa's classy Golden Hurricane today before 69,000 fans in the most sensational game in Sugar Bowl history.

Retail trade here was rather quiet last week, with a spotty response indicated to clearance events. Some stores had slight increases or broke even in sales for the week, but the average for department stores was estimated as likely to run about 3 per cent or more under the comparative week of 1942.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- Cornell's basketball team defeated Princeton in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game tonight, 41 to 39. Bod Gale tallied thirty seconds before the end to give the Ithacans their second victory in four starts.

Although the basketball season is just about one month old, there isn't an unbeaten major college quintet in the metropolitan area, for last night at Madison Square Garden, New York University, last of the local fives with a spotless record, had the misfortune to run into a Colgate aggregation that knew all the answers and subjected the Violets to a 48-41 setback before 16,108 persons.

Winston Churchill was out in the sunshine again last week. Seven weeks ago, on his way to the first Cairo conference, he caught a cold, though a few days later at Teheran he was able to celebrate his sixty-ninth birthday, clinking glasses with "my fighting friend President Roosevelt" and Premier Stalin.

AN orchestra in action is a moving and wonderful thing -- both to see and to hear. It may even be impressive in rehearsal, as the maestro commands, begs, cajoles or threatens, musical results notwithstanding. But when air-performance time comes around and men and maestro are "in the mood" to move together like a finely designed machine, the sight is good.

WITH a quiet ease, an engaging humor and genuine understanding of children, Ruth Holberg has told a convincing tale of a little girl who lived in a town on Cape Ann more than fifty years ago. Tibby Robbins was the fastest runner in Bay View.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 1 -- Renewed action to break the hold of the International Boilermakers Brotherhood, AFL, on the affairs of its Mount Hood Lodge here, has been started in the State courts by two factions in the lodge.
MIAMI, Fla. -- Hialeah Park, having served a patriotic purpose in the war program in this area, will resume on Friday the civilian status that won it national renown in the world of sports.

Just back this week from an ocean-hopping trip touching three continents, Dorothy Bohanna, chief stewardess for American Export Airlines, added the mileage flown to the more than half million miles already in her personal log -- and then went to sleep.

Every two and a half seconds a passenger or freight train pulls out of a railroad station somewhere in the United States. To move the train the services of more than thirty men are required. The country over, three-quarters of a million men get the rails ready for the trains, get the trains ready for their trips and guide and protect them along the way.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Pops Pick, B.F. Whitaker's colt, came from behind today to win the $5,000 added Sugar Bowl Handicap at the Fair Grounds and pay $17 for $2. Pops Pick was cleverly ridden by Lester Balaski to lead a fine field in the mile and sixteenth event.
Waste paper now ranks with steel, iron, aluminum and rubber as a No. 1 war essential.

" A TREATY entering the Senate is like a bull going into the arena: No one can say just how or when the final blow will fall, but one thing is certain -- it will never leave the arena alive." These bitter words of disillusionment were written by John Hay, some of whose finest achievements as Secretary of State were thwarted by the opposition of a minority in the United States Senate.

RAHWAY, N. J., Jan. 2 -- Sixfoot Pfc. Rudolph J. Kropaczek of this city and his foot-high fox terrier, Oahu, both war casualties, have been inducted as members of Mulvey-Ditmars Post, Veterans of Foreign Wars.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Henry Hayden of St. Benedict's College, Atchison, Kan., was elected president of the National Federation of Catholic College Students today at the close of the annual convention at Loyola University. He succeeds Robert H. Nelson of Detroit, a Navy midshipman student at Notre Dame University.
If New Yorkers do not become thoroughly acquainted with the value of raising poultry for food and recreation, it will not be the fault of the men and women already in the poultry industry.

Taking time off from their military reverses in China and the Pacific, the Japanese turned yesterday to a beguiling description of a fine new world after the war -- when rocket- driven Tokyo-Berlin express trains would glide along the "ceiling of the world."

In a sermon yesterday morning at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street, the Rev. Dr. Walton H. Greever, secretary of the United Lutheran Church in America, asked his listeners to let God "work out His will in our lives," and to help in disseminating the gospel so that human perversity and wickedness may be conquered.

HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 2 -- Congregation Beth Israel, largest Reform Jewish congregation in the South, enters the new year divided over a credo adopted by a vote of less than half its former voting membership, defining the mission of Israel "to witness to the unity of God," declaring that Jews form neither nation, nationality nor race but a religious community, and barring observers of the Jewish dietary laws and Zionists from voting membership.
ALGIERS, Jan. 2 (UP) -- A communique:

DETROIT, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The pace-setting Montreal Canadiens, with Ray Getliffe shooting three goals for the "hat trick," extended their winning streak to six games tonight by defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 5 to 2, before 12,246 spectators. It was the first defeat in four games for Normie Smith, Detroit's 35-year-old comeback goalie.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 1 (Delayed) (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek told the Chinese Army and people today that President Roosevelt fully approved at Cairo the generalissimo's ideas that "all Japanese militarists must be wiped out and the Japanese political system purged of every vestige of aggressive elements."

PHILADELPHIA Jan. 2 -- For an agency supposedly relegated to a back seat for the duration of the war, the Securities and Exchange Commission managed to break into print with accustomed regularity during 1943, thanks to some controversial action and at least one assist from President Roosevelt.

As 1943 drew to a close the nation's public utilities were speeding into the last lap of the biggest year in the history of the electric power and light industry. Records were set in efficiency and adequacy of service, and all demands for power were met in a manner that served as a tribute to the foresighted planning of utility executives and engineers throughout the nation.

The only consolation Hitler was able to offer the German people and the German Army in his New Year's messages was the assertion that they had escaped a "Napoleonic catastrophe" on the Russian front. But even as these words were being broadcast to the German nation they were already being mocked by the approaching thunder of the Russian guns.

The year 1943 was, without question, the most extraordinary yet experienced by American industrial and financial enterprise. Mobilization of industry for wartime operation reached its peak and, in the closing months of the year, increasing emphasis was placed on production for offensive warfare as our military program, as in a kaleidoscope, developed into a clearer picture of quickening victory.

There will be no more international disasters like Dunkerque and Pearl Harbor if the American and British people can be made to understand that an aggressor will always be our common enemy, Sir Godfrey D. N. Haggard, retiring British Consul General in New York, declared yesterday.

A willingness to share with the less fortunate was the common bond that brought many generous gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, including those sent by one who is jobless, another who had received a war-job bonus, another who has "always had the breaks," one who was inspired by seeing the fund "continuing despite bad times" and one whose brother, a naval aviator, "was killed in action."

Driving home seven goals before their rivals had a chance to score at all, the Boston Olympics had an easy time conquering the New York Rovers in the Eastern Hockey League engagement at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Back from a visit overseas, the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, pastor of the Baptist Temple in Philadelphia and president of the World's Christian Endeavor Union, declared last night that the war still could be lost on the home front.

In his latest letter to THE TIMES Professor Yandell Henderson errs in stating: "The United States has by long custom the strongest liquors of any of the civilized nations, until recently the lowest taxes, and correspondingly the most serious liquor problems." Each contention is wrong.
DALLAS, Jan.2 -- Mayor J. Woodall Rodgers of Dallas envisions a Cotton Bowl stadium seating 100,000, making this city the nation's football center.

For more than four years the Canadian National Railways have been doing the largest and most exacting industrial war job in Canada, according to the system's year-end statement. From Sept. 1, 1939, through the last week of December, 1943, the system carried more than 291,400,000 tons of freight and more than 98,200,000 passengers.

Temporary pay rises to help offset the increased cost of living became effective last Saturday for thousands of employes of the Departments of Health, Sanitation, Public Works, Welfare and Correction, but those scheduled for members of the Police Department are in abeyance, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 2 -- Great Lakes vessels operators, seamen and dock workers took one on the chin last spring when inclement weather delayed the opening of the 1943 navigation season for six weeks, but they came back fighting and piled up sufficient supplies of ore, coal and other commodities to keep vital war plants humming throughout the winter.

The British Information Service has emphasized that he British Conscription Law provides for full mobilization of both labor and capital: "More than two out of every three persons between the ages of 14 and 65 have been conscripted and are working full time in the armed forces, civilian defense or industry.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 -- The destroyer escort Senegalais, the first of four warships to be presented to the French fleet by the United States, was placed in commission today at the Philadelphia Navy Yard.

The beginning of a new year provides a convenient point for a survey of air power during 1943, a year when the ascendancy of this force was repeatedly demonstrated. Space limitations in these articles permit us to touch only peak developments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Boom towns, mushrooming into existence under war pressures, are not chasing the community chuck wagon as far up the trail as in the days when the point rationing system was new. Going after the groceries no longer necessitates driving forty miles, as it did within recent memory in Orange, Tex., according to Robert Davenport, assistant chief of the distribution division of the civilian requirements branch of the War Food Administration.

Barring some last-minute change in plans, only one new picture will have a Broadway premiere this week. The newcomer is "Government Girl," scheduled to open on Thursday at the Palace. Olivia de Havilland and Sonny Tufts are co-tarred in the RKO production, which was adapted and directed by Dudley Nichols from a story by Adela Rogers St. John.

ALGIERS, Jan. 2 -- Wac telephone operators, flown to Cairo to handle the switchboards during the conferences there, lived in anticipation of one important moment, but it never came. That moment was to have been the instant when the white light above the space marked "Mr. X" blinked on.

LONDON, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- The Berlin radio asserted today that a landing-craft and transport fleet of several hundred thousand tons was massing at various British ports and that reinforcements for Anglo-American forces in southern England had increased in preparation for large-scale landing attempts on the Continent.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- Reporting a production increase in 1943 of more than 50 per cent above 1942, a letter to Premier Joseph Stalin from 1,606,152 workers, residents of the Sverdlovsk district in the Urals pledge a further increase in 1944 production of 20 per cent over 1943.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES ON BOUGAINVILLE, Jan. 2 -- A 6,500-foot field for light and medium bombers, within less than 250 miles of Rabaul and only 850 miles from Japan's mighty naval base at Truk, is in operation today in these northern Solomons. The airfield, at the base of the fuming volcano Mount Bagana, was carved out of the heaviest of jungles and was dedicated Christmas Day.

Taxpayers, who will receive through the mails within the next few days forms for their 1943 in- dividual income and Victory tax returns, were urged yesterday to lose no time in visiting local Internal Revenue offices if they need assistance in filling out the blanks or computing the amount they owe the Federal Government or the amount the Government may owe them.

The comparatively few foreign currencies still traded in the New York market held at or near their respective "official rates," with the exceptions of the free-market Canadian dollar and Argentine peso. The Canadian rate began the year at 88.62 cents, in terms of the United States dollar, moved up to 89.56 within one week on the news of new financing plans of the Dominion Government, and continued higher by easy stages to 90.87 in mid-July.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Sergio Osmena, Vice President of the Philippines, declared today that maintenance of "adequate naval and air bases" in the Philippines after the war would "assure the mutual protection" of the islands and of the United States.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 2 -- Chasing Middle East thieves through the twisting by-paths of Oriental native quarters and employing at least fifteen different languages to bring them to justice is only part of the daily routine of the investigation bureau of the Provost Marshal's office of the United States Army Forces in the Middle East, which has already recovered more than $1,000,000 worth of stolen Army property.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 2 -- Construction has started on the $50,000,000 natural-gas pipeline from Texas to West Virginia, but rumblings from Texas officialdom are still heard. There appears little doubt, however, that the 24-inch line will go through.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Appointment by President Roosevelt of Lloyd K. Garrison, general counsel of the War Labor Board; as the board's first alternate public member, was announced today.

A three-day drive to enlist 20,000 volunteers as "minute men" to sell war bonds in Manhattan during the Fourth War Loan drive will be opened today by former Gov. Alfred E. Smith, it was announced yesterday by the War Finance Committee for New York State.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The German armies in Russia are faced today by the prospect that continued Russian success in the explosive offensive southwest of Kiev will open a gap between Field Marshal Gen. Fritz von Mannstein's German army group in the south and that commanded by Field Marshal Gen. Guenther von Kluge on the central front.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration today directed commercial airlines using Lindbergh Field in San Diego, to cancel all flights to and from San Diego because of "faulty maintenance" at the airport.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 2 -- Conditions inside France are becoming more chaotic than ever, according to trustworthy private sources, with considerable discord prevailing on the issue of Communist participation in the post-war government.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP) -The only goofy thing about that Rose Bowl game New Year's Day was the betting, what there was of it. Southern California, which never has lost a post-season contest in Pasadena's big amphitheatre, was priced at 5 to 2.

Bryant Park will be closed to the public after 10 P.M. until further notice, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall. Barriers will be placed at the entrances on Sixth Avenue, Fortieth Street and Forty-second Street at the curfew hour nightly.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- Governor Dewey, in his second annual address to the Legislature on Wednesday, is expected to recommend a series of benefits to be created by the State for disabled soldiers and for those discharged at the end of the war.

One blistering day last June we expressed a wish to be in Bismarck, N.D., where the temperature was 43 while New Yorkers were sweltering in a humid 89. Well, you can have Bismarck now, and we'll take Tucson, Ariz.

Mayor La Guardia declared in an interview at City Hall yesterday afternoon that retailers here could have sold eggs last week at least 10 to 15 cents a dozen below ceiling prices because of the over-supply in this section.

Preaching in the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street, yesterday, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, the pastor, declared that the world must face the fact of "radical readjustment for men and nations if we are to cure certain ills caused by the stubborn memory of man."

The president emeritus of St. John's University in Shanghai, China, the Rev. Dr. F.L. Hawks Pott, was guest preacher yesterday in Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street. He urged the congregation to do more to enrich their lives in the coming year than to follow a set of New Year's resolutions, however well intentioned.

I used to be pretty good at the shooting galleries down at Coney Island, but I doubt if at 70 I could take on a Jap fist-on-fist. Instead I'm recruiting Minute Men for the next War Loan later this month. This work, both for me and for the volunteers I hope to get to work with me, is as important as though we were in uniform.

A simulated bombing of the heart of Manhattan at 8 P.M. on Thursday will bring into action most of the volunteer units of the city's civilian defense army, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

Estimates that the United States will spend $35,000,000,000 for housing in the first post-war decade have been prepared by Charles B. Sweatt, vice president of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company. He said that many companies not normally associated with the building industry were now making plans to get into the field, which is expected to take up the first post-war slack.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -Republican members of Congress believe that the Equal Right Amendment will greatly influence the next election and that 1940 will see victory in the twenty-year campaign demanding equality for women under law, according to a announcement tonight by the National Woman's Party.

In an editorial of Dec. 14, "Power and Propaganda," whose significance may have been overlooked, after referring to the anticipated failure of efforts to draw Germany's Balkan satellites out of the war before Allied forces land there or Turkey enters the conflict, you generalize as follows: "And this reveals the limitations of propaganda, or moral suasion, unless it is coupled with power, which is still the final argument in international affairs.

For ten years Americans have been buying vitamins like cigarettes and candy. In fact, a vitamin craze has taken possession of the country. Yet the more biochemists and nutrition experts discover about food the more it becomes apparent that the kitchen garden and the butcher meet Nature's requirements without benefit of pills and capsules.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The newspaper War and the Working Class today replied to foreign criticism of the Kharkov war criminal trials and asserted this was "only one of the first blows inflicted upon the hideous fascist beast."

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 1 (Delayed) -- Argentina went a long way toward becoming a totalitarian state modeled on some well-known European patterns when the Government yesterday dissolved all political parties by decree.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Dr. R. Plato Schwartz, associate Professor of Orthopedic Surgery at the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry, today announced the development of a device to check and record the effectiveness of treatment of infantile paralysis.

Some investment company managers, after careful analysis, have reached the conclusion that except for a very short period of conversion lasting not more than four months our industrial machine will be kept turning at high pitch when peace returns, according to Floyd B. Odlum, president of Atlas Corporation.

At the concert of the New Friends of Music, late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, the Budapest Quartet opened the Beethoven program with the string quartet, Op. 130, which was given with the two finales the composer wrote for that work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A trend toward closer relationships between manufacturers and their retail dealers, evident for some years, "has assumed new significance under war conditions," Dr. Amos E. Taylor, director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, said today on the basis of a Department of Commerce study of "wartime dealer-aid programs."
A first-period scoring spree that netted them four goals put the Boston Bruins on the right road in their National Hockey League game against the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night.

With its industrial activity becoming greater than in pre-war years, the automobile industry doubtless will continue to be the nation's largest provider of jobs after the war, Ward M. Canaday, president of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., declared in a year-end statement.

In a New Year's message to the Latin-American press, Dean Carl W. Ackerman of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism appealed yesterday to editors and publishers in the Western Hemisphere to assume leadership in restoring the freedom of international news after the war.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 2 -- Asked what a college curriculum should contain to prepare a student for living in the post-war world, William C. De Vane, dean of Yale College, said tonight in a radio address:

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- Gen. Ivan C. Bagramian's men this morning were reported at the walls of Vitebsk after having overcome desperate enemy resistance. German shock troops rushed from Polotsk by armored trains to try to force the Russians off two places on the line to Vitebsk failed in their purpose although as many as twenty counter -- attacks were launched daily.

In the immediate post-war period the railroad industry will need the greatest amount of capital it has ever required to replace and repair car equipment that now has had the most intensive use for several years, according to a year-end statement of David A. Crawford, president of the Pullman Company.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 2 -- Brazil has helped toward winning the war by lending a string of war bases to the United States and the war has helped Brazil. Today, compared with 1929, she is several years farther ahead economically.

The American Women's Voluntary Services Salvage Department announced yesterday that it was starting the New Year with an educational campaign to supplement its already active cooperation in the waste-paper collection drive.

Heavy demand for military tires and other rubber products indispensable to the armed forces may result in continuing shortages of many essential rubber articles for civilians this year, John L. Collyer, president of the B.F. Goodrich Company, declared yesterday in his review of the industry.

Announcement that the New York Stock Exchange was studying post-war plans for utilization of American capital in foreign fields probably was the high spot of that institution's year. It was a year which saw a vast expansion of the special offering field, the employment of women on the floor for the first time, general mobilization of the Stock Exchange community for war bond sales and elimination of stamps for State and Federal transfer taxes.

Jack Moskowitz won an adjourned game from Dr. Joseph Platz yesterday and completed his schedule in the annual tournament for the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club with a score of 6 1/2 -- 2 1/2. Arnold S. Denker leads with 7 -- 1.

ON THE HUNAN FRONT IN CHINA, Dec. 29 -- Now that the Japanese menace has been removed, at least temporarily, refugee farmers and artisans are drifting back to their homes in Hunan, south of the Yuan River. On the long hard trek from Taoyuan our party of military attaches and correspondents met them on hard lumpy paths, crossing winter paddy fields.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Jan. 3 -- American Sixth Army troops in a new surprise move landed at Saidor on the north New Guinea coast, fifty-five miles below Madang, big Japanese base, on Sunday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Trading on the Chicago Stock Exchange during 1943 expanded to 9,527,000 shares, or a daily average of 31,546, compared, respectively, with 5,161,000 and 17,146 shares in 1942, Harry M. Payne, chairman of the board of governors, reported today.

Secretary Perkins is authority for the statement that the American cost of living rose only 3 1/2 per cent in 1943. The special War Labor Board Committee appointed by the President to study the cost of living index will not complete its work in the sixty days allotted to it.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman visited the Holy Name Center for Homeless Men, 18 Bleecker Street, yesterday and blessed the home's service flag honoring 641 in the armed forces. The Archbishop, before dedicating the banner, said a low mass at 8:30 A.M. in the Chapel of Our Lady Mother of Mercy on the second floor of the institution, which is operated by the New York Catholic Charities.
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Russian Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:...

The average level of prices of high-grade municipal bonds set a new high record in 1943, reflecting the relatively small supply of new long-term issues and the increased investment demand, due to the sharp increase in surtaxes on incomes, according to Louis S. Lebenthal, head of the municipal-bond firm of Lebenthal Co.

Postponement, until after the war, of action on the Wagner-Murray-Dingall bill to expand the scope and enlarge the benefits of the Social Security Act, as well as on all other such "palliatives," was urged upon Congress in a report made public yesterday by a special committee on social security of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

Frederick Brown, the operator, concluded his realty operations for 1943 by selling the ten-story apartment building at 620 West 116th Street to Dr. W. Goetz for investment. The building, which occupies a plot 75 by 100 feet adjoining the corner of Riverside Drive, contains forty apartments of various sizes and rents for about $42,000 a year.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Local fishermen, who are on strike, voted today to continue their walkout which is to protest failure of the OPA to adjust ceiling prices of fresh fish. It also was disclose that more than one-half of the number have turned to other work. The tie-up has lasted for almost two months.
The nation's railroads issued last year a total of $120,610,000 of new bonds in seventeen issues, compared with $35,440,000 in eleven issues in 1942 and $272,491,000 in forty-two issues in 1941.

The first performance in English of Verdi's opera "Falstaff" will be given by the Metropolitan Opera Company on Jan. 14, with Lawrence Tibbett in the title role and Sir Thomas Beecham conducting. The Italian version was heard at the Metropolitan in the season of 1938-39, when Mr. Tibbett also sang the role of Falstaff.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The United States will face a post-war population problem, with wide changes in traditional trends, according to a survey made by Dr. Philip M. Hauser, assistant director of the Census Bureau.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Grain markets closed the year at about the highest prices of the season with cash wheat quoted around $1.75 a bushel, a new peak since 1928. Rye likewise was in new ground for fifteen years and oats since 1920 and the ceiling price of $1.16 a bushel on No. 2 yellow corn put that market at a new high since 1937.

It may not be the best or the strongest metropolitan aggregation, but the basketball team that Nat Holman, in his twenty-fifth year at C.C.N.Y., has fashioned has been the most entertaining so far. The Beavers move around nicely and with speed, but lack sufficient height to harass the opposition.

ALGIERS, Jan. 2 -- All the wild weather that has plagued the Allied armies in Italy so far was outdone by the elements yesterday. The entire front was swept by raging winds and cutting rain bad enough to ground every strategic and tactical plane in Italy.

ALGIERS, Jan. 2 -- Delegates of the resistance movement in France said today that, if permitted to do so, possibly in a secret session, they would place before the Provisional Consultative Assembly on Tuesday a strong plea for greater aid for those in France who are fighting on the domestic front in what the French here sometimes call a double war, since the enemy is Vichy as well as the Germans.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Powerful formations of Lancaster bombers of the Royal Air Force slipped through a baffled German night-fighter force early this morning and pounded Berlin with more than 1,120 tons of bombs, bringing the total weight of explosives dropped on the Reich capital in the Battle of Berlin since Nov. 18 to about 14,000 tons.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Extensive reorganization of the State Police under Governor Dewey continued today with the naming of a new acting chief inspector and a new acting commander for Troop G in Troy.

Jesse Stuart, whose latest book, "Taps for Private Tussie," is a Book-of-the-Month Club selection, will have a new novel ready for publication next month by Dutton. "Mongrel Mettle: The Autobiography of a Dog," is the title. Dutton also announces for next autumn a volume of Mr. Stuart's verse, under the title, "Album of Destiny."

WITH CHINESE FORCES IN NORTHERN HUNAN, Dec. 29 (Delayed) (AP) -- Dead and wounded in the rice bowl battles from Nov. 7 to mid-December totaled nearly 100,000 for both sides, with the Japanese losing three men to every four Chinese, it was calculated today by the two Chinese military commands involved.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, today called for "a virile upsurge of private initiative" to pave the way for an orderly reconversion of business after the war.

The first three weeks of the Metropolitan Opera Fund drive have yielded $63,503, it was announced yesterday by George A. Sloan, president of the Metropolitan Opera Association. The contributions came from members of the opera audiences and from thousands of radio listeners, the amounts ranging from $25 to $1,000 or more.

At yesterday afternoon's concert of the NBC Symphony Orchestra, sponsored by General Motors, there was given under the direction of Leopold Stokowski the first performance of Howard Hanson's Fourth Symphony. This was preceded by the Stokowski transcription of the love music from "Tristan und Isolde" and by comment upon many things, description of forthcoming programs, etc., but very little about Mr. Hanson's symphony, which, presumably, was one of the principal interests of the audience assembled.

A "special German correspondent" writing in the Swiss weekly, the Weltwoche, said that a new priority system in Germany was giving precedence to the production of aircraft, tanks, artillery munitions and submarines in that order.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Eddie Sawyer, pilot of the Binghamton (N.Y.) baseball club, has been signed to manage the Utica team in the Eastern League, it was announced today by the Philadelphia National League club, which operates Utica in its farm system.

MADRID, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Germans, abandoning all pretense, intend to "crack down" on the southern zone of France with Pierre Laval as their agent, letting Marshal Henri Philippe Petain resign or remain as Chief of State as he pleases, dispatches from Paris indicated today.

Payments under the old-age and survivors insurance system in 1943 in New York, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware, newly consolidated into a social security region with headquarters here, amounted to $47,000,000, or 30 per cent of the national total of $155,000,000, Peter Kasius, the regional director, reported yesterday.

Germany is stripping Italy of railroads, factories and her gold reserves, and is threatening the country with "disastrous" inflation by collecting 6,000,000,000 lire a month from the puppet government, according to an article in the Swiss newspaper Libera Stampa, reported to the Office of War Information yesterday.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 2 -- Ice and unkind wind, conditions that can balk the intrepid winter dinghy sailors, almost stopped them in their tracks today as they set forth in their twelfth anniversary regatta, but they plunged on and Jack Sutphen, with his craft Rum Dum, won the event.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 2 -- John S. Herron, Newark Superintendent of Schools, announced tonight a classroom program emphasizing "tolerance and better understanding of other peoples and religions." He said the program, first in New Jersey to include such objectives, would begin next semester, and that local and State organizations were cooperating.

IN a recent column a rhetorical question was asked as to whether anyone could top the zany incident of Coaker Triplett stealing third with a man on the base and then getting caught in a double play. Charles Benowitz of Brooklyn took the question literally and promptly produced a baseball oddity. It was not a major league happening, but seems strange enough to be repeated in this corner.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A BRITISH NORTHERN NAVAL BASE, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The daring attack and pursuit by three British cruisers and audacious torpedo onslaught by four destroyers at a range of less than a mile were cited by Admiral Sir Bruce Fraser today as major factors leading to the destruction Dec. 26 of the German battleship Scharnhorst under the big guns of the British battleship Duke of York.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 2 -- Under an old State Civil Service statute recently brought to the attention of city officials the Board of Public Works has added the name of 81-year-old Frank Murphy, a street department worker for thirty-four years, to the municipal list of pensioners.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- After more than holding their own against outside competition, winning a total of thirty games and losing twenty-four, Big Ten basketball teams open their 1944 Conference campaign this week with Illinois appearing amply prepared to defend its title.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Miss Caroline Flexner, special assistant on the headquarters staff of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, has spent many years as an assistant to former Governor Herbert H. Lehman in relief work.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Mill receipts of domestic pulpwood in the United States totaled 11,911,000 cords during eleven months of 1943, or only 1,089,000 cords under the 13,000,000-cord goal set for the year by the War Production Board, with December figures as yet unreported, according to the War Activities Committee of the Pulpwood Consuming Industries.

LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The German High Command today clamied the capture of Meleda, Adriatic island off Yugoslavia's Dalmatian coast, in a renewed flurry of Nazi amphibious activity that reflected Germany's anxiety over a possible Allied invasion of the western Balkans.

The Eintracht booters of the German-American League surprised at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday, defeating the Brookhattans of the American League by 4 -- 2 in the first round of the National Challenge Cup soccer competition.

AN AMERICAN BOMBER STATION, in England, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- Carrying a dead waist-gunner, whose throat had been ripped by anti-aircraft fire, and eight other men blinded from lack of oxygen, a riddled Flying Fortress struggled home safely from deep in southern Germany against terrific odds, it was disclosed here today in the pilot's report to his commanding officer.

There is a danger of city consumers' paying too much for eggs in the present period of abundance, a foremost representative of the trade told this column. He said that huge supplies had knocked the bottom out of the market, that prices at the wholesale level had decreased greatly, but that some at retail had not changed correspondingly.

The transitoriness of life was the subject of a sermon preached yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Cecil C. Hine, pastor of the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour's Atonement, Bennett Avenue and West 189th Street.

The Pacific Coast has become what the housing authorities call a "congested area." From Washington to Detroit, from Norfolk to Miami, the country is full of these swarming war hives, but in no other section have so many towns grown so prodigiously in two years as on the Western Seaboard.

Newspaper advertising in support of the war effort amounted to $16,656,528 in the three-month period between August and October of last year, according to a report issued by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Shells from Canadian artillery are now in range of Pescara. This port is the goal of the Eighth Army's long push up the Adriatic coast. Once General Montgomery's men slog through the nine miles of mud ahead to take the town the whole campaign in Italy will change radically.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 2 -- Jersey City residents, with mounting ire, are making their way through piles of refuse and garbage that have stood uncollected on the sidewalks as long as three weeks.

Fashion rapport between the United States and Mexico is improving constantly. The beautiful country to the south is now a playground for Americans who have leisure. Among those who enjoy vacationing in Mexico City, the colorful towns in the hills and the tropical seaside resorts are fashion designers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- A billion dollar annual outlay for education of the veterans of this war is projected in a revised measure likely to get senate consideration this month.

STRASBURG, Pa., Jan. 2 -- Although the prospect of labor trouble on the Strasburg Railroad seems pretty remote, what with the chief of police representing half of its entire personnel, an Army lieutenant has been operating the four-mile line since last Wednesday.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine took action yesterday to halt anti-Semitic activities and desecration of church and synagogue buildings. He ordered an increase in mobile detective patrols in affected areas and directed Inspector George P. Mitchell, head of the sabotage squad, to see if the outbreaks were linked to organized subversive groups.

A program for community agencies, public and private, to curb child-labor abuses arising from wartime dislocations was urged in a statement by leaders in education, health and social service, made public yesterday through the National Child Labor Committee.

Considerably larger numbers of buyers are expected in the market this week and next, with estimates being that the influx will be outstanding, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The farmers of America are winning the battle of production on the food front, according to John A. Hartford, president of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, who says "the nation's consumers may reasonably expect that the 1944 food supply will equal or exceed the near record of 1943."

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 2 -- The nation's output of steel ingots declined last week 4 points to 88 per cent of rated capacity, one of the lowest points reached in the war period. This sharp drop, which was 10 1/2 points below operations during the pre-Christmas week, was due entirely to the steel workers strike early in the week, which shut several integrated mills.

A review of the shipbuilding industry's accomplishments during last year shows that while each expansion of the global war has imposed new burdens on the privately owned shipyards, every challenge has been met, every Presidential directive has been exceeded and every responsibility discharged successfully by the in- dustry, H. Gerrish Smith, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, declared yesterday in a year-end statement on the industry.

ALGIERS, Jan. 2 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who will soon leave to take his post as Commander in Chief of Allied invasion forces in the west, warmly praised his Mediterranean troops in a farewell message today.

Immediate rescue of thousands of Jewish children remaining in Nazi-occupied areas and abrogation of the British White Paper, which will restrict Jewish immigration in Palestine beginning next April, were advocated yesterday at meetings sponsored by the Rally of Hope and Courage Committee to Help Save European Children in Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 -- Year-end liquidation inspired mainly by favorable war news and predictions by military leaders accounted last week for a late reactionary trend in cotton futures on the Cotton Exchange here following earlier sharp upturns on short covering and mill price fixations in the near positions.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (AP) -Georgia Tech and Tulsa University broke at least three records in the Sugar Bowl stadium yesterday when Tech defeated Tulsa, 20--18. In fact, they broke the record for breaking Sugar Bowl records.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Unfair and deceptive practices were charged in a Federal Trade Commission complaint issued today against W.W. in the Western Hemisphere, Inc., a Brooklyn concern that publishes biographical reference books.

Adoption or a constitutional amendment to permit proposed constitutional amendments to be put on the ballot by petition was advocated yesterday by the Citizens Union, in completing announcement of its program of State legislation.

After a respite of two weeks because of the Christmas holiday vacation period, all teams in the Public Schools Athletic League championship basketball tournaments will resume action this week. Games are scheduled on Thursday and Friday.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 3 -- Russian troops, pursuing a demoralized German army across the northern Ukraine, swept to within fourteen miles of the Polish border yesterday with the capture of the town of Poyaski, and killed more than 4,000 enemy troops in general advances along a 200-mile front.

The aluminum industry last year attained an annual production rate of 2,100,000,000 pounds of metal, seven times the nation's peacetime production, according to Roy A. Hunt, president of the Aluminum Company of America. He said that it is one and one-half times the production of the entire world before this war and that it is far in excess of what the combined Axis countries can produce.

After moving within a narrow range in the first half of last week, prices of cotton registered wider fluctuations and closed with irregular net changes. At the end of trading on Friday the January delivery on the New York Cotton Exchange showed a net advance for the week of 24 points, while the more distant deliveries were up 11 to down 2.

Bulgaria is one of the countries with which we are at war. Still, a dispatch from Sofia saying that it has been found necessary to close all the night clubs might arouse sympathy. The Government had to take this step, according to an official announcement, because these places "were fields of activity for many foreign women who commit espionage, where many weak Bulgarians are subject to temptation."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 2 -- Vivian Blaine, former night-club singer who played opposite Don Smeche in "Greenwich Village" at Twentieth Century-Fox, has been assigned to the top feminine role in that studio's "When Irish Eyes are Smiling." 'She replaces Lynn Sari.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 2 (AP) -- A record crowd of 10,000 watched the Navy gain revenge for last year's defeat by handing the Army eleven a 19-0 setback today in the second annual Lily Bowl football game.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -New construction, conversion of existing buildings and intensified us of the pre-war housing supply he provided 3,400,000 housing unit for war workers' families and he overcome the housing problem in most industrial centers, John I. Blandford Jr., administrator of the National Housing Agency, reported tonight.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 2 -- An operating surplus of between $400,000 and $500,000, attributed to increased industrial consumption of water, will be divided among consumers early next year through rebates on first quarter bills, the Elizabeth Board of Water Commissioners announced recently.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Jan. 3 (UP) -- A communique:
The United States this year must prepare for reconversion to peace-time work that already is beginning, the National City Bank of New York says in its letter for January.

Jose Siqueira, founder and president of the National Symphony Orchestra of Brazil, who is touring this country under the auspices of the State Department and the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, told here yesterday of arrangements for an exchange of compositions of North American and Brazilian composers.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 3 -- The Argentine Government recognized the new Bolivian regime today in a note delivered to the Bolivian Ambassador, Adolfo Costa du Rels, by Oscar Ibarra Garcia, Argentine Foreign Under-Secretary.

Lieut. Field Marshal Franz Szombathelyi, Chief of Staff of the Hungarian Army and an admirer of Adolf Hitler, told his countrymen in a New Year's review reported yesterday to the Office of War Information that their desire for peace was "wishful thinking."
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Jan. 4 (UP) -- A communique:

ALGIERS, Jan. 3 -- Stopping here on his way back to London from Moscow, President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia said today that the new Russian-Czech treaty was designed to fit into a general system of security and that "we need a strong France" for European peace.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The first announcement by a big bank of its final dividends for 1943 was made today by Martin's Bank, Ltd., when it declared a distribution of 7 1/2 per cent, making 15 per cent for the year, the same as for the last four years.

Induction ceremonies for three Supreme Court justices elected on Nov. 2 were held yesterday morning in three parts of the County Court House on Foley Square. The ceremonies were for Justice Thomas A. Aurelio, Joseph A. Gavagan and Archie E. Morrison.

A retrospective loan exhibition of work by the famous Belgian artist, James Ensor, has been arranged by Curt Valentin at the Buchholz Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street. It will open this afternoon with a preview from 3:30 to 6:30, admission $2, proceeds to benefit Belgians in Britain, of which Mrs. Benjamin Philip Watson is president.
Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe have gone to Cherokee Plantation, their place in Yemassee, S.C., for the winter.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- City officials and commuters here were elated this afternoon by the Supreme Court decision, but attorneys for the railroad contended that the decision was based on a technicality and that at a rehearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission the railroad would again win the right to close the line.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Martin H. Weyrauch, professor at the Brooklyn Law School and former newspaper man, will be the principal assistant to Hiram C. Todd, special assistant attorney general in charge of the investigation of the Legislature, an inquiry originated by the Albany County grand jury and since taken over by the State.
The minute the Red Cross knew that disaster had struck with the explosion of the destroyer yesterday that organization was ready to rush aid to the scene.

To improve the selection of men for the armed services, teachers of boys 17 years of age and over will help compile this month a medical survey authorized by Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national director of Selective Service, it was announced yesterday by Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade.
ATLANTA, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Georgia Legislature pushed today toward quick passage a bill to assure a quarter million citizens in the armed services a sure and easy way to vote in the 1944 elections.

The Associated Press submitted to the three judges of a special Federal statutory court here yesterday a proposed form of judgment, designed to make clear and specific the provisions of the court's ruling in the Government's anti-trust suit against the cooperative news-gathering agency.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 3 (U.P.) -- Recent criticism of the labor strife in the steel and railroad industries by a high Washington official was assailed tonight by Philip Murray, president of the CIO United Steel Workers of America, in a telegram to Donald Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, with a copy to General George C. Marshal, Army Chief of Staff.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Production of a number of plastic items such as combs, buttons, cosmetic containers, zippers, lipstick containers and some small kitchenware items, will be curtailed during the coming few months because of restrictions in the use of plastics ordered by the War Production Board. Recent developments in the chemicals industry, WPB said, have made it necessary to cut down on some plastic materials used in certain civilian industries of lower essentiality.

UNITED STATES ELEVENTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Alaska, Jan. 3 -- Striking in the white glare of flash-bombs, four Army Catalina flying boats struck at Japan's North Pacific bases of Paramushiru and Shumushu about midnight, Dec. 31, it was revealed today.

Formation of a new operating unit within the General Foods organization to be known as the Birdseye-Snider division of General Foods Corporation, was announced yesterday by Edwin T. Gibson, vice president. The new unit, it was stated, is comprised of Frosted Foods Sales Corporation, Q-F Wholesalers, Inc.; the recently acquired Snider and Ray-Maling divisions, and B.E. Maling, a subsidiary.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The long-continuing month-by-month rise in the public debt came to a temporary halt in December as Federal income soared to a new record high of $5,736,000,000.

Whoever knows the German character must come to the conclusion that Hitler's New Year's proclamation is a victory for the Allies. Two sorts of Germans have read it: the people and the generals. Both will have noticed that their Fuehrer is in a state of mental bewilderment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Federal Power Commission announced today entry of a final order setting $27,910,538 as the actual legitimate original cost of the Niagara Falls Power Company's Project 16, near Niagara Falls, N.Y., as of March 2, 1921, when a license was issued for the development.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- A wooden lifeboat that will not catch fire even when passing through forty-foot flames in a sea coated with burning oil has been perfected for use by crews of torpedoed tankers, many of whom perish in seas set ablaze by their burning cargoes, it was announced today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 3 -- The capture of Novograd-Volinski resulted from a Russian attack that followed the converging movement pattern used so effectively in previous victories on the first Ukrainian front. It succeeded in gaining possession of the largest town in a wide area of a hilly, densely populated country.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- King George honored not only eminent politicians, empire leaders and British soldiers in his New Year's honors list but also several women who have made outstanding contributions to the nation's war effort.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease last week of 4 per cent under the like week a year ago, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported an increase of 20 per cent. In that period, however, there were five selling days against four last year.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Investors Syndicate Title and Guaranty Company of New York consented today to issuance of a Federal Court injunction restraining the company from sales of Series G certificates to investors by "any untrue statement of material fact."

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Pressure from houses with Northwestern and Southwestern connections gave the wheat market on the Board of Trade here an easy undertone early in today's trading and led to reports that farmers were selling cash grain on a larger scale.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- America's shipyards set a record in December by producing 208 vessels of 2,044,239 deadweight tons, including 118 Liberty ships, and production has reached a rate which, if necessary, could be maintained at 25,000,000 tons a year, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, said today.

The winter weather in this area continued to favor the Sanitation Department yesterday when the first authentic snow of the season turned to rain about noon and covered the streets with slush that made walking and motoring hazardous, but saved the city considerable on its snow removal bill.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 3 -- Nicholas Mouchanoff, pro-Ally leader of the Bulgarian Opposition, which has been fighting for a change in Bulgarian foreign policy since the appointment of the Regency Council, has headed a coup d'etat that has led to the overthrow of Premier Dobri Boshiloff's Cabinet, informed diplomatic circles here reported late tonight.

Thomas J. McMahon disclosed yesterday that he had resigned as treasurer of the New York County Democratic Committee, a position he had held for seven years. He said his retirement had no connection with the internal differences that have arisen in the organization since the nomination and election of Thomas A. Aurelio to the Supreme Court.
LONDON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
LONDON, Jan. 3 (Reuter) -- Poland would welcome an invitation to become party to the Soviet-Czechoslovak treaty, Polish Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk said in an interview today.

Mayor La Guardia advised New Yorkers yesterday not to buy eggs while the market was oversupplied, unless they were priced from 10 to 15 cents below ceilings. An independent survey showed some of the large food chains were selling medium grade A eggs at 49 cents a dozen, grade A brown at 55 cents, and large white grade A at 59 cents.

Thousands of tons of gifts, each with a label reading "To the heroic people of the Soviet Union from the people of the United States of America," are flowing from this country, Fred Myers, director of Russian War Relief, Inc., said yesterday.

Having exposed in its December bulletin the fallacy of the belief that a huge internal debt is no real burden because we only "owe it to ourselves," the National City Bank in its January bulletin proceeds to examine the Stuart Chase theory of a "compensatory" economy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The original proposal of the New York Central Railroad for abandonment of a three-mile electric branch line between Van Cortlandt Park Junction and Getty Square, Yonkers, ran into a snag in the Supreme Court today.

James A. Adams, president of Standard Brands, Inc., announced yesterday that the company had acquired all the outstanding capital stock of Shefford Cheese Company, Inc., of Green Bay, Wis., formerly wholly owned by Kingan Co., Inc., of Indianapolis.

ALGIERS, Jan. 3 -- Frigid weather tightened its grip all across the Italian front yesterday and the ground fighting was restricted to a coastal height three miles beyond Ortona, where the British Eighth Army continued its battle with the Germans barely nine miles below Pescara.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 4 (U.P.) -- Russian troops swept to within seven miles of the Polish frontier yesterday, capturing the town of Olevsk, while other units of the Soviet First Ukrainian Army advanced along a constantly expanding front toward three key German railroad junctions below Kiev.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The American daylight bombing attacks on the suburbs of Paris and southern French air bases Friday did heavy damage to the big Hispano-Suiza airplane engine plant and two cam ball-bearing plants, and destroyed at least twenty-five grounded German planes, reconnaissance photographs showed today.

ALGIERS, Jan. 3 -- Strong sentiment against the cardinal points in the plan of the French Committee of National Liberation for restoring the Government of France developed today among about thirty members of the Provisional Consultative Assembly here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- In the course of fourteen decisions handed down today by the Supreme Court at its first session in 1944 everyone of the nine justices dissented some of them three or four times in divisions of 5 to 4 and 6 to 3.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Jan. 4 -- The Red Army, continuing its offensive west of Kiev, has smashed across the 1939 Russian-Polish border, it was disclosed today.

A national sales force, comprising more than 300 representatives of newspaper, magazine, radio and outdoor advertising, has been established by the War Advertising Council to provide national advertisers with first-hand data on information themes relating to the war effort and home-front morale.

Advancing their openings by ten days to permit retailers to place orders for timely delivery through March, the eight members of the Millinery Creators Guild yesterday showed spring lines in their showrooms here. Buyer attendance was reported good, considering the weather.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Tokyo and recorded by The Associated Press:

Since the playwrights have been notoriously faithless this season, the actresses now are put to creating their own roles. Last evening the Music Box received "Over Twenty-One," by Ruth Gordon, the playwright, who wrote it especially for Ruth Gordon, the actress.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Another powerful force of British four-motored bombers shot their way through masses of Nazi fighters early today and blasted Berlin with 1,100 tons of bombs in a second such blow in twenty-four hours.

NO more rabid enthusiast for the State of Kentucky exists than Adolph Rupp, a Kansas boy who traded in a Midwestern twang for a soft Southern drawl fourteen years ago when he became the basketball coach at the University of Kentucky. He now has a true Chamber-of-Commerce outlook on life in Kaintuck and will recite the glories of the State at the slightest provocation.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz appointed yesterday as foreman of the January (1044) Kings County grand jury Herbert T. Miller, a Negro, of 558 Decatur Street, Brooklyn. In making the appointment, Judge Leibowitz said Mr. Miller was the first Negro to serve as foreman of a grand jury in any county of the nation.

The despair that has clouded the lives of Private Rudolph Schatzberg and his 29-year-old wife, Eve, an expectant mother, since last August, a month after the husband entered the Army, was dispelled yesterday when Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan refused to order Municipal Court Justice Christopher C. McGrath to sign a notice to evict the couple from their one-room apartment at 1064 Carroll Place, the Bronx.

Allen Berntson, 34 years old, formerly of 53 West Seventy-second Street, a soldier from Camp Croft, S.C., was in a Tombs cell yesterday and will plead in General Sessions today to an indictment accusing him of having defrauded Alvin L. Kaye, head of a fur corporation at Fairbanks, Alaska, of $10,000 and $15,000 worth of pelts.

The Manhattan Center, at Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, which in the past has resounded to many an operatic aria, rang yesterday with another kind of song. Two thousand chickens, pigeons, waterfowl and turkeys of various colors and shapes combined to stage a "barnyard symphony" as the New York Poultry Show opened its thirteenth annual exhibition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Representative James M. Curley was indicted anew by a Federal grand jury here today in connection with the operations of an alleged Government war contracts brokerage racket. A veteran of Massachusetts politics, he is Democratic National Committeeman for that State.

A lone helicopter poised a moment in the snowy sky, then dipped straight down to land on Manhattan's southern tip yesterday at 10 A.M. Fourteen minutes later it whirred down on the beach at Sandy Hook. Its cargo, unique in helicopter history, was two cases of blood plasma for the survivors of the destroyer explosion.

It is not a great many months since Adolf Hitler was complaining that he really did not have enemies who were smart enough to test his skill. It was in his Berlin address of Sept. 30, 1942, that he declared: "If I had an opponent of adequate scope -- of real military size -- then I could actually calculate approximately where he would attack.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan 3 -- President Roosevelt and his wife, Eleanor Roosevelt, have deeded their Hyde Park home and 33.23 acres of land on their estate here to the United States Government as a national historic site. The gift has been accepted on behalf of the nation by Secretary Ickes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The British Cotton Board of Manchester, England, advised the War Production Board today that because of its own import restrictions and rapidly expanding domestic war production programs, no further exports of English spun combed cotton yarns would be made following completion of the shipments for the period that will end about April 1, next.

Borough President Edgar J. Nathan Jr. of Manhattan filled two vacancies on his staff yesterday. Herman J. Barnard, an editorial employe of The New York Sun, was inducted as confidential assistant to the Borough President at $4,100 a year, and Mrs. Bertha Kelsh, Republican co-leader of the Eighteenth Assembly District, as secretary of the borough at $4,000 a year.

Your editorial discussion of the renegotiation of contracts has been, I think, most helpful in clarifying the issues and bringing out the main points. Mr. Krock's letter was particularly helpful. The letter from Under-Secretary of War Patterson is very enlightening.
PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 3 -- The "lost" ships that came back after Pearl Harbor have wiped out the blot of that day and have more than evened the score with the enemy, it was shown here today.

Unexplained explosions sank a United States destroyer in lower New York Bay about two miles south of Rockaway Point and six miles northeast of Sandy Hook at 7:05 A.M. yesterday, and shook the metropolitan area from Long Branch to Westchester, causing vibrations twenty-five to thirty-five miles inland.

On the evidence of the printed music, conveyed by telephotography and published in THE TIMES yesterday, Russia now has an admirably representative national anthem. Nor is it without significance that this new and valuable contribution appears after her relinquishment of Comintern and "Internationale," and at the time of one of her greatest victories on the battlefield.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3 -- Dana Andrews, now in the lead of Twentieth Century-Fox's "Purple Heart," has been named by that studio for one of the four top roles in "Wing and a Prayer" a yarn about the Navy's torpedo planes which will be put into production in two weeks under Henry Hathaway's direction.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Tropical Park's third hike in purse values became effective today as G.R. Watkins' Charitable churned through the heavy going to win the featured $1,500 Hallendale Purse.

It is proving rather difficult for members of the armed forces to keep up their morale upon hearing of strikes on the home front. It is proving difficult for former union members now in the service to be sympathetic toward these efforts for wage increases. In fact, some of us are beginning to get tired of the word overtime and annoyed at the easy manner in which labor walks out on necessary war industries.

In the First World War Bulgaria was the first of Germany's allies to surrender. In this war Italy has that distinction, but reports from Istanbul yesterday strongly suggest that Bulgaria may be second. Indeed, if the country were free from Nazi soldiers there can be no doubt as to what would happen.

The sixteen-story business building on a plot 94 by 78 feet at 404 Fourth Avenue, corner of Twenty-eighth Street, has been sold by Frederick Brown, operator, to a group of investors represented by Donohue Co., brokers. The seller acquired the property recently from the East River Savings Bank.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Bernhard Knollenberg, chief of the Materials and Supplies branch of the Bureau of Supplies, a key post in the Foreign Economic Administration, has resigned to return to his post as librarian of Yale University, it was learned here today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 3 -- Three-quarters of Adolf Hitler's Chancellery, his symbol of Nazi enterprise, was wrecked by explosive and incendiary bombs in the Royal Air Force attack on Berlin early today, according to an eye-witness with whom the writer talked after his arrival here from the Reich capital.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of approximately 1 per cent in December under the like month of 1942, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The final figure on Christmas trade was somewhat better than expected, but the decrease for December is the first for that month since 1939.
