WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Protests from twenty-five States on clothing shortages and clothing deterioration were reported today by the American Home Economics Association in the first summary of a nation-wide survey.

Reporting on operations of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for the fiscal year ended with last October, John W. Thomas, chairman, informs stockholders in the statement for release today that sales of $545,389,601 exceeded those of any previous year and were 55 per cen above the $352,693,500 of the previous year.

The sports pages last Sunday called attention to an error perpetrated in this column perhaps a fortnight ago. From a discussion of Japan's defeat in China's Rice Bowl on that occasion we went on to speak of our own happier Bowls at home.

A letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 31 praises King Victor Emmanuel, and brands efforts to oust him as the work of those "following in Mussolini's footsteps," presumably because the ex-Duce has set up a "republic" in northern Italy. A few facts are in order.

The latest move in the reorganization of the State Athletic Commission under Governor Dewey came yesterday with the appointment of John M. Christensen, Republican district leader of Queens, as executive secretary to fill the berth vacated with the resignation of Bert Stand last September.

A large apartment at 270 Park Avenue has been leased to the St. Anthony Club of New York, headquarters of the Delta Psi Fraternity, S.M. Swenson, president. Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker, arranged the lease for the club, quartered in the penthouse of the Berkshire, 21 East Fifty-second Street, for the last eight years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- News coverage of the impending United Nations' invasion of Europe will be planned ahead for integration into the general battle plan so that civilians here can be informed of the fighting as it progresses, according to Palmer Hoyt, retiring Director of Domestic Operations of the Office of War Information.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- H.B. Luro's Irish-bred Princequillo, a refugee from Europe, has been assigned top weight of 126 pounds for the running of the $25,000 added Widener Handicap at Hialeah Park March 4.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Feminine units of the Army Air Forces receive separate but uniform commendation from Gen. H.H. Arnold, commanding general, in his report to the Secretary of War, released today. As pilots, as nurses aiding in the long-distance evacuation of wounded and as members of the Wac on scores of jobs, they have, he indicates, more than passed muster.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A United States destroyer was torpedoed and sunk in the Atlantic a week ago Friday, the Navy announced today.

Shortly before five more members of the New York Regional Office of Price Administration resigned yesterday, G. Robert Ellegaard, chief regional personnel officer, reported that the turnover had reached a peak of 80 per cent last year and that it was "higher than it should be."

Gifts, both large and small, from old and new friends, from New York City and suburban communities, from other States and even from Mexico, came yesterday for the Neediest Cases Fund, lifting the total raised in the thirty-second annual Christmas appeal which started Dec. 5 to $270,023.97.

Survivors of the destroyer that sank off Sandy Hook told yesterday afternoon of the ship's last moments. They remembered chiefly the impact of the explosions, the discipline of the crew, and the rescue efforts of the Coast Guard, which received the unreserved praise of the Navy men.

A plan for a National Industrial Credit Corporation with capital of at least $500,000,000 to be subscribed by banks, insurance companies, corporations, individuals and labor organizations has been prepared by Herbert F. Boettler in collaboration with John W. Snyder, both of whom are vice presidents of the First National Bank in St. Louis, Mo., it was learned yesterday.

A beef extract has just been introduced in retail stores in this city by Armour Co. under the trade name of Vitalox. It is a brown fluid, thick as a puree, and a teaspoonful dissolved in a cup of boiling water makes a bouillon with refreshing tang.
MOSCOW, Jan. 3 -- Pravda asserted today that Finland has been guilty of "crimes against the anti-Hitlerite coalition."

Denying hotly that he expected the rest of the league to come down to the level of last year's Giants, Secretary Eddie Brannick of the National League club yesterday forecast a closer race in the National League for 1944. He based his prediction on the premise the league will have greater balance, and he finds this in the limited amount of material available.

As the Russian armies drive westward, pushing the Germans before them, the political question of Poland's eastern frontier returns to prime consideration among Allied statesmen. This frontier has plagued peacemakers for nearly two centuries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Repercussions from the declaration made anonymously Friday by "a high official" that the threatened railroad strike had given Germany a propaganda weapon with which it might stave off internal uprisings in Europe and add thousands to American casualty lists by a prolongation of the war brought two calls for Congressional investigation today, accompanied by denunciations and counter-charges from organized labor.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Jan. 4 -- Two Japanese heavy cruisers and one destroyer were left flaming from repeated bomb and torpedo hits after a carrier-based air attack on Kavieng, New Ireland, it was announced today. Admiral William F. Halsey's land-based bombers pounded Rabaul, New Britain, as well.

An increasing tendency on the part of employers in this State to accept the principle of collective bargaining and peaceful adjustment of labor conflicts was disclosed in 1943, Paul M. Herzog, chairman of the State Labor Relations Board, declared in his annual report yesterday.

The Bach Circle of New York, now in its seventh season, has carved out a useful niche for itself. Under the leadership of Miss Yella Pessl, harpsichordist, it has devoted itself largely to rarely heard works of Johann Sebastian Bach, his sons, contemporaries and predecessors.

Dr. James Rowland Angell, former president of Yale University and now educational consultant for the National Broadcasting Company, has been appointed director of New York University's Hall of Fame for Great Americans, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, Chancellor of N.Y.U. Dr. Angell succeeds the late Professor William Lyon Phelps.

Concern over impending war developments yesterday held trading on the New York Cotton Exchange to a minimum. Fluctuations were in a 12-point range. New Orleans buying and trade price-fixing against newly awarded textile contracts overcame scattered selling.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a draft registrant who objects to the classification given him by a draft board must report for duty before he can test in the courts the validity of the board's action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The President may call the New Deal slogan passe, but Mrs. Roosevelt said today she had not "laid it away in lavender," and also that this country needs something more in its place than "Win the War."
Yesterday's commuique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
LONDON, Jan. 3 (Netherlands News Agency) -- Word of the execution of thirty-two Netherlanders in Berlin was received here today in a copy of the Netherlands underground newspaper Het Parool.
LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 3 -- In spite of official assurances of loyalty to Germany and of faith in a German victory, the Bulgarian people are convinced that the Germans have lost the war and that the fate of their own country depends on how soon they can cut the bonds that tie them to the Ger-...

St. John's fears C.C.N.Y. While Joe Lapchick, coach of the Brooklyn Redmen, did not reveal his trepidations in his speech to the basketball writers at a luncheon at Toots Shor's yesterday, the lanky mentor, in an around-the-table discussion, conceded that City College's chances to down St. John's were better than fair.

The pattern for the Allied air attack in 1944 is clearly demonstrated by the two heavy assaults on what remains of Berlin within the first three days of the new year. They came within twenty-one hours of each other, and fires still blazing from the first were topped by flames lit by the second.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Japanese strategy is based on the hope that the United States will stop fighting before attaining complete victory, Brig. Gen. Merritt A. Edson, USMC, said today.

Marian Anderson gave her second and final New York concert of the season last night at Carnegie Hall, which was filled to capacity. The contralto, in magnificent voice, presented a new program, opening with a group of two songs in English by Haydn and two in German by Beethoven, "Von Tode" and "Neues Liebe, neues Leben."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Roosevelt today appointed Chief Justice Walter P. Stacy of the Supreme Court of North Carolina as chairman of a three-man special committee to study the racial discrimination case in which an order of the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practices has been challenged by sixteen Southern railroads and three labor unions.

Generally Broadway first-run motion-picture theatres did as much business as they could accommodate over the New Year, and with some theatres remaining open until dawn on Saturday, several houses hung up record grosses. A few theatre spokesmen, however, were of the opinion that business just about equaled that done for the same holiday last year.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Allied aircraft shot down thirteen Japanese planes and probably destroyed and damaged several others in a brisk air fight over southern Burma Friday, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarter's announced today.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 3 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Gen. Henry H. (Hap) Arnold, four-star general, who once was one of three aviators who constituted the Army's entire flying personnel, chose these words with which to conclude his 23,000-word report to the Secretary of War on the Air Forces:
Former Gov. Alfred E. Smith launched formally yesterday a three-day drive to recruit 20,000 volunteer war bond salesmen for the Fourth War Loan Campaign, which will start on Jan. 18.
WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY IN ITALY, Dec. 30 (Delayed) (Reuter) -- With tears in his eyes Gen. Montgomery said good-by today to the Eighth Army.
LeRoy D. Williams has been appointed industrial relations superintendent in the comtroller of manufacture organization of the Western Electric Company, with offices at 195 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A three-year plot to incite mutiny in the armed forces, unseat the Government and set up a Nazi regime, was charged by a Federal grand jury today with the indictment of twenty-eight men and two women on conspiracy charges.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 3 -- Partisan forces attacked Bahja Luka, an important town in Bosnia, on Saturday and succeeded in occupying about half of it, according to a communique from the headquarters of the Partisan army, broadcast over the Free Yugoslavia radio.
TRENTON, Jan. 3 -- A review by the New Jersey Supreme Court of the method adopted by the Legislature for revising New Jersey's Constitution was declined today by Justice Newton H. Porter.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 3 -- The New Zealand press today hailed Prime Minister Peter Fraser's New Year message to the effect that the scope of the drive of the United Nations against the Japanese would not diminish while the Germans were being driven back from all sides, but that on the contrary the war against Japan would be pressed continuously and undeviatingly with ever-increasing numbers and vigor.
The consensus of Manhattan beauty authorities appears to be that the cold, chemical permanent wave has passed the experimental stage and attained public acceptance -- both for summer and winter.

Seizure of Saidor in a sudden thrust by American troops against the New Guinea coast broadens the Allied front in the southwest Pacific by almost a hundred miles. By this single blow, delivered without loss, General MacArthur has anchored his wall across Vitiaz Strait, cut off the enemy retreating from the Huon peninsula and opened a two-pronged drive for Madang, the Japanese base on Astrolabe Bay.

ALGIERS, Jan, 3. "Be careful you don't get caught in the stampede," said the M.P at the door of the Opera House here tonight. We knew what he was talking about, for the line of G.I's had started forming an hour and a half before the doors opened.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A revised women's rayon hosiery price regulation, long awaited by the trade, was announced here today by the Office of Price Administration. The original regulation, with its provision for grade labeling of hosiery, was one of the most controversial orders ever issued by the price office.

Condition statements as of Dec. 31, released yesterday by leading Wall Street banks, generally showed small declines in deposits on the quarter, and consequently, in total resources. Cash positions were higher than three months ago, but such gains were just about offset by decreases in holdings of Government securities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 29, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The German High Command, striving to avert a disaster involving between sixty and seventy divisions in the Dnieper bend, is also faced with a manpower crisis that threatens to disrupt the entire system of defensive strategy on which Germany bases her hopes for a negotiated peace.
The Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices, prepared by the Index Number Institute, was 112.42 last week, a rise of 0.05 per cent over the previous week's level of 112.36.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The British Government has been discussing with the Netherlands, Norwegian and Belgian Governments in exile, as well as the French Committee of National Liberation, the control of civil affairs in those countries after the Allies have landed in Europe, but the United States Government has not yet participated in the discussions, it was said authoritatively today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Forecasting that the "near future" would be a "crucial period" in which "the survival or destruction" of the Luftwaffe would be at stake, Gen. H. H. Arnold promised tonight that, when the Nazi air arm was knocked out, ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A unanimous decision of the Supreme Court, delivered today by Justice Black, ruled that the Federal "kick-back" statute applies to a foreman who was alleged to have forced workmen under his supervision to pay him part of their wages without knowledge of the employer.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- More pork-on-the-hoof was crammed in Midwestern livestock pens today than at any other time in the last nineteen years.

Plans to reach 250,000 persons in the city for the balloting to determine the most popular sports figure were advanced at the second meeting of the sports committee for the Fourth War Loan Drive at Toots Shor's yesterday.

The minority in the new City Council, grown in relative strength at the last election, will try to give back to the burghers of New York what has been called the city's best "free show," a broadcast of the Council meetings at City Hall.

CAMP DAVIS, N.C., Jan. 3 -- The Women's Air Force Service, familiarly known as the Wasp, is providing pilots to replace men of the First Tactical Air Force here and release them for combat. The women pilots do target towing and mission flying, two of the most difficult and tedious jobs assigned to fliers.

The stock market got away yesterday to a faltering start for the new year as business slumped to the lightest in almost three months and prices closed mixed after narrow movements. Few of the prime investment issues attracted any attention as the bulk of the interest centered in low-priced shares.

Mayor La Guardia's proposal that the temperature of subway cars be reduced 10 degrees to save 13,000 tons of coal a month during the current shortage had been anticipated by the Board of Transportation, it was revealed yesterday as Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins declared that a 10-degree drop in heat would not be harmful.

As is customary, the Controller of the Currency, the Federal Reserve Board and the banking superintendents in most States, including New York State, formally issued calls yesterday for condition statements of banks under their respective jurisdictions, as of the close of business on Dec. 31.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 3 -- In an effort to check the steadily rising cost of living the Secretariat of Finance announced today that it would sell highway and possibly railway bonds to the general public so as to siphon off circulation of an unspecified amount of currency.
LONDON, Jan. 3 (U.P.) -- King George of Greece has deprived three Greek Quisling leaders of citizenship, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- In a decision regarded as of prime importance in utility rate-making, the Supreme Court by five-to-three held today that rates fixed by the Federal Power Commission should be based on the "prudent investment" theory, without the need for a "fair valuation" base.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The National Football League is ready to push its frontier westward, to Los Angeles and San Francisco.
Waste paper now ranks with steel, iron, aluminum and rubber as No. 1 war essential.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Of 23,000 nurse recruits needed to fill the quotas for classes starting in February, only about 11,000 have signed up, according to a report submitted today to Mrs. Roosevelt's press conference by Miss Lucile Petry, director of the Cadet Corps.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A West Indian Conference is being set up as a standing advisory body to the Anglo-American Caribbean Commission to provide a channel for consultation with local representatives on social and economic improvements, the State Department announced tonight.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Gov. Sumner Sewall of Maine called at the State Capitol today for a luncheon conference with Governor Dewey.

The six-family house at 327 Snediker Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Quinn-Yanover Corporation to Gussie Moss through the Aljo Realty Company, broker. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.
Walter Hill, industry and trade editor of The London Economist, sees the end of pre-war price rings which he says were allowed to flourish in Great Britain without Government intervention.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The continued lack of harmony between the Treasury Department and the tax-writing committees of Congress has developed into a proposal, said to have strong support, that the Bureau of Internal Revenue be divorced from the department and established as an independent agency.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Baseball's biggest problem, as the game approaches the 1944 season, is one of manpower -- and I am confident the sport will meet this problem as successfully as it has met many others which developed in baseball's first two wartime seasons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Attacking the Senate Finance Committee's proposed amendments to the War Contracts Renegotiation Law as tending to emasculate that statute and permit "a new crop of war millionaires," four members of that committee urged today the defeat of at least five of the proposals.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Business on the Stock Exchange here today was quiet with prices tending toward irregularity although there were a few bright spots.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Army and Navy jointly called attention today to the British-American Patent Interchange Agreement, which has now been in effect two years, and declared that the agreement has been of "great value" in the advancement of the war.

From all appearances the mythical metropolitan college basketball championship is wide open this campaign, but the first intracity clash, which will send St. John's against C.C.N.Y. at Madison Square Garden tonight -- N.Y.U. faces Penn State in the first half of the twin bill -- will afford the fans an opportunity to gain a better rating of the local quintets.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,078, which compared with 271 in the preceding week and 1,316 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BRANCH RICKEY is a very shrewd citizen and a very sound thinker. Yet it strikes this corner that the Deacon of the Dodgers was caught slightly off base when he remarked at a recent press interview that professional football was a threat to the majors in the postwar era and that college football would atrophy just as college baseball has done.

MOSCOW, Jan. 4 -- Fierce tank battles today marked the Red Army advance to the Polish border. The Russian forces were carrying out the High Command's order to sever the major supply lines serving the German Army remaining in the Ukraine and which daily finds itself in greater peril of encirclement.

The Swedish newspaper Dagens Nyheter said in an article reported to the Office of War Information last night that the Rumanian Government had developed a scheme to extort ransom fees ranging from 150,000 to 800,000 lei from Rumanian Jews now working at forced labor on the Russian front.

The Association of National Advertisers has distributed to all its members a pamphlet containing information on supporting the Government's food program of rationing and ceiling prices. Prepared by the Office of War Information, and the Office of Price Administration, in cooperation with the War Food Administration, the pamphlet explains the necessity of persuading the public to take the "Home Front Pledge" to to buy food without surrendering ration points and not to pay higher-than-ceiling prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Arthur D. Whiteside, chief of the Office of Civilian Requirements of the War Production Board, predicted today that the WPB and War Manpower Commission orders of Dec. 24 releasing more materials and more manpower to the manufacture of children's clothes would correct the scarcities in that field mentioned in complaints from twenty-five States to the American Home Economics Association.

Induced chiefly by the continued successes of Allied armies, nervous commission-house liquidation, combined with Southern hedge selling, yesterday caused a decline in the cotton futures market. At the close on the New York Cotton Exchange, the list of active contracts was 9 to 10 points below Monday's final quotations.

In a petition to the Board of Estimate, which is on tomorrow's calendar for the board's first meeting of the new year, the seventeen justices of the Supreme Court in the First and Second Departments demand a restoration of the $2,500 cut from their salaries in November, 1939.

The fourteen-story loft building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 237-9 West Thirty-seventh Street has been sold by Leo and Charles Zohlman to the 237 West Thirty-seventh Street Corporation for cash above a mortgage of $215,000. Louis Cooper and Michael Rozental were the brokers.

"Stagecoach," the Western produced by Walter Wanger and released here in March, 1939, will be reissued shortly by United Artists. Directed by John Ford, the film starred John Wayne and Claire Trevor, with Thomas Mitchell and Andy Devine in featured roles.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 4 -- A mild sensation was caused in Cairo today when the Yugoslav Information Office released for publication the text of a telegram from Premier Stalin of Russia to Prime Minister Bozidar Pouritch of the emigre Yugoslav government, acknowledging his New Year's greetings and predicting that the Yugoslav people would soon be liberated.

A belated New Year rally was staged yesterday by the stock market when, under the priming of substantial reinvestment demand in key issues, prices moved forward from fractions to about 2 points. The upsurge, which did not start until the afternoon, came when the steel group suddenly developed an enlarged demand, which the motors and aircrafts quickly followed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The author of the New Year's Eve statement on the delaying effect on victory of strikes, strike threats and their consequences, described by the White House as "a little more military than the President" and now accepted as Gen. George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, had something very important to say, and the information on which to base it.

Four former deputy internal revenue collectors, attached to the Brooklyn office, were indicted yesterday by the Brooklyn Federal grand jury for alleged illegal activities in connection with their Government work. The indictments, handed up to Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Brooklyn Federal court, charged two men with conspiracy to prepare and aid in the preparation of false income-tax returns, and the other two with accepting illegal fees.

Aircraft hull insurance policies covering flight risks have been extended to include general average and salvage charges at no additional premium, effective from Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by the United States Aviation Underwriters, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Private importers will handle the purchase and importation of Brazilian babassu kernels in the future, the War Food Administration announced today. The shiftover to private interests, it was added, is in line with the WFA's and the War Production Board's policy of returning importations of foreign fats and oils and oil-bearing materials to private trade whenever possible.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Bowing to demands of more than 100,000 individual petitioners for immediate legislative action, a House judiciary subcommittee will begin public hearings next week on national prohibition legislation.

MONTREAL, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Meat inspectors, milk testers and clinic staffs were included today in the strike of about 2,000 white-collar employes of the city of Montreal who walked out Dec. 21 in a demand for annual salary increases averaging about $500.

General Mills, Inc., is asking from the holders of its preferred stock proxies for approval of the proposed issuance of $20,000,000 of ten-year sinking fund debentures bearing 2 1/4 per cent interest, "in furtherance of immediate and future plans of your company," according to a letter signed by James F. Bell, chairman, and Harry A. Bullis, president.
William J. Noble has joined the production staff of the Niagara Fire Insurance Company.

James B. Schafer, one-time "lord" of Peace Haven in an old mansion on Long Island, left General Sessions yesterday to resume serving the State prison term imposed on him in 1942 for a $9,000 fraud on a woman patron of his Royal Fraternity of Master Metaphysicians, leaving the latter without a guiding hand.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Jan Ciechanowski, Polish Ambassador, conferred with Secretary of State Cordell Hull today. There were no indications that the United States was taking sides in the Polish-Soviet question.

AN ADVANCED NEW GUINEA BASE, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Few things would be more impressive evidence of our dominance over the Japanese in the air and on the waters of the Solomons Sea, the Vitiaz Strait and the southern portion of the Bismarck Sea than a trip here from Saidor, our newest invasion point on the northeastern coast of New Guinea, aboard a Navy landing ship.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Navy announced tonight that the destroyer that sank as a result of a mysterious explosion in lower New York Bay off Rockaway Point early yesterday morning was the U.S.S. Turner, a 1,700-ton ship that had been in service only since April 15, 1943.

The new draft of MPR-339 covering women's rayon hosiery, announced yesterday by the Office of Price Administration, "is a vast improvement over the original regulation and its various amendments," Earl Constantine, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, declared yesterday.

Such news stories as the one about "Finnish atrocities," released by the Russian Embassy in Washington, in The TIMES of Dec. 30 cannot be read with anything but disgust and resentment by anyone knowing anything about the country in question and the nature of its people.

NOUMEA, New Caledonia, Jan. 4 (AP) -- New Caledonia's Governor was not expressing the opinion of the majority of Caledonian citizens when he criticized American troops and American administration of this French island, Nicholas Hagen, leading business man and one of the best known figures in the South Pacific, said today.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Republic Steel Corporation reported today that it had surpassed all its basic production records in 1943, with operations maintained at an average of 100.4 per cent of estimated capacity, against 99.6 per cent in 1942.

While no records exist which disclose accurately what part of the nation's record-breaking steel production in 1943 was for direct and indirect military use, certain rule-of-thumb estimates indicate that probably 8 per cent of the 61,593,530 tons of finished steel products distributed in the first eleven months of the year were for civilian purposes.
PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 4 -- Heavy toll was taken of two forces of Japanese fighter planes attempting to intercept formations of Liberators that bombed three Marshall Island atolls Sunday.
Regardless of how the war's restrictions may hamper actual participation in hunting and fishing next season, sportsmen in New York and New Jersey will not lack for places to go if they can get there.

The Neediest Cases Fund received $2,069.88 in gifts yesterday from 144 contributors, raising to a total of $272,093.85 the amount contributed during the thirty-second annual appeal for the most distressed families and individuals in the city known to eight leading private family welfare organizations.
BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Bruins arrived at the halfway point of the National Hockey League's fifty-game season by outscoring the Black Hawks, 6 -- 4, tonight before 10,000 at the Boston Garden.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Hundreds of medium Marauders of the United States Eighth Air Force paced an unprecedented Allied aerial offensive involving about 1,250 bombers and fighters against the north coast of France today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 -- The Government of Brazil filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a maximum of $76,651,500 of new bonds to be issued in partial redemption of twenty-five different issues of State and municipal external dollar bonds now outstanding.

The rug and carpet industry will not have a formal opening this year, it was reported yesterday by Steele Winterer, vice president and sales director of A. M. Karagheusian, Inc. Mr. Winterer cited merchandise shortages as the chief reason for the industry's decision to abandon its annual January opening which usually coincides with the yearly furniture market.
BOSTON, Jan. 4 -- General George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, was extolled today by Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker as "the type of man who should be the next President of these United States."

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The death of Capt. Eric Erskine Loch, 53-year-old British explorer, was announced today and Ecuadorean police said he had fatally wounded himself yesterday with a pistol.

LILY BROWN'S mother was a prim and virtuous widow who earned a scanty living sewing and taking in boarders. One day in a fit of pique she threw a bread knife at a man who was courting her more impetuously than she thought proper. Unfortunately her aim was better than might have been expected and she pierced the cad's jugular vein so that he died promptly and most bloodily.
ALGIERS, Jan. 4 -- American Army nurses serving in combat areas in Italy are working in front-line field hospitals, some of them as close as three or four miles from the heart of active fighting.

President Green of the A.F. of L. has made an extraordinary answer to some Comments on the labor situation which, in company with other observers in Washington, he attributes to General Marshall and which he describes as "irrational, uninformed and inflammatory.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The mood of the German press and radio, in the face of the Russian advance, the Bulgarian crisis and the threatened invasion, is unusually somber.
Karin Branzell, noted Swedish contralto, announced yesterday that she would retire from the Metropolitan Opera Association after the present season, her twenty-first with the company.
"This is one of the toughest jobs I have ever tackled," Karl D. Gardner, director of the Community Sales Division of the War Finance Committee, 1270 Sixth Avenue, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The profit of the First National Bank of Chicago for 1943 was $7,633,489 after all charges and reserves, compared with $6,648,599 for 1942, Edward E. Brown, the president, reported today to stockholders. On the basis of the bank's former $30,000,000 of capital stock, the profit was equal to $25.44 a share and on the basis of the $50,000,000 of capital stock approved on Dec. 20 it was $15.26 a share.

What with the great need for cheese among our armed forces and the Allies, as well as a decline in production, the civilian allotment of domestic varieties for this year is expected to be considerably smaller than that of the past. The Food Distribution Administration estimates it at four pounds a person, as compared to five and a half pounds in 1943 and five and three quarters in 1935-39.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation has been called for Jan. 12 to vote on a plan advanced by the board of directors under which holders of preferred stock are asked to extend the maturity of the present preferred shares to Oct. 1, 1949.

The four-story apartment with stores on a plot 48 by 147 feet at 264-66 Summit Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold to the Rock-Summit Company, Inc. Assessed for $77,400, the property was sold for $64,000. The buyer gave back a purchase money mortgage of $57,500 due Jan. 1, 1954, at 3 1/2 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 -- Vice Admiral John W. Greenslade will retire on Feb. 1 as commander of the Western Sea Frontier and commandant of the Twelfth Naval District and the dual command will be split among two successors, it was announced today.

Continuing the brief survey of the role of air power during 1943, we must note the capture of the island of Pantelleria off Sicily on June 11, after eighteen days of continuous bombardment. The island surrendered to air power alone, and Gen. "Jimmy" Doolittle was justified in asserting that it was "definitely a landmark in the history of military aviation."

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Benjamin F. Feinberg of Plattsburgh was selected tonight as Republican majority leader and president pro tempore of the State Senate, succeeding Joe R. Hanley, now Lieutenant Governor. The selection of Senator Feinberg came after a bitter battle, going ten ballots, according to reliable reports.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union, and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 -- The Lone Star Gas Company and the Securities and Exchange Commission parted company today in an atmosphere of undisguised goodwill.

The Solid Fuels Administration for War reported last night that half the city's stockpile or "reserve" of 8,000 tons of anthracite coal, which is being built up against some grave emergency, would be on boats tied up at dealers' piers by nightfall.

The Berkey Gay Furniture Company, which had 1,005,110 common shares outstanding at the close of 1942, has granted options to purchase an aggregate of 994,890 common shares at $1 a share under a new and a former management contract and to certain officers, directors and personnel.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 4 -- Partisan forces were reported today to be holding their own in the town of Banja Luka, half of which they reported yesterday they had captured. In furious street fighting they were said to be ousting the Germans from houses that recently had been converted into fortresses, using machine guns and hand grenade throwers captured from the enemy.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 4 -- Of the nearly 30,000 battle casualties admitted to Middle East hospitals from April 1, 1942, to March 31, 1943, the percentage of fatalities was 2.1, compared with a mortality rate of 7.44 in hospitals in Egypt and Palestine in the last war.

ALGIERS, Jan. 4 -- At the opening session of the Provisional Consultative Assembly, which gave a good imitation of a real Parliament by its critical mood and its verbosity, Pierre Mendes-France, Commissioner for Finance, submitted the budget for 1944 for the empire and the four departments now liberated.

Vice Chancellor James F. Fielder of the Chancery Court in Jersey City ruled yesterday that a recapitalization plan of the Guantanamo Sugar Company of Cuba was "illegal and invalid" and enjoined the company from putting it into effect.

In his report to the Secretary of War, General Henry H. Arnold tells a thrilling story of the growth of American air power from a "corporal's guard," of 3,000 planes, less than half of which were really fit for service when war broke out, to the mighty force it is today.
LONDON Jan. 4 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

For the Russians the crossing of the old Polish border south of the Pripet Marshes will be of military, not political, significance. That border existed for them between the Treaty of Riga, which Pilsudski compelled them to accept in 1921, and the agreement which Hitler made with them in 1939 in order to avoid a two-front war.

ALGIERS, Jan. 4 -- Though the improvement in the weather was insufficient to alter the situation on land materially yesterday, Indian troops of the British Eighth Army managed to win another hill southeast of Villa Tommaso. Large formations of Flying Fortresses, however, were able to operate with deadly efficiency over northwestern Italy, where they renewed their attacks on railway yards at Turin and a ball-bearing factory at nearby Villar-Perosa.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 4 -- Jack and Jill, two platypuses in the Healesville sanctuary for Australian fauna, have made zoological history by breeding in captivity. There has been speculation among naturalists for many years whether this was possible.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 4 -- Unprecedented preparations have been completed here to welcome the Lebanese delegation to Pan-Arab talks marking the resumption of the efforts of Mustafa Nahas Pasha, the Egyptian Premier, to sound out Arab opinion on a plan for closer post-war unity, especially in the economic sphere.

Returning from the conquest of Tarawa, Brig. Gen. Merritt A. Edson of the United States Marines reveals the fundamental idea underlying the whole present Japanese war plan in the Pacific. The Japanese defensive strategy, adopted after the abandonment of the more ambitious attempts to invade Australia, India and the United States, he says, is based on the hope that America will stop fighting before attaining complete victory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Asserting that the Japanese now are "on the defensive" throughout the entire South and Southwest Pacific areas, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox dropped a hint today as to the course of future Navy action in the Central Pacific when he declared that our forces are continuing to "soften up" the Marshall Islands.

Wartime exigencies helped to make 1943 one of the most difficult in the history of the New York Botanical Garden, Dr. William J. Robbins, its director, reported yesterday at its annual meeting at the office of its president, Joseph R. Swan, at 14 Wall Street.

After four youths had been sentenced yesterday in General Sessions, where they had pleaded guilty in the fatal stabbing in Harlem last summer of another boy who had stolen a coat from one of the young slayers, the father of one obtained Judge John A. Mullen's consent to say in open court a prayer which he ended with "God bless you."

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4 (AP) -- An outline of a plan for creation of a $500,000,000 National Industrial Credit Corporation, to provide risk capital for existing and new business ventures in the post-war period, has been submitted to Henry Kaiser by Herbert F. Boettler and John W. Snyder, St. Louis bankers.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Jan. 5 (UP) -- A communique:

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Decision was reserved today by Dr. George D. Stoddard, Commissioner of Education, after a hearing of permanent substitute teachers who seek appointment to regular posts in the New York City school system.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Although the United Nations in one year have liberated almost a fifth of the territory that Germany held last January and a twentieth of the regions that Japan controlled, victory can be accomplished only by hard fighting, the Office of War Information announced in a survey today.

A tiny item buried under an irrelevant headline sometimes raises a question of world-wide significance. To date no one has commented on it. The item appeared in your issue of Dec. 25 and read "Women's suffrage, which the (French) committee promises immediately, is regarded by some as a constitutional change for which the committee has no authority."

Zasu Pitts, screen comedienne, will make her Broadway stage debut this evening at the Royale Theatre as star of "Ramshackle Inn." Corp. George Batson of the United States Army Signal Corps is author of the work, which is described as a melodramatic farce dealing with a spinsterish Vermont librarian who invests her savings in an old tavern near Gloucester.

Ralph T. Reed, executive vice president of the American Express Company, has been elected president of the company and of its foreign subsidiary, the American Express Company, Inc., to succeed Frederick P. Small, who becomes chairman of the executive committee, it was announced yesterday following a directors' meeting.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Expectations that the Office of Price Administration would announce price ceilings for cash wheat after the market closed resulted in nervous fluctuations in grain futures today on the Board of Trade. After an easy start, wheat firmed up on buying of May attributed to millers and of September by a commission house with cash and export connections, resulting in views that additional business might have been done with Mexico.

Tales of Minnie Spinach and Mr. Milk Bottle may compete this winter with the adventures of Little Red Riding Hood, as employes of the Department of Health begin to apply the lessons they are learning in courses sponsored by department's nutrition division.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Among the 605 casualties announced today by the War Department were the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:
The Daily Worker, official organ of the Communist party, endorsed yesterday the statements attributed to General Marshall concerning the threatened railroad and steel strikes.

Etta Shiber, Roi Ottley and Leland Stowe will be the speakers at Tuesday's Book and Author luncheon, third in the series at the Astor under the joint sponsorship of The New York Herald Tribune and the American Booksellers Association.

There were no surprises at the Philadelphia Orchestra's Carnegie Hall Concert last night. The program was turned over to Beethoven and Wagner and the audience seemed content. With Helen Traubel as a magnificent-voiced soloist, the audience was, in fact, more than content.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, replied today to recent newspaper criticisms that his organization has not fulfilled its principal function and has failed to work out a foreign economic policy in conjunction with the State Department.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A smaller fatality rate for the Women's Air Force Service Pilots than that for the Army Air Forces in the continental United States was announced by the War Department today.
Tonight's events: PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 o'clock: Wanda Landowska, Town Hall, 8:30.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Lehman Brothers and Kidder, Peabody Co. was high bidder yesterday for $9,450,000 of State of Minnesota rural credit deficiency fund certificates of indebtedness, due semi-annually from Aug. 1, 1956, to Feb. 1, 1963, and callable on and after Feb. 1, 1947. The bankers bid 100.11, naming the interest rate as 1.40 per cent.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 4 -- Increasing German nervousness is being noted in France as the Allies perfect their preparations for an invasion.

Standing before the massed flags of Central and South American republics, Mayor La Guardia greeted yesterday at City Hall the second group of students from those countries to come here to study under annual awards made by the New York City Committee for Latin-American Scholarships.

While the waste paper salvage drive was stimulated yesterday by the mobilization of 5,500 neighborhood agents of four large life insurance companies to carry an appeal for cooperation into 1,000,000 of the city's homes, a sharp warning came from the War Production Board that four large mills in the metropolitan area supplying war demands were operating on a "hand-to-mouth" basis and one mill had to close down for several days for want of waste paper.

In 1940 the Pierre Matisse Gallery, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street, held a one-man show composed of what then represented Andre Derain's most recent work. In the interval, due to war conditions, nothing by that artist has reached this country.

Close upon Mayor La Guardia's proposal that consumers boycott eggs while the over-supply continues unless they buy at 10 to 15 cents below ceiling prices, local trade reports yesterday showed the average drop in the price of eggs within the past week had been only 3 cents a dozen.
The twelve-story apartment house on a plot 120 by 100 feet at 315 Central Park West, corner of Ninety-first Street, has been sold by the Franklin Savings Bank to Henry Leeds of Plainfield, N.J.

Chain-store baseball, long a target for Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis, was seen by local baseball men yesterday to be in for some rough riding when the commissioner calls the meeting of the major-minor league committee the latter part of this month in Chicago to tackle the national pastime's post-war problems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Lieut. Col. Howard A. Rusk, who revolutionized the care of convalescent soldiers for the Air Forces, told the National Women's Press Club today that new Army methods might well be carried into civilian life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -The Office of Price Administration brought hard wheat under price control today for the first time and raised the maximum prices for soft wheat, setting levels for all classes of the grain that will reflect at least 100 per cent of parity.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Elmer Layden, Commissioner of the National Football League, today dug into the bankrolls of George Preston Marshall, owner of the Washington Redskins, and Ralph Brizzolara, general manager of the Chicago Bears, to the extent of $1,000.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 4 -- In the most thrilling finish of the meeting, which saw the first three horses hitting the wire noses apart, Arthur Murray captured the featured South Miami Purse before 5,154 fans at Tropical Park today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- A group of holders of bonds and preferred shares asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to delay the start of a reorganization plan for the Rutland Railroad Company until final disposition of court appeals, which the plan's backers said might hold up proceedings indefinitely.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 5 -Pounding out fresh gains up to eight miles, the Red Army captured the big German defense base of Belaya Tserkov, fifty miles below Kiev, on Tuesday and swung back east against the enemy salient along the Dnieper River while the Nazis counter-attacked fiercely to the northwest near the Polish border.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Wednesday, Jan. 5 -- Battle-toughened United States Marines crushed a Japanese counter-attack at Cape Gloucester, New Britain, yesterday, killing more than 200 Japanese, while American airmen in wide sweeps over this war theatre bombed five enemy airfields and shot down eleven Japanese planes and probably destroyed three others.

WITH THE AMERICANS, At Saidor, New Guinea, Jan. 3 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Veterans of the famed Red Arrow Division who secured the Saidor beachhead on Sunday paid one of the cheapest prices in the southwest Pacific campaign for an amphibious landing against the enemy -- three killed and four wounded.

Freezing temperatures were expected this morning with the probability that the slush and sleet still covering many of the city's streets and sidewalks would become ice, presenting additional perils to motorists and pedestrians.
A Japanese communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recoded by The Associated Press:

Mrs. Roosevelt told the reporters at her last press conference that she hoped to see "the interest in human needs," as summed up in the New Deal name, extended to the international sphere. For the present we are concerned with the New Deal at home.

John M. Christensen, newly appointed executive secretary of the State Athletic Commission, had his introductory to the administrative end of boxing yesterday, when the board subjected to the customary pre-battle physical examination Beau Jack, world lightweight champion, and Lulu Costantino, East Side challenger, who are to meet Friday night in a ten-round non-title bout in Madison Square Garden.
WARE, Mass., Jan. 4 (U.P.) -- Two large mill buildings and a mansion were destroyed and a third mill was enveloped in flames today by a general-alarm fire in which the loss was estimated at $750,000.

TRENTON, Jan. 4 -- Declaring that any proposal that members of the armed forces be restricted to voting only for candidates seeking posts in Washington "is repugnant," Governor Charles Edison called upon the New Jersey Legislature today to urge upon Congress immediately a simplified plan for handling absentee military voting.

Daniel J. Tobin predicted yesterday that Wendell L. Willkie would be this year's Republican nominee for the Presidency and that the Democrats would not be returned to office if the war is ended by election day, which he considered unlikely.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 4 -RKO has bought the screen rights to "Betrayal From the East," a non-fiction book by Alan Bynd, dealing with Japanese spies and sabotage activity within the United States. A sequel will be made to the company's "Behind the Rising Sun."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Senator Carter Glass -- his aggressive spirit undaunted by illness -- expressed joy on his eighty-sixth birthday today over the way the Allies "are shooting the hell out of the Axis."

Reporting a net profit of $3,010,901 after all charges for Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., in the fiscal year ended with September, Ward M. Canaday, president, told stockholders in the annual report issued today that the company's backlog of Government contracts approximates $225,000,000 and that the company's military "jeep" has created a background of world-wide good-will against which the company will build its post-war future.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 4 -- The Allied-Turkish conference in Cairo did not even temporarily shelve the question of Turkey's active participation in the war. It is alleged that strong pressure was brought to bear to induce her to become a belligerent forthwith.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan 4 -- Despite almost hourly German denials that anything is amiss in Sofia -- the only "direct" information from Bulgaria has been through German channels -- information in diplomatic quarters indicated today that the situation there had "considerably deteriorated during the past twenty-four hours."

BOSTON, Jan. 4 -- Men's wear retailers are not awake to their opportunities and in order to survive in the world of tomorrow must adopt a more aggressive approach to the consumer, Morton Freund of the Morton Freund Advertising Agency, New York, declared tonight in an address before the annual convention of the New England Clothiers and Furnishers Association here.
The Philadelphia Falcons last night defeated the Brooklyn Crescents, 4 -- 3, in an Eastern Hockey League game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace, scoring all their goals in the first two periods.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The Polish Cabinet held a long meeting here today after having received a report that Soviet Cossacks had crossed the frontier of Poland. After Prime Minister Stanislaw Mikolajczyk had reported to his colleagues on this situation, it was announced through the Polish Telegraph Agency that "the attitude of the Government will be made public in the nearest future."

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Criticism by an anonymous spokesman in Washington of organized labor's course in the recent railroad and steel disputes was denounced here today by Louis Hollander, president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, as playing into the hands of "anti-victory and anti-labor forces" within the country.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Labor and management consultants to the War Department said tonight they had joined in recommending to the department that members of the railroad brotherhoods which had not accepted Presidential arbitration of their wage demands should receive "the same terms and conditions and effective the same date as was made with the engineers and trainmen."
The Central Railroad of New Jersey reported yesterday a "critical" manpower shortage affecting the road's freight service for vital war industries in the metropolitan New York district.

A Canadian journalist, who is an active member of the British Proportional Representation Society, has written a pamphlet entitled "An International Electoral Commission," to which wide distribution is given throughout the British Empire as well as the United States.

LONDON, Jan. 4 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler's war losses are estimated at 6,000,000 men killed, wounded or captured in an analysis of Nazi fighting manpower prepared by Col. Francisco Moravec, chief military intelligence officer of the Czechoslovak Government in London.

MOSCOW, Jan. 4 -- For a goodly mile I walked along in a German dugout and still it stretched on and on, with no end in sight. This was only an advanced line position, a modern stronghold lost by the Germans to Soviet troops.

New York City, Boston, Baltimore and Cleveland are among the cities which have gained in relative importance as holders of war contracts placed during the fifteen months through September, 1943, it was announced yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board which has just completed an analysis of figures made available by the War Production Board.

To help meet the military shortage of one million tons of paper, the American Women's Voluntary Services began distribution yesterday to all salvage chairmen in the city of pictorial directions on how to bale scrap paper. Contents of home and office waste paper baskets provide a high quality of scrap, according to Mrs. Charles E. Copeland, salvage chairman, and all of it can be conserved for war purposes by a simple baling process.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The German entertainment industry, which the Government has always considered a valuable propaganda instrument, has suffered greviously from recent Allied air attacks.

Spring got a head start yesterday in spite of the snow and slush that made travel difficult in the city. For fully a quarter of an hour Walter Florell kept a steady stream of flower-bedecked hats flowing down the runway of the Oval Room at the Ritz-Carlton.

Eight men accused of having obtained $250,000 subscriptions for "advertising" in a bogus labor paper under representations that it was supporting the waste paper, Red Cross blood-bank, fat salvage and war bond drives, were held yesterday in the Felony Court for a hearing Jan. 18.
LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
MONTREAL, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The first-place Canadiens, piling up a 5-to-2 lead in the first period, went on to beat the Maple Leafs, 6 to 3, in a National Hockey League game tonight.

Williamson Pell, president of the United States Trust Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that net operating earnings in 1943, after all charges, amounted to $1,741,420, compared with $1,576,655 the previous year. In addition, the bank made profits of $294,401 in 1943 from the sale of securities, which profit was transferred to securities valuation reserve.

Further appointments completing the organization of the Bronx and Upper Manhattan rent control offices of the Office of Price Adminstration were announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, area rent director.

The one-story taxpayer on a plot 50 by 102 feet at 1069-71 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Bickford's Realty, Inc., to Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, through John J. Reynolds, broker. Sale was for cash. William J. Kennedy represented the buyer. C.A. Flaig was the attorney for the seller.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Restrictions on the production of razors and razor blades were revoked by the War Production Board today. The output hereafter of these items will be limited only by the volume of metal that can be allocated to manufacturers.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 4 -- In spite of a protest by Dr. Arthur Wilson, a civic leader here, over the failure of Michael A. Scatuorchio, municipal garbage contractor, to fulfill the terms of his contract, the Jersey City Commission awarded a new contract to Mr. Scatuorchio today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Federal Trade Commission yesterday charged Standard Brands, Inc., 595 Madison Avenue, New York City, with falsely advertising the therapeutic properties of Fleischmann's Compressed Yeast, a product of the concern.

Grover A. Whalen, chairman-director of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office in this city, reported yesterday that in the last two years 100,000,000 man-hours of service were donated by 185,000 volunteers. He declared that the country was entering upon the most difficult period of the war and that there would be an increasing demand for CDVO services.

When Patrolman Jacob Szwedowski of the East Sixty-seventh Street station yesterday afternoon entered the top-floor cold-water flat at 251 East Seventy-seventh Street through a partly opened window to investigate a roof leak, he found a baby boy, about a year old, with his feet tied to a couch.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Three members of Congress, Senator Reed of Kansas and Representatives May of Kentucky and Plumley of Vermont, declared today their agreement with a statement attributed to Gen. George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, that strikes and threatened strikes in this country had given the Nazis a propaganda weapon which might delay rebellion in Europe and prolong the war.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 (AP) -After skipping last year, the Los Angeles open golf tournament will be resumed tomorrow with a field that has the old-timers dreaming of the pre-war days.

Business men were urged yesterday by Homer E. Capehart to take a more active part in politics to pave the way for a post-war administration in Washington that will encourage private industry to resume peacetime output with maximum employment.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- Recently Pvt. Leonard Fierst rejected the Purple Heart Award for a wound he suffered on Guadalcanal because he did not want to worry his mother, Mrs. Harry Fierst of 162 Sheridan Avenue, this city, it became known today. Private Fierst is now home after eight months of combat duty in the South Pacific.

Progress in the liquidation of closed banks was made in 1943, with the affairs of sixteen banking institutions having remaining liabilities of $34,000,000 completed, according to Elliott V. Bell, New York State Superintendent of Banks, in his annual report yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- President Roosevelt congratulated tonight the 276,000 volunteers serving with OPA war price and rationing boards for the "fine job" they are doing.

As the first step in a post-war expansion program, Comprehensive Fabrics, Inc., distributors of Koroseal for the B.F. Goodrich Company, has rented the sixty-ninth floor in the Empire State Building, Joseph A. Kaplan, president, announced yesterday.

The Chase National Bank, in its statement of condition on Dec. 31, reported yesterday total deposits of $4,375,581,741, compared with $4,442,998,614 three months ago and with $4,291,466,886 one year ago. Total resources were $4,679,973,964, compared with $4,740,068,560 and $4,569,496,051.
I've got my Third War Loan job back again getting workers for this Fourth to go out and pound the sidewalks of New York as they were never pounded before.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 -- Plans to enter Philadelphia's bids for the Republican and Democratic national conventions have been dropped, Mayor Bernard Samuel said today. The Office of Defense Transportation had specifically ruled out Philadelphia as a possible convention site in 1944, the Mayor added, but the city would seek both conventions in 1948.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Treasury announces today the regulations that will govern the issue of excess profits tax post-war refund bonds and transactions that may take place in such bonds.

Although his salesmanship did not follow the usual pattern, Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto last night succeeded in selling the idea of being blood donors to eighteen of twenty-eight defendants in Brooklyn-Queens Night Court.

The American Federation of Labor will not accept the invitation of the British Trade Union Congress to send delegates in June to a world conclave of trade unions, including those of Soviet Russia, it was indicated yesterday by Matthew Woll, vice president of the A.F.L. and chairman of its post-war reconstruction committee.

It is to be feared that as a play the accent is on the first word of "Ramshackle Inn," which opened last evening at the Royale. A comedy-melodrama, it succeeds in being not very funny and not very exciting, which are two pretty serious strikes to have against it in the Broadway league.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- Despite pleas by American Federation of Labor leaders that drastic action be postponed, employes of Philadelphia's water, highway and street cleaning bureaus voted tonight to begin a city-wide strike tomorrow morning to protest failure to gain a 10 per cent wage increase.

A statement deploring incidents of juvenile delinquency and prejudice in Washington Heights will be read in Catholic and Protestant churches and in synagogues in the area on Saturday and Sunday, it was announced yesterday, as part of a campaign of the Inter-Faith Clergy Committee of Washington Heights to combat the tendencies.

Volunteer war service agencies are acting as the springboard to paid jobs for women. Leading organizations disclosed yesterday that hundreds of women who never worked before the war were now going from volunteer employment into paid jobs. Though many of these opportunities are strictly "for the duration," other volunteers are finding training and outlets that will lead to new fields for women after the war is over, it was pointed out.

Ten of the twenty-four elevators serving the Woolworth Building, which operates its own electric generating plant, were shut down temporarily yesterday afternoon owing to the coal shortage, which continued at the critical stage in the New York area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Leland Olds, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, said today that a Supreme Court decision this week on natural gas rates "marks the beginning of a new era" in the field of regulating utilities and paves the way for "very large possible reductions" in electric rates.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Perhaps it was the Christmas spirit that buoyed people's hopes, or maybe it is a natural hankering after the better things of life when one has digested four and a half years of war. At all events, austerity is out of fashion at the moment and the public is hoping for a break.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The United States submarine Pompano, whose daring and highly decorated skipper, Comdr. Willis M. Thomas, specialized in picking off enemy warships within sight of the Japanese homeland, is overdue and presumed to be lost, the Navy Department announced tonight.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- A bill to carry out the constitutional amendment for the creation of a Department of Commerce in the State Government, approved by the people in referendum in the fall election, was introduced today by Assemblyman Irving M. Ives of Chenango County, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Industrial and Labor Conditions.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -The movement of more hogs to market than can be slaughtered resulted today in another large holdover, and farmers again were warned to curtail shipments for the remainder of the week. In the first three days of this week hogs shipped to Western markets reached 500,000, the largest number received in such a period in recent history, according to the War Food Administration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The French Committee of National Liberation would like to have French troops participate in the liberation of France whenever and wherever a landing is made on French soil, Lieut. Gen. Paul-Etienne Beynet, recently appointed Chief of French Military Mission to the United States, made it clear today.

The Schenley Distillers Corporation, in its statement of operations covering the quarter ended with November, disclosed yesterday an increase in profits before taxes to $17,183,622 from $7,982,951 in the corresponding three months of 1942.

It is easy to understand why Wanda Landowska has an affinity for the harpsichord. Her playing has the meticulous clarity and penetrating simplicity which illuminates and is illuminated by music for the harpsichord. In her recital at the Town Hall last night the greatness of her art, which has been pared of all non-essentials and rests firmly on its search for the innermost secrets of a score, was once more to be admired.

Mabel Bernadotte Trainer and Margaret DeVito, each 17 years old, were sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to indeterminate terms in the Bedford Hills Reformatory for Women for helping three youths in holdups in the midtown district of service men and others.

Many millinery and garment firms figured in leases announced by brokers in the midtown section of Manhattan yesterday. Many contracts involved space on Madison Avenue, West Thirty-ninth and West Fifty-seventh Streets.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 5 -- Lebanon's visiting delegates of high officials, headed by Premier Riad Solh, was received with the highest honors on arriving here this morning, despite the background of undercurrent questioning on the part of the Opposition leaders in the Egyptian Chamber of Deputies.

Frances Pisano, 21 years old, left General Sessions yesterday to begin an indeterminate term in the Westfield State Farm Reformatory for Women at Bedford Hill as a shoplifter, but before she was ushered out she told Judge John J. Freschi: "The day I step into Bedford Hills is the day my criminal education begins.

An apartment of fifteen rooms and five baths in 420 Park Avenue, at the corner of Fifty-fifth Street, has been leased by Mrs. Constantin R. Goodlet through the Payson McL. Merrill Company and Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.

Larger figures for the redemption of War Savings Bonds in recent months have caused some comment and need interpretation. Comparison is frequently made between redemptions in any month and the sales in that month. Thus in December there were redemptions of $201 million against savings bond sales by the Treasury of $853 million; that is, redemptions were 23 1/2 per cent of sales.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Office of Defense Transportation will make no attempt to dictate the sites of the Republican and Democratic conventions, while serving as a clearing house for information on travel facilities available to various cities, Joseph B. Eastman, director, said today.

Medium weight rayon hose will maintain its pre-eminence on the city's stocking counters during 1944, a survey of manufacturers and buyers indicated yesterday. Predictions of the date when nylon and silk will reappear are not being made, while production of sheer rayons is limited by the Government's textile allocation program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- On the eve of two important meetings of chiefs of fifteen non-operating railroad unions and three operating unions here tomorrow, President Roosevelt stated today that he was reconvening a special emergency fact-finding board, headed by Judge Elwyn R. Shaw of Springfield, Ill., to consider the unadjusted dispute affecting the 1,100,000 non-operating employes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The AFL's official magazine indirectly injected words of General MacArthur tonight into the controversy over the relation of labor troubles to the war effort, but the Federation promptly disclaimed responsibility for the publication's action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Vincent M. Miles, legal adviser to Postmaster General Walker, who ordered the magazine Esquire deprived of second-class mailing privileges, said today that records failed to disclose a similar case in the United States courts.

Plans for petitioning the Board of Education to provide in the city's schools a broad cultural program that would help combat prejudice were outlined yesterday at a meeting under the auspices of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.
LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Nazi Propaganda Minister, told a group of Japanese newspaper men in Berlin that if Germany and Japan "let the present moment pass by," they would never have "the opportunity of crushing the United States and Britain," the Tokyo radio said yesterday in a broadcast to Japanese areas.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 5 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will co-star Susan Peters and Gene Kelly in "Strangers in the Dark," a drama to be based on "The Outward Room," a novel by Millen Brand which the studio acquired four years ago.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- George Bernard Shaw today advised the United Nations to abandon any plan they might have for the permanent disablement of Germany.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 5 -- Partisan forces of Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] continued today to make gains in Banja Luka, fighting street by street in a town where almost every building has been converted into a fort.

Nine five-story apartment buildings at 432 to 438 Central Park West, 1 West 103d Street and 2 West 104th Street, comprising a blockfront, have been purchased by Herbert H. Bachrach and Ira Rosenstock, operators, through Henry Feder, broker. Modernized recently into 110 apartments of small units, the buildings occupy frontages of 201 feet on Central Park West and 100 feet on the side streets. They rent for $52,500 a year.

Free maternity and infant care are now available to the wife of every Army man regardless of his rank, if it is needed, Lieut. Col. A.G. Rudd, who is in charge of the Army Emergency Relief organization in this area, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- Money counterfeiters are disappearing, but in their stead has appeared an army of "scratch artists," who steal and cash about 1,500 Government checks each month, the Secret Service revealed today.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- A communique:

The store building at 883-85 Manhattan Avenue, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Da-Sid Realty Corporation (Sidney Perlav, president), from the Manhattan Company. This structure is on a plot 48.5 by 100 feet and is assessed for $46,000. A purchase money mortgage of $35,700 was arranged at the closing. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

The results of a year-long study of Negro-white relations within the branches of the Young Women's Christian Association were turned over yesterday to its national board, meeting at 600 Lexington Avenue.

In bygone days, when some generous-minded citizen left trust funds for the upkeep of watering troughs for city horses or for the support of super-annuated sailmakers from our clipper ships the money was tied up for that particular purpose, no matter how useless it might become.

The recruiting officer, who used to be an actress, couldn't pin it down to more than "an intangible something." She was trying yesterday to explain her hunch that the Waves, Wacs, Spars and Women Marines "are finally reaching the country's women."

MOSCOW, Thursday, Jan. 6 -- Marshal Joseph Stalin announced early today the Russians' capture of Berdichev, important German communication center in the southwestern Ukraine, after five days of fierce fighting.

Senator Tydings of Maryland and Representative Disney of Oklahoma have introduced, in the Senate and House respectively, a proposal for a constitutional amendment governing Congressional appropriations. This amendment would provide that, except in time of war, Congress could not appropriate funds by less than a three-fifths majority of each house unless at the same time it levied taxes sufficient to cover the appropriation.

How to buy, cook and carve pork is explained in the leaflet "All About Pork for Your Menu," issued free of charge by the National Live Stock and Meat Board at a time when this meat seldom has been more plentiful. Illustrations of the wholesale and retail cuts are included, as well as diagrams and step-by-step procedures for slicing loins and hams.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan. 5 -- Taking the lead after the first five minutes and holding it thereafter, the Columbia University basketball team tonight defeated Stevens Tech, 49 -- 37, in the William Hall Walker Gymnasium. Walter Budko scored 16 and Bill Lolordo 14 points for the winners.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., of Great Britain, one of the empire's largest trusts, headed by Lord McGowan, who recently defended the cartel system in the House of Lords as the backbone of Britain's chemical industry, will be one of two corporate defendants named in an anti-trust suit to be filed tomorrow in New York, according to high officials.
TRENTON, Jan. 5 -- The State Supreme Court ruled invalid today a Newark ordinance regulating the closing hours of retail stores on the ground it was discriminatory.

Lulu Costantino, East Side lightweight, yesterday went snappily through his last hard workout in preparation for the ten-round bout in which he is to face Beau Jack, world titleholder, tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.

Leaving a note that told of unsuccessful attempts to get well, 75-year-old Aaron Benesch, a retired banker and business executive formerly of Baltimore, plunged to his death at 9:20 A.M. yesterday from the twenty-seventh floor of the Hotel St. Moritz, Fifty-ninth Street and Sixth Avenue. His body landed on a one-story extension of the hotel.

One of the season's outstanding exhibitions of drawings, including some seventy examples of work by well-known European and American artists of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, opened yesterday at the American British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Mrs. E.C. Salsbury's four-year-old filly Sparkling Maid easily romped off with the featured six-furlong Coral Way Purse at Tropical Park today.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey overruled yesterday a motion for dismissal of an action in which two Bronx tenants are seeking permanent injunctions against Municipal Court orders for their eviction. The suits were brought against the Trajer Realty Corporation by Murray Schwartz and Max Steinzor, living at 10 East 198th Street, the Bronx.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Jan. 6 -- United States Marines at Cape Gloucester, New Britain, threw tanks, artillery and aircraft into a determined drive on Japanese positions at Borgen Bay Tuesday while Allied airmen shot down or probably destroyed twenty-two enemy planes, sank two freighters and damaged an enemy cruiser, it was announced today.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 5 -- American transport planes of the Air Transport Command are delivering into China from airdromes in northeastern India today a greater monthly tonnage of military supplies than was ever carried over the Burma Road.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The Polish Government announced tonight that it had instructed its underground forces not to impede the progress of the Russian troops across Poland, but to cooperate with them only if Russian-Polish diplomatic relations were resumed.

DETROIT, Jan. 5 (AP) -- George T. Christopher, president and general manager of the Packard 1Vfotor Car Company, said today that his company produced $355,000,000 of Rolls-Royce aircraft and .Packard marine engines for PT boats in 1943.

Mayor La Guardia announced last night that the city's new Food Trades Vocational High School, to be built after the war, would adjoin "the largest Terminal market in the world," a project already under study by engineers.

The five-story apartment house for fifty-eight families on a plot 130 by 64 feet at 3810-20 Bailey Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by David S. Meister, operator, to an investing client of Nehring Brothers, Inc., brokers. It has an annual rental of about $30,000 and is assessed for $160,000.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Chinese troops have captured all villages surrounding Owchihkow, the Japanese-held port on the Yangtze River north of Tungting Lake, and are advancing on the suburbs of the city itself, the High Command announced tonight.

There were a few random observations on the New Deal in this column yesterday. They concluded with the statement that the New Deal has done notable service for social progress, but this does not mean that the New Deal ushered in the birth of social conscience in America.

After acting for several hours as the Good Samaritan who helped to comfort a traffic patrolman when he was knocked down and killed by a "hit and run" driver early yesterday at the Brooklyn approach to Manhattan Bridge. Philip Froim, 38 years old, of 24 East Ninety-fifth Street, Brooklyn, was arrested as the driver of the death car early this morning at the Poplar Street precinct station.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 5 -- Judge Adrian Lyon of the Court of Quarter Sessions, convinced that a man convicted before him several weeks ago had not received the benefit of a reasonable doubt, recalled him to court today and freed him of an indeterminate prison sentence, placing him on probation for three years instead.

Sustained re-investment demand, abetted by new cash buying, furthered yesterday the New Year rally in the stock market and values added 1 to 2 points to previous gains. Only a faint semblance of profit-taking was encountered in the course of the day, and this was rolled over easily by the strong demand, which reached the best tempo in almost a month.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature:
