Reflecting increased firmness in grains and securities, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday all of Tuesday's losses and trading ended with active contracts near the day's highest levels, 8 to 14 points over previous finals, with the strength in the distant positions.

The charter meeting of the Westchester County Association, an organization devoted to the cultural, commercial and physical betterment of Westchester and to publicizing the county's advantages, was held here yesterday afternoon in the Grand Central Terminal building.

Immediate enactment of an amended excess profits tax bill that would provide that the Federal corporate excess profits tax would terminate at the close of the tax year in which the President declares the war ended was urged yesterday by Walter Hoving, president of Lord Taylor.

In London and Washington it has always been felt that heavy American and British air attacks on German industry have been reflected in Russian victories on the Eastern front. Particularly it has been believed that the destruction of plants in France and Germany which were building tanks and trucks helped turn the tide against the Nazis at Stalingrad.

ALGIERS, Jan. 5 -- Allied air power was able to extend its trans-Adriatic offensive to a new target in Bulgaria yesterday. A small formation of Flying Fortresses of the United States Fifteenth Air Force attacked Dupnica, thirty-seven miles south of Sofia, which was the first Bulgarian target.

Gasoline supplies on the Atlantic Coast declined last week but stocks of both light and heavy fuel oils increased, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The institute's index of gasoline stocks at the close of the week stood at 42.5, against 43.2 a week earlier.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Chicago is to make bids of $75,000 each for the Republican and Democratic National Conventions.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Jan. 5 -- Long simmering charges of irregularities in the building of Camp Shanks, military establishment near here, were brought into the open today by Justice of the Peace George R. Lanchantin of Orangetown, who asked for investigations by the Rockland County District Attorney and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

UNITED STATES FIFTEENTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Mediterranean Area, Jan. 3 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Maj. Gen. Nathan Twining took over command of the growing Fifteenth Air Force from Maj. Gen. James H. Doolittle today with the emphatic promise that "we are going to knock out the German Air Force -- there's no doubt about it."

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Heavy, medium and dive bombers of the Seventh United States Air Force struck at the Mill and Jaluit atolls of the Marshall Islands on Jan. 3 and 4, it was announced today, resuming the daily schedule of attacks on those strategic Japanese outposts north of the American-held Gilbert Islands.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- American air and ground force nurses are beginning to prepare in earnest for the day when they will be ordered on to the Continent of Europe, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Dealing in case histories of war profits, a minority of four members of the Senate Finance Committee argued in a formal report made to Congress today that "it would be more honest" to repeal the Contract Renegotiations Act, through which a net of $1,500,000,000 has been recaptured by the Government to date, than to "weaken it fatally" by enactment of five amendments which have been approved by a committee majority.

A Wave, sending her contribution anonymously to the Neediest Cases Fund, wrote: "I am delighted to be able to again send you a check for $100 for the very fine appeal you make to assist families who find themselves in circumstances which make their lives more than difficult to bear."

" Government Girl," an RKO production starring Olivia de Havilland and Sonny Tufts, will open this morning at the Palace. Dudley Nichols, who wrote the screen play from the story by Adela Rogers St. John, also makes his debut as a director with this comedy.

ALGIERS, Jan. 5 -- A giant of a man, who would enormously out-bulk his predecessor, has been named commander of the famous British Eighth Army, it was announced today. He is Lieut. Gen. Sir Oliver Leese, who commanded the celebrated Thirtieth Corps which was in the vanguard of Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's forces on the push from El Alamein to Tunis.

The Council on Books in Wartime announces for release tomorrow a six-minute film dramatizing John Mason Brown's book, "To All Hands," recently published by Whittlesey House and now a bestseller. Lieutenant Brown is introduced in the film by Quincy Howe and then gives a description of action in the Sicilian invasion, against a background of actual battle scenes flashed on the screen.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 6 -- Enemy targets from Kiel, the great naval base in northwest Germany, to the airfield at Bordeaux, 800 miles to the southwest on the French coast, were hammered by Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force yesterday in attacks unprecedented in scope and strength in this theatre.
United States Senator Ralph Owen Brewster of Maine and Mrs. Brewster have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

From time to time one comes upon letters expressing conflicting opinions regarding realism and idealism. There is a marked tendency for the proponents of each to place the world's villains in the other's camp. Their use of the laboratory words "realist" and "idealist" frequently indicates confused thinking of the type which propagandists seek to induce by use of excess simplification and generalization.

At a meeting last night of the National Association of Play Shoe and Slipper Manufacturers, Inc., to protest certain regulations of the rollback order of the Office of Price Administration on synthetic sole play shoes, there was considerable favorable comment expressed when the membership was informed that OPA had announced the effective date of the order, following association protests, had been extended.

Acceleration of the trend toward informative labeling of merchandise was predicted by Harold W. Brightman, vice president of L. Bamberger Co. and chairman of the National Consumer-Retailer Council, at the meeting yesterday of the retailing division of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

A campaign to recruit 5,000 workers to help move a serious accumulation of freight for the European war fronts at railway piers in New York and New Jersey was launched yesterday by the War Manpower Commission and the Railroad Retirement Board.
Following is the text of Mayor La Guardia's annual message to the City Council:

The New York County grand jury that investigated how Frank Costello, the slot-machine "king," used political influence to aid Justice Thomas A. Aurelio gain the Supreme Court nomination, sent a letter to Governor Dewey a week after election advocating legislation to change the manner of such nominations, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The American aircraft industry in 1943 set a world's record in building 667,000 pounds of military airframes, nearly two and one-half times the weight produced in 1942 and about eight times the production in 1941, the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce stated today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 5 -- Pravda today described Wendell L. Willkie as "a political gambler" who is trying to win the confidence both of the friends and foes of the Soviet Union in an effort to win votes for the Presidency of the United States but who will end up in undermining confidence in himself.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, in his second annual message, presented to a joint session of the Legislature today four major recommendations which dwarfed all others in his 6,000-word message.

Myron McCormick, who has the leading role in "Storm Operation," lost the use of his voice yesterday. Consequently, the premiere of the Maxwell Anderson play, scheduled for this evening at the Belasco, had to be put off until next Tuesday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 5 -- Valentim F. Boucas, secretary of the commission in control of the Washington agreements with Brazil, left for the United States this morning on an official mission to smooth out the rough edges of both the Washington agreements and the agreement newly signed regarding the payment of Brazil's foreign debt.

ALGIERS, Jan. 5 -- Rene Massigli, Commissioner for Foreign Affairs, faced and successfully resisted a demand made today in the Provisional Consultative Assembly for a wholesale purge of the entire diplomatic service to eliminate all who did not desert Vichy and follow Gen. Charles de Gaulle on June 22, 1940.

Usual January overcoat clearances, prominently promoted by men's wear and department stores throughout the country, have been and will be further submerged from a promotional standpoint this year, with such offerings to date striking only a minor note in comparison to the pre-war events, buyers now in the New York market reported yesterday.

An exhibition schedule of eleven games, including two with the Giants and an additional pair with the Dodgers, has been drawn up for the Yankees' 1944 spring training campaign, according to an announcement made yesterday by Ed Barrow, president of the world champions.

WHEN American football was introduced in Australia the folks Down Under liked parts of it and disliked others. So they incorporated the best features of our game and their own into a hybrid sport which they christened by the quaint title of Austus (a combination of Australia and U.S.). It is booming in the South Pacific area and undoubtedly will be presented back here when the boys return.

There is a long-standing tradition that the annual message of the Governor of New York shall recommend a complete program of legislative action for the year, and Governor Dewey's message yesterday conforms to this pattern. It deals with subjects ranging all the way from the acquisition of rights-of-way for highways to reform of the administrative machinery for public welfare.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Further cut-backs in the steel production expansion program were recommended today to the Defense Plant Corporation by the War Production Board, which suggested that plans for building four plants be abandoned.

Representatives of teachers' groups and civic organizations interested in education offered a wide range of budget recommendations yesterday afternoon at a hearing before the Board of Education's committee on finance and budget.

Most of the volunteer units of the city's civilian defense army will swing into action at 8 o'clock tonight when midtown Manhattan will be "bombed" in a demonstration ordered by the State Civilian Defense Director and announced last Sunday by Mayor La Guardia in his weekly radio broadcast at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The strongest attack that has been made on the amendments to the Renegotiation Act, proposed by a majority of the Senate Finance Committee, came today from Senator Walsh of Massachusetts, a member of the committee, speaking for a minority of four.

Expressing hope that the nation had learned from past experience and would not let its merchant marine "filter away" as after the last war, Mayor La Guardia yesterday called upon the United States to maintain "the largest merchant marine service in the world."

Reports from Bolivia add little to what was known two and a half weeks ago, when a four-hour military uprising, accompanied by a little gunfire, drove out President Penaranda and installed Major Gualberto Villarroel. The new regime insists that it means to carry out its commitments to the United Nations, which is a point in its favor.

The Japanese-controlled Manila radio said yesterday that a unit of the pre-war Philippines Commonwealth Government still was offering resistance in the mountains of Cagayan, northern Luzon, under the leadership of the former Provincial Gov. Marcelo Adduru.

An investigation by Clinton White, regional salvage director here of the War Production Board, of charges that three Government agencies in the city had burned 211 tons of waste paper during the last six months -- while a nation-wide drive to collect every scrap of waste paper for war uses has been under way -- was ordered yesterday by H.M. Faust, WPB salvage director in Washington.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Despite the great weight of the Allied aerial offensive in 1943, in which the Royal Air Force operating from British and Mediterranean bases pounded enemy targets with more than 250,000 tons of bombs, the Germans have reinforced the Luftwaffe's first-line fighter strength by 1,000 aircraft during the year, according to a RAF commentator.

WASHINGTON, Jan 5. -- The total Marine casualties in the bloody conquest of Tarawa atoll in the Gilbert Islands will be "somewhat less" than the previously announced figure of 3,583, Capt. Leland P. Lovette, Director of Navy Public Relations, disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Representative Pat Cannon of Florida is planning to get signatures to a petition to force the Equal Rights Amendment out of the House Judiciary Committee. If he obtains the 218 (more than half) required in an action to discharge a committee, there must be a two-thirds vote in the House for passage of the amendment.

Throughout the first twenty minutes of the game, St. John's and C.C.N.Y. performed like two wonder fives last night at Madison Square Garden. Good, hard-driving, smart basketball was abundant on both sides and the crowd of 15,237 persons was treated to the best exhibition of the season. Halftime found the teams deadlocked at 23 -- all, the eighth tie of the period.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 5 -- The Argentine Government issued a decree regulating the activities of the press today. It applies not only to the Argentine press but also to foreign news agencies and correspondents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- So welcome and effective have been the meetings conducted the past year for men of the Army and Navy by the National Conference of Christians and Jews that they will be continued through the demobilization and post-war periods and extended, meanwhile, to employes in defense industries, Dr. A.W. Gottschall, director of progams for the armed forces, stated today.

As a result of the three-day rallies that have been going on throughout Manhattan, more than half of the 20,000 Minute Men for the Fourth War Loan, who will sell bonds under the direction of former Gov. Alfred E. Smith, starting Jan. 18, have been signed up, it was announced yesterday.

Frank Jiro, 25 years old, unemployed machinist's helper, and his wife, Julia, 23, whose two babies the police found alone in their tenement flat Tuesday afternoon, were ordered yesterday by Justice Herbert O'Brien to report this morning to the Children's Court.

Nothing much, excepted wasted time and money, is likely to result from the hearings on Representative Bryson's wartime prohibition law which a House judiciary subcommittee will undertake next week. One hundred thousand individuals are said to have signed petitions for this legislation, which would again make it a Federal crime to make, sell or buy any beverage containing as much as 51 one-hundredths of 1 per cent of alcohol by volume.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Decreases in the birth rate which have been a consistent trend for 200 years in this country as well as in western Europe, will be interrupted briefly by the rises recorded in the United States during the war, Dr. Philip M. Hauser said today.

The executive committee of the National Collegiate A.A. met yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore in closed session to transact the business of the association in lieu of the annual convention, which has been called off, as in 1943, because of wartime travel restrictions.

Supreme Court Justice Frank E. Johnson in the Richmond County Supreme Court at St. George, S.I., yesterday signed an order requiring the Board of Elections of the city to show cause on Jan. 12 why an order should not be made directing the board to issue to Municipal Court Justice Thomas J. Walsh, Democrat, a certificate of election to the County Court of Richmond.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Jan. 5 (AP) -- There were only ten deaths charged to football in the United States in 1943, and not a single one of them was due to injuries suffered on college gridirons, Dr. Floyd R. Eastwood, Purdue University professor, reported today.

The sealed entries for last season's competition among members of the Long Island Surf Fishing Club were opened at a meeting of the board of directors the other night and now their contents can be told. Not that the anglers who got big ones haven't done a bit of bragging about them many times already.

A German military spokesman has admitted that the Russian armies have broken through the Nazi winter defensive line west of Kiev and that Germany's eastern front has been split in two. That is perhaps the most important German admission in this war, all the more dramatic because it was made to neutral correspondents in the bomb-scarred Foreign Office amid the roar of fires still blazing from the latest Allied raids.

An issue of $1,650,000 of temporary loan notes was announced yesterday by Essex County, Mass., for award on Jan. 11. It will be dated Jan. 15, 1944, and will be payable in installments on April 1 and Nov. 1, 1944, and Jan. 15, 1945.

Captain Walter M. Markey Jr., 23-year-old flier, who has flown on 130 missions in the South Pacific and is credited with having bagged four Zeros, said yesterday on his first visit home in three years that the enemy "definitely is licked" in that area.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A German military spokesman admitted today that the Nazi winter defensive line on the Eastern Front had been split by a "very deep penetration," dispatches from the German capital said.

The twelve-story loft building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 22-24 West Thirty-eighth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, has been sold by David W. Frankel to a client of Abraham Sobil, attorney, for cash over a mortgage of $182,000 held by the American Museum of Natural Histtory.

The five-story apartment house at 871-77 Boulevard East, in Weehawken, N.J., has been sold by Clinton B. Snyder, trustee, to the River Cliff Realty Company of Union City. This building is on a plot 100 by 99 feet and is assessed for $144,000. It was sold for an indicated consideration of $92,000.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 5 -- New Italian-type planes are being operated by the Japanese, and New Zealand pilots are helping to provide fighter cover for the Allied bombers attacking the Rabaul airfields, an official news release said today.

As the climax of a three-month controversy at the institution, City College's Faculty Committee on Student Activities voted yesterday to charter the school's Tom Paine Club, affiliated with the American Youth for Democracy. In an unprecedented statement, however, the committee called undergraduate attention to the Communist "sponsorship and initiation" of the new national youth group.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- Three new rules relaxing some of the restrictions imposed under the Investment Company Act of 1940 were adopted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. They were effective immediately.
LONDON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- A joint British Air Ministry and United States Army European Theatre of Operations communique:

Fishermen operating out of New York decided yesterday to await further developments in Boston and New Bedford before voting on whether they should continue or call off their strike, now in its sixth week, Cornelius Drew, delegate of the Atlantic Fishermen's Union, disclosed last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Uniform legislation on the part of the States providing that ballots be mailed to men and women in the services overseas at least forty-five days before the election was suggested today by the Secretaries of War and the Navy as a means to "make more possible an effective cooperation by the services in absentee voting procedures."

In 1944 the relative supply position of the hard goods and soft goods industries will be reversed from that of the early stages of the war, and tight conditions on many types of soft goods appear likely to continue well into the early post-war period, Richard N. Johnson, director of the apparel, textile and leather products division of the Office of Civilian Requirements of the War Production Board, said yesterday.
LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 6 (UP) -The lussa :Weclnesday iclgkt supplementary oomrunque as broadcazt lrom Moscow:
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Although little business was done on the stock markets here today the tone was firm.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 5 -- Danish patriots lost one of their spiritual leaders when the well known author and clergyman Kaj Munk was found murdered this morning in a park near the Jutland city of Silkeborg, headquarters of Maj. Gen. Hermann von Hanneken, German commander of the forces occupying Denmark.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The attack by Pravda today on Wendell L. Willkie was interpreted here as an emphatic warning to Great Britain and the United States to keep hands off Poland and other states of middle and southeastern Europe whose borders the Red Army is now approaching.
No one knows how the developments of 1944 will shape the programs of baseball.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Senator Scott W. Lucas, Democrat, of Illinois, had in readiness a new absentee vote bill for service personnel today in place of the leave-it-to-the-States resolution which the Senate substituted for his original measure.

With counsel for a group of branded line producers in the women's full-fashioned hosiery industry indicating that a new appeal to the Office of Price Administration was under consideration, the industry generally began preparing yesterday for compliance with requirements of the second revised MPR-339, issued on Tuesday.

ALGIERS, Jan. 5 -- The land forces in Italy found the situation largely unchanged yesterday. The German Tenth Army, with ten identified divisions in the line and three others in the rear, kept up a dogged and bitter defense palpably intended to stave off the advance on Rome indefinitely.
LONDON, Jan. 5 (Reuter) -- The text of the statement issued today by the Polish Government follows:

The current basic tax rate of $2.89 on real estate, representing a record to date, must be increased to an even higher level unless the 1944 Legislature gives the city power to collect from $25,000,000 to $30,000,000 of additional revenue from other sources, Mayor La Guardia warned yesterday in his annual message to the City Council.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- Liang Han-tsao, Chinese Minister of Information, said today that the Chinese Army would launch "several millions" of men in a general counter-offensive against Japan during 1944, provided the weight of Allied arms was thrown against such points as Hong Kong, Canton and Burma and that Allied air strength in China was increased.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- No action on a petition to investigate civil liberties in Jersey City, N.J., is contemplated by the Department of Justice, a spokesman said today, until the New Jersey courts have disposed of the John R. Longo case.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Advocates of an appointive judiciary, active since the Aurelio case broke last fall, appeared to have suffered a setback under the method proposed today by Governor Dewey in his message to the Legislature.

Adoption of "streamline merchandising" by business and industry is essential if they are to maintain a certain post-war prosperity, and "we must work fast and think big" beginning immediately, Stanley Roth, vice president in charge of merchandising of D.A. Schulte, Inc., declared last night.
weather the storm.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 5 -- The State Highway Department put up for public auction today seventy-seven houses on Rutherford Avenue, and they went like hot toddies would go in the Aleutians, despite a sale stipulation requiring buyers to move the structures or demolish those not found movable and raze the foundations to the level of the roadway.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 5 -- Twenty-four points by Mike Shinkarik were not enough to stop Pennsylvania tonight and the Quaker five defeated Princeton in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game, 52 to 46. The losers overcame a lead of 31-20 which Penn had built up by half-time but lost in the final ninety seconds.

Herman Gelber, who was re-elected president of Local 306 of the Motion Picture Operators Union, and other officers chosen at a recent election of the membership, were installed yesterday in their offices at a meeting of the union in Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Contending that the White House had usurped the powers of Congress, Representative Jessie Sumner, Republican, of Illinois, said tonight that she would not be a candidate for a fourth term in the November elections.

The New York Trust Company reported yesterday for 1943 a net operating income of $3,905,875 after expenses and charges and a provision of $1,500,000 far taxes. This was equal to $6.51 each on the 600,000 capital shares of $25 par value outstanding at the end of the year.

New works placed by Dr. Rodzinski on the program of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's concert last night in Carnegie Hall were William Grant Still's "In Memoriam: The Colored Soldiers Who Died for Democracy," and the concerto of Vladimir Dukelsky for violin and orchestra, which Ruth Posselt played superbly.
The three-story apartment house containing forty-eight suites at 424-30 West Broadway, Long Beach, L.I., has been sold by the Manhattan Savings Bank to Mary C. Bode. Albert A. Lannin was the broker.

The corporate buying offices of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., have completed an agreement with the May Company whereby the services of the May Company's resident buying offices at the Merchandise Mart in Chicago will be made available to Macy's and its affiliated stores -- Bamberger's, LaSalle Koch and Davison-Paxon Company, it was announced yesterday by Macy's.

TRENTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court upheld today an order by the State Milk Control Director, Arthur F. Foran, increasing the dealer-to-farmer price of standard grade milk by 23 cents a hundredweight and said it was not convinced that the retail price of milk would have to be raised to save the distributors from disaster.

Arturo Toscanini, who three years ago turned down a Hollywood offer of $250,000 to make one motion picture, has finished starring in a film presentation of Verdi's "Hymn of the Nations" for which he volunteered his services to the Government, it became known yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 6 -- The murder of the Danish clergyman and playwright, Kaj Munk, reported from here yesterday, was officially mentioned for the first time in the Copenhagen newspapers this morning.

Beau Jack, recognized as the lightweight champion of the world by the New York State Athletic Commission, will still be so regarded at the conclusion of his bout with Charley (Lulu) Costantino of the East Side at Madison Square Garden tonight. For no matter what happens to the Augusta (Ga.) Negro, conditions surrounding the battle, which tops the card, are such that his title claim will not be disturbed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Department store sales for the week ended Jan. 1 were 6 per cent lower than sales in the corresponding period of 1942, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 22 per cent in the week ended Dec. 25.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt credited lend-lease equipment from the United States today with playing a major role in the Red Army offensive which is driving the Germans out of Russia, and in the devastation of German war centers from the skies.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The people of Belgium, whose homeland forms a bridgehead onto the northern European plain that extends eastward into Germany, received their invasion orders tonight.
With further reference to your editorial discussion of renegotiation of contracts, I desire to cite an example of the arbitrary action of officers of the War Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The circumstances relating to the letter which C. Nelson Sparks of Akron asserts was written by Harry Hopkins to Dr. Umphrey Lee of Dallas will be investigated by a Federal grand jury next week, Tom C. Clark, assistant Attorney General, said today

Immediate relief for "overburdened and distressed" real estate through a self-sustaining fare on the city's subway lines was demanded yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York in identical letters to Mayor La Guardia and the other members of the Board of Estimate.

Your recent editorial on renegotiation leads me to remark that most of our problems today are economic. No longer is it in the public interest to have legislators fulminate about moral issues. If the country is to make great progress legislators and administrators should have the capacity to evaluate the complicated and various factors involved in the country's economic development.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 6 (AP) -- The United States District Court approved today an application of the Securities and Exchange Commission, made at the request of the Central States Power and Light Corporation, seeking enforcement of the corporation's plan for liquidation and dissolution.

New issues of temporary loan notes amounting to $45,753,000 were awarded yesterday by fifteen local housing authorities throughout the country. A banking group headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company won the award of $39,283,000; Salomon Brothers Hutzler obtained the award of $4,192,000, and the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company and associates obtained the award of $2,278,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The roots of the railway labor controversy are as visible as the props of the mangrove trees.
The table shows the highest and lowest points reached in 1943 and a series of past years. All figures in thousands of dollars:
Yesterday's Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Definite word on when the new price regulation covering furs will be promulgated was still lacking in the industry yesterday, but it was understood that the regulation has been completed and is now in the Office of Economic Stabilization.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. William J. Bingham, the Football Rules Committee's new chairman, tonight said he was opposed to making any changes in the game's playing code for the duration.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Reversing an Appellate Division affirming of a sentence of ten to thirty years imposed upon Charles McLaughlin by Judge Colden in Queens County Court, the Court of Appeals today criticized the judge for errors committed at the trial.

About forty New York realty and business leaders conferred yesterday with State Senator William Bewley, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Assessing and Reviewing, and with Assemblyman Joseph R. Younglove, secretary of that committee, in the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn, to discuss possible means of "correcting over-assessments" in the city.

The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association has issued a booklet containing a collection of fifty newspaper advertisements on themes relating to the war effort for the help and guidance of advertisers seeking information on wartime advertising trends and ideas for their own wartime messages.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Office of Price Administration announced in detail the conditions of price control on food sales by United States Government agencies.

" God bless and prosper the magnificent work you are doing and may you go over the top!" wrote an anonymous donor of $5 for the Neediest Cases Fund, who said she was late because she had been ill with the grippe. And another contributor of $5 wrote: "Where needed -- delayed by illness."

Three former employes of the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, received yesterday short jail terms and six other former workers were fined $100 each by Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz for allegedly making false claims for additional wages through the manipulation of time clocks at the Navy Yard.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Since the airplane was first used as a military weapon there have been two schools of thought on how it can best be employed in warfare.

Winter struck with a fury in the North yesterday with the result that the finest skiing this season is to be found at virtually all areas. Those able to use their skis will find deep powder snow, the type that softens spills and makes for exhiliarating running, reaching as much as twenty-four inches in depth.
TORONTO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs moved into a second-place tie in the National Hockey League tonight by trouncing the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 -- 1.

OKANOGAN, Wash., Jan. 6 -- The mother of Marine Major Gregory Boyington, whose downing of his twenty-sixth Japanese plane in the Southwest Pacific was announced today, received word from the Navy tonight that he was missing in action.

Excess reserves of member banks of the entire Federal Reserve System declined $160,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $970,000,000, and all the decline took place in New York City, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Mayor La Guardia was informed yesterday by representatives of leading grocery chains that they had dropped their egg prices six to twelve cents a dozen and were considering further reductions, he disclosed last night.
LONDON, Jan. 6 (UP) -- An Admiralty, communique:

The Ramirez Government in Argentina, which seems to grow fiercer as its European models begin to totter, has just clapped restrictions on the press, with the object of preventing intelligent and truthful discussions of public questions. It infers, quite naturally, that such discussions would be harmful to it.

Dr. Arthur F. Chace, president of the New York Academy of Medicine, said last night at the academy's annual meeting that the academy was earnestly seeking to anticipate the form of society in which we shall live and was "in the process of adjusting medicine, in its broadest sense, to the new social order."

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The annual list of approved hospitals for the United States and Canada, as made public today by the American College of Surgeons contains the names of 3,253 institutions, an increase of 264 over the total of a year ago.

A tour through the markets reveals that although poultry and fresh fish are scarce and probably cannot be obtained for week-end meals, there is a more-than-adequate supply of meat and eggs and frozen fish. Vegetables and citrus fruits also are abundant, according to a spokesman for the War Food Administration who reports that receipts during the last few days were above normal for this season.

The War Production Board has set the domestic pulpwood production goal for 1944 at 14,000,000 cords, producers disclosed yesterday. The goal, which excludes imports expected to run about 1,500,000 cords, exceeds last year's scheduled domestic output by 1,000,000 cords.

In a further expansion of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company into the field of plastic resins, the corporation has acquired the Paramet Chemical Corporation, manufacturer of alkyl and phenolic resins and ester gums, it was announced yesterday by John D. Biggers, president of the glass company.

The increased strength in naval sea-air power accomplished through the construction program of the last year has made this nation vastly superior to any other in this respect, James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, told financial and business leaders of this city yesterday at a luncheon sponsored by the board of directors of Beekman Hospital at the Bankers Club.
TRENTON, Jan. 6 -- There may be a second Battle of Trenton, this one involving Charlestonians (of South Carolina) and Trentonians.

A violinist, who in certain qualities is without a rival today, played a new and brilliantly composed concerto at the concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, on which occasion a performance of one of the most familiar of all symphonies, Beethoven's Seventh, made as much of a sensation as the new concerto, and rightly.

After weeks of minor activity and preparation, the Anglo-American Fifth Army under General Clark has now started a new offensive in an effort to break through the German "Siegfried Line" in the mountains of central Italy and thereby open up the road to Rome.

David S. Meister has sold to a group of investors the five-story apartment house on an irregular-plot 132 by 153 feet at 3822-34, Bailey Avenue, near Van Cortlandt Park, in the Bronx. The annual rent roll of this property is reported to be about $30,000, and the assessed valuation is $160,000.

Furniture and objects of art from the estate of J.P. Morgan went on sale at auction yesterday afternoon, by order of the executors, at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. The Far Eastern porcelains, semi-precious mineral carvings, ivory carvings, English furniture, decorations and other lots sold at the first session brought a total of $26,747.50.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- States' rights Senators, despite the renewed overtures for a compromise on soldier vote legislation, moved in the opposite direction today with plans for a caucus to solidify resistance to any bill containing even a suspicion of Federal control over State election machinery.

The fifth anniversary of the establishment of savings bank life insurance in the State of New York was observed last night with a dinner meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt. Savings bank life insurance officials from New York, Massachusetts and Connecticut were present.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Polish Prime Minister Stanislaw Mikolajczyk in a broadcast to his homeland tonight indicated that the Polish people might soon be called upon for a widespread uprising against the German army of occupation.

LONDON, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans, driving German troops from house to house, have won several more blocks in heavy street fighting in the Bosnian communications center of Banja Luka, while another force of Marshal Tito's (Josip Broz) fighters have tightened their siege of Novo Mesto, in the Slovene lowlands, it was reported today.

The seventeen-story and penthouse apartment building at 1100 Park Avenue, northwest corner of Eighty-ninth Street, has been sold by the Bowery Savings Bank to the Parkhattan Corporation for investment. It contains 549 rooms laid out into sixty-six apartments and was sold for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $805,000.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Jan. 6 -- High tides undermined four more summer bungalows in the western part of this city and carried them out to sea today to add to the flotsam of ten structures of similar type that toppled during the storms of yesterday and Tuesday.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The "invisible" damage to Germany -- slackening of interest in the reconstruction of shattered cities and in maintenance of production -- is rising steadily in the Reich, according to well informed sources.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 7 -- Under the terrific battering the Germans are "retreating in disorder" and abandoning "a large part of their munitions and war materials," the Russian midnight communique reported, listing huge booty captured as well as "a considerable number of prisoners."
A simulated but uncannily realistic air raid in the heart of the city last night was witnessed by thousands from the hollow square in Bryant Park.
DETROIT, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A new glider capable of carrying thirty soldiers and with clearance to transport two jeeps was tested at the Ford airport in Dearborn today.

ALGIERS, Jan. 6 -- In a short speech before the tribune of the Consultative Assembly tonight at the end of a three-day discussion of the budget of the French Committee of National Liberation for the empire and the liberated regions of France, Gen. Charles de Gaulle told the members their debate had been important as "a new manifestation of the French democratic spirit."

The principal commercial banks throughout the country were notified late yesterday by the Treasury that it will make withdrawals on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday from government war-loan accounts in these institutions. Withdrawals in the Second Federal Reserve District will aggregate $90,355,000 on each day.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- A communique:
A total of 6,640 children was brought into the Children's Division of the Domestic Relations Court during 1943 on charges of juvenile delinquency, as compared with 4,904 in 1942 and 4,438 in 1941.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- General Sir Harold E. Franklyn, stern disciplinarian with a fine record for bravery as a young officer in World War I, has been appointed Commander in Chief of the Home Forces, the War Office announced tonight.

New York's coal famine grew worse yesterday as a shortage of delivery labor added to the problems arising out of a decline in the volume of both anthracite and bituminous reaching dealers' yards in the city.
" Modern war is a war for air bases," Gen. Henry H. Arnold, commander of the United States Army Air Forces, declared in an official report to the Secretary of War, made public this week.

Most Americans are outraged by the very serious strikes for more wages that are constantly occurring, but I wonder if much thought has been given to this high-cost-of-living excuse that the labor leaders advance and why that should be any justification of their claims for more money.

ALGIERS, Jan. 6 -- The Allied Fifth Army hurtled forward through rain and sleet Tuesday night on a ten-mile front west of the Venafro-Rocca d'Evandro line astride the Via Casilina to Rome, and American elements of Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's forces have burst into the heavily fortified village of San Vittore and wrested half of it away from the tenacious defenders.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 6 -- Illustrative of the state in which Allied air attacks have left Berlin was a story in yesterday's Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung there that a soldier reported home on leave from the Russian front likened the city to Zhitomir and Kiev.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION, England, Jan. 6 -- Cruising high above the Ruhr Valley yesterday after they had been prevented from bombing their assigned targets, a small force of United States Flying Fortresses blew up a factory producing about half of Germany's high-grade nuts and bolts when they spotted the plant through a break in the clouds, it was revealed today.

The Ellery-Stewart Company has sold the five-story thirty-family apartment building at 129-31 Kensington Avenue, in the Bergen section of Jersey City, to the Devia Realty Corporation, subject to a mortgage of $196,120 held by the Guardian Life Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The United States agreed today to a proposal of the Inter-American Emergency Advisory Committee for Political Defense at Montevideo to reach a decision concerning recognition of the revolutionary regime in Bolivia only after full information and views on the question had been exchanged among the nineteen anti-Axis Governments of the Western Hemisphere represented on the committee.

Ways of promoting racial and religious tolerance among New York City's school children are being considered by the educational officials here, it was disclosed yesterday. Dr. Jacob Greenberg, associate superintendent in charge of personnel, is going to Springfield, Mass., on Wednesday to study the Springfield plan.

The first annual report of the new Superintendent of Banks, Elliott V. Bell, is a quiet but lucid document and calls attention to quiet progress. One of the reforms achieved during the year was to influence the 121 savings banks of this State that were members of the Mutual Savings Banks Fund to take membership in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 7 -- Stettin, chief German seaport on the Baltic Sea for the supply of German armies on the Russian front, took a heavy hammering from hundreds of Royal Air Force Lancasters and Halifaxes early yesterday morning when German air defense commanders guessed wrong and sent up night fighters to meet an RAF feint at Berlin.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Admiral William F. Halsey, home on leave from his South Pacific command for the first time in sixteen months, said today that "when we get to Tokyo where we're bound to get eventually, we'll have a little celebration where Tokyo was."

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- A fairly large trade was done today in May wheat on the Board of Trade, and all was done at the temporary maximum price of $1.71 3/8 a bushel for futures. Millers, cash interests and shorts were buyers, while longs sold.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Strikes in United States industry in eleven months of 1943 cost war production 12,785,000 man-days of work, it was shown today in figures compiled from Department of Labor statistics for that period. The reports for December have not been correlated yet, but these are not expected to add greatly to the total.

On the train into town that morning the confirmed pessimist turned to his friend the unashamed optimist and gave the latter the surprise of his life. "Let a man invent a better mousetrap" -- said the man who was known to look at life through dark-colored glasses.

Lieut. Alfred White Paine, USNR, former top-seeded amateur squash racquets player in the metropolitan area, was killed while on active duty with the Navy on Jan. 1, according to word received from the Navy Department yesterday by his wife, Mrs. Carola Winter Paine of 113 East Fifty-fifth Street.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Algiers, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- Thousands of American soldiers in this theatre are demanding the right to vote in the forthcoming Presidential elections. The question is becoming more and more important to them. They are thinking of their future in the post-war era, many of them distrusting promises for the time when they are mustered out of the Army.

Puccini's "Gianni Schicchi" and Strauss's "Salome" formed the double bill presented at the Metropolitan last night. The Puccini work was revived, after an absence of five years from the repertoire, and "Salome" received its first performance of the season.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 6 -- An agency dispatch from Rome today states that Vatican circles do not conceal their expectations that the belligerent powers will react to the Pope's Christmas message.

The battlefronts of the vast Pacific area have instilled "a new faith" in service men of whatever creed or nationality engaged there and this faith has been an aid to the morale of the fighting forces in that area, Mauritz M. Gottlieb, special field commissioner for the Jewish Welfare Board and the United Service Organizations, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Net earnings of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company in 1943, after expenses and provisions for taxes, were $15,422,967, compared with $12,588,713 for 1942, Walter J. Cummings, chairman of the board, has reported to stockholders.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 6 -- Within a month after the fall of Rangoon in March, 1942, had closed the Burma Road, the last important Allied land supply route to China, American transport planes opened a new supply line. The line has been operated ever since "over the hump" of mountains from the tea gardens of northeast Assam to the high plains of central Yunnan Province.
One hot day last July Max Herskovitz of 756 Brady Avenue, the Bronx, was digging up the bricks of the foundation of a building of China University in Shanghai, bombed in 1937 by the Japanese.

William D. Katz, an insurance broker, who gave his address as 1660 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, was convicted last night by a jury in Brooklyn Federal Court for accepting a bribe in connection with a draft deferment and counseling evasion of the Selective Service Act.

Only a hundred applicants for freight handlers' jobs responded yesterday at United States Employment and Railroad Retirement offices in the New York-New Jersey area in answer to the appeal of the War Manpower Commission and the Railroad Retirement Board for 5,000 full and part time workers to help relieve the serious freight congestion at railroad piers in this district, it was announced at the office of the War Manpower Commission, 11 West Forty-second Street.

Following the example set two weeks ago by the Milk Industry Advisory Committee, Mayor La Guardia appealed yesterday to Roy F. Hendrickson, Director of the Food Distribution Administration, to revoke that board's order permitting sale of heavy cream on doctors' prescriptions.

Robert E. Woodruff, president of the Erie Railroad, warned yesterday against Government excursions into the field of private industry, and characterized such action as a potential threat to free enterprise. He told the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 65 Liberty Street, that forces were at work that would like to socialize all industry and would prefer to have the Government keep control of the railroads.

One twin sister was killed and the other seriously injured yesterday afternoon when a Manhattan-bound Long Island Railroad train on the Port Washington line knocked them from a forty-foot trestle at Gilman Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, Woodside, Queens.

Two newspapers in Germany, one of them the propaganda organ of nazidom's leading apostle of paganism, have echoed a new "back-to-church" order reportedly issued to the Gestapo and the Storm Troops with articles informing the German people that "religion has again become modern" and that they may fall back on it to find solace and bolster their morale, it was reported to the Office of War Information last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Paint will be spread, sewing machines will whirr, and hammer and saw will go into action promptly and widely on the cessation of hostilities, according to indications in a report by the United States Chamber of Commerce on the buying intentions of American families in the post-war period.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt today sent a radioed citation to Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, Commander in Chief of United States Army Forces in the China-Burma-India theatre, honoring the India-China wing of the Air Transport Command for "exceptionally outstanding performance in the face of almost insurmountable odds in moving vast quantities of military supplies by air to China.

There were noble contradictions in the life of Ida M. Tarbell, who died yesterday. She lived to be 86 years old and naturally had some of the physical infirmities of age, but her mind and personality never took on age -- they simply matured in richness and wisdom.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Legislative leaders withheld comment today on Mayor La Guardia's demand that the Legislature grant New York City broader taxing power to avert further increase in the city's all-time high basic tax rate on real estate.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Standard Oil Company of Ohio announced today the merger of three subsidiaries into the Sohio Petroleum Company, to "represent a simplification of the company's corporate structure."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The first tax contest of the new session of Congress starting Monday will be over the proposal to freeze for another year the present 1 per cent employer-employe Social Security old-age benefit levy, Senator Walter F. George, chairman of the Finance Committee, said today.

Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday extended the gains made on Wednesday as aggressive buying encountered a growing scarcity of offerings. The day's best levels were chalked up at the close with quotations 17 to 20 points over previous finals, or 85 cents to $1 a bale higher.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -- All work at the Cramp Shipbuilding Company, employing 17,000 men and women in the production of light cruisers and submarines, was halted today as the result of a dispute as to whether management had the right to compel painters to use spray guns instead of brushes.

The modern six-story apartment building at 75 Manhattan Avenue, at the corner of McKibben Street, in Brooklyn, has been sold by the Philmark Real Estate Company through Weprin Glass, brokers. The property is reported fully rented.

Organized baseball's major post-war policies should concern themselves with territorial realignments of minor league franchises, a drastic curtailment of major league chain-store operations in the minors and a practical system for the handling of players as they are mustered out of service with the end of the war.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The War Food Administration denied today excessive spoilage of reserve food stocks and revealed stored food inventories, in reply to Congressional charges of waste.
LONDON, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- The London Daily Mail said today that the new jet-propulsion planes probably had a top speed of between 500 and 600 miles an hour.

Frank Jiro, 24 years old, unemployed machinist's helper, and his wife, Julia, 23, were held in $50 bail each for Special Sessions by Magistrate William Klapp in Yorkville Court yesterday on charges of endangering the lives or the health of their two babies.
Large loft and business buildings in Fourth Avenue, Chambers Street and Broadway were listed yesterday as having passed into new hands.
LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Bank of England in its weekly condition statement issued today reported a decrease of 4,741,000 in note circulation, the first decline in fifteen weeks.
Net profit of the Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and all subsidiaries amounted to $3,031,355, according to the report for the three months ended with October, issued yesterday.
Col. Louis E. Jallade was appointed yesterday as deputy area rent director for Brooklyn by Louis H. Pink, rent director of the Office of Price Administration in the New York area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics index of commodity prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended Jan. 1 as a result of higher prices for grains and livestock. The slight advance brought the all-commodity index to 103 per cent of the 1926 average.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The importance of France in Allied military plans has increased to such an extent that Prime Minister Churchill and Gen. Charles de Gaulle undoubtedly will have to meet much sooner than had been expected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A gain of 16 per cent in November, 1943, as compared with November, 1942, in sales of independent retailers was reported today by the Bureau of the Census. November sales were 2 per cent under those of October.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet, made an unannouced visit to the San Francisco Bay area and pinned the Purple Heart medal on twenty marines and twelve Navy men wounded in recent engagements in the Pacific, the Navy disclosed today.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to serve notice upon seven airlines operating at La Guardia Field that they must submit, not later than Jan. 20, their plans for the handling of gasoline and oil sales at the new Idlewild Airport in Queens.

From the airdromes of northeastern India today there flows into China "a greater monthly tonnage of military supplies than was ever carried over the Burma Road." More planes go in and out of these fields every day than use La Guardia Field -- and La Guardia in normal times had 270 scheduled flights.

Subscriptions amounting to $95,000 have been received in the $300,000 Metropolitan Opera campaign, it was announced yesterday by George A. Sloan, president of the Metropolitan Opera Association. The 7,500 donations made include gifts from operagoers of the New York area, radio listeners throughout the country and corporations.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

SOMEWHERE in Rome there lives a man of 80 years. If the Nazis have not disturbed his declining days any more than did the Fascisti, the tumult and destruction of the ever-nearing battle will not have upset him unduly; the sad spectacle of the follies and cruelties, the blasted hopes and immortal aspirations of mankind, will not have greatly shocked or depressed him.
Dr. Alexander Loudon, the Netherlands Ambassador, and Mrs. Loudon are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Your editorial "Severance Pay" of Dec. 31 was timely. Most will agree that the service men as they are discharged should receive adequate grants spread over a reasonable period to provide support until they can find permanent employment in civilian life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Asserting that the Democratic party was going to "stand or fall on the job we do of winning the war and planning the peace," Frank C. Walker, national chairman, called today for election of a Congress pledged to support "an international policy that means something."

A charge that "probably hundreds of Christian Fronters" are on New York City's police force was made yesterday by David Livingston, New York State chairman of American Youth for Democracy, in a talk before the first meeting on the campus of City College's Tom Paine Club, an affiliate of AYD.

Charles F. Noyes, real estate owner and broker, called on realty interests yesterday to cooperate with Mayor La Guardia "in his efforts to get additional sources of revenue and help him to get the enabling legislation from Albany to bring this about."
The Dew Chemical Company announced yesterday that it would redeem on Feb. 15 its outstanding 5 per cent preferred stock at $105 a share.

Net asset value of the stock of the Lehman Corporation climbed $8.17 last year from $29.54 a share to $37.71, according to the report to stockholders of Robert Lehman, president, which was released yesterday. As of June 30 last, the end of the fiscal year, net asset value was $37.35 a share and on Sept. 30 last it was $37.51.

MOSCOW, Jan. 6 -- Prof. Alexander A. Bogomoletz, president of the Ukrainian Academy of Sciences, who recently received the award of Hero of Socialist Labor for the discovery of an antireticular cytotoxic serum that has proved valuable in the treatment of arthritis and war injuries, said today that it also was possible that the serum would be useful in preventing the recurrence of a cancer that had been removed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Fifteen railway unions charged today that President Roosevelt and his chief lieutenants were almost entirely to blame for failure to adjust the railway wage disputes.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -- A three-point formula calling for the immediate return to work of about 3,000 striking city employes before their demands for a 10 per cent wage increase would be considered, was offered late today by city authorities after prison labor was pressed into service to assure Philadelphia of a sufficient water supply.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Secretary Morgenthau said today that the Treasury still hoped to hold an international monetary conference this winter and that two members of a Russian delegation were already here, while three more were on the way.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The tone of the stock markets here again was firm today, but only a small amount of business was done. Interest centered in the industrial group, and Hudson's Bay rose quickly due to optimistic speculation concerning post-war oil developments in that company's territory.

Lieut. Col. William J. Bingham, director of athletics at Harvard and now on leave while in service with the General Staff at the First Service Command Headquarters in Boston, was named yesterday as the new chairman of the football rules committee, succeeding the late Walter R. Okeson of Lehigh.
Soft-hearted men and women who do not like doors slammed in their faces will find that being a Minute Man in the Fourth War Loan carries no such trials and tribulations.

The Atlantic Cat Club, Inc., opened its two-day show yesterday amid the crows and cackles of the 2,000 entrants of the New York Poultry Show, Inc., both of which were being held in the grand ballroom of Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth.

A slim, spruce Army corporal, with a small mustache and sparse hair that made him appear older than his 32 years, was brought in by the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday and jailed under charges of having served the Japanese as a secret propaganda agent up to three days after Pearl Harbor.
MOSCOW, Friday, Jan. 7 -- Smashing deeper into the western Ukraine, the Red Army yesterday captured Rakitno, seventeen miles west of Olevsk and ten miles inside Rovno Province.

A novel and altogether fascinating show has opened at the Downtown Gallery, 43 East Fifty-first Street, where Ralston Crawford is the one-man exhibitor. In the first place, the artist has a handle to his name now. He is a master sergeant in the United States Army Air Forces and is stationed in Washington, D.C., in the information branch of the weather division, headed by Col. D.N. Yates.

Four corporations and five individuals were made defendants yesterday in an anti-trust suit filed in Federal court here by the Department of Justice with the announced purpose of striking a "major blow" against the international cartel system.

High-priced book purchases made by the movies during the past year included $175,000 paid by Warners for Edna Ferber's "Saratoga Trunk" and $100,000 for Ambassador Joseph E. Davies' "Mission to Moscow." Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer paid $100,000 apiece for Anna Seghers' "The Seventh Cross" and for Capt. Ted Lawson's "Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo." A.J. Cronin's "The Keys of the Kingdom" also brought $100,000 from Twentieth Century-Fox.

An American tank operated by a Russian crew on the Eastern Front is a more deadly weapon against the Nazis than one lying idle in this country. That is such a self-evident fact that it should hardly be necessary for President Roosevelt to point it out in his thirteenth report to Congress on the operation of the Lend-Lease Act.

MOSCOW, Jan. 6 -- The Union of Polish Patriots called on the Polish underground today to rise against the Germans now, and announced a five-point political program involving the cession to Russia of disputed eastern Polish territory, to be offset by extension of Poland's frontier westward at Germany's expense.

AN ARMY AIR BASE in the Central Pacific, Jan. 6 -- The Seventh Army Air Force is inflicting severe punishment on the Japanese in the Marshall Islands at a minimum cost to us in men and machines, Brig. Gen. William J. Flood said here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 -- Dorothy McGuire and Alan Marshall, who are under contract to David O. Selznick, have been borrowed by RKO for the leads in "I Married the Navy," a comedy by Emmet Lavery about the marital complications of a Wave and a 4-F. Richard Wallace has been signed to direct the film, and Lavery will be producer with Val Lewton.

In anticipation of new and lower ceilings on some styles ordered in revised MPR-339, which becomes effective Jan. 15, some hosiery producers have begun disposing of year-end accumulations of women's circular-knit rayon meshes at reductions of approximately 50 cents per dozen from current ceilings, it was reported yesterday in the hosiery market.
MOORESTOWN, N.J., Jan. 6 (AP) -- The great stallion John P. Grier is dead.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The time-saving and other conveniences which ration tokens will bring to housewives and to retailers of foods will more than offset any inconveniences, Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, said today. He made it clear that his agency intends to go ahead with its plans for distributing ration tokens on Feb. 27, despite objections raised by transit companies and others.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- If hostilities in Europe are ended by June, civilians may look for a considerable production of peacetime goods this year, the Office of War Information said today. Otherwise, it added, whatever civilian goods production the War Production Board allowed in 1944 must be considered as purely temporary and as limited to the amount necessary to keep the civilian economy operative at peak efficiency.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The American College of Surgeons made public today a list of 3,253 approved hospitals in the United States and Canada, an increase of 264 over the total approved a year ago.

" A well organized smear campaign against labor" is under way in this country and General George C. Marshall has allowed himself to become a tool in this anti-labor drive," it was charged last night by David Dubinsky in an address at headquarters of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union at the graduation exercises of the Women's Service Brigade. Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt was also a speaker.

The buying power of the two preceding sessions retired yesterday from the stock market, and, with a smattering of profit-taking after the swift advance, prices turned irregularly easier. Alterations in values were narrow, however, since the opening was fairly strong and firmness toward the close reduced the intervening losses.

An appeal to all Yugoslav Moslems to rally to Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch was made by Mustafa Mulalitch, former Moslem member of the Yugoslav Parliament, at ceremonies held in the field Dec. 19, in honor of the general's patron saint, St. Nicholas, according to a dispatch of the News Agency for Democratic Yugoslavia made public here yesterday.

In a radio address commemorating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the death of Theodore Roosevelt, James R. Garfield, president of the Roosevelt Memorial Association, cited last night the inspiration the former President gave to the country in the first World War and declared that his spirit still "lives to call the nation to heroic service in its time of need."

The annual inspection of all units of the New York Guard began last night by order of the War Department when Brig. Gen. R.K. Robertson, commanding District No. 1, reviewed the First Brigade and the Sixty-ninth Regiment in the latter's armory.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Printed copies of the proposed new simplified State income tax form, the optional use of which was recommended by Governor Dewey, were distributed today by the Tax Commission.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 6 -- Hard on the heels of the decree of Dec. 31 dissolving all political parties comes another decree that marks an important step in the development of Argentina into a totalitarian state copied faithfully from the most approved European patterns.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A new type of fighter aircraft, powered by jet-propulsion engines which eliminate propellers and make flight at high altitudes and "extreme speed" possible, marking a revolutionary advance in aeronautical engineering, will soon be in production, the War Department announced today.

MIAMI, Jan. 6 -- With seventeen top sprinters named for the $5,000 Inaugural Handicap, Hialeah Park is scheduled to begin the longest meeting in its history, fifty days, with a purse distribution estimated at more than $600,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission exempted today from competitive bidding requirements Illinois Power Company's proposed private offering of $65,000,000 first mortgage and collateral trust bonds due in 1973 and between $4,000,000 and $5,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent serial notes.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 -- If peace is to be maintained in the future, it will be necessary for the United States to join with other countries in an international organization and to cooperate to a greater extent in economic affairs, according to an analysis made by thirty-two discussion groups assembled under the auspices of the Universities Committee on Post-War International Problems.

The first week of the new year witnessed, among other things, the introduction of a flock of new ideas in the beauty field. In the last few days the manufacturers of cosmetics and the directors of various salons about town have initiated the following devices -- all designed to make the acquisition of beauty an easier, quicker and more efficient process:

Fredric March, the film actor, who returned yesterday from a 33,000-mile tour of military camps abroad, was prohibited by an Army public relations officer from discussing with interviewers the opinions of soldiers concerning strikes on the home front.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, Jan. 7 -- Six hundred Japanese have been slain during heavy fighting now in progress in dense jungle country at invaded Cape Gloucester, New Britain, as both sides brought up artillery and strafing American planes supported the attacking Marines.

Lou Little, Columbia's veteran coach, became the sixth recipient of the annual award of the Touchdown Club of New York at its dinner in the Yale Club last night. Receiving his certificate -- wartime substitute for the trophy of peace years -- the coach accepted it for himself and the coaches of other teams which carried on last fall in the face of poor material in order to keep the game going.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Richard G. Casey, who has been British Minister of State resident in the Middle East for nearly two years and is now in this country making final plans before taking up his duties as Governor of Bengal, told a press conference today that his own career in recent months might become a pattern for post-war experiment in the British Empire.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A public offering will be made next week of $10,000,000 of the Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority's 2 1/2 per cent electric revenue bonds, it was announced here today by two of the underwriters of the issue.

Because of good business, the Rialto management has decided to retain its feature offering, "The Ghost Ship," for a third week, starting today. "Spider Woman," the Universal melodrama originally scheduled to open today, will arrive next Friday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan.7 -- While her $100,000 suit over the death of her husband in the June 8 blackout was on trial in Supreme Court here today, Mrs. Margaret Savage of Rye, mother of nine children, received a $30,000 settlement from three defendants. The trial, before Justice Henry C. Wenzel Jr. and a jury, continued against two other defendants.

Indications are that the authorities in Washington are easing up on the order issued in October, 1942, prohibiting the extraction of gold from mines producing only that metal. It is reported that the War Production Board recently permitted seventy gold mines, all small or fair-sized producers, to resume operations.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans, after seven days of bloody street fighting in Banja Luka, have been forced to withdraw from the strategic Bosnian communications center after inflicting heavy casualties on the German garrison, Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A warning against the assumption that the Japanese fleet is afraid to engage ours in action was issued today by Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy. No one must, he said, discount the courage of the Japanese, and added that their reason for not moving their warships into battle was because it did not suit their present purposes.
Yesterday's Soviet communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- National leaders of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers (CIO) joined the Navy Department today in declaring that the two-day walkout at the Cramp Shipbuilding Company was aiding only the enemy and ordered that the 15,000 strikers return to their jobs at once.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Manufacturers' ceiling prices for lightweights of the three major Kraft wrapping papers were increased today by the Office of Price Administration as part of a program to encourage production of these papers and to aid in conservation of fibers.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- The first exhibition of the collection of arts objects, principally rare rugs and antique furniture, of the late John D. McIlhenny, utility executive, opened today with a preview at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, which he headed from 1920 to 1925.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 7 (AP) -- An eyewitness to the Royal Air Force's attack on the German Baltic port of Stettin early Thursday morning said today that he heard reports within that battered city that 1,000 persons had been killed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Senator Walter F. George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, speaking in a radio broadcast tonight on the differences between Congress and the Administration on the tax bill, asserted that many persons in and out of Congress believed the limit had about been reached in raising additional revenue.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) -"The Polish tniderground continues to fight the Germans, but its members become prisoners of war when !taken by the Red Army," a Polish I spokesman declared tonight as the Poles took a pessimistic view of I reaching a reconciliation with Russia.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Lord McGowan, chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., termed "iniquitous" today the charges by Wendell Berge, chief of Attorney General Francis Biddle's anti-trust division, that according to reports reaching here the British chemical cartel and du Pont had frustrated the Allied war effort and even collaborated with the enemy.

Army officers and civilian personnel at military posts throughout the nation and at the battlefronts will cooperate in the Fourth War Loan campaign, which opens Jan. 18, leading Army staff and finance officers said at a conference held yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker.

Several dinners were given last evening before the performance of "Tristan und Isolde," the New York Smith College Club's annual scholarship opera benefit. Mrs. Merrell E. Clark, chairman of the event, was hostess in her home at 840 Park Avenue to Herbert J. Davis, president of the college, and Mrs. Davis; Mrs. Arthur Berry Richardson, president of the New York Smith Club, and Mr. Richardson, Miss Margaret Richardson and Mr. and Mrs. George Weeks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Of three leading dry organizations, only the Woman's Christian Temperance Unon favors a drive for enactment of the Bryson bill for wartime prohibition, it developed today.

An award for outstanding service to the American tea industry during 1943 was presented last night to H. Edward Lawrence, president of George C. Cholwell Co. and supervisor of tea allocations for the industry in cooperation with the War Food Administration at the annual dinner of the Tea Association of the United States, in the Waldorf-Astoria.

The distinguished playing heard from Emile Baume, French pianist, at his recital last night in Town Hall, was characterized by sanity and sincerity of approach throughout a program well chosen to display his abilities in the best light. Mr. Baume is primarily a sensitive lyricist in his art, rather than a heroic performer, and the offerings on this occasion ideally served his purpose.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Babe Ruth's former understudy with the New York Yankees, Gammy Byrd, surprised everyone by taking the lead today in the $12,500 Los Angeles golf championship with a dazzling 66 over the par-71 Wilshire Country Club course in the opening round.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Randolph Paul, United States Treasury counsel, charged tonight that the tax bill scheduled to go before the Senate next week started out to be a revenue measure but was now in large part "a measure to appropriate public funds for 'relief' of war profiteers and others."

WASHIGNTON, Jan. 7 -- Defense of the integrity of the Railway Labor Act and the fundamental principles of collective bargaining were the issues raised today by the eighteen operating and non-operating railway unions in discussion to formulate a policy in their wage disputes.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut, speaking here last night, characterized the Roosevelt Administration as "the tragic era, the bloody and depressed era of American failure and frustration." Speaking at a Republican rally, she said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Senator Thomas of Idaho said today that he would introduce a resolution Monday "directing the Office of Price Administration to suspend meat rationing until thousands of tons of surplus pork, lamb and beef, now destined to spoil or to be destroyed, can be consumed by the public."

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 -- Thousands of Japanese have been killed but only 377 have been taken prisoner by American forces in two years of jungle, beach and tundra warfare, ranging the Pacific from the Solomons to the Aleutians, Robert P. Patterson, Under Secretary of War, disclosed here today.

Acting on complaints of American importers regarding railroad freight congestion at the Mexican border, resulting from inclusion of the loaded merchandise under the restrictions of War Production Board Order M-63, the Latin-American section of the New York Board of Trade has filed a plea for relief and a list of suggestions with the Department of State, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- All wheat futures sold today at maximum prices in leading markets, except the July delivery in Kansas City, and although there was considerable profit-taking at times, the best prices were maintained, except on the December future, on the Board of Trade here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -- Brian Donlevy, whose suspension at Paramount for refusal to appear in "Incendiary Blonde" will expire Feb. 28, has been named by that studio to play a brutal ship's captain in "Two Years Before the Mast."

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 8 -- Anglo-American air power was again exerted to its fullest extent against both strategic and tactical targets in the European fortress yesterday. A strong force of American heavy bombers battered objectives in southwestern Germany, their third attack in four days, while forces of Royal Air Force and American medium and light bombers and fighter-bombers, estimated at not less than 750 aircraft, continued to hammer German targets in northern France.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 1 were 643,474 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 2,106 cars or .3 per cent more than for the preceding week, 22,301 cars, or 3.6 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 33,060 cars, or 4.9 per cent, less than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The Actors Equity Association, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, said yesterday that it never had suggested that Paul Robeson, Negro performer, might face suspension because he expected to accept an honorary membership later this month in Local No. 1 of the State, County and Municipal Workers Union, a Congress of Industrial Organizations affiliate.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Treble damage suits, totaling $124,038.60, were begun by the Albany District Office of Price Administration today against seven Mohawk Valley rayon knitting mills charged with selling at higher-than-ceiling prices.

The patrons of a motion picture theatre at Thirty-fourth Street and Third Avenue were given an unexpected view of real-life drama Thursday night when a burglary suspect was captured on the fire escape from the balcony after the picture had been stopped and the lights turned on to aid a patrolman in the chase.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 7 -- A Japanese submarine, after torpedoing a freighter off the Indian coast, rammed a lifeboat and raft and machine-gunned helpless British and Indian survivors, it was related today by thirteen survivors of the sinking.

Leo H.
