Hirsch Co., button manufacturers, have purchased the ten-story industrial building at 374-80 Second Avenue and 300-310 East Twenty-second Street, where they have been tenants for twenty-seven years. The building was acquired in the name of the Button Realty Corporation for cash over a mortgage of $267,254 held by the Seamen's Bank for Savings. Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., negotiated the sale. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Comdr. Melvin D. Abbott and Lieut. John R. Gepfert of the Navy have developed a new surface treatment for burns which they say is better than any of the many methods in vogue during the past two years.

After a slow start in which the lead changed hands five times in as many minutes, Long Island University's Blackbirds speeded up their attack and swept to an 84-to-37 triumph over the Fort Totten basketball team at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night.

AN AIR TRANSPORT BASE IN NORTHEAST ASSAM, Jan. 7 -- Within the last few months the Japanese have made three major attempts to disrupt the American air transport line over "the hump" to China. All three have failed.

Property of the estate of J.P. Morgan was sold for $23,535 yesterday afternoon at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc. This was the second session of part one of the auction, comprising furniture and objects of art from Mr. Morgan's residences at 231 Madison Avenue and at Matinicock Point, Glen Cove, L.I.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Reports tracing back to Axis-controlled Zagred said today that the Allies had, landed "in force" in Yugoslavia, but Allied Headquarters in Algiers denied it, and a highly placed British source suggested that all the smoke came from a spark of fact: that for some time small parties of Allied officers and specialists have been going into Yugoslavia to help the Partisans.

MAIMI, Fla., Jan. 7 -- Hialeah Park shattered all its opening-day betting records today as Adulator captured the $6,840 Inaugural Handicap under the handling of Jockey Ted Atkinson, who thereby completed a triple, in the last of the eight races on the program, Atkinson got his. fourth winner aboard Ksar of Audley.

Over and over again the German armies in Russia have made the same military mistake. This is a failure to liquidate defeat before it becomes disaster. The mistake has been repeated in progression from Moscow, Stalingrad, the Caucasus and Kursk to Kiev.

Spirits were running high in northeastern ski ranks yesterday as the results of the recent snow storm, which reached blizzard proportions at many points, were tabulated. Generally speaking, the elements brought six inches of snow to the valleys, and it ranged to more than two feet at the 2,000-foot level, giving needed powder surfaces to runs which hitherto had plenty of base.

An action was brought in Supreme Court yesterday by two members of the Millinery Blockers Union, Local 42, to compel Max Goldman and Mack Gross, individually and as secretary-manager and treasurer, respectively, to account for $900,000 collected as dues in the last nine years.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 7 -- The Newark Evening News, largest daily newspaper in New Jersey, suspended publication today as a result of a dispute with the Newark Typographical Union.

The Oklahoma Natural Gas Company, one of the country's leading independent natural gas concerns, disclosed yesterday plans for a comprehensive refinancing program involving the redemption of its entire debt and preferred stock capital structure.

A deep-furred blue Persian tomcat was judged best-in-show and best-champion-in-show yesterday as the Atlantic Cat Club, Inc., brought to a close its 1944 exhibition at Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street.

New financing in the first week of the new year was limited to a single issue of $9,450,000 of tax-exempt bonds. The offering compared with $3,675,000 for a railroad bond issue last week and $4,336,000 for three small municipal issues in this week a year ago.

Issues on next week's municipal bond calendar amount to $15,499,545, compared with this week's revised total of $59,991,368, according to Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of new municipal financing in 1943 was $15,561,568.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 7 -- The Allied air force has resumed operations over the Aegean Sea area, according to an official announcement today which states that on the night of Jan. 5 six Royal Air Force heavy bombers attacked Rhodes harbor and did a fair amount of damage to port installations.

Mayor La Guardia swore in Dr. Frederic Ernst yesterday for a second six-year term as a member of the board of superintendents of the Board of Education. Dr. Ernst will begin his new term next Wednesday. The post carries an annual salary of $10,000.

Regional Office of Price Administration Director Daniel P. Woolley announced yesterday that the OPA was considering plans to remove eggs from the ceiling list during the present oversupply of the market in the northeast.

MOSCOW, Jan. 7 -- Christmas was celebrated in more than fifty Moscow churches this morning. At Yelokhovskaya Cathedral the patriarch of all Russia, Sergius, officiated and was attended by members of the Holy Synod.

It has been decided to hold the Metropolitan A.A.U. indoor track and field team championships in the Thirteenth Regiment Armory, Sumner and Jefferson Avenues, Brooklyn, on Jan. 22. That announcement was made yesterday by the Metropolitan Association.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Jan. 8 -- The Soviet High Command announced late last night that a new offensive had opened on the Second Ukrainian Front, and that in three days it had resulted in the complete encirclement of Kirovograd in the Upper Dnieper bend and in the annihilation of three German infantry, one tank and one mortar division.

" Monsieur Lambertier," the French play by Louis Verneuil, which was produced here in October, 1928, under the title "Jealousy," has been bought by Warners as the first starring vehicle for Barbara Stanwyck under her recently signed contract.

Beau Jack beat Lulu Costantino last night in ten fast rounds at Madison Square Garden before a gathering of 14,876 persons who paid gross receipts of $43,161 to see the world lightweight champion in a non-title bout against perhaps the fastest man the Georgia Negro has faced.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a series of transactions, including the purchase by the Ohio Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the Cities Service Power and Light Company, of all outstanding common stock of the Marion-Reserve (Ohio) Company for a base cash price of $2,550,000 from the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York.

This is a tale of the Old World and the New that begins in Odessa, Russia, in 1908 when Morris Hertzberg was wed to Ruch Hertzberg by a rabbi. Eleven months later 18-year-old Ruch bore her husband a son, Nathan. Shortly thereafter Hertzberg disappeared from Odessa abandoning his wife and child.

The Publishers Association of New York City voted yesterday to oppose the plan of the War Production Board to stockpile 18,000 tons of Canadian newsprint monthly. A resolution will be sent to WPB following its adoption by the association embodying principal points of objection to the plan which was announced by the WPB on Dec. 21.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- In the first authoritative estimate by any Allied leader of damage caused by the air attacks on Berlin, Gen. Henry H. Arnold, chief of the United States Army Air Forces, said today that 75 per cent of the German capital lies in ruins.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Senator McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, aligned himself today with the defenders of the existing war contracts renegotiation law, declaring that amendments approved by the majority of the Senate Fi-...
BOSTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the Boston wool market tomorrow:

Reflecting the greatly accelerated rate of production of foods for the armed forces, civilian population and the allied nations through the lend-lease program the Cudahy Packing Company reported yesterday in its annual statement for the fiscal year ended with October that net sales and operating revenues were greater than in any former year.

RIVER EDGE, N.J., Jan. 7 -- To make it possible for the Rev. Charles S. Schmidling to follow his three sons and two brothers into the Navy, his wife, Mrs. Edith Jenz Schmidling, will take over next week his ministerial duties, except preaching, at the Grace Lutheran Church here.

Shortly after Mayor La Guardia had announced yesterday that an additional 100,000 tons of central Pennsylvania low volatile bituminous coal was on the way to this city, the Solid Fuels Administration in Washington explained that this was a monthly total of shipments to be continued throughout the coal shortage emergency.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt has recommended the displacement of Rear Admiral Joseph Redman, chief of Navy communications, at the request of Chairman James L. Fly of the FCC because of personal differences between Mr. Fly and the officer, Representative Clarence F. Lea of California asserted tonight.

The Perkin Medal, awarded annually by the American Section of the Society of Chemical Industry for outstanding accomplishments in the field of applied chemistry, was presented last night to Gaston F. DuBois, senior vice president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, St. Louis.

Another important sports governing body is expected to go on record today as to its plans for 1944 when the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association convenes in annual session at the Hotel Vanderbilt at 3 o'clock.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- The stock markets here were quiet today on the last day of an inactive week. The only interesting feature was the industrial group, in which aircraft shares went ahead on news of a jet-propelled airplane.

The highest scoring basketball team in the nation, the quintet representing Rhode Island State, will exhibit its point-making wizardry at Madison Square Garden tonight when it meets the St. John's University five in the feature game of a double-header.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- Some observers said today that they believed the new propeller-less, jet-propelled fighter plane would find its chief immediate value in this war as an interceptor of enemy bombers or as a high-altitude reconnaissance craft.

What is probably the first large exhibition in two decades of etchings by Anders Zorn has just opened at the Harlow Gallery, 42 East Fifty-seventh Street, to remain through the month. It contains 112 prints, most of these particular impressions from the collection formed by the late Nathaniel L. Amster.

Members of the Putnam County Fish and Game Association are going to see What they can do about correcting the pheasant shortage that was pronounced during last season's hunting. Concrete steps toward that direction were taken when the association set aside $250 to help restock covers and the county put up an additional $500.

Seven new medals to be won in competition each year are to be offered by the National Horse Show Association, it was announced at the annual luncheon of that organization yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. President Adrian Van Sinderen, in making the announcement, stated that the awards will be known as the division high score medals.
ALGIERS, Jan. 7 -- The Fifth Army attack on a ten-mile front ground forward slowly toward Cassino Thursday and the Allied air offensive around Cervaro continued despite discouraging weather.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- Union leaders called off the two-day strike of about 3,000 employes of the city's water, highway and street-cleaning bureaus and ordered the workers back to work after reaching an agreement with Mayor Samuel, who said he would make "every effort to effect an increase in wages for the year 1944."

With increased profit-taking and hedging operations offering resistance on the bulges, the cotton market yesterday moved moderately higher for the third consecutive session on the persistence of trade price-fixing and commission house replacement buying.

On land borrowed from the Pima Indians in south central Arizona a strange new city has arisen in the past year and a half. It looks like a cross between an American military camp and an Oriental town. The rows of regulation 100-foot-long barracks do not resemble soldiers' quarters, because they sprout curtains, home-made awnings and odd porches tacked on front and rear.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The liquor industry came under fire from two Government departments today, the Justice Department bringing, every important remaining member of it within the scope of the anti-trust inquiry which it stated two months ago and the Treasury requiring daily instead of monthly reports of wholesale transactions in distilled spirits.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- A Stockholm newspaper caused some excitement today by reporting as from Budapest, Hungary, that "crack Allied troops" had landed on the Yugoslav coast and were bitterly fighting the Germans and their Croat puppet troops.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 7 -- Vanguardia, for fifty years the official organ of the Argentine Socialist movement, voluntarily ceased publication today, asserting that it was impossible for it to continue to appear under the restrictions imposed by the Argentine decree issued Wednesday which robbed the press of whatever remnants of freedom it still enjoyed.

Trial of Count Ciano and other members of the Fascist Grand Council who voted for the ouster of Premier Benito Mussolini last July 25 will begin today in Verona in northern Italy, the Berlin radio said yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

The City Council's committee on rules, at an executive meeting held yesterday at City Hall, recommended Councilman Louis Cohen, Bronx Democrat, for the chairmanship of the finance committee. The recommendation, which will come before the Council for action on Tuesday, is regarded as tantamount to election.

MADRID, Jan. 6 (Delayed) -- A clear though tactfully worded warning to the combatant nations to keep their hands off Spain now that the war is approaching a climax came from Generalissimo Francisco Franco today in a speech to ranking officers of his fighting services.

A delegation front the General Export Association of Sweden and the Association of Swedish Industries is on the way to the United States to consult American exporters and importers on resumption of trade after the war, it was made known yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 7 -- An unusual new method of planting seeds and a device for automatically controlling the volume of loudspeakers, are covered in two more notable patents among the 614 listed as granted in this week's issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

PAIR LAWN, N.J., Jan. 7 -Laban Pittman, 48 years old, of Charlotte, N.C., a civilian employe of an Army air base near Charlotte, arrived here at 10 o'clock this morning to persuade his estranged wife, Mrs. Mazie Pittman, 29, to return to the South with him.

When he became president of the New York Academy of Medicine a year ago Dr. Arthur F. Chace promised that the relation of medicine to the changing social order would be studied. Under the leadership of Dr. Malcolm Goodridge a committee of fourteen fellows of the Academy was soon formed.

SAN VITTORE, Italy, 3 P.M., Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- American infantrymen closed the last three "death pockets" of German resistance here today in the bitterest house to house fight of the Italian campaign. This bloody, ravaged village of San Vittore is ours.

Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions yesterday refused to extend leniency to Mrs. Margaret F. Hind, 32 years old, a registered nurse, and sentenced her to a penitentiary term up to three years for stealing $4,500 in jewelry from the room of a patient who had just died in November, 1942.

The abundance of eggs, the wide availability of meat and the fact that extra stamps have again been granted for the purchase of pork are factors that now combine to eliminate to a great extent the use of dried beans and peas in main dishes.

Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, yesterday urged school children of the nation to make even greater efforts to collect waste paper. In a message issued through headquarters of the United States Victory Waste Paper Campaign -- sponsored by a national newspaper committee -- Dr. Studebaker said the shortage of paper threatens to delay shipment of numerous items to our armed forces.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 7 (UP) -- A southeast Asia Allied Command communique:

Fred C. Moffatt was nominated yesterday for re-election as chairman of the Board of Governors of the New York Curb Exchange. As there now is no paid president, this is tantamount to nomination as acting president. He has held this post since July 1, 1942, when George P. Rea, the institution's first and only paid president, resigned to enter educational work.

BUT not any more. John McDonald, vice president and general manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers' Montreal farm team, has been given the grand heave-ho by Branch Rickey in the longest and most circuitous double-play in baseball history -- from Flatbush to Montreal to the great outdoors. Having disagreed with the Deacon of the Dodgers once this week, this correspondent is going to do it again.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Bolivian revolution appears to have been inspired and aided by pro-Axis forces outside the country, Secretary of State Cordell Hull announced tonight.

Two gifts among the sixty-five received yesterday on behalf of the Neediest Cases Fund were made to carry on the interest of persons who in their own lifetime had contributed regularly to aid the men, women and children in greatest distress in the city known to eight leading private family welfare organizations.

Miss Mercedes Platt, naval attache's receptionist in the United States Embassy in Havana, and Herman Corman, a Washington, D.C., chauffeur, were taken on a 250-mile forced ride from Gravelly Point Airport, Va., to South Brooklyn yesterday by two genial kidnappers.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 7 -- The latest changes in the Vichy Cabinet go further than mere names. They come as a reminder that history ever repeats itself and that today, as in the time of Julius Caesar, Gaul is divided into three parts," the division being accentuated by the prospect of an Allied landing in France.

A wall of official silence on the part of military authorities here and in Washington rebuffed attempts yesterday to get an explanation of the Army's censoring of a press interview of Fredric March to delete the actor's reply to a question about how soldiers abroad felt about strikes at home.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Adoption of a new induction procedure whereby draft board screening examinations will be generally eliminated and Army-Navy physicals will be given to registrants at least twenty-one days before their induction into the armed forces was revealed today by Selective Service headquarters.

Thomas Jefferson High School's quintet gained undisputed possession of first place in Division 1 of the Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League race by downing Brooklyn Tech, with which it has been tied, 36 -- 28, in the loser's gymnasium.

Rabbi Louis Werfel of 490 West 187th Street, 27-year-old chaplain with the Twelfth Air Force Service Command in North Africa, was killed in a plane crash in Algeria on Dec. 24, according to word received here yesterday. Traveling by plane to serve air force men of Jewish faith at outlying points, he became known as "the flying rabbi."

Retail trade here again showed a declining trend this week. Clearances met a mixed response from customers, and the lack of promotional stress in line with the WPB declaration of policy was a factor in the showing. Some large stores here had decreases of as much as 20 per cent for the week, but it was believed that the department store average would show a smaller decline than this figure.

The New York Junior League will present a special showing of Alfred Hitchcock's new motion picture, "Lifeboat," through the courtesy of Twentieth Century-Fox next Thursday night in the Great Hall of the league clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- American factories produced 8,802 planes in December, to make the year's total 85,946, an increase for the year of 80 per cent in numbers and 127 per cent in weight as compared with the figures of 1942.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- American householders who are in the lower income groups and retailers who supply their wants face a problem in the growing scarcity of low-cost apparel and household furnishings, according to Miss Hazel Kyrk, chairman of the Consumers' Advisory Committee of the Office of Price Administration.

ALGIERS, Jan. 7 -- The nearer service men and women are to the fighting fronts, the greater "appears" to be their interest in voting in the next national election, according to an editorial in The Stars and Stripes, which does not run editorials as a routine.

The theft of $28,000 in United States Government bonds, $8,000 of them negotiable, from Allston E. Aveyard of the advertising firm of MacFarland, Aveyard Co., 30 Rockefeller Plaza, was revealed yesterday by detectives of the West Fifty-fourth Street station.

KINGMAN, Ariz., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Twenty-five aviation cadets, a gunnery instructor and their bus driver, an Army private, were killed last night in a collision of an Army bus and a fast Santa Fe freight. It was the worst crash in Arizona history.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- Frederic Bancker Shipley of 1374 Manor Circle, Pelham Manor, N.Y., New York City Tax Commissioner during the administration of Mayor John Purroy Mitchel and head of the Equitable Assessment Association, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital of injuries suffered when struck by an automobile Tuesday night near his home.

Strength in a few selected issues were overbalanced yesterday by sagging tendencies in the industrial groups with the result that the stock market fluctuated irregularly and closed with mixed changes in price. Speculative enthusiasm was shifted from stocks to the major commodities, with the grains the strongest under a broad buying movement.

After a series of conferences, leaders of the right wing of the American Labor party, now in control of its State committee, have decided to reject the plan of Sidney Hillman, chairman of the political committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, to give labor unions, including those dominated by Communists, control of the party's policy.
This is the second article of the New York Designer series.

As its contribution to an effort by Protestants to have a part in establishing international peace, the Methodist Church under the leadership of its Bishops will undertake a nation-wide series of one-day mass meetings in morning, afternoon and evening sessions, starting Monday, at Grace Church, Bangor, Me., and in several other cities.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Jan. 8 (AP) -- A communique:

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 7 (AP) -Willie Hoppe of New York, world three-cushion billiard champion, swept the fifth and sixth blocks of his 1,900-point non-title match with Welker Cochran of San Francisco today, increasing his lead to 30 points.

New Yorkers contributed 50,000 pounds of used clothing to be sent to the liberated areas in Europe during the two-week campaign conducted by the War Production Board and the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, it was announced yesterday by Frank D. March, city salvage director of the WPB-CDVO.

In his second purchase of a Manhattan property in a month, Nat Freedman, Brooklyn operator, has acquired the twelve-story apartment building at 520 West 110th Street from the Bertillon Corporation for cash over a first mortgage of $264,000. Realty Appraisers, Inc., negotiated the sale.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Reporting on the progress of negotiations for Cuba's molasses output, the State Department said today that Cuba had agreed to supply invert molasses equivalent to 800,000 short tons of sugar for the production of industrial alcohol at a price of 2 1/2 cents a pound total sugar content.

Despite the steel and coal strikes which cost the steel industry "several hundred thousand tons" of ingots in June and December, production by the industry set an all-time high of 88,872,598 net tons for the year, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.
Sales of small homes comprised the bulk of the New Jersey trading reported by brokers yesterday. Deals were listed in North Arlington, Fanwood, Jersey City and other centers.

The Women's Army Corps will be the first Government organization to schedule paid advertising in weekly newspapers and in every daily newspaper in the nation when its campaign to bolster recruiting breaks next week in 8,392 publications, published in 5,887 communities.

A survey of a half-dozen important war plants in this area made yesterday shows women workers have made good to such an extent that employers, labor management representatives, personnel directors and superintendents not only are willing to have them continue to work in industry after the war but openly are hoping that women will stay in their jobs.
Gov. Thomas E. Dewey in a message made public yesterday credited Theodore Roosevelt with laying the foundations that have made the United States Navy "the greatest armada in the world."

Selection of Chicago as the place for the next Republican National Convention seemed assured yesterday when Wendell L. Willkie, 1940 nominee for President and an aspirant for another nomination, announced that he had no personal objection to Chicago and was not interested in any particular city.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Minister of Foreign Affairs Jose Tamayo declared tonight that if information which United States Secretary of State Cordell Hull said "increasingly strengthens" the belief that foreign forces had aided the recent Bolivian revolution was made public, the Bolivian Government "will demand concrete and precise proof."

Evidently the astronauts who dreamed of kicking themselves from the earth to Mars were not mad. Their jet propulsion principle is to drive a new air fighter, according to an announcement issued jointly by the United States Army Air Forces and the British Royal Air Force.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 7 -- Three German-born naturalized citizens who were convicted by a Federal jury here on Dec. 7 of conspiracy to violate the Espionage Act of 1917 were sentenced today to serve eight years each in a Federal penitentiary by Judge Thomas F. Meaney.

The first person to be convicted in a Federal court trial here of selling kosher poultry at over-ceiling prices was sentenced yesterday to a four-month jail term, while he and his concern, also convicted, were fined $3,500, to be paid by either. The individual defendant was Louis Lapkin, 38 years old, and the corporate one was the Delancey Pitt Live Poultry Market Corporation, which has wholesale and retail poultry departments at 205 Delancey Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Prospects were seen tonight of an early relaxation of the stringent regulations under which use of iron and steel has been prohibited in the manufacture of more than 1,200 civilian items since May, 1942.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Senator Vandenberg today challenged Frank Walker, Democratic national chairman, to take the initiative in accepting what the Senator called an invitation from Republicans to eliminate the foreign policy issue from the Presidential campaign.

Men's clothing manufacturers must begin work immediately on studies embracing all angles of producing styles and models that will be acceptable to returning service men during the post-war period, with particular emphasis on the gathering of data pertaining to new average standards that will be essential to meet the changed physical appearance of this mass of customers that will be "clothes hungry" when they again enter civilian life.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 8 (U.P.) -- General Vatutin's advances yesterday were scored all along the mushrooming front west and south of Kiev. The drive into Klesov put the Russians within thirteen miles of the rail junction of Sarny, capture of which would virtually split the German armies of Poland in half and force the Nazis to fall back on Brest-Litovsk, 130 miles to the west, for their next big north-south railroad.

ALGIERS, Jan. 7 -- It was authoritatively said here today that, contrary to reports, Henri Etienne Hoppenot, diplomatic representative of the French Committee of National Liberation in Washington, was not coming here at present and that Rene Massigli, French Commissioner of Foreign Affairs, was not going to Washington either on a temporary mission or to replace Mr. Hoppenot, as some members of the committee had hoped a few weeks ago.

NEW DELHI, India Jan. 7 (U.P) -- American fliers have dropped more than 130 tons of bombs on Yenangyaung, important oil center, in an intensification of the aerial offensive against Japanese-occupied Burma, while Chinese troops have forced a crossing of the upper Chindwin River, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Jan. 7 -- An "unspecified number" of bodies and twenty-nine survivors were taken to the naval base here late today by two rescue ships from the scene of the sinking of a Navy patrol vessel after it was in collision with a merchant ship sixty miles southeast of here late last night.

Harcourt, Brace will publish "The Photographs of Abraham Lincoln" on Feb. 10. Frederick Hill Meserve and Carl Sandburg, two widely known Lincoln authorities, have collaborated on the book, which will contain all of the known photographs of Lincoln.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The imposition of virtual economic sanctions against Argentina is believed to have been discussed here today at an Anglo-American conference. The meeting was attended, among others, by Secretary of State Cordell Hull; Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury; Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator; Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, and Ben Smith, chairman of the British Supply Council in North America.

Britain is now far into her fifth year of war and the censorship makes no attempt to interfere with London reporters when they tell us over here that the British people are tired; as resolute and as hard-working as ever, but naturally hoping for the end of the war and the labor and the sacrifices.
ATLANTA, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Gov. Ellis Arnall signed into law today legislation intended to assure to Georgians in the armed service a vote in primary and general elections.

The Caton Operating Corporation has purchased from Lillian Mayer the four-story apartment building on an irregular plot 105.9 by 123.4 feet at 10 Argyle Road, in Brooklyn, subject to a mortgage of $150,000. The brokers were Anthony S. Donado, Jacob Wasserman, I. Salzberg and H. Lipton.

Reports in the New York market that the British Board of Trade would permit practically unlimited exports to this country during the coming year of men's suits, overcoats and topcoats made by English merchant tailors were refuted yesterday by Chauncey Depew Hunter, secretary of the Merchant Tailors and Designers Association of America.

An appeal to the Office of Price Administration will be made by the Infants and Children's Coat Association for relief of those manufacturers whose prices are frozen at low ceiling levels but who cannot obtain fabrics to meet those levels, it was made known yesterday following a meeting of the organization at the Hotel New Yorker.
LONDON, Saturday, Jan 8 -- The Times of London suggested today that Poland would in the long run strengthen her security by offering to make territorial concessions to Russia.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Jan. 8 (U.P.) -- Allied airmen, displaying their complete superiority of the air in the southwest Pacific war theatre, strafed and bombed Japanese shipping, installations and airdromes from the Solomons to New Ireland, New Britain and New Guinea, causing heavy damage in all the attacks, it was announced today.

There cannot be the slightest doubt in the mind of anyone capable of five minutes' sustained objective thought that both strikes and threats of strikes in wartime impede our war effort and aid the enemy. A strike that ties up production ties up supplies to the fighting fronts.

A group of war posters has been placed on view at the Guild Artists Bureau, Inc., 551 Fifth Avenue, where it will remain through Jan. 15. Artists represented are Warren Baumgartner, Dean Cornwell, Peter Helck, Norman Rockwell, Saul Tepper and Earle B. Winslow.

Milton Baron and his associates, Jean Muir and Toni Ward, decided yesterday to close their production of "Listen, Professor!" starring Dudley Digges, after tonight's performance. Produced as a memorial to the late Lem Ward, distinguished stage director, who died in 1942, it opened at the Forrest Theatre on Dec. 22 and will terminate its Broadway career after twenty-one showings.
Our primary concern, simply stated, is to make the coming invasion of Germany as economical as possible by drastically reducing the war potential of the Third Reich and its satellites.

Newtown's undefeated basketball team kept its slate spotless yesterday when it climaxed a five-game schoolboy show at Madison Square Garden by downing Bryant, 44 -- 32, to run its winning streak to nine straight games. The redjerseyed youngsters have won fore of these in the Queens P.S.A.L. North Shore loop.

Trying to explain the recent Japanese defeat in central China, where the Chinese recaptured the key highway junction of Changteh and drove the invaders from most of the "rice bowl" area, a Japanese spokesman was quoted, by the German Transocean News Agency yesterday as asserting that Japan was seeking no further territorial conquests in China.

" THE Two Mrs. Abbotts" is a delightful new novel in the Miss Buncle series. There really are two Mrs. Abbotts in it, but one is Miss Buncle herself. Married to her publisher and mother of two small children, she flutters about her household and the village of Wandlebury in wartime England the same vague and utterly charming Miss Buncle who has entertained many readers who enjoy flighty, gentle and humorous English comedy.

NO phase of vegetable gardening is approached with more trepidation, none is attacked more haphazardly than the planning. Many gardeners just don't bother. Yet the essence of success with a vegetable garden lies in a plan, well thought out in advance.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Sunday, Jan. 9 -- New Zealand fighter pilots' biggest battle over grimly defended Rabaul, in which twelve Zeros were known to have been destroyed and six others probably so, was described in an Air Department statement today.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Dixiana Stable's Amber Light won the $3,000-added Old Hickory Handicap at the Fair Grounds today, sprinting into the lead at the start and staying out front all the way to finish ten lengths ahead of Mrs. J.S. Letellier's Jack S.L.

Although the Federal revenue laws provide that the proceeds of a life insurance policy, upon the death of the insured, whether received "in a single sum or otherwise," are not subject to income tax, such proceeds may become taxable in part under Treasury rulings.
LONDON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Almost everybody intends to own a jeep after the war. But the jeep, it is said, must be toned down before it will be safe for civilians to play with. It is too eager for ordinary use. Like Whoozis in Steinbeck's "Of Mice and Men," it doesn't know how strong it is. . . .

Mayor La Guardia warned yesterday of a "migration" of 1,000,000 unemployed workers to this city in the months immediately after the war. The Mayor was the principal speaker before a regional conference on social welfare and relief problems at the Hotel Roosevelt called by the New York Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation and the Council of State Governments.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Governor William H. Wills of Vermont said tonight that it would mean suicide for the Republican party to allow a handful of bosses to stop the nomination of Wendell Willkie for President at the convention this year.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 8 -- With the Eastern Front situation rapidly deteriorating and threatening disaster to German arms, Adolf Hitler has issued a "die rather than retreat" order of the day to his troops in Russia, said a broadcast heard in Goeteborg and believed to have come from the illegal German radio.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 8 -- Close cooperation between the Argentine and Bolivian Governments, both of which seized power by revolution, was indicated by a decree issued yesterday forbidding twelve persons possessing degrees obtained in the Universidad Mayor San Andres of La Paz, Bolivia, to exercise their professions in Argentina.
MEMPHIS, Jan. 8 -- Asserting that baseball is "too cheap for me," William Harold (Bill) Terry said today that he was quitting the game "for good" to launch a career in the cotton business.

IT'S been a long time since Ethel Waters has raised her voice in song within the stuffy confines of a Broadway care, but come next month and the former torch singer, now regarded as one of the great ladies of the entertainment world, will return to that medium.

MIAMI, Jan. 8 -- Standing a hard drive from the head of the stretch to the finish line, Black Badge, the favorite, hammered out a head victory today in the $6,300 Hialeah Stakes on an afternoon when form horses won one right after the other.

ALGIERS, Jan. 8 -- In a debate whose frankness aroused the misgivings even of resistance leaders here, speakers in the Provisional Consultative Assembly urged today that lend-lease powers be used to send arms to clandestine fighters inside France, who, they complained, have been underestimated and neglected by the Allies.

TRADE swung into the New Year at the reduced pace which has recently characterized it. There is general agreement among merchants that results in the first quarter will fall below those of last year, when sales went soaring on rumors of clothes rationing. Moreover, large stocks

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The War Department has adopted a troop-rotation policy "which should assure" that by mid-1944 all soldiers in Alaska and the Caribbean areas with two years of overseas service will be returned to the United States, Senator Reynolds of North Carolina said today.

DETROIT, Jan. 8 (AP) -- About 100 employes of the Murray Corporation of America who failed to respond to an appeal by the Army Air Forces for emergency work on New Year's Eve and New Year's Day faced disciplinary action today in the form of dismissals, loss of seniority, lay-offs and reprimands.

The opening performance of Sonja Henie's Hollywood Ice Revue on the night of Jan. 18 at Madison Square Garden has been taken over by the Carroll Club of New York to advance its philanthropic work and its program of war activities. Mrs. Basil Harris is president of the club, an organization of Catholic women devoted to charitable and welfare projects.

A two-day program of spaniel competition will be opened this afternoon in the Hotel Roosevelt, where the American Spaniel Club will hold its twenty-seventh specialty show. The hours of the exhibition will be from 1 P.M. to 10 P.M. today and from 9 A.M. to 7:30 P.M. tomorrow.

With seventy-one entries, the "Bulldog" tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association for the benefit of the Red Cross started yesterday at the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street. The competition received its name because of the fact that the Yale Club donated two statues of Handsome Dan, Eli mascot, one to go to the winner and the other to the runner-up.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 8 -- Rear Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, generally credited with drawing the original design of the landing ships for tanks, presented the Army-Navy "E" to the Ambridge plant of the American Bridge Company today as such a vessel was launched and another commissioned.

EVEN its best friends will not be able to say the theatre season to date has been filled with humor. Not that the plays haven't tried their best, for there have been at least an average number of comedies, but humor is something special and most of them have fallen down rather suddenly.

Retail trade here again made an unfavorable showing last week in comparison with 1943, with the decline larger than in the preceding week. Mixed customer response to clearances and observance of the declaration of promotional policy of the WPB were factors in the comparative showing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Simplification of Federal tax laws was stressed as the No. 1 job for the Ways and Means Committee by Chairman Doughton today. He voiced the hope that way could be found to collect through the withholding levy the total tax for some 30,000,000 persons, thus removing necessity of their filing any tax returns.

REPORTS of new snow on an already good base in Vermont and New Hampshire are bringing out the skiers in force. From the Berkshires to Rutland, Vt., the snow is heavy. In and around Pittsfield, ten inches of new powder snow fell last week, with even more reported from Brattleboro and Big Bromley.

Wall Street banking trends, as reflected by the year-end statements of condition of banks published last week, are defined clearly. Most of the banks showed small declines in deposits in the final quarter of 1943, and, consequently, in total resources.

Taking box-lunches to a ball is a war-time conservation measure planned by a committee of this season's debutantes who are assisting with ticket sales and entertainment features of the annual President's birthday party to be held Jan. 29 in the grand ballroom and adjoining suites of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Russia's successive victories on the battlefields have guaranteed that when the war has ended she will be the great power of Europe. "Mistress of the Continent" was the phrase used a few weeks ago by South Africa's Premier, Jan Christiaan Smuts. Her emergence was re-emphasized last week when Soviet troops, pursuing Germans westward in one of their greatest triumphs, crossed the old Polish boundary into territory Russia acquired in 1939 by agreement with Germany.

BY design or happy coincidence, the first new program of 1944 was one which asks performers of some talent but little fame to step up to a microphone and try their respective specialties on the listening public, the show being known as "On Stage Everybody," each Saturday at 11 A.M. on WJZ-Blue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- A vivid description of a nation of women waging a man's war in a man's way came yesterday from Comdr. Victor F. Blakeslee, who has just returned from his post of assistant naval attache at our embassy in Moscow.

In a review of recent work of the Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarrantine (Department of Agriculture), Dr. P.N. Annand gives a leading place to mosquitos that carry yellow fever and malaria. The use of an aerosol bomb containing insecticides under pressure -- which when released atomizes the insect-killing material as a fine mist, deadly to insects but harmless to man -- promptly rids any room, tent, or screened area of pests.
KLAUS MANN and Hermann Kesten have put together an anthology of not quite 1,000 pages of fiction, verse and essay, taken from twenty-one European nations (with Great Britain excluded).

The claim that the University of Santo Domingo in Ciudad Trujillo is the oldest in the Western Hemisphere -- rather than the University of Lima in Peru -- is made in a letter received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES from Manuel A. Amiama, president of the Journalism Institute of Santo Domingo.

ARTUR RODZINSKI celebrated his birthday, which occurred last Sunday, by giving a Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra concert on Monday night for the convalescing service men at the Halloran General Hospital at Willowbrook, S.I.

When the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Dr. Serge Koussevitzky conductor, gave its second concert of the week yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, the impression deepened of the entirely unique quality of the orchestra and the continually growing art of the conductor.

LISTEN, Mac, the war is nothing to dance about, and you can say that again: but what I mean, it sure is something to dance on account of. This man's town never has seen so much strut and swing before, and pretty near half of it is being done by service guys. Gals, of course, do the other half.

THE past cannot be re-enacted except in the language and with the contrasts imposed by the present. The feelings of children, in particular, although intense, are not ordinarily long-lived or deeply rooted. We cry desperately or we silently hate, for not being allowed to do this or have that; but these objects are trifles.
THIS is a novel about very rich and very poor people. It tells what happens when a Los Angeles debutante falls in love with a fellow on WPA.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE SOUTH PACIFIC AIR FORCES, Jan. 4 (Delayed) (AP) -- Maj. Gregory (Pappy) Boyington, top-ranking Marine flier, who was shot down by the Japanese yesterday, was due to complete his Solomons tour of duty in a few days and return to the United States.

Despite the shortage of natural rubber and the continuing shipment of synthetics to the British under lend-lease, Britain appears to be hindering full production of the plantations in India, it was asserted in export circles here last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Canol Project, designed to supply oil to the Alaskan defense forces from the Norman Wells in Canada, should never have been undertaken and should have been abandoned when this fact became apparent, the Truman committee said in a report today.

Encouraged by the response to the current waste-paper salvage campaign, the city's various agencies are preparing to step up the drive this week. Although satisfactory progress has been made, it is being pointed out that there must be no let-up in the conservation of paper.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 8 -- With the Arab Federation discussions between Premier Mustapha Nahas Pasha of Egypt and Premier Riad Solh of Lebanon opening here tomorrow, it was announced today that Patriarch Alexendros of Antioch and Lebanon, holding one of the highest position in the eastern church, would arrive early next week for conferences with the Greek Orthodox Patriarch in Alexandria.
" I HAVE heard a rumor that there is war in the white men's country, and this is my thought: Come, . . . to visit us again at Tepuka, for here in our country there is peace."

CHARLES G. NORRIS' latest novel seems mainly to be about the Rutherfords a San Francisco family of wealthy ship-owners who went through some pretty gruesome years in the Thirties, what with the waterfront strikes and a streak of personal misfortune that amounted almost to a curse.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 8 -- Only in such times as these do people appreciate the full value of minor things taken for granted under normal conditions. For instance, the French today are practically without matches. For a long time they have been without string, wrapping paper, thumb tacks, mucilage, not to mention foodstuffs, textiles, metals -- and tobacco.

OTTAWA, Jan. 8 -- Canada, by special effort, will supply to the United States 200,000 tons of newsprint monthly for the next six months, it is stated here, but the distribution is entirely the affair of the War Production Board in Washington.

The annual meeting of the Citizens Union, held yesterday at a luncheon in the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street, turned into a City Council meeting, with variations. It developed into a forum at which both majority and minority members of the council amiably aired their views on the union's proposed legislative program for the city, chiefly on proportional representation.

THE "Vansittartness" of Noel Coward's ironic little ditty, "Don't Let's Be Beastly to the Germans," is earning cheers in the London music halls -- and its acid mockery is being backed up by several more solemn bits of writing soon to be issued. . . .

The War Shipping Administration announced last week reductions on ocean freight rates between this country and India, Ceylon and the Persian Gulf. The new rates, in either direction, from Atlantic and Gulf ports to India and Ceylon permit only a 25 per cent maximum surcharge on those rates authorized Jan. 30, 1942.

A GOOD book can be enjoyed and a bad book can be ignored, but a novel like Baroness van Boecop's "The King Tree" seems deliberately designed to drive the reading public to drink. It fits no classification. It is serious and it is silly.

THE itinerant portrait painter, journeying from inn to farm to city, with his canvases often ready-painted, except for the face to be filled in on order, was a debonair figure in the new United States. Gayest of them all, surely was Nathaniel Dunton, who really preferred to fiddle but who was mighty proud of that portrait he had dashed off after once seeing George Washington.

We should soon be hearing more about the little town of Kavieng on New Ireland. Seldom mentioned until recently, it has now assumed importance in the South Pacific war news. Since Christmas planes from an American task force have probably sunk five enemy warships and damaged several others trying to enter the port.

Comdr. Harry Manning, USNR, assumed yesterday the post of superintendent of the Maritime Service Training Station at Hoffman Island, New York City, succeeding Comdr. Malcolm E. Crossman, USNR, who had commanded the station since Nov. 15, 1942.

THOSE were the long days, the long hours, when Corsica's citizen army looked seaward, patiently waited. That was the time, seven days after United States troops clambered up the beaches of North Africa. Then the yellow ragpaper tracts were secretly passed hand-to-hand among the faithful, ever watchful of the Germans.

THERE is no doubt we are leaving the Japanese behind in the technique of jungle fighting. Two years ago, when the Japanese swept down through Malaya, advancing rapidly through a supposedly impenetrable maze of vegetation, the world suddenly realized with a profound sense of shock that Hirohito's minions were marvelously trained masters of jungle warfare; probably, at the time, the best jungle fighters in the world.

ALGIERS, Jan. 8 -- A poster campaign to get Allied soldiers to work together behind the lines without basically trivial, but occasionally awkward friction, started ten days ago, it was learned today, and, all the way from Casa Blanca to Constantine, British and American troops are being advised not to be "sligs."

The Police Department showed little enthusiasim yesterday for a suggestion that New York follow other cities that have relaxed regulations to permit "doubling-up" of passengers in taxicabs because of the shortage of gasoline and curtailment of bus lines.

Your editorial of Dec. 30 "To the Poles and the Russians" offers an honest and courageous warning. It has long been needed. Outbidding each other in their rivalry as ultra-orthodox champions of Russia, commentators in a few Eastern cities have developed an extravagant sectarian position.
LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- The Sunday Observer said today that Russia had advanced "definite proposals" to the Polish Government here for a settlement of the frontier question.

Leon Henderson, former director of the Office of Price Administration, will give the opening address at 7:80 P.M. tomorrow at the first session of the annual meeting of the Home Missions Council of North America, at Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

WE are taking off from La Guardia Field in NC 18694, a Tennessee Valley Authority two-engined Lockheed, bound south by way of Washington and Knoxville to the big dam now being built at Gilbertsville, Ky.

SWITZERLAND'S Christmas-time "Pro Juventute" (For Youth) anti-tuberculosis semi-postal series includes one commemorative: 5-centimes plus 5c green with philately's first portrait of Philipp Emanuel von Fallenberg, educationist, who died in 1844 at the age of 73.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Addressing members of the National Republican Club at the Non-Partisan Discussions Forum held in the clubhouse of the organization at 54 West Fortieth Street yesterday, Beardsley Ruml, originator of the pay-as-you-go tax plan and chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, reviewed the nine-point fiscal program which he has advocated as a framework of a program of economic adjustment in the post-war period.
CAIRO, Jan. 8 -- Yugoslav Partisans, driven from Banja Luka, important railway center between Zagreb and Sarajevo, by fresh German tank reserves, are fighting in an adjoining area.

THE Smithsonian Institution has not received Gen. Mark Clark's pants -- the famous ones lost early one October morn, 1942, off Algiers -- and doesn't mind saying so for the record. It might stop the questions coming from visitors ever since certain reports had the well-known britches en route from the Mediterranean to the Mall.

The War Prisoners Aid of the Young Men's Christian Association, 347 Madison Avenue, announced yesterday that at least two and probably many groups of Allied military prisoners of war in Japan have received and are making good use of welfare materials purchased for them in the Far East.

LOWELL THOMAS, a fixture on WJZ and the Blue network for many years, will be changing his base of operations to NBC and WEAF on Jan. 24. The time of his evening commentary will remain the same -- 6:45 to 7 P.M., Monday through Fridays.

Herbert L. Matthews has given such a graphic account of the fighting in Italy in "Road of Mud, Fatigue -- and Glory" in THE TIMES Magazine that only the most callous-hearted can fail to be moved by the extreme hardships of our gallant soldiers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Maximum prices on wheat futures traded on the Chicago Board of Trade were raised 2 cents a bushel late today by the directors of the Exchange. The new ceiling, effective on Monday, will be $1.73 3/8 a bushel.

THE appearance in one season of three books treating Russian literature is a propitious straw in the wind Mr. Cournos. in his introduction, states that his object is the eluciation of the Russian genius and aspiration, of "what it is that gives Russian quality."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 8 -- After an odyssey to Africa and Italy, where he found his missing aviator son and brought him home, Wilbert C. Macdonald of 58 Maple Street, a merchant ship first officer, now is looking for a ship to England to search for another son, reported missing in a flight over Europe, and a third who is in service somewhere in Britain.

The huge amount of copper and copper alloys in various stages of production and manufacture and the large quantities of scrap metal which can be obtained from war material and salvage present a post-war problem for the copper-mining industry, according to A.B. Parsons, secretary of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers.

Early in 1944 enough butadiene to produce nearly one-seventh the entire wartime program of synthetic rubber in the United States will come from a single plant erected by the oil industry at Port Neches, Tex. The first of two units is now almost completed and ready for operation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The record of labor was defended today by Mrs. Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, in her yearly report as one of "effective contribution for the production of record quantities of the implements of war."

THIS is a woman's story -- this tale of Cas Scott whose deep love for her husband gives her the strength to face death with rare courage. The reader is fighting along with Cas from the moment her doctor tells her that she has -- at the most -- only nine months to live.

ALGIERS, Jan. 8 -- The German defenders of San Vittore might have hoped to make the town another Ortona, but, if so, they failed. American units of Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army captured the battered village yesterday and are now engaged in further street fighting in tiny San Giusta, some 1,000 yards to the north.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 8 -- The management of The Newark Evening News and the Newark Typographical Union reached an agreement late this afternoon providing for resumption of publication by the newspaper on Monday after a two-day suspension resulting from a dispute over wages and working conditions.

Retail trade declined last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, although several store sections were active, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer-Both Reports.

THE Trylon and the Perisphere, once the symbols of a great international exposition, play a quite different role in this story. They form the identifying mark by which the ownership of three million do llars' worth of diamonds is to be established.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The revolutionary Government in Bolivia is sending another representative to Washington, although Secretary of State Cordell Hull has indicated that the chances for United States recognition are slim.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Although its contract with Bolivia has expired, the United States will continue to buy tin and other war-vital metals from Bolivia, Finance Minister Gustavo Chacon asserted tonight in a note to miners and producers.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows.

CAIRO, Jan. 7 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The Germans have been pulling their best troops out of Crete in a reshuffling of their Aegean forces to meet growing sabotage and the increasing Allied threat to the Balkans, two members of the Cretan "shadow" army said today.

Local college basketball prestige received a shot in the arm last night at Madison Square Garden, where St. John's University outran, outpassed, outplayed and outscored the highly feared Rams of Rhode Island State before 18,281 persons, the season's biggest turnout.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 9 -- The Russian Second Ukrainian Army captured the railway bastion of Kirovograd yesterday, endangering the entire Nazi position in the Dnieper bend, while the First Army to the northwest widened its spearhead in Poland and other elements reached eleven miles farther toward Rumania.

METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER is planning to transfer a Broadway institution to Hollywood by filming a "Ziegfeld Follies" at regular intervals, probably bi-annually. The first of the screen "Follies," which is scheduled to go before cameras around March 1, will carry a budget of approximately $3,000,000 and set a precedent for unusual pictures inasmuch as it will be presented strictly as a revue, without "story" and minus the atmosphere of the stage.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The driving effort that spurred American merchant shipyards to record production in December all but fulfilled its emergency purpose in the final surge.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Jan. 5 (Delayed) (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, in a message on the first anniversary of the formation of the Fifth Army, told his troops today that "you are the best soldiers in the world" and declared that "we have a rough road to tread, but not one of us will hesitate until lasting peace has been secured."

" THANK God the Red Cross is here," said the commanding officer at the opening party of the first recreational center in Iceland. The reader of "They Sent Me to Iceland" can only echo his words with three cheers that the Red Cross sent Jane Goodell to Iceland and that she has written a book about her experiences.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 8 (AP) -- As Premier Stalin's Ukrainian armies drove with unabated speed today toward Rumania's Dniester frontier, now little more than sixty miles ahead of the Soviet advance guards, Germany's Balkan satellites were reported frantically looking for an "out" and preparing for the worst.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (Reuter) -- The British, French, Swedish, Portuguese and Finnish Embassy buildings in Berlin have "disappeared" in the Royal Air Force attacks on the German capital, said an authentic report received today from a correspondent in Continental Europe.

NAVIGATION is one of our oldest arts and sciences. In the ancient world the Phoenician and Arabian voyagers found that the heavens "day unto day uttereth speech and night unto night sheweth knowledge." The Polynesians explored and settled the Pacific without hearing so much as a rumor of charts and almanacs, sextants and compasses.

The War Manpower Commission and representatives of industry joined yesterday to stress again the immediate need for thousands of additional workers in war plants in the metropolitan area despite widespread rumors of lay-offs and reports that applicants, including discharged service men, were being turned down when they sought jobs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Depending on the point of view, the return of prohibition loomed as a threat or a promise to most Americans this week as a House Judiciary subcommittee announced it would hold a hearing this coming Thursday on the bill, introduced by Representative Bryson, Democrat, of South Carolina, calling for national prohibition legislation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- One of the big problems just now coming fully into the public consciousness is what should be done to aid in rehabilitating and re-establishing in private life the 11,000,000 or more veterans the war is expected to produce.

Inroads of the military draft upon the operating forces of the city's unified transit lines have become so serious that Col. Arthur V. McDermott, director of Selective Service for New York City, has asked all local boards to give "the most serious consideration" to requests of the Board of Transportation for deferment of its employes, it was disclosed yesterday.

THE ban on recording caused by the deadlock between the Musicians Union and the recording companies was in force for most of the producers through 1943 and for several through most of the year. The result was that 1943 saw the release of fewer new albums than in any year since the industry grew up.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- With the question of the invasion of Western Europe and the amount of manpower such a venture will require now in the limelight, there is some discussion here as to whether the Allies have sufficient trained infantry divisions on hand to launch an assault on the large scale that will be required.

AT A UNITED STATES ARMY BASE IN THE PACIFIC, Jan. 8 -- Veterans of the Makin battle reported here today that the last Japanese left alive on the atoll was taken prisoner Dec. 13. It is be lieved he was the last man of the Imperial Navy garrison in all the Gilberts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Former Senator Robert Latham Owen of Oklahoma has created a global alphabet to simplify international communication and has presented it to President Roosevelt for consideration.

As the local office of the Solid Fuels Administration reported yesterday that additional shipments of soft coal should arrive here early this week to help ease the acute coal shortage. Brig. Gen. Bryce P. Disque, retired, president of the Coal Consumers Protective Committee, warned that the public should not be misled into believing any "material increase" in the coal supply is in prospect.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Maury Maverick, ex-Mayor of San Antonio and ex-Representative from Texas, was today appointed vice chairman of the War Production Board in charge of the Smaller War Plants Corporation.

ALGIERS, Jan. 6 -- America has its Waves, Britain its Wrens -- and France its Service Feminin de la Flotte. No one has yet figured out a way to abbreviate that into a cute one-syllable word, but the members of the four-month-old service are too busy to mind.

MADRID, Jan. 8 (AP) -- A neutral engineer who has just returned from Germany after having completed a work contract said today that the Hitler Youth, "arrogant with new police power given it because of a manpower shortage," had created a reign of terror in Germany.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Early British recognition of the revolutionary Government of Bolivia is improbable, and certainly any action would be taken only after full consultation with the United States, it is believed in London.

The Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation will hold its twentieth annual series of auditions for pianists, violinists, 'cellists and singers this spring. The auditions are open to artists between the ages of 16 and 30 who are ready for a professional career but have not been heard in a New York recital reviewed by critics.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 -- In the over-all strategy worked out for Japan's defeat, air power has the leading role, America's rapidly growing aircraft carrier strength will be "approximately double" in the next few months, our carrier offensive is finally under way in the Pacific and "nothing can stop it," high Army and Navy officials told the West Coast today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 8 -- To assay properly the role that the Service of Supply is playing in the war in Russia it must be remembered that it is serving one of the longest fronts in the history of modern war, stretching more than 1,000 miles from Leningrad to the Black Sea.

Offhand I should say that no American economist today has the reputation here that is enjoyed by two distinguished English economists, Sir William Beveridge and Lord Keynes. Perhaps this is as it should be, but my confidence in their value to us as advisers has been somewhat shaken by two statements of theirs which I have recently come upon.

IF the full story of England at war, or at least the phases thereof that have been documented on celluloid, is not brought to the attention of the American public, the blame will not rest with the film division of the British Information Services, which operates out of 30 Rockefeller Plaza under the direction of George Archibald and his assistant, Thomas Baird.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Bobby Jones, who is almost as well known here for his golfing triumphs as he is at home, returned to Britain about a week ago as a major handling intelligence work with a fighter wing of the United States Army Air Forces.

In the six months ended on Nov. 30, 1943, the Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $3,605,684, including dividends of $400,000 from an associated company, according to a report issued yesterday. This was equivalent to $2.75 a share on the outstanding common stock.

A flood of resignations by business and professional men from emergency service with Government departments is expected momentarily, industry executives declared yesterday, because of a Senate decision to strike from the pending revenue bill the exemption clause inserted by the House to liberalize for temporary and intermittent employes the immunity from prosecution for unintentional violation of outmoded criminal statutes.

Successful with its holiday presentation of juvenile entertainment, the Children's Theatre of the New School for Social Research yesterday afternoon gave a performance of Stanley Kauffman's fantasy, "Bobino," before an approbative audience of youngsters and their guardians.

THE ever-increasing wood and metal shortage has brought new prestige to old furniture. Battered rocking chairs and washstands, venerable horsehair sofas and late Victorian commodes are being ferreted out of dusty attics and refurbished for sale in several of Manhattan's smartest department stores.

Led by Bob Faught, formerly of Notre Dame, and John Unites, once a Duquesne star, the Columbia University Midshipmen's Naval Reserve School basketball team last night snapped the winning streak of the Mitchel Field five at the New York A.C., winning a hard-fought game with a sustained offensive through the closing minutes, 46 to 42.

THERE came a report one day that four women who are actresses and appearing in the same play were pals. In the tempestuous land of the theatre temperament reigns and jealousy and resentment form part of the artistic tradition.

Wendell L. Willkie, speaking at yesterday afternoon's Metropolitan Opera Victory Rally over the Blue Network, declared that while the conferences at Moscow, Cairo and Teheran established effective military coordination and cooperation of the United Nations, they had not yet produced sufficient political, economic and moral understandings.

LONDON -- Red Army triumphs in the Dnieper Bend are more than immediate military victories. They constitute a far-reaching threat to Germany's supply of manganese -- the essential yeast in the production of steel. We live in an age of tailor-made alloy steels to meet the strains to which the modern weapons of war are exposed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The War Manpower Commission today announced the addition of a number of items of infants' and children's wear to those already appearing in the commission's list of essential activities. This was done, WMC said, to conform to a War Production Board plan by which WPB assumes the availability of materials for manufacturing such clothing to establishments agreeing to produce a specified quantity during a specified period.

The former chief clerk of a Manhattan Selective Service board and his assistant were each held in 1,000 bail yesterday for a hearing next Monday following their arrest by Federal agents on charges that they conspired to prevent the induction of a wealthy restaurant owners, who was also arrested and held in bail for alleged violation of the draft law.

GOOD sense is a bitter burden for a 10-year-old to carry. But perhaps, thought Kate that first morning of her new life with Mr. and Mrs. Tuttle, it was all she had a right to expect "People with red hair and freckles couldn't expect very much.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- An overwhelming majority of the member bodies of the United States Chamber of Commerce favor an international organization after the war with power to enforce its decrees.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The alternative to the Four-Power Agreement reached by the Foreign Ministers at Moscow in October would have been "the dread certainty of a third World War," James C. Dunn, political adviser on European affairs to Secretary Hull, said tonight at the opening of the broadcast series entitled "The State Department Speaks."

MONTREAL, Jan. 8 -- The Montreal Canadiens held their 11-point lead at the top of the National Hockey League standing by trouncing the virtually defenseless New York Rangers, 8 -- 2, tonight for their eighth victory in a row.

ALGIERS, Jan. 8 -- Flying Fortresses of the Fifteenth United States Air Force carried the Mediterranean air offensive yesterday to a point twelve miles south of the Austrian border and forty miles west of the Hungarian border.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 9 -- Small formations of British bombers flew out across the English Channel last night, suggesting that the Royal Air Force's Mosquito planes might be attacking special targets on the Continent.

TORONTO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Subjecting Goalie Bert Gardiner to a withering fire throughout, the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight routed the Boston Bruins, 12 -- 3, to pull two points ahead of their beaten rivals in the battle for the National Hockey League's second place.

JAMIE'S position in life was as enviable as any boy could possibly imagine. Not only was his father a fireman who had two fire engines (you may remember January and February in "Jamie and the Fire Engine"), but his uncle who lived across the street was in the trucking business.

MOSCOW, Jan. 8 -- A Yugoslav volunteer unit composed of officers and men who escaped from enemy prison camps and of persons of Yugoslav origin residing in Russia has been formed here, it was announced in Red Star, the army newspaper, today.

Last week the United States Army Air Forces and the British Royal Air Force jointly announced that a new type of fighter aircraft driven on the rocket principle was about to be produced. "Jet propulsion" was substituted for the more familiar term "rocket." What we have is primarily a British development, for which credit goes to Group Capt. Frank Whittle, a 36-year-old RAF officer whose first rocket engine ran successfully in 1937.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- A fully armed Slovak force of 2,140, sent into southern Russia by the Germans, recently eluded the Nazis and joined the Red Army, swelling the number of nationals of German-subjugated countries now fighting under the Hammer and Sickle, the Czech Press Bureau said today.

Col. Frederick E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad and regional director, Eastern region of the War Department Operation of Railroads, expressed himself yesterday as encouraged by the progress being made in signing up 5,000 emergency workers to clear the congestion on New York and New Jersey railroad piers.

TODAY there are certain primitive tribes of the Himalayas, Miss Lucas tells us, who center their villages about a fruit tree. An eminently sensible idea and a picturesque one, which emphasizes the thousands of years of care, experimentation and dissemination which today literally bear fruit to the corner grocery store and peddler's cart.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 -- Sammy Byrd, one-time outfielder for the New York Yankees, continued to lead the field today in the $12,500 Los Angeles open golf championship.

THE scene is an English country house, but most of the characters are American. Among them is Pat Abbott and his wife, the former Jean Holly. Pat, formerly a private detective, is now a United States Marine and is reluctant to undertake any sleuthing -- but you know how it is in crime fiction.

A history of man could be written in terms of his ability to provide himself light. No chapter in that history would be more revealing than the story of the service of the humble kerosene lantern. Down through long centuries man has used a lantern. We do not know when he first learned to submerge part of a wick in animal oil and obtain light from the other end.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The health of the average child in Britain has improved "beyond the slightest doubt," according to Dr. Geoffrey Bourne, a research fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons and the Royal College of Physicians.

Military authorities in charge of the prisoner-of-war camps in the United States are conscientiously observing the Geneva Convention for the treatment of prisoners of war, Dr. William B. Lipphard declared last night at a meeting of the New York Schoolmasters Clubs at the Hotel McAlpin.

IN the few days that Station WJZ has been on the air from its new location at Lodi, N.J., a deluge of mail -- highly appreciative -- has flooded the Blue network offices. Listeners have written from Ottawa, Canada; Brattleboro, Vt.; Keene, N.H.; Pittsburgh, New Cumberland and Atlantic City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- President Roosevelt offered today to the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, the Order of Railway Conductors and the Switchmen's Union of America the same wage adjustment he had awarded by arbitration to the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 8 -- Paul Walker, Gordy Davis and Bill Knapp split 50 points among them tonight as the Eli basketball team came from behind in the second half to defeat Princeton in a keen battle, 55 to 51.

IF at first sight the Russians at war seem to be a people who allow themselves few smiles, closer contact with them reveals a very different picture, contrasting with the austerity of the press, radio and stage. The reason for the apparent contradiction is not hard to find.

THE growing interest of Americans in Russia and its people, as well as in the feats of the victorious Red Army, has been reflected in the steadily increasing demand from clubs, schools and other study groups for Soviet film products of both a historical and contemporary nature.

GERMICIDES and fungicides, used by the United States Army to make military fabrics antiseptic and to stop the growth of bacteria and fungi on them, have been found to make exceptionally satisfactory agricultural sprays.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The revolutionary junta which has seized power in Bolivia appears to be facing the definite prospect of a refusal of recognition by the United States and the other eighteen anti-Axis American republics represented on the Inter-American Advisory Committee for Political Defense of the Western Hemisphere at Montevideo.

ALL the books on Jesus have not yet been written; here is yet one more to attest the eternally vibrant quality of the personality of the Founder of Christianity. Though Dr. Lowrie is a theologian and a scholar who has written a host of books for other theologians and scholars, he has written this short Life for the benefit of the larger public.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8 -- Governor Warren announced today that he would permit his name to be entered in the May primary as a Republican candidate for President.

BOSTON, Jan. 8 -- A recommendation that industry prepare for post-war selling by "thinking -- and acting -- now to bring about the reconversion of sales personalities, as well as the reconversion of plants," was made today by David R. Osborne, president of the National Society of Sales Training Executives and training director of Studebaker Corporation, South Bend, Ind.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- The 167th session of the State Legislature which opened this week has one thing in common with the 155th session held in 1932, that is, a leading Presidential possibility occupies the gubernatorial chair. There, however, the parallel ends.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Driving inland from Borgen Bay, New Britain, in the face of Japanese machine-gun fire, marine jungle fighters have slain 200 enemy troops and reached Hill No. 660, a good artillery observation post, headquarters reported today.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will open to the public on Wednesday an exhibition of the Abbott Collection of Naval Aviation Paintings, comprising 101 pictures portraying the training and action in combat of Navy fliers and crewmen.

Further reductions in retail prices of eggs this week were forecast by Daniel P. Woolley, director of the Regional Office of Price Administration, when he signed yesterday an order effective Tuesday removing eggs from community ceiling lists and again placing egg pricing in the New York metropolitan area under Maximum Price Regulations 422 and 423.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Jan. 8 -- The bodies of thirty men who died in the collision Thursday night between the Navy patrol ship St. Augustine and a merchant vessel have been identified, Lieut. Daniel Bergen of the Fourth Naval District Public Relations said here tonight. Thirty survivors are hospitalized here.
