MOSCOW, Jan. 8 -- While Gen. Ivan S. Koneff's main forces were capturing Kirovograd, other Red Army elements this morning were reported developing a drive toward the south and shearing through an elaborate system of minor roads between Krivoi Rog and Novoukrainka.

DONNA FOX is at last beginning to suspect that Bill McShane got the better of the deal. They met the other day and never bothered to say hello. Instead, there was a two-ply accusatory greeting: "Hey, have you kept up the payment of the insurance premiums?" Each assured the other that he had.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 8 -- A small but aggressive Columbia five stayed within striking range of heavily favored Dartmouth for more than thirty minutes tonight, but the Indians had too much power and gained their fourth straight Eastern Intercollegiate League victory, 51 -- 40.

Faced with a further 15 per cent cut in paper, textbook publishers are now concerned with its effect on school texts and materials. When a 10 per cent reduction was ordered last year, the publishers absorbed it to a large extent through mechanical savings. They may not be able to absorb so much of the additional cut.

A DNB broadcast reported yesterday that the main Krupp works of the Essen Combine, Germany's biggest industrial and war-production trust, had been dissolved as a corporation by its directors and again turned into a privately owned firm headed by Alfred Krupp von Bohlen and Halbach.

SO many Long Island oysters and oystermen have gone to war that fewer and fewer bivalve mollusks of the genus Ostrea (or family Ostreidae) are to be found these days in succulent stews. The oyster beds are crowded but there is a manpower shortage and many oyster boats are spending the R-months fast to their wharves for lack of crews.

A regional conference of the National Victory Garden Institute, in cooperation with the Greater New York Victory Garden Council, will be held at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel on Jan. 13 and 14, starting at 10 A.M. each day.

OVER the holidays I have been reading again in that fine autobiography of John Buchan (Lord Tweedsmuir), published three years ago as "Pilgrim's Way." It is, in my estimation, one of the most rewarding books of its kind to be published during recent years. It skillfully avoids all the pitfalls which commonly beset the path of the autobiographer.

" DRINK TO ME ONLY" by Ethel Hueston starts out as a straight novel about a dipsomaniac and ends as a mystery yarn. Whatever its virtues on either score, the result suffers from this division of techniques.

Mrs. Read is the author of "Robert Henri," in the American Artist Series, and "Casper David Friedrich, German Romanticist."

Greater selectivity in purchasing is adding to the already difficult conditions surrounding the purchase of spring goods, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

WHEN, in January or February, one feels starved for the sight of lush, active green growth, a vine from the sweet potato -- or yam, if you prefer to call it that -- is an easy and rewarding thing to start. It will be difficult to find greater decorative value in any other kind of trailing green.

Accelerated hedge selling and week-end profit-taking in late dealings yesterday brought a halt to the sharp advances of the previous three sessions on the New York Cotton Exchange. After an early display of moderate strength on trade price-fixing and commission-house buying, active futures contracts closed near the day's lowest levels and 4 to 8 points below Friday's final quotations.

THE year recently ended introduced to philately the portraits or figures of fifty-six persons never before pictured in the hobby's expanding gallery. This is the smallest number of newcomers within the past decade or so.

Cartridges of .50 caliber are now packed sixty to a carton and four cartons to a load in a wooden shipping box. The top of each carton is sealed and then given two wax baths. After the second immersion khaki belts are put around the individual containers so that they can be placed into the tightly packed box and removed without damaging the carton or its contents.

Although stocks yesterday drifted narrowly and closed mixed, they ended the first week of 1944 at about the best levels in two months. Bonds, which enjoyed the heaviest weekly dealings since mid-May, were at the best levels since early 1937.

MANY a bridge hand contains one "vital" suit, in which declarer must manage to win a certain number of tricks if his contract is to be made. A great part of the repertoire of the skillful declarer is his knowledge of the various suit combinations and of the proper technique in handling them to get the maximum number of tricks.

MOSCOW, Jan. 8 (U.P.) -- Great columns of Soviet reserves plunging westward on the Novograd-Volynski front of the western Ukraine raced against each other tonight for front position among the motorized infantry, tanks, tractor-drawn artillery and self-propelled guns that are seeking to bring the fleeing Germans to bay.

HOOD RIVER, Ore., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Voters of the Hood River People's Utility District, with a population of 8,000 persons, defeated yesterday a proposed $175,000,000 revenue bond issue to finance the greatest public power venture in the Pacific Northwest's history.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Do the spectators at national political conventions, the local preferences for candidates which the galleries may or may not truly reflect, or the contents of powerful local newspapers ever vitally influence the choice of candidates by the conventions?

For the duration the college fraternities, long an accepted part of the American campus, have been eclipsed. Because of the drop in civilian enrollment, virtually all colleges and universities have had to curtail the activities of their fraternities and in many instances to stop them entirely.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- A smaller, scrappier University of Pennsylvania basketball team played Cornell off its feet for better than a half tonight, but had its hands full thereafter and barely managed to gain a 51-50 decision that virtually eliminated the Red from the Eastern Intercollegiate League race. The victors led by 23 -- 17 at the half.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The German Transocean news service -- perhaps with premeditated guile -- frankly broadcast an acknowledgment that "the battle for decision in the East is now under way" and said "there could be no doubt that the decision of the European war would be on the Eastern Front."

Gloria Greene, 13-year-old pianist, made her New York debut last night at Town Hall before an appreciative and much-impressed audience. The little girl, who is a pupil of Ethel Leginska, pianist and conductor, played an extraordinary program in consideration of her age.

LIEUTENANT DONAHUE was the first American to see action with the RAF. He fought through the Battle of Britain, and told the story of his adventures in a rousing book called, "Tally-Ho! Yankee in a Spitfire."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The new ration token plan which will become effective on Feb. 27 will enable the housewife to buy about the same amount of rationed processed foods, meats and fats as she is now buying, the Office of Price Administration made known today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 8 -- The Royal Air Force attack on Stettin early Thursday morning was so devastating that harbor operations at the German Baltic port were knocked out, said first-hand reports here today.

A dinner in tribute to Princess Juliana of the Netherlands, at which Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be guest of honor, will be given by the Netherland-American Foundation tomorrow in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE title of Mr. George Price's latest collections of cartoons, "Who's in Charge Here?" is a purely rhetorical question. In that department of the artist's mind where he assembles his quiet nightmares -- zanies, harpies, demented satyrs and paranoid animals -- Mr. Price is very much in command. Someone has to be. This assurance may steady you as you settle down to enjoying his tender little studies of human nature, done in prussic acid.

The Eastern Lawn Tennis Association took its place yesterday among the sports governing bodies to go on record in favor of as full a program of competition in 1944 as war conditions permit and justify.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 8 -- Until 2 P.M. today, Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha had not received the Bolivian agent who is here to approach the Brazilian Government on recognition but who, apparently, has no diplomatic standing. Thus his conversations will be unofficial.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- A uniform contract-termination clause for fixed-price war contracts which allows full payment at contract price for all articles completed by the contractor on termination date, and limits the profit on articles begun but not completed to 6 per cent, was made public and effective today by James F. Byrnes, War Mobilization Director.

MARTHA GRAHAM will give her second performance of the season tonight at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, repeating the program of two weeks ago. She is also apparently repeating the box office program as well, for when the seats went on sale on Monday at the theatre there were only a handful left, the bulk of the house having been sold by mail order immediately after the announcement of the event.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The text of the Uniform Article for the Termination of Government Fixed-Price War Supply Contracts which James F. Byrnes ordered immediately effective today is as follows:

TAKE a career woman in an emotional turmoil, drop her into the lush, disturbing atmosphere of Baja California and a reader can expect plenty to happen. It does -- and in as melodramatic a series of adventures as you'll find this side of a Class B picture.

RIO DE JANEIRO RECENTLY the Center for Folklore Research was founded in Rio de Janeiro. This new department, attached to the National School of Music at the University of Brazil, came into being on the initiative of Luiz Heitor Correa de Azevedo, Professor for Folklore at the School of Music, who, during 1941-42, had spent several months in the United States.

TRENDS in beauty -- like trends in frocks, food and even locomotion -- are showing the effects of war. The hair above and about the "fashionable face" of 1944 will be dressed in a different style, the powder that veils it will have another tone, and the make-up that accents it will be applied in a novel manner.

NAVY FIGHTER SQUADRON NO. 10 had its genesis in the Battle of the Coral Sea, the first great engagement among carriers. Six of the men around whom it was built saw action there. It fought as a unit in another of the four major carrier battles of the war against Japan.

When the invasion rolls over the beaches of Western Europe in the final effort to crush Germany, it will be the grimy and dogged infantry who will carry the responsibility of meeting the blast of war and charging through it to victory. On the courage, determination and skill of these men rests the fate of that awful action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (U.P.) -- Operation of the 1,476-mile "Little Inch" pipeline, which was scheduled to start carrying gasoline and fuel oil to the East Dec. 1, has been delayed at least two months by a series of sixty to seventy breaks in the pipe, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- President Roosevelt is expected to recommend adoption of a National Service Act in his annual State of the Union message to Congress next week, the unofficial but authoritative Army and Navy Journal said today.

THERE would be more contentment for all concerned if a child could be accepted and loved for what he is instead of for what parents would like him to be. It is not every parent who can bridge this gap, and in a recent address Sidonie Matsner Gruenberg reviewed some of the reasons why.
MOSCOW, Jan. 8 -- The Russian drive into territory that was part of the Polish State between the Treaty of Riga in 1921 and 1939 caused no excitement here comparable with the flurry noticed abroad.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 8 -- City College tonight gained revenge for a 66-61 early season defeat by Brown, downing the Bruins, 62 -- 51. Sid Trubowitz, the Beaver sharpshooter, made 19 points to lead the attack.

Despite the increase of war-related activities many aspects of normal college life were maintained at Duke University during 1943, a review of the year reveals. Students in sailor uniforms edited the campus papers and magazines, and the glee club not only survived but turned out good harmony in a mixture of uniforms and civies.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 8 -- The world champion Yankees moved into this famed resort today, and, while the movement was only a temporary maneuver, it developed practically from the start as an unqualified success.

Capt. Maurice M. Witherspoon, chaplain of the Third Naval District, a hero of the Aleutians; Sgt. Barney Ross United States Marine Corps, former lightweight champion and a hero of the southern Pacific jungle fighting, and MacKinlay Kantor, the writer, will speak at a breakfast opening the 1944 campaign for $500,000 of Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, in the Waldorf-Astoria-Wednesday at 8 A.M., it was announced yesterday by Gerald F. Beal, campaign chairman.

VICTORY gardens take first place in our accelerated plantings in 1944, and flower novelties from seed are noticeably fewer, a situation that will continue for the duration. The All-America Seed Selections, however, have become an annual event.

MEXICO D.F. -- Bright, sophisticated, unbelievably relaxed and free, wartime Mexico lies in its magic circle of mountains, a shimmering island of unreality in a world elsewhere almost too painful to bear. Mexico has become the Riviera, the Lido, the Waikiki, the Biarritz of America; the playground of escape for the lucky, the symbol of plenty and leisure and peace for the war-bound and sedentary.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Predicting that the Republican party would elect "anybody" it would nominate, National Chairman Harrison E. Spangler today called the Presidential campaign an "essential" war activity.

Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade declared yesterday that a broad cultural program to combat racial and religious intolerance is in force in the city's schools, encompassing virtually all known, successful methods.

THERE are several persons who find the corpse inconvenient and who try to dispose of it without attracting attention to themselves. It does not seem possible that all of these have guilty knowledge of the murder, but at least three give that impression.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The American Legion, with some strong Congressional support, put forth today a broad legislative program to assure to the veterans of this war sufficient Federal financial aid to bridge the gap between military and civilian life.

This month's meeting of the New Canaan (Conn.) Garden Club will be held tomorrow afternoon in the small ballroom of the Colony Club through the courtesy of Mrs. Edward Boies and Mrs. David A. Reed. Rutherford Platt will give an illustrated talk on insects and plants.

Chick Wergeles, who acts as manager of Beau Jack, world lightweight champion, must appear before the State Athletic Commission on Tuesday to explain a number of things as an aftermath of the ten-round, non-title fight last Friday night in Madison Square Garden in which the titleholder gained a close decision over Lulu Costantino, East Side challenger.

HAWAII, Pearl Harbor, 7.52 megacycles, Sunday 9 to 9:15 A.M., with news of Pacific battle progress. SWEDEN, Stockholm, 15.155 megacycles, daily, 11 A.M., with English preview and Swedish news of Norway at 11:05 A.M.

AFTER the severe and prolonged cold of last winter few gardeners will question the advisability of some sort of protection for plants of doubtful hardiness. Last year many perennials were killed which had proven hardy under ordinary winter conditions.

Washington last week was awaiting the return of Congress, which reconvenes tomorrow. For three weeks the Capitol had been as deserted as camp-meeting grounds in December. Newspaper men, wandering through the corridors, swore the only friendly faces they saw were on the statues.

HAVING reached the age where it is imperative (she says) to talk about herself. Louella O. Parsons, the veteran Hearst movie gossip columnist, has punched out a two-finger autobiography called "The Gay Illiterate."
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- This mammoth winter sports playground officially launched its snow and ice season today under conditions that might be described as fair to good.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Stan Matthews, international star for England, playing today for his peacetime club for the first time in three years, scored three goals as Stoke City defeated Aston Villa, 6 -- 3, in a featured game of the English League Cup qualifying competition.

THE old Theobald mansion at Eastlawn houses Mrs. Nellie Winter, her son Orrin and the latter's wife, Marta, plus the usual complement of servants. It houses also disunity, suspicion and mystery even before murder is committed within its walls.

While endorsing the intent of the War Production Board's program to stockpile secondary aluminum ingots through purchases by the Metals Reserve Company, secondary smelters yesterday declared present buying methods inadequate to prevent the market price of the alloys from dropping or keep smelters active.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow radio to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

After eighty-five years of service on the lyric stage Gounod's "Faust" remains so powerful a drawing card with the general public that the entire house was sold out by noon of the first day tickets were made available for last night's initial performance of the work this season at the Metropolitan.

The Supreme Court of the United States will be asked to decide tomorrow whether insurance is commerce. For seventy-five years it has ruled that it is not. Because the Department of Justice obtained an indictment against certain fire insurance companies for alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act -- conspiracy to restrain and monopolize commerce in fire insurance -- the court will hear arguments on the case tomorrow.
LONDON, Jan. 8 (Reuter) -- Results of football games played today in the British Isles:

CLAUDEL, once France's Ambassador to the United States, writes in a mood as remote from the cosmopolitan life of the diplomatic corps as could be well imagined. The series of lyrics now presented in a beautiful edition which prints the French originals and the English renderings side by side has to do with the liturgical feasts of the Catholic Church.

Leaders in public life, business, labor, church and educational organizations are joining in support of the proposal for the establishment of an International Office for Education. We feel that no peace program will be complete which fails to place education on a parity with political organization, police, distribution of raw materials, the stabilization of currencies and raising of standards of health.
The day may be not far distant when a woman may choose the color of her dress from the plant as the result of work done by the Russians and the Delta Experimental Station of Mississippi.

JOCOSELY amusing animal forms, by Kisa Beeck, are an attraction at the Argent Gallery. The artist has been working at the Mare Island Navy Hospital, demonstrating methods for wounded service men and drawing in color on sheets of newspaper to supplement the animal pieces.

A PSYCHOLOGICAL novelist could hardly find a more difficult or challenging story than that contained in the short, spectacular and bitter life of Edgar Allan Poe. Chancellor Williams in "The Raven" takes up the challenge eagerly.

Marine circles are watching with considerable interest the progress of the United Fruit Company's experimental installation of multiple Diesel engines in the steamer La Playa, one of the line's ships in the Central American service, according to an announcement made here last week by the Cleveland Diesel Engine division of General Motors Corporation, manufacturers of the motors.

A pair of shiny, black riding boots proved the undoing yesterday of two youthful desperadoes whose one-and-a-half-day outburst of lawlessness included two hold-up-kidnappings and a mad ride through a half-dozen States.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The tempo of preparations for the defense of western Europe is mounting swiftly. The coastal defense forces of forty to forty-five German divisions now concentrated in France and the Low Countries are being brought up to full strength. New equipment, including improved Mark III tanks, multiple-barreled rocket guns and thousands of Teller mines, has recently been moved into the areas where the enemy expects the invasion thrusts.

THE contribution which each of the United Nations is pledged to make toward common victory is set forth clearly in the Declaration of United Nations: "Each Government pledges itself to employ its full resources, military or economic, against those members of the Tripartite Pact and its adherents with which such Government is at war."

Lumber production continued to decline more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index dropped to 109.2, compared with 121.0 in the previous week. The figure for the week ended Jan. 2, 1942, was 101.9.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Seventy-eighth "Victory" Congress comes back for its second, or election year, session on Monday, with advance signs indicating little if any change of mood having set in during the nineteen-day holiday period.

AT the age of 80 Mr. Santayana is beginning his greatest book, his autobiography. It will run into many volumes, one hopes. At the moment it ends with his student days at Harvard, and the last line reads "The curtain drops here, to rise presently on other scenes."

HENRY GAMADGE is an amateur detective in the true sense of that term; he loves mysteries and solves them without hope of reward. In the case with which this story deals he does not, in the beginning, know what he is expected to investigate nor by whom he is employed.

The whole country shares with its only living ex-President the heavy loss which he has suffered in the death of Mrs. Hoover. Here was a kind and lovely lady, of broad interests and scholarly tastes and accomplishments, who won for herself the well-deserved respect and affection of the American people during her years in public life.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The leading U-boat killer of the Royal Navy, 47-year-old Capt. F.J. Walker, and his flotilla of secret list sloops using the "killer group" tactics he developed during the summer, sank two more enemy submarines within eight hours in the Atlantic recently, the Admiralty announced today.

Predicting that the colleges that played football in 1943 will do so in 1944, along with some that dropped the game last season, Asa Bushnell of Princeton made a strong plea yesterday for changes in the football code.
Mayor La Guardia devoted part of his regular Sunday broadcast from City Hall yesterday to a seven-count indictment of Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration.

A three-goal lead at the end of the second period failed to stand up for the New York Rovers on their Eastern Hockey League game with the Brooklyn Crescents at Madison Square Garden yesterday. As a matter of fact, this advantage was transformed into a one-goal deficit at one time during the third period, and defeat seemed their due.

The American Communists, whose political primer had for many years taught that there was no more difference between the Democratic and the Republican parties than between Tweedledum and Tweedledee, arrived at the conclusion yesterday, through their national committee, that this country's post-war political issues would be decided "within the form of the two-party system traditional in our country."

Mozart's infrequently heard piano concerto in C major (K. 467) was presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at its concert yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, with Hortense Monath as soloist. The program, conducted by Artur Rodzinski, also contained William Grant Still's "In Memoriam: ne Colored Soldiers Who Died for Democracy," Dvorak's 'lVew World" symphony and Stravinsky's "Fire-Bird" suite, all ttlree of which had been offerec at last week's concerts.
BOUGAINVILLE, (Delayed) -- Marine Major Leonard M. Mason of Glens Falls, N.Y., spent months of training for three hours on the beach at Bougainville, but he made those three hours count.

Disintegration of the family caused by "the absence of the virtues of religion and obedience" is responsible for "the deplorable condition of society" today, Mgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared at solemn mass there yesterday.

The appointment of Eugene W. Stetson, president of the Guaranty Trust Company, as chairman of the commerce and industry committee for Manhattan and the Bronx of the Red Cross 1944 War Fund was announced yesterday by John P. Stevens Jr., general chairman of the campaign that will begin March 1.

JOHN BARRYMORE'S life was as sad a tragedy as any he ever played. Blessed with a brilliant mind, physical beauty and the most transcendent acting genius of his time, he seemingly knew every satisfaction man can wish. His lordly pre-eminence in his profession was universally acknowledged, his income was fabulous, his men friends many and devoted, the women who loved him past counting.

Soy beans once more come to the fore as Joseph Tetley Co., Inc., introduces a mixture of soy grits, flour, dehydrated onions and other seasonings under the trade name Beanburger. This powderlike preparation may be used "as is" to make patties, or it may be employed as an extender for meat in hamburgers, croquettes, loaves, etc., thus eliminating the time-consuming business of adding separately eggs, crumbs and seasonings.

A handsome fawn-and-white 15-month-old dog from the kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Kettles Jr. of Glen Head, L.I., Warlord of Mazelaine, was named best-inshow at the American Boxer Club exhibition at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

The Fleetwood Garage, a five-story building at 113 Sterling Place, in the Park Circle section of Brooklyn, was sold by the City Savings Bank to a client of Max E. Greenberg for cash over a first mortgage of $26,000. It is assessed at $65,000 and was sold through the Brevoort Management Company, broker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Three Bronze Oak Leaf Clusters to Air Medal -- First Lieut. De Witt L. Alexander, 15 East Ninety-third Street, New York; Second Lieut. Edgar L.H. Stevens Jr., 161 West Sixteenth Street, New York; First Lieut. Albert M. Burbank Jr., 16 Marshall St., Newark, N.J.; Staff Sgt. Joseph Horvath, 1977 Fairfield Ave., Bridgeport, Conn. (reported killed in action on Oct. 6, 1943).

The Newark Milk and Cream Company bought the Isbell-Porter Estate property at 40 to 54 Bridge Street, northwest corner of the McCarter Highway, at the approach to the proposed new bridge over the Passaic. River in Newark, N.J., through Feist Feist and now controls the entire block facing Bridge Street between Garrabrant Court and the highway and fronting 400 feet on Bridge Street and 118 feet at 26-28 Orange Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Movement of hogs to leading packing points continues unusually heavy, and while another Office of Price Administration ration dividend on fresh pork has tended to increase demand for that product there has been some accumulation recently of both fresh and cured meats and lard.

The Brooklyn police were searching yesterday for victims of what they called "an old racket with a new twist," following the arrest Saturday night of Neil Vignapiani, 40-year-old chauffeur, who, they said, preyed on bereaved women by selecting survivors' names from obituary columns and writing to them as "an old friend."
AN EAST COAST PORT, Jan. 9 (AP) -- "I can't see the good old U.S.A. -- but even the air smells better!"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Resignation of Reagan P. Connally, director of the consumer goods price division of the Office of Price Administration, was announced today. He will return to his post as president of the Interstate Department Stores, New York.

MOSCOW, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- The Second Polish Division has left for the front to join the Red Army, its men shouting "On to Warsaw!" and eager to take their part in the great Russian winter offensive, it was announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 9 -- Twentieth Century-Fox plans to reunite Gracie Fields and Monty Woolley, stars of "Holy Matrimony," in "Sally and the Senator," an original screen comedy by Lazlo Vadnay and Montague Banks. The latter, better known as Monty Banks, is the husband of Miss Fields and a former film comedian and producer.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Jan. 8 (Delayed) (U.P.) -Point-blank combats with German tanks that feigned surrender to get within 300 yards were described today by American tank men who cooperated with British troops to repulse an enemy counter-attack on the slopes of Mount Porchia, below the Rome road southwest of San Vittore.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Rock Island's Golden State Limited left for Los Angeles today carrying one jittery express messenger, five bears and a problem for the railway express agency -- two problems, in fact.

The hope of the world lies in the sympathy and understanding of each group with the problems of the others, Prof. Arthur H. Compton of the University of Chicago declared in a message read at the annual scholarship and award luncheon of the League of Fraternal and Benevolent Organizations of the Jewish Education Committee of New York, held yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

It is a Presidential election year, and we the people of the United States find ourselves with a war for national survival on our hands. Our time-honored American way of pursuing happiness in Presidential years is rudely disturbed.

I have read with interest the editorial "Bulgaria Stirs," which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 4, wherein two points stand out -- that "if Bulgaria were free from Nazi soldiers there can be no doubt as to what would happen" and that "a Fascist Government, slavishly subservient to Berlin, betrayed them" in dragging the Bulgarians into the war.

Richmond, the smallest of the five boroughs in population, was disclosed yesterday as the leader in the waste paper salvage drive. It was credited with 11.9 pounds a person for December by Frank D. March, salvage director for the city War Production Board and the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.
Dr. Alfred Moore Paxon, dean of the College of Business Administration of the University of Tulsa, has been named director of the conference division of the National Industrial Conference.

Prices of cotton futures moved last week to the highest level since last October, but gains were pared in final dealings by profit-taking operations. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange registered net advances of 15 to 28 points for the week, with the exception of the March position, which showed a net gain of only 1 point.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Here and there in New York, New Jersey and New England are city women who liked farming so well last summer that they stayed on the land. While their count may be by handfuls, the Department of Agriculture takes great pride in the winter women's land army.

The service and gold star flags honoring Catholics of the Archdiocese of New York in the armed forces and those who have died in service were rededicated yesterday at military vesper services attended by 3,000 persons at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The Metropolitan Opera House is expected to be filled to capacity with members of society and other music lovers tomorrow night for the benefit violin recital to be given by Fritz Kreisler to initiate the 1944 maintenance fund campaign of the Salvation Army.
MOSCOW, Jan. 9 -- Moscow newspapers gave prominence today to news that the Second Polish Division recently went to the front to fight alongside the Red Army.

Because the Keynes and White plans for international currency stabilization are designed to operate in a stable world, which seems unlikely, they are not the most workable plans for the immediate post-war period, according to a study titled "British and American Plans for International Currency Stabilization" by J.H. Riddle, economic adviser of the Bankers Trust Company.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices, prepared by the Index Number Institute, was 112.32, a drop of 0.09 per cent from the previous week's level of 112.42. The farm products and raw materials indexes declined 0.5 per cent and 0.3 per cent, respectively, because the price decreases in oranges, wheat, potatoes, and some livestock were larger than the increases in cotton, milk, apples and oats.

The Rev. Dr. Theodore C. Speers, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, took the Christian Church sharply to task yesterday for its failure to promote unity, and its inability to plan and accomplish objectives that are essential to mankind's existence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Immediate establishment of a new Federal agency to plan and carry out a reconversion program for American industry was urged today by spokesmen for the American Federation of Labor and the Congress for Industrial Organizations.
MOSCOW, Monday, Jan. 10 -- Moving south and west, Soviet troops continued yesterday their systematic destruction of supply lines for the Germans remaining in the Ukraine's Dnieper bend.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $39,270,532,450. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes, certificates of indebtedness and non-interest-bearing discount bills as follows:

BEAUFORT, S.C., Jan. 9. -- Bringing in the third regime in its history of eighty years, Penn School, on St. Helena Island, near here, inducted Howard Kester as its principal today. The school has been called the foremost center of rural community education in the United States.

Attractive, snug-fitting slip covers occupy a permanent place in the American home. But in these days of conservation and shortages they are slated to play a larger part in a homemaker's life than ever before. For slip covers not only furnish an economical means of rejuvenating a drab corner or making an old armchair look new, but they also protect such irreplaceable pieces of furniture as a steel spring daybed or a down-filled armchair.
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- A portion of the blame for the severity of the famine that has ravaged Bengal was ascribed to the province's Government today by L.S. Amery, Secretary of State for India.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Income payments to individuals in November amounted to $12,420,000,000, 16 per cent above the total for the same month a year ago but 3 per cent less than the $12,741,000,000 figure in October, the Commerce Department announced today.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, Jan. 9 -- Returning to the form that several years ago earned him the recognition as one of the top three "ski riders" in the country, 25-year-old bespectacled Merrill (Mezzie) Barber of Brattleboro, Vt., today edged out Sgt. Torger Tokle of Uncle Sam's "fighting mountaineers" in an exciting invitation open ski jump.

The large number of buyers in the market last week held to expectations, and even larger numbers are scheduled to arrive this week. With stocks depleted, there is anxiety to fill-in for most departments, but many buyers are somewhat hesitant to take certain substandard or "victory" lines, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Enrique S. de Lozada, the Bolivian revolutionary Government's representative in Washington, declared today that he was "profoundly disturbed" over Secretary of State Cordell Hull's statement that the revolution appeared to have been aided by pro-Axis forces outside Bolivia.

In this era of almost incredible development of aircraft the prediction of yesterday becomes the reality of today with astonishing frequency. In the annual Wright Brothers Lecture delivered at Washington by William Scott Farren, director of the Royal Aircraft Establishment at Farnborough, members of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences were urged to give their attention to the problems which will soon arise from ordinary cruising speeds of more than 400 miles an hour.

Martha Graham gave the second performance of her two new works, "Deaths and Entrances" and "Salem Shore," at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre last night, and, as at her previous appearance two weeks ago, drew an audience that filled the house to the last inch of standing room.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- After booing their local and national leaders and verging on open rebellion, striking employes of the Cramp Shipbuilding Company paid heed to the counsel of Government representatives today and voted to end tomorrow morning a three-day strike that had cost the war effort more than 400,000 man-hours of constructional effort.
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Russian Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

A first-period attack that netted them three goals seemed to assure an easy triumph for the Canadiens of Montreal in their National Hockey League game with the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. As matters turned out the league leaders were pressed right down to the wire before they could claim a 6-to-5 triumph over the local skaters.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Jan. 10 -- United States marines on New Britain Island have reorganized and resumed their attack on the Japanese around Borgen Bay east of Cape Gloucester, while bombers and fighters of the South Pacific command raided enemy installations and met stiff interception at Cape St. George, on the south tip of New Ireland.

Stressing "the central importance of the church" in these days "when the forces of evil are tremendously organized," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday in his sermon at Riverside Church that it was the duty of all Christians to rally around their churches and the principles for which they stand.

Seven directors of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company, which controls the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, in a special letter sent yesterday to stockholders attacked the recently formed Mokan stockholders committee that was organized with a view to ousting William G. Maguire as president of the company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- A reversal of the tax trends of the Thirties with repeal of the excess-profits tax and establishment of a single normal tax, collected on all taxable income, individual and corporate, was recommended for the post-war period by the Brookings Institution in a study published today.

One-third of the babies born in this city are being cared for through the sixty-three health stations maintained by the Department of Health's Bureau of Child Hygiene, Dr. Leona Baumgartner, the director, declared yesterday at the bureau's headquarters, 125 Worth Street.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 9 -- Members of the crew of the first Swedish steamer to get back from Stettin after the RAF's heavy attack there early Thursday said today that the British bombing had left that German Baltic city "a picture of devastation and horror."

PATTY BERG is a very intense sort of person, plunging with grim determination and whole-hearted enthusiasm into everything she does. As a red-headed, freckle-faced tomboy she played football until her father induced her to trade in the gridiron for the golf links. Two years after she started as a divot digger she was runner-up for the women's national championship at the tender age of 17.

Predicting that the textile industry would eventually regard the export set-aside provision of the War Production Board order M-317 as "a long-range blessing in disguise," William C. Planz, president of the Textile Export Association of the United States, declared yesterday that most of the published complaints from the trade about the directive were without a factual basis.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 9 -- All western Europe is keyed to the highest pitch of tension in expectation of an early Allied invasion.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 9 -- A rebound in the production of steel ingots, a decline in the pressure of orders, a relatively balanced scrap market and a continuation of the heavy demand for flat-rolled products featured news of the steel industry last week.
Yesterday's communique, broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ALGIERS, Jan. 9 -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army, on the fourth day of its attack along a ten-mile front, pierced the German defenses ringing Cassino to a depth of about one-third -- in other words, an average of slightly more than two miles along the axis of the Via Casilina -- it was officially announced today.

AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 9 -- Sherman H. Dalrymple, International president of the United Rubber Workers of America, CIO, who expelled seventy-four tire production workers from the union here yesterday for taking part in wildcat strikes, served notice on all union members today that further stoppages would not be tolerated and expulsions would be continued if necessary.

AT A UNITED STATES BASE IN THE PACIFIC, Jan. 9 -- Four days after the invasion of Makin the Twenty-seventh Division established friendly contact with the Makin King and hereditary ruler who established himself on the island of Little Makin when the Japanese captured the Gilberts in December, 1941.

NAPLES, Jan. 9 -- It was Christmas Day on the front. An American doughboy was in a muddy foxhole just over the hill from where the Germans were pouring a hail of fire and steel in preparation for a counter-attack. The soldier was about to open a can of C rations for his Christmas dinner when something caught his notice from behind. He wheeled and gazed in startled amazement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- With the question of the role that paratroops and glider-borne soldiers will have in the coming invasion of Europe receiving considerable attention in military circles, Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair, commanding general of the Army Ground Forces, said today he believed that recent maneuvers have proved the usefulness, under certain conditions, of air-borne infantry.

It took forty hours of bitter fighting to clear the Germans out of the gateway town of San Vittore. One correspondent described the struggle as a deadly street brawl, with hand grenades and machine guns substituting for brass knuckles. The battle raged from house to house, with neither side daring to use artillery for fear of slaying its own men.

ALGIERS, Jan. 9 -- It appeared certain today that the Provisional Consultative Assembly's Committee on the Reform of the State would unanimously adopt a program for restoring the Republic in France that would be substantially different from the plan submitted by the French Committee of National Liberation and that submitted by the Socialist leader, Vincent Aureol.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Army Air Forces indicated today that one of the principal handicaps in the use of any new weapon against an enemy -- the need for long training of personnel -- has been avoided in the new revolutionary jet-propelled combat plane.
ALGIERS, Jan. 9 -- A communique:

LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Polish Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk arranged today to confer within the next day or two with President Eduard Benes of the exiled Czechoslovak Government. Russia's view toward Poland's post-war boundaries is expected to be the topic.

As the college basketball season approaches the half-way post in the current campaign, it becomes apparent that St. John's is the strongest combination in the city. The manner in which Joe Lapchick's Redmen handled the high-scoring Rhode Island State quintet the other night was concrete evidence that the St. John's squad will be hard to beat on any night.

Net assets of the General American Investors Company, Inc., on Dec. 31 were $25,262,580, equivalent to $394.72 on each share of preferred stock and, after provision for the preferred, to $14.50 on each share of common. The latter figure compared with $9.30 a share on Dec. 31, 1942, and with $15.30 on Sept. 30, 1943.

The total number of net paid copies of twenty-one national magazines for the twelve months ended June 30, 1943, was 2 per cent less than for the corresponding period one year earlier, according to a study of magazine circulation released yesterday by the Association of National Advertisers.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 9 -German military circles today abandoned all reserve in discussing the situation on the eastern front. Dispatches from Berlin report that newspaper comment is preparing the German public for news of a retreat by the Wehrmacht that may include not only evacuation of the Dnieper bend but also withdrawal of German forces along the entire Russian front.

Mayor La Guardia and Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins revealed yesterday that in November an embargo had been placed on $100,000 worth of proprietary medicines, prepared for shipment to Central and South American countries, on the theory that "what is no good for us is no good for our good neighbors."

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Heavily reinforced German troops have opened a five-pronged offensive against Yugoslav Partisans in a powerful new attempt to clear the forces of Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] from western and central Bosnia, a Yugoslav communique said today.

Scribners is featuring a window display at its store of books on the Netherlands, honoring Princess Juliana's visit to New York. Scribners also had an all-Netherlands window show in honor of Queen Wilhelmina's sixty-third birthday last Aug. 31.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (U.P) -- Housewives who have been combing grocery shelves these many weeks for a jar of the family's favorite jam or jelly are about to have their desires fulfilled, the War Food Administration announced tonight.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- The task of handling the controversial New York City legislation, which appears every year on the Albany scene, is scheduled to be assigned to Assemblyman MacNeil Mitchell of the Tenth Manhattan District. Mr. Mitchell, senior member of the Assembly from the metropolis, will take over the work in this field formerly handled by Abbot Low Moffat.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday, in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall, that an unofficial board named by him on Dec. 23, consisting of former Court of Appeals Judges Frederick E. Crane and Edward R. Finch and former Police Commissioner George V. McLaughlin, had reviewed the recent decision of Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine dismissing charges of subversive activity and anti-Semitism against Patrolman James L. Drew.

The one and two story building with eight stores at the southeast corner of Eighth Avenue and Fiftieth Street has been sold by the Bank for Savings to the 250 West Fiftieth Street Corporation, represented by Brush Bloch, attorneys, for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $435,000.

Aaron Copland's Symphony received its first New York performance at the concert given late yesterday afternoon by the NBC Symphony Orchestra, under Leopold Stokowski, at Radio City, on the "General Motors Symphony on the Air" program.

For some time the word "apathy" has been bouncing about in my head. And I can't say that I have arrived at any sane conclusion. The concept of total war is so terribly big that I feel lost in the shuffle, with a resulting emotion of panic or its opposite, "apathy."

In regard to the soldier vote bill there had been a great deal of discussion about States' rights. There has been much heat and little light. In a radio address on Dec. 24, Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois provided some factual information of great value in this discussion. I quote:

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Farmers have failed to sell cash corn on a liberal basis in the last few weeks, much to the surprise of the grain trade, although weather conditions generally have been favorable. The high moisture content of the grain and failure of the grain to dry out as rapidly as expected is regarded as the main factor in holding up the anticipated movement.

With the blessing of Mayor La Guardia, "Our Town" will be revived -- first time here -- this evening at the City Center, 131 West Fifty-fifth Street, for at least two weeks. In his weekly broadcast yesterday the Mayor intimated that Thornton Wilder's Pulitzer Prize play of the 1937-38 season would be kept going as long as the public wanted it, which is fair enough.

These days when every woman likes to be a quick-change artist, the vogue for vests and weskits is growing by leaps and bounds. They can turn suits into dinner costumes, brighten up winter dresses for the first days of spring, or make over last year's blouses and skirts into this year's favorite jumper.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The success of the western European invasion and of other Allied offensives planned for this year depends directly upon the United States landing-craft construction program, James Forrestal, Under Secretary of the Navy, said tonight.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 9 -- The greater part of one of the country's finest private collections of paintings by old masters, including Holbein and Rembrandt, belonging to the estate of Elizabeth Severance Prentiss, has been bequeathed to the Cleveland Museum of Art under her will, filed for probate yesterday.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Jan. 9 (AP) -- For two days Billy Miller, a 5-foot 5-inch private from Peoria, Ill., convinced his nineteen German captors that they were surrounded and then he got them to surrender and marched them to the Allied line.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- All deliveries of barley on the Chicago Board of Trade sold last week at new seasonal high prices following other grains and finished at gains of 1 3/4 to 4 1/4 cents a bushel for the week, with May at $1.24 1/2, July at $1.23 1/2 and September at $1.22 1/4.

A rickety, shell-blasted pier of coconut logs held the hopes of our Marines for two days during the assault on Tarawa, for along it passed a trickle of supplies to the pitiful handful of assault troops who had fought through the bloody surf to shore.

The American Labor party's State executive committee will meet Wednesday afternoon at the Hotel Claridge, it was announced yesterday by Alex Rose, its State secretary, to reject officially not only the Hillman plan, which would give the labor unions control of party policies, but also "any other plan which entails coalition with Communists."

LONDON, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force fighter-bombers punished the invasion coast of northern France today, roaring across the English Channel in several waves, after Mosquito bombers had made their eighth straight night stab in western Germany last night.

The story is written over and over again upon the roads of Europe and -- more dimly because the terrain is stranger and we cannot see so far -- on the roads of Asia. It is written in interminable lines of people forever running away from terror, from bomb-racked cities, from advancing armies, and never finding a resting place.
Three new films are slated to have Broadway openings this week. The schedule follows:

CLEVELAND, Jan. 9 -- Antanas Smetona, first President of Lithuania and its President-in-Exile since the Russians invaded it in 1940, died today in a fire which swept the home of his son, with whom he had been living here. He was 69.

Rudolph Serkin, pianist; Adolf Busch, violin, and Herman Busch, 'cello,' making up the Busch Trio, gave a substitute concert for the New Friends of Music at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon in place of the all-Beethoven Lieder recital scheduled for Lotte Lehmann, who had become ill.

Louise Doschek, Pittsburgh pianist, who made her debut here at Town Hall in February, 1942, gave a recital there last night, playing Bach, Brahms, Chopin, Debussy and Glazunoff. She was well received by a good-sized audience.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 9 -- Seventh Army Air Force dive bombers and Navy fighter planes attacked the strong Japanese base of Mili in the southeastern Marshall Islands last Friday, continuing the almost daily scouting and bombing of the Marshalls group that began in the middle of November.

The first week of the new year brought improvement in prices of securities and commodities after a cautious start on Monday. Thereafter until Thursday stocks moved up through the resistance area of the preceding three weeks to their best levels since early November; transactions of 1,157,120 shares on Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange were the heaviest since Dec. 8.

Speaking in St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street, the Rev. Elmore M. McKee took issue yesterday with those who believe that a great religious revival may be expected as a consequence of the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- United States output of airplanes is greater than that of all the rest of the world, Axis and Allies alike, T.P. Wright, director of the Aircraft Resources Control Office, declares in an article appearing in tomorrow's issue of Aviation News.

A "Free Movie Day" is planned by the War Activities Committee of the Motion Picture Industry for Jan. 18, the opening day of the Fourth War Loan Drive, the War Finance Committee for New York announced yesterday.

The current concern over wages has diverted attention from the pressure which higher farm prices have been exerting upon retail price ceilings. Under the Stabilization Act of October, 1942, OPA was prohibited from fixing the price of any agricultural product below the higher of two alternatives: (a) the parity price, or (b) the highest price in the period from Jan. 1 to Sept. 15, 1942.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 9 -- In announcing its budget for the 1944 calendar year the management of Pemex (Petroleos Mexicanos) the Government oil monopoly, says it will spend about $1,000,000 for exploration and drilling of twenty wildcat wells in explored areas and thirty-two new wells in regions already under exploitation.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The stock markets here started the year with quiet confidence but with less buoyancy than usual. This year is likely to prove the most important and decisive of the war but in view of repeated warnings as to the severity of the struggle ahead there is little disposition to increase commitments.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- Husky Johnny Bulla of Atlanta, Ga., playing golf as steadily as he pilots his commercial airline route between his home and Chicago, fired his third one-under-par 70 in a row today to tie with Leonard Dodson of Kansas City for the fifty-four-hole lead of the $12,500 Los Angeles open tournament.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has set Jan. 21 for a hearing on an application by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey for an order declaring it had ceased to be a holding company.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 9 -- Persistent reports from Germany said today that the Gestapo chief, Heinrich Himmler, had adopted a policy of executing defeatists, and others accused of undermining German morale, in the presence of their acquaintances as a most effective deterrent to others.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The question whether agreements with European refugee Governments for the restoration of civil administration in the countries that they represent should be negotiated in London or Washington seems to have become an issue sufficiently thorny to delay Anglo-American negotiations with them after they might otherwise have been concluded.

The first copies of The London Daily Mail's new journalistic venture, a miniature trans-oceanic newspaper containing a digest of the week's news in the British capital, was in the mail today headed for the "desks of influential people in America."
BALTIMORE, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Sir Anthony Hastings George, 56, British consul-general in Boston, was killed today in a fall from a fourth-story hotel window, the British consulate here reported.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- Claude A. Watson, formally notified of his nomination as the National Prohibition party's Presidential candidate, today called for a fight against governmental bureaucracy and extravagance, and against the "strongly entrenched liquor power."

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Ceiling prices were placed on cash wheat by the Office of Price Administration early last week at full parity at leading markets with a top of $1.71 3/8 a bushel, including commission charges, established for No. 2 red and hard winter here.

To the student of human expression the latest photograph of Hitler published today reveals amazing differences. The defiant rigidity and the poker face characterizing nearly all photographs since 1933 have given place to an attitude of unmistakable embarrassment and helplessness.

Listing preparedness as the main objective for any post-war stockpile of raw materials, E.O. Sowerwine, assistant to the president of Anaconda Copper Mining Company, yesterday urged that exclusive control over such stockpiles be vested in the Army and Navy.

Huddled next to a wall on the roof of a five-story building, a new pinwheel clutched in his stiff, bluish fingers, a 2 1/2-year-old boy was found frozen and dying at 4:30 A.M. yesterday nearly twelve hours after he had left the home of relatives at 630 Bergen Avenue, the Bronx, to play.

The full historic import of the October Conference of Moscow, whose results were later confirmed and supplemented at Teheran, was never more forcefully summarized than in the broadcast by James C. Dunn, political adviser on European affairs to State Secretary Hull.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- With taxes and mustering-out pay for service men topping its agenda of unfinished business, Congress returns to work tomorrow to face a number of politically-volatile new issues as it starts a session which may considerably affect the outcome of the elections next fall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Long-range as well as immediate problems involved in raising living standards in the American territories and British colonies of the Caribbean area are emphasized in a report issued tonight by the Anglo-American Caribbean Commission for the years 1942 and 1943.

Covered Brook Bombardier, a solid black puppy dog owned and handled by Mrs. R. Kenneth Cobb of Huntington Station, L.I., yesterday captured the Futurity Stake of the twenty-seventh specialty show of the American Spaniel Club at the Hotel Roosevelt.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEAD- I QUAlCTElCS IN NEW GUINEA,] Monday, Jan. 10 (U.P.) -- A comTru- / rique:

The intensified aerial assaults on the misnamed "Fortress Europe," it must be clear to all observers, is directly connected with whatever plans have been made for invading the Continent. There is reason to surmise, indeed, that such plans are, to a large extent, dependent on the progress of the war in the skies.

DETROIT, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Red Wings gained sole possession of the National Hockey League's fourth place by defeating the Black Hawks, with whom they had been tied, 4 to 2, before 11,192 tonight at Olympia Stadium. Detroit thus spoiled the return of Goalie Mike Karakas to the Chicago nets.

After a brief pause caused by the vicissitudes of booking, the City Center returned to the drama last evening with a revival of "Our Town." Written by Thornton Wilder for the season of 1937-38, it is a play which well deserves revival, and in putting it on for the city, Jed Harris has treated it with the greatest respect.

GAUDALCANAL, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Use of Allied low-level bombers from Bougainville airfields to strike at Japanese positions in the New Ireland area for the first time was heralded today as the start of an intensified air war against the enemy's base at Rabaul, New Britain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A swing back to pre-war models of baby carriages in about six weeks, with benefit not only to new babies in 1944, but also to the war economy, was revealed today by the War Production Board.
WITH GENERAL STILWELL IN BURMA, Jan. 6 (By Courier to New Delhi) (U.P.) -- More than eighteen months ago Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell led a long retreat out of Burma, arrived at New Delhi and said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Demobilization benefits and votes for members of the armed forces took an urgent priority in the legislative program today as Congress resumed work with the advice of constituents presumably fresh in mind.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Office of Price Administration this week will review present retail percentage mark-ups in the sale of distilled spirits and wines, that agency announced today. To aid them in the review a committee of twenty-one retailers, including Gerald F. Dunne, director, Metropolitan Package Store Association in New York City, has been named by OPA and will meet here for two days, starting Wednesday.

The 1943 net operating earnings of the Brooklyn Trust Company were $820,524, after all expenses, interest, depreciation and taxes, George V. McLaughlin, president, hold stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday. This compared with $720,639 in 1942.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The Dewey Administration sponsored tonight a move to bring the date of the spring primary election, at which delegates to the national conventions will be chosen, forward to March 28 instead of April 4, scheduled by the normal political calendar.

Gert Hans von Gontard, 37-year-old grandson of the late Adolphus Busch, founder of the Anheuser-Busch brewery in St. Louis, was indicted here yesterday with four other men. The four co-defendants were accused in the Federal charges of having assisted von Gontard to evade induction under the Selective Service Act.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 10 -- Gen. Sir Bernard C. Paget has arrived here to take over the Allied Middle East Command. He succeeds Gen. Sir Henry Maitland Wilson, who was transferred to command of all Allied forces in the Mediterranean theatre.
Mrs. J. Stillman Rockefeller and Miss Nancy Rockefeller of Pinehurst, N.C., are at the Weylin.

Although the War Production Board's new order on steel container packaging permits the resumption of production of many types of tin cans, F.J. O'Brien, president of the Can Manufacturers Institute, yesterday warned manufacturers who have been forced into substitute containers that they will first have to move existing stocks.

ALGIERS, Jan. 10 -- A heavy force of Flying Fortresses of the Fifteenth United States Air Force made the fifth attack in less than two months today on Sofia, the Bulgarian capital and the virtual hub of the Balkan rail system.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Roosevelt worked tonight putting the finishing touches on a message expected to cover most of the controversial issues before Congress, which he will send to Capitol Hill at noon tomorrow.

The American Communist party has been through a good deal since it split off from the Socialists a quarter of a century ago. It has been underground and above ground. It has had its martyrs who went to jail. It has had its bitter factional fights, with "splinters" flying in all directions.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 10 -- The nation's transportation system is entering a critical phase of operation and unless additional equipment, materials and personnel are made available soon "grave consequences" to the war program are threatened.

Thirty-two contributions amounting to $151.01 for the Neediest Cases Fund were received yesterday, raising the total of the thirty-second annual Christmas appeal to $275,899.62. The gifts included one for $25 from Mrs. George C. Newbury, who gave it through the Staten Island Social Service, one of the eight leading private family welfare organizations that attested the cases published during the appeal and administer the fund without any deduction for administrative or executive cost.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- An adequate program, started now, to help Europe produce its own food after the war could prevent a serious drain on America's bread-basket, according to the National Planning Association, which made public today a report on post-war food problems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Although the railway wage disputes affecting eighteen unions appeared deadlocked today, there were some signs that the controversies may move off "dead center" by the end of the week.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Although no test vote took place today or is expected at the meeting of the Republican National Committee tomorrow, supporters of Wendell L. Willkie for the Presidential nomination comprise only a minority of the committee members and a smaller minority among the State chairmen and women vice chairmen, a check of members of both groups indicated today.

LONDON, Jan. 10 (Reuter) -- The unexpected victory of Lieut. Hugh McDowall Lawson over the Conservative candidate in the Skipton, Yorkshire, by-election raised the Parliamentary /status of Sir Richard T.D. Acland's Common Wealth party to equality with the Independent Labor party.

A plan calling for an informal system of arbitration in connection with painting and decorating services by landlords under the OPA rent regulations has been vetoed by the local OPA Administrator, it was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, area rent director, at his office, 535 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- This nation's current food economy, which is keyed to the invasion of Europe, assures to civilian so much the best of nutritional value that they may well share "borderline" foods quite cheerfully with our Army, our Allies, and the liberated peoples, according to Dr. Henry C. Sherman, chief of the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics.

There was an abundance of youth and concertos at Carnegie Hall last night. Youth was represented by the recently wed pair of virtuosos -- Carroll Glenn, violinist, and Staff Sgt. Eugene List, pianist, as well as by the young men and women who make up the personnel of the National Orchestral Association conducted by Leon Barzin.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt urged yesterday that the women of this country rise above "party lines," if necessary, in questions concerning the future peace of the world. She also decried the fact that women lack interest in exerting the power they have gained in the last quarter century.

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University announced yesterday that for the first time "Gold Star Scholarships" will be awarded to the children of the university's graduates who have lost or may lose their lives in the war.

Borough President Edgar S. Nathan of Manhattan praised yesterday the children of the Israel Asylum, 274 East Second Street, who collected so much waste paper for the salvage drive now under way that several trucks had to be assigned to pick it up.
At the annual meeting of the American Power Boat Association in the Hotel Lexington yesterday all officers of the forty-one-year-old organization were re-elected.
Investigation Commissioner William B. Herlands' report on anti-Semitic disturbances in the city -- more than a year in preparation -- was made public yesterday.

The stock market followed yesterday a thin line, although specialties again showed up strong and in active dealings. The radio and television issues were brought out for another of their increasingly frequent appearances and the rails and sugars registered some sizable gains, but elsewhere prices drifted irregularly.

In the region west of Kiev the Red Army is now pressing on the heels of the retreating Germans in what many historians regard as the original home of the Slav peoples. From this center along the upper waters of the Pripet, the Bug and the Dniester Rivers the Slavs are believed to have expanded in all directions in the centuries preceding and succeeding the collapse of the western Roman Empire.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Heavy profit-taking sales developed in wheat at the opening today on the Board of Trade. Brokers had anticipated a rush of buying after announcement that ceiling prices on futures had been advanced 2 cents a bushel to $1.73 3/8 at a special meeting of the directors of the Exchange late Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture estimated today that 1,996,100,000 bushels of corn were stored on farms as of Jan. 1, compared with 2,246,592,000 a year ago and an average of 1,562,290,000 during the 1933-42 period.

"No Greater Love," the Soviet importation dealing with a woman who turns guerrilla leader when her husband and baby are killed by the Nazis, will have its premiere at the Victoria Theatre on Wednesday, Jan. 26. The drama, with dialogue in English, features Maretskaya as the woman partisan leader and was directed by F. Ermler.

Rechristened, the organization now known as the League of President Day Artists used to be the bombshell Group. "Bombshell" was a startling and timely title, outgrowth of a prolonged controversy that raged in the columns of our Sunday art pages in 1941.

Eight staff members of the Chinese Blood Bank received their commissions in the Chinese Army Medical Service from Dr. Tsune-chi Yu, Chinese Consul General in New York, at Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South, yesterday afternoon. They will leave soon for Yunnan Province, China, where, at the request of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, they will set up a blood bank.

The Uniformed Firemen's Association in a move to restrain Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh from eliminating the three-platoon system obtained a show cause order yesterday afternoon from Supreme Court Justice Charles. M. McLaughlin.

LONDON, Jan. 10 (U.P.) -- The Yugoslav Partisans of Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] reported today that they were fighting bitterly against strong German infantry and tank units waging a five-pronged offensive against Partisan territory in central and western Bosnia and observers here believe the Germans threaten to envelop the Tito positions.

President Roosevelt's share of the common cold will unfortunately keep him from going personally before Congress today, but his words will reach Congress and country, as they have at about this time of year since 1933. It is interesting to look back over these addresses and messages.

The six-story apartment house fat 4026 Carpenter Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Florence Longman to Assunda Laraja through Eugene J. Busher, broker. Alfred A. Parisi was the attorney for the buyer and Thomas V. Tozzi represented the seller.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- Military skiing has now become a "must" in the curriculum of the cadets here on the Army post high on the snow-covered banks of the Hudson River. Future officers and, for that matter, present officers, too, are currently going through rigorous programs designed to familiarize them with mountain warfare.

Many a friendship has been formed over the backyard fence when Mrs. Brown has given her recipe for lemon meringue pie to Mrs. Smith and in return Mrs. Smith has told Mrs. Brown how to make a puffy and practically non-collapsible omelet.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The formation of 824 new stock companies in December, the greatest monthly total since April, 1942, raised the 1943 total to 8,660, compared to 8,696 in 1942, Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran reported today in a statement covering the twelve-month period.

In addition to abandoning their status as a political party, American Communists have decided not to raise the issue of socialism in the post-war period "in such a form and manner" as to weaken national unity, Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party of the United States, declared last night.

The report, issued yesterday, of the Western Union Telegraph Company for November, which includes the operations of the merged Postal Telegraph system, shows that net income for the month declined to $385,212 from a net of $814,426 in November, 1942. Postal Telegraph accounts have been consolidated with those of Western Union since the merger of the two companies became effective last Oct. 8. Gross revenues rose to $14,754,939 from $11,593,226 in November, 1942.

Interstate Department Stores, Inc., announced yesterday that negotiations had been completed for $8,000,000 of private financing for expansion in the retail field in the post-war period and to retire the present preferred stock.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Winning tonight's block, Willie Hoppe, the champion, led Welker Cochran, 100 to 99, after the first day's play here in their non-title cross-country three-cushion billiards match.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- The German armies in southern Russia are facing a major military disaster on a scale greater than either Stalingrad or Tunisia, according to qualified military observers in London.

Setting up of an agency to be known as the Post-War Surplus Distributing Corporation to insure the equitable distribution through recognized retail channels of $10,000,000,000 to $15,000,000,000 in Government surplus stocks of consumer goods is recommended by the post-war planning committee of the Association of Buying Offices, representing 2,000 department stores and apparel specialty shops.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Official silence greeted the announcement from Moscow suggesting a border compromise and reiterating that the western portions of the Ukraine and of White Russia had become part of Soviet Russia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- At frequent intervals, since the Japanese swooped on Pearl Harbor, some voice in Washington has been raised against "the people" in castigation or lament that they are not "in the war." They have been charged with "complacency" and urged to reality.

The right wing group in the American Labor party solicited advice from Mayor La Guardia on Friday night and from political advisers of the Roosevelt Administration in Washington over the week-end on the wisdom of fighting left wing elements for control of the party organization in this State or withdrawing from the party, it was disclosed yesterday.
The following is the text of the declaration on the Russian-Polish boarder issue, as reported by the Federal Communications Commission from a Moscow broadcast:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (U.P.) -- Walter Nash, New Zealand Minister to Washington, predicted today that lend-lease arrangements soon would be revised to provide cash payments by the United Nations for all supplies not directly connected with the war effort.
NAPLES, Jan. 10 -- Sicilians are buying two-thirds of their total bread requirements at ten times the official price.

May I comment on THE TIMES' story about the Equal Rights Amendment, dated Jan. 5, and fill in some of the gaps. That article lists the American Association of University Women, the League of Women Voters, the Y.W. C.A. through its National Board, among organizations opposed to the amendment.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 11 -- The Moscow radio announced early today that Russia was prepared to guarantee a "strong and independent Poland," provided that the Polish Government agreed to abandon its eastern frontier demands and to accept the Curzon Line as the boundary between Poland and Russia.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine extended yesterday the deadline for the withdrawal of pension applications of department members to Thursday, the date of the scheduled meeting of the trustees of the Police Pension Fund. He previously had ordered all who wished to withdraw applications to do so before last Dec. 31.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The nation's high school football code underwent three changes during the annual meeting of the National Interscholastic Football Committee.

AFTER reading "Lend-Lease: Weapon for Victory,"* by the former Lend-Lease Administrator, E.R. Stettinius Jr., it is hard to keep from feeling smug, complacent, and all the other things that one shouldn't feel while the Russians and the Chinese are still doing most of the dying. Well, let us be complacent for an hour or a day; it won't hurt.

The new uniform article for the termination of war supply contracts is expected to put an end to delays by Government agencies, other than the War Department, in the setting up of termination procedure, war contractors declared yesterday in endorsing the BaruchHancock clause as an "important step on the road to reconversion."

Mildred Walker's new novel, "Winter Wheat," which Harcourt, Brace will publish next week, has been chosen as the February selection of the Literary Guild. Her earlier novel, "Dr. Norton's Wife," also was chosen by the guild.

For the first time in many years the Richmond County Court at St. George, S.I., was unable to function yesterday because it had no judge. The January term of the court was scheduled to open at 10 A.M., and a grand jury of twenty-four members appeared to be sworn in.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn stores showed a decline of 11 per cent last week in comparison with the like week of 1943, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a decrease of 4 per cent in sales.

The two twelve-story office and loft buildings at 450 and 460 Fourth Avenue, southwest corner of Thirty-first Street, have been sold by the Franklin Savings Bank to Frederick Brown, operator. These properties are assessed for $657,000 and have an annual rent roll of more than $110,000.

The one-story taxpayer on a plot 125 by 65 feet at 2864 Boulevard, in the Journal Square section of Jersey City, has been sold by Julia P. and Helen D. Gillick and the other heirs of Joseph P. Gillick and Mrs. Emma G. Madigan to the 2864 Boulevard Corporation (Joseph Roth, president).
From the voluminous case histories in his report of anti-Semitic incidents, Commissioner William B. Herlands pictured the composite make-up of the young vandal, male or female.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Calm reigned today in the Supreme Court, where only a week ago the atmosphere was tense. Then fourteen decisions were announced; each one of the nine justices dissented in one or more cases; only four unanimous rulings were presented, and Justices Hugo L. Black and Frank Murphy twice criticized Justice Felix Frankfurter.

LONDON, Jan. 10 (Netherlands News Agency) -- About 1,000,000 persons have been turned out of their homes in the Netherlands by the Germans to make room for Germans bombed out of cities in the Reich and to permit the razing of houses for the construction of defense works along the coast, Radio Orange, the Free Netherlands station here, reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- Striking employes at the Cramp Shipbuilding Company won an important victory within a few hours of their return to work today when Neil L. Ellis, labor relations adviser for the company and an adversary of Local 42 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers (CIO), was removed from office and transferred to other duties.

The Anderson estate, comprising four and one-half acres, with a fifteen-room house and a four-room structure with three garages, at Sands Point, L.I., has been sold by the Brooklyn Trust Company, as trustee, to the Sterling Investing Corporation (Joseph K. Alliger and Hyman Ratner) and Harry Carey of Great Neck.

Champion Try-Cob's Favorite Girl was best in the twenty-seventh specialty show of the American Spaniel Club, which was concluded yesterday evening at the Hotel Roosevelt.
