This beautiful coal black specimen, one of the most popular show dogs of today, was adjudged the best among 198 spaniels of various breeds which contested under various judges for two days.

The thrice-postponed "Storm Operation," which opens this evening at the Belasco, represents Maxwell Anderson's twenty-fifth produced work and the season's second new offering by the Playwrights Company. One of our top-flight authors, the accomplished Mr. Anderson won the Pulitzer Prize for "Both Your Houses" and holds two awards from his best pals and severest critics (Drama Critics Circle) for "Winterset" and "High Tor."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 5, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

In what has been called the most comprehensive program ever put behind an advertised vitamin product, Standard Brands, Inc., has inaugurated a campaign on behalf of Stams, multi-vitamin and mineral tablets. Newspapers, magazines and radio are being used in promoting distribution through major drug outlets throughout the country.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 -- A program under which convicts in State prisons may reclaim and salvage castoff shoes and clothing for use in foreign countries by Herbert Lehman's United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration was revealed today by Maj. W. H. Burke, head of the Prison Industries Branch of the War Production Board.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world offers a partial list of free amusements available today. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets 4, 5:30, 6:30 and 7:30 P.M. Apply 99 park Avenue for passes.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 10 -- After taking a refresher course with the Fourteenth United States Army Air Force, Major Witeld Urbanowicz, Polish ace, visited Chungking today en route to England, where he will rejoin the Polish fliers.

HE was never a diplomat to begin with. William Harold Terry always had the uncanny knack of saying the wrong thing at the wrong time and his farewell blast at the sport which made him what he is today is quite typical of the man. "Baseball is too cheap for me," he said in announcing his complete retirement from the game for the idyllic life of a cotton farmer.

ALGIERS, Jan. 10 -- An appeal to Britain and the United States to consider the French underground as the vanguard of the Allies' invasion of Europe and to arm it before its force was exhausted was made today by the Provisional Consultative Assembly in the presence and with the approval of Gen. Charles de Gaulle after resistance leaders had made impassioned speeches pleading for immediate aid.

Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia has a taste for sliced turkey, but not when the price is $5 a pound. It was on a complaint made by the Senator to Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, that a Madison Avenue delicatessen store operator appeared in Municipal Term Court yesterday on charges of violating the ceiling prices on bologna and with failing to keep proper records or post ceiling prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A suggestion that Mayor La Guardia direct his critical harpoons at "enemies of price control rather than against those of us who are struggling against heavy odds to make price control effective," was made today by Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, in answering a seven-point "indictment" of OPA broadcast by the Mayor yesterday.

Men in the armed forces have become "church conscious" and "are going to church a little better than here at home," the Rev. Dr. William Barrow Pugh, Stated Clerk of the Presbyterian General Assembly and chairman of the committee on Army and Navy Chaplains, told the Presbytery of New York yesterday at its meeting at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 West Fifty-fifth Street.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 -- Harold (Jug) McSpaden, Philadelphia golfer, won the $12,500 Los Angeles Open today, shooting a five-under-par 66 on his final round to give him a total of 278, a 72-hole record for the Wilshire Club course.

Harold S. Jacobs, 43-year-old plumber, is a smiling fellow who would like to be thought of as a kleptomaniac who "just likes to take things home with him," according to E. E. Conroy, special agent in charge of Federal Bureau of Investigation offices here.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- The stock markets here opened the week quietly today and the tone tended to be uneven.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- With many Eastern cities, including Philadelphia, reporting the worst coal shortage of the winter and in some cases the most critical in history, the so-called independent production of anthracite has been slashed sharply in the last two months as a result of pressure from the State, the industry and the United Mine Workers of America, it was learned tonight.

Over 3,600 buyers registered at the New York Furniture Exchange yesterday on the opening day of the annual January furniture market to set a new attendance record for such openings. The figure exceeded by 800 the previous record of 2,800 buyers registered on the opening day of last year's market.

As complaints from householders and apartment dwellers continued to pour in on the Health Department yesterday, Mayor La Guardia held out hope for at least slight relief from the coal shortage. He said the additional 100,000 tons of bituminous coal allocated to this area began to leave Pennsylvania mines yesterday and would arrive here at the rate of 25,000 tons weekly.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10 -- While the great battle is progressing in south Russia, Leningrad's ordeal continues. Reports from the city state that German shelling goes on day and night, that carcely a building now is unscarred and that anxiety, sleeplessness are placing a heavy strain on the inhabitants' nerves.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Postwar baseball problems affecting major and minor leagues alike will be discussed at a special meeting in New York Feb. 5, Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of baseball, announced tonight.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 (AP) -- An item of $50,000 with which to finance the State legislative-spending investigation ordered by Governor Dewey was included in nineteen certificates of intent totaling $548,000.66 submitted to the Senate and Assembly tonight.

By the last quarter of 1944, when "a very sharp drop in war output is expected," the United States will have to face a serious unemployment problem arising out of the fact that civilian goods manufacture will not have risen rapidly enough to absorb the volume of war production thus removed, Leo M. Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America, declared yesterday.

Organized retailers of the nation meeting last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania responded with approval when their president, Edward N. Allen, declared that all problems were subordinate to winning the war and inconsequential by comparison.

DETROIT, Jan. 10 -- The so-called "dream car" of tomorrow, represented by extreme styling and the tear-drop design, came in for some caustic remarks today by Edgard C. DeSmet, executive engineer for Willys-Overland, Inc., in a paper read before one of the opening sessions of the war engineering annual meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

Your editorial today on "Russia's New Anthem" is a well-deserved tribute to a stirring marching song. It is a little difficult to understand, however, just what your editorial writer means by his description of it as "lying well within the compass of the average voice."
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Jan. 11 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Net earnings of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in 1943 amounted to $15,331,000, compared with $4,568,000 in the previous year, Allan Sproul, the president, reported yesterday in the bank's twenty-ninth annual earnings statement to member bank stockholders.

Onlookers left yesterday's fashion showing in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis Hotel feeling that they had seen a performance keyed to resort life, which means that all the items will be suitable in the North later in the year. Many are acceptable in town now.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 10 -- A German news agency dispatch from Milan, Italy, states that the Special Fascist Tribunal, which has been sitting in camera at Verona since Saturday, today passed sentence of death on Count Ciano, former Italian Foreign Minister and son-in-law of Premier Mussolini, and seventeen members of the former Fascist Grand Council, for high treason in plotting the overthrow of Benito Mussolini on July 24.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The question whether members of Congress can also serve in the armed forces was decided by President Roosevelt today on the basis of advice from Attorney General Francis Biddle that it would be improper under the Constitution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Unit of Nations losses through U-boat action again were low during December despite expanded efforts by Nazi submarines, it was revealed tonight by a joint Anglo-American statement, which also disclosed that merchant shipping losses through submarine action in 1943 were 40 per cent of the 1942 total.

The large audience that assembled in Town Hall last night to hear Jan Cherniavsky, Russian pianist, in his first solo appearance in this city, gave early evidence of amazement. After the third number, there was an ovation.
LONDON, Jan. 10 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
LONDON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Col. Oveta Culp Hobby said today there was an excellent chance the Wacs would go to northwest Europe after Allied forces had established their lines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Seventy-eighth Congress came back for its second session today fresh from contacts with its constituencies and bearing a few proposals for compromising the legislative and policy snarls it left behind when it recessed on Dec. 21.

"Now that the Fourth War Loan is here," Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, chairman of the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, declared yesterday, "we need the help of all the volunteers who worked so splendidly in the Third War Loan, and were responsible for sales amounting to over fourteen million dollars.

Commercial banks were notified yesterday afternoon that the Treasury will make withdrawals from Government war loan accounts in these institutions on Thursday, Friday and Saturday For the Second Federal Reserve District, these calls will amount to $38,849,000 on each day, and for the nation as a whole, to $90,986,000 on each day. In all, these

CHICAGO, Jan 10 (AP) -- Hog marketings were considerably in excess of slaughter requirements today and holdovers totaled about 25,000 head. An estimated 55,000 swine, including 15,000 directs, were unloaded here, and were supplemented by 5,000 head of farmer-owned hogs which had been held over from last week.

NAPLES, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Italian political party leaders told members of the Allied Control Commission in a series of individual conferences today that they were determined to continue their opposition to King Victor Emmanuel until he was forced to abdicate.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange on Dec. 31 amounted to 737,042 shares, compared with 760,166 shares on Nov. 30, according to reports received yesterday by the Exchange from members and member firms. In addition short interest in all odd-lot dealers' accounts was 33,027 shares, compared with 42,864 shares on Nov. 30.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Allied air squadrons roamed the skies from Celebes Island far north of Australia to the Solomons to deliver heavy bomb loads on Japanese bases and barge supply routes, the High Command anonunced today.

The cotton futures market eased moderately yesterday under scattered hedge selling, a few liquidating orders and evening-up operations following an early display of strength resulting from trade price fixing. The list of active contracts ended the session on the New York Cotton Exchange with quotations unchanged to 6 points below Saturday's finals, with the distant positions weakest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The United States in the future must maintain a social security program providing its citizens with economic protection comparable with that a business man gets when he takes out an insurance policy, Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, declared today.

War production will suffer a "first-class calamity" unless a Selective Service order virtually ending industrial and educational deferments for men 18 to 22 years old is annulled by Congress, Dr. Albert B. Newman, regional representative of the War Manpower Commission, declared yesterday.

How war contracts should be terminated may seem at first glance an uninteresting and purely technical question that can be dealt with in a routine manner. It turns out on close examination to be, in fact, an extremely difficult question, upon the answer to which may depend the whole economic character of the months and possibly years immediately following the end of the war.

Over the Tokyo radio comes the clearest note of concern yet heard from the southwest Pacific. Japanese listeners are told that in this area "the enemy has completely crushed into our air mastery." In this connection the Tokyo commentator warns his public that raids on Rabaul are increasing in intensity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 10 -- Paramount has renewed interest in Augusta Tucker's story of Baltimore boarding house life, "Miss Susie Slagle's." A new screen play is being written for the novel, for which the company has owned screen rights for three years. Betty Fields may appear in the lead.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The 16,000,000 taxpayers who may be deserving of refunds because of withholding tax over-payments may get them without red tape, but perhaps not until a lapse of two to four months after March 15, Bureau of Internal Revenue regulations made clear today.

ALGIERS, Jan. 10 -- Three more stony obstacles to the Fifth Army, closing in inexorably on Cassino, were eliminated yesterday. The Allies are now battering with the help of tanks at the outskirts of Cervaro, within four and a half miles of Cassino.
The Curzon line, which Soviet Russia proposes as Poland's eastern frontier, has been denounced by the Poles since Versailles.
ALGIERS, Jan. 10 -- The influence of Harry Celwicks, veteran Queens newspaper man, was felt sharply this morning at Allied Press Headquarters here.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- National Football League club owners will meet with Commissioner Elmer Layden on Wednesday and Thursday to mull over player prospects for the 1944 season and to hatch ideas about post-war expansion of the professional sport.

Crediting the results to mass-production methods, George A. Eastwood, president of Armour Co., declared yesterday in the annual report to stockholders that, while the net profit a pound was small, so many pounds of meat were produced and sold in 1943 that profit afforded a modest return on invested capital.
LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Opposing an attempt of the Department of Justice to obtain a ruling by the Supreme Court that insurance companies are subject to the Sherman Anti-trust Act, thirty-four States asserted today that such a decision would "result inevitably in Federal regulation destroying the sovereignty of the States in this field."

The speakers at the American Dialect Society's meeting reported on Jan. 1 have perhaps insufficiently considered that Basic is not designed to take the place of full English. Mr. Churchill put this point with characteristic vigor in the House of Commons on Nov. 4. "People are quite purblind," he said, "who discuss this matter as if Basic English were a substitute for the English language."

LONDON, Jan. 10 (U.P.) -- Switzerland today heard reports that Count Ciano had escaped from custody during the week end only to be tracked down by a German Army patrol and wounded by gun fire. It was asserted that he was returned to the courtroom and that he heard there the death sentence imposed on him.

A new issue of 450,000 shares of 4 1/2 per cent series cumulative preferred stock of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, with a par value of $45,000,000, is being offered at par today by a nation-wide group of 141 investment firms headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Otis Co., Inc.

To help meet the "critical needs of children during the present emergency period," New York's school system plans to increase its child welfare facilities and services, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday in a statement on the 1944-45 school budget.

A high-grade basketball attraction will be presented to the patriotic, sports-loving public Wednesday night, Jan. 26, at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, it was announced yesterday at the basketball writers' luncheon at Toots Shor's.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 10 -- One thousand delegates at the opening session of the sixty-fifth annual convention of the New Jersey State Federation of Labor, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, heard today from two ranking officials opposite opinions on the Little Steel wage formula.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 10 -- Heavy bombers of the Army and Navy raided Japanese bases on three Marshall Island atolls over the week-end, sinking two small ships, destroying several planes and damaging enemy defense installations.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 10. -- Thoughts and talk of Man o' War and Whirlaway were on many tongues at Hialeah today when two 3-year-old candidates, Whirlette and Gramps Image, won their races to enhance their future stake chances.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 10 -- When Irving S. Reeve, chairman for the last two years of the infantile paralysis fund campaign here, heard today that Englewood could not find a 1944 chairman, presumably because Englewood is rockbound Republican, he immediately obtained a chairman, Edward G. Redfield, who, like Rr. Reeve, is a Republican leader.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 10 (U.P.) -- Striking at the Japanese on four widely separated fronts, American and Chinese fliers inflicted telling blows yesterday on enemy shipping and other targets, a communique from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana, chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee, pledged tonight that a Republican President, if elected in November, would retain the American military and naval commanders who are now directing our forces with success, but would put an end to the snooping and spying and inefficiency of the bureaucracy now entrenched in Washington under the Roosevelt administration.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Two important measures of Governor Dewey's program, which were introduced Wednesday after recommendations were made by the Governor in his message, were accepted today by the Assembly Ways and Means Committee at a special meeting and will be reported out tomorrow.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The close-fitting bonnet that hugs the top and sides of the head, leaving the back hair uncovered, was the silhouette most favored by Mme. Pauline in the collection of spring hats presented yesterday at her salon at 6 East Fifty-third Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- Difficulties in retaining skilled personnel have become so acute for Westchester County that vital public services are endangered, Herbert C. Gerlach, County Executive, said today in a 4,000-word annual message to the Board of Supervisors.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- The Royal Air Force's great offensive against Berlin, the heaviest aerial attack ever launched against a single center, has crippled the city as the administrative and industrial capital of the Third Reich.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Supreme Court stood pat today on a decision which was criticized as denying a group of Negroes the right to choose their own collective bargaining representatives.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in a radio address last night at ceremonies preparatory to the opening of the Fourth War Loan Drive a week from today, declared that American workers would continue to put their dollars into war bonds.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 11 -- Jockey Ted Atkinson got another pair of winners at Hialeah Park today, including Grant Thorn's filly, Leaving, who took the featured Rainbow Purse in decisive style at the end of six furlongs.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 12 -- The strategic bombing of Germany proper by the United States Eighth Air Force reached a new peak yesterday when hundreds of Flying Fortresses and Liberators escorted by United States and Royal Air Force fighters, including new long-range American fighters, attacked targets in northwest Germany.

The increase in employment of minors in industry has brought "appalling conditions," the Women's Club of New York declared yesterday. Corrective legislation, it added, would be introduced in Albany to regulate hours of work of school children.

Current controls on exports as administered by the Foreign Economic Administration in practically all cases are "outmoded" and "unnecessary" and should be eliminated immediately, James B. Herzog, former chief, transportation branch, and one-time head of the commodities licensing division of the recently superseded Office of Economic Warfare, declared yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 11 -- The meteoric career of Count Ciano across the international Fascist horizon came to a violent end this morning when the 41-year-old son-in-law of Benito Mussolini faced a firing squad outside the walls of the Salvio Prison in Verona, Italy, according to the German news agency DNB.
Fritz Kreisler gave a benefit violin recital last night at the Metropolitan Opera House that raised $105,000 for the Salvation Army.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Republican and Democratic leaders of the House agreed today to drop the matter of the Republican poll of the soldier vote after it had been reported that Democrats had also made such a poll.

All war contractors, particularly smaller ones, should start immediately, now that the Baruch-Hancock standard termination clause has been issued, to put their accounting systems in order so as to help speed ultimate reconversion to peacetime output, Dr. Fred I. Kent, chairman of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York's post-war planning committee, declared yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Reflecting the great changes in baseball resulting from the war, the 1943 All-Star major league team, announced today by The Sporting News, includes nine players chosen for the first time by members of the Baseball Writers' Association.

The Abbott Collection of "Naval aviation" paintings has been intalled in the balcony that extends round the upper part of the entrance gallery at the Metropolitan Museum There was a private opening last night at 9, to which ranking officers of the Third Naval District, State and city officials and members of the museum were invited.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Jan. 11 -- The manner in which the Japanese troops are acting, and their physical condition, are causing startled comment here as the Australians, having broken through again, drive fair-sized trapped forces either toward the Americans established at Saidor or into the towering Finisterres to starve, and as the Marines continue to make progress toward Borgen Bay, New Britain, against regimental opposition.

The Russian declaration on Poland makes it necessary for the American Government and people to clarify their thinking about territorial settlements in Europe -- and elsewhere. We are not primarily concerned with details of European boundaries, but we are very much concerned as to the manner in which boundaries are fixed and in their large effect on questions of security and justice.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 11 -- Seventy-seven junior colleges have suspended or closed permanently as a result of the war, according to reports made at the annual conference of the American Association of Junior Colleges, which opened here today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- William Shea, representing Boston, was among the first arrivals today for the two-day meeting of club owners and officials of the National Football League opening tomorrow.

Hungry for merchandise to build up inventories depleted by heavy consumer demand and scarcities, and anxious to gauge current and future supply conditions, buyers representing stores all over the country are pouring into the wholesale markets here in unprecedented numbers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Continued congestion at the Union Stockyards here led Charles Rice, president of the Chicago Livestock Exchange, to ask hog producers today not to ship any more swine to Chicago for the remainder of this week.

Wolfgang T. Achtner, described as a former member of the "People's Court" of Munich, before which offenders against the Nazi party were tried, was held in bail of $5,000 here yesterday by Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard. He pleaded not guilty to a charge of having represented himself falsely as an American citizen before his arrest as a dangerous alien enemy the day after Pearl Harbor.

A plea for the admission of the Negro to full participation in American life was voiced yesterday by Roi Ottley, author of "New World A-Comin'," at the third book and author luncheon of the season, held at the Hotel Astor. The luncheons are under the joint sponsorship of the American Booksellers Association and The New York Herald Tribune.

On the theory that the younger they are the more they need guidance, the Girls Service League has lowered to 14 the age level of girls eligible for its help. In 1943, its thirty-fifth year, the league held 3,312 consultations with troubled adolescents and their parents.

Contending that it supplies the bulk of the party's membership, the New York State Industrial Union Council, central body of Congress of Industrial Organizations unions in New York, moved yesterday to take over direction of the American Labor Party machinery in this State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Democratic membership of the House, while still the largest, shrank below a numerical majority today with the resignation of Representative Joseph Gavagan of New York, to accept a seat on the State Supreme Court.

"Gentlemen, Trinity chimes have just struck eleven, and we will now begin the meeting." With these words Leon Fraser, president of the First National Bank of New York, surveyed the little group of stockholders and newspaper men assembled yesterday morning in the director's room on the second floor, cleared his throat, and said he supposed that they would like to hear something of the operations of the bank during the past year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Mrs. Margaret Savage of Rye received today from a jury before Supreme court Justice Henry G. Wenzel Jr. an additional $25,474 damages for the death of her husband, Mark, an auxiliary policeman, in a blackout last June 8.

Various blocks of bonds of Baltimore, Md., aggregating $4,200,000, formerly held in an undisclosed investment account, have been sold through competitive bidding by Baker, Watts Co. of Baltimore. The bonds, due variously from 1945 to 1962, bear interest at 2 3/4, 3 and 4 per cent.

Canners will be permitted to pack in 1944 several foods that have not been tinned since the start of the war, according to an announcement by the War Production Board. Notable among the items due to appear once again in metal containers are cranberry sauce, boned chicken and turkey, corned beef hash, baked beans, pimentos and lemon juice.

Stockholders of the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company of New York approved at their annual meeting yesterday a split-up of the institution's capital stock on a five-for-one basis, changing the outstanding capital shares from 70,000 to 350,000 shares and restating the par value from $100 to $20 a share.
For the first time in six weeks the general death rate for New York City took a drop during the week ending last Friday, Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday.

Members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, attending their thirty-third annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania, agreed in a panel discussion last night that the employe who had filled the job of the man entering the armed services in many instances had proved superior to the man for whom he substituted.

Two Army airmen who had flown on forty-one missions each in the India-Burma area and two who had participated in twenty-five missions over Europe described here yesterday the hazards of aerial warfare.

executive officer of the Rock Island Railway, and Louis Ware, president of the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation. Board membership was increased to twenty-five, one of the new directors replacing the late Bernard E. Sunny.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Field Marshal Gen. Karl Rudolf Gerd von Rundstedt, senior field marshal of the German Army, has left his command in northwestern Europe and gone to Berlin, leaving Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel as senior commander of the coastal defenses and field armies awaiting the Allies' invasion.

In March, 1929, twelve women met one day to discuss the possibilities of forming an organization to abolish an evil called prohibition. In May of that year we held our first meeting. We had no name for our organization. We had no definite platform.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The President's message asking a national service law and the reintroduction of a revised Austin-Wadsworth bill today set the Census Bureau experts figuring on the country's womanpower.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Roosevelt's legislative program, submitted to Congress today, ran quickly into snags on two points, those dealing with the proposed national service system and taxation.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Four members of a Flying Fortress crew were killed and the rest of the crew was injured last Friday when all four engines quit as the craft was approaching an East Anglian village, it was announced today.
ALGIERS, Jan. 11 -- American troops dominating Cervaro from the newly won height of Mount di Pipernis are now only slightly more than four miles from Cassino, it was officially announced today.

TRENTON, Jan. 11 -- In an atmosphere of ill-will between Gov. Charles Edison, whose three-year term ends next Monday, and the Republican-controlled Senate, the 167th New Jersey Legislature adjourned sine die at noon today only a short time before the 168th session was convened.

LONDON, Jan. 11 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans announced today that they were "offering tenacious resistance" to five German columns attempting to penetrate Partisan-held territory in central and western Bosnia.

AT A NAVAL AIR STATION, in the Central Pacific, Jan. 11 -- New and secret technics that will give our naval air forces an even greater superiority over the enemy are being developed in ceaseless training operations in these and other Pacific waters.
Carl Hubbell was in town yesterday, enthusiastic over his new job as director of the farm system and chief scout of the Giants, and not exactly pessimistic over baseball's outlook.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Thirty-six States have had higher quotas assigned to them for war bond sales to individuals during the Fourth War Loan than they drew in the September campaign.

Announcement that British and American aviation engineers have successfully developed a rocket or jet-propelled type of airplane has stirred up immense interest. This is one of the most important technological advances made in this war, likely to have telling effects on the further course of the conflict and deep influence on the whole future of flying.
Forty-six contributions amounting to $1,182.98 were received for the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, increasing the total of this season's campaign, which opened on Dec. 5, to $277,082.60.

The famous bathysphere used by Dr. William Beebe for the study of deep sea marine life has gone into war service, it was disclosed last night by Fairfield Osborn, president of the New York Zoological Society, at its annual meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Despite the President's criticism in his message to Congress today of the pending tax bill and his request for a "realistic" law, there were no indications that his appeal would carry any more weight than other recent Administration requests on taxes.

Dominic Torpe of George Washington High School yesterday was elected chairman of the high school games committee for a period of two years, succeeding John McNulty of Grover Cleveland, whose term expired. Torpe was formerly chairman of the baseball committee. The election was announced yesterday at the monthly meeting of the high school games committee of the P.S.A.L. at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Schooling civilians in general and families in particular to prepare them for the shock of encountering maimed and neuro-psychiatric soldiers from overseas was urged by six Army nurses from the hospital ship Acadia who made a detailed hospital ship report today at a press conference.

Approval of Investigation Commissioner William B. Herlands' report on anti-Semitism in New York, with its criticism of the Police Department for alleged laxity and indifference in dealing with some of the incidents, was voiced yesterday by a number of organizations that have taken a special interest in the problem.

NAPLES, Italy, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Demands of Italian political leaders that King Victor Emmanuel abdicate in favor of the 6-year-old Prince of Naples, his grandson, were laid before the Soviet and French members of the Inter-Allied Advisory Council on Italy today.

ALGIERS, Jan. 11 -- A decree just promulgated by the French Committee of National Liberation has united the two French women's auxiliary army organizations and incorporated them as a single group into the nation's military forces.

Army and Navy contract cancellations already amount to $8,000,000,000, with resultant unemployment that will become a serious problem in some communities this year as cancellations continue, Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri asserted here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- John Holmes, president of Swift Co., denied today assertions made to the small business committee of the House that packers and producers were not cooperating in the Government's meat control program.

Retail institutional advertising has increased greatly during the war and the increase is likely to be prolonged after the cessation of hostilities, according to an article entitled "Has Retail Institutional Advertising Come of Age?" by Joseph Lorin in the Journal of Retailing.

Admonished to deliver to the State Athletic Commission any future criticisms he has to offer concerning the conduct of boxing in this State, Chick Wergeles, manager of Beau Jack, lightweight titleholder, yesterday was let off with a reprimand at a hearing of the commission which demanded an explanation of why Wergeles vehemently criticized Referee Eddie Joseph for his scoring of the recent Beau Jack-Lulu Costantino bout in Madison Square Garden.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday accused Chester A. Bowles, Office of Price Administration chief, of "dishing out carbon copy" while the people of New York were asking for food. The Mayor's broadside was contained in a telegram to the OPA administrator and marked the third round in the battle of words that began with the Mayor's seven-point "indictment" of Mr. Bowles, broadcast over the municipal radio station last Sunday.
Stephen A. Dutton is dead. He was buried last Monday in Potters Field.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- With members expressing confidence in a growing trend against President Roosevelt and the New Deal, the Republican National Committee voted unanimously today to hold the national convention in Chicago, beginning Monday, June 26. The meeting was, on the surface, completely harmonious.

Many a good fisherman devotes the off season to bowling but few bowlers give a thought to fishing as they heave the sixteen-pound ball down the alley. Nevertheless, the kegling clan can take a deep bow for what it is doing for fishermen in the armed forces.

Actors Equity Association rejected yesterday afternoon a request by the Central Trades and Labor Council, central body of American Federation of Labor unions here, that it take "appropriate action," against Paul Robeson, Negro actor and singer, for his honorary membership in a Congress of Industrial Organizations union.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The text of President Roosevelt's annual message to Congress was as follows:

Post-war planning now under way by at least 1,000 corporations will tend to reduce the time necessary for a return to civilian economy, Noel Sargent, general secretary of the National Association of Manufacturers, said yesterday in an address before the Association of Customers Brokers, meeting in the governors' room of the New York Stock Exchange.

The Dressmakers Local 22 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union has voted to subscribe $600,000 to the Fourth War Loan, it was announced last night by the local's manager, Charles Zimmerman, at a rally in Manhattan Center, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

The Committee of Fifteen, headed by Paul Windels, is rendering a service in pressing its side of the five-cent fare issue. Last week another real estate group joined the agitation for increasing the rapid transit fare in New York.

Wagner's cycle, "Der Ring des Nibelungen," unabridged, will be given by the Metropolitan Opera company on the last four Tuesday evenings in February, Edward Johnson, general manager, announced yesterday. "Das Rheingold," which opens the cycle, will be presented on Feb. 8; "Die Walkuere" on Feb. 15, "Siegfried" on Feb. 22 and "Goetterdaemmerung" on Feb. 29.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 11 -- Changes in directors and officers were announced at five Montclair banking institutions at annual meetings held today.

Charging that the nation has a tax system "of appalling complexity," and that unless a new program is adopted that will stimulate and not depress the national income, other measures can produce only "false and fleeting prosperity" after the war, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that it is high time that the matter be studied.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Like the Hatfields of Kentucky, the McIntyres and the Mitchells of Chicken Island in Yonkers feel they are entitled to a little free play with firearms when feuding gets in their blood, patriarchs of the clans told a Westchester County grand jury here today in winning dismissals of two charges of first degree assault.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Admiral William F. Halsey Jr. declared here today that, when the "showdown" comes, the United States Pacific Fleet will be able to fight in the home waters around the Japanese islands as effectively as it has in the Solomon Islands and elsewhere.

The role women will play in the post-war economy will be discussed at The New York Times Hall, 240 Future of Women," to be held Thursday, Jan. 20, at 8:30 P.M., at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- A German blockade-runner sunk recently in the South Atlantic was flying the Argentine flag and had eleven Argentine seamen in her crew, the newspaper O Globo said today.

The cotton futures market advanced moderately yesterday as increased fixations by the trade, particularly in the near positions, met only scale-up hedge offerings and scattered realizing operations. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts registered net gains of 3 to 5 points.
ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Governor Dewey at a press conference today declined to say that if he was nominated for President he would not run and that if he was elected he would not serve.

Lehman Brothers and an associated group of Mexican bankers and industrialists yesterday announced completion of the formation of the Compania de Fomento Panamericana, S.A., or Pan American Development Company, with headquarters in Mexico City.

The National City Bank looks forward to financing the post-war needs of its business clients without Government protection, Gordon S. Rentschler, chairman of the board, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders here. The bank has unallocated reserves of more than $40,000,000 after transfers to surplus, which will enable it to be "ready to take reasonable banking risks in meeting the legitimate credit needs of its customers," he declared.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- Striking union employes of the city's Water, Highways and Street Cleaning Bureaus flatly rejected tonight an offer by the City Council of a wage increase amounting to about three cents an hour and countered with a proposal that would accord to them their original demands of 10 cents an hour until May 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Chester Bowles, Federal Price Administrator, denounced in a radio address tonight "unscrupulous pressure groups, often financed by war profiteers and chiselers," for "resourceful and relentless" efforts to break down price control through the hiring of "expensive lobbyists" and "skilled publicity men."

Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore, in a letter to Mayor La Guardia yesterday, not only turned down the Mayor's invitation to speak over WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station, but delivered a stinging attack on the use of the station as a waste of public funds and for what he said was the exploitation of the public at its own expense.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The United States is expected to continue its efforts looking to a reasonable adjustment of the Polish question in the face of Soviet claims to territory up to the Curzon Line and denunciations in Moscow of the Polish Government-in-Exile in London as insufficiently representative of the Polish people.

Lawrence Ottinger, president of the United States Plywood Corporation, said yesterday that according to present indications the plywood industry faces a complicated situation this year, whether we have war or peace.
John Garris, Metropolitan Opera tenor, gave his debut song recital in the United States at Town Hall last night before a large and enthusiastic audience.
LONDON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, speaking yesterday at a memorial meeting for Carlo Tresca, anarchist editor slain a year ago, criticized "police inactivity" in the case.

The auction sale of the library of the late Charles C. Kalbfleisch of this city, which was completed last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., brought a total of $73,239. The collection, which comprised more than 1,000 lots, was called by its owner "The Arts of the Book," and included rare items of early printing, fine illustration and binding.

Making a pointed exception, for the present, of the police and firemen, Mayor La Guardia announced late yesterday afternoon that he had granted cost-of-living pay increases to 100,000 employes in fifty-three city departments and county offices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today in his third wartime message on the state of the Union to enact "wholly non-partisan" national service legislation to put every able-bodied man and woman, with certain exceptions to be specified, at the service of the Government and to "prevent strikes" for the duration of the war.
Reports of annual meetings of banks here and in other places at which important changes were made yesterday follow. The national banking laws set the second Tuesday in January for such meetings.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 11 -- Sigurd A. Emerson of the law firm of Hood, Lafferty Emerson, was elected today a member of the board of directors of the Fidelity Union Trust Company at the annual meeting of the stockholders.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 12 -- Admiration for the courage of President Roosevelt in speaking out as he did in election year and on such topics as a national service law was the reaction of the British people as reflected in the press.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Organized labor is strongly opposed to national service legislation as unnecessary at this time, according to comment by spokesmen here today.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Ann Clare Brokaw, 19, daughter of Clare Boothe Luce, Republican Representative from Connecticut, was fatally injured in an automobile collision near the Leland Stanford University campus today and died before she reached a hospital.

Further relaxation of metal limitation controls is expected to take place first in products which are using wood or plastics as substitute materials, due to the fact that the supply of the latter is becoming increasingly severe for war production, manufacturers observed yesterday in reviewing recent WPB orders.

Since Berlin announces it, there is no reason to doubt the accuracy of its report that Count Ciano, Mussolini's son-in-law and former Foreign Minister, as well as four other Fascist stalwarts, have been executed at Verona. They richly deserved their fate, but it is one of the ironies of history that they should have died, not for crimes they committed, but for crimes they did not commit.

ALGIERS, Jan. 11 -- In reply to charges that the French Committee of National Liberation had been lax in purging Vichy office holders in North Africa, Francois de Menthon, Commissioner of Justice, told the Provisional Consultative Assembly today that a special new military court formed by the Committee would begin in a few days to try 288 persons accused in the past two months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Recent action placing on a jobber's price for woven decorative fabrics a top limit of 185 per cent of the manufacturer's or converter's ceiling is intended to apply only to the jobbers sales of goods acquired from sources other than manufacturers or converters, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

The Horn Hardart Baking Company, which operates restaurants and retail bakery shops here, in Philadelphia, Camden, N.J., and other cities, transacted a record volume of business in the year ended on Sept. 30, with sales of $21,560,981, or $3,612,289 above the total for the preceding fiscal year, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 11 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 11 (U.P.) -- Allied troops, crossing into western Burma in possible preparation for a major offensive, have captured Maungdaw, fifty-five miles above the Burmese port of Akyab, and are driving on down the Mayu Peninsula in the face of heavy Japanese opposition, Admiral the Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters announced tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan by the Public Service Company of Oklahoma to issue 15,000 shares of 5 per cent preferred stock and to assume $6,640,000 face amount of 3 3/4 per cent first mortgage bonds of Southwestern Light and Power Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (U.P.) -- Fighting Squadron 27 has been disbanded after having scored a "proud record" in twelve months of almost continuous fighting in both the Pacific and European theatres, the Navy announced today.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 11 -- Ex-Mayor William H. Seaman was elected a trustee for three years of the Glen Cove Trust Company at the annual stockholders' meeting today. William H. Ogden, president of the New York Water Service Corporation in Glen Cove, was elected a director for two years.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Jan. 12 (UP) -- A communique:
ALGIERS, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Maj. Gens. Ernest N. Harmon, Lowell W. Rooks and Manton S. Eddy were among the American generals named Companions of the Order of the Bath in the list announced today.

The decision of Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine clearing Patrolman James L. Drew of charges of anti-Semitism and association with persons engaged in subversive activities was upheld yesterday by the unofficial board appointed by Mayor La Guardia to review the evidence.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- The American Council for Judaism issued today a declaration through its president, Lessing J. Rosenwald, opposing the provisions of the British White Paper on Palestine that would stop immigration of Jews to the Holy Land and restrict their purchase of land.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- The Government filed suit in Federal District Court here today for an injunction in perpetuity to end what it called a conspiracy among sixty-five individual and corporate defendants in the long-distance moving industry.

While permanently higher prices and higher wages will prevail in the post-war period there will be a relative decline in the prices of manufactured products compared to wages and costs, Lewis H. Brown, president, Johns-Manville Corporation, predicted yesterday.

CHICAGO. Jan. 11 -- Although the wheat market showed a relatively firm undertone, prices on the Board of Trade failed to get to the ceiling level for the first time in about a week. Speculative interest was not large and there was an absence of aggressive buying attributed to cash or milling interests.

ALGIERS, Jan. 11 -- King George VI of England has honored eighteen United States generals, ten other commissioned officers, one sergeant and two privates with various decorations and this morning at his headquarters here Gen. Sir Henry Maitland Wilson, Allied Commander in Chief in the Mediterranean theatre, formally presented them to six of the generals and three of the other officers.

Maxwell Anderson has contributed a good many distinguished plays to the theatre, but "Storm Operation," which opened last evening at the Belasco, is not one of them. To gather material for it, he toured the Army's lines in North Africa, and from General Eisenhower, himself, he received the suggestion for the title -- which was the code name for invasion.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 11 -- Rabbi Barnett R. Brickner said today that he had been particularly impressed by the good care taken of American soldiers in all the theatres he had visited, including India, the Persian Gulf and the Middle East.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 11 (AP) -- King Gustav V, in a speech from the throne at the opening of Parliament, declared today that Sweden must remain armed and on guard while the belligerents are "rallying forces with the aim of gaining a decision in the great struggle."

Opening tonight at the Cort is "Suds in Your Eye," Jack Kirkland's dramatization of Mary Lasswell's gusty novel. It deals with the good-natured Mrs. Feeley, her San Diego junk yard and her two beer-drinking companions, who consume so much beer that the wall surrounding the junk yard is almost entirely made up of guess what? -- empty beer bottles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The President sent his annual message to Congress on the state of the Union and included the major part of it in a broadcast from the White House during the evening. The President's message was read in both House and Senate.

ALGIERS, Jan. 11 -- Royal Air Force Wellingtons resumed the crushing air offensive against Sofia last night. During the day the Bulgarian capital had suffered the heaviest bombing in its history in a noon attack by Flying Fortresses of the Fifteenth United States Air Force.

Harriman, Ripley Co., Inc., and Otis Co., Inc., have announced the over-subscription of their offering of 450,000 shares of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company's 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value.

A broad rally swept yesterday over the stock market and returned values to the best level of the new year although prices were shaded and activity dwindled after the release of President Roosevelt's message to the Congress. The upsweep during the morning was spearheaded by the steels, rails and an assortment of specialties, notably the radio and electronics group, and it was in the pre-noon period that volume reached its peak.

SOMEWHERE IN ITALY, Jan. 11 -- Any idea that German resistance is about to curl up is certainly not shared by the fighting men bearing the brunt of the American end of the Allied drive in Italy. Reports brought in by new troops and travelers that many people back home look for an almost momentary end to the European phase of the war are greeted by these men with amazement.
The request for a National Service Law was put forward as the fifth point of a five-point program which the President recommended as a unit. The first four points deserve individual consideration:

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Australians using mortars, artillery and tanks against a strong Japanese rearguard have advanced across the Buri River on the Huon Peninsula coast of New Guinea in their push toward American invasion troops at Saidor.

The Boston Olympics extended their Eastern Hockey League winning string to twelve games by defeating the Crescents last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace, 7 to 4. Boston led all the way. Don Raleigh of the Crescents and Russell Kopak of the Olympics each scored three goals.

Howard A. DeLong, who has been manager of the New York office for the Charles P. Cochrane Company, carpet manufacturers, Bridegport, Pa., has been appointed Eastern division manager, it was announced yesterday. Mr. DeLong has been associated with the company for the past fifteen years.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- The Senate and Assembly, by concurrent action today, voted $15,000 for the use of the Joint Legislative Committee on Reapportionment in assisting the counties of the State and the City of New York to draw Assembly lines under the legislative redistricting bill enacted at the 1943 session.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (U.P.) -- The Federal Trade Commission brought charges today against seven manufacturers, 300 distributors and two trade associations of conspiring to suppress competition and monopolize the rock-crushing machinery trade and issued a cease and desist order, effective immediately.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Luis Lopez Cordon-Cuenca, 24 years of age, and Jose Martin Munoz, 20, both Spaniards, were executed this morning at Gibraltar for the parts they played in a sabotage ring developed by enemy agents, it was announced here today.

LONDON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Great Britain's National Service Act, which was praised by President Roosevelt today as "a unifying moral force," provides for compulsory service for both men and women and is administered by the Ministry of Labor.

A series of baffling jewelry thefts in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, was laid yesterday to a former tap-dancer who was said to have made a set of duplicate pass keys while employed in the building as a night watchman.
What is the true motive behind the anti-trust suits, which have increased over 3,000 per cent since 1933?

W. Hunt Hall, holder of thirty-seven shares of stock in the New York, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company, brought suit yesterday in Supreme Court to compel the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railway Company to pay approved stock dividends under a sixty-two-year-old lease.

The problem of what to do with obsolete bank records that merely have gathered dust in bank vaults for many years has been answered by the Lincoln National Bank of Newark, N.J. The answer is easy: bale them and turn them over to a local Paper Salvage Committee.
ALGIERS, Jan. 11 -- A communique:

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 12 -- Soviet troops, reaching thirty-nine miles into Poland, yesterday split the tottering German armies of the Ukraine from those in White Russia by capturing railroad points north and south of Sarny. The Red Army also opened a new push to the southeast, advancing within sixteen miles of the five-way rail junction of Shepetovka.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- When the Curzon Line, which Soviet Russia has now proposed as Poland's post-war eastern border, was drawn in 1919 by the victors in World War I, a representative of the United States Government participated in a meeting of the Supreme Council in Paris at which this boundary was approved.

Wilhelm Albrecht von Pressentin Gennant von Rautter, a naturalized American who was born a German count, wept yesterday before United States Commissioner Jacob A. Visel in Brooklyn. Said to have received at least $5,000 for services to the Nazis, he was accused of conspiracy to violate the wartime espionage statute, a crime punishable by death or imprisonment up to thirty years.

Although the Japanese soldier is an aggressive and brave fighter, his fear of loss of face eventually will contribute to victory over Japan in the Pacific, Capt. W.S. LeFrancois of the Marine Corps asserted yesterday at its public relations headquarters in 90 Church Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The dispute between the railroad managements and the three holdout operating brotherhoods over the "freeze" status of the five cents an hour awarded in place of overtime pay by President Roosevelt to engineers and trainmen was the major obstacle to an agreement, it was reported tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Count Ciano, Marshal Emilio de Bono and three other members of the Italian Fascist Grand Council who were executed by a firing squad at Verona today, insisted to the end that they were innocent of the charge of treason, the German news agency DNB said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- One of the most important issues in recent years was left today for settlement by the Supreme Court as argument closed on the question whether the fire insurance business legally constitutes commerce and thus may be subject to prosecution under the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

The rise of Isaac Stern to the upper ranks of violinists has not been as sensational as that of some of his colleagues and predecessors, but he has arrived with an authority that indicates he belongs and plans to stay. In his recital at Carnegie Hall last night he played with admirable integrity.

NYACK, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Stockholders of the Nyack Bank and Trust Company voted today to authorize an increase in the common stock from $200,000 to $400,000 through a 100 per cent stock dividend. It was announced that during the past year $250,000 of Class A preferred stock held by the RFC had been retired.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Speaking at a football award dinner of the Touchdown Club, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox said tonight the Navy planned to continue its football program. He declared Navy officials were convinced of its training value in fitting men for combat, adding that be disagreed emphatically with the Army policy of banning varsity sports in its college training schools.
Grover Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's Committee on New York as the World's Fashion Center, made known yesterday that the committee will issue its report on the project next week.

TORONTO, Jan. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Toronto crushed the league-leading Canadiens, 5 -- 0, in a National Hockey League game tonight before 12,641 spectators at Maple Leaf Gardens to end a Montreal streak of nine consecutive victories.
MOSCOW, Jan. 11 -- Details of the recent fierce fighting at Kirovograd were made public in a frontline dispatch to the Red Army newspaper Red Star today.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- Enormous fleets of fighter-escorted American heavy bombers, constantly battling great swarms of Nazi interceptors and the full might of Germany's most desperate aerial defense, spread ruin and destruction over northwest Germany yesterday -- possibly also hitting Berlin -- in what probably was history's greatest air battle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's recommendation for a national service law may bring to a final decision whether sports is essential to the war effort -- a verdict long sought in the sports world and in Congress.

How to salvage ten tons of waste paper daily from the city's 900 theatres will be discussed today at a meeting of the American Women's Volunteer Services with the theatre managers and representatives of the New York City Newspaper Publishers Association in the Times Tower, Times Square.

Women throughout the nation are entering wholeheartedly into the war program -- working in war industries, engaging in volunteer services, cooperating in salvage and other projects -- but when the war is over, there will be a general exodus from these outside activities back into the home.

Mr. Churchill's dressing gown, as passed by the censor and pictured in this newspaper yesterday, is obviously not something that he picked up on a visit to the bazaars between conference sessions in Teheran.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Allied fighters, fighter-bombers and medium bombers of both the Tactical and Strategic Air Forces swarmed over Burma from Nanyaseik, twenty-five miles northwest of the rail and river-port city of Mogaung in the north to Akyab in the south, suffering no losses, it was announced today.

For more than a year this newspaper has repeatedly urged upon the President and Congress the enactment of a National War Service Act which would impose upon the whole adult population of this country the same binding legal obligation to help win the war which has hitherto rested exclusively upon young men of draft age.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 12 -- There were not more than 2,500,000 Poles, of a population of 11,000,000, in the provinces east of the Curzon Line when the latest reliable census was taken in 1931, according to a study of the Russian-Polish frontier problem published in The Times of London today.

DETROIT, Jan. 11 -- Gross operating income of the National Bank of Detroit for 1943 was $14,007,281, or substantially more than the $10,881,603 reported for 1942. This resulted from firmer short-term interest rates, maintenance of a larger Government securities account, in keeping with the bank's growth, and a greater volume of loans, Walter S. McLucas, the chairman, said at the annual meeting today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Bituminous coal production during 1943 rose to an estimated total of 589,000,000 tons, a new record, exceeding by 9,000,000 that of 1942 but "at least 21,000,000 tons less than the year's combined consumption and export total, which will run between 610,000,000 and 620,000,000 tons," Secretary Ickes, Solid Fuels Administrator, stated today.
LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Stock markets here were quiet again today and the tone was dull.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Proposals for legislation on behalf of veterans were conspicuous in the first full day's session of Congress since the holiday recess.

Securities of the Florida Power and Light Company amounting to $55 000,000 will be offered today to the public by an underwriting syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation. The offering consists of $45,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1974 and $10,000,000 of 4 1/8 per cent sinking fund debentures due in 1979.

The last college basketball double-header until Feb. 8 will be offered at Madison Square Garden tonight, with C.C.N.Y. engaging Brooklyn College in the feature attraction and L.I.U. meeting West Virginia. City College and Long Island are the choices.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Soviet Russia's offer to "guarantee the integrity of a strong and independent Poland," provided the Poles move their eastern frontier to the vicinity of the Curzon Line has precipitated a crisis in Russo-Polish relations.
One of the most notable gatherings of sports figures to assemble in years will participate in a radio broadcast to launch the program of the Fourth War Loan Drive Sports Committee.

The 1,096 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $90,840,915,406 par value as of Dec. 31, had a total market value of $90,274,071,634, according to a report by the Exchange yesterday. As of Nov. 30 there were 1,098 issues, aggregating $90,969,856,933 par value, which had a total market value or $90,076,888,558.

The Anisfield Awards, founded by Mrs. Edith Anisfield Wolf in memory of her father, will be offered again this year under the sponsorship of The Saturday Review of Literature for the best books on racial relations. Two prizes, a first award of $1,500 and a second of $500, will be given.

The vital part that retailers, operating through their regional associations must be prepared to take in post-war planning at the community level was stressed yesterday by Edward N. Allen, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 11 -- Boris Morros, former Paramount and Twentieth Century-Fox producer, announced today that he had acquired the film rights to "Of Thee I Sing," the Pulitzer Prize musical show of 1932. According to Morros, the picture will be made for United Artists in the summer, with George Kaufman, Morrie Ryskind, Ira Gershwin and the estates of the late Sam Harris and George Gershwin sharing in the profits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Roosevelt gave his Pacific War Council a full report of his Cairo and Teheran conferences today at his first meeting with its members since his return from the Middle East. It also was the first time he had come over to the executive offices from his adjoining residence since his illness with the grippe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Practice air raid alerts and blackouts in which the public participates have been eliminated except in some coastal areas, the War Department and Office of Civilian Defense announced today. Henceforth, such alerts will be held along the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts not oftener than once in three months and then on Sundays.
A twelve-room duplex penthouse apartment at 1100 Park Avenue was leased to Benjamin Kovner through Rossbach Associates, brokers, and the Payson McL. Merrill Company, agent.

Winter brings with it special hazards for motorists and pedestrians. Streets and highways are treacherous. Short days add to the dangers which always accompany the hours of darkness. Traffic accidents last winter increased the mileage death rate in snow-belt States 24 per cent above the summer total.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Two American conflict, one against the Luftwaffe over central Germany yesterday and the other against President Roosevelt's proposed national service legislation, were prominently displayed on front pages of London newspapers.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- It was weird, waiting for death up there where the temperature was 33 degrees below zero, but you sweated so that you took off your gloves and turned off the heat in your flying suit. It was eerily quiet, with even your engines sounding strangely muffled while you waited for death to make his entrance.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs were reduced to 20,000 head today, but holdovers at the end of the session were reported at 17,000. Packers had 7,000 of the fresh arrivals on direct billings, leaving 13,000 head, plus the 23,000 head acid over from Tuesday's trade, available for sale.

Women are taking a steadily increasing part in campaigns of labor-management committees to stimulate war production. These volunteer groups, supported in essential plants by the War Production Board, have many women members and four women chairmen in New York State, Reuben A. Posner, regional manager of the WPB production drive in this area, revealed yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 12 -- Unless the nations of the world unite to destroy the Nazi educational philosophy that trains children to be "young fanatics" we will have to fight Germany again in another war, Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, warned a thousand educators here today.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Field Marshal Gen. Fritz Erich von Mannstein is making a desperate effort to stem the Russian advance toward the Bug River to extricate the Eighth and Sixth German armies farther east. The movement from the eastern Ukraine has already started, according to well-informed observers here, and the Germans probably intend to withdraw to a line on the Bug.

Brooklyn College's first basketball victory over C.C.N.Y. still is something to be dreamed about in Flatbush. The rivals met at Madison Square Garden last night and in the presence of 15,333 persons, Nat Holman's Beavers recorded their fourteenth straight conquest in the series, 41 -- 33. The opener resulted in a 51-39 triumph for Long Island University over West Virginia.

Collaboration of the United States with other Governments to establish and maintain orderly production from oil resources throughout the world for the benefit of the consuming nations is suggested by the Standard Oil Company (N.J) in the Lamp, official publication of the company.

Sidney Hillman's proposal that trade unions, primarily those affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations, be given control of the political machinery of the American Labor party in New York State was rejected formally yesterday by the party's State executive committee, which denounced it as "illegal, undemocratic and immoral."

Top executives of two leading American airlines debated yesterday the merits of free and unrestricted competition for post-war transoceanic air routes as compared with the "chosen instrument" plan under which all airlines would pool resources to develop a restricted number of lines.

After twenty months the Government has raised the ban on the publication of figures showing the stocks, consumption and production of non-ferrous metals. The figures for the copper industry, released yesterday by the Copper Institute, reveal that the war demand for that metal was met, although foreign sources had to be called upon rather heavily.

The inventory position of gasoline and light fuel oil on the East Coast was improved last week, but there was a deterioration in heavy fuel oil supplies. The index of the American Petroleum Institute covering gasoline stocks on the Atlantic Coast at the end of that period stood at 43.6, against 42.5 a week earlier.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12--The[ Office of Price Administration today tightened its shoe rationing regulations to forbid any supplier from transferring shoes to any dealer who owes ration currency either to the supplier or, within his knowledge, to any other supplier.

Col. C.V. Whitney's Pukka Gin, who joined the ranks of 3-year-olds with other thoroughbred race horses on Jan. 15, heads John B. Campbell's Experimental Handicap made public yesterday by The Racing Calendar. The handicap, based on 2-year-old performances, is purely mythical -- or was until Jamaica started actual six-furlong racing at these weights.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- A bill making it a misdemeanor to publish or cause to be published any false written or printed material promoting hatred of any group because of race, color, or creed, will be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow under bi-partisan sponsorship.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- A communique:

WITH GENERAL STILWELL in Burma, Jan. 6 (Delayed) (AP) -- American construction genius has pushed the new Ledo road through the primeval jungle of northern Burma almost on the heels of Chinese troops clearing the zone of Japanese in the upper reaches of the Chidwin River.

President Roosevelt has effectively summed up the reasons why the Federal Government must take the responsibility for getting in the soldiers' and sailors' votes. He rightly challenged the argument that the Constitution must be construed to "take away the franchise of any of those who are fighting to preserve the Constitution itself."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Government is endeavoring to establish a ninety-day stock pile of newsprint for publications in Latin-American republics, the State Department announced today.

From Mary Lasswell's book of the same title Jack Kirkland has brought forth an evening in the theatre called "Suds in Your Eye." It could not be called a play, exactly, for it has no particular plot; probably Brown and Del Bondio, who offered it last night at the Cort, would settle for naming it a character study.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The State Department held out little hope tonight for the early repatriation of American citizens remaining in Japanese custody since the two trips home of the exchange ship Gripsholm, but it emphasized that it was bending every effort to obtain Japanese consent to further exchanges.

Two groups of wartime clothing for women were shown to the public for the first time last evening in the Waldorf-Astoria Ballroom at the tenth annual fashion show sponsored by the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers.

A conspiracy in which the Chase National Bank of the City of New York was described as having assisted a refugee diamond merchant to obtain illicit access to funds with which he financed an extensive trade with Axis nations, in circumvention of United States laws, was alleged in two Federal indictments opened here yesterday.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- United States Marines on New Britain Island have killed six Japanese for every American killed or wounded since the leathernecks landed at Cape Gloucester on Dec. 26, it was disclosed today, as Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique revealed that 300 more Japanese were slain Monday and Tuesday in the Borgen Bay area.

DETROIT, Jan. 12 -- A low opinion of Japanese war materiel was expressed tonight by Maj. Gen. G.M. Barnes of the Army Ordnance Department, speaking at the annual dinner of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Senate moved today in the direction of a compromise measure on ballots for service men to take the place of the State rights bill which it adopted and sent to the House before the Christmas recess.

The appointment of Mrs. Betty Hawley Donnelly, vice president of the New York State Federation of Labor, and Miss Sadie Reisch of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union to the Camp Fire Girls Council of Greater New York, to further the cooperation of organized labor with the council's program for the prevention of juvenile delinquency, was announced yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Army established a new home court record by trouncing Swarthmore, 80-29, today in the academy filed house as the cadets opened their first season under Coach Ed Kelleher, former Fordham basketball mentor. The previous scoring mark was 72, established last winter.

New York City's 1944 quota for the American Red Cross War Fund has been set at $22,386,000, the largest amount ever sought by that organization in this area, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of Red Cross officials in the Council chamber at City Hall.

Offering will be made today of a new issue of $20,000,000 ofI Puerto Rico Water Resources Au-{ thority electric revenue 2@ per cent bonds, due semi-annually on Jan. 1, 1945 to 1969, and priced to yield 1.80 to 2.50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A country-wide program of educating civilians on how to meet maimed soldiers returning from battle, such as was suggested yesterday by six Army nurses from the hospital ship Acadia, was declared "eminently practical" today by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The House Committee on Foreign Affairs took the first legislative step today toward furnishing relief to the peoples of war-devastated countries after their liberation from Axis domination.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Bombers of the United States Army Air Forces yesterday smashed three important German fighter plane factories in "one of the hardest blows yet struck against the German Air Force," Gen. H.H. Arnold, AAF commanding general, reported tonight.

Long Island's first frozen food locker plant is being constructed at Westbury and is expected to be in operation by mid-March or thereabouts, according to a representative of the owners, Country Life Frozen Foods, Inc. This building -- or rather series of buildings -- will take care of Slaughtering live- stock and poultry, curing and smoking meats and quick-freezing all manner of fruits and vegetables.

Vinton Freedley, who has been specializing in the production of hit musicals for many years, is bringing "Jackpot" to the Alvin this evening. For the sake of all concerned and the cash customers, too, he hopes the show is appropriately entitled.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Germans fought violently to hold their positions, sending many futile counter-attacks against the Russians. They failed with a loss of 2,000 men, twenty-two tanks destroyed and forty artillery and mortar batteries silenced. War material was captured and prisoners were taken, Moscow reported.

In the text of the Moscow broadcast on Polish boundaries the first sentence, as printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES, refers to "a declaration of the exiled Polish Government." This is the translation furnished by the Federal Communications Commission.

The Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America, producer of a wide variety of self-locking nuts and other fastening devices, has filed an amendment to its registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, in which it gives the interest rate on the proposed issue of $3,500,000 of fifteen-year sinking fund debentures as 5 per cent.

United Artists yesterday announced that Arthur W. Kelly, vice president and member of the board, had relinquished his post as supervisor of foreign distribution to assume the direction of the company's television activities. This was the first indication that the distributing company was contemplating entering the television field.

International action to keep peace, including use of force if necessary, was urged last night by Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Boston Methodist Area at a mass meeting of Methodists here. Sessions started in the morning and were held throughout the day in Hanson Place Central Methodist Church at St. Felix Street, Brooklyn.

The Federal Government's crackdown on a "million dollar" black market whisky ring, which began last month with the arrest of seven alleged racketeers, spread yesterday to the wholesale supply branch of the liquor industry as the alcohol tax unit of the Treasury Department set a license revocation hearing for a company with offices here and at Philadelphia.

The former Ardrey estate of about three and one-half acres at Guion Road and Grace Church Street, in Rye, Westchester County, has been sold by the Bank for Savings to J.I. Padawer through Previews, Inc., and the Raymond R. Beatty Organization.

A program of Basic English for adults, to be tried out during the school term beginning in February, was adopted yesterday afternoon by the Board of Education at its regular meeting. Ten to twelve classes will be set up in the evening elementary schools.

Decrying excessive optimism] over an early end of the war and[ scoring the belief that the peak of requirements of the armed forces has been passed, Ernest L. Olrich, president of @Iunsingwear, Inc., warned yesterday that production of civilian textile merchandise thisI year will be far short of what the buying public will want and need.

Stuart Crocker, president of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, announced yesterday that stockholaers of the company at a !recent special meeting had apreproved a pension plan for employes of the Columbia Gas system.
