With 8,651,410 shares represented at the meeting, Mr. Cooper said, 5,514,609 shares were voted in favor of the plan and 3,087,237 against it.

Jesse Stuart, author of "Taps for Private Tussie," who was scheduled to speak at Town Hall Saturday morning, has been called into the Army and will not be able to fill the engagement. Stewart W. Herman Jr., author of "It's Your Souls We Want," former attache at the American Embassy in Berlin, will be heard in Mr. Stuart's place.

While consumers' cooperatives have more than doubled their sales volume since 1939, such growth cannot continue unless existing retail and other distributive institutions fail to keep up the sales value they have offered in the past, Dr. Paul H. Nystrom, Professor of Marketing at Columbia University, stated yesterday at the Opening day sessions of the American Marketing Association's marketing conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The complex affairs of the Chosen Corporation, of which Serge Rubinstein, who is now in the United States, was former managing director and is still the biggest shareholder, are being aired again in most of London's leading newspapers.
Mr. and Mrs. George Peabody and Stephen Peabody Jr. have come from Westport, Conn., to the St. Regis.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The extent to which uncertainty over conditions in the immediate future has its influence on legislation is being manifested particularly in connection with current attempts to revise the State's system of unemployment insurance to provide for "merit-rating."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Captured Germans marvel at the expert small arms marksmanship of United States troops, two Army ground forces observers reported to the War Department upon their return from Italy, where they watched the Fifth Army in action, it was stated today.
With three new players set for action, the Rangers, seeking their fifth victory of the National Hockey League campaign, will oppose the Black Hawks tonight at Madison Square Garden.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 12 -- A tall, fast-moving St. Joseph's five handed the Princeton basketball team its fourth straight defeat tonight. The score was 48 to 31. John Flannery paced the Hawks with 13 points, while John McEnroe and Gabriel Poletti followed with 10 apiece.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The Polish Government-in-Exile will offer to discuss the question of the Russo-Polish boundary with Soviet officials as soon as diplomatic relations between the two Governments are resumed, it was learned tonight.
WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Gen. Henry H. Arnold, Army Air Force chief, here on an official trip, issued a statement amplifying previous reports on the big air assault on Germany Tuesday.
May I analyze the letter from the Under-Secretary of War, Judge Patterson, published in the Dec. 30 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 12 -- The Hellenic News Service announced today that the Greek Ambassador to Moscow, Athanasios Politis, had received a note from Alexander Korneichuk, Soviet Vice Foreign Commissar, yesterday in which the Russian attitude toward the guerrilla bands fighting in Greece was clarified.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Prices were lower today in most sections of the stock market here. Grit-edge issues, held steady but home rails again gave way. Among the industrials British Celanese was the weak spot and store shares were lower.

ALGIERS, Jan. 12 -- The tightening of the Allies' clamp about Cassino brought Fifth Army troops yesterday to the foothills of Mount Trocchio, slightly more than three miles from their objective. Mount Trocchio is the final razor-back astride the path to Cassino south of the Via Casilina.

Consumer "resistance" toward Victory-model furniture, designed to save critical materials, has in many cases been strong enough to discourage further manufacture of such pieces, it was agreed yesterday by wholesale dealers and buyers at the annual exhibit of the New York Furniture Exchange.

Ole Singstad, chief engineer of the New York City Tunnel Authority, was chosen yesterday by the students of Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn as the recipient of this year's Lincoln Award for meritorious service to the city, according to an announcement by Gabriel R. Mason, principal of the high school.

Reflecting the improved mill demand for spot cotton throughout the South, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday extended the gains made on Tuesday. Trading was relatively light, with price fixations by the trade against textile contracts and New Orleans buying largely accounting for the advance.

We had the pleasure and profit last night in Carnegie Hall of hearing Nathan Milstein play the violin in a program that embraced Mozart, Bach and Paganini, with short pieces by Prokofieff and Stravinsky. This was very distinguished and masterful playing.

A large increase in active tuberculosis in the next few years was predicted yesterday by Dr. Herbert R. Edwards, director of the bureau of tuberculosis of the Department of Health, who said "thousands" of persons with the latent disease probably were in war industries now.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 12 -- David O. Selznick today bought the screen rights to "Portrait of Jennie," a novel by Robert Nathan, within twenty-four hours after Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer dropped its option to buy the property for $25,000, the price that Selznick is understood to have paid for the book, which will be a starring vehicle for Jennifer Jones.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury questioned C. Nelson Sparks, former Mayor of Akron, Ohio, for an hour today about a letter bearing the name of Harry Hopkins and purporting to predict that Wendell Willkie would be the Republican Presidential nominee.

SOMEWHERE IN ITALY, Jan. 12 -- Readily expressed attitudes of American service men and women throughout the North African-Italian war theatre leaves no doubt of their increasing desire to vote in next fall's elections at home.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Starting with an inspection of the Chicago Stadium, Walter S. Hallanan, chairman, and other members of the committee on arrangements of the Republican National Committee began preparation today for the convention which opens here June 26.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP)--An amended plan of reorganization for Rock Island the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company, involving several major changes in the previous plan, was issued today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The principal amendments would:...

Net operating earnings of the Manufacturers Trust Company in 1943 amounted to $7,202,416, after preferred stock dividends and reserves of $1,500,000. This compared with the 1942 net of $6,646,613. These figures were reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders by Henry C. Von Elm, vice chairman, who presided instead of the chairman, Harvey D. Gibson, who is now in London serving as American Red Cross Commissioner in the European theatre of operations.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Tucked away in a corner of Switzerland is a factory that was, until recently, turning out munitions for Germany.

Harriman Ripley Co., Inc.,] head an investment-banking group] which today will offer the unsub-! scribed portion of an issue of $10,503,200 of 4@ per cent $100-par Ipreferred stock of United Air ILines, Inc., amounting to 27,272 Ishares, priced at $100 each. Common stockholders subscribed to 77,760 of the shares under an offer which expired on Jan. 10.

The Publishers Association of New York City made public yesterday a resolution outlining the basis of its opposition to the War Production Board's proposal of a Government-owned stockpile of newsprint.

While local baseball men and others interested in sports promotion were still wondering yesterday what effect President Roosevelt's proposal for national service would have on sports, were it to become law, information came to light indicating strongly that, regardless of developments, professional sports would continue to operate throughout the year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Omar B. Ketchum, legislative representative of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, told the World War Veterans Committee of the House today that the rates of mustering-out pay, stipulated in the American Legion's Omnibus bill now under consideration, were too high.

ALGIERS, Jan. 12 -- Flying Forresses of the Fifteenth United States Air Force delivered yesterday the heaviest aerial blow ever struck at the Piraeus, the historic port of Athens, and last night British Wellingtons followed it with another smashing attack on the railway yard and harbor area vital to the German supply system in Greece.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A letter from a naval lieutenant who is on combat duty in the Pacific, denouncing strikes and asserting that "we have a double battle -- one with our external enemies, the other with our internal enemies -- has been received by Representative Compton of Connecticut.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 12 -- Heavy bombers of the Army and Navy air units in the central Pacific struck the enemy in widely separated areas of the Marshall Islands in the last two days, starting fires, sinking two ships and wrecking planes on airfields, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, announced this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- An assertion that Texans had a constitutional right to organize "a white man's Democratic party" to the exclusion of Negroes was made today before the Supreme Court by George W. Barcus, Assistant Attorney General of the State.

Chicago's eminence as a convention city has received another tribute from the Republican National Committee. The tribute may be worth all the more because the expense guarantee of $75,000 is small, as such things go. Tops for this sort of encouragement have run as high as $200,000.

This is New York State's story of death and injury in the hunting field last year and emphasizes once again the point that the careless man with a gun is a menace to himself and to others. The figures were supplied yesterday by Conservation Commissioner John A. White and show that accidents, fatal and others, were about half what they were in 1942.

In war and peace the Salvation Army has served this city for sixty years. It is an army which is never mustered out but which reaches the height of its service in the emergency of war, when it serves with our troops on the battlefronts.

Immediate placement is offered to 10,000 women in the New York area who can qualify as welders, bench workers, typists, clerical workers, lathe and press operators, farm workers, needle trade workers and welder trainees.

WHEN the lights were still shining in the Atlantic coastal cities in early 1942 German submarines started to pick off many a tanker that loomed obligingly against the shore glow. The Navy was slow in meeting the challenge; truth to tell, it lacked the small craft needed to patrol the wide sweep of water from Key West to Eastport.

Striking at Formosa for the second time in the war, China-based Allied fliers, presumably American, Tuesday night bombed two points on the west coast of the island that guards the southwestern approaches to Japan, the Tokyo radio reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey and Wendell L. Willkie were tied as first choice for the Republican nomination for President this year in a poll taken among eighty-seven members of the party's national committee which ended its meeting here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Without mentioning President Roosevelt's plea for higher taxes, the Senate all but completed action today on the revenue raising provisions of its $2,275,600,000 tax-bill.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 13 -- An American aerial armada of probably at least 1,400 planes scored a "major military success" in the virtual obliteration of three German fighter plane assembly plants despite the loss of fifty-nine heavy bombers, the United States Army announced last night, and brought admissions from Germany today that the Luftwaffe had more than met its match in the United States Air Force, at least temporarily.

The lamp division of the International General Electric Company will release a campaign in Central and South American media based on the business psychology and other elements peculiar to Latin-American markets. The program will not attempt to offer copy which is a mere translation or adaptation of North American advertising but will reflect ideas geared to the Latin-American market and its needs.

Instead of redefining "house slippers" as suggested by the rationing division of the Office of Price Administration for its Ration Order 17, the National Association of Play Shoe and Slipper Manufacturers, Inc., would have producers submit samples and photographs of all such models to the division for certification as to classification.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- British troops, breaking into open country after capturing Maungdaw, drove on down the Mayu peninsula in Burma today, killing a number of Japanese in a skirmish near the village of Kanyindian, a Southeast Asia Command communique reported tonight.

PHILADELPIA, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set Jan. 27 for combined hearings on a reorganization plan of the Federal Light and Traction Company designed to consolidate its subsidiaries in Arizona, New Mexico and Colorado.

LONDON, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans admitted a German break-through in the defenses of their capital of Jajce, in Bosnia, today, while Axis sources claimed capture of the city, and other reports said Partisan reinforcements were being rushed northwestward from Serbia to stem the Nazi onslaught.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The most extensive scramble for player material in the history of pro football was under way today as prospects developed at the annual midwinter meeting of the National Football League that at least eleven teams and perhaps twelve will operate in the circuit in 1944.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- Governor General Lord Gowrie announced in Parliament today the award of British honors, medals and citations to thirty-nine members of the United States fighting forces -- from commanding generals to privates -- in the southwest Pacific area "for distinguished and valuable services."

A wartime program for American Protestant churches and missions was offered yesterday by the Home Missions Council of North America in ending its three-day annual meeting at the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- In an attempt to move into useful channels a considerable quantity of excess steel which is piling up in the hands of war contractors, the War Production Board today removed all curbs on its purchase by dealers and warehouses.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been appointed as transfer agent and the National City Bank of New York as registrar for the newly authorized issue of 450,000 shares of $100 par 4 1/2 per cent preferred stock of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The President had appointments with William Green and Philip Murray, presidents of the AFL and CIO, and with Leighton McCarthy, Canadian Ambassador, and members of the Pacific War Council.

Allied air attacks on Sofia are being renewed with increased force. From new airfields at Foggia British Wellingtons follow American Flying Fortresses to spread one day's destruction into the next. These raids may help a distracted Government choose between defeat and chaos with Germany or truce and recovery under a white flag.

Events in Burma have moved at a slow pace since the end of the monsoon season, but the British now announce the capture of Maungdaw. This strategic port on the Bay of Bengal is the nearest to India the Japanese have been. Their expulsion does not necessarily mean the opening of the Allies' long-awaited Burma offensive, but it does indicate a resumption of the Arakan campaign which Marshal Wavell's expedition had to abandon last winter.

Youth springs eternal in Sally Victor's collections. She has met the incoming year with a group of hats that are as full of fun and fancy, to say nothing of wear-ability, as you can desire. She led off the gay procession of spring headgear at her opening, held yesterday morning in her establishment at 18 East Fifty-third Street, with a "wedding ring" hat.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 12 -- The Mexican Government last week sent a note to seventeen Latin- American republics and the United States proposing a general meeting of Ambassadors and Ministers to discuss recognition of President Gualberto Villarroel's new Bolivian Government, it was learned today.
LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

The room shortage evident among the city's better-known hotels for some time has taken a turn for the worse, it became known yesterday when out-of-town visitors discovered that it had become almost impossible to obtain accommodations.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 12 -- Vichy's method of government becomes clear when one analyzes its budget. It may be summed up thus: Bribe your supporters and also your opponents. The latter will probably cost the more.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association was told yesterday by speakers at its thirty-third annual convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania that the pending Wagner Murray social security program for returning war veterans would "put a premium on idleness," and that the country should not expect too much from a public works program.

The Solid Fuels Administration began yesterday a hunt for treasure troves of coal in abandoned Civilian Conservation Corps camps after the discovery of 450 tons lying idle in two former camps in New Jersey. Mayor Thomas Mace of Butler found a 300-ton pile at a camp site near that town.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- Four new directors of the Bank of Westchester were elected today by stockholders in annual session here at the bank. They were John D. Reilly Jr., whose father is president of the Todd Shipyards Corporation; George E. Mills, vice president in charge of the bank's branch in Larchmont; Harold T. Garrity, a lawyer, and Frederick A. Freund, vice president in charge of the bank's branch in Mount Kisco.

Mayor La Guardia indicated yesterday, after conferences with Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and Patrick W. Harnedy, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, that he soon would make formal announcement of an annual "cost of living" bonus of $420 for uniformed members of the Police Department.
ALGEIRS, Jan. 12 -- A communique:

The five-story apartment house at 544 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Ritter Co. to an investing client of the Dover Realty Company, broker. Assessed for $50,000 it was purchased for cash above a mortgage of $34, 965 held by the Home Life Insurance Company.

Some young men from New York now in the nation's armed services throughout the world had puzzled moments around Christmas time, according to letters which are beginning to reach the New York Public Library.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 12 -- A temporary' injunction restraining the Hudson Manhattan Railroad from increasing the fare on its downtown New York line from 8 to 10 cents, or selling eleven rides for $1, was made permanent today by a 2-to-1 decision of a three-judge Federal court here.
Houses on the West Side comprised the bulk of properties and figured in Manhattan deals reported yesterday.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Jan. 13 -- The Soviet High Command last night announced the opening of a new offensive on a nineteen-mile front in the Pripet Marshes southwest of Gomel, in the direction of Mozyr, as well as the capture of Sarny, important railway junction thirty-six miles inside Rovno Province.

Yank, the Army weekly, was "guest of honor" yesterday at a luncheon of the Overseas Press Club of America in the Lotos Club building, 110 West Fifty-seventh Street. High Army officers and literary personalities paid tribute to the enlisted personnel responsible for the publication at the presentation of The Saturday Review of Literature award for distinguished service to American letters.

The Greater New York Council, Boy Scouts of America, opened yesterday a campaign to raise $500,000 for maintenance and expansion of the Boy Scout program at a Dawn Patrol Breakfast in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The breakfast was held also to honor the 150,000 Scout-trained men from New York City now in the armed forces.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Postmaster General Frank C. Walker was reported here today to be ready to resign as chairman of the Democratic National Committee at its meeting Jan. 22 in Washington. Robert E Hannegan of St. Louis, Commissioner of Internal Revenue in Washington, was said to be favored by a majority of the national committeemen to be his successor.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 12 -- The first odds-on favorite to be defeated at the Hialeah Park meeting was Pig Tails, who bowed today to the speed of G.R. Watkins' Charitable, 5-to-2 second choice, in the six-fur-long Grade B Handicap.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The recent sinking of two more German U-boats at the hands of United States Navy air men operating in the South Atlantic was described by the Navy Department today.

THE gnarled old Scotsman was crying as he stood on the links at St. Andrews and reverently watched Bobby Jones sink his last putt for a sub-par 70. "Isn't it graund?" he whispered. "We have Bobby back with us." That was in 1936 when the Emperor Jones last visited the British Isles. It was an informal round he played, but some 6,000 spectators jammed the course to see their idol in action once more.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Control of Great Britain's food supply by the Government after the war is one of the provisions in the Labor party's food policy, it was made public tonight. Absolute priority should be assigned to food as soon as the war is over, the party declared.

Martin A. Nichols, now an executive of a hotel in Washington, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of violating the State Civil Rights Law last spring by refusing to accept a Negro as a guest at the Knickerbocker Hotel at 120 West Forty-fifth Street, where he was assistant manager at the time.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Control of Great Britain's food supply by the Government after the war is one of the provisions in the Labor party's food policy, it was made public tonight. Absolute priority should be assigned to food as soon as the war is over, the party declared.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The rigid ban on political activity in southern Italy, which was imposed by the Allied Military Government and caused loud protests by Count Carlo Sforza and other Italian liberals, has been relaxed by new orders sent to the military authorities there.

HONOLULU, Jan. 12 -- The average American sailor of the Second World War is not a dollar-slinging character who comes back from shore leave minus all his pay. He has a head for business and is saving a considerable part of his pay for the future. Much of the money goes into war bonds.

Martin A. Nichols, now an executive of a hotel in Washington, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of violating the State Civil Rights Law last spring by refusing to accept a Negro as a guest at the Knickerbocker Hotel at 120 West Forty-fifth Street, where he was assistant manager at the time.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies declined 7.3 per cent in December, compared with the like month of 1942, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The decrease, resembling a similar pattern in department store holiday trade, was held to reflect the heavy advance Christmas shopping done by the public in November in response to appeals to shop early.
Max Mencher, for the last seven years secretary of the Department of Markets, is resigning, effective Jan. 24, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Despite the fact that he had to play against a difference of fifteen strokes in handicap yesterday, W.D. Hoag, veteran Yale Club player, managed to reach the round of sixteen in the National Squash Tennis Association's tournament sponsored by his club for the benefit of the American Red Cross.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman made known yesterday, through a letter to Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the American Jewish Committee, his approval of efforts to overcome racial and religious animosities and to promote mutual respect, understanding and tolerance among all American groups.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 -- As a sequel to the acquisition of a block of stock last spring by the Transamerica Corporation, five directors representing the Transamerica interests were elected yesterday to the board of directors of the Citizens National Trust and Savings Bank at the annual meeting of stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- If pork were eliminated from point rationing there would follow immediately an average increase of 62 per cent in the point-value of the remaining rationed meats and fats, Col. Bryan Houston, Deputy Administrator of the Office of Price Administration in charge of rationing, said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration, which is still paying pensions to dependents of soldiers who fought in the War of 1812 and the Mexican War, is getting ready for the biggest group of all, the veterans of the second World War.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- The grain markets, with the exception of that for rye, held today within narrow limits on the Board of Trade. Trading in rye overshadowed business in other pits and prices were up 1 5/8 cents a bushel early on buying headed by commission houses with Eastern connections.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A declaration that the great body of organized labor in the United States was unalterably opposed to enactment of a national service act at this or any other time was made to President Roosevelt today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

TRENTON, Jan. I2 (AP) -- New Jersey's commission on post-war economic welfare proposed today that the Legislature create a $5,000,000 fund to guarantee loans up $3,000 to veterans of the present war wishing to establish themselves in small business enterprises.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 12 -- The complete outlawing of all political activities in Argentina was completed yesterday by a decree dissolving "those entities that are named 'Nationalist' and all those whose members appear to meet for political ends."

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Another chapter in the matrimonial dispute between James H.R. Cromwell, former United States Minister to Canada, and Doris Duke Cromwell, tobacco heiress, was written here today when Advisory Master Dougal Herr issued an order directing Mrs. Cromwell, now living in Reno, to answer within thirty days a petition to nullify the Nevada divorce she obtained last month.
PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 12 (AP) -- The first Victory ship, one of the freighters expected to form the backbone of the post-war merchant fleet of the United States, was launched here today.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden admitted today that he did not know when the invasion would start "and therefore I am in no danger of telling."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A caution to all exporters to use "due prudence" in keeping themselves advised of exchange and import restriction developments in Bolivia was issued by the Foreign Economic Administration here tonight in connection with a bulletin divorcing Bolivia, temporarily, from the group of Latin-American nations participating in the decentralization plans.

The large commercial banks in the Second Federal Reserve District were notified yesterday that the Treasury will make further withdrawals from Government war loan accounts in them on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. For this district the withdrawals will aggregate $72,459,000 on each day, and for the nation as a whole they will total $170,359,000 daily.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Legislation to provide a $1,000,000,000 educational program for discharged members of the armed services and the Merchant Marine was molded into final form by a Senate subcommittee on education and labor late today, having been rewritten extensively to meet opjections raised against the original draft by service organizations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The War Production Board announced today that it has amended order M-217 to permit manufacturers of misses' and children's shoes to concentrate their production, within their quota, on any established line or lines of misses' and children's footwear.

Eight hundred and twenty-seven members of the Police Department -- a record number -- were retired yesterday by the action of the board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund, which met at Police Headquarters. This leaves the police force 3,221 short of its normal complement.

Release of Government surplus stocks to civilian use so far as possible while the war is still going on was urged yesterday as an effective means of combating inflation by Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Accelerated liquidation and New Orleans hedge selling in late dealings weakened the cotton futures market yesterday. Although a measure of support appeared to be provided throughout the session by trade price fixing in the nearby months, heavy selling pressure easily overcame it.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- "G.I. Joe," who has established himself in the affections of British children because of his openhandedness with chewing gum and candy, seems to be no less generous toward high ranking British Army officers.

In his recent report on the rise and significance of American air power General Arnold declared that the near future would be a crucial period in which our fliers would undertake to knock the German Luftwaffe out of the skies in order to clear the way for the coming invasion of the European continent
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The twelve budget messages which President Roosevelt has sent to Congress will have accounted for more than three times as much money as all his thirty predecessors spent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A broad program to provide new feeding facilities on the job for 5,500,000 war workers has been started by a group of Government agencies. The program plans to increase facilities, now available for 6,500,000 workers, so that one good meal can be provided a day for 12,000,000 persons.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Municipal Court Justice Joseph F. Caponigri, who leased an apartment in 308 East Seventy-ninth Street through N.A. Berwin Co., Inc., brokers

Producers of women's branded line rayon stockings indicated yesterday that, pending further study of the second revised MPR-339 which becomes effective tomorrow, they will proceed to allot current output to retail and wholesale distributors for the first quarter of 1944.

The movement originating in the Bronx to bring the rod and gun clubs of Greater New York together under one association to promote mutual interests is gaining momentum and something is bound to come of it if John J. O'Connor has his way.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A self-styled yeast group of women leaders, whose aim is to cause women to rise to their present-day responsibilities by assuming policymaking positions, ended a two-day conference today with a joint summary by two spokesmen, Dr. Margaret Mead, anthropologist, and Miss Rachel Crothers, playwright.

The following nine books, all January publications, are being especially recommended by the Council on Books in Wartime for wartime reading. Already brought out are Kay Boyle's "Avalanche," (Simon Schuster) and "Lend- Lease: Weapon for Victory," by Edward R. Stettinius (Macmillan).

A UNITED STATES FLYING FORTRESS BASE IN ENGLAND, Jan. 11 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The bombardier's sense of duty that sent Second Lieut. Charles W. Spencer of Peoria, Ill., back into the shattered nose of the Flying Fortress Stardust five miles above Bremen on Nov. 26 was recognized today as something worthy of the nation's highest honor.

On March 1 the American Red Cross will ask $200,000,000 from the American people, $22,386,000 from the people of New York City. As Leon Fraser, national chairman of the fund, said, this money is not for the Red Cross. It is "for the boys in the armed forces everywhere, for their comfort in time of need and for their aid in time of distress."

Although the American League, unlike the National, does not go in for exploiting "slugging percentages" in its annual output of official averages in December, the statisticians in the junior circuit's service bureau decided to compile figures this winter patterned along similar lines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A decline of 0.1 per cent occurred in the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices in primary markets during the first week of 1944. The all-commodity index dropped to 102.9 per cent of the 1926 average following a rise of the same amount in the preceding week.

The development of polythene, a new plastic adaptable to the manufacture of products ranging from collapsible tubes for toothpaste to waterproof coatings, piping, adhesives and electric wiring for wires and cables, was announced yesterday by the plastics department of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The Democratic leaders of the Legislature announced today their opposition to Governor Dewey's proposed constitutional amendment which would elect a Governor and a Lieutenant Governor together, instead of by separate ballot.

Good trail and slope running continues to be the word from the North Country, with indications that another large turnout is expected to visit the popular areas extending from the Poconos of Pennsylvania to Mont Tremblant in Canada. The tows and lifts will be in full operation at virtually all resorts.

Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., and other film industry executives met yesterday with representatives of the State Department to explore the possibility of obtaining governmental aid to insure a free market abroad for American motion pictures after the war.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will start today its nation-wide 1944 fund-raising appeal. The drive will continue through Jan. 31 and will reach a climax in a nation-wide series of parties on Jan. 29 in celebration of President Roosevelt's sixty-second birthday, which will occur Jan. 30, a Sunday.

The "urgent need" in French North Africa for farm machinery and parts to produce its own food was described here yesterday by George Le Cloux, technical adviser on farm machinery to the French Committee of National Liberation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs were reduced sharply today, but the available supply exceeded slaughter requirements and 10,000 head remained in first hands at the end of trade. At the twelve Mid-western markets 509,000 salable hogs were received so far this week, compared with 620 000 in the first four days last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Attorney General Francis Biddle ordered today an immediate investigation of charges made by Representative Howard W. Smith, Democrat, of Virginia, that President Philip Murray and other officers of the Congress of Industrial Relations had violated criminal provisions of the Connally-Smith anti-strike law.

The nation's newspapers, in order to live up to their recognized leadership as dispensers of information on broad problems created by the war, should launch a drive for economic stabilization, particularly in the food industry, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., said yesterday in an address before a luncheon meeting of the Newspaper Representatives Association of New York at the Lexington.

Almost any living American writer, we imagine, would be reasonably content if he were told that forty-five years after his death he would have ten million readers. That is why we are puzzled by the conclusion drawn by the Children's Aid Society from its Horatio Alger poll when it calls him "unread" today.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Most sections of the stock markets here continued dull today. The general apathy was attributed mainly to the suspense over the invasion of western Europe. Home rails were marked down again, and store shares were weak. British Celanese hardened slightly but Courtaulds eased fractionally. Oils were irregular. Kaffirs became firmer.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities to be at a new high record, while note circulation decreased $11,790,000 during the week.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 13 -- Announcing that the complete evacuation of the city of Sofia is to be carried out immediately, the Bulgarian radio tonight -- confirmed in a Budapest broadcast later -- called on all owners of trucks and automobiles "not already requisitioned for military use" to present themselves without delay to the nearest police headquarters for "further instructions."

Among Republicans of diverse views on other questions there is substantial agreement that labor laws should be changed to impose legal responsibilities on the leaders of trade unions, Senator C. Wayland Brooks of Illinois and Governor Dwight Palmer Griswold of Nebraska indicated last night in a forum discussion at Town Hall carried over a national radio network.

Lightweights again will feature the boxing program at Madison Square Garden when Bobby Ruffin, Astoria gladiator, tackles Tippy Larkin of Garfield, N.J., in a ten-round battle tonight. Interest in the activities in the 135-pound class is at a high peak, as attested by the crowd of 15,000 spectators which turned out for last Friday's clash between Beau Jack and Lulu Costantino, and promoter Mike Jacobs is confident that tonight's gathering will be just as large.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson expressed doubt today that the "hundreds of thousands" of German soldiers now trapped in the Dnieper bend in Russia would be able to withdraw from their "advanced and exposed" positions without suffering "heavy losses."
The National Retail Dry Goods Association formally advocated yesterday continuance of Government price control and the disposal of some of the Government's excess stockpiles of goods.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 13 -- Every act of Greek sabotage or even a hint of hostility brings forth retribution by the Germans -- carrying off of hostages by the score, shootings by firing squads, burning of villages and destruction of crops, reports reaching here today said. Even the cheering of Allied aircraft is considered a serious offense.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A charge that leading liquor distillers who had few holdings in California's wine industry before 1938 had bought up so many wineries there since then that by 1942 they controlled more than 24 per cent of California wine sales, slightly more than 25 per cent of the wine inventories and crushed 19 per cent of the wine grapes, was made by witnesses before a Senatorial subcommittee today.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 13 -- The way was paved here today for the merger of the National Conference of Church-Related Colleges and the Association of American Colleges, the two foremost higher educational organizations in the country. By a nearly unanimous vote, the 400 colleges in the conference approved the merger. The association will take a formal vote tomorrow.

The main difficulty with the jet-propulsion airplane just made public is the rapid rate at which it consumes fuel. Until that handicap is licked -- as it surely will be in time -- the new craft will have greater speed than the conventional airplane but will be incapable of long sustained flights.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Air Marshal Sir Richard Hallam Peck of the Royal Air Force reported today that twenty of Germany's biggest industrial cities had been crippled for a long period by the Allied air offensive and that about fifty more centers were "well on their way" to destruction.

Three dwellings and a commercial building at 484-86 Willis Avenue and 402-04 East 147th Street, the southeast corner, in the Bronx, have been sold by the estate of Elizabeth Doherty to the 484 Willis Avenue Corporation. They are assessed at $50,000 and were sold through Peter A. Clancy, broker, who also arranged with the Dollar Savings Bank to extend the first mortgage of $31,000.
LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Today's Rome broadcast said:

ALGIERS, Jan. 13 -- While American troops of the Allied Fifth Army seized Cervaro at 1 P. M. yesterday and also completed occupation of Mount Capraro, 2,285 feet high, just north of the shell-wracked town, French forces under Gen. Alphonse-Pierre Juin attacked in the mountains southwest of Rocchetta in the northern sector of the Cassino front, retook two heights and in general pushed forward some 1,000 yards.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The War Production Board issued a policy statement tonight blocking any large-scale resumption of civilian goods production in the near future.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Federal Communications Commission voted unanimously today not to establish any general rule on newspaper ownership of radio stations, thus bringing to a close a long inquiry undertaken at the request of President Roosevelt.

Rochester, N. Y., announced yesterday that it will open sealed tenders on Jan. 20 on a new issue of $2,225,000 of refunding bonds. The issue will be dated Jan. 15, 1944, and will mature serially from July 15. 1949, to 1953. Bidders are to name the interest rate.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Rival Republican and Democratic managers met in conference today to arrange for sharing joint expenses of putting the Chicago Stadium into shape for the Republican and Democratic national conventions. They met on the assumption that the Democrats, following the lead of the Republicans, would pick Chicago as the convention city, which Democratic leaders deem more than probable.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Soviet Government and the Spanish underground have almost simultaneously issued denunciations of the Franco regime as an ally of the Axis. The Supreme Council of the National Union, as the underground is styled, has, in addition, called on the Spanish people to sabotage Generalissimo Francisco Franco's shipments of war material to Adolf Hitler, exterminate his lieutenants and finally to overthrow his regime.

Containing a new third act and otherwise, completely revised, Somerset Maugham's play, "Sheppey," which London inspected back in 1933 is announced by Jacques Chambrun to enter rehearsals late next month. Sir Cedric Hardwicke will direct.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Republican members of the House of Representatives conferred for the first time today since the opening of the session. They criticized President Roosevelt's message this week as "not specific enough" in its legislative recommendations.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Increased evidence of hedging pressure in wheat was presented today on the Board of Trade and brokers said that with Kansas City and Minneapolis selling at about a full shipping discount there was every reason to look forward to the bulk of the hedging against an enlarged country movement to come into this market.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 13 -- The Army-Navy teams, attacking the Marshall atoll bases of the Japanese, struck again two days ago and inflicted sever damage on Maloelap atoll despite the efforts of six enemy figherts to break up their formation.

SOMEWHERE IN ITALY, Jan. 13 -- Keenly aware that worry over home affairs is second only to wounds and disease in limiting the usefulness of service men and women overseas, American commanders operating through the American National Red Cross are perfecting and extending throughout the North African Italy war theatre a system of communications and personal counsel designed to reduce such apprehension to a minimum.

MOSCOW, Friday, Jan. 14 -- The Red Army, advancing rapidly despite resistance from well-prepared German defenses, has placed the important railroad centers of Mozyr and Kalinkovichi in the Pripet Marshes under fire from three sides, according to the Soviet midnight communique.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 13 --Reprints of an article by Henry J. Taylor in the August, 1943, issue of the Reader's Digest with the title, "Boondoggling on a Global Basis," is being distributed by the Department of Foreign Affairs to a mailing list including names of many Americans.
LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Note circulation of the Bank of England decreased 8,634,000 in the week ended yesterday, according to the report issued today by the Bank.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 -- A warning that the "growing tendency" toward delisting stocks or withdrawing them from registration on national securities exchanges must be considered seriously by the Securities and Exchange Commission or "otherwise the time may shortly be at hand when there may be no regional exchanges and the securities industry will be turned over to the over-the-counter market" was voiced today by the Boston Stock Exchange before the SEC.

The ten-thousandth gift to the $300,000 Metropolitan Opera Fund, a donation of $2 from Mrs. John Hirvela, wife of a Centralia, Wash., coal miner, was received yesterday, George A. Sloan, president of the Metropolitan Opera Association and chairman of the fund campaign, announced.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 13 -- Pan- Arab talks between the Lebanese delegation headed by Riad Solh, Moslem Premier, and Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha of Egypt ended here this afternoon.
The Soviet Government's declaration of Jan. 11, proposing the Curzon Line as a basis of settlement of the Russo-Polish border issue, offers, in our opinion, a sound foundation for a solution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Dry leaders received a Congressional hearing today for the first time since repeal of the prohibition law and called for passage of the Bryson wartime prohibition bill on the ground that "week-end sprees" and "payday drinking" were largely responsible for absenteeism in war plants.

MONTREAL, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Making up a two-goal deficit, the Red Wings gained a 2-2 tie with the Canadiens on Flash Hollett's third-period tally before 10,000 fans tonight in a National Hockey League game.

Further ground was given yesterday by the stock market, although spots of strength cropped out among the specialties and the rails generally were improved. Activity was dulled in anticipation of President Roosevelt's budget message, but demand increased after publication of the details of his requests, although no immediate reaction appeared to the nation's second hundred-billion-dollar financial requirements.

A UNITED STATES FLYING FORTRESS BASE in England, Jan. 13 (AP) -- From a 21-year-old gunner on a Flying Fortress that reached England battered into a "mess of holes and ribbons" came a combatant's account today of Tuesday's aerial battle over Germany.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Welker Cochrane made a sensational rally tonight against Willie Hoppe, world's three-cushion billiard champion, to wipe out Hoppe's 25-point advantage at the end of the tenth block of their exhibition match -and gain a 3-point lead.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13 -William Cameron Menzies, who recently has been identified chiefly with the production and designing of Technicolor productions, has been signed by RKO to stage and direct "The Gibson Girl," forthcoming Ginger Rogers picture.

Mrs. Emma Van Coutren, who has a dozen letters a week to write to her twelve children, all of whom are in the nation's services, took time off from her job in a local 5-and-10 cent store yesterday to sign up as a Minute Woman in the Fourth War Loan drive, which opens next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Roosevelt's Victory budget went to Congress today. It called for appropriations to finish off the Axis and outlined his approach to problems of readjustment in the event of an armistice.

Eggs no longer are glutting the market as they did a few weeks ago, but they are sufficient to meet demand and probably will be so through April, which marks the peak of the season. Retail prices, which were reduced recently in an effort to move the superabundance of stocks, are still low and are expected to remain moderate for some time because of increasing production.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Admiral Sir Bruce A. Fraser, Commander in Chief of the Home Fleet, recently visited Vice Admiral Arseny Grigorvic Golovko, Commander in Chief of the Russian Northern Fleet, at an unspecified Russian port, the Admiralty said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Veterans of the present World War had received $8,223,000 in pensions up to Nov. 30 and dependents of those killed $8,443,000 more, Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans Affairs, reported today to the World War Veterans Committee of the House.

The Foreign Press Association, an organization of correspondents for foreign news organizations in the United States, at a meeting in the Lotos Club voted last night to extend active membership to "radio journalists." The change in the rules of the organization approved by the membership described such journalists as the correspondents here of foreign radio stations or those engaged in the preparation or supplying to foreign countries of news broadcasts originating in the United States.

"An extraordinarily large amount of peacetime business" has been booked by the Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company of St. Louis, W.S. Symington, president, declared in discussing the company's post-war planning program in the fifty-third annual report issued to stockholders yesterday.

MAYBE it was the appearance of Zeke Bonura in the news which brought back memories of the strong, silent men whose crashing bats drew smiles of delight from their managers and whose fielding antics drew groans of dismay from those same eminent gentlemen. Zeke was a rare prize, of course, but Babe Herman was no Tris Speaker and Smead Jolley no bounding gazelle either.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The Polish Government-in-Exile, like any patient facing the possibility of an amputation, hesitated today and finally postponed its decision to submit its boundary dispute with Russia to negotiation and arbitration.

Chips, an Army dog born and raised in Pleasantvllle, N.Y., has the honor of being the first canine in the history of the United States to receive the Distinguished Service Cross for heroism in action, it was announced yesterday by Dogs for Defense, Inc. It was through this organization that Chips was enlisted in August, 1942, by his owners, Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Wren, of 26 Orchard Street, Pleasantville.

"Spider Woman," the latest film in the Sherlock Holmes mystery melodrama series produced by Universal, will open this morning at the Rialto. Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce again portray the respective roles of Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson, with Gale Sondergaard, Dennis Hoey, Alec Craig, Mary Gordon and Arthur Hohl among the supporting players.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Japanese inland positions in the Arawe area, southwest New Britain, were successfully raided by American patrols Wednesday, Allied headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- British-American policy in Italy is playing into the hands of the Communists, it was asserted by a delegation from the Mazzini Society that visited the State Department today to ask that Italian democrats receive more freedom of assembly and speech.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine issued a general order yesterday amending the rules and regulations of the Police Department to forbid members to associate knowingly with persons engaged in subversive activities or to join organizations that foster racial or religious hatred.
Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn called last night for a vigorous campaign to rid the city of hatemongering.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Department store sales in the week ended Jan. 8 were 3 per cent below sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a loss of 7 per cent in the week ended Jan. 1 when compared with the like week of 1942.
So many butchers are entering the armed services that a definite manpower problem exists in this field, but shoppers and men in the trade agreed yesterday that women workers are not the answer.

Net operating earnings of the Bankers Trust Company in 1943 were $9,486,838, compared with $8,467,463 in 1942, S. Sloan Colt, president, reported at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday. This was equivalent to about $3.80 a share, against $3.39 a share in 1942. In addition the banks had $3,471,730 of profits during 1943 on the sale of securities, and recoveries amounted to $289,979.

J.B. Maller, chief of the social research section of the Federal Public Housing Authority, and John A. Kerwick, assistant director for project management, will lecture on housing problems tomorrow evening at the New School for Social Research.

When Director General Herbert F. Lehman of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration testified last month before the House Foreign Affairs Committee he said that "if UNRRA suceeds the world will know that international cooperation is possible, that common interests can be stronger than separate differences."

While the lifting of price controls over textiles, clothing and consumer durables can be expected shortly after the end of the European phase of the war, regulations over food cannot be abolished until after the first full harvest is reaped in Europe under Allied supervision, Richard V. Gilbert, economic adviser to the Office of Price Administration, stated yesterday.

In reply to a protest over the burning of 211 tons of waste paper by Government agencies here, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, telegraphed Edwin S. Friendly, chairman of the Victory Waste Paper Committee, that in the future "everything possible will be done to avert needless destruction of this urgently needed material."
Apartment houses and store and loft buildings passed to new control in deals reported yesterday. Several of the properties were disposed of by savings banks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- After deliberating for hours while seekers of franchises paced the outer vestibule, the National Football League concluded its annual mid-winter meeting today by taking this definite action: Inserting the word "one" in place of the word "the" in a section of its by-laws affecting players drafted from colleges.

Ridabock Co., makers of uniforms for officers of the Army, Navy and Marine Corps since 1847, have leased the second floor and part of the third floor at 420 Madison Avenue through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. The Ridabock family, which has operated the business through the Civil War, the Spanish-American War and World War I, is moving from 65 Madison Avenue to larger quarters to outfit officers in the present war.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 13 -- The unknown hand striking at Conservative leaders in Denmark has now been supplemented by the German Security Police. This morning it felled two more victims, Leo Kaeraa, a dental mechanic, and his wife, who were shot down while taking artificial sun baths in their villa outside Aarhus.

MOSCOW, Jan. 13 -- All Soviet newspapers published today a map showing the Curzon Line in comparison with the present frontiers of the Soviet Union and gave a historical background for the recent Soviet Government's statement of willingness to negotiate with Poland new frontiers based on that line.

FOURTEENTH UNITED STATES AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, China, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- Striking at Japanese targets more than 1,500 miles apart, China-based American Liberator bombers blasted a vital aluminum plant in Formosa Tuesday night, and last night pounded railway yards and an airdrome in Bangkok, Thailand.

Deposits in the 132 mutual savings banks in New York State on Dec. 31, 1943, were $6,167,077,469, a new high record, and an increase of $596,986,673 in the year, the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York reported yesterday. The number of accounts rose 229,485 during the year to 6,231, 489, also a new high.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress transmitting the budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 was as follows:
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, Jan. 14 (U.P.) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A joint statement by the War and Navy Departments revealed tonight that military establishments in the Atlantic and Pacific coastal areas were being reduced to augment combat teams overseas, "now that the battle fronts have moved further from our borders."

MIAMA, Fla., Jan 13 -- A 5-year-old mare, Zaca Rosa, and a 3-year-old filly, Blue Sash, were in the spotlight at Hialeah Park today, the mare capturing the Mesdames Purse and the filly setting a new grass course record of 1:44 3-5 for a mile and a sixteenth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Roosevelt outlined "the financial requirements for victory" to Congress today in his annual budget message calling for total war expenditures from June, 1940, to mid-1945 of close to $300,000,000,000.

Charitable, religious and educational institutions will share eventually the bulk of the $97,070,933 estate left by Edward Stephen Harkness, financier and philanthropist, who died on Jan. 24, 1940. This was disclosed yesterday in an estate tax appraisal filed by Deputy Tax Commissioner and New York County Appraiser Louis J. Lefkowitz.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 13 -- Brazilians representing each of the twenty-one States and Territories will form the Brazilian expeditionary forces. Their training is nearly completed.

The Refugee Relief Fund of the Coat and Suit Industry of New York presented contributions of $445,000 collected in the industry during 1943 to twenty philanthropic and relief organizations at a dinner in the Hotel Astor last night.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 13 -- Although it is difficult to say what is China's gravest problem, the decline in the number of trucks fit for service is a source of great anxiety. Before a counter-offensive can be mounted a large tonnage of war supplies must be moved from the air terminal to advanced bases over roads that are not too good but are negotiable.

The proposed school budget estimate for 1944-45 has been fixed at $136,799,165, a net decrease of $855,436 under the current budget, but the city's appropriation would have to be increased by $3,515,230 to offset an expected decrease in State and Federal contributions, it was announced yesterday by the committee on finance and budget of the Board of Education.

TRENTON, Jan. 13 -- Neither the State nor any of its political subdivisions has the authority to deal with trade unions as collective bargaining agents for public employes, Attorney General David T. Wilentz said today in an opinion requested by David L. Cole, chairman of the State Board of Mediation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced a schedule of flat, nation-wide, cents-per-pound mark-ups over net cost by which retailers must now determine their maximum prices for fish and seafood.

The General Electric Company, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of war equipment, disclosed yesterday that more than $450,000,000 of its orders had been canceled in 1943, and that orders received in the last three months of the year were 76 per cent less than those of the same quarter of 1942.

Let the last come first! Following the event, one is still under the impression of the final performance of the program given by Dr. Rodzinski and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, which was that of Ravel's Spanish Rhapsody.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Secretary Stimson announced today that Army casualties, killed, wounded, captured and missing, totaled 105,229 as of Dec. 23. This makes the announced casualties for all services 139,752.
The text of the Federal Court judgment in the Government's civil anti-trust suit against The Associated Press follows:

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Jan. 13 (AP) -- John Franklin Noxon Jr., 47, a corporation lawyer, was indicted, charged with murder in the first degree today, by the Berkshire County grand jury over the electrocution, Sept. 22, of his six-month-old abnormal son, Lawrence.

As the hard coal famine threw its chill yesterday even over the towns and villages within sight of the Pennsylvania mines, the possibility of increasing production by working the mines on Sundays was under study by Secretary of Interior Harold L. Ickes, the nation's Solid Fuels Administrator.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 13 -- Despite all promises to the contrary, the deportation of French youths to Germany began again with the New Year, according to trustworthy private advices. To cover up all tracks, however, the deportees are represented as volunteers.

Refugees from central Europe who immigrated to South America within the last ten years have introduced many modern merchandising methods and a variety of trades hitherto unknown there, Louis H. Sobel, South American representative of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The east coast, says Secretary Ickes, has enough fuel oil for home heating during the present cold spell, but just enough.

The first-degree murder trial of Wayne Lonergan, former aircrafts-man in the Royal Canadian Air Force, in the death of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, in her apartment at 313 East Fifty-first Street, last Oct. 24, will open before Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions on Jan. 31.

The principal problem faced by American business and industry in the post-war period will not be reconversion but the need to expand production to from thirty to forty-five per cent over 1940 levels, it was declared last night by Paul Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Edison Illuminating Company of Easton, Pa., asked the Securities and Exchange Commission's permission today to sell at market value $72,000 principal amount of the Lehigh Valley Transit Company's first mortgage bonds.

Although he calls his latest show "Jackpot," Vinton Freedley unfortunately may be fathering the wish rather than the reality. For the musical which opened last evening at the attractive Alvin is not up to the producer's generally high standards of living; it is, in fact, so much below them as to be a not very good show at all.

That this country at war last year witnessed strikes in virtually all its coal mines and was threatened with a strike on all its railroads does not appear in the least to disturb Secretary Perkins. In her annual report she once more finds peace and quiet among her statistics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A story brought back by Technical Sergeant Elmer Wexler, Marine Corps combat artist of Bridegport, Conn., concerns a Marine communications man in the Southwest Pacific who inadvertently gave the day's password over a telephone line that was suspected of having been tapped by the Japanese, the Marine Corps 4reported today.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The conviction of Ben Fein and Abe Cohen for criminally concealing and withholding stolen property was dismissed by the Court of Appeals today. A sealed truck containing $5,000 worth of women's wearing apparel was stolen in New York County and was found in a Brooklyn garage,

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 13 -- William H. Morley, Jacob Eagleson, Lowell K. Morrow and William Eagleson, present and former officials or bosses at the Pawtucket, R.I., plant of the Anaconda Wire and Cable Company, were in Providence county jail today, awaiting sentence after having been found guilty of conspiring to defraud the United States.
Yesterday's Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE IN ENGLAND, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The newest and longest-range single-engine fighter planes in the world, the American P-51B Mustangs, were disclosed today to have destroyed at least fourteen German craft in the great air battles of Tuesday.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 13 -- Australia has addressed herself to a solution of the labor problems which President Roosevelt is asking Congress to tackle through her own system of national service, authorized in June, 1940, by an amendment to the National Security Act introduced by Prime Minister Menzies.

Governor Dewey's plan to leave millions of dollars in State funds idle in anticipation of post-war needs was criticized by the Women's City Club in a letter to him made public yesterday. In the face of many curtailed essential public services, such as education and social welfare, such saving may prove in the long run to be false economy, the club said.

LYNN, Mass., Jan. 13 -- The absence of "McGlue's News Vues" from The Telegram-News here for several weeks has resulted in inquiries from readers and subscribers who wanted to know why the column dealing with political and other news failed to make its weekly appearance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The large crop of sharply worded dissents in opinions handed down by the Supreme Court on Jan. 3 drew the attention of many to the fact that the seven justices who had to pass the New Deal's legal philosophy test before they were appointed are not dwelling together in amity as mental brethen.

A judgment, findings of fact, and conclusions of law in the Government's anti-trust suit against The Associated Press, were filed yesterday by the three Circuit Judges who had formed a special expediting court to consider the case. Unless appealed to the Supreme Court within sixty days, or modified in accordance with its own terms, the judgment is final.

A showdown in the efforts of some district leaders to oust Michael J. Kennedy as leader of Tammany Hall has been tentatively scheduled for next week as a preliminary to the designation of candidates for delegates to the Democratic national convention this Spring.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Yugoslav Partisans under Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) are striking back vigorously at German communications between Banja Luka and Zagreb, a principal supply route for the Nazi thrust into the heart of liberated territory, they announced today.

A committee of four will be appointed, probably within the next ten days, by the Defense Supplies Corporation, to act as an advisory group in the disposal of the approximately 330,000,000 pounds of foreign wool owned by the agency, it was stated in industry circles yesterday.
This is the third article of the New York designer series.

Gasoline ration coupons will be mailed to motorists under the Office of Price Administration's central issuance system that will soon be put into effect, it was announced yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, regional OPA administrator.

The New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System improved their reserve positions during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. They finished the fiscal week with a reserve deficiency of only $15,000,000, whereas the week before it amounted to $95,000,000.

The hush order, an old fixture at City Hall, where Mayor La Guardia doesn't let his aides talk to the reporters unless he gives them a message to deliver, made its appearance yesterday at the regional Office of Price Administration in the Empire State Building.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- The War Production Board said today that domestic pulpwood production must reach 14,000,000 cords in 1944 to supply the expanded needs of the armed forces and the home front.

Twenty-eight teams have been named for the three major relay events in tomorrow night's Grover Cleveland meet at the Seventh Regiment Armory, opening event of the track and field season. New York University, with two teams, Columbia, City College, the Columbia Midshipmen and Bayonne High will be in the club, school and college relay at one mile.

The fiftieth annual meeting of the Jockey Club was held at 250 Park Avenue yesterday, with Alfred Hennen Morris, one of the two surviving charter members; George D. Widener and F. Skiddy von Stade re-elected as stewards. At the stewards' meeting which followed, William Woodward was returned as chairman, A.H. Morris as vice chairman, Joseph E. Davis as secretary-treasurer and Marshall Cassidy as assistant secretary.

Two losing streaks clashed in the National Hockey League game last night at Madison Square Garden, where the Chicago Black Hawks tackled the New York Rangers. When it was all over, naturally only one streak remained and, just as naturally, it remained with the Rangers.

After speakers before the Regional Victory Garden Conference at the Savoy Plaza Hotel had urged yesterday a 2,000,000 increase in the 20,000,000 Victory gardens planted last year and efforts for record production in 1944, the Office of Price Administration was asked to emphasize to the public that the removal of some processed vegetables from the ration list in no way lessens the need for increased food production.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association left no doubt yesterday of the intention of its 7,000 members to welcome home and restore to their former jobs returning veterans of the war. Their guarantee of former jobs to service men was stated by Edward N. Allen, president of the association and president of Sage-Allen Co., Hartford, Conn., at the Victory and Post-War Conference of the association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 13 -- Victor Basch, 81 years of age, was reported today to have been murdered in France near Lyon in circumstances as yet unexplained. He played an important part for many years behind the scenes of French politics. His wife was killed with him and their bodies were found on the highway.

With scarcely a live chicken -- except those raised in backyards -- or a kosher killed fowl anywhere in the city yesterday as a result of the industry's strike against existing price ceilings, the Office of Price Administration agreed last night to increase the price limit for New York City by one cent a pound.

How often, over the past four years, has it been shouted to the heavens that we are fighting to protect and preserve the self-respect, the personality and the dignity of the individual? And now, as giving contradiction to all such preachments, we are proposing to establish an American breadline for, if the figures of the War Food Administration are correct, 18,000,000 of our citizens.
CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A communique of the Fourteenth Army Air Force:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The announced policy of the Government to lend or charter tonnage to smaller nations to make up at least part of the losses suffered by these allies has resulted in only token transfers, it became known today.

Vfurad Sutton, in 90 Riverside Dr; {ax Gussow, in 36 Central Pk South; Frances Robinson, in 121 ]adison Ave; P. Bergman, i: 101 W 55th St; Mme. Viobley Lushanya, in 57 W 58th St--Rose Fabricant, broker.

Pierre and Genia Hemenoff, duo-pianists, were heard in a Town Hall recital last night that aroused the enthusiasm of a large audience by the technical address, tonal charm and highly perfected ensemble of each of the offerings presented.

The board of directors of the Travelers Aid Society of New York will give an "Anchors Aweigh" party and dance, with a buffet supper, tonight at the Hotel McAlpin for 150 officers and enlisted men from five Navy LCI (Landing Craft, Infantry) ships to be "adopted" at sponsoring ceremonies earlier in the day at a Hudson River pier.

In a year which saw many of its athletes called into the services, the New York Athletic Club was nevertheless able to maintain its high position in the sports world during 1943, when thirty-eight championships were won by Winged Foot athletes.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 13 (Delayed) -- Bold plans are now being conceived and formulated by Palestine Jewry's leading communal organizations with a view to bringing material and spiritual rehabilitation to the pillaged but surviving Jewish communities that will be liberated as British-American invasion forces move across Europe after the "second front" opens, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Failure of draft inductions to meet net manpower requirements of the armed forces for the last three months of 1943 will necessitate the calling of about 700,000 additional registrants in the first half of this year, the Selective Service System informed Congress today.
Washington, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A War Department spokesman said tonight the Army was investigating the award of a Silver Star to a dog for heroic attacks on the enemy in Sicily.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Wheat showed an easy undertone in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, with some hedging in evidence, and there also was pressure from traders influenced by reports that the cash grain situation was not as strong as recently, although all sales in the open market continue at maximum prices.

MOSCOW, Jan. 14 -- In seeking to alleviate the sugar shortage that has been felt since the Germans overran the rich sugar-beet field in the Ukraine in 1941, the Soviet Government is taking many steps to insure the rapid re-establishment of the beet industry in liberated areas.

Cooperation with the National Housing Agency was urged in an appeal sent yesterday by the Rev. Harlan M. Frost, executive secretary of the Christian Commission for Camp and Defense Communities to church councils and ministerial associations in 170 areas where housing shortages for war workers and families have been found.

Retail trade here improved this week. Department stores had sales increases over the like week of last year, with the average increase estimated at around 7 per cent. For some stores, however, the gain was substantially larger, ranging up to 15 per cent or more.

Sidjak, Inc. (Jack H. Gorta, president) proves to be the buyer of the five four-story buildings and one-story taxpayer at 862-68 Eighth Avenue and 258-60 West Fifty-second Street, sold recently by the Franklin Savings Bank for cash over a first mortgage of $90,000.

Surveys indicate that reconversion of the industrial plant now devoted to war will take at least a year, because fully half of the country's industrial organizations have been changed drastically as a result of their conversion into armament production, according to McKinsey Co., management consultants of New York and Boston.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 15 -A lone Nazi plane slipped through London's bristling air defenses last night and dropped a bomb on a crowded movie theatre in a suburban business area, killing seven persons and injuring thirty-one.

Electrical manufacturers will produce from 500,000 to 1,000,000 refrigerators for civilian use during 1944, Charles G. Pyle, managing director of the National Electrical Wholesalers Association said yesterday. Mr. Pyle also predicted that a like number of electric washing machines will be placed on the market before the end of the year and added that indications pointed to a gradually rising production in these items.

A gift of $5,000 from the Charles Hayden Foundation, 25 Broad Street, was received yesterday for the Neediest Cases Fund. This contribution, with twenty-six others which added to $156, increased the Fund's total to $282,662.50.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The Dewey Administration was asked today to appropriate $5,000,000 during the next fiscal year for child care and foot the entire cost of the program in the State, except where Federal funds are made available.
The New York Dress Institute gave a "star" party, reception and fashion show yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Plaza Hotel as the climax of a week's showings for out-of-town fashion editors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The United States is disposed to collaborate with Great Britain in facilitating an adjustment of the Polish question, according to indications tonight.

Bad Habits BackMid-January is the deadline on one inventory. This is the annual self-examination on how we have come along with performance on the New Year's resolutions so bravely made a fortnight earlier. The reason it cannot be delayed much beyond mid-month is that the resolutions themselves will by then have been forgotten and the inventory made impossible.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 14 -St. Andrews, the host club, retained three rinks in competition at the end of the first day's matches for the Douglas Medal at the indoor rink today. Ardsley, Boston, Mahopac and the Country Club of Brookline, Mass., also were represented as the field was reduced from nineteen to ten.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 15 -The Royal Air Force's heavy bombers attacked in Germany in strength last night, it was announced early today, after an all-day pounding of the enemy's special targets across the English Channel by great fleets of Allied bombers and fighters.

Another indoor track season will get under way tonight at 8 o'clock when the games of the Grover Cleveland Democratic Club are revived on the floor of the Seventh Regiment Armory. The meet is significant in more ways than one, for it will mark the reopening of the armories, shut to the public in 1940, and the entry of 450 college, school and service athlete measures well up to the pre-war years for these games.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP). -Donald M. Nelson told the Newspaper Industry Advisory Committee today that the War Production Board would stand by its policy in the handling of newsprint supplies. His words were interpreted as a rejection of publishers' pleas that WPB abandon its plan for stockpiling newsprint.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Advocates of a Federal ballot for service men and service women suffered a setback in the House today when the "States' Rights" soldier voting bill approved by the Senate was reported by the Elections Committee with only minor amendments, but they promised to carry the fight to the floor.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 14 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Allied Command communique:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 (AP) -The University of Pennsylvania announced today that the annual football game with Cornell, a Thanksgiving Day fixture for half a century, would be played this year on the Saturday following Thanksgiving.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A new lend-lease agreement is in process of negotiation between Washington and London. The matter under discussion is not a new over-all agreement but revisions "to meet special problems which have arisen in the circumstances that exist today."

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 14 -- Fighting continues with unslackened intensity in the Banja Luka-Prijedor sector of central Bosnia, where the enemy is exerting strong pressure, using tanks and armored vehicles, according to the communique of the People's Army of Liberation broadcast over the Free Yugoslav radio.
