CLEVELAND, Jan. 14 (AP) -- W. S. Jack, president of Jack Heintz, said today that "the Roosevelt Administration is flirting with a revolution" as he commented on the War Department's order for his company to reduce by $7,000,000 the cost of products which it had sold to the Government during 1942.
Mrs. Blanche S. Kahn is a woman to be reckoned with among the officer personnel, of the North Atlantic Division of the Army Engineer Corps.

The record volume of traffic handled last year by the New York Central Railroad resulted in the road's net earnings exceeding $8.50 a share, according to F.E. Williamson, president, in a letter accompanying the dividend check of $1 a share, payable today. For 1941 the company had reported a net income of $49,082,182, or $7.61 each on the 6,447,413 shares outstanding.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 14 (U.P.) -- Developing their drive toward the Japanese supply port of Akyab, Allied troops have advanced another four miles into western Burma, seizing two villages in the face of stiff opposition, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Maj. Billy Brooks Southworth, back home from bombing Nazi-occupied Europe, made known an important decision today.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Globe, "Where Are Your Children?," a drama about juvenile delinquency produced by Monogram, is the newcomer. Produced by Jeffrey Bernerd and directed by William Nigh, the film's cast is headed by Jackie Cooper, Gale Storm, Patricia Morison, John Litel, Gertrude Michael and Addison Richards.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14 (AP) -Racking up an eagle 3 and playing faultless golf except on one hole, Byron Nelson of Toledo, Ohio, shot a four-under-par 35, 33 -- 68 today to lead the field at the end of the first round of the seventy-two-hole $10,000 San Francisco Victory open tournament.

DETROIT, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Jake La Motta of New York punched out another victory tonight over former welterweight champion Fritzie Zivic of Pittsburgh, taking a 3-to-1 edge in their series. La Motta, bigger and younger, finished strong to gain the ten-round decision.

Right-wing groups in the American Labor party decided last night to make a last ditch fight to retain control of the party's political machinery in this State. In arriving at this determination they gave notice that they were looking to Mayor La Guardia and the New Deal leadership, whom they have consistently supported in the past, for help lest the party come under communist domination.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Twelve corporate defendants and thirteen individuals charged with conspiracy to fix brick cheese prices were acquitted today by a Federal court jury after more than fourteen hours of deliberation. The trial started Nov. 15.
ALGIERS, Jan. 14 -- A communique:

POPLAR BLUFF, Mo., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Fifty-five Butler County farmers, vowing not to post bonds in protest against what their lawyer called "an oppressive charge," were put in jail tonight on an indictment accusing them of inciting to riot in connection with the alleged ejection of four Negro families from an all-white rural district.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Jan. 15 -- In swift enveloping thrusts, the Red Army yesterday captured the rail junction of Kalinkovichi and Mozyr, the political center of Polesye Province, in the heart of the Pripet Marshes. The Soviet communique reported that, in exploiting those victories, the Red Army already had swept to twenty miles west of Mozyr, on the south bank of the Pripet River.

Government warehouses now hold an abundance of raw wool, but "if this were released tomorrow to the country's mills, it wouldn't have the slightest effect on the average consumer," a spokesman for wool manufacturers said yesterday, commenting on trade reports that liquidation of the supply is being discussed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Commander Warren Atherton of the American Legion spent forty-five minutes today at the White House, discussing with President Roosevelt the provisions of the Legion's omnibus bill for aid to service men of this war, now under consideration in Congress.

A large part of the warehouse industry was accused yesterday by the Office of Price Administration of victimizing service men and their families by demanding storage rates so exorbitant that many members of the armed forces "will never be able to get their things out of storage when the war is over."
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
The question of the arming of the French underground appears to be one of the most pressing before the French Committee of National Liberation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Lighter marketings of hogs here resulted today in a substantial decrease in holdovers. Other major hog markets where congestion has prevailed all week were clearing leftover supplies. Loading at the twelve Midwestern markets this week to date were 3.6 per cent smaller than last week, but about 250,000 lead more than for the same period last year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14 -Boris Morros said today that he is about to conclude negotiations with Jack Benny and Fred Allen for their appearance in a film again in co-starring roles in his proposed film version of the musical "Of Thee I Sing."
An article in THE NEW YORK TIMES last week described the experience of an airline pilot who was forced to return to La Guardia Airport after flying into a flock of sea gulls on his take-off.

The butcher, the grocer and the other retailers who sell rationed foods will save $35,000,000 a year on bookkeeping and clerical expenses through the general use of fiber tokens in point rationing, Walter Straub, Office of Price Administration national director of food rationing, said yesterday.
The purchase price of 1,000 heavy bombers to send over Tokyo, or $300,000,000, was the goal set yesterday for the liquor and wine industry in the Fourth War Loan drive, which opens Tuesday.

For almost two years authorities in Washington have prohibited the publication of figures showing the amount of oil in storage on the East Coast. A few months ago they relaxed the order and permitted the American Petroleum Institute to issue indices covering the principal products, based on stocks in 1940 and 1941 adjusted for seasonal variations.

The group of buildings, containing about 60,000 square feet of space, on a plot 100 by 200 feet at 87-101 Perry Street, Jersey City, has been sold by Oscar Schmidt International, Inc., to Chardenbert, Inc., leather goods. Cross Cross and Leo J. Linder represented the purchaser.

McKesson Robbins, Inc., will increase its advertising budget by $2,500,000 this year and will place the company's name and its six nationally advertised products before the public through the use of all major media. The company will sponsor a new radio program beginning in March.

The mention of what happened at Boyle's Thirty Acres on July 2, 1921, will stir no memories among those now of military age. It was, however, quite an occasion. There was a moment in the second round when "Gorgeous George" Carpentier, leaping clear of the sawdust, planted a hard right on Jack Dempsey's bristling chin.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 14 (U.P.) -A new wave of strikes hit the Pittsburgh district tonight, hampering municipal and industrial activities.

Reports that at the end of the war with Germany there will be an immediate resumption of the manufacture of important consumer items was discounted yesterday by Henry A. Dinegar, director of durable goods and products, Office of Civilian Requirements, War Production Board, appearing as one of the panel speakers at a war production conference in the Hotel Commodore, sponsored by fifteen engineering organizations in coopreation with the WPB.

The report of the Patino Mines and Enterprises Consolidated, Inc., announced yesterday for the period covering the nine months ended with last September, estimates the net income at 888,534, equivalent to $3,585,235 in United States dollars, and a loss of 6,553,253 bolivianos, or approximately $156,030.

An analysis of German war losses prepared by Col. Francisco Moravec, chief military intelligence officer of the Czech Government in London, places the Wehrmacht's casualties at about 6,000,000 men killed, wounded and captured. Such estimates cannot be exact and may not even be approximately accurate, but there can be no doubt that German losses, especially on the Eastern Front, have been stupendous.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 15 -The Polish Government in Exile offered last night to discuss "all outstanding questions" with Soviet Russia provided the United States and Britain would act as intermediaries and sit in on the discussions.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 15 -- The Association of American Colleges, ending its three-day conference, passed by unanimous vote today a resolution calling upon the National Government to cooperate with the other United Nations in establishing an international education office.

The Nazi-sponsored Fascist Cabinet of Benito Mussolini has adopted a decree seizing direct control of all vital "economic concerns" in German-occupied northern Italy, including those providing essential raw material supplies, power, and other "indispensable" services, the Rome radio said in a broadcast reported to the Office of War information last night.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 14 -The first victim of partisan vendetta against the judges of the Verona trials fell early this morning when the Fascist Militia Colonel Mittica crashed into a tree after the brakes of his racing car failed to work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed in December totaled 852,016 bales of lint and 107,559 bales of linters, compared with 935,870 of lint and 108,437 of linters in December a year ago.
Only three matches were played yesterday in the National Squash Tennis Association's "bulldog" tournament at the Yale Club, for the benefit of the American Red Cross. A fourth match went by default.

The City Center of Music and Drama, which opened last month under civic auspices, is planning for next fall the organization of repertory and opera companies of its own, it was disclosed last night by Newbold Morris, president of the City Council and chairman of the board of directors of the project.

The Walgreen Drug Company of Chicago has leased the tenth floor in the building at 345 Madison Avenue for a long term for its Eastern headquarters. The lease was negotiated by the R.B. Wattley Company.

In an effort to break the coal delivery bottleneck at the Jersey City loading platforms, Mayor La Guardia has called a conference of railroad officials, wholesale coal dealers and Federal authorities, to be held Monday morning at City Hall, he announced yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan, 14 -- Stake horses are on hand in such numbers at Hialeah Park that tomorrow's Palm Beach Handicap will be run in two divisions, each of which will carry $5,000 in added money and each of which has eight entries.

Senator Harry F. Byrd's indignation at being asked to pay $5 a pound for sliced turkey in a Madison Avenue delicatessen last November resulted yesterday in the assessment of fines totaling $95 against the store and its owner on charges made by the Office of Price Administrator -- but not for its turkey prices.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 14 -Patents for a simpler way of producing organic compaunds in the aliphatic hydrocarbon group, a new chlorinated rubber varnish, and for a system for preventing "wabbles" in vehicles, stand out among the 538 listed as granted in this week's issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

The first announcement of Great Britain's new official position, forced by manpower considerations, under which there will be no future allocation whatever of fine cotton yarn and fabrics for United States production purposes, including output under which strategic materials had been moving to this country since Pearl Harbor, was made here yesterday by M. Stanley Brown, United States representative of the Cotton Board of Manchester, England.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 14 (U.P.) -- United States Seventh Air Force planes attacked Japanese installations on Mili atoll in the southern Marshall Islands for the third straight day Wednesday, meeting no enemy fighter opposition and returning safely, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz reported today.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The stock markets here were quiet today, due to the nearness of the week-end, but the tone was firm. Little business was done in Kaffirs and diamond shores, but both these sections held steady.

Only $4,210,500 of new municipal issues will come up for award next week, compared with this week's revised total of $20,639,545, according to Daily Bond Buyer. More than one-half of next week's financing will be accounted for by a single issue, that of $2,225,000 of Rochester (N.Y.) refunding bonds due from 1949 to 1953, on which bids will be opened on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The United States will have two "admirals of the fleet" and two "generals of the armies" if Congress approves legislation to be introduced by its Naval Committee chairmen.

Mayor La Guardia witnessed yesterday the signing in his office of a labor agreement reached recently between the RCA Communications Company and the American Communications Association, a Congress of Industrial Organizations unit representing the company's 750 employes.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Jan. 15 -- As United States Marines stormed Hill 660 at Borgen Bay, east of Cape Gloucester, New Britain, in a continuing battle, 500 more Japanese dead were counted in two days, bringing the total to 2,975 killed since the landing.

Can a pack of hounds wear down a bear and kill it eventually? That was the question asked of Long Tom Currier, "biggest man in the north country," and his answer was no, the bear would kill the dogs one at a time if they stuck with him long enough.

The third point in the President's economic program in his annual message was a request for a "cost of food law." This appears to be merely a new name for subsidies. Mr. Roosevelt suggests that this program will cost "about 1 per cent of the present annual cost of the war."

Mr. Johnson decided to return Verdi's "Falstaff" to the Metropolitan repertory this season, in English. The reception of this project by last night's audience, which had bought out the theatre days in advance of the event, proved the popularity of this course.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 14 -- New England housewives and their daughters are literally weaving war's sinews in the form of high-speed belts, without which precision grinding of vital armaments parts could not have been achieved in time to meet the Axis war threat, it was disclosed here today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Welker Cochran surged ahead of Champion Willie Hoppe tonight in the Chicago phase of their three-cushion billiard marathon, winning the thirteenth and fourteenth blocks and gaining a 700-to-682 lead.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Plans for a drastic reorganization or realignment of responsibilities in the State Department have been practically completed and are expected to be discussed over the radio tomorrow night by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under Secretary of State.

Axis broadcasts yesterday said that Premier Hideki Tojo of Japan had conferred with a number of high Government officials, including five former Premiers, during the day and that Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu had conferred with Heinrich Stahmer, German Ambassador to Japan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Legislation authorizing Federal agencies to pay whenever necessary the traveling expenses of person recruited for Federal employment has been requested by the Civil Service Commission, which has submitted to Congress the draft of a proposal bill.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- United States troops in Britain began buying war bonds some eighteen months ago, but not until last summer, when a branch office for the United States Treasury was opened here, did the idea of investing for the future really catch on in the Army.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The American Forestry Association began today a survey of forestry resources of the United States designed to help in formulation of a post-war program for agriculture and industry.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Liberators ranged far over the northwestern sector of the southwest Pacific war theatre Wednesday and Thursday in raids that took in Dili on Timor, Macassar on Celebes Island, Balik Papan on Borneo and the island of Ceram -- all in the Netherlands East Indies -- and Keaukawa village in Dutch New Guinea.

Humble tools have always been man's good friends. Whether in time-mossed lands of the East or on new and rapidly expanding frontiers, simple tools have played a major role. The axe, the rifle and the hoe were tools that helped push this nation across the eastern wall, through the river valleys, across the grass-padded plains and over the divide to the western ocean.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 14 -Judge Frank S. Katzenbach imposed today fines and suspended prison sentences in Mercer County Court on three men charged with entering the OPA office here last April 14 and stealing stamps exchangeable for more than 5,000,000 gallons of gasoline and fuel oil.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 14 -- The first group of Yugoslav refugees to leave that country has arrived in the Middle East and is now being fed and receiving medical attention in fairly comfortable camps provided by the Middle East Relief and Refugee Association [MERRA], which is a division of the British Ministry of State.

A campaign to send art materials and supplies to Soviet artists has been initiated by the Artists Committee of the National Council of American Soviet Friendship. Announcement was made by Paul Manship, chairman of the committee, which was formed to encourage the interchange of information between American and Soviet artists.

Spice traders here, concerned over the complete stoppage of the movement of pepper into the hands of grinders, despite the knowledge that approximately a year's supply is being held in storage pending upward adjustment of ceiling prices, have made a "last-ditch" appeal to the Office of Price Administration for relief, it was learned yesterday.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 13 (Delayed) -- Two more bombings like the ones of Monday will "wipe Sofia off the map," said a traveler who arrived today from Bulgaria. The center of the Bulgarian capital is already almost entirely destroyed and Sofia has ceased to function as a city, he added. Thousands were killed, but it is impossible to assess the casualty total, as the bodies are still buried under the debris.

Because of the increase in truancy and behavior disorders, "resulting from unsettled conditions brought about by the war emergency," the Board of Education's committee on finance and budget has made provision in its proposed budget estimate for 1944-45, made public yesterday, for special "opportunity" classes in elementary and junior high schools.

After an early display of moderate strength on price-fixing orders increased hedging operations weakened the cotton futures toward the close. Yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, the list of active contracts ended dealings near the day's lowest levels and with quotations unchanged to 4 points below Thursday's last prices.

Surveys indicate that 56 per cent of the major companies can reconvert their plants to regular or redesigned products within three months after the war ends, Donald M. Hobart, manager of the research department of the Curtis Publishing Company, declared yesterday at a meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Lee Marshall, chairman of the board of the Continental Baking Company, will rejoin the War Food Administration, on leave from his company, in the near future, Marvin Jones, War Food Administrator, announced today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Randolph Paul, Treasury counsel, referring the issue of income tax simplification back to Congress, expressed sympathy tonight with the common man who would like a tax law that is easy to understand.

The Newspaper Radio Committee, representing 140 radio stations owned by newspapers, welcomed yesterday the action of the Federal Communications Commission in deciding not to establish any general rule regarding newspaper ownership of broadcasting facilities.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The entire weight of Britain's early post-war building effort will be directed to the construction of homes, with the men in the services having the highest priority and the newlyweds among them receiving special consideration, Lord Woolton said tonight in Liverpool.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Senate considered the tax bill again today, but made so little progress that Senator Barkley, the majority leader, announced a session tomorrow in an effort to finish the revenue phases of the measure.
The lone surviving elephant of the bomb-battered Berlin Tiergarten retires to Barcelona, but the New York Zoo carries on gamely, doing its bit for its country.

THE revolution that swept Mexico between 1913 and 1920 was supposedly a regenerative flame. Wasn't the Indian to get back the land that had been taken from his ancestors by Cortez's greedy minions? Wasn't there to be a schoolhouse in every village, an agricultural experiment station attached to every large communal land holding?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -President Roosevelt will have an opportunity next week of restoring harmony in the ranks of Southern Democrats, some of whose leaders have been talking of forming a third party.

The stock market gave yesterday another important clue as to the vast reinvestment funds awaiting employment and in a fairly broad upsweep eliminated the losses of the two preceding sessions. The trading again proved highly selective and the program of buying clearly indicated that issues with profit possibilities and post-war outlooks were being hunted out painstakingly.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 14 -- United States Army personnel in the Middle East will have full protection against all forms of staphyloccocic infections from now on as the result of the arrival here of additional larger supplies of penicillin, Col. Eugene V. Billick said today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. l4 -- The President's proposed national service legislation for the drafting of labor received today the endorsement of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Supply plans for the opening of a new front in Europe, wherever the invasion forces attack, are moving forward, ranking authorities of Army Service Forces disclosed today.

In a decision involving several million dollars which may be refunded to American importers of British merchandise, the United States Custom Court ruled yesterday that it is illegal for this Government to collect duties based on computed costs which include the British purchase tax.
WASHINGTON, Ind., Jan. 14 -Homer E. Capehart, manufacturer, farmer and political leader, announced himself in an address at his home here tonight as a Republican candidate for United States Senator.

Beekman Hospital, at Beckman and Water Streets, is unique among institutions of its kind. It stands guard over the well-being of all downtown Manhattan below Canal Street, a district of 45,000 residents, where a million persons, white-collared or in overalls, come to work daily.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Someone, who must be the meanest saboteur in the world, has succeeded with devilish cunning in depriving this fruit-thirsty nation of its first general distribution of oranges in years and years. Shipments from Spain have been delayed because, of all things, small, round, high explosive bombs were concealed among the cases.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 14 -- Following is the prepared text of Secretary Knox's address tonight before the Greater Cleveland Council of the Boy Scouts of America:

The New York Stock Exchange firm of Mallory, Hollister Co. will dissolve on Jan. 31. On the following day Mallory, Adee Co. will be formed by Charles H. Mallory, George T. Adee, Paul W. Havener, William L. Strong Jr., Robert L. Gill, Stanley W. Burke, Henry E. Coe Jr. and Robert E. Strawbridge Jr. The last three are limited partners.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Flotations of new securities here this week were the largest in amount for any week in a year. The total was $79,155,000, representing three new issues of bonds. It compared with $9,450,000 for a single issue of bonds offered last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Jack Heintz, Inc., of Cleveland, makers of military aircraft accessories and whose salary and bonus payments have attracted nationwide attention, have been commanded to cut $7,000,000 off excessive profits on equipment sold to the Government in the year ended on last Oct. 31, the War Department announced today.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 15 -The day's heaviest fighting raged in the Vinnitsa area, where Moscow dispatches said the Germans, trying to halt a drive toward the Odessa-Warsaw railroad, the Bug River and Rumania by the southern wing of Gen. Nikolai F. Vatutin's First Ukrainian Army, were reported throwing fresh reserves into action.
Officials and prisoners in all city prisons were recruited yesterday in the waste paper salvage drive through an order issued by Dr. Peter F. Amoroso, Commissioner of Correction.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Flotations of new securities here this week were the largest in amount for any week in a year. The total was $79,155,000, representing three new issues of bonds. It compared with $9,450,000 for a single issue of bonds offered last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Jack Heintz, Inc., of Cleveland, makers of military aircraft accessories and whose salary and bonus payments have attracted nationwide attention, have been commanded to cut $7,000,000 off excessive profits on equipment sold to the Government in the year ended on last Oct. 31, the War Department announced today.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 15 -The day's heaviest fighting raged in the Vinnitsa area, where Moscow dispatches said the Germans, trying to halt a drive toward the Odessa-Warsaw railroad, the Bug River and Rumania by the southern wing of Gen. Nikolai F. Vatutin's First Ukrainian Army, were reported throwing fresh reserves into action.

In his radio broadcast last night from Cleveland Secretary Knox must certainly have spoken for the great majority of his fellow-countrymen when he said that if there is any one theory which has been thoroughly exploded by events it is the theory that military preparedness makes war.
Officials and prisoners in all city prisons were recruited yesterday in the waste paper salvage drive through an order issued by Dr. Peter F. Amoroso, Commissioner of Correction.

Representatives of the Federal, State and city governments, the Army, the Navy and the theatrical profession, joined yesterday in starting the 1944 March of Dimes campaign on the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building, Wall and Nassau Streets, in the presence of hundreds of workers from the financial district.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -High zinc production in Eastern States is aiding the war effort, according to the Bureau of Mines, which said today that maintenance of output in the face of handicaps was an important factor in supplying adequate quantities of the strategic metal for war uses at smelters and manufacturing centers close to the Eastern mines.

The two years promoters of the metropolitan district spent trying to match Bobby Ruffin, Astoria lightweight, and Tippy Larkin, dancing, prancing boxer from Garfield, N.J., proved last night to have been only boxing's reprieve from a distasteful demonstration.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 14 -- One year's military training "for every boy when he attains the age of 17 or 18" was advocated tonight by Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 14 -- Col. Enrique P. Gonzales, Secretary of the Presidency, held today his first press conference for local and foreign journalists, which will henceforth take place every Friday, and once every month will be held by President Gen. Pedro P. Ramirez himself.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 14 -- A locomotive engineer was killed and nearly a score of passengers were painfully bruised at 10:55 o'clock tonight when a "deadhead" train of the New York, New Haven Hartford line crashed into the last car, a baggage car, of a crowded New Haven-bound train of the same line in the railroad station here.
Yesterday's Soviet communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The Polish Government in Exile has put up to Russia, Britain and the United States, in its statement issued in London yesterday, a question which the three leaders who conferred so amicably and so successfully at Teheran need not find insoluble. This is, naturally, the future of Poland.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- One of the two major obstacles to Government return of the country's railroads to their owners was removed tonight when the Brotherhood of Railroad Firemen and Enginemen, the Order of Railway Conductors and the Switchmen's Union of North America reached an agreement with the carriers.

ALGIERS, Jan. 14 -- German troops who were hammered out of Cervaro at 1 P.M. Wednesday struck back the same night in a furious counter-attack intended to recapture the village. But American units of the Allied Fifth Army withstood the blow and repulsed the enemy, and have now advanced beyond Cervaro to threaten the northern edge of Mount Trocchio three miles from Cassino.

WITH AMERICANS OF THE FIFTH ARMY AT CERVARO, Jan. 13 (Delayed) -- If you can find a building with a dependable second story and not show too much of yourself in craning for a look, you can see from Cervaro the rooftops of our next objective on the road to Rome -- Cassino -looming over the dust and smoke of battle.

H.L. Mencken has decided to devote most of his time this year to preparing a supplement to "The American Language," his standard work, first published in 1919, last revised in a fourth edition in 1936. Knopf, his publishers, expect to be able to bring out the supplement early in 1945.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The extraordinary grand jury investigation of alleged crime in Albany County which was ordered several weeks ago by Governor Dewey, was blocked temporarily today when Justice Christopher J. Heffernan of Amsterdam, a member of the Appellate Division, signed a writ of prohibition pending a court hearing.

The Rev. Dr. Liston Pope of New Haven, Conn., becomes editor today of Social Action, a monthly periodical published under auspices of the Council for Social Action of the Congregational Christian Churches of America. He has been assistant Professor of Social Ethics on the Gilbert L. Spark Foundation of Yale Divinity School since 1938.

The Fourth War Loan drive, aiming at a national over-all goal of $14,000,000,000, will be opened officially in New York City Tuesday morning at 11:50 o'clock with a parade from the Battery to City Hall in which dozens of wounded men of this war will participate.

The Axis powers still have not given up hope of being able to overthrow various governments in Latin America and to create an anti-United States bloc, Dr. Enrique de Lozada, Washington representative of the new regime in Bolivia, warned yesterday at a meeting of the executive committee of the Free World Association at the Hotel Commodore.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, Jan. 16 (U.P.) -- A communique:

The War Shipping Administration's recent campaign to lessen crew shortages that might have resulted in ship delays during the holiday period was successful and not a single vessel of the United States or Allied merchant fleets missed her sailing date off this coast between Dec. 15 and yesterday, according to Craig S. Vincent, Atlantic Coast representative of the recruitment and manning organization of the WSA.

BACK in 1938 Random House published a handsome five-volume edition of President Roosevelt's "Public Papers and Addresses." Highly praised by reviewers and accepted as a valuable historic record, the set, once launched, lagged on the bookstore shelves, and eventually was remaindered.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, as parent concern of the Bell System, earned its $9 annual dividend rate in 1943 by a margin of 8 cents, according to figures released yesterday by Walter S. Gifford, president. Net income for the year, with December results party estimated, was $169,905,000 after all expenses, taxes and other charges, equivalent to $9.08 a capital share.

OUR town has been in the theatre business for a little over a month now, and obviously it is doing all right. At least it is weathering storms as fast as they blow up, and that is one of the major tests of doing all right in the theatre business.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- A burning ring set off by British pathfinder planes appeared in the sky over Brunswick, ancient German town that is now the site of Messerschmitt factories, a little after 7 o'clock last night. In the course of the next twenty-three minutes Brunswick was hit by a bombing attack more intense than any yet inflicted upon the enemy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A bipartisan group rallied today behind a drive to increase service men's mustering out pay above pending proposals.

Dr. F.A. Hermens' reference to Irish experience with P.R. in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 5 is especially interesting to me, as I was a member of the Irish Parliament, first in the Dail and then in the Senate, from 1932 to 1943.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Harold L. Ickes, Solid Fuels Administrator, today directed high volatile coal producers in the northern West Virginia fields to fill major orders from all-rail retail dealers in the northeastern States and to make the remainder available to him for emergency distribution there.

A ribbon of steel swirls through a maze of machinery and chemical baths at 1,000 feet a minute, emerging with a shining coat of bright tin in a new, continuous du Pont electro-plating process which is aiding the tin-plate industry. Yearly savings of tin resulting from the use of electrolytic processes total 1,200,000 pounds.

First of the important all-breed exhibitions of 1944 is the thirty-first annual snow of the Maryland Kennel Club, which will be held at the Fifth Regiment Armory in Baltimore Saturday and Sunday, Feb. 5 and 6. The final closing of entries will be at noon, Jan. 31. The event will be given for the benefit of the Baltimore Council of the Navy League.

"THE GOLDEN FLEECE" is a cozy story for a bleak winter's night -- all about the doings at an old English inn in the rugged days of 1817, with a big hearth fire crackling in the kitchen, love in the hay mow, ghosts in the attic, and a sinister guest seeking lodging for the night.
January is the depth of the winter, by custom and record, but if you walk through the frozen woodland even in January you will see spring on the branches and in the frozen earth beneath your feet.

YES, even 250 years ago, a salvage campaign for paper-making materials, different only in scope from the drive to collect 8,000,000 tons of waste paper in 1944, was being waged. By the middle of the eighteenth century the shortage of cotton and linen rags had become acute, forcing European scientists to hunt for substitutes.
HOWARD PHILLIPS LOVECRAFT died five years ago at the age of 47, leaving behind an imposing mound of manuscript, either wholly unpublished or confined within the coarse covers of the pulp magazines.

OTTAWA, Jan. 15 -- By sending over to England the three top men in the Navy, Army and Air Force to take part in the direction of the invasion of Europe the Canadian Government, it is said here, has taken one more of those realistic steps that have characterized its whole conduct of the war.

ROBORE, Bolivia, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- A military detachment returned today from the Santo Corazon jungle and reported finding the bodies of five American missionaries in the camps of savage Indians near the Santo Corazon River.

ALGIERS, Jan. 15 -- Figures for the purchase of war bonds by the uniformed personnel in this theatre will "go up tremendously" over last month, it was said today by a spokesman at the Army Finance Office. At the same time, he revealed, figures indicate that despite all their present difficulties in Italy, Americans of the Fifth Army are among the most regular buyers of bonds.

SKIERS who haven't the time to reach the snow fields of North Conway, Franconia Notch and other New England resorts, are finding good sport at Bear Mountain. Forty-five miles from Manhattan and easily reached by bus or train, it offers a convenient and diversified center for sports lovers.

WHEN the history of this war comes to be written, the material aid supplied by the United States to her Allies (before and after her own participation in the conflict) will be accounted one of the chief factors in their victory -- and the "lend-lease" procedure under which this aid was granted will be remembered, to President Roosevelt's credit, as a happy stroke of political genius.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 15 -- Typhus-stricken Naples is getting a mass delousing on a scale probably never before attempted by medical science. Fifty times as many cases a day are reported now as were found in the city at the time of the Allies' entry in October, Brig. Gen. Leon A. Fox of Birmingham, Ala., field director of the United States Typhus Commission, said on his return to Cairo from the pestilence-ridden area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Members of Congress discovered during their Christmas holiday that their constituents were thinking a great deal about the men and women in the armed forces, particularly about their right to vote.
For the third consecutive session, the cotton futures market yesterday turned easier in late dealings under the influence of selling pressure in the far deliveries.

MR. NOYES has written this story of the squirrels and other creatures of Pooduck Island and their human friend, the boy Solo, out of a deep love of the Maine country. His descriptions of sunrises and sunsets, pine-darkened islands and the creeping blue reach of the sea, the autumn leaves flying like flocks of gorgeous birds, create for the reader the atmosphere of out of doors and are the most convincing part of the story.

FOLLOWING are twelve points on which we must all insist. Alone they will not insure peace, but without them no peace is possible. They require amplification, but here is the rockbottom minimum for security.

Prof. H.V.A. Briscoe recently told the Royal Society of Arts that the Department of Inorganic and Physical Chemistry at Imperial College, London, has been experimenting with mineral powders which combated the grain weevil and which were entirely removed by the normal cleaning processes prior to milling.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- There is no official reaction here yet to the Polish Government's statement on the boundary issue, but well informed, usually reliable, sources said Premier Stalin had informed President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill in advance concerning the recent Soviet proposal in the most general terms at the Teheran conference.

THE twelfth part of the famous collection of the late Col. E.H.R. Green will be sold at auction on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday and on Jan. 24, 25 and 26 through J.C. Morgenthau Co., Inc., 1 West Forty-seventh Street. At the three afternoon sessions this week 1,373 lots will be offered by Walter S. Scott, presiding.

Opinion among airplane designers is divided on the subject of jet propulsion. Glenn Martin thinks that the rocket principle will have its commercial as well as its military uses, but that fuel consumption will have to be reduced. On the other hand we have Prof. R.H. Goddard's word for it that the efficiency of a rocket motor is far higher than that of the economical Diesel.

The anniversary last Wednesday of the sixth month of the Russian offensive found the German General Staff faced with a crucial, eleventh-hour decision. Under the hammer blows of one of the most sustained drives in the annals of war -- begun July 12 in the ripening grain fields around Orel -- the Wehrmacht had suffered an unbroken series of defeats.

VAUDEVILLE is low-born, dealing in the common coin of entertainment. It fell upon lean times in the Nineteen Twenties when road touring went on the rocks because the movies had taken over the theatres in the provinces and put the low-priced three-a-day houses out of business in New York. Now it has got a new lease on life and is going strong. What's mainly responsible is the war.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 15 -- As the war in the Pacific turns into its third year -- the year that may be decisive if it brings the necessity of battle to the enemy fleet -the role of Hawaii in the unfolding drama assumes increasing importance.

TWO big group exhibitions at clubs -- one at the National Arts, the other at the Salmagundi -- are, as usual, predominantly academic in tendency. The former includes characteristic paintings by Leon Kroll, Ivan Olinsky, Helen Lawrence (a portrait of the late Ida Tarbell), Gene Alden Walker, Julius Delbos, Gerald Leake, Gordon Grant and many well known academicians.

Rosalyn Tureck gave the New York musical community an unusual treat yesterday afternoon when she played the first of a series of three all-Bach piano recitals at Town Hall. For the pianist made "old Bach," as Frederick the Great affectionately referred to the great cantor, a living and throbbing human being of our own time.
Greater emphasis than ever before is being placed on courses in American civilization and culture by colleges and universities in all sections of the country.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 15 -- Four Freedoms and Old Grad were surprise winners of the two Palm Beach Handicaps at Hialeah today as 6,514 persons braved storm and mud to back the thoroughbred horse.

While prices of grains cracked yesterday about 2 cents a bushel, giving up the remainder of their recent advances, stocks on the New York Stock Exchange extended their gains to around the best levels of the new year and made the most active and broadest Saturday market in four months. Final prices were at the best levels in two months.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 (AP) -- John D.M. Hamilton, former chairman of the Republican National Committee, asserted tonight that Wendell L. Willkie's managers had brought "undue pressure upon party leaders in every section of the country to pledge themselves to his cause before anyone else had a chance to be heard."

Retail trade was active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were active and there was a good call for dresses, coats and suits, sportswear and millinery.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The strike threat of three operating railroad brotherhoods was lifted today and as a result Secretary Stimson ordered put into effect the wage increases agreed upon by them and the carriers yesterday.

COOIKING meat to get the most out of it -- a pertinent subject nowadays, for obvious reasons -- depends to a great extent on suiting the method to the cut. This means knowing what procedure -- braising, roasting, broiling or simmering in water -- effects the best results in preparing a portion of beef or veal, lamb or pork.
OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 15 -- War has stimulated the Corn Belt farmer to the greatest production he has ever attained, has returned him his greatest income and has given him his biggest grouch.
The American Red Cross announced yesterday that 200,000 men and women must be recruited before March 1 to solicit New York's 1944 Red Cross quota of $22,386,000.

IT was not until we "denizens of the city" (as the country policeman called us) moved out to the village that we heard about this new war bartering. It is a sort of blind man's buff among the tightly rationed or disappearing things. With a certain nonchalance in the winter, for instance, you give an onion to the man with three apples, and hope for the best.

THE New York Botanical Garden and THE NEW YORK TIMES are cooperating again this winter to present a free course in Victory gardening at The New York Times Hall, west of Broadway on Forty-fourth Street.

Fifteen hundred persons attending a rally against anti-Semitism last night at Carnegie Hall heard speaker after speaker warn that disunity on the home front must be combated lest the peace be lost after the military war against Hitlerism is won.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The War Production Board today granted manufacturers of upholstered wood furniture permission to resume the use of a limited quantity of steel springs to take the place of various types of wooden springs, padding and other devices utilized while steel for springs was not available.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Two challenging messages went from the White House to Congress this week. One demanded action to bolster the national war front. The other coupled with an outline of the "financial requirements for victory" a trumpet call to prepare for the post-war world and the national and international economic problems that the post-war world will pose.

THE British have two qualities which guarantee their survival as a great power: They are capable, in spite of their love of tradition, of making sudden and even revolutionary changes and they thrive on catastrophe.

In a second-half comeback against Cornell in the Columbia gymnasium, the Lions defeated the Ithacans' quintet last night, 33 to 29. It was Columbia's first Eastern Intercollegiate League victory. The gymnasium was filled to capacity.

EVER since Pearl Harbor we have been told on the best authority that we must get boys and girls in on needed and useful tasks; that younger adolescents need, want and are eager to feel part of their country's effort; that they are disappointed and restless when left out.

LATE in the pages of "Good Night, Sweet Prince" Gene Fowler pauses in his fine biography of John Barrymore to tell how it came to be written -- and to dwell for a brief moment on his doubts at writing it.

HERE is a novel about love, family conflict, political intrigue and slap-bang sea fights. Its background is the Maine coast in the days of wooden ships and iron men -- specifically, the turbulent Seventeen Nineties, when Washington struggled to hold his country to a middle course in a world shaken to its core by the impact of the French Revolution.

BY a deathbed decree, Peter the Great in 1725 commissioned Vitus Bering, a Danish sea captain in the Czar's service, to discover whether Asia and America were joined by a land bridge in the North Pacific -- or separated by the strait then called Anian.

Coming fortuitously at the time when Congress has begun consideration of a tax measure which would allow corporations to set up reconversion reserves amounting to 20 per cent of taxable net income, the American Institute of Accountants issued yesterday a memorandum disclosing that many companies in a group of medium-sized war contractors show no provisions in their reports for 1943 for reconversion, rehabilitation or dismissal pay.

CONTRASTS in abstraction are afforded by three of the week's exhibitions. Bradley Walker Tomlin, at Frank Rehn's, had his last one-man show more than a decade ago. Since then his style has sharpened and become more personal.

THE League of Composers will present its first concert of the season Sunday night, Jan. 30, in New York Times Hall, when a program of contemporary chamber music will be offered, including several new American works not heard before in this city.
Columbia University's Midshipmen came from behind in the last minute to defeat New York University, 46 to 43, last night at the University Heights Gymnasium. The Violets led at the half, 23 to 20.

Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature contained good news for the harassed taxpayers of this State. A new, simple, one-page tax return which can be filled out in five or ten minutes by the average citizen has been prepared and can be used by most taxpayers. Contrast this sharp reduction in paper work with the more complicated tax forms promised by the Federal Government.

LAST week, in writing about John Buchan and his autobiography. I drew attention to a passage in which, recognizing the need and desireability of change in human, affairs, he expressed the belief that it is best to try "to bring all change into harmony with the fundamentals drawn from the past.

MUCH of the current discussion of post-war planning in the domestic field centers on housing. This is only natural, since the home, whether rented or owned, is one of the fundamentals of life, a matter of close personal interest to everyone.

NO one who knew Paris well can read Jules Romains' new book without experiencing a bitter nostalgia. Yet the most genuine emotions will be read into this novel, rather than being implicit in it. . . . When did the author begin this, the latest installment in his "Men of Good-Will" series?

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- The Democratic party organizations of New York City moved today to abolish proportional representation as a method of electing city Councilmen. Following the last election, when two Communists and one man accused of being one were elected to the Council of seventeen members, the Democratic legislative leaders said today that they would sponsor measures when the Legislature reopens Monday night to end that system of election.

THERE is no better way of determining the popularity of a motion picture than on the basis of its box-office record. That's the yardstick the producers and exhibitors go by, and, if it doesn't always necessarily indicate artistic attainment it at least is an infallible index of contemporary audience taste.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 -- Cracking par again with another superior round, Byron Nelson, the favorite, strengthened his lead in the $10,000 San Francisco Victory open golf tournament today as he passed the halfway point of the 72-hole event with a total of 137.

FULLY one person has asked me why I, at the pinnacle of my success, should announce that with my final performance of "Our Town" next Saturday night I intend to retire from my acting career. At first I brushed aside the question.

It sounded just a trifle odd to hear the President (1) enumerate no less than eight rights of the individual, constituting a new Bill of Rights; (2) follow this up with the statement that these rights of the common man must test America's rightful place in the world, and then (3) almost immediately quote somebody who said that this nation stands in grave danger of "rightist reaction."

LONDON, Jan. 15 (Canadian Press) -- The biggest provincial soccer crowd of the season today jammed transport routes to Villa Park where the visiting Stoke City team advanced to fourth place in the Football League cup qualifying competition by defeating Aston Villa, 2 -- 0.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- Additional details of the battle for Mozyr and Kalinkovichi, published today, confirm earlier impressions that Red Army units were called on to display all their military craft and fighting spirit to overcome the formidable obstacles the Germans had placed in the path of the approaches to these highly prized bastions in the Pripet Marshes.

THIS, the second volume in a series about foreign-born families who have contributed to the American heritage, keeps up the high standard set by the author's preceding volume, "They Came From Sweden."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- One-third of the pilots of the British Fleet Air Arm and the crews necessary to maintain the American planes that they fly are now being trained in the United States, British naval spokesmen announced here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- There was no indication today whether the United States Government would accede to the request made by the Polish Government to London and Washington yesterday for Anglo-American mediation in Poland's difficult boundary dispute with Soviet Russia or whether Russia would accept it.

Positive proof exists here today in the shape of a dead six-pound groundhog definitely backing the early spring forecast of Robert D. Edwards, weather prognosticator of Colgate University's Naval Flight Preparatory School.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- There is a growing belief here that Poland will obtain important territorial concessions in the west as an inducement for her to accept Soviet terms on her eastern frontier. It is believed here that Poland may be offered the most of East Prussia, parts of Prussian Silesia and other smaller segments formerly impinging on her western border.
WEST POINT, Jan. 15 -- Army had rather an easy time with Colgate on the basketball court today, downing the Red Raiders 69 to 44. It was the cadets' second victory in two contests.

Retail trade here improved last week, checking the decline noted since the first of the year. Department stores showed an estimated increase of about 7 per cent over the like week of 1943, with some establishments scoring gains of up to 15 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Penicillin is credited by physicians at the Walter Reed Hospital with another miracle -- the curing of a secondary brain abscess of a type heretofore considered fatal.
LONDON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 15 -Madgeburg, seventy miles west of Berlin, was a target of last night's RAF attack. Preliminary reports available here indicate that the Krupp branch there, as well as the Gruson iron foundries and the Elbe River shipyards and port installations, were severely damaged.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- The defending St. Andrews rink, skipped by Pitt F. Carl Jr., had a close call in advancing through the quarter-final round of the annual Douglas Medal bonspiel on the lanes of the St. Andrews Golf Club indoor curling arena today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Over the strenuous protests of Senator Barkley of Kentucky, majority leader, the Senate approved today the so-called Marshall Field amendment to the pending tax bill which would limit the amount of tax reduction by individuals because of businesses that regularly lose money.

ARCH OBOLER has no budget restrictions to worry about in casting the novels and plays he will rewrite and the one original he is planning to do for "Everything for the Boys," opening Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. on WEAF-NBC.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- General liquidation developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, and with stop-loss orders uncovered wheat lost 2 1/8 cents and rye 3 1/8 cents a bushel before sufficient support developed to check the break. There was a fair rally at one time, but the upturn was not impressive and selling pressure was in evidence until the close.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, expressed the opinion today that wartime employment has reached its peak and said that the coming months may bring a progressive decline in the total number of workers engaged in manufacturing.

HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY AIR FORCE, Jan. 14 (Delayed) -- Two months of almost daily bombing by Liberators and Billy Mitchell medium bombers of the United States Seventh Air Force have "well neutralized" two of the principal Japanese air bases in the Marshall Islands and have wrought serious damage to three others, Maj. Gen. Willis H. Hale. commander of the Seventh Air Force, declared here today.

SEEING Martha Graham's, "Deaths and Entrances" for the second time is an experience that is both astonishing and comforting. At first seeing it is perfectly safe to say that not a single spectator can honestly report that he knows what the work is all about, though he must acknowledge that it is gripping and emotionally moving.

Prof. Felix Ehrenhaft, noted Vienna physicist, who fled after the Nazi occupation of Austria, presented yesterday before the American Physical Society, meeting at Columbia University, a set of his latest experiments, carried out in his laboratory in New York, which he said provided for the first time experimental proof of the existence of pure magnetic current.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Poland, without any desire on her part, proved to be the decisive factor for war in 1939 and now it looks as if she may prove decisive again in determining whether we shall have a secure peace.

AN event outside the customary run of performances which are reviewed in the daily press took place last Tuesday afternoon in the Soviet Consulate in this city when Vladimir Horowitz gave before an invited audience which included most of the leading musicians of the city a first hearing in America of the Prokofieff Piano Sonata No. 7, op. 83, which, in 1942 in Russia, had won the Stalin prize.
Metals must be turned, bored and otherwise worked by machine tools before they can be converted into parts of machines. The turnings and borings are not thrown away but remelted and cast into ingots.

Continued improvement in the supply of non - ferrous metals, clearly demonstrated in recently released production figures, will call for the extension of the government's foreign metal purchase program to domestic output, if production is to be kept at present levels in a market curtailed by War Production limitation orders, producers asserted yesterday.

I'd like to put in my two cents' worth in the controversy going on in your Magazine regarding the architecture of New York's new asphalt plant. Both Mr. Moses and Mr. Binger are incorrect in their "final" statements in so far as both have missed the real point at issue.

ONCE, while I was broadcasting an appeal for charity in the Southland, I told the beautiful allegory of the creation of man -- of how Truth and Justice asked that man not be made, for, they said, he would pollute the Almighty's sanctuaries.

WITH this new novel, Martha Gellhorn (Mrs. Ernest Hemingway) establishes herself as an honest and intelligent writer who has something to say and knows how to say it well. "Liana" has certain agreeable qualities of maturity and emotional understanding which are not always to be found in even the best modern art, still a predominantly male affair.

The ever-enlarging role being played by the American Merchant Marine in the prosecution of the war has caused the United Seamen's Service to make preparations to handle an unprecedentedly large number of men during this year in its sixty centers scattered all over the world, Douglas P. Falconer, executive director of the service, said here yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 15 -- Very few men in the whole world, even among such obstinate admirers of German military might as the army officers who compose the majority of the Argentine Cabinet, still believe that the Axis has the faintest chance of winning the war.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Sergeant Oram C. Hutton, formerly a reporter and photographer of The New York World-Telegram and New York Post, received today the Army Air Medal and was honored with a letter of commendation from the Association of American Correspondents in London.

LET'S have another little chit-chat on the ever-lively subject of shorts. It's a topic on which this reporter cannot, for too long a time, keep quiet. A few weeks ago we were casting warm and approving eye upon some of the then current specimens of outstanding work in this field, and a sharply convincing thought intruded which we hadn't then the time to explore.

Mishel Piastro presented a violin program yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, which marked his return to the recital platform after an interim of many years. He had not been heard here in a similar capacity since 1924, when he devoted his talents to an all-Vieuxtemps list in Aeolian Hall.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The British Foreign Office still lacks full details of the series of recent bomb explosions aboard vessels bringing much desired cargoes of oranges from Spain to Britain, but it was learned from private sources today that Sir Samuel Hoare, British Ambassador, already has protested vigorously to Gen. Francisco Franco.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 15 -- The Dartmouth five scored its fifth straight Eastern Intercollegiate League victory of the season tonight, defeating Princeton by 54 -- 31.

In the evolution of income tax law something akin to common law of taxation has been in course of development for at least a decade. Principles of taxation growing out of court decisions, dealt with in this column from time to time, indicate that doctrines are being formulated which are a very real consideration by the courts in deciding tax questions.

Unless conditions arise making it impracticable or a matter of war necessity not to hold them, the United States Lawn Tennis Association will carry on its national championship tournaments in 1944 as in 1943.

THIS light and charming novel is the adult recreation of a childhood fantasy, of an imaginary world that all children at some time must have made for themselves. In the vicinity of a small fishing village on the west coast of Ireland a landslide, aided by some hot summer weather, exposes and warms to life the eggs and seeds and dormant animals of a long past era.

FOR every person who is "air-minded" here is a fascinating little book. William B. Stout built the world's first metal airplane, the famous Ford tri-motor's, the Scarab car with engine in the back, and has designed a "SkyCar," a four-wheel airplane that becomes a motor car when its wings are taken off.
THE grand strategy recently adopted at Cairo and Teheran has no doubt confirmed in the minds of the Japanese militarists what they had already sensed -- that their doom is sealed.

The late P.E. Foxworth, formerly in charge of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was honored yesterday afternoon by Mayor La Guardia, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the FBI, and Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the New York State Guard, with the presentation of a plaque in the Great Hall of the Chamber of Commerce Building, 65 Liberty Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers may get back into the American Federation of Labor next week.
The address of Vice President Henry A. Wallace before the political action committee of the CIO here yesterday follows:

HERE is a quick-paced story about the ornery backcountry swampers who lived "a week past Montgomery" in the days of the War Between the States. John Bennett, a forest engineer, born and raised in the Carolinas, shows in this, his first novel, that he has an ear for the flat dialect of the coast country.

AS closely as I can figure, "Wonderings" is Mr. Masefield's one hundred and first book. It will not add much to his poetic reputation built by the other thirty-odd volumes of his verse. The opening pages suggest that the poem is to be a new "Prelude or Growth of a Poet's Mind" -- the full title is "Wonderings (Between One and Six Years)."

The most pressing diplomatic problem plaguing the Allies is the present controversy between Russia and the Polish Government-in-Exile over Poland's eastern frontier. To most observers it is far more than a boundary dispute; it is a test case of the Allies' ability to deal jointly and fairly with other similar problems that may arise before the war ends and in the post-war period.

PAUL CRESTON'S concerto for saxophone will have its first performance on Jan. 27 and 28, when it will be played by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, with Vincent J. Abato, the bass clarinetist, as soloist.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Two examiners for the Interstate Commerce Commission who have been investigating the transportation of new automobiles since January, 1939, reported today to the commission that present interstate rates and practices had not been shown to be unlawful.

IN his East Side house, the living room of which is well furnished with Bach records and well-selected, well-read books, Paul Robeson talked last week of some of the living, the vital experiences, that have gone into his role of Othello.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Jan. 15 -- The bootleggers of anthracite, masters of improvisation, have more than met the challenge of the State, the legitimate industry and the United Mine Workers of America to legalize their ramshackle enterprise or go out of business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The post-war occupation of Germany by Russia, Great Britain and the United States -- each garrisoning one-third -- was considered by President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin at the Teheran conference.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Frank C. Walker, National Chairman, tonight urged the Democratic party to stand on its war record in the coming election and "the people will see to it that we prevail."

DECADES before Grosvenor Square became a bombsite, in the days when security was cheap and prose jeweled. Max Beerbohm observed that he was more interested in the placing of a comma than in the fortunes of the British Empire.

Charles Brinton of Philadelphia, former national squash racquets champion, playing No. 1, led his mates to a 12-to-3 victory in the annual squash racquet team matches between the United States and Canada for the Lapham Trophy on the courts of the University Club yesterday.

BUFFALO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- City College of New York made up a 7-point deficit in the last six minutes tonight to inflict on Canisius its second basketball defeat in ten starts, 37 to 36, before 7,081 spectators.
MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 15 -- It was not so long ago that this historic Vermont region went into seclusion at the first sign of cold weather. Today, it's another story, one entirely different.
WINKING at young ladies may not be quite proper.

Organic fungicides have long been sought to supplement or supplant compounds of sulfur, copper and mercury, which are now scarce and which have their limitations. Hence the importance of a report submitted to the American Chemical Society by W.P. Ter Horst and E.L. Felix on successful experiments with an organic fungicide identified as 2, 3-dichloro-1, 4-napththoquinone.

Warning that this nation is as unprepared for peace as it was for the Pearl Harbor attack, John W. Hanes, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, told the Women's National Republican Club yesterday that their party should assume leadership for a "moral regeneration" of America.

AGAIN artists have been painting the war, and once more -- as was the case last summer when Life Magazine held its war art exhibition at the Metropolitan -- results of an intensive and comprehensive effort have been made available to the public in the same museum (this time, however, in the balcony gallery of the big entrance hall).

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Anything other than complete cooperation with Soviet Russia after the war would be "tragic blundering" on the part of the United States, said Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under-Secretary of State, during an hour's broadcast tonight over the National Broadcasting Company's network entitled "The State Department Speaks."

MISS KAY BOYLE has been criticized for using plots too trivial and too tenuously strung to uphold the thematic structure of her stories. She has also been charged with a frigidly mannered prose -- exquisite, elegant, but less actually brilliant than beautifully competent.

SUCCESSES and failures of the Victory gardener during 1943 were attributed to a "special knack" or seed or weather or "bugs," all of which factors doubtless made a difference. But one of the really important things was fertility of the soil, and this depends on the application of two ingredients -- organic matter such as manures, composts and green manures, and the use of chemical fertilizers.

THE radio division of the Office of Research, affiliated with the College of the City of New York, has made public its annual copyrighted poll of the songs that proved the most popular over the national networks in 1943.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Dogs that return from the war will bear honorable discharge certificates and service records, according to an announcement today by the Army. Due to changes in military duties for which they have been trained, some of the animals are being released from K-9 Corps.

The Lener Quartet played a Russian program of uncommon interest and suggestive contrast yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, with Ania Dorfmann as pianist in the performance of the Shostakovich Piano Quintet. The Quintet was preceded by the Quartet in E flat minor, too rarely played, of Tchaikovsky.

LONDON -- United States Airmen operating from British bases in daylight raids on Western Germany are now equipped with armored vests made in a London factory. Many of our boys have visited the factory and shown the workers their jackets with the outer covering of brown canvas burned and pipped by cannon splinters or spent machine-gun bullets.

IF you have included plants in your garden for the sake of their winter beauty, you probably regard the blooming of witchhazels as marking the end of the season. If on the other hand, you find spring hard to wait for, this flowering in the dead of winter will seem like the first blossoming of another gardening year.

Sensing a possible avenue through the State Department to early re-tooling for peacetime output, some builders of basic textile equipment indicated last week that for 1944 they will abandon last year's time-consuming wait for piecemeal decisions from various war agencies on this vital subject.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, Jan. 16 -- Australian troops occupied the Nambariwa barge center, capturing big Japanese supply dumps and armaments, including artillery, Friday afternoon and then advanced to the outskirts of Sio, last remaining Japanese base on the Huon Peninsula of New Guinea.

ALGIERS, Jan. 15 -- Gaining momentum despite the peak-studded and ridge-spined terrain, where the Germans are fighting back furiously, French units of Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army have captured Acquafondata and three more heights and extended their gains in the three-day offensive to almost five miles, it was officially announced today.

The announcement by the American Foundation for the Blind that it has just completed recording the Bible, from Genesis to Revelation, as a Talking Book, draws attention to a service to our sightless population in which all of us as taxpayers have a share. These Talking Books consist of long-playing phonograph disks on which trained readers from stage and radio have recorded much that is outstanding in classic and contemporary literature.

As early as March, 1942, only three months after Pearl Harbor, the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director, reached the conclusion on the basis of its exceedingly well-informed surveys that a substantial majority of the American people favored a national war service act.
THE beginner at bridge hesitates to pass up any trick he can win, but any more experienced player learns the occasional value of a hold-up play, in which the winning of a trick is postponed.

A YEAR ago the "Bougainville Express" was an important branch line on the Japanese southern Pacific road. It highballed down on a night run through the narrow strip of water separating Savo Island from Guadalcanal, carrying reinforcements and supplies to the Japs on Guadalcanal.

ANYONE who thinks Fred Allen is enamoured of life before the impersonal radio microphone had better speak softly. The other afternoon the comedian was chatting with Tenkswatawa's little cousin and their talk turned to things theatrical.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The hog marketing committee of the stock yards here advised producers today not to ship swine to market on Monday unless arrangements had been made with the selling agency. Today's report by the War Food Administration follows.

The course of the war in Europe began to move slowly last week toward the inevitable gigantic climax of 1944. The Russian winter offensive drove well into Poland, United States day bombers opened another chapter in the "softening-up" process of Germany, and Fifth Army troops began a new offensive in Italy as both sides prepared for the coming invasion of western Europe.

AS is its annual custom, Variety, the show business weekly, recently celebrated an anniversary with a fat edition to which sundry experts in the entertainment business contributed essays on their respective specialties, and an uncommonly interesting symposium it was.

BOSTON, Jan. 15 -- The crippled Bruins, aided by three of their amateur farmhands, subjected the Rangers to their seventh straight National Hockey League setback, 7 -- 5, tonight before 11,800 persons at the Boston Garden.

An attendance of two thousand persons, including many high-ranking officers of the armed forces and their wives, is expected for the Polka Military Ball, eleventh annual benefit entertainment sponsored by the Kosciuszko Foundation, which will take place Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

THAT old advice on the value of "moderation in all things" is as applicable to garden tools as to other human affairs. Obviously, to have so many that half of them are never used is as silly as trying to get along with only one. An intelligent middle course is just plain horse-sense.

WHEN the history of higher education in America is written, the amazing growth of the junior college movement will be looked upon as one of the most significant academic developments of the present century.

Beginning with the 1944 summer session, Keuka College will operate on a quarterly basis rather than the present two semester program. This change adjusts the yearly schedule more equitably to take care of the field period plan and the School of Nursing.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 15 -- In Vichy the main concern among the remaining collaborationists in governmental service relates to jobs vacated and jobs filled.

THREE particular terms of opprobrium have been applied to this Administration as a whole, with particular reference to certain members thereof. The first badge of disgrace was "braintruster." The second, which has run throughout the years, has been, and still is "New Dealer."

Eric A. Johnston's article, "In Defense of the Profit System," in THE TIMES Magazine is misnamed. It treats almost wholly of "benefits from unlimited trade." But profit-taking is in restraint of trade.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 15 -- This week's Allied advance toward Akyab in Burma is a forecast of things to come.
AN ADVANCED NAVAL BASE, New Guinea, Jan. 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- Tokyo reported that thirty of the Emperor's dive bombers had destroyed two P-T boats, but Tokyo was wrong.

CENTERVILLE, Del., Jan. 15 -- Admiral William F. Halsey agrees that "the way to win the war is to lick the Hun first and polish him off, and then get the stuff out there in the Pacific so we can polish off the yellow monkeys."

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, after ten days in Britain divided between training centers and the gloomy rooms of the War Office, has finished his first inspection of the troops he expects to lead into Berlin and made his first appraisal of the Allied invasion plan in which his armies will play so important a part.

While some semi-official calculations figure as high as 120,000,000 net tons of steel ingots as the annual demand in the early years of peace, Walter S. Tower, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, said last week that actual experience never had produced a peacetime demand for steel as high as 65,000,000 tons of ingots.

WITH THE MARINES AT CAPE GLOUCESTER, New Britain, Jan. 13 (Delayed) (AP) -- Battling under what one Guadalcanal veteran termed "the worst fighting conditions I ever saw," United States Marines fought step by step for Hill 660 on rain-soaked Cape Gloucester today.

GIBRALTAR, Jan. 15 -- The departure this week from Gibraltar of Lieut. Gen. Frank N. Mason-MacFarlane, one of Britain's ablest soldiers and administrators, after eighteen months as Governor is generally read here as a sign that Britain is convinced that Gibraltar and the Mediterranean are now secure against any foreseeable threat.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- The sudden appearance in Washington of Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's air commander in the Southwest Pacific, coincided tonight with new speculation on an early three-way pincer drive against Japan.

All district offices in the New York Region of the Office of Price Administration have been instructed to begin preparing charts to show the legal top prices that consumers should pay for approximately forty-five commonly used species of fish, it was announced yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, Regional OPA Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, announced stringent controls tonight to keep civilian production from being carried on in labor shortage areas where it would interfere with war work.

Apparently penicillin has been successfully used in conjunction with heparin, an anticoagulant, in seven patients with subacute bacterial endocarditis (inflammation of the membrane which lines the heart), a condition almost invariably fatal. CINCINNATI, Jan. 15 -- Taking as their theme "The Colleges Prepare for Peace," 1,000 educators, representing every important institution of higher learning in the United States, looked ahead and found that the general outlook for education in 1944, despite the setbacks caused by the war program, was decidedly encouraging.

EVER since Louis of the house de Rochemont went Holly-woodward some months ago, the destinies of March of Time have been mainly guided by his younger brother, Richard. WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- War expenditures of the United States in the calendar year of 1943 totaled $85,135,000,000, an increase of 62 1/2 per cent over the 1942 total of $52,406,000,000, the War Production Board reported today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 15 -- Reports from the sickbed of Bulgaria show a rise in temperature. PERFECT posture -- in the language of industrial medicine -- is a prerequisite to the safe performance of any job. In the language of beauty, it is a prerequisite to grace. PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- St. John's University, generally conceded to be the best basketball team in New York's metropolitan area, notched its eighth victory in nine starts this season at Convention Hall tonight, overcoming smartly drilled Temple University, 36 -- 32.

HORSES are with us still, and that in spite of the gas engine, "in the air, on land and sea" -- like the United States Marines. On the tracks the thoroughbreds still run -- draw bigger crowds than ever and bring more money into the betting ring.

LEE STOWE is, with Archie Steele, a rugged mainstay of The Chicago Daily News foreign staff. A Pulitzer Prize-winning correspondent, Stowe quit The New York Herald Tribune at the outbreak of war. They said he was "too old" (39) to cover war.

Rear Admiral Stanley V. Parker, district Coast Guard officer in charge of all activities of this branch of the service in the Third Naval District, issued a call yesterday for young women recruits for the Spars to meet an increased demand for enlisted members and officers at various posts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Following is the text of a broadcast tonight over the National Broadcasting Company network, being the second of a series outlining State Department policies and problems.
