WASHINGTON. Jan. 15 -- Secretary Hull gave out details tonight of a far-reaching reorganization of the Department of State designed "to facilitate the conduct of the foreign relations of the United States, in war and in peace." The sweeping changes in the department's administrative organization were made effective today by an order of the Secretary.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., reported yesterday a consolidated net profit for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31 of $8,238,483. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to $2.12 a share for the common stock, comparing with $8,554,512, or $2.20 a share, in the previous year.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- The movement for judicial reform, which grew out of the Aurelio case in New York City at the last election, is making such slow progress that the possibility is growing that no conclusive action may be taken by the current session of the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- There probably is no subject that arouses President Roosevelt's ire more rapidly than a direct question about the prospects of his running for a fourth term. But whether he like it or not, Mr. Roosevelt in recent weeks has become the focal point of a groundswell moving definitely in that direction.

The exigencies of war, and the continuation of strikes, finally wrung from Congress last year a corrective known as the Smith-Connally bill which Congress then repassed over the President's veto.

NAPLES, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The people on the island of Ponza, a sea-girt Shangri La off the coast of Italy, are sure now that there's a war going on.

The exigencies of war, and the continuation of strikes, finally wrung from Congress last year a corrective known as the Smith-Connally bill which Congress then repassed over the President's veto.

IN December the Brazilian Symphony Orchestra, which is conducted by Eugen Szenkar, closed the year's concert season. The orchestra gave a yearly total of seventy orchestral concerts, fifty-two broadcast, four of which were transmitted by short wave to the United States.

THE sports fans of New York have been singularly fortunate. They have had the opportunity to see, almost without exception, every great athlete this nation has produced. The parade has been constant and eye-filling with thrill piling upon thrill from the time that the mind of man runneth not to the contrary.

The Hadassah Choral, made up of the combined choral groups of Far Rockaway and New York chapters of Hadassah, gave a concert with an unusual program last night at Town Hall for the benefit of Youth Aliyah, which has saved 10,000 children from the Nazis in Europe, transferring them to Palestine and supporting them there.

INDICATIONS point to a big curtailment in the production of war pictures during 1944 and a corresponding increase in the filming of so-called escapist material. Of the forty-five feature films in production at the various major studios last week only seven were war subjects and, of these, only two treat specifically with the conflict.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 15 -- The Peruvian Government announced today that a number of conspirators, including Germans and Japanese, plotting a New Year's pro-Nazi coup, had been detained and would be deported, while others had been notified to leave the country. The Government charged that the conspirators had staged anti-Jewish outbreaks on the day before New Year's, planning to cloak their subversive activities in the subsequent disorder.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- There probably is no subject that arouses President Roosevelt's ire more rapidly than a direct question about the prospects of his running for a fourth term. But whether he like it or not, Mr. Roosevelt in recent weeks has become the focal point of a groundswell moving definitely in that direction.

A heavy influx of buyers made last week a very active period in the wholesale markets here, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. With the bulk of spring ordering already behind them, these buyers were chiefly concerned with rounding out their spring purchases and getting the first glimpses of the new summer lines.

Edwin L. James wrote in a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES: "It comes pretty near the truth to say that the people of the United States threw over the League of Nations. Despite what the Senate had done, if the people of the country had wanted the League they wouldn't have elected Harding President.

The world's best-seller, the King James version of the Holy Bible, has been prepared for distribution to the blind as the latest Talking Book to be issued by the American Foundation for the Blind, it was announced yesterday at that organization's headquarters, 15 West Sixteenth Street.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 16 -- Soviet troops hurled back powerful German counter-attacks on two sectors of the front south of Kiev and swept westward across the Pripet Marshes yesterday as Berlin reported that the Russians had opened a new offensive in the Leningrad and Lake Ilmen areas.
The Dodgers gained a ball club yesterday but almost immediately received word they might soon lose another ball player.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 15 - On the second anniversary of the Rio de Janeiro Conference newspapers voiced regret today that Argentina had broken continental unity and had donned the mantle of neutrality which, said Dairio Carioca columnist, Antonio Bento, jeopardized the security of the Americas.

A new indoor track season opened in New York last night with the Grover Cleveland Democratic Club games at the Seventh Regiment Armory and Bill Hulse of the New York Athletic Club stepped at once into the headline role he has apparently inherited as the miler of the year.

Trustworthy reports from Algiers are to the effect that the Americans and British are unpopular with the French there and getting more so. Sentiment in the French National Committee of Liberation and in the Consultative Assembly is increasingly unfriendly toward Washington and London. It is unfortunate that this is the case. It is not only unfortunate from the standpoint of winning the war; it is unfortunate from the viewpoint of post-war adjustments.

ABOARD THE AMERICAN MARINER, Jan. 14 (Delayed) -- Newspaper men obtained their first opportunity to observe at first-hand the training of young men for the merchant marine under actual wartime sea conditions, during a two and one-half day cruise from New York to Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- John W. McCormack, House Democratic leader, said tonight that only a "political miracle" would enable members of the armed forces serving overseas to take part in the November elections.

An intensified program to supplement the work of chaplains in the armed forces has been initiated jointly by officials of the National Council of the Young Men's Christian Association and the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, according to announcement yesterday.

Shorter term commitments gained favor among many retail merchants last week as the record number of buyers who were in the wholesale markets here failed to obtain conclusive answers on the supply outlook for most types of consumer goods.

A complete re-examination of the entire structure of the wartime trading arrangements of the United States in the Middle East, including lend-lease and so called "joint-area" agreements with Great Britain, may be expected as a result of a report to be presented to Government authorities here by James M. Landis, American Director of Economic Operations in that area.

Although the vagaries of chance, the military draft and the proposed national service act, should it become a law, might make some more substantial alterations in their ranks between now and next April, the Giants at the moment have twenty-seven baseball players on their list and all twenty-seven had contracts mailed to them yesterday for the 1944 baseball campaign.

Miss Sonja Henie and her Hollywood Ice Revue, a long-awaited event in the eyes of winter sports lovers, will open a fifteen-night run in Madison Square Garden on Tuesday. It will mark Miss Henie's seventh annual presentation of her revue in New York.
PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 15 -- An American bomber of the Seventh Army Air Force landed at a forward base in the central Pacific area yesterday morning flying a Japanese ensign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Applauding the food industry's contribution to victory, Marvin Jones, War Food Administrator, announced in a radio address today a widening of eligibility for the WFA's "A" award. He made the award open to all food-processing plants, except those qualifying for the Army and Navy "E," and open also to farm families for food production.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- The Mount Washington Hotel, one of the largest and most elaborate of the White Mountain hostelries, was sold to a Boston corporation today for a reported price of $500,000.

PETUNIAS, like marigolds and some other flowers, have become something of a problem in the last few years. There is such a long list of good varieties that it is hard to choose among them. Whatever may be the petunias grown by this writer, one variety is never omitted -- the large single one known as Flaming Velvet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- After two years of war, accompanied on the home front by continuous concern and impatience over "the manpower muddle," Congress is confronted, squarely and by Presidential direction, with a choice between adopting and rejecting national service.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: "Better late than never" applies to winter protection of evergreens. A windbreak or some shelter against prevailing winds is helpful. Heavy snow should be dislodged carefully from specimen shrubs or evergreen hedges.... Look at roots of Witloof Chicory (French Endive) which are being forced down cellar, They should be producing tender greens for salad soon.

Under the impetus of an enthusiastic welcome by 400 Congress of Industrial Organizations leaders at a luncheon session of the CIO Political Action Committee at the Park Central Hotel yesterday, Vice President Henry A. Wallace departed from his prepared text and made what was construed as an apology or "explanation" for President Roosevelt's labor draft proposal and other recent actions that have not been to the liking of the CIO.

Police Headquarters, Fire Headquarters, newspapers and the Navy all received telephone calls around 11 o'clock last night from persons inquiring about "the explosion offshore." None of the authorities -- and the Navy made an extensive check -- could learn of an accident.

Representatives of the cattle industry declared yesterday that the War Food Administration report last Thursday showing the number of feeder cattle moving to market had dropped 16 per cent from last year, had failed to tell the worst. The livestock industry's own survey indicates that the number of feeder cattle dropped from 25 to 30 per cent.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 15 -- Yugoslav Partisan forces, which for the past few days have been on the defensive in several areas in Bosnia, were reported in today's communique from headquarters of the People's Army of Liberation to have evacuated the towns of Bugojno and Gornji-Vakuf. In that manner, it is said, they managed to escape German encirclement.

ENOUGH improvement was reported from scattered areas last week to make it appear that trade may pull away from the minus side in sales comparisons for a few weeks at least. There is little or no chance, however, of staying on the plus side for very long because of the sharp gains that were made last year when the hoarding rush reached a peak.

PETUNIAS, like marigolds and some other flowers, have become something of a problem in the last few years. There is such a long list of good varieties that it is hard to choose among them. Whatever may be the petunias grown by this writer, one variety is never omitted -- the large single one known as Flaming Velvet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- After two years of war, accompanied on the home front by continuous concern and impatience over "the manpower muddle," Congress is confronted, squarely and by Presidential direction, with a choice between adopting and rejecting national service.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: "Better late than never" applies to winter protection of evergreens. A windbreak or some shelter against prevailing winds is helpful. Heavy snow should be dislodged carefully from specimen shrubs or evergreen hedges.... Look at roots of Witloof Chicory (French Endive) which are being forced down cellar, They should be producing tender greens for salad soon.

Under the impetus of an enthusiastic welcome by 400 Congress of Industrial Organizations leaders at a luncheon session of the CIO Political Action Committee at the Park Central Hotel yesterday, Vice President Henry A. Wallace departed from his prepared text and made what was construed as an apology or "explanation" for President Roosevelt's labor draft proposal and other recent actions that have not been to the liking of the CIO.

Police Headquarters, Fire Headquarters, newspapers and the Navy all received telephone calls around 11 o'clock last night from persons inquiring about "the explosion offshore." None of the authorities -- and the Navy made an extensive check -- could learn of an accident.

Representatives of the cattle industry declared yesterday that the War Food Administration report last Thursday showing the number of feeder cattle moving to market had dropped 16 per cent from last year, had failed to tell the worst. The livestock industry's own survey indicates that the number of feeder cattle dropped from 25 to 30 per cent.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 15 -- Yugoslav Partisan forces, which for the past few days have been on the defensive in several areas in Bosnia, were reported in today's communique from headquarters of the People's Army of Liberation to have evacuated the towns of Bugojno and Gornji-Vakuf. In that manner, it is said, they managed to escape German encirclement.
Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff have gone to Palm Beach for a visit with Princess Kaplanoff's daughter, Mrs. James Abercrombie de Peyster.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 16 -- The city of San Juan, capital of the Andes Mountain Province of the same name, suffered catastrophic damage in an earthquake that struck most sharply for a period of fifty seconds at 8:48 o'clock last night.

The Manufacturing Chemists Association of the United States, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, announced yesterday that the chemical industry was seeking additional workers and offered to the War Manpower Commission a plan to give to thousands of returning service men an opportunity to enter the industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association decreed today that Phil Terranova, featherweight king, and Sammy Angott, NBA lightweight champion, must defend their titles against "worthy contenders" within a month.

Dodd, Mead announces "The Man With the Lumpy Nose," by Lawrence Lariar, cartoon editor of Liberty magazine and editor of "Best Cartoons of the Year 1943," as winner of the eleventh Red Badge detective story prize. The book is a murder mystery with a cartoon background.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The wild, suicidal tactics of the Japanese are no match in the long run for the carefully thought-out, well-executed infantry-artillery teamwork practiced by the American forces in the South Pacific, the War Department declared today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 16 -- From Stara-Zagora, the new seat of the Bulgarian Government set up after its evacuation of Sofia, Minister of War Nikola Michoff today ordered all reserve officers of the army at present on leave or not yet called to the service to report to their mobilization centers by tomorrow noon, where they will receive further orders.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 16 -- Speaking in the name of President Pedro P. Ramirez Friday, upon inauguration of weekly press conferences, the secretary of the President, Col. Enrique P. Gonzales, stated that the Government solicited the collaboration of the press and invited it to criticize whatever Government measures it considered harmful.

The Joint Conference on Merit Rating, representing employer, labor and civic organizations, sent to both houses of the Legislature yesterday a letter condemning proposed bills designed to change the existing system of employer contributions to the State's unemployment isurance fund by substituting a range of rate variations for the present uniform 2.7 per cent tax on payrolls.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 16 -- There will be milk on the doorsteps of 18,000 homes here tomorrow morning. One hundred forty employes of the Castanea Dairy Company, subsidiary of the Borden Company, voted almost unanimously late tonight to end their walkout, which started Friday evening.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 16 -- Under New Zealand's three-pronged plan for national service the home front service chiefs are charged with the task of aligning the manpower available for compulsory service in the army, staffing the home front defense organizations and spreading the remaining labor over the industrial field so that high priority industry is assured that its needs will be filled.

The "shouting, singing confidence" of the early Christian Church is needed today, the Rev. Dr. J. Valdemar Moldenhawer declared in his sermon yesterday morning in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue, between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets.

Founded in 1561 by Juan Yufre, San Juan, in the Argentine Andes, was nearly destroyed once before by an earthquake in 1894. The city is in a great bend of the San Juan River, north of the major western province of Mendoza. The river provides easy irrigation and the surrounding country is covered with a network of irrigating canals for the agricultural foothills region for which San Juan is the center.

The part hobbies and handicrafts play in rehabilitation of returning service men will be demonstrated in a display by Halloran Hospital at the seventh annual American Hobby Show, which will open today at 10 A.M. in Hearn's Auditorium, Fourteenth Street and Fifth Avenue.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Eighteen enemy ships and boats attempting to maintain precarious German supply lines to their "iron ring" of Aegean Island defenses were left burning, damaged and enveloped in smoke from a series of low-flying RAF attacks in the past three days, a Middle East communique announced today.

Firing home five goals in a row in the third period, the Philadelphia Falcons erased a lead held by the New York Rovers and beat the local stick-wielders in an Eastern League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, 9 to 6. The battle, briskly waged from the start, had its highlight when only fifteen seconds of play remained.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Slaughtering of hogs in the West continues at the maximum capacity of packing plants and of the available manpower and it has been necessary in some instances to have farmers hold back supplies to reduce congestion.

It seems incredible, after our experience under the Eighteenth Amendment, that the Congress should be compelled to consider a new prohibition law. Yet a subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee is now holding hearings on the Bryson bill, which would bring back many of the ills of the "Noble Experiment."
Presidential messages run long nowadays, Vice-Presidential contributions to reading and reflection reach a record high, and the Supreme Court output of words is uncommonly large.

John Golden will turn over this afternoon at Governors Island to Maj. Gen. T. A. Terry of the Second Service Command a check for $96,500 to be applied to Army Emergency Relief. This represents the profits, it was announced by Mr. Golden, from the tour of "The Army Play by Play," five prize-winning one-acters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Combined Production and Resources Board today announced the formation of a textile committee. The new committee will carry on the work begun by the board's former subcommittee on textiles.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16 -- Burning up the course with a third successive sub-par round, Byron Nelson of Toledo, Ohio, increased his lead today with a 54-hole total of 205 in the $10,000 San Francisco Victory open golf tournament.

Alexander Brailowsky played the First Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto, B-flat minor, with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Artur Rodzinski conducting, yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. At the end he received an ovation, a spontaneous outbreak of applause and cheers rare in Carnegie Hall.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A Middle East air communique:

After making a valiant attempt to prolong its engagement, "Listen, Professor!" vacated the Forrest on Saturday night. The Peggy Phillips adaptation of Alexander Afinogenov's Russian comedy, starring Dudley Digges, managed to linger for twenty-nine performances under the auspices of Milton Baron, Jean Muir and Toni Ward.
LONDON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The purpose of the Churchill-de Gaulle meeting was to discuss the degree and form of cooperation of a French expeditionary force in the invasion of Europe and the degree of authority of the French Committee in the control of civil affairs inside France after the Allies had landed.

STATISTICS generally are cold, but often they are interesting. Professional football had a far higher average attendance last season than at any time in the past, but a new and different set of figures has come into the possession of this corner. They are illuminating, to say the least.

Mayor La Guardia has called for a revision of the system of meat, butter and cheese rationing. Chester Bowles agrees that the proposed separation "has several obvious and welcome advantages." But he points out two disadvantages: the need to distribute 132 million new ration books, and the increased paper work required of grocers.

It's time to revise the jokes about Washington's housing problem -- and write a new batch about New York's. The state of things with "white collar girls" in the nation's capital, subject of statistical researches and comic movies, is no longer unique -- not with New York in the picture.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- Slanting away from the others in three of the dinghy races today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, Jack Sutphen kept his boat Rum Dum up in four others and made the top score of 64 points. In second place was Skip Etchells in his Sno Fun, 12 points back.

i The tenth week of the Diamond[ Jubilee season of the Metropolitan[ Opera Association will be marked' by the first presentation of Dubussy's "Pllas et MdLisande" Wednesday night, Jan. 26. Bidu Sayao and Martial Singher will have the title roles for the first time, and Emil Cooper will make his debut as a conductor with the Metropolitan.

OTTAWA, Jan. 15 -- President Roosevelt's reference to Canada's experience of selective service as an example for guidance in drafting a national service law in the United States has gratified Canadians.

Consumption of silver in the arts and industries in the United States last year reached a new high of 125,000,000 ounces, an increase of 10,000,000 over the previous record of 115,000,000 used in 1942, Handy Harman, bullion dealers, report in their twenty-eighth annual review.
A special communique, as broadcast yesterday from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ALBANY, Jan.16 -- Employers in New York State are estimated to have paid $77,708,858 more in unemployment insurance taxes in a year than they would have paid under the average tax for the forty-one States which have adopted experience rating.

MADRID, Jan. 10 (Delayed) -- Heavy new increments of German agents have been pouring into Spain in recent days in an obvious effort by Germany to save what she can of a situation that has gone badly against her here.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Jan. 17 -- United States marines captured the vitally strategic Hill 660 on the Borgen Bay front of western New Britain Island Friday, overrunning strong Japanese defenses and advancing down the eastern slopes Saturday to break the anchor of the enemy's defense line, it was announced today.

The church and its members must adopt a global way of thinking and acting if they are to keep up with the new outlook of service men, who have come to realize that "civilization is more closely drawn together than ever before in history," the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Parish, declared yesterday in a sermon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A tall, white-haired Canadian officer, Maj. William Jones of Toronto, holds the record for length of service as liaison officer with Marshal Josip Broz (Tito), leader of the Yugoslav Partisans.

A Navy and Air Force larger than any in the world, a sizable Army, peacetime selective service and the merging of the War and Navy Departments into a single Department of War are among the post-war military measures advocated by majority military and naval opinion in Washington.

LONDON, Jan. 16 (Netherlands News Agency) -- Plans have been completed for tracking down German and Netherland Nazi looters of the Netherlands like other war criminals and taking their spoils from them, the Netherlands Finance Minister, Johannes van den Broek, warned in a broadcast this evening.

Reviewing a quarter century of "doing something for the welfare of mankind," the Commonwealth Fund, founded in 1918 by Mrs. Stephen V. Harkness, made public yesterday its annual report. The fund, concentrating on the betterment of health, both physical and mental, has now made grants in this field totaling $28,000,000 out of appropriations reaching $41,000,000 for all purposes in the twenty-five-year period.

Demands for all kinds of merchandise were strong last week as a result of the record influx of buyers in the market, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Bishop William T. Manning dedicated yesterday morning the Henry Mottet Memorial Chapel in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion, Sixth Avenue and Twentieth Street. The Rev. Dr. Henry Mottet was rector of the parish for fifty years, from 1879 to 1929.

Claiming the signatures of a majority of the Tammany executive committee to a petition requesting Representative James H. Fay to call a meeting, members of the committee announced yesterday their intention of calling on Michael J. Kennedy today to ask him to resign as leader.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Russian Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 16 -- Steelingot output last week advanced 2 1/2 points to 98 1/2 per cent of rated capacity. This rebound, it is believed, is due to an attempt on the part of those steel companies affected recently by furnace repairs, strikes, etc., to make up the loss.

Confronted with a mass of facts and figures about our national economy, markets for securities and commodities had alternating periods of strength and weakness last week. After reaching a new high since November on Tuesday, stocks declined in the next two days, then rallied at the week-end and erased practically all the previous losses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Service men and women take top billing on Capitol Hill this week with mustering-out pay and soldiers' vote legislation drawing special Congressional attention in this election year.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- With the return of 8,600,000 in currency from circulation to the Bank of England in the week ended on Jan. 10, there has been a total decline of 13,400,000 since the turn of the year. In the same period last year the circulation dropped 9,400,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration said today it was discontinuing the training of instructors by its war training service, as the Navy and Army air forces now had enough flight instructors without training more through civilian agencies.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 16 -- It is said in neutral military circles that the new secret weapon propagandized by the Germans for home consumption is "nearing completion" of its experimental stages east of Lake Constance, where firing has already been carried out from the region of Markdorf into the Austrian Vorarlberg.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- An upward revision of 2 cents in the ceiling price on wheat futures to the basis of $1.73 3/8 a bushel on the Board of Trade here failed last week to have much effect as a price-making influence, except for a brief period immediately after announcement of the change.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Difficult readjustments for the Catholic Church in the post-war period are forecast in a survey of papal foreign and political policy published today by the Foreign Policy Association.

Women fliers were at first used by the Russian High Command along supply routes only. When in the Finnish campaign of 1939-40 foreign correspondents reported rumors of finding female pilots in a few shot-down combat planes of the Soviets, the Moscow Pravda officially and categorically denied these stories. Girl fliers were employed in the supply service alone, and never in combat.

ALGIERS, Jan. 16 -- A meeting between Prime Minister Churchill and Gen. Charles de Gaulle, which the French Committee of National Liberation tends to interpret as marking a fresh start in Anglo-French relations, was held in Marrakesh, Morocco, last Wednesday, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (U.P.) -- Guarantee of the soldier vote, support of legislation outlawing strikes and removal of "dispensable" aliens from Federal agencies were proposed today in resolutions adopted at the closing session of the Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- The Ardsley Curling Club's No. 1 rink, skippered by the veteran W. Barton Eddison, captured the Archibald Douglas Medal by defeating Mahopac's No. 2 team, directed by John MacFarlane, 16 to 15, in the 17-end final at the indoor rink at the St. Andrew's Golf Club today.

Many people have thought of Christianity as utterly impractical idealism, but now these people are disturbed, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday morning in his sermon in the Riverside Church. He said that now they looked at a world that has rejected Christ and wondered whether what they were doing was practical.
The stage was set last night for the United States to start on its Fourth War Loan drive.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 16 -- After four days of discussion between Finance Minister Arthur de Souza Costa and a group of Brazilian industrialists whom he called in to study the treasury's excess profits tax proposals, Dr. de Souza Costa announced today that in agreement with the industrialists he will present the full tax measure to President Getulio D. Vargas on Tuesday for enactment.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Dick Werner, Paterson, N.J., and Joe Bree, New York City, are co-holders of the Eastern States speed skating championship in the senior men's division.

SOMEWHERE IN ITALY, Jan. 15 (Delayed) -- Reports of the free and fancy life being led by some people back home -- especially those suggesting a possible relaxation in morality -- are an increasing cause of anxiety to American soldiers and sailors overseas, Rabbi Barnett R. Brickner of Cleveland, Ohio, declared today.

LELAND STOWE is a dynamic, belligerent, eloquent crusader for the brotherhood of man. For seventeen years he has been a foreign correspondent and war correspondent, first for The New York Herald Tribune and then for The Chicago Daily News, whose able reporting of the facts could never disguise his own dedication to humanitarian ends as he saw them.

ALGIERS, Jan. 16 -- American infantrymen, charging up Mount Trocchio in a two-pronged assault powered by a shattering artillery barrage and met by sweeping return fire from the Germans, seized the vital ridge overlooking Cassino yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The German airplane-manufacturing city of Brunswick has "ceased to exist" after the RAF's 2,000-ton bombing on Friday night, a Stockholm dispatch declared today. Neutral reporters estimated that 12,000 persons had been killed and 50,000 had been bombed out.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 16 -- Paramount is planning to remake the Norman Krasna play, "Small Miracle," first filmed in 1935 under the title "Four Hours to Kill," with Richard Barthelmess in the lead. Alan Ladd will be starred in the new version under the direction of Mitchell Leisen.

An offering of $3,500,000 of fifteen-year 5 per cent debentures of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America due 1959, with stock purchase warrants attached, will be made today at par and accrued interest by a banking group headed by H.M. Byllesby Co., Inc., and Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. Proceeds of the financing, plus additional funds, will be added to general funds as additional working capital.

The Army Air Force is looking with eager eyes to the annual increment of young men as future pilot and aircrew material. In the 1,200,000 boys who will become 17 years of age this year the air arm sees its most desirable pool of future manpower. It finds that these young men as a class are physically hard as nails, mentally quick and willing to learn new things.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 16 -- Inauguration of a joint post-war plywood sales expansion program which calls for the establishment and operation of a plywood warehouse chain of fifteen units was announced today by the United States Plywood Corporation and the Mengel Company.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- Three United States fliers were among fifteen persons killed and eight American airmen among thirty passengers injured last night when a Northampton to London train smashed into the rear of a Yarmouth to London train as it waited to take on passengers at suburban Ilford station.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has arrived in London to assume command of the invasion of northwestern Europe, the greatest military enterprise ever commanded by an American, and the final phase of the preparation for invasion has begun.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 17 -- The Russian Government this morning rejected the Polish Government's offer to enter into negotiations on the Russian-Polish boundary dispute and refused to consider renewing diplomatic relations with Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk's Cabinet.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The United States' mightiest bomber, the B-29, now has the official name of "Superfortress."
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- A G.I. who is supposed to have asked after his first tour of London, "Why have they got so damned many swimming pools all over the place?" posed a natural, if mythical, question.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 15 (Delayed) -- The British capture of Maungdaw, on the Burmese coast, is the result of what is described in some quarters here as "leaning tactics."

It was just a year ago that a starving but heroic Leningrad was able to celebrate the end of a 515-day siege -- the longest any city of comparative size had ever endured in history. But the lifting of the siege, which brought food for its emaciated population and new supplies for its defenders, did not end all of its trials.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Governor Dewey, it was indicated today would clarify his position on increased taxing powers for localities, and a redistribution of the State-Local tax dollar this week.

MOSCOW, Jan. 16 -- Moscow newspapers prominently displayed today a suggestion made in the United States by Dr. A. Penzik, who is described as a leader of the American Friends of Poland, for the formation of a Polish Committee of National Liberation as a temporary Government for Poland, replacing the London group.

The Vanderburgh Apartments, a four-story walk-up for twenty-one families at the southwest corner of Chatsworth and Vanderburgh Avenues, in Larchmont, Westchester County, have been resold by David S. Meister, operator, after a brief ownership to an investor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Post-war expansion of food production even beyond the current peak was put forth by Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard today as a major peacetime goal for American farmers.

The A minor sonata of Serge Prokofieff was the most novel feature of the program that Abbey Simon presented last night in Carnegie Hall. The score is an interesting indication of the distance that this composer, one of the most important contemporaneous figures in Russian music, has traveled in a space of years.

When a museum meets children on their own level of activities and interests it becomes a popular place with them, says Louise Condit, supervisor of the Junior Museum of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which opened yesterday its latest and most ambitious exhibition, "India's Gods and Kings."

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 17 -- Gen. Ivan C. Bagramian's First Baltic Army veterans, renewing their offensive westward toward the Baltic States in the Nevel sector below Lake Ilmen, have hammered five miles into the German lines on a front nine miles long during a three-day offensive, Moscow announced last night. The new drive already has cut the railroad running north from Novosokolniki Junction to the Leningrad area, about seventy miles from the Latvian border.
SOMEWHERE IN THE PACIFIC (Delayed) -- Here is a story that was making the rounds after the battle of Tarawa.

Discarded newspapers and other waste paper collected in the city subways last year yielded the municipality $8,559 from sale to scrap dealers and aided the salvage drive to the extent of 800 tons, it was reported yesterday by the Board of Transportation.
The recent concentrated American bombing attacks on the great naval base of Kiel in northern Germany were notable for a minor Nazi surprise in the way of new weapons.

Cotton prices were easier last week, although for the most part they held within a narrow trading range. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts closed on Saturday with net losses for the week of 4 to 17 points. In the preceding week the market had recorded net gains of 1 to 28 points.

OPA recently estimated that subsidies costing $925,000,000 were saving consumers and the Government $2,373,000,000. The total net savings thus estimated came to $1,450,000,000, of which almost $1,200,000,000 was accounted for by two programs: Petroleum ($290,000,000), and copper, lead and zinc ($902,000,000).

License Commissioner Paul Moss denied the renewal applications of six New York ticket agencies after hearings held at his office, 112 White Street, it was announced yesterday. Four of the applications were denied because of complaints of overcharging, one for failing to comply with restrictions and the sixth because the broker had no place of business.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The league-leading Canadiens and the Black Hawks battled to a 1-1 tie tonight in Chicago Stadium before a record crowd of 18,150 in a National Hockey League game.

LONDON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) declared today his Partisan army had brought German drives to a halt and had seized the initiative in several sectors of Bosnia. Nazi sources said the Yugoslavs were trying to hold open an Allied "invasion corridor" from the Adriatic.

Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, commander of the Fifth Army, has congratulated the French Expeditionary Corps for its successes in Italy, the Algiers radio said yesterday, the Federal Communications Commission reported.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- Breaking with precedent, the Philadelphia Orchestra has engaged for the next three seasons William Kapell, 21-year-old pianist, who has created a flurry in musical circles as one of the "finds" of the year, Harl McDonald, manager, announced today.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Jan. 16 -- Japan is not only deeply worried but shocked by the German disasters in Europe and by the possibility of an early Nazi collapse, it is increasingly apparent out here.

Abraham Straus announced yesterday that a special meeting of stockholders had been called for Jan. 25 to consider a proposed retirement plan for employes. It provides for retirement at age 65 and covers all employes who have completed five years of service and are between the ages of 35 and 65, inclusive.

The Colonial Publishing Company bought from the Third Presbyterian Congregation in Newark the group of three, four and five story buildings at 875-87 Broad Street, southwest corner of William Street, including 10-14 William Street and 12-14 Chapel Court, in Newark, N.J.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- A communique:

The execution of Count Galeazzo Ciano as a traitor to fascism, or more accurately as a traitor to the Nazis, for the Fascists who tried him were mere marionettes in a German puppet show, attracted little attention because the macabre tragedy of Italy is marked by so many dizzy turns and grotesque incidents that it has lost reality.

More than one of every four children in the United States 14 through 17 years old is at work, according to the latest figures of the Children's Bureau. The percentage is close to one in three, and the numbers are increasing.

Adopting a novel procedure in corporate reporting, John A. Brown, president of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., has sent to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and other officials a report covering the activities of his company in 1943 in New York State.

The fellow who invented the broad-beamed, flat-bottomed snow shovel probably thought he was a very clever friend of mankind. He may even have considered himself a public benefactor. But after due deliberation in the midst of a soggy snowfall we can state quite firmly that he was neither friend nor benefactor, but merely an ingenious man who sat down one July day to invent something -- anything.
Three new films will arrive on Broadway this week. These are:

Mayor La Guardia said in his regular Sunday broadcast from City Hall yesterday that he planned to hold a "love-feast" soon in Chicago with Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration. At that time he hopes to persuade Mr. Bowles to put through some of the regulations the Mayor has sought to end difficulties in the sale of fish, poultry and oranges.

F. Warren Oakes Jr, president of Fleischman Distilling Corp, in 40 W 55th St; Luis Jatoba, in 319 E 50th St; J.L. Taliman, in 340 E 57th St; Kipp Solwedel, in 320 E 57th St; Doris Lewis Hirsch, through Douglas L. Elliman Co, in 17 E 89th St -- Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.

Beginning tomorrow, patrons of Manhattan's 2,600 bars and taverns, when ordering a drink can expect to be greeted with: "What will you have with it, soda, ginger ale or a war bond?" all because 7,500 bartenders have set themselves up as bond salesmen in the Fourth War Loan drive, hoping to dispose of $2,500,000 of bonds.

Mary Pickford delighted fourteen children, ranging from 1 to 12 years in age, in the infantile paralysis ward of the Hospital for Special Surgery, at 341 East Forty-second Street, when she visited the ward yesterday to hand out lollypops and promises of toys.

The United States Rubber Company will launch a new national advertising campaign in newspapers, national magazines and farm papers beginning next week on the theme "Saving Through Science." Copy will emphasize the preservation and protection of human life made possible by scientific developments.

Declaring that the making of the peace has already begun with the Moscow pact and the Cairo conference, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street, said in his sermon there yesterday morning that the people "must be preparing our peace attitudes while the war goes on."

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The stock markets here continue to display a pronounced lack of initiative. Current developments in the war situation are favorable enough but investors throughout the country appear to be unable to shake off the attitude of caution engendered by the knowledge that every day brings us nearer the grand assault on Europe with all that implies regarding the hopes and fears concerning this final phase of the war.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The fate of five American missionaries missing for two months in the Bolivian jungles remained a mystery today, although a Franciscan father had received information last night that, he said, indicated that they had been killed by savages.

In this era of high-speed, high-scoring basketball, when it is not altogether uncommon for a team to ring up 100 or more points in a game -- Rhode Island State has done it time and again -- the outcome of one particular encounter in Saturday's crowded schedule must have been a shock to court fans the country over.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 16 -- Copies of the Nouvelliste, a Lyon newspaper, bearing last Thursday's date, are passing from hand to hand throughout France and are being read avidly. The reason is that they are fakes -- wherefore they contain real news.

An investor has purchased from the New York Life Insurance Company the fifteen-story apartment house at 473 West End Avenue, southwest corner of Eighty-third Street, through the Globus Realty Corporation, broker. There are forty-five apartments in the building, which is on a plot 78 by 100 feet and is assessed at $620,000.

Frankie Frisch, manager of the Pirates, is back in town with glowing reports of a six-week tour of Alaska and the Aleutians where Dixie Walker of Brooklyn, Hank Browdy of the Yankees, Danny Litwhiler and Stan Musial of the Cardinals joined him in a series of walkie-talkie fanning bees with service men under auspices of the USO camp shows.

The National Refugee Service here has been praised by President Roosevelt for its refugee adjustment plan and its accomplishments during the last five years in a letter to William Rosenwald, retiring president of the organization. The letter, read yesterday at the group's meeting in the Hotel Commodore, was as follows:

WELLSBORO, Pa. Jan. 16 -- Women are taking over heavy farm chores in this section to permit their menfolk to work in essential war industries, a report by Arthur H. Dunn, chairman of the local board of the Office of Price Administration, showed here today.

When the Rangers yielded five goals to the Boston Bruins in the first period of their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night while scoring only two themselves, it seemed evident to everyone of the 15,201 fans on hand that the Blue Shirts were on their way to their eighth straight defeat.
It would seem that the civilian population is already becoming indifferent to the souls that accompany the mutilated bodies of this war's veterans.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 16 -- With many of its native sons doing their skiing for Uncle Sam's "fighting mountaineers," Manchester is now devoting its attention whole-heatedly to getting the youngsters of this Green Mountain community on the wooden runners at a tender age.

Lotte Lehmann gave the first of a series of three song recitals yesterday afternoon in Town Hall before a capacity audience, with the overflow seated on the stage. The soprano devoted her program to offerings by Schubert, including some of the composer's most exacting and searching Lieder, such as "Erlkoenig," "Der Doppelgaenger," "Die junge Nonne" and "Die Stadt."

There seems to be no question that the thirty-five-mile-an-hour maximum speed limit for passenger cars recommended in the Baruch report more than a year ago has resulted in great savings of rubber and gasoline, but when it comes to the question of speed for trucks and buses there are a number of clear indications that the thirty-five-mile limit is not necessarily the most economical over-all rate.

Real estate exempt from city taxes for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1944, is valued at $5,513,701,424, or more than 25 per cent of the total real estate valuation of $21,524,925,480, according to William Wirt Mills, president of the Tax Commission, whose report to Mayor La Guardia was made public yesterday.

According to "The Treaty-Making Power" editorial in THE TIMES of Dec. 31, the present constitutional provision is in your opinion illogical, undemocratic and all but ruinous to the continuity of foreign policy.

Mushroom soup in canned form has been said to be one of the most popular products of the sort on grocers' shelves. So it is logical to assume that there may be a good deal of interest in a new version of this food that may be obtained without ration points.

The letter of Florence L.C. Kitchelt, vice chairman, Connecticut Committee for the Equal Rights Amendment, in THE TIMES, Jan. 11, tells us that in South Carolina the husband owns his wife's clothes. This law of South Carolina is but one of the many existing ancient laws placed on our books by the early American Colonists.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- No hope for speedy alleviation of the critical shortage of anthracite in most Eastern cities will be held out by the chief executives of seven of the principal hard-coal centers when they come to Philadelphia Thursday for a conference with Mayor Bernard Samuel.

DETROIT, Jan. 16 (AP) -- For the second successive night the rebuilt Red Wings rallied in the third period to defeat the Maple Leafs tonight, scoring three goals to win by 4 to 1 in a National Hockey League game before 13,859, the season's largest crowd at Olympia Stadium.

HAMTLTON, Belnuda, Jan. 16-The Unite0. States increased its lead as the chief exporter to Bermuda i$ t3 when imports set a recordf u2,52,$37, with America supplying u1,790,033 of this amount -- an all-time high for any one country.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices prepared by the Index Number Institute was 112.43, a rise of 0.09 per cent from the previous week's level of 112.32. The farm products and the raw materials indexes increased 0.4 per cent and 0.3 per cent, respectively, as a result of increases in the price of cotton, oranges, grains and some livestock.

Robert Willman, winning his adjourned ninth-round game with Harold M. Phillips in the tournament for the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday, tied Arnold S. Denker for first place, both having scores of 8 -- 1. Willman won a well-played ending after 62 moves.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Jan. 16 -- Comdr. George H. Tilghman, USNR, former headmaster of the Morristown (N.J.) School, has died at his station in the Pacific, where he was in command of a carrier aircraft service unit, according to word received by his family of 282 Sea View Avenue here.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Almost one-third of the most densely built-up areas of Leipzig, one of Germany's most important industrial and railway centers, was reduced to rubble by the 1,500-ton Royal Air Force attack on the city last Dec. 3, the Air Ministry announced tonight.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The Germans are beginning to "crack down" on women who refuse to comply with industrial mobilization orders.

Prayers for the restoration of "man's unity with God" and the consequent unity of man with man were asked yesterday by Mgr. Walter P. Kellenberg, vice chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided in the sanctuary.
Jack C. Gordon has been appointed sales supervisor of the western division of the Pal Blade Company.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Guerrillas are operating in Malaya, led by British officers who survived the fall of Singapore, the Rev. Marcus Cheng, Chinese Christian who escaped from Singapore last year, said today.

Add to the list of films opening this week, "Higher and Higher," the Frank Sinatra musical produced by RKO and co-starring Michele Morgan and Jack Haley, which will arrive on Friday at the Palace. Based on the Broadway success of the same name, the film also features the dancing Hartmans, Leon Errol, Dooley Wilson and Barbara Hale.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Because of the increased number of schools serving lunches and the greater percentage of children who are eating at school cafeterias, due in large measure to their mothers being on war jobs, the Office of Price Administration today announced a new plan for making available rationed foods to schools.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -The Supreme Court held constitutional today New York legislation enacted April 13, 1940, modifying retroactively personal property laws relating to mortgage salvage operations.

The Fourth War Loan drive will get off to a good start in this city today with a parade, following on yesterday's Times Square curtain raiser. Parades, public meetings and shows are good for this cause and good for those of us who can witness them. They make us feel our unity in the common objective.

A new issue of $2,500,000 of aviation bonds, Series A, was announced yesterday by New Orleans, La., for award on Feb. 2. The issue will be dated Feb. 1, and will mature serially from Aug. 1, 1945 to 1968, and will be callable, in inverse number, beginning Feb. 1, 1954, and on any interest payment date thereafter, at a price of 102.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- The hog market jam throughout the country today was the worst the industry has ever experienced. It was estimated farmers attempted to dispose of about 700,000 hogs at all markets and packing centers in the country and found an outlet for about 400,000, which is about the daily slaughter capacity.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE IN ENGLAND, Jan. 17 -- Sgt. James R. Hamilton of Joycetown, Ky., tail gunner of a Flying Fortress, shot down possibly ten German planes in the attack on Oschersleben Jan. 11 and probably set a record.

Resumption of business in the live poultry market, extension of Mayor La Guardia's butterless lunch plan, and the resignation of three more Office of Price Administration executives here were among the developments along the food front yesterday.

Government-to-government dealings probably will constitute the bulk of American foreign trade for the duration and, in the post-war period "it will probably be necessary for government to be of assistance to private industry and private banking," Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, declared yesterday in one of his first public statements of policy.

Reflecting trade uncertainty over legislative developments at home and the favorable tenor of the war news abroad, prices in the cotton futures market yesterday fluctuated nervously within a twelve-point range and in the vicinity of previous closing levels.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Lieut. Gen. Omar Nelson Bradley, "the doughboys' general," under whose leadership the American Second Corps stormed Hill 609 and smashed through Mateur into Bizerte in Tunisia and fought with great distinction in Sicily, will command the United States Army divisions now gathering in Britain for an invasion of Europe, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Roosevelt remained in his rooms on advice of his physician; his visitors included George S. Messersmith, Ambassador to Mexico; a group of Southern Governors and President Alfonso Lopez of Colombia, his luncheon guest.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 17 -China's need for X-ray plates and many other vital medical materials is now being met by regular shipments of American Red Cross goods from India, according to John D. Nichols, director in China.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- On behalf of a coalition of seven members, Representative John E. Rankin of Mississippi today filed a negative majority report for the House Elections Committee on the Worley-Lucas bill providing for a soldier vote, at the same time requesting a rule from the Rules Committee under which the amended measure might be brought to the floor for debate.

Specially packaged telephonei and telegraph equipment, which permits several messages to be sent simultaneously over one pair of wires, is being supplied by the Bell System to the Army Signal Corps for shipment overseas, it was disclosed yesterday.

Sports writers these days have a frustrated feeling of covering a lesser game, so they owe a vote of thanks today to Sgt. Charley McKenna of Charleroi, Pa., a Marine Corps combat correspondent on Bougainville who thinks the lesser game vitally important.
Col. Matt J. Winn, one of the most colorful figures of American racing, will return to the turf in New York as president of the Empire City Racing Association.

In a small town in the Middle West there lives a chubby little boy of nine months. Because there is a great sickness in the world he never will know his father. He was born six months after his dad, a naval officer, went down with his ship off Savo Island in the Solomons one bitter, black night a year ago last November.

While the statement of principles accompanying the Baruch-Hancock termination clause departs from traditional governmental procedure in that it designates advertising as an allowable cost in fixed-price supply contracts, observers pointed out yesterday that the statement also places limitations on such expenditures.
LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 18 (UP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

POPLAR BLUFF, Mo., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Louis J. Cooper took the Negro couple he had hired to help work his farm out of Butler County tonight and the racial trouble in Ash Hill Township appeared to be over for the present.
The great art collection formed by Jules S. Bache, New York banker, will go eventually to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Some 12,000 members of New York City's financial community have set as their objective a minimum of one million individual subscriptions in the Fourth War Loan Drive. This amounts to an average of 83 subscriptions a person in the Banking and Investment Division.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- A national association of clubs supporting Gen. Douglas MacArthur for President was formed here today to set up clubs in every State. The plan was adopted at a meeting of representatives of MacArthur Clubs from Illinois, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Indiana and Ohio.

MARTHA GELLHORN, who is Mrs. Ernest Hemingway, has written a novel, "Liana,"* which might be called a feminine version of "For Whom the Bell Tolls." It is not a story of fighting, for the entire action takes place on a blockaded Vichy French Caribbean island, but it is about a young man who cannot make a separate peace for himself in a world that is almost universally at war.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Hedging pressure and scattered liquidation caused a decline of about 1 cent a bushel in wheat futures in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, prices dipping to a new low in about two weeks before short covering and buying on resting orders checked the break.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 18 (U.P.) -- British newspapers denounced today as "a lie," "an insult" and "mischievous" a Russian allegation that Britain had engaged in separate peace talks with Germany -- an allegation which, diplomatic quarters suggested, may reflect Russian suspicion that the Germans would prefer to throw open their territory to the Western Allies rather than see the Red Army overrun it.

"Much is heard about post-war planning, but perhaps the most important single factors in the post-war world are the children of today," declared Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, chairman of the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, in issuing a call for volun teer child care assistants.

MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- The Communist party organ Pravda published today a sensational rumor that "two leading British personalities" had been discussing with Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Foreign Minister, for a separate peace with Germany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- Donald Nelson in his address tonight said that the nation's productive achievements have staggered the imagination of the world and that he deeply believes that the nited States, after winning victory, will go steadily forward with a democratic spirit ever stronger "to amaze the world by our achievements in peace."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 17 -- All Copenhagen police, including high officials have been interned and police headquarters and stations have been occupied by German troops and police, it was learned here this afternoon.

The Downtown Rationing Board's quarters at 107 Walker Street, midway between Police Headquarters and the District Attorney's office, was entered twice by burglars over the week-end. On the second try the thieves' loot included 1,250,300 gallons' worth of fuel oil coupons, 200,000 gallons' worth of gasoline ration coupons and 700 food ration books, according to Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, who announced the theft.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- An appeal to the refrigeration industry to speed the day when quick-freezing can take the place of canning for farm women was made at a General Motors Club luncheon today by Dr. Louise Stanley, assistant to the administrator of the Agricultural Research Administration.

William C. Planz, president Textile Export Association of the United States, declared yesterday that the Foreign Economic Administration "has made an excellent start in the right direction" in announcing that allocations of cotton yarn and fabrics for certain Middle Eastern countries will be handled in the future through commercial firms if this method is acceptable to the importing country.

Local track fans are in for a treat Saturday when the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior indoor championships will be held at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn, for when the track and field championship committee met in the A.A.U. offices in the Woolworth Building yesterday to pass on the entries they could scarcely believe their eyes.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Continued disappearance of grain reserves "will dissipate our surplus of wheat to a point far below a safe reserve, particularly with the volume of wheat being fed to livestock," Philip R. O'Brien, president of the Board of Trade, warned today in his annual report.

A special panel of 200 talesmen was drawn yesterday by Commissioner of Jurors James McGurrin, from which the jury is to be chosen when Wayne Lonergan goes on trial in General Sessions on Jan. 31 for first-degree murder in the death of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan. Judge John J. Freschi is to preside at the trial.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Senate spent most of its day on an amendment to lift the Federal tax on oleomargarine, but only after the Finance Committee had agreed at a morning session to amend the tax measure further by terminating the war contracts renegotiation act on Dec. 31, 1944.

A three-point program to afford returning soldiers an opportunity to re-enter industry was offered to the War Manpower Commission yesterday by Harry L. Derby, president of the Manufacturing Chemists Association of the United States and head of the American Cyanamid and Chemical Corporation.

Alexander Uninsky, Russian pianist who made his first appearance in this country last February in Carnegie Hall, played there again last night before a large audience. He gave a big program in a big way, his style tending to the heroic, with extraordinary power and with brilliant bravura.

Fresh fruit and vegetables will be sold by the pound beginning early in February, Milton Rich, regional chief of the food-price section of the Office of Price Administration, revealed yesterday. This resolved a debate that had raged in a series of letters between Mayor La Guardia, who favored an immediate change, and Chester Bowles, OPA chief, who had delayed naming the day.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Practical approaches toward resumption of normal trade after the war ends were the main topics of conversation aside from actual placing of orders as furniture manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers converged on Chicago today for the opening of a two-week market event.

Speculative efforts managed yesterday to hold some of the specialties which recently have been favored on the higher side, but the stock market generally turned moderately easier as demand contracted. A handicap to any furtherance of investment buying was the inauguration today of the Fourth War Loan campaign.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- The British Government remained hopeful tonight that a little quiet inquiry and private diplomacy might yet resolve the Russian-Polish boundary dispute. But this is not the unanimous opinion of diplomats in London.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 17 -- An estimated 70,000 to 80,000 persons were rendered homeless by earthquake in the Andes Mountain Province of San Juan, which almost totally destroyed the provincial capital of the same name over Saturday night, according to word received here today.

Mrs. Strakacz and her husband, who is Polish Consul General at New York, are among the many Polish-American leaders aiding plans for the Polka Military Ball, eleventh annual benefit entertainment sponsored by the Kosciuszko Foundation, which will take place Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The American Power and Light Company, which in February, 1943, received authorization from the Securities and Exchange Commission to spend up to $10,000,000 for the acquisition in the open market of its debenture issues, has spent to date $6,814,000 to retire $6,618,000 face amount of its 6 per cent obligations.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- The stock markets here today were quiet but firm in tone at the opening of the week's business.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Bombs from Navy Catalina patrol planes sank a 10,000-ton Japanese vessel and set afire two other merchantmen of a six-ship enemy convoy caught off the Japanese base at Kavieng, New Ireland, Sunday night, Allied headquarters announced today.

The Grand Central Terminal of the New York Central Railroad System and the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad had the busiest year in its history during 1943, when passenger traffic in and out totaled 59,929,493, it was reported yesterday by J.H. Hustis Jr., terminal manager.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The State appeared tonight to have won its fight to obtain possession of Louis Buchalter, otherwise known as Lepke. After months of controversy, the Federal Government made an offer today to surrender Lepke and the offer was accepted tonight by Nathaniel L. Goldstein, State Attorney General.

There has been increasing discussion of the advisability of national military training for youths. The idea of training for physical fitness has many merits as well as disadvantages. However, I feel that we have overlooked the type of training which would be more important to world peace and without which no peace can long exist.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 17 -- Columbia has closed a deal with George Abbott and F. Hugh Herbert to film "Kiss and Tell," under which Abbott will be executive producer and Sol Siegel, representing the film company, associate producer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Government-operated coal mines need not be returned to private owners, despite their production records, since to do so probably would cause a recurrence of labor disturbances, Attorney General Biddle has informed Secretary Ickes.

The apartment houses known as Bayonne Gardens at 19-43 East Eleventh Street and 22-52 East Twelfth Street, Bayonne, N.J., have been sold by the Bayonne Garden Apartments to Bernard Reswick and John Avrutis.
ADVANOED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Jan. 18 (UP) -- A communique:

Omar Nelson Bradley was the hard-hitting commander of our Second Corps to whom the General of a broken German Army surrendered at Bizerte. Now he has been named senior commander of American ground forces in the United Kingdom.

Very important reasons exist why New York can remain the "supreme market" for women's lower price apparel as well as the more selective types of garments, although some expansion of the dress markets in Chicago, St. Louis and Dallas may be expected, Saul Cohn, president of the City Stores Company, said last night at the meeting of the Women's Wear Salesmen of New York, Inc., in the Hotel New Yorker.

The hairnet has returned to feminine favor. Manufacturers of the fragile mesh report that demand for their product is greater today than it has been since the heyday of the Gibson Girl -- and retail stores, stringently rationed by the wholesalers, are unable to keep supplies in stock for more than a few days after they are delivered.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 17 -- With his three-year term ending at midnight and Governor-Elect Walter E. Edge prepared to take over the Executive office at noon tomorrow, Gov. Charles Edison called upon the Legislature today to impeach Louis A. Reilly, former State Banking Commissioner.

ALGIERS, Jan. 17 -- Gen. Sir Henry Maitland Wilson in his first press conference as Mediterranean Commander in Chief, defined his "front" today as the entire stretch from the Pyrenees on France's Spanish border to the Maritza River, which is part of the boundary between Bulgaria and Turkey.

Michael J. Kennedy arranged yesterday for a showdown with Tammany district leaders who are seeking to depose him as leader of Tammany Hall and who have been maintaining for several days that they represent a majority vote in the executive commtitee of the organization.

AN EAST COAST PORT, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- Pfc. Hoshinoa Omiya of Honolulu, a Japanese-American who fought bravely until both eyes were blown out by a land mine, was among battle wounded of the Tunisian, Sicilian and Italian campaigns who have been flown from this port to the Memphis General Hospital by the troop-carrier command of the Army Air Forces.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 17 (AP) -- The final two of sixteen counts in the action of the Securities and Exchange Commission against Investors Syndicate and two affiliated firms, Investors Syndicate of America, Inc., and Investors Mutual, Inc., were dismissed in Federal Court here today by Judge Gunnar H. Nordbye.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- Representative Wright Patman of Texas asserted today that while the Treasury was selling new chinaware to junk and salvage companies in December for 8 cents per piece the Navy Department was awarding a contract to a pottery maker for 110,000 pieces of the same item at 18 cents each.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Jan. 18 -- Gen. Nikolai F. Vatutin's powerful forces have pushed farther westward into Rovno Province and last night were officially reported fifteen miles northeast of Rovno.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Pravda report that two prominent Britons had recently conferred secretly with Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Foreign Minister, on a possible separate peace struck with the force of a bombshell here today.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, joined last night with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Admiral Chester C. Nimitz in sounding the keynote for the Fourth War Loan drive, which opens today. Mr. Morgenthau and the military and naval leaders spoke during an hour's broadcast over the four major networks.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, declared yesterday that the Army's plan to take over the assignment of students to medical schools was "potentially dangerous to public health." He spoke at the opening symposium on "Medical Education in Relation to the Practice of Medicine in the Future" at the university's College of Medicine.

Two hundred persons prominent in the law and politics crowded the court room in Part Eight, County Court House, yesterday to witness the induction of Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler, unsuccessful candidate against Thomas A. Aurelio in the last election, but subsequently appointed to the bench by Governor Dewey.

ALGIERS, Jan. 17 -- The American conquerors of the Trocchio Ridge have pressed down the western slope, crossed the main rail line to Rome and thrust their forward elements as far as the banks of the Rapido River at a point barely two miles below Cassino, it was officially announced today.

Plans for the Sports War Bond Committee's all-star basketball double-header to be played at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory on Jan. 26 as part of the committee's efforts in the Fourth War Loan Drive were completed at a luncheon at Toots Shor's yesterday when the metropolitan basketball writers announced the New York vs. Brooklyn All-Stars teams.
The excellent letter from Florence L.C. Kitchelt, vice chairman of the Connecticut Committee for the Equal Rights Amendment, in THE TIMES of Jan. 11, is most valuable and interesting.

In a hungry time, 100 years ago this winter, twenty-seven English weavers met to consider how to make their meager wages buy more food. A food store of their own, one that would buy at wholesale and sell at barely enough profit to cover expenses, seemed a good idea. For a year they went a little hungrier and saved their pennies, and those pennies became the capital for the Rochdale Cooperative Store.

Miss Sonja Henie arrived here yesterday with her Hollywood Ice Revue which makes its premiere in Madison Square Garden tonight. It marks her seventh annual appearance with the revue which will be in the Garden for fifteen nights, running nightly through Jan. 27 and resuming Jan. 31 through Feb. 4.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- There can be no return to volume production of less essential goods until the war picture is a great deal clearer, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, said today after a conference with a group of leading industrialists.

Five matches were played and four defaults were chalked up last night in the "Bulldog" handicap tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association at the Yale Club, which is a Red Cross benefit. Three of the matches were in the third round, and two of them went to three games.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor unanimously pledged itself today to support President Roosevelt's subsidy program.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set hearing dates on pending transactions involving the Florida Power Corporation, the Federal Water and Gas Corporation and the Southwestern Public Service Company.
MADRID, Jan. 11 (Delayed) -While Spain has turned a half circle in the direction of the United Nations, Portugal has turned threequarters of the way.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (Delayed) -- Norman Hartnell, dressmaker to Her Majesty the Queen, has become in this war "dressmaker to the average British woman."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- On the ground that the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad had not done everything legally to adjust a dispute with its employes, the Supreme Court today unanimously upset an injunction issued in January, 1942, to prevent the workers from striking.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17 -- Jockeys Harry Pratt and Conn McCreary divided the victories and the features between them today at Hialeah Park, the former getting three winners and McCreary two, the various features being included in the sweep.

The Booksellers' League will hold its first dinner of the yar at the Hotel Brevoort tomorrow at 6:30 P.M. Speakers will include Dan. I. Auster, Special United States Attorney; Norman Cousins, editor of The Saturday Review of Literature, and Alvin F. Harlow, author of "Old Bowery Days" and other books.
ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The State's surplus of $140,000,000 was put safely under lock and key tonight.

The soldier vote is the sort of ghost that will not down. The issue is still very much alive a month and a half after the Senate dropped the Green-Lucas bill, which would have provided Federal supervision of the balloting, and adopted a substitute measure handing all the responsibility back to the States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Standing on a forty-year precedent, the Supreme Court today refused to consider within Federal court jurisdiction the case of Joseph E. Snowden, a Negro, of Chicago, who sued Illinois election officials for failure to certify him as a Republican primary nominee for the State Legislature.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 18 -- The British Foreign Office issued a formal and complete denial of Pravda's story that Joachim von Ribbentrop, Nazi Foreign Minister, met leading British figures in the Pyrenees to discuss a separate peace.

DETROIT, Jan. 17 -- Nearly 1,000 Chrysler Corporation foremen in four Detroit plants were on strike today and officials of the Foremen's Association of America (independent) were threatening to extend the walkout unless the union is given recognition and grievances are redressed.
ALGIERS, Jan. 17 -- Sentence has been passed on twelve men and one woman recently arrested in Trapani, Sicily, for plotting a revival of fascism there.

Churches in England and Scotland are taking deep interest in the negotiations for union among Episcopalians and Presbyterians here, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary and Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, said last night at a testimonial dinner in the Hotel Roosevelt.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- Allied troops have occupied two more villages north of Akyab in western Burma and are continuing to drive on the Japanese supply port, the Southeast Asia Command announced today.

A FIFTEENTH AIR FORCE BASE, in Italy, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Lightnings were zooming all over the sky above Klagenfurt, Austria, yesterday in a vicious battle with more than ten Messerschmitts when a thin voice came over their radios:
Mrs. John H.P. Gould and the Misses Jenifer and Barbara Gould have arrived from Lenox, Mass., and are at the Madison.

Two of the country's "top-ranking Army wives" teamed up yesterday in a local preview of the Fourth War Loan drive and walked off with the hearts of New Yorkers. Making her debut for the Treasury Department was the soft-spoken Mrs. George C. Marshall, wife of the Chief of Staff.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 -- Gen. Henry H. Arnold, commander of the Army Air Forces, assailed tonight "a penny-ante attitude" on the part of some critics, who, in computing American losses in recent air battles over Germany, failed to recognize that the missions were completely successful in helping to bomb the heart of the Axis and bring about its "dying convulsions."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 12, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 17 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

With high anticipation of something new and at least provocative if not pleasing, this reporter attended the concert of contemporary American and English music sponsored by the publishers Boosey and Hawkes and given last night in Town Hall under the artistic direction of Daniel Saidenberg.

After conferences at City Hall that lasted virtually all day, Mayor La Guardia announced late yesterday afternoon that measures were being taken that should result in a step-up of coal deliveries here, but he warned that noticeable improvement could not be expected "earlier than Thursday." A check will be made Saturday to determine results.

Though devotees of hitter orange marmalade may be unable to purchase the product that formerly was imported from England, they may, for a short time at least, buy the fruit and make the preserves themselves. A shipment of oranges with the necessary acrid flavor arrived recently from Florida, and they are to be found at the shop of John R. Buchanan, Grand Central Terminal (near the entrance to the shuttle train).
