WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -Operators of "for hire" commercial vehicles seeking Office of Defense Transportation authority either to institute a new service or to extend present operations must first get approval of the interested regulatory bodies, ODT ruled today.

Delegates representing 80,000 members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers in New York City voted unanimously yesterday to support the candidates backed by the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in the approaching primary of the American Labor party.

LONDON, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- Reports from Yugoslavia indicate that two strong German forces, one pressing southward through central Bosnia and the other thrusting inland from Dalmatian ports, are closing the gap to split the Partisan forces of Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] before the Allies invade the Balkans.

Relations among people of different races and religions are likely to be good when no one is sufficiently conscious of them to ask whether they are good or not. This seems to be the case with the Actors Equity Association. Someone wanted to know recently who was the first Negro member of the association. As the organization states in an editorial in its own magazine:

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, German Minister for Occupied Territories in the East, said in an address in Prague, Czechoslovakia, yesterday that the United States caused World War II to divert the attention of the people from internal conflicts and corruption.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 17 -- The Charleston Navy Yard said today it has a great-grand-mother -- and has had for eight months -- running a cold press in the shipfitter shop.

ONE of the most peculiar sights of the past football season was the spectacle of Frank Cope, the oversize Giant tackle, rushing in to smear someone and then suddenly sitting down of his own volition, no longer interested in the game, the ball-carrier or anything else except the strange behavior of his right knee.

The Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation was declared officially yesterday to lead the nation in the production of military aircraft and thus was the largest producer in the world as well, it was announced by Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The old Murray Hill Association, designed to protect from commercialism the residence property of the J.P. Morgan district of New York, was cited by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today as an instance that all zoning laws and agreements must eventually give way to "the greatest good for the greatest number."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 -- Byron Nelson, Toledo, Ohio, golf stylist, smashing par for the fourth consecutive day, turned in a 2-under-par 70 today to win the $10,000 San Francisco open golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 275, 13 under par.

Meyer O. Mortensen, 35 years old, a gunman from Everett, Mass., who perpetrated more than thirty-five hold-ups in this city in the last year, was committed to Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane yesterday by Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions.

The American Communist party is, in my opinion, the greatest obstacle to decent relations between the United States and Russia. This belief is shared by many who like myself were among the first to urge recognition of Russia after the end of the last war.

Mayor La Guardia told Budget Director Thomas D. Patterson yesterday to "cover in" the members of the Police Department on salary schedules so that they could receive as soon as possible a $420 cost-of-living increase retroactive to Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -Vice President Wallace told the Southern Governors conference tonight that the Federal Government must break the "monopoly power" of the New York money market if the South is to achieve economic equality with other sections.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 17 -- The air blows being exchanged by Americans and the Japanese in the central Pacific was heightened in intensity during the week-end. On Saturday and Sunday we bombed four Marshall atolls in five different operations, destroying two Japanese planes and probably knocking out two others from the air and striking four cargo ships, sinking at least one.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Office of Price Administration said today that twelve red stamps in War Ration Book 4, with a total value of 120 points, were validated for the buying of pork and other rationed meats direct from farmers.

A SOUTH PACIFIC AIR BASE, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Thirteenth Army Air Force destroyed 378 Japanese planes while losing only fortyseven of its own from August, 1942, to the end of 1943, force headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -Vice President Wallace told the Southern Governors conference tonight that the Federal Government must break the "monopoly power" of the New York money market if the South is to achieve economic equality with other sections.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 17 -- The air blows being exchanged by Americans and the Japanese in the central Pacific was heightened in intensity during the week-end. On Saturday and Sunday we bombed four Marshall atolls in five different operations, destroying two Japanese planes and probably knocking out two others from the air and striking four cargo ships, sinking at least one.

The meeting between Prime Minister Churchill and General de Gaulle, held in the midst of preparations for new Allied invasions of the European continent, is a promising development. It is especially promising because the French themselves hail it as a fresh start in the relations between France and her allies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A stronger and more comprehensive program of social security for the nation was urged today by the Social Security Board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Abrogation of the limitations imposed by the British Government on the rights of Jews to enter and purchase land in Palestine was urged in a memorandum from the American Jewish Committee which was presented today by Joseph M. Proskauer of New York, president of the committee, to Viscount Halifax, Ambassador of Great Britain, who promised to transmit it to London.

The two apartment houses containing fifty-six suites on a plot 180 by 110 feet at 1249-61 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, have been bought by Samuel J. Blank, president of the Luba Realty Corporation, from the Frank Construction Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Office of Price Administration said today that twelve red stamps in War Ration Book 4, with a total value of 120 points, were validated for the buying of pork and other rationed meats direct from farmers.

A SOUTH PACIFIC AIR BASE, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Thirteenth Army Air Force destroyed 378 Japanese planes while losing only fortyseven of its own from August, 1942, to the end of 1943, force headquarters announced today.
WASINGTON, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The United States, in a message dispatched on Saturday night, offered its good offices to the Russian Government, if acceptable, toward facilitating discussions between Moscow and the Polish Government in exile in London looking toward a resumption of their diplomatic relations, Secretary of State Cordell Hull announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Representative Dewey Short, Missouri Republican, lost an appeal today in the House Rules Committee for a closed rule on the mustering-out pay bill of the Military Affairs Committee.

The five buildings comprising the blockfront on the west side of Sixth Avenue from Twentieth to Twenty-first Street on about 35,000 square feet of land have been sold by the trustees of Series F-1 to a client of Louis Nadel, attorney.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Jan. 17 -- Taking a few hours off during his very busy schedule on his recent trip to the United States, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower enjoyed a brief family reunion in Kansas, it was learned today.

In any war fought on so gigantic a scale as this one there are bound to be reverses in the diplomatic field as well as on the battlefronts. Under this heading must be put Russia's reply to Poland and Pravda's circulation yesterday of the "Cairo rumor" that "leading British personalities" have been conferring secretly with von Ribbentrop to find terms for a separate peace with Germany.

SAN JUAN, Argentina, Jan. 17 -- Survivors clawed at the ruins of this once-beautiful city today, seeking loved ones buried amid the wreckage left by Saturday's disastrous earthquake that shattered San Juan as if salvoes of blockbusters had been dropped from the Andean peaks that tower over the city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court today had what might be termed a field day in handing down dissenting opinions to the majority views written by his colleagues.

DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 17 (AP) -- W.G. Bramham, minor league baseball's boss, suggested today that private ownership of teams is preferred to the farm system and that now is the time to revamp sprawling idle loops into compact circuits.

One sin that cannot be fairly charged against Tammany Hall is that of totalitarianism. What would be the complete opposite, the antonym, of total? Fractional? Then it has been shown more than once that Tammany Hall can be an extremely fractional institution, down to seven-twelfths.

Plans to establish dollar-and-cents prices for raw furs have been dropped and for the present season raw skins will remain under existing ceiling controls, the Office of Price Administration made known in Washington yesterday.

In answer to a departmental query on Sunday concerning a rumored postponement of "Peepshow," Ernest Pascal, author and co-producer of the play, wired from Boston that it was "talk, just talk; loose as usual." Yesterday his representative passed the word along that the attraction had been put off from Jan. 26 to Jan. 31 at the Fulton.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Why the Soviet Government has sternly rebuffed a tender from the Polish exile government which was so obviously encouraged by the Foreign Office and the State Department; why Pravda yesterday published the rumor about a separate British-German peace which was so clearly loaded with the seeds of international anti-Axis misunderstanding -- these are mysteries of Kremlin policy which may in time be explained.

ALGIERS, Jan. 17 -- The belief prevailing today, not only among de Gaullists but in all quarters, was that Prime Minister Churchill's meeting with Gen. Charles de Gaulle at Marrakesh presaged an early decision by Britain and the United States regarding their relations with the French in the coming decisive phase of the war and in the making of the peace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Senator Langer, Republican of North Dakota, attempted today in the Senate to link Secretary Harold L. Ickes with the letter which C. Nelson Sparks of Akron asserts Harry Hopkins, Presidential assistant, wrote to Dr. Umphrey Lee, president of Southern Methodist University at Dallas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The danger from native Fascists and those in all ranks of American life, including industry and labor, who "play into the hands of would-be Hitlers by helping to destroy the country's unity and the democratic balance" was cited tonight by Donald M. Nelson, chief of the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. l7 -- Colombia became the thirty-fourth nation to subscribe to the Declaration by the United Nations of Jan. 1, 1942, when President Alfonso Lopez Pumarejo of that republic signed the document at the White House today in the presence of President Roosevelt.
The United States is preparing to assume some of the obligations of international policing after the war.

The estimated cost of new construction, alterations and miscellaneous improvements in the city fell from $16,633,775 in 1942 to $5,719,443 last year, William Wilson, commissioner of the Department of Housing and Buildings, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- Representatives of the country's railroads and fifteen unions of non-operating employes were believed tonight to have reached an agreement for settlement of their sixteen-month-old wage dispute.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 19 -- Elation over the development of the Russo-Polish dispute is evident in all broadcasts and published comments to reach here in the past thirty-six hours from the real winner of the frontier wrangle -- the Wilhelmstrasse in Berlin.
The George Arents collection of books relating to tobacco, considered by bibliophiles the largest and most comprehensive of its kind, was opened yesterday afternoon at the New York Public Library.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Lorne Carr, Toronto's veteran right winger, made three goals and an assist to become the National Hockey League's highest point scorer tonight while the Maple Leafs were overwhelming the Boston Bruins, 7 -- 2, before 13,500 fans at the Boston Garden.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The newest Roosevelt-Churchill story that has enlivened London was told by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 18 (U.P.) -- By timing their new Leningrad drive with three other offensives in progress along the northern front, the Russians have been on the march in every sector of the huge eastern front since they began their summer offensive July 12.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The War Department is making an "intensive" investigation to determine whether a poll of political opinion, sponsored by Harrison E. Spangler, chairman of the Republican National Committee, has been made among our troops in England.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 18 -- It appears that the British-American air attacks on Sophia have served to give new Impetus to hitherto more or less dormant anti-Nazi organizations in Bulgaria. Notwithstanding the tightening of the Gestapo grip throughout Bulgaria, the opposition groups are becoming more active and underground forces are carrying out much sabotage against the Germans in all parts of the country.

More women will be making tax returns this year than ever before. To women who are filing a Federal income tax form for the first time Capt. William J. Pedrick, Collector of Internal Revenue for this area, gave advice yesterday.

Tonight's events: "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30; "The Marriage of Figaro," Nine O'Clock Opera, Town Hall, 8:30; Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson, duo-pianists, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Genia Nemenoff and Pierre Luboshutz, duo-pianists, concert sponsored by Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, Inc., 457 Madison Avenue, 9.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Roosevelt was unable to throw light today on the publication by Pravda of the Cairo dispatch concerning reports of Anglo-German discussions for a separate peace.

It begins to look as if the Princeton Club will have little trouble winning the Metropolitan Combination Team League squash racquets tournament as it continues to conquer all adversaries. Playing on their home court last night, the Tigers defeated the Yale Club, 5 to 0, thus taking a lead of five matches over their nearest rival, the Harvard Club.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The investigation by an extraordinary grand jury of spending by legislative committees, ordered by Governor Dewey at the request of Republican leaders, began today with a warning from Supreme Court Justice Eli W. Personius, who is presiding over the special term, that there will be "no politics" in the inquiry.
Mr. and Mrs. Fellowes Davis have arrived from Washington and are at the Carlyle.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Jan. 19 -- President Roosevelt announced final settlement of the railway wage case yesterday afternoon and Secretary Stimson returned the railroads to their owners at midnight.

The Sports War Bond Committee's tennis program, which will be held at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Jan. 28 as part of the committee's effort in the Fourth War Loan Drive, was given additional luster yesterday when it was announced that Lieut.

Negotiations have been completed for the acquisition of P. Duff Sons, Inc., a 77-year-old food concern, by the American Home Products Corporation through an exchange of capital shares, it was announced yesterday by Alvin G. Brush, chairman of the latter company.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, first large concern to announce earnings for 1943, informed stockholders yesterday that sales reached a new high of $414,263,939, compared with $369,212,044 in 1942.

This is an important week for sportsmen because it is the time observers all over the United States take what amounts to a census of migratory waterfowl. It is of interest to sportsmen because the data assembled form the basis upon which 1944 hunting regulations will be issued, according to Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, director of the Fish and Wildlife Service.

The TIMES' editorial, "Shovels and Spades," says that few praises have been sung to these tools. One poem which does pay this honor is Patrick MacGill's "The Song of the Shovel" from "Songs of the Dead End," published by Mitchell Kennerley. It begins:

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that its five steel-producing subsidiaries had asked Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, to certify to the War Labor Board various issues growing out of the wage demands of the United Steel Workers of America, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, as the basis for a new contract.

The week-old strike of dealers and slaughterers in the live poultry market rapidly heard its end yesterday when a fifth dealer joined the four at the New York Live Poultry Terminal in Queens who had reopened for business the day before.

Gallantry, said The United Press dispatch, impelled the Navy publicity officer to withhold the exact age of the great-grandmother who has been operating a cold press in the Charleston Navy Yard for nearly a year.

The railroad issues rescued the stock market yesterday from a general decline, but, at the best, prices closed mixed. The late rally in the carriers followed close on the heels of the news that the non-operating unions' wage agreement had been submitted to Stabilization Director Fred M. Vinson.

The wife of Lieut. John C. Wilmerding of the Navy, living in Westbury, L.I., learned yesterday that her husband had received the Legion of Merit Medal from Vice Admiral William F. Halsey, commander of Allied forces in the South Pacific, "for exceptional direction of a destroyer's gunfire during the initial landings on Guadalcanal and New Georgia."

Two of the high ranking airmen in the Allied air effort in the European Theatre, Air Marshal Sir Richard Hallam Peck and Lieut. Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, last week submitted to a transatlantic radio interview, staged by the National Press Club from Washington.
NEW DELHI, India Jan. 18 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

Expressing support of cooperation between an independent and democratic Poland and the Soviet Union, and declaring that Poland had furnished "ample proof" of her desire for such cooperation, seventeen Polish professors now living in the United States and Canada issued yesterday a statement assorting that "to achieve such cooperation the territorial claims of Soviet Russia must be withdrawn."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Prison sentences ranging from a year and a day up to 18 months for four defendants, probation for another and the maximum fine of $10,000 against the company were imposed in Federal Court today by Judge John P. Hartigan in the Anaconda Wire and Cable Company war fraud conspiracy case.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Each civilian will be entitled to four pounds more of coffee and one-half pound more of cocoa in the current year than in 1943, the Department of Agriculture revealed today.

In the Third War Loan 5,000,000 volunteers sold war savings bonds to more than 43,000,000 individuals in the United States. This was a great demonstration of the spirit of democracy at work in support of the war effort.
The decline in the city's death rate which set in two weeks ago after six weeks of gradual increases continued last week, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, Health Commissioner.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Ralph Chapman of Farwell, Chapman Co., Chicago, was elected today chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., succeeding Henry G. Riter 3d of Riter Co., New York.

An automobile carrying three war workers to the Sullivan Dry Dock at the foot of Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn, plunged last night into the Gowanus Canal when the driver failed to heed a dead-end warning sign. Two of the men, Joseph LaBue, 27, of 916 Sales Street, Brooklyn, and Francesca Terico, the driver, of 744 Coster Street, the Bronx, were rescued by a police launch and taken to Holy Family Hospital, suffering from submersion.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 18 -- President Pedro Ramirez, who arrived at the earthquake-stricken Andean city of San Juan by train today, ordered the zone affected by the quake declared a military area.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Jan. 18 -- The question of post-war acquisition of territory has now been raised in the Pacific, as well as in Europe. A program calling for future control by Australia and New Zealand of islands in the south Pacific area not hitherto under their jurisdiction has been presented by the Australian Government to the current conference at Canberra.

The sleeping mountains have brought death and destruction to the Andean province of San Juan in Argentina. Deep down in the earth furtive influences, secret impulses, insidious drifts upset the equilibrium of huge masses. Nature shrugged her shoulders, as it were, and houses crumbled and hundreds perished.

With the arrival of General Eisenhower in London and the appointment of Lieutenant General Bradley as senior commander of the American Ground Forces, the staff of the "Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Expeditionary Force" has now been assembled and is ready to lead the greatest and most daring amphibious invasion in history.

The growing racial unrest in the United States is a recognized fact. It may, of course, be instigated by outsiders to further their own ends. But that is beside the point, since such instigations cannot take root unless they fall into fertile soil.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The staid House of Commons rang with cheers as usually undemonstrative M.P.'s waved papers and shouted greetings this morning when Winston Churchill, as exuberant and as confident as ever, strode past the speaker's chair to take his place as the King's First Minister after an absence from England of more than eleven weeks.

LONDON, Jan. 18 (Reuter) -- A final twenty-four-hour rehearsal in anticipation of actual invasion was completed here today by Dutch civil affairs authorities who will accompany Allied troops into the Netherlands as administrators.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Representatives of the South, including nine Governors attending the Southern Governors' Conference, appeared more hopeful today of success in their long effort to break down differentials in freight rates charged on products manufactured in the South.

Assets of the Tri-Continental Corporation before deducting bank loans and funded debt, totaled $32,760,010 on Dec. 31 last, against $25,619,063 at the end of 1942, according to a report issued yesterday. This was equivalent to $179.65 for each share of preferred stock and $4.63 for each share of common stock, against $122.07 and $1.28 a year earlier and $179.26 and $4.61 on Sept. 30 last.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 18 -- Alaflag and Stinging Bee, neither heavily played, were the winners of the divisions of the Tamiami Purse, Hialeah feature today which was split into two events because of the large number entered. Last Saturday the Palm Beach had to be divided similarly and again substantial-priced horses won this afternoon.

When Winston Churchill "suddenly emerged from the shadows behind the Speaker's chair" in the House of Commons yesterday the roar of cheering that went up was echoed throughout the United Nations' world. A great man and a great soldier had taken his place again in the line of battle.

Legislation which would permit the mutual savings banks of New York State to engage in the personal loan business was recommended yesterday by the legislative committee of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York at the annual midwinter conference of the association in the Waldorf-Astoria.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Jan. 19 -- Members of twenty Indian tribes, participating as bushmasters -- jungle fighters specially trained in Panama -- have cracked the Japanese positions at Arawe, New Britain, an Allied communique announced today.

Big Ed Levy, who has spent most of his time since leaving college as a Yankee infield farm hand, will be one of Manager Joe McCarthy's outfield experiments at Atlantic City in the spring, if present plans materialize. This was indicated yesterday at Yankee headquarters when President Ed Barrow looked with favor on a proposal to give the gangling Levy a trial as successor to Charley Keller, slugging left fielder who has entered the service.
LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 18 -- China now faces the bleakest year of her long war with Japan, in the opinion of foreign observers in Chungking. Inflation has carried prices 200 times above their 1937 base. The price of some manufactured goods has increased 500-fold; other goods have been doubled in price only fifty times.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Moscow gave full acknowledgment tonight to Britain's repudiation of peace talks with Germany, but at the same time cited a story in a British Sunday newspaper as a basis for rumors that the Nazis actually were seeking a peace.

Twelve paintings have been acquired recently by the Museum of Modern Art. Eight have been placed on view in the recent accessions gallery, the other four being among the contemporary work included in the "Romantic Painting in America" exhibition.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The Most Rev. Bernard Griffin, formerly Bishop Auxiliary to the Archbishop of Birmingham, was enthroned as the sixth Roman Catholic Archbishop of Westminster in Westminster Cathedral today.

NO branch of the services is as completely sports conscious as the Pre-Flight division of the Navy. The embryonic aviators are required to take part in athletics not as a diversionary afterthought but as a formal part of their training. It is as integral a portion of their curriculum as mathematics, physics, ordnance or gunnery.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 18 (U.P.) -- Australian and New Zealand governmental leaders today concluded a pact for future full exchange of information and cooperative action in south Pacific problems. They also proposed the forming of a South Seas Regional Commission made up of the two Dominions and Britain, France and the United States to consider post-war development and native welfare in islands adjacent to Australia and New Zealand.

The Hollywood Ice Revue, featuring Miss Sonja Henie, petite Norwegian skating star, opened at Madison Square Garden last night for a fifteen-performance run. Except for a three-night interlude, the revue, beginning its seventh annual season, will continue through Feb. 4.

Small trade price-fixing orders in the near positions against textile contracts caused prices in the cotton market yesterday to work up to moderate gains during a session quieted by continued anxiety over domestic and military developments.
A five-goal uprising in the third period enabled the New York Rovers to defeat the Brooklyn Crescents, 9 to 5, last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace in an Eastern Hockey League contest.

Janet Bush, mezzo-soprano, was heard in a recital last night in Town Hall. The program presented contained arias from Handel's "Julius Caesar" and "Partenope" and Wagner's "Rienzi"; Lieder of Brahms, Franz, Strauss and Erich Wolff; Russian items by Rachmaninoff and Mussorgsky, and a final group of English songs.

French colonial divisions under General Juin have advanced through the mountains to seize Sant' Elia, northern anchor of the enemy's line defending Cassino. This village on the Rapido River outflanks the junction of the valley road to Rome. American troops have also reached the Rapido, less than two miles below Cassino.

Extensive use of airplanes for cargo shipments in the post-war period will result in releasing large amounts of capital tied up in inventories, will mean more style trends, with a consequent increase in sales and turnovers, and will add to the decentralization influence first brought about by the automobile.

Rival calls for meetings of the Tammany executive committee on separate dates and at different places were sent out yesterday, one on behalf of the faction seeking to oust Michael J. Kennedy as leader and the other at Mr. Kennedy's own request.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday total 1,831, which compared with 2,568 in the preceding week and 1,782 in the corresponding week of last year, according to the lists appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Amid a constant clatter of teletype machines, a detachment of Wacs is operating the New York Signal Center for the Second Service Command -- receiving and sending military messages of all types. Assignment of Wacs to such a center is a new development, and one that is expected to be the forerunner of similar Wac operations in other sections of the country.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Proof of new Nazi terror rising in Western Europe is now in possession of the Belgian Government-in-Exile, which issued today from its headquarters here a sombre warning to the Germans that they must desist from torturing imprisoned civilians and shooting hostages for no apparent reason.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Sir James Grigg, Secretary of State for War, announced in Parliament today that the Daily Worker's application to have one of its men accredited as war correspondent with the British forces had been rejected.

Bill Hulse, the New York Athletic Club miler, continues his winter's campaign Saturday night with a bid for the Metropolitan A.A.U. indoor crown in the championships which are this week's track highlight at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- The job of national economic reconversion after the war must not be left to politicians, but must be done by clear thinking, practical men, William M. Jeffers, president of the Union Pacific Railroad and former Federal rubber director, said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Senate voted today to require labor unions and other non-profit, tax-exempt organizations to file financial reports with the Treasury. It acted after Senator Josiah W. Bailey, Democrat, of North Carolina, declared that labor organizations had gained so much power that the Government itself was in jeopardy.

Increased apporpriation to permit strengthening the book stock and personnel was sought yesterday by the New York Public Library in submitting its budget request for 1944-45 to Thomas J. Patterson, Director of the Budget. An increase of $395,294 in the budget was asked, making a total of $2,117,505 for the year.

A UNITED STATES MUSTANG FIGHTER BASE, in England, Jan. 18 -- Major James H. Howard, tall, spare leader of one of the new Mustang P-51 fighter squadrons operating from this field, was officially identified today as the lone United States fighter pilot who for more than thirty minutes last Tuesday fought off about thirty German fighters trying to attack the Eighth Air Force B-17 formations returning from Oschersleben and Halberstadt in Germany.

Formation of the MacArthur National Associates, based on the "moral certainty" that Gen. Douglas MacArthur will accept the Presidential nomination if chosen at the Republican convention, was announced here yesterday by Ormsby McHarg.

Establishment of factory distribution branches and wholesale outlets in New York, Philadelphia, and Los Angeles to handle General Electric major appliances is not part of a company policy of changing over from independent distributors to factory branches, officials of the company's appliance and merchandise department stated yesterday.

Bond market volume records since 1937 have been snowed under by the activity so far this month. Volume up to last night in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange was $197,998,950, a figure 21 per cent above the comparable 1943 mark of $162,844,500 and topping many a full month in recent years.

The Metropolitan Opera House was the scene of a jazz jam session last night, given by the Esquire All-American Band, 1944, in connection with the Fourth War Loan Drive. A total of $650,000 was raised from the sale of tickets, which went only to 3,600 purchasers of war bonds of denominations from $25 to $100, and subscribers for the boxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Harlan F. Stone, Chief Justice of the United States, joined a thousand other Washingtonians today in paying tribute to Miss Mahel T. Boardman and her forty-four years of Red Cross work.
LONDON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Roosevelt went over to the executive office this afternoon for the second time since his illness with the grippe to meet the press for the first news conference he has held since Dec. 28.

The letter of Alexander Kerensky and Alexander Konovalov, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Jan. 14, although dictated by a sincere desire of contributing to Russo-Polish amity, gives, however, a wrong picture of the history of Russo-Polish relations.

Declaring it was the personal business of every American to see that the Fourth War Loan was a success, President Roosevelt warned, in a statement issued in Washington yesterday, that "until we have actually occupied Berlin and Tokyo we cannot indulge for a moment in the pleasant day dream that the war is almost over."

A new Government measure, which became known generally yesterday and is to go into effect next month, requires grocers to sell all fresh fruits and vegetables by the pound. At first this may confuse customers who always purchased such foods as oranges, grapefruit and celery by the dozen, piece and bunch, respectively.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The stock markets here today again were steady in tone but business was on a smaller scale than yesterday.

Miss Ruth Geiger, pianist, and a winner of the Walter W. Naunburg Musical Foundation prize, gave the recital which that prize gives to successful contestants yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. She played perceptively and with a fine sincerity and enthusiasm a program which showed the breadth of her tastes and her curiosity about music.

Total newspaper advertising linage in fifty-two cities during 1943 registered an increase of 12.5 per cent over that of 1942, according to a compilation issued yesterday by Media Records. The gain in total linage for December was 5.9 per cent over the corresponding month in 1942.

Dozens of ingenious ways to dramatize a plain dark dress were displayed in the showing of Arpad's collection of spring accessories at luncheon in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton yesterday. Pert little hats tilted over the brow, scarf-collars and ascots, belts and costume jewelry, were grouped in a wide variety of go-together combinations.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Miss Vivien Kellems, Westport, Conn., owner of a war plant, said in an address here today to service and civic clubs that she had not paid her Dec. 15, 1943, income tax, and called on all business men to follow her example by putting aside "post-war reserves out of their taxes."

Rather than offer Broadway a farce they thought could stand more polishing, Ted Gerken and Joe Chandler pigeonholed "Kicked Upstairs," by Clyde North, after witnessing the Boston tryout last May. Now the Messrs. Gerken and Chandler are trying their luck with another farce, "Mrs. Kimball Presents," the work of Alonzo Price, who also will be responsible for the direction.

When Efrem Zimbalist appeared in recital last night in Carnegie Hall the audience had occasion again to admire the sureness of his technique, the reaffirmation of the noble school of interpretation in which he developed; the straightness and suppleness of the bow arm, firm as a rock; the almost infallible fingers that stood guard like a trusted battalion against so much as a slip or miss of a tone.

Spokesmen for parent, teacher and civic groups urged the Board of Education yesterday to defend its proposed budget of $136,799,165 as "minimum," and to resist any cuts by the city's fiscal authorities. In statements made before the board's committee on finance and budget, most of the speakers, representing thirty-three organizations, approved the estimate but called for further extension of school services and increased compensation for school personnel.

The City Council unanimously adopted a resolution at its meeting yesterday calling upon Mayor La Guardia to issue a statement "clarifying the situation, beyond any reasonable doubt" on Patrolman James L. Drew, who was cleared of departmental charges of associating with anti-Semitic and subversive elements.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Wednesday, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- New tactics by Admiral William F. Halsey will be used to "eliminate" Rabaul, New Britain, and Kavieng, New Ireland, with their estimated 100,000 Japanese, Rear Admiral Robert Carney, South Pacific Chief of Staff, indicated today.

City Fuel Administrator Edwin A. Salmon reported yesterday that railroad officers had agreed to concentrate on the movement of coal consigned to New York City that has been piling up in New Jersey freight yards and at piers. Coincidentally, Gardner Pattison, president of Burns Brothers, hailed what he described as Mr. Salmon's "very constructive proposal" that preference be given to dealers on this coal.

The letter of William H. Matthews, former director of the City Emergency Work and Relief Bureau, stated by way of strong disapproval that he is "not ignorant of either the good or the evil" of the War Food Administration's proposed revival of the subsidized food-stamp relief program.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- Allied heavy bombers continued to pick off Japanese shipping, setting a 9,000-ton merchant vessel afire in Ambon harbor, Ambonina. Japanese planes attempted interception, but three of eight that challenged the bombers were shot down and another was probably destroyed.

The National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday a decided slackening in immediate and prospective demands upon the nation's labor resources. It declared that, against the background of easing requirements except for the armed forces, proposed national service legislation "would appear to be designed to assure the full tame performance of those at work rather than to introduce a substantial body of new workers."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Roosevelt's recommendation to Congress a week ago that it enact a national service program for the mobilization of civilian manpower and womanpower received a setback today when the House Military Affairs Committee voted to postpone indefinitely further consideration of such legislation.

Ralph Damon, vice president and general manager of American Airlines, Inc., has been elected a trustee of the New York Trust Company, it was announced yesterday by John E. Bierwirth, president of the bank. Announcement was also made of the promotion of Donal C. O'Brien from assistant vice president to vice president.

Some real changes have occurred in Girl Scouting since the days when the emphasis was on knot-tying and making a fire with three matches. The trends were typified yesterday afternoon when Audrey McNeill, 15 years old, reported on the Brooklyn Inter-Racial Conference to 300 delegates at the annual meeting of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York.

The speed and unanimity with which the Legislature voted to put the State's surplus of $140,000,000 under lock and key constitute almost a political miracle. One would have expected great pressure to dissipate this surplus either through additional wartime spending or through reduction of present taxes.

A Federal grand jury returned yesterday an indictment accusing Arthur Clifford Read, an Army corporal who once served briefly with the Chinese Army, of failure to notify the State Department while serving as a Japanese propaganda agent. The defendant is 32 years old and until his recent arrest here by the Federal Bureau of Investigation was stationed at Camp Croft, S.C.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- In an apparent answer to long-continued comments that the Office of Price Administration should not try to put price ceilings on such luxury articles as women's expensive fur coats, OPA announced a complete exemption from price control of women's fur garments with a manufacturer's or manufacturer-retailer's selling price of $8,000 or more.

ALGIERS, Jan. 18 -- Both the Rapido River and the Cassino-Atina road have been breached north of Cassino by American troops, it was officially announced today. French units pushed on to capture Sant' Elia and the near-by hamlet of Valvori and also to attain the banks of the Rapido.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The State American Legion began a drive here today to get full preference in all State, county and city offices for veterans of all the wars including the present one. The group sponsored a proposed constitutional amendment which is broader in scope than any previously suggested and which, if adopted, would virtually restrict progress in governmental jobs within the State to those who had fought in this or past wars.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The United States shipped $338,000,000 worth of goods to Soviet Russia in November, this being the largest amount sent in the history of the lend-lease program. The Foreign Economic Administration said today that "lend-lease shipments have kept pace with the rising tempo of the Red Army's advance."

TORONTO, Jan. 18 -- On the eve of his 100th birthday, Sir William Mulock, who has spent sixty years in public service in Canada, has one ambition -- to live long enough to see complete unity in Canada.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 (U.P.) -- Edith Louise Sylvia Fairbanks, the former Lady Ashley and widow of Douglas Fairbanks Sr., the film star, was married here late today to Lieut. Comdr. Edward John Lord Stanley of the Royal Navy.

Assets of the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland increased $2,215,311 during 1943 to a total of $81,876,929 at the year end, Frank A. Bach, president, declared yesterday in the annual report to stockholders. The company writes various forms of insurance.

LONDON, Jan 18 (AP) -- The Yugoslav Partisan leader, Marshal Tito [Josip Broz], was reported today to have been wounded in the upper left arm when his army broke out of German encirclement in Montenegro, but the time was given indefinitely, as last summer.

The 4,100 American boxers who are in the nation's fighting services will be honored tonight at Ruppert's Brewery when, at the sixth annual dinner of the Boxing Writers Association of New York, the Edward J. Neil Memorial Plaque will be awarded in the name of the group to be hung later in the rotunda of Madison Square Garden.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Governor Dewey disclosed definitely tonight that he does not intend to "bail out" municipalities confronted with financial difficulties by granting to them a greater share of State revenue, nor does he intend to allow them broader taxing powers on a long-term basis. However, he is willing to afford what may amount to substantial temporary relief for the current year.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Paramount the new offering is "The Miracle of Morgan's Creek," a comedy written and directed by Preston Sturges for Paramount. Betty Hutton, Eddie Bracken, Diana Lynn and William Demarest head the cast.

Spring and Summer millinery, streamlined in accord with coiffure trends, wartime psychology and conservation of materials, were shown to more than 1,500 buyers and trade executives at the fashion promenade held last night by the Millinery Stabilization Commission at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- The Republicans captured another seat in the House of Representatives today by winning a special election in the Second Congressional District while maintaining their hold on the Seventeenth Congressional District to cut the Democratic plurality in the House from ten to eight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- United sentiment in favor of mustering-out pay for veterans characterized a long discussion in the House today, with diversity apparent only concerning the size of the payments and the method of handling.
MIAMI, Jan. 18 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor denounced today "the almost indiscriminate" employment of war prisoners "in competition with free American workers."

SOMEWHERE IN ITALY, Jan. 18 -- A seriously wounded soldier lying on a litter in an evacuation hospital receiving tent is at once a pitiable and inspiring sight. You see the man then at his lowest and at his bravest.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 18 -- Germans have been puzzled to find across the front pages of their newspapers since Sunday the threatening gray shadow of a man in a soft hat who, judging by his contour, might represent President Roosevelt or Prime Minister Churchill.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 18 (AP) -- William S. Jack, president of Jack Heintz, Inc., reported today he expected his "associates" (employes) to pour an estimated $30,000,000 into non-voting preferred stock to replace post-war operating capital he contends the company is losing through Government contract renegotiation.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 18 (AP) -- American-trained Chinese troops have taken two more villages in the Ninghyen area of northern Burma's Hukawng Valley and Allied forces on the Mayu Peninsula have thrown back two Japanese counter-attacks, Allied Headquarters announced today.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Wilson C. Van Duzer, Orange County farmer, without consultation with party leaders, tossed into the legislative session today the first "red hot" political issue it has received.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -Claude M. Baker, president of the International Typographical Union, defied the War Labor Board to its face today despite a warning that his attitude might block pay rises for his union through any other channels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The letter attributed to Harry Hopkins, intimate friend of President Roosevelt, and predicting that Wendell Willkie would be the 1944 Republican Presidential nominee, was denounced today as "a definite forgery" by Henry A. Schweinhaut, who is investigating the affair for the Department of Justice.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- It is useless to expect anything like full employment in the United States after the war if the construction industry is left out of plans, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, said today at the twenty-fifth annual convention of the Associated Equipment Dealers here.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 18 -- American soldiers in this area now are eating fresh chicken in their mess halls for the first time as a result of an untiring campaign by Army veterinary supervisors to clean up poultry dressing establishments, which hitherto were unable to meet the rigorous standards of cleanliness demanded by the Army authorities.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Wheat fluctuated nervously today on the Board of Trade, holding within a range of less than 1 cent a bushel, running into fair commission-house support on the breaks and encountering hedging pressure on the upturns Closing trades showed gins of 1/4 to 1/2 cent.

The board of directors of The Associated Press last night directed counsel to "appeal without delay" the summary judgment, filed by a Federal court without full trial, in the Government's civil anti-trust suit against the non-profit news cooperative.

SOMEWHERE IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 16 (Delayed) -- The realization that Germany cannot win the war seems at last to have penetrated into the German Army, to judge by statements made today by German prisoners at the largest prisoner-of-war camp in North Africa.

CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 13 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- One by one, the five Americans in the big B-24 cargo plane stepped into the icy wind and watched their parachutes bloom above. One by one, they drifted down toward snow-capped mountains.
The nation's permanent post-war military forces may number 1,000,000 to 2,000,000 uniformed men.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The House of Commons took time out from more momentous subjects today to discuss what the nations should do about an Oxford laundry that not only knocks the buttons off the shirts of members of Parliament, but loses 7 per cent of all the shirts it handles.

The Seamen's Church Institute of New York announces a marine poetry contest for merchant seamen of the United Nations and for students in the maritime schools. It offers $25 as the first prize, $15 as second and $10 as third. The contest closes Feb. 1.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Jan 19 (UP) -- A communiqe:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- While compulsory national medical insurance still awaits the action of Congress in the form of the Wagner Murray Social Security bill, various branches of the Federal Government are promoting similar programs increasingly on a regional and voluntary basis.

MADRID, Jan. 12 (Delayed) -- The gradual shift of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime from the position of a satellite and moral ally of the Axis to its present one of full neutrality has a variety of causes. Among them are:

ILONA RALF SUES is a Polish intellectual, journalist and left-wing idealist. She speaks six languages -- Polish, Russian, German, French, English and Chinese; travels accompanied by a black cat named Gueidze; combines the daring and resourcefulness of the true adventurer with the humanitarian zeal of the born crusader.

In Washington yesterday the House Committee on Military Affairs voted, in the words of its chairman, "to hold in abeyance for the time being" the President's proposal for a National War Service Act. It is explained that a Senate committee planned some time ago to hold hearings on this question anyway, and that House members can listen in if they want to.

SEATTLE, Jan. 18 -- At least 10,000 American Federation of Labor members were idle in more than eighty foundries of Washington and Oregon today as molders and foundry workers went on strike and threw out picket lines in protest against a directive order of the Regional War Labor Board refusing an eight-cents-an-hour wage increase for journeyman. molders.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Survivors returning to port on another vessel told today of a five-day battle with a North Atlantic storm which ended with the foundering of the Army freighter Nevada and the loss of thirty-five men from her crew of sixty-four.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs in the Middle West showed today a general slackening in number, but because of yesterday's record supply the salable receipts of 361,000 head at the twelve markets for the first two days this week were about the same as a week ago. Twelve markets reported 126,000 salable hogs today, compared with 142,000 on last Tuesday.

The second annual exhibition presented by Merchant Seamen of the United Nations was opened yesterday in the terminal headquarters of the Grand Central Art Galleries. This exhibition is sponsored by the United Seamen's Service and the War Shipping Administration, and the full list of individual sponsors as it appears in the catalogue is headed by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A letter from Adm. Emory S. Land, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, to Representative Clarence Lea, Democrat, of California, and sponsor of the Lea bill for Federal control of civil aviation, requesting that American steamship lines be permitted to engage in international aviation, was read before the House Rules Committee today.

Textile processors were warned yesterday by George A. Lanier, assistant director of the War Production Board's textile, clothing and leather bureau, that despite manpower shortages they will be called upon to handle large quantities of textiles in the coming six months to meet both military and foreign rehabilitation needs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- It did not appear at all strange to this correspondent today to be anonymously informed over the telephone that Sherlock Holmes had arrived in town and desired a secret meeting. Though Holmes was once or twice put to death by the late A. Conan Doyle and the late Dr. Moriarity, life was restored to him by Hollywood some years ago, accompanied by the grant of immortality.

The Democratic majority in the City Council served notice yesterday that it would not go along with Mayor La Guardia's request for additional taxing powers from the State to raise from $25,000,000 to $30,000,000. The Mayor had said this sum would be needed if additional burdens were not to be placed on real estate.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Jan. 19 -- On the first anniversary of the cracking of the blockade of Leningrad the Soviet High Command announced last night that the Red Army was successfully developing new offensives in sectors west and south of the old Czarist capital.

Governor Edison's last official act was characteristic. He reported the expenditures of his office and the cost of four investigations held in his last year of office. This was a new proceeding and surprised veteran observers at Trenton. He wanted State business done in a businesslike manner.

THE heavyweights capture the headlines and captivate the imagination. They are the glamour boys of the boxing profession and any little fellow who can vie with them for boxing immortality certainly has what it takes. Such a man was Terrible Terry McGovern, a champion among champions even though he was only a featherweight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A second and more specific nation-wide survey on civilian consumer goods items which are in short supply will be made in March, Dr. Austin Grimshaw, who conducted the first civilian shortage census for the War Production Board's Office of Civilian Requirements, told the Fashion Group today.

DETROIT, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- New automobiles may be purchasable before the end of 1944, but they will be neither a streamlined "dream" car nor the $400 economy vehicle which Henry J. Kaiser predicts, says Charles L. McCuen, vice president and engineering chief of the General Motors Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Roosevelt hailed the "cooperative movement" today as "one of the appropriate instruments for relief and rehabilitation of Axis-invaded lands."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today that it will apply retroactively to 1943 a new salary stabilization policy removing dollars-and-cents limitations on commissions and bonuses.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Authorized spokesmen said today information exchanged between eighteen American republics had shown that Bolivian revolutionary leaders were in contact with Argentine nationalists in the home of Count Karl von Luxburg, former German Minister to Buenos Aires, before the Dec. 20 coup in La Paz.
Boxing paid tribute to its service heroes, living, dead, injured and missing in action, last night.

The Bartholomew Building, a twenty-story office structure at 205-17 East Forty-second Street, through the block to 204-210 East Forty-third Street, has been sold by the Bartholomew Holding Company to an investing client of the Charles F. Noyes Company in a cash transaction. The property is assessed at $4,155,000 and the sale included the two parcels at 669 and 677 Third Avenue.

Columbia's basketball team scored its second victory over Yale this season by triumphing, 46 -- 35, in the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night. In the first meeting of the quintets at New Haven last month the Lions were the winners, 46 -- 42.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 -- Robert Paige, who was teamed with Louise Allbritton in two recent Universal feature comedies, has been named by the studio for the singing lead with Deanna Durbin in the Jerome Kern Technicolor musical "Carolina." The same company has assigned Anne Gwynne and David Bruce to the top roles in a musical, "Moon Over Las Vegas," which will go into production next week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 -- Women are still being hired in larger numbers than men in West Coast aircraft plants, in spite of reports that the demand is easing off, and officials said today that the need would increase as 1944 wore on and more men left the assembly lines for military service.
Gold medals awarded annually for special achievements in horticulture in this area were presented yesterday by the Horticultural Society of New York at its monthly meeting at 398 Madison Avenue.

ALGIERS, Jan. 19 -- Typhus cases are occurring at the rate of thirty to forty daily among the civil population in Italy, it was officially announced today, but there have been no cases at all among the Army personnel.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Lack of aggressive demand for wheat futures from cash interests is regarded as operating against the maintenance of advances in the market now. Today short covering caused an upturn of around 3/4 cent a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade, but when hedging sales from the Southwest appeared, accompanied by a revival of peace talk of an indefinite character, the market reacted quickly.

Declines were recorded last week in stocks of gasoline and light fuel oil along the Atlantic Coast, but supplies of heavy fuel oil were slightly higher. According to the American Petroleum Institute, the index covering gasoline stocks at the close of the period stood at 42, compared with 43.6 a week earlier.
MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- One of the big topics of conversation in Moscow is why there has been no winter this winter.

Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson, duo-pianists, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Their playing possessed sparkle, life and verve, and these assets found ample scope in an elaborate program which covered a wide range of styles and periods.

The total public debt of Germany stood at 240 billion marks at the end of the fiscal year last Aug. 31, compared with 47 billion marks at the outbreak of hostilities, the Office of War Information said yesterday, quoting the Munich newspaper Muenshener Neueste Nachrichten.

The main controversy arises in the area of food subsidies where the Government has asked for a new hundred million dollars additional. Price Administrator Bowles has announced that with a total outlay on food of $1 1/2 billion annually, as compared to the present outlay of $1,100 million, he could stabilize food prices.

ALGIERS, Jan. 19 -- Col. Oveta Culp Hobby, director of the Women's Army Corps, here on an inspection tour that will take her to Italy, denied today that recent Wac recruiting had been a "flop" and declared it had gone "remarkably well in the last three months."

For the second time within the last five weeks, the Fern Dress Company, manufacturers of dresses with a large plant at 330 West Thirty-eighth Street, near Eighth Avenue, was held up late yesterday afternoon by a lone, armed Negro who shot two employes, one seriously, and then escaped without obtaining any money.

The American Paper and Pulp Association called on the War Manpower Commission yesterday for still more labor to cut pulpwood and for expansion of the programs devised last August to revise selective service rules so as to keep men in wood-cutting work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- This year's production of military aircraft is expected to total more than 100,000 planes of an average weight of about 10,000 pounds each, Charles E. Wilson, chairman of the War Production Board's aircraft production division, stated today.

In your sketch of Dean Jones of Yale you mentioned a quatrain that has behind it an amusing bit of literary history. One Holy Cross banquet night in Boston Dr. John Collins Bossidy of Lee (1860-1928) delivered himself of the following:

The four-story apartment on a plot 50 by 80 feet at 3139 Boulevard, Jersey City, has been sold by Sharon Gardens, Inc., to the Point Line Realty Company. Sale of this building, which contains twenty suites, was subject to a $48,000 mortgage held by the Lincoln Mortgage Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Amendments to regulations which will require certain industrial consumers to make further reductions in their orders for soft coal so that a larger share of the current mine output will be made available for diversion to users distressed by the lack of fuel were announced today by the Solid Fuels Administration.

Loew's, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders covering the year ended with last August a net income of $13,422,853, after provision for depreciation and $21,239,870 Federal income and excess profits taxes.

LONDON, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans entrenched in hills overlooking the Vrbas Valley of western Bosnia blasted a trapped German motorized division and its 400 vehicles with all the artillery at their command today while a German rescue column, slowed by deep snow and mud, strove to break open an escape gap.

BAYONNE, N.J., Jan. 19 -- In as brusque a condemnation of a strike as any Federal agency has delivered, the Second Region of the National War Labor Board tonight applied the word "sabotage" to the walk-out this afternoon of an estimated 1,000 employes of the Bayonne plant of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company in a dispute over seniority in the filling of four positions in the refinery.

Refugees from Nazi-occupied countries are making their way to Allied territory in Morocco through Malaga, Spain, at the rate of nearly 6,000 every fifteen days, Luis Garcia Guijarro, commercial counselor at the Spanish Embassy in Washington, said yesterday on his arrival at La Guardia Field aboard a Pan-American Clipper.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Beardsley Ruml urged Congress today to lay the foundation immediately for a post-war fiscal policy which would insure full employment while stabilizing or reducing taxes and balancing the budget.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 19 -- A hint that the Arab countries whose representatives recently concluded successful talks for post-war collaboration would act to create a committee to represent the Arab world at the peace conference was contained in a dispatch from the Baghdad correspondent of Al Ahram published today.

Malden, Mass., awarded yesterday a new issue of $750,000 of temporary loan notes, dated Jan. 19 and due Nov. 6, 1944 on an 0.424 per cent basis. The National Shawmut Bank and the Merchants National Bank, both of Boston, and bidding separately, each obtained the award of $375,000 of the notes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Class I railroads will have to pay about $340,000,000 annually for the wage increases won by their operating and nonoperating employes, according to an estimate by an expert of the Association of American Railroads.

Employes of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company voted yesterday by 768 to 609 to reject the United Office and Professional Workers of America, affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, as a collective bargaining agency.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- In a message to the United States Conference of Mayors, meeting today, President Roosevelt made this promise:

In sentences imposed immediately after they had pleaded guilty yesterday in the first rent-gouging case prosecuted here, Louis Grodsky, 68 years old, and his son, Bernard, 32, received sixty-day jail terms and the Beckmar Realty Corporation, which they control, was fined $500.

A gold wrist watch "in recognition of distinguished service to America" was presented in absentia to Rear Admiral Harold G. Bowen, special assistant to the Under-Secretary of the Navy, at a luncheon yesterday afternoon of the Advertising Club of New York, 23 Park Avenue.

Various manufacturers of women's sweaters have adopted the procedure of filing individual protests with the War Production Board, in an effort to step up output of larger sizes which, owing to wartime yarn limitations, are in short supply in most parts of the country, it was reported yesterday in the knitwear market.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 19 -- A sentence of eighteen months in the Essex County Penitentiary was imposed today on Charles A. Barts, New York detective, who was convicted Dec. 14 of extorting $1,000 from Miss Marion Greenberg of this city under threat of exposing a $10,000 theft.

The German Propaganda Minister, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, as quoted by DNB, asserted in the current issue of the Reich, in an article headed "In Ninety Days," that the Germans were ready "at any moment and in any place" for an Allied invasion of western Europe.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Jan. 20 (UP) -- A communique:

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Jan. 20 (U.P.) -- An armada of Allied bombers blasted eight enemy cargo ships, sinking at least three, in an attack on Monday on the Japanese base at Rabaul, New Britain, where they also shot down eighteen of 100 intercepting enemy planes, it was announced today.
ALGIERS, Jan. 19 -- A communique:

An expanded advertising and sales promotion program designed to acquaint the public with the advantages of gas and Certified Performance Gas Ranges and to contribute toward the war effort and post-war employment has been approved by the American Gas Association's domestic gas range division and the sales management committee of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers.

Dioramas constructed by Louis Paul Jonas under the sponsorship of Textron, Inc., recreating spectacular action scenes of the war, opened last Monday on the forty-second floor of the Empire State Building and will remain on view during the Fourth War Loan drive. The exhibition was prepared in collaboration with the War Department.

Sir William Mulock, formerly Chief Justice of Ontario, was 100 yesterday. If long life be a blessing, no man better deserves it. He was in Parliament for twenty-three years. Postmaster General in Sir Wilfrid Laurier's Cabinet, he brought about two-cent postage and was perhaps the chief hand in the project for a cable to Australia.

Chancellor Samuel P. Capen of the University of Buffalo was elected president of the Association of Colleges and Universities of the State of New York at the annual meeting of the association yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore. Chancellor Capen succeeds the Rev. Joseph M. Noonan, president of Niagara University.

Salvage leaders of the American Women's Voluntary Services, working with teachers and students of nine schools in Astoria, Queens, have increased the collection of loose paper by more than one and a half tons a week, it was reported yesterday to the Newspaper Publishers Waste Paper Drive committee.

Golf faces another difficult year, but it is the belief of the officers of the United States Golf Association that we can, even without tournaments, render valuable service to the game and to the golf clubs of the country.

MIAMI, Jan. 19 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor was urged today to favor creation of a central Government agency to coordinate some twenty-five Government divisions now seeking to regulate wages and conditions of employment.

The board of directors of the Discount Corporation of New York announced yesterday that Dudley H. Mills, who has been a director fourteen years and president for the last ten years, has been elected chairman of the board. There had been no chairman.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Bewildered by the furor caused by her speech advocating a post-war reserve "out of taxes" which she made yesterday in Kansas City, Miss Vivien Kellems asserted tonight that Secretary Morgenthau's charges were "too serious" to answer at once but she said she would answer them, "and in full."

Whatever relief was to have come to the coal-pinched East from receipt of all bituminous coal mined in West Virginia was nullified yesterday, at least temporarily, by an embargo on rail shipments of coal here from that State and other fields in the South.

LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's warning to Generalissimo Francisco Franco today, voiced in the House of Commons in the presence of Prime Minister Churchill, was couched in such strong terms as to suggest that Mr. Eden, while side-stepping an open rupture, was leaving no doubt that Britain's patience was running out over the thinly-disguised Spanish aid to Germany.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 19 -- The Germans have ordered an end of the investigation into the murder of Dr. Kaj Munk, Danish preacher and dramatist, by three Danish Nazis, according to Monday's Frie Danske, Copenhagen's illegal newspaper.

A full-fledged program of postwar preparedness, with American resources and energy geared to be thrown into war economy on a moment's notice, was advocated last night by Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, as this nation's best guarantee against any future Pearl Harbors.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The official announcement made by the United States Army headquarters yesterday that the long-range, hard-hitting North American Mustang P-51 fighters have been operating in this theatre since last December appears to give the Allies the advantage over the Germans in this category of planes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- As was generally expected and widely prophesied the railway workers of the country got a better financial award out of the prolonged and conflicting Federal negotiations of their wage demands than they could and would have accepted under the undisturbed processes of the Railway Labor Act.

As at previous court appearances, Mrs. Julia Jiro, 23 years old, did all the talking for her husband, Frank, 24, when they surrendered yesterday in Special Sessions as fugitives on a charge of endangering the health of their two small children when they left them alone Jan. 4 in their apartment at 251 East Seventy-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- Representative Ranulf Compton, Republican, of Connecticut, accused President Roosevelt and his aides today of attempting to undermine Congress by agitating for Federal soldier-vote legislation, and contended it may take a civil war to "tear out some of the excesses" of the New Deal.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation sold through Michael P. Curnin, Inc., and E.P. Bacike, co-brokers, the two-family house at 975 Fifty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, and through Slomka Bros., Inc., the two-family dwelling at 2258 Seventy-ninth Street to John Zagami. The Clark Realty Company was co-broker in the latter deal.

The railroad issues gave again yesterday to the stock market its only argument for bullishness, but even this group lost most of its strength before the close. The selling lacked sufficient force seriously to disturb values, nor was the demand strong enough to furnish any general strength.

Two 16-year-old girls received suspended sentences yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court and three other younger girls were taken to Children's Court after one had struck her public school principal and kicked and scratched a patrolman, and the entire group had caused a rumpus in Public School 40, Jennings and Prospect Avenues, the Bronx.

Stockholders of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company at the annual meeting yesterday approved the proposals of directors to reduce the capital stock from $6,000,000 to $3,000,000 by cutting the par value of the 500,000 shares from $12 a share to $6 and by adding $1,500,000 of the $3,000,000 reduction to surplus account and the remaining $1,500,000 to contingency reserve.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Democratic leaders, headed by Postmaster General Frank C. Walker, took steps today to prevent a rift at the meeting of the Democratic National Committee, to be held here Saturday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 19 -- Part 2 of the New Jersey Supreme Court in Trenton granted today a motion by counsel for John R. Longo to postpone a hearing on Longo's appeal until the May term of the court.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Gen. Isaias Medina, President of Venezuela, was received with formal honors at the White House this afternoon.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The stock markets here today were dull and most issues lost ground.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 19 -- The Cleveland Trust Company reported today for 1943 a net income of $2,897,183, or $20.99 a share, after all taxes, interest on capital notes and transfer to reserves, compared with $1,886,091, or $13.66 a share, in 1942.

A warning that the United States textile industry may expect keen post-war competition in world markets from "lend-lease countries that we have helped to retool" was sounded yesterday by Hugh Comer, president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association, who spoke at the opening of the annual convention and exhibit of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute in the Hotel New Yorker.

Leopold Stokowski announced yesterday afternoon that he had accepted the invitation of Mayor La Guardia to organize and conduct a full-sized orchestra sponsored by the City Center of Music and Drama, to be known as the New York City Symphony.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A charge that the Office of Price Administration, by issuing an advance release of impending ceilings on California grapes, caused grape growers to lose $20,000,000 which they would otherwise have received for the current year's crop was voiced here today by Senator Abe Murdock of Utah during a hearing of a subcommittee of the Senate's Judiciary Committee investigating the liquor shortage.

Thirteen engineers were honored yesterday at the ninety-first annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers in the Engineering Societies Building. Society medals and prizes went to nine men and honorary memberships were conferred upon four others.
A home economics diploma presented yesterday at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn marked another milestone on the road back to home in the Netherlands for Miss Chedwah van Tijn.

Here is a far from inconceivable situation, not to say contretemps, in a public speaker's life. He has just been warning his audience against the perils of complacency when one of his hearers asks if he may put a question.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Mrs. Adele Williams, wife of Frank Starr Williams, an attache of the State Department in Washington and formerly commercial attache at the Tokyo embassy, was shot in the head and seriously wounded tonight in her hotel suite by an unidentified woman.
Louis Untermeyer, distinguished American poet, has written English lyrics to the new Soviet national anthem, Broadcast Music, Inc., the copyright proprietor, announced yesterday.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Jan. 20 (AP). -- Flying from Solomon Islands bases, the Allied bombers went in at Rabaul at 1 P.M. on Monday, on the seventeenth raid attack this month. They found eight ships anchored on the west side of Simpson Harbor and four more in Keravia Bay, a few miles south.

An optimistic view of prospects for the motorcycle industry in the post-war period, provided Government restrictions are not onerous, was taken yesterday at the annual meeting of the Motorcycle and Allied Trades Association at the Hotel Lexington.

The Schools Motions Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Secretary Stimson called today for immediate enactment of a national service law, telling the Senate Military Affairs Committee that the soldiers on the fighting fronts were demanding that all Americans accept with them the same liability for service to the country.

As the second day of the Fourth War Loan drive brought reports that six towns and three counties in the nation already had surpassed their quotas, New York City's financial district set in motion a determined campaign that has as its goal a minimum of 1,000,000 individual subscriptions in the district below Fulton Street.

ALGIERS, Jan. 19 -- Almost three weeks after a sharp exploratory attack near the mouth of the Garigliano River, British units of Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army have crossed the river at several points and are engaged in a fierce struggle to maintain and extend their bridgeheads, it was officially announced today.

A new kind of jury was instituted yesterday by Markets Commissioner Henry M. Brundage to hear food cases and decide whether Magistrate's Court summonses should be issued for alleged price ceilings violations. The food jury, formerly drawn from panels of consumer and trade representative volunteers, now consists of four Department of Markets employes.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art had a deficit of $35,993 for 1943 and probably will have one of $69,119 at the end of 1944, Laurence S. Harrison, business administrator for the museum, disclosed yesterday at a hearing before Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson.

In discussions of the Polish border problem the accusation frequently crops up that the present Government-in-exile, with headquarters in London, is "reactionary," or unrepresentative, or lacking in real authority. It is true that the Government of Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk cannot claim to derive its powers directly from the people of Poland, but it is probably as close to being representative of them as it is possible for a Government-in-exile to be under wartime conditions.

It was a good "down-to-earth" showing that Arnold Constable set before the luncheon guests in the Sert Room at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. The clothes were of the wearable kind -- those a woman might like to take South if she is going now, or jump into when the first call of spring comes here.

Support of the Thomas bill on child care now pending in Congress was urged yesterday by Mrs. Eugene Meyer of Washington in an address at the annual convention of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations at the Hotel Astor.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- A substantial reduction in the real estate tax for New York City, amounting to more than $10,000,000, is in prospect as a result of plans being worked out here. It appears possible that the reduction may be sufficient to bring the city's tax rate down to the 1942-43 level, before the ten-point raise enacted last year in the Mayor's budget.
LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 20 (UP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- By a vote of 387 to 0 the House of Representatives adopted today the mustering-out pay bill for veterans of this war, as amended by its Committee on Military Affairs.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 20 -- Supported by the broadsides of the Red Fleet, Soviet forces have smashed through and around immense Nazi fortifications below Leningrad for advances of up to twelve miles in five days of a furious offensive that has riddled seven enemy divisions, Moscow reported last night.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 19--Naval air forces have bombed the island of Kusaie, extending our air raiding to the heavily defended Caroline Islands for the first time. Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's headquarters announced today that Navy search planes...
