A new "streamlined" monthly bill, already used by one department store for charge accounts and scheduled for adoption by another, has been evolved "to make payment less painful to both consumer and retailer," it was said yesterday.

Mrs. Katherine Botsford, in 161 E 79th St through George F. Meyer Co; Mrs. Montgomery Hare, in 116 E 68th St; Mrs. Hester Griffin, in 400 E 59th St; George Posner, in 20 E 76th St; Mrs. Ernest Brooks, in 1160 5th Ave; Lesle C. Stillman, in 136 E 67th St; Mrs. Royden Peabody, in 60 Gramercy Park -- Douglas Gibbons Co. brokers.

Former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Tammany leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District, expressed the opinion yesterday that the meeting of the Tammany executive committee called for Saturday evening at the Hotel Biltmore was illegal and that the only legal meeting was that called by Representative James H. Fay, chairman, for Friday, Jan. 28, at the Democratic County Committee headquarters, 331 Madison Avenue.

To build for lasting peace it is essential that we develop a worldwide educational program, Pearl Buck, author, told 1,600 teachers and supervisors yesterday at a conference on world problems sponsored by the Board of Education at the Needle Trades High School.

" Typee," the Herman Melville classic based on the author's adventures among the cannibal Typees of the Marquesas Islands in 1842, will be filmed by Monogram as one of its most ambitious projects of the year. The picture will be produced and directed by George D. Green, and the story will be adapted by Jack Natteford.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 19 -- A German diplomatic plot to capitalize on the present "friction" existing between the Allied nations and the Kremlin because of Washington's and London's alleged "meddling interference" in the Russo-Polish dispute is reported in an unconfirmed dispatch to the newspaper Suisse of Geneva today from a frontier source in Basle.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Sir Samuel Hoare, British Ambassador to Spain, has received new instructions to make further representations to the Spanish Government concerning Spanish troops still remaining with the Germans on the eastern front, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden announced in the House of Commons today.
The Fourth War Loan will be truly successful to the extent that it is subscribed by Mr. and Mrs. Average American.

DETROIT, Jan. 19 -- A strike of 643 Ford Motor Company technicians, including metallurgists, chemists and physicists, started today in the Rouge and Willow Run bomber plants in a dispute over the experts' demands for union status.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The motives that inspired Pravda to publish separate peace rumors involving the British were still a mystery today to the State Department, the British Embassy and apparently even to the Soviet Embassy.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Britain's plans for post-war aviation include construction of the world's largest aircraft, the Brabazon, a 100-ton passenger and freight plane; use of a smaller transport plane, the thirty-two-ton Tudor, and a fleet of at least 2,000 planes, Lord Beaverbrook told the House of Lords today in his first speech since he took charge of plans for post-war civil aviation.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world offers a partial list of free amusements available today. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets 4, 5:30, 6:30 and 7:30 P.M.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- After leading throughout three-quarters of a hard-fought game, the highly touted St. John's University basketball team met defeat for the second time this season when Army registered a 49-to-36 triumph over the Redmen at the Military Academy today.

The railway wage dispute has been settled. The strike threat has been canceled. The railroads have been returned to their owners. The incident is officially closed. But the manner in which the President handled the dispute, and the terms on which he settled it, seem certain to have far-reaching effects on future union policies and labor relations.

In the presence of high-ranking Army officers, Maj. Gen. John L. Homer, commanding general of the New York-Philadelphia sector of the Eastern Defense Command, received the Legion of Merit Medal in a ceremony yesterday the parade ground at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn.

About the last industry that one would expect to see discriminated against in this country, in war or peace, is the printing and publishing of books. Yet according to the War Committee of the Book Publishers' Bureau, speaking for the producers of 90 per cent of the nation's printed volumes, this is happening.

The mortification of four armed thugs who discovered on ransacking the contents of a shiny station wagon the driver of which they held up early yesterday that the haul consisted of OWI overseas broadcast scripts was equaled only by a general mystification concerning the motive behind the attempt.
AN ADVANCED NAVAL BASE, in New Guinea, Jan. 12 (delayed) -- Give Joe Burk a boat and he'll set a record.

ALGIERS, Jan. 19 -- In quarters in a position to know it was indicated today that Prime Minister Churchill's meeting with Gen. Charles de Gaulle at Marrakech was considered the probable first step toward an understanding that is expected to lie somewhere between the present limited recognition of the French Committee of National Liberation and the recognition as the provisional Government of France that the Committee desires but, it is said, did not formally request.
LONDON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)--A check-up today shows that preliminary steps have been taken looking to the pledging of 236 of the 1,176 Democratic convention delegates to a fourth term for President Roosevelt.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

Existing forms of business organization whether corporations, partnerships or single proprietorships should be retained in order to avoid divorcing a business from the security afforded by the provision of the Revenue Act of 1942 permitting a two-year carry-back of net operating losses, Bernard M. Joffe of the certified public accounting firm of Bernard M. Joffe Co., told the luncheon meeting yesterday of the Downtown Textile Credit Group at the Arkwright Club.

A pickpocket attempting to flee along the subway tracks near the 103d Street station of the Broadway IRT line was killed last night by a southbound train. A companion of the dead man escaped by using the 104th Street exit to Broadway.

Coincidentally with the announcement here on Tuesday by the directors of The Associated Press of an appeal against a summary judgment filed in Federal court, President Roosevelt said at his press-radio conference in Washington that he did not think he wanted to comment on the judgment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Even though the railroads have been returned to private ownership, the seven railroad presidents whom the Federal Government summoned to run the systems remain full colonels in the Army.
By purchasing a $1,000 War Bond, Mr. and Mrs. Sydney E. Lesser of Washington Heights yesterday sent the late Lou Gehrig into the lead in the Sports Popularity Contest now in progress.

Although the War Production Board's 1944 lumber goal has not been set because of the fact that the armed forces have not as yet submitted their requirements, the industry's output will have to exceed last year's 33,000,000,000 feet, J. Philip Boyd, director of the lumber and lumber products division of the WPB, stated yesterday.

Formation of the National Association of Army and Navy Stores, to be composed of small and intermediate distributors of Government merchandise, principally textiles, will be effected in the near future, it was learned last night.

As a result of reports that heavy lend-lease shipments of raw cotton were being considered in Washington and that part might be bought in the open market, the cotton futures market yesterday moved higher. Increased trade price-fixing orders in the near-by positions encountered a scarcity of offerings.
MERCHANTVILLE, N.J., Jan. 19 (AP) -- The pastor of the Presbyterian Church in Janvier, N.J., had his name removed from the rolls of the West Jersey Presbytery today at his own request.

MOSCOW, Jan. 19 -- The magazine War and the Working Class declared today that the long-suffering peoples of Western Europe have a right to expect the prompt storming of Adolf Hitler's European Fortress and that Allied invasion troops "will not be afflicted by that slowness which, until now, has weakened the effectiveness of the operations of the Allied forces in Italy."

Six-week-old Barbara-Avis Allsop stole the show yesterday afternoon at a baby clinic at the Namm Store, Brooklyn, in cooperation with the New York City Department of Health. Barbara-Avis, who had been relaxing with her mid-afternoon bottle while her mother listened to the speakers, was chosen from the audience to be principal in a "weighing-in" demonstration directed by Geraldine Cunningham, nurse of the Health Department's Red Hook Center.

Taking issue with the Office of Price Administration, which had held that many warehouses had profited from a shortage of storage space by charging excessive fees, the Movers and Warehousemen's Association of Greater New York, Inc., announced yesterday that it had requested Daniel P. Woolley, regional OPA administrator, to make public any violations of Federal regulations.

Jimmy Herbert, Grand Street Boys veteran, the defending champion, and Joseph Francis Hall, Columbia V-12 trainee, will match strides in the 600-yard event at the anuual Metropolitan A.A.U. senior indoor track championships at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, on Saturday night.

The Women's National Book Association will hold its January meeting Tuesday at 8:15 at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street. Nina Brown Baker, author of "Juarez, Hero of Mexico," will be the chairman of the meeting, which will deal particularly with "escape" books.
MADRID, Jan. 13 (Delayed) -- Spain's trend in foreign policy away from the Axis has been matched internally by a trend away from fascism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Emphasizing the need for doing everything helpful to "the fortunes of General Eisenhower's invading army," the Office of Censorship called today for "a complete moratorium on backstairs gossip and hairline authenticity" in connection with the coming assault on Fortress Europe.

France will succeed in rehabilitating herself both socially and economically after the peace, although she will need aid and supplies badly in the first few months after withdrawal of the Nazis, Robert E. Murphy, former United States representative in North Africa and now American member of the Advisory Commission for Italy, said last night in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York had net operating earnings of $16,617,544 in 1943, excluding $4,336,114 of profits realized on sales of investment securities, it was declared yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders by W. Palen Conway, who conducted the meeting as chairman of the board.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 19 -- Continuous Allied air activity over the Aegean and Ionian Seas is part of the carefully planned strategy that authoritative sources in the Middle East believe will soon lead to the definite weakening and possible destruction of Adolf Hitler's outer defenses of southeastern Europe.
While in New York recently I was made aware of a condition which to me is deplorable, and that is a lack of appreciation of the work done by the USO clubs around the country.

MOSCOW, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A charge that the Polish Government in London "and its sympathizers" do not want to establish friendly relations between Russia and Poland was made today in the magazine War and the Working Class.

Superb music, admirable singing and a charming production were laid before a most appreciative capacity audience at Town Hall last night when the Nine O'clock Opera Company gave Mozart's comic opera, "The Marriage of Figaro."

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The Appellate Division, Third Department, referred to the Court of Appeals today the question of whether a writ of prohibition should be issued against the methods employed by George P. Monaghan, Special Prosecutor, in the selection of grand jurors for the investigation of alleged crime in Albany County.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Following are excerpts from Secretary Stimson's statement today to the Senate Committee on Military Affairs urging adoption of a National Service Act:

The most pretentious ski program ever attempted so close to New York City has been scheduled for Bear Mountain Park on Sunday, Feb. 6, by the Metropolitan Ski Jumping Council. The twenty-two clubs in the New York City Council will engage in what should develop into an interesting battle for team honors.

LYNBROOK, L.I., Jan. 19 -- Leo Santos made arrangements today with the Home Owners Loan Corporation that will prevent the eviction of himself and three other persons who were living with him at 280 Station Road, Mineola -- Mrs. Catherine Tsavalas, 105 years old; her son, Nicholas Tsavalas, and her grandson, Aristotle Tsavalas, who was crippled in an accident while in the Army.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The board of directors of The Associated Press was congratulated today by 100 editors and publishers attending a convention of the New York State Publishers Association for deciding to appeal to the United States Supreme Court from the Federal Court judgment in the Government's civil anti-trust suit against the non-profit news cooperative.

NEWTON, Iowa, Jan. 19 (AP) -- District Judge Henry N. Graven denied today a request for appointment of a receiver for the $20,000,000 Iowa Southern Utilities Company of Centerville, Iowa, but ruled invalid 39,460 shares of stock in the company held by Martha Bechtel of Davenport, Iowa.

The Chicago Tribune, one of the defendants in the Government's civil anti-trust suit against The Associated Press, said yesterday it would appeal the Federal Court judgment "because it believes it to be the worst decision that has ever been made in the history of the fight for freedom of speech and the press."

Illness prevented Thomas W. Lamont, chairman, from presiding at yesterday's annual meeting of stockholders of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., and Russell C. Leffingwell, chairman of the executive committee, occupied the chair. At last year's meeting J.P. Morgan, who died on March 13, 1943, presided.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

In a recent Sunday broadcast Mayor La Guardia promised that "Our Town" would be kept going as long as the public wanted it. Yesterday announcement was made that the revival of Thornton Wilder's Pulitzer Prize play, with a cast headed by Marc Connelly, Martha Scott and Evelyn Varden, would continue for a third week. That would bring it up to Jan. 29.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 -- War manpower officials stated today that aircraft plants in Southern California faced a possible shortage of more than 15,000 workers in the plants of five principal aircraft companies.

Jack Topping, Sonja Henie's brother-in-law, testified in downtown Traffic Court before Magistrate Harry Andrews yesterday that he lost $12,000 in checks and $500 in cash in a game of chemin de fer at a midtown hotel last Sept. 18.

The Tami Mauriello-Joe Baksi heavyweight bout of ten rounds, twice postponed, yesterday was set as a Madison Square Garden attraction on Feb. 25, it was announced by Promoter Mike Jacobs. The match was originally set for last Friday, and, when postponed because of the illness of Mauriello, was scheduled for Feb. 9.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- A bill was offered in the Legislature today to set up a court for wayward minor girls within the Magistrate's Court in New York City.

The Office of Price Administration's latest weapon against the gasoline black market -- which is to be used in New Jersey starting next Tuesday and in New York some time later -- was described yesterday as a "screening" procedure that will make the gasoline station operator responsible for all outdated or counterfeit ration coupons he accepts and also for those without the motorist's car registration number written on them.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- "We are not without hope that a favorable solution may be attained," Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden informed the House of Commons today when asked to comment on the Russian-Polish situation.

More hogs came to market on Monday than on any day in the history of the meat industry, according to reliable reports. Supplies are expected to remain super abundant for another month, and then to decline. Advantage may be taken of the temporary plenitude by serving one of these three fresh pork roasts, which are suggested by home economists of the Department of Agriculture:

An extensive selection of upholstered furniture with steel springs will be available to consumers within a month, Martin J. Bernholz, chairman of the Upholstered Furniture Joint Conference, said yesterday.

ALGIERS, Jan. 19 -- A young American from Tucson, Ariz., who became known as the greatest fighter pilot in the Mediterranean theatre, although he once had been told he would never become a fighter pilot, has flown his last mission.

Leaders of civic, educational, labor and church groups, comprising the National Federation for Constitutional Liberties, joined yesterday in urging "concrete programs of action for stopping the spread of anti-Semitism and racial hate" at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Among the 875 Army and 155 Navy casualties announced today by the War and Navy Departments were the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

Tonight's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Artur Rodzinski conducting, with Bronislaw Huberman, violinist, as assisting artist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Frances Cleveland, soprano, and H. Maurice Jacquet, composer and pianist, Carnegie Music Hall, 8:30.

The Vatican radio broadcast to Germany last night an excerpt from an address today by Pope Pius XII. He told members of the Catholic nobility in Rome that they could work for the "salvation of human society" by preserving it "from the catastrophe into which it would be guided and led by reckless adventurers and prophets with hallucinations of a vain and false future."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Secretary Ickes took luncheon with President Roosevelt today and later spent fifty minutes before the grand jury investigating the authorship of the "Harry Hopkins" letter, which Mr. Hopkins, the President's friend, and Henry A. Schweinhaut, Department of Justice investigator, have declared a forgery.

The uncensored reports sent from Madrid by Mr. Denny provide a realistic appraisal of the present situation in Spain. There can be little doubt that our State Department's policy has had an effect on this situation. It was conciliatory enough not to drive Franco into Hitler's arms and still potent enough to keep Franco from falling into Hitler's arms of his own accord.

Frank Robbins, the well-known coastal sportsman who is the new president of the New York County chapter of the Izaak Walton League of America, think that while concrete action on conservation measures and the advancement of coastal privileges cannot be taken now because of the war, this is the time to work on post-war problems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Taking note of a woman industrialist's call for business to follow her example in putting aside post-war reserves out of tax money, Secretary Morgenthau said tonight that "to advise citizens to refuse to pay taxes -- particularly in time of war -- smacks of disloyalty."

It is not surprising that the Germans are launching counter-attacks against the three bridgeheads established by British troops of General Clark's Fifth Army across the Garigliano River. Unless the banks of this stream can be cleared where it enters the Tyrrhenian Sea the whole enemy front across the peninsula is in danger.

The Rev. Melvin J. Joachim will be installed this evening as the fourth pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Mount Vernon, N.Y. He goes from the pastorate of the Presbyterian Church, Springfield Gardens, Queens, to succeed the Rev. Ernest J. Houghton.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Senator David I. Walsh, Democrat, of Massachusetts, a member of a subcommittee named to try to reach a compromise on the renegotiation provisions of the pending tax bill, said late today that he thought an agreement had almost been reached and might be concluded tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Another Senate test on the subsidy issue was assured today with the approval by the Banking and Currency Committee, 10 to 9, of the Bankhead bill which would put an end to most of the Administration's food subsidy program.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 19 -- Piccadilly, a sprinter who has been known to grow faint-hearted in the stretch, surprised more than a few at Hialeah today when he not only scored in the featured Orange Blossom Handicap at six and one-half furlongs but ploughed through very slow footing to do it.
Permanent peacetime selective service is a basis for most of the Army's post-war military planning.
LONDOn', Fridayj Jan. 21 (UP) The midnight LppZementary communtque az broadcast Jrom MozCO.O :

While a definite labor shortage in the Jersey City rail yards continued to slow the movement of coal accumulations into this city, an improvement was reported yesterday in distribution of the coal on hand to heatless buildings.

ALGIERS, Jan. 20 -- The French Committee of National Liberation at a meeting today abandoned the proposal it had adopted in December for creating a provisional government in France in favor of a procedure closely resembling that advocated by Vincent Auriol, Socialist, which has met approval among members of the Consultative Assembly here and among those resistance groups in France that have been consulted.

Gen. Isaias Medina Angarita, President of Venezuela, arrived in Washington Tuesday to be the guest of President Roosevelt. In Caracas he declared that the object of his visit is "to reaffirm the spiritual unity between Venezuela and the United States." His address to the Senate yesterday was made for that purpose.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Employes of Jack Heintz, Inc., "meant it when they asked for a chance to participate in ownership of our company," William S. Jack president of the war-busy concern, asserted today in reporting a survey showed his 7,400 "associates" ready now to toss $17,000,000 into the "Jahco" post-war operations kitty as preferred stockholders.

Ski enthusiasts will find ample opportunities to test their elementary turns and high-powered "tempos" this week-end. Snow conditions were reported as favorable, if not better, than those which greeted the large outpouring of devotees last Saturday and Sunday by observers yesterday in the Northlands.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 21 -- The Red Army, uniting two offensive fronts below Leningrad, yesterday encircled and began wiping out the Germans in the siege corridor west of the old Czarist capital, while at the southern end of a ninety-mile battle line moving toward the Baltic the Russians captured the powerful fortress of Novgorod, Moscow announced last night.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 21 -Great black thunderbirds of the Royal Air Force reopened the battle of Berlin early last night with a smashing attack on the German capital, already bombed ten times since Nov. 18.

George L. Harrison, president of the New York Life Insurance Company, announced yesterday that the company had in force insurance amounting to $7,340,581,744 under 3,178,888 policies at the close of 1943, increases of $209,099,338 in amount and 97,447 in number for the year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- C. Nelson Sparks, author of "One Man -- Wendell Willkie," expressed the opinion today that Secretary Ickes cooperated in providing him with an alleged letter by Harry L. Hopkins, the President's friend, for the purpose of showing that Mr. Willkie was a stooge "of the New Deal."

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 20 -- The evacuation of the population of San Juan, where 5,000 persons are believed to have been killed in Saturday's earthquake, is causing difficulties in neighboring cities, especially Mendoza, which has been converted into a huge hospistal and refugee camp.

International University Press, 227 West Thirteenth Street, announces publication of "War and Children," by Anna Freud and Dorothy T. Burlingham in a popular edition. The proceeds will go, as did those of the more expensive first edition, to the Foster Parents Plan for War Children to support Anna Freud's three war nurseries in England.
The Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association will mark its twenty-fifth anniversary with a war and post-war conference in Chicago during the week of June 19.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (U.P.) -- Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky defended in the Senate today the eleven years of the Roosevelt Administration and asserted that its accomplishments should point "the way to a more sympathetic and cooperative procedure in the solution of future problems.

The same Polish family name appeared on two different pages in our issue of Jan. 14. On the front page Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, Prime Minister of the Polish Government in London, was pondering the frontier crisis with Soviet Russia.

DETROIT, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The revived Red Wings, getting superlative support in the final minutes from Goalie Connie Dion, defeated the Black Hawks, 4 to 3, in a National Hockey League game tonight before 9,222 spectators. Carl Liscombe scored the winning goal in the third period.

Through an error admitted by the management, 600 seats for last nights performance of "Carmen Jones" in the Broadway Theatre at Broadway and Fifty-third Street were sold twice over with a resulting confusion that lasted for an hour and necessitated the services of a police emergency squad, patrolmen from the West Forty-fourth Street station, detectives of the Third district and members of the Fire Department's theatre division to straighten out.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Gen. Isaias Medina Angarita, President of Venezuela, who is making an official visit here was received by Congress today and, in identical addresses to the Senate and House, declared that all "available raw materials and articles of primary importance" of his country were at the command of the United Nations.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20 -- John L. Lewis held a secret meeting a fortnight ago with President William Green of the American Federation of Labor in an effort to clear away the obstacles which would delay re-admission of the United Mine Workers of America to the AFL beyond the present quarterly meeting of the executive council.
The program and the performances .given by Dr. Rodzinski and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall were uncommonly interesting and provocative.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Disavowal of its no-strike pledge was threatened today by the building and trades department of the American Federation of Labor, representing 1,500,000 building trades workers, in a protest against Government "circumvention" of the Davis-Bacon act and "violation" of a stabilization agreement between the Government and the department.

ALGIERS, Jan. 20 -- The air offensive in central Italy and particularly in the quadrangle bounded by Civitavecchia on the Tyrrhenian Sea, Perugia directly in the center of the peninsula, Avezzano on the transverse road from the Adriatic and the capital city of Rome itself continued unabated yesterday.

Food, clothing, rent and other living expenses for the woman worker of New York State are 4.6 per cent more costly than a year ago, and to provide herself with what the State Department of Labor regards as "the normal necessities of decent living at a minimum standard," the woman worker must earn $146 a month.

The announcement that Leopold Stokowski will act without pay as musical director and as conductor of symphonic concerts to be given at low prices as part of the year's program of the new City Center of Music and Drama is one of additional promise for the quality and value of the artistic services which that institution desires to give its public.

Sam Langford will be taken care of. The Boston Tar Baby, one of the most feared heavyweights early in the century, was discovered blind and indigent in a Harlem rooming house two weeks ago, and the publication of his condition in a newspaper article attracted the attention of a number of persons prominent in the business and boxing world.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 20 -- In addition to electric refrigerators, washers, radios and other pre-war household products, there will be greatly increased demand in new major appliances that were just getting started when war came, J.H. Rasmussen, commercial manager the Crosley Corporation, predicted today.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur W. Tedder, foremost Allied exponent of the combination of air and ground forces, arrived in Britain today to take over his duties as Deputy Commander in Chief of the Allied invasion forces under Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Those Senate committee amendments to the Renegotiation Act which could fairly be criticized as emasculating the law seem largely to have disappeared in the compromise, announced tentatively today. The draft has restored -- though over the protest of some important units of industry -- necessary preventives of post-war crusades against business men as profiteers in the war.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Renewed reports of excessive dry weather in parts of the winter wheat and rye territory, combined with removal of hedges on wheat attributed to mills and said to represent sales of flour to the family trade, gave the grain markets a strong undertone today on the Board of Trade.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUAITEtS IN NEW GUINEA, Fricla. y, Jan. 21 (UP) -- A oommu;iqe:

The present maternal mortality rate of 2.1 deaths a thousand births is the lowest ever recorded in New York City, and with proper maternity care, can be cut by two-thirds again, Miss Hazel Corbin, general director of the Maternity Center Association, declared yesterday at the twenty-sixth annual meeting of the organization at the Cosmopolitan Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- During the week ended Jan. 19 member bank reserve balances increased $213,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Increases in member bank reserves arose from a decrease of $234,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and an increase of $103,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit, offset in part by an increase of $4,000,000 in money in circulation, $9,000,000 in Treasury cash and $113,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

BAYONNE, N.J., Jan. 20 -- The strike of 1,000 of the 1,600 employes of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company in a dispute over seniority in promotions ended this morning. Aided by Federal and State conciliators, representatives of the Employes Association, Inc., an unaffiliated union, and the company reached a settlement at 4:30 A.M. after a series of conferences beginning yesterday afternoon.

ATHENS, Ga., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Coach Wallace Butts of the University of Georgia, whose school was fined $500 today by the Southeastern Conference for alleged use of ineligible football players last season, asserted tonight "if I hadn't used the five players the Bulldogs wouldn't have had a football team."

Having played to modest receipts during a hectic Broadway career, "Victory Belles" will shut down tomorrow night at the Ambassador. Marjorie Barkentin, who represents Henry Adrian, producer of Alice Gerstenberg's farce-comedy, confirmed the closing of the show.

Hailed as a great philanthropist, a benefactor of science, especially through his contribution to the Department of Psychiatry at New York University College of Medicine and Bellevue Hospital, Lucius N. Littauer, retired manufacturer, received yesterday the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from that university at a brief ceremony held in the amphitheatre of the Psychiatric Division of Bellevue Hospital.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 20 -- Eagle's Nest, the country estate of William K. Vanderbilt Jr., on the westerly side of Northport Harbor in Centerport, is to become a public park and museum after the death of Mr. Vanderbilt's widow, Rosamond Lancaster Vanderbilt, or after she ceases to use or occupy the property, according to provisions of his will, filed today with Surrogate Richard W. Hawkins of Suffolk County.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (U.P.) -- The Army and Navy revealed today that 1,825 new war casualties were reported during the past week, raising to 141,577 the number of American servicemen killed, wounded, missing or prisoners since Pearl Harbor.

Despite the signs of revival in some branches of the real estate market here, such as hotels, theatres, some loft buildings, and office buildings in the midtown area, there is little evidence that general recovery has set in and many difficult obstacles remain to be surmounted, Henry Bruere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank, warned last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Spar Betty Hicks, who wants to organize a Women's Professional Golfers' Association of America, said today she favored holding the meets with the men's and having a winter tour as well as a summer program.

Precision instruments valued at $50,000 and used in airplane manufacture and other phases of the war program were stolen from the office of Feuer Co., 1150 Broadway, late Wednesday night or early yesterday morning, Benjamin Feuer, an officer in the company disclosed last night.

Sentencing a meat dealer to the workhouse yesterday for violating ceiling prices, Magistrate Ambrose J. Haddock lamented that the cost of living had soared so high that even his own $10,000 salary "is almost nothing to me today and confines me to the barest necessities."

The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals cared for 210,508 animals in the New York City area during 1943 and provided special services for 10,642 horses during the same period, it was revealed last night in a report read at the organization's seventy-eighth annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria by Alexander S. Webb, president.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Prime Minister Churchill stepped into the Russo-Polish dispute today. He invited Polish Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, Foreign Minister Tadeusz Romer and Count Edward Raczynski, Polish Ambassador to London, to 10 Downing Street where he and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden reviewed recent events for about an hour.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Legislation setting up the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration was challenged and defended today as it came to the floor of the House for debate.

Eight buildings, comprising an ett.e holding in Wet Harlem. passed to new control yesterday when the Kohring Realty Company and the estate of William F. Kohring sold 3230 to 3236 Broadway, 580-82 West 130th Street and 57476 West 131st Street to a client of Fred Berger Co.

The Ducks Unlimited Quarterly, now in the process of distribution, brings the first authoritative picture of what the recent duck season was really like on a national scale. There's too much of it for a complete summary here, but it adds up to one of the oddest seasons in the memory of veteran wildfowlers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Byrd Economy Committee recommended today that the free-mailing privileges of Federal departments and agencies be abolished to eliminate "excessive use."

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 20 -- The John A. Roebling's Sons Company suspended war production today at its plant here because of a work stoppage involving the 2,700 employes. B.F. McClancy, the company's industrial relations manager, said the tie-up resulted from a "minor grievance" between the firm and nineteen employes in the aircraft department.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 20 -- Youth camps in the southern zone of France pass under the control of the Labor Ministry, Vichy announced today. This announcement comes as official confirmation that the Germans have insisted on more French labor being furnished them.

Members of the Tammany executive committee group seeking to oust Michael J. Kennedy as leader encountered yesterday another obstacle to their plan to elect Edward V. Loughlin, leader of the Fourteenth Assembly District, to succeed Mr. Kennedy, when Dennis J. Mahon, leader of the Ninth district, made known that he was a candidate for the leadership and did not intend to vote for Mr. Loughlin.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Speaker Rayburn of the House of Representatives called upon public officials, business men, labor and agriculture today to aid Congress in planning "a peace of plenty," and revealed as a step toward that goal plans for the formation of a bipartisan House committee on postwar fact-finding to gather information, recommend policy and propose legislation.

ABOARD A FRENCH WARSHIP IN THE MEDITERRANEAN, Jan. 18 (Delayed) -- In April, 1941, this correspondent fled Axis-engulfed Europe by a sea dash aboard a tiny Greek sponge- fishing caique bearing also demobilized airmen and sailors escaping to their island homes.

Directors of the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association, who also are members of the War Production Board's shoe industry advisory committee, protested yesterday against the relatively large quantities of top-grade sole leather which is being allotted to shoe repairers.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- The right of Avon Pocket-Size Books to publish the same type of books as has been put out by Pocket Books, Inc., since 1939 was upheld today in a five-to-two decision by the Court of Appeals.

Agreeing that a large number of the millions of women who have been drawn into industry by the demands of the war would seek to retain their jobs in the post-war period, a group of eight distinguished men and women discussed last night some of the problems that would have to be solved for the fulfillment of their hopes.

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 20 -- Accused of pilfering 1,000 chickens in Fairfield, Litchfield and New Haven Counties in the last six months and using their 18-month-old twins as "stage props" to avert suspicion on their forays into the poultry industry, Howard E. Hurlburt, 27, of Seymour, and his wife, Dorothy, 30, were held today in default of $5,000 bail each in the Danbury jail.

A fashionably dressed young woman who identified herself as Miss Ruth Waldo, secretary to Floyd F. Green when he was Mayor of Columbus, Ohio, appeared as a surprise defense witness yesterday in the Special Sessions trial of Aaron (Arky) Schwartz, a middle-aged former midtown night club owner.
CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 20 -- In Shanghai cynical Japanese facetiously say:
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 20 (UP)-An Allied Southeast ,Asia Command communique:

A vast post-war building boom in suburban areas with a resultant huge demand for home furnishings and expansion of retail outlets beyond city boundary lines was predicted yesterday by speakers at a luncheon meeting of the post-war planning group of the American Marketing Association at the Sheraton.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Higher prices for fruits and vegetables, particularly apples, citrus fruits and potatoes, brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of commodity prices in primary markets up 0.1 per cent during the week ended Jan. 15.
MADRID, Jan. 14 (Delayed) -- The decline of Nazi prestige in Spain and the growth of United Nations prestige is graphically apparent in the field of international information propaganda.

The arrest of five men accused of the theft of $20,000 worth of valves intended for the repair of warships here in and in other parts of the world was announced yesterday by E.E. Conroy of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The trade cooperative societies of pre-war Europe, many of which have been inactive since Nazi occupation, should be used to the utmost in the work of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, the Cooperative League of the United States of America and representatives from twenty foreign nations declared today at the end of a conference on international reconstruction.

Successful development for commercial application of a very fine viscose rayon staple fiber of the extra strength type is announced by American Viscose Corporation. The fiber is described as being as fine as silk and is for use in production of fine goods in cotton system mills and for spun silk or schappe spinners.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The critical coal shortage, seriously hampering India's war effort, has forced temporary employment of women in the mines. Leopold S. Amery, Secretary of State for India and Burma, informed the House of Commons today. Governmental prohibition of such work by women, in effect since 1937, has been suspended, he said.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Governor Dewey announced today his approval of a program under which the sixty-two cities in New York State will obtain, for this year only, $19,500,000 of revenues which would normally go into the State Treasury itself.
LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Bank of England's weekly condition statement, issued today, reported a decrease in note circulation amounting to 7,916,000 in the week ended yesterday.

In a decision handed down yesterday afternoon by the Court of Appeals at Albany, Municipal Court Justice Thomas J. Walsh, Democrat, was elected County Judge of Richmond over former County Judge Thomas F. Cosgrove, Republican and American Labor party candidate, by nine votes.

A post-graduate course for sales executives covering nearly every phase of sales promotion, personnel training and marketing, will be inaugurated on Tuesday evening, Feb. 1, at the Roosevelt by the Sales Executives Club of New York and will continue sessions through April 11.
Today's events: "Norma," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P.M.; Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Juliette Durand Texte, piano, Town Hall, 8:30.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Allied ground forces, moving up behind heavy assaults by strong forces of American heavy and medium bombers, have opened a new North Burma land front in attacks on Japanese positions in the Chindwin area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Senate Finance Committee adopted today a compromise on war contacts renegotiation which apparently went a long way toward meeting Administration objections to the renegotiation provisions in the pending tax bill.

IN the fourth century, when German barbarians were gleefully flinging themselves upon the remnants of Roman civilization, there lived a British cleric of highly unorthodox opinions. His name was Pelagius, and he preached the superior value of ethics and good manners to spiritual grace. He was a good many hundreds of years ahead of his time: the contrary opinion backed by the weighty authority of St Augustine prevailed.

Several hundred pedestrians did some quick sidestepping and then gazed in surprise and indignation as more than a score of pigeons fell dead or dying on the sidewalk at Fiftieth Street and Fifth Avenue, outside of St. Patrick's Cathedral, yesterday afternoon.

Locally caught fish arrived yesterday in Fulton Market for the first time in more than a month, when one of the boats in the Manhattan fleet docked with 12,000 pounds and another with 10,000. The first cargo consisted principally of porgies, with lesser quantities of butterfish, sea bass and fluke, while the second contained only fluke.

Plans for the functioning of a corporation to aid in the equitable distribution through recognized retail channels of Government war stocks of such goods as are usually sold by department stores and apparel specialty shops are being actively pushed by the Association of Buying Offices, it was learned yesterday.

Germany is upholding the Geneva convention for treatment of war prisoners, it was reported here yesterday by Hugo Cedergren, associate director of the World Young Men's Christian Association, who visited in November a number of German camps housing American prisoners of war.

Emphasizing that civilian textile supply this year will depend upon the size of foreign rehabilitation programs, Frank L. Walton, former director of the War Production Board's textile, clothing and leather division, predicted here yesterday that there would be a decline of about 15 per cent in civilian supply of cotton textiles in 1944, compared with last year.

A new one-story taxpayer build-I ing at 671 Anderson Avenue, Cliff-I side Park, N. J., has been pur-] chased by the 671 Anderson Ave-I nue Corporation for cash over aI mortgage of $25,000 held by an! insurance company. It is on a plot l 52 by 258 feet and includes a parking lot, 101 by 125 feet.

The petroleum industry is producing at virtual capacity and could not refine more than it does now even if production could be stepped up, Dr. Robert E. Wilson, president of the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company, told 350 members of the Propeller Club of the Port of New York yesterday at the club's monthly luncheon-meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Shampan Shampan, architects and A.B. and B.B. Block have purchased a plot 260 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Wetherole Street and Sixty-sixth Avenue, in Forest Hills, Queens. The plot was assembled from three separate owners, Charles Balletto, John Lehto and the Warnell Realty Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The air attacks against the German fighter aircraft factories a week ago were even greater victories than had been realized at the time Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, said at a news conference today. It seemed certain, he added, that production at these plants had been eliminated for a matter of months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Hope that Soviet Russia would return to membership in the International Labor Office was expressed today by Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins and Carter Goodrich, chairman of the Governing Board of the ILO, after a conference with President Roosevelt.

The bobby pin situation -- regarded anxiously by a considerable army of wispy-haired American women -- has taken little turn for the better, in spite of a recent easing of governmental restrictions on use of metal for this purpose.

On the motion of the Federal Government for a summary judgment without full trial, a Federal court in this district recently handed down a 2-to-1 decision in a case which raised the question whether The Associated Press, a non-profit cooperative news agency, has been guilty of violating the anti-trust laws.

Merchandise of American origin accumulating in various parts of the world may be returned to this market free of duty unless timely preventative measures are taken, Frederick K. Barbour, president of the American Tariff League, warned last night at the fifty-ninth annual meeting of the group at the Union League Club.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- Allied bombers and fighters destroyed or damaged forty-nine Japanese planes Tuesday and Wednesday in blows against the two major centers of enemy air power at Wewak, New Guinea, and Rabaul, New Britain, it was announced today.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Fantastic prices were paid today at the auction of household articles and objects of art from the home of Alfred and Nancy Oakes de Marigny.

More than 99 per cent of all the vast office, shop and studio space in the fourteen buildings of Rockefeller Center are now under lease, Hugh S. Robertson, executive manager of the midtown amusement and office project, announced yesterday.

Consolidated net sales of Gar Wood Industries, Inc., for the fiscal year ended with October were $48,438,726, an increase of $10,542,931, or 27.8 per cent, over the previous sales record of $37,895, 795 made during the preceding fiscal year, Glen A. Bassett, president, disclosed in the annual report issued yesterday to stockholders.

All Russia is rejoicing in a double victory of special significance to the revived Russian sentiment of history and tradition. On special orders from Marshal Stalin the victory guns of Moscow have boomed again to announce the capture of Novgorod, which was not only a major German stronghold for the defense of the Baltics but also the original semi-legendary Russian capital.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Alan Ford shattered two national swimming records today in a special time trial sanctioned by the Connecticut A. A. U., but, officials said, because of a misunderstanding on the part of the timers, one was nullified.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Agreement to provide an additional $35,000,000 in bond issue funds for post-war public housing projects in New York City was indicated here today. Identical measures were introduced in the Senate by Thomas C. Desmond and Frederic R. Coudert Jr., and in the Assembly by MacNeil Mitchell.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Office of Price Administration acted today to plug another loophole in its fight against high liquor prices, with an order placing all domestic sales of imported liquors under price control. Today's order applies principally to rum from: Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands and covers sales to importers, F.O.E. port of arrival, and sales by non-importing domestic bottlers which were not covered in previous regulations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Office of War Information classed accidents in war plants today as "a major production and manpower problem" as it reported that deaths and injuries on the job were causing the loss of 270,000,000 man-days a year or the equivalent of the withdrawal of 900,000 workers for a full year from the production lines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Subpoenaed as a witness before the special House Committee appointed to investigate the Federal Communications Commission, J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, declined today to answer almost every question put to him on the ground that a written "directive" from the President barred him from discussing matters relative to the national security.

EDGEWATER, N.J., Jan. 20 -- A crisis apparently was reached tonight in the relations between the management of the Ford Motor Company's assembly plant here and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, Local 906, as a result of the management's refusal to dismiss two employes whom the union has suspended.

The financial districts of New York City will be mobilized to support the Red Cross 1944 War Fund under the leadership of Henry C. Brunie, chairman of the board and president of the Empire Trust Company of 120 Broadway, it was announced yesterday by Eugene W. Stetson, chairman of the Manhattan Commerce and Industry Committee for the campaign.

New York's basketball fans will have an opportunity to see one of the strongest court teams in the country in action on Wednesday night, when the District Office quintet of the United States Coast Guard opposes the All-Star West Point post team at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 20 -- Despite its compliance in 1942 with a War Labor Board maintenance-of-membership directive, the basic policy of the corporation still opposed membership or non-membership in a labor union as a condition of the "right to work," Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, declared in an address here tonight.
ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- The hospital at Camp Shanks has, of all things, a maternity case.

The Maurella Products Company, manufacturer of cosmetics and toilet preparations, has leased the entire two-story building at 92 to 100 Varick Street, facing the Holland Plaza, through Cushman Wakefield.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A meeting of Senate Republicans today, heralded in advance as a test of strength of the leadership of Senator McNary of Oregon, now absent because of illness, resulted in endorsement of arrangements he made while active in the leadership.

The adoption of a national service act would bring victory sooner at less cost in lives and money, Warren H. Atherton, national commander of the American Legion, said last night in a debate with James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

ALGIERS, Jan. 20 -- British troops of the Allied Fifth Army who crossed the Garigliano River under a smoke screen have captured the villages of Sujo, Tufo and Argento and are within the outskirts of Minturno on both the south and east sides. The Germans are fighting back furiously and a tremendous artillery duel is raging throughout the battle area.

Representatives of Government, industry and labor, speaking at a dinner of the National Industrial Conference Board at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, agreed last night if this nation is to avoid dictatorship or some form of the corporative State after the war it would be necessary for labor and capital to establish their relations on a voluntary basis, with the Government acting as umpire only in exceptional circumstances.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The security markets here remained generally quiet today. Gilt-edge issues were dull, but home rails hardened, London Midland Scottish and Southern deferred recovering some ground.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Agreement on a combined Federal and State voting program for service men was reached late today by the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections, and plans were made immediately to take it to the floor next week as a substitute for the original Green-Lucas bill which was defeated before the Christmas recess.

Preparations of investors for heavy subscriptions in the Fourth War Loan drive were reflected in this week's Federal Reserve figures, covering the week ended Wednesday. Demand deposits in the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Reserve System in New York City jumped $419,000,000 in the week to $13,090,000,000, highest since the beginning of the Third War Loan drive on Sept. 9.

A Chinese Government spokesman said yesterday that a ban on gambling, dancing, card playing and "other forms of pleasure" had been imposed in Chungking so that "more resources and energy may be diverted to constructive channels," the Chungking radio reported.

A promise to keep the cost of feminine adornment within reason even though such items do not affect the cost of living was given yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, as his legal staff prepared to argue a case in Federal Court today against nine concerns accused of black market dealings in materials essential to the manufacture of vanity cases and costume jewelry.
ALGIERS, Jan. 20 -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A code of procedure designed to make both military and civilian officials more circumspect in discussing the problems of war production and employment has been worked out by the Office of War Information with high officials of the Army, Navy and other Government agencies, Elmer Davis, OWI director, stated tonight.
The board of directors of Swift Co. declared yesterday at their meeting in Chicago a special dividend of 40 cents, payable on March 1, and a quarterly dividend of 40 cents to be paid on April 1.
