CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Serious difficulty in handling the accumulated supply of hogs continued here today and another big holdover was indicated. Salable receipts of 128,000 head at twelve mid-western markets were reported, the heaviest Thursday run this season. The total for the week to date was 604,000 head, compared with 601,000 a week ago and 251,000 a year ago.

It is a simple requirement of justice, not to speak of gratitude, to provide adequate mustering-out pay for the members of the armed forces. This obviously makes far more sense, both from the standpoint of the veteran and of the national economy, than a bonus or "adjusted compensation" paid out years later.

In the voluminous discussion of the Russo-Polish boundary question two important points have been for the most part overlooked in this country. First, neither the Paris Peace Conference nor the Conference of Ambassadors ever proposed that the territory east of the Curzon Line be awarded to Russia.

SAN GABRIEL, Calif., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Over the same picturesque country club course where he took up golf seriously after laying aside his famous tennis racquet, Ellsworth Vines today equaled the links record of 64, seven under par, to lead gross scorers in a one-day, eighteen-hole pro-amateur best-ball tournament.

The Association of Colleges and Universities of the State of New York, which closed its annual two-day meeting here yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore, adopted resolutions endorsing Federal and New York State plans for post-war education and outlined certain principles and procedures, which, in the opinion of the college presidents present, would help avoid pitfalls and assure maximum results.

The principal commercial banks throughout the country having Government war loan deposit accounts were notified late yesterday by the Treasury that it will make further withdrawals from these accounts on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.

TRENTON, Jan. 20 -- The draft of a new State Constitution, prepared by an unofficial, all-Republican committee of legislators, was handed to Gov. Walter E. Edge at the Capitol today by the Senate President, Howard Eastwood of Burlington County, and the Assembly Speaker, Dominic A. Cavicchia of Essex County.

Stockholders of the American Products Corporation voted yesterday at a special meeting at Wilmington, Del., to increase the authorized capital from 1,000,000 shares to 1,500,000 shares, of $1 par value. All but 21,530 of the previously authorized 1,000,000 shares are outstanding.

With the death of J. McKeen Cattell a man long a pioneer and a leader in psychology has passed. It is hard to realize that when he returned to this country in 1887 after studying in Germany, working in Wundt's famous laboratory and lecturing at the University of Cambridge there was no chair of psychology in any of our universities.

SEARCY, Ark., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Miss Vivien Kellems of Westport, Conn., manufacturer who disclosed in Kansas City that she did not pay her Dec. 15 income tax because she needed to set aside postwar reserves, issued a statement tonight defending her action and accusing the Government of squandering billions on "boondoggling."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Senator Hugh Butler, Republican, of Nebraska. renewed his attacks on government spending in Latin America today and contended that the Administration, in seeking to show that he was "95 per cent wrong" in his estimate of $6,000,000,000 of good-will outlays, cited figures relating to a different period.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20 -- Air Current, now owned by Allen T. Simmons, carried a Canadian rider as well as Canadian hopes when he got up to win a nose decision today in as tight a finish as the Hialeah Park meeting has seen. In the saddle was Ted Atkinson, Canadian-born but adopted as their own by Florida racegoers.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 -- Producing Artists Corporation, the recently formed David L. Loew and Arthur S. Lyon production unit, has joined with Boris Morros for the making of "Of Thee I Sing."

Sticking to the determination reached last week to make no compromise with Communists, leaders of the right wing of the American Labor party rejected yesterday a proposal of Sidney Hillman, chairman of the political committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, to give Communists minority representation on the State committee and State executive committee of the party, now controlled by the right wing.

Anyone who may have doubts about how becoming the new spring hats might be to her particular type of face or favorite hair-do could quickly forget them after seeing the new collection by House of Caesar presented at luncheon yesterday at the Plaza's Persian Room.
Precious-stone jewelry from private owners, including Miss Rose de Rose, Southampton, L.I., was sold yesterday for $62,257 at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc.

Bishop William T. Manning was re-elected as president of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society yesterday afternoon at the 113th annual meeting at 580 Fifth Avenue. Vice presidents elected were James W. Gerard, Bishop Charles K. Gilbert, the Rev. Thomas McCandless, rector of St. Michael's Church; the Rev. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Parish, and Thomas S. McLane.

The three-story building at 138-142 West Forty-third Street, near Times Square, formerly occupied by Schrafft's, has been purchased by Paramount Caterers from the Greenwich Savings Bank. Improvements, including interior alterations and sandblasting, are being made.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Wherever there are women workers in numbers, particularly in industries where they have never worked before, there should be women personnel directors and counselors, the Federal Women's Bureau asserted today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Wherever there are women workers in numbers, particularly in industries where they have never worked before, there should be women personnel directors and counselors, the Federal Women's Bureau asserted today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Mrs. Adele Williams, wife of Frank Starr Williams, an attache of the State Department, died tonight in St. Luke's Hospital of a bullet wound inflicted, under strange circumstances, by a mysterious woman in Mrs. Williams' hotel apartment last night.

TO most folks curling is a very mysterious operation which women perform with their hair. But to such persons as Ford Frick, the president of the National League, curling also is a very engrossing game, although most sports fans wouldn't be able to differentiate between a bonspiel and a skip. In brief, this ancient Scottish pastime could be the most secret of secret weapons for all the general public knows about it.

Active selling by New Orleans operators combined yesterday with commission-house liquidation to send the cotton market to the day's lowest levels toward the close of trading after an early display of moderate strength on trade price fixations in the near March position.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 20 -- The presence last night of Constantine A. Oumansky, Soviet Ambassador at an official reception attended by Carlos de Lima Cavalcanti, Brazilian Ambassador, was the main topic of conversation in diplomatic circles today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (U.P.) -- American citizens of Japanese descent will become subject to call for military duty at an early date, the War Department said tonight.

" Higher and Higher," an RKO musical based on the Rodgers and Hart stage success, will open this morning at the Palace. Produced and directed by Tim Whelan, the picture is the first starring vehicle for Frank Sinatra. Co-starred are Michele Morgan and Jack Haley, with Marcy McGuire, the dancing team of Paul and Grace Hartman, Barbara Hale, Leon Errol and Dooley Wilson among the featured players.

In his statement before the Senate Committee on Military Affairs Secretary Stimson met and in our judgment answered persuasively all of the principal arguments that have been made against the enactment of a National War Service Act.

New York City, recognized as the forty-ninth State" in the War Production Board's national salvage structure, has sent to the war factories since Pearl Harbor more than 1,000,000 tons of waste paper and 900,000 tons of iron and steel scrap, according to a report made yesterday by Frank D. March, city salvage director, on the two years' activities of the WPB-Civilian Defense Volunteer Office salvage division.

While Thomas Cradock Hughes, Acting District Attorney of Brooklyn, awaited yesterday official notification for the transfer of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter from the custody of the Federal Government to a cell in the death house at Sing Sing Prison, papers were served on the Brooklyn prosecutor indicating that one of Lepke's co-defendants, Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss, would seek a new trial because of the alleged discovery of new evidence.

Sales to individual residents of New York State in the Fourth War Loan drive have amounted so far to $85,800,000, Nevil Ford, executive manager of the War Finance Committee for New York, said yesterday in the first announcement of sales figures for the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Aroused by a reference to "political witch hunts of the anti-trust variety," the Department of Justice said today it would protest to the Office of War Information over a slip in the official speech clearance machinery.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Plans are well advanced within the War Production Board to lift the ban slightly on the manufacture of civilian goods in small shops and factories for the use of idle and excess metals only.

Our daylight attacks on the source of German air power in the towns of Oschersleben, Brunswick and Halberstadt on Jan. 11 represented the first deep penetration into Germany by American air forces since the costly bombardment of Schweinfurt ball-bearing plant on Oct. 14, 1943.
The merging of the War and Navy Departments into a single "Department of War" are among the many post-war military reforms now being considered.
President First National Bank, Captain 4th War Loan Team No. 9

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 20 -- To provide educational facilities for returning war veterans, Yale University plans to establish an Institute of Collegiate Study for Ex-Service Men after the war, President Charles Seymour announced in his annual report, made public today.

More than 500 owners and managers of motion-picture theatres in the metropolitan area will attend an "appreciation breakfast" in connection with the March of Dimes" this morning in the Astor Hotel as guests of Nicholas M. Schenck, chairman, and the executive committee of the industry's drive to aid infantile paralysis victims, which begins on Monday.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Another battle in the Legislature on the question of reducing the legal voting age from 21 to 18 appeared likely tonight as Assemblyman Irwin D. Davidson disclosed that he would re-introduce a bill amending the State Constitution along these lines.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin has reduced the assessed valuation on the New York Trust Building at 100 Broadway from $7650,000 in 1941-42 and $7,475,000 in 1942-43 to $6,600,000 for each year. G. Irwin Kyle, vice president of the Cruikshank Company, testified for the owner and Raymond Ryan for the city.

Since the war began the number of women engaged in pottery making has nearly doubled. Here and in other parts of the country they are making decorative and useful articles of glazed clay, which replace metal items ranging from kitchen pots to costume jewelry.

ORAN, Algeria, Jan. 15 (Delayed) -- A gradually rising moslem movement to unify Tunisia, Algeria and Morocco and to form a Western Arab empire known to the natives as "Moghrib," which existed loosely before European colonization, has been detected here by Allied officials whose business it is to observe such developments.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- British coastal guns, firing at a range of about twenty miles, sank one of the largest German merchantmen in a large convoy creeping through the English Channel and seriously damaged another early this morning in a two-hour shelling that brought a taste of things to come to the war-hardened Channel coast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Modification of the reorganization plan for the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company to permit early dividends on the common stock and equal payments on the debt-retirement fund was asked today of the Interstate Commerce Commission by holders of adjusted mortgage bonds headed by Darragh A. Park.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Jan. 22 (AP) -- One hundred and sixty Japanese troops, apparently bent on reinforcing the besieged defenders of Madang, New Guinea, were killed when speedy boats caught them in their barges sneaking down the coast Tuesday night, Allied headquarters announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- German U-boat commanders have resumed the practice of taking prisoner the senior officers of merchant vessels sunk, the War Shipping Administration reported today.

Retail trade continued active here this week. An average increase of about 8 per cent over the like period of last year was estimated for department stores. Main floor activity was brisk, but volume in most soft good lines was well maintained.
A BOMBER BASE IN ENGLAND, Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- Most of the American airmen who came back from Brunswick and Oschersleben called it "another Schweinfurt."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Women have a large stake in the plans to broaden the Social Security Act under the Wagner-Murray-Dingell bill.

The city's banks and trust companies, numbering more than 600, pledged yesterday their all-out support for the waste paper salvage drive. Paul Zeckhausen, War Production Board salvage director, announced the appointment of Frank Houston, president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, as chairman of the bankers' committee, and he has agreed to study carefully every possible means of recovering every bit of waste paper from the city's financial institutions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The House Committee on Rules rejected late today a resolution designed to force members of the House to go on record for or against a combined Federal and State voting program for absentee soldiers similar to one recommended to the Senate by its Committee on Privileges and Elections.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The American offer of good offices, along with Great Britain, in an adjustment between Russia and Poland of the Polish boundary dispute has not yet been accepted by the Soviet Government, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today.

The city police force apparently is one service for which the current acute manpower shortage cannot be remedied by the appointment of more women. With the Police Department 3,221 short of its normal complement, and with every member of the force re quired to serve overtime, it became known yesterday that there is little likelihood of an increase in the number of policewomen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The validity of the measure setting up the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration was defended in the House today by Representative Albert Gore, Democrat, of Tennessee.

Nine convicted bookmakers, one arrested thirteen times, one eight times, got a "work or jail" decree before Magistrate Charles Solomon in the Flatbush Court in Brooklyn yesterday, when they came up for sentence.

It is now definite that Mary Jane Welsh will have one of the important roles in Alfred Bloomingdale's forthcoming musical production, "Allah, Be Praised!" Contracts were signed yesterday, it was announced. Miss Welsh, who recently withdrew from "Marianne," which closed its pre-Broadway tour in Washington last Saturday, was last seen hereabouts in "Let's Face It!"

Mrs. Velvalee Dickinson, 50 years old, was arrested and later held in bail of $25,000 yesterday on charges of violating the censorship code through the alleged use of a code based on the names of antique dolls, on which she is a recognized authority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Precautionary measures to insure that the limited supply of work gloves available reach war-production plants where they are most needed, were taken by the War Production Board today. To eliminate waste and over-buying, the war agency orders all war industries requiring work gloves in their operations to file Form PO-1A applications for preference rating in procuring work gloves.

A property in the financial district has been added by Charles F. Noyes to his personal realty investments through the purchase of the ten-story building at 40 to 44 Pine Street, near William Street, from the Mary A. Hoyt estate. The building, for many years the home of Hallgarten Co., is on a plot 71 by 61 feet and contains 35,000 square feet of space.

An improved supply of better quality wool-content blankets will be available to retailers for 1944 merchandising, it was indicated yesterday at a forum of sellers and buyers conducted by the Linens and Domestics Buyers' Club of Metropolitan New York in the Advertising Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Representative James P. O'Connor of Montana, a member of the Public Lands Committee chided the Navy Department today because it had not brought condemnation proceedings against lands owned by the Standard Oil Company of California in the Elk Hills Petroleum Reserve, and accused the department of ignoring a Presidential directive for such proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The War Frauds Unit of the Criminal Division of the Department of Justice is investigating Camp Shanks, a military installation at Orangeburg, N.Y., it was learned today. At the same time the House Military Affairs Committee disclosed it would start public hearings Thursday into alleged irregularities in the camp's management.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 21 (AP) -- German propagandists admitted today that the Reich's war production had shrunk to a point at which fighting on the Eastern Front and submarine warfare has been affected, although they claimed such setbacks were temporary.
LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 22 -- Allied air power has struck two shattering blows at Hitler's European fortress in almost continuous operations from Britain since early Thursday evening.
LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 22 (AP) -- An Allied Air communique, issued early today:

ALGIERS, Jan. 21 -- British units of the Allied Fifth Army, having captured Minturno, slugged their way to the outskirts of Castelforte, while Gen. Alphonse-Pierre Juin's French forces around Sant'Elia thrust across the upper reaches of the Rapido River to take Mount Il Lago, five miles north of Cassino, and thus threatened to turn the northern flank of the German Gustav Line.
Marshall M. MacLeod, assistant manager of the Manhattan ordinary agency of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, has been promoted to manager of the Brooklyn ordinary agency.

A committee will be appointed by the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A. to discuss problems associated with proposed changes in the style limitation order of the War Production Board, L-224, according to Harry A. Cobrin, secretary, following a meeting of the board of directors at the organization's headquarters yesterday.
WASHINTGON, Jan. 21 -- The Office of Price Administration issued today its long-awaited schedule of maximum prices for fresh vegetables at all levels, except for sale by retailers.

Post-war responsibilities of advertising and methods by which the trade can discharge them will be discussed at the fortieth annual meeting and second war advertising conference and exhibit of the Advertising Federation of America which will be held in Chicago from June 4 to June 7.

TORONTO, Jan. 21 (Canadian Press) -- The National Hockey League's board of governors emerged from closed sessions tonight to announce that Stanley Cup play-off dates have been decided, that a dispute between the Bruins and Canadiens over the purchase price of Goalie Bert Gardiner has been resolved and that the question of appointing a full-time league statistician will be discussed at the annual meeting next May.

DETROIT, Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- Slowly and methodically Grace Buchanan-Dineen, a confessed Nazi spy, traced in Federal Court today operations of a German espionage ring, giving detailed testimony on which the Government hopes to obtain convictions and thirty-year prison sentences for two of her alleged conspirators.

ALGIERS, Jan. 21 -- That the intention of Allied air power in the Mediterranean is to knock out airfields around Rome and cut off supply routes feeding the Eternal City was emphasized again yesterday, when the pattern of the attack by Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Fifteenth Air Force was nearly identical with that of the day before.

TEX O'ROURKE is one of those fabulous characters whose lives sound like incredible movie script. He has been a messenger for the Texas Rangers, a Wild West show performer, a boxer, a trainer for Jess Willard, a sports promoter, a writer, a painter, a lecturer and, for the lack of a better descriptive phrase, a soldier of fortune.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans announced today they had recaptured Jajce, their capital, which Axis troops had entered nine days ago. The Partisans added they had ripped through enemy lines into the railway city of Tuzla, in a sudden counter offensive against strong German forces in Bosnia.
J.F. Vallet has been named representative of the American Brake Shoe Company for Argentina, Chile, Paraguay and Uruguay, with headquarters in Buenos Aires.

New corporate and local government financing was sharply curtailed here this week while investment bankers were devoting their energies to the Fourth War Loan drive, which started Tuesday. Only two issues of bonds aggregating $5,725,000 were marketed; one before the drive began and the other during the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Alexander Waigandt of Astoria, L.I., a 19-year-old purser, who risked his life and helped save the Liberty ship Daniel Huger from destruction, received the Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Despite reduced receipts of hogs today, accumulated supplies resulted in 10,000 head of farmer-owned hogs remaining unsold at the end of trade. The War Food Administration reported that about 700,000 hogs had been received at the twelve major Midwestern markets this week, causing serious congestion all week at some points.

Every little while a sign floats up from the book reviewer's page timidly suggesting that perhaps there have been too many war books. Now and then a book reviewer will actually put that thought into words.

A search was being conducted last night for Edward Magruder Jones, a 15-year-old schoolboy who disappeared early Tuesday morning after losing his wallet containing $55, including $35 that belonged to his school club, of which he was treasurer.
PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A Japanese cargo-transport vessel was damaged and two American planes were lost in new raids in the invasion-marked Marshall Islands, Fleet Headquarters announced today.

MIAMI, Jan. 21 -- The basis upon which State labor restrictive laws will be appealed to the United States Supreme Court was discussed here today by Joseph A. Padway, general counsel to the American Federation of Labor.

Support for the current drive of the United Steelworkers of America to increase steel wages was pledged yesterday by the national executive board of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, which asserted that the "fight of the steelworkers is the fight of every working man and woman in America."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A good chance that the Office of Price Administration will suspend temporarily the rationing of canned vegetables in the near future is seen by canners who have come here to confer with governmental officials concerning the glutted condition of the canned vegetable market.
BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- Control of the Boston Braves funneled tonight from a syndicate into the hands of three Boston contractors.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- In a twenty-one page report following an eighteen-month investigation of charges of labor racketeering on the $300,000,000 New York City Aqueduct project in the Hudson Valley, a special grand jury of the Orange County Supreme Court called upon the Legislature today to adopt anti-racket laws to protect labor union members from exploitation by officials of their own unions.
LONDON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

" Kings of the Ring," a feature-length film compilation of scenes from famous prize fights, with a narration written and spoken by Nat Fleischer, will start an engagement this morning at the World. Included are highlights of boxing championships from 1907 through 1940, with Jack Dempsey, Gene Tunney, Joe Louis, John L. Sullivan, James J. Corbett, Jess Willard, Max Schmeling, Max Baer and others.

It's still a good idea to go to the man who makes them when seeking advice on the care or any of the many implements made scarce by the war. That's why these tips on how to look after old fishing tackle, suggested by Heddon, are relayed to you as sound.

The readers of our metropolitan press are accustomed to look to it for a consistent and able defense of the constitional freedom of the press. They must be all the more perplexed, therefore, by the readiness of THE NEW YORK TIMES and other papers of national circulation to endorse the proposed violation of another constitutional freedom -- that of the person.

Additional speakers at the forum of the New York Newspaper Women's Club tomorrow evening at Town Hall are Henry J. Taylor, Scripps-Howard correspondent who has just returned from Europe, and Paul Manning, Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent, who has made several bombing missions over Berlin and has just returned to this country.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- With the intention of "taking the judiciary out of politics" and averting Aurelio cases, the Westchester County Bar Association will conduct plebiscites on the qualifications of candidates for county judicial offices, according to an amendment to the association's constitution announced today.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Jan. 22 (UP) -- A communique:

ALGIERS, Jan. 21 -- The tactical air force whose medium, light and fighter bombers will cooperate with the Fifteenth Air Force in intensifying the Mediterranean campaign against Germany will be headed by Maj. Gen. John K. Cannon, it was announced tonight by Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, commander of Allied air forces in this theatre.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Secretary Hull renewed his charge of "unfair" when asked to comment today on the new attack made by Senator Hugh Butler, Republican, of Nebraska, on Government spending in Latin America.
It has been said that about half the subscribers to War Savings Bonds have been prompted primarily by patriotism. This is an admirable record.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 21 -- Willkie sentiment is again stronger in Connecticut, according to statements made here this evening after a closed meeting of forty Republican men and women of prominence, but none of whom are party leaders at present.

A "style show" of safety work suits for women in war plants and a Civilian Volunteer Defense Office film on child care were featured last evening at a meeting of a hundred members of the United Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultural Implement Workers, Local 259, at 709 Eighth Avenue.
Yesterday's Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 21 -- The Foreign Ministry announced today that the Government was actively investigating a complaint received from the British Government to the effect that a pro-Axis spy ring was operating in Argentina and added that "some persons" already had been arrested.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Soon after Harry Hopkins, confidante of President Roosevelt, appeared today before a grand jury, obviously to denounce as a forgery the "Hopkins letter" relating to Wendell L. Willkie's candidacy for President, George N. Briggs, suspended aide of Secretary Ickes, wired from New York to Henry A. Schweinhaut, special assistant attorney general, that he would voluntarily appear at the Department of Justice on Monday.

THEY are taking up a fund for Sam Langford, the old Boston Tar Baby, who once spotted Jack Johnson forty-five pounds yet managed to stay fifteen rounds with him. Sam is both blind and broke, so it's nice to know that he'll be taken care of. Sam deserves well of his countrymen, for he fought many a good fight for their amusement in the days when purses weren't very large.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The country's gold production in 1943 fell 61 per cent because of the war, and Utah jumped from fourth to first place among the States because of its copper mines, which produce huge quantities of ore containing gold as well as copper.

Taking "On to Victory" as the theme for its eleventh annual benefit dance and entertainment, the Kosciuszko Foundation presented last night a polka military ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event, through its decor and varied program of divertissements, accented a wartime keynote of United Nations amity, in particular the close ties between Poland, Great Britain and the United States.

The cotton futures market made moderate gains yesterday as covering operations by locals combined with continued trade price-fixing in the near-by positions to bring about an upswing near the close of trading. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures advanced as much as 8 to 10 points early in the session, but final quotations were only 3 to 7 points higher than the previous close.

Plans for the creation of about 100 emergency stockpiles of coal throughout the city to supply consumers buying in 50 and 100 pound lots were announced by City Fuel Administrator Edwin A. Salmon yesterday following a meeting of dealer and consumer representatives with city officials in the Municipal Building.

The Democratic majority of the City Council endorsed yesterday Mayor La Guardia's contention that the State's proposal to allocate $13,500,000 of its revenues for the next fiscal year to the city falls far short of meeting municipal budget requirements.
The creation of a civilian commission to study all aspects of post-war military organization is considered essential by many Washington observers to any reasoned program of military reform.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 -- Claudette Colbert, currently in the David O. Selznick picture, "Since You Went Away," on loan from Paramount, is scheduled to return to her home studio in time for another co-starring role with Fred MacMurray.

The Bayonne Opera House, a three-story building on a plot 100 by 160 feet at 583-89 Avenue C, Bayonne, N.J., has been sold by the Victory Theatre Corporation (Philip Stein, president) to the G. S. Amusement Corporation.
Alfred R. Pastel, in 1112 Park Ave through Rossbach Associates.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Twelve more Japanese ships have been sent

When citizens on the Western Seaboard speak of the Pacific campaign as "our war," as they habitually do, they do not mean that the war with Japan is peculiarly America's war. As many boys from the West are battling in Italy and swelling the invasion forces in England as are fighting in the Pacific theatre.
NEWBURGH, Jan. 21 -- Here is an abstract of the report by the Orange County extraordinary grand jury on the labor-union situation at the Delaware River Water Supply project:

AT A YUGOSLAV PARTISAN REFUGEE CAMP, in the Middle East, Jan. 18 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- A German bullet winged Marshal Tito in the upper left arm but failed to prevent the commander of the Yugoslav Partisans from leading his forces out of a trap set by 35,000 enemy troops in the mountains of Montenegro last June, a wounded guerrilla leader who had participated in the battle said today.

Public leaders were urged yesterday "to take steps to endow the projected post-war world organization with responsibilities that are curative and creative, not merely repressive," in a statement made public by the Commission on a Just and Durable Peace of the Federal Council of Churches.
LONDON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded:

Awaiting announcement of plans for the disposal of the Government's stock pile of approximately 330,000,000 pounds of foreign wool, principally from Australia, owned by the Defense Supplies Corporation, the wool and woolen industries are in practical agreement upon the following points:

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 21 -- Headed by Mar-Kell of the Calumet Farm, the best mare in the country in the opinion of many, the Evening Handicap will be run at Hialeah Park tomorrow with eight named overnight. Certain to be the favorite, the popular Mar-Kell by no means is so certain to be the winner.

It begins to look as though fighting for one's country would not be regarded this year as a reason for taking citizens' votes away. Seemingly decisive action was reported yesterday. The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections has voted 12 to 2 to accept the amended Green-Lucas bill for service balloting under Federal supervision.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, warned the United States Conference of Mayors today that the country was "coming into a period in which there may well be a certain amount of idle manufacturing facilities, idle materials and scattered pockets of temporarily unemployed men and women."

Judge George D. Donnellan in General Sessions yesterday sentenced Private Allen Berntson, 34 years old, formerly of Fairbanks, Alaska, to a Sing Sing term of eighteen months to three years for the theft of $10,000 cash and $15,000 in furs from Alvin L. Kaye, head of a fur trading corporation in Fairbanks.

Federal and State agencies are using all the arguments at their command to encourage people to eat what it is plain from recent surveys many of them don't eat --a good breakfast. Now the Community Service Society lends its hand in the most recent issue of its publication, "Nutrition Notes."

War bond sales to individuals in New York City since the start of the Fourth War Loan campaign had reached $79,937,800 up to yesterday, representing 11.4 per cent of the city's $698,500,000 quota. By coincidence sales for the entire State were also 11.4 per cent of the quota, amounting to $104,300,000.

EDGEWATER, N.J., Jan. 21 -- W.K. Edmunds, manager of the Ford Motor Company's assembly plant here, came to the defense today of two employes who contend they were expelled by the plant's CIO union, in a move to get them dismissed from their jobs, because they were doing more work than their fellow test drivers.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Don Meade said today he would file application this spring for a jockey's license, and was hopeful that one would be granted.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Allied ground forces, expanding their foothold on the Mayu Peninsula of southwestern Burma, have captured new Japanese positions near Buthedaung in slashing hand-to-hand battles, an Allied southeast India communique announced today.

Excessive encroachment of the power of centralized government into private affairs, under the guise of idealistic social planning, is a danger against which the United States must stand on guard in the generation that follows the termination of the war, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, declared last night at the annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of the New York State Bar Association.

ALGIERS, Jan. 21 (AP) -- One of the war's most persistent rumors -- a visit by a German mission headed by Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop to North Africa to discuss peace terms -- has been in circulation here for the last two months.
LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The capture of Mga was part of a new break-through on a thirty-mile front from the Neva River southeast to the town of Venyagolova.

For a long time the British were perforce officially tolerant of the "non-belligerency" of Spain. Britain was so weak and so preoccupied with other more urgent problems, and Spain was so vulnerable to Axis attack, that it was considered the better part of valor in Downing Street to turn a blind eye to much that was being done and said on the Iberian Peninsula.

Wing Comdr. J. Rossie-Brown, staff chaplain to the RAF training units in Canada, will preach tomorrow at the 4:30 P.M. vesper service in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, and also at 8 P.M. at the annual "Scotch Night Service" in the Second, formerly the Scotch Presbyterian Church, Ninety-sixth Street, near Central Park West, to be attended by Scottish societies in the Metropolitan area.

Net income of the Federal Home Loan Banks for 1943 amounted to $3,916,974, compared with $3,903,460 in 1942, Everett Smith of 31 Nassau Street, financial representative of the system, announced yesterday. Of the 1943 net, 20 per cent, or $783,000, was transferred to the legal reserve, as required by the act of Congress that established the system in 1932.

Leonard Brand, 61 years old, of 151 North Eighteenth Street, Orange, N.J., who admitted defrauding customers of the old jewelry business at 30 East Twenty-third Street, established by his father sixty-five years ago, was let off with a suspended sentence yesterday in General Sessions because Judge George L. Donnellan feels "you still are an honest man."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 21 -- The hep cats and rug cutters who feast on the "sendings" of Frank Sinatra, Harry James and other maestros of jive may not be interested, but Artur Rodzinski, conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, is distinctly a "long hair" when it comes to boogie woogie.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The high courts of England have been swamped with such a volume of divorce cases that the Government has at last taken steps to have more judges appointed to handle them. In many quarters this trend toward instability in family life is regarded as among the most serious by-products of the war.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A purported photograph of

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Germany distributed through her overseas agency today a series of peace rumors designed to prolong the controversy among the Allies over the recent peace report published in Pravda in Moscow.

Louis (Lepke) Buchalter joined his fellow-murder defendants Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss and Louis Capone in the death house at Sing Sing Prison yesterday afternoon. He was taken there by officers of the New York City Department of Correction who were designated to guard him on the automobile trip to Ossining from the Federal House of Detention in Manhattan.

Party enrollment figures for New York City, made public yesterday by S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, showed that 789,394 more voters had enrolled as Democrats than as Republicans. The totals for the three legal parties were:

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Major Robert Tyre Jones Jr., intelligence officer for the United States Army Air Force fighter outfit and once upon a time a pretty good golfer, said at a press conference today, "I think it would be taking money under false pretenses," when British writers urged him to play golf for charity.

Seven matches were completed on the courts of the Harvard Club last night as the Class C championship singles of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association started. The field comprises thirty-one players.

J. Thurston Noe of South Orange, N.J., has the unique experience of having been named for the third time as organist and choirmaster of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street. He held these offices from 1923 to 1928 under the late Rev. Dr. John Roach Stratton, then the pastor, and from 1931 to 1936 under the Rev. Dr. Will H. Houghton, then the pastor, and now president of the Moody Bible Institute, Chicago.

Judging by the action of the mercury market, which has declined sharply in the last two or three weeks, the problem of obtaining enough of this strategic mineral for war purposes has been solved. Yesterday the price declined to $150 for a flask of seventy-six pounds, a new wartime low mark.

William S. Richardson. general manager of the chemical division i of the B. F. Goodrich Company, last night told the annual joint meeting of the Harvard, Yale and Princeton engineering associations the Harvard Club that the Unitiie States ,viii have use for both synthetic and natural rubber after the war.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Jan. 21 -- The auction of household articles by Nancy Oakes de Marigny was completed early this afternoon, one day ahead of schedule, with the bidding high throughout. Although Mrs. de Marigny withdrew several valuable items from the sale, the proceeds totaled more than 900.

With 261 athletes from colleges, schools, clubs and the services entered, the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior indoor track and field championships will be staged tonight on the board floor of the Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn. Twelve titles will be decided on the big evening program starting at 7:30 after three field events have opened the meet at 1:30 P.M. on Columbia's South Field.

The annual report of the Caterpillar Tractor Company, issued yesterday to stockholders by L.B. Neumiller, president, disclosed for 1943 an increase in sales to $173,945,023 from the $142,168,849 volume for 1942.

The stock market exhibited yesterday an increase of internal energy but the main power was supplied again by the railway shares and an assorted list of specialties. The real interest for the day centered, however, in the bond list.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 -- The regional War Labor Board here ordered tonight that the 2,700 striking employes of the Trenton (N.J.) plant of the John A. Roebling's Sons Company return to work immediately and directed that the company and the United Steel Workers, CIO, proceed with settlement of the dispute through established grievance machinery.

A 16-year-old bridegroom and his 19-year-old wife were arrested last night at Jamaica, Queens, Police Headquarters on perjury charges connected with the youth's obtaining a marriage license last Dec. 14. The couple, who will be arraigned in Queens Felony Court this morning, are Louis and Dorothy Krennrich Wolf of 143-05 102d Avenue, Jamaica.

A galaxy of tennis stars, who couldn't have been brought together at this time by any other agency, has been assembled by the War Bond Sports Committee and may be seen in action next Friday night at the Seventh Regiment Armory by war bond purchasers.
ALGIERS, Jan. 21 -- A communique:

With only ten days remaining before the expiration of the three-year contract covering 85,000 dressmakers in 2,100 shops, the New York Dress Joint Board, affiliated with the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, announced yesterday that negotiations with the five employers' associations for a new agreement had broken down after a five-week conference.

West Point's basketball cadets, who zoomed into the limelight with a convincing victory over St. John's, will make their only appearance in New York this campaign in meeting Columbia on the Morningside Heights court tonight.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Most sections of the stock markets here were quiet today, in view of the week-end closing. Gilt-edge stocks showed little change and home rails turned dull.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Important progress has been made during the past week in the drawing up of plans between the United States and British Governments on the one hand and the refugee European Governments on the other, with regard to the restoration of civil government in Europe after we have landed on its shores.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 21 -- Two hunting rifles were taken today from Dr. Leopold Brandenburg's home in Union City by Montclair detectives working on the revived John Longstreet Ely murder investigation. At the same time they arrested Fred Nell, the doctor's chauffeur, and booked him as a material witness in the case, as was done with the physician yesterday.

A UNITED STATES AMPHIBIOUS BASE, England (Delayed) (AP) -- Believing they had shot down an enemy plane, Navy gunners cheered when they first saw a Nazi rocket glider bomb appear in the midst of a convoy, execute a perfect banking turn, then plunge into the sea with a violent explosion.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Jan. 22 -- Rapidly following up their crushing blows on the right and left flanks of the German positions in northern Russia, Red Army units under the command of Generals Leonid A. Govoroff and Kirill A. Meretskoff yesterday struck in a combined frontal attack at the railway junction of Mga and wrested from German hands that vital link on Leningrad's rail communications with central Russia.

Premier Hideki Tojo told the Japanese Diet yesterday that air power would determine the outcome of the Pacific war -- where there was "only a hair's breadth between final victory and defeat" -- and that his people must work harder than at present to insure a growing output of warplanes.
Representative James H. Fay, chairman of the Tammany executive committee, was put forward yesterday as a possible compromise candidate for leader to succeed Michael J. Kennedy.

The normal flow of cotton and rayon textile exports to Good Neighbor countries and other outlets is threatened as a result of confusion created by the War Production Board's recent amendment to its order M-317, it was indicated yesterday at an open meeting of merchant exporters of textile products with officials of the Office of Price Administration in that agency's regional office.

Organization of the Stevens Research Foundation, a non-profit corporation for scientific and industrial research and related educational purposes, was announced last night by Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, at the forty-first annual dinner of the alumni association, held in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Astor.

LEWES, Del., Jan. 21 -- One man was burned to death in a flaming oil slick and fifteen other members of a tanker-barge crew were rescued by Coast Guard and Navy patrol boats five miles off the Delaware Capes tonight.

Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, German Minister for Occupied Territories in the East, must have got hold of some of our depression-period literature, both prose and fiction. In a speech delivered at Prague this week the learned Doctor said that "the technical revolution in America destroyed the peasant, laid waste forests and prairies, causing 12,000,000 unemployed," and that "millions of farmers wandered from place to place."
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 21 (UP) -- An Allied Southeast Asia Command communique:...

New issues of municipal bonds amounting to $6,372,803 will come up for award next week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with this week's revised total of $8,004,500. More than one-half of next week's financing will be accounted for by a single issue, that of $3,310,000 Chicago, Ill., Park District refunding bonds, due 1964, which is scheduled for Tuesday.

Sixteen more pigeons and ten sparrows plummeted to their deaths here yesterday as the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals revealed that seed coated with strychnine had been found in four of the flock of pigeons which had died on Thursday outside of St. Patrick's Cathedral and in Madison Square Park.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 21 -- A remarkable wartime transportation system for convoys, a method of synthesizing wound hormones, and a novel way of keeping birds away from planted seeds are the subjects of widely differing patents listed among the 513 granted during the past week and published in the current volume of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Professional buying combined with support from millers and shorts lifted prices of wheat around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade to a new top for the week, about 3 cents above Monday's low level.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Now that the Americans and the British are about to open the long-awaited "second front" in western Europe, the Germans are beginning to wonder why Japan does not open a second front against the Russians in the east in Germany's behalf.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Government's purchase of ten cargo ships from the Southern Pacific Company (Morgan Line) in 1941 for $4,733,952 resulted in "a wasteful and extravagant expenditure of public funds," Lindsay Warren, Controller General, has reported to Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Democratic National Committeemen from twelve Middle Western States, convening informally today on the eve of the committee's meeting, adopted unanimously a resolution endorsing President Roosevelt for a fourth term.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 21 -- One of the principal distributing centers, if not the headquarters, of a ring dealing illegally in counterfeit and valid gasoline ration stamps, which operated with underworld ramifications in at least four States, appeared shattered today with the arrest of eleven men in this city.

Floris W. ter Meulen, American representative of the Netherlands banking company of Heldring Pierson, jumped or fell to his death at 12:45 P.M. yesterday from his office on the twentieth floor of 60 Wall Street. Mr. ter Meulen's body landed on the sidewalk near 65 Pine Street, narrowly missing passers-by.

Baseball's doubting Thomases, who have been expressing fears that the game, both in the majors as well as in the minors, would not be able to survive another war year because of the increasing manpower shortage, received their second shot in the arm in twenty-four hours yesterday when Frank Shaughnessy, president of the International league, asserted he felt certain the double-A circuits, especially his own, would be able to operate throughout the 1944 season.

This week the Supreme Court handed down a decision which must attract increasing attention with the passage of time. In that decision the Court carried still farther the doctrine of a special legal license for unions to commit violence which it laid down in the case of the teamsters' union in March of 1942.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- The murder of Mrs. Frank Starr Williams, wife of a State Department attache, who was fatally shot by a woman in a fur coat in the Drake Hotel Wednesday night, took a new turn today, which police thought might lead to a solution of the mystery.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- A British submarine of a new "Eastern Fleet" has sunk a Japanese cruiser and three large supply ships, it was announced today, in attacks hailed by Britons as their Navy's first move toward joining the American Pacific forces for the final two-way attack on Japan.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Lowell Bennett, 24-year-old war correspondent of the International News Service, who has been missing since he went as an observer on an RAF attack on Berlin on Dec. 2, is alive, unhurt, and a prisoner of war in Germany, it was revealed here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Production of milk and cream this year will fall 6,000,000,000 pounds short of the War Food Administration's goal of 122,000,000,000 pounds and 1,000,000,000 pounds below last year's total of 117,800,000,000 pounds on the basis of present production trends, the Office of War Information stated today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Senate adopted a tax bill late today which will raise about $2,275,600,000 in new revenue and sent it to conference with the House. Before the final vote, amendments to the war contract renegotiation phases of the measure were accepted.

Today's events: "Carmen," 2 P.M., and "The Magic Flute," 8, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Young People's concert, Carnegie Hall, 11 A.M.; free orchestral concert conducted by David Mannes, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 4 P.M.; Lener Quartet, Town Hall, 5:30; operatic concert conducted by Alberto Bimboni in Victory series, New York Public Library, 5:30; Golden Hill Chorus, Town Hall, 8:30; Marjorie Lawrence, soprano, and Gordon Manley, piano, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30.

A three-month jail term and a fine of $5,000 were imposed by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind yesterday on Mrs. Ida Frank, whose wholesale kosher poultry market at 1927 West Farms Road, the Bronx, is the largest of its kind in that borough.

It is good news to music lovers of New York and to the civic-minded in general that David Mannes and his symphony orchestra will open today their twenty-seventh annual series of free concerts in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with three other Saturday concerts to follow.

The French Committee of National Liberation is enforcing its control over all military commanders on land and sea. How badly needed is that vindication of the political authority was vividly demonstrated by scandalous scenes in Martinique of which Washington has just heard.

THE Tuckers are a nice family. You undoubtedly remember Sally, who on her seventh Christmas schemed and saved to give her mother "A Pint of Judgment" and never did discover that it was sense not cents that Mrs. Tucker had wished for; and the day the children joyfully discovered "The Rabbit's Nest" and learned another lesson in the art of giving.

MOSCOW, Jan. 22 -- Russian capacity for rapid, thorough analysis of experience is often commented on by students. No less important are the ingenuity and industry with which Russians apply the lessons of the past to the present.

Jewelry, handbags, gloves and neckwear were outstanding in brisk retail trade last week in the major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

AN ancient prophecy comes true when several persons die mysteriously at or near an old Roman camp shortly after a treasure has been removed therefrom. But Sir Clinton Driffield, who is investigating the deaths, does not believe in mumbo jumbo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A declaration that few if any members of the armed forces would be able to vote under the "States' Rights" solider voting bill was made today by Secretary Stimson in a letter to Representative Eugene Worley, Democrat of Texas, House leader of advocates of a Federal ballot.

LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A national minimum weekly wage for Britain's 700,000 coal miners -- $20 for experienced underground workers and $18 for surface workers -- was announced tonight by the national tribunal for the industry.

The attitude of the United Nations toward France today is one of callous misunderstanding. The United Nations are not to be censured for being in error, since only those who do nothing make no mistakes. Those who persist in them, however, are the insensitive, the blind and the unintelligent.

Revision of New York City's textbooks, as well as those in other schools system of the country, to eliminate biased references to the Negroes and other minority groups was urged yesterday by Justice Hubert T. Delany of the Domestic Relations Court.

THIS is an excellent book. Indeed, for the purposes of a general reader who wants to know all about Canada, past, present and with a glimpse into the future, I do not know of a better. It has the advantage of being more than an outline or sketch and yet stopping short of such length and detail as to place it outside the limits of the ordinary reader's available time.

TRADE managed to hold its small margin over a year ago for the week, according to reports, and the month may do better than was expected earlier. However, War Bond purchases from now on will have their influence.

AN ADVANCED AIR BASE, in Italy, Jan. 22 -- Small landing craft commenced unloading their first batches of men and equipment below Rome at 2 A.M. today without encountering even coastal gunfire and the only trouble was mines met by some British units, Allied fliers at this base said today.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 22 -- Again establishing herself as a first-class mare, Mar-Kell scored at Hialeah Park today in the $5,840 Evening Handicap, the first competitive effort for Blenheim II's daughter since last October.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The Smiths have now conquered Scotland. Whereas names beginning with "Mac" used to predominate, now the surname Smith outnumbers all others.
On every front the war last week was marching faster.

THAT anyone in the entertainment world should suffer from the Broadway millennium seems anomalous. And it seems incredible, also, that the boys in the services should be the victims of the boom that is radiating from Times Square.

At the fifth concert of its current Town Hall series, late yesterday afternoon, the Lener Quartet presented a program featuring the Second string quartet of Stanley Bate, young English composer, which received its world premiere. The work was excellently written for the strings, and sounded sensuous and rich in texture.

The Japanese, who two years ago were moving ahead in the South Pacific as if nothing could stop them, now are moving backward and will not stop until they reach Tokyo, Walter Nash, New Zealand"s Minister to the United States, declared here yesterday.

A course in Victory gardening is to be given by the Extension Division of Columbia University on Wednesday afternoons from Feb. 9 through May 17. Registration for the classes, which include lectures, discussions and greenhouse practice, begins Jan. 31.

ALGIERS, Jan. 22 -- The new invasion of the Italian west coast is regarded here as extremely hazardous, yet having the advantage of the experience of the previous invasions of North Africa, Sicily and Italy.

Awaiting action by the Congress on the pending revenue bill, this is a review of some of the effects of existing tax laws upon individual taxpayers and a restatement of the sources from which the Treasury is now deriving revenues of more than $40,000,000,000 a year.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, elaborated today on his assertion, made a month ago, that the American general staff feared a British invasion of the United States after the first World War.

CHRISTOPHER SAXE and his friend Buzz find excitement and adventure in the mountains of New Jersey. What is more important, they find a two-million-dollar baby. Because Christopher has unconventional ideas about detecting, they decide to keep the baby instead of turning it over to the police.

WITH THE FRENCH EXPEDITIONARY CORPS, in Italy, Jan. 21 (Delayed) -- French troops are putting up a gallant fight along one of the toughest sectors of the Fifth Army's front ranging high into the snow-capped Apennines.

There should be only one seamen's union in this country, not three or four whose jurisdictions are figured out by geography -- the American Merchant Marine means just what it says, not a Gulf merchant marine, or Atlantic merchant marine, or Pacific merchant marine, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, declared last week before a national council meeting of the National Maritime Union.
THE late Lord Wedgwood was another in that great line of English "eccentrics" who so brilliantly and usefully combined apparent incompatibles. A wealthy man, he helped to organize the Labor party.

DR. MICAUD has studied the shades and shifts of French conservative opinion as reflected in the press and in parliamentary discussions during the years when Frenchmen were trying to decide between a military alliance with Soviet Russia -- in spite of its revolutionary communism -- and some form of collaboration with Nazi Germany -- in spite of the traditional enmity between France and that country.

Captain Martin Olsen, veteran shipmaster who has commanded Esso tankers for twenty years, was honored last week by the marine department of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey upon completion of thirty years' serivce with the Esso tanker fleet. At a luncheon attended by seventy of his associates, B.B. Howard, marine department manager, presented a watch to him.

Shares of investment trusts regained last year some of their previous popularity, as investors rediscovered the advantages of leverage in a rising market. On the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange volume in investment trusts for 1943 was 12,394,885 shares, against 4,500,900 in 1942.

On the North American continent are 130,000,000 people engaged in a great enterprise of their own making -- the United States. It is a great enterprise because man's individual freedom is enjoyed here to a degree unknown elsewhere.
AT 4 1/2 Jimmy considers the infant pursuits of his nursery school a pure waste of time. "But, Mummy." he argues, bored with rhythms and block-building, "I can't read, I can't write."

An unusually interesting and well-arranged program was given at Town Hall last night by the Golden Hill Chorus, George Mead conducting, at its winter concert. George Britton, baritone, was the assisting artist, singing two groups.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Uruguay and Cuba announced today they would not recognize the month-old revolutionary regime in Bolivia, topping off a series of widely separated developments in connection with allegations of Nazi activities in South America.

The 1943 tax blanks which taxpayers are now receiving are the most complicated ever devised. Accompanying the blanks is a statement designated as Form 1125, showing the taxpayer's total tax for 1942, the amount paid at the time of filing and the subsequent payments.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- Striking employes of the Street Cleaning, Water and Highway Bureaus here voted today to end their seventeen-day strike and accept the city's compromise offer to increase wages about 5 cents an hour.

THE Pan American Union is expected shortly to recommend to the twenty-one American republics that each issue a special postage stamp, or a series of stamps, "dedicated to the laudable spirit of international humanitarianism exemplified by the Red Cross."

Reflecting the announcement of the contemplated purchase of 332,000 bales of raw cotton for lend-lease purposes, aggressive trade demand and mill buying lifted prices in the cotton futures market yesterday to gains of as much as $1.05 a bale.

IN the sense that it is laid in the wheat country of Montana, Mildred Walker's new novel, "Winter Wheat," is a regional novel. But to leave it in that classification gives insufficient tribute to its finer virtues. In her story of Ellen Webb, daughter of a New England father and a Russian mother, Miss Walker uncovers the tangled roots of human relationships and human conflicts.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The Supreme Allied Command has held a series of conferences in London during the past week in which the ultimate shape of the invasion operations has been ironed out and details of the command of tactical forces have been discussed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Democratic party, now an 11-year-old machine, is being overhauled energetically into the best possible facsimile of a 1944 racing model. The process of overhaul itelf reveals the broad cracks that have occurred in the political organization that has dominated American politics since 1932 but faces a genuinely severe test before this year expires.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra, having straightened out its difficulties with the American Federation of Musicians, returns to the radio via CBS and WABC on Jan. 29. It will be heard from 3:30 to 4:30 P.M. Saturdays.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Nov. 28, which only reached us a few days ago, we read Mr. MacDonald's story about "Men Who Work the War" with rather mingled feelings. Every word of the article is highly laudatory of the so-called non-fighting branches, but nobody could help feeling that the general tenor of it is apologetic, as if saying: "Don't be harsh on these poor boys.

PEARL CHAVEZ was a poor relation of the rich McCanles clan. She was also "part Injun," and Niven Busch, who tells of Pearl and her kindred in "Duel in the Sun," holds that an admixture of Indian blood, plus poverty, was indeed shameful in Texas of the Eighties.

LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Carl A. Spaatz said today that, weather permitting, the German air force was likely to be knocked out during the Summer and disclosed that American bombing operations were limited only by weather, with no limitation because of a shortage of planes, crews or facilities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Conclusive demonstrations that Democratic leaders consider President Roosevelt the only possible nominee for this year's Presidential race were given here at today's meeting of the National Committee and at tonight's Jackson Day dinner.

Trust funds established for three sisters-in-law and five nieces in the will of the late Charles H. Ebbets, principal owner of the Brooklyn Dodgers, were not annuities and payments cannot be made out of the principal of the estate or out of future surplus, it was decided yesterday by Brooklyn Surrogate Francis D. McGarey.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- Moscow's midnight communique, recorded here today from a broadcast, said that in the Novgorod sector north of Lake Ilmen the Germans had defended Tatino "stubbornly," attempting to gain time to reorganize disorganized units.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Present indications are that a big majority of the 1,059 delegates who will make up the Republican National Convention starting June 26 at Chicago will be uninstructed as to a Presidential nominee.

Although the war, quite naturally, has curtailed the normal activities of the Grace Line, the company has built twelve new freighters in the last four years and also has five more new C-2 type vessels under construction at present, D. Stewart Iglehart, president of W.R. Grace Co. and the Grace Line, declared in a statement released here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Marvin Jones, War Food Administrator, stripped the $3,000,000,000 Commodity Credit Corporation and its president, J.B. Hutson, of important policy-making powers over the WFA's food production program today.

PLANTS that grow indoors during winter without demanding too much attention are not so plentiful as they might be. Billbergia nutans, which has much to recommend it, is not so well known as many of the older stand-bys for the house.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY'S AMPHIBIOUS FORCES, South of Rome, Jan. 22 -- We walked in behind the German lines today with hardly a shot fired in a most sensational amphibious operation. It was so easy and simply done and caught the Germans so completely by surprise that, as I write this dispatch six hours after the landing, American troops are standing with their mouths open and shaking their heads in utter amazement.

THE part -- which between the lacquered pompadour and high curled bang of recent years has been all but ignored -- has suddenly come into its own as a striking feature of the current, flat-on-top coiffure. The part is important.

WPB restrictions that cut the use of wire for frames to 40 per cent of the peacetime norm and completely prohibit the use of copper for wiring have begun to cause shortages of all kinds of lamps and lampshades in retail stores. Existing stocks of lamps, department store buyers report, will be just barely adequate to supply the young couples who are setting up housekeeping for the first time.

CECIL BROWN, explosive commentator, who made a swing around the country last autumn for a projected home front analysis, is now in Mexico, resting and reconsidering the whole idea. His publishers, Random House, stand ready to publish the book any time the author cares to write it, but Mr. Brown is doubtful as to the conclusiveness of anything he learned and feels much more time and evidence-gathering would be necessary . . . .

War or no war, some attempt will be made to observe the total eclipse of the sun which will occur on Tuesday. It has always been thus. When Paris was besieged during the Franco-Prussian war of 1870-71 the French astronomer, Janssen, packed himself and a telescope into a balloon and floated away over the heads of the German Army.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 22 -- A late rally by Sworthmore's basketball team fell one point short tonight and the Garnet five bowed to Princeton, 45 -- 44, for its ninth defeat in a row.

Few fiction stories of hope and courage are more touching than the moving story of real life told by Harold A. Littledale in our Magazine today. His heroes and heroines are the patients at Warm Springs, Ga. Crippled victims of the poliomyelitis scourge, they do not despair. They will yet make something of their lives.

TORONTO, Jan. 22 -- The National Hockey League's cellar-dwelling Rangers tonight trounced second-place Toronto, 5 to 1, before 10.735 fans at Maple Leaf Gardens for their second victory in the eight games in which the two teams have met this season. Both New York triumphs have been on Toronto ice.

UNLESS we had seen it with our own eyes, we would never in this world have believed that a film could have been made in this country in the year 1943 which sold out the democratic ideal and elevated the Nazi "superman."

Fantastic tales come out of neutral Switzerland and Sweden about Germany's secret rocket weapons. Jules Verne never gave us anything more hair-raising. The splitting of the uranium atom a few years ago, with the release of energy on a minute scale, evidently inspired the recent Swiss account of a German rocket shell which is loaded with liquid air and a solution of uranium salt.

Crowded Broadway on a Saturday night is "lots more dangerous and exciting" than a sky full of Japanese Zeros in the southwest Pacific area, in the opinion of Major Alexander Guerry Jr., veteran of eighteen months of flying with Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenny's Fifth Army Air Force.

Support of the principle of equal service by the whole population in wartime was pledged yesterday by the national executive board of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organization, with the qualifications that all five points of President Roosevelt's program must be carried through to make it work.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, Jan. 23 (UP) -- A communique:

THE Wenderley of Gertrude Mallette's new story is a large defense project in California, where 2,000 people live in small trailers, placed side by side with only some eight feet of dry, dusty earth between them.
MOSCOW, Jan. 22 (U.P.) -- Stated in bluntest terms, the solution of the Russian-Polish crisis lies in London, not in Moscow, in the view of authoritative Russian opinion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Roosevelt set up by Executive Order today a War Refugee Board "to take action for the immediate rescue from the Nazis of as many as possible of the persecuted minorities of Europe, racial, religious or political, all civilian victims of enemy savagery."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The $14,000,000,000 war bonds to be sold to the American people during the Fourth War Loan drive which began this week will raise total borrowings for war purposes since July 1, 1940, to $135,000,000,000.
This is the week that sports go into high in New York in their organized effort to help provide the sinews of warmaking.

While stressing the need for women in the armed forces and industry, Capt. Mildred H. McAfee, commanding officer of the Waves, declared yesterday that certain women could serve their country best by remaining in college.

The question whether Michael J. Kennedy is to be ousted as leader of Tammany and a successor elected will be decided at a meeting of its executive committee to be held in the New York County Democratic headquarters, 331 Madison Avenue, next Saturday evening at 7 o'clock.

LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Yugoslav Partisans have pressed their attack against the main rail line running from Budapest down through Zagreb to the port of Spalato on the Adriatic and have gone over to the offensive in bitter fighting in the mountains of Croatia, the Yugoslav communique said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- It is trite, now, to say that no one is going to shoot Santa Claus but the thought and the hope that it may be true comforts Congress these days.

Final arrangements for the twenty-eighth annual dinner dance in aid of the Blue Ridge School at Bris, Va., which will take place on Friday in the main ballroom of the Pierre, will be discussed tomorrow at a meeting and tea to be given by Mrs. F. Graham Cootes at the Regency Club, 15 East Sixty seventh Street.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEAD QUARTERS, New Guinea, Sunday, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A jungle drive by Australians in the Ramu Valley against the shipping base of Madang, a costly retreat of trapped Japanese under fire of strafing planes on the near-by New Guinea coast, and a 15-to-6 air victory over Rabaul, New Britain, were reported today by headquarters.

AMONG other events, the Broadway merchants of nocturnal divertissement will be offering this week two new floor shows. The first of these is "Top Hats and Tom Tom's," a revue which Joseph Springer unfolds this evening at his Ubangi Club, the emporium of sepian entertainment.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcasts from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Failing in his quest for a job in a war factory, Edward Magruder Jones, 15-year-old schoolboy, who disappeared from his home at 1425 Broadway last Tuesday morning, telephoned to his mother, Mrs. Marguerite Moor-Jones, early yesterday from Apalachicola, Fla.

AN ADVANCE AIR BASE IN ITALY, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Returning pilots who flew a sunrise cover for the Allies' landing on the west coast of Italy said today that they had seen little or no artillery fire from the shore and that there had been no fires on the beach.

Arthur Eilenberg read last Sunday the strange saga of the common eel and decided to do a bit of research on the subject. When he was through he came up with a theory that is pretty vast for a column devoted to hunting and fishing news, embracing as it does the lost continent of Atlantis, no less, but we'll take the chance of cracking slightly at the seams and present it.

At the third concert of the twenty-first season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's Young People's Concerts yesterday forenoon at Carnegie Hall, Rudolph Ganz conducted new as well as old music for an audience that nearly filled the house.

NEITHER of the two short novels in this volume, "The Lodger" and "One Way Out," is a detective story, but both deal with crime. In the first a cowardly murderer goes into hiding and stays there, too apathetic to seek another refuge when he is warned that the police are on his track.

THERE are many kinds of war reporting. There's the slam-bang, stop-press work of the press associations, whose chief concern is the new fact told at the earliest split-second. There's the more thoughtful, but still hurried, dally dispatch of the special correspondent.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Soaring far and wide over Germany and German-occupied territory, more than 1,000 British bombers blasted Magdeburg, one of the most important industrial cities of north central Germany, gave Berlin a minor hammering, dropped bombs in northern France and laid mines in enemy waters last night.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Jan. 23 -- The Red Army made further important progress in north Russia yesterday, capturing more than seventy additional places in the Leningrad area, the Soviet Command announced late last night.

With a torpedo hole in her bow large enough to admit a locomotive, the 500-foot American tanker W.S. Rheem managed to steam 5,500 miles across the Pacific to her home port, according to a report issued yesterday by the War Shipping Administration.

Eugene W. Stetson, chairman of the commerce and industry committee of the Red Cross 1944 War Fund, announced yesterday the appointment of three chairmen to mobilize 150 divisions in business and industry.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 22 (U.P.) -- Allied troops, methodically clearing the Japanese from the jungles north of Burma's west coast port of Akyab, have captured a village within two reties of Buthedaung, enemy outpost at the headwaters of the Mayu River, a southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

On Jan. 15 there was an earthquake in the Andes Mountain province of San Juan, Argentina. Some 80,000 persons found themselves homeless, 1,500 were killed, more than 13,000 were injured, about $100,000,000 worth of property was damaged or destroyed. As usual fires broke out.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

AFTER a two-year lapse the Music Teachers National Association, the National Association of Schools of Music and the American Musicological Society will hold a joint convention March 23-25, in Cincinnati, Ohio.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22 -- Dartmouth tonight achieved its thirty-ninth consecutive hockey victory when Captain Dick Rondeau, playing his fourth season for the Indians, shot the goal that beat Yale in overtime, 7 to 6.

VLADIMIR MIASKOVSKY'S Twenty-fourth Symphony, his latest work, was performed recently in Moscow by the State Symphony Orchestra under the direction of the conductor, Radinsky. This is the third symphony to be written by Miaskovsky since the war began.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Army and Navy Register said today that there were "rumors" that American snipers in the jungle war, wearing camouflage suits, were "summarily executed as spies" when caught by the Japanese.

MAN defends himself as much as he can against truth, as a child does against a medicine, as the man of the Platonic cave does against the light. He does not willingly follow his path, he has to be dragged along backward.

Declaring that a textbook on labor relations issued by New York State in September was "unsuitable" for general use in the classroom, a special committee of the Association of Teachers of Social Studies in the City of New York went on record yesterday as opposing all State-sponsored school books.
