IN a world tolerably full of uncertainty you can be sure that the radio will bring new dramas of American family life at an average rate of about one per month; and a curious time the sociologists will one day have with these sagas as they pore over musty scripts and play old records of long-forgotten shows.

MIAMI, Jan. 22 -- The American Federation of Labor will soon demand that organized labor be represented "on all national delegations dealing with matters affecting post-war world organizations and programs." This was made evident today when the executive council made public part of a report of its post-war planning committee headed by Matthew Woll, vice president.

MOSCOW, Jan. 22 -- That Adolf Hitler's plans to sow discord among the democratic lands had failed and that confidence and unity were growing among members of the anti-Hitler coalition was asserted in Moscow last night by Col. Gen. Alexander Scherbakoff, head of the Red Army's Political Department, member of the political bureau of the Communist party and secretary of the Moscow Province Communist party.

NO school or period of composition can possibly be represented on a single program. No four composers can be taken as a summary of a period or a school. And only God can make a tree or a creator of epochal music.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- While rumors increased that the United States Government would announce next week its refusal to recognize the Bolivian revolutionary regime, Ferdinando Iturralde, Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs in that regime, asserted at a press conference today that it had no ties either with the Axis or the Argentine Government.

IN the next room a bugle sounds. The noise is one of ear-splitting dissonance. It rises to a yowl and falls to a bray. Only a boy, and a beginner at that, could perpetrate such sounds and be satisfied. It seems strange in a hospital.

Now that the great bulk of spring buying is finished and most of the buyers have gone home. deliveries have again become the No. 1 problem, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Probability that Mrs. Patricia Goodbody will undergo a lie detector test Monday in connection with the slaying of her mother, Mrs. Frank Starr Williams, was expressed today after her attorney, William J. Welsh, had conferred with investigators.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 22 -- Almost daily bombing of the Channel coast approximately between Dunkerque and Boulogne is producing symptomatic reactions among both the French and Germans.

A few years ago I was privileged, through these columns, to address a letter to your fellow-author and, I am sure, friend, William Shakespeare. Since he never registered any marked objection to my temerity I am emboldened to take the same liberty with you, even though I can claim only a comparatively tenuous acquaintance with yourself.

J.K. Lippert of Jackson Heights defeated W.E Schwab, representing the Seventh Regiment, in a bitterly fought first-round match in the Class C championship singles of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association at the Harvard Club yesterday.

In the season's third performance of Mozart's "The Magic Flute," last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, Audrey Bowman, 26-year-old soprano from Cleveland, made her debut with the company in the difficult role of the Queen of the Night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Army is pushing to completion its Canadian oil project despite criticism by the Truman committee. Apparently it is confident that a new contract more favorable to the United States will be worked out with Dominion oil interests.

Reminders of our late national era of Glorious Nonsense, meaning the Nineteen Twenties preceding the economic collapse, keep turning up from time to time and receive due comment. New York City offers for sale the tugboat Macom, on which so many official delegations went down the harbor to welcome distinguished visitors.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: When the seed orders have been made out, the next things to select are rose bushes and fruit plants. Prompt decisions this year insure delivery and ease pressure on harassed nurserymen. . . . Window boxes, even though planted with evergreens, need occasional deep soaking of the soil, except during very cold spells.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Roosevelt, in a letter today, asked Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, to do what he could to get from the company's board an extension of the leave of absence it granted to Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, "so that he can help to see the Government through this critical period."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The basic issue in the fight being waged by the Southern States before the Interstate Commerce Commission is whether or not the Northeast, which was the nation's industrial center when the South still had a largely one-crop plantation economy, shall continue to enjoy the competitive advantage of lower freight rates at a time when the South is struggling to develop her own industries.

In celebration of President Roosevelt's birthday and in conjunction with the opening of the March of Dimes campaign, the annual President's Birthday Party will be given next Saturday night -- eve of Mr. Roosevelt's anniversary -- in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Japanese based on Paramushiru Island at the northern tip of the Kuriles was twice bombed on Friday night (east longitude time) by Aleutian-based Navy bombers, the Navy Department announced today. No planes were lost.

WHEN sailors in the merchant fleet settle down to read they are more likely to choose a book on practical navigation than a novel or a mystery story. In a recent month, according to the American Merchant Marine Library, out of every 100 mariners who were reading, 67 concentrated on technical nautical volumes, 17 read non-fiction, 16 read fiction.

MUSIC has unique power. It is a universal tongue. It requires no translations or explanations. Consider the tunes of "La Marseillaise" and "God Save the King," or "The Star-Spangled Banner." These melodies immediately evoke countries and peoples and even their histories.

Now that there has been time for detailed analysis of the Baruch-Hancock report, setting up a uniform contract-termination article for fixed-price war contracts, criticism of certain features of it have developed in high quarters of industry, representing the bulk of American war production.

Charles P. Taft, former head of the Community War Service Agencies, criticized Mayor La Guardia yesterday for failing to institute an organized program to cut down venereal disease infections among soldiers and sailors visiting the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- Staving off a desperate closing drive that twice deadlocked the score, the New York University Violets tonight managed to eke out a victory over the Temple University Owls, 45 to 43, before a crowd of 10,349 spectators in Convention Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Congress is not likely to look favorably upon the Byrd economy committee's recommendation that the free mailing privileges of Federal departments and agencies be abolished, because as one member put it, sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander.

IN "A Short History of the Chinese People," Professor Goodrich has written a human drama, treating the Chinese as ordinary human beings instead of saints or devils as other historians have tried to do.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The amphibious landing near Rome, which has come as a thrilling surprise, fulfills a long cherished dream of the part of the Allied commanders from Generals Eisenhower, Alexander and Clark downward.

Commissioner of Investigation William B. Herlands made public yesterday an official report denouncing as "wretched" the conditions prevailing at the children's center maintained at 2 East 105th Street by the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

QUITE apart from their particular merit, these four volumes taken as a whole offer a more stimulating and satisfactory definition of American art and opinion than any one of them achieves individually.

The big three of the Eastern kennel world have completed arrangements for their annual indoor exhibitions, they being, in order, the Maryland Kennel Club, Feb. 5 and 6; Westminster Kennel Club, New York, Feb. 11 and 12, and Eastern Dog Club, Boston, Feb. 21 and 22.

The Liberty Bell in Philadelphia was tapped four times and the radio carried the sound to the country. There were parades in New York and other cities. Military equipment, some of it Allied, some of it trophies captured from the enemy, was on view in public parks and squares.

THAT phenomenal post-war era which is known as "The Golden Age of Sports" has come in for considerable attention recently, the war bond popularity contest bringing back to public gaze such athletic gods as Babe Ruth, Jack Dempsey, Bobby Jones, Tommy Hitchcock, Bill Tilden, Johnny Weissmuller and all the other immortals.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- The Army's big field house was filled with spectators today to watch cadet athletes engage in a triangular track meet with Cornell and Dartmouth, and wrestling bouts with Muhlenberg College, as well as a boxing match with Penn State.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The so-called "Hopkins letter," stamped as a forgery by its purported author and by its addressee, was grist to the mill of certain Republicans for a very plain reason:

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 22 -- The Dartmouth Indians assured themselves of at least a tie for the title in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League by turning back Pennsylvania, 61 -- 49, before a large crowd in the Alumni Gym today.

CAMP EDWARDS, Mass., Jan. 22 -Within a heavy, barbed-wire enclosure covering more than three acres of this military post the Army is proving that it can make a good soldier out of a deserter from overseas duty.

ON Aug. 17, 1942, 210 United States Marines led by Lieut. Col. Evans Fordyce Carlson landed on Makin Island in the Gilberts, killed all but a couple of the 350 Japanese defending that dot of coral, destroyed everything military in the place and went their way rejoicing.

ALGIERS, Jan. 22 -- In the most stunning and potentially hazardous operation of the Italian campaign so far, British and American troops of the Fifth Army waded ashore on the west coast of Italy south of Rome at 2 A.M. today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced that ceiling prices on all by-product and retort gas coke produced in the East have been increased by fifty cents a ton to compensate for increases in labor and coal costs experienced during the last two years.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The Russo-Polish dispute has moved "upstairs," to the region of great men and great affairs; it has passed from Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to Prime Minister Churchill, from Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, to Premier Joseph Stalin, and from a controversy over a strip of territory and the tactics of diplomacy to the broader question of whether a stable congress of equal powers can be created.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 22 -- The publication in Razon, a Montevideo newspaper, of a document allegedly purporting to prove the existence of widespread anti-Allied activities throughout this Continent, under the direction of the German Embassy in Buenos Aires, has caused something akin to consternation in the Argentine Foreign Ministry.

Let us hope that out of the present war will come more national consciousness to the average American. That our citizens by birth and naturalization will realize as never before the dignity and privilege of being nationals of a Government benevolently conceived and scientifically carried into operation; the only Government in history whose course was charted from the beginning.

The American Superpower Corporation has offered to exchange its holdings of 70,000 shares of common stock of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and 30,000 shares of common stock of the American Gas and Electric Company, together with cash, for shares of its own first preferred stock. The offer will expire at the close of the market on Jan. 31.

In conjunction with its annual report on the operation of the Andrew Furuseth School of Seamanship in San Francisco, the Sailors Union of the Pacific criticized last week the training division of the War Shipping Administration for what it termed "unnecessary and criminal waste of both manpower and taxpayers' money."

THE subject of "trapping," or "trap bidding," has been discussed in this department from time to time. It is probably the worst and most costly bidding fault of advanced players who are of somewhat less than expert rank.

LEONARD BERNSTEIN is the young musician who is having a whirl in the news this season. As the assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra who has stepped in twice to conduct for indisposed conductors, he has drawn attention as one of the up-and-coming young men of the podium.
THE Metropolitan Opera is asking for donations, and deserves ten times as much as is asked, for it brings to all of us more glorious music than we ever expected to hear.

Yes. "Lifeboat" does have a theme. As that fifth wheel of film making -- the producer -- I must tell you how delighted I was to find the theme coming to the surface through the progressing paragraphs of your critic's review. He saw that these images of the democracies huddled together in the boat were facing a superman out of the Herrenvolk, and must ultimately rise up to kill him.

When Mayor La Guardia left City Hall yesterday afternoon he announced that he would spend the week-end working to complete plans for the establishment of 100 emergency dumps throughout the five boroughs where cash-and-carry customers could buy 100-pound bags of coal.

A NUMBER of Hollywood figures recently have come to Broadway, exchange professors, as it were, from the West Coast. There have not been enough of them to cause Tecumseh to bite his nails over a New Trend, but that may develop later.

IN the preface to his new collection of smiling satires Mr. Leacock comments that his characters laugh too much, cry too easily, lie too hard. Yet, while there is always the element of the fantastic in these stories, there is a certain everyday homeliness about the people and their problems which, despite their absurdities, endears them to the reader.

By taking the "sound track" off the noisy primer used in peacetime shotshells, an almost silent primer for Army lemon-shaped hand grenades, known as "Mark V," has been developed. American troops will now be able to throw hand grenades without revealing positions to the enemy.

One of the most valuable parts of the home garden is the section that might be called the "permanent" plot. Here vegetables and fruit which are perennials make a real contribution to the family larder. We have found that asparagus, hubarb, raspberries, blackberries, strawberries and grapes fit into the picture.

To the German people news of the successful landing of Allied troops behind their army's lines in Italy must come as further proof that in boldness of strategy, no less than in sheer weight of arms, the initiative has now passed from German hands. Nowhere on the military front can the Germans find encouragement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 -- As some war contracts are canceled and the period of gradual recon-version of industry approaches, the Far West is becoming apprehensive, and suspicious, especially when the War Production Board throws a monkey wrench into the steel program of a new $180,000,000 plant at Geneva, Utah.

TWO aviation authorities well known to readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES have combined their efforts in the editing of this book of flying. Since it is the first of a projected year- by-year series, any comment as to its cumulative value must wait, but it can be said from the evidence in hand that it is off to a good start.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Roosevelt announced today the resignation of Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr. as Ambassador-Minister to the Exile Governments in London to become a lieutenant colonel on the staff of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Jan. 22 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur presented tonight to Col. Neel Kearby, fighter pilot, the Congressional Medal of onor. The award, made on behalf of President Roosevelt, was the second such made in the Southwest Pacific theatre.

Increased shortages of paper supplies accompanied by greater availability of metals will accelerate the switch-over from substitute containers to tin cans, container manufacturers stated yesterday. While recent relaxation of War Production Board order M-81 permits resumption of manufacture of many types of cans, the significance of the order, it was said, rests in the fact that it marks the beginning of a trend.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (Canadian Press) -- Everton scored its fifth successive triumph in the English League Cup qualifying competition today and stayed at the top of the fifty-six-team table.

MONTREAL, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Canadiens strengthened their lead in the National Hockey League tonight by whipping Boston, 6 -- 2, in the first game of a week-end double-header before a sell-out crowd of 12,000.

War production at vital plants is being slowed down by the critical situation in which motor haulers and heavy truck operators in general find themselves. Authorization was given recently in Washington for the production of 1,000,000 motor trucks in 1944. On the surface this would appear to be a solution of the problem.

I cut out Dorothy Canfield Fisher's article from THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine and sent it to my husband overseas, who has indicated in several letters an interest in the subject of women's post-war relationship to the home.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Grain markets fluctuated aimlessly today on the Board of Trade. Buying attributed to millers caused a small advance in wheat early, but commission houses and professionals sold later and prices dipped easily.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (AP) -A three-judge Federal District Court declined today to modify an opinion holding that the four-company Pullman sleeping car combine is violating the anti-trust laws and must be broken up.

C.J. Hambro, president of the Norwegian Parliament, discussed "The Four Big Powers and Lasting Peace" at the eighth opera victory rally of the season, broadcast over the Blue Network yesterday afternoon from the Metropolitan Opera House. Dr. Hambro declared the small nations must yield to the large ones after the war, in cooperating for political stability and a secure peace.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Navy communique 498:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Following is the text of the resolution adopted by the Democratic National Committee today calling on President Roosevelt to continue as a world leader:

NORTH CREEK, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- This picturesque community in the southern central Adirondacks one of the real pioneer ski centers of the country, is carrying on this winter and most of its facilities are being maintained despite the short-age of manpower and the absence of youth of fighting age.

A scientific laboratory on wheels to raise Navy men's diets to the peak of nutritional efficiency is ready for use. For seven consecutive days, beginning on Dec. 13, it analyzed food which is served at the United States Marine Base, Quantico, Va., and determined accurately the nutritive composition of victuals at the time they reach the table, rather than in the cooking or pre-cooking stage.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The War Food Administration is organizing wage boards for States where farm pay has risen to inflationary levels. These boards will determine farm wage ceilings.

PAINTINGS by Esther Williams in her current exhibition -- the first in three years -- at the Kraushaar Gallery, testify eloquently to her progress. This is sound, sensitive, livable work, romantic in character, never sensational in technique or subject-matter.

Cities are slaves to refuse cans and surface collection vehicles, said Morris M. Cohn before the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at Schenectady, N.Y., recently. City-dwellers are inconvenienced by irregularity of collections because of manpower shortages, mechanical breakdowns and weather conditions.

RADIO, electronic and electrical engineers from all parts of the country will come to New York this week to attend three major technical conclaves. One group will discuss present and future plans of frequency modulation and touch on television.

The keen ears of Rex, a 2-year-old Doberman pinscher, caught the stealthy tread of a Japanese patrol before a Marine Corps position on Bougainville in the Solomons Islands just before dawn one day last November.

HERE is a tale of strange doings in the home of Dr. Benton of Sedham in England. The doctor is too ill to attend to his practice, and he has a new assistant, Kerry McClure, who encounters opposition and distrust because she is a woman.

Department store volume was estimated as running {about 8-per cent ahead of the like iweek of 1943, with a larger in!crease noted for specialty shops. !Main floor departments were busy, but merchants said business was Lwell distributed among a wide va!riety of soft goods items.

The Supreme Allied Command for the invasion of western Europe was being assembled in England last week as the Allies prepared to open a new and climactic phase of the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -Members of the President's Cabinet were reported today to be divided on the question of a Presidential pardon for Lieut. Gen. Robert C. Richardson Jr. of the Hawaiian Department, who was cited in contempt of court last year for refusing to obey a writ of habeas corpus issued by a Federal judge.

In the interest of international understanding and good-will, Princeton University is now conducting classes for British officers and soldiers comparable to the courses offered American soldiers at Oxford and Cambridge.

THE honeymoon might have been as bright as honeymoons should be if Ian Ross' Uncle Richard had not died so suddenly. As it was, it looked as though Ian's bride, Miriel, might have been responsible for Uncle Richard's death.

AN ADVANCED AIR BASE, in Italy, Jan. 21 (Delayed) -- A German front-line air corps headquarters, carefully hidden in what was previously considered "neutral" territory because of its proximity to the summer residence of Pope Pius XII, was reported to have been destroyed today by dive-bombing Invaders from the Twelfth United States Air Support Command.

LEWES, Del., Jan. 22 -- Survivors of the Socony motor barge Plattsburg recounted today how a Brooklyn man saved the craft from destruction by fire last night after a collision in a dense fog off the Delaware Capes.

ARGENTINA has for the first time issued semi-postals. Word comes from Buenos Aires that on Jan. 5 were released 3-centavos plus 2c violet and black, portrait of Samuel F.B. Morse, inventor of the electric telegraph; 5c plus 5c rose and black, the terrestrial globe with the Americas in white and the letters U.P.A.E. (initials of the Spanish words meaning Postal Union of the Americas and Spain); 10c plus 5c orange and black, likeness of Alex

The "T" loan, a new type of termination loan designed to simplify and facilitate financing re-conversion of war contractors to ultimate peacetime output, has been recommended by War Department fiscal officers to the Baruch-Hancock committee on war and post-war adjustment problems, it was indicated yesterday by controllers who were in touch last week with their Washington "pipelines."

When Allied bombers start on a mission over Italy or France they carry two kinds of maps. One shows them their "target for tonight" while the other shows them how to avoid bombing historic and cultural monuments.

A NEW experiment in caring for our battle-weary soldiers is in progress in the nation. The new idea, pioneered by the Army Air Forces, is so simple that it is rather startling. It involves Private Johnny Jones, who has labored for long, monotonous months in some dank hell of a Pacific or Caribbean jungle, or Lieut. Bill Smith. whose nerves arc frazzled by months of peering through a bombsight over the fiak-filled skies of Europe.

The music kettle boiled over yesterday. From Leopold Stokowski, and from Broadway's leading maestri of boogie woogie and swing came declarations in firm support of the younger generation's favorite mediums.

AFTER the annexation of Austria by Hitler in March, 1938, there were nineteen "small nations" in Europe, or eighteen if Poland is excluded as too big. Today four survive; that is, four have still the fact as well as the form of "independence" Eire, Portugal, Switzerland, Sweden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Representatives of the New York watch-importing trade have been discussing with Government agencies here concerned with foreign economic relations the possibility of an agreement which will allow the import of Swiss watches to the United States to be increased.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 22 -- Arrest of twenty present and former Michigan legislators and six automobile finance company officials was ordered today in a warrant issued by a one-man grand jury after an investigation which began in August.

The fourth War Loan drive provides the opportunity for all to support the men in the armed forces, "which shall enable them to gain a speedy victory," Rabbi Joseph Zeitlin declared yesterday in a sermon in Temple Ansche Chesed, 100th Street and West End Avenue.

THE quality of Colonel Lanza's comments on the Maxims of Napoleon explains why he is the most widely read of American writers on military affairs. He speaks with an authority acquired by a lifetime spent in the armed forces, and indeed ex cathedra, for he was head of the Department of History and Strategy at Fort Leavenworth for four years.

To help improve the professional skills of New York City's teachers, the Board of Superintendents is offering 250 in-service courses for the spring term which begins next week, covering every subject in the school curriculum. It is estimated that more than 10,000 teachers, supervisors and administrators will participate.

HARRY LEVY, whose "The Burro That Learned to Dance" is one of the most spontaneous and pleasing of the books about Latin America for the younger children, tells in this present volume four natural childlike tales for 7 to 10 year olds, the scenes laid respectively in Guayaquil, Mexico, Argentina and Peru.

NATHAN STRAUS learned about housing the hard way, first by trying to provide low-rent accommodations with private funds, then by administering the United States Public Housing Act between 1937 and 1942.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Why the United States sends oil to Spain was explained tonight by Dean Acheson, assistant Secretary of State, and Charles P. Taft, director of the State Department's Office of Wartime Economic Affairs, during the third of a series of four broadcasts over NBC entitled "The State Department Speaks."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the So viet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ROSEMARY OBERMEYER has written a fine and distinctive first novel which richly deserves its honors as an Avery Hopwood Award winner and the Catholic Book Club selection for January. It ought to collect a few more medals along the way, and lots of readers.

Well, here are the catalogues. Now we can get going on the garden -- on, not in. See those luscious tomatoes on the cover? And that sweet corn, just right for the pot? And those crisp heads of lettuce? You'll see those in our garden. Rows of them. And beets and onions and peas and beans and squash and -- well, the works, as they say.

ALGIERS, Jan. 22 -- The Allies' heaviest bombers have attacked two airports in France, rail centers and junctions on both sides of Italy and targets directly in the line of the land offensive, it was officially announced today.

THERE isn't any law which says that the only plant usable in a goldfish bowl is the "seaweed" commonly sold in pet shops and dime stores. Other small aquatic plants, while not exactly capable of satisfying the desire of would-be private lake owners for lotuses and water lilies and kitchenette-sized floating leaves, are nevertheless more unusual and interesting than the overworked Anacharis.

A group of Smith College students taking Spanish subjects are to spend their junior year studying in Mexico. The same distribution of courses will be followed in the Mexican institutions as at Smith College, and full credit will be given by the college for the year's work.

JOHN J. APPETITE, a middle-aged man of New England ancestry living in a quiet Massachusetts town, has a taste for gorgonzola cheese, developed during a trip he took through Italy as a college student. Mrs. Appetite, who never had the benefit of European travel -- everybody says John married much beneath him -- dislikes gorgonzola heartily, fondly preferring the Wisconsin cheddar on which she was brought up as a girl on her father's Midwestern farm.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 22 -Negotiations are under way in India for an American firm to supply and install the majority of machinery for a $10,000,000 ammonium sulphate plant in the State of Travancore in southern India. The plant would contribute toward producing fertilizing chemicals for Indian agriculture. The plant would produce 150 tons daily.

DUNSTAN THOMPSON'S first book of poems is a brilliant display of verbal fireworks. Some pages glitter like stardust. Some have the glow of dying embers. And some have nothing more than the glint of sparklers.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Jan. 22 -The Australian-New Zealand pact is seen here as the first formation of a united military, political and economic front by the two Antipodean Dominions, holding large possibilities for influencing the future international developments in the South Pacific.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 22 -- Taken completely by surprise shortly after 2 A.M. today, German forces defending the Italian littoral between Ardea and Nettuno, in the lowlands southeast of Rome, were overwhelmed and forced to withdraw to "prepared positions" northeast of the littoral road leading to the Cassino front, the Berlin radio said late this afternoon.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 22 -- The deadlock over the issue of wage increases between the War Labor Board and Claude M. Baker, president of the International Typographical Union, appeared broken today with the announcement here by Mr. Baker that national officers of the ITU were to confer with the WLB next Monday in Washington.

ALGIERS, Jan. 22 -- In an animated and at times disorderly session today, the French Consultative Assembly called on the Committee of National Liberation headed by Gen. Charles de Gaulle to prepare a new scheme for the restoration of government in France in place of the scheme the committee has virtually abandoned as a result of criticism in the Assembly.

As a part of its field work, the Colgate Council on Post-War Problems will cooperate with the Hamilton Community Forum on eight town meetings starting Jan. 25 and continuing through March 14. The council of eleven faculty members has also assisted a group of Utica business men to organize for monthly discussions, and similar discussions will be sponsored soon in near-by towns.

WAR dogs, comparatively new to our armed forces, are at the front. They are getting mention in dispatches. And though the Army was first to take into regular service these four-footed auxiliaries, the first news of dogs in action comes from the Pacific, where they serve with the marines.

Despite their continuing difficulties with the regulations of the Office of Price Administration, independent retail grocers in this State are of the almost unanimous opinion that they would be in a worse position if it had never been established and that the Emergency Price Control Act which expires in June should be renewed, according to a survey just completed by the New York State Food Merchants Association.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 22 -- The increasing pressure of Bermuda's population on an inadequate area, now reduced by the United States bases was pointed up today by the release of authoritative figures revealing that there were 955 births last year for an estimated 35,000 permanent population.

Surely there is nothing new about Argentina's standing up to the United States. That happened at most of the Pan-American conferences in recent years; there was generally a bloc headed by Washington and a rival bloc headed by Buenos Aires.

MITCHELL LEISEN, who directed Paramount's Technicolor productions "Lady in the Dark" and "Frenchman's Creek," disclosed the other day that a process of natural color photography has been developed for Army aerial observation which will antiquate the present methods used for commercial films.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -Aerial photography and mapping, accurately accomplished under trying conditions and at record speeds, contributed materially to allied victories at Kula Gulf in the Pacific and in Tunisia, two military map experts said today.
Their eyes and arms working more in unison than those of their opponents, Army's basketball players defeated Columbia last night, 55 to 37, in the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

The Hambletonian, harness racing's Kentucky Derby, will be returned to Goshen, N.Y., in 1944, stewards of the Grand Circuit announced last night following their annual meeting, The United Press reported.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The National Security Award has been granted to twenty plants and facilities in eight States. The award is issued in recognition of outstanding achievement in the protection of employes, plant facilities and production processes against air-raid, fire, accident, sabotage and other factors which might interfere with production or service.

In a letter published in THE TIMES of Jan. 16 John B. Elliott makes several inaccurate statements in commenting on an earlier article by Edwin L. James. Because such statements are rather frequently made and not always challenged it may serve some useful purpose to indicate them.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- The chances of abolition of proportional representation in New York City Council elections, which was proposed last week by Democratic party leaders, appear to hinge on finding an adequate substitute.

An increased amount of churning of both fresh and storage cream in the New York milkshed should be reflected soon in increased supplies of butter in the New York area, according to the Daily Market Report of the Food Distribution Administration, released here yesterday.

CLIFTON FADIMAN is to be congratulated on his premonition that "one of the things this sad world needs" is a new collection of Collier stories. For in Mr. Collier's fantasy world of devils, murderers and angels there is a strictly ordered justice.

Investigating groups that reported a large increase in adolescent crime last year in Brooklyn were rebuked sharply by Magistrate John F. X. Masterson in the annual report of the Brooklyn Adolescents Court, submitted yesterday to Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran.

ONE of the sturdiest flowers for the garden, and also one of the best for cutting, is snapdragon (Antirrhinum). But if we are to grow those colors and types whose descriptions sound closest to our liking there is little time to be lost in ordering the seeds and planting them for reasonably early summer bloom.

A field X-Ray machine has been designed by Westinghouse Engineers under Col. Alfred A. de Lorimier, to detect bullets and shrapnel in wounded men and to mark with iodine the spot where the surgeon must begin his work. The stretcher bearing the wounded soldier is placed on the topless X-ray field table and becomes the table top.

The nation's post-war military problems are so major and so many, in the opinion of most competent observers in Washington, and the solution of those problems will so intimately affect the lives of every one of us, that thorough studies of them should not be long delayed.

To sharpen public awareness of the sacrifices the armed forces are making, the week starting today was designated yesterday as Sacrifice Week in the Fourth War Loan Drive. Many of the events to stimulate bond sales will feature appearances by war heroes and Gold Star mothers.

Lieut. Col. Howard J. Berry of the Marine Corps declared yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the New York City Association for Health and Physical Education at the Hotel Pennsylvania that although twice as many men have been mobilized in this war as in World War I, "we have rejected more men than were in the armed forces last time."

THE iron and steel industry of the United States has just completed its greatest production year; within a few million tons, it produced almost as much steel in 1943 as the rest of the world combined. At the year-end this industry, basic in war and peace, possessed capacity for turning out as high as 94,000,000 net tons of ingots annually from its plants.

Reconversion of industry to peacetime production has long been regarded as one of our most important problems in the early post-war period. Just as it took considerable time to convert from peace to war output, so time will be needed to reconvert. The reconversion of productive facilities to peacetime goods, however, should take less time because manufacturers will be planning for the production of goods with which they are familiar.

Rail, oil and liquor stocks were features in the trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and prices were irregularly higher, the result of sharply selective trading. Business was active, and the volume of 520,510 shares compared with 661,940 on the preceding Saturday, which was the largest two-hour session since September.

IT begins to look as if Ephraim Tutt, Arthur Train's illustrious legal character of fiction, is really serious about coming to Broadway after all. Sure, Tecumseh knows something like this has been disclosed to a breathless populace before -- let's be conservative -- about a half dozen times. And yet Mr. Tutt has steadfastly remained in the wings.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Russia's proposal that Poland's post-war eastern border be established in the vicinity of the "Curzon line" and the Kremlin's virtual rejection of mediation of the problem by the United States and Great Britain, a step sought by the Polish Government-in-Exile in London, has, with few exceptions, strengthened opposition to the Soviet Union's demands among Polish-Americans throughout the United States.

WAR came to the Rev. William C. Taggart, chaplain of the Nineteenth Bombardment Group, as he was on a transport ten days out of Honolulu, bound for the Philippines. His ship hastily changed course for Australia when the news of the attack on Pearl Harbor came over the radio.

THERE is no need for this department to direct attention to the opening volume of George Santayana's autobiography. Recently published under the title. "Persons and Places: The Background of My Life," it had been eagerly awaited, and it has been ably reviewed.

MAY 22, 1940. The House of Commons met in a mood of impending disaster. The new Prime Minister, Winston Churchill had gone to France. The aged, white-wigged Speaker opened the session appropriately enough by announcing the death of a member. Across the Channel the Germans had taken Brussels, reached the old battlefield of the Somme and captured British General Headquarters at Arras.

Critical shortages which have existed in infants' and children's wear are being eliminated as Government agencies achieve marked progress in their program to solve manpower and fabric difficulties which have beset this field, according to Mrs. Crete Dahl, who has just returned to private industry after serving on loan to the Office of Civilian Requirements of the War Production Board as chief of the infants' and children's section.

The quiet decorum of the British House of Commons was broken last week by salvos of cheering. M.P.'s waved papers and shouted like schoolboys as Winston Churchill, sun-tanned and exuberant, strode past the speaker's chair to take his accustomed seat. The Prime Minister, seemingly none the worse for his recent illness, was in good form.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- For the first time in the Battle of the Atlantic the Germans have delivered a concentrated attack both by submarine and heavy bombers in a desperate attempt to halt a convoy steaming on its course between the Azores and the coast of Europe.

The Senate Banking and Currency Committee has approved the Bank-head bill allegedly designed to prohibit food subsidies. An interesting aspect of this anti-subsidy bill is that it does not prohibit all food subsidies. They may still be paid on vegetable oils, fats and seeds and "the ingredients and products thereof."

NORTH PLAINFIELD, N.J. Jan. 23 -- James C. Manchester, a 61-year-old New York City bartender, was stabbed to death at 3 A.M. today in the basement of the home of Mr. and Mrs. Lambert Melick, 8 Allen Place, here. Scott Wolfe Farland, a first-class seaman of the Navy, whose home is in Plainfield, was arrested and charged with the killing.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 23 -- To the accompaniment of the distant rumble of battle, punctuated at frequent intervals by air-raid alarms and aerial duels over the outskirts of the city, thousands of persons knelt in St. Peter's Square throughout the day, praying for the safety of Rome.

KEARNY, N.J., Jan. 23 -- The Kearny Americans and the Kearny Celtics drew at 1 -- 1 in the second round of the National Challenge Cup competition at Scots Field today. At the change of ends the Americans were leading by 1 -- 0.

With "The Duke in Darkness," opening tonight at the Playhouse, Patrick Hamilton will be represented by two plays on Broadway. The other one is "Angel Street," now in its third year. Starring Philip Merivale and featuring Edgar Stehli and Louis Hector, "The Duke in Darkness" has an all-male cast of ten.

The Polish problem must not be settled by "unilateral action," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America declared yesterday at the annual communion breakfast of the Carroll Club at the Waldorf-Astoria. It was the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the organization for Catholic women, and 1,500 were present.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Congress will undertake this week to settle one and possibly two of the most vexing issues on its calendar, soldier voting and price subsidies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The post-war legal and economic position of American women was the subject of discussion today at the first round-table session on the status of women ever included in the program of the American Economic Association.

UNITED STATES PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Hawaii, Jan. 23 -- Mars, the world's largest flying boat, entered naval service today with a flight from California to Hawaii with twenty passengers and a record cargo of 13,860 pounds of mail and highest priority war materials. She had fifteen men in her crew.

At Dover Plains in Dutchess County there is a preserve kitchen from which comes a homemade lime and lemon marmalade the color of fresh mint leaves. The marmalade is prepared under the supervision of Mrs. Marion N. Warwick according to a recipe that originated with her and that calls for nothing but the fruit juice, pulp, shredded peel and sugar.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Possibility of widespread price-cutting in some canned vegetable items and a return to "loss leaders" in grocery merchandising despite apparent food shortages, was predicted today by food trade leaders gathering here for their annual meetings.

Mayor La Guardia withheld comment yesterday on the report made public on Saturday by Investigation Commissioner William B. Herlands charging that the children's shelter of the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children had caused "incalculable harm" to thousands of children.

May I reply to a letter in your Jan. 16 issue regarding preventive medicine? Though I have not had the opportunity of seeing your editorial, I find that the writer objected to (1) "In this country there is no sign as yet of any assumption of new educational responsibilities" and (2) "Social and preventive medicine are taught in a sketchy fashion."

Despite the Federal Government's appeal for maximum food production, fruit and vegetable canners plan a smaller output this year, according to a survey released yesterday by the American Institute of Food Distribution, which attributes the prospective shrinkage to Washington's delay in announcing a 1944 food program.

The most formidable warship in the world, the USS Missouri, a 45,000-ton vessel, will be launched at the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn on Saturday, it was announced yesterday. Present plans call for completion of the ship at least nine months ahead of schedule.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- For the first time since the outbreak of the war, British bankers in their annual statements to shareholders have discussed at considerable length the financial and economic problems that will confront Great Britain during the switch-over from war to peace conditions.
The third movement of the Boogie-Woogie and Hep Cat Symphony opened yesterday with increasing fortissimi.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The new Allied attack south Continued on Page Three of Rome inspired the populace in northern Italy to violent demonstrations, particularly in the industrial cities, a dispatch from the Swiss border to the Morgen Tidningen said today.
Numerous sales of one-family homes in Brooklyn were reported over the week-end.

Servicemen in Alaska and the Aleutians are eager for baseball news and hopeful that the game can continue in 1944. That's the word brought back by Stan Musial and Danny Litwhiler of the St. Louis Cardinals who arrived in New York yesterday, according to The Associated Press.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Farmers sold corn last week on a much

Democracy is based upon a doctrine of man that stems from the Christian contention that he is a spiritual personality to be respected, the Rev. Louis W. Pitt, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, declared yesterday in a sermon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A canvass of the eighteen members of the Senate Military Committee which holds the fate of the proposed labor conscription bill showed tonight only one certain vote for the measure -- that of its author, Senator Austin of Vermont.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- A Senate-House group of Western and Southern members is preparing through two special committees to attack "Eastern money interests" and the alleged concentration of industry in the Northeastern States.
The Allies opened new offensives in widely scattered parts of the world last week, but there has been no major strategic change in the world situation since the start of winter.

Faith in Christ is a fundamental necessity for the achievement of world peace, the Rev. Thomas Lester Graham declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, exhorting the congregation to pray to Christ "to lead us out of the bondage of mutual distrust into the brightness of a peace-Father Graham, who is a member of the cathedral staff, said.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Yugoslav guerrillas said today that they had annihilated a strong German column and had thrown back other Nazi forces with losses in the Livno-Grachovo sector of western Bosnia and were continuing a bloody street battle for the mountain stronghold of Tuzla in eastern Bosnia.

MADRID, Jan. 23 -- The road out of Rome is filled with official cars of Germans and Italian Fascist authorities, fleeing because of the threat of Allied forces pressing in from the south, diplomatic reports from Rome declared today.

Army may have had a bit of trouble mastering the T-formation in football (to be brutally frank, the Cadets never did succeed in getting it down to a T), but the boys in Army gray are doing all right with the K-formation in basketball "K," of course, stands for Kelleher, first name Ed, who moved on up to the Plain this year to take charge of the Army squad.

The American people are being conditioned to take the shock of heavy losses in the military operations that lie ahead of us. Day after day official spokesmen prepare the public to expect the worst in the matter of casualties.

The House of the Holy Comforter will be aided by recital of original monologues by Mrs. Francis Rogers and English and American ballads by Earle Spicer to be given on Thursday afternoon in the ballroom of the Colony Club. The Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, will preside.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- General apathy continues to characterize the stock markets here. Portentous events lie ahead and everyone is waiting for something to turn up that will give the markets a definite lead one way or the other.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 23 -- The first four productions of International Pictures, the Leo Spitz-William Goetz producing organization, will be released through RKO Radio Pictures, Inc. The deal was concluded here during the week-end, with Ned Depinet, president, signing for the distributing company.

A UNITED STATES AIR FORCE FERRY STATION, Northern Ireland, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- It's a tough game when a ferry pilot takes off in the Irish fog to deliver a bomber to England, and winds up in Scotland with only a drop of gasoline, after flying to Iceland and back by dead reckoning, desperately seeking a place to land.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Final drafts were being drawn over the weekend on Administration program bills granting $19,500,000 in temporary aid to cities and setting up benefits for members of the armed forces demobilized during the coming year. Both bills tie in closely with Governor Dewey's executive budget to be submitted to the Legislature a week from tomorrow.

The report of the Orange County extraordinary grand jury on the labor situation at the Delaware River Water Supply project is an unanswerable argument for curbing the present "unbridled" economic powers of union officials.

Mayor La Guardia, backed up by Chief City Magistrate Henry H. Curran and Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins, retorted sharply yesterday to Charles P. Taft, former head of the Community War Service Agencies, who charged on Saturday that New York City was first on the list of cities responsible for venereal disease infection among members of the armed forces.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 23 -- Samuel Hirschberg, attorney for Dr. Leopold Brandenburg, who is being held as a material witness in the mysterious slaying of John Longstreet Ely, 80-year-old retired farmer, three years ago, announced today he had arranged a conference tomorrow to discuss the release of his client.

The question whether the Christian Church has the "right to survive" was taken up yesterday morning by the Rev. Laton E. Holmgren, associate minister of Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, who asserted that unless the church was willing to take a position on the front line and tackle the difficult problems that confronted mankind, its voice would be silent and it would become irrelevant.

After holding within a narrow range during most of last week, cotton prices advanced sharply on Saturday on the announcement that purchases of about 332,000 bales would be made in the open market for lend-lease purposes. At the close of the day's trading, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the week net advances of 16 to 37 points, with the strength centered in the near positions.

I was greatly perturbed by the letter of the Greek Ambassador, C. Diamantopoulos, in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 10, branding the Bulgarian people as responsible for the pro-Axis policy of Bulgaria's Quisling Government.

The Rev. Dr. F. Howard Callahan, pastor of the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, in his sermon yesterday suggested, as a measure that might help to win the war, postponement "of any national election until the war is won."

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 23 -- A prominent Greek said today that for every German soldier killed by guerrillas fifty Greeks were slain, that for one German officer killed 100 Greek lives were exacted and that for any German wounded ten Greeks were shot.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Jan. 24 (UP) -- A communique:

On the ground that a unification would not be in the public interest, the New York Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had denied the application of the Niagara Hudson system to consolidate six operating utilities and one holding company into a single operating company to serve 760,000 electric and 267,000 gas customers in a territory 400 miles long.

The New York Women's League for Animals will hold its annual meeting Thursday afternoon at the home of Mrs. M. Orme Wilson, 3 East Sixty-fourth Street. Mrs. J. Dyneley Prince, president of the league, and Henry C. Holt, treasurer, will present reports for 1943 and officers for the coming year will be elected.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS IN ITALY of the Supreme Allied Commander in Chief, Mediterranean Theatre, Communique 2:

A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE, in England, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Torn by ground fire and with three of its engines gone, the Liberator Liberty Bell crash-landed near a southeast England town after the Friday attacks on the French coast. For three hours the pilot and four fellow-crewmen battled to save three others trapped in the blazing wreckage with the bodies of two dead officers.

The Association of Natural Advertisers has distributed to all its members a booklet prepared by the Forest Service of the Department of Agriculture in cooperation with the Office of War Information, which urges all advertisers to bring the importance of timber in the war effort to the attention of the public and to stress prevention of forest fires by means of sustained campaigns.

Mrs. Beatrice W. Robbins has resigned the directorship of the Hudson Guild Child Care Center to serve as supervisory nursery education consultant for the twenty-nine wartime nurseries operating with State and city aid in the child care program of the Mayor's Committee, it was announced yesterday by Miss Helen M. Harris, executive director of the committee.
LONDON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Lend-lease shipments of food during the first eleven months of 1943 totaled 10,500,000,000 pounds, an increase from a year before, but the quantities shipped were only a small proportion of United States supplies, the War Food Administration and the Foreign Economic Administration said today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The movement of hogs to leading Midwestern markets continues unusually heavy. The Government predicted a short time ago that it would fall off late in January, but the forecast now is that shipments will be large until late in February, and some packers are inclined to look for heavy receipts for a longer period.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Jan. 23 -- The matter of weapons is a leading topic of conversation with any American combat unit. Individual marines tell of stripping down machine-guns to get maximum firepower with the smallest amount of weight.

Having gambled Japan's resources on a short war and lost, Premier Tojo now tells his people their one hope of victory lies in a long war. They are to win, he says, by the moral exhaustion of their enemies. But in his address to the Diet even this hope is modified by two significant provisos.

Provided with an initial fund of $4,500,000 by clothing manufacturers, the Amalgamated Life and Health Insurance Company will go into effect today for the benefit of 125,000 clothing workers and their families, under a collective labor agreement between the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States of America.

IN one respect it will be a very expensive basketball double-header, because you can pay as high as $1,000 for your seat, a price which is sufficient to scare even a cold-blooded scalper. If your means are more modest, you can settle on a $25 ticket, or to be more precise, one costing $18.75. But regardless of the amount subscribed, it is an exceedingly cheap evening of entertainment.

Junior American Nurse, Inc., a nonprofit, nonsectarian and nonpartisan organization devoted to training young women from the ages of 13 to 23, will share in the proceeds from the piano recital to be given by George Copeland on Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall.

Nine families who had been shivering for four days in an unheated Brooklyn apartment house went out yesterday and brought in a ton of coal to start the furnace. They acted for their own protection as Mayor La Guardia, in his regular Sunday broadcast, explained further the city's plan to establish about 100 coal dumps this week.
Alfons Bach, director of Alfons Bach Associates, has been re-elected president of the American Designers Institute. The election marks the second to that office for Mr. Bach.
Among many reasons why subscriptions to War Bonds should be made during the Fourth War Loan drive are the following:

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Mill buying and short covering in wheat developed last week to bring about an upturn of about 3 cents a bushel from the recent low, but the volume of business was decidedly subnormal. The May delivery came within 2 cents of the ceiling price on futures, but the deferred months were under comparative pressure and lost ground relative to the near delivery.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Because tires made available by the Office of the Rubber Director for the first quarter of this year for trucks and buses fail by substantial percentages of meeting requirements estimated by the Office of Defense Transportation, Joseph B. Eastman, ODT director, today asked all truck and bus operators to report to his office if they are unable to obtain tire certificates from their ration boards.

Seven apartment houses at 1457 to 1483 College Avenue, in the Bronx, were purchased by S.N. Petchers from the Gedex Realty Corporation. They contain 147 apartments and occupy a plot with a frontage of 280 feet on College Avenue and a depth of ninety-two feet.

Very little of a favorable nature has been said of the now waning flu epidemic. Like most ills, however, it had its cheerful aspects. Some persons had forced upon them a few days of complete rest which they may have needed badly.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The creation of a new Bulgarian constabulary resembling Germany's Elite Guard and Storm Troop units to suppress revolt, anti-government demonstrations and sabotage was announced by the Sofia radio tonight.

"A DEFENSELESS neighbor is the strongest inducement to war," wrote Gen. Hans von Seeckt in the days when Germany was far from defenseless but was pretending to be so. Although Germany then, under the Weimar Republic, was in no danger of being attacked by anybody, the remark was one of the truest things ever written if it is taken as applying to Germany, for whom a defenseless neighbor is indeed a strong inducement to war.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Ohio Republican, said tonight that the new Lucas soldier vote bill, if enacted, "might throw the whole election into a legal tailspin."

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, Below Rome, Jan. 22 (Delayed) -- American and British troops hold the coastal towns in their new invasion area and the terminus of a highway to Rome, and today they are awaiting with some impatience the first retort of the Germans.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 23 -- Australia has enjoyed such an abundance of food in the past that it is difficult for her people to adjust themselves to the present condition of scarcity.

May I offer my hearty approval of the sentiment expressed in your editorial of Jan. 18, although, under the Constitution of the United States, no exception can be taken to the action of the Senate and of the House committee in rejecting the proposed measure for Government control or regulation of the balloting by the armed forces for President and Vice President in the forthcoming November elections.

Trim and spruce in his uniform of the Army Air Forces, Lieut. Don Budge, world champion tennis player, arrived in New York last night ready to play his part in the drive to swell the sale of bonds in the Fourth War Loan Drive. Accompanied by Mrs. Budge, the court champion was greeted as he stepped off the train at Grand Central Station by Walter Pate, former captain of the United States Davis Cup team.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt has approved establishment of two new hospitals for treating veterans with nervous and mental disorders, Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans' Affairs and chairman of the Federal Board of Hospitalization, said tonight.

ALGIERS, Jan. 23 -- The Allies' air effort over Italy yesterday was the greatest since the two worst days below Salerno, when everything from fighters to heavy bombers battered the Germans until they were forced to withdraw.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- What may prove to be a test case of the ability of the United States and Great Britain to reconcile their wartime political partnership with their normal commercial competition was discussed with President Roosevelt on Friday by James M. Landis, American Director of Economic Operations in the Middle East, it was learned today.

The first flow of raw refinery gases will start today through the world's largest petroleum butadiene plant at Port Neches, Tex., it was announced here yesterday. The plant is being operated without profit by five large oil companies with refineries near by.
CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 23 -- The Bengal rice market, which three weeks ago seemed to be getting out of hand, has steadied and prices have eased in most parts of the province.

ALGIERS, Jan. 23 -- Wherever American sailors are helping to bring the Mediterranean campaign to a successful conclusion, they are also part of that collaterally important campaign, the war-bond drive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Charboy Products, Inc., Red Bank, N.J., has been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease and desist from disseminating false advertisements concerning Cuproloid, a medicinal preparation it sells and recommends for treating diseases and ailments of the skin, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Seven of thirteen sailing dinghies in the winter regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club capsized today in a treacherous northwest wind and the sailors suddenly found themselves sprawled in the icy waters.

Katya Delakova and Fred Berk, who were trained in the modern dance schools of Vienna, presented last night a program called "Make Way for Tomorrow" in Times Hall. Departing from the usual pattern of the dance recital, it added to its dance scenes interludes of song and verse, and bound all the elements together with a kind of theme.
It was a great day for the Chinese yesterday and an auspicious beginning for Chinatown's own drive for the Fourth War Loan.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 23 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Jan. 24 -- Australian troops, attacking in force through mountain country, drove the Japanese from positions at the head of the Faria River and won a hold on the Kankiryo ridge, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced in his communique today.

The Brooklyn Wanderers and the Brooklyn Hispanos played a 3-3 tie in their second-round National Challenge Cup soccer match at Brooklyn Oval yesterday. Owing to the muddy condition of the grounds extra periods were not ordered and the game will be replayed next Sunday at the same place.

TRENTON, Jan. 23 -- Gov. Walter E. Edge made a pledge today to the American Legion that his State administration would have an adequate program to cope with the problem of returning war veterans and "to cushion the whole civilian economy of the State against the strain of reconverting from a wartime to a peacetime economy."

Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the Zionist Organization of America, declared yesterday that establishment of a War Refugee Board by President Roosevelt was an important move toward saving thousands of Jews in Europe who are threatened by the Nazis with extermination.

Infrequently heard works by Beethoven featured the tenth concert of the New Friends of Music Series at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon, given by the Kolisch Quartet and assisting artists. The latter were Gerald Kunz, viola; Marjory Hess, soprano; Winifred Heidt, alto; Hans Heinz, tenor: Jess Walters, bass, and Konrad Wolff, piano.

Anticipating a huge increase in street traffic as the result of mass production of low-priced cars after the war, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday his intention to appoint a committee headed by Park Commissioner Robert Moses to make a comprehensive city-wide study in order to find methods of handling the problem.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Allied ground forces, slowly pushing the Japanese back on two widely separated Burma fronts, reported new successes today in the Mayu Peninsula in the southwest and the Chindwin Valley in the northwest.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 (AP) -- More than half of the 2,300 public works employes who voted yesterday to end their 17-day-old strike returned today to the job of removing 90,000 tons of garbage and debris littering the city streets. Unofficial estimates said the clean-up would take three weeks.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 23 (AP) -- "Too young" for the Army, Sgt. Thomas Kincaid of Columbus, Ohio, 16, who has more than 300 hours of combat flying to his credit, is going home. He holds the Distinguished Flying Cross and the air medal with a silver and four bronze oak leaf clusters.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- In a determined attempt to win a place in Congress for Miss Jane H. Todd of Tarrytown, women of the Westchester County Republican organization are laying the groundwork for their greatest political skirmish for recognition since they won the suffrage.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 23 -- The Canberra agreement with New Zealand, signed last Friday, is officially regarded as a landmark in British Commonwealth relations and in Pacific affairs. It is in effect a loose confederation of the two Dominions for purposes of foreign policy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23 -- California Republican leaders do not expect any kind of contest at the May 2 Presidential preference primary election now that Wendell L. Willkie has formally announced he would not be a candidate.

CARTERSVILLE, Ga., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Rudy York, 1943 American League home run king, paused in his farm chores today to express the opinion that "within sixty days" he would join his chief rival, Charley (King Kong) Keller, in the armed services.

The Board of Education proposes to ask for funds which would enable it to conduct 113 after-school playgrounds throughout the school year, in place of the seventy-five now organized, and to increase vacation playgrounds from 262 to 354. An extension of both facilities is needed.

"When I design I never start with the neck and finish with the hem, I design from the head to the sole." These words were spoken by Norman Norell, clever young designer from Indiana, whose style influence is strongly felt in New York.

Wendell L. Willkie announced yesterday that as a result of telephone conversations with Gov. Earl Warren he had decided not to enter the California Presidential preference primary. Although Governor Warren, possibly to prevent entry of any aspirant, technically will be a candidate for the Presidential nomination, Mr. Willkie said the Governor had assured him that he would not be an actual candidate.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 17 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Because First Lieuts. Roy E. Thomas of Buffalo, N.Y., and Cecil A. Gibson of Columbus, Ga., knew a lot of guys in China would be disappointed if the mail didn't come through they stuck to their plane and landed 5,000 pounds of letters last night after trying to fly through the top of a mountain.

Reuben A. Lazarus, counsel for the Board of Statutory Consolidation and for many years the city's legislative representative at Albany, was named by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to the post of assistant to the Mayor.
ALGIERS, Jan. 23 -- The Allies have penetrated to a depth of several miles along the widening beachhead below Rome without a sign of the expected counter-attack, it was officially announced today.

Postponement of a meeting of the Tammany executive committee to next Saturday evening was interpreted yesterday by supporters of Michael J. Kennedy as lessening the chance of his ouster from the leadership.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices prepared by the index number institute was 112.49, a rise of 0.06 per cent from the previous week's level of 112.43. The raw materials index and the farm products index rose again.

A 10-cent subway fare was advocated yesterday as the chief among a series of proposals to rehabilitate city finances in a program offered by the Committee of Fifteen, headed by former Corporation Counsel Paul Windels.

The Molly Pitcher Hotel, at Red Bank, N.J., has been sold by Coleman House, Inc., to Jersey Hotels, Inc., the lessee for the last twelve years. The new owner plans several improvements, including the construction of a dock and boathouse on the Shrewsbury River.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Eight persons were killed and ten injured tonight in the collision of a passenger train and a city bus near a suburban railroad station.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Scoring three times in the first period and twice in the second, the Chicago Black Hawks defeated the second-place Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 to 3, tonight in a National Hockey League game before 16,546 at Chicago Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- United States Navy bombers, following up their first double assault on Japanese installations on Paramushiru Island at the northern tip of the Kuriles, struck again early Sunday morning (East Longitude time) with a two-group attack.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The pacesetting Montreal Canadiens gained their first Boston Garden victory over the Bruins since Nov. 26, 1940, by outskating Art Ross' injury-riddled forces for a 4-1 triumph before a 12,200 crowd tonight despite a sensational goal-tending exhibition by Bert Gardiner.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Wilson Co., Inc., processors of meats and other foods, reported today net earnings of $7,403,182, equal to $2.73 a common share, for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, 1943. This compared with net earnings of $7,319,508, or $2.68 a common share, in the preceding fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- Dimes and dollars of the public in general, will be the chief financial backing of the Democratic Presidential campaign whether President Roosevelt seeks a fourth term or not, party officials indicated tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- Dr. Enrique de Lozada, confidential agent in Washington of the new revolutionary Bolivian Government, reigned today coincident with intimations that the State Department this week might formally announce its refusal to recognize the La Paz regime.

Defeating Walter Goldwater in the eighth round after 56 moves, Pfc. Herbert Seidman, former champion of the Marshall Chess Club, improved his standing at the head of the list of competitors in the current title tournament yesterday, with a record of 7 1/2 points out of 8.

With the home relief case load now down where it is expected to remain fairly constant, at least for the duration of the war, the principal problem facing the City Department of Welfare is that of child care, especially as it relates to finding foster homes, Commissioner Leo Arnstein declared yesterday.

DES MOINES, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Sixty producers of hogs in ten Midwestern States adopted today a resolution urging immediate remedy of the hog-marketing situation "to prevent further liquidation of brood sows and of unfinished, lightweight pigs."

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Lord Vansittart, a bitter opponent of Germany, declared today that the Germans were interested in winning the peace now that they were beginning to see that they could not win the war. Addressing a meeting of the Win the Peace Movement, of which he is president, Lord Vansittart said:
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 -- Raw steel output last week remained unchanged at 98 1/2 per cent of rated capacity. Indications are that the ingot rate this week will show little or no change.

Fletcher Pratt, Max Werner and Col. Carlos Romulo are to speak at the first book meeting tomorrow evening at The New York Times Hall, under the sponsorship of THE NEW YORK TIMES. The discussion topic is "When Will the War End?" Hanson W. Baldwin, military editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will preside.

Large numbers of buyers were in the market again last week and a continued influx of arrivals is looked for during the current week. Deliveries appear to be worrying buyers, and pressure is being placed for shipments, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

MADRID, Jan. 23 (AP) -- German concern over the possibility that an invasion of France will come in a dual attack from both the Atlantic and the Mediterranean is no longer a secret but is shown by elaborate defense preparations along the coast from the Pyrenees to Marseille.

The argument against the Equal Rights Amendment which seems to carry most weight is that it will under mine legislation designed to protect women. To this I would say that we all have a right to demand and expect justice.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Allied aircraft attacked enemy shipping and supply dumps at Lorengau, in the Admiralty Islands, northeast of New Guinea, leaving a 2,500-ton freighter burning, destroying barges and setting fires in the supply areas.

Construction of a world fashion center, comprising six to ten new buildings to house the leading apparel and allied interests of the country, as "New York City's post-war business project No. 1," was proposed in a report made public yesterday by the Mayor's Committee for World Fashion Center.

Financial markets were moderately active but devoid of wide price changes last week, a propitious condition for the Fourth War Loan Drive that started on Tuesday. Stocks moved irregularly within a narrow range, with rails and low-priced specialties featured in the trading; bonds were firmer, carriers pacing the improvement and reaching their best levels since January, 1937; trading, although large, was below the previous week's dealings, and grains and cotton were higher on the week.

One of the most vital tasks of the church at the end of the war will be the spiritual rehabilitation of our fighting men, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, said in his sermon yesterday on "Rebuilding This Shattered World."

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The question of who would succeed Lieut. Gen. Jacob L. Devers in command of United States forces in the European Theatre of Operations was answered today in an announcement that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower would take on that command in addition to his duties as Supreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force.

The first award of its kind to be presented to any professional society has been conferred by the Ordnance Department on the Society of Automotive Engineers. Presented on the occasion of the Society's annual meeting, the award was made "in recognition of outstanding and meritorious engineering advisory services in war and peace; in design, manufacture and maintenance of ordnance materiel."

A conference of 2,000 Congress of Industrial Organizations officials at Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, under the auspices of the Greater New York CIO Council, adopted a resolution yesterday calling upon President Roosevelt to run for a fourth term and pledging him full support.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- A stern warning that the war is approaching Bulgaria and an appeal to the Bulgarian people to join their brother Slavs in the war against Germany was issued in Moscow today by representatives of Russia, he Ukraine, White Russia, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and Poland.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A conference of representatives of the United Nations, meeting at the call of the United States, to discuss the post-war plans and international adjustments for peace and security was proposed today by Senator Harold H. Burton of Ohio.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 24 -- The Red Army opened a new drive yesterday in the Kirishi area, 50-odd miles southeast of Leningrad, and wiped out a strong German bridgehead on the east bank of the Volkhov River, while in southern White Russia, Gen. Konstantin K. Rokossovsky's forces were revealed by Moscow to have driven forty miles deeper into the heart of the Pripet Marshes during the past nine days.

More than 1,500 uniformed men and women of the armed forces will be among the guests at the forty-second annual entertainment and ball of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club, which will be given the night of Feb. 9 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The executive board of directors of the American Bowling Congress recommended yesterday a plan to hold qualifying tournaments when the ABC tourney is resumed after the war, The Associated Press reports.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 24 -- Hundreds of medium and light bombers and fighter-bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force and the Royal Air Force hit Nazi targets from the Cherbourg peninsula to the Netherlands yesterday.
Britain's First Lord of the Admiralty, A.V. Alexander, said over the Columbia Broadcasting System from London yesterday afternoon that the Allies "are now definitely on top at sea."

By a brilliant stroke which is a tribute to both their strategy and their military intelligence service the Allied forces in Italy have suddenly leaped across all the fortified positions which the Germans had hoped to hold all winter and have brought the long-drawn-out battle for Rome to the very gates of the Italian capital itself.

The calling of a three-power Japanese, German and Italian conference to draft a joint declaration expressing the Axis concept of the world as against the United Nations plan outlined at Cairo would be "devoid of benefit," Premier Tideki Tojo told the Japanese Diet yesterday, a Domei broadcast from Tokyo said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- The Federal Power Commission advised Congress tonight that the agency did not expect during the war period to initiate additional cases against natural gas companies for rate reductions.
Four new films will arrive on Broadway this week. The schedule follows:

The Allied troops just "walked in" to the sleeping little coast towns of Anzio and Nettuno. No one was there to stop them. A few miles away, in the hills above Frascati, the German headquarters staff had been bombed out of the old villa they occupied, but apparently they were asleep somewhere else.
DETROIT, Jan. 23 -- In the most decisive victory in National Hockey League history, the Red Wings blasted the Rangers by 15 to 0 tonight before 12,293.
