WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Speaker Rayburn rules a slight choice over Vice President Wallace among members of the Democratic National Committee who are willing to express a direct preference for the Vice Presidential nomination.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Tales of German torture were told today by almost a score of Greek refugees who escaped from Europe in a small boat during a violent storm.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Hugo Cedergren of Stockholm, the former Countess Elsa Bernadotte and niece of the King of Sweden, revealed tonight that she would soon make a tour to bring cheer to enemy alien camps in this country at which family groups are interned.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Short supplies of articles for retailers were said today to be troubling buyers who are in Chicago today to attend two markets.

Despite Nazi oppression of the Christian Church, it remains the chief center of resistance against Hitlerism in occupied Europe, the Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, declared yesterday in a sermon at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

After a brief ownership, Henry Goelet, the operator, has resold the ten-story store and loft building at 291-93 Seventh Avenue, between Twenty-sixth and Twenty-seventh Streets, in the fur district, to the Furdis Realty Corporation for investment.

MIAMI, Jan. 23 -- Influential leaders in the American Federation of Labor who are attending the meeting of the federation's executive council are strongly urging that the application of the United Mine Workers for readmission be favorably acted on before the council winds up its deliberations late this week.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet press and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- Moscow said last night that in the fighting around Novgorod the Russians had pierced the German defenses along the Veronda River to occupy twelve towns. About a regiment of Germans -- 3,000 to 4,000 men -- was killed in all the fighting as the Russians struck both west and southwest of Novgorod.
Gen. Isaias Medina-Angarita, President of Venezuela, arrived at Pennsylvania Station at 8:05 P. M. yesterday, where he was greeted by Mayor La Guardia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Senate's new Service Men's Voting Bill, supposedly bearing compromises suitable to all factions, received a far from harmonious reception as it reached the floor today. By nightfall its position was admittedly uncertain, with sponsors studying further concessions in the hope of getting it through.

QUINCY, Mass., Jan. 24 -- The Navy had another new giant aircraft carrier in the water tonight, this one of 25,000 tons, named after the first Governor of Massachusetts, John Hancock, and paid for with $96,000,000 in war bonds bought by agents and policyholders of the insurance company bearing the same name.

OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- After twenty-eight years of service at Clinton Prison at Dannemora, William Snyder, who rose from guard to principal keeper there, arrived at Sing Sing Prison this afternoon to take over the duties of warden on a provisional appointment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The United States Public Health Service, armed with a $200,000 fund by Congress, is ready to help communities suffering a shortage of physicians and dentists, Surgeon General Thomas Parran said today.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Yugoslav Partisan headquarters announced today the Germans were recklessly throwing men and materials into a costly and bloody bid for Senj, a Croat coastal town thirty-five miles south of Fiume.

Al Schoendienst, hard-hitting shortstop of the Rochester Red Wings, carried off the batting championship of the International League for the 1943 season with a mark of .337, according to the official averages announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A compromise that would give veterans of this war payments from $100 to $300 when mustered out was agreed upon by House and Senate conferees today.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Jan. 25 (UP) -- A communique:
Mayor La Guardia spent his noon hour yesterday making a prediction and a wish, both aimed at the betterment of mankind.
LONDON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 24 -- Revised and more significant courses in American history should be taught in the schools and colleges of the United States, Prof. Edgar Bruce Wesley of the University of Minnesota declared tonight at a meeting of the New Jersey Association of Social Studies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Introduction of ration tokens by the Office of Price Administration on Feb. 27 is expected by officials to cure one of its most troublesome problems, the "stuffing" of ration stamp envelopes deposited in banks with blank pieces of paper.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Behind the question asked in the House of Commons the other day about two men of Irish birth being parachuted from a German plane over Eire territory there is a peculiar and as yet incomplete story that like many dramatic war tales may remain unfinished for all time or may become a documented account when the war is over.

The opening of the General Sessions trial of Wayne Lonergan in the killing of his young wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, which had been set for Jan. 31, was postponed yesterday by Judge John J. Freschi until Feb. 14. The court acted on the motion of two of the three defense lawyers, Millard H. Ellison and Abraham J. Halperin, to which Assistant District Attorney Jacob Grumet, who is to prosecute Lonergan, agreed.

I have seen reference in your paper from time to time to the Equal Rights Amendment proposed by the Woman's party and introduced in Congress twenty-three years ago. Because of the fact that there is a great deal of opposition to that amendment by the women's organizations and particularly by women in industry, I want to give you some facts.

There were surprised looks on the faces of the committee that did the seeding for the Class C championship singles of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association at the Harvard Club yesterday when their No. 1 choice, A.F. Douglas of Bronxville, suffered defeat at the hands of T.L. McCray of the Dartmouth Club.

The Stagehands Union resumed picketing last night of Cafe Society, a night club at 128 East Fifty-eighth Street, because the proprietor, Barney Josephson, had refused to engage a member of the union at $90 a week to "push a button" three times a night to provide light for the evening floor show.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Sidney Hillman, chairman of the CIO political action committee, said today that he would make public tomorrow at the conclusion of the two-day meeting of twelve of the fourteen regional directors a list of Senators and Representatives to be apposed by the committee in the 1944 elections.

JOE BURK is up to his old tricks again, stepping into a boat and winning with it. The finest single sculls performer of all time is now operating a P-T craft in the South Pacific and already is credited with being the leader in the championship sweepstakes. Ensign Joe would rather capture that title than the Diamond Sculls which once was the standout achievement of his brilliant career.

Unusual tropical flowers on the spring toque, the addition of flattering back treatments to the forward tilted beret, and special emphasis on the wide-brimmed cartwheel silhouette were highlights of the spring hat showing yesterday by Erik of Paris at his salon at 15 East 53d Street.

THE TIMES is to be congratulated for publishing Harold Denny's dispatches on the present situation in Spain. These dispatches demonstrate clearly the wisdom of our State Department's policy and that of the British Government toward Spain during the past three years.

The ten-cent subway fare stands out like a sore thumb among the proposals submitted yesterday by the Committee of Fifteen to "restore the financial health of the city." The membership of this unofficial group, headed by former Corporation Counsel Paul Windels, is evidence that this is a responsible and public-spirited program.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Jan. 24 -- Migratory workers are leaving this West Coast area of critical labor shortages in greater numbers than replacements are arriving, largely because of "a notion prevalent elsewhere in the country that the war is over," War Manpower officials asserted today.

BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- William Cardinal O'Connell, dean of the Catholic Hierarchy in the United States, and Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Methodist Church, representing the Massachusetts Council of Churches in a joint statement issued today, called "racial antagonism" offensive to "the precepts of the Almighty and the traditions of our beloved nation."

Full-time employment for university-trained women increased 153 per cent last year, Miss Mary A. Wegener, acting secretary of appointments at Columbia University, revealed yesterday in her annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president. The report is concerned with all university placements, excluding Barnard College.

For the last six months our planes have been raiding Paramushiru at intervals, both to drop bombs and take photographs. Now the attack has suddenly been intensified, with American fliers hammering Japanese installations for four consecutive nights. Relays of naval planes have hit the entire coast of the island with heavy pattern bombing.

Allie Stolz, 132 3/4, Newark, N.J., knocked out Angelo Callura, 136, Hamilton, Ont., in the feature bout scheduled for eight rounds before a 2,900 crowd at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The end came after the sixth session had been completed, Referee Billy Cavanagh stepping in and halting hostilities in order to save the Canadian from further punishment.

The total of 9,525 new books and new editions published in 1943, as quoted in this week's Publishers Weekly, reveals a decrease of 1,200 under the figures of 1942 for the same production. The shrinkage probably is accounted for by the number of authors engaged actively in the war program and thus not writing books, as much as by paper shortages and rationing.

CHUNGKING, Jan. 23 (Delayed) -- Although modern China officially frowns on a Chinese New Year's celebration, firecrackers are sputtering in the streets tonight and the exciting clang of gongs is shattering the clammy darkness to mark New Year's Eve.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- A combined excess profits tax and industrial reconversion reserve law was signed today by President Getulio Vargas, retroactive through 1943.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Although the good war news brought a cheerful tone to the stock markets here today, business was on very small scale.

Willie Hoppe and Welker Cochran each took a block yesterday in opening the New York phase of their cross-country three-cushion match at the Metropolitan Billiard Club, 225 West Fifty-seventh Street. Hoppe led at the conclusion of the two blocks, however, l00 to 86. Six blocks are to be played here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Extension of the Government's price support program to include choice butcher hogs weighing from 300 to 330 pounds was announced tonight by the War Food Administration.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN ITALY, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Gen. Sir Henry Maitland Wilson said today that Allied troops were racing to build up the Nettuno beachhead against expected German counter - attacks that might develop fighting as fierce as the Battle of Salerno.

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein and Rollin Browne, president of the State Tax Commission, announced yesterday a new working arrangement between their offices for a more effective tax law enforcement. With the announcement came word of the filing of two informations by a Kings County grand jury charging two Brooklyn residents with income tax evasions for 1942.

Changes in the State Workmen's Compensation Law and its administration were recommended yesterday by Louis Hollander, president of the New York State Industrial Union Council and Dewey Dorsett, assistant general manager of the Association of Casualty and Surety Executives, representing sixty-two stock insurance companies.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered the Middle West Corporation to strip itself of interest in all the companies in its far-flung utilities system except the Illinois Public Service Company and the Kentucky Utilities Company, over which it received only a tentative right to retain control.

The Army, Navy and Marine Corps will certainly be interested to learn that this is "Sacrifice Week" for the folks at home. Between battles they will want to know what is going to happen to us. Are we going to be asked to lie in muddy ditches while somebody shoots at us?

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The salable supply of hogs was cut sharply under the permission-to-market plan that became effective today and a fairly good clearance was experienced. The general cattle trade was steady to firm. Sheep sold strong to a shade higher.

W.R. Grace Co., one of American's leading international trading and shipping concerns, made public yesterday a statement that challenged the argument frequently made that if the United States maintains a large merchant marine after the war it will suffer a disastrous loss in exports because the British and other maritime nations will have to decrease their purchases in this country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Those whose visions of the future are fulfilled are always few, and this will be proved again if the President decides not to accept nomination for a fourth term. The capital for the past few days has been crowded with professional Democratic politicians from all parts of the country, but less than a dwarf's handful expressed the slightest doubt Mr. Roosevelt will seek the Presidency again.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Dividends paid by industrial concerns in occupied Holland in 1942 were less than half the dividend payments in 1939, the last year before the German occupation, according to reports of the German-controlled Central Bureau of Statistics received here by the Netherlands News Agency (Aneta).

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 24 -- The extent to which the Allied troops in the Middle East were unwittingly serving the interests of the hashish traffic in Lebanon, Syria, Palestine and Egypt was revealed today in an account of the activities to the special investigation branch of the Military Police Corps of the British Army.

The battle of Rome appears to have developed into a race between two armies. The Allied landing forces now centered on Nettuno are moving swiftly to cut German communications with the Gustav line, some eighty miles south of the Italian capital. Meantime the approximately 100,000 Germans on that line have staged a desperate counter-offensive to extricate themselves from their precarious position.
Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Bogart will leave the Plaza today to spend the remainder of the season in Palm Beach.
Activities of the United Service Organizations in the Western Hemisphere outside the United States were described yesterday at headquarters in the Empire State Building.

Mrs. Felix M. Warburg has given the imposing mansion in which she and her husband, the late Felix M. Warburg, banker and philanthropist, made their home for many years, to the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, it was announced yesterday after the board of directors of the seminary had voted at a special meeting to accept the gift.
ADVANCE HEADQUARTER IN ITALY of the Supreme Allied Commander in Chief, Mediterranean Theatre, communique 3:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 24 -- Warner Brothers have named Ann Sheridan for the lead in "Doughgirls," film version of the play by Joy Hodges. Mark Hellinger expects to start production on the picture in March, with James V. Kern directing.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 park Avenue (at Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world offers a partial list of free amusements available today. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets 4, 5:30, 6:30 and 7:30 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue for tickets.

The article by Edwin L. James in THE TIMES of Jan. 23 on United States-Argentine relations probes a sore spot that is marring hemispheric solidarity. Mr. James does not think there is much hope that economic sanctions, which are being applied to a limited extent, will pry Argentina away from her pro-Axis leanings.

As all must know by this time, "The Cherry Orchard," tonight's opening at the National, is looked upon as a classic of pre-Soviet Russia Forty years ago this month, historians aver, the Anton Chekhov play was first produced in Moscow by that city's now world-famous Art Theatre. Broadway last saw it performed in English in 1933 with Eva Le Gallienne, who is co-starred with Joseph Schildkraut in the present version.

After a show of strength in the early dealings, cotton futures developed yesterday an easier tendency under intermittent flurries of liquidation and hedge selling At the close active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 6 to 8 points, or 30 to 40 cents a bale.

OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- Meyer Luckman, one of the men who murdered Samuel Drukman in the Luckman Brothers Garage in Brooklyn on March 3, 1935, died in the Sing Sing Prison Hospital yesterday of a chronic heart ailment. He was 67 years old.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 25--United States heavy and medium bombers struck in force yesterday at industrial targets in western Germany and Nazi defensive installations along and behind the coast of western Europe, especially the Pas-de-Calais area of ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Roosevelt today directed Secretary Frank Knox of the Navy to take immediate possession of the York Safe and Lock Company plant at York County, Pa.. which is manufacturing 44-mm. gun-mounts for the Navy.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, near Cassino, Jan. 23 (Delayed) -- "The boys fought until they did not have a bullet to shoot," Lieut. Col. Andrew Price of Fort Worth, Tex., said tonight, explaining how the Americans had been thrown back across the Rapido River by the overwhelming weight of German counter-attacks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (U.P.) -- A simplified individual income tax structure which would relieve 30,000,000 taxpayers of the need for filing returns is the objective of legislation introduced today by Representative Carlson, Republican of Kansas.

The 139th annual exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts opened on Sunday in Philadelphia. The Temple medal for the "best picture" in the exhibition was awarded to Franklin C. Watkins for his portrait of Thomas Raeburn White.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The House of Representatives voted today to take supervision of the expenditures of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration out of the hands of the President and put them under the State Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Four of the five members of the International Typographical Union's executive council, called before the War Labor Board today to sign a no-strike pledge, declined to give such unconditional assurance either in writing or verbally, but offered statements accepted by board members as a satisfactory substitute.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The compulsory evacuation of women and children from the increasingly vulnerable French Mediterranean coast by the German Army, working through Vichy, is interpreted here as one of the first results of a more elastic Allied strategy in the Mediterranean, exemplified by the successful landing of British and American units of the Fifth Army at Nettuno.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Two of Britain's most brilliant military leaders, Gen. Sir George Giffard and Lieut Gen. W.J. Slim, have been selected for important posts in the fight against Japan under Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten, it was announced tonight.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

JERUSALEM, Palestine, Jan. 24 -- The presence in Palestine of large numbers of refugees from the Greek Aegean islands was revealed today. Most of them came from Samos, but there also were some from the small Italian Dodecanese islands.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 24 -- Farm women of many States are beginning to study their household tasks with a view to applying factory speed-up methods, according to Miss Mary Rokahr, home management specialist of the Extension Service of the Department of Agriculture.

There is one form of lawlessness which it would be wrong to blame on the war, though no doubt the war has made things worse. It is the type of anti-social behavior described yesterday in our columns by Miss Frances Phillips, manager of the domestic service branch of the local United States Employment Service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- It took Tommy Harmon just a few minutes to shoot down two Zeroes and lose his own plane and half his pants, but thirty-two days to get back to his base from the Chinese lake into which he parachuted.
A smuggled dispatch received by International News Service yesterday indicated that Lowell Bennett, 24-year-old war correspondent, escaped from a German prison camp in December.

With sales of bonds in the Fourth War Loan Drive mounting in city, State and nation, a thousand volunteer salesmen in this area gathered last night at a dinner in the Commodore Hotel to hear firsthand reports of how the dollars they raise are fighting on battle-fronts all over the world.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 (AP)--He said it, all right, but he didn't mean it to sound the way it did.

UNITED STATES AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS IN CHINA, Jan. 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- The activation of two composite wings of medium and light bombers and fighters with their own reconnaissance service so as to divide the vast Chinese theatre and adjacent southwestern territory between two small but versatile tactical air forces was announced today by Maj. Gen. Claire Chennault.

One of the most remarkable versions of the do-it-yourself theme is the home-made permanent wave. To judge by the sales figures of several Manhattan department stores, at least 30,000 women are walking triumphantly about town in permanent waves wound, set and styled by their own hands.

TORONTO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, called tonight for a closer post-war linking of the British Commonwealth of Nations to make up together one of the world's four great powers.

Many buyers plan to return to the wholesale markets here early next month to check up on women's apparel orders, inasmuch as deliveries promise to be slow in the face of current consumer interest in spring merchandise and the earlier arrival of Easter on April 9. Merchandisers reported yesterday that difficulties on reorders, particularly on suits, already were beginning to crop up.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- George N. Briggs, suspended assistant of Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, appeared today before the Federal grand jury which is investigating the mystery of the "Harry Hopkins" letter. Both Mr. Hopkins and Henry A. Schweinhaut, the assistant attorney general conducting the inquiry, have said the document is a forgery.

The other day I went to the Red Cross blood bank at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street to contribute blood for the fifth time. I was disappointed to see that people are not responding as faithfully as they previously did, in spite of the fact that everyone knows of the great need.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Retailers today were assured by the War Production Board that inventory limitation appeals resulting from the variable Easter date will be given prompt consideration, as Easter on April 9 is sixteen days earlier this year than last. Many stores merchandise some or all of their spring stocks in relation to Easter, the war agency explained.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- British women should receive positions of higher responsibility and authority in the Church of England after the war, according to a report issued today by the committee appointed by the Archbishops of Canterbury and York.

Samuel Burkowits, 64-year-old temporary postal clerk, was denounced yesterday as a bottleneck in the "March of Dimes." Postal inspectors who arrested him said they found in his possession five unopened "March of Dimes" letters addressed to the President and $20 in dimes.

Early revision of leather price ceiling regulations to overcome the industry's and Government's dissatisfaction with present regulations was promised yesterday by Daniel Keeler, price executive of the Office of Price Administration's leather section at a meeting of leather jobbers, wholesalers and retailers held at the regional offices of the agency in the Empire State Building.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase last week of 7 per cent over the like period of 1943, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a rise of 6 per cent in sales.

Marguerite Namara returned after an absence of several years to the New York concert stage last night, singing a program largely in French before a distinguished musical and social audience at Town Hall. The soprano was in fine voice, and her personality, always a prime feature in her recitals, was irresistible. With Miss Namara informal acting is always as much a part of the performance as the singing.

New York City has not lost as many as 70 per cent of its experienced refrigerator repair men, which is the national figure announced last week by the War Manpower Commission, yet the shortage here presents a real danger to public health, maintenance officials for three large companies agreed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Light showers were reported in parts of the winter Wheat Belt over the weekend and a Weather Bureau forecast held out hope of additional precipitation. This led to scattered commission house and professional selling early today and prices on the Board of Trade declined 3/4 cent a bushel before support developed.

A new issue of $6,625,000 of temporary loan notes was announced yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority for award on Feb. 1 through competitive bidding. The issue will be dated Feb. 11 and will be payable on Aug. 15, 1944.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's American-trained Chinese forces have captured Mingru Ga in their drive toward Taipha Ga in the Hukawng Valley of North Burma, an Allied Southeast Asia headquarters communique announced today.

SOUTH TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 24 (AP) -- This small community on the outskirts of Tucson will vote tomorrow on a $9,500,000 bond issue for the purchase of the Tucson Gas, Electric Light and Power Company, which its neighbor, Arizona's second largest city, rejected Oct. 29, but now is considering again.

The disposal of surplus war supplies and the turning back of war plant facilities to civilian use will constitute major economic problems after the war, according to the current issue of the Guaranty Survey, published by the Guaranty Trust Company, which adds that the problems already have appeared in preliminary form.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Proposed amendment of the Federal Reserve Act to provide that absorption of exchange and collection charges by member banks shall not be deemed payment of interest on deposits was opposed today by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System.

ON THE AMERICAN BEACHHEAD, south of Rome, Jan. 24 -- First Lieut. Robert Bangert of Great Falls, Mont., led a squad of twenty-seven engineers on one of the most dangerous missions of this amphibious operation today.

MIAMI, Jan. 24 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor today rejected John L. Lewis' demand that the United Mine Workers of America be readmitted to the federation with most of its present membership, but proposed to take back the miners' union as it was constituted in 1936.

American medicine must cooperate with the Government in planning for the prevention and treatment of diseases, Dr. Conrad Berens declared last night in his inaugural address as president of the Medical Society of the County of New York.

The proposal to create a "world fashion center" in midtown Manhattan has much to commend it to all who wish New York well, although it cannot be overlooked that New York's great retail stores already make this city the fashion center of the country.

In the Mohegan Lake district in the northern part of Westchester County an estate of twenty acres fronting on Crompond Street, Shrub Oak, was purchased by Arthur D. Heilbrun of New York City from Harry Yormark through the brokerage office of A. L. Shongut. A residence of eight rooms is on the property.

Industry facilities used in war production should be restudied to properly evaluate their remaining useful life after accelerated usage, as a preliminary to reconversion to peacetime products in order to justify accelerated depreciation allowances in corporate tax returns, Clarence Crocheron, vice president of the American Appraisal Company, declared last night at a meeting of the New York chapter of the National Association of Cost Accountants in the Hotel New Yorker.

Damages of $300, plus $100 in counsel fees, were awarded yesterday to a Brooklyn housewife against two butchers accused of overcharges of 60 cents and 54 cents above Office of Price Administration ceilings. The verdict was in favor of Mrs. Betty Traunstein of 2041 Seventy-third Street, Brooklyn, chairman of the Bensonhurst Consumers Association.

Lieut. Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, commandant of the Marine Corps, who led the Marines in the Bougainville invasion, will be the guest of honor at a Fourth War Loan rally on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange next Tuesday at 3 P.M., it was announced yesterday by Emil Schram, president of the Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Stepping into a struggle between the Army and civil authorities in Hawaii, President Roosevelt has pardoned Lieut. Gen. Robert C. Richardson Jr., who was fined for contempt because he refused to obey a habeas corpus writ.

As the liberation of Europe proceeds it is almost certain that new and often unexpected political problems will confront the military commanders after each military success. In these circumstances General Eisenhower could not have done better than to induce Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr. to relinquish the post of United States Ambassador to the exiled Governments in London and join his staff as a Lieutenant Colonel.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY ON THE RAPIDO RIVER, Jan. 23 (Delayed) -- After a terrific drubbing from the Germans' powerful prepared positions, the remnants of the American force that had staged a series of heroic frontal attacks across the savagely cannonaded Rapido River through minefields and into a trap of machine-gun crossfire withdrew yesterday afternoon by swimming through the raging, icy water.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- While the attempt of the Dewey administration to make its proposed benefit payments to discharged soldiers conditional on the amount of Federal aid met some difficulties today, the Democratic leaders in the State Legislature proposed a plan of their own.
No need to take a ration book to Delman's to get the new "fun shoes" made with wooden soles and without the use of leather. The tops are of fabric.

The last, lingering doubt about night baseball at the Polo Grounds and at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, next summer, was removed yesterday. After a consultation with Leo Bondy, Giant treasurer, and Branch Rickey, Dodger president, Mayor La Guardia at City Hall announced the nocturnal games, banned last summer because of Army dim-out regulations, could be resumed this year providing the military situation is unchanged.

The Office of Price Administration was petitioned yesterday by the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute to grant needed relief to producers of sheets, sheeting, denim, chambray and similar goods in a telegram sent to Chester Bowles, OPA Administrator, by Henry Matter, managing director of the institute.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The cumulative effect of the Royal Air Force assault on Berlin has been so great that it is now believed here that a total of 40,000 tons of bombs will knock out the city. This is well below the maximum bomb tonnage Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur T. Harris first intended to devote to the destruction of the military, political and commercial capital of the Reich.

SOMEWHERE IN ITALY, Jan. 24 -- Amid battle debris, along a rugged mountainside or above a beach in Italy one runs frequently into a pile that attracts unusual attention. In it one usually finds two cans, two bottles and a discarded carton bearing the label: "The plasma contained in this package was processed from blood obtained from volunteer donors enrolled by the American Red Cross."

The new "streamlined" plan for handling draft inductions, which is to be put into effect by all the city's 280 local boards no later than next Tuesday, was explained yesterday by Col. Arthur V. McDermott, local director of selective service.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 24 -- "Collaboration," long moribund, breathed its last in Vichy this morning as a policy regulating relations in France between victor and vanquished. Coercion replaced it openly after having dominated the situation publicly for many months.

TRENTON, Jan. 24--The Legislature received today from Gov. Walter E. Edge the tentative draft of a proposed new State Constitution designed to replace the one under which the State Government has operated for ninety-nine years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton of 1943 growth ginned to Jan. 16 totaled 10,938,138 running bales, counting round as half bales and excluding linters, compared with 12,116,690 bales to that date a year ago and 10,225,179 bales two years ago.

The American Bosch Corporation announced yesterday, in its report to stockholders covering the first nine months of 1943, net earnings of $652,116, after all charges including a provision of $4,872,000 for Federal taxes on income after deducting $509,000 post-war credit and after a transfer of $318,000 to reserve for post-war readjustment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The State Department announced today that the United States would not recognize the revolutionary regime in Bolivia.

The stock market passed through a routine session again yesterday, an early attempt by the railroad issues to further their recent gains being checked by profit-taking. Stocks idled in quieter dealings and, after moving narrowly from a firm start, closed irregular with price alterations small in both directions.

At the Massachusetts Quincy yesterday the aircraft carrier Hancock took her first swim. Related to the Lexington and the Wasp, she belongs to an honored and a beloved family. This type of ship has been of conspicuous and gallant service. Four of the seven that were afloat at the beginning of the war have perished.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Jan. 25--Moscow's victory guns boomed again last night and red, green, blue and white flares from 124 guns lighted the sky in a salute to the advancing troops on the Leningrad front who had captured the important enemy centers of Pushkin, Pavlovsk and Ulyanovka while severing the railway line between Gatchina and Narva, one of the few major roads available for German troops in their retreat westward.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 24 (AP) -- In an opinion denying a contention that newspaper reporters are "professional" workers, the Sixth United States Circuit Court of Appeals today unheld an order of the wage-hour division of the Department of Labor against the Sun Publishing Company, publisher of The Jackson (Tenn.) Sun.

Japan's military budget, setting an all-time record of 38,000,000,000 yen, was approved by Emperor Hirohito and submitted to the Diet yesterday, the Tokyo radio said in a broadcast beamed to Japanese areas and recorded by United States Government monitors.
Nominations for the Associated Press board of directors, to be voted upon at the annual meeting on April 24, were announced last night by the nominating committee of The Associated Press.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Despite the shift to offensive operations on the military front, supplies of food allocated to civilians during 1944 will be at approximately the same level as last year, Lee Marshall, director of food distribution, War Food Administration, reassured food trade representatives meeting here today.

The six-story apartment house for fifty-three families at 645 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Underwriters Trust Company, as trustee for certificate holders, to the Sullivan Holding Company. It is on a plot 105 by 150 feet at the southeast corner of Albemarle Road.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 24 -- Army and Navy planes have unleashed a powerful assault on atolls of the Marshall Islands in the last two days, striking eight objectives in six separate atolls, knocking down Japanese planes, bombing ships and strafing and raiding shore installations.

Scandinavian foods that would tempt even the conservative who belongs to the school of thought that might be labeled, "If it's a new dish I don't like it," were sampled yesterday at a tasting sponsored by the Common Council for American Unity.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Jan. 25 -- Allied fliers shot down fifty-one planes in attacks on the big Japanese New Guinea air base at Wewak and the main enemy stronghold at Rabaul, New Britain, for the greatest aerial victory in weeks.

Walter D. Hoag and Malcolm Muir Jr., both of the Yale Club, took the bracket finals yesterday in the Red Cross benefit "bulldog" tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association held in the Yale Club. They will meet in the concluding test tomorrow.

Coach Joe Lapchick's Brooklyn All-Stars, scheduled to play Nat Holman's New York All-stars in half of tomorrow night's War Bond double-header at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory as a part of the sports world's contribution to the Fourth War Loan Drive, received bad news yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Southeast Asia Command communique:

As mild weather favored the New York metropolitan area yesterday and "no-heat" complaints received at the Department of Health totaled only 1,471 for the forty-eight hours ending at 4:30 P.M., City Fuel Administrator Edwin A. Salmon announced that the city's 100 emergency coal dumps should be operating tomorrow.

ALGIERS, Jan. 24 -- That the morale of troops at the front is high but that they have been less prepared mentally and spiritually than physically were among the conclusions drawn by Rabbi Barnett R. Brickner of New York on a tour of the Middle East, Italy and North Africa for the National Jewish Welfare Board.

Our enemies are being driven from the skies and soon, without "vainglory or exaggeration," we shall be able to call the air "our air," Gen. Henry H. Arnold, Commanding General of the Army Air Forces, declared last night in a message to the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences.

In that part of his recent budget message which deals with the public debt, the President, envisaging a 1945 national income earned of 125 billions, says: "I am confident that we can devise a tax structure and other appropriate economic policies which will permit both payment of interest (five billions) and gradual repayment of principal during years of prosperity without impairing the stability and growth of the national income."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Cash dividends of $710,300,000 in December brought the 1943 total of these payments in the United States to $3,541,000,000, a fractional rise over the $3,529,000,000 paid out in 1942, the Department of Commerce announced today.

The program of tennis matches arranged by the Sports War Bond Committee for the Seventh Regiment Armory Friday night was enlarged yesterday with the addition of another nationally prominent player to the all-star cast.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has sold to Frederick Brown, operator, the thirteen-story apartment house at 740 West End Avenue, northeast corner of Ninety-sixth Street. It is on a plot 125 by 100 feet and contains seventy-eight suites with an annual rent roll of about $87,500.

" Gung Ho!" the Walter Wanger production based on the exploits of Carlson's Raiders, the Marine detachment which attacked and destroyed the garrison and installations of Japanese-held Makin Island in the South Pacific, will have its local premiere at Loew's Criterion today.
AT THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, South of Rome, Jan. 23 (Delayed) -- Our landing was accomplished with clock-like precision from the very first, with a calm sea aiding Allied troops.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)--A Pacific Fleet announcement:

SEATTLE, Jan. 24 (U.P.) -- The Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., and three of its officers were indicted today on charges of negotiating wharfage rebates with the Port of Seattle in an alleged conspiracy which the Government said delayed forwarding vital lend-lease war materials to Russia.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 24 -- Solidly entrenched behind $175,000,000 worth of fortifications, most of which have been modernized along lines evolved after the study of military developments in this war, Switzerland is ready to defend her independence and neutrality, with a good chance of success, according to Dr. Karl Kobelt, Army Minister.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 24 (AP) -- A resolution memorializing Congress to enact promptly the Lucas-Green Bill "or other adequate legislation to provide for voting in the 1944 election by members of the armed forces" was introduced in the Legislature tonight by Assemblyman Frank A. Emma, Democrat, of Utica.
Public health nurses everywhere, in schools, clinics, and health centers, are severely handicapped in their essential work by the shortage of trained volunteers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 19:

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Three high British officers who spent years as prisoners of war have escaped and are now home again in the United Kingdom, it was announced today by the War Office and the Air Ministry.

Patrick Hamilton is an expert at probing into the peculiarities of the human mind, as witness "Angel Street," which has been running since early in the last century; "Rope's End" and the novel "Hangover Square." Patrick Hamilton, like every other playwright, can stub his toe, however, and this he has done most thoroughly in "The Duke in Darkness," which opened last evening at the Playhouse.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 24 -- One of racing's paradoxes was again illustrated at Hialeah today when Mrs. Weston W. Adam's Side Boy won the featured Indian River Purse in sharply slower time than a presumably more obscure horse had just won over the same distance and under similar conditions.
AT THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, Jan. 23 -- (Delayed) -- Most soldiers and officers felt let down today as the result of the lack of fighting in our surprise landings behind the German line.

As against $10,500,000,000 of new annual taxes recommended by the Administration, both the House and the Senate have now passed tax bills either of which is expected to yield only about $2,000,000,000. The differences between the House and Senate bills now remain to be adjusted.

In a strongly worded advertisement shortly to be released throughout the United States, Californians, Inc., a non-profit organization of citizens and groups, which has been urging visitors to come to San Francisco for the last twenty-two years, warns the public, especially pleasure seekers and persons with non-essential business in the city, to avoid visiting it for the duration.

WITH FIFTH ARMY AT A BRIDGEHEAD SOUTH OF ROME, Jan. 24 (Delayed) -- A man with a suitcase full of bread who had left Rome only on Saturday noon reported the following items regarding the Italian capital:
LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Russian troops have sent the Germans into retreat from their last fifty-mile hold on the Moscow-Leningrad trunk line, Moscow announced today.

The efforts of Governors in the South to establish a freight rate structure through Congressional action is for the purpose of further inducing northern industries to change their location, according to George E. Mace, manager of the transportation bureau of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- The State Capitol contains the key to a mystery. The characters in the drama are Governor Dewey, with a supporting cast consisting of three veteran Washington correspondents, James C. Hagerty, Mr. Dewey's press secretary, and members of the Legislative Correspondents Association.

The Carrier Corporation, maker of air-conditioning, refrigerating and industrial heating equipment, reported yesterday for the year ended with October a net profit of $701,309, equal to $1.73 a common share. This compares with $618,083, or $1.52 a share, earned the year before.
Another of the all-star cast of tennis players who will compete in the War Bond program Friday night at the Seventh Regiment Armory arrived in New York yesterday and immediately began practice.

Gen. Isaias Medina-Angarita, President of Venezuela, receiving the city's official welcome yesterday, promised the full cooperation of his government in defending the ideals of democracy, promoting world peace and maintaining "the unity of the Americas."
LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Apart from reactions to dividend statements by two companies, there was little activity on the stock market here today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A more even distribution of shipments of hogs for the last two days has resulted in a reduction of unsold stock here and prices advanced today for all classes except those within the limits of government support, 200 to 300 pounds, which, remained at $13.75 a hundredweight.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Precipitation in the Southwest and Central West overnight proved to be too light to be of material benefit to the wheat crop, and reports of a tightening in the cash situation and lack of hedging pressure led shorts to cover today on the Board of Trade.

Your editorial "Mustering-Out Pay" is optimistic when it says that the discharge pay just voted by the House makes far more sense, both from the standpoint of the veteran and of national economy, than a bonus or adjusted compensation paid out years later.

ALGIERS, Jan. 25 -- It was not until 7:25 A.M. Saturday that the Germans learned of the invasion below Rome and thus the operation had virtually five and a half hours' start, a senior staff officer of the Coastal Air Force disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- George N. Briggs, suspended assistant to Secretary Ickes, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on a charge of forging the celebrated "Harry Hopkins" letter, heart of the mystery which has stirred Washington.

"The Song of Bernadette," Twentieth Century-Fox's adaptation of the Franz Werfel novel, will have its local premiere this morning at the Rivoli. Jennifer Jones, a newcomer, plays the chief role in the drama dealing with the miracle at Lourdes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- A dispute between Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, and Robert Sherwood, OWI overseas chief, has been referred to President Roosevelt, it was learned today.

This evening Meyer Davis, orchestra leader and frequent backer of Broadway shows, will emerge as a solo producer with "Wallflower," opening at the Cort. Of the current attractions he has investments in "The Merry Widow," "Tomorrow the World," "Suds in Your Eye" and "The Cherry Orchard."

SOMEWHERE IN ITALY -- As a supplement to the life-sustaining plasma being sent from the United States, ablebodied men at the front areas in Italy are giving literally gallons of whole blood daily so that their "buddies" may have the utmost that science provides for recovery from wounds and disease.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Casualties of the armed forces of the United States from the beginning of the war to recent dates total 142,289, the Office of War Information stated today. Among these were: Dead, 32,662; wounded. 47,123; missing, 32,699; prisoners of war, 29,805, of whom 1,933 have died in prison camps, principally in Japanese-occupied territory.

The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, criticized a few days ago for alleged "wretched" treatment of its wards and for alleged archaic conduct of the institution, sharply rebuked its critics yesterday.

The stock market drew some comfort yesterday from indications that the remaining South American ties with the Axis might be severed, but aside from another minor adventure among some specialties the trend of prices veered slightly to the easier side.

A tract comprising 180,000 square feet of vacant land at Northern Boulevard, Willets Point Boulevard, Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth Avenues, at Flushing Bridge, with another vacant plot at the southeast corner of Northern Boulevard and Lawrence Street, in Flushing, Queens, has been purchased by Tully Di Napoli, general contractors, of Long Island City.

There is an element of irony in the fact that the Germans are engaged in a drastic "purge" of Vichy. While the Committee of Liberation in Algiers is weeding out "pro-Vichy" and collaborationist officers and officials outside of France, within the country the Nazi overlords are cleansing Marshal Petain's administration of all those they cannot absolutely rely on when the approaching showdown comes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- December tax collections by the Bureau of Internal Revenue were almost 100 per cent ahead of the same month in 1942, thanks to substantial increases in income tax payments and recovery of excess profits, the Treasury Department disclosed today.

Protesting the recent action of the Office of Price Administration in abandoning plans for fixed ceilings on pelts, six advisory committees of the fur industry have united in urging the price agency to set dollar and cents ceilings for raw furs and establish a "percentage over cost" basis for manufacturing, wholesale and retail levels, it was made known here yesterday by the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc.

F. Kenneth Stephenson of Goldman Sachs Co., chairman of the executive committee of the New York group of the Investment Bankers Association of America, announced yesterday at a luncheon meeting of IBA members, at the City Midday Club, 25 Broad Street, the appointment of six committees to serve for the ensuing year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 25 -- Cary Grant has been named by RKO for the starring role in "I Am Thinking of My Darling," a farce by Vincent McHugh about a fantastic epidemic which causes its victims to lose their inhibitions. The picture will follow the actor's appearance in "None but the Lonely Heart," which is scheduled to go before cameras next week.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Judge A.D. Barksdale ruled today in the Federal District Court that the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 was not intended to force mine operators to pay underground employes for the time they consumed traveling in mines to and from their places of work.

COL. MATT WINN is a vigorous young fellow of 83 who has just assumed a new job, the presidency of the Empire City race track. He has reached a time of life when an ordinary individual would hesitate about embarking on a new venture, preferring mellow memories to action. But that is not the colonel's way of doing things.

A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of $3,310,000 of Chicago, Ill., Park District refunding bonds, due March 1, 1964, and callable from Sept. 1, 1946 to 1963. The bankers bid 100.279, naming the interest rate as 1 1/2 per cent.

The major problem for central airport traffic is traffic control, and no system "even remotely adequate for future needs has yet been developed," it was declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at Columbia University by M.G. Beard of American Airlines.
Basketball Double-Header (tonight, Seventy-first Regiment Armory) -- Bonds may be purchasedl and tickets exchanged at Forty-ninth Street lobby of Madison Square Garden (today, 12 noon to 6 P.M.)

Violation of the Federal Government's milk-conservation program was charged against four of the 221 milk handlers serving the New York metropolitan area yesterday by Dr. Charles J. Blanford, market agent of the New York-New Jersey Metropolitan Milk Sales Area.

The death toll of New York pigeons that have mysteriously perished in the last week rose to fifty-two yesterday. The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals reported that poison killed at least four birds and was believed to have been responsible for the deaths of the others.

To the weird rhythm of a drum and cymbals the dragon danced yesterday in celebration of the Chinese new year through the streets of Chinatown, whose residents expressed a desire for victory and peace in the coming months.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 25 -- After a fire that started in a hay shed behind the hay and grain store of Joseph Cohen at 84 Belmont Avenue had damaged it and four other frame structures late today, Fireman Joseph Dolan of the arson squad approached a 4-year-old boy who was playing in the street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The plight of an estimated 15,000,000 "white collar" persons and others who must live on largely fixed incomes in the face of increasing costs was laid before a Senate group today by six witnesses in the first day's hearings on this problem.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Jan. 26 -- The Red Army was reported officially last night to have smashed forward another eleven miles in the center of the highly fortified German defense line south of Leningrad, while other troops on that front drove to the suburbs of Krasnogvardeisk, where they engaged the Germans in fierce battle for control of that terminus of the Gatchina-Narva-Talinn railway.

ON THE FIFTH ARMY'S BEACHHEAD, South of Rome, Jan. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- American soldiers battled all night to hold vital bridges along the Mussolini Canal that the Germans attempted to size with counter-attacks, but at dawn today the Americans still held the bridges and had thrown the enemy back.

A searching crew with delicate electrical apparatus discovered a one-inch length of radium tube, thick as a match, in a plumbing trap in the basement of the skyscraper at 515 Madison Avenue yesterday, but gave up as irretrievably lost two similar tubes that vanished at the same time last Saturday afternoon.

The high drama of our days is being played upon such a vast stage and is moving at such a swift pace that it is necessary now and then to try to get a perspective of the whole of it in order to evaluate the significance of day-to-day events. Today is a good day for taking stock.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 25 -- Not only are the French in France to be submitted to a reign of intensive terror under Joseph Darnand, Secretary for the Maintenance of Order, but their nerves are to be racked by Philippe Henriot, Secretary for Information and Propaganda.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to refund $35,000,000 of indebtedness to its parent, the Electric Bond and Share Company, by the payment of $5,000,000 in cash and the issuance of $30,000,000 of 3 per cent serial notes.

Before there is too much cheering over the news that the Ramirez Government of Argentina is preparing to break off diplomatic relations with the Axis let us recall a few noteworthy facts about the Ramirez Government itself. Within the last three months that Government has --

One of the greatest basketball attractions ever offered in this city will be staged tonight when the "million dollar" double-header will be put on by the Sports War Bond Committee at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

An extra week's vacation to save fuel will begin today for New York City's million school children and continue until next Wednesday. This unprecedented winter holiday was voted by the Board of Education to conserve oil and coal used in the city's 800 school buildings.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Jan. 26 -- The man who has not taken a day off since Japan attacked the Philippines strode up to meet his old acquaintance. No one would have guessed from the spring in his step, from the hair unspecked with gray or from the jaunty mannerisms unchanged by age that this was the day when he should be retiring.

Col. Carlos P. Romulo will lecture at the Brooklyn Academy of Music at 8:15 this evening on "The War in the Pacific Today." Colonel Romulo, who wrote "I Saw the Fall of the Philippines," is also the author of "Mother America," published last season by Doubleday, Doran.

Something more than the fate of a single South American regime is involved in the refusal of the United States, Great Britain and fifteen Latin-American republics to follow Argentina in recognizing the revolutionary Government of Bolivia. Our own State Department linked the uprising with "subversive groups hostile to the Allied cause."

Cotton prices drifted listlessly in slow trading yesterday. Activities consisted chiefly of routine trade and mill buying to fix prices. Contracts were supplied largely through hedge selling and a small amount of liquidation. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, active futures contracts were 2 to 5 points net lower.

The ten-story loft building with store at 298 Broadway, running through to Manhattan Alley and occupying a plot 21.10 by 130 feet has been acquired by a client of the Kempner Realty Corporation, brokers, for cash above a purchase-money mortgage of $56,000 taken back for ten years by the Central Savings Bank, seller of the building.

Experts appearing yesterday before Moreland Act Commissioners William F. Bleakley and Herman T. Stichman, investigating irregularities in administration of the State workmen's compensation law, charged inefficiency, laxity and disregard of the interests of injured workmen and made recommendations for elimination of abuses.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's announcement in Parliament today that Britain does not recognize the revolutionary junta in Bolivia was overshadowed tonight by the report that Argentina was on the verge of breaking relations with Germany.

Moscow Pravda in the last few days cannot help bringing to mind the parallel case of that sterling publication, The Babylon Dally Bugle. It is only a week or so since Pravda set the world by the ears with its featured Cairo dispatch about Anglo-German peace feelers.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- British labor leaders and liberal journals are outspokenly critical of the American Federation of Labor's decision to decline the invitation to attend the international labor conference in London next June.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, commanding the Fourteenth Air Force in China, reported today that his planes during December had sunk seventeen enemy ships totaling 30,000 tons.

Allied troops who made a new landing in Italy thirty miles from Rome last Saturday apparently had weathered the first crisis of any invasion attempt yesterday. And farther south the apparent enemy abandonment of Cassino, stronghold of the so-called "Gustav Line," may presage the beginning of a general German retirement.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Both houses of the Legislature, overriding Democratic opposition, passed today a proposed constitutional amendment which provides that the candidates of any party for Governor and Lieutenant Governor shall run as a "team," as do the President and Vice President.
I often wonder if the mothers and fathers of America realize what joy the American soldiers gave at Christmas time to the children of England.
The Chemical Bank and Trust I Company hs been appointed New l ]York registrar for common stock] Iof the Gray Manufacturing Corn-I I party.

MIAMI, Jan. 25 -- A veiled threat, that the United Mine Workers of America might withdraw its application for readmission to the American Federation of Labor was reported to have been sent to the AFL executive council here today by John L. Lewis, mine union chief.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Federal Power Commission approved today proposals of two utility companies -- one in Indiana, the other in Texas -- to eliminate from their plant accounts a total of nearly $20,000,000 in write-ups and other excesses over original cost.

Skillful manipulation of straws and fabrics produced some interesting new silhouettes for Hattie Carnegie's spring millinery showing yesterday. Relying for her effects on high shades of shocking pink, purple and light blue and a restrained use of bead and sequin trimming, the designer used a minimum of flowers and almost no veiling.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Thirty-four more industrial plants have been selected to receive the joint Army-Navy Production Award, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A possibility that Soviet Russia will side with United States experts to break the deadlock with British monetary negotiators on the question of post-war currency stabilization is being hopefully considered in some official quarters.

A 28-year-old mother who neglected her three small children while she gambled her husband's war job earnings was held in $100 bail yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court on a charge of abandonment. Her youngest child, Roberta, 5 months old, was taken to Lincoln Hospital suffering from malnutrition.
LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Plans are being made for a United Nations conference to analyze and if possible to outline an international policy to restrict the use of cartels after the war.

A panel of four military experts discussed last night the question, "When Will the War End?," adhering to the Office of Censorship's caution against speculation over the possible date of a Western European invasion so carefully that even an approximate estimate of the time did not come until the final moment of the program.
Those of you who are thinking of a trip to Florida may get a few hints on what the fishing down there is like from the reports received at this distant observation post.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Although the American League currently has ample manpower for a successful start in the 1944 baseball season, it is only a far-fetched guess what the situation will be on opening day, less than three months away.

The death rate for New York City continued to decline in the week ended on last Friday, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, Health Commissioner. The rate was 12.2 for each thousand of population, a drop of almost 5 points from the 17.0 a thousand recorded for the week ended on Dec. 31, when the flu epidemic was at its peak.
CHICLAYO, Peru, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A total eclipse of the sun was observed here today by scientists and hundreds of sight-seers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The House of Representatives adopted today by a roll-call vote of 338 to 54 the bill providing for this country's participation in the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in the amount of $1,350,000,000. It now goes to the Senate.

ADVANCE ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Jan. 26 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's air force heavily bombed objectives in the Admiralty Islands, Japanese sea and air staging point, 240 miles north of New Guinea, on Monday, damaging two airdromes and destroying enemy shipping as the range of the south Pacific war spread.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- Advance Chinese forces in northern Burma have driven to within 500 yards of the important road junction of Taipha, in the Hukawng Valley, while to the southwest other Chinese units made slight gains in their push along the Mawngyang Hka River and repulsed three Japanese counterattacks, a Southeast Asia Command communique reported tonight.

ALGIERS, Jan. 25 -- The Allies' invasion forces, fanning out through the minefields surrounding the captured ports of Anzio and Nettuno, thirty miles south of Rome, have thrust inland twelve miles and are within a mile or two of both the principal coastal railway and the Appian Way, it was officially announced today.

The concert given last night in Carnegie Hall was one of signal achievement on the part of the conductor, Eugene Ormandy, and the Philadelphia Orchestra. To remind readers of the tonal beauty and technical excellence of this orchestra would be to repeat a familiar tale, although one that redounds very much to the credit of the conductor's industry and conscience in his task.

Initial shipments of an entirely new type of war-born strong rayon, said to bridge the gap between ordinary synthetics and nylon, have been started without any preliminary announcement by the rayon division of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., it was reported here yesterday by users in the textile and industrial fields.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 25 -- Premier Edwin Linkomies' government escaped defeat in the Finnish Riksdag by the margin of two votes last Saturday, when the Premier, irked by criticism of Vaino A. Tanner, Finance Minister, and Dr. Henrik Ramsay, Foreign Minister, and an outright demand by the Opposition for their resignation, asked a vote of confidence, it was disclosed today.

Dorothy Fisher, young contralto from Fort Vancouver, Wash., who was trained in Portland, Ore., made her debut here last night in Town Hall, with a program of French, German, early English and modern songs, as well as the aria "Re dell' abisso," from Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Policies and measures designed to put low-priced and scarce goods back into the markets were the principal subjects of discussion at a two-day conference of the Consumer Advisory Committee of the Office of Price Administration, the sessions of which ended today.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Dealings on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange, continuing their decline in 1943 as the result of ceiling prices imposed by the occupation authorities, were little more than one-third of the volume the year before. They amounted to 203,000,000 guilders ($109,000,000) in comparison with 563,000,000 ($304,000,000) for 1942.

What the post-war home will look like, how decorators are exercising their ingenuity in getting new effects with the furnishings a client already owns, and the present trend toward a simpler type of American decor were some of the ideas brought out in the thirteenth national conference of the American Institute of Decorators, which opened yesterday for two days at the St. Regis Hotel.

The Lawyers Mortgage Corporation, as trustee, reported yesterday the sale of the six-story apartment house at 775 Riverside Drive and 156-08 Riverside Drive West to a client of Oscar Roy Chalk. The properties are assessed at $330,000 and $335,000 respectively, and were sold subject to purchase-money mortgages of $210,000 and $222,000 taken back by the trustee.

Ackman Brothers, brokers, have placed a new first mortgage of $110,000 at 4 1/2 per cent interest for ten years on the six-story apartment house at 320 Ocean Parkway, in Brooklyn, for the 5694, Inc., owners.

The article by Edwin L. James under the title "North Africa Problem Getting More Difficult," published Jan. 16, raises some very interesting speculation regarding our relations with General de Gaulle. According to Mr. James' argument, the immediate difficulty seems to be our present reluctance to furnish arms to the underground movement in France.

AN ADVANCE COMMAND POST, Overlooking Cassino, Jan. 25 -- An American patrol of fourteen men, led by Second Lieut. Filbert Munoz, 22 years old, of Kansas City, Kan., entered the outskirts of Cassino today and penetrated to a point within 400 yards of the heart of the city.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Air Marshal Sir Arthur Coningham, who commanded Allied Tactical Air Forces in the Mediterranean theatre through three victorious campaigns, has been placed in command of the No. 2 Tactical Air Force of the Royal Air Force for the invasion of western Europe.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25 -- Two eligibles for the Bahamas Handicap and the Flamingo Stakes, Jimmie and Freezout, captured the featured races at Hialeah Park today, but it was diminutive Jockey Conn McCreery who took the largest share of the spotlight with three winners.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- An institutional group representing holders of bonds of the Boston Terminal Company and the Mutual Savings Bank group committee of creditors presented today objections to the proposed further supplemental report and order by the Interstate Commerce Commission suggested by the Connecticut District Court for reorganization of the company.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- The major part of the program announced in November by the State Tax Commission for revision of the State's corporation tax structure was introduced today in the Legislature. Senator William Bewley of Lockport, chairman of the Senate Committee on Taxation, introduced an omnibus measure at the request of Rollin Browne, chairman of the State Tax Commission.

The cigar manufacturing industry may be approaching a period when relative production in the various classes will reverse the present shift to the higher priced varieties, Charles E. Gage, chief, tobacco branch of the War Food Administration, said last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The House Military Committee may recommend abolition of a large part of the Army's specialized training program soon in a move designed to save an estimated 200,000 pre-war fathers from induction into the forces.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Slightly more butter will be available for civilians next month, while the February and March supplies of meat will be somewhat lower than in the current month, Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that individual retailers and jobbers of men's rubber boots and rubber work shoes may sell limited quantities of excess stocks ration free on authorization from OPA district offices.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,349, which compared with 1,831 in the preceding week and 1,245 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
LONDON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A "Rayburn for Vice President" boom is taking shape in the House. Southern Democrats opposed to Vice President Wallace are the sponsors. They expect the backing of Southern Governors and Senators, despite a remark by Senator Maybank of South Carolina that "we haven't picked our man yet."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Industrialists anxious to experiment with models of civilian products for post-war markets won a point from the War Production Board today when that agency ruled that manufacturers hereafter may use aluminum for such research.

The halfway mark of $150,000 was passed yesterday in the Metropolitan Opera Fund campaign, according to George A. Sloan, president of the Metropolitan Opera Association. The fund committee is appealing for at least $300,000 to meet unexpected financial problems arising from the delay in the application of the realty-tax exemption on the opera house and from the war-imposed cancellation of the usual spring tour.

Reynolds Realization Corporation reports that liquidation of the company's securities proceeded rapidly during 1943, with sales amounting to 80 per cent of the market value of the portfolio at the beginning of the year. Proceeds were $1,161,505, representing a profit of $460,525 over values on Nov. 18, 1940, when the assets were transferred by the trustees to the corporation.

The Treasury issued yesterday a sheaf of new rulings and amendments to old rulings, concerning foreign funds and property control. For one thing, Corsica is no longer "enemy territory," although it continues to be territory of a blocked country, France.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, at the Rapido River, Jan. 24 (Delayed) -- The Rapido River looks like nothing. But the men of one American battalion -- tired and cold and many of them suffering from preliminary twinges of trench foot -- have a somewhat different view of the Rapido and of its other bank, on which they had a foothold for some time yesterday.

Assailing the "pious hopes and wishful thinking" contained in post-war plans put forth by building associations, Mrs. Dorothy Rosenman, chairman of the National Committee on Housing, Inc., declared yesterday that private industry cannot give "glib or pat answers" to the gaps which lie between possibility and accomplishment if it is to supply the vast potential market in housing.

While Governor Dewey fixed the date for a clemency hearing for Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss and Louis Capone at Feb. 2, the convicted murderers' counsel filed papers in Brooklyn yesterday disclosing that they sought a new trial for their clients, who were convicted of killing Joseph Rosen, a Brooklyn candy store owner, in 1936.
LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25 -- Industry must plan now to reduce manufacturing costs and establish post-war prices which will result in moving the maximum amount of goods and services to the consumer after the present wartime sellers' market comes to an end and a buyers' market is ushered in by easing of production restrictions, Clarence Francis, chairman of General Foods Corporation, said tonight.

The United States Steel Corporation had a deficit of $1,618,499 in the fourth quarter of 1943 after having made provision for the regular preferred dividend and a dividend of $1 a share on the common stock although it operated at 98.9 per cent of capacity for the period, according to the preliminary annual report made public yesterday by Irving S. Olds, chairman.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25 -- In the most pessimistic statement made to date by a major league baseball executive, President Sam Breadon of the Cardinals asserted today: "The way players are being taken by the draft, it does seem questionable whether we'll have enough left to operate."

Warning that the people of the United States would not be able to enjoy their desires, which he defined as "a decent living and a good time," in the post-war world unless the peoples of other nations did likewise, Supreme Court Justice Wiley Rutledge pleaded last night for a policy of cooperation with other countries.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 25 (AP) -- The naming of a Liberty ship launched here today in honor of Edward H. Crockett, a war correspondent for The Associated Press, who was killed in action, was fitting, John Evans, AP executive said, because "the beauty and real worth of freedom are ever in the minds of the American reporter abroad."

The body of Frank A. Rice of Miami, Fla., who disappeared last month from thronged Pennsylvania Station, causing his wife to become so hysterical that she gave away $1,500 of their savings to passers-by, was found yesterday in the East River.

LONDON, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- German motorized troops have smashed from Gospic to Senj, completing in six days of fighting a Nazi drive to seal off the lower Croatian coastal supply routes to Yugoslav Partisans in the interior, Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] admitted today.

The virtue of cooking potatoes without peeling them -- a subject of particular interest now when the vegetable is plentiful -- has been investigated by scientists at the New York State Experiment Station and the United States Department of Agriculture.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 26 -- Sir John Anderson, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today that Great Britain's contribution to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration must be at least 80,000,000 or about $320,000,000 at the present rate of monetary exchange.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 25 -- A tree may grow in Brooklyn, but a Brooklyn man and a New York man had to go to Rivervale, N.J., to get one, and in doing so ran afoul of the law.

All proceedings for removal of William Griffin to Washington were quashed in Federal Court yesterday by Judge William Bondy, who acted on motion of James D.C. Murray, defense attorney, and with the consent of the Government.
OTTAWA, Jan. 25 -- As was obviously intended, Viscount Halifax's speech yesterday on the future of British Commonwealth relations has provoked an immediate and lively outburst of comment.

Three Allied hospital ships lying off the Italian beach at Anzio were bombed by German planes and one was sunk despite the fact that all were "lighted up like Christmas trees," a CBS correspondent reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Senate recessed at 12:23 P.M. until noon tomorrow after a brief session, in tribute to Senator Van Nuys of Indiana, who died early today. The Education and Labor Committee favorably reported a $1,000,000,000 veterans' education bill and a sub-committee heard Philip Murray, president of the CIO, assert that living costs are much higher than official Government figures indicate.

An article in THE TIMES of Jan. 19 reports that American lend-lease aid to the Soviet Union has reached a new high. Simultaneously, it summarizes a current dispatch in the Information Bulletin of the Soviet Embassy at Washington which describes the strides made by Soviet economy in 1943 but makes no mention of lend-lease.

Monday was New Year's Day in China. It is a movable feast dated by the moon, that inconstant orb. It can't be earlier than Jan. 21 or later than Feb. 19. Last year it fell on Feb. 5 and was marked by unusual celebration on account of the American and British treaties abolishing extraterritoriality.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson reported tonight that "the nation has definitely solved the major problems involved in mass-production of munitions" and in the War Production Board's monthly production statement disclosed this new record for naval ship construction set in 1943:

They did more than cheer in the Bronx yesterday; they bought war bonds. The borough known far and wide for the wrong kind of cheering is far in the lead in individual bond sales, having attained 29.1 per cent of its goal in the Fourth War Loan Drive while the average for the city is 17.2 per cent, according to figures released by the War Finance Committee for New York.

The "silver beaver" for distinguished services to boyhood was presented to four men last night at a dinner of the Manhattan Council of the Boy Scouts of America at the Grand Street Boys Club, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A search of the records of the Democratic National Committee today brought to light the fact that, when the President's forces last week put through its 1944 session a resolution urging him to accept a fourth nomination, the committee exceeded functional limits which Mr. Roosevelt himself set for it in 1931 and 1932.
