WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- All the war housing projects erected for the Federal Government by the Defense Homes Corporation were put on sale today, and Herbert Emmerich, president of the corporation and commissioner of the Federal Housing Authority, said that offers would be considered for any of the twenty-five projects, representing an investment of more than $71,000,000.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The United States Eighth Air Force and the Royal Air Force returned to their hammering of Europe's doorstep from the Netherlands to northern France today with a series of attacks featured by sharp blows at enemy airfields in the Netherlands by American Thunderbolt fighter-bombers.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The gathering of the Prime Ministers of the dominions for a conference here with the British Government on matters of mutual interest after the war is expected to take place early in April, according to the best information available today.

If Sidney Hillman will agree to the exclusion of all Communists from the American Labor party's governing board, right wing groups are ready to agree with him on a program for eliminating internal strife at the approaching spring primary, Dr. George S. Counts and Alex Rose, chairman and secretary, respectively, of the party's State committee, said yesterday.

Underpaid women and children in New York State -- 9,897 of them -- recovered $100,133 from their employers during 1943 through the work of the State Labor Department's division of women in industry and minimum wage, Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi announced yesterday.

Prophesying a rebuttal from his "friends in labor" for his statement, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that post-war employment would require a "wider spread" that might involve a shorter day or a shorter week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- OPA officials here tonight sought to fix responsibility for what they termed the theft of ration coupons worth 20,000,000 gallons of gasoline and fuel oil in the largest single black market operation yet uncovered.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Jan. 25 -- Maj. Gen. John K. Cannon, jointly commanding the Allies' tactical air force as well as the Twelfth United States Air Force, said today that "the Hun must stop our beachhead from advancing and it is certain that the beachhead will be counter-attacked.

Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the United States Conciliation Service, said last night he believed the dispute between the Ford Motor Company's assembly plant at Edgewater, N.J., and Local 906 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, should be settled through the regular grievance machinery maintained by the union and the company.
Willie Hoppe and Welker Cochran concluded the second day of their cross-country three-cushion match at the Metropolitan Billiard Club, 225 West Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday with an even break.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- An official report to the public concerning the war requirements for industrial alcohol, indicating that there is little hope of relaxation of the ban against distilling of potable spirits, will be made by the War Production Board this week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- Representative Lyle H. Boren, Democrat, of Oklahoma, chairman of the House subcommittee investigating newsprint, revealed tonight that his group has urged President Roosevelt to implement reverse lend-lease shipments of pulpwood from Russia to help alleviate the critical shortage of newsprint.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A regulation of the Federal Reserve Board forbidding member banks to absorb exchange charges "is just one more way of saying private business should cease," R. P. Holding of Smithfield, N. C., asserted today before a House committee.

ON THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, South of Rome, Jan. 25 -- Allied Military Government officials who landed only twelve hours behind the first assault troops have already organized civil affairs at this beachhead on a temporary basis quite different from the procedure in other towns, where the residents had remained.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 25 -- Have the germs causing present and past influenza epidemics come earthward from Mars and other planets?

Needs for planning parenthood, preparing young men and women for marriage and providing adequate housing, day care and educational facilities for children were termed basic yesterday by speakers at a luncheon given in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the Planned Parenthood Federation of America and the New York State League for Planned Parenthood.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Sponsors of the Senate's new bill to provide for service men's voting in November decided today against any further compromise and to fight to put the measure through as it is now drafted, regardless of the outcome.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The New York Joint Board of the Dressmakers Union, an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, has agreed to extend until Feb. 29 a contract governing 85,000 employes in the dress industry, Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the United States Conciliation Service, announced last night.

If there was any doubt as to how the State Athletic Commission stands on the matter of the lightweight championship, it was dispelled yesterday by Maj. Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the board, as he laid the groundwork for a meeting Friday at which the 135-pound title situation is to be reviewed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Even while the great battles of the war still lie ahead and the situation is critical, strikes have become so common on the home front that newspapers no longer notice them as feature news, Secretary Stimson said tonight in a radio address in which he pleaded for a National Service Act.

From May, 1940, to last December the Nazis executed at least 20,000 Netherland citizens -- an average of more than 460 a month, according to a copy of the underground paper Het Parool which recently reached Allied hands, the Netherlands Information Bureau disclosed yesterday.

Montclair, on its New Jersey hillside, will deny that it is a town of highbrows, but will admit that its civic-mindedness is keen. Its people are noted for feeling that statesmanship begins at home, and that as the citizen is bent, so is the Congressman inclined.

The War Advertising Council has issued a message to advertisers, agencies and media urging more advertising support for the recruiting of additional war workers. The message declares such support is needed more than ever before despite cut-backs in some war production plants and the possibility of passage of the proposed national service act.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Sharply denying the widely held notion among food trade representatives meeting here this week that recent releases of canned food items into civilian trade channels indicates that a surplus exists and that caution is necessary to avoid heavy inventory losses, Government spokesmen today termed the view "peacetime' jitters" and warned that Army requirements will actually be increased this year.
"The gift of this ambulance is a manifestation of the spirit of a man who was loved by everybody."

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Jan. 25 -- American forces used their new rocket artillery from ships in the New Britain landings at both Arawe and Cape Gloucester, as well as at Saidor in New Guinea and in ground attacks on the Gloucester airfields, which quickly fell, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Argentina as expected tonight to break relations with the Axis and by that act align herself on the side of the Allies and with the forces of solidarity in the Western Hemisphere as a result of decisions reached in Buenos Aires.
Mrs. Carlos Martins, wife of the Brazilian Ambassador, has come to the St. Regis from Washington.
BOSTON, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- The Red Wings stretched their unbeaten streak to eight games tonight in the National Hockey League by defeating the Bruins, 6 -- 3, before 10,000 fans at Boston Garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A new $14,214,877,000 appropriation "kickback," raising to $27,378,396,000 the amount which the War Department expects to return to the budget bureau reserve this year, was reported to the House today.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Sir Cuthbert De Hoghton, 63 years of age, holder of the second oldest baronetcy in England, announced today he would marry his 19-year-old secretary, Philomena Simmons. Miss Simmons' mother, widow of an insurance man, is a tenant on the De Hoghton estate.

LONDON, Jan. 25 (Reuter)-Smaller shipyards in Sweden are Iplanning to build forty-five largel modern fishing boats of the cutter type for Iceland, according to the! Goeteborg newspaper Handelstid-! ningen, quoted by the Norwegian! Telegraph Agency. The boats are expected to be delivered immediately after the war.

Wind-defying hats are a Peg Fischer feature. She has devised a way of building her hats with a point that descends on the back of the hair, tightly gripping the head, to serve as an anchor. In addition to the safety feature, it offers an opportunity for decoration and she places miniature bows of pique, ribbon or straw on the head-gripping sliver.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- House and Senate tax bill conferees rejected today House individual income tax proposals in favor of the Senate provision, leaving most taxpayers with the prospect of somewhat higher payments for 1944 than they made for 1943.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- Former champion Bob Montgomery knocked out young Ike Williams, latest lightweight sensation, in the twelfth round tonight before 14,807 fans at Convention Hall, breaking the Trenton (N.J.) Negro's winning streak at thirty-three consecutive victories.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- Not single hour of production has been lost by strike or slowdown in any of the seventeen major war factories in this city since the nation began to rearm, industrialists said today in claiming a national record of wartime harmony -- a record that they explained might be equalled elsewhere but not beaten.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 25 -- Foreign Minister Alberto Gilbert, speaking to the press, tonight announced the Argentine Government would take severe measures against German espionage. The case against the Germans, he said, has been fully proved and the Government is determined to end such activities once and for all because they injure Argentina's good name and national honor.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Jan. 26 (AP) -- A communique:

ADVANCE SOUTH PACIFIC AIR BASE, Jan. 18 (Delayed) -- Crack Japanese fighter pilots are flying in defense of Rabaul, Lieut. Comdr. Hawley (Monk) Russell of Scituate, Mass., warned American pilots attacking that New Britain base.

At the end of their non-title three-cushion match, during which they played forty-three blocks of 50 points each in four cities, there was a total of 209 points separating Willie Hoppe and Welker Cochran, and the Old Master was on top.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 26 -- A decree signed by President Pedro Ramirez and countersigned by Foreign Minister Alberto Gilbert was issued this morning, declaring diplomatic relations between Argentina on the one hand and Germany and Japan on the other had been broken as of today.

Capt. Vincent Astor, now on active duty with the Navy, has extended his real estate holdings in Flushing, Queens, by the acquisition of two more large store properties on Roosevelt Avenue, in the heart of the city's shopping center.

Describing the present conditions in industry as "a second civil war," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, advocared yesterday a strong public policy and action by Congress to check further inroads on "the fundamental principles of liberty" for which the nation is fighting.

Testifying in the Morland act inquiry into the administration of the workmen's compensation law, Dr. Leopold Brahdy of the Corporation Council's office charged yesterday that employes of New York City were being "over treated" by doctors in compensation practice, to the detriment of the patients and of the city's treasury.
Reports from Italy yesterday were still sparse and dated and indecisive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Roosevelt stepped directly into the Congressional controversies and deadlocks over service men's voting programs today, and in a bluntly worded message branded the "States' rights" measure passed by the Senate last month and now awaiting action in the House as "a fraud on the soldiers and sailors and marines."

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- As a result of the report that the Argentine Government had severed relations with the Axis nations, Argentine railway issues came into keen demand today and other Argentine shares also took an upward trend.

LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The aerial pounding of the German fortifications guarding the shortest invasion route to western Europe rolled through its fourth consecutive day today, with medium and light bombers and fighter-bombers striking at secret military installations in northern France.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Germany is facing a crisis in her declining productive capacity at a time when her military requirements are rising to a peak, the Earl of Selborne, Minister of Economic Warfare, said today.

The Marine Midland Corporation, which owns 98 per cent of the capital stock of twenty major banks in New York State, announced yesterday that consolidated current operating income of the corporation and its affiliates for 1943 amounted to $4,874,214, equal to 86 cents a share on the corporation's stock in the hands of the public.

When the sports committee for the Fourth War Loan Drive was planning a varied program of exhibitions to promote sales, the fishermen and hunters, whose name is legion, were given no formal part, perhaps because of the difficulty of getting them together en masse.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 26 -- News of the severance of diplomatic relations between Argentina and the Axis powers found official Berlin reconciled to the closing chapter in a protracted battle for what is termed "Anglo-American domination" of the last powerful unit among Latin-American republics.

The fortunes of war blew hot and cold on the affairs of two of our local ball clubs yesterday. The Giants, one might say, "gained" a player when they received word from Nashville, Tenn., that Ace Adams, their indefatigable relief hurler, recently-tabbed 1A, has been rejected by the military authorities and reclassified 4F.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE FOURTEENTH ARMY IN BURMA, Jan. 24 (Delayed) -- Fighting men of many races and nations make up the Fourteenth Army, in which the ground forces engaged against the Japanese on the Burma front have been grouped.

Thousands of men will be seeking jobs when the war is over. Many of them will come from the armed services. Many others will be left unemployed by the transition to peace production. And youngsters leaving school must begin earning.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Jan. 26 (AP) -- President Roosevelt awarded to Gen. Douglas MacArthur today the Distinguished Service Medal for successes in New Guinea and New Britain. The occasion was the southwest Pacific commander's sixty-fourth birthday.

ALAMEDA, Calif., Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- The Mars, largest operating airplane, completed its first round trip to Hawaii today, setting a new record in cargo carried by a plane across the Pacific and bringing back twenty-five persons, including Comdr. Gene Tunney, the former world's heavyweight boxing champion.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Jan. 27 (UP) -- A communique:

The Sheffield Farms Company, one of four milk handlers accused on Tuesday by Dr. Charles J. Blanford, market agent of the metropolitan milk sales area, of having violated the Federal Government's milk conservation program, denied the charge yesterday in a statement by its president, F.J. Andre.

A committee of the House, appointed to investigate executive agencies, accuses the National War Labor Board of policies "highly dangerous and menacing to the system of private enterprise and the constitutional right of judicial review of administrative decisions."

Maybe we have gained one good thing from the Pravda affair. In an AP dispatch from Moscow Eddy Gilmore reported that Pravda put the Russian word, "slukhi," over its alleged Cairo dispatch alleging that British leaders had been talking peace with the Germans.

An active demand for business space in midtown buildings was reflected in the reports of commercial leases made by brokers and property owners yesterday. Several contracts for space along Broadway also were noted.

The younger Henry Ford, addressing the national automobile dealers in convention assembled, warned them against current rose-colored dreams about the car of "tomorrow." It is practically the same reminder made several months ago by another big automobile executive.

New Yorkers failed in the last month to attain the quota of 180,000 tons of waste paper every two weeks that was fixed at the beginning of the city's salvage drive, it was announced yesterday by Harry A. Levy, Manhattan campaign director of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- An attempted revolution against the government of President Gen. Higinio Morinigo, apparently led by members of the outlawed Liberal party, was quelled after a brief fight in which one man was killed, it was officially disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today that it would consider applications for new, or enlarged, facilities for radio broadcasting stations, under a new procedure worked out with the War Production Board.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Lord Woolton, Minister of Reconstruction, promised today to do his utmost to prevent a recurrence of "social sores" after the war such as he saw between 1908 and 1911 when he lived among poverty-stricken dock laborers in Liverpool.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 -- Declaring that the concept of fair play had been clearly violated, the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., has demanded that the Securities and Exchange Commission set aside its recent order granting the Department of Justice leave to intervene in the proceedings involving the association and certain of the underwriters of the $38,000,000 bond issue of the Public Service Company of Indiana that was sold in 1938.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Edward H. Green, chairman of the finance committee of Merck Co., Inc., Rahway, N.J., drug and chemical manufacturers, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that his company would prefer to have its $1 par value common stock traded over the counter until it could apply for listing on the New York Stock Exchange and register under the Securities Exchange Act.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Military and essential civilian requirements for industrial alcohol are so large that all alcohol facilities, including those formerly devoted to liquor production, must be used to their full capacity this year to meet war needs, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- In the flames of the controversy over means to register and collect the votes of men and women in uniform at the 1944 general elections some important facts have been obscured. But they have successfully resisted the heat of the dispute, and when the issue is settled they will appear in the permanent record.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Tech. Sgt. John M. Webb of the United States Army Air Forces, who is now stationed "somewhere in Britain," has a unique story of bailing out from a plane and landing safely astride a farm horse.

Seven emergency coal depots will be opened today by the city in Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens to enable householders to buy anthracite in 50 and 100 pound "tideover" lots, which they will have to carry home themselves.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- In a sharp denunciation today of the National War Labor Board as indulging in policies and practices "menacing to the system of private enterprise and the constitutional right of judicial review," the Select Committee of the House named to Investigate Executive Agencies of the Government called on Congress to define and limit clearly the board's powers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Bell Telephone System has agreed to an annual reduction in interstate rates of about $7,950,000, effective Mar. 1, the Federal Communications Commission announced today. About $5,600,000 of the reduction will result from an agreement to place the night long-distance rate in effect at 6 P.M., instead of 7 P.M.

As further details of the Allied landing at the very gates of Rome become available, it is evident that the success achieved was by no means due to mere luck or German blundering. The principal factor which enabled the Allies to capture, consolidate and extend their beachheads was a brilliant strategy which set a classic pattern for future amphibious operations.

Today's events: Frances Pelton-Jones, harpsichord, Mary Craig, soprano, recital at the Plaza Hotel, 3:30 P.M.; "Un Ballo in Maschera," Metropolitan Opera House, 8; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra concert, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Louis Persinger, violin recital, Juilliard School of Music, 8:15.

The Shirt Institute protested to WPB in Washington yesterday through a committee of four, against application of M-317 to the men's and boys' dress-shirt industry, claiming that unless the order is modified production of members will be reduced about one-third during the current year.

Since the story about sex among the very young has been filling theatres of late, Mary Orr and Reginald Denham decided it would bear telling again. Their version opened last evening at the Cort under the title of "Wallflower," and as the first production of Meyer Davis, the orchestra leader, who hitherto has been associated in the backing of somewhat better shows.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 26 -- There was a roomful of people, but no bids today at the scheduled resale by the State Highway Department of seventy-seven dwellings on Rutherford Avenue that must be moved to make way for the construction of Route S-3 when the war is over.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Germany is getting from neutral European countries sizable quantities of materials for her war effort, but in some cases she is not getting as much as she formerly did.

Civic, realty and other organizations in a position to know the needs of their particular communities were urged yesterday to cooperate with the recently appointed three-man advisory planning board of the City Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- The War Labor Board Shipbuilding Commission punished Cramp shipbuilding employes at Philadelphia today for a recent strike by ordering the first financial penalties ever imposed by a WLB agency for union defiance.

Substantial gains in nearly all types of advertising were registered during 1943, according to an article by Dr. L.D.H. Weld, research director of McCann-Erickson, Inc., in the current issue of Printers' Ink. Basing his statement on the publication's general advertising index, which comprises newspapers, magazines, radio, farm papers and outdoor, Dr. Weld points out that all advertising advanced 14.6 per cent compared with that of 1942.

FAIR LAWN, N.J., Jan. 26 -- A general alarm fire early today swept the northern half of the Radburn Plaza Building, civic and business center of the Radburn residential area here, causing damage estimated by police and Fire Department officials at $275,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The United Nations were urged to complete without delay a common policy for dealing with war criminals by Terje Wold, Norwegian Minister of Justice, in an address before the Manchester Reform Club in England.

In your recent interesting editorial "Back Seat for Prepositions" you say Fowler holds that a preposition is allowed at the end "only when used in the literal or the most obvious sense." Such a position, you declare, seems too constrictive.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Air-borne units of the United States Army, including paratroops and glider-borne infantry, have completed extensive battle maneuvers in Britain, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's invasion headquarters announced today.

If history sometimes seems like a dream, what part of it is more dreamlike than the march on Rome of the armies of a nation that wasn't discovered until Rome was more than twenty-two centuries old? Every day the map of the route looks like an extract from the classical atlas.
Alexander Loudon, the Netherlands Ambassador, has come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Washington.

One year later than Chile, about two years later than the other nations of this hemisphere, Argentina had kept her agreement to break off relations with the Powers threatening the security of this hemisphere. The reasons given by the Ramirez Government for this step are cogent.

The fighting program contained in President Roosevelt's message to Congress is being overlooked. It is a program around which all progressive and liberal forces can rally and exert their influence to effectuate.

Despite the use of substitute foods and vitamin pills, it will cost $13,000 more to feed the birds and animals in the Bronx zoo in the year beginning July 1 than it did last year, Fairfield Osborn, president of the New York Zoological Society, said yesterday at a hearing before Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- John Morrell Co., meat packers, Ottumwa, Iowa, reported today a net income of $1,447,924, equal to $3.62 a capital share, for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, 1943. Net income in the preceding fiscal year was $1,547,950, equal to $3.97 a share.

The Belasco has been selected as the haven for "Decision," opening next Wednesday night. Edward Chodorov is the author and director of the play; Edward Choate is the producer. Among those in the cast are Ralph Greenleaf, Gwen Anderson, Larry Hugo, Merle Maddern, Jean Casto and Matt Crowley.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- One German airman is now a "guest" of this country all because two British Tommies stayed too long in a "pub" near their camp in the southeast of England, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Lieut. Richard Barklie Lakin, a 29-year-old British submarine commander, disclosed today that between October, 1942, and May, 1943, British underseas craft had sunk 1,250,000 tons of enemy shipping in the Mediterranean, or about half the Axis vessels undertaking to supply Marshal Rommel.

Robert V. Fletcher, vice president of the Association of American Railroads, proposed last night at a dinner of the Economic Club of New York that for the duration of the war the findings of the President's Emergency Board be made final and binding on all parties to railway labor disputes.

The sharp answer by the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children to a joint report by Commissioner of Investigation William B. Herlands and a judicial committee that investigated the institution recently, evoked a statement yesterday from the committee.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Re-enactment of the price control and stabilization acts scheduled to expire in June in a form "substantially the same" as the current statutes was urged today in a resolution unanimously adopted at the closing sessions of the National American Wholesale Grocers wartime conference.

Hosiery producers were warned yesterday by Earl Constantine, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, to prepare for the possibility that the War Production Board ultimately may be forced to adopt a program calling for overall allocation of cotton yarns to industries requiring this product for war and essential civilian needs.

An automatic control of the turbo-supercharger, the "wings of the stratosphere" that made high altitude flying possible, was described yesterday at the annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at Columbia University by W.H. Gille and H.T. Sparrow of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company, Minneapolis.

The three-story business building on a corner of Schuyler Place and Washington Street, Morristown, N.J., has been sold by the Home Furniture Company to the Hayes Circle Holding Company of Newark and will be occupied shortly by the Clinton Square Auto Parts Company.
Operating results for 1943 of two large steel companies disclosed slightly improved earnings over the previous year, according to their preliminary annual figures announced yesterday.

It is impossible to say how long rent control laws will remain in effect, Louis H. Pink, rent director of the New York City Defense rental area, declared yesterday at a meeting of the Long Island Society of Real Estate Appraisers, held at the Forest Hills Inn, Forest Hills, Queens.

The absence of any effective measures to rescue the oppressed European Jews was declared by Dean Alfange last night to be indicative of an imminent defeat "on the ideological front," even while victory on the military front was assured.
MIAMI, Jan. 26 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor adopted today four sections of an elaborate report prepared by its post-war committee headed by Matthew Woll.
PANAMA, Jan. 26 -- The Star and Herald is suspicious of the sudden change of attitude by the present Argentine Government that brought the break in relations with the Axis.
PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 26 -- Army and Navy planes made seven attacks throughout the Marshall Islands on Monday, maintaining the increased tempo of attacks that began over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The United States could support an Army of 16,000,000 men in the field, if necessary, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, told the Senate Military Affairs Committee today.

LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Yugoslav Partisans have stormed and reoccupied the western Bosnian stronghold of Mrkonjicgrad, near Jajce, the recently liberated headquarters of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz), but have been forced to evacuate the strategic town of Tuzla in eastern Bosnia, their war bulletin said today.

Population controls among the peoples of the Far East will be essential to permanent world peace but probably cannot be obtained for decades, speakers declared last night at the annual dinner of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Acting to get low-price women's and children's dresses, coats and other outer garments back into production, the Office of Price Administration today granted manufacturers who normally made garments for sale in the lowest-price lines to sell at slightly higher price levels.

The bicycle manufacturing industry may look for a partial resumption of production for civilians during or following the third quarter of the year, according to information received from the War Production Board, Neely Powers of the Colson Corporation told the annual meeting of the Bicycle Institute at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

A new issue of $1,517,000 of refunding bonds was awarded yesterday by Fernando County, Fla., to a syndicate comprising John Nuveen Co., B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., Leedy, Wheeler Co., the Trust Company of Georgia, of Atlanta, Ga., the Robinson-Humphrey Company and the Ranson-Davidson Company, Inc.

During the "March of Dimes" campaign of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis it will cost at least 10 cents to get into Mayor La Guardia's office at City Hall. The humblest taxpayer, the mightiest commissioner and even the City Hall reporters must drop their contributions into the blue and white container that was placed just outside the Mayor's office door yesterday.

The training campaign for one of the most controversial ring battles of recent years came to a close yesterday. Beau Jack, Atlantan, who is recognized here as world lightweight champion, and Sammy Angott, Kentuckian, ruler in National Boxing Association circles, concluded preparations at Lou Stillman's Gymnasium for their ten-round, non-title bout tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The adventures of Lieut. Margaret Jennings of Spring Lake, N.J., Army Nurse Corps, and Lieut. Lois Thomas of Syracuse. N.Y., Army dietitian, on the hospital ship Seminole under German bombing in Naples were described today by the War Department. The vessel was blacked out for an hour, but three bombs fell close enough to jar metal fittings loose.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Newspaper men who form the advisory board to the press division of the Office of Censorship urged today extreme care to see that nothing is published that may adversely affect coming military operations in Europe.

Although this nation began many years later than the Axis powers to prepare for a mechanical, technical war, it has more than made up for that disadvantage because of the miracles performed by free, untrammeled industrial and scientific enterprise, Dr. Vannevar Bush, president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, said here yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, England, Jan. 26 -- "Health Commandos," flying squadrons of scientists who "raid" schools, towns and institutions at the first sign of disease, have helped to keep Britain remarkably free of epidemics during this war.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Rose Brancato, 28, a reporter for the New Haven Journal-Courier, who disappeared July 5, was strangled and her fully clothed body was cremated in a fire box in a building in the center of the city, Raymond E. Egan, captain of detectives, said today in announcing that Walter W. Law, 39, married and the father of three children, had signed a written confession of the crime.

The retail price of several kinds of fresh fish will be reduced substantially today, as top dollars-and-cents ceilings placed on them by the Office of Price Administration become effective, it was said last night by Daniel P. Woolley, regional OPA administrator.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Vice President Wallace announced today his support of the equal rights amendment in a letter to Mrs. Emma Guffey Miller, joint Congressional chairman of the National Woman's Party and sister of Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania.

Notre Dame, for the past twenty years represented in many of the Millrose games, yesterday became officially a part of this year's edition to be held in Madison Square Garden Feb. 5. Represented in the past by such men as Greg Rice, Jack Elder and Oliver Hunter, the Irish again will send some excellent performers to New York.

Justice John E. McGeehan in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday reserved decision until Feb. 4 on an application to force Bronx private bus companies to halt school buses. It was a taxpayer's action seeking to establish the authority of the New York State War Council. Pending his decision Justice McGeehan ordered the cessation of all privately operated bus companies in accordance with the War Council's order of Oct. 4.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Speaker Rayburn appointed this afternoon a bipartisan committee of eighteen members of the House to study post-war economic policy and planning, in line with the announcement he made last week at the United States Conference of Mayors in Chicago.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Thursday, Jan. 27 -- A large Japanese tanker and five cargo ships ranging from 300 to 7,500 tons were destroyed and two other vessels beached Monday when United States Navy land-based Avengers, with a heavy escort, struck Rabaul harbor, which is becoming a graveyard for Japanese ships.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress concerning legislation to give service men opportunity to vote was as follows:

In your issue of Jan. 14 you say that the Administration's tax program "seems to be concerned almost exclusively" with incomes of above $5,000 a year. As a matter of fact, as the general counsel of the Treasury has recently pointed out, only 42 per cent of the entire added revenue under the Treasury program, and only 48 per cent of the additional individual income taxes would come from people with net incomes above $5,000.

ON THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, South of Rome, Jan. 25 (Delayed) -- Reinforcements and a growing stream of supplies and equipment are pouring into the sheltered port of Anzio or are being transported up the beaches by "ducks" loaded to the gun wales. American troops have now seized the initiative from the still disorganized Germans and, under the cover of a gradually growing artillery barrage, are slowly attacking farther inland.

Endorsements by leaders of our armed forces of the "March of Dimes" appeal of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis were made public yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the foundation. From Italy Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, commander of the Fifth Army, sent this message: "I have been interested for years in the 'Fight Paralysis' campaign.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 -- Attorney Loyd Wright disclosed here today that articles of incorporation for the Academy Foundation, a non-profit educational institution concerned with the cultural and technological advancements of motion pictures, were filed today with the Secretary of State in Sacramento.

General Isaias Medina Angarita, President of Venezuela, responded last night to tributes to his country's wartime cooperation with the United Nations with a suggestion that "a harmonious union of North American capital and technique with our natural resources and manpower" can be "a contribution toward a better world in the postwar period."

FLETCHER PRATT, speaking in the New York Times Hall Tuesday night, remarked that the war in Europe would end "soon after the failure of a German counter-attack" against Anglo-American invasion forces in the West. Mr. Pratt based his theory on the supposition that Germany lacks the reserves to retrieve a single failure of arms in a two-front war.

George Copeland gave one of his far too infrequent recitals last night in Carnegie Hall for the benefit of Junior American Nurse, Inc. The pianist was in top form, and his playing never has been more replete with the characteristics which won him an enviable niche of his own among keyboard artists from the outset of his career.

ALGIERS, Jan. 26 -- The Allies' invasion forces south of Rome, with continuing heavy air and naval support, thrust inexorably ahead yesterday against German resistance that was increasing but still slight.

Individual participation in the Fourth War Loan is much wider than in the previous bond campaigns and is expected to result soon in raising the daily sales level materially, according to reports reaching the War Finance Committee for New York State yesterday.

SMOLENSK, Russia, Jan. 22 (Delayed) -- An extraordinary Soviet commission investigating German atrocities reported today that its examinations had definitely established that the Germans had individually shot and killed 11,000 Polish officers and men in near-by Katyn forest during August and September, 1941.

Basketball made its contribution to the Fourth War Loan Drive last night when its double-header not only drew a capacity crowd of 6,000 to the Seventy-first Regiment Armory but added a total of $1,676,750 to the fund now being raised to beat the Axis.

Venezuela's visiting President, Gen. Isaias Medina Angarita, joined yesterday with Mayor La Guardia and James S. Carson, president of the Argentine-American Chamber of Commerce, in expressing delight over Argentina's break with the Axis.
A perfectly astonishing performance, and an equally astonishing, indeed sensational, success resulted from the Metropolitan Opera Association's revival last night of Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande."

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- The Spanish Government, through its Ambassador, the Duke of Alba, informed Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today that it had adopted the most stringent measures to stamp out sabotage in shipments of oranges from Spain and to punish those responsible.

Major League Club owners, all with their own private problems, sympathized with Sam Breadon's pessimistic view of the prospects for the 1944 season yesterday, but only a few wanted to use a corner of Breadon's crying towel, according to The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- George N. Briggs, who was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on the charge of forging the "Harry Hopkins letter," gave bond of $3,000 in District Court today preparatory to his arraignment, which is forecast for Friday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 26 -- Somewhere in the mountains of northern Greece representatives of Greek guerrilla bands are reported meeting to discuss some sort of agreement at least for the duration of the war.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 26 (AP) -- A proposal that cities receive 25 per cent of the State gasoline tax, beginning in 1946, under a constitutional amendment, was offered in the Legislature today by Assemblyman George B. Parsons, Onondaga Republican.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- The British Government, standing by the principles of the Atlantic Charter, does not recognize any territorial changes that have taken place in Poland since the start of the war and does not intend to recognize any territorial changes unless they occur with the free consent and good-will of the parties concerned, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden declared today in the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Reductions totaling $1,654,857 from the $6,146,000 requested for national defense activities of the Federal Communications Commission were recommended today by the House Appropriations Committee. The cuts included one of $1,000,000 for "war activities" of the commission's radio intelligence division, which, the committee said, should be transferred to the War and Navy Departments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Otto S. Beyer, director of transport personnel of the Office of Defense Transportation, today recommended to the executives of the railroads a report on jobs suitable to women on a typical railroad, compiled by Miss Dorothy Sells, of the ODT, and Miss Olive Dennis, engineer of service of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, who served as an ODT consultant during the survey.

Alleged to have painted "Down With the Jews" with red paint and tar on a one-story store building at 218-90 Hempstead Avenue, Queens Village, five 17-year-old boys were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Peter M. Horn in the Flushing court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull expressed gratification today over Argentina's severance of diplomatic relations with Germany and Japan and said he assumed Argentina would now "proceed energetically" to take other measures in line with that action for the security of the Western Hemisphere.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz deferred until this morning his decision on whether he or Judge Franklin Taylor will hear arguments for a new trial in behalf of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Louis Capone and Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss, who are in the death house at Sing Sing Prison as the murderers of Joseph Rosen, a Brooklyn candy store proprietor, in 1936.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The texts of the Argentine Government's decree breaking relations with the Axis and of its explanatory announcement follow:
The one-family house at 246 Bay Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Mrs. Sara Wind to Angelo Taurozzi through Slomka Bros., Inc., brokers.

The question of unity among the United Nations returned yesterday to plague the stock market. Despite the moderation of the selling pressure, stocks suffered a general decline, with the setback the widest in more than two months, initially as a reflection over the report of United States Steel and later over the new developments in Allied talks on the Polish border dispute.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Creditors holding $12,300,000 in securities of the Pittsburgh Railways Company and the Pittsburgh Motor Coach Company proposed today termination of bankruptcy proceedings which began in 1938.

Mayor La Guardia does not recognize the right of any city employe to strike against the city government he warned yesterday after declaring that labor relations principles in private industry did not apply to municipal workers.

Declaring that it was the obligation of industry to "take care of every returning service man," William S. Jack, president of Jack Heintz, Inc., of Cleveland, Ohio, charged yesterday that the Roosevelt Administration "hasn't recognized its obligation to see to it that industry has something left for post-war conversion."

Indecisive and narrow fluctuations marked quiet dealings in cotton yesterday. Routine trade price-fixing absorbed the scattered hedge offerings and liquidation. At the close active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to off 3 points.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 27 -- Russian troops, hammering the Germans back along a fifty-mile curving front south of Leningrad, have captured the fortified city of Krasnogvardeisk, cut the last railroad escape route for many thousands of the enemy in the Volkhov River area and advanced to within forty-two miles of the Estonian border, Moscow disclosed last night.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 26 -- The news of Argentina's severance of relations with the Axis was received with great satisfaction by the Mexican Government, according to Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla who said that it would "insure that continental unity which has been the goal of the Americas since the Rio de Janiero conference in 1942."

A million pounds of fresh fish arrived in Manhattan by boat during the last three days, and a like amount came in by truck and rail. As a result, the market is almost normal for the first time in more than two months, or since the strike began.

The United States has the most highly insured armed forces in history, with 14,000,000 applications for national service life insurance exceeding $100,000,000,000, the Institute of Life Insurance declared yesterday. It said the total did not include either regular civilian insurance owned by service men and women or veterans' insurance dating from World War I.

Private construction after the war is more than likely to go beyond fulfillment of deferred demand, and with States and many communities in good financial condition, there probably will be no need for a post-war Federal emergency works program with subsidies for States and local governments, Thomas S. Holden, president of the F.W. Dodge Corporation, declared yesterday.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust in 1943 increased the number of shares outstanding from 6,410,210 to 6,850,013 and the net asset value of a share from $16.89 to $20.20, ending the year with net assets of $138,370,263.

Joined by Sidney B. Wood Jr., former Wimbledon champion Lieut. J. Donald Budge, world tennis champion, and Lieut. (j. g.) Donald McNeill and Ensign Ted Schroeder, both former national amateur titleholders, worked out at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn yesterday for tomorrow night's War Bond matches at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Seized in a raid -- said to have been the first of its kind led by a woman prosecutor -- Dr. Charles Victor Ducoff of 38 Fort Washington Avenue, 49-year-old native of Russia, was booked at the District Attorney's office last night on a charge of criminal abortion.

On publication day, publishers of "A Dictionary of American English," at the University of Chicago Press, found they had only 100 sets left to sell. The dictionary, a four-volume work priced at $100, was issued in paper-bound parts at intervals beginning in September, 1936, with a run of 2,500 copies.

Louis Lanza, 34 years old, a convict from Attica State Prison, and Natalie Bruno, 37, of 51 East Houston Street, pleaded guilty to charges of first degree manslaughter yesterday at their murder trial before Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions.
LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26 -- A rush forward from last place to first won for Lieut. Col. Gustave Ring's Hasteville today at Hialeah where 8,722 persons watched the races and rolled up a handle of $703,322. The winner of the featured Grade B Handicap dashed seven furlongs out of the chute in 1:26 flat but he was a surprise to most in the crowd who had made Alforay a favorite.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Congress completed action today on a bill to provide mustering out pay of up to $300 to veterans of World War II as the House and Senate in quick succession voted approval of a conference compromise. The bill was sent to the President for signature.

President Roosevelt's award of the Distinguished Service Medal to General MacArthur on his sixty-fourth birthday is the nation's recognition of two years of resourceful and successful leadership of the armed forces in the Southwest Pacific. At this time in 1942 the Japanese were overrunning the Philippines, and our hopelessly outnumbered forces had been crowded into their last defenses on Bataan.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- An estimated 13.000 hogs remained unsold at ts end of today's trading here despite the marketing permit system placed into effect to bring about better distribution of swine loadlngs over the week. Many producers were holding oaek swine exceeding 300 pounds until tomorrow when they. too, wlll be covered by the Government support price of $13.75 as the 200 to 300 pounders are covered.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Marvin Jones, director of the War Food Administration, made public today 1944 support prices for farm products but insisted that the execution of the program depended upon future action by Congress.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Roosevelt sent a special message to Congress denouncing the soldier vote bill already passed by the Senate as a "fraud" on service men.

A quick turnover of a large property on the East Side was announced yesterday by Frederick Brown, operator, who resold the two twelve-story office and loft buildings at 450 and 460 Fourth Avenue which he had purchased two weeks ago from the Franklin Savings Bank.

Statements of earnings of the railroads for 1943 show generally that taxes are taking an increasingly larger part of the gross revenues. The Southern Pacific, one of the nation's large systems, estimated tax payments last year at $126,719,369, up almost $50,000,000 from 1942.

Advantage should be taken of current low inventories "to wipe the distribution slate clean" and to develop new techniques which will assure effective consumer demands for post-war production, Arthur A. Hood, director of dealer relations, Johns-Manville Corporation, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The CIO "political action committee" will be investigated soon by the Dies committee, Chairman Dies of Texas disclosed today following House approval of an additional $75,000 for expenses of the committee.

For successfully destroying a Nazi submarine unaided and capturing her skipper, the officers and men of the Navy patrol vessel PC-565 received yesterday a silver plaque donated by H. Leggitt Gray of Riverside, Conn., who was a member of the crew of a first World War craft of similar type, which was sunk in 1918.

Conrad Thibault, popular radio baritone, gave a recital at Town Hall last night before a good-sized audience that was cordial in its approval of the singing. The program opened with a seventeenth century group by Handel, Cavalli, Rosa and Falconieri, all in Italian.

A taxpayer's suit was filed in Supreme Court yesterday to compel a court review of Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine's dismissal of charges of un-American activities against Patrolman James L. Drew.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The American public school system has failed to pay its teachers enough to keep pace with increased living costs and this threatens to produce many young voters a decade or two hence who will bring the greatest threat to democracy, Donald DuShane of the National Education Association today told a Senate group studying the effect of rising living costs on white collar workers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, refused today, for the second time, to answer questions put to him by a House committee investigating the Federal Communications Commission and was backed up by Attorney General Biddle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Soviet Government has rejected, in the present circumstances, the tender of good offices by the United States looking to a resumption of relations between that Government and the Polish Government in Exile in London, in view of the Polish boundary dispute.

H.L. Brooks, president of the Toilet Goods Association, in opening the first meeting of the scientific section of the organization yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, hailed the gathering as evidence that the toilet goods industry "has come of age."

"Swing Fever," a musical produced by Metro, will have its premiere this morning at Loew's State. Kay Kyser heads the cast of the picture, which was directed by Tim Whelan. Marilyn Maxwell, William Gargan, Lena Horne, Nat Pendleton, Curt Bois, Maxie Rosenbloom and Pamela Blake are among the supporting players.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Jan. 27 (U.P.) -- Ground activities on New Britain in the Caue Gloucester area were confined to patrol action, with for-Bay front, Allied Headquarters announced today.

Six hundred radio engineers, program men and station owners of the country, meeting here yesterday at the FM Broadcasters Convention, heard James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, warn that radio needs some long-range planning to be ready for the benefits of frequency modulation after the war.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 -- Radio-Keith-Orpheum has concluded a deal with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to borrow Laraine Day for the lead roles in two pictures a year for a period of four years. The actress' first RKO film under the arrangement will be "Spanish Main."

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Existence of a British bomber-reconnaissance plane called the Albemarle was made public today, more than three years after it first went into production. It has been on the secret list longer than any other British aircraft.

Runaway inflation has forced almost every woman in unoccupied China's cities to get a job to help support her family, in addition to bearing much heavier home burdens, according to Maude Russell of the foreign service of the Young Women's Christian Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The United States has suspended oil shipments from the Caribbean area to Spain for February, it was learned on excellent authority tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Four-engined Allied bombers were reported by the Germans tonight to have slashed at the Marseille area of southern France today while British and Canadian aircraft carried out sweeps over northern France, Belgium and the Netherlands and shot down ten Nazi fighters.

THE TIMES of Jan. 12 recorded the passing of John Walter Christie. I note this with considerable regret, the more so because our nation, which was definitely in his debt, had, through failure to properly reimburse him for services rendered, unwittingly caused a great genius to be in want.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Lieut. Tom Harmon, home again after two escapes from death in crashes of Army airplanes, was reunited here today with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Harmon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -Development of the post-war economy on a foundation of private enterprise, with a minimum of government interference, was recommended to Congress today by Governor Bricker of Ohio, an announced candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Senate Republicans met today and took under advisement for two weeks a suggested program by which they would establish a new system to divorce party consideration of controversial matters from control over members in public debate now exercised by the floor leader.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 27 (AP) -- L. Edmund Zacher, president, has reported that the combined assets of the Travelers Insurance Company and its three affiliates amounted on Dec. 31, last, to $1,376,969,339, an increase of $90,551,247 during the year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- During the week ended Jan. 26 member bank reserve balances decreased $12,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from decreases of $34,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $10,000,000 in gold stock and increases of $4,000,000 in Treasury cash and $36,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by decreases of $21,000,000 in money in circulation and $53,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks.

ALGIERS, Jan. 27 -- In the low coastal plain southwest of the Fascist-built town of Littoria, administrative center for the Pontine Marshes, British and American forces fanning out from the invasion beaches around Anzio and Nettuno have fought and won the first important battle since the landing five days ago.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Selling agents of hogs here had difficulty today in clearing the stockyards of accumulated supplies and around 15,000 swine went unsold at the close of trade. Although supplies have been distributed evenly this week under the new plan of permission to ship, demand has not kept pace with the daily quotas, and hogs have gone unsold after each session.

"The Geography of the Peace" is the title of the new book by Nicholas John Spykman to be published by Harcourt, Brace this spring. The book presents in text and fifty-one maps "the power position of the United States" and how "the basis of world planning for peace must be world geography."

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 27 -- Preparations are under way to convert Winfield Hall, the Long Island Sound estate of the late Frank W. Woolworth, into a chemical and metallurgical institute where university and commercial scientists will assemble for research and conferences to exchange information.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation made voluntary price reductions under its contracts with the Government amounting to $69,000,000 to the end of 1942 and further reduced its billings by close to $144,000,000 during 1943, Eugene G. Grace, president, said yesterday after the quarterly meeting of directors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- While only one refugee government -- that of Norway -- has been able to reach a final agreement with the State and War Departments in the matter, extraordinarily complete and detailed arrangements have been made by nearly all for the resumption of civil government in their countries when Allied troops invade Europe.
A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE IN ENGLAND, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Oliver R. Germann, 25, of Moran, Wyo., recently a farm hand, had seven decorations pinned on his tunic today for bravery as an airman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The tax bill conferees almost finished the excise tax schedule in the pending revenue measure today, accepting the highest rate in most instances, and agreed to the Senate provision with regard to the excess profits credit allowed corporations for invested capital.

The Procter Gamble Company reported yesterday in its operating statement for the six months ended on Dec. 31, net profit amounted to $10,405,490 after deducting provision of $6,945,000 for Federal income tax and net excess profits taxes of $3,109,500.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The way was opened today for resumption of the extraordinary investigation of alleged crime in Albany County by a Court of Appeals decision which held that Justice Parton Swift, named by Governor Dewey to hear the State's case, had not exceeded his jurisdiction in permitting dismissal of jurors on the ground that they might be "subject to bias."

At a meeting yesterday of the Association of Buying Offices at the Hotel Martinique, John Block, president of the organization, received unanimous approval from the membership for the corporate plan he has sponsored for the disposal of Government surplus merchandise.
LONDON, Jan. 27 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:
Book dealers, textile firms, milliners and interior decorators figured as lessees of business space in the renting contracts announced here yesterday.

Permission was obtained from the United States Coast Guard yesterday for six outstanding hockey players now in that branch of service to participate in the All-Star match listed for Madison Square Garden on Sunday afternoon as part of the Fourth War Loan Drive.

The recent clamor in the United States over Poland's eastern boundaries is a foretaste of what we may expect recurrently throughout the next few years, as each foreign-born minority group calls upon the Administration to orientate United States foreign policy in support of the ambitions of their brethren overseas.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Gains in Argentine rails, caused by Argentine's decision to sever diplomatic relations with the Axis, and improvements in British gilt-edge securities were the main features of the stock markets here today. Among the gilt-edge issues, the 3 1/2 per cent War Loan showed a rise of some shillings.

WITH BRITISH FRONT-LINE TROOPS SOUTH OF ROME, Jan. 26 (Delayed) -- The British held firm in this sector today when the Germans unleashed their heaviest counter-attack yet, employing twenty-five tanks, including both Mark VI's and Tigers.

The city and Federal Governments began separate check-ups yesterday to see that the new retail price ceilings on fresh fish, which entail a substantial reduction for the consumer in the price of several varieties, are observed.

While the battle of Rome is still in its initial stages, it is evident that a test is approaching both of Allied professions to restore democratic government in Italy and of the ability of the Italian people themselves to share in the victory. Thus far Italian participation in the war has been virtually nil.

Due to drastic curtailment in the production of men's and boys' clothing brought about by shortages of cotton linings and pocketings, modification of priority rating percentages embodied in the revised cotton goods conservation order, M-317, is expected by the industry.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Friday, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A mile and one-half expansion of the vital month-old American beachhead on northwestern New Britain was announced today by headquarters.

World and national tennis champions, headed by Lieut. J. Donald Budge of the Army Air Forces and Miss Alice Marble of San Francisco, will go into action tonight in the second big sports show staged by the Fourth War Loan Drive Sports Committee to swell the sale of war bonds.

The stock market bogged down yesterday as interest dwindled and prices eased to an irregularly lower close. Spots of strength appeared in distilling and public utility issues, but not in other major sections. Trading on the Stock Exchange was the slowest since the first session of the year, involving only 595,190 shares, against 778,495 on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks broke a third period 4-4 tie tonight to whip the last place New York Rangers, 6 -- 4, before 10,166 spectators in a National League hockey match at the Stadium.

BOSTON, Jan. 27 -- Immediate establishment of an international commission on education to plan for educational rehabilitation in the devastated countries is urged by the faculty groups of thirty-seven American colleges and universities cooperating with the Universities Committee on Post-War International Problems.

Care of their soil on a long-range basis, and wise irrigation and use of nutrients, will net victory gardeners rich results, it was declared yesterday by T.H. Everett, horticulturist at the New York Botanical Garden.

Sales of coal in 50 and 100-pound lots at the six emergency depots established by the city amounted to less than two tons yesterday as the depots began to operate. The lack of demand was attributed by officials and depot operators to the unseasonably warm weather and to unfamiliarity with the emergency arrangement.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan 27 -- Putitthere and Reztips, running within a fifth of a second of each other, captured the two divisions of the Palm Grove Purse at Hialeah Park today as 8,621 watched the races, including a dead heat in the grass race.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- There were more strikes in Great Britain and Northern Ireland in 1943 than in any other year in this century, a survey disclosed today.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- In striking contrast with last year's blinding blizzard, it was a clear, sunny day that greeted Prof. Branch Rickey and a corterie of New York baseball scribes today as they made their second annual pilgrimage to the Dodgers' wartime training base.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- The heaviest rainfall in several months blanketed the greater part of the winter Wheat Belt last night and early today, with reports indicating that the threat of drought virtually has been eliminated as a market influence for some time.

Among the ranks of this country's overseas Army waging an invisible but highly effective "war of nerves" with words for weapons are eighty-nine women who have been sent without fanfare from the Office of War Information overseas branch in New York in the past year to take part in the campaign against the enemy.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 27 (U.P.) -- Gen. Pedro Ramirez, President of Argentina, asserted tonight that his nation would not tolerate the diplomatic rupture with the Axis as an excuse for intimidation against Argentine citizens and property.

The skiers' scourge, the January thaw, with its unseasonable warm temperatures, mountain fog and rain, now prevails in the north country and as a result yesterday's ski observations were generally disappointing. Following last week-end's snowstorm, which had deposited upward to ten inches of new powder on trails and slopes, the elements, in striking at this time, gave the ski fraternity a real setback.
IN THE NORTHERN BURMA JUNGLE, Jan. 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- From the east, west and north Chinese troops are slowly converging on the Japanese strongpoint of Taipha Ga, the fall of which is imminent.
WASHINGTON Jan. 27 (UP) -- Text of the joint Army-Navy report on Japanese atrocities in the Philippines:
Howard A. Flogaus has been named vice president in charge of engineering of the J.G. Brill Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, administrator of veterans' affairs and chairman of the Federal Board of Hospitalization, received today a delegation of officials and representatives of veterans' organizations from New York and Brooklyn who called to present plans and arguments in favor of the erection of a veterans' hospital in Brooklyn.

ALGIERS, Jan. 27 -- The trial by a military tribunal of the first group of former custodians of Vichy's concentration camps in North Africa is expected to begin early in February. The trial will mark the first judicial application of the purge program adopted by the French Committee of Liberation, which has been criticized for its slowness of action by the Consultative Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- With consideration of service men's voting procedure developing into spirited and at times bitter fourth-term debate in the wake of President Roosevelt's message to Congress yesterday, a compromise proposal was offered in the Senate today by Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, under which the proposed Federal ballot would prevail to the extent that the States failed to meet specifications.

Oswald Ryan, acting chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, predicted yesterday that New York's position as a seaport would be matched with an international air terminal after the war, while Mayor La Guardia reiterated his claim that the Idlewild Airport now under construction in Queens would be the "greatest" in the world.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Hercules Powder Company reported today for 1943 net earnings of $5,704,511, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $3.93 a common share, against $5,546,980, or $3.81 a common share, for the preceding year.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- British naval and economic warfare authorities recently increased their vigilance against the smuggling of contraband war materials of small bulk bound from South America to Germany in neutral ships. Many, though not all, such ships are of Spanish registry.

Since his message to Congress on Jan. 11 the President has not referred again to the proposal for a National War Service Act which he then described as indispensable to the winning of the war in the shortest possible time and with the least possible loss of American lives.

MOSCOW, Friday, Jan. 28 -- The swiftly advancing Red Army yesterday captured the important rail junctions of Volosovo and Tosno and completely cleared the Germans from the section of the main Moscow-Leningrad railway between Tosno and Lubyan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Recipients of mustering-out pay under terms of the bill, now awaiting signature by the President will not include service men who were honorably discharged on their own initiative to take employment in civilian life, members of Congress emphasized today in answer to inquiries.

Oil supplies along the Eastern seaboard were virtually unchanged last week. The index of the American Petroleum Institute covering gasoline stood at 41.9 at the end of the week, compared with 42 a week earlier. The light fuel oil index increased to 87.3 from 86.2 and that of heavy fuel oil was unchanged at 67.9.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- There was little movement in commodity prices in primary markets except for certain farm products during the week ended on Jan. 22, and the Bureau of Labor Statistics all-commodity index remained unchanged at 103.0 per cent of the 1926 average.

The gold medal of the National Institute of Arts and Letters will be given this year to Willa Cather, distinguished American novelist. The medal, the institute's highest award, is given in recognition of an individual's distinguished achievement in arts or letters.

Half the members of the graduating class of the Children's Aid Society's West Side Center, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street, failed to make the grade. At commencement exercises yesterday afternoon they sat in the audience and watched fifteen of their more successful classmates, appropriately clad in academic gowns and mortarboards, receive diplomas attesting their satisfactory completion of kindergarten studies.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total l holdings of United States Government securities to be at a new high record, having increased $113,336,000 during the week. Total Gold Holdings

The Phillips Petroleum Company, one of the nation's largest oil producing and marketing concerns, is completing plans to issue $40,000,000 of new debenture indebtedness, the proceeds to be used to pay off existing bank loans and provide new working capital, it was learned yesterday.

Entry of the screw machine industry into the field of plastics after the war and greater expansion in that period were forecast yesterday by Orrin B. Werntz, executive secretary of the National Screw Machine Products Association.
BOSTON, Jan. 27 -- Bob Quinn, president of the Braves, announced tonight that he had received a letter from Casey Stengel notifying him of Stengel's resignation as manager.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The German air force will rely on standard bombers and fighters for most of its defensive air strength when the invasion comes, air experts here said today. Practically all fighters and the majority of bombers will be flown as dual-purpose machines: Messerschmitt 209's and Focke-Wulf 290's as fighter-bombers; Me-110's and Junkers 88's or their improved versions, the Me-410 and the Ju-l88, as combination heavy fighters and long-range bombers.

The triumphant guns of Moscow have grown hoarse this winter barking out the news of great victories. But since the epic battle of Stalingrad was won, just a year ago, the special salvos have announced nothing more thrilling to the Russian people than the lifting of the siege of Leningrad.

Officers of the National Women's Council of the Navy League of the United States will give their annual luncheon on Feb. 12 on the Pierre Roof. Speakers for the occasion will be Rear Admiral Harry L. Brinser, USN, Capt. Maurice M. Witherspoon, Chaplains Corps, USN, and Henry J. Taylor, war correspondent who returned recently from a tour of European battlefronts.

Mrs. Helen Byrans, 28 years old, who is accused of having left her three small children alone in her three-room apartment at 1205 Simpson Street, the Bronx, to gamble, declared yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court that she played cards in a "desperate" attempt to raise money to support her family.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Stories of how the Japanese barbarously tortured and cold-bloodedly starved to death and mercilessly murdered more than 5,200 American and many times that number of Filipino soldiers captured on Bataan and Corregidor were disclosed in official reports made public jointly by the Army and Navy tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -Union demands in five steel concerns for pay rises that go beyond the Administration's "hold the line" limit reached the War Labor Board today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Department store sales last week were 14 per cent above those in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The weekly index, however, dropped one point from the previous week and stood at 136.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 27 (AP) -- The three-man committee recently appointed by Judge Calvin W. Chesnut of Baltimore to handle final reorganization of the Seaboard Air Line Railway Company has obtained from the Virginia State Corporation Commission a charter to operate, as the "Seaboard Railway Company," a new corporation which will take over the records of the Seaboard Air Line.
Thomas Moffa purchased from Briarcliff Estate, Inc., the six-story apartment house at 1440 Undercliff Avenue, in the Bronx, occupying a plot 100 by 119 feet.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The high standard set by the American Red Cross in its provision of hostels for men on leave has caused some heart searching among authorities responsible for catering to British and dominion troops. Lord Trent today made a plea in the House of Lords for at least 10,000 more beds for persons in the services. About 30,000 are available.

Net assets of the State Street Investment Corporation, now 20 years old, rose last year to $46,865,526 and at the year-end were equal to $78.59 a share, a gain of 24.2 per cent from the $63.29 reported at the end of 1942.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A new clause in income tax legislation which would allow deduction of a madi's salary from the returns of working mothers is being sought here by the Working Mothers Club, composed of employes of the War Manpower Commission.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 27 -- Police were guarding today the home of Mrs. Christian M. Schmidt Sr., 61-year-old housewife, who was foreman of a Federal jury that convicted a German spy in August, 1942, after a threat that enemy agents would kill her within three days.

With record speed the Senate and House have agreed upon and sent to the President a bill to provide mustering-out pay for members of the armed forces. This pay will range from $100 to $300; the measure is expected to cost altogether a little more than $3,000,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Federal Light and Traction Company's plan to retire its $6 preferred stock at the liquidation price of $100 a share instead of the call price of $110 is "a windfall for the common stockholders at the expense of preferred stockholders," the Securities and Exchange Commission was told today by Linhart Stearns, vice president of Bernstein-Macaulay, Inc., of New York, investment advisors.

A thoroughgoing reorganization of the system of workmen's compensation in this State to eliminate existing abuses and irregularities was recommended by Justice Justine Wise Polier of the Domestic Relations Court yesterday when she appeared as witness in the Moreland act investigation of the operation of the law at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.
Small-home sales featured Brooklyn realty activity reported by brokers and buyers yesterday.

The competitive system, or at least the principle of competition, is the recipient of two warm tributes from rather unexpected sources, recorded in a single day's news. Vice President Wallace has written to the National Woman's party endorsing the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 27 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

Warning against over-optimism that holds that any Republican candidate can be elected President, Livingston Goddard, new president of the New York Young Republican Club, put forward last night what, in effect, was a suggestion for drafting Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for the nomination.
LONDON, Friday, Jan. 28 -Royal Air Force bombers attacked Berlin last night, it was announced in a brief communique issued this morning.

To accelerate the vital flow of war workers and materials between New York and New Jersey, the north tube of the Lincoln Tunnel, idle since that under-river link was opened to traffic six years ago, will be placed in service in July, it was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, disclosed yesterday that he and other executive officers of the company again had volunteered reductions in their incentive compensation, as they did early in 1943, placing it at levels far below the rates of 1942.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -Three principal advances scored by the Red Army in the Leningrad area cut great chunks from the rapidly shrinking bulge held by the Germans. In addition, the Vichy radio reported a new Russian offensive in the Ukraine.
Dr. Alfred Meyer, the oldest alumnus of Mount Sinai Hospital and the second oldest living graduate of Columbia University, observed his ninetieth birthday yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UP) -- A Pacific Headquarters announcement:

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- A substantial decline in estimated State expenditures for the coming fiscal year is expected to be shown in Governor Dewey's second annual budget. The document, which goes to the Legislature next Monday night, will be revealed to reporters and editors at the annual "Budget School" tomorrow afternoon, in confidence, as has been the custom for many years.

Seven thugs who have probably earned themselves a place on the Axis honor roll were arrested yestetrday for assault and robbery. The police say they mugged and robbed scores of United Nations seamen along the Brooklyn waterfront during the last several months.

A meat dealer who admitted he had violated price ceilings in giving special service to hotels in the way of trimming and boning their purchases was suspended from business for six months yesterday after a hearing at the Office of Price Administration in the Empire State Building.

Kings County Judge Franklin Taylor reserved decision yesterday on the applications of the lawyers for Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Louis Capone and Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss for a new murder trial on the ground of newly discovered evidence. Counsel for the men, who are now in the death house at Sing Sing Prison, unsuccessfully sought to have Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz pass upon the pleas for a new trial on Wednesday.
