The President presented strong arguments in his Wednesday message for an effective Federal service voting law. The matter simply can't be left wholly to the States with any assurance that the men and women of the Army, Navy and Merchant Marine will be able to vote for Federal officials next fall.

According to a London dispatch the British Admiralty has resolved "in principle" that Greenwich Observatory shall be moved. Something over two years ago it was damaged by German bombs. Aircraft fire isn't conducive to scientific observation. It is even said mysteriously that the street lights affect it unfavorably.
ATLANTA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. St. Elmo Massengale, mother of a soldier, disclosed tonight that she had received a letter signed by G.S. Patton Jr., commander of the Seventh Army, in which he said:

Because the shelter service of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children has proved unsatisfactory the city is working out its own plan for the care of delinquent and neglected children, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday. The Mayor declared that he expected to announce a specific plan next week.

The Treasury will receive a heavy volume of funds next week when large investors, corporate and individual, subscribe to the new Government bonds and certificates that are included in the Fourth War Loan drive. As these bonds and certificates do not bear interest until Feb. 1, few if any advance subscriptions have been made thus far in the loan drive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The House of Representatives heard a proposal today for the erection of a monument at the grave of Lieut. Col. William Edwin Dyess, shortly before his story of Japanese tortures inflicted on American and Filipino war prisoners was disclosed to the American public.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Stanley M. Bruce, Australian High Commissioner, speaking in the Guildhall today, predicted that the relationship between Britain and the dominions after the war would be reconsidered in the near future, possibly within a matter of months.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- American Liberator bombers, in the heaviest attack of the Southwest Pacific war against the Admiralty Islands, strategic Japanese shipping and supply center, on Wednesday rained 120 tons of explosives on enemy installations there, adding to destruction caused by raids the two previous days, it was announced today.

LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Yugoslav Partisans, skilled in the art of mountain warfare, have liberated 70 per cent of central Bosnia from the German invaders, headquarters of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) announced today.

Waiter Reade, who has owned the Mayfair Tower Theatre Building at 701-709 Seventh Avenue, northeast corner of Forty-seventh Street, for about fifteen years, has bought the land on which it stands from the Chase National Bank, Thalia W. Malcolm and Stephen C. Millett, trustees of the Robert E. Westcott estate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (U.P.) -- A recent visitor to General MacArthur's headquarters in the Southwest Pacific has sent a report on political sentiment there. The summary was passed through the general's own military censorship.

PALM BEACH, Jan. 27 -- Eighty-four Palm Beach residents have sent to Lieut. Gen. Somervell, Senator Claude Pepper and Represenative Pat Cannon a telegram expressing regret at the proposed abandonment of the Ream General Hospital and allowing it to revert to its pre-war status as the Breakers Hotel on March 31.

ALGIERS, Jan. 27 -- It was learned today that Rear Admiral Frank J. Lowry, USN, had received the following messages in connection with the work of the Allied naval units he commanded in the invasion below Rome on Saturday:
Two important changes in the rule for special offerings of shares and an amendment to the so-called "$5 rule" on margins were announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Replying to criticism leveled at the agency by shirt manufacturers and other textile interests, the War Production Board's cotton branch today defended its amendments to Order M-317 covering distribution of non-rated textiles.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Amid sobs Mrs. Walter W. Law told dramatically today that her husband confessed to her on the night of the crime that he killed Miss Rose Brancato, New Haven reporter, last July 5.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Friday, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Today's communique:

The post-war paint industry will usher in a more colorful commercial and industrial equipment world, with somber black and neutral tones giving way to brilliant colors, speakers at the post-war marketing conference of the New York Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association at the Hotel Biltmore, said yesterday.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Army Air Forces Training Command made public tonight statistics on the training which has produced manpower for "the world's greatest air force, now numbering in excess of 2,300,000 officers and enlisted men."

Rose Kramer, 44 years old, for twenty-five years a pickpocket, was spared a life term of imprisonment yesterday in General Sessions as a fourth offender. But, in accepting a guilty plea to petit larceny and sentencing her to a six-month workhouse term, Judge George L. Donnellan advised the woman to quit crime on her release, commenting that she has lost her one-time skill.

A letter in THE TIMES of Jan. 25 speaks of "the wisdom of our State Department's policy and that of the British Government toward Spain during the past three years," and continues, "Had Mr. Hull followed the advice of our armchair diplomats the whole course of the war in the Mediterranean would have been sadly different.''
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Two-thirds of the American Army representing a fighting force of 5,000,000 to 6,000,000 men will be overseas by Jan. 1, Secretary Stimson announced today.

Testimony taken in the Moreland act inquiry revealed that several thousand physicians have been splitting fees and bribing officials to get workmen's compensation cases. To this Dr. Leopold Brahdy of the Corporation Counsel's office now adds the charge that patients are also "over-treated."

Plans were nearing completion yesterday for the annual President's Birthday Party in the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow night, the eve of President Roosevelt's birthday. At the party, events of the years 1919 to 1944 will be recalled in songs, dances and commentary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The names of twenty-two countries, signatories of the declaration of the United Nations, have been assigned to Victory ship hulls under construction in three Pacific coast shipyards.

Two large New York liquor distributing firms have been cited to show cause why their permits should not be suspended or revoked for alleged violations of the Emergency Price Control Act, it was revealed here yesterday by William E. Dunigan, assistant superintendent of the Alcohol Tax Control Unit Enforcement of the Treasury Department.

Confused and worried by the WPB order directing nearly all production of neoprene thread into military channels, corset manufacturers will canvass the situation at a special meeting called for today by the Corset and Brassiere Association of America at its offices here.

OTTAWA, Jan. 27 -- In the Government program, read by the Governor General, the Earl of Athlone, at the opening of the new session of Parliament today, the intention of the administration to commit Canada during the present session to a wide policy of international cooperation as the best means of insuring peace, was disclosed.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 27 (U.P.) -- Mitchell medium bombers of the Fourteenth United States Air Force sank two Japanese freighters and a minesweeper off eastern China Tuesday, raising to nine the number of enemy ships destroyed in Chinese coastal waters in two days, a communique from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, made public today a letter in which he defined the opposition of organized labor to the equal rights amendment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (U.P.) -- Chairman Sol Bloom of the Foreign Affairs Committee told the House today that the British Government had agreed to suspend enforcement of the White Paper until 30,000 Jews seeking entry into Palestine were so accommodated, "even if it does not occur until March of 1945."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The grave debate in the Senate on the armed services' voting bill and indications of what will be said in the House suggest the possibility that the 1944 elections will be attended with most serious complications, costly to the conduct of the war.

ABOARD A BRITISH WARSHIP, Jan. 26 (Delayed) -- The Fifth Army forces who have established themselves firmly on the Anzio-Nettuno beachhead south of Rome are now in position to take the initiative, Gen. Sir Harold R. L. G. Alexander told this correspond...

WASHINGTON, Jam 27 -- A vast public work program, much of which will be started within thirty days after victory, has been formulated and is being kept up to date. Secretary Ickes stated today in his annual report to President Roosevelt.

"The Return of the Vampire," a melodrama produced by Columbia, will open this morning at the Rialto. Heading the cast of the film, which was directed by Lew Landers, are Bela Lugosi, Frieda Inescort, Nina Foch, Miles Mander, Roland Varno and Matt Willis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Point values for all twelve of the major canned vegetables are reduced two to four points, and in some cases more, in a new schedule for rationed foods, effective Sunday and expiring March 4, which the Office of Price Administration announced today.

With sales of E bonds setting the pace, as a single day's total purchases in that category mounted to $4,600,600, New York City's total sales of war bonds to individuals have risen to $146,168,400 in the Fourth War Loan, Nevil Ford, executive manager of the War Finance Committee for New York, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, and Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, went before the Senate subcommittee inquiring into the economic plight of white-collar workers today and said the problem of such workers' pay was a real one, calling for increases within the stabilization program and demanding continuation of the food-subsidy program.
Has anyone else, I wonder, given thought as to what is being done with the millions of dollars the Government has collected from premiums on war-damage insurance?
MONTREAL, Jan 27 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs and Canadiens fought to a 2-2 tie tonight in a heavy-bumping National Hockey League game before more than 12,000 fans.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 27 -- Two Parisian masons have been arrested near Meaux outside of the French capital for "achieving the impossible" in robbing the vaults of the French National Bank in Paris of 25,000,000 francs in thousand-franc banknotes, according to an official statement issued tonight.

Because of the indisposition of Artur Rodzinski last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall was conducted by Wilhelm Steinberg, who had never directed before during the organization's regular winter season.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Creation of a youth correction authority of three members appointed by the Governor to work out means of halting juvenile delinquency and develop a program to rehabilitate offenders is asked in a bill offered in the Legislature today.
William T. Dewart, president and a principal owner of The Sun, long a leader in the newspaper publishing business, died at 8:30 o'clock last night at his home at 660 Park Avenue. He was 68 years old.
LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The statement of condition of the bank of England for the week ended yesterday, issued today, showed a decrease of 128,000 in note circulation.

The Republic of Venezuela has enjoyed important social and economic development and is on the way to greater progress but in this undertaking it needs the cooperation of the United States -- its organizing ability and its capital -- Gen. Isaias Medina Angarita, President of Venezuela, declared yesterday in a speech read for him by Don Eugenio Mendoza, former Venezuelan Minister of National Development.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The value of manufacturers' shipments destined for war use last year was $90,000,000,000, which was slightly more than three-fifths of the total deliveries of $147,000,000,000, the Department of Commerce announced today. The value of goods delivered to the civil economy -- even though only two-fifths of the whole -- was equal to that of 1939 and only 25 per cent less than the record deliveries for that purpose in 1941.
PORTSMOUTH, N. H., July 27 -- A record was set this afternoon at the Portsmouth Navy Yard when the Razorback, Redfish, Ronquil and Scabbardfish went into the water in the first quadruple launching.

The president of Swarthmore College, in his annual report, tells of forty-nine Chinese naval officers who have been assigned to the college for the current term. Early in the fall the college was asked to receive them as soon as they arrived in this country. The men appeared on the campus on Oct. 28 and began classes on Nov. 1.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 27 -- The sixth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship will be held the night of Tuesday, Mar. 28, in New York's Madison Square Garden, H.G. Olsen announced today.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The Norwegian Government in London is awaiting word from Berlin that "peace" has been signed between Norway and Germany, it was learned here today. It is a development in the tightening-up process being carried out by Nazi Puppet Premier Vidkun Quisling on Adolf Hitler's orders handed to him personally.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations lined up solidly tonight in a new expression of opposition to national service legislation. A resolution opposing the Austin-Wadsworth bill and reaffirming the action of the national CIO convention opposing any national service act was adopted unanimously at a meeting of the executive board.

Picked Japanese forces, who boasted that it would take a million Americans 100 years to remove them from Tarawa, were completely terror-stricken and demoralized by the will of American marines, who refused to waver in the face of withering machine gun and canon fire, Lieut.

Nugent Fallon, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria that net income for 1943 was $483,715. Of this amount, $250,851 was paid in dividends, the United States Government receiving $189,632.
William A. Pludo, sales manager of Adam Hat Stores, Inc., has been named vice president in charge of sales promotion and public relations.

Details of the superbomber B-29, which is being made ready for action, are not yet public. Enough, however, has been revealed, particularly in the British press, to show clearly that the plane was designed for action from bases deep inside the present Japanese sphere of conquest.

A situation that defies explanation will confront the boxing fan tonight. Sammy Angott of Washington, Pa., recognized by the National Boxing Association as the lightweight champion of the world, will meet Sidney Walker, better known as Beau Jack, a native of Augusta. Ga., who is regarded as the lightweight champion of the world by the New York State Athletic Commission, at Madison Square Garden.

Mill buying and trade price fixing combined with less aggressive hedging operations yesterday produced an improved tone in the cotton futures market. At the close of trading, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were around the best levels of the day and 8 to 11 points, or 40 to 55 cents a bale, over Wednesday's final.

Charles H. Greenhaus, once known as the "boy wizard of Wall Street," pleaded not guilty along with seven other men in General Sessions yesterday, to charges of conspiracy through which business men and corporations were said to have been defrauded of more than $250,000 for "advertising" in a bogus labor union paper.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The 1,700,000 deferred farm workers, especially the young bachelors, were advised by a draft official today that they might be called for military duty unless they produced substantial shares of the nation's food supply.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Sixty women leaders of Pleasantville and vicinity -- most of them wives and mothers of men in the armed services -- began a campaign a fortnight ago against "treasonable" strikes that hinder armament production.

Five buildings in the Carl Schurz Park section of Yorkville will be displaced by a modern apartment house after the war, it was disclosed yesterday, when it was announced that a builder had added the four-story house at 518 East Eighty-fifth Street to recent purchases there.
Slowly and without benefit of much publicity the solid ground-work for a future Southeast Asian campaign is being laid.

Although most vegetables are plentiful and reasonable in cost at present, a few Southern varieties that were damaged by frost are noticeably scarce and sell at ceiling. Among them are green lima beans, shipments of which have been nonexistent for the last two weeks and probably will be spasmodic at best until mid-February.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has announced plans for making a Technicolor version of "Uncle Tom's Cabin" this summer. The picture will be produced by Arthur Hornblow Jr. and will take the place on his schedule of "Quo Vadis," which has been postponed because of casting difficulties.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor told its six million members today that the war crisis meant that no strikes or stoppages of work could be justified at the present time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 -- Commander Gene Tunney, back from a six-month visit to the Pacific battle areas, reported today that he found the best morale "up at the front, where the boys are being bombed every night and are slugging it out with the Japs."

The Women's Trade Union League yesterday attacked Vice President Henry A. Wallace's declaration in favor of the proposed equal rights amendment, made Wednesday in a letter to Mrs. Emma Guffey, Miller, joint Congressional chairman of the National Woman's party.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The difficulty of arranging leave for players in the Canadian and American armed forces necessitated the cancellation yesterday of the All-Star hockey game scheduled for Madison Square Garden tomorrow afternoon. The event was to have been part of the Fourth War Loan Drive.

Retail trade here continued active this week. Department store volume was estimated as averaging about 8 per cent ahead of the like week of 1943. Most soft goods departments made a good showing, with expanding interest noted in early Spring apparel and accessories.

The stock market returned yesterday to the higher side, although the recovery was limited and selective, with the best gains in individual issues and not in group classifications. Buying power did not develop readily, and the rally carried on more from lack of pressure than outright enthusiasm, as was evident from the session which was one of restricted volume, being the third smallest so far this year.

Returning members of the armed forces should not be subject to the Federal Reserve System's Regulation W, restricting personal credit, according to the Retail Credit Institute of America, Inc., which has petitioned the board of governors of the system to waive application of the regulation to veterans to enable them to re-establish themselves and their homes promptly.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The British people were profoundly shocked today by disclosures of Japanese cruelty to civilian and military prisoners made in Parliament by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, who explained that the Government felt duty bound to make public the facts of "this unspeakable savagery."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Economic and political relations between Spain and the United States are being reconsidered because of the recent course of Spanish policies, and meanwhile further shipment of oil from the Caribbean is being denied to Spain, the State Department announced tonight.

MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- The splitting of the armies of Field Marshal Gen. George von Kuechler and Col. Gen. Lindemann by the Russian sweep across the Narva-Tosno railway is now being followed up by a converging movement of the combined forces of Generals Govoroff and Meretskoff from three sides on the blunt-headed salient that the Germans still hold between the Volkhov River and the Gulf of Finland.

Refusing point-blank to be outdone by basketball, which on Wednesday had added $1,676,750 to the Fourth War Loan Drive through the medium of its double-header in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, tennis last night topped that figure handsomely.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The British Government has joined the United States in shutting off supplies of fuel oil, gasoline and other petroleum products to Spain, it was learned authoritatively tonight.

Justice Harold J. Crawford of Queens Municipal Court took the extraordinary precaution yesterday of obtaining a special oath from each member of a six-person jury to insure the full protection of the legal rights of an alien Japanese plaintiff appearing in his court.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 28 -- Mrs. Rita Ferris Killian, widow of Capt. Francis M. Killian, received by mail today the Distinguished Flying Cross posthumously awarded to her husband. The decoration was sent by mail at Mrs. Killian's request, as she wished to dispense with the customary ceremonies.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Saturday, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- A communique:

With the Tammany executive committee called to meet tonight at 7 o'clock at Democratic county headquarters at 331 Madison Avenue, success of the movement to oust Michael J. Kennedy as leader and elect a successor seemed last night to be in some doubt, with the latter part of the program of the anti-Kennedy group the more doubtful.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Fourteen high school students from New York and three from New Jersey are among forty finalists, twenty-eight boys and twelve girls, named today by Watson Davis, director of Science Clubs of America, as having been chosen from 15,000 entrants in the annual Nation-wide Talent Search.
The Allied Kid Company declared yesterday a cash dividend of 25 cents and a stock dividend of one share for every ten shares outstanding of record Feb. 8, both for payment on Feb. 15.

ALGIERS, Jan. 28 -- Allied penetration around the Anzio-Nettuno beachhead below Rome has reached at least six miles along the entire length and spearheads are known to have pierced at least twice that far, while above the beachhead and far and wide in the Italian war theatre Allied airmen kept up a devastating offensive.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 -- President Green of the American Federation of Labor said today that the Executive Council had authorized him to send a fraternal message to the workers of Latin America and an offer to cooperate with "the free and independent unions" there "in developing a concrete program for the future."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Senator Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, is seeking to force President Roosevelt's hand on a fourth-term decision by legislation requiring that the names of Presidential candidates be printed on the ballots which must be mailed early to let service men vote.

New issues of municipal bonds up for award next week amount to $10,904,303, compared with this week's revised total of $12,489,803, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average for 1944, thus far, stands at $25,531, 304.

DETROIT, Jan. 28 -- Jake LaMotta of New York encountered surprising difficulty tonight before outpointing Ossie (Bulldog) Harris of Pittsburgh in a ten-round bout at Olympia Stadium. LaMotta weighed 158 1/2, half a pound more than Harris.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 28 -- Last night's RAF bombing of Berlin was very concentrated and the number of victims was probably higher than in most of the previous major attacks, because so many shelters had been destroyed, according to passengers arriving by this afternoon's plane from the Reich capital.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 28 (UP) -- An Allied Southeast Asia Command communique:...
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 28 -- French Protestantism has suffered great loss by the death within two weeks of Freddy Duerrlemann, aged 62, and his son, Valdo, aged 32, both pastors.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Hundreds of Lancasters of the Royal Air Force's Bomber Command made an exceptionally destructive mass attack on Berlin last night, dropping more than 1,680 tons of bombs in twenty minutes and starting vast fires in industrial sections of the city that were visible for 200 miles.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 -- Vivian Blaine, a former New York night-club singer who recently completed a role in "Greenwich Village" for Twentieth Century-Fox, will have the Ethel Merman part in that company's screen version of "Something for the Boys." June Havoc will replace Miss Blaine in the feminine singing lead in the studio's forthcoming "When Irish Eyes Are Smiling."
LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's statement on Japanese treatment of prisoners, made in the Commons today, follows:

The Salvation Army has received $198,472 toward its goal of $550,000 for its wartime activities and welfare needs, according to reports of committee chairmen yesterday at a meeting in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.
Yesterday's Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A protest against the rise from 20 to 25 per cent in the proposed excise tax on cosmetics was telegraphed yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association to Senator George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 28 -- The Argentine military Government of President Pedro Ramirez was split wide open tonight as a result of the country's severance of diplomatic relations with the Axis.

Renewed trade and mill buying raised cotton prices yesterday and carried the March position to a new seasonal high. In the late trading, however, a part of the early gains was lost and final quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances for the session of only 3 to 5 points, or 15 to 25 cents a bale.

The two claimants of the world lightweight title clashed in the ring at Madison Square Garden last night before a gathering of 19,113 fans who paid gate receipts of $84,870, and, at the conclusion of ten ordinary rounds, the boxers were exactly where they started -- all even.
ALGIERS, Jan. 28 -- A communique:

LONDON, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisan forces in a series of lightning blows along a 180-mile front have cut the main Zagreb-Belgrade railway line in six places, a communique broadcast by the Free Yugoslav radio reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- During the session of the Senate Education and Labor subcommittee today on the problem of "white collar" workers, two witnesses outlined the situation from the Government viewpoint.

The main ballroom of the Pierre was the setting last night for the twenty-eighth annual dinner dance in aid of the Blue Ridge School of Bris, Va., formerly known as the Blue Ridge Industrial School. The institution for more than thirty years has received the support of prominent persons here who have been interested in its training of underprivileged boys and girls.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 28 -- In addition to the 500,000,000 francs a day that the Germans take from France for costs of occupation, the Nazis are now getting the 1,000,000,000 francs monthly that France paid to Italy before the Italian surrender to the Allies, according to information here today.

The growing number of letters to the newspapers, advocating a negotiated peace with Germany, makes me wonder whether there isn't an organized "let's-not-be-too-hard-on-Germany" campaign afoot. Even if these letters are spontaneous expressions of individual opinion, their writers are advocating a policy that would probably engulf us in another war within twenty-five or thirty years.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation, formerly the Consolidated Oil Corporation, announced yesterday that it would-redeem on Feb. 23 all of its 3 3/8 per cent sinking fund debentures outstanding. This issue, sold privately on Aug. 1, 1938, was oustanding originally in the amount of $25,000,000 and due on Aug. 1, 1950.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Jan. 28 -- Everyone in the Pacific war zones, including the enemy, knows that there is to be another series of blows at all points on the weakened Japanese outer Pacific defense perimeter.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Treasury appealed to wage-earners today to begin filling out their income-tax returns as soon as they receive wage and tax receipts from their employers.

Consolidated net profit of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation and its subsidaries for 1943, according to the report to be released today, was $9,512,228 after all charges, including depreciation, depletion, interest, $2,000,000 provision for contingencies and $19, 650,000 estimated Federal income and excess profits taxes.

Responsive to the ruling of the Tax Court, bonds of the Port of New York Authority, which are traded over-the-counter, were firm yesterday, closing unchanged to up fractions of a point. Triborough Bridge 3 1/4s, due 1980, closed at 102 5/8 bid, 103 3/8 asked, up 1 1/8 points.
The State Athletic Commission yesterday set a definite time for the development of an undisputed world lightweight champion. The date is not later than May 26.

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 442-48 East Fifty-seventh Street, adjoining Sutton Place, has been sold by the 444 East Fifty-seventh Street Corporation to a syndicate headed by Milton Spitz. Formerly a cooperative, the house occupies a plot 72 by 127 feet.
Mme. Ivy Litvinoff, who recently arrived in Moscow from the United States, is now at work on her autobiography, which Coward-McCann plan to publish soon.

New life insurance written by thirty-nine United States companies having 81 per cent of all life insurance outstanding amounted to $9,019,011,000 for 1943, or 9.2 per cent above $8,261,848,000 new paid for business in 1942, according to a report by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Department of Commerce.

Air-conditioning plants equipped to provide year-round controlled temperatures in virtually every home in the nation will function almost immediately after the war, Louis Ruthenberg, president of Servel, Inc., said last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Reports that the temporary ceiling price on cash oats would be continued fox an indefinite period, eliminating fears of a rollback of 5 cents bushel or more in the market, brought today general buying of all grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade. Oats led the advance, moving UP 1 3/4 cents, and other grains were up around 1 cent before profit-taking checked the upturn.

" Kings of the Ring," the feature-length film compilation of scenes from famous prize fights of the last three decades, today starts its second week at the World Theatre. Although no figures were announced, the picture has broken all box-office records for the house, including those set by such foreign films as "Harvest," "The Baker's Wife" and "Pepe Le Moko," according to the management.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- State Controller Frank C. Moore today denied the application of the city of Port Jervis to refund $50,000 of bonds due this year. The city on Dec. 31, 1943, had a total bonded debt of $1,158,000, of which $470,000 was self-supporting water debt; $60,000, public improvement debt; $226,000, home relief debt, and $402,000, refunding debt.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces in northern Burma have cleared the Japanese from the area north of Ahawk Hka, eight miles northeast of the Chindwin River ferry station of Taro, inflicting heavy casualties and capturing much equipment, a Southeast Asia Command communique said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A group of younger members of Congress intend to ask President Roosevelt personally next week to let them enter the armed forces and at the same time retain their legislative seats.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. William E. Dyess, who escaped a Japanese prison camp in the Philippines and returned to report on atrocities he had witnessed there, told his wife of his experiences before he was killed in a plane crash at Burbank, Calif., last month, she said in an interview today.

Once Japan had a code of chivalry called Bushido. Many Occidental observers praised it. Perhaps they were mistaken, perhaps not. The military rulers of today's Japan claim to have inherited it. What they have inherited or invented, as the case may be, is a code of foul dishonor.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 28 -- The Army is continuing its unceasing hammering of enemy defenses in the Marshall Islands and has again raided Wotje, Mili and Maloelap atolls, bombing airfields and installations, with "light" losses to our formations.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 29 -- Russia's northern armies, squeezing the Germans inside a 165-mile horseshoe-shaped front, yesterday cut the next to the last enemy escape railroad south of Leningrad, advanced to within twenty-eight miles of the Estonian border and regained all but a small stretch of the Moscow-Leningrad main line.

This is the time of year when the first hours of warm sunshine or a whiff of dampness from an early thaw give the cue for spring prints. Their gay colors peek out brightly from under furs or at the openings of winter coats. And they're distinctly practical, since they can be worn right along from now to September.

Mayor La Guardia cited a critical shortage of coal in Staten Island yesterday when he appealed to Secretary Harold L. Ickes, head of the Solid Fuels Administration for War, to transfer that borough from the New Jersey to the New York Regional SFA jurisdiction.

OTTAWA, Jan. 28 -- Adding to the reports officially issued by the Office of War Information in Washington and the statements in the British House of Commons regarding Japanese brutality and organized sadism toward prisoners, Prime Minister William L. Mackenzie King told Parliament today that the Japanese had ignored or made hypocritical or cynical replies to all protests addressed through the protecting power, Switzerland.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Shocked and enraged over the official accounts of Japanese atrocities against American prisoners, the national capital was full of a spirit of revenge today which brought calls from Congress for acceleration of the war against Japan.

Records were piled up for Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday when an army of parents and friends gathered in its School of Nursing, 5 East Ninety-sixth Street, to watch a traditional "capping" ceremony. Not only did the ninety-six girls receiving their student nurses' caps represent the largest class in the sixty-three-year history of the school but the class's average percentage of 87.4 per cent surpassed any previous record.

A lad in uniform squints at a street sign, glances at a penciled note in his hand, and seems puzzled. Two passing New Yorkers turn to offer to help him find his way, but three other New Yorkers have reached him first. New York has a warm heart for the thousands of service men and women who nowadays throng the town.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Voicing new demands for food subsidies, spokesmen for "white collar'' workers told Congressional investigators today that "creeping price increases" are endangering "the health, stamina and morale" of millions.

Seymour E. Harris, in a letter published Jan. 20, defends the Administration's present and pending food subsidy program, He makes the significant point that payments now in force "involve the Government in outlays at an annual rate of $1,110 million, but since the Government spends $267 million for the purchase of food, its net disbursements are only $837 million."

To Mr. Dewart, for more than twenty years publisher of The Sun, the whole commonwealth of decent newspapers owes a lasting gratitude. Frank Munsey, owner of The Sun, directed in his will that it be sold. There was a just apprehension that it might fall into hands that would change its character and disrupt its long continuity of distinction.

Net assets of the Adams Express Company at the end of 1943 were $23,274,055, or $15.90 a common share, against $16.52 on Sept. 30, last, and $11.69 on Dec. 31, 1942. On Jan. 27, 1943, net assets were $15.94.

David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, told the 215 graduates of New York University's College of Engineering yesterday that their primary task was the bring the gifts of scientific research and discoveries to the world of peace that would emerge from the world into which they were graduating.

The Supreme Court has decided that a railroad had no right to obtain an injunction to restrain strikers from interfering by violence or threats of violence with its property and interstate operations because it had refused to make "every reasonable effort" to settle the dispute with its employes.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Japanese planes destroyed or damaged at Rabaul during a sustained air offensive there this month were raised to 390 by the downing of between twenty-two and thirty out of sixty enemy interceptors during a raid Wednesday by more than 100 Allied bombers and fighters.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Jan. 28 -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark has issued strict instructions to his Fifth Army in its advance on Rome, which instructions have been issued in duplicate to the Allied air forces, that all attacks on papal or church property should be carefully avoided unless absolutely dictated by military necessity.

Two American Merchant Marine officers employed by the United Fruit Company received yesterday morning the company's silver medal for meritorious service at sea beyond the call of duty. H. Harris Robson, vice president, made the presentation in his office at Pier 3, North River. The men honored were Chief Officer Edward Hutchinson and Capt. Earl M.Swan.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Contributions to the joint war organization of the British Red Cross and the St. John's Ambulance Corps have reached a total of 30,730,246, the Duke of Gloucester announced today at the annual meeting. The record month was January when 1,456,000 was subscribed, and the average since June, 1943, has been more than 1,000,000 a month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Japanese responsible for torture and mistreatment of war prisoners, under an interpretation of international law by Maj. Willard B. Cowles of the Judge Advocate General's division, are liable to whatever punishment an American military commission may find proper.

New financing virtually was at a standstill here this week while investment bankers were selling bonds in the Fourth War Loan Drive. Numerous awards of fair-sized issues of tax-exempt securities were made to bidders in the week, but only two issues, totaling $6,902,000, were offered for public subscription.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- Dr. Forrest C. Allen, speaking for the "conservative, decent elements in intercollegiate athletics," charged tonight that proselyting had become so flagrant by some schools that a "high commissioner like K.M. Landis in baseball was needed immediately to stop it."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- It has been June in January at the headquarters of the General Federation of Women's Clubs this week. Fifty bridal costumes, some complete even to the "something old, something new, something borrowed, something blue," were sent to London for brides in the British Women's Armed Services.

The Eleto Building Corporation, a subsidiary of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, has sold the ten-story service building warehouse at 331 East Thirty-eighth Street, occupying the First Avenue block front between Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth Streets.

An indictment was handed up by a Federal grand jury yesterday in the liquor black market case which was first alleged Dec. 21, 1943, when seven men were arrested by Treasury Department agents as the result of a tip from a wine steward of the Hotel Astor.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

The Old Guard of the City of New York, one of the most venerable patriotic organizations in the country, gave a reception and dance last night in the East Ballroom of the Hotel Commodore to continue its series of annual celebrations which have been held for more than a century.
During 1943 there were 7,322 realty transfers in the Bronx, or 9 per cent more than in the previous year. Prices averaged 92 per cent of assessed valuations, against 95 per cent in 1942.

In something over twelve hours the Mars completes its return trip from Honolulu to San Francisco. It is the new Navy flying transport and the largest operating airplane in the world. Bigger and faster planes are being planned and built. Can anyone seriously deny that the future belongs to aviation? No one can deny it, except with a proviso.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The belief grew here today that President Roosevelt would take early steps to settle the difficulties in the Office of War Information by trying to induce Byron Price, Director of Censorship, to head a set-up combining his present work and the public information units of the OWI.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Spies in this country will risk their lives to gain and send vital information about the coming invasion of Europe by the Allies, and thus the American people must exercise unusual vigilance, Byron Price, Director of Censorship, warned in a radio speech tonight.
ALGIERS, Jan. 28 -- The Mediterranean Allied Air Forces on their first day of operation under that name scored their biggest air victory since the wind-up of the Tunisian campaign.

Boogie-woogie, you can take it from a group of 'teen agers who wrestled last night with the problem of juvenile delinquency on the stage of the New York Times Hall is more a deterrent than a contributing factor to the missteps of youth.

In spite of our welfare and public health agencies preventive medicine still lags. To be sure, the subject is taught, but not in the light of new needs. Those who study it naturally gravitate into administrative positions or become official doctors who carry out special duties. The great mass of the people is reached only by controlling infectious diseases and by the enforcement of sanitary measures.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Cash requirements of the Pennsylvania Railroad for 1944, hitherto unpublished, have been revealed by the road in answer to a request for information by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The statement showed gross working capital of $101,474,812 at the end of 1943, net free working cash of $41,445,113 and total cash resources of $167, 773,129 when special tax and contingency reserves are added.
The two-story structure containing apartments and stores at 1749 Crosby Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold to Israel B. Diamond through Realty Management, Inc., broker.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, was named one of five defendants in a $500,000 damage suit filed in Supreme Court yesterday. Other defendants are Lafayette Dramatic Productions, Inc.; John S. Ferentz, president of the Detroit Federation of Musicians, Local 5, American Federation of Musicians; Jacob Rosenberg, president of the Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802, A.F.M., and the United Booking Offices, Inc.

Immediate appointment of 769 teachers and supervisors in the New York City school system has been recommended by the Board of Superintendents, it was learned yesterday. Of this number 502 are in the elementary grades and 166 in the junior high school division.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- House supporters of the Worley bill for a Federal ballot for service men declared today that they had obtained enough pledges to assure a record vote next week on the question of amending the rule which, they contend, would prevent that measure from undergoing the "stand-up-and-be-counted" test which President Roosevelt asked for in his message to Congress Wednesday.

The decision yesterday by the Tax Court of the United States that the interest on bonds of the Port of New York Authority and of the Triborough Bridge Authority is not taxable was gratifying not only to the managements of the two Authorities concerned, but also to the municipal bond fraternity generally.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A story of how some 150 leading British concerns pool ideas on making life more livable for workers was told here today by Mrs. Ethel M. Wood, secretary of England's Management Research Groups.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Shortages of glass and pottery giftware likely will become more stringent as a result of manpower problems, according to distributors who were preparing today for the opening of the two-week China, Glass, Pottery Market and Gift Show at the Merchandise Mart here.

The first anniversary of the nurse recruiting service of the New York chapter of the American Red Cross which occurs on Wednesday will coincide with the beginning of an intensified program to raise a new quota of Army and Navy nurses by July 1, Miss Eleanor Lee, director of the New York nurse recruitment, announced yesterday.

MAYWOOD, Ill., Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- A long line was waiting when the War Bond sales office opened today in this suburban community, twelve miles west of Chicago, where hundreds of residents are the mothers, fathers, sisters and sons of men captured by the Japanese on Bataan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- House conferees on the revenue bill accepted today the Senate's proposal to continue social security taxes for old age and survivors benefits at 1 per cent for 1944. An increase of 1 per cent is scheduled in existing law.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Further indications were given today that the State administration intends to end the investigation of labor union racketeering on New York City's Delaware River water project, which has been going on in Orange County since 1942.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A demand that the United Nations "bomb Japan out of existence" and hang the Mikado in retaliation for atrocities committed on American and Filipino prisoners of war was voiced today by Senator Clark of Missouri.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Jan. 28 -- An example of the unfortunate type of red tape that sometimes manifests itself in otherwise excellent conditions has developed on the Fifth Army front where a number of able and brave pilots, doing exceptionally useful work, have been refused flying pay even after the personal intervention of Gen. Henry H. Arnold.

Developments in racing yesterday made it appear probable that John Shevlin, secretary of the New York State Racing Commission for the past several years, would become general manager of Aqueduct and Jamaica before the start of a new season in the State. Asked about reports published to this effect, Shevlin referred questioners to officials of the tracks.
Mayor La Guardia has improvised on many a diversified subject -- without benefit of manuscript -- at moment's notice. But yesterday afternoon found him speechless -- overcome, in fact, with emotion.

John J. O'Connor, president of the Greater New York Federation of Sportsmen's Clubs, the new outfit that originated in the Bronx, read in this space how the hunters and fishermen had been overlooked in the sports program of the Fourth War Loan Drive and decided to do something about it. Good for Mr. O'Connor!

I was shocked to read of Charles P. Taft's attack recently on our very efficient Health Department relative to the management of the venereal disease problem. I do not knew from what sources Mr. Taft derives his information but there can be no doubt that he has been very seriously misinformed.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Fifteen prominent educators, editors and business leaders were elected members of the board of directors of Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Inc., here today. The educational film company, formerly known as Erpi Classroom Films, recently was purchased by Encyclopaedia Britannica.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 28 -- The choice the voters will make in the next Presidential election will be a choice "between the Republic and dictatorship," Representative John Jennings of Tennessee declared tonight before the Nassau County Republican Committee convention called to designate delegates and alternates to the Republican National Convention and State committee members.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Cutbacks of 25 per cent for large and 35 per cent for small steam locomotives on order for the military for 1944 were announced today by the War Production Board. Altered military requirements, it was said, will reduce by 741 the number of steam locomotives of eighty tons or more and by 162 the number weighing fifty to eighty tons.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The war-conscious West Coast, home of well over 100,000 persons of Japanese ancestry prior to Pearl Harbor, found words tonight a poor palliative for stories of Japanese atrocities and many were the vows of vengeance.

Executives of business and trade organizations, including insurance companies, joined with members of the medical and legal professions yesterday in recommending greater efficiency in the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Law and in denouncing prevailing practices, at a session of the Moreland Act inquiry in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

Chief Justice John A. Byrnes of the City Court, appearing yesterday at a hearing before Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson, asked for a 1944-45 budget appropriation $81,874 greater than the 1943-44 allotment. Most of the increase, he explained, was to cover cost-of-living pay rises for 205 employes of the court and twenty-one secretaries to its judges.

A complete advertising kit for gas appliance dealers has been prepared by the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers for insertion in newspapers, general magazines and trade publications on behalf of the Certified Performance gas range program.

Kings County Judge Franklin Taylor denied yesterday motions for a new murder trial for Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss and Louis Capone, who are now in the death house at Sing Sing prison for killing Joseph Rosen, a Brooklyn candy store owner, in 1936. It is expected the defense attorneys will seek a review of the decision from the Court of Appeals.

Details of an omnibus war contract termination bill to be introduced shortly in the Senate to provide machinery for reconversion of thousands of war-material producers to peacetime operations, were disclosed yesterday by Senator James E. Murray, Democrat, Montana, chairman of the subcommittee of contract termination of the Senate Committee on Military Affairs.
WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY in Italy, Jan. 25 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- This little story is just a month late, for it should have appeared on Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Aircraft plants, operating at the greatest efficiency since the war started, have built more planes in January than in any month in history, officials of the War Production Board said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States issued today an analysis of the problems of little business in which it warned against Federal action which would discriminate in favor of any class of enterprise.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Two major moves of the War Production Board which became known today suggest that the United States is planning to taper off on its stockpiling of critical raw materials.

Every veteran of earlier wars can cite some example of "soldier's luck." But three hairbreadth escapes reported in a single issue of this newspaper seem so engagingly improbable that most fiction editors would have rejected them. Nevertheless, the fact remains that three top-ranking British generals, an American flier and an American newspaper man have all managed to walk straight through the enemy's vaunted steel wall.

War bond sales to individuals rose sharply yesterday, largely as a result of disclosures by the War and Navy Departments of Japanese atrocities against American troops taken prisoner with the fall of Bataan and Corregidor, the War Finance Committee for New York State reported last night.

The Appellate Division by a vote of 3 to 2 yesterday directed the Board of Estimate as head of the New York City Employes Retirement System to approve the petition of Philip A. Hines, former first deputy city clerk in charge of the Marriage Licence Bureau for a retirement allowance.

The Rev. John D. Bodger, sub-dean of the Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul, Papua, New Guinea, will preach tomorrow at 11 A.M. in Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway, at the head of Wall Street. He is diocesan chaplain to the Right Rev. Philip N.W. Strong, Anglican Bishop of New Guinea.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Despite the news that Catchers Ken O'Dea and Jerry Burmeister had been reclassified in 1-A for military service, President Sam Breadon of the Cardinals reversed himself today and asked to be restored to good standing as an optimist over prospects for the 1944 baseball season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Tax Court of the United States refused today to support the treasury's contention that interest from bonds of such public enterprises as the Port of New York Authority and the Triborough Bridge Authority of New York should be taxable.

IF you are the kind of drinker I am, one who can't tolerate the smell or the taste of alcohol on the morning after or even on the second and third mornings after, you will probably be both fascinated and flabbergasted by Charles Jackson's "The Lost Weekend."* For this is a novel about that most mysterious of creatures, the chronic alcoholic.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The week's last day of business saw little activity on the stock markets here, but the tone was cheerful. The strongest feature was the gilt-edge section. Most stocks there rose farther and the 3 1/2 per cent War Loan showed a small increase.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 28 -- That the Germans will drop Pierre Laval in two weeks was the prediction of an informed traveler who arrived here from France today. Although Marcel Deat is the man generally considered most likely to succeed Laval, this informant said he thought there would be no successor and that instead the Germans would make an attempt to govern France through some sort of Gauleiter or Reichcommissar, perhaps Dr. Cecil von Rente-Finck.

The return engagement of the George Gershwin-DuBose Hayward operetta, "Porgy and Bess," at the New York City Center, has been advanced from Feb. 28 to Monday evening, Feb. 7, it was announced yesterday. The musical attraction will be seen at the civic playhouse for a fortnight, instead of six weeks as originally planned. With the exception of William Franklin, Who will interpret the role of Porgy, the cast will remain the same.

Obviously overwhelmed by his disgrace, Dr. Aloysius M. Mulholland, 52 years old, bowed his head in General Sessions as Judge John A. Mullen sentenced him yesterday to three Sing Sing terms of two to four years each, to run concurrently.

Let this morning's news from Broadway be all to the good for a change. Bobby Clark is back. With cigar, painted glasses, wistful air and the murderous roll of rrrrrrr, he arrived in town last evening at the Winter Garden in Mike Todd's "Mexican Hayride."

For the second time in less than a year, Mrs. Lucille Malin, 36 years old, the widow of Gene Malin, the Hollywood female impersonator, was sentenced to six months in the workhouse yesterday for operating a "call-house" for prostitution in her West Fifty-fourth Street apartment.

BOSTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Freed from possible embarrassment by the unsolicited resignation of the droll Charles Dillon (Casey) Stengel as their manager, the serious-minded directors of the recently reorganized Boston Braves' baseball club today were deliberating about his successor.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Fourteen are named for the Bahamas Handicap at Hialeah Park tomorrow, including most of the 3-year-olds rated Flamingo Stakes timber. The Flamingo, in turn, is considered Florida's prep for the Kentucky Derby.

An article written by Palmer Hoyt, former director of the Domestic Activities Branch of the Office of War Information, for publication in next week's issue of the American Magazine charges that the Japanese have "brutally murdered" most of the 50,000 American and Filipino prisoners-of-war taken on Bataan.

Something more than echoes of the "Golden Age of Sports" will be heard over WOR, WHN, WINS and 171 Mutual network outlets tonight in a Fourth War Loan radio show broadcast from the Mutual Playhouse, Fifty-second Street and Broadway.

ALGIERS, Jan. 28 -- The French colonial conference which opens at Brazzaville on Sunday will proceed on the basis of the long agenda drafted by Rene Pleven, Comissioner for Colonies of the French National Liberation Committee, which envisages the development of an equatorial empire in Africa by increasing the representation of natives in the administration and the Advisory Councils and the broadening of education to fit the native for added responsibility.

Next week's menus relate the story of a smoked beef tongue, one of the most economical meats because of the absence of bone and other waste. This particular tongue, to be consumed by the hypothetical family of two adults and a school-age child for whom these meals are planned, weighs three pounds and costs nine points in brown stamps.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt, who will celebrate his (2d birthday anniversary Sunday, is in better health than at any time since he came into office in 1933, Dr. Ross T. McIntire, his personal physician, said today.

TORONTO, Jan. 28 (Canadian Press) -- Gilbert LaBine, president of the Eldorado Mining and Refining Company, Ltd., announced here today that he had been advised officially that the Canadian Government had appropriated all shares of the company.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 28 -- Among the 534 patents listed as issued in this week's Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office is one of the widest ranges of unusual inventions of general interest covered in many months. They include a new kind of surgical dressing, a collapsible boat easily carried on a small automobile trailer, a radically different method of egg wrapping and many items in the "gadget" category.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Capitalization of the Central of Georgia Railroad would be reduced from $112,429,905 to $84,412,798 and its leased lines would be merged with the main system under a reorganization plan filed in Federal court here today.

Tomorrow marks the eleventh anniversary of Hitler's accession to power. It will be interesting to see what use is made of the day in Berlin. In pre-war years this was always the occasion for a tremendous display of pomp and self-glorification by the leaders of the Nazi movement.

Behind the scenes of the cosmetic industry, kaleidoscopic changes are taking place daily. The exigencies of war remove a basic ingredient from the raw-material market, a substitute is found or developed, the cosmetic formula is perhaps completely revised to include the new substance -- and the finished product appears on the counter, looking, smelling and feeling precisely the same as its predecessor.

A victory by John Ringhauser in the 100-yard back-stroke, the only first scored by his school, carried Richmond Hill through to triumph in the P.S.A.L. swimming championship meet at the Columbia University pool last night.

THE pictures of the finish of the fight are among the most famous sports photos ever snapped. They show Jack Johnson flat on his back and apparently shading his eyes from the direct rays of a hot Havana sun. It is no wonder that so much suspicion was attached to the knockout of the then champion of the world by Jess Willard.

Approximately 3,500 children from the schools of New York City, Westchester County, Long Island, New Jersey and Connecticut attended the junior performance of Thomas' "Mignon," presented yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera House, under the sponsorship of the Metropolitan Opera Guild as the first of the two offerings of the kind to be made during the current season by that organization.

Invitation by the United States Treasury procurement division yesterday for bids on sizable quantities of men's and boys' suits and slacks for lend-lease use in French North Africa is regarded by the industry as probably indicative of the opening move in additional purchases of new clothing that will be needed not only by lend-lease but for UNRA, the Red Cross and other buying agencies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, said tonight that Great Britain hoped India would remain in the British Commonwealth after the war but would no try to block her if she desired to sever empire relations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- Congressional reaction to the report of the atrocities committed by the Japanese in the Philippines was more bitter today in many cases than after Pearl Harbor.

Back on their own ice after an absence of two weeks, the Rangers will match strides with the Canadiens of Montreal in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. In their recent road trip the New Yorkers, who are still lodged in last place in the loop race, started off very well, nicking the Maple Leafs for a 5-to-1 triumph.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Whether Congress and the country were left in the dark by the State Department before Pearl Harbor "about the realities that were sweeping us toward inevitable war" or whether, on the other hand, they were warned but failed to heed the warning was debated by Secretary Hull and Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan during tonight's State Department broadcast over the NBC.

Release of steel springs last week for upholstered furniture had far-reaching implications to the average merchant, for it brought him face to face with the problem of "ersatz" or "victory" merchandise and how to dispose of it when pre-war quality goods is once more available, recording to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

Volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was the smallest since Dec. 4 but stocks closed firm and moderately higher. The turnover of 345,310 shares compared with one of 520,510 shares on the preceding Saturday. Of the 632 issues traded, 269 rose, 146 fell and 217 were unchanged.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Jan. 28 (Delayed) -- The Japanese authorities are employing the torture of American and British prisoners, as described in the joint United States Army and Navy reports and in Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's statement, to keep their own men fighting to the bitter end, it is reliably reported.
LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 30 (U.P.) -- A joint Eighth United States Air Force and British Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Pedro Ramirez cabled to President Roosevelt today that he had broken relations with the Axis. He said that he had taken this step not only for Argentina's own protection but in the interests of continental defense and he assured the President of his intention of strengthening Argentine-American relations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- Thousands of Americans danced tonight to swell the infantile paralysis fund on the eve of President Roosevelt's sixty-second birthday.
Mr. and Mrs. Wirt D. Walker of Chicago are at the Pierre.

Complete disarmament of Japan and the creation of a strong China after the war were demanded by T.S. Tsiang, Director of Political Affairs of the Department of the Executive Council of China, in an address at a Metropolitan Opera Victory Rally yesterday afternoon, broadcast over the Blue network from the Metropolitan Opera Guild room in the opera house.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 30 -- Eleven years ago this morning the twisted cross of the swastika triumphantly flung its arms over Germany and above Berlin -- a city streaked this Sunday morning by thousands of dirty ash piles that are stark reminders of the doom that lies upon it.

ONE of the eternal truths that every woman knows is this: Important "occasions" and interesting invitations invariably arrive on the day when she ought to have gone to the hairdresser but hasn't because she was too busy.

THE tedious pages of this fictionalized biography of Mohawk sachem Joseph Brant will make readers feel new affection for the romanticism of "Hiawatha" and "The Deerslayer." According to Harvey Chalmers, the Indian raids on the Schoharie and Mohawk Valleys during the Revolutionary War were not sporadic scalping expeditions by unorganized savages but part of a careful plan to defeat the rebels.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Differences between the Senate and House conferees over the war contracts renegotiation provisions of the tax bill delayed agreement on the new measure today.

There are strange goings on in Duke University's psychological laboratory over which Prof. J.B. Rhine presides. Day after day dice are thrown to study what he calls the "psychokinetic effect," or PK for short. When a crap shooter turned up at the university some time ago and claimed that by wishing hard or yelling "come seven, come eleven" he got results it was decided to try him out.

Bond-buying sports fans stormed the doors of the Mutual Playhouse, Fifty-second Street and Broadway, last night intent upon seeing famous sports figures who helped to put over WOR's "Golden Age of Sports" Fourth War Loan Drive broadcast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- For the first time since the outbreak of the global war the Americas at last stand as a unit against the Axis in consequence of Argentina's severance of diplomatic relations with Japan and Germany.

Poetry in Poland THE most amazing literary competition to date has come to light via the Polish Telegraph Agency, which reports the Polish underground monthly, Culture of Tomorrow, holding a competition for the best poem on Warsaw.

GEORGE WASHINGTON HILL, president of the American Tobacco Company, is known as a man of his own mind in the radio world, having initiated such slogans as "The Best Tunes of All Move to Carnegie Hall," the chants of auctioneers and, most recently, the use of the letters "LS-MFT."

In terms of their lives, careers and personal fortunes, the men who do the fighting are making the real sacrifices in this war. All that we are asked to do now is to put our money aside to buy as many War Bonds as often as we can.

LONDON, Jan. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Bath City, a small west-country club which is in the League Cup football competition by special permission, today gained the top rung of the fifty-six-team cup qualifying table along with Leicester when Everton, the previous leader, was beaten for the first time.

ALGIERS, Jan. 29 -- The audacious Allied sea-borne thrust thirty miles below Rome a week ago this morning has gone well but there is not the slightest tendency at this headquarters to minimize the obstacles ahead or to forget that this operation, like all military gambles, has a dangerous as well as spectacular side.

Your comments in Topics of The Times on the Supreme Court's output of words and the growing length of opinions will be appreciated by lawyers who have to familiarize themselves with the findings of the courts.

Lynn H. Korndorff, president of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, reported yesterday that eighty ships, with an estimated value of $300,000,000 were delivered last year by the company's yards at Kearny and Port Newark, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Relief needs for the 70,000,000 people of the Netherlands Indies, now living under Japanese domination on their more than 3,000 islands, were stated in detail to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration today by Peter H.W. Sitsen, member of the Netherlands economic mission in the United States.

ALGIERS, Jan. 29 -- Tearing into the German air force and ravaging German communications and airfields with unslackening fury, Allied planes over Italy and off Albania brought down thirty-seven more enemy machines against a loss of five.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 29--West Point's winter sports teams went into action today in a carnival of athletics that saw the varsity basketball, track, hockey and swimming teams face intercollegiate rivals while the fencers met the Salle Santelli of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A letter to the FBI, a donation of $28 to the Infantile Paralysis Relief Fund and a letter described as "our will" were the clues found today in an investigation of the deaths of Gustav Spahn, a German alien of 45, recently questioned by the FBI, and a woman known as his wife, Elsa.

The "bold and broad" plans for community rebuilding work being developed in England are the reflection of a social revolution and a new spirit of community responsibility crystallized by the tragedies and destruction of war, the Citizens Housing Council was told yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore.

Music lovers in Southern California have a serious grievance, and surely there is no better forum than THE TIMES radio columns for the ventilation of that grievance. We get no chamber music here of any sort.

" MAKE the old rug do" has become the intelligent homemaker's refrain these days. Rugs are scarce, not only in supply, which is 20 per cent of 1941 retail inventories, but variety and quality are giving headaches to the woman buyer who believes that the basic furnishings of a room should be "right."

Franklin Delano Roosevelt was 51 years old when he became President. He is 62 years old today. The eleven years in between have done with him what they did with other men of his age, and the burden of the Presidency has done a little more. The burden has included our greatest depression and, not yet completed, our greatest war.

The United Service Organizations, with headquarters in the Empire State Building, will mark its third birthday next Friday with luncheons in cities and towns throughout the nation and open house for the public in all USO clubs on that day and the following week-end, Chester I. Barnard, president, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Discontent among British coal miners increased today as a result of a mediation report recommending that underground workers be paid a weekly minimum of 5 [about $20] and surface men 4 10s [$18], which is 1 less than they had demaded.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 -- Squat, bandy-legged Honus Wagner, a terror on the base paths and a scourge to pitchers during twenty-one years at shortstop in the National League, today returned his signed contract to the Pittsburgh Pirates -- almost on the eve of his seventieth birthday.

NOT all of today's youngsters want their music hot. While there are the frantic jitterbugs who stampede the theatre whenever Benny Goodman, Harry James and other pipers appear, over at the Metropolitan Opera House there are youngsters who stand for hours to listen to good music.

Industry executives responsible for keeping up with the War Department's handling of both termination and renegotiation of contracts indicated yesterday that the latest administrative change of rules -- implying ultimate joining of the two issues -- has convinced them more than ever of the need for prompt legislative action to lift these vital subjects out of the realm of arbitrary man-made decisions before the end of hostilities.

LESLIE TURNER WHITE has written a rip-roaring, blood-and-thunder adventure story of the first water -- muddy Mississippi, blue Atlantic and greenish-brown Amazon water. The Southern Belle, a 155-foot long, 27-foot beam, shallow-draft side-wheeler is practically the heroine.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Meat processors cleaned up today most of the holdover supply of hogs as well as new arrivals, and at the end of the session only about 2,000 head were left for Monday's trading. Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

FLINT RYDER won from his older brother the right to bring home his father's new horse is a bronco-breaking contest which starts this story for older boys off in a whirl of dust and action. The horse was a valuable and beautiful Palomino Quarter Horse and the two understood each other from the first.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 29 (AP) -- American-trained Chinese troops have pushed deeper in the Hukawng Valley area of northern Burma, wiping out Japanese elements fighting above Taipha Ga and driving back enemy units between the Tarung and Tanai Rivers, a Southeast Asia communique declared today.

Edward V. Loughlin, leader of the Fourteenth Assembly District, was elected leader of Tammany last night at a special meeting of the Tammany executive committee at the headquarters of the Democratic County Committee, 331 Madison Avenue.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 30 -- Delivering its heaviest blow thus far at Germany, the United States Eighth Air Force carried out a mighty attack in the early daylight yesterday against Frankfort on the Main.

A grim picture of Italy as a country without food, without means of transportation, without business or industry, its population tired and about to turn to communism nor chaos, was described yesterday in a letter written from Naples on New Year's Day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Office of Price Administration directed local rationing boards today to authorize purchase of passenger car tires after Feb. 1 on the basis of the war importance of the applicant's travel rather than on the type of gasoline ration he holds.

German production of civilian consumer goods had dropped sharply long before the RAF and United States Eighth Air Force set out to smash Hitler's war machine by the most powerful air offensive unleashed since hostilities began. It was only by a great reduction in the German standard of living that war production could be maintained in the face of ever-increasing demands of the Army for men.

Three British fliers, stranded in a doughnut type raft somewhere off the coast of Africa, probably owe their lives to Capt. Emory J. Martin, skipper of an American Export Airlines plane. The story was disclosed yesterday when he brought his thirty-ton seaplane into La Guardia Field with sixteen passengers aboard.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Grain markets backed and filled nervously today on the Board of Trade. Prices were slightly lower early, but short covering and professional and commission-house buying developed and they rallied quickly, offerings being light.

THE destruction by the Nazis of the centuries-old Greek monasteries and of religious art and literary relics will be denounced at a mass protest rally sponsored by the Greek Daily National Herald to be held this afternoon at 2:30 at the Manhattan Center.

Leonard Rose, 'cellist in the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, appeared as soloist with the orchestra in Carnegie Hall last night, playing Lalo's Concerto in D minor, with Wilhelm Steinberg conducting in place of Artur Rodzinski, who has been ill with influenza.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Rabaul was raided again on Thursday, the twenty-fifth raiding mission there by the Allies this month during which twenty-three more planes were shot down to send Japanese losses in January above 400.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- More than 150,000 Jewish men and women in Palestine, nearly one-third of the Jewish population of that country, are directly helping the war effort, according to Barnett Janner in his presidential address tonight at the annual conference of the Zionist Federation here.

Below Leningrad the Red Army slashed into the Wehrmacht's crumbling defenses, cut huge chunks from a shrinking Nazi bulge that had long threatened the city. SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 -- After a Christmas jam which left warehouses filled with parcel post and resulted in the piling up of stacks of newspapers destined for overseas mailing, Army and fleet postoffices on this part of the West Coast have caught up with their backlog, it was stated yesterday.

A two-day conference of the North Atlantic Area of the American Red Cross will open tomorrow morning at Carnegie Hall devoted to the tasks that will confront the organization this year. With the exception of a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow night and a luncheon at the same hotel on Tuesday, the sessions will be held at Carnegie Hall.

Considerable importance and many dire predictions have been attached to the recent decision of the United States Supreme Court in the case of rates of the Hope Natural Gas Company. Many utility investors viewed the decision with alarm, believing that the court had established an "original cost" theory of utility valuation for rate making purposes.

DETROIT, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings stretched their winning streak to six games in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Boston Bruins, 6 to 1, before 13,197 spectators at Olympia Stadium. Syd Howe scored twice for Detroit, the first being his 200th major league goal.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 29 -- Taking a 5-0 lead in the first period, Dartmouth's hockey team defeated Yale, 8 -- 3, for the second time in eight days on Davis Rink tonight. Cuniff and Rondeau scored a pair of goals each to help run the Indians' victory skein to forty over a three-year period.

Results in two elections last September in which employes of the Horn Hardart Company, restaurant chain, voted against two American Federation of Labor locals as their bargaining agencies were set aside yesterday by the New York State Labor Relations Board after hearings held following protests by the losing unions that the company had permitted employes to vote in working hours.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 29 -- The Japanese, girding themselves for the battle of Burma, are rushing construction of a railway from Thailand to southern Burma at a callous expenditure of the lives of British Empire prisoners of war and Chinese civilians, according to reports from reputable eyewitnesses.
