WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- Senator Scott Lucas, co-author of the Lucas-Green soldier vote bill, said tonight that he had taken an informal poll of the Senate which showed the Administration had strength to pass a Federal ballot bill for service personnel on Monday "without crippling amendments.''

THE first council meeting of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration has passed into history. Now it is the turn of the UNRRA program, formulated at that meeting, to make history. If the enemy is to be cheated of his goal and defeated in his purpose of leaving in the occupied countries only a race of "half-men," that program must be put into action at the earliest possible moment.

ON THE ARAKAN FRONT, in Burma, Jan. 27 (Delayed) -- British forces on this front are assaulting one of the strongest Japanese fortified areas in Burma. After the initial attack Indian and British infantry are infiltrating through the enemy front and are battling furiously in close-in small arms and mortar combat for control of the dominating jungle-covered hilltops.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Virginia Press Association endorsed today the action of the board of directors of The Associated Press in appealing to the Supreme Court of the United States the decision of the special three-judge court in the Government's anti-trust suit.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Japanese atrocities against war prisoners, revealed in recent Washington and London announcements, are part of a deliberate campaign to subdue "all who come within Japan's feudalistic empire," Associated Press Correspondent Russell Brines told the Virginia Press Association today.

Americans, more angry than they have been at any time since Pearl Harbor, turned again last week to study their enemy in the East. They had just been told that 7,700 of the approximately 22,300 American soldiers, sailors and marines captured by the Japanese in the Philippines had been tortured, murdered and starved to death.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Board of Directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States ordered a membership referendum today on a policy urging this country to take part in international relief and rehabilitation utilizing private business channels "to a maximum degree."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The return of President Roosevelt today after several days' absence increased expectations of early action by him to end the dispute between Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, and Robert E. Sherwood, chief of its Overseas Branch.

The article "Will Japanese Morale Meet the Big Test?" in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine should be looked at askance. The author, Mr. K.K. Kawakami, seems all too sure that the Japanese home front cannot withstand a catastrophic air assault by American bombers, once they get within striking distance of crowded Japanese cities.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The air war in this theatre has begun its penultimate phase. The strategic bombing of Germany, which has grown from modest beginnings in 1940 to the heaviest aerial assault of history, has been augmented by a tactical offensive against enemy targets along and behind the coastline of western Europe.

More than one-third of the total number of active merchant seamen in the off-shore shipping industry, now roughly estimated at 115,000, have left the security of shore berths to return to sea in the past year and a half. The Recruitment and Manning Organization of the War Shipping Administration reports the recruitment and assignment of a total of 35,000 experienced men, with another 4,370 who have declared themselves potentially available for our wartime merchant fleet.

NEXT month will see two national holidays, Lincoln's Birthday on the 12th, and Washington's on the 22d. Before the war made every day a workday, these dates were occasions for general celebration. This year, with the exception of schools, banks and a few offices, the days will not be widely observed.

Paul Zeckhausen, salvage director of the War Production Board, predicted yesterday that "waste paper, badly needed in the closing months of 1943, will become literally precious within the next ninety days." He pointed out that the WPB recently had cut the amount of bags and wrapping paper allocated to civilian use for the first quarter of this year to one-half that consumed in the same period of last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- With an estimated 10,000,000 potential Presidential, Vice Presidential and Congressional votes at issue, and with perhaps 5,000,000 of them to be deployed along thirty-odd overseas battlefronts by autumn, Congress is deadlocked and enmeshed in one of the strangest and most politically dangerous situations that have confronted it in modern political history.

PICK up a map of Australia and off the southeast tip you'll discover tiny Flinders Island. Reading this book by Ernestine Hill you'll discover it via exploration and adventure on the high seas. For this island is called after the little-known Matthew Flinders, the young navigator who named Australia and charted its shores.

FORTUNE is indeed lavish with nations. Once again Britain and America will have the opportunity to lead the world in new directions. They can fritter away the chance as they did after the last war if, as then, they fail to stand together in the making of a new world.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Sensitive instruments of Allied diplomacy in this capital continue to register disturbances in the wake of the dispute between the Polish Government-in-Exile and the Soviet Union. There are implications in it for all of them, and the fact that the storm may blow up again without warning adds nothing to the general peace of mind.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--The new War Refugees Board, meeting four days after its establishment by President Roosevelt, said today that negotiations were under way with foreign Governments to determine the extent to which they were willing to cooperate in rescuing Jews and other victims of Nazi aggression.

ALGIERS, Jan. 29 -- As American light artillery stood within range of Cisterna, the most vital road and rail junction in the new Italian invasion area, British troops below Rome lanced ahead yesterday to capture a bridge beyond Aprilia, more than twelve miles north of Anzio and barely a mile below the electrified main coastal route southward.

ALMOST twenty-four years ago -- on March 19, 1920, to be exact -- the Treaty of Versailles, containing the Covenant of the League of Nations and the reservations adopted by the Senate, came to its final vote. The vote was forty-nine in the affirmative, thirty-five votes being cast against it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Federal employes are suffering equally with other classes of white-collar workers because of increased living costs in the face of gross incomes which are largely fixed, a Senate Education and Labor subcommittee was told today.

A special six-week term for entering freshmen, beginning Feb. 14, is being offered by Hamilton College. Its program already shifted from the semester to the quarter plan to accommodate students who, because of anticipated Army induction, cannot commit themselves for long periods of college training, Hamilton plans its new term as a further step in this direction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Secretary Ickes appealed to anthracite miners today to work seven days a week next month to avert "serious and tragic consequences" of a critical shortage of domestic fuel in the New England and Middle Atlantic States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Marine Corps Division of Public Relations said today that the family of Corp. Elizabeth Hima rated eight stars in the service flag at the home, 103 Delaware Avenue in Milford, N.J., with six brothers and sisters in the armed services and two in defense industry.

INSIDE the old Tiffany Building at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, where the impeccable sales clerks used to yearn above their trays of jewels, two volunteer Red Cross workers now sit at little tables near a sign with "Blood Donor Service" printed on it in big red letters.

OLD Rio de Janeiro, joyful in Brazil's new independence, is the setting for Miss Dalgliesh's story of the amusing, vivacious Silva family. It was a large family, with so many little boys and such active ones that it is hard to keep track of them. and just one little girl.

MRS. PARSONS has used the bluff just north of Piermont for two interesting purposes. She has hung her house high on its rugged face overlooking the Tappan Zee -- and she has hung this penetrating collection of anecdotes, character studies, humorous and philosophical observations and vivid appreciations of nature like a garland on her front door.

OF the one-man shows recently opened, three present work by artists who have measurably developed since their previous exhibitions. Two other events bring forward work by newcomers to the local field.

THE VERSAILLES, the well-known East Fiftieth Street pleasure haunt, is offering the week's major contribution to New York's night life. Come Thursday evening and the club will present a new floor show headed by Perry Como, radio and motion-picture thrush who at one time used to be heard five times a week over Station WABC-Columbia.

THE leading bridge players in New York are unquestionably prejudiced against the Blackwood slam convention, which is used by serious players in every other part of the country. Part of the prejudice is attributable to the technical aspects of the convention, which most of the local experts consider unsound.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission cleared the way today for a full dress test of the right of other Federal agencies or departments almost automatically to inject themselves into proceedings under statutes administered by the SEC.

Patrick J. McKenna will give a course in Ornamental Gardening in the Hunter College evening session on Tuesdays from 6:30 to 8:30 P.M., starting Feb. 8. Registration will take place at the college from Jan. 31 through Feb. 3.

American colleges during the past week found their war-training and civilian programs attacked on two fronts. New regulations issued by the Selective Service division at Washington severely restricted the deferments to be given college students. This new policy will become effective on Feb. 15.
PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 26 (Delayed)--Navy honors are coming in quick succession to "The Chief," fighting Indian skipper of aircraft carriers in the Atlantic and Pacific.

A program for improving racial and religious understanding through various educational activities has been prepared in Massachusetts, Dr. Julius E. Warren, Commissioner of Education, reported last week. A committee to study the problems of developing better understanding among the different races and groups within the State was appointed by the Governor several months ago.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 -- Like Mahomet's coffin, John L. Lewis is suspended in mid-air. His plans had called for the re-admission of the United Mine Workers of America to the American Federation of Labor not later than this week by reason of favorable action at the midwinter meeting of the federation's executive council.

Icely of the Wilson Sporting Goods Company until 4 A.M., several of the court stars were again on the job helping the good cause yesterday afternoon.

The rarely played second String Sextet, G major, Opus 36, of Brahms was given yesterday afternoon in Town Hall by the Lener Quartet assisted by Pvt. Nicholas Harsanyi, viola, and Janos Scholz, 'cello. The quarter alone, in the sixth of its series of eight concerts, opened the program with the Brahms String Quartet in A minor, Opus 51, No. 2, the only other number presented.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Wayne L. Morse, public member of the War Labor Board, has resigned from the board and from the Law School faculty at the University of Oregon to clear the way for his entrance into the Republican Senatorial race in Oregon.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 29--The popularity of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York as a Republican Presidential nominee has increased substantially during the past six weeks. Wendell Willkie's popular standing has shown a slight drop.

LONDON, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- The historic vineyards of France and Italy, with their roots sunk sixty feet deep into the earth, are safe from total destruction and will bear fruit again the year the war ends even though they are trampled by mechanized armies, it was predicted today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 29 -- Alan Ford, Yale's "Balboa Bullet," set a new world swimming record for the 100-yard free style today of 50.1 seconds, bettering also the American, collegiate, pool and Yale marks in his record-smashing effort.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- Celebration tonight of President Roosevelt's birthday, despite the fact that it falls on Sunday, is arranged largely for the convenience of his son, Lieut. Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., USNR, who enters the Sub-chaser Training Center on Tuesday.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 29 -- The hired hand has sometimes been referred to as the forgotten man of agriculture, but he hasn't been entirely forgotten in the war prosperity which the farmer is now enjoying. To some extent he is sharing in it, too. Wages have gone up along with prices.

The item of greatest interest, and the biggest stumbling block, in making out the current income tax returns is the "forgiveness" feature. Both Forms 1040 and 1040A incorporate the unforgiven part of the 1942 tax in the total amount due in 1943.

Preliminary earnings of the country's two largest steel producers and shipbuilders for 1943 disclose a substantial reduction in provisions for Federal Income and excess profits taxes, despite large increases in the volume and worth of their output.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, Jan. 30 -- In a radio broadcast at midnight President Roosevelt called upon Americans for "an outpouring of dollars" to "assure that superiority of fighting equipment with which we shall blast our way to Berlin and Tokyo."

LONDON, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- Acting on instructions from Allied western front headquarters, Europe's vast underground army has launched a pre-invasion campaign to help pave the way for the coming assault by British and American forces, it was learned tonight.

T.M. Liang of the Chinese Supply Mission in this country told the closing session here yesterday of the winter technical meetings of the Institute of Radio Engineers of the "staggering totz of radio-electronic and mechanical machines and men" that will be needed by his country, largely from America, after this war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Senator Barkley of Kentucky, the Democratic leader, said tonight that Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania had submitted his resignation as chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, effective when a successor is chosen.

The publicity received by the Army Specialized Training Program for the teaching of foreign languages has helped to stress the importance of a knowledge of other idioms. Opposition to maltreating Japanese prisoners in retaliation for mistreatment of American prisoners was expressed yesterday by Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein in a sermon in West Side Institutional Synagogue, 122 West Seventy-sixth Street.

The United States and Foreign Securities Corporation had on Dec. 31 net assets of $31,333,683, or about $182 a share on the first preferred stock, according to a report issued yesterday. This compared with net assets of $25,252,289 a year earlier, or $146 a share on the first preferred.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- The Japanese plot against the United States was born immediately after the last war, "when our guard was down" and was still being carried on "both in and out of Japanese relocation centers," the Dies Committee charged tonight.

OTTAWA, Jan. 29 -- The suggestion made by Lord Halifax in his speech at Toronto, Monday, that the time had come for reconsideration of the functional relationship of the Commonwealth countries to give the dominions a share of the responsibility in the shaping of foreign policy and organizing mutual defense has provoked a livelier debate than this country has known for some time.

Infant care has become "a highly mechanical procedure," with attention focused on formulas and cleanliness, while the baby's mental functioning is completely ignored, Dr. Margaret A. The sudden deluge of war bond sales, resulting from the national anger over the torture by the Japanese of American war prisoners, washed away yesterday even the sales record that War Finance Committee members had estimated on Friday night, and set new high marks in many parts of the country.

BASEBALL players who have paraded before the critical gaze of Branch Rickey probably would reach, if all were placed in single file, from Flatbush to St. Louis and back again. The Deacon of the Dodgers has seen all kinds and all types. Yet if he ever were backed into a corner and asked to name his favorite of them all, it is very likely that he would select Pepper Martin.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Jan. 29 -- Dartmouth's talented array of skiers were well on their way to victory in Middlebury College's thirteenth annual winter carnival, which started today under exacting conditions on Chipman Hill.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Despite warnings from Government officials that current high demands on food supplies are certain to be continued and will probably be increased as the war progresses, food trade leaders at their annual meetings here this week indicated that in view of the improved supply situation in processed foods and the apparent change in consumer psychology from fear of scarcity, retrenchment policies are now in order.

SPINACH has a rival. It is tampala, a vegetable of oriental origin, introduced this year in time to give Victory gardeners an easily grown and nutritious new green. Its leaves and stems can be cooked together or separately, and young crisp leaves may be used in salads, to add new tempting dishes to summer menus.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Valdina Zenith rocketed to victory in the $5,000 added Gulf Coast Handicap at the Fair Grounds today, only seven hours after William G. Helis had purchased the 3-year-old at a private sale.

THE aroma of boiling turnips and baking felt boots is the predominant effluvium of a Maine farm kitchen in winter. We have other smells from time to time, but the one that lifts your hat off is the combined attar of turnips and boots.

The New York State Senate adopted last week a bill sponsored by Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr. which is designed to strip the New York City Board of Superintendents of virtually all but advisory power. If the Assembly concurs, the local school system will get a radically changed Board of Superintendents and greater executive authority will go to the Superintendent of Schools.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The labor members of the Presidential Committee on the Cost of Living stated in a report today that living costs had risen 43.5 per cent since Jan. 1, 1941, instead of 23.4 per cent as given by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Jan. 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- Two men -- an American captain and a private -- carrying a Red Cross banner tied to two sticks marched through a battered no-man's-land to the edge of the bloody Rapido River today and crossed into German territory amid a deathly silence.

AFTER last Sunday's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, Bruno Zirato, associate manager, presented the players with a completely refurnished clubroom backstage in the name of William Rosenwald, a member of the board of directors, who had made a gift of the refurnished room and who was present.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 29 -- Admiration for what he called the fierce and relentless attack New Zealanders have been maintaining against Rabaul was expressed in a congratulatory message received today by the Government from Gen. Douglas MacArthur, Acting Prime Minister Daniel Sullivan said last night. General MacArthur asked that his congratulations be relayed to the New Zealand Air Force.

Retail trade here was again active last week, producing gains in dollar volume at about the rate of improvement noted in the preceding week. Department store sales were estimated as running about 7 to 8 per cent above the like week of last year. Most soft-goods lines are selling well and active interest is being shown in early spring apparel and accessories.

Making the most of their rivals' first-half nervousness, the Dartmouth basketball players outscored the Columbia quintet in the Lions' gym last night, 69 to 53. In registering the triumph the Hanover Indians clinched the championship in the Eastern Intercollegiate League, their record in loop competition reading seven victories as against no defeats, with only one game remaining.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 29 -- The Naval Academy basketball team managed to subdue a Duke rally in the closing half of the final period today and emerged the victor by a score of 45 to 42.

LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Sir Richard Acland, leader of the Common Wealth party, gave to the nation today two big estates valued at $1,000,000, explaining that it troubled his conscience to advocate common ownership of all great resources, including land, while a private landowner.

The congress of six Italian political parties at Bari unanimously adopted a resolution yesterday calling for the abdication of King Victor Emmanuel, the Bari radio said last night in a broadcast recorded by United States Government monitors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Naval, Transport Air Service is now conducting services over a world-wide transoceanic and overland network of more than 65,000 miles as the result of rapidly expanding operations, the Office of War Information said today.

Retail trade was active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey for THE NEW YORK TIMES made by Meyer Both Reports. Millinery was outstanding.

The St. John's University Redmen last night had little trouble in downing a spirited Cathedral College quintet, 68 to 43, in the De Gray Gym, Brooklyn. Notching their ninth victory in eleven starts, the Redmen were never headed by the New Yorkers.

HERE are the impressions generally bright and lively, sometimes naive, always uninhibited, of an American woman in China before and after the outbreak of war with Japan in 1937. Miss Sues was at various times a journalist, a Chinese Government propagandist and a censor of the foreign press.

WEST POINT, Jan. 29 -- On behalf of Col. George F. Schlatter, commander of Stewart Field, Capt. Albert E. Farone, adjutant of the flying field, accepted today a fully equipped medical and veterinarian detachment day room which has been furnished as a memorial to Sgt. Meyer Levin, the Army Air Forces bombardier who flew with Captain Colin P. Kelly on the mission in which he crash-dived on the Japanese battleship Haruna.

FROM the sale of considerably less than half of the philatelic holdings of the late Col. E.H.R. Green at twelve auctions about $464,00 has been relized thus far. There are thousands of rarities in the material yet to be sold and If the present high price levels are maintained at the coming auctions the total figure is expected to exceed the appraisal value of $1,200,000.

The second session of the Seventy-eighth Congress has been at work for two full, busy weeks. Mornings the members have been attending to correspondence in their offices, visiting the various Government departments on errands from home or sitting in committee meetings where, in most instances, the real business of Congress is transacted.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- Premier Ion Antonescu, yielding to pressure from Berlin, has permitted the Germans to set up virtually their own state in Rumania, persons in reliable church circles said tonight, quoting "unimpeachable information."

The Triborough Bridge Authority had a net operating income of $1,596,597 and total interest on funded debt of $3,067,125, leaving a net loss of $1,470,527 for the year, according to the annual report made public yesterday.

ALGIERS, Jan. 29 -- At a dinner table a few days ago sat three young men who had recently come from France, two within a few weeks. One was a large fellow whose physical prowess had been felt by the Germans. The other two were of a more ascetic and intellectual type but they too had done their work in the Underground, and commando methods were familiar to all three.

The sun broke briefly through the cloud wrack and haze over the Navy Yard in Brooklyn yesterday and skippers in the East River held down their whistles as the USS Missouri, fourth and perhaps last of a class of giant heavyweights, had her first taste of the salt.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 29 -- In a written interview given to a South American correspondent and cited in tomorrow morning's issue of the Suisse of Geneva, Don Juan, pretender to the throne of Spain, announced that there was no further possibility of a rapprochement between the monarchy and General Franco's regime.

MOSCOW, Jan. 28 (Delayed) -- In the presence of Premier Stalin, the Supreme Soviet convened tonight in the Grand Palace of the Kremlin for its second wartime session. It heard the Government propose a 1944 budget totaling 245,600,000,000 rubles, of which 128,300,000,000 would be devoted to the prosecution of the war.

The meat shortage that members of the livestock industry have forecast would recur in the East by spring as a result of curtailed feeder activities and other problems is already showing indications of its return, it was learned yesterday. Government representatives now admit that the meat shortage next spring may be more acute than that of last spring.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The State Department waited today for word from Spain whether yesterday's imposition of an oil embargo would move Generalissimo Francisco Franco to heed the suggestions made to him by the United States and Great Britain that he cease sending supplies and money to Germany, release Italian merchant vessels and warships now detained in Spanish ports, prevent acts of sabotage against Allied vessels and withdraw Spanish soldiers from the Russian front.

PAM NORTH (Mrs. Jerry North to you) has a hunch, and Lieut. Bill Weigand is worried because this hunch has to do with a case on which Bill is working, and it is such a preposterous idea that it can't possibly be correct.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 29 -- Fifty thousand persons gathered in front of the Opera House last night to mark the second anniversary of Brazil's break with the Axis. Among the speakers were Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha, the Governor of Rio de Janeiro State, Commander Ernani Amaral Peixoto, and the Chilean Ambassador, Gabriel Gonzalez Videla.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 29 -- Strong carrier task forces of the Pacific Fleet penetrated the enemy's Marshall Islands today and blasted his strongholds on Kwajalein and Wotje Atolls and Taroa Island in Maloelap Atoll.

An urgent appeal for stronger public support of the movement to feed the children of Nazi-occupied countries of Europe was made yesterday by Dr. Howard E. Kershner, chairman of the Temporary Council on Food for Europe's Children, 70 Fifth Avenue, and a member of the executive committee of the National Committee on Food for the Small Democracies, 420 Lexington Avenue.

LONDON, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans smashed at German garrisons on a fifty-mile front from Bihac to Prijedor today in a mounting effort to drive the enemy from western Bosnia while in the eastern section of the province a simultaneous attack carried units of Marshal Tito's Fifth Division into Borece and Celic.

MR. HEIDEN'S first book appeared during 1932, when it was still possible to believe that nazism might eventually become a "strong political party, defending the interests of the middle class." It was a good, observant, well-informed essay which is very useful even today.

The statement by leaders of Polish groups published in your issue of Jan. 8 will prove, we believe, to be as unrepresentative of the majority of Polish-Americans as it is incorrect in its historical and ethnographic assertions.

RETAIL trade is winding up the first month of the year with results which were quite in line with expectations. In the merchandise category there will be a small gain over January, 1943, as an offset to the decline which is more or less inevitable in February because of the scare buying which sent sales soaring last year.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 -- Ariel Flight easily captured the $6,320 Bahmas Handicap at $53.20 for $2 at Hialeah Park today to give a tonic to his ailing trainer, Willie Martin, who all along had maintained that he had a "Derby horse" in the brown gelding.

The annual "flush" in the New York milkshed next May and June will be even more acute than that of last spring, when thousands of cans of milk were dumped in roadside gutters, according to Government and trade forecasts released yesterday with announcements of prices to be paid to the producers.

WHEN Chopin was completing the cycle of his great works for the piano in Paris, there was as yet no Russian piano literature worthy of the name. Only in the last quarter of the past century did Russian piano music enter the world market, and soon it occupied a place of honor in the repertoire of every pianist.

At a recent meeting of the board of directors of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company Edward P. Farley was elected chairman of the board to succeed Roger D. Lapham, who resigned upon his election as Mayor of San Francisco.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 29 -- Despite President Pedro Ramirez's warning that anyone who does not approve the breach with the Axis "would be well advised, for his own peace of mind, to keep his opinion to himself," there are increasing protests in various parts of the country from the most inflamed nationalist elements.
DODGE CITY, Kan., Jan. 29 -- What is a Kansan, a Jayhawk or some other term that has not been invented?

Warning that "the tyranny of the mob is just as dangerous as the power of the dictator," Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley last night expressed the fear that "we are breeding a spirit of class hatred and intolerance into our people's lives that some day, as certainly as I am talking to you, we will reap with a very bitter weeping."

An award of $500 will be given in 1944 to the scientist who has made the most significant contribution to research in human fertility -- either in the control of conception or the correction of sterility, Dr. J.H.J. Upham, president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, Inc., announced last week.

In Nazi plans for world domination the twenty Latin-American nations were to have played an important part. They were considered fertile fields for Nazi doctrine and exploitation and, if necessary, vulnerable gateways for military invasion of the Western Hemisphere.

Major league baseball, beset by endless difficulties as it strives to hold its battlefront intact in the face of a player shortage that becomes more serious with each passing day, is about to bring a memorable "off season" to a rousing climax.

In all the world today, not in the remotest frozen island, not in the blackest solitary cell, can there be any man as lonely as Adolf Hitler. Only those who have shared his crimes can experience anything like the same fathomless solitude. Even among these wretches there can be no companionship. Not one of them trusts another.

Harold Bradley, young Canadian pianist, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The program opened with Bach's "Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue," which was followed by Beethoven's "Appassionata" sonata.

The latest version of the "Revenue Act of 1943" (H.R. 3687), which passed the Senate on Jan. 21 with 311 amendments, is rather a different document in many regards from the original bill passed by the House last Nov. 24. It is now unlikely, however, that additional major changes will be made in the bill as now written.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 29 -- Henry Knight, Kentucky sportsman, today purchased the entire racing stables of Valdina Farms, Uvalde, Tex., in one of the biggest transactions in the history of the American turf. There were 149 horses, some of them long-time standouts at America's top tracks, involved.

A theatre strike affecting the operation of thirty odd Broadway legitimate houses and involving about 600 stagehands -- electricians, property men, carpenters and other technicians of the theatre -- loomed yesterday as officials of Theatrical Protective Union, Local 1, sent out orders to its members to stand by for a possible strike call.

My only quarrel with your critic is that he seems to feel that we Americans aren't capable of being quite as idiotic as the occupants of "Lifeboat" in time of crisis. I also appreciate that "Lifeboat" could very easily be turned to the advantage of the Nazis, and that, in fact, it might strike some people as defeatist propaganda in its present form.

In THE TIMES Magazine you publish "Vansittart's Twelve Points for Germany." These items and their further elucidation in the text seem to follow pretty closely the Old Testament line of "an eye for an eye." But it seems to some readers that Lord Vansittart nevertheless stops -- somewhat abruptly -- short of the full expression of this policy.

In addition to the prestige he lost in his indecisive battle against Beau Jack, world lightweight champion, recognized by the New York State Athletic Commission, last Friday night before an $84,870 house in Madison Square Garden, Sammy Angott, National Boxing Association titleholder, also suffered a severe pain in the exchequer.

THESE are important books and their authors are key people. United Nations relief officials overseas will do well to study these volumes with great care before engaging in their post-war work. The book by Dr. Basch probes deep into the economic problems of the entire Danube region, while that of Mr. Allen describes one of the most heart-warming American rehabilitation projects in the Near East.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 -- Barring a political miracle California's fifty-member delegation will go to the Republican convention in Chicago committed to following the leadership of Governor Earl Warren, who has been reiterating too frequently to suit some of his stanch backers that he is not a candidate for either place on the party's national ticket.

DON COYOTE prowls his wily way through this handful of Mexican folktales, stirring up trouble for the creatures of the barnyard who have taken refuge from the hazards of the desert behind man's cactus fence.

A BARREL full of 3-to-5-year-old hats would get you one of those "get them out of here quick" looks if you tried to peddle them down at the corner haberdasher's. But if that same barrel was filled with films of about the same vintage you could easily sell them, and at a nice profit, to the corner movie house.

WHAT is happening at the Museum of Modern Art? What is the administrative and directorial setup there? These and similar questions have been asked so frequently of late as to presuppose a pretty widespread mood of mystification in the art world.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 30 -- The Red Army's crushing northern offensive yesterday thrust westward from Leningrad to the town of Zagoritsi, twenty-two miles from the Estonian border, captured the important rail hub of Novosokolniki, 230 miles south of Leningrad, in a surprise attack, and struck the last Nazi shackles from the Moscow-Leningrad trunk by seizing Chudovo, a junction seventy-three miles southeast of Leningrad.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE, in England, Jan. 29 -- A group of Flying Fortresses started from this airport just before dawn today and soon took its appointed place in the procession of heavy bombers heading for Frankfort on the Main. By midafternoon all of them had returned.

PROFESSOR BELLAC, a well-known character on the French stage, was a great favorite with society ladies; he invariably discoursed on "Love." Andre Maurois deliberately courts the title: the Bellac of our days. Strangely enough, he is a professor at heart.

The changes in Selective Service procedure, effective Feb. 1, represent a constructive step forward. Under the new arrangement the registrant will receive only the comprehensive examination; the local perfunctory medical examination has been eliminated. On the basis of this pre-induction examination he will be classified as fit for service with the armed forces or as 4-F.

The virtual completion of plans for a national federation of shipping companies, combining all the elements of the maritime industry on all three of our coasts, was reported yesterday in shipping circles here. While no definite official announcement has been made, responsible men in the field revealed the new organization is to be headed by Almon E. Roth, industry member of the War Labor Board.

A UNITED STATES LIBERATOR BASE IN ENGLAND, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Major Jimmy Stewart, with brand new gold oak leaves gleaming from his cap and collar, flew his Liberator, "Nine Yanks and a Jerk" from this base today as the command pilot of his squadron on the Frankfort attack.
TORONTO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks moved within one point of fourth place in the National Hockey League tonight by shading the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 3, before 11,565 fans.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A roaring crowd of 5,132 in Convention Hall tonight saw Chink Crossin, Penn basketball ace, score a field goal in the final two seconds of an overtime period to give the Red and Blue a 41-39 victory over Princeton in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game.

Two lapses within two minutes cost the New York Rangers their game against the Canadiens of Montreal last night. In these two minutes the high-flying sextet from the north jammed two easy shots past Ken McAuley into the local cage, and these two shots enabled the visitors to skate off with the triumph by the score of 5 to 3.

Instead of ever larger and larger congregations, what the Christian church needs is stronger and more faithful ones, the Rev. Dr. Paul Austin Wolfe declared yesterday in a sermon delivered after five years of service as minister of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Ninety-first Street.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided and Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin was the principal speaker yesterday afternoon at the ninety-second commencement exercises of Manhattan College. The ceremony, held in the George R. Smith Auditorium on the campus, was the second annual midwinter commencement.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 30 -- ExlpectaUons of huge Government! Continued on Page Twenty-three

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- There is a body of opinion among the men who cover the White House for the nation's press that President Roosevelt has been getting increasingly out of touch with the public as he has become immersed in direction of the war.
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 31 (AP) -The Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

The world's currencies are so interdependent that economic difficulties of increasing severity appear likely in the post-war era if coordination, or at least inter-governmental collaboration, does not materialize, according to a survey by Dr. John Parke Young, economist engaged in post-war economic planning for the State Department.

THE transfer of the ownership of the Boston Braves last week was viewed with practically no interest at all by this corner except that it gave greater financial stability to the club, and that always is a good thing for baseball. What probably induced such a feeling of complacency was the simultaneous announcement that Bob Quinn would carry on as president.

William Dolan, 14, of 246 Beach 127th Street, Rockaway Park, Queens, crippled by infantile paralysis since August, 1942, sat across the desk from Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday and received two $25 war bonds in recognition of the brave fight he is making to recover from his ailment.
LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- An Eighth United States Army Air Force, and British Air Ministry communique:

The only film newcomer scheduled to reach Broadway this week is "Three Russian Girls," which will open on Friday at the Palace. Anna Sten and Kent Smith are co-starred in this drama of Russian nurses under fire on the front lines. It is a United Artists release, produced by Gregor Rabinovitch and Eugene Frenke from the Soviet picture "Girl From Leningrad," which was distributed here by Artkino in 1941.

I liked your bright and cheery editorial "Catalogue Garden," in the issue of Sunday the 23d, so much that I read it through again today. There is one catalogue, though, that you did not mention, to my mind a very important one.
I am glad you emphasized "the principle of fair play" in your today's editorial "The Soldier's Vote."

The first community center in Harlem to provide all-day care for children of school age will be opened early in March at Utopia House, 170 West 130th Street, it was announced yesterday. The project will be the sponsored by the Utopia Neighborhood Club, the New York branch of the National Association of College Women, the Play Schools Association and the Mayor's Committee on the Wartime Care of Children.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Reports that there will be no immediate change in ceiling prices on cash oats and rye, the temporary maximums being extended for an indefinite period resulted last week in a sharp advance in prices on the Board of Trade here.

Raymond E. Ryan, a downtown Manhattan real estate dealer, has purchased for investment the twelve-story store and office building at 180 Broadway, near the southeast corner of John Street, from the Estate of Charles A. Baudouine, Inc.

Schindel-McDaniels Company, 341 Broadway, announces expansion of its export department under the direction of John L. Amberg. A diversified line of textiles suitable for the export trade will be handled.

The cotton market was irregular last week, prices declining in the, first half of the period and turning firmer in the second half. At the: close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the NewI York Cotton Exchange were up 1 to 7 points. In the previous week l themarket had advanced 16 to 37i points.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Less favorable weather conditions resulted last week in a reduction of country offerings of cash corn, but industries have managed to accumulate a fair reserve of the grain and are more inclined to purchase the cereal for deferred shipment rather than for immediate loading.
PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 30 -- A fierce battle raged today across hundreds of miles in the Marshall Islands between American carrier and other surface forces and defending enemy strongholds.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Jan. 30 -- Cliff Hendrix, former Blue and White star, now completing his Marine Corps Reserve training at Dartmouth, smashed the Chipman Hill record to capture the ski jumping honors and lead the Big Green squad from Hanover to a decisive team victory as Middlebury's thirteenth annual winter carnival was concluded today.

The transit rider had better be on guard lest the latest fare increase proposal of the Committee of Fifteen reaches the ear of a sympathetic public servant in the city government. Going beyond its 7 1/2-cent suggestion of two years ago it now proposes a ten-cent fare.

The eleven representing the Eintracht Sport Club of Astoria, champion of the German-American League, defeated the New York Americans of the American League in a national challenge cup soccer upset at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (;P) -- Liquor imports during the last half of 1943 more than doubled those of the first half, while the year's total of 26,277,000 gallons similarly was more than twice the 11,065,000 gallons imported in 1942, a Treasury report revealed today.
In a second-round challenge cup soccer replay at Brooklyn Oval yesterday the Wanderers and the Hispanos battled to a 4-4 draw.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Appointment of Miss Mary Agnes Craig McGeachy as chief of the Welfare Division of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration was announced tonight by Herbert H. Lehman, UNRRA Director General.

An "international bill of rights" for the individual as well as the State, in which the "narrowing forces of supernationalism and chauvinism" would give way to the demands of justice and reason, was advocated yesterday in a program for solution of post-war Jewish problems by former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (U.P.) -- Administration sponsors of a Federal soldier-vote ballot and Republican opponents engaged in a last minute exchange of name calling tonight as they squared away for a showdown this week on the legislation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Construction of ships to carry men and materials to the Pacific battle fronts will continue without any major reductions in the pres ent program here, Sam Kagel, acting War Manpower Commission director, said today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Grain traders apparently have no definite ideas of the immediate trend of the wheat market, and prices last week held within a range of about 2 cents a bushel. The market was nervous and fluctuations were extremely rapid at times, due largely to professional operations, as out side and mill interest has been limited.

A great multitude of Protestants in New York City are out of touch with the church, the Rev. Ralph Beryl Nesbitt, associate pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street, declared in a sermon preached there yesterday morning.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- The Legislature is prepared to scrap the State's system of soldier voting and adopt a system to fit whatever Federal plan is finally adopted. Leaders and membership seem ready to drop partisanship on the subject and disregard consideration of whether the bulk of the service vote will go Democratic or Republican.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP) -- The champion mare of 1943 looks as though she will be the horse of the winter, too.

The Fourth War Loan drive, which turns the halfway mark of its four-week run tomorrow morning, is outstripping both the second and third loans in bond sales to individuals throughout the State, it was reported last night by Nevil Ford, executive manager of the War Finance Committee for New York.

The recent survey of civilian consumer needs by the Office of Civilian Requirements was cited as a good example of a relatively small sampling that yielded factual data quickly and cheaply by T. Mills Shepard of Dun Bradstreet in a recent address before the American Marketing Association.

A Tammany delegation to the Democratic National Convention favorable to renomination of President Roosevelt was said yesterday to have been assured by the election of Edward V. Loughlin as leader to succeed Michael J. Kennedy.

A junior committee under the leadership of Miss Eleanor Lansing Thomas, a debutante of this season, has been organized to assist with the current ticket-selling campaign for the benefit evening premiere showing of the new film, "Jane Eyre," at the Radio City Music Hall, proceeds from which will aid the West Side Day Nursery.

LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- In a sweep over northern France today the RAF's hottest fighter outfit -- a wing of Typhoons containing four young Canadian pilots -- destroyed twelve German planes and damaged several others without loss to themselves.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Commercial trade channels are to be utilized for exporting small and and tools to South Africa for on-military use, it was announced jointly today by the Foreign Economic Administration and the Union of South Africa Government Supply Mission.

Arnold S. Denker, former New York University star and subsequent New York State titleholder, regained the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday when he defeated Robert Willman for the second time in the supplementary series of games played between them to break the tie in the annual club tournament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Secretary Wickard tonight pictured 1944 as likely to be a year of increasing food difficulties for both sides in the war, but with the United Nations, as a whole, facing somewhat better prospects than the Axis nations, particularly Germany.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Vice President and Mrs. Wallace and Associate Justice Frank Murphy of the Supreme Court were among notables at the annual Red Mass today at the Catholic University of America.

Introduced by an hour's overture of Wagnerian music as his only identification, Adolf Hitler has delivered another speech. The occasion was the eleventh anniversary of that day of infamy on which treachery to all that was best in Germany and in our civilization brought Hitler and his foul gang to power.

Declaring that fascism is collapsing in Europe, and that Russia can scarcely be called a communistic state any longer, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at West Twenty-ninth Street, said in his sermon there yesterday morning that there was no place in America for either of these "un-Christian, un-American doctrines."

The recurrent meat shortage, disclosed by Federal Government reports released here on Saturday, will be "extremely serious" in the months just ahead, according to Claude K. McCan, president of the Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association.

The League of Composers presented its first concert of the season last night in Town Hall. The program, devoted to chamber music, enlisted the services of the Guilet String Quartet; Virginia Morley and Livingston Gearhart, duo-pianists; Fredelle Lack, violin, and Harold Shapero, composer-pianist.

With a capacity audience filling the Alvin Theatre, the sixty-second annual benefit all-star show for the Actors Fund of America took place last night. On the varied program were specialty numbers and performances by leaders in the entertainment world.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 31 -- Gen. Leonid A. Govoroff's Leningrad army racing toward the thirty-mile-wide Narva gap between the Gulf of Finland and Lake Peipus, swept up fifty more localities yesterday, capturing the rail junction of Veimarn, sixteen miles from the Estonian border, Moscow announced early today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 -With the revelation by the War Department of Japanese atrocities, RKO Radio Pictures has announced plans to rush into production "This Is My Brother," a novel by Louis Paul, which tells a story of brutal treatment suffered by five American soldiers at the hands of their Nipponese captors.

Charges that Argentine and Spanish Legation officials in Buenos Aires conspired in the pro-Nazis overthrow of the Bolivian Government Dec. 20 are contained in the State Department document that precipitated Argentina's break with Berlin and Tokio.

The body of a woman about 55 years old was found frozen in six inches of ice in the Pond in Central Park, opposite Sixtieth Street, late yesterday afternoon. No marks of violence were on the body. The woman was not immediately identified.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Major Clement R. Attlee, Deputy Prime Minister, told the British public today that people at large had heard "only a few" accounts of the terrible atrocities committed by the Japanese.

Relations of the United States with foreign nations, particularly those in Latin America., were discussed yesterday at the annual communion breakfast of the New York Province of the Federation of Newman Clubs, celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary.

ALGIERS, Jan. 30 -- In one of the most lopsided triumphs in the history of fighter combat, a fleet of Thunderbolts downed thirty-six German planes today in a furious battle over northeast Italy in which only one Thunderbolt was lost.

In an Allied victory lies the assurance of justice to the Jews and other victims of the Nazis, speakers declared at the annual meeting of the National Council of the United Palestine Appeal, held yesterday in conjunction with a conference of the Council of Organizations for Palestine at the Hotel Commodore.

The program given by Margot Rebeil, soprano, yesterday evening in Town Hall was one of novelty, thoughtfully arranged. In the solo cantata of Scarlatti, "Tu mi chiami," she displayed flexibility and regard for the style of the old music, which is florid but classic and ingratiating.

Produce dealers at the Bronx Terminal Market declared a boycott against onions yesterday. The boycott is the first aimed at that homely component of hamburger sandwiches and Spanish omelettes in an effort to halt runaway prices, according to Marcel Martino of Cuomo Martino, 11 Bronx Terminal Market, who announced the dealers' action.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 30 -- Authenticated reports of Japanese atrocities against American war prisoners exceed in agony and frightfulness the sort of thing many people normally expect from the Japanese. But China, after suffering from the horrors of Japanese conquest for nearly seven years, has learned from thousands of macabre incidents that in his terrible moments of military success the Japanese is a psychopathic sadist.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Army and Navy attack planes and fighters hit Japan's once-formidable bastion of Rabaul on New Britain for the seventh successive day Friday -- the twenty-sixth this month -- and wiped out at least thirty-one Japanese planes.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Jan. 31 (UP) -- A communique:

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Jan. 30 -- Thanks to the enlightened war policy of the Army and the work of the American Red Cross, facilities are being extended throughout the rear areas to provide rest and recreation for the men engaged in the onerous and dangerous tasks of war.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 31 -- Continuing the merciless blasting that since Thursday has torn and seared Germany with more than 6,000 tons of Allied bombs, strong formations of fighter-escorted American Flying Fortresses and Liberators yesterday struck heavy blows at Brunswick and Hanover.

The latest move in organized labor's drive for higher wages is an attempt to prove that the cost of living has risen about twice as much as the official index reveals. First, Philip Murray, president of the CIO, told a Senate committee that the cost of living had risen 50 per cent, as compared with the rise of 23.4 per cent reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

With the New York region a leader in "economic preparation for peace," its post-war outlook is highly favorable, Carl H. Henrikson, regional business consultant of the United States Department of Commerce, indicated yesterday in his fourth quarterly report for 1943.

In the twelfth week of its diamond jubilee season the Metropolitan Opera Company will begin its fifty-eighth presentation of Wagner's unabridged Ring Cycle, with "Das Rheingold" on Tuesday night, Feb. 8. George Szell will conduct "Der Ring des Nibelungen" for the first time at the Metropolitan.

CAIRO, Jan. 30 -- Maj. Gen. Ralph Royce, commander of United States forces in the Middle East, received the Distinguished Service Medal today for his work from April to August, 1943, as commander of the First Air Force, with headquarters at Mitchel Field, L.I.
LONDON, Jan. 30 (U.P.) -- The text of the speech by Adolf Hitler as broadcast by the German radio and recorded and translated by The United Press:

Some of the few women active in international councils. Miss Gabriele Rohde, a Danish citizen, has completed her work as financial consultant to the Interim Commission on Food and Agriculture established last May at the conference in Hot Springs. Va.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -President Roosevelt received a $240,000 birthday present today to help combat infantile paralysis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Administration is preparing to carry on its present food-subsidy program until November on the assumption that Congressional opponents will be unable to override a veto of a measure designed to stop price rollbacks.

Truk is the center of a Japanese front of which Rabaul and the Marshall Islands are the right and left wings. Both wings must be smashed before the main assault on the center can be organized. Both are under increasingly powerful attack, which appears to have reached the crucial stage.

Claudio Arrau, pianist, and Joseph Szigeti, violinist, gave yesterday afternoon three of Beethoven's ten sonatas for piano and violin as part of the season's Beethoven series of the New Friends of Music at Town Hall. The program consisted of the C minor, Opus 30, No. 2; the A major, Opus 12, No. 2, and the G major, Opus 96.

Latin-American credit and collection classifications during the last six months of 1943 continued the upward trend which has been in progress since July of 1940, the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau of the National Association of Credit Men reported yesterday in making public its semi-annual survey on Latin credit terms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Wayne Coy, assistant director of the budget and formerly a special assistant to President Roosevelt, is leaving government service to become a member of the Staff of the Washington Post, according to an announcement today by Harold D. Smith, director of the budget.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The Polish Government has asked the American and British Governments to define the territorial boundaries that they believe Poland should have after the war, it was learned tonight.

The rising trend in war expenditures and Treasury borrowing apparently has ended, and money market problems are beginning to change, according to a review prepared by the Bankers Trust Company, New York.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Coming from behind with two goals in the final period, the Black Hawks tonight broke the Red Wings' victory streak of six straight by defeating them, 3 to 2, before 18,261, the largest National Hockey League crowd of the season.

George Arents has made the city his debtor by the gift to the New York Public Library of his collection of four thousand volumes about tobacco. Many are of the greatest value and rarity. If to assemble them was a delight, to part with them must have been a great stroke of self-denial.

The war was responsible for one out of every five of the problems brought to the family welfare agencies in New York in the last year, it was reported yesterday by Miss Clare Touseley, as spokesman for eight if the leading private family agencies of Greater New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The two Houses of Congress prepared today for the extremely unusual procedure of simultaneously considering the same important question, that of voting by the armed forces in the November national election.

Mayor La Guardia used his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall yesterday to align himself with President Roosevelt against the proposal to have the soldiers' vote recorded on ballots prepared and sent out by the States.

Plans for new quarters for delinquent or neglected children, to replace the shelter of the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, were advanced yesterday at a conference in Mayor La Guardia's office in City Hall.

AN RAF PATHFINDER HEADQUARTERS, in England, Monday, Jan. 31 (AP) -- On a bleak expanse of English moor, which for a few kaleidoscopic minutes was a "little Berlin," there was presented a tabloid view of the awesome sights that assail German eyes when the Royal Air Force hurls down its thousands of tons of high-explosive death and destruction.

Many boxes have been taken by members of society for the sixty-eighth annual show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which will be held at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 11 and 12. The dog show this year will be a benefit for Dogs for Defense, Inc., official procurement agency for dogs for the K-9 Corps of the armed forces.

ONLY a little more than twenty miles from the northernmost tip of Manhattan Island and just across the Hudson River in Rockland County is a large and precipitous bluff locally known as The Mountain. Its total area, counting its crown and various slopes, is about twelve square miles. Near this "little, obstreperous, illogical, tumbling town" a number of celebrities from the metropolis have made their homes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Dramatic views of the United States Navy at war, as pictured by five official combat artists, drew several hundred spectators to the Corcoran Gallery of Art this afternoon for the opening of a special exhibition.

HAMPTON, Va., Jan. 30 -- Combined mid-year baccalaureate and Founder's Day service in the Memorial Church was the highlight of the observance at Hampton Institute today of the 105th birthday anniversary of Samuel Armstrong, who founded the institute in 1868.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 30 (AP) -- More than 100,000 subscribers of The Sunday Democrat and Chronicle failed to receive copies of today's editions following an unexplained dispute between the newspaper's management and a pressmen's union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Butter will be available to civilians this year at the rate of slightly more than one pound a month, which will mean about one-third pound less for the year than was available in 1943, the War Food Administration announced today.

Reorders are proving a problem on most lines, with buyers also being anxious to speed deliveries on Spring merchandise. Buyers in the market during the past week more or less concentrated on spring fillins and efforts to get assurance on deliveries, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Lack of real faith in the omnipotence of God and the divinity of Christ, "the incarnation of the godhead," is delaying the peace, Mgr. James H. Griffiths, Chancellor of the Military Ordinariate, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

More than a score of art exhibitions open this week in local museums and galleries. The Whitney Museum, which has been closed, except for its annual exhibition of contemporary American art, since its amalgamation with the Metropolitan last year, will place on view a cross-section of the painting, sculpture and graphic art from its permanent collection beginning Tuesday.

ALGIERS, Jan. 30 -- Circles close to the French Committee of National Liberation are increasingly eager to insure the widest possible recognition of the committee as the provisional authority to take over from the Allies' military authorities at a certain point in the reconquest of France.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The Royal Army Medical Corps is the only branch of the British Services in which women have completely equal rights with men in pay, rank and privilege. Several hundred women are now serving with the RAMC.

The board of governors of the League of New York Theatres and producers of current Broadway shows will meet at noon today in the league's offices, 234 West Forty-fourth Street, to discuss the threatened strike of local stagehands, which would affect thirty-three legitimate houses.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 30 (U.P.) -- Three marriages of Australian girls to two United States officers and one American Red Cross official took place over the weekend.

Nobody has pronounced a harsher judgment on Germany's policy in Europe than Hitler himself. His eleventh anniversary speech is a desperate appeal to Europe to save itself from the consequences of eleven years of Nazi aggression. It is the speech of the destroyer begging those he has tried with all his might to destroy to rise up and rescue themselves, and him, from destruction.

MALVERNE, L.I., Jan. 30 -Bare-footed and clad in a nightgown, the body of Mrs. Josephine Smith, 36 years old, of 72 Lexington Avenue, a war plant worker, was found about 10:30 o'clock this morning in the side yard of a vacant house at 32 Lexington Avenue, in the same block as her home.

A proposal to amend the law governing boxing and wrestling in this State to permit 17-year-olds to participate in ring bouts and mat events under the supervision of the State Athletic Commission will be introduced in the State Legislature tonight.

The Eversafe Insulator Company, manufacturer of plastics, bought the Texal Corporation's plant in Plainfield, N.J., consisting of an acre of land and several one-story buildings. The Cross Brown Company and Henry C. Gorell of Plainfield arranged the deal.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 30 -- The output of steel ingots rose last week one-half point to 99 per cent of rated capacity. Indications are that the same level of activity will prevail this week.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

Waste paper salvage must be stepped up so that one-third more paper is reclaimed this year than last if military and essential civilian requirements are to be met, Edwin S. Friendly, national chairman of the Victory Waste Paper campaign, said yesterday.

A minimum of 100,000 new workers, not including replacements for Selective Service withdrawals, will be required for essential war plants in this State in the first six months of 1944 to help meet demands for war materials, according to Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission.
Police swarmed in Coney Island's streets yesterday, hospitals were watched and radio alarms blared after a pedestrian had reported that a truck driver had run down and kidnapped a young girl.

LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] announced today that his Yugoslav forces had severely defeated a mixed force of Germans and Chetniks in western Bosnia and that a battle was raging in Hercegovina with an Axis contingent trying to break into Partisan-held territory.

As the wave of horror over Japanese atrocities committed on helpless American prisoners sweeps the nation some inflamed patriots are demanding that our fleet steam forthwith into Tokyo Harbor and blast that barbarian citadel off the map. But if our fleet could do this it would be there now.

OTTAWA, Jan. 30 -- Details of a new Allied secret weapon, so powerful its projectile will penetrate four inches of the finest armor plate and yet so light it can be carried easily by one man, were revealed for the first time tonight.

Dispatches from the west European front disclose that our high-altitude fighter plane, the Thunderbolt, is being used effectively for bombing purposes at low altitude. Its most recent action in this capacity was against airfields in the Netherlands from which Nazi fighter squadrons operate to intercept Allied bombers en route to Germany.

After a short interlude forced by mid-term examinations, basketball in the metropolitan area comes back full blast this week when all the teams will resume operations to continue an almost unbroken schedule until the season's end in March.
ALGIERS, Jan. 30 -- The Allies' front south of Rome became more clearly defined yesterday. The occupation of at least four villages was officially confirmed.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES DESTROYER, Off Anzio, Jan. 28 (Delayed) -- Allied supplies continue to pour into the beachhead near Rome despite almost ceaseless German bombings, which so far have been more frequent than at Salerno.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 30 (U.P.) -An Army private was said today to have confessed to the series of "Lovers' Lane" murders in which three couples in parked cars were slain at intervals of about a year in the secluded Duck Island area near here.

Activities in financial markets last week were cautious as traders awaited a clearer picture developments here and abroad. Except for a sharp upward movement in South American bonds prices of both securities and commodities fluctuated irregularly, stocks losing ground in the smallest weekly dealings this year, while bonds were generally higher and grains and cotton improved moderately.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Jan. 22 to 28 are given in the appended tabulation:

With the largest crowd of the local Eastern Hockey League season looking on, the New York Rovers enjoyed a field day at the expense of their city rivals, the Brooklyn Crescents, in the feature game of the matinee double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

In an effort to steer business through the trying post-war period and to anticipate the many problems expected to arise in connection with transition to a peacetime economy, the National Association of Manufacturers is issuing a series of five guides, the first two of which appear today, pointing up various obstacles that will have to be met and surmounted.
ALGIERS, Jan. 30 -- A communique:

Investigation by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals of the wave of deaths among pigeons here indicates, it was disclosed yesterday, that strychnine spilled in some way into an open scratch feed bin in a downtown market is responsible.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Stimulating news from Russia and Italy has fallen distinctly flat as a bull factor for the stock markets here. It is true they did make some response but it was very slight and it was evident that not only the City but also the investing public generally still was laboring under the suspense about the opening of the second front.

A report from embattled New Guinea, describing the heroism, loyalty and self-sacrifice of the Christianized natives in supporting the Allied cause was presented yesterday by the Rev. John D. Bodger, sub-dean of the Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul in Papua, and diocesan chaplain to the Bishop of New Guinea.
LONDON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Large ground floor space in 630 Fifth Avenue, in Rockefeller Center, has been leased by the Gotham Hosiery Company for occupancy about May 1 through Clark T. Chambers, broker. The space formerly was occupied by Sweden House and includes an entrance court on Fifth Avenue.

With a strong team from the United States Military Academy scheduled to compete and a sizable delegation of Big Ten performers slated to come East, the annual Millrose track and field meet at Madison Square Garden Saturday night continues to gain in stature.

Having an election during the war, and especially at the very climax of that war, may be deplored in some quarters as likely to be harmful in its distracting effect. But the American people would not have it otherwise.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30 -- The freeing of the whole stretch of main Moscow-Leningrad railroad between Tosno and Chudovo, approximately sixty-five miles long, is a gain that will have a far-reaching influence on the further conduct of the war in northwestern Russia.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Shipments of hogs to Midwestern markets were curtailed last week by the start of the system of permits at additional points. However, reports from Nebraska indicate that it will be necessary to hold back hogs as long as six weeks to prevent continued congestion at slaughtering centers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Justice Frank Murphy of the United States Supreme Court announced tonight the formation of the National Committee against Nazi Persecution and Extermination of the Jews, of which he will serve as chairman.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 30 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Reports from the fighting fronts last week again emphasized the ever-changing nature of the tactics and techniques of warfare.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 30 (AP) -Two major appointments in administrative and instructional personnel of Cornell University and establishment of a scholarship fund were announced today by President Edmund E. Day.

Lee F. Johnson, assistant commissioner of the Federal Public Housing Authority in charge of project management, leaves the Government service today to become executive vice president of the National Public Housing Conference.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Allied ground forces, slowly penetrating Japanese positions on three Burma fronts, have made slight progress at two points and fought off enemy attacks at a third, a Southeast Asia communique said today.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, told a Zionist Federation conference here today he had a "hunch" that the British White Paper of May 1, 1930, concerning Palestine would not survive the war.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 30 -- The eleventh anniversary of the accession of national socialism to power in Germany brought Adolf Hitler to the microphone at noon today for one of the briefest of his wartime pronouncements to the German people. The delivery of the speech required only twenty minutes. It was transmitted from Hitler's headquarters and was confined almost exclusively to arguing whether Germany or Soviet Russia would dominate Europe.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 30 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 30 (AP) -Two major appointments in administrative and instructional personnel of Cornell University and establishment of a scholarship fund were announced today by President Edmund E. Day.

Lee F. Johnson, assistant commissioner of the Federal Public Housing Authority in charge of project management, leaves the Government service today to become executive vice president of the National Public Housing Conference.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Allied ground forces, slowly penetrating Japanese positions on three Burma fronts, have made slight progress at two points and fought off enemy attacks at a third, a Southeast Asia communique said today.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, told a Zionist Federation conference here today he had a "hunch" that the British White Paper of May 1, 1930, concerning Palestine would not survive the war.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 30 -- The eleventh anniversary of the accession of national socialism to power in Germany brought Adolf Hitler to the microphone at noon today for one of the briefest of his wartime pronouncements to the German people. The delivery of the speech required only twenty minutes. It was transmitted from Hitler's headquarters and was confined almost exclusively to arguing whether Germany or Soviet Russia would dominate Europe.

Net asset value of American International Corporation at Dec. 31 amounted to $19,436,068, equal to $11.49 for each share of common stock after providing for outstanding debentures at face value. This compares with $7.76 a share at the close of 1942, Harry A. Arthur, president of the company, reported yesterday.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announces in the February issue of its monthly review of credit and business conditions that it has suspended its monthly production and trade indexes. The December figures, therefore, will be the last until further notice.

ADVANCED SEVENTH AAF BASE, Central Pacific, Jan. 19 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Corporal Henry B. Krush, 115-57 151st St., Jamaica, N.Y., a member of the combat and documentary photography section, Seventh AAF, won the air medal today on his twenty-third birthday, which he spent on a raft before being rescued.

It is altogether possible, according to the director of a special course in beauty technique, to apply a proper make-up at 8 in the morning (or evening) and leave it completely untouched for the next five hours, with no need to patch it up betweentimes.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 31 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Women's apparel and accessory manufacturers met in Chicago today in three separate groups, with plenty of ideas for spring and summer clothing, but not much in the way of merchandise. Interest of buyers was great, however, even though styles have been simplified further and orders allotted, and attendance at the three shows was greater than ever before.
LONDON, Jan. 31 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
ALGIERS, Jan. 31 -- A communique:

The August grand jury of Kings County, which criticized Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine for conditions in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area, handed up its final presentment yesterday, asserting that crime in the borough's "Little Harlem" had decreased greatly as a result of its criticism.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 31 -- Production of more goods in the post-war period at lower prices and better qualities was predicted here today by David R. Craig, president of the American Retail Federation, in an address before the Economic and Business Foundation.

Nine of thirty-three men who had been rounded up by the police in November, 1942, in a suspected gambling conspiracy, were relieved by General Sessions Judge George L. Donnellan of the bail on which they had been at liberty. The judge acted because of the lack of prosecution on misdemeanor charges and announced that if the prosecution were not instituted "in a reasonable time" he would dismiss the charges.

The power assumed by the Office of Price Administration, in the second revised MPR-339 issued Jan. 4, to limit the amount of branded hosiery which may be sold by individuall producers of women's rayon stockings will be the basis of a new appeal to be filed within a few days in the Emergency Court of Appeals on behalf of fourteen branded hosiery manufacturers, it was announced yesterday by O'Connor Farber, counsel for the group.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Private reports from Buenos Aires today said an Argentine Government crisis was expected in the next few days and that Gen. Arturo Rawson, recently resigned Ambassador to Brazil, had been denied permission to return to Argentina.

The one-story taxpayer at 3865 Broadway, northwest corner of 161st Street, has been purchased by Jerome C. Mayer, operator, from Samuel H. Golding. This property, on a plot 100 by 102 feet, is assessed for $200,000 and contains twelve stores. Harry Thoens Co., Inc., were the brokers.

Despite the discouraging rebuffs that have been encountered, the American Red Cross, with the approval of the Army and Navy, will persevere in its efforts to send relief supplies to the Americans who are prisoners of war in the hands of the Japanese, it was disclosed yesterday by Richard F. Allen, vice chairman of the American Red Cross.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 10 per cent last week over the like week of last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the previous week the bank had reported a gain of 6 per cent.

The board of directors of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children, at its annual meeting yesterday at the executive offices, 580 Fifth Avenue, re-elected Mrs. H. Edward Bilkey, president of the association. Mrs. Charles N. Rambo was elected first vice president, Mrs. George P. Bent 2d, was re-elected secretary, Mrs. Ludlow Bull was elected treasurer and Charles C. Jordan was re-elected assistant treasurer.

As has been the case in recent years, a performer out of Notre Dame is expected to dominate the two-mile picture on Saturday night when the annual Millrose games are run off at Madison Square Garden. He is Ensign Oliver Hunter 3d, former South Bender, who is now an athletic officer at Columbia's Midshipmen School.

With a total of 134 sports figures included in the pool to date, the late Lou Gehrig, Yankees' famous slugger, leads in the sports popularity balloting being conducted by the Sports Committee of the Fourth War Loan drive, it was announced yesterday by the War Finance Committee for New York.
