A brief item in our education columns last Sunday took note of the fact that no magic formula has been discovered for teaching foreign languages. The reference was to the Army Specialized Training courses in the colleges.
Tonight's events: Sidney Foster, piano recital, Carnegie-Hall, 8:30 o'clock; Henri Temianka, violin recital, Town Hall, 8:30.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month dropped to the smallest total since last October, and turnover was slightly below the corresponding month in 1943. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 17,811,394 shares, compared with 19,526,660 in the previous month, and with 18,032,142 in January, 1943.

With canned or bottled apple-sauce selling for sixteen points a pound tin or jar, there may be considerable interest in a new quick-frozen form of this fruit that is unrationed. It is a product of Frosted Foods Sales Corporation, under the trade name of Birds Eye.

ALGIERS, Jan. 31 -- The United States Government has given formal assurance to the French Committee of National Liberation that it will not again deal with the Vichy Government or with any Frenchmen who have collaborated with Vichy, it was understood today.

Walter L. Rice, president of the Reynolds Mining Corporation, in an address yesterday before the New York Institute of Finance in the New York Stock Exchange, said that a 1,000,000-ton aluminum industry will look small to this country within the next ten years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- State laws preventing public street sales by minor children do not violate the Constitution's standards of religious freedom or the basic rights of parenthood, the Supreme Court held today in a 5-to-4 decision on a case brought by the Jehovah's Witnesses against the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31 -- After nine consecutive losing favorites, A.W. Wentzers Spook Ship rescued the form players by the comparatively narrow margin of a half length in the Surfside Purse at Hialeah today and returned $4.40 in the machines.

ALGIERS, Jan. 31 -- No confirmation is available here tonight of the London report that the Germans are evacuating Rome, but it can be said flatly that if such a report is true it would not be a great surprise.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- An increase of 45 cents a net ton for anthracite coal for February was ordered today by the Office of Price Administration to compensate for added costs of production caused by the necessity of operating the mines seven days a week for four consecutive weeks during the month.

LONDON, Jan. 31 (U.P.) -- Three widely separated Partisan offensives beat against the Germans in Yugoslavia today and there were indications that the forces of Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] were meeting success in their drive to choke off the supply, route to Nazi troops defending Banja Luka, in eastern Bosnia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Tacit acceptance by the House of Representatives of its Appropriations Committee's action in cutting $1,000,000 from the requested budget of the Radio Intelligence Division of the Federal Communications Commission featured passage today of the $8,000,000 Independent Offices Bill through the lower house.

Paced by heavy tanks, American troops have broken into the Gustav Line and outflanked Cassino, central anchor of the German southern front in Italy. The attack was made through flood waters of the Rapido River which had been turned across our supply road by German engineers.

The United Jewish Appeal announced yesterday the opening of a campaign for $32,000,000 during 1944 among Jews in this country, the money to be used for overseas war relief, reconstruction work in Palestine and refugee assistance in the United States.

Edward V. Loughlin formally took over yesterday the leadership of Tammany Hall with a public promise that "no act of mine, as leader or otherwise," will cause anyone "to regret the honor confered upon me."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- A strong indictment of Japan for torturing and executing American prisoners, for not abiding by the terms of the Geneva Prisoners of War Convention and for not living up to ordinary standards of decency in its treatment of...

THE return of night baseball to our town will mean a hypodermic shot in the arm to the exchequers of the Giants and the Dodgers, both of whom can stand it. As a matter of fact, who can't? The two clubs will have fourteen games each and that will add up to considerable increases in attendance and income.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 26:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- In order to provide an "authoritative" voice for American shipping interests in their program for an adequate post-war merchant marine, it was announced today that the National Federation of American Shipping has been organized with headquarters here.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Governor Dewey, by implication, disputed today Mayor La Guardia's declaration that the aid to cities planned by his administration was insufficient in so far as it applied to New York City.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 31 (AP) -- A new celestial phenomenon, a star flattened at its poles, was reported today by Dr. J.S. Paraskevopoulos, director of the Harvard Observatory at Bloemfontein.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Navy communique 500:

Showing a decrease of $113,601,050, the tentative total of assessed valuation of taxable real estate and special franchises in New York City has been set at $15,897,623,006 for the fiscal year 1944-45, William Wirt Mills, president of the Tax Commission, will report to Mayor La Guardia today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- Anticipating a great post-war migration of factory workers from industrial areas into residential counties such as Westchester, several members of the Westchester Board of Supervisors spoke heatedly at a board meeting this afternoon in favor of seeking amendments to the State Settlement Law so that persons could not go permanently on relief here after only a year's residence.

YORK, Pa., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Eleven top officials of the York Safe and Lock Company, among them Charles F. Sioberg of New York, president and general manager, have been relieved of their duties and dropped from the payroll since the Navy took over operation of the plants last week, it was announced today.

The stock market completed yesterday the first month of the new year with moderate gains from the levels for the opening days and on the day the list closed irregularly higher. Although the average gains were modest, the character of the buying showed decided improvement over recent sessions, with the investment stocks in greater demand.

New issues of corporate and local Government bonds offered here for public subscription in January aggregated $104,796,000 for ten separate flotations, the smallest amount for the month since 1940, when $100,117,000 in thirty-three issues were marketed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- About 12,000 out of 46,000 employes of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company's yards at Kearny and Port Newark, N.J., get a new "escape" period under the 1944 maintenance-of-membership contract, according to a ruling today by the Shipbuilding Commission of the National War Labor Board.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Grain markets were somewhat unsettled today on the Board of Trade, wheat holding within narrow limits with traders awaiting developments in regard to sales of flour next month. It is expected that mills will report during the next few days disposal of the bulk of their February output, especially if Government demand continues as active as it was in January.

ALGIERS, Jan. 31 -- When all the figures were in for yesterday's 900 sorties by Allied planes, it was confirmed that the Germans had lost sixty-two planes -- the highest twenty-four-hour toll in the Italian campaign. The total included the thirty-six shot down by Thunderbolts in the victory announced last night.

Net premiums written last year by the United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company of Baltimore totaled $44,027,305, the largest volume on record. Net income from investments and rents was $1,631,073, the forty-eighth annual report disclosed yesterday.

Following ten months of preliminary study of American-Chinese economic relations, announcement was made yesterday of the formation of the China-American Council of Commerce and Industry to interest American business in the post-war development of China.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A communique:

Temple Israel of Great Neck, L.I., has purchased the former Von Bernuth property having a frontage of 176 feet on the south side of Old Mill Road with a depth of 433 feet. A brick building of Colonial type will be erected on the site from plans by Irving Lurie.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Feb. 1 -- Gen. Leonid A. Govoroff's forces smashed forward seven more miles yesterday and are battling in the suburbs of Kingisepp, only eight miles from the border of Estonia.

Drawing on its vast supply of specialized information spanning millions of years, the American Museum of Natural History is helping the Army and the Navy in many ways to fight a modern war, Albert E. Parr, director of the museum, told its board of directors at their seventy-fifth annual meeting last night at the museum.

The War Refugee Board created by President Roosevelt has a difficult task before it, as the executive order points out. The task is to do what can be done, consistent with fighting and winning the war, to rescue as many as possible of the persecuted minorities of Europe from Nazi savagery.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The mighty United States Navy has unwittingly pulled a "fast one" which has given rise to considerable perplexity here but has not in the least hindered the war effort.
LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Japanese Government spokesman, Sadao Iguchi, was quoted in a DNB, German official news agency, dispatch from Tokyo which was broadcast tonight, as saying that United States and British disclosures of Japanese cruelties to Allied war prisoners were "a cloak for cruelties committed by the Allies themselves."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today to Congress that the agency was rapidly working itself out of its biggest job -- making public utility systems conform to the standards of the so-called death sentence clause of the Holding Company Act of 1935.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Jan. 31 -- Today again it was a question of slow probing through the wooded slopes of the Mount Cairo and Monte Villa areas and gradually prying a passage north.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 31 -- A gigantic air armada and powerful supporting fleets are taking the Battle of the Pacific into the enemy's domain today as action is reported still raging in the Marshall Islands.

Former Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the American Jewish Committee, telegraphed yesterday to Associate Justice Frank Murphy of the Supreme Court that "the formation of the National Committee Against Nazi Persecution and Extermination of the Jews will be commended by right-thinking men of all faiths and creeds."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (U.P.) George N. Briggs, suspended aide to the Secretary of Interior, Harold L. Ickes, pleaded not guilty today to indictments charging him with being the forger of the "Harry Hopkins" letter and with using the mails to defraud.

In its no-quarter fight against black markets, New York City's Department of Purchase is refusing to buy poultry at more than ceiling prices. For more than six months, except on special occasions, the city has bought no poultry for its hospital and other institutions, in which it is an important item of diet.

AT THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, Jan. 31 -- In the past forty-eight hours American troops have run into some of the toughest fighting in the beachhead since the landings, and are knocking out enemy tanks and self-propelled guns with hand grenades.

While skiing is looked upon by hundreds of thousands as a sport and a means of relaxation, it is an important part of the nation's physical fitness program. The Army has taken this civilian activity and made it a salient part of its training program for its mountaineers, who must not only be expert in the ordinary infantry training the regular GI goes through but also a specialist on skis and on the mountainside.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 31 -- While welcoming the strong stand Washington and London have taken with regard to Generalissimo Francisco Franco, Spanish Republican leaders here said today that the oil embargo must be accompanied by other restrictions, both of an economic and political nature, if the United Nations intended to cause the fall of the Spanish dictator.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 31 (U.P.) -- American-trained Chinese troops have wiped out the equivalent of one Japanese regiment -- 3,000 to 4,000 men -- since starting their drive in the Hukawng Valley of northern Burma last Oct. 26, Brig. Gen. Haydon L. Boatner, Chief of Staff of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, said today.

BARI, Italy, Jan. 29 (Delayed), (Reuter) -- Count Carlo Sforza, delivering the concluding speech at the Congress of Political Parties here today, denounced King Victor Emmanuel as "a stupid, vile, abject criminal monarch" and his government as "a putrid little corpse."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Japanese are bolstering morale at home by reports that the spirits of Japanese slain in battle are resisting the American fighting forces.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Governor Dewey, submitting his second State budget to the Legislature tonight, hewed strictly to the conservative fiscal line he had previously laid down, both as to taxes and expenditures. He proposed for the fiscal year starting April 1 expenditures of $371,800,000 and estimated revenue at $398,000,000.

Like all the "secret weapons" of which we have heard since the outbreak of war, the radio-controlled bomber of the Germans turns out to be no secret at all. It is nothing but an enlargement of the German winged, radio-controlled rocket bomb described by Mr. Churchill last year.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 -- Pravda printed another Cairo rumor story today, but this is one anti-Soviet in character concerning alleged plans for Sovietizing the Balkans, and it is the subject of a bitter satire by David Zaslavsky, whose last major article ridiculed Wendell L. Willkie.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Senate and House conferees today agreed upon a tax bill estimated to yield $2,315,800,000 in new revenue after the Administration won a sweeping victory in the struggle over the renegotiation provisions of the measure.

Deposits in mutual savings banks in the United States increased $1,086,067,095 in 1943 to a new record peak of $11,707,025,048, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday. This was the widest gain of any year in the 128-year history of savings banking in this country.

The announcement yesterday of three additional film arrivals brings the total of this week's newcomers to four. On Thursday "Jane Eyre," Twentieth Century-Fox's adaptation of the Charlotte Bronte classic, will have its world premiere at the Radio City Music Hall.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Josiah W. Bailey, admittedly the most ichthyophagous citizen of Raleigh, N.C., who ever attained a seat in the United States Senate, asked Congress a $20,000 question today.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Feb. 1 -- Thirty-six more Japanese planes were destroyed at Rabaul Saturday as Admiral William F. Halsey's fliers kept up their incessant pounding of the Japanese Southwest Pacific bastion on New Britain Island.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 1 -- The elimination of Berlin as the political and military capital of Germany seems imminent. The city was hammered by another 1,680 tons of bombs Sunday night in the Royal Air Force's third great attack in four nights and has been burning since Thursday.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 -- Pravda described today the Katyn Forest funeral yesterday, the reburial of 11,000 Polish officers and soldiers at which officers of Polish units denounced as lies the German charges that the Soviet Union had murdered the men.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- To adult civilians, and to veterans of World War I who are not again in uniform, one of the mysteries of the present global conflict is the small number of casualties, actual and in relation to those of 1914-18. Several explanations have been offered by persons with sufficient knowledge and battle experience to make them.

I should like to call to the attention of your readers the leading article in the October issue of The Monthly Labor Review, official publication of the United States Department of Labor, entitled "The Level of Factory Wages in Wartime."

A Washington dispatch to this newspaper yesterday called attention to the fact that recently the President has sharply curtailed the number of his conferences with the press. This has been due largely to his illness, but in all of 1943 the President held only fifty-nine press conferences, compared with ninety-six the year before.

The third year of the Manhattan Beach Training Station in Brooklyn, largest Coast Guard training base in the United States, will begin today. In the two years of its existence more than 50,000 men have been trained there, it was announced yesterday.

Eugene Ormandy, music director and conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, will go to Australia at the end of the orchestra's regular season as the first official "lend-lease musical artist" under arrangements made by the Office of War Information and the Australian Broadcasting Commission, according to an announcement yesterday by Macklin Marrow, Music Director of the Overseas Branch of the OWI.

A loan exhibition of paintings by the nineteenth-century American artist Worthington Whittredge opened yesterday at the Macbeth Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street. It will continue through Feb. 19.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- A group of holders of fifty-year 5 per cent mortgage gold bonds, Series A, due February, 1975, of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company, petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission today to modify the plan for reorganizing the company as set forth in its second supplemental report and order of last Dec. 6.

Lloyd's, the old London association of underwriters, ship brokers and insurance brokers, has decided to liberalize its qualification for membership to permit affiliation of subjects of the British Dominions, the Colonies and India.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Civilians will have to make shift with a limited supply of alarm clocks again this year because no substantial increase in production can be effected without interference with war work, according to a report submitted to the War Production Board by members of the Non-Jeweled Clock and Watch Manufacturers Industry Advisory Committee.
ALGIERS, Jan. 31 -- Allied troops pushing inland from the widening beachhead below Rome have beaten off a German counter-blow three miles from Cisterna, it was officially announced today.

AT A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION, in England, Jan. 31 (U.P.) -- Unable to knock the sturdy American heavy bombers out of the sky with their gunfire, battle-crazed Nazi fighter pilots deliberately rammed several of the big planes to send attackers and attacked to earth in a thousand pieces, Flying Fortress crew members who took part in Saturday's big air battle over Frankfort-on-the-Main reported today.

Aubrey Pankey, Negro baritone, gave a widely varied program at Carnegie Hall last night under the auspices of the National Negro Congress before a good-sized audience, which was enthusiastic in its response. Opening with Beethoven's "Adelaide" and "Neue Liebe, Neues Leben," Mr. Pankey continued the first portion of the program with a Schubert group, which was followed by numbers by Rachmaninoff, Thomas Dunhill and Frank Bridge.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature accompanying his budget for the fiscal year beginning April 1, 1944:

The Museum of Modern Art announces the appointment of Rene d'Harnoncourt as director of the newly established Department of Manual Industry. The function of this department will be to study the potential contribution of manual industry to the modern world and to assist in its development.

After an early advance with the March position reaching a new seasonal high, the cotton market in the late trading yesterday lost virtually all of its early gains under a flurry of hedge selling and profit-taking. On the New York Cotton Exchange final quotations were off 2 points to up 2 points, with the gains in the May and July positions.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The British are beginning to catch the election fever. They never come down with it as badly as we do, and they have a very mild case at the moment, but at least they are getting around to discussing a reform of their electoral system in case they should decide to put an end to this nine-year-old Parliament.

Found critically injured in the roadway of the 153d Street railroad bridge over the Mott Haven yards between Park and Sheridan Avenues, the Bronx, at 7 o'clock last night, Allen Apter, 6 years old, of 711 North Cummings Street, Los Angeles, Calif., died four hours later at Morrisania Hospital.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The Luftwaffe's fighter command, the most potent aerial weapon against Allied invasion in Hitler's armory, has sustained a major defeat in the last three days. It has lost 268 planes under the guns of American bombers and fighters based on Britain and Italy, 255 over Saturday and Sunday and thirteen more today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Casualties for all the country's armed forces since the start of the war total 146,186, including 33,153 dead, 49,518 wounded, 33,617 missing and 29,898 taken prisoner, the Office of War Information reported tonight on the basis of the latest tabulations by the War and Navy Departments.

Hollywood design has entered a new and constructive era, in the opinion of Edith Head, premiere designer for Paramount, who arrived in New York yesterday. Her remark was brought forth in a discussion of the extravagant clothes that were made for the screen version of "Lady in the Dark," starring Ginger Rogers.

Larry Anzalone, Brooklyn middleweight, outpointed Marvin Bryant of Dallas, Tex., in the feature bout of eight rounds before a 2,900 crowd at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The victor weighed 157 pounds while the Texan scaled 162 1/4.

With the drive for corporate subscriptions to the Fourth War Loan opening officially today, seven life insurance companies "beat the gun" yesterday by announcing combined subscriptions of $681,000,000. Other large concerns were helping to get the corporate drive off to a running start, and sales to individuals continued to pile up unprecedented totals.

The seventh annual National Invitation Basketball Tournament will open Thursday, March 16, in Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday by John Coffey of Fordham, chairman of the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Basketball Committee, which will sponsor the tourney.

When Adolf Hitler poses as the defender of "European culture" against "the Russian Colossus," as he did on Sunday, he is, of course, making one more desperate attempt to drive a wedge into the unity of the Allied nations. He is appealing to the old fears and suspicions of Russia.

First nighters are hereby advised that next week's calendar holds three events. There will be a conflict on Monday night, though, what with the premiere of "Take It As It Comes," a satirical comedy, at the Forty-eighth Street, and the return of "Porgy and Bess" at the City Center for two weeks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Abbott Laboratories, manufacturer of pharmaceutical products, announced today that it proposed to offer 94,439 shares of common stock at $45 a share to common stockholders at the rate of one new share for each eight shares held.

For the first time in forty-six years, or since Staten Island became part of the Greater City, it will have no municipal justices today, and to make matters worse Mayor F.H. La Guardia does not plan to fill the vacancies at present.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- A new campaign is about to be launched in certain Southwest Pacific islands that may have an important bearing on future military operations. It is designed to protect the United Nations forces and the local populations against malaria.

TRENTON, Jan. 31 -- Judge Walter D. Van Riper of the Essex County Common Pleas Court was confirmed promptly today by the New Jersey Senate as Attorney General after his nomination was forwarded by Gov. Walter E. Edge.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 31 -- Edward Small, United Artists producer, who in recent years has filmed six Alexandre Dumas stories has announced that he will produce "Edmund Dantes" this summer. He intends to make the picture after producing one from another Dumas novel, "Caliostro," for which he has opened negotiations with Charles Boyer.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 (AP) -- A blare of trumpets and a toast in vodka to President Roosevelt's health highlighted Moscow's first Presidential birthday ball last night at the Spasso House, Ambassador W. Averill Harriman's residence.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- British Government issues continued today to be favorably influenced by last week's announcement that the 5 per cent conversion loan would be repaid. Business was fairly active and most stocks improved.

WASHINGTON, JAN. 31 -- Assurance that industry itself will have a considerable voice in production shifts which will occur under reconversion was seen by business men here today in the provisions of a general administrative order by which the War Production Board set out in a single regulation the policies to govern the use of industry committees as advisory groups to WPB.
I am writing this letter to THE TIMES as one of its readers and feel that its publication may help.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Proposed limitation of debate after a week's voteless consideration of servicemen's voting programs was blocked in the Senate late today as new compromise moves marked a situation which left the outcome of the upper house fight, in the minds of members of contesting factions, close and uncertain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- While declaring herself against the Equal Rights Amendment which was endorsed last week by Vice President Wallace, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt suggested today that the "whole list of discriminatory laws be reviewed."

To bring about a settlement of pending tax litigation and future tax problems as well as reduction of the system's fixed charges, a plan of merger for the Lackawanna Railroad Company of New Jersey into the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad has been agreed to by conferees representing both roads, it was announced here yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Hog receipts were higher today than they were a week ago when the permission-to-market plan went into effect, and approximately 9,000 head remain unsold.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The successes of United States submarines listed today were announced by the Navy with the usual brevity given to reports of submarine activity -- no mention of time, place or details. A possibility, however, is that the three transports and some of the eleven other ships were carrying men and supplies to enemy bases in the Marshall Islands.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (U.P.) -- Text of the State Department's statement on Japanese treatment of war prisoners:...

ABOARD A UNITED STATES WARSHIP, in the North Atlantic -- The table on which this is being written is lashed down, as is most everything else in the cabin. The floor is tilting first to the right and then to the left -- only they call it starboard and port out here -- like a room in a Coney Island fun house.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 31 -- Throughout the Balkans the German Army and secret police are being seriously harassed by the growing number of Partisans and underground movements.

The Treasury Department has begun an intensive check-up on Cuban and Mexican "gin" at the various ports of entry and, according to preliminary results, the majority of samples tested do not warrant the use of the descriptive term, is was learned yesterday.

IT would be easy to build a quite conventional theory about the collapse of France on certain excerpts from Jean Malaquais' "War Diary."* For here we have the picture of the army that didn't believe in itself, the generals who had antiquated ideas of war, the equipment that would have done very well in 1917, the pressure groups incapable of suspending their picayune squabbles in the face of the German enemy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- States have power to prevent the transportation of intoxicating liquors when the purpose is to break Federal laws and those of another State, the Supreme Court held today in a Virginia case. The decision was unanimous.

The Atlantic Refining Company and its subsidiaries cleared $10,688,000 in 1943, or $3,888,000 more than the 1942 profit of $6,800,000, the annual report of the company disclosed yesterday. Both figures are after interest, depreciation and taxes, as well as a deduction of $2,000,000 in each year for a reserve for wartime and post-war contingencies.

Enlistment of parents and young persons in the fight on juvenile delinquency was urged yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Lower West Side Council of Social Agencies in Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street.

Cuban advertising volume has been reduced by 40 per cent since the outbreak of the war because of the acute shortages of consumer goods and the extreme difficulty in obtaining newsprint supplies from the United States, Mariano Guastella, managing director of Publicidad Guastella, one of the largest advertising agencies in Havana, said yesterday.

Accused of selling scotch whisky above ceiling prices, Popper-Morson Co., wholesale liquor dealers of 630 Fifth Avenue, was cited yesterday by the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Bureau of Internal Revenue to show cause why its permit should not be revoked.

ST. COME, P.Q., Jan. 31 -- In this French-Canadian town and in dozens of others near by today there may be seen hundreds of able-bodied young man loafing on the streets, in garages and in stores, while a few miles away over the American border manpower is so scarce that wood, vitally needed for munitions and pulp, cannot be cut and taken to the mills.

All loyal Americans want wholeheartedly to back up our armed forces as they fight on the many fronts throughout the world. Through the purchase of War Bonds to the limit of our ability we shall do our bit toward providing the vital arms and equipment which our soldiers, sailors and marines must have to carry on.
Alexander P. de Seversky, author of "Victory Through Air Power," will speak on air power at Town Hall tomorrow morning.

Accused of selling scotch whisky above ceiling prices, Popper-Morson Co., wholesale liquor dealers of 630 Fifth Avenue, was cited yesterday by the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Bureau of Internal Revenue to show cause why its permit should not be revoked.

ST. COME, P.Q., Jan. 31 -- In this French-Canadian town and in dozens of others near by today there may be seen hundreds of able-bodied young man loafing on the streets, in garages and in stores, while a few miles away over the American border manpower is so scarce that wood, vitally needed for munitions and pulp, cannot be cut and taken to the mills.

All loyal Americans want wholeheartedly to back up our armed forces as they fight on the many fronts throughout the world. Through the purchase of War Bonds to the limit of our ability we shall do our bit toward providing the vital arms and equipment which our soldiers, sailors and marines must have to carry on.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration disclosed to a Truman sub-committee of the Senate and to New England and New York lumbermen today that it was increasing ceiling prices 6 per cent on Northeastern hardwood, but the Senators and operators promptly insisted that it be regarded only as an "interim" boost and demanded at least 15 per cent.

A plan for pooling baseball material against emergency caused by the operation of the Selective Service Law probably will be the most important topic discussed when baseball's club owners and executives get together Saturday at the call of Commissioner Landis for a general discussion of the situation in which the game now finds itself.
Alexander P. de Seversky, author of "Victory Through Air Power," will speak on air power at Town Hall tomorrow morning.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1--The Supreme Soviet late tonight unanimously approved a proposal by Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff for major changes in the Soviet constitutional system under which each of the sixteen constituent republics will form its own army formations and have separate diplomatic representation abroad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Several minor misunderstandings between the Canadian and United States authorities about the supply of Canadian pulpwood, pulp and paper to this country have been ironed out during talks between Donald Gordon, Canadian Price Controller, and agency heads here in the last few days.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 1 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Running to a grass course mark that may make him a favorite for next Saturday's Miami Beach Handicap, Grasshopper II today captured the Palms Purse in a bitter finish with African Sun that needed the camera and all of the judges to decide.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick sold yesterday to a syndicate of banks of this city, by allotment, an issue of $25,000,000 of New York City revenue bonds. The issue is dated Feb. 2, with $10,000,000 maturing on April 17, and $15,000,000 on April 24, 1944. It was sold on an 0.50 per cent basis.

Passage of the Scanlon-Dawson bill for establishment of a permanent Fair Employment Practice Commission, with power to enforce its decisions, was urged yesterday at a conference of leaders of the National Council for a Permanent FEPC in the offices of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, 1710 Broadway.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet press and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Manager Leo (Lippy) Durocher of the Dodgers has been delayed on his trip overseas to entertain service men, but expects to be on his way anytime now.

LONDON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Diplomats studying American and British relations with Spain speculated tonight that something was in the wind awaiting a final decision since Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden did not make an expected statement on the subject today to the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Whether Great Britain should seek in her own Commonwealth or on the Continent of Europe the added strength that would enable her to hold her own in the post-war world with Russia, the United States and China is the problem to which the much-debated speech by Viscount Halifax in Toronto last week was designed to find an answer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The first atrocity posters printed by the Army in this war will soon be displayed in factories throughout the United States.
ALGIERS, Feb. 1 -- A communique:

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The city of Berlin, until lately the heart of Hitler's great military empire, is dying under the British bombing assault, which in January devoted about 10,000 tons of missiles to the destruction of the Reich capital in six great assaults.

On May 25, 1925, a catastrophe occurred in the heavens. A star exploded, threw out shells of glowing gas and shone with a new brilliance. Astronomers called it Nova Pictoris. Such explosions occur frequently -- thirty every year in the great nebula of Andromeda alone. Why they should occur nobody knows.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War iFood Administration follows:

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 1 (U.P.) -- American-trained Chinese troops, in the greatest victory of their fourteen-week-old drive in northern Burma, have captured the important Tanai River ferry station of Taro, at the southwestern edge of the Hukawng Valley, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The long-delayed clemency hearing in the case of Louis Buchalter, otherwise known as Lepke, is scheduled to take place in the Executive chamber in the State Capitol tomorrow, starting at 10:30 A.M. Heard at the same time will be the pleas of Louis Capone and Emanuel Weiss, whose executions were stayed repeatedly by Governor Dewey while Lepka, convicted with them of the same racket murder, was out of State custody.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 -- Warner Brothers announced today plans for a picture based on the colorful show business life of the late Sime Silverman, founder of the New York theatrical newspaper, Variety. The film will reach the screen as "Mr. Broadway," the title of a series of anecdotal articles by Abel Green, present editor of the publication.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The proposed cut of $7,500,000 in State aid for education in Governor Dewey's budget has become its most controversial item, probably the only major one that stands a chance of being changed.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- A bill requiring equal pay for women in New York State doing the same work as men was introduced in the Legislature today, with Assemblywoman Jane H. Todd, Westchester Republican, sponsoring the measure in the Assembly, and Senator Alexander A. Falk, Manhattan Democrat, acting in the Senate.
PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 1 -- Tremendous American amphibious forces have invaded the Marshall Islands and established beachheads in bitter fighting on islands of the Kwajalein Atoll.

Jay Otis Ball, who has just retired as president of the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association, has been named managing director of the Council for Industrial Government and Public Relations, with headquarters in the Chrysler Building.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- A proposal to set up a division of assessment review in the executive department was offered today in a bill by Senator William Bewley, Lockport Republican, as a means of obtaining "an impartial, inexpensive and prompt review of valuations placed on property by the various subdivisions of the State Government.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff's statement today to the Supreme Soviet as translated into English and broadcast by Tass, official Soviet news agency.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALTA, Feb. 1 -- The question of censorship in the war theatres remains a subject of key importance -- as it has been since the war started -- to the American people, who are anxious for accurate news.

Whether New York City's Purchase Department is boycotting the poultry market rather than pay black market prices, or whether the poultry trade is boycotting the City of New York may be clarified this morning by the response to the Purchase Department's invitation for bids on 25,000 pounds of poultry.

Two men who made a business of cashing checks, and were in the habit of stationing themselves conveniently near the main postoffice to accommodate postal employes, were held up and robbed of $19,000 that they had brought in a taxicab to Ninth Avenue and Thirtieth Street to start business at 8 A.M. yesterday, they reported to the police.

The first industry-wide retirement fund in this country, that of the New York coat and suit industry, covering 30,000 workers, members of the Cloakmakers Union, an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, was launched last night at a dinner at the Hotel McAlpin attended by representatives of the industry, the union and the Government

ALGIERS, Feb. 1 -- The program of tearing up airfields in northeastern Italy and southern Austria at which German planes en route from other areas to the Balkan invasion beaches could refuel continued yesterday. Heavy bombers smashed Udine and Aviano in Italy and Klagenfurt in Austria.

TRENTON, Feb. 1 -- Opposition arguments at legislative hearings today to the proposed new State Constitution were more limited than anticipated, leading New Jersey legislative leaders to believe the public generally would support the new charter at the November election.

As the waiting list of city girls who want to be Girl Scouts neared a record total of 8,000, the Greater New York Council of the organization opened yesterday a month's campaign to find and train women to be troop leaders. The shortage of such leaders is the only draw- back to enlisting the girls in the organization.

Mayor La Guardia has asked the Office of Price Administration to reject "unqualifiedly" the petition of New York City landlords for a blanket increase of at least 10 per cent in housing rents, it became known last night.

After being "told" by the marines -- specifically Lieut. Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, commandant of the Marine Corps -- Wall Street yesterday "told" it to Hitler and Hirohito by subscribing for $103,889,600 in bonds of the Fourth War Loan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democrat, of New York, acting for Senator Taft and himself, introduced a resolution today advocating that the good offices of the United States be utilized on behalf of free and unlimited entry of Jews into Palestine for the establishment of a Jewish commonwealth.

The most formidable barrier standing between the Allies and successful invasion of the European Continent is the German fighter force. The notion that Hitler went into large-scale fighter plane production exclusively for the defense of his industries against bombing is fallacious. These fighters will also be of major importance to the Germans in their attempt to smash the projected invasion.

Warren Lockwood, Federal Housing Administration director of New Jersey, has notified Abner H. Ferguson, Commissioner of the FHA, that the probable construction volume in the State under privately financed auspices during the first year following the removal of wartime restrictions will be about 12,000 housing units.

The recent food and Ultra conferences should be followed by a conference dealing with the problems of displaced persons. We need desperately three things: a population census at the earliest possible moment; a policy toward the migration question, or preferably toward the whole complex of population; and a United Nations Population and Migration Authority to administer the policy.
LONDON, Feb. 1 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

To the Belasco this evening comes "Decision." It represents Edward Chodorov's warning about the lurking dangers on the home front and tells what a courageous high-school principal did to combat them. In Boston, where the play was tested last week, Elliot Norton of that city's Post went so far as to say "it may well become the 'Uncle Tom's Cabin' of our time."

SHUMPI UTO was a very contented young man up to the last fifteen meters of the Olympic 400-meter swimming championship race at Berlin in 1936. He was about to bring further glory to Japan and the Emperor. That hulking American, Jack Medica, had trailed him all the way -- sometimes very badly, too -- and the elated Nipponese was about to claim victory.
ALGIERS, Feb. 1--Smashing ahead against furious resistance, American troops have driven into the suburbs of Cisterna, the most vital choke-point in the German supply system below Rome.

In itself a vivid world, a wonder-house of earth, sea and sky, the Museum of Natural History is one of our best and greatest universities. In one way or another it reaches many millions of people in the course of a year. Its versatility and adaptability to new situations are remarkable.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Mellon of Convent, N.J., have come to the Carlyle.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Gilt-edge issues continued to go ahead on the Stock Exchange here today. Both war loans, the 3 1/2 per cent conversion, the 2 1/2 per cent national war bonds and the 3 per cent redemption issues all showed improvement.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- A defense of private industry in general and Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., in particular was made today by Lord McGowan, chairman of the board of the firm, in Glasgow.

WITH A CARRIER TASK FORCE, Off Wotje, Jan. 29 (Delayed) -- The greatest battle fleet in world history is closing inexorably with giant-like claws upon the Marshalls to complete the greatest over-all naval job ever attempted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Over the protest of Senator Barkley of Kentucky, majority leader, that "if it takes as long to beat the Germans and the Japs as to get a decision on the soldier vote bill, the war will last until the Presidential election of 1972," the Senate debated on the Green-Lucas measure all day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The attack of Izvestia, official organ of the Soviet Government, on the Vatican, was characterized last night by Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the American Catholic University as an attempt to confuse the political atmosphere in Europe in preparation for a separate peace by Moscow with the German Army after the expected overthrow of Hitler.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 -- The first public disclosure that the Engineers Public Service Company was contemplating a program leading to its eventual dissolution was made today by its president, Donald C. Barnes, in testimony before a trial examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Warning that the factors which boosted fur volume in 1943 may be lacking this year, Louis F. White, president of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., urged a conservative production and raw skin purchase policy upon the industry at the annual meeting of the organization last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The island-hopping strategy so far adopted in the Pacific must be continued to win victory over Japan, because "if there are any short cuts, we have a long way to go to find them," Lieut. Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, commandant of the Marine Corps, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the North Atlantic Area Conference of the American Red Cross in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Joseph C. Grew, former American Ambassador to Japan, declared that words were inadequate to describe his "fiery rage" when he was asked today for his views of the atrocities reported committed by the Japanese military against American and other prisoners in the Philippines and elsewhere.

Realty men appeared yesterday to find scant comfort in the report of William Wirt Mills, president of the City Tax Commission, showing a decrease of $113,601,050 in the tentative total of assessed valuation of taxable real estate and special franchises in the five boroughs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Mobile surgical groups organized within the Army Medical Corps were credited by the War Department today with a large share of credit for the record of fewer than 3 per cent of wounded who reach hospitals in this war die, compared with 7.4 per cent of wounded who died in the first World War.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 1 -- Dr. Eugene E. Agger, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, reported today progress in liquidating defunct banks in New Jersey and predicted that by the end of the present year only one bank will remain in control of the department for liquidation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The War Production Board acted today to make available upper leather needed in the manufacture of infants', children's and misses' shoes.

With the arrival of February yesterday, an icy wind roared down on New York City, bringing back freezing temperatures after several days of thaw and near-thaw. The old New England saying, "When the days begin to lengthen, the cold begins to strengthen," seemed to be borne out as the Weather Bureau predicted that the mercury would drop to about 10 above early today.

Plans for the series of ring battles designed to establish an undisputed world champion in the lightweight division yesterday underwent an unexpected change. Because he is anticipating a call from his draft board within the next month and is eager to have boxing matters adjusted before entering the greater fight, Beau Jack, recognized as champion by the New York State Athletic Commission, requested an advance in the bout dates to meet the hey conditions.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Registration figures indicated today that there will be more State motor vehicles running this year than last, despite Governor Dewey's implied budget prediction to the contrary.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 1 (U.P.) -- Alva Bradley, one of organized baseball's frankest magnates, advised major league owners today to suspend operation for the duration rather than present "a low form of comedy" during the 1944 season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Eight hundred New York City concerns have already made definite plans for post-war expansion and improvement, calling for an aggregate expenditure of $1,035,000,000, three-quarters of it in the first post-war year, Mayor La Guardia stated today before a House committee studying post-war problems.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- John J. McDonough, Mayor of St. Paul, testified today that his city contemplated a $36,000,000 to $37,000,000 post-war program but that Federal assistance was needed. If business was good immediately after the war there would be a reduction of about 15,000 to 20,000 workers in the city, he estimated, in appearing before the House Public Buildings and Grounds Committee.

A full report on the city's billion-dollar post-war public works program was made public yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses at the same time that Mayor La Guardia was using the report before the House Public Buildings and Grounds Committee to support a plea for Federal aid.

Led by Guy Labrie, who tallied twice, the pace-setting Boston Olympics continued to make the Eastern Hockey League race a one-sided affair by downing the Brooklyn Crescents, 7--3, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The triumph was the twenty-fourth for the winners in twenty-five starts and gave them a total of 48 points, 21 more than the New York Rovers, who are in second place.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The War Department told tonight how 1st Lieut. Julian E. Baker of 67-12 Fifty-second Avenue, Maspeth, Queens, N.Y., had made a landing in an Italian olive grove with gasoline gauges reading empty, one engine cut out and four 1,000-pound bombs and a full crew aboard.

Stocks of marketable potatoes on Jan. 1 were the biggest in our history, says a bulletin just received from the Bureau of Agricultural Economics of the Department of Agriculture. Supplies had reached the imposing total of 138,000,000 bushels, as compared with the ten-year average (1931-40) of 103,601,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Proceedings in Congress thus far on the various legislative devices that have been proposed for polling the armed forces in the 1944 general elections strongly support the conclusion that the issues involved are political, legal and social.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Feb. 2--The Allies' control of the southern coast of Netherland New Guinea extends to a point 150 miles west of the Papuan border, it was disclosed today in an announcement that a combined Netherland-Australian force had repulsed an attack by Japanese barge-borne troops on the Eilanden River.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 1 -- The Germans have increased their Aegean Sea shipping recently to send supplies to the outlying islands that form part of the defense ring of Europe, yet despite this it was revealed here by reliable sources that Allied sea and air activity is keeping abreast.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 1.7 per cent in January over the like month of last year, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The sixty-fifth annual appeal of the United Hospital Fund of New York, recently ended, was most successful, Roy E. Larsen, fund president, reported yesterday at the fund's annual meeting at its headquarters, 370 Lexington Avenue.

Yesterday was the first day in the Fourth War Loan Drive for the major subscriptions to the new 2 1/4 and 2 1/2 per cent bonds and the seven-eighths of 1 per cent certificates for the reason that all three issues are dated Feb. 1 and therefore did not begin to bear interest until yesterday.

Latin America's women were showered with compliments yesterday by Mme. Helena Rubinstein, cosmetic manufacturer, who has just returned from a nine- month tour of our neighbors to the south. "In every line of work they are taking advantage of the wonderful opportunities opening to them," she said.
The Navy announced the long-expected invasion of the Marshall Islands yesterday. A campaign of great importance to the course of the Pacific war has started.
SAN PEDRO, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Private Floyd Steward is home with the monkey which he says saved his life three times, and on one of those occasions the lives of fourteen other men as well.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- One of every fourteen Americans suffered a disabling injury in 1943 when accidents took a total of 94,500 lives and injured 9,700,000 persons, statistics compiled by the National Safety Council disclosed today. The council estimated the monetary loss was $5,000,000,000.

The Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., has arranged a $75,000,000 long-term credit with a nation-wide group of twenty-three banks to finance the purchase of Frankfort Distillers for $41,800,000, which was effected late in 1943, and to provide working capital funds when and if needed.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 1 -- After wandering in some cases more than ten years across Europe as transients until they reached temporary haven of Portugal, 754 Jewish men, women and children landed at Port Haifa in Palestine, today.

An announcement of an agreement by THE NEW YORK TIMES to purchase the Interstate Broadcasting Company, Inc., which operates Station WQXR in New York City, was made yesterday by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of THE TIMES, and John V.L. Hogan and Elliott M. Sanger, president and executive vice president of the broadcasting company.

MONTREAL, Feb. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Boston's Herbie Cain pulled into a first-place tie with Lorne Carr of Toronto during the last week of National Hockey League play, picking up three points to raise his total to 56.

Henri Temianka, violinist, who has played many times in Town Hall since his debut there sixteen years ago, appeared on the same platform last night before a large and enthusiastic audience. For the Scottish-born player of Polish ancestry, who studied in this country at the Curtis Institute has, as is his due, developed a public here that admires his extraordinary technique, his fine, pure tone and his intelligent interpretations.

The manuscript of Dr. Albert Einstein's epoch-making theory of relativity, universally regarded as one of man's greatest intellectual achievements, together with a second manuscript, still unpublished, in which he reports on his latest explorations into the uncharted realms of the cosmos, have been given by Dr. Einstein to the Fourth War Loan drive to be converted by the alchemy of war bonds into weapons against our enemies, it was revealed yesterday.

This crucial year of the war will bring both hope and despair to the Jews of Europe. As Allied arms tighten the circle around Hitler's fortress many will be liberated. But others, the millions still caught in Nazi coils, will suffer the fanatical oppression of a savage enemy embittered by defeat.

AFTER the death of Peter the Great in 1725 "and until the revolution of 1917 the history of Russia and her wars was fated to be a struggle between the sturdiness of her soldiers and the incapacity of someone at the top." Or, in other words, Russian soldiers have always been as courageous as any in the world and usually physically stronger and more enduring than their foes.

When Ned Bogorod, 44 years old, who operates the Art Kraft Dental Laboratories, reported that everything was "all set," he didn't know how right he was, according to the story told about him yesterday by E.E. Conroy of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The long-expected all-out American assault on the Marshall Islands, clearly foreshadowed by the terrific air and naval bombardments previously announced, is now under way. Stabbing right to the heart of the whole archipelago, American Army troops and Marines have landed in the vicinity of Roi and Kwajalein in the Kwajalein atoll and are now locked in fierce battle with the enemy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Navy revealed tonight that twenty-two Corsair fighter planes from a twenty-three-plane marine squadron were lost in a severe storm last Friday while on a "routine flight" between the American-held Gilbert and Ellice Islands.

MADRID, Feb. 1 (U.P.) -- United States Ambassador Carlton J.H. Hayes, who conferred with Foreign Minister Count Francisco Gomez de Jordana yesterday for the second time in three days, was reported to have told the Spanish official that the British and American Governments were not asking Spain to sever diplomatic relations with Germany or to enter the war on the Allied side.

Were the ancient Romans fond of beach life? Anzio, the center of our beachhead below Rome, is, in the matter of distance, the Jones Beach of the Eternal City. About the modern Romans there is no question.

The ten-room house on a plot 100 by 170 feet at 130 Richmond Place, Lawrence, L.I., has been sold by Samuel Sack to Morris Weinberg for occupancy. This property is assessed for $16,500. The Lewis H. May Company was the broker.

The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, placed on public view yesterday a large group of oils, water-colors, drawings and sculpture from the permanent collection. The show will continue through March 14.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- The most active ground fighting in the Southwest Pacific in weeks flared up on Sunday, while to the north American airmen struck again at Rabaul, New Britain, shot down at least twenty-three fighters and blasted four enemy ships, one a destroyer, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota, a leading Republican advocate of post-war international collaboration, urged tonight the drafting as Republican Presidential nominee of Lieut. Commdr. Harold E. Stassen, formerly Governor of Minnesota, now on duty with the Navy in the South Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Roosevelt gave the lie this afternoon to Japanese reports said to be circulating through India to the effect that United States troops have gone to that country to aid Britain's imperialistic designs.

Driven by a high degree of selectivity and increased demand, the stock market edged slightly higher yesterday, inspired partly by corporate news developments. The business on the Stock Exchange was the largest in more than two weeks, but the volume tapered toward the close of trading as the floor was gradually cleared in preparation for the war bond rally that was staged after the final bell.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES WARSHIP IN THE NORTH ATLANTIC -- For days this convoy has moved along with such comparative smoothness that sometimes one forgets where one is and what one is doing, almost imagining that one is on a pleasure cruise under somewhat rugged weather conditions.

Magic new fabrics of all sorts of synthetics have bulked large in many post-war predictions. But pure old-fashioned silk, as produced in steadily increasing quantities by Brazil, has lately been stealing some of the limelight.

Participation by New York City in the War Production Board's tests for the resumption of civilian goods manufacture by small plants was urged yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York. WPB, the group pointed out, has thus far named only Philadelphia, Cleveland and Kansas City as "test areas" where small plants will be given an opportunity to manufacture such items to utilize idle and excess metals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Evidence of falsification of personnel records in the Federal Communications Commission's Foreign Broadcast Intelligent Service to advance the interests of clerks, favored by Chester A. Tietgen, resigned senior supervisor of the section, was given today at a hearing by the special House committee investigating the FCC.

A sport that is making a big hit among Pennsylvania sportsmen is fox hunting. Foxes have become a pest and a threat in that State, so the men who are helping to eliminate them not only are having a lot of fun but are lending a hand to solve an acute predator problem.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Newell (Jeff) Cravath, University of Southern California football coach, may leave the Trojans to boss the Washington Redskins of the National Football League.

Kurt Schurig, 49 years old, for twenty-eight years an over-the-counter dealer in securities at 50 Broadway, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to a Sing Sing term of eighteen months to five years in connection with thefts of $74,000 in securities from twenty customers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- While some of the thousands of 'teen-age girls who have gone into war industries will return to school after the war, most of them must have further educational opportunities through part-time vocational and technical schools, in the opinion of Commissioner John W. Studebaker of the United States Office of Education.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- The Government newspaper Izvestia asserted today that Vatican foreign policy had disillusioned Catholics throughout the world and "earned the hatred and contempt of the Italian masses for supporting fascism."

Today marks the first anniversary of the Russian victory at Stalingrad. It finds that city rising dauntlessly out of the ruin that the Germans made of it. Neighborhoods are blasted beyond recognition, yet the people who loved the city as their own are returning with intrepid spirit to set up house again.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Chicago gained a firmer grasp on the National Hockey League's fourth place, thereby improving its playoff chances, by subjecting Boston to its first shut-out of the season, 2 -- 0, tonight before 8,500 spectators at the Boston Garden.

It is not as easy as falling off a log to open a piano recital in a huge auditorium with the Chopin Barcarolle, which was the undertaking of Sidney Foster last night in Carnegie Hall. This most poetical of all compositions in its genre has nothing of the noise or pontification of some prelude in the grand manner, a la Bach-Busoni or worse.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market in January set a new high record, of 7,068, increasing 4.7 per cent over the previous high reached in January, 1943, when 6,752 listings were made. Buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 848, compared with 1,349 in the preceding week and 717 for the corresponding period a year ago.

ABOARD AN ARMY TRANSPORT En Route to Kwajalein Atoll, Jan. 30 (Delayed) -- The battle-hardened veterans of the Seventh Division, who conquered Attu in the Aleutians, know that their next battle will be on a coral atoll in the Marshall Islands, for they have been studying an enormous map laid out on the former shuffleboard and tennis deck of this huge transport.

With the filing of five criminal informations attributing ceiling-price violations to converters of cotton, rayon and woolen piece goods, United States Attorney James B.M. McNally announced yesterday his opening of "a drive to break the black market affecting wearers of garments in the lower income brackets."
Even before the Americans announced successful landings in the Marshall Islands, Japanese newspapers were preparing their readers for losses.

Carl Carmer, author of "The Hudson," in the Rivers of America Series, "Listen for a Lonesome Drum" and "Stars Fell on Alabama," will be the guest speaker at the luncheon of the Women's Committee of the Music Box Canteen, 68 Fifth Avenue, today at 12:30 P.M.

LONDON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Yugoslav Partisan troops have defeated "a German and Chetnik force" near the towns of Andrijevica and Berane, in Montenegro, not far from the Albanian frontier, Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] reported today.

The themes for the 1944 "Food Fights For Freedom Campaign" during the first nine months of the year have been listed in a plan formulated by the War Food Administration, in cooperation with the Office of Price Administration, the Office of War Information and the War Advertising Council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, announced today his support of the program for a national service act because President Roosevelt and the chiefs of the armed services favor such legislation.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 1 -- George E. Adams of Maplewood, N.J., executive secretary of the Kwantung International Relief Committee, who has just visited the Kwangtung famine area, reported today that 200 persons were still dying daily in Swatow, which is occupied by the Japanese.
One of the most important works of art in the collection of the late J.P. Morgan has been bought, without public announcement, by the Frick Collection, 1 East Seventieth Street.

The death of Piet Mondrian has taken from the art world a figure of peculiar significance. This brilliant artist of the School of Paris was an acknowledged leader of the "nonobjectivists." Before he left Paris his work had long exerted a profound influence in that field of abstract painting.

A plan for merger of the Morris Essex Railroad Company into the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company was made public yesterday by representatives of both roads. The plan is intended to settle pending tax litigation and future tax problems, as well as to reduce fixed charges.

Now that the revival of Thornton Wilder's "Our Town" has completed a stand at the City Center, the Sol Lesser film adaptation of the play also is returning to Broadway. It will begin an engagement on Saturday at the Manhattan Theatre, Broadway and Fifty-first Street.

A moderate amount of price-fixing, combined with continued trade covering and mill buying, produced yesterday an improved tone in the cotton futures market. At the close of trading, active futures contracts in the New York Cotton Exchange showed gains of 1 to 8 points, or 5 to 40 cents a bale over Monday's final quotations.

Books of comics -- what they mean to children, why they read them and what, if anything, should be done about them -- came in for expert discussion yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of the Child Study Association of America, Inc., 221 West Fifty-seventh Street, when 100 teachers, librarians, parents and publishers of comics met. The children, although they were not represented, carried the day.
Continuing his investment in Manhattan properties, Irving Maidman announced yesterday that he had acquired three more buildings of varied types.

Banks and other credit grantors were warned last night by Dr. Joseph J. Klein, accountant, that as war production tapers off they will encounter instances where corporations which borrowed funds for expanded volume have become liable for such high excess profits taxes that little of the gain will be available for debt liquidation.

A petition for reorganization under Chapter X of the Federal bankruptcy laws was filed yesterday in Federal court by the United States Realty and Improvement Company, whose assets include four buildings owned through subsidiaries. These properties are the Whitehall Building, 17 Battery Place; Trinity Building, 111 Broadway; United States Realty Building, 115 Broadway, and, in Boston, the Lawyers Building.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 2 -- Gen. Leonid A. Govoroff's Leningrad army captured the German stronghold of Kingisepp yesterday after brief street battles, while his advanced spearheads pushed on toward Estonia along a ten-mile front, reaching to within less than a mile of the border at the town of Keikino.

Real estate dealing in Bergen and Hudson Counties, N.J., by Alexander Summer brokerage firm established a new record last year with 1,195 transactions having a total sales value of $6,379,145. The increase over the best previous year was more than 25 per cent.

Fred Schmertz outlined his plans for the relays at Saturday's Mill-rose games and Jim Herbert exploded something of a bombshell when he announced his entry for the Mel Sheppard 600 had not been sent in a yesterday's weekly luncheon of the Track Writers Association.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 1 -- One of the wryest occupations in Chungking these days is listening to Japanese transcriptions of the voices of American war prisoners from Japanese prison camps. In thin, strained voices they say: "I'm doing as well as can be expected" or "I'm kept very busy."

The five-story building containing stores and lodge rooms at 157-61 East Eighty-sixth Street and known as Yorkville Temple, has been sold by Amos R. Pinchot to an investing syndicate formed by Nathan A. Lashin, attorney.

The conviction of Jack Wallace, a business agent in Local 17, International Hod Carriers and Common Laborers Union, of Newburgh, N.Y., on charges of grand larceny of union funds was reversed yesterday by the Brooklyn Appellate Division.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The House by a vote of 233 to 160 refused today to subject itself to the "stand-up-and-be-counted" showdown between Federal and State ballot plans for the armed forces as President Roosevelt urged in his recent message to Congress.
PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 27:

In THE TIMES of Jan. 23 Herbert L. Matthews, in a dispatch from Washington, D.C., writes, among other things, that "the disappointing reaction to appeals for sabotage and guerrilla fighting within the German zone during the last four months was due to the inability of the Italians to sustain a heroic level in the face of ruthless German repression."

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Allied Mills, Inc., and subsidiaries reported today for 1943 a net profit of $2,023,980, equal to $2.53 a share on capital stock. This compared with $1,497,524, or $1.87 a share, for the previous year.

ALGIERS, Feb. 1 -- Members of the French Committee of National Liberation were wary of commenting today on the American note disavowing any intention to deal further with Vichy or its collaborators, evidently believing that any news about it should come from Washington.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Feb. 2 (UP) -- A communique:

ABOARD A FLAGSHIP APPROACHING KWAJALEIN ATOLL, Jan. 30 (Delayed)--A large part of the American Navy, constituting the most powerful sea force ever assembled, is converging from north and south today on Kwajalein Atoll in the Japanese mandated Marshall Islands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Roosevelt gave assurances at his press conference this afternoon that the individual Japanese responsible for atrocities against American prisoners, such as was reported last week by the War and Navy Departments, would be tracked down and brought to justice.

The latest plaint from Alva Bradley, president of the Indians, that baseball had rather close for the duration than "promote a farce," drew scarcely the lifting of an eyebrow among Giant, Dodger and Yankee officials yesterday. The fact that some such statement seems to have become an annual institution in Cleveland appeared to lessen still further its chances of being taken seriously in local quarters.

MADRID, Feb. 2 -- Two commentaries on the political and economic dispute between the Allies and Spain, broadcast over a nation-wide hook-up today, asserted that the Franco Government was ready to defend its sovereign neutrality at all costs.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Feb. 3 (UP) -- A communique:

The peak demand for war products is being met "more comfortably than most observers believed possible," the National City Bank reports in its February review of economic conditions, adding that the margin of raw material supplies above war requirements, particularly metals, has increased.

A designer duet set the tone for Saks Fifth Avenue's custom-made spring millinery yesterday afternoon. Each gave out an individual theme. Tatiana du Plessix reflected the French tradition; Josephi, fresh young American individualism.

The Furniture ]V[anufacturers Representatives of New York is now preparing a national advertising campaign designed to publicize its new service to manufacturers who wish to engage competent wholesale furniture salesmen. According to the plans being formulated, manufacturers will be able to call on the organization for qualified representatives and will secure salesmen recommended by it on a basis of satisfactory background.

Youth in the United States seems to have developed an attitude that offers great promise for inter-racial and inter-faith friendship in this country, Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, declared last night in a forum at Freedom House, 5 West Fifty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Army has blocked efforts of American importers to resume the importation, through private channels, of essential resin gums from recovered territories in the Far East, it was disclosed here today. Its opposition springs from a fear that a resumption of civilian activity in newly recaptured territories might divert local manpower and transport from essential military activity.

The first of 3,000,000 household emergency kits to be sent to Russian civilians by Russian War Relief, Inc., was presented yesterday by Mayor La Guardia to Capt. Danil Kladoff of the Red Navy and Capt. Orest Shevtsoff of the Red Army at a ceremony at City Hall to commemorate the first an niversary of the German defeat at Stalingrad.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 2 -- Four American track and field records, two of them by Fred Wolcott, have been accepted as world standards by the International Amateur Athletic Federation as represented by the organization's president, J.S. Edstrom and Secretary Bo Ekelund, both of Sweden.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Hours of debate brought the House of Representatives to adjournment with no test of sentiment on either of the two bills today providing for ballots for service men.

The property comprising the one-story garage and service station, with a two-family structure and another four-family building, at 184-90 Neperhan Avenue, Yonkkers, Westchester County, has been sold by Elizabeth S. MacDougal to Michael Cascarano.

Confronted by a lamb chop, for which he was accused of having charged more than the ceiling price, Louis Fass, a Bronx butcher, pointed at the evidence yesterday in a Department of Markets hearing room and said:

"I don't know if it's a singing Army, but they sure are a lot of singing boys." A feather-bobbed hostess at a service men's dance last night summed up the opinion of the girls who entertain and the women who supervise at canteens and service clubs throughout the city.
LONDON, Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans have inflicted heavy losses on the First German Alpine Division brought from Greece into Dalmatia, it was announced today.

Here's a survey on how the ice fishermen are faring up Putnam County way. Bob Holmes of the Putnam County Fish and Game Association gathered the data and concluded that this was the best pickerel season in many a year.

LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the Soviet decrees putting into force a plan for granting independence to the sixteen Soviet Republics, as translated by the Soviet monitor from a Russian broadcast:

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 2 -- Because some kind person many months ago knitted a pretty red sweater for the Red Cross Chapter of Larchmont, N.Y., a bright-eyed little Yugoslav boy named Ivica Javorcic is warm and happy in a desert refugee camp tonight.

An increased subway fare will merely postpone for ten years any real solution of the city's fiscal problems, Council President Newbold Morris declared yesterday. Any proposal to increase the fare, he predicted, would be overwhelmingly defeated under the referendum provision of the Muzzicato law, which gives the City Council power to call for such a plebiscite within thirty days after any fare rise is voted by the Board of Estimate.

The Scientific Book Club, Port Authority Building, 76 Ninth Avenue, announces "Beloved Scientist," by David O. Woodbury as its February selection. The book, published by Whittlesey House, is a biography of Elihu Thompson.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 2 (UP) A Southeast Asia Command communique:

Howard S. Cullman, president of Beekman Hospital, yesterday urged the city tO replace its plan for using capital funds for hospital expansion with a system of greater reimbursement to voluntary hospitals for the care of city cases. The suggestion was made at the hospital's annual meeting in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, at which it was announced that $165, 000 had been raised in the hospital's 1944 maintenance fund campaign.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Wheat traders turned bearish today, and although there was some buying early on the Board of Trade attributed to millers or cash interests, the undertone was heavy most of the day and professional operators showed more tendency to take the selling side than in some time.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- There is an American note these days in the roaring chorus of London's anti-aircraft guns when the Luftwaffe planes dare to raid the British capital. It is a deep one, toe, for it comes from the throats of 90 mm. guns.

Purchase of the historic edifice of the former Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, at Henry and Remsen Streets, Brooklyn, by the Roman Catholic parish of Our Lady of Lebanon, a Syrian congregation now worshiping at 295 Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, was authorized yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff.

Mr. Willkie's habit of plain speaking led him last night to recommend the stiffest dose of wartime taxation that any American in public life has yet proposed. This is a decidedly unorthodox position for an aspirant for public office in an election year. The regular procedure is a rosy promise of tax reduction.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Forty-one States have or will make adequate provision for absentee balloting by service personnel, Senator Byrd of Virginia told the Senate today.

Recognition is given by the Army and the Navy to industrial plants that excel in producing armaments for the fighting fronts. There could also be "E" awards for communities that keep their house in order, as our close neighbor Yonkers has done in averting strikes and slowdowns in factories vital to the war.

Sweeping administrative changes in the Municipal Court, including amendment of the State law to merge twenty-six district clerkships into the single post of Chief Clerk, were recommended yesterday by President Justice Keyes Winter at a hearing before Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson.

ABOARD JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FLAGSHIP, Kwajalein Atoll, Feb. 1 (Delayed) -- Waves of the veteran Seventh Army Division today surpassed their first day's objective when they swarmed across the islets of Gea, Ninni, Ennylabegan and Enubuj in the Marshall Islands invasion.
