BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 2 -- More "irked than annoyed," the German Propaganda Ministry backed by the High Command communique today has plugged in both press and radio German claims to have sent two large bombing forces over the British capital last month, which they charge "the British for obvious propaganda reasons" have so far refused to admit.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- While London awaits Generalissimo Francisco Franco's reply to the Anglo-American barrage of representations on the breaches of Spanish neutrality, Berlin has turned on its own propaganda to support Spain in resisting the demands of ,the United Nations.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- While large expenditures on public works may be required to ease the transition to a peacetime economy, Harold D. Smith, director of the Federal Bureau of the Budget, told the American Road Builders' Association today, private enterprise must take the lead in maintaining high employment and a maximum of national income after the war.

CALDWELL, N.J., Feb. 2 -- Built to meet aviation needs of the future, when it may be called upon to test propellers up to thirty feet in diameter on engines of 5,000 horsepower, a proving ground for aircraft propellers was opened here today by the propeller division of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Army doctors were puzzled by the number of draft selectees who showed up at Fort Myers with high blood pressure and they asked the FBI for answer.

Stocks of finished oil products on the East Coast increased moderately last week excepting heavy fuel oil, which declined further. The index of the American Petroleum Institute covering gasoline supplies stood at 43.2 at the end of the week, compared with 41.9 a week earlier.

With 113,424 new members this year, a record annual net increase in enrollment has been set for 1943 by Associated Hospital Service, New York City's Blue Cross plan, it was announced yesterday by Frank Van Dyk, vice president in charge of enrollment.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 2 -- The marines have captured Roi Island, primary objective in the northern portion of Kwajalein Atoll in the Marshall Islands and the first prewar Japanese territory to fall to United States forces.

Net sales of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation reached a new high of $11,857,771 in its fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, after allowance for price reductions and refunds to the Government, Benjamin Abrams, the president, reported yesterday to stockholders.

Ernest Pascal's comedy, "Peepshow," opening this evening at the Fulton after a couple of postponements, is somewhat of a novelty in characterization. The leading player's conscience (in this instance an Equity member in good standing) follows him around like one of those good-natured, but annoying kibitzers.

"Jane Eyre," the Twentieth Century-Fox adaptation of the Charlotte Bronte work starring Joan Fontaine in the title role and Orson Welles as Rochester, will have its world premiere this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. Featured in the drama, which was directed by Robert Stevenson, are Agnes Moorehead, John Sutton, Sara Allgood, Henry Daniell and the child actresses, Margaret O'Brien and Peggy Ann Garner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Although the country has a large surplus of aluminum at present and production is "abundantly able" to meet military demands, indiscriminate use of the metal for civilian products is still a long way off, officials of the War Production Board said today.

At the request of Wayne Lonergan, awaiting trial in the slaying of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, General Sessions Judge John J. Freschi yesterday vacated the order that had assigned Edward V. Broderick, Milliard H. Ellison and Abraham J. Halprin as Lonergan's counsel at the expense of the State.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Though quotable official reaction from the State Department or the British Embassy here was lacking, Moscow's announcement that the sixteen Soviet Republics would receive autonomy as regards foreign representation and military defense had an effect in Washington today that caused one diplomat to nickname it promptly a "Molotoff cocktail."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- In the last twenty-four hours there have been three important developments in the Congressional struggle over methods to poll the armed forces in this year's elections. These illuminate, particularly for the citizens of New York State, the difficulties in working out a device that is both effective and legal.
The apartment house at 62 Kensington Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by the Collins Holding Company to the Phildor Realty Corporation through the A.F. Roe Company, Inc., broker.
The following is the text of a talk delivered by Wendell L. Willkie at The New York Times Hall, last night:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Associate Justices Owen J. Roberts and Felix Frankfurter believe that "a tendency to disregard precedents" in some recent Supreme Court decisions has left prospective litigants and the lower courts "without any confidence that what was said yesterday will hold good tomorrow."

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- Hundreds of American heavy and medium bombers escorted by fighters blasted "mystery" targets and an important airfield along the French invasion coast yesterday with tons of high explosive and fire bombs without encountering a single enemy plane.
Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that action by Congress ending food subsides would plunge the country into a black market worse than that in prohibition days.

OFF ROI ISLAND, Kwajalein, Feb. 1 (Delayed) -- This morning we can hear the rumble of bombs and shells on Roi and Namur Islands, which are hidden from our view by the heavy smoke clouds raised by the bombardment of the last twenty-eight hours.

The steel industry produced 12,966,878 net tons of plates for sale in 1943, a new high record, at 136.6 per cent of plate mill capacity, comparing with 11,543,171 tons at 136.4 per cent of capacity in 1942, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- Australian jungle fighters scored a break-through on Monday in their drive toward a junction with American troops at Saidor, New Guinea, overrunning strong enemy resistance, killing 220 Japanese and reaching a point only thirty miles from the Americans, it was announced today.

Wendell L. Willkie declared last night in an address in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, that the $10,600,000,000 tax program urged by the Administration and rejected by Congress was "unrealistic." He called for the imposition of additional taxes to yield more than double the net of $8,000,000,000 that he said would be realized by the Treasury's proposal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Senate forces, demanding a maximum use of State ballots in voting by the armed services, presented a complete program late today for "a stand-up-and-be-counted" showdown with the pending Green-Lucas Federal ballot bill.

J.G.L. Molloy was elected president of Greenwich House at a meeting of the board of managers held yesterday at the 41-year-old settlement house, 27 Barrow Street. He succeeded 1Viarshall Field, who served as president for six years and continues as a member of the board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration announced tonight that it had agreed with the Prices and Trade Board of Canada whereby restrictions on imports of pulpwood would be eased and imports from three Canadian Provinces would be placed under United States price ceilings. in the three Provinces," with re-Brunswick and Nova Scotia.

Stanley Need, New Haven pianist, gave his third recital in Town Hall last night, having made his New York debut there two years ago. Mr. Need, who is a former pupil of Alexander Siloti, disclosed unusually fine piano playing and the audience was warm in its response.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 2 -- Guerrilla activity in Greece, according to information from reliable sources, has increased during the past month. So, too, has the policy of German reprisals.

LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- An official account released today by the Government of India accused the Japanese of forcing a prisoner to go without water for a long period, then compelling him to drink large quantities and finally jumping on his stomach until water poured from the mouth, nose, ears and eyes.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 3--A Red Army spearhead advanced one-half mile into Estonia yesterday by capturing the village of Vanakula, while other Soviet forces under Gen. Leonid A. Govoroff drove to the border along a curving front extended to thirty-five miles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Small War Plants Corporation today inaugurated a new loan policy under which the amount that banks are permitted to carry under a deferred participation is raised to $250,000 from the previous limit of $100,000, where the bank takes a direct participation in the loan of 10 per cent or more.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Army Air Force casualties have been so far below expectations that the United States now has a "superabundance" of trained fliers, Senator McCarran of Nevada said today.

The Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, supporting the plea of New York landlords for a blanket increase of at least 10 per cent in housing rents here, issued a statement last night replying to Mayor La Guardia's memorandum to the Office of Price Administration in which the Mayor opposed the petition for higher rentals.

ON THE ARAKAN FRONT, in Burma, Jan. 30 (Delayed) -- For the first time in the warfare in Southeast Asia tanks were thrown into battle in a series of assaults carried out by British forces on the Arakan Front during the last three days.

With the breathtaking speed possible only under a dictatorship, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, which in its new state anthem designates itself as "mighty Russia" and as "indissoluble," has suddenly reorganized itself into sixteen individual though not independent republics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt's nomination today of three chiefs of Navy Department service bureaus for promotion from rear admiral to vice admiral may raise in the Senate a question whether a three star precedent shall be established permanently for men in such positions.

I would like to know if there are not responsibilities and obligations connected with each State right. It seems to me that there is much more talk about the rights of each so-called "sovereign'' State than of the responsibilities of these States. Take the soldier vote issue for example.

TRENTON, Feb. 2--Insertion into the proposed new State Constitution of a provision lowering the voting age to 18 was urged today by Mrs. Maxwell Barus of Montclair, president of the State League of Women Voters, and Carl Holderman, secretary-treasurer of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, as three legislative committees held public hearings for the second day on the tentative draft of the charter.

Dr. Morris Weiss, 57 years old, and his wife, Bella, of 960 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, were arrested yesterday in a raid on an alleged "abortion mill" at 60 East Ninety-sixth Street. Assistant District Attorneys John Moore and Manuel L. Robbins directed the raid by detectives under Acting Captain Vincent J. Kieran.

The Selective Service ruling, effective two days ago, which prohibits the deferment of men between the ages of 18 and 22 except under very special considerations, will impair war production, Dr. Albert B. Newman, chairman of the manpower committee of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, declared yesterday at the headquarters of the institute, 50 East Forty-first Street.

Russia is not likely to provide a large market for American exporters in the post-war period, since German industry will probably be impressed into service to supply Russian needs, and imports will undoubtedly be confined principally to capital goods, it was asserted yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Three five-story tenements at 1088 to 1092 Second Avenue, adjoining the northeast corner of Fifty-seventh Street, were sold by the Central Savings Bank to Jacob Freidus through the M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company and Dwight, Voorhis Helmsley, brokers.

LONDON, Feb. 2--The Moscow radio announced tonight the terms of two decrees giving the constituent republics of the Soviet Union a certain degree of autonomy in the conduct of their defense and foreign relations.

Several hundred teachers, parents and community leaders attended yesterday afternoon a meeting of the Board of Education at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, to urge immediate appointment of 800 teachers, but they were confronted by a proposed cut in State aid to education.

In support of their charge that Sidney Hillman is seeking to gain control of the American Labor party by an alliance with Communists, George S. Counts, State chairman, and Alex Rose, State secretary, declared yesterday that four of the seven members of the committee on vacancies named on petitions of left-wing candidates for members of the party's State committee were "veteran followers of the Communist party line."
War bond sales to individuals reported yesterday for the city, State and nation were the greatest for any single day in the Fourth War Loan drive.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Col. William O'Dwyer, District Attorney of Kings County now on military leave, is prepared to recommend executive clemency for Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Emanuel Weiss and Louis Capone, it was asserted today at a clemency hearing conducted by Governor Dewey for the three men, sentenced to death for the murder of a Brooklyn candy-store owner in 1936.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The coverage of serious American news in the British national newspapers has greatly improved since the start of the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- After hearing the representatives of Federal nursing services tell of the shortages of nurses a House Interstate Commerce subcommittee speedily made a favorable report today on perfecting amendments to the Bolton Nurses Training Act.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Charles U. Peat, Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Supply, denied in the House of Commons today assertion by D. Robertson, Conservative M.P. for Streatham, that the Ministry had granted a virtual monopoly to three or four British firms in the production of penicillin.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb 2 (AP) -- John T. Cahill, former United States attorney for Southern New York, and Oliver T. Remners of St. Louis asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to dismiss broker-leader license revocation proceedings against E.H. Rollins Son, Inc., New York, and a St. Louis sub-office manager, Walter Cecil Rawls.

The great increase in the armed services and their assignments to distant areas are two of the principal factors necessitating a larger Red Cross 1944 War Fund, John P. Stevens Jr., chairman in the New York area, declared yesterday at a luncheon for executives of advertising agencies and retail stores, held in the Hotel Roosevelt.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 2 -- The lack of transportation is the basic reason for the difficulty in relieving the famine in Kwangtung, a Government spokesman, P.H. Chang, declared today. In Kwangtung, the Central Government Ministry of Communications does not control a single truck.

WITH THE UNITED STATES NAVAL FORCES IN THE CENTRAL PACIFIC, Feb. 1 (Delayed) -- Just before shoving off for the Marshalls, whose channels are tricky and dangerous, I talked with a Navy commander, saying: "I'd like to know what the Japs have done in those channels -- obstructions, nets, mines and so forth."

A picture of a lean and hungry New York, meat-starved for the remainder of this year while the rest of the country is to get enough meat for all civilian requirements, was painted for the State Joint Legislative Committee on Nutrition yesterday by the non-slaughtering wholesalers.

Post-war plans of the State Department of Education were discussed yesterday at the regional conference for district superintendents at the Hotel McAlpin. Dr. Edwin R. Van Kleeck, assistant commissioner for instructional supervision, presided at both the morning and afternoon sessions.

A varied collection of easy-to-wear hats ranging from casual felt classics to flower-and-feather trimmed toques was presented by Dobbs Park Avenue during luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. Worn with fresh-looking suits and toppers designed by Vera Maxwell, the hats illustrated the diversity of flattering types suitable for spring tailleurs.

Wendell L. Willkie declared last night during a question-and-answer period following his address at THE NEW YORK TIMES Hall that he hoped the Polish boundary question would be solved "through some kind of United Nations organization or an international society."

A DISTINGUISHED lawyer who prefers to remain anonymous read in this space recently an account of the Willard-Johnson fight in which the rumor of fakery was denied emphatically by Tex O'Rourke, Jess' trainer at the time. Thereupon the legal light could not resist the temptation to file a brief of his own on his impressions of the battle.
The first phase of our operations in the Marshall Islands has been successfully and brilliantly concluded.

Declaring that the backlog of orders for television, radio and household appliances is so great that it will take years in the post-war period to meet the demand, D.W. May, at a press conference in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, made known his resignation as Eastern regional manager of the electronics department of the General Electric Company to form his own distributing organization to be known as D.W. May, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- January war spending of $7,138,000,000 topped the previous month's total by $420,000,000 but fell $403,000,000 short of the November record. It brought the war total for the first seven months of this fiscal year to $49,003,000,000, compared with $38,061,000,000 in the same period a year ago.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 2 -- Two men were convicted and a man and a woman were acquitted here today on charges on nonfeasance arising out of election irregularities in 1942 in the Eleventh district of the fourth ward in Passaic. A jury returned the verdict to Judge Joseph A. Delaney in the quarter sessions court.

The question of the equal rights amendment is a hardy perennial which can be counted on to come up every season regardless of how many times it has been met and refuted. This is partly due to a well-organized and untiring lobby in Washington and partly to the fact that it has a plausible sound which misleads the unthinking into an easy acceptance of a delusion.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 2 -- The Jack Heintz Company, Inc., maker of equipment for airplanes, has scrapped "pledges" which authorized it to make large deductions from the wages, salaries and bonuses of its employes, it was learned today.

WITH AN AIRBORNE ENGINEER AVIATION BATTALION Somewhere in Britain, Feb. 2 -- Wave after wave of light, medium and heavy bombers roar over an advanced airfield a short distance behind the lines where the ground armies are struggling.

With the entire poultry industry declining to bid for its order for 25,000 pounds of fowl a week, the City of New York went to market yesterday -- like any hopeful housewife seeking a chicken for the dinner pot -- to see if it could pick up enough here and there to give the inmates of municipal institutions an occasional chicken dinner.

Action of the enforcement division of the Office of Price Administration in dressing one of its investigators in a Merchant Marine Service uniform to get evidence in a shoe rationing violation drew sharp criticism yesterday from Harry B. Chambers, chief Regional OPA Hearing Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes, as Coordinator of Fisheries, chided the fishing industry today as having fallen below the 1943 production goal, and called upon fishermen to bring in 5,300,000,000 pounds this year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Lieut. Gen. Millard F. Harmon, commander of Army forces in the South Pacific, today expressed the hope that as soon as transportation facilities were increased troops who had served in his theatre would receive furloughs home.

New Orleans, La., opened bids yesterday on a new issue of $2,500,000 of aviation bonds, Series A, dated Feb. 1, 1944, and due serially from Aug. 1, 1945 to 1968, and callable in inverse number, beginning Feb. 1, 1954, and on any interest date thereafter at 102.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. said today that the $14,000,000,000 "savings" recently announced by the War Department had no bearing on expenditures estimated necessary for war activities and did not represent surplus funds.

At his recital last night in Carnegie Hall the playing heard from Alexander Borovsky, the Russian pianist, reached its climax of accomplishment in a superb performance of Liszt's "Feux Follets," at the close of a program in which the artist's work was far from even.

Last year, for the first time since 1936, the New York Stock Exchange had an operating profit. According to the annual report released yesterday by Emil Schram, president, it was $676,509, in contrast to a net loss of $815,972 in 1942.

Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, commanding general of the Army Service Forces, expressed appreciation yesterday to the motion-picture industry for its contribution of free screen programs to soldiers overseas. He spoke at a luncheon of the industry's War Activities Committee in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, marking the presentation of the 10,000th free motion-picture program to the Army.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz dismissed yesterday an indictment charging two men, now fighting in the South Pacific, with burglary and grand larceny. The complainant, Peter Villanova, a Filipino merchant seaman, agreed not to press the charges.
LONDON, Feb. 2 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Since THE NEW YORK TIMES mentioned that George Hartmann, chairman of "Peace Now," has been a Socialist candidate for office, I am sure you will want to bring to the attention of your readers the fact that the Socialist party is politically opposed to the "Peace Now" movement and to any negotiated peace.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 2 -- Muriel Heagney, women's organizer of the Australian branch of the Amalgamated Engineering Union and honorary secretary of the Council of Action for Equal Pay, is convinced that the Women's Employment Board which the Curtin government instituted in 1942 to facilitate the transfer of women to war industries normally regarded as men's work has achieved fundamental and far-reaching changes in the status of pay and opportunities for Australian women workers.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Feb. 2 -- The heroic group of chaplains attached to one American Fifth Army unit on this front believes the luckiest member of their outfit is First Lieut. Israel L. Yost of Nazareth, Pa., not because he received a much-deserved Purple Heart Medal but because he has had a missionary enterprise tossed into his lap.

ALGIERS, Feb. 2 -- Returning from a visit with Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud to the French sector of the front in Italy, Brig. Gen. Paul-Arsene-Gerard de Vinci, General Giraud's Chief of Staff, told today of the hard, successful fighting by French units in difficult mountain country where, he said, they had got the better of the Germans in a prolonged series of fierce hand-to-hand encounters.

The news of the horrors after Bataan has come and gone from the headlines with about the expected Congressional reaction -- good copy, infantile and futile. Can plain citizens still hope, in the face of experience, that anything short of national disaster will bring sober second thought to our elected representatives and induce in them the moral stature which would restore Congress to the honored place it once had?

The two five-story buildings each on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 2380-86 Grand Avenue, the Bronx, have been purchased by the Primust Corporation from Frederick A. Wurzback, president of the Bronx County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Sid Luckman, master mind of the Chicago Bears' famous T formation, today was judged the National Football League's most valuable player for the 1943 season.

ALGIERS, Feb. 2 -- As German reinforcements were pouring down from north of Rome yesterday and the expected major counter-attack against the Allies below the capital was believed to be imminent, the Fifth Army's forces in the mountains north and west of Cassino reduced the Gustav Line, over a stretch of several miles, to a thing of the past.

Civilians will have a chance to see what a United Service Organizations club looks like this weekend when in cities and towns throughout the nation, in observance of the USO's third anniversary, clubhouses will be opened to the public for the first time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The National War Labor Board threatened today to invoke the full sanctions and penalties provided by the War Labor Disputes Act against a local of the International Wood Workers Association, CIO, which has been picketing a Hoquiam, Wash., lumber plant since Dec. 4, despite a board order directing it to cease such picketing on Jan. 17 and instructing employes to return to work.
Three inspectors were shifted yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine in orders that also noted several promotions in the detective bureau.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- Twenty-five years ago Charles C. McGonegal walked out of Walter Reed Hospital, a tall, slim youth from North Dakota whose hands were bright steel hooks.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2 -- One of the best played favorites at Hialeah Park today was Air Patrol, carrying the spotted silks of Max Wexler, and he was the easiest sort of winner after trailing much of the way in a small field. A crowd of 9,300, wagering $720,462, could see little besides Air Patrol and the 3-year-old chestnut returned 11-10 after he had completed his mile and a furlong journey in 1:54 3-5.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 2 -- Beginning this morning with Savoie, Joseph Darnand, charged with "maintenance of order," is showing the French what the German purpose was when he was raised to power at the beginning of the year.

Mill buying and trade price-fixing, combined with considerable trade covering, yesterday enabled cotton prices to reach their highest levels in about four months. At the close of trading active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed gains of 3 to 11 points, or 15 to 55 cents a bale above Tuesday's final prices.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- A proposal made to Congress that the Government compute 1943 income taxes for some 30,000,000 small taxpayers ran into opposition today from the Internal Revenue Bureau, which said it did not have and could not get enough help to do the work.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2 -- Sir Cedric Hardwicke and Thomas Mitchell, who are portraying the late Senator Henry Cabot Lodge and Joseph P. Tumulty respectively in Twentieth Century-Fox's "Wilson," have been assigned to two of the top character parts in "Keys of the Kingdom" at the studio.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Feb. 1 (Delayed) -- American infantry and tanks battered on the back door of Cassino today, trying to burst its last hinge, and hammering at German suicide squads manning cleverly emplaced guns.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the So viet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

SOMEWHERE IN THE UNITED KINGDOM, Feb. 2 -- The last lap of our journey with an important convoy is over. It has been a tremendous success. No soldier, no ship, no scrap of material was lost. Our arrival has been very bad news indeed for Adolf Hitler.

With more steel expected to be available for the construction of railroad equipment, many of the railroads are making inquiries for additional rolling stock. The Chesapeake Ohio Railway is reported to be seeking sixteen mallet-type freight locomotives and 5,000 hopper coal cars of fifty-ton capacity each.
LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Jim Herbert and the Millrose A.A. settled their differences yesterday and the star became the fifth entry for the Sheppard 600, one of the major features of Saturday's renewal of the games in Madison Square Garden.

Stocks and bonds of the nation's railroad systems broke yesterday through previous high levels to show decisive gains, but the trend proved lower in most industrials and some of the recently favored specialties. Common and preferred issues of the carriers set new price marks for more than six months, while the funded debt obligations of the roads reached peaks which were the highest in several years.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Anti-Administration Democrats gathering from a score of States to lay plans are prepared to go as far as calling another National Convention, separate from the one to be held in Chicago in July, it was indicated today by Robert E. O'Brian of Des Moines.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 2 -- The United States needed a national war service law two years ago, and needs it more than ever right now, Warren H. Atherton, national commander of the American Legion, told the Senate Military Affairs Committee today.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Prime Minister Churchill gave expression yesterday to two views that have lately become the conviction to his Government: That the impending battles will be of unprecedented difficulty and violence, and that "an altogether unwarranted optimism has taken possession of large numbers" of British people.

The magazine Trusts and Estates has compiled an instructive list of the variety of estimates made by OPA officials concerning the savings to be effected from the use of subsidies. It found at least five additional estimates in recent months:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 -- A Virginia farmer, a theatre manager, a lumberman, a cannery operator, a town manager and several Mayors read into the Securities and Exchange Commission's record their opinions in respect to the proposed merger of the Vir ginia Public Service Company and the Virginia Electric and Power Company.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, Commander in Chief of the British Invasion Forces, told troops at a southeast English town today that the launching of any invasion would signal that all plans for certain victory had been perfected.

In a speech yesterday the Mayor proclaimed that in general, as far as municipal employes are concerned, "you can't apply the same rule of labor relations between an employer and employe in private industry to government,'' and more specifically he added that he did not recognize their right to strike.

Mink ruled firm at the sale held yesterday for the account of the Hudson's Bay Company by Lampson, Fraser Huth. The top price was $40. Muskrats were slightly easier, selling up to $3.04. Blue fox brought a high of $76, and held firm.

Outplayed by an unbelievable margin in the first half, the St. John's University basketball team rallied to register a 60-to-55 triumph over St. Francis College at DeGray Gymnasium in Brooklyn last night.

An increase of 132 per cent in the incidence of infectious syphilis in the 15 to 19 age group in New York City during the first ten months of 1943, as compared with a similar period in 1941, was reported yesterday before the annual conference of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association and 118 other health organizations at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Broadway theatre finally took note of the times last evening when Edward Choate brought to the Belasco the play called "Decision." To call it the most thoughtful drama of the season to date no doubt is to damn it completely, but it is that -- and something more.

The sixteen-story office and showroom building at 381 Fourth Avenue, southeast corner of Twenty-seventh Street, has been bought by Frederick Brown, operator, from A. Fillmore Hyde through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., and Joseph G. Dubraska, brokers.

ABOARD THE FLAGSHIP OFF KWAJALEIN ATOLL, in the Marshall Islands, Feb. 2 (AP) -- United States military government officers went ashore with assault troops in the Marshall Islands invasion to establish administration over the natives in the first pre-war Japanese territory to be seized from the enemy.

There now are 1,354 committees There representing community, county, State, district and regional organizations working to bring about orderly reconversion from a wartime to a peacetime economy in the Committee for Economic Development set-up, as compared with only three at the beginning of 1943, Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the board of trustees of the organization, said yesterday at a press conference here.
Random Shots to the outlying districts:
Ten million of our bravest and best have dedicated their lives to the nation. The Fourth War Loan is offered directly and specifically to back them up -- to Back the Attack.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The embarrassment caused by the fact that while Finland and Britain are enemies Finland and the United States are officially friends was stressed by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in the House of Commons today in discussing the invitation by the International Labor Office to Finland to the convention to be held in the United States.
The Russian successes announced yesterday represent the most important strategic gains the Red Army has yet made in its winter campaign.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 3 -- The Cabinet crisis precipitated by the resignation of three Ministers immediately after Argentina's breach with the Axis has been successfully overcome, according to an official Argentine source. It never even came to the knowledge of the general public.

The five-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 142 feet at 62 East 190th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the Lasan Realty Corporation (Charles Justen, president), to a client of Irving Smith, attorney. It has an annual rent roll of $14,000 and was sold for cash and a purchase money mortgage of $12,000 above a first mortgage of $52,000 held by the American Savings Bank.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Railroad executives and Government transportation officials announced today that orders would be placed at once in volume to keep the nation's available car-building capacity in full operation throughout 1944. The meeting of 200 executives resulted also in a joint plan for assistance in meeting the carriers' manpower problem.

The free gold standard on a world-wide basis should be restored as quickly as possible after the war, Benjamin M. Anderson, former economist for the Chase National Bank, said yesterday in an address before the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

A Bronx warehouse concern and two of its officials were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday in an alleged price-ceiling fraud which United States Attorney James B.M. McNally said had victimized service men and their families.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming was appointed today chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee by Senator Alben W. Barkley, majority leader, coincident with his acceptance of the resignation of Senator Joseph F. Guffey of Pennsylvania.
A cash deal which required the sending of the deed to Ireland for signature featured activity on the West Side yesterday.

Ministerial circles at Ankara have an extraordinary story to tell about Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain. It has been made known to the outside world by a foreign diplomat who found it significant enough and had it telegraphed to his Government.

Action on pending bids of major oil companies for the contract to sell aviation fuel at the new Idlewild Airport in Queens was postponed by the Board of Estimate yesterday until April 13 after Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick disclosed that the airlines now using La Guardia Field had submitted a joint proposal covering the fuel and oil situation at the new airport where they expected to be tenants.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The marines pushed the Japanese back from the building and barracks area on the west side of Namur Island into the bushy, scrub-covered northern portion Tuesday. There the enemy made a last stand.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Movement of increased quantities of drugs, pharmaceuticals and other health supplies to the Middle East through normal commercial channels is assured this year, the Foreign Economic Administration said today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Feb. 3 -- The Japanese fleet is not going to fight the American Navy in the Eastern Marshalls. Despite the Paris radio and other reports, this may be stated now with as much assurance as it is possible to state anything in wartime.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The next three months will be a critical period in respect to supply of petroleum for the Eastern seaboard and the situation will develop into a race between available transportation and domestic consumption, Secretary Ickes, who is Petroleum Administrator for War, said today.

Freeing the moisture in the soil below the top layer by cultivation rather than too frequent use of the garden hose was favored yesterday by James B. Jack, superintendent of the A. A. Cook estate at Mount Kisco, N.Y., in a talk on Victory Gardens.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted by wireless from Moscow to the Soviet press and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ALGIERS, Feb. 3 -- The long and bloody battle for Cassino, hub of the Gustav line and the greatest bastion of the German defenses below Rome, is within 500 yards of its end, according to the latest information reaching this headquarters this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Economical conduct of the war was reflected today in a letter from Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, to James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization, itemizing the Amy's saving of $27,000,000,000 of funds made available by Congress.

OTTAWA, Feb. 3 -- Lieut. Gen. A.G.L. McNaughton, who had been in command of the Canadian Army in Britain since the beginning of the war until his retirement was announced last month "on account of ill health," arrived in Canada today and said to an interviewer: "I am very fit; there is nothing the matter with me."

As several of the city's nineteen emergency coal depots ran out of supplies again yesterday, Edwin A. Salmon, municipal fuel administrator, said the opening of additional stations was being slowed up by the difficulty in locating suitable sites.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A midnight Moscow bulletin said nearly 10,000 Germans already had been killed in trying furiously to break out of the huge Ukrainian trap. An entire German regiment was wiped out in all-day fighting in one sector, fifty-eight German tanks destroyed or captured and scores of big guns seized, it said.

Of all the incendiary literary bombs manufactured in Moscow since the Teheran conference and thrown with such light-hearted recklessness into the unity of the Allied nations, none is likely to do greater damage than Izvestia's unjust and intemperate attack upon the Vatican as "pro-Fascist.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The diamond section again was the center of activity on the stock markets here today. De Beers rose sharply on a good demand and Consolidated and Anglo-American Trust also went ahead. Kaffirs were dull, Rhokana easing slightly.

The concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Bruno Walter, last night in Carnegie Hall was memorable both for splendid conducting and accomplished playing, throughout a program made up of Mahler's Fourth symphony, Brahms' "Tragic'' Overture and Schoenberg's "Verklaerte Nacht."
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 3 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

One observer listened and looked at the performance of Puccini's "Tosca" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House with very mixed feelings. The interest and excitement of the audience in this performance was manifest. The interpretation was dramatically short of the requirements of the libretto.

The second annual American Fashion Critics Award. for excellence in the field of fashion design was presented to three American fashion designers denoted as "tops in their fields in 1943" before an audience of 5,000 in the auditorium of Hunter College yesterday afternoon. The winners were Claire McCardell, designer of casual dresses and sportswear; Sally Victor, prominent milliner, and Mr. and Mrs. William Drown Phelps, the Phelps Associates, designers of leather accessories.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Presidential citations of twelve Army units for courage and outstanding performance of duty in the recapture of Attu in May were announced today by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War.

Retail food dealers from all parts of the city, tired of being blamed for black-market practices, which they concend originate at the wholesale level, formed a alliance yesterday with consumer organizations and sought the aid of the regional Office of Price Administration in a program to curb illegal sales.

The January thaw apparently has made a hurried exit, much to the delight of Eastern skiers, and now good to excellent snow conditions are to be found at most of the popular areas in the North. Heavy accumulations of snow fell in the wake of the recent unseasonable weather and yesterday's observations are far more encouraging than the reports of a week ago.

American fighter planes, which are now being used extensively to escort bombers on strategic missions, have not been designed for that purpose. Their use in shielding bombers therefore becomes a most complex procedure, the success of which once more attests the ingenuity, resourcefulness and skill of our personnel in theatres of action.

BEIRUT, Syria, Feb. 3 -- Lebanon has no desire to yield her sovereignty by joining any greater Syria constitutional structure that aims at regrouping in one State all the countries that after 1918 were carved from the old Ottoman Empire, President Bechera el Khoury said in a press interview.

Production of the Johns-Manville Corporation in 1943, the second full year of wartime operations, almost equaled the record-breaking volume established in 1942, measured by sales, Lewis H. Brown, president, declared in the annual report released last night to stockholders.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Britain manages to "hold the line" and in some instances even to push it back a bit in controlling the prices of necessaries for the working class in the past year, according to a survey just published in the Ministry of Labor Gazette.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 3 -- Dennis Morgan and Irene Manning, who played the leads in Warner Brothers' "The Desert Song," will be teamed again this summer by the studio in a musical comedy, "Henrietta VIII." The film will have a contemporary American setting and will be based on an original story by David Saunders.

MOSCOW, Friday, Feb. 4 -- Soviet troops of the First and Second Ukrainian fronts have encircled ten German divisions in a five-day advance of thirty-one to forty-six miles along a 100-mile front in the middle Dnieper region, it was announced officially last night.

The first-degree murder trial of Wayne Lonergan, who strangled his young wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, was put off yesterday by Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions from Feb. 14 to Feb. 23. The action was coincidental with the revelation that the defense of the 27-year-old former Royal Canadian Air Force craftsman probably would be insanity.

"Three Russian Girls," a topical drama produced by Gregor Rabinovitch for United Artists release, will have its local premiere this morning at the Palace. Directed by Fedor Ozep and Henry Kesler, the picture stars Anna Sten and Kent Smith, with Mimi Forsaythe, Alexander Granach, Kathy Frye and Paul Guilfoyle among the supporting players.

An added incentive for the many stars who will compete in the thirty-seventh annual Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night is the Rodman Wanamaker International Trophy. This coveted prize, placed in competition as a perpetual trophy in 1925, will be awarded to the meet's outstanding performer.

North of the narrow flying field stood Mount Bataan, its jagged crater rising 4,600 feet above us into the clear, cool sky. To the south, smoke still was rising from the rubble which a few days before had been the little seaport town of Mariveles.

Apart from current shortages, the liquor and wine industry is faced with two major problems now and during the post-war period -- the "dry threat" and the "low opinion" of its activities in the public mind -- Kenneth S. Baxter, executive director of the Conference of Alcoholic Beverage Industries, declared yesterday at the first annual meeting of the Association of Wine and Spirits Wholesalers of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Criticism of the wartime public power policy of the Federal Government is contained in the annual report of the State Power Authority, sent to the Legislature today.
LONDON, Feb. 3 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The stock market suffered yesterday a short-lived but radical shaking out, during which values slumped more than a point. The retreat was crowded into the noon hour and stopped almost as quickly as it started. Thereafter, the list negotiated a slow recovery which left prices generally above the lows of the day.

This week-end USO observes the third anniversary of its founding by holding open house at its many clubs and inviting the public to drop in to see what is being done for the comfort and the entertainment of our young men and women in military uniform. The public will conclude, we believe, that no country has ever done better by its youth at arms.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Seizure of the Marshall Islands will not only shorten our lines of communication and supply to the South and Southwest Pacific but widen the cracks in Japan's outer defense ring that guards Tokyo and the Philippines, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, stated at a news conference today.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Friday, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- Allied Liberator bombers and attack planes, preparing the way for the next land drive against the Japanese in New Guinea, battled through tropical storms Wednesday to batter the enemy's Madang-Alexishafen area with 107 tons of bombs, it was announced today.

ABOARD SEVENTH AAF LIBERATOR OVER KWAJALEIN, Feb. 1 (Delayed) -- The air over Kwajalein Island is filled with United States war planes and the sea is alive with American warships as landing craft line up offshore for a beach assault on this smoking Japanese stronghold.

The favorable tenor of war news, combined with increased liquidation, yesterday halted the rapid advance of the cotton market. After early gains of as much as 50 cents a bale, prices declined steadily. At the close of trading active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 2 to off 9 points.

The Board of Higher Education has requested an appropriation of $5,500 by the Board of Estimate to help finance the designing of the four municipal colleges' $715,900 post-war program of plant reconstruction and reconditioning, it was revealed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set March 7 for a hearing on the United Corporation's plan to comply with corporation simplification provisions of the Holding Company Act.

To finance community and wartime projects, members of the Association of Junior Leagues of America spent $489,790 in 1943, their directors learned yesterday from a report made by Mrs. Robert E. Dingman, consultant on ways and means.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Arabian-American Oil Company, jointly owned by the Standard Oil Company of California and The Texas Company, will begin immediately the construction of a privately owned and financed refinery in Saudi Arabia to make petroleum war products for the United Nations, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and Petroleum Administrator for War, announced here today.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Czechoslovakia, by virtue of the treaty binding her fortunes to those of the Soviet Union, now considers her foreign policy settled and her security assured, Dr. Eduard Benes, President of the Czechoslovak Government-in-exile, said today in addressing the State Council for the first time in fourteen months.

A Veterans' Counseling Service to aid returning service men and women in planning educational programs in consideration of their military and naval occupations has been established at New York University, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A report on international cartels, charging that the cartel became an instrument of war and propaganda in the hands of German interests, was made public today by the war mobilization subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Military Affairs.

Instead of the improved supply of essential cotton textiles which Latin-American countries had been led to expect would result from the War Production Board's "set aside" order covering 10 per cent of domestic output, textile exporters declared yesterday that a new bottleneck has developed as a result of the increasing number of license applications being returned by the Foreign Economic Administration on the grounds that individual country quotas, never officially announced, have been exhausted.

In a population of 1,500,000 in the Tadzhik Soviet Socialist Republic (capital, Stalinabad) it is a mathematical certainty that there must be more than one gifted poet. It is no trouble at all to imagine such a native Tadzhik bard addressing the Russian Soviet Federated Socialist Republic (population 110,000,000; capital, Moscow) in some such terms:

MADRID, Feb. 3 (UP) -- The Spanish Cabinet, under the presidency of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, met this afternoon following a two-hour discussion by Ambassador Carlton J. H. Hayes and Count Francisco Gomez de Jordana, the Foreign Minister, on American-Spanish relations.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities to have decreased $245,519,000 during the week while reserve note circulation increased $132,765,000.

Since the war began there has been an increase in the prevalence of bigotry, as evidenced by occurrences in many parts of the country, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman declares in an article entitled "Bigotry Is Un-American," in the current issue of the American Magazine.

The purpose of the special meeting of stockholders of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., to be held in Montreal on March 1 is to increase the borrowing capacity of the company as well as to strengthen further the position of the preferred stock, the proxy statement shows.

Money is pouring in from subscribers to the Fourth War Loan Drive, but most of it is going, temporarily, into the Government's war loan accounts in commercial banks. Yesterday the Treasury made known that it will make withdrawals on Monday and Tuesday from these accounts, but these withdrawals will be based on the funds in these accounts on Jan. 15, which was just before the present drive started.

Business and civic leaders, as well as his associates in the diplomatic and consular services, joined yesterday in tribute to Sir Godfrey Haggard, who is retiring after five years as British Consul General in this city. He was the guest of honor of the Rotary Club at luncheon in the Hotel Commodore and received a testimonial parchment scroll from that organization.

The four five-story apartment houses at 5401-15 Park Avenue, comprising the entire blockfront from Fifty-fourth to Fifty-fifth Streets, West New York, N.J., have been sold by the Sanger Investment Company to the Elber Realty Corporation (William J. Berkman, president).

Schuster Again Heads Salesmen Mel Schuster, who has traveled the Far West for many years representing several outstanding New York lines, was re-elected president of the Far Western Travelers Association, Inc., at the annual meeting of the organization last night at its headquarters at 23 West Seventy-third Street.

By reducing from nineteen to four pages the financial reporting forms which corporations will receive this month from the Office of Price Administration, that agency has taken a long step toward effecting greater compliance on the part of industry besides simplifying its own study of facts on which to base decisions as to the adequacy of existing price ceilings, it was declared yesterday by cost accountants.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- More than 2,000 heavy Army Air Force bombers are now collaborating with the Royal Air Force in carrying devastation to Germany and its satellite states, Gen. George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, said here tonight.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Grover Cleveland Bergdoll, 50, draft dodger of the first World War, was released from the disciplinary barracks today, and the Government closed its books on the twenty-seven-year old case.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- George Murphy, head of the recreation section of the Office of Civilian Requirements, today agreed to support a Government-approved program which would sustain professional sports for the duration, provided there is no interference with any phase of the war effort.

Adolph G. Kraus resigned as technical adviser to the downtown rationing board yesterday in the middle of a hearing at Office of Price Administration headquarters in the Empire State Building, where he was appearing as counsel for a meat wholesaler in a price-violation case.

One robber suspect pleaded guilty and another was acquitted yesterday in Kings County Court when the testimony of a hold-up victim, now dead, was read in Brooklyn Felony Court to Judge Peter J. Brancato and a jury. The victim, Joseph Kryznonek of 164 Dupont Street, Brooklyn, committed suicide on Jan. 25 in Brooklyn City Prison, where he was being held as a material witness.

Magistrate Morris Rothenberg was elected last night as president of the Jewish National Fund of America at the annual meeting of representatives of the Zionist Organization of America; Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America; Mizrachi, the Orthodox Zionist Organization, Poale Zion-Zeire Zion, the Zionist Labor party and other groups working for the fund at 41 East Forty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Raymond Clapper, Scripps-Howard newspaper columnist and radio commentator, was killed in an airplane crash during the invasion of the Marshall Islands, the Navy announced today.

DETROIT, Feb. 3 -- Defying orders of their union officials to return to work, 6,500 employes of the Chevrolet gear and axle division of General Motors Corporation were on strike here today, with the result that four of the division's plants were closed.

AT A UNITED STATES TROOP CARRIER COMMAND STATION in Britain, Feb. 3 -- All the twin-engined transport planes on this station look alike in their grubby green-brown war paint, but one is really different. Its two chief points of difference are the white lettered name Butchski on the nose and the fact that its entire crew of five are all from New York.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, who thus far has sponsored the only legislative proposal for revising the method of selecting Supreme Court justices, which became an issue as a result of the Aurelio case, introduced two new proposals today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Department store sales last month were 6 per cent above those of January, 1943, and the seasonally adjusted index for the month is estimated at 151, compared with 143 a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- First of the major procurement agencies of the Government to announce a program for disposal of surplus materials, the United States Maritime Commission today gave details of a plan for unified procedure for disposal of surplus property and set up an order of preference for such sales.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Federal financial aid to help the country through the post-war demobilization period will be worth anything it costs if it succeeds in keeping up the present productive momentum, Henry J. Kaiser told the House Public Buildings and Grounds Committee today.
MADRID, Feb. 3 -- The Spanish Cabinet tonight ratified a policy of strict neutrality and announced it would demand the strictest conformity not only from its own nationals but from foreign subjects.

NAMUR ISLAND, Kwajalein Atoll in the Marshalls, Feb. 2 (Delayed) -- United States Marines are mopping up on the last enemy resistance today on Roi and Namur Islands, all but leveled by the heaviest naval bombardment in history that cleared the way for the invasion forces.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Robert E. Hannegan, new chairman of the Democratic National Committee, credited the Roosevelt administration tonight with saving America from "the disaster of inflation" and accused Republicans of "never offering constructive help."

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz announced yesterday that he would dismiss an indictment charging Murray Goldman, 29 years old, of 145 Sumner Avenue, Brooklyn, with attempted rape if Acting District Attorney Thomas Cradock Hughes failed to prosecute the case by Feb. 14.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The Germans were reported tonight to have notified Pope Pius XII that the fate of Rome would be "subject to military considerations," but the Pope has refused to abandon "his Rome."

Every bit as weary as the housewife whose shopping trip is studded with the stony stares of butchers, the city's two official shoppers who had set out Wednesday in search of 25,000 pounds of poultry in the open markets reported yesterday to Commissioner of Purchase Albert Pleydell that they had been able to buy only 6,800 pounds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Air power will be the dominating factor in winning this war and in maintaining the peace, Viscount Trenchard, creator of the Royal Air Force as an entity in World War I and Britain's Chief of Air Staff from 1918 to 1929, asserted today.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in a two-to-one decision yesterday that the Selective Service Administration practice of setting separate quotas for the calling of Negro and white men did not constitute illegal discrimination.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 4 -- The aerial offensive against Germany proper was resumed yesterday after a lull of four days when more than 700 Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Strategic Air Force and about half as many fighters hit the important port cities of Wilhelmshaven and Emden.

I read with great interest the excerpts from Commissioner Herlands' statement and the Committee of Justices of the Domestic Relations Courts report on conditions found by them in the Shelter of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, located on upper Fifth Avenue.

Sales of $916,069,700 more in Fourth War Loan bonds in New York City were reported yesterday by the State War Finance Committee. This is the highest sales volume announced on any single day since the start of the current drive and is two and a half times the previous high for a day reported on Wednesday.

Much was made of the increase in venereal diseases at the annual conference of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association and 118 other health associations. The reason is that in the 15-to-19-year-old age group the incidence of syphilis has increased 140 per cent since 1941.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A belief is held by some officials of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Association and representatives of some of the smaller United Nations on the UNRRA council that the United States Army is using its wartime preeminence to make agreements with European governments in exile which will leave UNRRA with little to do and nowhere to go.

One of the advance post-war signs is the increasing attention to war memorials. Before long thousands of cities and towns will have committees, appointed by municipal administrators or self-appointed, to investigate this question.

The suit brought by Jockey Robert Merritt to compel the Jockey Club and the New York State Racing Commission to grant a license for him to ride on the tracks in this State was heard in the Appellate Division yesterday. After hearing argument, the Court reserved decision.

Dr. Morris Weiss, 57 years old, of 960 Sterling Place, Brooklyn; his wife, Bella, 43, and Dr. Saul (Sam) Apfel, 45, of 897 Park Place, Brooklyn, who were taken into custody Wednesday in a raid on a ground-floor apartment at 60 East Ninety-sixth Street, were indicted yesterday on abortion charges.

Speaking before 800 persons at the annual dedication dinner of the American Red Morgen Dovid for Palestine, Inc., at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night, Representative Emanuel Celler said he would introduce a bill in the House of Representatives making it mandatory "that the State Department, like all other departments, give a report each year to the people through their duly elected Representatives in Congress."

Branch Rickey's long quest to gain contact with his roving manager, Leo Durocher, finally reaped its reward yesterday when the Dodger major-domo announced that he had caught up with the skipper, via long-distance telephone, at Camp MacDill, Tampa, Fla.
HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- The Federal grand jury indicted Edward M. Sheridan, 28, today on charges of draft evasion because he had listed his horse as a dependent.

Asserting that the Board of Regents program for post-war education is "farsighted, forward-looking and defensible at practically every point," Dr. J. Hillis Miller, associate State commissioner of education, told yesterday State district superintendents that the entire plan is now in the hands of those who can provide money to put it into effect.

Donations of forty-eight pints of blood by the same number of persons, whose names were recorded in the enrollment book on Feb. 3, 1941 -- opening day of the New York Red Cross Chapter's blood bank at 2 East Thirty-seventh Street -- were compared with the recent record of 1,800 pints in one day, during brief exercises yesterday to mark the center's third anniversary.

The war picture today is of furious and victorious Allied action on four great fronts. The assault on the Marshall Islands is proceeding with a swiftness that reveals the massive force we have put behind the blow. The Russian armies have encircled ten German divisions in the Ukraine and swept forward in a mighty rush across the Estonian frontier, deep into pre-war Poland and far along the road to the borders of Latvia.

Suggesting that foreign correspondents in this country educate the British public about the United States, "since we don't get many British tourists over here compared with the large number of American tourists to Britain," Sir Godfrey Haggard, retiring British Consul General in New York, called the lack of British newspaper space an obstacle in recording American affairs.

Stressing the critical need for more salvaged paper, Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, chief of the Army Supply Services, declared yesterday that the "toughest job" of the war lies ahead. With Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board; Rear Admiral Harry L. Brinser, inspector of naval material, and Mayor La Guardia, he spoke at an emergency meeting of the salvage committee of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A discussion of tax simplification during which Senators criticized Wendell L. Willkie's proposal for higher taxes was touched off in the Senate today by a resolution introduced by Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin.

Coward-McCann announces that the Canadian fiction and non-fiction contest which it is conducting in cooperation with Longmans, Green in Toronto has been extended to June 20, 1944. The contest prize for the winning manuscript written by a Canadian citizen on any subject is $1,000 in addition to royalties.

Commissioner of Licences Paul Moss was scolded yesterday in a decision of Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan for withholding the license of a theatre broker and was upheld in another decision by the same judge in the case of another broker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- During the week ended Feb. 2, member bank reserve balances decreased $155,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from decreases of $253,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $18,000,000 in gold stock and an increase of $147,000,000 in money in circulation, offset in part by decreases of $9,000,000 in Treasury cash and $176,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks and $76,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Military experts and civilian observers figured that the total casualties of the war are in excess of 25,000,000. The Baltimore Evening Sun said today, adding that United States casualties had been fewer than those of any other major combatant.

The Republican County Committee of the Twenty-first Congressional District last night nominated William S. Bennet as its candidate in the special election on Feb. 29 to pick a successor to James A. Gavagan, Democrat, who resigned upon election to the Supreme Court in November.
CLEVELAND. Feb. 3 (AP) -- Owner Alva Bradley assured the American League today he had no intention of closing League Park, where his Indians play baseball.

Predictions of a meat shortage that were made Wednesday by New York's non-slaughtering wholesalers show signs of coming' true in the near future, according to several market authorities. A spokesman for the United States Department of Agriculture says that receipts of Western lamb, which have been plentiful for many weeks, already are tapering off and that local slaughtering has decreased appreciably.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 3 -- If the American democratic system of free enterprise is to survive, it must shoulder its share of the stupendous responsibility of providing jobs for returning service men, John A. Stevenson of Philadelphia, president of the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company, said tonight at a conference of company leaders in the Hotel Claridge.

If he is like his leading player and has a conscience, Ernest Pascal must be catching the very devil this morning. For Mr. Pascal was out on the town last evening, as both the author of "Peepshow" and its co-producer, and if the man who follows him around has nothing to say about it, that conscience is not honest and should be dismissed.

DETROIT, Feb. 3 -- The veteran Syd Howe punched in six goals tonight for a National Hockey League record as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the New York Rangers, 12 to 2, before 8,147 spectators at the Olympia Stadium. The Wings thus seized sole possession of second place, breaking their tie with the idle Toronto Maple Leafs.

Only one opening is now scheduled for the week after next. It is "Caukey," due at the Blackfriars Guild on Thursday night, Feb. 17. Rev. Thomas M. McGlynn wrote the play, which deals with problems confronting Negroes. The author is the son of Frank McGlynn, who gave a memorable portrayal of Abraham Lincoln in the John Drinkwater play of that name.

Sister Elizabeth Kenny, discoverer of the Kenny method for the treatment of infantile paralysis, said yesterday, in an interview at the St. Regis Hotel, that she was seriously considering leaving this country because technical assistance she desired had not been forthcoming.

while the late Lou Gehrig continued to hold first place, Mel Ott, Player-manager of the Giants, made the biggest spurt in the latest tabulation of votes for the Sports Popularity Poll, which is being conducted by the Fourth War Loan Drive Sports Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The House of Representatives, accepting President Roosevelt's challenge to "stand up and be counted" on a decision between a Federal or State ballot program for voting by the armed forces in the November elections, voted 224 to 168 by roll-call late tonight to reject finally the Administration-sponsored Worley bill.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have captured the Tanai River village of Taipha Ga in northern Burma, opening the way for a drive on the important Japanese supply base of Maingkwan to the south, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

One of the long-held convictions of every respectable American -- that "nice women don't dye their hair" -- rapidly is crumbling. Perhaps this is partly because the tints, dyes and rinses developed in the last few years are designed to imitate the natural color of one's own hair rather than to effect radical changes that look garish.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- A flying wreck of a British Lancaster wabbled down to an English airdrome at dawn Monday with a strange story of having tried to land on a German airfield by mistake -- a mistake that the Germans themselves righted for the crew just in time.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The nation's airlines added to surpluses and reduced indebtedness in the twelve months ended last June 30, the Civil Aeronautics Board reported today.

Unless conditions in the present American Expeditionary Forces are radically different from those which prevailed in 1918 and 1919, the question of the soldier vote is largely academic, as I am satisfied that few soldiers outside of continental United States will get a chance to cast their ballots.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3 -- Black Badge,' who has raced so well in Florida, further enhanced his chances for the rich Flamingo Stakes by scoring decisively in the Coconuts Purse at Hialeah Park today when certain conditions seemed adverse.
ALGIERS, Feb. 3 -- A communique:

An East Side property, recently acquired from a bank, figured in a resale yesterday when David W. Frankel, operator, disposed of the twelve-story business structure at 104-12 East Twenty-fifth Street to a syndicate of investors represented by Bernard Barnett, attorney.

Gifts to the New York Public Library during 1943 totaled more than $2,200,000 and 203,285 books, pamphlets, maps, prints, photographs, programs, copies of sheet music, posters and newspapers, it was revealed at the library yesterday.

ALGIERS, Feb. 3 -- The French Committee of National Liberation has suggested to the Allies that the Italian Provisional Government be recast by dropping King Victor Emmanuel and Premier Pietro Badoglio without awaiting the fall of Rome.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, Feb. 3 -- Small advance elements of American infantry, supported by a few tanks, crept up to battered Cassino today, but were driven back again with some losses, and late this afternoon the Germans remained in full control of the stone-built hillside town that has been transformed into a strong and exceedingly well-camouflaged fortress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The reception here of Mr. Willkie's speech on fiscal policy at New York Times Hall last night was, for the most part, dismal confirmation that the elected of the people firmly believe a display of this type of courage and candor by a Presidential candidate, even in wartime, is politically fatal.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- Martin Hagenah, owner of the Fair Play Trucking Company in Brooklyn, was fined $3,500 here today by County Judge Frederick G. Schmidt for having given a $600 bribe on Aug. 28, 1942, to David J. Soule, former State Police sergeant now serving five to ten years in Sing Sing prison for accepting bribes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Higher prices for livestock, fruits and vegetables largely were responsible for a rise of 0.1 per cent in the Bureau of Labor Statisitcs index of commodity prices in primary markets during the last week of January.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Army officer candidate schools in the United States and abroad have graduated more than 240,000 men since the program started in September, 1941, the War Department stated today, as it announced that the training program had been sharply cut because the first demand for junior officers had been met.
PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 3 -- American forces now hold the entire northern portion of Kwajalein Atoll and are engaged in hard fighting against stubborn enemy forces in the south on Kwajalein Island itself.

Raymond Clapper went from life as a man of his high quality would choose to go. He died in harness. He died on the hot trail of the biggest news of the day. It was characteristic of him that he should have followed close to our forces in their desperate drive against the enemy-owned Marshalls.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A report on travel time from portal to portal by underground bituminous mine workers, submitted to President Roosevelt today by a committee headed by Morris L. Cooke, confronted the National War Labor Board with the problem of whether to reduce the miners' basic daily wage of $8.50.

ONE uncanny power which motion pictures have is the ability to roll back the years to the forgotten or vaguely remembered yesterdays. That is the great value of the production "Kings of the Ring," which is currently showing just off Broadway, an approximate mashie shot from Jacobs Beach, where the fight mob basks daily in the winter sun.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Maximum prices for all sales of packaged whisky to stockholders of the American Distilling Company under its recent distribution plan were announced by the Office of Price Administration today, in advance of an OPA order covering details of the sales.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Col. Oveta Culp Hobby, director of the Women's Army Corps, who has just returned from a twenty-six-day, 29,000-mile inspection tour in England, North Africa and Italy, predicted today that in an invasion "the Wac will go in as soon as lines are established and field establishments set up."

Total newspaper advertising linage for, eight New York newspapers during January showed an increase of 2.1 per cent over the same month of 1943, according to Meda Records. The largest percentage gain in any classification was recorded in financial advertising, an advance of 28.6 per cent. General advertising, with 10.4 per cent ran second, and retail increased 2.1 per cent.

Raymond Clapper went from life as a man of his high quality would choose to go. He died in harness. He died on the hot trail of the biggest news of the day. It was characteristic of him that he should have followed close to our forces in their desperate drive against the enemy-owned Marshalls.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 4 (AP) -- A decree of the New Jersey Court of Chancery dismissing in 1933 a suit instituted against the American Tobacco Company by stockholders who objected to an officers' stock allotment plan was challenged today in the State Court of Errors and Appeals.

BOUND BROOK, N.J., Feb. 4 -Dr. Sidney Albert Cook, for twenty-two years head of the Department of Philosophy and Psychology at the New Jersey College for Women in New Brunswick, was found dead today with a bullet hole in his head beside his wrecked automobile on Mountain Avenue, in Bridgewater Township, near here.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY ON THE ANZIO BEACHHEAD IN ITALY, Feb. 2 (Delayed) -- Is the fateful pattern of Salerno being repeated on this wide but shallow bridgehead within sight of Rome's radio towers?

William A Patterson, president of United Air Lines, Inc., has been elected a director of the Stewart-Warner Corporation to fill the vacancy created by the death of Frank A. Ross, senior vice president, it was announced yesterday by James S. Knowlson, chairman of the board and president.

" Our Town," the film version of the Thornton Wilder play produced by Sol Lesser for United Artists release, will start a revival engagement this morning at the Manhattan Theatre, Broadway and Fifty-first Street. The drama, which had its premiere at the Radio City Music Hall in June, 1940, includes Martha Scott, William Holden, Thomas Mitchell, Fay Bainter, Beulah Bondi, Guy Kibbee, Stuart Erwin and Frank Craven among its featured players.

A raid reminiscent of the prohibition era resulted yesterday in the arraignment in Brooklyn Federal Court of three men charged with operating a modern air-conditioned bootleg plant camouflaged in a three-story frame dwelling at 1,715 Bath Avenue, Brooklyn.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 4 -- The University of Minnesota is "absolutely willing" to cooperate with Sister Elizabeth Kenny in investigating the possibilities of her newly announced discovery for the early diagnosis of infantile paralysis, Dr. Harold S. Diehl, dean of medical sciences at the university, said today
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- Navy communique 501:

Directors of the Aluminum Company of America authorized yesterday a 50-cent dividend on the common stock for payment on March 10. Gordon W. Cameron, treasurer, states that prior to recent three-for-one split-up of common stock the company had been paying $1 a share in each of the first three quarters of the year and $3 in the fourth quarter, making a total of $6 for the year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 -- Producers Corporation of America has begun negotiations with Joan Blondell to return to the screen in a musical version of "The Greeks Had a Word for It." John Cecil Holm, the New York playwright, is due here Tuesday to write the screen play.

One of the severest jolts of the present year was administered yesterday to the stock market when sharp inroads in the liquor issues on the New York Stock Exchange produced a general uneasiness throughout the list. Although a few specialties managed to keep their heads above water, the further inability of the industrials to certify the recent strength in the rails brought out periods of selling.

Jarmila Novotna, Czech soprano of the Metropolitan, whose European activities have included the Paris Opera, La Scala of Milan and the Vienna and Berlin Operas, has been engaged for the chief role in "Helen Goes To Troy," the Jacques Offenbach-Henri Meilhac-Ludovic Halevy operetta which the New Opera Company will present.

A 62-year-old widow, Mrs. Marian J. Bennett of 380 Riverside Drive, was sentenced yesterday to two to five years in prison by General Sessions Judge Owen W. Bohan after she had pleaded guilty of defrauding another widow, Mrs. Bessie Edmond Andrus, 230 West Fifty-ninth Street, of $7,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Senate, by a vote of 46 to 42, rejected the proposed "States' rights" substitute for the pending Green-Lucas Service Men's Voting Bill today. The action, opening the way for a more liberal use of the Administration-sponsored Federal ballot than the substitute would have permitted, was taken after the House last night adopted by 328 to 69 the Eastland-Rankin bill, which would allow the use of State ballots only.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4 -- Once again a Hialeah Park stake has had to be split, because of the large number of entries, and there will be two Miami Beach Handicaps tomorrow, each carrying $5,000 in added money.
LONDON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Charles Minot Dole, chairman of the National Ski Patrol System, yesterday came through with an informative report on important operations of that voluntary organization. Certificates of merit have gone to nine patrols scattered over the nation for the "performance of services for their country far beyond their regular duties and in accordance with our contract with the War Department."
