HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 4 -- Telescoped into a day and a half because of Navy leave regulations, which govern most of this year's contestants, the thirty-fourth annual winter carnival of the Dartmouth Outing Club gets under way tomorrow morning on Balch Hill with the downhill race.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 4 -- Arno Anthoni has been removed from his post as head of the Finnish State police, which he had obtained through German influence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -The Office of Price Administration tonight set maximum prices for oats, barley and grain sorghums at "freeze" levels, but said oats and barley would be reduced later to reflect parity.

Alarmed by the overnight ruling of the Office of Price Administration in Washington on the base prices at which stockholders of the American Distilling Company may sell the liquor they are entitled to purchase from the company at cost, provided State laws permit them to do so, trading in the shares did not open on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday until 11:10 A.M., when the first transaction, involving 2,500 shares, was off 5 points.

They are the children who do not figure in the disquieting juvenile statistics, though they are all around us. They are like the motorists who do not contribute to the country's accident record, like the taxpayers who do not get into trouble with the Internal Revenue Collector, like the happy nations in the adage whose annals are blank.

The fifteen-family flat at 62 Kensington Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by the Collins Holding Company (Charles Clott, president) to the Phildor Realty Corporation for $21,500 above a $42,000 mortgage held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

First of the campaign's major track and field extravaganzas, the thirty-seventh annual Millrose A.A. invitation games, will be presented tonight at Madison Square Garden, where a capacity crowd is expected to turn out for the featured tests, the twenty-ninth Wanamaker Mile and the thirtieth Mel Sheppard 600.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A captured German Ju-88 airplane has been carefully inspected at Wright Field after being flown across the Atlantic and found to be "rough and ready and a plane to inspire respect at any time."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -- The ten-acre estate of the late Frederic Stanley Groves Jr. in the exclusive residential district of Riverton, N.J., north of Camden, has been sold to a group of retired white and Negro school teachers.

Play in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association championship doubles was started yesterday at the University Club. It originally was planned to carry on the tournament both there and at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn, but the entry list did not require that. Only twenty-eight players for six starting matches and two byes were listed.
Eddie Aubel called to point out an oversight in the recent column about Jimmie Hayes, one of the many surf fishermen who "roll their own" so far as making a lot of their gear is concerned.

The major emphasis in the Fourth War Loan drive is on sales to individuals. Now that the larger purchases of insurance companies, savings banks and corporations are swelling the subscription figures, we must not lose sight of the importance of individual participation.

The War Production Board's order reducing the amount of wood pulp that can be used in this country to make newsprint threatens the future of newsprint mills in the United States, according to a statement issued yesterday by the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

NAMUR ISLAND, Kwajalein Atoll, The Marshalls, Feb. 3 (Delayed) -- Scattered snipers and unseen enemy wounded remain on this shattered, stinking island, but the actual end of sustained combat came at 1 P.M. yesterday in a little corner near the northwest tip of Namur Island as the marines pressed in for the kill.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., playing the greens superbly, carded a five under par 66 to take a two-stroke lead today at the end of the first round of the seventy-two-hole Phoenix Open.

Refusing to condone the use of a merchant marine service uniform by an OPA inspector to gather evidence of rationing violation against a shoe dealer, Harry B. Chambers, Chief Regional OPA Hearing Commissioner, yesterday dismissed a complaint against Clark's Shoes, 117 West Forty-second Street.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 3 (Delayed) -- "There will be no civil war between the Central government and the Chinese Communists," Gen. Ho Ying-chin, Minister of War, declared unequivocably in an exclusive interview with THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Feb. 3 (Delayed) -- The battle for Cisterna will be remembered as one of the bloodiest and most fiercely contested of the whole war. Hardly a foot of ground has changed hands in the fifth day of fighting. From a haphazard, thinly held defense that relied chiefly on farmhouses for strongpoints, the enemy since Sunday has amassed a very considerable force.
PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The text of Admiral Nimitz' proclamation establishing a military government in the Marshall Islands follows:

Reflecting peak sales of $53,631,634 for the year ended on Jan. 1, the consolidated net income of the Purity Bakeries Corporation increased to $2,210,010 after all charges, from $1,714,538 earned in the preceding year, Lewis A. Cushman, chairman and president, reported yesterday in his annual statement to stockholders.

TORONTO, Feb. 4 -- To supply additional men to work in the Maine woods would aggravate the acute shortage existing in the Canadian forests, the Ontario Forest Industries Association stated today in citing figures which showed the four Eastern provinces of Canada were short 19,500 men.

Marriage information bureaus for men in the armed forces will be established by the American Women's Voluntary Services at all its units near military camps, it was announced yesterday at national AWVS headquarters at 342 Madison Avenue. The bureaus will be patterned after the successful one set up Oct. 25 in the Brooklyn Municipal Building.

Subscriptions to the Fourth War Loan reported yesterday sent the nation-wide total to $10,298,000,000, or 74 per cent of the goal; that of New York State to $3,453,000,000, or 82.3 per cent of the State goal; and that in this city to $3,135,022,500, or 85.1 per cent of its goal.
PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 4 -- American forces have occupied two more Kwajalein Atoll islands against moderate resistance and have occupied half another small island.

Sermons will be preached tomorrow in the churches of New York City in anticipation of the anniversary of Lincoln's birth next Saturday. "Lincoln Speaks Again" will be the topic of the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Fortyeighth Street.

In the first official indication of the extent to which nylon yarn output has been expanded since Pearl Harbor, when military demands forced abandonment of civilian outlets, Robert A. Ramsdell, sales director of the nylon division of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., declared last night that when military needs subside "nylon yarn capacity, even at the present rate, will be sufficient to supply most of the hosiery industry."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Office of Civilian Requirements of the War Production Board today advised shoppers that they must expect to do with fewer package wrappings this year because a war shortage of wood pulp for paper making will not permit a normal supply of wrapping paper and bags.

During the long and frequently bitter debate in the House of Representatives on the question of legislation to facilitate the soldier's vote, a great deal was said on all sides about the attitude of the Southern Representatives on such matters as States' rights, the poll tax and (in the words of one Southern member of Congress) the question of "white supremacy."

New municipal financing will continue light next week, reflecting the fact that most communities prefer to await the conclusion of the present war loan drive before entering the investment market. New issues scheduled for award next week amount to only $5,326,295, compared with this week's revised total of $14,666,303. The weekly average for the year to date now stands at $23,358,303.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Reporting the Government's plans to import 40,000,000 bushels of wheat from Canada by rail this year, representatives of Federal agencies said today that it was more practical to tap Canada's exportable surplus than those of Argentina and Australia.

A trend to State monopolies of liquor sales through proposed legislation to be offered this year and next calls for strong action on the part of the industry if private enterprise in the present "free" States is to continue, Thomas J. Donovan, general counsel to Allied Liquor Industries, declared yesterday before the first annual meeting of the Wine and Spirits Wholesalers of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The encroachments of the Federal Government upon local political subdivisions, which cause losses in tax revenues to those areas, including the Township of Hyde Park, N.Y., met with the protests of officials from seven States yesterday at a hearing before the Congressional Committee on Public Lands.

Action taken yesterday by the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange may be interpreted as a strong indication that Emil Schram, former head of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, will continue as president of the Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Bills to re-establish the ranks of General of the Armies and Admiral of the Navy, one grade above general and admiral, now the highest ranks in the armed services, were introduced in the Senate and House today.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- A recommendation that a permanent election frauds bureau be set up within the State Department of Law to insure future elections "free from the taint of fraud" was advanced today with the consent of Attorney General Nathaniel I. Goldstein.
LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 5 -- American heavy bombers did it again yesterday, smashing at Frankfort on the Main in large force with escorting fighters.

The Soviet Government is moving as fast politically as the Red armies are moving in the field. The two movements, of course, are closely related; this was never so apparent as in the decision to extend autonomy in foreign policy and military defense to the republics of the Union.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace warned here tonight that a post-war struggle for power among "the big three -- big business, big labor and big agriculture" -- might bring fascism to this country.

Georgette Michel, youthful soprano of this city, made her local debut last night in Town Hall. The program began with a group of early classics by Stradella, Scarlatti, Caldara and Paisiello. French lyrics by Xavier Leroux and Debussy and Norina's caratina from Donizetti's "Don Pasquale" completed the first half of the list.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Appropriations Committee reported today a bill to provide $1,318,519,672 for operation of the Treasury and Postoffice Departments during the fiscal year 1945, together with a recommendation for steps to abolish "very unhealthy competition" for manpower among Federal departments.

A sentimental song of hearts and flowers is the spring theme of costume Jewelry designers. Cupid's arrows, forget-me-nots and love birds have been worked into pins and earrings with a demure, oldfashioned air just in time to make charming ways of saying "Be my valentine."

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- Moscow's broadcast war communiques said the Germans were suffering enormous losses in men and equipment as they unsuccessfully tried to break out of the 1,000-square mile trap in the middle Dnieper.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Feb. 5 -- Eighty Japanese planes were destroyed on the ground and in the air as Liberators and Mitchells, with United States fighter support, hurled a record of 200 tons of bombs on the Japanese airfields at Wewak, New Guinea, on Thursday.

One way to achieve a well-balanced diet is to plan it with an eye to the basic seven food groups established by Government nutritionist. An approved menu for a single day includes at least one food from each of these groups, which consist of meat and fish and poultry, green and yellow vegetables, milk products and so ,on.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- Mrs. George B. St. George of Tuxedo Park, first cousin of President Roosevelt, was unanimously designated for delegate to the Republican National Convention at a meeting of Orange County Republicans tonight after Representative Hamilton Fish had waived his claim to the place.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt received the Good-Will Award of the James Monroe High School, 172d Street and Boynton Avenue, the Bronx, during a special assembly held in the school's auditorium yesterday morning. She told several thousand students that it was up to them to help build a "peace for future."

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Exports of British woolens to the United States, suspended since 1942 because of Britain's own clothing needs, will soon be resumed, it was learned today. It will be only a slight trickle, however -- a token rather than a supply -- designed merely to keep the American market alive.

Justice John E. McGeehan in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday warned that he would appeal to Mayor La Guardia and Governor Dewey to invoke a section of the City Charter calling for the removal of the Police Commissioner unless school bus lines now operating in the Bronx in violation of rulings of the New York State War Council discontinue their service immediately.

It will take twenty years to clear the Pacific islands of Japanese soldiers who will continue guerrilla warfare after Japan is beaten, Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker declared yesterday at a war bond luncheon at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

Too many schools in this country are run on an autocratic basis, with the teachers "cowed" by principals and supervisors, Dr. Robert K. Speer, chairman of the New York University Elementary Education Department. charged yesterday in an address before 1,500 parents and educators at the regional conference of the Progressive Education Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration and the Petroleum Administration for War made it plain today that they saw no need for cutting gasoline rations in this quarter, which ends March 31.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A reconversion plan under which companies re-entering civilian goods markets after completing war contracts would be limited to production of the amount of goods they sold in 1939 or 1940 has been blocked out at the War Production Board and is under study there.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- "Our patrols crossed Bougainville Wednesday and reached a point within five miles of Numa Numa on the east coast," General MacArthur's spokesman said today in announcing the land offensive across the rugged Emperor mountain range.

With all the decorum of veteran concert-goers, 150 spirited youngsters, 5 to 6 years old, listened silently to a children's concert given at Teachers College, Columbia University, yesterday. Sitting on miniature chairs in the school's kindergarten room, only their tapping feet betrayed controlled excitement as they listened to the folk tunes of radio artists Margaret Johnson and Bella Allen.

A year ago Marshal von Paulus and his army were marching through the ruined streets of Stalingrad not as conquerors but as prisoners. Ironically enough, that was the deepest penetration the Germans ever made into Russia. Two years ago the Nazis, after seven months of headlong assault, had failed to take Moscow.

The Nazi Transocean news agency said last night in an overseas wireless dispatch that "many civil servants of different Ministries" in the Vichy regime had participated in a "plot" to assassinate Joseph W. Darnand, pro-Nazi Secretary-General for the Maintenance of Order.

As regularly as the moon crosses the path of the planets, some conscientious police reporter tells newspaper readers of a baby found in a tenement, "neglected, cold and filthy." The circumstances of the neglect vary: sometimes the mother has wandered away for keeps, sometimes she has gone to look for a job, sometimes she has merely gone to the movies.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 -- Following is the prepared text of the speech delivered tonight before a win-the-war rally by Vice President Wallace:

Multi-family houses featured Brooklyn realty trading as reported by brokers yesterday. One of the leading deals involved the Embassy, 130-family apartment building occupying a blockfront at 7901 Fourth Avenue, which was sold by a group headed by Morris Goodman subject to an institutional mortgage of $405,450.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Roosevelt told his news conference today about a minor operation he underwent on Wednesday at the new Naval Hospital at Bethesda, Md. It was to remove what he called a wen on the back of his head.

Retail trade here this week was not quite as active as in the preceding two weeks. Percentage-wise, volume suffered somewhat by comparison with the high sales totals of February a year ago, when scare buying of apparel was a factor. However, it was believed the average for department stores here might run above the 1943 figures, depending upon sales results today.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 4 -- All powers of the Emperor of Japan in the areas of the Marshall Islands occupied by American forces have been suspended and vested in a military government headed by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet.

AT THE FIFTH ARMY BEACH-HEAD SOUTH OF ROME, 5:05 P.M., Feb. 4 -- Allied troops are fighting stubbornly against fierce continuing attacks by German infantry and armor against their beachhead within twenty miles of Rome.

Women's apparel woolens and worsteds for the fall season will be opened generally by mills during the latter half of this month and early March, with prices unchanged on staples from the previous season, and with strict allocations to hold, as has been the case for about two years. Previous to the war the openings were made a month or more later.

TRENTON, Feb. 4 -- Former Essex County Judge Walter D. Van Riper became Attorney General of New Jersey today and immediately received from Governor Walter E. Edge the special task of passing upon qualifications of prospective nominees to State judicial posts and prosecutorships.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 4 -Pvt. Howard Meinen of this city almost succeeded in stretching a three-day furlough into one of three years. His nemesis was a fruit-store window.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Feb. 4 -- In the successful offensive against the Marshalls the United States Navy has proved that carrier-borne aircraft can protect warships in operations against enemy shores protected by land-based aircraft if enough carriers are involved.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Allied Military Government is ready to turn control of Sicily and southern Italy over to the Armistice Commission on Feb. 10, it was learned today, but larger tasks than ever before are planned for the AMG despite criticism of it in high places in Washington.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 4 -- By a decree issued this afternoon, the Argentine Government severed diplomatic relations with the Governments of Bulgaria, Vichy France, Hungary and Rumania.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 -- Twenty-two thousand members of the Mechanics Educational Society of America (Independent) in Detroit and four Ohio cities joined in a walkout today as a result of a jurisdictional dispute with the CIO.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Maj. Gen. Clayton L. Bissell, now Deputy Assistant Chief of Staff, Military Intelligence Division of the Army, will assume command of Military Intelligence tomorrow, succeeding Maj. Gen. George V. Strong, who will be retired Feb. 29, after nearly forty-four years of service.

Although expenses of the New York Curb Exchange last year rose $10,732 to $862,198, income advanced $230,861 to $1,001,205 and resulted in a net profit of $121,855, the first addition to surplus since 1937, the Exchange reported yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 4 -- Further details of the Kwangtung famine were revealed by George Adams of Maplewood, N.J., in a speech at the famine relief benefit in Bankers Hall tonight. Mr. Adams, executive secretary of the Kwangtung International Relief Committee, has just returned from a month's trip into the famine area as close to Swatow as Japanese occupation permitted.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Execution of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Emanuel Weiss and Louis Capone, sentenced to death for the murder of a Brooklyn candy store owner in 1936, was stayed today until the week of Feb. 28 by Governor Dewey when he learned that counsel for the condemned men had obtained permission to seek a reargument of the case before the Court of Appeals.

Substitution of lawyers for laymen as referees in Workmen's Compensation cases is one of several recommendations in a memorandum submitted to Moreland Commissioners William F. Bleakley and Herman T. Stichman by a committee of lawyers of which Julius Henry Cohen, former general counsel to the Port of New York Authority, is chairman.

Impairment of the nation's food production program is resulting from the Federal Government's delay in announcing, ceilings or support prices for the 1944 vegetable crop, according to reports made at a conference of Farm Bureau presidents of thirteen Northeastern States at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -- A petition was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission protesting against a retirement annuity plan formulated by the United Gas Improvement Company and to be voted upon at a stockholders' meeting on Feb. 29.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- One of the first and most important tasks of the new War Refugee Board will be to see that refugees are moved out of European neutral countries to make room for others who might escape from Nazidom to take their places, according to John W. Pehle, whose appointment as acting executive director of the board was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Three Nazi blockade runners trying to sneak vital war materials from Japanese ports around Cape Horn to Germany were sunk early last month in the South Atlantic by American warships, the Navy Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Roosevelt is awaiting more information concerning the grant by Moscow of autonomous powers to the sixteen component republics of the Soviet Union in the fields of foreign affairs and defense before he will be in a position to make any comment concerning it, he said at his press conference today.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin in a decision yesterday set Feb. 14 for a "full trial" of the suit of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, which is seeking to set aside Fire Commissioner Patrick J. Walsh's emergency duty that would abolish the three-platoon system.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Harry H. Woodring, Secretary of War in the Roosevelt Cabinet until 1940, declared today his opposition to a fourth term for President Roosevelt and proposed that the Democratic party nominate Secretary of State Cordell Hull for the Presidency.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Jersey City's budget, introduced today on first reading, calls for a tax rate of $53.11 for each $1,000 of assessed valuation. This rate, however, is based on valuation compiled by the City Assessors and is subject to revision by the Hudson County Tax Board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Roosevelt said today that the cooperation out there in the Marshall Islands, presumably on the part of the press, was very good, since secrecy, which was the chief element in the action, had been so well maintained that the Japanese were taken by complete surprise.

Wendell L. Willkie left New York yesterday for a two-week political tour of the West. He was accompanied by Mrs. Willkie. Ralph Cake, Republican National Committeeman from Oregon, and Lamoyne T. Jones, Mr. Willkie's political secretary, who will also make the trip, left by an earlier train.

Salary increases of $2,500 a year were requested yesterday by four General Sessions Judges at a hearing before Thomas J. Patterson, Budget Director. Their requests were submitted by General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace, one of their five associates, who receive annual salaries of $25,000 compared with the $22,500 paid the petitioners.
The article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Jan. 29 headed "Would Appoint 769 Teachers Now" properly notes, "As substitutes are now filling the jobs, the actual addition to the budget would be $341,650."

New York, kept more than mildly baseball conscious ever since the curtain rang down on the 1943 world series, yesterday found itself again the focal point of the national pastime as the game's bigwigs trooped into the city to bring the current off-season to its grand climax.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Feb. 5 -- Russian soldiers and airmen carrying forward the battle to annihilate the ten enemy divisions encircled in the region of Zvenigorodka have captured seven more towns and shot down or destroyed seventy-three three-engined Junkers transport planes that might have been bringing reinforcements and supplies or evacuating trapped German soldiers, the Red Army communique announced last night.

I disagree somewhat with two recent writers to THE TIMES in their unreserved condemnation of "The Melting Pot" as a symbol of America, because I think they do not understand the real idea that is behind this symbol, imperfect as it may be.

Working with the women and children of Greece, combating the misery now existing among them and helping them readjust to peace conditions will be the task of representatives of the foreign division of the Young Women's Christian Association as part of a pattern just developed for post-war liberation relief work in Greece.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The average soldier or sailor writes 6.13 letters a week and, usually to obtain air mail service, pays postage on 1.03 of them, according to testimony by Postmaster General Frank Walker made public today by the House Appropriations Committee.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY OUTSIDE CASSINO, Feb. 4 -- American troops have now established a definite toehold in the northern outskirts of Cassino and are now engaged in a grim house-to-house fight in that battered stone wreckage heap, exchanging point-blank fire with German tanks.
ALGIERS, Feb. 4 -- The first thunderous blows of the Wehrmacht roared down on the Allied invasion forces below Rome yesterday and were believed to herald still heavier blows to come.

UNITED STATES PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- Rear Admiral Richmond K. Turner, commanding amphibious operations in the bold Marshalls invasion, revealed in a dispatch today that all troop transports and many of their supporting warships were now concentrated in the great Kwajalein lagoon, surrounded by the largest atoll in the world.

By its very participation in the war, America has inevitably assumed a large share of responsibility for the future of Europe. This applies not only to such questions as the fixing of post-war national boundaries and the provision of machinery for preserving peace but even, whether we like it or not, responsibility for the kind of government and regime within each of these countries.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker declared tonight that the Roosevelt Administration had made "a studied attempt to undermine the newspapers and radio" and called for lifting of governmental restrictions which he contended endangered the freedoms of press and speech.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Roosevelt signed the mustering-out payment bill today. He hailed it as "a first step" and called on Congress to adopt the rest of the program for the veterans which he has three times recommended in the last year.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 4 -- The Germans are re-grouping their forces in Yugoslavia and have recently brought up reinforcements from Bulgaria and Greece to replace units sent to the eastern front and Italy, according to a broadcast from the free Yugoslavia headquarters of the People's Army of Liberation.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 4 -- Patents for a method of making plastic molding material from coffee beans and for a baking machine which cooks through use of infrared rays stand out among the 564 listed as granted in this week's issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

Harry Thacker Burleigh, 78-year-old composer, who adapted the spirituals "Deep River" and "Were You There?", was honored last night at a reception marking the fiftieth anniversary of his membership in the choir of St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square and Sixteenth Street.

Submachine guns, a shotgun, revolvers, a running pistol duel in the streets and an automobile crash figured yesterday in a lower West Side payroll hold-up that followed the all-but-forgotten gang-era pattern of a decade ago.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- William J. Grace, secretary of the Republican Nationalist Revival Committee, said today he would file a petition to put Col. Robert R. McCormick on the Illinois primary ballot as a candidate for the Republican nomination for President.

Prof. Arthur H. Compton of the University of Chicago received from The Fraternal League of the Jewish Education Committee of New York its annual award yesterday for having made "the most significant contribution toward the promotion of human brotherhood."
Local Draft Board 32, with headquarters at 660 Madison Avenue, yesterday officially went on record against the proposal that draft boards advise deferred registrants to enlist in the New York Guard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The $2,315,200,000 tax bill, a measure so disliked in Administration circles that a veto is regarded by some officials as a possibility, is scheduled to be taken up in the House and Senate Monday. It will probably be sent to the White House without extended debate.

Although the Far Eastern front proper, as distinguished from the Pacific area, has of necessity been relegated to secondary position thus far, there can be gathered from isolated news dispatches in the last few days material for a progress report that is far from insignificant.

" Ten Escape From Tojo" is the title of the book now scheduled for March publication by Farrar Rinehart, telling the story of Japanese brutality to American war prisoners. The authors are Comdr. Melvyn H. McCoy, U.S.N., and Lieut. Col. S.M. Mellnik, U.S.A., two of the men who escaped and who told their story to Lieut.

Among the exhibitions scheduled for the Metropolitan Museum in the near future is one made up of nineteenth century Polish paintings, opening on Feb. 16. Some fifty pictures by twenty-five artists have been lent by American collectors for the exhibition.

The Naoussa Society, Inc., consisting of natives from a city in Macedonia known as Naoussa, would feel grateful if permitted to express regret that Mr. Peff, in a letter to THE TIMES of Jan. 24, tries to exonerate the Bulgarian people.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The official reaction here today to the news that the Spanish Cabinet had declared for a policy of "strict neutrality" was that this was all right as far as it went but that time must elapse before the United States and British governments could be sure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- School administrators put truancy at the top of the list of forms of juvenile delinquency in a pamphlet, "Juvenile Delinquency and the Schools in Wartime," just issued by the United States Office of Education.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- In a successful blow against Japanese communications in Burma. American fliers made an attack in strength yesterday on the Okshitpin bradges which span the branch of the Irrawaddy River linking the important enemy supply center of Prome to Taungup, on the west coast below Akyab, a Southeast Asia command communique announced today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Central Railroad of New Jersey has applied to the Office of Defense Transportation for authorization to withdraw from service seventy-two passenger trains to facilitate the movement of troops and war materials, William Wyer, chief executive of the railroad, announced today.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The stock markets here were quiet but firm in tone today at the close of the week's business.

The Naoussa Society, Inc., consisting of natives from a city in Macedonia known as Naoussa, would feel grateful if permitted to express regret that Mr. Peff, in a letter to THE TIMES of Jan. 24, tries to exonerate the Bulgarian people.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The official reaction here today to the news that the Spanish Cabinet had declared for a policy of "strict neutrality" was that this was all right as far as it went but that time must elapse before the United States and British governments could be sure.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- In a successful blow against Japanese communications in Burma. American fliers made an attack in strength yesterday on the Okshitpin bradges which span the branch of the Irrawaddy River linking the important enemy supply center of Prome to Taungup, on the west coast below Akyab, a Southeast Asia command communique announced today.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The appointments of Arthur K. Davenport, 18 Frost Lane, Hewlett, L.I., and John C. Carlin, 146 East Lynde Street, Watertown, as junior bank examiners were announced today by the State Banking Department. The compensation is $10 a day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Tax collections last year of $31,924,500,000 were nearly double the $16,774,000,000 figure for 1942 on the basis of internal revenue reports made public today.

The reclamation of the city's blighted areas by means of moderate-rental housing projects in the post-war period must be accomplished by private capital because public funds for that purpose will be exhausted when pending public housing projects are completed, Park Commissioner Robert Moses declared yesterday at a public hearing before the finance committee of the City Council.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 4 -The wives of three members of the United States Army Air Forces bade an unfond farewell to Hudson County today after getting a dark brown taste of Jersey justice as it is stewed, heavily salted with technicality, in the bailiwick of Mayor Frank Hague.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 4 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Final returns on Brighton's by-election, in several respects the most sensational since the outbreak of the war, show that Prime Minister Churchill's Tory candidate won by a significantly small margin. There could not be a plainer reproof of the Prime Minister's rough handling of the political situation.

Harry Craig Cooper, 40 years old, of 1016 Fifth Avenue, president of the Century Travel Service Corporation at 655 Fifth Avenue, was arrested yesterday in his office as, detectives alleged, he was about to flee from a grand jury investigation of what District Attorney Frank S. Hogan charged was a "black market conspiracy in the sale of railroad passenger reservations."

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Lieut. Comdr. Harold E. Stassen and Wendell L. Willkie are at present the two top choices of Minnesota Republican voters for the Republican Presidential nomination this year. Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York runs a close third, with Gen. Douglas MacArthur fourth.

Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The work of the United Service Organizations was declared yesterday by Chester I. Barnard, the association's president, to have expanded 50 per cent during 1943 in providing recreational, entertainment and other activities for members of the armed forces.

The United Seamen's Service headquarters here yesterday received a plea for clothes from merchant seamen prisoners in Germany to "make them look just as respectable as others in the camp." The letter, signed by Vernon L. Frank, prisoner of war 149, was addressed to the United States Maritime Commission and was sent from the United States Merchant Marine Unit, American Seamen Internees, Marlag u Milag Nord, Milag.

OTTAWA, Feb. 5 -- This week's debate on Government policy as laid down in the speech of Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King has produced a very fair outline of how Canadians are thinking about the war and the afterwar.

JOHN T. FLYNN did not like Franklin D. Roosevelt before the last election and he does not like him any better on the eve of this one. The difference is that his first book on the subject in 1940 was devoted to a personal disparagement of the "Country Squire in the White House" while a good two-thirds of this one never even mentions the hated name.

Zoltan Fekete and a small orchestra, composed of members of the NBC Symphony, assisted by Jane Snow, American contralto, and Ralph Hollander, American violinist, gave a concert in Town Hall last night under the auspices of the Harmony Guild of New York and dedicated to the memory of Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott.
LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A joint United States Army Air Force and British Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Comdr. Gene Tunney of the Navy came back from his recent tour of Pacific battlefronts with a bit of news about a hitherto unheard-of American boxer which should be of interest to Sgt. Joe Louis of the Army.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- There was little pressure today on the wheat market on the Board of Trade, and a small dip early in sympathy with other grains was followed by a fair rally, with professional operations accounting for the bulk of the business.

JUST when are we going to get around to doing something about the American dance? Sooner or later it will come about inevitably, for we are not prone as a nation to overlook our natural resources. It is habitually only a question with us of how long we have to misuse and neglect them before we wake up to the fact that they should really be conserved.

MADRID, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Sir Samuel Hoare, British Ambassador to Spain, declares "there is no cause of conflict between the Allied and Spanish Governments" if Spain "is really neutral" as the Franco Cabinet affirmed two days ago.

New York City's growing army of small investors rang up their biggest single day in the Fourth War Loan drive on Friday when they bought $8,772,000 worth of E bonds, according to figures released yesterday by the War Finance Committee of New York. Manhattan accounted for $5,357,600 worth.
ABOUT the time a young woman reaches the age of 14 she begins to gaze into her mirror with intense and analytical interest and to wonder just how she may set about looking like Hedy Lamarr.

CHERYL CRAWFORD, that industrious woman of the theatre, is forging ahead with new plans. She has given her word, the lawyers call it a verbal agreement, that she will produce Samson Raphaelson's latest play, now in the polishing stage.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 -- The Bruins snapped a seven-game National Hockey League losing streak tonight by overwhelming the last-place Rangers, 7 -- 2, before a crowd of 8,500 at the Boston Garden. Rookie Russ Kopak set the pace with two third-period goals as Boston advanced within a point of the fourth-place Chicago Black Hawks.

Sandbags, tents, jungle hammocks, insect netting and other articles of military importance are attacked by micro-organisms, particularly in moist, warm climates. Tests made with four soaps (copper naphthenate, copper cleate, copper tallate and copper hydrogenated resinate) revealed that copper naphthenate prevents rotting of cotton fabric in soil at lower concentrations on the fabric than do the others.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey is running for President of the United States in the only way he can, by sticking to State business. He can say truthfully that outside the State of New York he has not actually sought a delegate.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 5 -- Craig Wood of Mamaroneck, N.Y., national open champion, and Byron Nelson, Toledo, Ohio, the one-time Texas caddy who has held most of the big titles, battled to a deadlock in the seventy-two-hole Phoenix Open Tournament today as they posted 137's at the half-way mark. The event winds up with thirty-six holes tomorrow.

A patriotic pageant set against a background of United Nations flags will be a feature of the forty-second annual entertainment of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club to be given Wednesday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 5 -- Champion Flornell Rare-Bit of Twin Ponds, owned by Mrs. Edward P. Alker of Great Neck, L.I., started a new year of dog shows today in the hopes of adding to his remarkable record of twenty-one best-in-show awards.

DON'T look now -- and you probably wouldn't believe it if you did -- but Babe Ruth will be 50 years old tomorrow. Time certainly flies in swift, relentless fashion. Still it seems inconceivable that the Babe has reached the half-century mark and no doubt someone will raise a glass at the Baseball Writers Dinner tonight in a toast to the greatest player who ever lived.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, alleged today that the House Select Committee investigating his organization was "deliberately" delaying a presentation of the commission's defense of the long series of charges made by the committee until Congress had disposed of the appropriation for the commission.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows.
Baseball's current off-season splurged itself on a variety of fronts yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- To facilitate administration of the Mustering-Out Payments Act the War and Navy Departments have issued instructions on how to apply for the benefits, amounting to $100 for veterans with less than sixty days' active service; $200 for those with more than sixty days' but no overseas service, and $300 for those with more than sixty days' service who had overseas duty.

A tendency toward increased Federal control of education has arisen in this country, Dr. Harry J. Carman, dean of Columbia College, warned yesterday at the regional conference of the Progressive Education Association, held at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

An underground newspaper, Het Parool, estimates that 20,000 Netherlanders have been executed by the Germans since May, 1940. Perhaps the figure is exaggerated. Perhaps the total should be only 15,000 or 10,000 put to death for loving their country. This is one item in one day's news.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The time is "not far distant," the Army and Navy Journal said today, when Japan must send out her fleet to offer us battle.
New York University's aggressive and speedy basketball team defeated Brooklyn College last night in the University Heights Gymnasium, 62 to 40.

The outlook is indeed black if the Hitlerian "Twelve Points" of Lord Vansittart in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine are the basis of strategy of any large element of Allied leadership. Militarism, imperialism, intense nationalism and fascism are inconsonant with real peace and human progress, but they must be recognized as such whether they be of Allied or Axis inspiration.

No race is more predisposed to crime than another, according to the late Prof. Willem Adriaan Bonger of the University of Amsterdam, whose study, "Race and Crime," has been published posthumously by the Columbia University Press in a translation by Margaret Mathews Hordyk.

JOSH CLUNK, famous alike for his unctuous humility and for his sleuthing ability, successfully defends a man accused of burglary but is not satisfied. He sees something fishy in the case and proceeds to follow it up with the result that he becomes the principal agent in uncovering a vast conspiracy which threatens the security of the realm.

THE welcome news this morning is that Gracie Fields, the internationally famous singer and comedienne of the London music halls, who of late has expended much of her time in the Hollywood celluloids, has decided to return for a while to the cafe medium.

PROFESSOR STOLL'S new book is a collection of essays, most of which have already appeared in the journals of his profession, a miscellany which derives its coherence not from any continuity in the subject, as its title suggests, but from the persistent application of the same principles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A drive by the Treasury's alcohol tax unit to dry up the black market in liquor had "salutary effect" in 1943, Elmer L. Irey, chief coordinator of Treasury enforcement agencies, reported today.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- The Army's big field house was filled this afternoon as cadet athletes engaged in boxing, wrestling and basketball contests.
Piscatorially minded citizens of the metropolitan district loom large in the list of prizes for the George Ruppert fishing contest for 1943, eagerly awaited and finally made public yesterday.

The quiet of the old residential villages of Grymes Hill and Ward Hill on Staten Island was shattered early yesterday afternoon by exploding shells, accidentally fired from a 20-millimeter rapid-fire anti-aircraft gun mounted on a freighter anchored in Upper New York Bay, between Tompkinsville and Stapleton.

Enjoying a comfortable 34-to-20 lead at the mid-point, the St. John's University Redmen suddenly fell apart in the second half and were forced into overtime last night to defeat a service quintet from the Brooklyn Army Base, 59 to 50, in the winners' De Gray gymnasium.

Rosalyn Tureck's second piano recital of her three devoted to the music of J.S. Bach, given yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, presented only the thirty "Goldberg" Variations. This work, however, is one of the greatest ever written for a keyboard instrument, and was sufficient to display Miss Tureck's splendid Bach playing.

" LITTLE JO" could do without the diminutive which suggests words like "lively and engaging" and does the boy and his author an injustice. Actually he is a nice sensitive child, growing up in a sleepy New Mexican village, thick with dust and superstition.

LONDON, Feb. 5--Winston Churchill, Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Viscount Simon, Minister of Information Brendan Bracken and Sir Otto Niemeyer and Sir Findlater Stewart, financial experts, are included among a number of prominent people mentioned as legatees in the will of Sir Henry Strakosch, banker and economist, which was made public today.

While the number of new cases filed in the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board in 1943 was slightly less than in the preceding years, close to 1,000,000 workers, a record total, were involved, Charles T. Douds, the regional director, disclosed here yesterday in his annual report.

Cold has scaled the ponds, lakes and rivers, and across the northern States farmers are getting up the ice. In the fall, before freezing weather set in, the old weather-beaten icehouse was cleaned of its damp, pungent sawdust -- except a few inches at the bottom.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The acute housing shortage that will face this country after the war probably will be solved by the erection of thousands of prefabricated dwellings, perhaps of American design, thrown together in a hurry and good for about ten years.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communicattons Commission.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- Victorious Partisan forces drove the Germans out of two vital Bosnian towns today, consolidating their hold on the heartland of Yugoslavia, while Allied motor torpedo boats teamed with other land units of Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] to smash German supply routes by land and sea.

ABOARD JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FORCE FLAGSHIP, Kwajalein Lagoon, Feb. 4 (Delayed) -- Picking their way forward under deadly sniper fire, troops of Maj. Gen. Charles H. Corlett's Seventh Army Division, conquerors of Attu and Kiska, today were blasting out the Japanese on Kwajalein atoll, pillbox by pillbox, and bringing the American concrete-bursting arms to bear on remaining enemy positions.

IT is unfortunate for "The Siege of Leningrad" that it cannot fail to challenge comparison with "The Last Days of Sevastopol," since both are short books descriptive of the two most gallant defenses conducted by the Soviet armies.

The Maritime Commission's annual report to Congress, which was released publicly last week, outlines the steps taken in the fiscal year ended June 30 to achieve the greatest shipbuilding feats in history. The report covers the period during which shipbuilding facilities and other resources of the nation were synchronized and enlarged to obtain construction of the largest possible number of ships.

LATELY, on the occasion of a certain "opera quiz" between the acts at Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street, a question came in which seemed a very simple one to answer. All of the quizzed had ideas on the subject.

THIS department has just returned from taking part in one of those round-table discussions which concern themselves with the shape of the future. The second annual Middlebury Conference, which I attended, had for its general subject "Cultural-Values in a Changing World."

DURING the last decade of the nineteenth century a group of poor and ignorant folk gathered in the backlands of Brazil around a man known as "Antonio the Counselor," who was said to work miracles. They were illiterate, undernourished and weather-beaten people with a natural craving for a happier life.

Cornell University will continue to offer instruction "in those areas of controversy in which enlightenment is most needed," Dr. Edmund Ezra Day, president of Cornell, declared yesterday in reply to critics of the university's course on contemporary Russian civilization.

W. Lawrence McLane, Chairman of the Borough Block Canvass Committee of the Red Cross 1944 War Fund of New York, yesterday announced the opening of an intensive drive to enlist 30,000 volunteers to conduct a house-to-house canvass in Manhattan for the coming drive on March 1.

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- The Soviet Government has declined to sign a treaty of mutual aid and post-war collaboration with the present Yugoslav Government-in-Exile. The action made clear again the Soviet preference for the Committee of National Liberation, headed by Marshal Tito (Josip Broz), which Moscow papers said "is supported by the wide masses in the Yugoslav nation."

DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- Henry Ford said today that America c0uld realize full prosperity and employment after the war "if we think straight, use our own men and machines wisely and teach our young people to do things for themselves."

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Douglas Aircraft Corporation reports that a fleet of thirty-five twin-engine American transports has flown 1,970 miles from Natal, Brazil, to Africa, carrying five tons of cargo each.

It has been said that this war is a young man's war and that older men must give way to virile youth, but Capt. John F. Jensen, Danish-born veteran United States Lines skipper, who at 60 retired from active duty in 1936 under the company's pension plan, did not see it that way.

The Federal Government is doubling the allotment of butter recently made to hospitals from its huge hoard of 130,000,000 pounds. At the same time the black market is offering stocks at reductions of as much as 11 cents a pound.

To raise funds for housing, clothing and providing general welfare aid to some 11,000 Danish refugees in Sweden, a gala concert will be given on the night of Feb. 17 at the Metropolitan Opera House under the auspices and patronage of leading figures in diplomatic, consular, music and society circles here.

PHYLLIS ARGALL has skillfully selected everyday incidents of her twenty-six years in Japan to give a fair and illuminating appraisal of our foe. She offers a liberal education in Japanese thoughts and deeds, with modesty and a sense of humor that places "My Life With the Enemy" high on the list of Far Eastern reading.

In a ceremony to promote the Fourth War Loan drive, representatives of the Camp Fire Girls Council of Greater New York and Benjamin Franklin High School yesterday placed two wreaths at the Park Row statue of the flamed patriot.

NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Lieut. Robert W. Hanson of Newtonville, a marine fighter pilot with a record of downing twenty-five enemy planes in the South Pacific, is missing in action, Lieut. Gen. A.A. Vandegrift of the Marine Corps notified his parents today.

BOYS are fitting cardboard shoulder pads on their football uniforms; girls are painting cardboard urns to hide the robbers of "Ali Baba"; "The Commandos" are opening their afternoon meeting with lusty song; Timmie and his friend play checkers; Kate squashes clay; Concetta, who comes from a crowded home, sits peacefully for a while looking out a window.

THE family doctor is in the service and the family case histories are crowding the files of another overworked physician. We wait our turn for office appointments and have learned to expect a home visit only for serious ills.

A HISTORY of the Hays Office, as the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., has become popularly known, is being prepared by Raymond Moley for publication in book form early in the summer by Bobbs-Merrill, the author revealed the other day in an exclusive interview.

THE electron is at work on every battlefront and in every factory. Wherever guns are fired at an enemy airplane, wherever there is bombing, counting, wrapping, sorting, packaging, heating, oil refining and watching the electron is in action. Yet this electronic industry is not new.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The War Department said today that information was being made available at all military installations on how qualified soldiers may vote in the April primaries in Illinois, Nebraska and Pennsylvania and the general election for State and local offices to be held in Louisiana April 18.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $789,356,113 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the exchange. Average price per share of all listed stocks on Jan. 31 was $32.47, compared with $31.96 at the end of 1943.

For three years the Westinghouse Company has been offering cash prizes to boys and girls who stand high in their classes and who want to become scientists and engineers. This year forty were selected out of 15,000 contestants. Their average age is under 17.

A SHARP drop in temperature the past week and reports of new powder snow on a good base at Lake Placid and other northern ski fields promsies a lively February for sports lovers. Champions will compete for honors at Placid's skating carnival Feb. 19-20, where an innovation will be introduced in the form of broadcasts from the Olympic Arena.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The Russian decision to offer autonomy in defense and foreign affairs to the Soviet Union's constituent Republics was a political "Molotoff cocktail" of considerable potency, and while the British managed to swallow it without losing their diplomatic balance, it looks as if the hangover is going to be greater than the celebration.

IT is indeed strange that whereas each of us accepts the existence of insoluble personal problems, we can hardly bear to think that there may be no ideal solution for the problems of humanity as a whole. Individuals go on living with equanimity in spite of chronic bad health, money difficulties, inextricable family troubles or mental suffering of one kind or another.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A $500,000,000-a-year program of food subsidy aid limited to low income families was proposed today by a group of Senators opposing the Administration's $1,500,000,000 system of general food subsidies.

Six hundred and fifty Hunter College students were graduated last night at the school's eighty-fourth commencement exercises held in the college assembly hall. Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, delivered the principal address and conferred degrees upon the graduates, who were presented to him by Eleanor H. Grady, Dean of Faculty.
May I answer some of the assertions of Lord Vansittart in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine?

IT looks as if Hollywood is set for a cycle of Japanese atrocity pictures now that Washington has released its censorship on news accounts of the brutal treatment of American prisoners. During the past week three companies announced plans to rush stories of Jap brutality into production and more studios are expecting to follow suit.

President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia soberly outlined his nation's foreign policy in a speech to the Czechoslovak State Council last week. Before it fell to Hitler, Czechoslovakia had been a democratic republic cut to the pattern of Britain and America. It had drawn its political philosophy from the West and its military security was based on an alliance with France.

Retail trade was generally good last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were active and practically all types of merchandise were selling.

EVERY so often this corner hears a vigorous or testy complaint that too little recognition is given the people who write for the screen. The protesters usually argue that the screen writer rates the same regard as the dramatist in the legitimate theatre -- and folks are always talking about him.

All through the back country and pretty well down into the suburbs the old-fashioned foot-warmers have been hauled out of attics and musty storage closets this Winter. Rubber hot-water bottles have gone the way of rubber bands and automobile tires, but we kept our feet comfortable between the icy sheets, just the same.

Boston University has introduced the Army's specialized method of language teaching in its French course, and after a semester's experiment it has been pronounced successful. In a class of forty French students, no use is made of written language. The student is faced with perfect French from the beginning.

ONE of the eight persons seated about the dinner table expects to be murdered, and she has confided her fear to one of the others. It is Lora Karen who expects death, and the man in whom she has confided is Philip Cabot, a private detective.

THE invasion of Sicily is barely six months old -- yet here, hot off the griddle of war, is a first novel dealing with a town in Sicily taken by the Americans. Whether or not John Hersey has established some kind of a speed record in writing "A Bell for Adano" I am not sure.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 5 -- Seventh Division Army troops have captured Kwajalein Island and two other important isles of the Kwajalein Atoll, Pacific Fleet headquarters announced today, and the most successful naval and military operation in the central Pacific campaign is nearing its final phase.

" I DON'T see why you think it's such an honor to ask me to ride in that thing," said Bernard Shaw, glaring at me furiously through his shaggy eyebrows. "Now, if I invited you to ride in my Rolls-Royce -- that would be different!"

TWO weeks after the Luftwaffe leveled Rotterdam, Hitler's new gauleiter in Holland, Seyss-Inquart (erstwhile Austrian Quisling), proclaimed the Dutch "blood-relatives of the German people." The Dutch weren't interested.
ALGIERS, Feb. 5 -- Flying Fortresses of the Fifteenth United States Air Force bombed the German submarine base at Toulon yesterday.

MEDITERRANEAN THEATRE: Vatican City, heard Monday, 17.44 megacycles, in English at 9:50 A.M.; uses 5.97 megacycles from 2 until as late as 5:30 P.M. But since Jan. 26 Vatican broadcasts have been irregular and hurried.

THE soil and structures of England are permeated with traditions of many kinds. Here, in a well-produced volume, are photographs with accompanying text showing landscapes and buildings associated with names and scenes famous in literature -- the Hardy country, the Lake district, the ruined castles and abbeys, the buildings which housed writers or served as inspirations.

Enrollment of college students will reach a record in the years immediately following the war, Livingston W. Houston, executive vice president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, predicted yesterday at the annual midwinter meeting of RPI alumni in this city, held at the Murray Hill Hotel.

Dr. William H. Kilpatrick, Professor Emeritus at Columbia University, urged yesterday at the annual meeting of the Foreign Division of the Young Women's Christian Association that letters be written to the members of Congress to bring to them "the voice of the people back home."

In Madison Square Garden next Friday and Saturday the Westminster Kennel Club will give its sixty-eighth annual all-breed dog show, in which the thoroughbreds of the kennel world of the United States and Canada will be on exhibition and in competition.

DETROIT, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Matthew Smith, national secretary of the Mechanics Educational Society of America, an independent union the members of which are on strike in some forty-four war plants in Michigan and Ohio, said tonight that he would ignore a subpoena calling for his appearance before a National War Labor Board hearing in Washington at 10 A.M. Monday.

PHYSICIANS tend generally to think of human beings as systems of organs, whose functions determine the fate and destiny of their possessors. In consequence of the heavy emphasis placed upon biological factors throughout their period of training, they often tend to overlook the importance of non-biological, of social, factors in the causation and treatment of disease.

" EPIGRAM" is a word of ancient and honorable lineage. Like most words, time and practice have modified its meaning. In its essence and origin it was an inscription, an epitaph, or a dedication. Its body was a fact or a sentiment, but its soul was pure poetry.

LONDON. FIELD MARSHAL Gen. Erwin Eugen Johannes Rommel used to be called "Rommel Africanus" by the German press and German people. Although associations with Africa have now no pleasant ring in German ears, Nazi propaganda has been careful to preserve the fame and reputation of the man whom Hitler has chosen to perfect the defenses of Europe against invasion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- A solution of the crisis in American -Spanish relations that flared up after Spain had granted a $40,000,000 credit to Germany may be announced early next week, observers believed tonight.

Before the bombers rise from England to demolish German towns something must be known about the weather. Since meteorological reports are no longer exchanged by all the powers of the world, forecasting is not easy. Facts must be collected from half the world.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 5 -- The first entirely American military government since our acquisition of the Philippine Islands becomes effective with the capture of the valuable islands and islets of the Marshall atoll group.

FEBRUARY is the month when pruning starts. So many classes of plants will require pruning during the next two months -- vines, many of the shrubs, fruits and roses -- that we must take advantage of any mild weather there may be to make headway on the program, and this year fruit trees ought in all conscience to receive first attention.

In the past week Internal Revenue Officials told American taxpayers that they should put off filing their 1944 income tax estimates, due under existing law on March 15; that they, the officials, believe the Congress will authorize a delay of at least thirty days in which to make the declarations.

NEW RIVER, N.C., Feb. 5 -- When all factors such as tropical diseases are taken into consideration, the capture of atolls like Tarawa is less costly in human casualties in the Pacific warfare than the seizure of larger jungle islands like Guadalcanal, Lieut. Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, Marine Corps Commandant, told Marine officers here today while on a four-day inspection tour of Camp Lejeune.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 5 -- Wendell L. Willkie started his trans-Continental quest for support at the Republican nations convention by addressing twenty-four candidates for delegates in Wisconsin pledged to his nomination for President. Mr. Willkie spoke at a private luncheon for these candidates and later addressed about thirty publishers of Wisconsin daily and weekly newspapers.

Last week Dr. J.S. Paraskevopoulos of Harvard's South African observatory cabled that Nova Pictoris had broken up into four pieces which were drifting apart, that what was left of the original star had flattened poles and that possibly the phenomena which he had been watching might lead to a new theory of the origin of solar systems.

Christian R. Holmes, Hawaiian sportsman and plantation owner and a grandson of Charles Fleischmann, yeast company founder, died yesterday morning in his apartment at the Hotel Savoy-Plaza of an overdose of sleeping tablets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Production of inner-spring mattresses is not expected to be resumed, and no proposal to make such mattresses available in the near future is under consideration, the War Production Board announced today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- The Soviet Government reported today the progress it is making in rahabilitating devastated farms, factories and homes in the territories that have been liberated by the Red Army from German occupation.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -No one can tell how many men without a country will be wandering around the world or penned up in strange lands after the war. Humanity will be fortunate if the number is kept within 1,000,000 and hard pressed if it soars above 2,000,000, according to the best informed quarters here.
AMONG the changes which the Four Aces team has made in its bidding system this year is the adoption of an opening bid of two clubs as the only original forcing bid.

THIS is not a blueprint for a new world order. Mr. Callender has set for himself a more modest, and probably more useful, task: to illuminate the future problems of the peace settlement by extensive background discussion of the countries which will be affected by this settlement.

Plans for doubling the present capacity of Boys House, a residence study center at 88 Fourth Avenue for selected, unattached and homeless boys, were anounced yesterday. An entire new floor will be opened in the five-story building, which served eighty-five boys last year.

The New York University Adult Education Division, Washington Square, will have two courses in farming for the city dweller, both given by Mr. Richard B. Mihalko, former county agricultural agent. The beginners' course meets at 8 P.M. and the advanced course at 6 P.M. on Tuesdays, starting Feb. 8.

Preparation of Form 1040A, the simplified income-tax blank that may be used by an individual whose gross income is not more than $3,000, can be comparatively easy if a few rules are followed. First, be sure to have Form 1125, showing your total tax for the year 1942 with the amounts paid on that tax.

United States Senator Harley M. Kilgore of West Virginia, speaking at the tenth victory rally of the Metropolitan Opera season over the Blue Network from the Opera Guild's room at the Opera House yesterday afternoon, declared that the post-war world must be built on Thomas Jefferson's dictum that "all men are created equal."

As a partial offset to the decrease in retail sales which is expected this month because of the high sales total recorded last year as a result of scare buying, January volume for apartment stores ran 6 per cent ahead of the same month in 1943, according to the Federal Reserve Board report issued in the week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A story used to be told of an Irish immigrant who landed in New York and was pounced upon by two rival ward heelers who demanded to know if he was a Republican or a Democrat.

PRIVATE MORRIS G. GREENMAN, stationed in North Africa, who was the first contributor to the current drive of the Metropolitan Opera Association's emergency fund, has written a second letter to George A. Sloan, president of the association, explaining that the timeliness of his gift was only a coincidence.

Ricardo Odnoposoff scored a triumph at his first appearance in the United States yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, where he immediately established himself as one of the outstanding violinists of the day. The Argentine artist, who came here virtually unknown to the general public, took his audience by storm by the virtuosity, power and fire of his performances.
BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 5 -- The press of Rome is waging a violent campaign against what it calls the "inconceivable" indifference of the capital's population toward the effects of the war.

At 3 A.M. of April 12, 1942 -- the second day after our surrender -- we arrived half dead at Orani, in northeastern Bataan, after a 21-hour march from Cabcaben near the peninsula's southern tip. That 30-mile hike over rough and congested roads had lasted almost from dawn to dawn.

FOUR of the exhibitions of the week were distinctly in the modern European vein. Under title of "Classics From the School of Paris," the Perls Gallery is showing paintings by Soutine (one especially good flower piece), Braque, Picasso, Dufy, Vlaminck, Utrillo ("Chateau Blanc," dated 1912, is one of his most arresting "white" period pictures), Rouault (four gouaches and an oil), and Modigliani (two portraits).
