WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A warning issued to motorists two years ago that the tire situation would reach its "toughest" phase early in 1944 came true this week.

While conceding that the Baruch-Hancock uniform termination clause is a necessary step along the road to ultimate reconversion of industry, accountants declared yesterday that after detailed study of the article they have become convinced it cannot be accepted as a complete solution of the problem and that further progress is most likely to be made through pending legislation.

In a move designed to strengthen international cooperation in cultural fields the Department of State has established a Science, Education and Art Division and has embarked on a long- range program in this area. The department is now consulting responsible school leaders in the preparation of plans for meeting immediate as well as post-war educational problems.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The War Labor Board will appoint four alternate public members to serve on a full-time basis, thus enabling it to operate as two or three divisions and speed up its decision-making schedule. Alternate labor and industry members already are serving on the board.

" What to Do in Summer" is the topic E.T. Lloyd will discuss at the third session of the Victory garden course given by the New York Botanical Garden and THE NEW YORK TIMES at Times Hall, Forty-fourth Street west of Broadway, on Thursday, Feb. 10.

SO far as the theatre was concerned, the month of January went out bravely, its head up, for a change, and not sunk deep and bandaged into the shoulders. For, during the final few days before February reached the calendar, two more shows added themselves to the list of Broadway pleasures.

WHEN Morton Downey cuddles up to a WJZ-Blue microphone this Tuesday at 3 P.M. sharp (assuming that the schedule does not go awry) and pours his daily quota of vocal mellifluence onto the air he will be embarking on his second year as a leading daylight troubadour, wherefore a quick anniversary note may not be amiss.

LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Germans lost 4,500 more men and ninety-five tanks yesterday in a vain effort to crack the Russian trap closing on ten Nazi divisions facing death or surrender near the Dnieper River, Moscow announced last night.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- Six Germans were sentenced to five to thirteen years' imprisonment each and a seventh ordered deported today when they were found guilty of a Nazi plot to occupy Uruguay with unidentified troops and convert the country into a Nazi colony.

JEAN HERSHOLT, the well-known Danish-American actor, whose collection of editions of Andersen's works is the largest in the world, has trans lated some twenty-five of the best-known tales and has added an interesting, readable introduction telling of Andersen's life and work.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Feb. 6 -- The Russians last night announced the capture of Rovno, Lutsk and Zdolbunovo, as well as 200 other places deep in Poland. At the same time, it was announced that 2,000 prisoners had been taken so far in the resumed offensive of Gen. Nikolai F. Vatutin and that remnants of the Eighteenth and Nineteenth Hungarian Divisions had been routed in battle.
LONDON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON -- Another "Overrun Countries" series of United States postage stamps appears to be in prospect for release during 1944. It is learned unofficially but authoritatively that the Post-office Department is considering the issuing of such a group, which would complement the twelve five-cent stamps placed in circulation last year to commemorate the resistance by twelve European nations to Axis aggression.

HOW easy is it to commit a murder and get away with it? Ask Mr. Bowling. He knows. His first murder is quite unpremeditated, and no suspicion rests upon him. Encouraged by this, Mr. Bowling proceeds to eliminate, one by one, persons who annoy him.

OPPORTUNITIES to build up a fuller, more substantial perspective in our study of American art, provided both between covers and in the field of exhibitions, have increased during the last few years. The continuity of American development from colonial days to the present has been, as it should be, stressed.

ACCORDING to a dispatch from Addis Ababa to The Times, London, five stamps of Abyssinia were overprinted "Obelisk" in English and in Amharic to commemorate the unveiling of a "Liberty" statue by Emperor Haile Selassie on Nov. 3.

Three thousand homes are needed in Greater New York for foster care of needy children, according to James A. Burke, Borough President of Queens, who announced today that Monday through Friday would be Foster Homes for Children Week in Queens.

American colleges and universities are preparing guidance and counseling services for the veterans who are now returning, and for the many thousands who may want to enter the classrooms when the war ends. During the past week New York University and the University of Pennsylvania announced specific plans to aid the war veteran.
A Congressional study of possible stabilization of private construction, related to post-war problems, was advocated last night by Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Upon the invitation of four youthful members of a freighter's gun crew Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday made her first visit to the United States Naval Armed Guard Center, Fifty-second Street and First Avenue, Brooklyn. In honor of her visit those of the 45,000 guardsmen who were not away at sea, 5,000 strong, held a special inspection.

CAPT. PROF. CYRUS HATCH (that is what his bride calls him) is on his honeymoon with Jane, who was formerly his secretary. They are accompanied by Cy's bodyguard, Danny Delavan, for no particular reason except that Danny just has to be in any story that concerns Cy Hatch.

ALGIERS, Feb. 5--Like louder rumbles before the storm, the Germans continued their counter-attacks in the Allies' wedge below Rome yesterday while, sixty miles to the south, other German troops clung to Cassino despite a see-saw battle in the northeast corner, where streets and buildings changed hands many times.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A critical shortage of natural gas threatens to curtail war production in the Appalachian region and Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chief, asked today that natural gas consumers in the supply area restrict their consumption to the bare necessities for the rest of the winter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- The new tax bill, which probably will be put before President Roosevelt next week, will increase the Federal revenue to $42,239,200,000 a year, Congressional tax experts said tonight after a final check.

Because I am a great admirer of Woodrow Wilson I have worked on a life of that great man for more than forty-one years. Wilson accomplished so many magnificent things that it will not damage his place in history to tell the truth about his connection with the League of Nations.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- A bipartisan demand was voiced today for State development of power resources of the St. Lawrence and Niagara Rivers, if the Federal Government fails to take immediate action.

WHAT is the ultimate purpose of American foreign policy? Until that question is clearly thought out and fixed in our minds it is impossible to explain our past policy in time of peace, the reasons why we should go to war, or the purpose of an organization of nations after the war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Necessary and increasing shifts in the quantities and types of production of war goods have introduced a new word into industrial war language -- "cutbacks."

The war in the Pacific last week entered a new phase. Gathering enormous forces, including the largest fleet the world has ever seen, the Americans struck at and won Japanese territory for the first time. Ships of the United States Pacific Fleet rode at anchor in a Japanese harbor.

IT is fitting and truly Dalinian (the unique Salvador's own word) that Salvador Dali's first effort at the novel, "Hidden Faces," to be brought out by the Dial Press in April, should have for its theme a philosophical idea (?) discovered by no one other than Dali himself -- complete with definition, ready for the new Webster-Merriam.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5 -- Air Current and Rascal were the winners of the Miami Beach Handicaps at Hialeah Park today, the former scoring away off by five or six lengths in the very smart time of 1:44 2-5 for the mile and a sixteenth.

ALTHOUGH people who make their living in radio tremble at stated intervals over the listener survey ratings, which render them blissful or disconsolate by the change of a decimal point one way or the other, it may have occurred to you that such services as the Crossley and the Hooper contain a singular gap.

BORDE KANE'S eyes were gray, "but anger deepened them to a greenish tinge"; he had "high temples, slicing downward to a strong jaw," and he carried his "six feet of sinewy body" well. When he walked "the ball of his foot touched the ground before the heel.

From each of the active theatres of the war dispatches continue to bring encouraging news of the constant and disproportionate destruction of enemy fighters by our own aircraft. Although we should never underestimate the enemy, especially at this crucial period of the conflict, it is plain that his air arm grows weaker as ours continues impressively to mount in strength.

The inflation in China about which so much is being written is serious indeed, but it threatens to lead to fallacious conclusions through false analogies. In a modern Western country it might very well be fatal. In other words, it might lead to collapse and withdrawal from the war.

" IN THE GARDEN OF THE HOME GOD" retells with fine simplicity a Navajo story of planting and harvesting, of bean plants and squash vines, of raindrops splashing on the corn, of the white lightning, of the rainbow and the voice of the bluebird.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A reorientation of Anglo-American foreign policies that will entail closer cooperation with the French Committee of National Liberation, recognition of the hopeless unpopularity of King Victor Emmanuel of Italy and his son, Crown Prince Humbert, and continued pressure on Spain to drop all connection with the Axis is believed to be imminent.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 5 -- Finnish opposition to the Government's policies has now organized itself, in that Prof. Vaino Voionmaa, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Subcommittee, has been chosen as its leader, according to private advices from Helsinki.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- Columbia's basketball team was subjected to its worst defeat of the season tonight by a faster university of Pennsylvania quintet in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game. Before 4,715 persons at Convention Hall, Elmer Ripley's Lions were no match for the Red and Blue, which romped to a 53-28 triumph, leading all the way.

Over-the-counter dealers in this city have commenced a rebellion against the board of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc. In a resolution circulated and voted last week, the New York Security Dealers Association has appealed to the Securities and Exchange Commission to force the NASD board to hold a nation-wide referendum on the matter of limiting profits to 5 per cent.

IN the columns of QST, the organ of the American Radio Relay League, there currently is being conducted a discussion of the post-war lot of the amateur radio operator, popularly known as "the ham." Underlying the majority of communications is concern as to just how the amateur will make out when peace comes and the anticipated boom in all phases of radio bursts on the American scene.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- With 6,000 added employes, a new 2,500-man sorting office in New York City and a prayer on its lips, the Bureau of Internal Revenue addresses itself this winter to the hardest job of tax assessment and collection it has ever faced.

Brokers and members of their staffs clustered around the horseshoe-shaped posts of the New York Stock Exchange last week to hear a talk by Lieut. Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, commandant of the Marine Corps. Afterward they subscribed to more than $100,000,000 in war bonds.

George Bernard Shaw in his eighty-eighth year shows no perceptible change in his epistolary style from the Bernard Shaw who wrote sharp and/or humorous letters to the press in his sixtieth year in an earlier world war.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The slow fires of civilian resistance in enemy-occupied lands now have been burning nearly three to five years. The explosive force generated by them for release at the time of the invasion of the Continent by the liberating Allied armies is something which the high commands both in London and Berlin are trying to gauge today.

Philanthropic projects of Everybody's Thrift Shop, 922 Third Avenue, will be materially advanced through proceeds from a "Cocktail Bundle Party" to be given the afternoon of Feb. 15 at the Pierre Roof. Plans for the fete will be discussed Tuesday at a committee meeting and tea to be given by Mrs. Hugh J. Chisholm, benefit chairman, in her apartment at the hotel.

After an early setback, cotton prices steadied near the end of the short session yesterday. Small scale trade price-fixing in the near months, combined with a small amount of New Orleans buying, enabled prices to recover virtually all of their earlier losses.

BEATRICE CURTIS BROWN, whose book of verses about Jonathan Bing is a perennial favorite, again shows in this book (which she has written with Helen Arbuthnot) her understanding of children and their interests.

The octane rating of gasoline generally available for automobiles after the war is not likely to be much higher than that of the pre-war product, according to a statement issued yesterday by the Standard Oil Company of Indiana. The company stated that the reason for this conclusion was that the economics of producing aviation gasoline for war and motor gasoline for peacetime operation were vastly different.

Teachers' colleges throughout the country have lost nearly 60 per cent of their normal pre-war enrollment, tropping from 175,000 students in 1940- 1941 to a total of 72,000 for the current school year. Educators are concerned it the possible teacher shortage that will occur as a result of the growing lack of adequately trained teachers.

ONCE, when we lived on a farm in Iowa, we had a hired man who did not like anything about his job. His name was Oscar and he had worked up in Minnesota and out in Nebraska and down in Missouri. He had been around.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Powerful formations of American Flying Fortresses and Liberators escorted by large numbers of fighters -- an estimated 1,200 Allied warplanes were on the mission -- penetrated deep into France today. The "heavies" blasted six Nazi air bases around and beyond Paris.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The third Army-Navy College qualifying test will be held in high schools, preparatory schools and colleges throughout the country at 9 A.M. on March 15, the War and Navy Departments announced today.

Vice President Wallace, speaking from Springfield, Ill., and the Archbishop of Canterbury, speaking from London, will participate in a Lincoln's Birthday program to be broadcast throughout the world by the Office of War Information and the British Broadcasting Corporation, The Associated Press said yesterday.

Relaxation of inventory control orders by the War Production Board has changed the function of the regional redistribution activities of that agency from that of aiding manufacturers who possessed unusable inventories of materials due to limitation orders to that of rebuilding wholesalers' and jobbers' stocks, Alfred G. Birkenmeier, regional redistribution chief, stated yesterday.

LAST September the Special Services Division got a million dollars out of the War Department to can music for American soldiers wherever they may be. Col. Howard G. Bronson, Chief of the Music Section, summoned Capt. Robert Vincent, in civilian life a recording engineer, and told him to get busy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Senator Murray of Montana asserted today that cost-plus war contracts had resulted in a "tremendous waste of money and manpower"; that they had "aggravated the manpower shortage," and that a Senate investigation would "convince the country that there is no need at this time for a labor draft law."

ALGIERS, Feb. 5 -- The editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday advocating that the United States recognize the French Committee of National Liberation as the provisional Government of France was conspicuously republished here today.
With little more than a week to go, Lou Gehrig, the pride of the Yankees, continues to hold first place in the Fourth War Loan sports popularity poll.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- When the issue of North Africa and the Mediterranean was in doubt, when Gibraltar stood alone and vulnerable with a dubious Spain behind it, when Germany still had the power to wreck our European strategy if Spain granted her unopposed passage to the Straits, the United States and Britain dealt gingerly with the Franco Government and were thankful for each concession.

ONE might, I suppose, dignify Percy Marks' latest gift to the circulating libraries by calling it a problem novel. "Shade of Sycamore" embroiders the old Cinderella theme, beginning where the fairy tale left off. As fiction, it is slick, flashy stuff; as social commentary, it is arrant non-sense.

HERE is a novel which takes place in the trying years of readjustment following the first World War. Through the narrative of Peter Oliver and his bank one learns how inflation dollars changed the thinking and the lives of the inhabitants of the small town of Acadia, S.D.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 5 -- This week having proved a particularly black one for German arms in Russia, Berlin comment on the situation there was, to quote one Swedish correspondent in the Reich capital, "eloquently confused."

The preliminary annual statement of the Pittsburgh Steel Company and its subsidiaries, issued yesterday to stockholders, disclosed for 1943 a net profit of $1,734,222, subject to audit and renegotiation.

In deference to the views of military leaders, the War Production Board will not alter its policy on the production of civilian goods to stimulate the disposal of surplus materials until the main invasion beachhead in Europe is firmly established, small manufacturers asserted last week.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 5 -- Yale tonight made a clean sweep of its annual Princeton basketball series by recording a 70-40 victory. It is believed to be the largest score ever attained against the Tigers in modern basketball. Nearly a thousand spectators, many of whom are here for the Yale classday exercises Monday, witnessed the game.
TORONTO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Toronto moved back into a second-place tie with Detroit tonight by defeating the Red Wings, 3 -- 1, before 12,546 spectators.

Premier Hideki Tojo, speaking to the Japanese Diet, warned yesterday that the war keeps "increasing in ferocity day by day and we are now being confronted with the situation where the fate of the GEA (Greater East Asia) sphere and the rise and fall of Imperial Japan will be decided."

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Petitions were filed in Springfield today for placing on the State Presidential preferential primary ballot the names of Gen. Douglas MacArthur and Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Quick action by Administration forces brought an extraordinary Saturday session of the Senate to an abrupt halt without the transaction of any business today when it appeared that the Green-Lucas bill for the service men's ballot under Federal auspices was heading into new difficulties.

SOMEWHERE IN ITALY, Feb. 5 -- The daring and skill of American doctors, who are taking the most modern techniques of surgery and medicine right up to the battle front, are saving the life and limb of many a man who otherwise might be killed or maimed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Something new in the way of Congressional hearings has developed here in the last few months -- the conducting of committee investigations into specific subjects with no specific authorization to do so, and with no related bills pending.

VIRGINIA CHASE has written an engaging and amusing story specializing in odd tidbits of Americana dated 1909. Readers who can remember that era fairly easily will be surprised -- and perhaps gratified -- to find how quaint and antiquated it seems now.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Governor Leverett Saltonstall was "saying nothing, but sawing wood" today as the State awaited his decision on selection of a successor to Henry Cabot Lodge, who resigned his Senate seat yesterday to enter the Army.

Permission to use the former residence of J. P. Morgan at Thirty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue for religious and church administrative purposes has been granted to the United Lutheran Church in America, it was learned yesterday.

ONE of the most coherent one-man shows of the season is that of eight recent paintings by Peppino Mangravite, at Frank Rehn's. The canvases, which represent aspects of one general theme, are supplemented by a group of striking pastel-rich gouaches and a group of diverse drawings.

The Edward J. Neil Memorial Plaque, awarded for 1943 by the Boxing Writers Association to the 4,000-odd boxers of the past and present, living and dead, who answered the nation's call to war, will be dedicated in the ring at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night by former Mayor James J. Walker.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 5 -- The green clad skiiers of Dartmouth dominated the opening of their own thirty-fourth annual winter carnival today when they won first and second places with their A and B teams in the downhill and the jump, and ended the day with a lead that made the A team an almost certain winner.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The subcommittee on housing for the National Republican Convention in Chicago starting June 26 said today that all applications for rooms, except those for press and radio, must be channeled through the national committees of the various States.

PARADOXICALLY, it is necessary to bring folk music back to the people. Americans have a lot to discover in America, especially about the music that is distinctly, inescapably the voice of our people. Of course there are thousands, possibly millions, who still keep alive the traditions, of our native music, and uncounted others who have rediscovered its beauty in recent years.

YOU'VE read the stories of the "name" heroines -- the battleships, the cruisers, the destroyers, the submarines. Now take time out from the rousing actions for a tale of a less glamorous lady, a junior miss of the fleet.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 5--Dartmouth's champions defeated Cornell, 58--46, today to sweep their Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League slate of eight games.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

EDGEWATER, N.J., Feb. 5 -- A walkout of an estimated 1,000 of the 1,500 members of the 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. shift at the Ford Motor Company's truck and jeep assembly plant here occurred at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon as the dispute between the union and the management over two employes took a new turn.

FIBER and medicinal plants will be studied in the last two conservatory tours at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden on Feb. 9 and 16 at 3 P.M. These are the last two meetings of a six weeks' course conducted by Dr. Alfred Gunderson, Dr. A.H. Graves and Miss Hester M. Rusk.

The United States took its first long stride forward in the Pacific war last week when one of the greatest fleets ever assembled blasted the Japanese out of one of their strongholds in the heart of the Marshall Islands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- By building a pipeline about 1,200 miles across Saudi Arabia from Persian Gulf refineries to the Mediterranean at a cost of $130,000,000 to $165,000,000 the United States is going to obtain a minimum reserve of 1,000,000,000 barrels of petroleum to meet military and naval needs.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- Organized labor must raise its voice in post-war planning to equal that of industry, Vice President Wallace told a meeting of teamsters belonging to the American Federation of Labor today.

With a declaration that international developments, both toward winning the war and achieving "the world-wide brotherhood of man," were more encouraging than domestic approaches toward the post-war economy, the American Labor party made public yesterday the first part of its Federal and New York State legislative program.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 5 -- The popularity of the Democratic party among the rank and file of organized labor has shown a slight decline since mid-December -- a decline which coincides with increasing criticism of President Roosevelt by union leaders.

Several hundred Americans of Lithuanian descent, representing 1,000,000 of their compatriots in twenty-one States, endorsed a petition to President Roosevelt yesterday for aid "in the restoration of the independence of the Republic of Lithuania.

THREE group shows of the week make up in diversity whatever they may lack in size. A dozen artists are represented at the Barzansky Gallery, headed by Samuel Rothbort with three of his impasto lyric landscape impressions.
Featured by surprises as well as slow times, the thirty-seventh annual edition of the Millrose games passed in review at Madison Square Garden last night before an almost capacity crowd of 15,000.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Sunday, Feb. 6 (U.P.)--American Liberators, torpedo planes, dive-bombers and fighters again blasted Rabaul, New Britain, Thursday, shooting down an estimated nineteen enemy fighters from the weakest air defense ever thrown up by the Japanese over their battered Southwest Pacific stronghold, it was announced today.

THIS book is an anthology of General Smuts' speeches. It begins with a precis of South African history, and ends with a biographical summary. Standing alone it contributes little to an understanding of South Africa, or of Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, but added to the rest -- to his biographies to articles, in magazines, to editorials in the press -- it contributes a great deal.

THE spring semester of the Iranian Institute and School for Asiatic Studies will open on Feb. 14. Consultations and registration will be held from Feb. 9 to Feb. 11. The faculty includes Prof. Arthur Upham Pope, Prof. John Shapley, Prof. Bernhard Geiger, Prof. William Haas, Prof. Robert Von Heine-Geldern, Prof. John F. Normano, Prof. Lawrence T. Beck, Dr. Phyllis Ackerman, Dr. Leo Bronstein and Dr. A.L. Oppenheim.

PAINTING provides an excellent and economical means of refurbishing old pieces of furniture, finishing new ones, and adding a note of cheer to a setting which, through the exigencies of war, is becoming a bit shabby.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Army and Navy Journal said today that the American advance across the Pacific had pressed upon Tokyo strategists "the necessity of an immediate answer to their vital question of when and where they shall attempt to stop us."

BUFFALO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Long Island University scored its ninth basketball victory in eleven starts by whipping Rhode Island State, 99 to 68, tonight in the highest-scoring game in Memorial Auditorium annals. A crowd of 9,108, largest of the season here, saw the contest.

THE dramatic section of a recent Sunday TIMES comments about the decline in the number of plays registered with the copyright division for the year 1943. Producers for a long time have been shedding their crocodile tears over the dearth of good new plays and playwrights.

WHEN Hitler launched the German Wehrmacht across the frontiers of Russia on June 21, 1941, many military critics "sold the Red Army short," predicting that it would collapse in a matter of weeks or months.

THE Fancy-Leaved Caladium, smaller kin of the huge Elephant's Ear familiar to most of us, is useful and highly decorative in the garden. It may be at its best when grown in a small conservatory or greenhouse under lightly shaded glass, but, planted out of doors, it also retains the distinctive and varied leaf coloring which makes it desirable.

GOOD soil and sufficient moisture are recognized as prerequisites to the healthy development of plant life. Whatever deficiencies appear in the garden can be remedied by selective fertilization. However, this is not going to yield luxurious growth unless the plant is able to absorb the nutritives in the soil, and this means that water must be present.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Bob Feller, former Cleveland star pitcher, fanned fifteen men and drove in three runs in a baseball game -- and none of the sports writers carried a line about it.

An appeal to consumers who have substantial supplies of coal in their bins not to ask the Department of Health for emergency deliveries was made yesterday by Walter J. Dockeriff, area district manager of the Solid Fuels Administration for War.

Sky fighters and the rest of us are a good deal alike. Some fliers do best in formation, regimented. Others are free lances, born to thrive by private initiative. There is Maj. James Howard, the "one-man air force," who downed six interceptors over Oschersleben.

The Co-operative Analysis of Broadcasting, Inc., radio research organization operated on a non-profit basis by the American Association of Advertising Agencies and the Association of National Advertisers, will expand its program measuring services on April 1 to measure program audiences of all cities in the country with more than 50,000 population.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif. Feb. 6 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will star Judy Garland in a non-singing dramatic role in "The Clock," an original screen story by Paul and Pauline Gallico, which deals with the experiences in New York of a soldier and his sweetheart during the forty-eight hours preceding his departure for overseas.

Post-war improvements for the Bronx, including a civic center, airport, helicopter landing fields, development of its waterways and waterfronts, new tunnel and bridge connections with Manhattan and a cross-country highway, are being studied by borough officials and engineers in addition to the $200,000,000 of Bronx projects on the city's post-war program, Borough President James J. Lyons announced yesterday.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- To Sgt. Robert F. Winter of Wilmette, Ill., the miracle of coming back alive was second to the miracle of Christmas dinner washed up on a tropic beach after he had been left to die with machine-gun wounds in both legs, forty-two miles behind Japanese lines in the New Britain jungles.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 7 -- Soviet Russia made clear today that the first move of her new Foreign Office in the Ukraine would be to make a treaty with a "new" Poland and suggested that the Polish Government in London might be ignored entirely.

Twice held to a tie in the annual cup competition of the United States Football Association, the Brooklyn Hispanos, national champions, finally succeeded in breaking the deadlock with the Brooklyn Wanderers when they won the third match, 3 to 2, before a crowd of 3,500 at Brooklyn Oval yesterday.

To Johnny Fulton, a galloper from the Golden West; Gil Dodds, Boston's prancing preacher, and Jim Rafferty, New York Athletic Club veteran, went the track writers' accolades following Saturday night's Millrose A.A. games.

The effects of our capture of Kwajalein Atoll will be like those of a bomb dropped within the enemy fortress instead of outside its walls. But for the moment it is a delayed-action bomb. Its full explosive force cannot be felt until the rest of the Marshall Islands are reduced and organized as a base for new offensives.

Protesting against approval by the Textile Workers Union of a plan promoted by Sidney Hillman for reorganization of the American Labor party, Samuel Baron, general manager of the joint board of the textile workers' organization, submitted yesterday his resignation to Emil Rieve, president of the TWU, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Feb. 7 (UP) -- A communique:

There was a fair amount of activity in the wholesale markets last week, with retailers still very anxious to get assurances of deliveries on spring lines. New purchasing is being made to some extent in certain lines as buyers believe that standard lines may soon replace ersatz and victory models, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 6 -- One man was killed and two others seriously injured by a hit-and-run driver at Newark's four corners at Broad and Market Streets shortly after noon today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- Announcement that the temporary price ceilings on oats, barley and grain sorghums had been made permanent, but would be revised, probably downward, within about thirty days, had a depressing effect late last week on the markets for those grains on the Chicago Board of Trade.
LONDON, Monday, Feb. 7 (UP) -- The Russia Sunday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
LONDON, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- Partisan forces have wrecked seven enemy trains and recaptured Kresevo and Fojnica, towns west of Sarajevo, a Yugoslav People's Army of Liberation communique announced today.

NAMUR, Kwajalein Atoll, Marshall Islands, via Navy Radio, Feb. 6 -- A powerful American naval and air base is rising at a brisk pace out of the wreckage of Roi and Namur Islands, until a few days ago a pair of Japanese strong points in the Marshalls.

Julius Goldstein, pianist, was heard in the first of two recitals devoted to Bach's "Well-Tempered Clavier" yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. His initial program was concerned with nineteen of the twenty-four preludes and fugues from the first book of that work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it has charged the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company of Jersey City with disseminating advertisements which misrepresent the composition, properties and effectiveness of Palmolive soap, Colgate dental cream, Colgate tooth powder, Palmolive lather cream, Palmolive brushless shave cream and Concentrated Super Suds.

Governor Dewey's executive budget cut of $4,500,000 in State aid to New York schools "calls for" a cut of $7,500,000 in the city's own appropriation, and the resulting shortage of $12,000,000 will result in serious damage to the educational program as well as a sharp reversal of the growing trend toward smaller classes, Mayor LaGuardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

Dates for the 1944 racing season were formally assigned by the New York State Racing Commission on Saturday, it was announced by the commission yesterday. The New York program will start on Saturday, April 8, and will run for 181 days, concluding on Nov. 4.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- Weather conditions last week were generally favorable for winter wheat. Snow started to melt and the moisture went into the ground, as in only a few areas has there been much frost in the soil. This is especially true in Nebraska, where twelve to fourteen inches of snow fell over the greater part of the Western area, furnishing moisture to carry the crop a month or more.
LONDON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- A joint United 3tare8 Army, European Tieatre of Operations, anit Britisk Air Ministry communique:

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 7 (U.P.) -- In four days of fighting in the new Nikopol offensive, General Malinovsky's army has killed more than 12,000 Germans, captured 2,000 others and put to flight four infantry and three tank divisions of approximately 70,000 to 105,000 men.

ABOARD THE CENTRAL PACIFIC AIR COMMANDER'S FLAGSHIP, Feb. 4 (Delayed) -- Seventy-five days of pre-invasion aerial bombardment on the Marshall Islands by combined Army, Navy and Marine aircraft saved the American invasion fleets from Japanese air attack, Rear Admiral John S. Hoover, air commander of the American Central Pacific force, said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Nominations of motion pictures and individuals for 1943 "Oscar" awards in the sixteenth annual competition were announced tonight by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

EDGEWATER, N.J., Feb. 6 -- To avert a possible repetition of the work stoppages that occurred yesterday at the Ford Motor Company's assembly plant here, members of the executive committee of Local 906, United Automobile Workers, will be at the gates tomorrow to instruct the workers to report for their jobs and stay on them, it was announced today after a committee meeting.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- Stocks of lard and other hog products continue to pile up at leading western markets as the result of a record kill, but the gains were not as large as would indicate by slaughterings because of large shipments on Government and other orders.

Although they had a two-goal lead going to the final period, the New York Rangers had to settle for a tie in their National Hockey League game with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. A brace of goals by Doug Bentley in the third chapter brought the Hawks upon even terms with the New Yorkers and the deadlock, 4 to 4, remained through the end of the play.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Allied headquarters said today that heavy casualties had been inflicted on the Japanese on the Arakan front of southwestern Burma, where Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's forces are consolidating their positions in the hilly jungles northeast of Buthedaung on the Mayu peninsula.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Feb. 6 -- American artillery gave the eviscerated town of Cassino its worst pounding today as a bright winter sky offered mountaintop observation posts and aerial spotters ideal conditions.

With the expected German counter-offensive against the Allied beachheads in the Nettuno-Anzio region now under way, the battle of Rome is apparently entering into its crucial stage. Heavy fighting is raging along the whole periphery of the Allied zone, only fourteen miles long and an average of eight miles deep, against which the Germans are hurling strong forces assembled both from the Gustav Line farther south and from their occupation troops in the north.
The Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin, pastor of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, preached yesterday morning on "Sleeping Christians."

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 6 (AP) -- The effects of the "mild flue" epidemic of December, 1943, were reflected today in a State Health Department report showing a 27 per cent increase in the State death rate over the same month in 1942.

Next to the Japanese our boys fighting in the southwest Pacific are gunning for Hollywood movie producers who depict the South Sea Islands as scenic paradises filled with slim, saronged maidens. So said Miss Catherine Shaw, Navy nurse, who recently returned after serving a year in the southwest Pacific area on the naval hospital ship Solace, when interviewed yesterday at her current post, St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 -Vice President Henry A. Wallace declared in an address here tonight that the American people could pay the interest on their gigantic war debt and still have a post-war standard of living at least 50 per cent higher than during the decade of the Nineteen Thirties.

In an otherwise complimentary article Marc Connelly, playwright, actor and wit, was described the other day in The New York Post as having been known for years as "the best-looking bald man on Broadway."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Senate, living up to its reputation as the world's greatest debating society, begins its third week of argument tomorrow on the revised Lucas-Green soldier voting bill amid indications that it probably will not dispose of the legislation until late in the week.

In a sweeping indictment of "City Hall interference" with the independence of the Board of Education, the National Education Association's investigating board charged yesterday in its report that Mayor La Guardia had exercised illegal influence over the New York City school system. This influence, it asserted, has been in many respects injurious to the schools.

OLD FORGE, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- One of those ideal skiing days, new powder snow on firm packed base, brilliant sunshine that brought a sugary-like surface to exposed terrain and temperature around 20 above, provided a perfect setting for the huge influx of recreational skiers who etched new tracks on the varied facilities available in Old Forge area today.

Additional self-denial and discipline are needed on the home front, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday in his sermon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street. He had returned on Saturday from a week's mission at Camp Croft, S.C., under the auspices of the evangelistic commission of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP)--Tom C. Clark, assistant attorney general, head of the Criminal division of the Department of Justice, tonight announced a reorganization of the division into six new or redefined sections under the immediate supervision of Harold Judson of Los Angeles.

The American housewife is becoming glass-conscious. With limitations on both metals and hardwoods in, civilian markets, glass has been put to extensive and often unexpected uses. Glass furniture and glass kitchen utensils have appeared in retail stores and are being accepted by housewives in some cases by choice and in others by necessity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- An Allied transport carrying 1,977 men and women, including Canadian troops and nurses, was sunk recently in the Mediterranean with the loss of four lives, it was disclosed today.
Four new films are scheduled to pen in Broadway houses this week. They are:

The grocer as well as the shopper is plagued by wartime shortages and rationing and irritation and friction only complicate the problem, the National Consumer Retailer Council declares in an appeal titled "Your Grocer Needs Your Help."
ABOARD A U.S. AIRCRAFT CARRIER, in the Pacific, Feb. 6 -- The British plane swooped low to drop a message.

Helen Willcox in her letter published in THE TIMES, Jan. 29, 1944, states that farm opposition to subsidies will melt away when wise and unwavering wage and food controls are impartially and non-politically administered. She cites the demands of organized labor for higher wages and the yielding to railroad labor as giving basis for continuing such opposition.
LONDON, Feb. 6 (Reuter)--A announcement today by United States Army headquarters here said:

What Frederick B. Hodges of Rome, N.Y., wrote the other day is true: "I believe that one who has learned to know the wild flowers in youth can never be wholly unhappy." Even after one has passed one's middle age the ability to make new friends may remain.

At the NBC Symphony concert of yesterday afternoon in Radio City Leopold Stokowski conducted first performances of his own arrangement of an aria by Marc Antonio Cesti from one of that seventeenth-century masters cantatas, and of Arnold Schoenberg's piano concerto, in which the solo part was discharged with great skill and devotion by Edvard Steuermann, who for years has been a passionate exponent of Schoenberg's muse.

Russia's decision to grant autonomy in foreign and military affairs to sixteen territorial divisions was denounced yesterday by Col. Povilas Zadeikis, Lithuanian Minister to the United States, as an attempt to make the world believe that the Baltic States were willing members of the Soviet Union.

Mayor La Guardia denounced yesterday, in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall, a proposal to permit school principals to give working papers to children 15 years old who indicated a desire to drop their studies and go to work. The Mayor said that such a plan was on his desk, but after the broadcast he declined to describe it or name its author or authors.

Resignation to God's will is the keynote to happiness, the Rev. Michael J. Deacy told a congregation of 3,000 yesterday at the 12:55 o'clock mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The choir stalls in the sanctuary were filled with uniformed members of the armed forces.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 6--Kwajalein atoll is now in American hands with the exception of a few minor segments where scattered enemy forces still hold out or where we have not yet attempted to put troops ashore.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the resignation of William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, effective on March 1, when he will resume the private practice of law.

The prejudice against the use of oleomargarine still persists, even though its ration value and cost are appreciably less than butter. A report by the committee on public health relations of the New York Academy of Medicine demonstrates how ill-founded the bias is. Some remarks of the bulletin follow:

The majority of Parisians are starving, although a small minority who cooperate with the Germans can still live well, according to an eyewitness account published in the Algiers magazine Toujours quoted yesterday by the Brazzaville radio.

Declaring that a careful survey of the electric power industry failed to produce conclusive evidence showing whether private enterprise was more or less efficient than public enterprise, the Twentieth Century Fund appealed yesterday for better coordination of public and private power systems throughout the nation.

Charging that serious shortcomings exist in the present treatment of youths convicted of criminal offenses, the Committee on Youth and Justice of the Community Service Society, 105 East Twentysecond Street, urged in a report made public yesterday the creation of a State-wide Youth Correction Authority to have charge of youths between 16 and 21 who are committed by the courts for correctional treatment.

Prof. Benjamin M. Anderson has made a powerful attack on the Keynes and White monetary plans. He advocates a return to the old-fashioned international gold standard in their stead. The purpose of the Keynes plan, he points out, is to hold exchange rates together by putting the strength of the stronger national currencies behind the weaker ones.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the creation of a Youth Center Administrative Committee to supervise a program under which the Children's Court of the Court of Domestic Relations will send boys under 16 to Lavanburg Corner House, 331 East Twelfth Street, and girls under 16 to the Brooklyn shelter of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children pending final disposition of their cases.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 112.36, a drop of 0.1 per cent from the previous week's level of 112.47. The raw materials index and the farm products index each decreased 0.3 per cent, as a result of decreases in the prices of eggs, lambs, and potatoes, which outweighed the increases in cotton, apples, oranges, wheat and hogs.

A special service of "prayer and intercession" for the Dominion of Canada was held yesterday at Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street. The Canadian Legion of New York massed the flags of the United States, Great Britain and Canada on the outside steps of the church just before the service.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Monday, Feb. 7 (U.P.) -- American airmen in the southwest Pacific Saturday extended their pulverizing aerial assaults to the Japanese base at Cape Hoskins, New Britain, blasting the airdrome there with 167 tons of bombs, while other fliers in raids on New Guinea bases sank at least two Japanese merchant ships, fourteen barges and two float-type planes, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- A Congressional investigation of why the War Department's Pentagon Building -- "the city with the roof on top" -- cost almost $75,000,000, instead of the $35,000,000 originally appropriated, was demanded tonight by members of three committees on Capitol Hill.
The operations in the Nettuno beachhead area in the last week have brought to light some defects of American tactical concepts.

Continued strength in the nearby positions featured the cotton-futures market last week. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts in the nearer positions on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 7 to 14 points, but the more distant deliveries were off 2 to 3 points.

The report of the special panel of the National Education Association, charging him with improper and illegal domination of the Board of Education, has seriously hurt the cause of education throughout the country, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.

The newly appointed committee which will advise with the Defense Supplies Corporation on a program for disposal of its 330,000,000-pound stockpile of foreign wool will meet with the agency in Washington today, it was learned yesterday.

During the past week the stock market moved uncertainly, declining slightly in the last few days, but the bond market advanced. So far as concerned stock prices, the weakness in no respect reflected war news, which was altogether favorable, both in Europe and in the Far East. In particular, the attack on Japanese island fortresses, the protection of her homeland, was notably successful.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Monday, Feb. 7 -- The Russian Air Force made a violent attack upon Helsinki last night and followed it with a second attack that began at midnight and that was still continuing up to an early hour this morning. Last night's bombing lasted from 5 to 10 o'clock, reportedly causing fifteen casualties and starting numerous fires.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- Although the wheat market failed last week to develop a definite trend, the undertone was easier, due in part to the failure of expected mill buying to develop despite large Government orders for flour. It is understood that more than 1,300,000 barrels of flour will be taken for lend-lease and other purposes within sixty days, equal to about 5,000,000 bushels of wheat.

We neared San Fernando, Pampanga, province, during the afternoon of our fifth day's march as prisoners of the Japanese. It was now April 14, 1942. It was at San Fernando, according to rumor, that we were to be put aboard a train and carried to a concentration camp.

NORTH PLATTE, NEB., EN ROUTE TO SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 6 -- Wendell L. Willkie announced today that he would enter the Nebraska preferential primary as a candidate for the Republican nomination for President, thus making it clear that he intends to make an all-out fight for the nomination all along the line.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- Charles P. Arnot, United Press correspondent, disclosed that in the final phase of the attack on Kwajalein Island the infantrymen had used loudspeakers to invite the Japanese to surrender. A considerable number responded, he said.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Feb. 6 -- British women factory workers may, as Prime Minister Churchill says, be wonderful, but they cannot sleep on praise or dine o compliments, and providing these necessities is one of the real headaches facing the Government.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- March 16 has been set as the goal for adjournment of the Legislature and in conforming with this aim it is possible that the budget will be adopted during the legislative week beginning Feb. 14. This would allow four weeks, where three are normally considered ample, for the disposal of other legislative business.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A . oitheast Asi Comlzc corn-

Thomas Richner, pianist, winner of the Naumburg Foundation award in 1941, when he played under the foundation's auspices at Town Hall, gave another recital there yesterday afternoon before a large and cordial audience. He played the Bach-Busoni Chaconne, the Schubert Sonata in B-flat major, two etudes and the Barcarolle by Chopin and four pieces by contemporary composers.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Feb. 5 (Delayed) -- German artillery shelled the famous old Abbey of Mount Cassino today, although there is every reason to believe that German troops are in the vast abbey, which the enemy is thought to be using as an observation post.
Secretary of State Cordell Hull yesterday commended the Camp Fire Girls Council of Greater New York for its two-day celebration of the Treaty of the Alliance with France signed on Feb. 6, 1778.

A group of downtown buildings passed to new ownership for the first time since their erection when Mrs. Sadie Stern bought for investment the three six-story store and loft buildings at 113-15-17-19 and 121 Prince Street from the Wemaca Realty Corporation, a holding company formed by the heirs of the late Richard Sidenberg.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 6 -- The City Council here stands ready to fly into the face of legal technicalities to reward an Englewood youth now serving on the Italian battlefront.

For the first time since the beginning of the depression more than a decade ago the Board of Superintendents has asked for the appointment of a considerable number of teachers for the New York City schools. In all, 769 teachers and supervisors are requested by the Superintendents.
ALGIERS, Feb. 6 -- A ' co'zmui.. qu6:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Too many communities, fighting against child delinquency in wartime, are putting too much trust in juke boxes and dance halls, said public-welfare conferees meeting at the Children's Bureau here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Jan. 29 to Feb. 4 are given in the appended tabulation:

MOSCOW, Monday, Feb. 7 -- The trapping of five more German divisions, all described as infantry, in the Dnieper Bend was announced last night in an order of the day by Premier Joseph Stalin, who disclosed that the German war machine had lost its principal source of manganese through the Russians' isolation of Nikopol, the easternmost enemy-held city on She lower Dnieper River.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -John P. Frey, president of the metal trades department of the American Federation of Labor, called today for a central Federal agency to administer wartime labor policies, and said the morale of industrial workers had been injured seriously by "an almost impossible administrative condition in government."

With the postponement of "Take It As It Comes" from tonight until Thursday at the Forty-eighth Street, tonight's sole arrival will be "Porgy and Bess" at the City Center. The latter played a return engagement here for several weeks last September and since then has been traipsing around the country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Supplies of evaporated and condensed milk in the United States will permit civilians to continue their present rate of consumption, although the over-all allocation for 1944 will be somewhat less than was available through 1943, the War Food Administration announced today.

Baseball's post-war planning committee held its second session with Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday and at the close of another seven-hour siege of heavy deliberations announced it had reached unanimity on a number of recommendations which at a later date are to be submitted for joint action by the major and minor leagues.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 7 -- There is some very honest heart-searching going on over the question whether it is worth sacrificing the lives of Allied troops to save the ancient towns and buildings of Italy, treasured through centuries for their inherent beauty and historical interest.

That serious shortcomings exist in the present system of correctional treatment of youths convicted by New York criminal courts has long been known. Now the Committee on Youth and Justice of the Community Service Society has brought out a well documented study, "Correctional Treatment of Youth Offenders," which illustrates the "chaotic nature" of criminal justice procedures in attempts at reforming convicted youths.

The Rev. Dr. E. Clowes Chorley, historiographer of the Episcopal Church and trustee of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said in a sermon there yesterday that there is a popular notion that religion narrows life and that many young persons shrink from discipleship from the fear that it will crib and confine human interest, rob life of its zest and make it drab.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The shadow of the second front still overhangs the financial markets here, particularly the Stock Exchange, and one must look in vain for anything like renewed animation until the combined assault upon Europe is well and truly launched.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 6 (AP) -Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Philadelphia and Byron Nelson of Toledo, Ohio, battled to a tie today for the $5,000 Phoenix open golf championship, each posting a nine-under-par 273 for the seventy-two holes of medal play. The deadlock will require an eighteen-hole playoff tomorrow.

Householders of the New York metropolitan area using coal for heating should have used, as of Jan. 31, not more than 65 per cent of their fuel requirements for the period from Sept. 1, 1943, to March 31, 1944, it was announced yesterday by Walter J. Dockerill, regional representative of the Solid Fuels Administration for War.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 6 -- For the second year in succession an Afghan hound went best-in-show in the all-breed exhibition of the Maryland Kennel Club, which was concluded this evening in the Fifth Regiment Armory.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- Post-war planning is going full speed ahead at all levels of government and in business and industry, the Department of Commerce reported tonight.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Feb. 6 -- The start of the seven-day week for February in the anthracite industry provided 131,000 extra tons of hard coal for empty bins throughout the East today.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Urgent appeals by the chiefs of French patriots in Haute-Savoie, calling on the French public to collaborate with them, were sent out all day today by the British Broadcasting Corporation in special broadcasts to France.

The annual report of the Shawinigan Water and Power Company for 1943, issued yesterday, shows new high records for both gross earnings and power production. Generally higher expenses, however, resulted in a slightly lower net profit, after all charges.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Appointment of a Cigar Manufacturers Industry Advisory Committee to aid in setting price ceilings of new brands and sizes of cigars and to consider such additional problems as maximum prices on cigar cuttings and clippings and the general situation surrounding increasing tobacco leaf costs was announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

LONDON, Feb. 6--Heavy bombers of the United States Strategic Air Force, which hammered half a dozen German airfields near and south of Paris yesterday, continued their assault today on the Luftwaffe's bases on French soil and pounded the undisclosed German targets in the Pas-de-Calais area.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- A veteran of approximately one week's sojourn in London, the writer feels a report is in order on what it is like to go through this 1944 style of the practically toothless blitz. Thus far the answer can be summed up in one word: boring.

DETROIT, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings regained sole possession of the National Hockey League's second place by staging a three-goal rally in the third period tonight to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 2, before a capacity crowd of 13,587 spectators.

The other day a strange museum was formally dedicated at Yale. It consists only of a cabinet. Within its glass are over 300 labeled chemicals which have been isolated from living tubercle bacilli and which represent seventeen years of effort expended by Dr. Rudolph Anderson, with the financial support of the National Tuberculosis Association.
ALGIERS, Feb. 6 -- Overseas assignments bring all sorts of reunions of service men and, because of its key position in the Mediterranean theatre, Algiers has had more than its share of them.

The number of individual war bond purchasers throughout the State is 500,000 above the figure for the same period in the last bond drive, the War Finance Committee for New York disclosed yesterday. Nine days remain in the Fourth War Loan drive.
LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Moscow tonight denounced the Bulgarian Government, and charged that Bulgarian ports were being used by the Germans against Russia.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6 -- A slight increase in the output of steel ingots, a heavy volume of orders, a continued tightness in flat rolled steel products and a quiet scrap market were the main items in steel industry news last week.

With center Roland Lemire performing the unprecedented feat of scoring three goals unassisted, the New York Rovers vanquished the Philadelphia Falcons in an Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday, 6 -- 1. The contest was the feature of a double-header.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- Attorney General Francis Biddle announced tonight the appointment of Israel B. Oseas of New York City as a special assistant, with assignment to the Anti-Trust Division office in New York.
LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Unite Press:

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 6 -- Strength in the near positions, especially the spot month of March, as the trade continued to make fixations and transferred contracts out of the near into the more distant positions highlighted an otherwise listless cotton futures market here last week.
SOMEWHERE IN THE MARSHALLS -- Next to the Army, Maj. Gen. Charles H. Corlett, commander of the Seventh Division invading Kwajalein, likes to talk about cattle.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Raymond Blum, a 24-year-old New Jersey shipyard worker, today won the Middle Atlantic speed skating championship, leading a strong field which included Pvt. Kenneth Bartholomew of Camp Wood, N.J.; Dick Werner of Haledon, N.J., and Joe Bree of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Army Air Forces disclosed today information about the new P-38 or Lightning fighter, which, in dispatches from London recently, was reported to be escorting bombers on raids into Germany.

Ramon Lavalle, former Argentine consular official in the Par East, disclosed last night that he had seen American prisoners from Wake Island, inadequately clothed and many of them sick and wounded, exposed in freezing weather on the decks of Japanese transports in Yokohama Harbor.

Tonight's events: Jorge Bolet, piano recital, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 o'clock; Robert Rudie, violin recital, Carnegie Music Hall, 8:30; John Harms Chorus, Verdi's "Requiem," Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at Ninetieth Street, 8:30.
ALGIERS, Feb. 6 -- The over-all picture of the 156-day-old battle of Italy, as reflected in today's reports from the central Mediterranean command, is not overly encouraging and it is time to say so.

The Mutual Life Insurance Comsold the seven-story office pany building occupying the westerly blockfront on Washington Street, from Liberty to Cedar Street, and known as 136 Liberty Street, to Jacob Freidus. The property is 113 by 98 feet and is assessed at $360,000.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Feb. 6 -- Four New York boys serve a howitzer that sends over a terrific load of explosives.

The 66,000 New York City members of the Boy Scouts of America are making their annual appeal for funds from friendly grown-ups who know the value of the example of their organization in the life of the city. In this unsettled time when youthful delinquency seems increasing, or is less restrained than usual, the Scout movement exerts an influence that is worth much to all of us.

Baseball, beset by ever increasing problems of the moment and up to its elbows in post-war planning, brushed aside its worries for a few hours last night when more than 1,200 persons jammed the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore to attend the twenty-first annual dinner of the New York baseball writers.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon yesterday in Riverside Church expressed concern because many who should know better are turning to superstition as a substitute for faith in the providence of God.

PROCESSED FOODS (most canned vegetables, concentrated soups but not ready-to-serve soups, fruits and fruit juices, jams, jellies, preserves and fruit spreads -- except citrus marmalade -- dried beans, frozen vegetables and fruits, and prunes, raisins and currants) -- Green stamps G, H, J, K, L and M in War Book 4 are valid. G, Z and J are good through Feb. 20, and K, L and M through March 20.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 114.5 on Jan. 25, compared with 114.6 a fortnight before 113.7 a month before, 113.5 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

There will be no increase in the percentage of civilian goods for non-priority users of cotton textiles until April or May, it was reported yesterday by Worth Street suppliers, who based this assertion on developments resulting from the War Production Board's amendments to its order M-317 covering priority allocations of the product.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase last week of 1 per cent over the like week of last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported an increase of 11 per cent.

The Queens County Grand Jury yesterday handed up a presentment to Judge Peter T. Farrell in Queens County Court in which it declared that the unimpeded growth of weeds in vacant lots and along the edges of sidewalks and streets in the borough was a menace to public health and safety. It urged that positive steps be taken toward weed control.
In an otherwise commendable report on the British electoral system by James B. Reston in today's TIMES there are two rather serious distortions by omission.
Tonight's events: "Das Rheingold," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30; Alexander Brailowsky, piano recital, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; William Gephart, baritone, recital, Town Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Congress today approved and sent to the White House a $2,315,200,000 tax bill which fell more than eight billion dollars short of the $10,500,000,000 in additional revenue which the Administration requested early in October.

One of the arguments often made against the President's proposal for a National War Service Act is that the "manpower problem" is a thing of the past. War industries, it is said, are now actually beginning to discharge more men than are taken on for new production, because of "cutbacks" in the Army and Navy programs.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 6 (Delayed) -- "Only six consecutive bombings of Bulgaria will be necessary to get her out of the war," an official report that reached here yesterday said.

With the early lead piled up by Lou Gehrig, the Yankees' mighty slugger of past years, apparently putting him out of the reach of the remainder of the field, interest in the Fourth War Loan's sports popularity contest continued to center on just who would finish as the runner-up.

The board of directors of the General Motors Corporation voted yesterday to increase the common dividend to 75 cents a share from the 50 cent payments made in each of the eight quarters of 1943 and 1942. It is the largest dividend since the United States entered the war. Dividends for the full years of 1941 and 1940 were $3.75 a share.

Clean technique, a healthy, virile style and a virtuoso flair distinguished the performance of George Bolet, the young Cuban pianist, who appeared in uniform at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall. The F major sonata of Mozart could have had a more delicate lyricism, but this was a musicianly reading, one which articulated the melodies clearly, without affection and always with vitality.

The long line of prisoners straggled through the eastern portal of O'Donnell prison camp, between high towers from which floated the Japanese flag. Gates in the barbed wire barricade closed behind us. Our guards marched us up a hill just south of the gate and seated us in the blazing sun near Japanese military headquarters.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Wheat developed a heavy undertone today on the Board of Trade. This was despite early buying of the May, regarded as removing hedges against sales of about 100,000 bushels of cash wheat by Southwestern interests, presumably a reflection of the distilling business.

A STOCK catch phrase which is occasionally heard hereabout and which sounds more like cryptic Chinese than Broadway argot is, "Long time, no see." Basketball is entitled to such a greeting when it returns to Madison Square Garden tonight after an absence of almost a month. Never before was the arena dark to the court dervishes in mid-season for so extended a period of time, and it is pleasant to welcome them back.

The weight question came up to plague Tippy Larkin, Garfield, N.J., lightweight, yesterday in connection with his ten-round bout tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden, against Lulu Costantino, East Sider. Compelled by agreement to weigh not more than 137 pounds at noon tomorrow, Larkin discovered he must shelve three pounds to get down to this figure, or forfeit a $1,000 guarantee.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Feb. 7 -- In the sixth successive day since they first crept into the outer ridge of stone houses of the little mountain town of Cassino, American troops kept up their stubborn fight, trying to expand their hard-won toehold.

GUADALCANAL, Feb. 7 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Robert N. Hanson of Newtonville, Mass., marine flying ace credited with downing twenty-five Japanese planes, was killed near Rabaul, New Britain, on Feb. 3 when his Corsair fighter struck the water after a strafing dive, a fellow-flier reported.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Allied fighters and bombers delivered two hard blows Saturday against La-kunai airdrome at Rabaul on New Britain, meeting strong anti-aircraft fire but, again, weak Japanese aerial resistance, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

Release of wartime chemical production, inventory and consumption data by the Census Bureau of the Department of Commerce has given an indication of the scope of the problem the industry will face in cutting vastly expanded production down to normal post-war demands, chemical distributors stated yesterday.

Prices for industrial issues set a new low for the year yesterday as the stock market continued to sag, although pressure was at a minimum. When an early attempt to bolster the list failed to bring out any real bidding, trading quieted. Business on the Stock Exchange dropped to the second lightest of the year with transfers only 572,576 shares against 600,420 shares on last Friday.

The speech made by Mr. Wendel Willkie at The New York Times Hal Feb. 2 is one to be pondered by every thinking American. There is no doubt that he displays courage in advocating a very heavy tax during wartime and his blunt statement that in so doing our standard of living will have to come down during the war and perhaps after the war.

A market for synthetic rubber production will exist in the post-war period in the production of combination synthetic-natural rubber tires which will have twice the longevity of pre-war tires, William S. Richardson, general manager of the chemical division of B.F. Goodrich, predicted yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 7 -- Sun Again, Widener Cup candidate of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Wright's Calumet Farm, won at Hialeah Park today in the six and a half furlong Poinciana Purse, but it took his hardest drive to do it.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Coventry Cathedral, only the tower and four walls of which were left standing after the German blitz in 1940, is to be rebuilt after the war in such a fashion that it will embody ancient and modern features, according to plans announced today.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 7 -- Helsinki had two new alerts today shortly after noon, but no bombs were dropped.
Bobby Jones' grand slam of golf in 1930 is the outstanding sports achievement of all time in the opinion of the nation's sports editors.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- After a grand jury was completed today, for the beginning of the long-delayed investigation of the O'Connell organization in Albany County by appointees of Governor Dewey, the State Senate, after bitter debate, passed tonight a bill which the Democratic opposition charged would give the prosecutor in any such investigation the right "to a hand-picked jury."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 2:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- Although they were fewer in number, the principal amount of the securities of electric and gas utility companies issued in 1943 was considerably larger than in 1942, according to an annual review made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A campaign to help end racial and religious discrimination in industry through adoption of a Federal bill to make permanent the Fair Employment Practice Committee and to give it power to enforce its rulings in the courts was launched last night at a meeting in Town Hall under the auspices of the National Council for a Permanent FEPC.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- In another move to compel motorists to pay for the Westchester parkways, the County Board of Supervisors approved today by 41 to 1 a proposed State bill that would permit Westchester to collect ten-cent tolls.
A surprise order directing the transfer "forthwith" of three Police Headquarters favorites was carried out cagily yesterday without giving them time to take along their personal belongings.

An average of $225 in war bonds for every man, woman and child in the country will have been sold between May, 1941, and the completion of the Fourth War Loan drive next Tuesday, Theodore R. Gamble, national director of the War Finance Division of the Treasury Department, declared yesterday.

The framers of the present City Charter envisioned a Department of Investigation that would serve as the Mayor's eyes, ears and good right hand. They assumed that it would, as a matter of course, ferret out misconduct or corruption in city affairs. They hoped that it would be a constructive force, pointing the way to better and more efficient municipal government.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 7 -- Casualty figures in the Marshall Islands campaign, made public at Pacific Fleet Headquarters today, showed that, until last evening, our total losses in the entire operation were 1,516: 286 dead, 1,148 wounded and 82 missing.

The Hamil Realty Company, William G. Hille, president, has sold the three-story flat on a plot 50 by 104 feet at 30-32 Woodcliff Avenue, North Bergen, N.J., to Joseph Sabo of Garfield and Frank Radich of North Bergen for $20,000 above a $28,000 mortgage.

The tax bill that Congress now sends to the President is neither simple nor adequate; but it would increase revenues by about $2,315,000,000, and the President should not prevent it from becoming law. Let us hope that Congress will now devote itself, however belatedly, to removing complications in our Federal tax laws that have become intolerable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Two Pennsylvania anthracite operators will appear Friday before C.J. Potter, Deputy Coal Mines Administrator, who is acting to make sure that coal is marketed and distributed equitably.
CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 7 -- Chungking food prices have risen 22 per cent over all since last week.

At the request of two educational organizations in this city the National Education Association undertook some months ago a study of school conditions in New York. Various charges had been made that the Mayor had exerted his influence to weaken the independence of the Board of Education.

For the first time in this war shells from American fighting ships have burst on the Soil of Japan's homeland. The bombardment of Paramushiru by Admiral Fletcher's task force, venturing deep into enemy waters, was not a sporadic raid. It was part of a systematic pattern, prepared by previous bombing flights and supplemented on the same night by another attack made by more American planes.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Smooth-stroking Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Philadelphia, the winter season's top golf money winner, today added a $1,000 War Bond to his earnings by shooting a 70 for a two-stroke victory over Byron Nelson of Toledo, Ohio, in an eighteen-hole play-off to decide the Phoenix open.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 -- California Democrats entered President Roosevelt's name today in the May 16 Presidential preferential primary by filing a ticket of fifty-six national convention delegates representing all factions of the party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The National Administrative Council of the Mechanics Educational Society of America, meeting at Cleveland today, called off "temporarily" the strike of 20,000 tool and diemakers in Michigan and Ohio plants, but the National War Labor Board insisted, nevertheless, that a hearing on the case would be held by the board at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow and ordered the union officials to appear then.

SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 7 -- Wendell L. Willkie, candidate for Republican renomination for the Presidency, conferred today with leading Utah Republicans and left the State tonight, after making a favorable impression but without asking for or receiving commitments for support at the national convention.

ROI ISLAND, Kwajalein Atoll, Feb. 3 (Delayed) -- This island is ours today by virtue of the most magnificent naval support, including both shelling and bombing, that has ever accompanied an amphibious assault. This statement is confirmed not only by our own experienced observers but also by British officers with this task force who have seen similar operations in other theatres of the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- United States warships in a daring foray into Japanese home territory gave Paramushiru Island its first ship-to-shore bombardment Friday night (Tokyo time), the Navy Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- With almost all units of the industry engaged entirely upon war production, the possibility of production of aluminum household and cooking utensils is extremely remote, a committee of industry members has reported to the War Production Board.

Commenting on the recent remark by Mayor La Guardia that the New York City Defense Rental Area Office of the Office of Price Administration had been "rather generous already" in approving temporary interim rent increases, Louis H. Pink, director of the office, revealed yesterday the latest figures on such increases.

Before a crowd of 14,525 at Madison Square Garden last night Frank Briggs of the Grand Street Boys annexed the twentieth annual men's senior Silver Skates Derby in a rousing finish in which he defeated Ivan Rosalsky of the Brooklyn Ice Palace by inches. Gilbert Swordsma of Prospect Park, N.J., was third. Time for the two-mile test was 7:24.5.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 7 (AP) Affiliated with the advertising field for more than fifty years, J.F. Duffy was one of the first to advocate the use of consumer studies and marketing studies as an approach to advertising.
