LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Thousands of Finns fled from Helsinki today, their capital still smoking from a Russian bombing which wrote a fiery notice to get out of the war now.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Construction of a larger number of complex, special-purpose vessels accounted for a decline in the total number of ships delivered by United States builders in January, the Maritime Commission said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Senate reversed itself today and adopted a requirement that if the proposed Federal ballot is used by the armed forces in the election of the President, Vice President and members of Congress the voter must write in the names of the candidates he favors, rather than either the names or merely the political party designations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Justice Felix Frankfurter added fresh fuel today to the conflict among Supreme Court justices over the interpretation of constitutional law by asserting that his colleagues were resorting "gratuitously" to a "wholly novel doctrine of constitutional law."

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Feb. 8 -- Further progress in the annihilation of the fifteen German divisions trapped in the Dnieper bend was reported today when the Russians officially announced the Red Army had carried the battle to the eastern approaches of Nikopol and pierced the natural shield of Field Marshal Gen. Fritz Erich von Mannstein's forces encircled in the northwestern part of the Dnieper bend.

Having been out on the road since the fall -- or quite long enough from this end -- "Porgy and Bess" has returned to town for another engagement. It opened last evening for a fortnight's stay at the City Center of Music and Drama, filling that large stage more completely than it has been filled before, and being, as it always has been, a whale of a show.

Catching a 7 A.M. ferryboat to Staten Island never daunted a nurse's aide assigned to Halloran Hospital, but the young women now serving there are spared one of the long journeys to their post through a new arrangement made by Army officials.

Spokesmen for teachers' organizations accused Mayor La Guardia yesterday of throwing up a smoke-screen of personal attack in his comments on the findings of the investigating board of the National Education Association. In its report, made public Sunday, the board charged that the Mayor had exercised illegal influence, in many respects injurious to the schools, over the New York City school system.

For the purpose of stimulating the Fourth War Bond drive, special matinees of "Early to Bed," "The Two Mrs. Carrolls" and "Winged Victory" will be given on Feb. 14, 21 and 22, respectively. Only purchasers of bonds will receive tickets for these performances as there will be none available at the box offices.

United China Relief sent $8,612,155 to China in 1943, Dr. James L. McConaughy, the president, announced yesterday. The total was $3,500,000 more than that sent in 1942 and $5,000,000 above the 1941 figure. Administrative costs for 1943 were put at 5.92 per cent, including service of the relief program in Chnia, compared with 8.73 per cent in 1942.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration today announced eligibility requirements for manufacturers of certain building goods and consumers' goods who apply for increases in present ceiling prices.

Veterans of this war will not be satisfied to sell apples and they won't "be trifled with," Park Commissioner Robert Moses declared yesterday in an open letter sent to Beardsley Ruml, department store executive, and Paul Windels, president of the Regional Plan Association, in reply to their criticisms of Mayor La Guardia's war planning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A member of the Allied command reported today that the Anglo-American forces in the beachhead south of Rome were losing the initiative "to a certain extent" but "pessimistic expectations about our being driven into the sea" are unwarranted.

"Undercover," a new film dramatizing the activities of Yugoslav guerrillas, has been acquired for distribution ill the United States and Latin America by Paul Graetz, it was announced yesterday. The film was produced in England last year by Michael Balcon and includes John Clements, Mary Mor ris, Godfrey Tearle and Tom Wall in its cast.

Reading the evening papers will not be quite what it was, now that Cartoonist Will B. Johnstone is gone. It was the fond habit of thousands of us, on our homeward way at the close of the workday, to look for his cartoon strip in The World-Telegram, and, before that, in the old Evening World.

The American Council of Christian Churches announced yesterday that it had called to the attention of Congress a telegram it had sent last Sept. 30 to President Roosevelt, asking that two Japanese State Shinto shrines be destroyed by bombs to shatter the Japanese belief "in the protective power of the divine emperor and his ancestors."

A new kind of currency will make its appearance on Feb. 27 when grocers begin to give tokens as change for ration stamps. The "coins," which are red and blue and slightly smaller than a dime, will be used, however, only in connection with red and blue stamps in War Ration Book 4, each of which will have a 10-point value irrespective of the number originally stamped upon it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The project announced from Moscow of having the newly constituted Ukrainian Foreign Office negotiate a revision of the Polish boundary, possibly with a group or government within Poland instead of with the Polish Government-in-Exile in London, will not, in the present circumstances at least, encourage the United States Government to withdraw its support from the Government-in-Exile, according to indications today.

Major and minor league magnates, digging their way out of the debris that remained in the wake of Sunday's hilarious evening at the baseball writers' dinner, went back to their more serious affairs yesterday to prepare for the final chapters of the now rapidly waning off-season.

ADVANCED SEVENTH USAAF HEADQUARTERS, Central Pacific, Feb. 3 (Delayed) -- The invasion trail into the Marshall Islands was pioneered, developed and softened by the Seventh Army Air Force, an organization virtually unknown to the American public until it started its blazing central Pacific air war in mid-November.

Many business organizations, normally devoted to the production of consumer goods but now limited almost entirely to war work, are releasing test campaigns in various media on behalf of new products which they intend to place on the post-war market in quantity following the removal of manufacturing restrictions.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 7 (AP) -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, made a fervent no-strike appeal to unions today, calling on American workers to "give all we got" to the war effort.

"Ships and Men of the Sea" is the new theme of the next children's program in the series "Fun With Book People," sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES in cooperation with the Association of Children's Book Editors and Junior Programs, Inc.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Feb. 8 (UP) -- A communique:

The five business buildings on a plot 110.8 by 125 feet at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street, known as 233-41 Fifth Avenue and 1 East Twenty-seventh Street, have been purchased by Frederick Brown, operator, from a client of Wm. A. White Sons, brokers in the deal.

Although the synthetic rubber program still is running behind schedule, production is increasing steadily and in January reached a new high of 50,000 tons. For all of last year production averaged 33,000 tons monthly, with the average for the fourth quarter a little better than 40,000 tons monthly.

In its Green Room spring showing yesterday morning, Bloomingdale's offered many of the popular trends that have been gradually emerging from the many silhouettes seen since the turn of the new year. Featured was the short-belted coat made with collarless neckline and full skirt. It was seen in gray wool for daytime and offered in camellia red for evening.

In April Princess Elizabeth, heiress presumptive to the British throne, will be 18, There have been suggestions that her coming of age should be marked by some title of honor. She will become a member of the Council of Regency. One rather ingenuous proposal is that she be made a royal duchess.

ALGIERS, Feb. 7 -- The American troops in the death-infested mountains behind Cassino gave another turn yesterday to their wrench-like grip on their objective, taking in most of the 1,712-foot height topped by the Abbey of Mount Cassino.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Men wounded in action, discharged and then fully recovered, are being drafted again, it was disclosed today, and the War Department took cognizance of the situation by ordering the veterans to be given their old ranks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A summary of the child care needs of women who work for the Federal Government, with maps to show where child centers might check absenteeism, was contained in a report issued today by the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

Women's organizations here and in 448 other cities are responding wholeheartedly to the appeal of the War Production Board for their support of the Victory Waste Paper Campaign, Edwin S. Friendly, national chairman of the drive, announced yesterday.

The Vatican radio said Monday night in broadcasts to Italy and Germany, and also in French, English and Spanish broadcasts, that Vatican officials had lodged "formal protest" with Fascist officials in Rome after the invasion of St. Paul's Basilica, one of the most famous Church of Rome institutions.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- A greatly simplified system for soldier voting was presented to the State Legislature tonight by the Democratic leaders -- John J. Dunnigan in the Senate and Irwin Steingut in the Assembly.

The number of persons employed in the steel industry declined to 605,000 in December, the lowest since February, 1941. It compares with 611,000 in November and 633,000 in December, 1942, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 7 -- The New Jersey Legislature today received the first annual budget message from Governor Walter E. Edge in which he proposed administrative expenditures totaling $38,254,976.
The Tokyo radio said Monday that "the enemy's raid on northern Chishima (Kurile Islands) must not be regarded light."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Representative Colmer, Democrat, of Mississippi, announced today that Bernard M. Baruch has accepted an invitation to act as an adviser to the new Post-War Planning Committee of the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (U.P.) -- The Agriculture Department reported tonight, in summarizing prospective civilian food supplies in 1944, that food costs to consumers last month were 37 per cent above the pre-war average after a slight decline from May's all-time peak.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- New York State shows a complete change-over to complacency regarding the war, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, said today in a talk before the Women's National Press Club.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Members of the Molders and Foundry Workers Union of North America, AFL, struck today in more than thirty-five Chicago foundries producing gray forge iron for war materials after refusal of the Regional War Labor Board to approve an agreement for 6 cents an hour wage increase.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- One of the easiest, things to acquire from the President is what has come to be known under the New Deal as a plenary "directive," investing a government official with broad and detailed power. The depth, width and clarity of the investiture are in exact proportion to the President's immediate need for the man and the set-up.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- A registration statement covering 60,790 shares of no par common stock has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Masonite Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told the National War Labor Board today that he wished to admit "frankly" that "we are trying to change the stabilization policy" and wanted the panel hearings in the steel wage case held in Washington, "where the nation can have a look at what we are doing."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Roosevelt authorized Secretary Stimson today to take over and operate textile plants of seven companies in the Fall River area in Massachusetts because of the interruption of production by a labor disturbance.

The Bambino still can cut the cake. He did it yesterday, literally, on his fiftieth birthday, just a few seconds before it slipped from the table to land frosted-side down with a squashy plop on the floor of the little den lined with pictures and souvenirs of the days when Babe Ruth was making baseball history with home runs.

Under mystifying circumstances, her mouth sealed with six wide strips of adhesive tape and her nostrils stuffed with cotton, Mrs. Helen Oetjen, 39 years old, former vaudeville dancer, was found dead at 9:45 o'clock last nght in a six-room apartment she shared with two other women on the second floor of 70 East End Avenue, near Eighty-third Street.

In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, J. Kaiv, Acting Consul General of Estonia, cited the relations between Estonia and Russia since 1917 and showed that Russia had signed treaties with Estonia as recently as 1939 recognizing the independence of that country and that in 1940 Russia had committed an act of aggression against Estonia by invading the country and setting up a "puppet government" that, contrary to

ALGIERS, Feb. 7 -- In his first press conference in thirty-seven years at sea, Admiral Frank J. Lowry, who commanded the amphibious operations below Rome, shunned all praise for their success by suggesting that they had been undertaken at one of those moments "when the Lord has you by the right hand."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Senator Reed, Republican, of Kansas, complaining about the WFA's purchase of Canadian wheat, told Marvin Jones, Food Administrator, today that "you WFA gentlemen are the slipperiest bunch I've ever had to deal with.

Robert Rudie, violinist, who played in a concert in this city in 1931 at the age of 10, reappeared last night in a recital at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Mr. Rudie, who has studied with Louis Persinger and Jaques Malkin, gave a well-ordered and interesting program.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 7 -- A twelve-point program "to help save 3,000,000 Jews in Europe form extermination by the Nazis" was outlined today at a special conference of 400 Jewish leaders from all sections of the country who are attending the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds.

ALGIERS, Feb. 7 -- Frenchmen here are eagerly awaiting Prime Minister Churchill's forthcoming speech in the House of Commons, which, they hope, will be another step toward fuller cooperation between the Allies and the Committee of National Liberation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 7 -- Paramount has named Alan Ladd and Gail Russell to star in the forthcoming racetrack story, "Salty O'Rourke." Stanley Clements, 17-year-old boy, who recently played the leader of a youthful gang in "Going My Way," the Bing Crosby picture, has received a term contract and will have the title role in "Salty O'Rourke."
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 7 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:
An exhibition bearing this curious title, "One Hundred Artists and Walkowitz," opened yesterday afternoon with a members' preview at the Brooklyn Museum and will be open to the public today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (U.P.) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York is the leading choice for Republican Presidential candidate in 1944 among party Senators who were willing to express a choice, a United Press poll revealed today. Twenty of the Senate's thirty-seven Republicans registered their choices.

Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, announced yesterday that he had reached an agreement about administrative matters with Robert E. Sherwood, director of the Overseas Branch of the OWI, and that he had accepted the resignation of three key executives of the New York office of the Overseas Branch.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 7 -- The Sporting News, national baseball weekly, disclosed today a letter from White House Secretary Stephen Early which indicated President Roosevelt may leave baseball's future this year to the regulations of selective service and the manpower situation.

ABOARD A U.S. DESTROYER IN THE NORTH PACIFIC, Feb. 4 (Delayed) -- The first United States naval force to attack Japanese home territory is steaming safely homeward, leaving the flustered enemy on Paramushiru Island's Kurabu Point firing harmlessly into the air and sea and along their own beaches.
LONDON, Feb. 7 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

After having had to play second fiddle to Sonja Henie, Gil Dodds, and even to lo! the poor Rangers, these last few weeks, basketball comes back into its own at Madison Square Garden tonight with an up-State vs. down-State doubleheader, Canisius of Buffalo and the University of Rochester carrying the banner of the hinterland against Long Island and New York universities.

Shrewd and sardonic Henry Adams was greatly impressed sixty-two years ago when a burly Democratic Mayor of Buffalo named Grover Cleveland was elected Governor of New York by a crushing majority over his Republican opponent.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Assemblyman John A. Devany Jr., Bronx Democrat, introduced in the Legislature tonight a resolution deploring the attack made on the Vatican as "pro-Fascist," as printed recently in Izvestia, official organ of the Soviet Government.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- The military situation in Italy, which, despite local successes, has never been wholly satisfactory to the British people, is becoming a target for the critical comment that was heard here during the dark years that Britons believed ended in the autumn of 1942.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A pamphlet soon to be issued by the Office of Education, "F-M for Education" will introduce to the public the post-war possibilities in radio of the frequency modulation channels reserved for education.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, In Italy, Feb. 7 -- Complete preparations have been made by the Fifth Army to safeguard church property and whatever works of art remain in the Abbey of Mount Cassino as soon as American troops can occupy this historic ground.

Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., had a net income of $668,223 for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30, E.S. Phillips, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders. After preferred stock dividends of $137,868, the net is equal to $3.44 each on 153,894 shares of common stock outstanding. In the previous fiscal year the company earned $764,521 or $5.03 each on 151,869 common shares then outstanding.
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- The Red Army's arrival on the Estonian frontier was heralded by a remarkable letter sent to The Times of London from Moscow last Wednesday and published today.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Tokyo and recorded by The United Press:

A moderate amount of price fixing in the near months, supplemented by renewed trade and mill covering, dominated yesterday an otherwise quiet cotton market. March contracts moved to 20.43, or within 5 points of the season's best level, established last week.
BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 7 -- As part of the "white terror," to which France is now subjected, twenty-two hostages have been shot in Lyon.
LONDON, Feb. 7 (UP) -- A Russian air communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Immediate action by Congress in proclaiming and implementing a joint resolution setting its primary post-war objective as the withdrawal of Government from control of private business and the restoration of a free, competitive economy was urged yesterday by H.W. Prentis Jr., head of the Armstrong Cork Company and past president of the National Association of Manufacturers.

Governor Dewey's support of a State ballot program for voters in the armed services this fall was protested yesterday by S.L. Dewey, Suffolk County chairman of the American Labor party, on behalf of his 19-year-old son, Corp. Thornton Greeley Dewey of the marines, who is not old enough to vote.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Both Houses of Congress completed action today on the conference report on an appropriation bill to assist in providing and distributing sufficient farm labor for 1944, and sent it to the White House for signature.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 (AP) -- West Texas Utilities Company of Abilene, Texas, today asked permission of the Securities and Exchange Commission to acquire all the property and assets of Pecos Valley Power and Light Company in Abilene.

HAROLD CALLENDER'S "A Preface to Peace"* is an anomaly among books of its type in that it seeks to base its hopes for the future on the fair and accurate reporting of present facts. The author, who has covered the news fronts of the world for THE NEW YORK TIMES for almost two decades, is liberal, internationalist, and on the side of the common man.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Japanese troops striking back on the Arakan front in southwestern Burma captured the town of Taung Bazaar on Feb. 4, an Allied communique reported today.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Britain is considerably ahead of the United States in making plans for handling the admittedly delicate problems of demobilizing her armed forces and reconverting industry from war to peace production.

The latest shipment of Argentine butter en route to the United States totals 1,800,000 pounds. The size of this third consignment, which has been the subject of much speculation in the trade in the last week, was revealed yesterday by Leo T. Crowley, head of the Foreign Economic Administration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Chief Justice Edward C. Eicher of Federal District Court accepted pleas of innocent today from five persons among thirty indicted in January for sedition.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Private Clarence Hill, 33 years old, Hamilton Township Negro soldier, was arraigned today in Hamilton Township Police Court on six charges of murder in connection with the six Duck Island "lover's lane" slayings that occurred in 1938, 1939 and 1940.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court balked today at approving an Interstate Commerce Commission order that the court said extended to motor carriers the same rate-making policy that has long governed volume shipments by railroads.

WHITE PLAINS, N.J., Feb. 7 -- Candidates for eight positions as delegate and alternate to the Republican National Convention were designated here this afternoon by executive members of the Westchester County Republican Committee.

The election of a new and independent board of directors for the Certain-teed Products Corporation was proposed yesterday by Rawson G. Lizars of 331 Fourth Avenue in a letter to stockholders seeking proxies for the annual meeting to be held on April 12 at Baltimore.
EDGEWATER, N.J., Feb. 7 -- The Ford Motor Company plant here was back in full scale production today as the 4,000 employes returned after the unauthorized walkout staged on Saturday by 2,000.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES AIRCRAFT CARRIER, Off Kwajalein Atoll, Feb. 1 (Delayed) -- The most solid job of reporting I ever heard over the radio was performed at the battle for Roi and Namur islands in Kwajalein Atoll today and by rank cubs at the business.

A list of alleged Allied "outrages" against Japanese internees was cited yesterday by Sadao Iguchi, Japanese Board of Information spokesman, in apparent reply to American-British charges of atrocities by Japan.

A new issue of $3,000,000 of refunding bonds of Buffalo, N.Y., was announced yesterday by Frank M. Davis, City Controller, for award on Feb. 15. The issue will be dated March 1, 1944, and will mature on March 1, 1948 to 1954. Bidders are to name the interest rate in multiples of one-quarter or one-tenth of 1 per cent.
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Although the stock markets here opened the week quietly today the tone was firm.

OTTAWA, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Bank of Canada announced today its rediscount rate to chartered or savings banks, which controls credit policy, would be reduced effective tomorrow to 1 1/2 per cent from 2 1/2 per cent.

AN ADVANCED UNITED STATES AIR BASE in the Cen- tral Pacific, Feb. 5 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Raymond Clapper, noted colum- nist whose last "story" was the Marshall Islands invasion, died in a flaming Avenger torpedo bomber on Feb. 2 when his pilot, apparent- ly trying to give the writer a final look at the just-bombed Eniwetok airdrome, peeled off from the gathering formation and crashed into another American plane.

A vellum copy of the Kelmscott Press edition of the works of Geoffrey Chaucer was bought by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach for $5,300 yesterday at an auction of rare books at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc. The three-session auction, which ended last night, included property of the late Herbert Ten Broeck Jacquelin, Harry S. Durand and others. Only thirteen copies of the Kelmscott Chaucer were printed on vellum.

Trailing, 3 to 2, going into the final chapter, the Brooklyn Crescents defeated the New York Rovers, 6 to 5, last night in an Eastern Hockey League game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace. Hank Damore and Fred Shero shared the four tallies made by the Crescents in the final stanza.

Higher tax rates to meet the war needs of the nation were described as imperative yesterday by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, who warned that failure to adopt such a program would merely lead to inflation and result in difficulty during the transition to peace-time economics.

Three economists who addressed the Association of Customers' Brokers at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday were in substantial agreement that the major trend of the stock market for the next few months would be downward, but that the long-term trend was upward.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- President Roosevelt was asked a direct question this afternoon whether he would accept a fourth-term nomination, but he did not give a direct answer.

A long-drawn-out dispute within the Office of War Information has at length been settled by the forced resignation of three executives. The situation illustrates once again the administrative ambiguities typical of the present Administration. Elmer Davis, Director of OWI, had asked Robert E. Sherwood, Director of the Overseas branch, to dismiss these three executives.

The industrial buildings at 41-53 Hamilton Avenue and 10-14 President Street, Brooklyn, have been sold by the Nicholas Realty Corporation to the Basin Realty Corporation through the John Pullman Real Estate Company, Inc., brokers. These structures are on a plot 135 by 95 feet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Heedless of heavy flak from the anti-aircraft guns of a Nazi submarine, a United States Navy Consolidated Catalina flying boat kept steadily on its target and sank the U-boat in the South Atlantic some months ago, the Navy Department revealed today.
LONDON, Feb. 8 (U.P.) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

When people say that a policeman's lot is not a happy one it need not mean that the policeman is an isolated case. As a matter of fact, in the whole structure of law and order, from the patrolman on his beat to the chief justice on the bench, it may be said that the lot of these useful public servants is not a happy one, taking one consideration with another.

James A. Burke, Borough President of Queens, declared yesterday that the coal shortage in his borough was "desperate" and he appealed to Federal authorities for relief for "thousands of families whose homes are without heat, some of them for extended periods, and whose health is gravely imperiled."

Coventry of the past and of our own day is a charmed name. Its recorded history covers more than nine hundred years. Godiva of the legend rides through it. Falstaff's ragged regiment marches through it. Just outside of it is Gosford Green, where Bolingbroke, the future Henry IV, and the Duke of Norfolk were to fight their duel in "Richard II."
TWIN FALLS, Idaho, Feb. 8 -Following is the prepared text of the speech of Wendell L. Willkie at a Republican meeting at Twin Falls High School tonight:

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 8 (AP) -- A system of State real estate taxes based on rental values rather than capital valuation was advocated today by Edward K. Hardy, president of the National Council of Real Estate taxpayers.

Mrs. Louis W. Noel, chairman of the Women's special gifts committee of the Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York, Mrs. Cord Meyer, executive vice chairman, and Mrs. Guy Fairfax Cary, assistant chairman, will be luncheon hostesses next Tuesday at the Biltmore to Miss Katherine A.D. Blake, who recently returned from overseas duty for the Red Cross.

Elsewhere on this page this morning there is a V-mail letter from an American corporal, somewhere in Britain, strongly urging the enactment of a Federal voting plan and expressing the fear that the adoption of the alternative so-called "States' rights" plan would breed resentment and distrust among the armed forces.

ALGIERS, Feb. 8 -- Pierre Mendes-France, Commissioner for Finance, today announced the accord with the British Treasury by which the French Committee was enabled to bring virtually the whole French Empire, as well as Algeria and Corsica, under a single monetary unit stabilized for the duration.

BOSTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Governor Saltonstall named Sinclair Weeks, treasurer of the Republican National Committee, to the Senate today and then announced his own candidacy for the post in the fall election.

James H. Torrens, Tammany leader of the Twenty-third Assembly District, was nominated last night by the Democratic committeemen of the Twenty-first Congressional District for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Gavagan, who had represented the district for many years.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 8 -- Advocating a free exchange of news in the post-war world, Kent Cooper told hundreds of workers at the launching of a Liberty ship today that "if the true spirit of our country in its attitude toward the world is really understood, then not only these ships but their cargoes and passengers will be cordially welcomed in every port and in every land."

Despite the widespread grumblings and other expressions of discontent that greeted the rationing of meats, butter and processed foods, the point system has had a remarkably good effect on New Yorkers, Henry M. Brundage, Commissioner of Markets, declared yesterday.

Lifting of the embargo by the British Board of Trade on shipments of woolen and worsted piece goods to the United States is regarded in the industry here as being a victory for those consuming trades which have sought relief from the curb since, it became effective on May 31, 1943.
LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 9 (AP) The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

At the eighty-second annual meetings of the board of managers and members of the American Bureau of Shipping yesterday in the bureau's headquarters, 47 Beaver Street, J. Lewis Luckenhach, president, asserted that the shipbuilding effort of American shipyards during the war years had reached a point where the American Merchant Marine now ranked first in the world in numbers and tonnage.

BOSTON, Feb. 8 (U.P.) -- A conspiracy to control the New Bedford fishing industry and monopolize the sale of some kinds of fish throughout the United States was charged today in an indictment returned by a Federal grand jury against five fishing corporations and seven officials.

For the greater part of his mature life Dr. Bernard Sachs was a leader in American neurology. The New York Academy of Medicine recognized him as such by electing him to its presidency, and mental institutions by engaging him as a consultant. That he should have maintained his hold upon his many colleagues throughout the country must be attributed to a flexibility of mind that was his distinguishing characteristic to the last.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 8 (U.P.) -- Pope Pius XII has protested energetically against a German interpretation of a clause in the Vatican's Lateran Treaty with Italy, fearing that it may foreshadow further German searches and seizures in churches in Rome, an unimpeachable source at the Italian frontier stated tonight.

Tonight's events: "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 o'clock; Boston Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Emanuel Vardi, USN, viola, and Roland Gundry, violin, recital, Town Hall, 8:30; Budapest String Quartet, with Milton Katims, viola, Lexington Avenue Y.M.H.A., 8:50.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Representative Everett Dirksen, Republican, of Illinois offered a new bill today to liquidate the Government's Home Owners Loan Corporation within two years from June 30, 1944, by selling its mortgage loans to private investing agencies. In an accompanying statement he urged turning the liquidation over to RFC on the ground that HOLC seems to have little interest in winding up.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Lessing Rosenwald, appearing this afternoon before the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, endorsed a resolution advocating United States intervention to obtain abrogation of the British White Paper ending Jewish immigration to Palestine and urged deletion from the document of that portion which anticipates the establishment of a Jewish state in the Holy Land.

The City Council adopted unanimously yesterday a resolution declaring that "millions of citizens of New York are of Jewish faith and have next of kin and relatives seeking a haven of refuge in Palestine from Nazi and Fascist oppression abroad" and urging that Great Britain keep Palestine open for immigration without interruption.

The annual report of the Lawyers Title Corporation of New York submitted to stockholders yesterday by Lee Thompson Smith, president, disclosed a net profit of $106,689 for 1943, compared with $28,165 the year before. The increase was attributed largely to the improvement in title insurance business, Mr. Smith explained.

The plain facts of the spring fashion were presented to the press yesterday morning by Lord Taylor. So unadorned were the styles that the writers were asked to "look twice" to record style points accurately. It was a good showing that told the story of the increasing simplicity of clothes.

The 1,091 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $90,741,549,801 par value as of Jan. 31, had a total market value of $90,544,387,232, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday As of Dec. 31 there were 1,096 issues, aggregating $90,840,915,406 par value, which had a total market value of $90,274,071,634.

" The Sullivans," a drama about the five brothers who died in the sinking of the cruiser Juneau, will open this morning at the Roxy. Starred in the Twentieth Century-Fox film are Thomas Mitchell, Selena Royle and Anne Baxter. Playing the sailor brothers are Edward Ryan, John Campbell, James Cardwell, John Alvin and George Offerman Jr.

Two regiments of Waves in basic training at "U.S.S. Hunter" in the Bronx marched in review yesterday on the first anniversary of the opening of the school for Navy women. Rear Admiral E.J. Marquart, commandant of the Third Naval District, took the review in the Eighth Regiment Armory at Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue, where the Waves were led by their own drum and bugle corps.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,122, compared with 848 in the preceding week and 878 in the like period last year, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 584, aaginst 406 last Tuesday.

The current abundance of pork and the heavy marketing of cattle that now are beginning to taper off represent a "liquidation of livestock" that will be followed by acute shortages after April, it was asserted yesterday by spokesmen for the livestock industry.

ALGIERS, Feb. 8 -- As the battle for Cassino continued in the northern sector of what was once a town and American forces inched bloodily nearer the crest of Mount Cassino, the German Air -- Force roared down on the Allies' beachhead below Rome yesterday in a new offensive that may herald the long awaited major counter-blow by the steadily reinforced German ground troops.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A rayon knit fabrics price regulation providing dollars-and-cents ceiling prices for such fabrics for manufacturers, jobbers and converters, was announced by the Office of Price Administration today. The regulation replaces the March, 1942, maximum prices which have been charged by sellers in the past.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 9 -The Red Army yesterday captured the great manganese center of Nikopol, inflicting on the Germans one of their most crippling economic defeats of the war, while other Soviet forces killed more than 15,000 Nazis in a four-day companion offensive that cleared the enemy from the entire east bank of the lower Dnieper River.

No opening of a "Ring" cycle in many years at the Metropolitan has been so auspicious as the one that George Szell directed last night for the first of the evening performances of the special Wagner series given outside the regular subscription nights.

Asserting that the nation's tax policy must be changed if private enterprise is to survive in the post-war period, Henry A. Theis, president of the trust division of the American Bankers Association, told delegates to the division's twenty-fifth mid-winter conference at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that maintenance of the present tax policy threatens to lead to national socialism.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 8 (U.P.) -Vice President Wallace reiterated tonight his prediction that President Roosevelt would run for a fourth term but said he doubted the Chief Executive "was clear in his own mind about it, as everyone else is."

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 9 --The methodical big-scale smashing of German industrial power within the Reich and German military strength in northern France was resumed yesterday with the United States Army Air Forces' bombers and fighters playing the leading role in a dawn-to-dusk battle.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 8 -Slowdown on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad, particularly between the stations in Hoboken and uptown New York, is being conducted by disgruntled union employes who have unsuccessfully sought wage increases, according to M.J. O'Connell, assistant to the superintendent of the railroad.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 8 -- The Argentine Government announced today the arrest of one German and two Japanese members of the diplomatic corps accredited to Buenos Aires, whom it describes as "the persons truly in charge of all of the espionage activities that were carried on in Argentina."

Sidney Hillman's "unity plan" for the American Labor party, rejected by its Right Wing leaders as designed to facilitate control of the organization by Communists, was repudiated yesterday by Samuel Wolchok, national president of the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes Union, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8 -- Gen. Rodion Y. Malinovsky is continuing to push southward from Apostolovo, outflanking Krivoi Rog and severing the roads between the Dnieper and the Kherson railroad, according to reports received here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Senate, in a four-hour burst of action, passed two service men's voting bills today and sent to the House in each a program for use of a Federal ballot by the armed forces, such as the House rejected by 224 to 168 last Thursday night.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 8 -- Valdina Punch and African Sun took the feature races at Hialeah Park today as 9,007 persons, who wagered $765,456, saw the Alhambra Purse split into two divisions because of the large number of entries.

One reads that the men of an American service unit somewhere in this global war were allowed by their commander, in reward for accomplishing an exceptionally difficult mission, to have breakfast in bed next day. The item stirs nostalgic reflections.

The Religious Book Club has chosen as its March selection "The Christian Way in a Modern World," by the Rev. W. Norman Pittenger, a member of the faculty of the General Theological Seminary of New York City. The book is published by the Cloister Press, Louisville, Ky.
A hundred New York women, who have hitherto been charged with helping to decide what to do with criminals, are now setting out to help prevent crime.

In the first move to assure war manufacturers equitable treatment in getting back their peacetime markets, the War Production Board is studying a plan which would require clock manufacturers who are authorized to increase their production of civilian products to sell certain percentages of this output to producers who are still engaged on war contracts, it was learned yesterday.

One of the few cosmetics revealed by wartime surveys as "indispensable" to women in both Great Britain and America is the deodorant. And yet, according to the findings of local dermatologists, the average woman knows next to nothing about what she can, or should, expect from this important aid to grooming.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Feb. 9 (UP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- A warning that the Red Army might march on Helsinki and that the Soviet Union had forces to spare from the main fronts against the Germans was given in a sharply rephrased editorial in Izvestia today. On the same page the paper printed the results of the latest Helsinki raid and on another the Tass denial of a Russian separate peace maneuver with Finland.

ALGIERS, Feb. 8 -- On the grounds that the accompanying publicity had been "prejudicial and detrimental" to the Wac recruiting drive, the United States War Department a few days ago instructed Wac officials here to discontinue "Swing, Sister Wac, Swing," the G.I. musical show which opened Jan. 3 and closed after four disappointing performances, it was learned today.
Dr. Vladimir Rybar, Counselor of the Yugoslovak Embassy, and Mrs. Rybar have arrived from Washington and are at the RitzCarlton.

Michael Todd was on the telephone yesterday, but that's nothing unusual. This time, however, he was talking from Hollywood and reporting that he had purchased a complete and original Victor Herbert score from the master's estate.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Feb. 9 (U.P.) -- Allied planes, again battering the Japanese base of Rabaul, New Britain, shot down thirteen more enemy planes and probably destroyed ten others Sunday, a communique announced today

A plan to permit the electorate of any judicial district to use a modification of the Missouri system in choosing the judges of its constitutional courts was approved yesterday by the Lawyers Committee on Selection of Judges of the First Judicial District, composed of fifty-six attorneys representing the major bar associations of the district.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 8 -- One out of every three jobs in Canada is now being filled by a women, according to the subcommittee on post-war problems of women. The committee, whose chairman is Mrs. R.F. McWilliams of Winnipeg, has just presented its report to Parliament.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Prices of wheat declined around 1/2 cent a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, the near-by futures selling at the lowest marks in more than two weeks and September going lowest since late last December.

Active buying in anticipation of Government purchases of 332,000 bales of raw cotton in the open market for lend-lease shipments, caused yesterday a sharp rise in cotton futures. At the close of trading, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 4 to 14 points over Monday's final prices.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- The Republican party, which controls the executive and legislative branches of the State Government, is interested in public housing "only as a palliative to be used in extreme circumstances," Senator Desmond of Newburgh asserted in defending the majority's action today in reporting his bill providing only $35,000,000 for such purposes.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 (AP) -- the Oklahoma Natural Gas Company of Tulsa registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission $18,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds due in 1961 and 180,000 bares of Series A $50-par value cumulative preferred stock.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- The State Legislature voted unanimously today to investigate its own "methods, practices, expenditures and procedures," to see if any of them are outmoded and antiquated, and make such changes as might be found to be necessary.

The National League held its annual schedule meeting in the Hotel New Yorker yesterday and by way of demonstrating that baseball occassionally could do things swiftly and efficiently cleaned up its business in jig time.

TWIN FALLS, Idaho Feb. 8 --Addressing a Republican meeting tonight in the auditorium of the high school here, Wendell L. Willkie made a double plea, one to the voters of the United States and one to the members of the Republican organization.
Benefiting by the $52,375 worth of bonds pledged by those attending the New York baseball writers' dinner, big league idols went farther ahead in the Fourth War Loan sports popularity poll yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate today attached a Federal war ballot amendment to a House-approved "States' Rights" service vote bill:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Aerial combat losses of both the Japanese and Allied air forces in the Pacific war reached new heights in January, a month of increased Allied offensives in the skies.

It Was Grantland Rice who some years ago went on a voyage of discovery to find what kind of foods the All-American football team was fed. To his great amazement he found that all of them were black-bread eaters.

The element of surprise in weapons, tactics and strategy has a direct bearing on the new super-bomber, the B-29, which was announced some time ago as in production. The new aircraft, it has been indicated, is twice as big as the present Flying Fortress, but the details must necessarily remain secret.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. (AP) -A Southeast Asia Command communique:

The activities of the United States Government in the development of rubber production in Brazil have now been discontinued and Brazilian authorities have undertaken to assume the financing of all such operations in return for a 33 1-3 per cent advance above current prices for natural rubber, I was announced yesterday by Dr. Valentim F. Boucas, special representative of the Brazilian Government.

The Continental Motors Corporation reported yesterday in its preliminary statement for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, 1943, a net profit of $6,017,208, equal to $2.01 a share on the common stock. In the preceding fiscal year the corporation earned $5,472,884, or $1.82 a share.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Allies continued to carry the war to the enemy yesterday in all theatres of operations, though on one front in Italy and one in Burma the enemy has wrested the tactical initiative from us.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Four young members of Congress called on President Roosevelt at the White House today to urge modification of his recent order requiring members to give up their seats if they entered the armed services.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8 -- Legality of the procedure under which Attorney General Biddle issued a deportation order against Harry R. Bridges, West Coast longshoremen's leader, was attacked and defended today before five judges of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

The preliminary report of the New York Telephone Company for 1943, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $31,700,547, compared with $25,358,504 in 1942, a gain of $6,342,043.

The six-story store and loft building at 8-10 West Forty-fifth Street has been sold by the Greenwich Savings Bank to an investing client of Joseph Howard Katz, lawyer, subject to a ten-year mortgage of $64,000.

KWAJALEIN, Marshall Islands, Feb. 5 -- The capture of Kwajalein Atoll in the Marshall Islands will result in a quickening of the tempo of the Pacific war, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet and Pacific Ocean Areas, said here today shortly after his arrival by air to inspect the new bases added to his command by Army and marine forces in the last five days.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8 -- The Russian Army newspaper Red Star followed up last week's Izvestia's article on Vatican policy by printing extracts from a pamphlet on Vatican policy in Europe, described as having been written by a former German business man and doctor of philosophy, Leopold Mannaberg.

BOSTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Bruins, in a surprising exhibition of offensive and defensive play, shut out the league-leading Canadiens, 3 to 0, tonight before 12,000 at Boston Garden. It was Goalie Bert Gardiner's first shut-out of the season and only the second time this season that Montreal had been blanked.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Increased frozen vegetable allocations for civilian use and a slight decrease in the civilian rice supply were announced today by the War Food Administration.

Mrs. Henry A. Wallace, wife of the Vice President, revisited yesterday at a Brooklyn pier the Liberty ship Patrick Henry, which she sponsored almost two and a half years ago. She often had expressed a desire to inspect the ship, but it was not until yesterday that she and the vessel managed to be at the same place at the same time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- What legislation for voting the armed forces will finally emerge from the untidy heap of combined Federal - State election Machinery which the Senate dumped into the House today cannot yet be foreseen.

Forehanded income taxpayers filed through two offices of the Bureau of Internal Revenue here yesterday at the rate of 1,500 to 1,750 an hour. Lines were waiting at 2 Broadway when the office opened at 9 A.M. and there was still a short line at 3 P.M., although 6,000 persons had consulted the deputies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The United States has given a renewed warning to Finland that if she continues in the war she must be prepared to take the consequences. This was confirmed today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull after Stockholm dispatches had told of the warnings.

Yesterday was the thirty-fourth anniversary of the founding of the Boy Scouts of America. In this city it marked the start of the celebration of National Boy Scout Week by 55,000 Scouts. There will be special meetings, patriotic rallies, exhibitions and the WEAF-Greater New York Boy Scout War Bond drive, in which all troops in the city will take part.

AT THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, South of Rome, Feb. 8 -- A jammed beachhead evacuation hospital -- so plainly marked with red crosses that it could not have been mistaken for anything else -- was bombed by a German dive-bomber yesterday.

Two discouraging facts with regard to wartime motoring are reported by the National Safety Council. The council finds that traffic violations of all kinds are on the increase. Police forces, operating with fewer officers, are issuing more than the normal proportion of tickets for such offenses as double parking, running red lights, driving with one headlight, or driving while intoxicated.

A new Government-endorsed conservation campaign, combining all phases of previous programs, to save fuel, electric power, automobiles, food, metals and fats in the interests of the war effort will begin in newspapers, magazines and trade papers during the latter part of this month and continue throughout 1944.

It was economic and not military considerations that led the Germans to cling so tenaciously to Nikopol and their last bridgehead on the Dnieper. They needed desperately the manganese produced there. Now they have lost not only the city and its garrison but the whole bridgehead maintained to shield it.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Feb. 8 -- There is today closer cooperation between the various theatres in the Pacific than at any time since the war started.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 8 -Ethel Barrymore will return to the screen, after an absence of twelve years, to play the leading feminine role in the RKO picturization of Richard Llewellyn's novel "None But the Lonely Heart." Her last picture was the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer film "Rasputin" in which she was starred with her brothers, John and Lionel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The National War Labor Board sent to President Roosevelt tonight the case of the Mechanics Educational Society of America to enable him to invoke at once the criminal sanctions of the War Labor Disputes Act if the society orders a resumption of a strike of 25,000 tool and die makers which was called off "temporarily" at the board's demand yesterday.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Feb. 8 -- After a week of extensive in-fighting along the fringe of houses in the outer limits of Cassino and on the craggy ridges above it, American infantrymen began today to make a definite penetration, although at a snail's pace.

ROI ISLAND, Kwajalein Atoll, Marshall Islands, Feb. 2 (Delayed) -- Rattling machine guns and rifle fire punctuated by the tremendous explosions of pillboxes being blown up by the Fourth Marine Division grew louder in our aching ears as our landing boats approached the beach at Namur Island yesterday afternoon, three hours after the first landing and with the battle at its peak.
LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- A joint Unite States Army, European Theatre of Operations and British Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Advance preparation by the War Production Board for problems which will arise with the reconversion of industry to peacetime production contemplates an arrangement under which the Office of Civilian Requirements and the Smaller War Plants Corporation, key agencies in the reconversion period, will report directly to Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, according to information here.

UNTIL the day before yesterday, when John Hersey's "A Bell for Adano" was published, the best novel that had been written about this war was probably "Signed With Their Honour" by James Aldridge. That fine and stirring tale about British fighter pilots and their gallant sacrifices against the Italians and Germans in the skies of Greece was the work of a 24-yearold Australian journalist.

In his Carnegie Hall recital last night, his first here this season, Alexander Brailowsky, the distinguished Russian pianist, captured his audience with a display of pianism in the grand manner that few artists in the country could match.

Something like 200 sportsmen will gather at the Columbia University Club tonight to attend the annual dinner meeting of the New York State committee of Ducks Unlimited, the big international wild duck restoration group that was formed a little more than six years ago to fight the threatened extinction of waterfowl.

If there are no neutrals in this war, neither are there any sanctuaries or places of refuge. The struggle of states like Sweden and Switzerland, Turkey and Spain to maintain a precarious and unnatural balance against pressures from both sides demonstrates again and again how impossible it is for any nation to be at peace while the combat goes on.
CHUNGKING, China, Feb, 8 (AP) -A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Fritz Kreisler, the violinist, who for years has firmly refused to perform for the radio, will appear in a series of five programs beginning next summer over the National Broadcasting Company network, it was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 -- The Department of Justice, defending its right to intervene, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to dismiss as "novel and unsound" the petition of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., designed to void an order of the commission granting the anti-trust division of the department leave to participate in the underwriting case of the Public Service Company of Indiana.

A concerted effort on the part of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, the National Association of Manufacturers, the National Retail Dry Goods Association and other groups to produce a plan for price control which would meet "basic needs, preserve the right to reasonable profit, and serve the public interest" was suggested yesterday by Saul Cohn, chairman of the post-war planning committee of the retail organization and president of the City Stores Company.

Having rolled out last month the largest amount of steel ever produced in a January and the third highest output for any month to date, the steel industry now has an annual productive capacity 3,359,630 tons greater than at the start of 1943 and 5,082,320 higher than on Jan. 1, 1942, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Vatican radio, commenting on the Fascist raid on St. Paul's Basilica last Thursday in which sixty-four Italian officers and Jews who had received sanctuary there were arrested, said tonight that the church would never yield in offering charity to everyone.

A bill to give the Board of Education and the New York City public school system fiscal independence, as recommended by the National Education Association's investigating committee, is to be introduced in Albany on Monday by Assemblyman Lewis A. Olliffe of Brooklyn, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- A Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- President Roosevelt decorated today two winners of the Congressional Medal of Honor, the country's highest award for bravery under fire. They were Second Lieut. Gerry H. Kisters, 24-year-old exfurrier of Bloomington, Ind., who also received the Distinguished Service Cross, making him the only soldier in this war to receive both, and First Lieut. Kenneth A. Walsh, Marine Corps aviator, a native of Brooklyn.

Stimulated by the General Motors Corporation's increase of its dividend, the stock market negotiated yesterday a reversal of form in which some of the key issues recovered a point or more. Just as the list previously had turned downward on meager selling, the rally was accomplished with only a slight expansion in business.

Recognizing the increasing importance of plastic tools and fixtures in aircraft production, a national society of plastic tooling has been organized by five major air-craft producers in Eastern States, it was announced yesterday by Delmar Anderson, its president.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Six out of seven Italian merchant ships in metropolitan Spanish ports have been released and three have sailed, it was announced officially today. The seventh is held because of a dispute over her ownership.

Frank Dunne, president of the New York Security Dealers Association, announced yesterday that that organization had approved and sent to the Securities and Exchange Commission a protest against the 5 per cent limitation on mark-ups approved last fall by the National Association of Securities Dealers. Adoption of the protesting resolution was reported in these columns on Sunday.

Two exhibitions are on this week's schedule at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. In the large fifth-floor galleries have been installed drawings, gouaches and pastels, ranging in point of time (and it constitutes the exhibition's title) "From Clouet to Degas." All of this French work will be placed on view today.

Destruction of irreplaceable objects of art at the Brooklyn Museum by vandals has taken an unaccountable spurt in the last two weeks, it was disclosed yesterday by the director, Mrs. Isabel S. Roberts.

New York City has reached 90.6 per cent of its goal in bond sales covering all classifications in the Fourth War Loan drive, the War Finance Committee for New York announced yesterday. The city's over-all sales up through Monday total $3,338,512,000, according to Nevil Ford, executive manager of the committee.

A do-or-die set shot by Bob Mulvihill, ex-Fordham Ram, from far out in the court with only two seconds left lifted the University of Rochester to a 44-to-42 basketball victory over New York University last night in Madison Square Garden, thereby nullifying a valiant attempt on the part of Coach Howard Cann's men to undo a bad start.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Wounded volunteers of the Army's crack original Ranger Battalion who trained with British Commandos on the moors of Scotland and are back in the United States today praised highly the intelligence units that provided them with vital information for invading Dieppe, North Africa, Sicily and Italy.
One Hundred and Second Street, from West End Avenue to the Hudson River, was disturbed yesterday, as it had been since Sunday, by the unsolved mystery of the leaping dog.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Two American submarines, the 1,525-ton Cisco and the 850-ton S-44, are overdue and are presumed to be lost, the Navy Department announced today. No location was given, but it was believed the undersea boats were lost while raiding Japanese supply lines in the Pacific.

John W. Kunkle of Garden City, L.I., seems to me to have touched upon a fundamental truth when he said in a recent letter to THE TIMES that world peace cannot long exist unless we here in this country train our youth in the responsibilities of citizenship. If we hope to carry forward the principles of democracy, surely we must make them a living reality to our children.

A UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE STATION, Somewhere in England, Feb. 8 -- Two of the strangest stories yet told by American fliers in this theatre of war were among the many eyewitness accounts related today by United States Eighth Air Force crews upon their return to this station from the Frankfort-on-the-Main mission.

Increases in both the price and weight of the standard loaf of bread in the New York area were introduced yesterday with the approval of the Office of Price Administration. Many New York City consumers paid 1 cent more for the new 20-ounce loaf priced at 12 cents.

Young Johnny Fulton, who shook with fright as the day of the Millrose games approached and then proceeded to go out and beat Jimmy Herbert in the "600," to be voted the stand-out performer, is now looking for longer distances on board tracks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- President Roosevelt was urged today by Philip Murray, head of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, to veto the new $2,315,200,000 tax bill, but at his news conference the Chief Executive told reporters that he had not made up his mind on the matter.

AT THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, South of Rome, Feb. 8 -The Germans forced a slight retirement in the British sector today while continuing fierce pressure at a number of other points on the fan-shaped beachhead.

Calling for a redefining of States' rights in new terms of duties, responsibilities and opportunities to bring about more effective cooperation between State and Federal agencies, Governor Raymond E. Baldwin of Connecticut told the New York Credit Men's Association last night that as a result of close harmony with Federal agencies Connecticut has been able to turn out the greatest per capita dollar volume of war materials of any State in the union.

William Gephart, baritone, of Spokane, Wash., who has appeared in many opera productions of the Juilliard Graduate School of which he is a graduate, made his debut last night at Town Hall before a large and cordial audience.

The four-family apartment house at 1106 West Street, Union City, N.J., has been sold by Mrs. Carrie Larson to a client of John J. Carlin, attorney. The Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization was the broker.
PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 8 -- The battle for Kwajalein has ceased and organized resistance throughout the islands and islets has been annihilated. Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced here today.
LANCASTER, Pa., Feb. 8 (AP) -Six soldiers were injured, one seriously, when a car in which they were riding crashed into the rear of a trailer-truck east of here tonight.

The Boston Metropolitan District, Mass., awarded yesterday a new issue of $2,600,000 of refunding bonds, dated March 1, 1944, and due serially from March 1, 1945 to 1969, at a price of 99:919 for the bonds as 1 1/4 per cents. The proceeds will be used to purchase a like amount of bonds of the Boston Elevated Railway Company.
LONDON, Feb. 8 (U.P.) -- Bombs fell on the outskirts of Florence this afternoon, one killing the singer, Lina Cavalieri, and demolishing her house, the Rome radio reported tonight.

Lulu Costantino, East Side lightweight, tonight gets a chance to fight his way into a position where he can command attention as a serious contender for the world title. The speedy little East Sider is to face Tippy Larkin, Garfield (N.J.) veteran, in the feature ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden and on the outcome will depend whether Lulu qualifies for consideration among the top flight 135-pounders.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission's plan of reorganization for the St. Louis-Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway, cutting its total capitalization from $105,946,995 to $75,000,375, was approved today by United States District Judge George H. Moore.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- In a move that indicates a growing desire in London for a new Entente Cordiale, the British Government signed a financial agreement and a mutual-aid agreement today with the French Committee of National Liberation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- An investigation which will determine whether the Alleghany Corporation, as a holding company exercising a controlling interest in the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company, the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company, and the Pere Marquette Railway Company, should come under the jurisdiction of the Interstate Commerce Commission was ordered today by the agency.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 8 -- The main task ahead of the United Nations after victory will be to provide an international organization to facilitate future re-adjustments in the relations of nations on the bases of necessity and justice, John Foster Dulles declared in an address here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- An estimate that Japanese factories are turning out aircraft at a rate of 1,200 or more a month came from high quarters here today, coupled with a report that the Japanese, like the Germans, were concentrating on defensive types.

It is undoubtedly true, as pointed out in Topics of The Times and in the letter of Mr. A. Outram Sherman which you published Jan. 30, that the Supreme Court is writing longer opinions than it did in the recent past; and it is also undoubtedly true that the physical ease of dictating an opinion as compared with the physical labor of writing it in longhand induces to some extent to verbosity.

The brown and white collie that had stirred pity among 102d Street's residents since last Sunday by unaccountable vigil under a ground-floor apartment window at 300 Riverside Drive was taken yesterday by agents for the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8 (Delayed) -- The Soviet Government is still talking war rather than peace with Finland. With the relief of Leningrad the Finnish position has become tremendously accentuated. The Red Army is now in an excellent position to launch an offensive against the Karelian Isthmus.

MONTREAL, Feb. 9 (Canadian Press) -- The Lake St. John Power and Paper Company, Ltd., announced today that its profit in 1943 available for dividends was $185,987, equal to $10.33 a share on the preferred stock, compared with $124,980, or $6.95 a share, in 1942.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Roosevelt named Lloyd K. Garrison today to be a public member of the National War Labor Board to succeed Wayne L. Morse, who resigned to run for the Republican Senatorial nomination in Oregon. Thus one law school dean succeeds another.

Plans are now afoot to stimulate the cultivation of victory gardens and the allied industry of home canning. The Government hopes to equal or even better last year's record of 4,100,000,000 jars of home-processed foods, the preparation of which involved 24,800,000 persons.

NAMUR, Kwajalein Atoll, Marshall Islands, Feb. 6 (Delayed) -- Capt. James L. Denig, son of Brig. Gen. Robert L. Denig, in charge of public relations for the United States Marine Corps, was killed in action here Feb. 2 while leading a section of light tanks against a Japanese position.

"Song of Russia," a topical romantic drama produced by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, which arrives at the Capitol, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Heading the cast of the film, which was directed by Gregory Ratoff and produced by Joseph Pasternak, are Robert Taylor, Susan Peters, John Hodiak, Robert Benchley and Felix Bressart.

ALGIERS, Feb. 9 -- Striking back at the tenacious Germans, the Allied forces in Italy threw the heaviest weight of their air power into the battle on both fronts yesterday. Apart from strategic heavy bomber attacks on Verona and other rail junctions in the north, the majority of more than 1,500 sorties were carried out in direct support of the largely stalemated ground forces.

Sales of department stores in the second Federal Reserve District last year increased 6 per cent over 1942, while inventories at the end of the year showed an 8 per cent decline, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

KWAJALEIN, Marshall Islands, Feb. 4 (Delayed) -- With the occupation of Kwajalein Island completed at 3:30 P.M. today, when Seventh Army Division infantrymen reached the narrow northeastern tip, not only this atoll but all of the Marshall Islands came under American control.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Production of tires for passenger car use will fall 6,000,000 to 12,000,000 short of the 30,000,000 minimum goal set for 1944 some time ago, Col. Bradley Dewey, Rubber Director, told a press conference today.

Reflecting the greatest volume of sales in its history, earnings of Best Co., before taxes, were the best on record, according to the preliminary statement for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 released today by Philip Le Boutillier, president and general manager.

Practical fashions for the wartime bride, from her wedding gown through her complete wardrobe, were presented yesterday in a fashion show at Loeser's. Planned to meet the varying needs of the 1944 bride, whether she's going to live at an Army post or keep on with her job in a big city, the show included clothes suitable for all parts of the country and all kinds of living.

AT A BRITISH ARMY BATTLE SCHOOL, Feb. 9 -- The British Army is now rigorously weeding out and toughening up its combat officers in preparation for the unprecedented trials that the invasion of the Continent will bring.
KWAJALEIN, Marshall Islands, Feb. 5 -- Careful plans for military government of occupied territory are being carried out for the first time in the Pacific on Kwajalein atoll in the Marshall Islands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The extent to which the Controlled Materials Plan, fathered in the War Production Board by Ferdinand Eberstadt when he was a vice chairman of the agency, has eased the flow of materials and supplies, was emphasized here today by W.C. Skuce, director of the CMP Division of WPB.

I have noted in your issue of Feb. 2 a letter from August Maffry of the Department of Commerce criticizing a recent article in The Grace Log, which refuted the "balance of payments" argument against post-war expansion of the American Merchant Marine.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Despite determined resistance, the Japanese have made advances in the last four days toward the British supply line in the Arakan district of Burma, an Allied communique revealed today.

To help independent tire dealers meet the competition of "company-owned stores," the United States Rubber Company is planning distribution of automotive accessories through its independent outlets, R.W. Collings, eastern sales manager for the company, told a meeting of distributors at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.
Employment opportunities for Negroes will be greater in post-war industry than before the conflict, according to a report of a study made public yesterday by the National Urban League.

Shortage of manpower on the city's police force resulted yesterday in a suggestion to all local draft boards to give "serious consideration" to policemen coming up for induction, but at the same time it was noted that firemen, with the exception of some "outstanding cases," would continue to be accepted for the armed forces.

Joining the Broadway managerial ranks with "Take It as It Comes," which will have its delayed premiere tonight at the Forty-eighth Street, is Armin L. Robinson, a gentleman who was better known on the Continent during the pre-Hitler period as a producer and the head of a music publishing house.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Russia has cooperated with Britain in the relief of prisoners in Japanese hands to the extent of clearing correspondence and forwarding relief supplies through Russian territory, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden informed Parliament today.

Directors of the North American Company declared yesterday a common stock dividend in the form of common shares of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company at the rate of one share of Pacific Gas for every 100 common shares of North American held.

BOISE, Idaho, Feb. 9 -- In a speech aimed at other aspirants for the Republican Presidential nomination and party leaders opposed to him as well as against President Roosevelt, Wendell L. Willkie called today for complete frankness in the discussion of important international and domestic issues in this time of crisis.

Lulu Costantino, gallant little East Side lightweight, undertook concede to Tippy Larkin, Garfield (N.J.) welterweight, every natural advantage last night in Madison Square Garden in a ten-round bout that attracted 11,535 fans and gate receipts of $31,914 -- and got an artistic beating for his pains.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Mechanics Educational Society of America asked President Roosevelt tonight to order an investigation of CIO and AFL membership on the War Labor Board.

Some of the most thrilling moments in sports history, as captured by the moving picture camera, will be shown on the screen at the Waldorf-Astoria on Sunday night at the Stars for Victory Show, the grand finale of the program put on by the Fourth War Loan Drive Sports Committee.

Characterizing governmental commissions and agencies created in the last decade as a "fourth branch" of the government in that they "exercise legislative, executive and judicial functions," A.L.M. Wiggins, president of the American Bankers Association, told delegates to the Mid-Winter Trust Conference of the association yesterday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that the growth of this system is democracy's greatest threat.

One of the undeniable achievements of the present Congress was the repeal last year of the Chinese Exclusion Acts and the modification of other statutes prohibiting the immigration of Chinese and their admission to citizenship. The long heroism of the Chinese people, our comrades in war, prompted this retraction.
ALGIERS, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A communique:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Recalling the success of the Easter week-end war bond drive of last year -- when Stock Exchange members were called together on the floor and urged to use the holidays for special canvassing -- Joseph A. Bower, director of the banking and investment brokerage division of the War Finance Committee, will appear today and tomorrow on the floors of the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Infringement by labor on management's "age-old prerogatives," subjects which are not arbitrable between unions and management and indirect demands of labor upon management were discussed today at the annual midwinter conference of the American Management Association.

Though the Fourth War Loan attained yesterday 90.3 per cent of its $4,198,000,000 quota in New York State, it lagged far behind the Third War Loan drive for the same period. New York's total sales reported yesterday were $3,791,900,000, compared with $5,049,400,000 for the Third War Loan at the comparable date.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Legislation to enable service men to vote in November struck a new snag today when the House, disagreeing with the Senate amendments to the Eastland-Rankin (State ballot) bill, including the Administration's Federal ballot system, sent the omnibus measure to conference.

The prosecution started submitting evidence yesterday in the General Sessions trial of four former officials and attaches of the defunct Madison Personal Loan Corporation on a seventeen-count indictment accusing them of conspiring to commit forgery in bogus claims on false insurance losses, made on loans to automobile and truck owners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- She's a ghost ship on Nazi records, but the aircraft carrier Ranger is very much alive and a continual threat to German shipping. Ten months ago Adolf Hitler boastfully reported the Ranger had been sunk by torpedoes and decorated Lieut. Otto von Buelow for the exploit.

Gibbs Lyons, chief national bank examiner of the Second Federal Reserve District, has been elected president of the First-Stamford National Bank of Stamford, Conn., effective March 1, the bank announced yesterday, Mr. Lyons will succeed Clarence W. Bell, who has been elected chairman of the executive committee.

A comprehensive survey of the 1944 advertising budgets of retail stores as compared with those of the previous year, recently undertaken by the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, indicates that the overwhelming number of these business organizations have increased their use of institutional advertising since the war began.

The honor and dignity of New York's ferryboat captains has been vindicated by Capt. Thomas Cavely, 54 years old, master of the Liberty ship Waigstill Avery. Captain Cavely's feat of piloting an ocean steamship around the world has removed the tarnish his profession acquired recently when the ferryboat Catskill toured the harbor in a fog, seeking Cortlandt Street.

TRENTON, Feb. 9 -- While approving most of the provisions in the judiciary article of the proposed State Constitution, a majority of the State Bar Association's special committee on constitutional revision raised objections today before a legislative committee to elimination of the present county courts and transfer of jurisdiction over matrimonial cases from the equity to the law section of the proposed unified court system.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The British Government has made it clear that it has enough worries on its hands without trying to regulate the kind of hats women are to wear or what they shall pay for them.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- The Legislature's investigation of its own activities, authorized yesterday by resolution, took form today with the appointment of a committee of six to conduct the inquiry and the selection of counsel by the committee.
