The seventy-seventh annual exhibition of the American Water Color Society will be opened with a private view this afternoon from 3 to 7 in the galleries of the National Academy, Fifth Avenue, between Eighty-ninth and Nintieth Streets.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, In Italy, Feb. 9 -- For the eighth successive day since they first established a slender toehold on the outskirts of the battered town, American troops were held back by the stone-wall defenses of Cassino, which showed no signs of cracking.

Although the report that 62,722 tons of waste paper had been collected in the city during January cheered salvage drive leaders yesterday, Edwin S. Friendly, chairman of the newspaper-sponsored national paper-saving campaign, announced that there had been a decline last week in mill receipts of waste paper throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Repeated statements by our political and military leaders that we shall surely the war are made with sincerity and conviction that grows deeper with every report from the tactical commanders in the field. When the collapse of resistance really begins -- and the prevailing belief is that the locale will be Europe, the date this year -- grave, new tasks will devolve upon the American Government.

ST. COME, Que, Feb. 9 -- Accusing Humphrey Mitchell, Minister of Labor, of misrepresentation and of stating half-truths in his recent report to the House of Commons on the availability of Quebec labor to cut wood in Maine for America's war production, Mayors and residents of this and other border towns today offered to produce 500 idle woodsmen on a day's notice.

MONTREAL, Feb. 9 -- The postwar period will be one of substantial prosperity for retailers, and especially for credit retailers, Carl N. Schmalz, treasurer of R.H. Stearns Company, Boston, and formerly chief of the bureau of business research of the Harvard Business School, said in an address today before the local chapter of the Canadian Credit Institute.

American and British armies are now poised in the west for an amphibious mass invasion of the European continent on which will depend the outcome of the whole war. This undertaking will involve military, naval and air operations which for their size and for the problems involved are without precedent.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 9 -- The biggest "talk" horse at Hialeah Park, Director J.E., had a workout in the Grade A. Handicap today and his admirers professed to be much pleased when the 3-year-old finished third in a race with three older horses.

Peter Albisani, 28 years old, who owns a shoe repair shop at 134 Nassau Street, became yesterday the first veteran of this World War to apply for membership in the City Patrol Corps. He presented his application to City Council President Newbold Morris and Maj. Gen. Robert M. Danford, USA, retired, commandant of the corps, at exercises in City Hall.

The United Corporation, major utility holding company, is planning to convert itself into an investment company in compliance with the integration and simplification provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, William M. Hickey, the corporation's president, disclosed yesterday in his 1943 annual report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Firing another broadside at the wage aspect of the national stabilization policy, American Federation of Labor members of the National War Labor Board petitioned the board today to ask President Roosevelt to modify the "Little Steel" formula "realistically."
Aggressive resumption of trade and mill buying, supplemented by a moderate amount of price-fixing, allowed the cotton futures market yesterday to continue its advance.

A clean sweep for the union administration, headed by Thomas de Lorenzo, in an election of officers of Local 365 of the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations affiliate, was announced yesterday. The local embraces employes of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation plants in Long Island City, Newark and Johnsville, Pa.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Feb. 9 -- The Village Board here has moved to protect the estates of its wealthy summer colony in the south and west sides of the community and the village's lucrative ratables therein from the growing encroachment of commercial potato farmers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Establishment of an Office of Demobilization, responsible only to Congress, to direct industrial reconversion with a complete disregard of red tape and with the "paramount" objectives of preserving free enterprise and achieving full employment was recommended to Congress today by the special Senate Post-War Committee.

LONDON, Feb. 9 (U.P.) -- Britain today recognized Mexican, Peruvian and Iranian contributions to the Allied war effort by elevating her legations in those countries to the status of embassies and inviting them to appoint. Ambassadors to the Court of St. James.

The police announced yesterday that they had seized the gunman who held up the Saks Thirty-fourth Street store Dec. 17 and got away with $5,000. The prisoner is William H. Copeland, 35 years old, of 174 West 121st Street. Copeland was also charged with being a fugitive from justice in Washington, where he is wanted in a murder case.

How yachting as a sport has been carried on not only in a recreational way but in a war effort, was stressed last night by the coast-to-coast delegates who attended the annual general meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union, ruling body of sailing in this country and Canada, which was held in the New York Yacht Club.

MOSCOW, Feb. 9 (U.P.) -- The authoritative journal War and the Working Class asserted today that Russia's constitutional changes proved more than ever the Soviet Union's desire for international cooperation and denounced as Nazi-inspired foreign speculation that the revisions were part of a plot to seize other countries and rule the world.

Gasoline and light fuel oil stocks along the Atlantic Seaboard increased further last week, but there was a drop in heavy fuel oil supplies. The American Petroleum Institute's index covering gasoline at the end of period stood at 44.5, against 43.2 a week earlier.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 9 -- The proposed Construction by the United States Government of the 1,250-mile pipe line from the Persian Gulf to an eastern Mediterranean port will, it is felt in many quarters, make for political complications in the Middle East, only a few of which may be forecast at present.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Casualties of the United States armed forces now number 150,478, split into 112,030 for the Army and 38,448 for the Navy, the Office of War Information said today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 9 -- Columbia's basketball team left the Eastern Intercollegiate League cellar tonight at Princeton's expense, scoring an easy 48 to 25 victory over the Tigers. The teams had been tied for last place in the standings.

LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Premier Marshal Pietro Badoglio asserted in a special communique broadcast by the Bari radio today that Generalissimo Francisco Franco had released only one of fourteen Italian merchant ships detained in Spanish ports.

Officials of thirty unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations joined yesterday in a statement calling upon Sidney Hillman, chairman of the CIO Political Action Committee, to abandon "the campaign he is waging for the election of Communist candidates" to the State committee of the American Labor party.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Educational authorities pleaded with legislators at a budget hearing today to give them the money to maintain the kind of educational system to which the State has become accustomed.

There is a strong case for a system under which, once the over-all appropriation for the schools has been decided upon, the educational authorities themselves are left with full discretion concerning how those funds are to be spent. But "independence" of the school system can be carried too far.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9 -- Paramount is planning a remake of the Ernest Hemingway novel, "A Farewell to Arms," with Ingrid Bergman and Ray Milland co-starred. The decision to make the picture this season rests on the outcome of negotiations now under way with David O. Selznick for the loan of Miss Bergman.
CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- All it will cost five Army sergeants to witness the 1944 world series eight months hence is their sixth sense.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Senate decisively defeated the Administration today on the food subsidy issue, apparently insuring passage tomorrow of the Bankhead bill which would ban most of the existing operations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill jointly announced tonight that the Anglo-American campaign against the Nazi U-boats had been highly successful.

Presiding Bishop Henry St. George Tucker of the Episcopal Church announced yesterday at a quarterly session of its National Council at 281 Fourth Avenue that he had received and disbursed $127,755 in 1943 in the denomination's "bishop's fund."

TRENTON, Feb. 9 -- Growing sentiment among New Jersey Republican leaders for the Presidential nomination of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York was found today in a survey that was made after E. Bertram Mort, Morris County Republican Committee chairman, announced that petitions to enter Mr. Dewey in New Jersey's preferential primary were being circulated throughout the county.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 9 -- In an opening assault on black-market liquor rings in this area the Federal grand jury here returned today five indictments against fourteen persons and one corporation, charging them with conspiracy to sell liquor above Office of Price Administration ceiling prices, to falsify records required by the Internal Revenue Department and to violate other Federal statutes.

Fearing a production drop due to the current shortage of pulp which is needed in the output of fiber clock cases, clock manufacturers have requested the War Production Board to allocate steel for such cases, it was reported yesterday.

BUFFALO, Feb. 9 (AP) -- In reply to a published comment by President Roosevelt that its Monday editorial, suggesting a bipartisan Presidential nomination, was "hoary with age," The Buffalo Courier-Express will publish another editorial tomorrow, saying:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Judge M.G. Underwood of the Federal District Court ruled today that military courts held jurisdiction over merchant seamen on vessels operated in Army supply lines, and a spokesman for the CIO National Maritime Union promptly announced that the case would be carried to the Circuit Court of Appeals.

Reports from the farm front say that once again cream is being churned into butter. In many areas it is impossible to buy a churn. Attics are being searched; that dusty space above the woodshed is getting cleaned at long last; the countryman is untangling that mass of old chicken wire, barrels, baskets and broken tools on the unused scaffold over the calf pens.

A duck, a cat with seven pads on its right paw, 150 other cats, roosters, dogs of all shapes and sizes, turtles, fish and white mice, were on exhibition yesterday in the gymnasium of the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street, at the club's twenty-second annual pet show.

A girl who grinds cylinders in an aircraft plant and a woman who plays in a band were opposing star witnesses at an unofficial "Court of Appeals" on the proposed Equal Rights Amendment last Friday in the living room of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's New York apartment, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Subpoenas have been issued by the Special House Committee Investigating the Federal Communications Commission for the principals and participants in the alleged forced sale to Edward J. Noble, former Under-Secretary of Commerce, of radio station WMCA in New York, which, according to Donald Flamm of New York, its former owner, was effected as a result of coercion and duress exerted upon him by the purchaser and his attorneys.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 9 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

The Macom, once the proud flagship of the city's "navy," was sold yesterday for $3,150 to Joseph A. Moran of the Battery Sightseeing Company. The new owner said that he would spend $40,000 to make it seaworthy, change its name to the James J. Walker and put it in service by July 1 to make tours around Manhattan Island.

LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- An RAF commentator declared tonight that Germany could be knocked out of the war in two to three months if her protective force of fighting planes was annihilated and Allied air forces could roam over the country at will.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Creation of a special Senatorial investigating committee to recommend a national oil policy was urged today as the project for a 1,200-mile pipeline from the Persian Gulf to the Mediterranean, announced Saturday by Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Administrator for War, was brought into Senate debate.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Reorganization of the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway, under a plan approved yesterday by Federal Judge George H. Moore, would leave effective control with the Southern Pacific Railroad, which now owns 87 per cent of the Cotton Belt's common stock, it was stated today.

ABOARD U. S. NAVY HOSPITAL SHIP, Kwajalein, Marshall Islands, Feb. 8 (delayed) (AP) -- Navy nurses aboard this hospital ship were the first American women to have a close-up look at United States forces in offensive action against the Japanese in the Pacific.

TRENTON, Feb. 9 -- The State House Commission will take action tomorrow to put voting machines in the 658 election districts of Hudson County in accordance with a bill adopted by the Legislature last Monday and approved by Gov. Walter E. Edge today.

Columbia University's annual winter alumni reunion festivities on Saturday will be high lighted by the presentation of awards to members of the varsity and freshman crews and to the varsity football players. Meanwhile Blue and White athletes will compete in track and field, fencing, wrestling and basketball.

Bob Elliot writes from New Hampshire that it's high time something was done about the natural bait situation. Elliot is chiefly concerned with his own State, of course, but his remarks are equally applicable to other regions.

I KNOW a fellow, the son of a Mormon, who grew up in a farming region of old Mexico. The contrast between what his energetic father was able to get out of the land and what the Mexicans got out of it made him a violent free enterpriser for life. He now works in Detroit, and loves it. "Shiftlessness" did not appeal to him.

Emanuel Vardi, violist, and Roland Gundry, violinist, joint winners of the 1943 Town Hall Endowment Series Award, shared the Award recital last night at Town Hall. Mr. Vardi is 28, Mr. Gundry 21, and both have unquestionable talents even though last night's concert wasn't all it might have been.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 9 -- The trip home of Vilhelm Assarsson, Swedish Minister to Russia, "to report" is taken here in political circles as a sign that Moscow is bringing pressure on Sweden to further modify her policy regarding trade and other matters to conform more to Russian ways.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 9 -- The Argentine State Merchant Fleet issued a statement yesterday, which was published by some newspapers today, giving the position both at sea and in port of all its ships.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A communique:

The novelty of Saturday night baseball will be offered to patrons of the Polo Grounds next summer. This was revealed yesterday when Secretary Eddie Brannick of the Giants announced the fourteen nocturnal dates at home provided in the National League schedule recently ratified.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Feb. 10 -- Last night's Soviet communiques reported new Red Army gains in north and south Russia, including advances against Luga and Krivoi Rog, the mopping up of German groups in the Nikopol region and important progress against the encircled Eighth German Army.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Feb. 10 -- All enemy warships have withdrawn from the enemy base at Rabaul, New Britain, key to the Japanese Bismarck Archipelago defense system, apparently as a result of the day-to-day Allied bombing that reached a climax on Monday when the field was hammered with 129 more tons of bombs, it was disclosed today.

The Department of Markets served notice yesterday on chain food stores that hereafter Magistrates Court summonses for ceiling price violations would be served on the chain corporations instead of only on individual stores in the chains or on employes.

China will embark upon a concentrated drive for industrialization in the immediate post-war period, Dr. T.F. Tsiang, chief political secretary to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, forecast last night at a dinner, in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, of the China-America Council of Commerce and Industry, Inc., formed recently to further trade between the two nations.

SEATTLE, Feb. 9 -- Vice President Wallace charged tonight that American Fascists "at this very moment" were "desperately striving" to control delegates to county political conventions so that they might in turn control delegates to the State and national conventions of both the major parties.

The forty-second annual entertainment and ball of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club was given in a flag-bedecked setting last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The fete was attended by nearly 2,000 persons, including about 1,500 uniformed men and women of the armed forces.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Hammering relentlessly at German air power, many hundreds of Allied bomber and fighter planes today raked undisclosed targets around Pas-de-Calais and in other areas of northeastern France and blasted Tergnier, strategic railroad junction midway between St. Quentin and Soissons.

Two hundred and fifty women work today at Fort Hancock, N.J. -- Wacs, Army nurses and dietitians, civilian employes, volunteers from the Red Cross and the American Women's Voluntary Services. Day in, day out, they go about their jobs, as steady as the wind that sweeps across the post from Sandy Hook bay.

Two-symphonies, the "Fantastic" of Berlioz and Hindemith's "Marthis der Maler," formed the offerings presented by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, last night in Carnegie Hall. To devote an evening to works both belonging to the programmatic category might easily have lacked sufficient variety.

Diplomatic sources have it that Andrey Y. Vishinsky, Vice Commissar for Foreign Affairs who was recalled by Moscow from Algiers last week, will be entrusted with the enforcement of the constitutional reform approved by the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Cooperation, of club women in recruiting more women for industry and in providing community services for them is urged by the women's advisory committee of the War Manpower Commission in a pamphlet, "The Wartime Responsibility of Women's Organizations," issued today.

The stock market attained yesterday as neat a balance as yet seen in its current cycle, with price changes insignificant and volume enlarged only slightly because of a special offering. The heaviest trading centered in the rail section, and the remainder was scattered through an assortment of unrelated issues.

Mr. David Anderson, your London correspondent, in his dispatch Feb. 5, on stateless persons makes clear that influential circles in England feel that at the end of the war as many as possible of the Jewish refugees from Germany should return to their former country of residence.

Citizens who object to the centralizing of government have one preventive at hand, if they will use it. Let them attend to the problems of their home communities, and the drift toward centralization at Washington will diminish. Too often the voter is content to damn government in general and consider his civic duty done.

The English Book Society has taken Christine Weston's novel "Indigo" as its April choice. The book, a story of India, was published by Scribner's last autumn and was a selection of the Literary Guild here in November, 1943.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Free Yugoslav radio reported today that Partisans meeting recently at Cernomelj had approved unanimously a resolution "forbidding" King Peter II to return to Yugoslavia.

Isn't education wonderful? For some time now the War Labor Board has been at odds with the Mechanics Educational Society of America. At the moment of writing there are charges and countercharges, threats and counter-threats.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The Netherlands, Norwegian and Belgian Governments have been advised by Great Britain and the United States that control of civil affairs in their countries will be handed back to them at the earliest possible moment after the liberation of their territories, it was learned from a reliable source tonight.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose sharply last month, advancing from 737,042 shares at the end of December to 847,335 shares on Jan. 31. Neither figure included the short interest in odd-lot dealers' accounts, which was 38,139 shares on Jan. 31, against 33,027 shares on Dec. 31.

The War Production Board has called a meeting of the men's and boys' clothing industry advisory, committee to be held in Washington on March 1 at which advisability of lifting or modifying style curbs will be discussed. The limitation order, L-224, has been the subject of considerable industry comment since the opening of spring lines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee concentrated today on obtaining an accurate definition of Judaism, with some witnesses contending that it is a religion, and as such the only cohesive factor among Jews, and others maintaining that it is traditionally, and in the acceptance of a majority, both a religion and a nationality.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Members of Congress and spokesmen for the lumber and pulp industry urged a House Military subcommittee today to expedite action on legislation to grant blanket draft deferment to men engaged in timber and pulpwood and related occupations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The United States must use every human resource it has to wipe out Japanese militarism, because even the demolition of Tokyo itself would not necessarily end the Japanese menace to free nations, said Joseph C. Grew, former Ambassador to Japan, in a statement today before the Senate Military Affairs Committee, supporting adoption of a national war-service law.

A team that has shown an unmerciful tendency to maul and batter the Rangers without stint will skate against the blue-jerseyed stick wielders at Madison Square Garden tonight. The visiting sextet is the Red Wing troupe, holder of the Stanley Cup and at present in possession of the second best record in the loop.
Detectives working on the West Side Iron Works hold-up at 801 Greenwich Street, in which gunmen got away with $13,669 last Friday, stumbled onto two caches of illicit ration stamps yesterday.

Henry M. Brundage, Market Commissioner, admitted yesterday at a hearing before Thomas J. Patterson, Budget Director, that black market practices existed at the Queens Terminal Market, where live poultry shipments are handled.

A strike that had halted production during most of the day at the two Brooklyn plants of the Marine Division of the Bendix Aviation Corporation was ended last night when union employes were ordered back to work by officials of Local 853 of the United Automobile Workers.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Replying to a barrage of questions in the House of Commons today from members who wanted to know all about the proposed construction of a United States pipeline from the Persian Gulf to the Mediterranean, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said the project was only in an early stage and that he was awaiting a report from the British Ambassador to Washington before making a detailed statement.

Terming the recent reduction in prices of scrap brass and copper by the Office of Price Administration "prejudicial" to the trade, Elias Bernstein, president of the Empire Metal Merchants Association, yesterday protested the "lack of consideration" given by the agency to the industry's viewpoints and problems.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Preliminary estimates of the Department of Labor disclosed today, showed that there were 3,750 strikes in 1943, as compared with 2,968 in 1942.

Planes from our China force have just sunk six more Japanese merchantmen in the Yellow Sea. Rabaul and Kavieng are graveyards of Japanese freighters. And the latest report of our submarines, listing fourteen more victims, brings the toll of Japan's lost tonnage to well over a thousand ships.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

ABOARD A SEVENTH ARMY AIR FORCE LIBERATOR, Over Maloelap Atoll, Marshall Islands, Feb. 4 (Delayed) -- Two weeks ago Maloelap was a Japanese stronghold alive with anti-aircraft fire and protected by swarms of vicious fighters. Tonight the defenders have been able to send up only weak fire and no planes against attacking planes.

William Bradford of 355 West Twenty-ninth Street, an attendant at Roosevelt Hospital, was watching a keeper feed the polar bears at the Central Park Zoo on Aug. 3, 1943. It was good, clean entertainment until a keeper, trying to pitch a five-pound chunk of meat into the enclosure, lost control of his high, fast curve.

Dimitri Shostakovich and Sergei, Prokofieff, Soviet Russia's most famous living composers, will broadcast to this country for the first time, on a special program Saturday afternoon. The broadcast, which will be heard over the the National Broadcastnig Company network from 2 P.M. to 3 P.M., Eastern war time, calls for composers to join forces in a performance of Shostakovich's Piano Concerto. He will conduct and Prokofieff will be piano soloist.

Eagle's Nest, the country estate of the late William K. Vanderbilt Jr. in Centerport, L.I., containing his celebrated marine museum, has been examined by the Long Island State Park Commission and found not suitable for State Park purposes, it was disclosed yesterday.

GRAND ISLAND, Neb., Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Democratic State Central Committee voted today to enter President Roosevelt's name in the Nebraska Presidential preference primary and also adopted a resolution demanding removal of Secretary Wickard and of Governor A.G. Black of the Farm Credit Administration.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Highway advertising signs, proclaiming the advantages of this or that medicament or the comforts of this or that hotel or the superiority of this or that newspaper over any other, etc., will be prohibited in this country if proposals under consideration by government officials are approved.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A German who deserted the Nazis and gave himself up to the British several days ago was officially identified by Allied spokesmen today as Erich Vermehren, clerk of the military attache in the German Embassy here and a son of the German authoress, Petra Vermehren.

WITH THE SEVENTH DIVISION, at Kwajalein, Feb. 4 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The ship's news brought the story of Japan's treatment of the men of Bataan to American invasion forces while they were on their way to the Marshalls.

William T. Dewart, president and principal owner of The New York Sun, who died at his home, 660 Park Avenue, on Jan. 27, left his entire estate to his family, it was disclosed yesterday, when his will was filed in Surrogate's Court.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 -- A blanket embargo was laid today by the American Association of Railroads on thirteen large commission merchants, barring them from receiving further produce until the clogging of railroad sidings has been relieved.

Plattsburg Barracks at Plattsburg, N.Y., an Army post since 1812, will be taken over by the Navy on Feb. 20 for use as a naval training and officer indoctrination school, a joint Army and Navy announcement disclosed yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 9 -- Frenchmen believe that the Germans expect another Allied beachhead north of Rome, one in the vicinity of Genoa and yet another in southern France, coinciding with a landing in the west.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A German who deserted the Nazis and gave himself up to the British several days ago was officially identified by Allied spokesmen today as Erich Vermehren, clerk of the military attache in the German Embassy here and a son of the German authoress, Petra Vermehren.

WITH THE SEVENTH DIVISION, at Kwajalein, Feb. 4 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The ship's news brought the story of Japan's treatment of the men of Bataan to American invasion forces while they were on their way to the Marshalls.

William T. Dewart, president and principal owner of The New York Sun, who died at his home, 660 Park Avenue, on Jan. 27, left his entire estate to his family, it was disclosed yesterday, when his will was filed in Surrogate's Court.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, Feb. 10 -- The State Department announced early today that the United States and Iran had agreed to elevate the status of their legations from that of legation to embassy.

Cartons of red and blue "tiddly-winks" -- the new ration currency that will go into use Feb. 27 -- were carried yesterday into many of the metropolitan area's 1,600 banks, which will start distributing them next week.

I wonder whether our men fighting like Trojans around the little town of Ardea, not far from Rome, realize that here was fought the famous decisive battle between the Trojans and Latins, as described so vividly by Virgil in the twelfth book of the Aeneid.

Col. Bernard Lentz, commanding officer of Fort Slocum, N.Y., spoke yesterday to members of the Metropolitan Opera Guild from Westchester Connecticut and New Jersey at a Gold Card Rally for the Opera Fund at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue.

Unless 8,000 additional nurses enlist in the Army Nurses Corps this year wounded soldiers overseas may not have the best possible care, Major Kathleen H. Atto, head of the corps for the Second Service Command, said yesterday. She spoke at the first anniversary celebration of the Nurse Recruitment Center of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross at 139 East Thirty-sixth Street.

As he was walking up the rear steps of his home early yesterday morning, Joseph Stabile, 43 years old, of 24 Bay Thirty-first Street, Brooklyn, was killed by the double blast of a 16-gauge double-barrel shotgun, twelve slugs having entered his neck and back.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts announced yesterday that it will open sealed tenders tomorrow on a new issue of $2,000,000 of notes. The issue will be dated Feb. 29, 1944, and will be payable on Feb. 27, 1945.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 9 -- That Finland will choose to fight rather than surrender unconditionally was the prevalent opinion in Helsinki political circles today. This impression was heightened when it became known that Foreign Minister Henrik Ramsay visited the German Legation to ascertain Berlin's attitude toward an eventual Finnish exit from the war and was rebuffed with a threat that Germany would oppose any "false move" on Finland's part toward a separate peace.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Buying of wheat futures attributed to millers and cash interests as well as professional traders, including shorts, lifted prices 1 1/4 cents a bushel at one time today on the Board of Trade. Profit-taking shaded the upturn, but the close was at net gains of 3/8 to 5/8 cent. Kansas City was up 1/2 to 5/8 cent and Minneapolis gained 3/8 to 1/2 cent.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 9 (AP) -- An argument that New Jersey's Fair Trade Act is rendered useless when prices established thereunder conflict with ceiling prices of the Office of Price Administration was advanced today before the State Court of Errors and Appeals.

Resistance to Nazi occupation tnl France could be strengthened if J machine gtms and small arms wereI dropped by 'parachute behind Ger-J man lines for latriot grbups, lr0f. I Francis Perrln declared yesterclayI at a luncheon of the French-Amer-j ican Club fin' the' Hotel WaldorfI Astoria.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- The revised American Standard Version of the New Testament, the first standard Protestant revision undertaken since the Eighteen Seventies, is now complete and in the hands of the final editors, and will be delivered to publishers this fall.

The proficiency with which our forces are overpowering the Marshall Islands is proof that we have accumulated tremendous naval strength and are also becoming increasingly expert in the tactics of amphibious warfare. By this time it must be clear to the enemy, too, that it is only a matter of time before the smaller islands of the Pacific, perhaps including even Guam and Truk, must fall to the Americans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (U.P.) -- More than half of those who cast ballots in November will be women, and they will vote for the candidate they think will work for an enduring peace, Mrs. Charles W. Tillett, assistant chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today.

Rayon stockings are getting finer in texture. This was evidenced yesterday at the exhibition held by the Gotham Hosiery Company in the Perroquet Suite of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. With one exception, the hosiery displayed was of 75 dernier yarn.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 10 -- Colombia's Conservatives, who are opposed to the Government and who had threatened to promote a civil war, were warned today that authorities were prepared to place the country under martial law. The Government declared that, in view of the present state of international belligerency, the provocation of civil strife would be regarded as treason.

Despite wartime scarcities of rayon and cotton yarns as well as complete absence last year of silk and nylon, total mill shipments of all types of hosiery in 1943 amounted to 152,904,621 dozen pairs, a gain of 2.8 per cent over 1942, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers reported yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Winston Churchill, who is admired in this island more as Prime Minister, orator, writer and historian than as a politician, intervened in the Western Derbyshire by-election tonight in an effort to block rising opposition to his coalition.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Charles E. Johnston, chairman of the Western Association of Railway Executives, asserted today that allegations of the Department of Justice that Western railroad agreements retarded technological development were "wholly unfounded." His statement read in part:

AT THE ANZIO BEACHHEAD, Feb. 10 -- The German drive that started against one sector of this beachhead last Monday night appeared today to have been slowed down as American resistance tightened and held.

ALGIERS, Feb. 10 -- The German offensive against the Allied beachhead below Rome grew in intensity Wednesday when the enemy made virtually continuous counter-attacks that tended to pin down our coastal flanks. Sixty miles due east on the main transpeninsular front the Wehrmacht clung desperately to Cassino despite the slowly tightening Allied grip.
TRENTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Gov. Walter E. Edge appointed Essex County Prosecutor William A. Wachenfeld today as the State's unsalaried defense director, succeeding Leonard Dreyfuss of Essex Fells.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Main responsibility for meeting production and delivery schedules in the munitions program was turned over to industry today by the War Production Board through a revision of its general scheduling order M-293.

Three Russian scores, strongly contrasted, made the program of the concert given by Arthur Rodzinski and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. As it happens, the latest score composed proved to be the most conservative in substance and style. It was the Sinfonietta No. 2, for String Orchestra, of Nicolas Miascovsky, played for the first time at these concerts.

Both the House and the Senate have indicated their determined opposition to the $1,500,000,000 subsidy program proposed by the Administration. This opposition has solid grounds. It would be unfortunate, however, if it were extended to less ambitious subsidy programs. Subsidies have a useful, though limited role, to perform in the inflation battle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The dislocations of World War II in the United States affect civil as well as military. groups, and the politicians whose business it is to bring to the polls all who can vote are not forgetting the former. These blocs of away-from-home citizens are the migratory war workers who, in some areas, have doubled the local populations.

The one-story garage on a plot 80 by 100 feet at 1414-18 Willow Avenue, Hoboken, N.J., has been sold by the Emrau Realty Corporation (Joseph Haas Jr., president) to the Henmayer Realty Corporation. The property is assessed for $31,800.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A U.S. EIGHTH AIR FORCE HEAVY BOMBER STATION, in England, Feb. 10--American heavy bombers struck deep into Germany again today in the eleventh massive attack in the past fourteen days. Rolling across the English Channel at midday, they fought their way to Brunswick, an important industrial city of central Germany, rained high explosives and incendiaries and then fought their way back from the smoking ruins.

Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, announced yesterday the resignation of Mitchell Jelline, for nearly two years chief enforcement attorney of the New York district, but declined to comment on rumors that four other key men also had tendered their resignations.

Market value of all stocks dealt in on the New York Curb Exchange rose $2,046,442,206 to $9,892,394,376 last year, according to a compilation just issued by that institution. At the year-end there were 935 stock issues, against 975 at the close of 1942, and the average price was $15.41, against $12.50.
SEATTLE, Feb. 10 -- Wendell L. Willkie said today that, on invitation of Governor Warren of California, he and Mrs. Willkie would have luncheon with the Governor Sunday at Sacramento.

Season baseball passes in the National and American Leagues will be auctioned off at the Waldorf-Astoria Sunday night at the Stars for Victory Show to be presented by the Fourth War Loan Sports Committee in conjunction with the United Theatrical War Activities Committee.

War material subcontractors who have been affected by contract terminations or cutbacks are displaying increasing willingness to have the remaining parts of their contracts absorbed by prime contractors, manufacturers reported yesterday.

The spell wielded by the Detroit Red Wings over the New York Rangers manifested itself once more last night. Trailing by a goal early in the game, the fast-skating Wings quickly erased this margin and moved along easily to an 8-to-3 triumph at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio made his Washington debut as a Presidential aspirant tonight with a call for the restoration of "a responsible Cabinet Government in Washington."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Attorney General Biddle today ordered an investigation of charges that prisoners at the medical center of the Federal Bureau of Prisons at Springfield, Mo., have been treated brutally by guards and other institutional personnel.

The appointment of Monroe Goldwater, attorney, as head of the 1944 War Emergency Campaign of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, was announced at a dinner last night for the founders of the organization in the Hotel New Yorker.

The Dodgers announced yesterday the acquisition of two players who speak rather eloquently for the pressure clubs are laboring under at the moment to make certain they will have sufficient playing strength next summer.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 10--The late Samuel Untermyer's eighty-seven-acre estate, Greystone, in Yonkers, that neither New York State, Westchester County nor Yonkers wanted as a gift because of the tax exemption and maintenance costs that its use as a public park would entail, is now entitled to tax exemption under its new private philanthropic set-up as the "Samuel Untermyer Park and Gardens," Supreme Court Referee J. Addison Young ruled here Today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The violent German counter-attacks on the beachhead below Rome are a threat not to be minimized, but with the improvement of the weather our air forces have punished Nazi planes off the beachhead, attacked communications north and south of Rome and also Nazi concentrations in the neighborhood, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, said today in outlining the progress of the Italian campaign.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Strand Warners' "In Our Time," a topical drama set in Poland, will have its local premiere. Ida Lupino and Paul Henreid are starred in the picture, which was directed by Vincent Sherman.

Mrs. Edna Hancock, a former employe of Brooklyn State Hospital who was responsible for the conviction of Murray Goldman on a charge of attempted rape, was locked up last night in the Manhattan Women's House of Detention as a material witness when she was unable to raise a bail bond of $10,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Senate agreed unanimously today, after a compromise was reached on the floor, to be represented in the conferences for adjustment of differences with the House over service men's voting legislation by a committee of five members.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10 -- Gramps Image, Flamingo Stakes hope of the Abel family, hammered out a nose victory in the mile and a furlong Beach Comber Purse at Hialeah Park today. Returning $16.80 for $2, the son of War Hero and grandson of Man o' War defeated the heavily played favorite, Spook Ship, in a hard drive down the stretch.
Last September Charles Wissman, wholesaler of meat delicacies to hotels and clubs, decided that his business could get along without his presence.

Breaking all previous records, sales of the United States Rubber Company last year rose 45 per cent above the 1942 volume and earnings climbed to a new high despite taxes that more than doubled those of the previous year, according to the fifty-second annual report of F.B. Davis Jr., chairman, issued to stockholders today.

While the mighty naval arm of the giant Allied pincers offensive in the Pacific has stretched out for another 600 miles to smash the Japanese on the Marshall Islands, the other arm, consisting of General MacArthur's forces to the southwest, is achieving equally important if perhaps less spectacular results.

In a session dominated by the railroad issues, which saw shares of the carriers at the best levels in six months, the stock market broke free of its uncertainty yesterday with a sharp increase in business. Values among the rails were raised 1 to 2 points, with the top reached in the afternoon, when the demand proved heaviest.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 -- Charles Chaplin, the screen comedian, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury for violation of the Mann Act and on criminal conspiracy charges in a series of true bills which also accused six other persons of various offenses.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- A drive to enact legislation at the current session which would greatly relax the mortgage moratorium that has been in effect for ten years is under way, with substantial prospects of success.

The men's and boys' clothing style limitation order, L-224, should be revoked just as soon as "it is possible to safely determine that the supply of woolen cloth is in process of being increased," according to Jerome I. Udell of Max Udell Sons Co., in a market letter issued yesterday.

With the exception of oranges and grapefruit, which are arriving in approximately the same quantities as last year, virtually all fruits coming to Manhattan show a marked decrease from 1943. Apples are particularly light, having totaled only 484 carloads last month in contrast to 740 for the previous January.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP.) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities to have decreased $611,538,000 during the week, while reserve note circulation increased $45,169,000.

MOSCOW, Friday, Feb. 11--Pressing the tempo of the attack on the German Eighth Army trapped in the Dnieper River bend, Gen. Ivan S. Koneff's forces yesterday nibbled off the tapering tail of the encircled area in an advance from Gorodishche to within six miles of Korsun and by capturing Mleyev, five miles northeast of Gorodishche.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Introduction into the Senate subsidy fight of a proposal for a food stamp plan deferred a vote on the issue but a decision is looked for tomorrow and both sides expect it to end in an Administration defeat.

The F.W. Woolworth Company, in its annual report for 1943, which includes Canadian subsidiaries, disclosed yesterday that sales established a new high record for the fifth successive year. The total of $439,009,003 in 2,008 stores operated in the United States, Canada and Cuba represented an increase of $15,788,404 over the $423,220,598 sales from 2,015 stores in 1942.

Quincy, Mass., announced yesterday that it will be in the market on Tuesday with a new issue of $900,000 of temporary loan notes. The issue will be dated Feb. 16, and will mature variously on Nov. 6, Nov. 17 and Nov. 27.

Accountants and other experts of the New York and Washington offices of the Office of Price Administration are making a survey of the costs of operating apartment buildings and other residential structures here, it was learned yesterday.

John P. Marquand's "So Little Time" leads the list of ten novels chosen by the critics in the Book of the Month Club's poll of the outstanding books of 1943, it was announced yesterday. Wendell L. Willkie's "One World" is the leader on the non-fiction list.

Involved in the program for the development of the vast oil resources of the Middle East is a contemplated agreement among the United States, British and Russian Governments with respect to the sale and distribution of petroleum products in the world markets in the post-war period.

A protest against the hearings on the sale of Station WMCA, which are being held in Washington by the Select Committee to Investigate the Federal Communications Committee, has been made to the committee chairman by Franklin S. Wood, counsel for Edward J. Noble.

A baby giant tortoise weighing only-six-and-three-quarter ounces, but which in 150 years or so may reach 500 pounds, was put on exhibition today at the Bronx Zoo. It is the smallest of the giant Galapagos species ever exhibited by the Zoo.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Belgium and the Netherlands, which were politically parted by revolution in 1831, have decided to set an example for post-war Europe by uniting economically in a customs union that is expected to be announced in April. Included will be the Duchy of Luxembourg, but not the Netherland or Belgian colonies.

Mrs. Marie Fox of 316 Jerome Street, Brooklyn, testified yesterday against four officials and attaches of the defunct Madison Personal Loan Corporation who are accused of mulcting small sums from borrowers by compelling them to take out auto insurance from a subsidiary.

Last year only one industrial share and four railway issues from THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks appeared as well in the list of the twenty most active issues. Last year United States Steel, which once did 60 per cent of all the business on the Stock Exchange, did two-thirds of 1 per cent of the business, a decline in relative importance of 89 per cent.

Bobby Jones' grand slam of 1930, in which year he carried off the four blue ribbons of the golfing world, the American and British amateur and open championships, has been voted the greatest American sports achievement of all time in a poll of sports editors.

Three-quarters of the General Foods Corporation's stockholders who replied to a recent questionnaire urged the company to continue its wartime dividend rate of 40 cents a share, which was cut from 50 cents in May, 1942, and four out of five urged that investments in research be heavy.
The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, department store holding company, reported yesterday un-audited sales of subsidiary companies for the quarter and twelve months ended on Jan. 31, as follows:

ABOARD AN LCI AT KWAJALEIN, Feb. 4 (Delayed) -- Navy men on a big, sleek warship refer to an LCI (landing craft, infantry) as a "barge with a house on it." These ugly ducklings of the Navy are seldom noticed except to be cussed or good naturedly derided, and they do a ticklish job under fire with scant credit.

A Hindu seaman from Cape Providence, South Africa, who said his name was David O'Brien, was released yesterday in the Bowery Court by Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney. The seaman had come into the hands of the police last week by "confessing" to a murder in Glasgow, Scotland, three years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Roosevelt asked the Senate today to approve promotions for Vice Admiral Raymond A. Spruance, commander of the Central Pacific Fleet, which took part in the attack on the Marshall Islands, and Rear Admiral Richmond K. Turner, who commanded the amphibious forces which landed on Roi and Kwajalein.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Vice Admiral John H. Towers, former chief of the Navy's Bureau of Aeronautics, now commander of Air Forces of the Pacific Fleet, is expected to be appointed Deputy Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet shortly.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 10 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:
The mysterious jumping dog of Riverside Drive was claimed yesterday at the office of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, Avenue A and Twenty-fourth Street.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 10 -- Army and Navy warplanes have struck widely scattered enemy bases in the central Pacific for three straight days, continuing the unrelenting air pressure designed to keep airdromes and staging stations useless to the Japanese forces.

The United States Rubber Company is undertaking one of "the most ambitious advertising campaigns" in several years, according to C.J. Durban, advertising and sales promotion manager. Asserting that the company "must build its name in the public mind soundly against the time that competition will hit us," Mr. Durban disclosed that a three-pronged newspaper and magazine campaign is proposed in addition to its current radio programs.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, Feb. 11 -- Australian and American jungle fighters have joined forces near Saidor in northern New Guinea after a strenuous eighteen-week campaign that wiped out the major part of a Japa nese force of 14,000 men and won complete control of the entire Huon Peninsula, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Revenues of radio broadcasting companies were higher and their net incomes were lower in 1942 than in 1941, according to the ninth annual report of the Federal Communications Commission, made public today.

The young wife of a sailor captured a 17-year-old burglar in her apartment Wednesday afternoon and probably saved his life when she hung onto the seat of his trousers when he attempted to climb out of a bedroom window three stories from the ground.

The Board of Estimate approved unanimously yesterday at a special meeting in the office of Mayor La Guardia at City Hall a preliminary appropriation of $50,000 for a Youth Center at Lavanburg Corner House, 331 East Twelfth Street, to which the Domestic Relations Court is to remand delinquent boys under 16 years old pending final disposition of their cases.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index number of commodity prices in primary markets remained steady during the first week of February at 103.1 per cent of the 1926 average. Average prices for farm products and foods dropped about one-half of 1 per cent as a result of weakening markets for steers, hay, potatoes and seasonally lower prices for eggs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The railroads are handicapped in the performance of their war task by out-of-date equipment, facilities and operating technique, which could have been modernized if the carriers had not prevented it by monopolistic practices and collusion, Wendell Berge, assistant attorney general, charged today.
Walter A. Davis has been appointed vice president and general manager of the Metropolitan Motor Corporation, DeSoto and Plymouth dealers.

Millions of us on the home front are stirred this week by news of the self-sacrifice of our fighting men at Cassino and Kwajalein and the courage of our nurses and surgeons under fire in the war hospitals. Here in the humdrum civilian round we wish that we, too, might be heroic. But we need not stop with wishing.

Toru Matsumoto, a Japanese Christian who came to the United States in 1935, was ordained last night into the ministry of the Reformed Church in America in the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

Official of the India Famine Relief Committee, Inc., will cooperate with the American Friends Service Committee to send immediate shipments of foods and medical supplies to the famine-stricken Bengal region in hope of rehabilitating "millions of persons" in that area, Richard J. Walsh, president, announced yesterday at headquarters, 40 East Forty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A wage increase beyond the "Little Steel" formula, awarded by a majority of labor and industry members, was attacked today by the public members of the War Labor Board as an "improper application" of the national wage stabilization policy.

Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, a leader of the Reformed Church in America, gave his sanction yesterday to Allied bombing of German cities, declaring "there is such a thing in this world as retributive justice," The Associated Press reported.

A "flying squad" of picked inspectors has been organized in the Department of Markets to mop up parts of the city where black market dealings in food seem to be increasing, Markets Commissioner Henry M. Brundage disclosed yesterday in announcing that the squad had visited West Harlem on Wednesday.

Substantial price reductions for middlemen's sales of bulk fluid milk, designed to retain present consumer milk ceiling prices, were fixed in an order signed yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, Administrator of the Regional Office of Price Administration, to become effective Feb. 16.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) -- In a rousing third period punctuated by fisticuffs among opposing players and attacks on spectators by two Boston skaters, the Bruins scored the deciding goal tonight in the last minute to whip the Black Hawks, 5 to 4, and break the tie with Chicago for fourth place in the National Hockey League.

Dr. Shih-Chieh Wang, head of a Chinese good-will mission to Great Britain and former Chinese Minister of Education and Information, arriving here yesterday aboard a Pan American clipper at La Guardia Field, emphasized that Burma is the key to a United Nations Pacific offensive.

Members of the National Education Association's investigating panel, whose report on local school issues accused Mayor La Guardia of illegally interfering with the Board of Education and the New York City school system, disclosed yesterday that officials in their communities whom they had queried had not heard from the Mayor in respect to their professional record or standing.

With the coming of spring New Yorkers will have to exercise Spartan frugality at the dinner table in the matter of meat and butter, it was predicted yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, Federal food supply experts and local meat distributors.

Given "able leadership and a reasonable amount of teamwork," the nation can meet the challenge that it will face after the war in business and foreign trade, Joseph C. Rovensky, vice president of the Chase National Bank, told delegates to the twenty-fifth annual Midwinter Trust Conference of the American Bankers Association at the last session of the three-day meeting yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Magistrate Harry G. Andrews dismissed yesterday in Special Sessions the charge that Aaron (Arky) Schwartz, 43 years old, a former midtown night-club Owner, operated the chemin de fer game in a suite in the Hotel New Yorker last Sept. 18 in which Jack Topping, 22 years old, charged he lost $12,500.

Civilian prisoners of the Japanese interned at Weihsien did not fare badly at the hands of their captors, Dr. Alice M. Boring told members of the New York branch of the American Association of University Women yesterday. Along with others of the faculty of Yenching University, Peiping, she was detained for five months in a missionary compound in the Province of Shantung until repatriated on the Gripsholm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- "Even though oil shipments to the East are nearly 300,000 barrels daily above those of a year ago," the East coast is now facing a crucial gasoline and fuel oil test, Secretary Ickes, who is Petroleum Administrator, said today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 10 -- Surprising even the most ardent supporters of the post-war Arab collaboration program, Mustapha Nahas Pasha, Egypt's Prime Minister, this afternoon indicated that his talks with representatives of the Yemen had proved highly satisfactory, suggesting that the Yemenite delegates were closely in accord with his views.
LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday, issued today, reports a gain of 2,552,000 in note circulation.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Inside the room a warm coal fire was burning and half a dozen well-upholstered chairs, deep and cozy, were grouped around the hearth. The atmosphere was comfortable, secure, almost homelike. Sitting in the room or standing around drinking beer were perhaps a dozen men, mostly young -- all of them Dutch, who had escaped from the Gestapo, some of them many times.

PERHAPS nothing has focused as much attention on the wartime turnover of athletes as a pair of events which were staged in Madison Square Garden within the past week -- the Millrose track meet and the basketball double-header a few days later. The Navy and the Marines have jumbled the sports picture almost beyond recognition.

KWAJALEIN, Marshall Islands, Feb. 2 (Delayed) -- Roi and Kwajalein Islands, the principal objectives in our invasion of the Marshall Islands, have been given an unbelievably swift house cleaning by Army and Marine engineers and naval construction battalions in the few days since the fighting ended.

Two years ago the Boston Comic Opera Company did its best to relieve Broadway's insatiable thirst for those ageless Gilbert and Sullivan offerings. Tonight the same group, now called the Gilbert Sullivan Opera Company (J.J. Shubert's pet project, of which R.H. Burnside is managing director) is coming off the road to the Ambassador, with "The Mikado" as the first bill.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 -- A 95 per cent cut in the production time of making a typical fighter plane was reported today by the West Coast Aircraft War Production Council, Inc. A tremendous reduction was reported for a four-engine bomber also. Neither plane was identified.

Dog lovers from everywhere will gather in Madison Square Garden today and tomorrow for the sixty-eighth annual all-breed show of the Westminster Kennel Club during which 2,510 canines of high degree will be on exhibition in the basement and contesting for cash and trophies in the judging rings in the big arena above.

The first money-raising campaign of the National War Fund, started last fall throughout the country in behalf of seventeen relief agencies, can be considered a complete success, Prescott S. Bush, national chairman of the drive, reported yesterday to a meeting of the fund's board of directors in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

ALGIERS, Feb. 10 -- By a decision of the Allied Advisory Council for Italy at a meeting Dec. 17, all Italian territory south of the northern borders of the Provinces of Salerno, Potenza and Bari, as well as Sicily and Sardinia, will revert tomorrow to control of the Badoglio Government of Italy, Gen. Sir Henry Maitland Wilson, Commander in Chief in the Mediterranean, announced tonight.

A classy wire-haired foxterrier puppy of nine months captured highest honors at the seventy-third specialty show of the American Foxterrier club yesterday in the roof garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Two men, one of them a first-class private in the Army and the other an ex-convict, were arrested by detectives last night as accomplices of Mrs. Gertrude McIntyre, 24 years old, a department store salesgirl of 59-40 Queens Boulevard, Queens, in the decoy hold-up of John J. Young, a manufacturer, of 69 Etna Street, Brooklyn.
When the American officers and men who had been captured on Corregidor began arriving at O'Donnell prison camp in Tarlec Province we learned the truth of what had happened on The Rock.

LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Moscow radio warned tonight that Budapest, Hungary, was next on the Russians' bombing list and asserted that it would "share the fate of Helsinki," Finland, if Hungary continued to fight.

" College Instructor," writing in your columns recently, calls attention to the plight of the group of city employes of which he is a member. His statement, presenting the case of the average college teacher, is substantially correct. Moreover, conditions are deteriorating because of the failure, so far, of the city administration to meet the acute, wartime problem facing all fixed-income recipients.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Department-store sales for the week ended Feb. 5 were 2 per cent above sales in the like week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Giving unqualified approval to proposals of the special Senate Post-War Committee as reported by Senator Walter F. George on Wednesday, Ernest R. Breech, president of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, described the study as a fine presentation of industry's needs for successful reconversion.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Sunday's production of anthracite coal exceeded expectations with a total of 130,000 tons, a result to which 84 per cent of the mines and 64 per cent of the miners contributed.

In recent months many utterances of the Vice President have been disturbing to those who recognize the supreme importance in wartime of preserving the greatest possible measure of national unity. That unity can be preserved only by temperate discussion of our own differences. It can only be endangered by reckless charges and abusive language. And in this last respect the Vice President has recently set a deplorable example.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- Placement of disabled veterans of the present conflict is one of the most serious manpower problems now confronting the nation, members of the American Management Association were informed here today by representatives of the War Manpower Commission and the Veterans Administration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, took Vice President Wallace to task today for talking of fascist tendencies in the United States, in his speech last night at Seattle.
In a statement issued here yesterday, David A. Crawford, president of the Pullman Company, replied to the charges made by Assistant Attorney General Berge in Washington.

WITH AMERICAN INFANTRY, Anzio Beachhead, Feb. 10 -- Three Americans of a seven-man patrol returned safe and sound after killing twenty-five Germans behind the enemy lines in the bloodiest American patrol action since the beachhead landings.
I wish to heartily endorse Dr. Paul Nettl's letter of Feb. 2. More and more, Government authorities and music educators should be thinking along these lines.

The E.B. Morris signed to "Take It as It Comes" is the nom de plume for someone working downtown who wished his right hand not to be credited, or debited, with what the left had done. As his play went on last evening at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, he seemed to have a point there.

An organized campaign to eliminate publicly owned and operated housing from the post-war picture and to substitute therefor vast subsidies to private enterprise is disclosed in the recent statement to the Lanham Committee of Congress by Frank W. Cortright, Executive Vice President of the National Association of Home Builders of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Senator Wagner of New York introduced today an amendment to the American Legion omnibus bill as a substitute for Title V of that measure, referring to veterans' employment in the post-war period.

J. Edward Lynch, vice president of the National Bank of Far Rockaway since 1938, has been elected president and a member of the board of directors to succeed the late John R. Burton, it was announced yesterday by the directors at the bank's offices in Far Rockaway, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Roosevelt nominated Joseph D. Nunan Jr., today, to be Commissioner of Internal Revenue to succeed Robert E. Hannegan, who resigned to become chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

RENO, Nev., Feb. 10 -- Joan Mary Leseuer received a divorce today from Lawrence Leseuer, CBS commentator in London, on the grounds of cruelty. They were married in New York City June 15, 1943. Mr. Leseuer did not answer the complaint although served in person in London.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 10 (AP) -- British troops supported by tanks still clung tonight to the vital Ngakyedauk Pass through which the Japanese have been attempting to crash to cut communications of the British operation in Arakan on the northern end of the Bay of Bengal.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 -- Columbia has bought an original story, "What's Wrong With Love" by Laslo Gorog and William Thiele, as a starring vehicle for Rosalind Russell. The actress is expected to return to Columbia for the comedy, dealing with the romantic adventures of a woman psychiatrist, after the completion of "Elizabeth Kenny" at RKO.

Two of the justices of the United States Supreme Court have broken out in rather caustic criticism of their associates on the bench for refusing in some cases to follow precedent. They claim that such practice is unfair to judges of lower courts, to lawyers and to litigants and that, as one of the justices said, "the law becomes not a chart to govern conduct but a game of chance."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Passage of a national service act would encourage our Allies, frighten our enemies and shorten the war by preventing excessive labor turnover, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, told the Senate Military Affairs Committee today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Bishop Paul Yu Pin, Roman Catholic primate of China, was received to day by President Roosevelt in what was said to be the first call by a Chinese Bishop of any denomination on an American President. He was introduced by Liu Chieh, Chinese Minister, who acted in the absence of the Ambassador.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 10 -- An increase in Westchester County real estate transactions was indicated today by the annual report of County Clerk Robert J. Field, which covers operations of the Division of Land Records and shows that last year 12,524 deeds were recorded, an increase of 1,433 over the 1942 total.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 10 -- Through nation-wide publication of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's warning note, the Finns now know the seriousness of their country's situation for the first time since they got into the war against the Russians in 1941.

After establishing the highest prices since last July, cotton futures prices yesterday lost a part of their early gains in a late wave of profit-taking and hedge selling. Trade and mill covering, however, absorbed the offerings rather easily and final quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 1 to 9 points, with the largest gains in the new crop months.

TRENTON, Feb. 10 -- Former Governor Charles Edison, who was the mainspring in the movement to give New Jersey a modern Constitution, views the tentative draft with a mixture of favor and disfavor in his first appraisal of the document.

Skiing enthusiasts will find enjoyable sport awaiting them in the North Country this holiday weekend. While snow continues to bypass the metropolitan area, the word is good in the Berkshires, Adirondacks, Green and White Mountains and the Laurentians of northeastern Canada.

George W. Healy, director of domestic operations of the Office of War Information, last night called on the nation's advertisers and their agencies for more intensive campaigns on war themes to combat complacency on the home front and promised that his agency will provide all possible aid so far as information is concerned.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 10 -- Leaders of Greek guerrilla bands that have hitherto fought against each other have issued orders to cease firing, it was learned here tonight. As far as is known here, the order is being obeyed, which means that the civil strife that has torn the country since last October is at an end.

Three tons of magazines and pamphlets alleged to contain lewd and indecent pictures and text were seized yesterday by detectives of Deputy Chief Inspector Michael Murphy's squad in raids on two bookstores and a printing concern in the midtown section.

The old superstition about "too many cooks" was squelched yesterday afternoon when a dozen 'teen-age girls of the Children's Aid Society served in five minutes four meals, guaranteed for their economy, nutritive value and taste.
LONDON, Feb. 10 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, Feb. 11 (UP) -- A communique:

Three tons of magazines and pamphlets alleged to contain lewd and indecent pictures and text were seized yesterday by detectives of Deputy Chief Inspector Michael Murphy's squad in raids on two bookstores and a printing concern in the midtown section.

May I correct an erroneous impression which Topics of The Times of Feb. 4 probably left on many readers? Your columnist states, in speaking of Russia, that "Kipling is not a widely translated author," that his "having the reputation of being an imperialist would not commend him to people in Moscow."
NEW YORK Mrs. J. Griswold Webb has arrived from Beaver Creek Ranch, Monument, Calif., and is at the Ritz-Carlton.

War bond sales of $56,361,000 to all types of buyers on Wednesday brought New York City's total for the Fourth War Loan drive to $3,468,339,000, 94.2 per cent of its quota, it was announced yesterday by Nevil Ford, executive manager of the War Finance Committee for New York.

DELAIR, N.J., Feb. 10 -- Eight persons were injured today when a freight train ran through a stop signal and collided with a three-coach passenger train at a switch on the outskirts of this community, ten miles north of Camden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Americans of Italian descent have appealed to President Roosevelt to support some method of resuming an interchange of mail between this country and those parts of Italian territory now occupied by the United Nations, in order to expedite the transmission of news about relatives and friends from whom they have had no word since the invasion.

The choice of a wartime valentine gift should involve a minimum of extravagance but a maximum of sentiment. "Service men are masters of this art," the personal shopper for a large department store said yesterday, "and civilians might profit by their example."

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- The defeat yesterday of an Administration-backed subsidy proposal by the Senate and a belief that elimination of the subsidy on flour might increase the demand for wheat, brought in fair commission-house buying of that grain in the early trading today on the Board of Trade.

Representatives of half a dozen agencies engaged in varied types of social service explained their work last night at the winter meeting of Smith College Alumnae Club of New York with the New York Alumnae Smith College School of Social Work in the parish house of Christ Church, 520 Park Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- The Philadelphia Stock Exchange was permitted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to grant unlisted trading privileges to ten securities but the same right was denied to it with respect to the $7 cumulative second preferred stock, Series A, no par value, of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc.
A Japanese communique, as broadcast from Tokyo yesterday and recorded by The United Press:

The Vatican radio, quoting the Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano, said that bombs had fallen yesterday for the third time on the grounds of the pontifical villa at Castel Gandolfo, south of Rome, causing "both damage and victims."

The new French currency that will be used by Allied troops on their landing in France, and also soon afterward by the whole civilian population, is now being printed in the United States. Some idea of the magnitude of the operation can be gathered from the fact that to make up an aggregate sum of 10,000,000,000 francs, no less than 86,000,000 separate bank notes are required.

LONDON, Feb. 10 (U.P.) -- British units have landed on the Dalmatian island of Lesina in their first operation on Yugoslav soil and have joined Partisan forces battling German marines for control of that vital coastal supply outpost, Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for a $150,000,000 appropriation for additional public works facilities in congested war plant communities, including a new departure into Federal construction of stores, shops and other "out-plant facilities."
The Federation Bank and Trust Company announced yesterday the election of Joseph Reilly to the board of directors. Mr. Reilly is chairman of the Electrographic Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Dr. V.H. Spensley of Albuquerque, N.M., chosen National Chairman of Bataan Relief Organizations, charged today that the War and Navy Departments had been "brutal and dastardly" in their telling of Japanese atrocities on prisoners in the Philippines.
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- The stock markets here were cheerful today and yesterday's gains generally were maintained.

A $135,000 mortgage at 4 1/2 per cent for ten years on the property at 214-32 Forty-third Avenue, Bayside, Queens, was arranged by John F. Bottomley, Inc., with the Seamen's Savings Bank. Title was insured by the Guaranteed Mortgage Company.

Marked expansion of central buying in staple and semi-staple lines, with a record development of private brands to meet the competition of chain-store and mail-order brands, was predicted yesterday by Wilton J. Greenebaum, vice president of Felix Lilienthal Co., resident buyers.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Russian troops have cut off several German groups from the main remnants of ten crack Axis divisions trapped around Korsun in the Dnieper River bend and are "wiping them out," Moscow announced today in a bulletin foreshadowing the climax of the biggest single Nazi disaster since Stalingrad.
John E. Flannery has joined Barrett Co. and Harold R. Chapel has joined Crouse, Bennett, Smith Co.

A check list of the steps which all war contractors, whether prime or subcontract suppliers, should take in the preparation and conduct of contract terminations was issued yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers as part of its new manual for the guidance of members in dealing with terminations.

We must not think that Monte Cassino has been "spared through all the warring centuries" for Rommel and us to quarrel over. The monks whom St. Benedict established in 529 in the temple of Apollo were overwhelmed and the buildings demolished by Germans -- the Lombards -- before the end of that century; not till 720 was it rebuilt.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Navy Department communique 505:

Tomorrow will be observed in the churches as "Race Relations Sunday" because it is the day after Lincoln's birthday anniversary. Many pastors will devote their sermons to Lincoln and to Washington, the anniversary of whose birth will be celebrated soon.

Refuting the old saying that they never come back, Champion Daro of Maridor staged a notable return to Madison Square Garden yesterday in the sixty-eighth annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which will continue through tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The War Department made it plain today that if unions demand a check-off system for private employers of war prisoners the Army is determined that neither the prisoner nor the United States Government will pay the money.

News that the Governments of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg have decided to form a customs union is as significant in its smaller way as Moscow's bold invitation to the neighboring states to become autonomous members of the Soviet Union. It signifies that Europe is in the first stages of revival and reformation.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
ROCHESTER, Feb. 11 -- Amendment of the State labor law to safeguard America's children and prevent a serious social breakdown was advocated at a conference here today of women labor leaders.

As major coal dealers reported deliveries only slightly retarded by the heavy snowfall yesterday, the supply of coal at the city's emergency dumps dwindled to the point where twenty-two of the thirty-nine stations were without coal. At the end of the day their aggregate sales were 34,600 pounds.

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 12 -- Russian troops advanced yesterday to within four miles of Korsun, heart of the "Cherkassy pocket" in which the remnants of ten German divisions are being annihilated, while 200 miles to the west other Red Army units captured the five-way rail junction of Shepetovka, near the Polish border.
LONDON Feb. 11 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press.

If the mere suggestion of another world war did not sound cynical and defeatist, a person would be tempted to say that in the next great war there will be no Ministries of Propaganda and no official agencies of war information.

Trading in railroad issues continued yesterday to dominate the activity in the stock market, but the carriers failed to maintain their early gains and closing prices were mixed. With major Exchanges throughout the nation shut today in observance of the Lincoln Birthday holiday, short-term operators adopted a cautious attitude and profit-taking was in evidence.

Judge John J. Freschi will hear argument next Tuesday by Edward V. Broderick, counsel for Wayne Lonergan, and Assistant District Attorney Jacob Grumet on another motion by the defense lawyer for a stay of the opening of his client's first-degree murder trial on Feb. 23 and the appointment of a Government commissioner in the Canal Zone to interrogate a possible important Lonergan witness.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Bids were opened today in the office of the Alien Property Custodian here for the purchase of 135,000 shares of stock in the American Wine Company of St. Louis formerly possessed by Henkell Co., wine merchants of Wiesbaden, Germany.
