The double bill composed of Puccini's "Gianni Schicchi" and Strauss' "Salome" received its second presentation of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Both operas fared better than at their earlier hearing, the performance of "Salome," in which Lily Djanel assumed the title role, being particularly vivid and convincing.
Lieut. Comdr. Willis P. Beal, USNR, and Mrs. Beal of Boston are at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The release from jail of Senator Laureano Gomez, leader of the Conservative party, appeared today to have dampened opposition hopes of developing a political fight into a revolution against the Liberal Government of Acting President Dario Echandia.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 11 -- Chief Justice Sir Brooke Francis today upset the administrative arrangement of concurrent jurisdiction of American and Bermudian authorities. He asserted the situation should be regularized by legislation because from a legal standpoint the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court includes two United States bases.

TACOMA, Feb. 11 -- Drawing a parallel between conditions now and those preceding the re-election of Abraham Lincoln in 1864, Wendell L. Willkie warned the Republican party tonight not to permit subversive, discontented and reactionary groups, the forces of disunity, to dominate its national convention, write its platform and dictate its nominee for President.

"Where Are Your Children?" starts a fifth week today at the Globe. . . . "Kings of the Ring," the feature-length film compilation of scenes from famous prize fights, today begins a fourth week at the World. . . . The dual Swedish film program comprising "The Merry Go Round Family" and "The People of the Hogbo Farm" enter a second week today at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. . . .
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, withdrew his name from the State Presidential preference primary today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Roosevelt said today that the United States would have to have outside sources of oil for the future in view of the predictions of depletion of our reserves within fifteen to thirty years.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11 -- Eight are named for the Black Helen Handicap, $5,000 added mile and a furlong run at Hialeah Park tomorrow, and Wise Moss looks like the favorite despite her top weight of 120 pounds. Strong contenders are Silvestra and Loveday, while the comparatively obscure Moon Maiden will have a strong following because of her recent good races.

The Coast Guard Invaders, famous for their fighting qualities as well as for their musicianship as a band in the Mediterranean theatre of war, will appear on the Stars for Victory program to be staged at the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow night by the Fourth War Loan Sports Committee and the United Theatrical War Activities Committee.

The 135th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln will be observed today with patriotic exercises and meetings. Exchanges, banks and many other business enterprises will be closed, but war plants will continue at work.

A program designed "to protect the interests of small business men" in the disposal of Government surplus war merchandise has been formulated by a steering committee of the National Association of Army and Navy Stores, Inc., appointed at the organization meeting of the group recently in Chicago.

Plenty of war bonds were being sold in the city and State -- although not quite enough to satisfy officials -- but the totals of sales recorded through Thursday showed substantial decreases from those reported for Wednesday. This resulted from the fact that various large purchases by corporations previously credited to New York

Trade Pace Slower in Week Retail trade here slowed down this week. Department store volume slipped behind last year's figures, which were swollen by the heavy volume of scare buying of apparel being done at that time. Percentage changes were spotty, with some stores having decreases of around 5 per cent.

Only $4,807,500 of new municipal bonds will come up for award next week, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with this week's revised total of $12,207,295, and with the weekly average for the year, thus far, of $21,499,802. The principal issue on next week's list is that of $3,000,000 Buffalo, N.Y., refunding bonds, due from 1948 to 1954, which will come up for award on Tuesday.

The six-story apartment house at 92-11 Thirty-fifth Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens, occupying the blockfront between Ninety-second and Ninety-third Streets, has been sold by Raleigh Associates to the Nore Realty Company, subject to a mortgage of $289,000 held by a savings bank.

Three programs of entertainment, designed especially for the juvenile trade, are scheduled today in the metropolitan area. At the New York Times Hall Joseph Robotti will offer this afternoon and evening a musical fantasy entitled "The Crocodile Island," by Geoffrey F. Morgan and Frederick Johnson.

The celebrated "feminine touch" has been applied to Office of Price Administration ceiling charts, and the result -- a handy, attractive twelve-page booklet -- will be distributed throughout Westchester County beginning Feb. 18.

ALGIERS, Feb. 11 -- Attacking during a wild storm that swept the battlefield with deluges of rain, Fifth Army troops fighting on the Anzio beachhead were reported tonight to have advanced slightly in fierce hand-to-hand battles with the Germans in the Aprilia area.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 -Charles R. Hook, former president of the National Association of Manufacturers, asserted today that industry faced possible "economic starvation" unless the Government assumed a "more reasonable" attitude toward corporate taxation in the post-war period.

The appearance of women nurses on the scene resulted in a marked improvement in the morale of wounded and ill men in a South Pacific Navy hospital where casualties from Guadalcanal and other early campaigns of that theatre were taken, Lieut. G.H. Williams, Navy medical officer, told a "fresh-man" class of nurses at St. Vincent's School of Nursing yesterday.

All the principal securities and commodity markets in the United States will be closed today in observance of Lincoln's Birthday. Livestock markets will remain open, as will the Savannah naval stores market. Banks in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut, and in twenty-four other States will be closed.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers:

The Federal Government disclosed yesterday that it was selling an additional carload of 41,462 pounds of aging butter from its huge hoard estimated on Feb. 1 at 130,000,000 pounds. The latest offering increases to 257,519 pounds the total offering of deteriorated butter this week.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 11 -- Unlike every other trade or industry, reinsurance is brisk in France -- but it is political reinsurance marked by the preparation of alibis against the opening of a second front. The latest to prepare an alibi is Fernand de Brinon, Secretary of State to Pierre Laval.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that if had received the following message by cable from the Bank of England:
President, James McCreery Co., Chairman New York City Retailers War Finance Committee

Manny's, Inc., operator of Manny Wolf's Forty-ninth Street Chop House, 201 East Forty-ninth Street, was suspended yesterday from dealing in meats, fats and oils, effective March 5, until its 126,144 ration point deficiency is repaid to the Midtown Rationing Board, 1775 Broadway.

The preliminary annual statement of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, announced yesterday, showed a net income of $22,355,300 after voluntary price reductions in line with the 1942 renegotiation agreement and provision of $82,008,429 for Federal taxes on income.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 11 -- Outstanding among 659 patents listed as granted in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office this week are issues for a malleable cast iron, a textile fiber made from peanuts and a machine for quickly sterilizing and irradiating milk or other liquids.

ARMONK, N.Y., Feb. 11 -- A $4,000,000 "memorial park," with burial, wedding and baptismal features said to have no equal this side of California, is being planned for a hilltop north of here by Dr. Charles V. Paterno, New York real estate operator, it was learned today.

ALGIERS, Feb. 11 -- Against a doggedly attacking enemy who has increased his strength in the beachhead area below Rome to elements of at least six divisions, the Allied central Mediterranean forces in Italy Thursday called in their heaviest and deadliest bombers to break up the network of German communication and supply feeding the assault.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 11 -- The American people, on the basis of a cross-section survey of the nation, vote nearly two to one in favor of sending food to children of France, Belgium, Holland and other occupied countries of Europe.

LONDON, Feb. 11 (U.P.) -- Powerful German armored forces, striking on all sectors, have launched their seventh general offensive in Yugoslavia, it was indicated today as Partisan headquarters reported withdrawals under heavy pressure.

Philip Murray, president of the CIO, has told the National War Labor Board that he wished to admit "frankly" that "we are trying to change the stabilization policy." The change to which he referred, of course, was a rise in wages. One of the tactics in this drive for higher wages is the attempt to prove that the official cost-of-living index vastly understates the rise which has taken place.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- A uniform General Allocations Order, which eventually will take the place of many of the orders which now control $150,000,000 volume of chemicals each month, was issued by the War Production Board today.

Since potatoes are particularly abundant, they are used as often as possible in the menus for the coming week. With the exception of the Monday evening meal, they are included in all of the dinners, in addition to which they form the main dish at three lunches.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told the National Planning Conference on Building Better Race Relations today that if citizens really faced problems of what racial prejudices caused they would do something important in the field of better understanding.
The New Yorker magazine announced in a note to contributors yesterday that it has decided to end the agreement permitting The Reader's Digest to reprint New Yorker material.

Columbia University's athletes face a busy time today when most all of them will see action in the course of an athletic program that is part of the celebration of thee thirty-seventh annual alumni reunion festivities.

The Rev. Francis J. Lynch of St. Robert Bellarmine Roman Catholic Church, Bayside Hills, Queens, was burned painfully yesterday while rescuing a 2-year-old boy and his great-grandmother from a fire in a four-family apartment house at 519 Ninth Street, Brooklyn.

Bunting is on Army and Navy priorities, so the 600 flags of the New York chapter of the American Red Cross must see service again when, mended and washed, they will fly on March 1 to herald the opening of the organization's 1944 fund drive.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Vice President Wallace proposed tonight the establishment of a jobs authority or jobs council made up of the very best minds in government, business and labor drafted by the President to get full employment of resources and skills for the post-war period.
LONDON, Feb. 11 (UP) -A joint communique of the United States Army, European Theatre of Operations, the British Air Ministry:

The Broadway Savoyards have been deprived of their staff of life for a bit over two years, or far too long for most of hem. In an effort to remedy that disturbing situation, R.H. Burnside last evening brought the Gilbert and Sullivan Opera Company to the Ambassador, opening its local career with "The Mikado."
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 11 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

DETROIT, Feb. 11 -- Filing a bill of complaint in Wayne County Circuit Court today asking a declaratory judgment and an injunction the Detroit Edison Company opened its fight to prevent the city of Detroit from enforcing its new excise tax ordinance, levying on the excess profits of utility companies.

A plan to bring 1,500 student-specialists here from occupied countries for training in education, industry and agriculture has been adopted by American education leaders and representatives of twelve European and Asiatic countries, it was learned yesterday.

There were bad deeds on both sides in his war, but there was chivalry, too. Lincoln could find room in his heart for compassion for a defeated enemy, and no room at all for vengeance.

TACOMA, Feb. 11 -- Following is the prepared text of Wendell L. Willkie's address here tonight:

When tall, thin, 16-year-old James Gerrity decided to "have some fun and be a big shot," he got more results than he expected -- and different ones. Among them was a trip to the psychopathic ward of Bellevue Hospital for mental observation.

A prediction that the part played by Negroes in combat forces and in Red Cross field work would change the status of their race after the war was made yesterday by Jesse O. Thomas, assistant administrator of domestic services at national Red Cross headquarters in Washington.
BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the Boston wool market tomorrow:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The situation in the Anzio-Nettuno beachhead in Italy has deteriorated since yesterday and may soon approach a climax.

While New Yorkers continue to dig themselves out from under a six-inch snowfall, local skiers are chuckling with glee at the outlook, which definitely is the best thus far this season. Certainly those who have been unable to get away this winter because of traveling and working hardships, will now find ample opportunity for testing ski legs here in the city.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis today released a statement and a copy of a letter to Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service, apropos of denial that organized baseball had any part in a letter dated Jan. 28, which J.G. Taylor Spink, publisher of The Sporting News of St. Louis, addressed to President Roosevelt, which was answered by Presidential Secretary Stephen Early.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Navy reported tonight that the battleship Oklahoma, capsized in the Japanese sneak bombing raid on Pearl Harbor Dec. 7, 1941, is "once more afloat."

OTTAWA, Feb. 11 -- In a statement to the House of Commons this evening, Col. James L. Ralston, Defense Minister, declared that medical reports had repeatedly indicated that it was extremely inadvisable for Lieut. Gen. Andrew G.L. McNaughton to remain in command of the Canadian Army.

Pending legislation in Kentucky and agitation in some other States for elimination of private wholesalers and establishment of a monopoly system of wholesale distribution are causing considerable concern in the liquor trade here, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden persuaded an aroused Parliament today to support the government's policy of assigning members of the House of Commons to jobs outside their regular duties, sometimes taking them overseas, but not until he had promised to have the whole matter well aired within the coming year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11 -- Gloria Jean, Universal's young singing star, has been given the romantic lead in the Olsen and Johnson picture "High Spirits," which goes into production Thursday. The murder mystery, written by Milt Gross and Edward Hartmann, will be directed by Edward Cline.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Vermonters, opposing Federal construction of a $29,000,000 dam at West Dummerston, Vt., presented their case before a Congressional committee today and received assurances from Army engineers that their objections would receive consideration.

Pre-holiday liquidation, supplemented by reports that the recent sharp price advance was attracting larger offerings from Southern holders, caused yesterday an irregular decline in cotton futures. At the close of trading, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed losses of 3 to 4 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Japan was charged with violation of "the common laws of civilization," failure to apply the humane provisions of the Geneva Prisoners of War Convention and with "inhuman cruelty or callous failure to provide the necessities of life" to our prisoners in the comprehensive protest sent to Tokyo by Secretary of State Cordell Hull on Jan. 27.

Mayor La Guardia, while presenting Dr. Ole Singstad, chief engineer of the New York City Tunnel Authority, with this year's Lincoln Award for meritorious service to the city, took the opportunity yesterday to praise the people of Norway, pay tribute to Abraham Lincoln, and deliver lectures on the progress of science and the building of tunnels.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 11 -- The Secretary of the Presidency, Col. Enrique Gonzalez, confirmed today that no special measures would be taken to protect Argentine ships against possible attack by German submarines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Vice Adm. John H. Towers, present commander of the air forces of the Pacific Fleet, and former chief of the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics, today was named as deputy commander in chief of the Pacific Ocean areas.

The full list of artists engaged for the three productions to be presented by the New York City Center Opera Company during its initial week of eight performances, beginning Feb. 21, at the City Center of Music and Drama was announced yesterday.

The Milk Industry Foundation announced yesterday the award of eleven Pasteur medals to milk company employes for distinguished service in line of duty. A gold medal will go to Carl M. Knapp of New Haven, Conn., for risking his life and incurring severe injuries to save a crowd of children when his horse ran away, and Roland Richard, Fargo, N.D., won a silver medal for rescuing a small boy from drowning.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The British Government withdrew today the license of the weekly Polish newspaper Wiadomosci Polskie, whose comments have been the subject of several protests by the Soviet Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Most of the new passenger cars remaining in the ration pool -- estimated at fewer than 50,000 -- will have been released to eligible buyers by July 1, the Office of Price Administration reported today. It added that meanwhile monthly quotas will become smaller and eligibility requirements will be tightened.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Feb. 11 -- The collection of union dues from Nazi war prisoners working at Seabrook Farms here is "strictly a matter between the union and the Army" as far as the company is concerned, Jack Seabrook, vice president, said today.

The four-story apartment house, with stores, at the southwest corner of Church Avenue and East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the East Brooklyn Savings Bank to Loomis J. Grossman, operator. It is on a plot 78 by 58 feet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- An unprecedented volume of Christmas buying brought total retail sales for 1943 to an all-time high of $63,269,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today. This was an increase of 10 per cent compared with 1942 and a gain of 64 per cent over the 1935-39 base period.

The big job of post-war industry is to fight poverty, disease and crime, Prof. William S. Lynch, head of the Department of Humanities, Cooper Union, said last night at the annual Founder's Day celebration in the Cooper Union Institute, Astor Place at Eighth Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Here is the vote by which the Senate today passed a bill barring further food subsidies after June 30:
LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Flying Fortresses are finding their way to targets in Germany with a new gyro flux-gate compass which enables navigators to get instant bearings high in the sky.

The Bari radio broadcast last night a proclamation by Premier Pietro Badoglio thanking the United Nations for their "generosity and confidence" in restoring liberated Italian territory to Italian rule and calling on the people for "most loyal, frank and intimate collaboration with the great allied peoples."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Roosevelt met with the American Chiefs of Staff at noon today shortly after he had told his news conference that we confronted a tense situation in the Italian campaign.

A plea to the citizens of Greater New York for 3,000 foster homes for needy children, and an intensive drive for foster parents in Queens during the last week, has resulted in a total of only 152 applications for children, it was revealed yesterday.
MEMPHIS, Feb. 11 -- An American Airlines transport plane crashed into the Mississippi River last midnight, carrying twenty-four persons to their deaths.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 11 -- Central Pacific naval air forces have raided Wake Island for the fourth time in twelve days, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today. This was the second blow at Wake in two days.

James A. Stillman, former president and chairman of the board of the National City Bank of New York, who died on Jan. 13, last, left his residuary estate in equal shares to his four children. His estate was formally valued at "more than $20,000," according to the petition for probate filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- One of the most significant features of the Marshalls operation "is that it is a pretty good denial of the favorite bugaboo of armchair strategists -- island hopping," Secretary of the Navy Knox told a news conference today.

Although most dividend payments on stocks in 1943 were unchanged from the preceding year, a number were revised by well-known companies. To assist taxpayers who now are compiling their income tax returns the following table lists dividends paid last year on common stocks of leading companies whose shares are listed on the New York Stock Exchange and on which the dividend status was changed from the preceding year:

One of the most difficult problems of warfare in the Pacific, the conquest of a fortified atoll, was solved at Kwajalein. The Battle of Tarawa was an inconclusive test, considering the heavy cost. But on the steel-swept coral of Kwajalein, Roi and Namur the answer is devastatingly complete.

OTTAWA, Feb. 11 -- Canada's war expenditure during the coming year will total $3,650,000,000 and normal expenditure for essential services will reach $702,369,000, according to estimates presented to Parliament today by Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Constitutional limitation of Presidential tenure to single terms of six years or two terms of four years each was advocated here today by Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio, Republican Presidential candidate, in his second speech in the capital in a two-day visit.

When the President suggested to Congress recently that civilians be registered for the home front, just as we register young men for the fighting front, one of the Senators said that he would be ready to do so if he knew that the people want it done.

According to the original provisions of the White Paper issued by the British Government on May 17, 1939, Jewish immigration into Palestine was limited to 75,000 for a five-year period and was due to be stopped completely on March 31, 1944. Even that small quota was not filled because of war conditions, and the terms were modified last November to permit the entry of immigrants who were unable to reach the country before the deadline.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 11 (U.P.) -- Former Gov. Alf M. Landon of Kansas urged tonight a union of Republicans and Democrats in the November election to oust President Roosevelt and "clean house" in Washington.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The question whether New York should join with other States in seeking to limit the taxing power of the Congress came to the fore today when Assemblyman Justin C. Morgan of Erie County urged adoption of a resolution proposing a constitutional amendment putting a 25 per cent ceiling on Federal income, inheritance and gift taxes.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Feb. 11 (AP) -- The work stoppage at seven Fall River textile mills, now in its ninth week, is hampering military plans, Col. Curtis G. Pratt said tonight.

The figures for the city aren't complete yet, but since the Fourth War Loan drive began children in the Bronx alone have purchased with their war stamps 200 jeeps, twenty field ambulances, five ambulance planes, three railroad hospital cars, three clearing stations for wounded and three bombers.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Bolivian revolutionary regime moved today to get rid of elements that other American republics have found objectionable because of their known connivance with Axis agents in a supposed plot to establish a number of Governments inimical to the United Nations.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- A bill cutting the time that children can work while still attending school was sponsored in the Legislature today by Senator Frederic R. Coudert and Assemblyman John R. Brook, Manhattan Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Selective Service, the War Manpower Commission and the Army joined today opposition to a bill by Representative Philbin of Massachusetts which would authorize the draft deferment of workers in the lumber and logging industry. He estimates the shortage at 22,000.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Saturday, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A communique:

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Feb. 11 -- Amid rising cold winds and a mixture of sleet and and rain, American infantrymen resumed their direct attack on Cassino this morning, following extensive artillery preparation.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies increased 1.9 per cent in January, compared with the like month of 1943, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The volume of thirty-one reporting companies for the month was $336,427,104, compared with $330,153,690 in January, 1943.

Men's and boys' shirt and pajama manufacturers and the clothing manufacturing industry have reached the point where urgent relief from operation of the cotton goods conservation order, M-317, is essential if seasonal production of civilian goods is to proceed at anywhere near an orderly rate, it was stated yesterday in the markets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- W.L. Clayton, Assistant Secretary of Commerce and right-hand man of Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones in setting up and supervising the operations of many wartime corporations, including the Defense Supplies Corporation, was reported tonight as the likely choice to head any over-all policy agency for economic demobilization which is set up as a result of recommendations of Bernard M. Baruch.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs at all main midwest markets were cut today below expectation by the heavy snow storm and clearance was reported by the War Food Administration at all points. Only 56,000 hogs were received at the twelve major markets, the lightest Friday run of the winter season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- A legislative program for uniform termination of war contracts, designed to facilitate maximum production now and expedite recon-version to civilian operation, assure speedy and final settlements, prevent improper payments and aid in prosecuting fraud, was introduced in the Senate today by Senators James E. Murray of Montana, head of the Special Committee on Small Business, and Walter F. George, chairman of the Committee on Finance.

TADWORTH, Surrey, England, Feb. 11 -- The British Government, worried about the flagging strength of many women after four years in war factories, is sending groups of them for a forthnight or more to "Restbreak Houses" to mend their health. The purpose of Restbreak Houses, far from their being convalescent or medical homes, is to avert mental or physical breakdowns by having exhausted workers take a breather when the danger signals first appear.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 10 (Delayed) -- Shanghai merchants and manufacturers, unwilling to hold puppet government currency, are now shipping billions of Chinese dollars worth of textiles to Free China, according to Chungking authorities consulted today.

TADWORTH, Surrey, England, Feb. 11 -- The British Government, worried about the flagging strength of many women after four years in war factories, is sending groups of them for a forthnight or more to "Restbreak Houses" to mend their health. The purpose of Restbreak Houses, far from their being convalescent or medical homes, is to avert mental or physical breakdowns by having exhausted workers take a breather when the danger signals first appear.

AT THE ANZIO BEACHHEAD, in Italy, Feb. 10 (Delayed) -Americans, their faces blackened with soot from cooking utensils, wiped out the entire nazi garrison of a town in a daring night plunge behind the German lines and returned today jubilant.

Associates of the late Thomas A. Edison met yesterday to commemorate the ninety-seventh anniversary of the inventor's birth and adopted plans to promote a fitting celebration of the centennial of this event.

Three polite robbers held up the president and five employes of the Magnesite Flooring Asbestolith Manufacturing Corporation, 257 Kent Street, Brooklyn, at 1:30 P.M. yesterday and escaped with a $5,000 payroll after suggesting: "You might as well take it easy and not get hurt. You're covered by insurance anyway."

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 12 -- Strong formations of Flying Fortresses hammered Frankfort on the Main, in southwestern Germany, again yesterday when the longest sustained offensive yet mounted by American air power in this theatre struck with devastating result in the Reich and in northern France.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Broad-shouldered Harold (Jug) McSpaden defied near-freezing temperatures and a stiff wind today to batter par on Brackenridge course by four strokes for a 67 and the lead in the first round of the Texas Open.

AT THE ANZIO BEACHHEAD, in Italy, Feb. 11 -- Four German shells landing on an American field hospital carefully marked with Red Cross flags, both on the tents and on the ground, killed two women nurses and wounded four medical officers and three enlisted men.

President Roosevelt's promotion of Vice Admiral Spruance, commander of the Central Pacific Fleet, which attacked the Marshall Islands, to Admiral and of Rear Admiral Turner to Vice Admiral will be approved unanimously by the Senate and the country. These two men are of about the same age, on the good side of 60.

The parcel comprising a four-story apartment house, thirty-four garages and a two-story factory building at 14-18 Park Street, Jersey City, has been sold by the Hudson Building and Loan Association, in liquidation by the New Jersey State Department of Banking and Insurance, to the G. G. Realty Company.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Operators of a Newark tavern were chided tonight by Commissioner Alfred E. Driscoll of the State Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control for conducting what he called a "biannual Christmas Club."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Continued increase in payments to the armed forces, larger war-plant payrolls and a less-than-seasonal decline in farmers' cash income from marketings brought December payments to individuals to $13,460,000,000, the highest monthly total on record, the Commerce Department announced today. December's new high brought total income payments for the year 1943 to nearly $142,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Exploratory discussions of post-war aviation are expected to be held in Washington soon by representatives of the United States, Great Britain and Canada. Lord Beaverbrook, British Minister responsible for civil aviation, has been pressing for such a parley and it is understood he will come here for the event.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 11 -- The Finnish Social Democratic party's parliamentary group expressed a desire today that the Government find out Russia's peace terms. The members met with Vaino A. Tanner, Finance Minister and leader of the group, present, dispatches to the Swedish press from Helsinki said tonight.

Lincoln's birthday calls to mind two recent books of photographs of Lincoln and the men of his time. "The Photographs of Abraham Lincoln," published recently by Harcourt, Brace, brings together all the known photographs of Lincoln which are now in the Frederick Hill Meserve collection, and also contains an essay on Lincoln by Carl Sandburg.
The vacant plot 175 by 98.9 feet at 331-43 East Thirty-ninth Street has been sold by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company. This parcel is assessed for $151,000.

Wyandotte Chemicals Corporation has placed a full page advertisement in four colors in the current issue of a magazine to send a valentine to the indispensable behind-the-scenes personality -- the office cleaning woman. Copy stresses that this essential factor in any business man's success performs such important duties as locating missing raincoats, emptying ashtrays, closing windows when rain threatens to create a minor deluge within and cleaning up after a busy day at the office.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Roosevelt gave noncommittal replies today to questions regarding the revision of the Anglo-American attitude toward the French Committee of National Liberation that is believed to be in prospect.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Feb. 12 (AP) -- More than 250 bombers and fighters, the largest attacking force ever assembled from new Allied bases in the Solomons, struck Rabaul's Vunakanau and Tobera airdromes Wednesday in the heaviest blow on that key New Britain Japanese stronghold in months, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The quickening tempo of war in Burma today found British forces beating off repeated Japanese attacks in the Arakan area, while to the northeast the Chinese pressed slowly forward against strong resistance to clear the way for the Ledo road to China.

LENINGRAD, Feb. 8 (Delayed) -- Red Army officers today led foreign correspondents through the thickly mined fields protecting what Hitler had formerly considered his impregnable Leningrad defense system of strong steel and concrete fortifications.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Democratic National Convention will open in Chicago Wednesday, July 19.

Out of the blood donated by Americans on the home front as their contribution to the war, scientists at Harvard University are extracting seven different life-saving substances, it was reported last night at the meeting of the New York section of the American Chemical Society at the Hotel Pennsylvania by Prof. Edwin J. Cohn of the Harvard Medical School.

Whipped by strong winds that approached gale proportions at times, the first major snowfall of the season descended on New York yesterday, delaying trains and highway traffic, grounding airliners, interfering with harbor operations and causing a number of accidents.

With the snow swirling down hard and fast outside the window, yesterday was a great day to be writing about fishing in Florida, so the sun-colored bulletin from the Miami Beach Rod and Reel Club got a bit of extra attention.

WITH the trend in trade showing little variation from what was expected, distribution interests in the week received a Commerce Department report which disclosed that retail volume in 1943 amounted to $63,269,000,000 or a rise of 10 per cent in dollars and 1.4 per cent in physical quantity over 1942. The jump over the 1935-39 average was 64 per cent.

ALGIERS, Feb. 12 -- German troops have overrun the area of Castel Gandolfo, the site of the Pope's summer farm and palace barely twelve miles below Rome, and Allied Headquarters announced today that, "whenever vital enemy targets appear there, they will of necessity be bombed."

School leaders of the future may teach their pupils the ABC's of proper diet, housing and clothing along with the three R's, as the result of a two-year study, now under way, by the American Association of Teachers Colleges. Eight member colleges in various parts of the country have been commissioned by the association to examine current experiments in such teaching and to try out similar projects in their own laboratory schools.
SEATTLE, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The weight of a Flying Fortress is watched closely.

The fifty-eight members of the current graduation class of the Upgrading School for Cooks and Bakers of the United States Maritime Service, at 208 West Thirteenth Street, yesterday heard Russell W. Varney, director of industry services for the Fleischmann division of Standard Brands, Inc., declare that nothing could be more important to the success of the USMS than a reputation for serving good, nutritious food.

In his annual report last week to the board of managers of the American Bureau of Shipping, J. Lewis Luckenbach, president, declared that more radical advances in the field of marine machinery and propulsion may be expected as soon as the war ends and conditions become normal.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Russia has reaffirmed her demand that the Russian-Polish boundary must be moved westward to the Curzon Line, but has indicated to Allied diplomats that she is prepared to see a "friendly" Polish Government get former German territory reaching roughly from just west of Koenigsberg, East Prussia, to the vicinity of Stolpmuende in Pomerania.

THE bridge hands reported in newspapers and magazines are seldom representative of those which occur in the usual bridge game played in a home or in a club. The bridge writer usually tries to select hands which illustrate correct bidding and play; or hands in which a proper contract is reached and would be made except for improper play.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Feb. 13 -- In a renewal of Red Army operations on the front south of Leningrad, the important rail junction of Batetskaya, eighteen miles east of Luga, was captured yesterday, the Russians' late communique announced last night.

Before a crowd of 15,000 wildly enthusiastic lovers of dogs, the famous Welsh terrier, Champion Flornell Rare-Bit of Twin Ponds, gained the highest honor last night at the sixty-eighth annual all-breed show of the Westminster Kennel Club in Madison Square Garden.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Four world records were set as the powerful Great Lakes swimming team defeated Ohio State, 46 -- 29, today. Buckeye Coach Mike Peppe probably was the happiest mentor ever to lose a meet -- because the new marks were set by his former proteges.

LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Germans now were crowded into an eleven-mile-long strip of territory from Korsun north along a railroad. Golyaki was captured at the northern extremity of this last Nazi toehold, and Kavashin, less than three miles southeast of Korsun, was taken on the southern end, the communique said.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 12 -- Dr. Isaac Herzog, chief rabbi of Palestine, declared on his arrival here that "large numbers of suffering Jews may yet be rescued if the Allied and neutral countries follow the lead of the United States."

STEADY growth through years of quiet unostentatious work is evident in the current exhibition of paintings by Sol Wilson at the Babcock Gallery. A somber romanticism tinges Wilson's work and finds expression through a generally somber palette and, frequently, in somber subjects.

RHINELANDER, Wis., Feb. 12 -- You would think old Paul Bunyan himself was back in the woods of northern Wisconsin and the Michigan peninsula "giving 'er snoose" for the hottest logging seen in half a century.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 10 (delayed) -- Staff Sgt. James L. Shannon of Jamestown, N.Y., took off in a transport for home today after three years of overseas duty. Smiling Jim is a little yellow around the eyes from the jaundice he recently contracted in India, but his farewell statement was anything but jaundiced.

BETWEEN the time rumors began that Moss Hart, Ira Gershwin and Kurt Weill were staging "Lady in the Dark" and the night the curtain first went up, five weeks elapsed. On Broadway this was thought a pretty brisk rate of speed.

THREE ladies of distinction are scheduled to grace the confines of as many local cafes this week. They are Ethel Waters, Gracie Fields and Celeste Holm. In one of her rare New York night club appearances Miss Waters will be seen and heard at Joe Howard's Cafe Zanzibar starting Thursday night.

Poems have been written and paeans sung to the nickel-plated, autocratic base burner, but too little has been said and too few verses dedicated to the humble kitchen stove. Gas and electric stoves are modernistically efficient. They serve their purpose well, and doubtless in the Elysian days of post-war marvels they will increase in numbers. But they do not have the cheery comfortableness of the wood or coal burning range.
AN interesting description of musical life in Hawaii is contained in a letter just received here from Cpl. Abe Kosakowsky.

LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The American strategic bombing of Europe from Britain has been undergoing a subtle change since Maj. Gen. James H. Doolittle assumed command of the Eighth Air Force last month.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 12 -- Princeton Mike Shinkarik touched off a sparkling second-half drive tonight to give the Princeton basketball team a 42-33 victory over Cornell in the final Eastern Intercollegiate League contest for both teams.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 12 -- Egypttian public health authorities were winning their battle against bubonic plague reported recently in Suez Canal areas, and particularly in the city of Suez itself, Egypt's chief Red Sea port and the southern terminus of the canal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Together, the United States and Great Britain should "stamp out" cartels, which threaten the life of democracy in the post-war world. Wendell Berge, Assistant Attorney General, told a conference of The People's Lobby, Inc., here today.
MOSCOW, Feb. 12 -- Pravda warned its readers today not to be "taken in" by the soft words of friendship spoken recently by members of the exiled Polish Government.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 12 -- Salvage of the ill-starred battleship Oklahoma, one of the ships badly hit and sunk in the enemy's unheralded attacks on Pearl Harbor more than two years ago, was the penultimate act in a drama that was something more than a mere sideshow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The possibility that Moscow might warn the Japanese Government that it would be expedient to seek peace with the United States and Britain, as the United States has already admonished Finland to seek peace with Russia, is discussed by The Army and Navy Journal today.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 12 -- Wendell L. Willkie stated at a press conference today that he would enter the Oregon preferential primary as a candidate for the Republican nomination for President.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 12 -Two Manhattan Boy Scouts proved their resourcefulness and preparedness last night when their holiday week-end encampment was shifted from a wind-swept, snow-bound site at near-by Tibbetts Brook Park to the steam-heated second floor of Westchester County parkway police headquarters, here.

A wave of apprehension swept over Finland last week. In Helsinki officials of President Risto Ryti's Government faced a grave decision on the war with Russia. Soviet victories had freed Leningrad, opening the way for a possible drive up the Karelian Isthmus -where Russian guns had smashed the Mannerheim Line in 1940.

BREAKFAST has been a meal in disrepute. Evidence of the fact is found in the statements that have been made about it. These include familiar expressions like "We don't have time to pay much attention to the morning menu"; and "I just never have any appetite when I get up"; and "I'm on a diet and take only coffee."

OUR pet statistician having donned khaki, we cannot tell you how many times around from here to there the combined writings of Channing Pollock would extend. Plays, thirty-one of them, including hits like "The Fool" and "The Enemy," essays, articles, stories and librettos, have poured from the prolific Mr. Pollock over twoscore years.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Feb. 12 -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark disclosed tonight that Allied reinforcements were still arriving at the Anzio beachhead below Rome and that heavy armor had already been established there. He said that the next step in the operations on the twin Italian fronts would be a junction of the two Allied forces and "a victorious march into Rome and to the north."

DESPITE the difficulty in getting reservations to southern resorts, the present travel trend continues in that direction. The Florida season will be a late one this year, much later than usual, according to travel bureau officials.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Sunday, Feb. 13 (UP) -- A communique:

AT a time when the fate of the world rests with a group of great powers that are at best partially European, the question is no longer whether the end of Europe's political supremacy has come but what its consequences will be for Western civilization.

While the food shortage in Europe is still "critical," it is not as bad as represented and Europe should be able to stand alone agriculturally after she has harvested her first full crop following the end of hostilities, the American Institute of Food Distribution asserted in a forecast distributed yesterday to its membership of more than 3,000.

There has been so much discussion of "Post-War Planning" recently and so many schemes have been advanced that a great segment of the American people has come to expect that a neat blueprint of our economic future inevitably will be put into effect upon the conclusion of the European phase of the war.

Four years ago last week President Roosevelt told reporters that questions about a possible third term were out of order. Vice President John N. Garner consulted friends on whether to seek renomination despite Mr. Roosevelt's opposition. Paul V. McNutt, aspirant for Mr. Garner's post, made three speeches.

Although the excess profits tax was intended to recapture only the bulk of corporate profits resulting from the war effort, its net effect goes far beyond this purpose. In theory, at least, normal profits should escape the excess profits tax and be subject only to the corporate normal tax and surtax.

MORNING GLORIES, if started from seed now, will bloom in pots by a sunny window in about ten weeks. The quick flowering will be a revelation to those who recall that garden-grown plants often do not bloom until late summer.

Pope Pius XII has written a letter to the Bishop of Mainz, Germany, expressing the wish that German Catholics "may remain immune" to Nazi doctrines, the Swiss newspaper Neue Zuercher Nachrichten said in an article reported yesterday to the Office of War Information.

Citing Abraham Lincoln as one who "died believing that the rights of man were more precious than the rights of private property," Vice President Henry A. Wallace told a world-wide radio audience yesterday that those who seek a people's peace out of this war "shall fight unceasingly against anyone who puts the dollar above the man."

Both governmental and private agencies continue to urge upon the motorist the necessity of conserving his car and his tires. This lesson is again emphasized sharply by a study made by the American Automobile Association, which shows that there is little hope for a lifting of the mileage ceiling during the first half of the year.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Claire Chennault's fliers attacked Japanese shipping off the China coast and blasted Japanese installations in China on Thursday and Friday, a Fourteenth United States Air Force communique announced today.

PHILADELPIA, Feb. 12 -- The Department of Justice held today that the underwriting agreement, historic device of the financial industry for orderly distribution of a new security, was a flagrant violation of the price-fixing and economic boycott prohibitions of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

Teachers College, Columbia University, has introduced a new adult adjustment course to train men and women to organize community adjustment centers. Trainees will be taught to coordinate into a single counseling program services and workers in education, medicine, guidance, psychiatry, personnel and social work.

MOULTRIE, Ga., Feb. 12 -- Spurgeon (Spud) Chandler, New York Yankee pitcher who was voted the American League's most valuable player in 1943, left his home in Carnesville today en route to Atlanta for a physical examination for the armed forces Monday.

In anticipation of radical changes in grocery merchandising and sharp competition in the post-war period the National Association of Retail Grocers is planning a nation-wide educational program for the benefit of independent operators who compose its membership and the thousands of returned soldiers who are expected to enter the grocery business.

THERE are few books which go with midnight, solitude and a candle. It is much easier to say what does not please us then than what is exactly right. The book must be, anyhow, something benedictory by a sinning fellow man.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -- St. John's University scored its twelfth victory in fourteen starts when the Redmen defeated the St. Joseph's basketball team at Convention Hall tonight, 41 -- 36, before 10,108 spectators.

Flurries that added only a fraction of an inch to the city's seven-inch blanket of snow gave way to clearing skies just before noon yesterday, leaving Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey and his army of regulars and volunteers the job of clearing the streets and highways for traffic, in the face of dropping temperatures and a Weather Bureau forecast of 14 degrees before dawn today.

One hundred and twenty-five thousand workers in the men's and boys' garment industry throughout the country will be affected by a National War Labor Board ruling authorizing paid vacations in the industry, Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, said yesterday.

BEFORE you begin to read this book you should master the King Tut Alphabet on the page preceding Chapter 1. It is easy and it will help you to understand the secret code of the three young detectives, Dinah, April and Archie.

FEW gardens have enough spring flowering bulbs, yet every year literally thousands of narcissus bulbs are thrown away after the plants in the window garden have finished blooming. Yet most narcissi can be saved.

For the past five months the National Education Association, largest spokesman for teachers in the country, has been conducting public and private inquiries into New York City school conditions. Educators and interested citizens wondered what the committee would discover.

RAYMOND B. FOSDICK, president of the General Education Board, says in his latest report: "If the colleges are to weather the storm they must face their responsibilities with realism and courage, resting their case not on tradition or mere historical significance but on ability to render service that will justify public confidence and command respect."

It will be the Maple Leafs' turn to make capital of the misfortunes of the Rangers tonight. The teams meet in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden, and the Leafs, complacent in the knowledge that the Blue Shirts have fared poorly recently, are confident that they will merely have to go through the motions to win.

Chausson: Symphony in B flat Major, Op. 20. Frederick Stock and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra (Victor, DM. 950, four twelve-inch records). This album. released as a memorial to Dr. Stock, who died in October, 1942, shows Dr. Stock at his best.

WE had a rendezvous with a lady in a secluded and intimate little room in a small out-of-the-way hotel where we met, completely secure from interruption or intrusion. We stayed there in the gathering twilight hours after discretion, if not convention, should have suggested departure.

THE success stories in this book are tied together by the fact that these "modern pioneers," fighting against heavy odds in American society, all have some Negro blood. They have other blood, too -Indian, French, Dutch, Irish, Spanish and other white strains.

Thomas Burke, former international communications chief of the State Department, has been elected vice president of the American Export Airlines, it was announced last week by John E. Slater, executive vice president of the company. Mr. Burke will have charge of the company's international relations and will assume his duties soon.

THE airy unreality and easy plausibility of a happy hangover morning pervade the pages of "Jitter Run." A six-foot corpse or a case of vintage wine can be handily procured if it is needed to further the plans of Colonel Jitter.

RAILROAD executives are giving increasing attention to winning and keeping the good-will of the public. They realize that passenger competition after the war will be keen and that thousands of new train riders today may be kept or lost by the treatment they receive now.

OUT at First Army Air Force Headquarters, Mitchel Field, L.I. the other day a visiting colonel of artillery stood at the edge of the landing field watching a formation of fighter planes circling far overhead. "Look, Billy," he said to his 9-year-old nephew, the son of an air officer, "there's a lot of fighters getting ready to come in."

This is the first war in which the civilian at home, safely and painlessly, can shed his blood for his country. He sheds it as a blood donor under the supervision of the Red Cross. It goes to hospitals and dressing stations in the form of plasma, which is often administered to severely wounded soldiers under the very fire of the enemy.

The success of the Allied campaign against German submarines is indicated in figures released yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute which show a drop of more than 90 per cent in casualties between April of last year, with 357, and November with only seventeen.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Lieut. Gerry H. Kisters, first soldier in this war to win the two highest military awards of the United States, came home to Bloomington today and several thousand fellow-citizens turned out to honor him despite 12-above-zero weather.

HUGE Army and Navy orders for Modern Library books unbalanced the paper situation at Random House a few weeks ago and some kind of legerdemain is being devised now to put the newest venture, the Illustrated Modern Library, back in print.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- American diplomatic officials and others who were trapped in France when the Germans swept over the formerly unoccupied area are to be returned home under an arrangement disclosed by the State Department tonight.

THE proprietor of the Conqueror Inn reports the finding of a box of banknotes on the moor near his place. When Inspector Bobby Owen goes to investigate he makes another discovery -- the nude body of a man whose face has been mutilated beyond recognition.
Through the steaming and filthy Japanese prison camp of Cabanatuan in July, 1942, there swept a series of epidemics that took an appalling toll of lives among American soldiers quartered there.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 12 -- State Republicanism is in no danger and the Democratic party here has little to hope for except a majority for President Roosevelt if he runs again. This has become clear as the aftermath of Senator Henry Cabot Lodge's dramatic resignation in order to don a uniform.

SEVERAL times deferred since last summer, the American Stamp Dealers Association's philatelic auction for the benefit of the United Service Organizations will be held at the Collectors Club, 22 East Thirty-fifth Street, on the evening of March 8, it was announced last week by Emil Bruechig, president of the A.S.D.A.
The discovery that common yeast is in some instances more potent than penicillin is announced by C.W. Carpenter, associate pathologist of the Hawaiian Sugar Planters Association Experiment Station.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- The athletes of the United States Military Academy spent the afternoon of Lincoln's Birthday meeting the men of seven visiting groups in five different sports. On the whole, the cadets provided a pleasing day for their supporters.

SIDI-FERRUCH, Algeria, Feb. 12 -- From Casablanca to Corsica, from Bizerte to Battipaglia, from behind the lines in Algiers and from the front-line foxholes on the main Fifth Army front, 186 American, British and French service men have gathered at a seaside training camp here.
MEN have always been baffled by some extraordinary quality in Abraham Lincoln's features and in his rocklike mold.

OTTAWA, Feb. 12 -- The fierceness of the battle in Italy has suddenly brought everybody back to a realization that the war has not been won. ON THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, in Italy, Feb. 12 -An American officer died in a German minefield today because he couldn't stand to see a ragged little Italian girl crying for her dog.

TORONTO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Despite a couple of long goals for the opposition and a brilliant net-minding performance by Paul Bibeault, the Canadiens dominated sufficient of the play tonight to defeat the Maple Leafs, 3 -- 2, before 12,589 fans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Roosevelt presented the Senegelais, a new American-made destroyer-escort, to the French people today and hailed the transfer under lend-lease as symbolic of the "ancient friendship between France and the United States."

The Harvard Glee Club, conducted by G. Wallace Woodworth, and the Sarah Lawrence College Chorus, under William Schuman, gave a joint concert last night in Town Hall for the benefit of the scholarship funds of the two schools.

Carol Silver, young Chicago pianist, made her New York debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall in a program opening with the Bach-Busoni Toccata in C major and closing with the Chopin B minor Sonatta, Opus 58. Shorter works by Chopin, Liszt, Ravel and Khatchatourian made up the remainder of the list.

DORIS HUMPHREY and Charles Weidman will open the fourth annual repertory season at their Studio Theatre, 108 West Sixteenth Street, on Feb. 27. The season is late in starting this year and will include only Sunday evening performances because several members of the company are also appearing in Broadway shows.

DALLAS, Tex., Feb. 12 (U.P.) -Clarence Budington Kelland, speaking as Republican National Committeeman for Arizona, asserted tonight that the Administration had debauched American self-respect and that national integrity was at stake in the coming Presidential election.

A slow but continuous decline in the business population, resulting from the fact that a subnormal number of new concerns has been organized since the end of 1941, has brought business population figures as reported in Dun Bradstreet reference books to the level of late 1936, the company reported yesterday.

ANDRE GIDE once wrote in his journal, "Je ne suis jamais. Je deviens." This eternal preoccupation with his own quest, an unending scrutiny of the present instant within himself, is once again manifest in the latest collection of Gide essays, "Interviews Imaginaires."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Determined to put an end to reports of rivalry, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman, threatened disciplinary action today against any executive of the agency who permitted himself to become a party to spreading stories of such dissension between them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A Japanese Zero of the latest type, reconstructed by the Army Air Forces from parts of five of the enemy's speedy fighter planes that were shot down in the Pacific, has afforded proof that the craft is a "killer, a dangerous adversary in aerial combat," but of such fragile construction that "in flight, the wing surfacing wrinkles like tissue," the War Department reported today.

WHEELING, W. Va., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, House Republican leader, asserted tonight that President Roosevelt had possessed "absolute domination" of the country for twelve years and showed no signs of seeking to relinquish it."

As the Solid Fuels Administration released quantities of anthracite coal from its emergency reserve to supply the city's emergency coal stations yesterday, Mayor La Guardia voiced indignation because a holiday manpower shortage had curtailed the movement of coal to the emergency stat ions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Roosevelt tonight informed his long-time friend and adviser, Harry L. Hopkins, that his 18-year-old son, Stephen, had been killed in the fighting to wrest the Marshall Islands from the Japanese.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 12 -- William Helis' strawberry roan, Olympic Zenith, became a likely Kentucky Derby prospect at the Fair Grounds today by winning the $15,000 added Louisiana Derby in a strong field of three-year-olds. This was the colt's first race under the name of Olympic Zenith, since he previously had run as Valdina Zenith.

Stepping up retail selling to a new high pitch will be one of the first tasks retailers will face in the post-war period, or in the intermediate stage when consumer goods begin to be more plentiful. ALGIERS, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Allies' grip on the beachhead south of Rome was firmer tonight than at any time in the past seventy-two hours after a German attack had been repulsed with the aid of warships.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Keeping up the Allies' steady hammering of Nazi-occupied France, United States heavy bombers escorted by Thunderbolt and Mustang fighters attacked the Germans' "secret weapon" coast of northern France again today in the thirteenth major assault carried out by American war planes from Britain in the last sixteen days.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A fierce battle has been raging for nine days southwest of Taung Bazaar, on the Arakan front in Burma, a southeast Asia Command communique reported today. Allied troops are standing firm, although often attacked from many sides at once.

As he followed Alexander on his enthusiastic tour of Europe he grumbled and sulked as the Czar, with a wily eye to politics, admired the craftsmanship of foreign workmen.

Do Americans realize how we in England are affected by cramped scope for the expression of opinion?

TWENTIETH CENTURY-FOX put the A.J. Cronin novel "The Keys of the Kingdom" into production last week, anticipating that it will be the most costly picture of the year for this company. After initial study of the 1943 Renegotiation Act, now awaiting Presidential approval as part of the new revenue bill, industrial accountants declared yesterday that the attitude shown by Congress in reviewing the excess profits limitation, far from being entirely fruitless, has undoubtedly made price adjustment officials more careful than ever before not to violate the spirit of fair and equitable treatment of war contractors.

The re-establishment of an international cooperation agreement among tramp ship operators such as existed for four years before the war was urged yesterday by the Greek Shipowners New York Committee. Francis Perrin, member of the French Consultative Assembly which will meet with Gen. New York State, which had reported individual subscriptions to the Fourth War Loan totaling only 65.5 per cent of its quota yesterday, began the last week-end of the bond selling drive with redoubled activities on the part of War Finance Committee officials and volunteer workers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -The Office of War Information, Director Elmer Davis states, will probably have to change its policy of not identifying Presidential aspirants as candidates. He made this statement today when asked why OWI's dispatch for foreign consumption on Governor Bricker's press conference Thursday identified the Presidential candidate only as "a prominent Republican" and the "Governor of Ohio."

AT this writing Archibald MacLeish's new program, "The American Story" (Saturdays, 7 P.M., WEAF-NBC), has had but a single airing, but already you may detect in it the material and the mood of a significant event.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- "Soldiers of God," recently adopted official march of the Army Chaplain Corps, will be introduced to radio audiences as a part of the Army Hour tomorrow, 3:30 to 4:30 P.M., NBC.

Accessories still hold the spotlight in brisk retail trade in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

IRENE CLEATON'S first novel is a good creepy thriller with Edinburgh of the Eighteen Twenties as the bleak background. "The Outsider" is a good title, for the reactions to hanging and murder are felt via pretty Lucetta Linton, a fashionable London miss, newly arrived in Edinburgh to live with her guardian, Sir Bruce MacNeill, and his blue-stocking daughter, Jane.

Sports celebrities of the past and present, led by Jack Dempsey and Babe Ruth, will join with stars of the stage, screen and radio this evening at the Waldorf-Astoria in the grand finale show of the Fourth War Loan Sports Committee, working in conjunction with the United Theatrical War Activities Committee.

Appealing for leadership among the alumnae of women's colleges in formulating decisions concerning present and post-war education, Dr. Constance Warren, president of Sarah Lawrence College, addressed more than 500 members of the Hunter College Alumnae Association at their annual breakfast yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.
The prepared address of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey at the Lincoln Day dinner of the National Republican Club at the Waldorf-Astoria last night follows:

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- Ridgeway P. Bishop, 50 years old, bridge expert and member of a prominent Chicago family, was instanly killed early today when he plunged sixteen stories into Clark Street from a corridor window in the Morrison Hotel.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 12 (AP) -- J.G. Taylor Spink, publisher of The Sporting News, said today he was speaking only for himself, on a matter of news for his weekly sports paper, when he wrote recently asking President Roosevelt for an expression on the status of baseball in the war effort.

BOSTON, Feb. 12 -- The Boston Braves announced tonight the signing of former coach Bob Coleman as manager for the 1944 season to succeed Charles D. (Casey) Stengel, who resigned two weeks ago following a change in ownership of the National League baseball club.

Gen. Henry H. Arnold, chief of the Army Air Forces, was given the Marconi Memorial Commemorative Medal of the Veteran Wireless Operators Association, at the nineteenth annual dinner of the association last night at the Hotel Astor.

Dillon Myer, head of the War Relocation Authority, charged yesterday that the country's effort to relocate the Japanese from camps to already inhabited communities was being hindered by "organized and persistent opposition."

There was a time when mid-February meant the height of the Southern Season, when those who had labored so hard all through December and January simply had to catch their breath on a Florida beach. Remember the travel posters? And the stories from the resorts? Not many of us went, but there were lots of dreams.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 12 -- Samuel K. McKee of the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced tonight the arrest of a former Marine Corps private on charges of impersonating a Marine officer, in the course of which he gave the Red Bank Rotary Club a stirring account of adventures in Southwest Pacific fighting and later persuaded two members to endorse his notes for $150 and $100.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The Russian-sponsored Union of Polish Patriots has already organized a National Council inside Poland, the Moscow radio disclosed tonight, adding a new climax to the open conflict between Russia and the Polish Government in exile.

IDLING engines of the dingy-looking Flying Fortress Nervous Nellie suddenly clear their throats with a roar that makes the damp morning air vibrate. The roar shades off into a relatively soft purr and the plane moves forward slowly. Ground-crew men, standing clear of the wing tips to avoid the sand and moisture-laden cyclone churned up by the four propellers, direct the pilot by hand signals.

BACK in the dark summer of 1942, a young Australian war correspondent named James Aldridge gave us his first novel, "Signed With Their Honour" -- a story of British airmen in Greece, which many reviewers hailed as the finest fictional treatment of World War II then extant.

An unpublished letter sent by Abraham Lincoln to a Jewish congregation in which the Civil War President expressed his thanks for a prayer for the country as well as for its welfare was made public last night at the opening session of the annual meeting of the American Jewish Historical Society at the Jewish Theological Seminary, Broadway and 122d Street.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- In Britain, as in the United States, whisky is becoming a rare and costly beverage, what with the diversion of alcohol to war needs and high taxes.

READERS who are feeling nostalgic about Maine in these days of limited travel might enjoy Miss Elizabeth Foster's "Dirigo Point" which is full of rustic and homely details of life in a backwoods Maine camp.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY in England, Feb. 1 (Delayed) -- What is undoubtedly the best trained, best equipped and physically toughest army ever raised by Americans is soberly preparing for its greatest campaign -- the invasion of Western Europe.

DALLAS, Texas, Feb. 12 -- The controversy that Mexico has raised with Texas over discrimination against Mexicans and American citizens of Mexican blood has caused Texans to hasten to cultivate more friendly relations with its neighbor to the south.

ALGIERS, Feb. 12 -- The process of winning Cassino, the hub of the bent back Gustav Line, continues on an inch-by-inch basis. But the Germans still control all but the north sector of the town. The Abbey of Mount Cassino is also still in the hands of the Germans, who have used it as an observation post.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Bob Leder's field goal two seconds before the end gave Brooklyn College a 46-44 victory over Toledo in a nip-and-tuck basketball game tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Ranking Democratic and Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee, where tax legislation originates, promised today that the committee would give "immediate attention" to simplification of the tax structure.

THERE is always something slightly poignant about the growth of a boy into a man, or of a girl into a woman -- something poignant and strangely acute. Not that it isn't normal and natural; of course it is. A fine world we'd have if everybody just blithely refused to grow up!

When a woman designs clothes she is apt to do it for her own type, when a man creates fashions he does it for his ideal. Bruno Stehle -- in the business world he goes by the name of Bruno -- thinks in terms of the smart active woman whose life encompasses social and professional fields.

IN your radio news column of Jan. 30 I happened upon an item that I think should be corrected. You credit the new program "Theatre House" of W2XWV as starting a new era with television's first serial. This is wrong. Back in 1941-42, WPTZ, Philco's station in Philadelphia, under about the same experimental conditions as I understand the Dumont people are working under at present, did a weekly show called "Last Year's Nest."

THE past week's arrivals of new stamps include the series of six which the Royal Yugoslav Embassy in London had printed for use on ships of the Yugoslav Navy and mercantile marine beginning Dec. 1. Inscribed "1918 1 December 1943," the group marks the twenty-fifth anniversary of the "Union of Liberated Yugoslavia."

LENINGRAD, Feb. 10 (Delayed) -- Russian officials here estimated today that more than one-fifth of the city's buildings had been destroyed and thousands of others damaged by the more than 100,000 artillery shells and thousands of tons of bombs that had fallen in the city during the twenty-seven-month-long siege.

A bridge party, tea and special entertainment will comprise the afternoon's program tomorrow at the seventy-first St. Valentine's Kettledrum, which will be given at the Colony Club as the traditional annual benefit for the Samaritan Home for the Aged, one of the oldest institutions of its kind in the country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- In addition to the payment of cash for capital goods from the United States formerly obtained under lend-lease Great Britain, it is understood, will be asked to pay for fish from Iceland and sugar and molasses, which has also been imported under the same arrangement, from Caribbean countries.

YOUR discussion of renewed attempts to determine listener preferences fills me with considerable apprehension as to the potentialities inherent in such projects for reducing broadcasting activities to a general pattern in conformity with what will be found to be "the average level" of taste.

ALGIERS, Feb. 12 -- Three weeks ago this morning British and American troops of Gen. Mark Clark's combined Fifth Army carried out a conspicuously successful amphibious landing at Cape Anzio, thirty miles south of Rome. They achieved a complete tactical surprise, and it was hours before the first German shot was fired at the incredulous invaders, some of whom not unnaturally wondered, "Is the war over?"

ON and off the air, the radio industry has had quite a ten days, the most recent reports being to the effect that the vice presidents and the assistants to the vice presidents are in continuous executive session at Toots Shor's and Armand's.

Fifty pastors of Protestant churches in Manhattan will devote their entire sermon or part of it this morning to the work of the Boy Scouts as today is the thirty-fourth anniversary of the Boy Scouts of America.

Terming the union's refusal to give a no-strike pledge a "cool, calculated and clearly announced statement of short-sighted self-interest," the regional War Labor Board yesterday denied a maintenance of membership provision to 1,600 employes of the Tidewater Associated Oil Company of Bayonne, N.J., who are members of the Tidewater Employes Association, an independent union. The decision was unanimous.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 12 -- Argentina may declare war on the Axis within a few weeks at the most, according to reports circulating here. Although these reports, originating in Montevideo, Uruguay, have not progressed beyond the rumor stage and have received no official confirmation, they have gained wide credence.

Denouncing the recent anti-Semitic and kindred activities of boys in his school, Ralph W. Haller, principal of Andrew Jackson High School, Queens, announced yesterday that any student who participated in such activities in the future would not be graduated.
As a teacher of "movie appreciation" within the New York City schools, I turn to you with a plea for support.

Mayor La Guardia won the gratitude yesterday of Lieut. Charles R. Gallagher of the U.S. Navy and Alice May Carroll, both of Ventura, Calif., by making it possible for them to get a marriage license, although the marriage license bureau was closed because of the holiday.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 12 -- Johnny Revolta, the Evanston, Ill., professional whose forte is iron play, swept over Brackenridge course for a seven-under-par-64 today to take a five stroke lead at the half way mark in the 72-hole $5,000 Texas Open.

BRYAN HEXTALL of the Rangers and Hal Jackson of the Red Wings dropped their hockey sticks, peeled off their padded gloves and began exchanging punches in earnest. For a fight on ice it was a pretty brisk affair because, as often as not, there are more wild and ineffective swings launched in these impromptu hockey imbroglios than Beau Jack ever made in a dozen ring engagements.

CHAPLAIN MAGUIRE never shouted "Praise the Lord and pass the ammunition" that black Sunday at Pearl Harbor. For all that, his book is a a modest yet virile record of service to his God, his country and his men.

IT took two years to discover radium; it takes only a second to lose it. And radium has a way of getting lost. Used in infinitesimal amounts, enclosed in delicate needles of platinum or gold, or in tiny tubes, it is frequently overlooked in old dressings and bandages, is tossed into waste baskets, or is simply carelessly dropped and swept up.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 10 (Delayed) -- Thanks to the shrewdness and friendliness of Chinese Eighth Route Army guerrillas, Prof. William Band, formerly head of the Physics Department of Liverpool University, and his wife now are relaxing in Chungking after walking a thousand miles through Japanese-infested mountains.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- Sudden suspension of month-long secret talks between the Turkish General Staff and a British military mission was disclosed today.

The "old wives' tale" that the phases of the moon have a profound effect on living organisms may not be entirely fantastic after all, according to Dr. Harold S. Burr, Yale Professor of Anatomy, in The Yale Journal of Biology and Medicine. He describes preliminary experiments which apparently show a strong correlation between the activity of maple trees and the phases of the moon.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Bolivian Government announced today that the expropriation of all Axis firms had been decreed and declared the action was "of public necessity."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 12 -- Using fifteen players, including a sprinkling of sharpshooting freshmen, the Naval Academy basketball team today rolled over the West Virginia University players, winning, 67 to 49.

THE death of Robert Vivian recently prompts a moment's reflection on one of the longstanding weaknesses of our theatre. David Belasco called Mr. Vivian "the stage's best butler," and so now the newspapers rightly record that he was known to the public only in that role.

Dr. H.J. Corper of Denver, Col., has developed a new tuberculin test which makes it possible to diagnose tuberculosis within twelve to twenty-four hours. He applies the tuberculin with a transparent adhesive to the skin and watches the reaction. The tuberculin is described as a pure simple "autolytic" uncontaminated by the medium on which the tubercle bacilli are grown and in which all live bacilli are killed and removed.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -- Thirty-two underwriters will handle the $40,000,000 issue of 2 3/4 per cent sinking fund debentures, due 1964, of the Phillips Petroleum Company, an amendment filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission showed today.

The ambitious program for the expansion of sources of petroleum now under consideration by the United States and the British Governments for the Middle East, in conjunction with the oil companies operating there, is primarily for the post-war period.

Though Stephen Crane in "The Red Badge of Courage" and Erich Maria Remarque in "All Quiet on the Western Front," among other novelists, have described fear in battle, there was no scientific study of the subject until Drs. John Dollard and Neal E. Miller (Yale) came along.
