IT is only fair to post a warning, as do both the publisher and author of "How to Think About War and Peace," that here is a book that requires the reader to work almost as hard as did the man who wrote it. For it is a book that makes one think for himself, and think hard.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 12 -- By his speeches and conferences during his trip to the Middle West and the Northwest, which will last more than a week longer, Wendell L. Willkie has made it clear that he intends to make an all-out fight for the Republican nomination for President.

THE anniversary tea party of Zion Chapel in Swarebridge is brought to an abrupt end by the murder of Alderman Harbuttle, one of the pillars of Zion. Superintendent Nankivell of the local police is present at the time and takes immediate charge of the case, which proves to be anything but a simple one.

The work of the Catholic Big Sisters among maladjusted children of the city will be advanced through the annual card party and tea of the organization, which will be held on Feb. 21 at Sherry's. An entertainment committee for the benefit is under the chairmanship of Mrs. Kimball G. Colby, from whom tickets may be obtained at 825 Fifth Avenue.

The battle for Italy loomed large in the calculations of Allied strategists last week. Elsewhere in the world the forces of the United Nations were on the march. In the West the Red Army was hammering the Wehrmacht back in Russia, old Poland and Estonia. The air offensive against German cities and Nazi installations in conquered Europe was being pressed home relentlessly.

The names of the twelve Negroes and six white persons or institutions on the Honor Roll of Race Relations of 1943 have been announced by Dr. Lawrence D. Reddick, director of the Schomburg Collection of Negro Literature of the New York Public Library.

LONDON, Feb. 12 (U.P.) -- Appointment of two Foreign Office advisers to the British censorship office aroused concern among London correspondents today that censorship, which in theory applies only to matters of military security in wartime, might in fact extend beyond the hostilities to include political developments surrounding the peace negotiations.

IN Switzerland, best of European listening posts, people have come to the conclusion that the war is drawing to its end and in Geneva there is hope that this city is about to emerge from its eclipse into the full brilliance of international recognition.

ABOUT this time of year many gardeners begin dusting off the south window sill or rearranging the furniture on the sun porch in a rather peculiar way, which can mean only one thing -- the seed-sowing season is about to open.

Details of the deaths of three Japanese officers posthumously promoted to the rank of vice admiral were reported by the Japanese Domei Agency yesterday in English-language wireless dispatches transmitted to the Pacific zone and recorded by United States Government monitors.

On the war's widespread battle fronts, every device of science, every stratagem of warfare, every contrivance of human ingenuity is being employed to speed victory. Our armed forces are meeting the responsibilities of battle with vigor and resourcefulness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- In the last six months of 1943 the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practices adjusted 359 cases to comply with the Executive order directing it "to promote the fullest utilization of all available manpower, and to eliminate discriminatory employment practices." In all 989 cases were closed.

Speaking out on foreign policy, Governor Dewey last night told 1,400 leaders of his party, gathered in the Waldorf-Astoria at the Lincoln Birthday Dinner of the National Republican Club, that the people of the nation are "desperately anxious that we shall build well and strongly in international cooperation after this war."

The name of "Grandma" Moses has become familiar through a series of local shows. In the current exhibition at Galerie St. Etienne she makes her most impressive ap pearance thus far and we are told that her following is such that the show was practically a sellout before opening.

YOU never know the surname of the family who takes the reader right into the heart of Dutch life as it was lived before the war. You don't need to, because, as soon as you have straightened out the first names and the nicknames, you become a part of it, learning each one's personality and problems.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Senator Gerald Nye, Republican, of North Dakota, and Senator Bennett C. Clark, Democrat, of Missouri, had a lively discussion on the floor yesterday as to which might have to "swallow hard" in the coming Presidential campaign, and they agreed that both of them might find themselves in "a whale of a fix."

The name of "Grandma" Moses has become familiar through a series of local shows. In the current exhibition at Galerie St. Etienne she makes her most impressive ap pearance thus far and we are told that her following is such that the show was practically a sellout before opening.

YOU never know the surname of the family who takes the reader right into the heart of Dutch life as it was lived before the war. You don't need to, because, as soon as you have straightened out the first names and the nicknames, you become a part of it, learning each one's personality and problems.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- The budget hearing held before the joint fiscal committees of the Legislature Wednesday had as its feature a declaration by Senator Arthur H. Wicks, who was presiding, that the Legislature could do nothing about increasing the amount of State aid for education.

THE American music festival, now in its fifth season over WNYC, New York's municipal broadcaster, was begun as an experiment. The purpose was to make the annual festival not only an established institution in the city's musical life, but if possible a factor in the growth of American musical composition, performance and appreciation -a forum where anything from symphony to jazz might be presented regularly and heard by many.

One hundred and fifty thousand municipal employes have been organized under the chairmanship of Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses, to participate in the Red Cross 1944 War Fund, it was announced yesterday by John P. Stevens Jr., general chairman for New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- For the first time since Argentina's severance of relations with the Axis was hailed as an outstanding triumph for the Good-Neighbor policy in the Western Hemisphere, evidences are appearing here of a questioning note.

THE fascination felt by the weak for the strong, and the corruption of the best by the worst -- these are the themes of this original and brilliantly written study of evil. That evil here is conceived in the most trivial human terms rather than in the grand, tragic terms of great works inevitably reduces the scope of the novel but hardly its edge.

One hundred and fifty thousand municipal employes have been organized under the chairmanship of Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses, to participate in the Red Cross 1944 War Fund, it was announced yesterday by John P. Stevens Jr., general chairman for New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- For the first time since Argentina's severance of relations with the Axis was hailed as an outstanding triumph for the Good-Neighbor policy in the Western Hemisphere, evidences are appearing here of a questioning note.

THE fascination felt by the weak for the strong, and the corruption of the best by the worst -- these are the themes of this original and brilliantly written study of evil. That evil here is conceived in the most trivial human terms rather than in the grand, tragic terms of great works inevitably reduces the scope of the novel but hardly its edge.

The time is at hand to see what the spring is going to bring forth in the way of coats. As in the case of suits, the story is one of soft treatments. Even the severe redingote bows to the new order of the day and is cut with a scalloped front panel by one of New York's leading coat designers, Vincent Montesano.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Civilians are in for a 43 per cent cut in canned fruits and a 19 per cent cut in canned vegetables this year, an official of the War Food Administration told the food processors' convention today.

Babe Ruth, Jack Dempsey, Sid Luckman, Carl Hubbell, Earl Sande, Alice Marble, Eleanor Holm, Gene Sarazen, Sgt. Barney Ross, Greg Rice, Nat Holman and other notables of sport contributed last night to one of the most successful promotions for the sale of bonds during the current Fourth War Loan drive.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Increased costs to importers caused by changes in the rate of foreign exchange or from purchases of foreign exchange at a "free" rate rather than an "official" rate will not be recognized in the administration of the regulation establishing maximum prices for imported goods to be marketed here, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

Although the facts have been reported in dispatches from the fighting fronts, there has perhaps not been sufficient popular awareness of the terrific military force we have concentrated against the Marshall Islands, before that against the Gilberts, and in general against the isolated Pacific islands.

We are weary of hearing praise of the great production of war materials by the employes of our American factories. It would be much more interesting if we were permitted to hear of the greater quantities of material of which the production has been forbidden by the restrictions imposed by the labor unions.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The outcome of heavy fighting on the Arakan front in Burma, where the Japanese have slipped behind British positions, cannot be predicted, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters said in a communique today, but the battle has gone "not unfavorably for us."

Bishop William T. Manning, preaching yesterday morning at a confirmation service in the Episcopal Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy, 26 West Eighty-fourth Street, emphasized three principles that he said were necessary "if our religion is to be a reality to us."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 14 -- Soviet troops, in a new five-day advance in northern Russia, have captured more than 800 towns and settlements, including Luga, have occupied practically the entire east bank of Lake Peipus and driven the Germans back to within forty-three miles of Pskov, gateway to Latvia and southern Estonia, Moscow announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (U.P.) -- Old friends, fellow newspaper men and public officials paid tribute today to the memory of Raymond Clapper, who was killed in a plane crash Feb. 2 while covering the invasion of the Marshall Islands.

Having decided to inaugurate his tenancy of the Ziegfeld Theatre with a novel revue called "The Seven Lively Arts," Billy Rose has gone to the trouble and expense of recruiting outstanding craftsmen for his technical staff. Yesterday Mr. Rose announced he had signed George S. Kaufman to assemble, edit and direct the material; Hassard Short to stage and light the production; Lemuel Ayers to design the scenery and Raoul Pene du Bois the costumes.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Stormy weather interfered with the movement of cash corn last week and country offerings fell off considerably. However, transportation difficulties rather than weather conditions are blamed for the falling off in the receipts at terminal markets, and brokers express the belief that a large movement is likely to develop between now and the time farmers become busy with field work.
LONDON, Feb. 13 (U.P.) -- An Air Ministry communique:

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 13 (AP) -The Yugoslav Government in exile announced today that the congress of royalist factions held last month in the mountains of Yugoslavia had demanded post-war territorial expansion to include "all territories where Serbs, Croats and Slovenes live,"

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- From a heavily snow-banked shore there was a smart northerly breeze today that lasted long enough for the dinghy sailors at the Larchmont Yacht Club to hold two competitive sessions on smooth water that contrasted with the freezing shore line.

Wallace Stegner, novelist and short-story writer, has joined the staff of Look to prepare a series of pictorial articles dealing with minority group problems in the United States. From the proposed series Mr. Stegner and the editors of the magazine will prepare one of a set of projected "picture books" now planned by Look.

NEW RIVER, N.C., Feb. 13 -- Women marines have proved so versatile and adept in learning marine duties and freeing men to fight during the past year that they have greatly impressed the fighting men themselves, Lieut. Gen. A.A. Vandegrift, Marine Corps commandant, declared over the radio to 2,000 women marines celebrating their first anniversary here today at Camp Lejeune.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The blasting of German military targets along the northern coast of France went on on even larger scale today when strong formations of United States heavy and medium bombers escorted by swarms of American, British, Dominion and Allied fighters and supplemented by Royal Air Force fighter-bombers poured down one of the most concentrated bomb barrages of the war.

ALGIERS, Feb. 13 -- The Allies' armies in Italy seem to be coming closer to grips with the delicate and complex question of church property, long anticipated as one of the most difficult problems of the campaign.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 13 -- From somewhere in the jungles of north Burma, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell announced today the "largest and newest cargo carriers available" would soon start operating to China to supply a stepped-up air and land offensive against the Japanese.

A committee to study and remove the causes of racial and religious antagonisms in New York City will be named by Mayor La Guardia this week, he announced yesterday afternoon at the opening session in the Hotel Pennsylvania of the National Conference to Combat Anti-Semitism.

A plea for blood for our wounded fighting men was made yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York Archdiocesan Holy Name Union in the Cathedral High School, Fiftieth Street and Lexington Avenue. Support of the Fourth War Loan campaign was urged by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, while the seriousness of juvenile delinquency was stressed by other speakers.

It is a great misfortune for the Government, in its relations with the public, that as the income tax increases in amount the income tax return grows larger and more complex. There should have been some mitigating circumstance.

General Arnold commends Negro fliers with our forces in Italy, and praise is won by our Negro fighting men on the battlefronts. More slowly comes recognition of the value of the Negro worker here at home, where he and his fellows make up one-tenth of our total manpower.
A prediction made by Frank L'Verso, a 53-year-old laborer who died last Friday, came true in Brooklyn in the early hours of yesterday's snow-clogged morning amid bizarre circumstances.

Tonight's events: "Faust," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15 o'clock; concert of National Orchestral Association, Louis Kaufman, violin, and Frederick Williams, USNR, flute, assisting artists, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; piano recital, Nadia Reisenberg, Town Hall, 8:30; members' concert, Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, Hotel Plaza, Artur Rodzinski, conducting, 8:45; piano recital, Martha Pollak, Carnegie Music Hall, 8:30; war-bond concert by Arved Kurtz, violin, and Bruno Eisner, piano, Central Jewish Institute, 8:30.

The increasing number of women in war industries is creating a moral problem that the church cannot ignore and neither can the country "if it expects to continue the morally stable life which has made it great," the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, warned in his sermon yesterday.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Pvt. Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis, North American speed skating champion, made a clean sweep of all point-scoring events in his division to win the New York State senior men's speed skating title today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Slaughtering of hogs continues at capacity at meat-packing plants and, although the Government is shipping large quantities of lard and meats for lend-lease purposes, stocks of pork products continue to pile up and the available storage room is regarded as inadequate.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Although 1944 "will be the outstanding year in history and will see tremendous military events," the British people "have a hard, steep, bloody path to tread before the war is won, and must be prepared for tense efforts, heavy sacrifices and harsh surprises," Hugh Dalton, President of the Board of Trade, warned this afternoon in a speech at the Battersea Town Hall.

Several large group exhibitions in museums and galleries are among the art attractions opening this week. On Wednesday, the Metropolitan Museum will present to the public an exhibition of nineteenth-century paintings by Polish artists.

Helena Morsztyn, Polish pianist -- and Countess -- who was a pupil of Emil Sauer and a friend of Paderewski, gave another recital last night in Town Hall, where she was last heard in March a year ago. Her program was made up mostly of compositions by Schumann and Chopin, and there was a closing group by W.H. Kirby, Malipiero, Castelnuovo - Tedesco and Granados.

Every group in the war effort except one has been lauded for its patriotism, morale-building and bravery. This group, the Army and Navy wives, suffers as much, if not more, than any and plays an extremely important role.

The fourteenth week of the Metropolitan Opera season will have two first performances -- Wagner's "Siegfried" and Verdi's "Il Trovatore" -- on Tuesday night, Feb. 22, and Friday night, Feb. 25, respectively. Ella Flesch will sing her first Santuzza in "Cavalleria Rusticana" on Wednesday night.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, at Cassino, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Three American soldiers came down the rocky, shell-splintered trail from the hills above Cassino today and sputtered, almost in unison: "They ought to wipe that monastery off the hill."

Warning that our correctional system must be prepared "for the almost certain increase in crime following the war," the Prison Association of New York, in its ninety-ninth annual report, made public yesterday, urged the State Legislature to undertake a carefully planned review of the strong and weak points of the existing system.

THAT a large proportion of the human race is evil by nature and addicted to cruelty to others is so obvious a truth it is hardly necessary to consult the headlines of your daily paper for confirmation. Why this should be so is a problem that has puzzled theologians and philosophers and plain, bewildered men of good-will for millenniums.
The heavy Allied bombing attacks upon Germany have continued at a high level of intensity during the past six weeks, despite the poor visibility and wild weather of western Europe's winter.
LONDON, Feb. 13 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

No national basketball championship, mythical or otherwise, will be at stake tonight at Madison Square Garden, but when Notre Dame and New York University come to grips, the Eighth Avenue arena is likely to be filled to capacity.

BOSTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Detroit's flying Red Wings outskated and outsmarted the Bruins for an easy 4-1 triumph in a penalty-free National Hockey League game tonight before 13,000 at the Boston Garden. Connie Dion, the visitors' tiny goalie, held the home forces scoreless until late in the third period.

What the well-dressed woman wore a century or so ago and some of her household furnishings are shown in the exhibition, "Over One Hundred Years Old," which opened yesterday afternoon at the Newark Museum. Many of the articles have been traced back to early Newark families and craftsmen; some link up with New York City's past.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 112.55, a rise of 0.2 per cent from the previous week's level of 112.36. The farm products index increased 0.5 per cent as a result of the price increases in fruit, livestock and cotton.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Feb. 14 (U.P.) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- President Roosevelt sent congratulations to the Marine Corps Women's Reserve on its first anniversary today, and said each member could feel herself a part of the victories which American Marines have won over the Japanese in the Pacific.
Four new films are scheduled to open in Broadway houses this week. The schedule is:
ALGIERS, Feb. 13 (AP) -- A communique:

ROSWELL, N.M., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Hiram M. Dow, chairman of the National Conference of Petroleum Regulatory Authorities, took issue last night with a remark by President Roosevelt that the United States must now seek other petroleum sources.

After a week of furious fighting, watched with some anxiety in Allied lands, the tide of battle below Rome appears to be turning in our favor again. Both Prime Minister Churchill and General Clark have issued reassuring statements about the outcome. The first, granting that all battles are anxious as they approach the climax, nevertheless declared that there was no justification for pessimism.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 -- Diana Barrymore, who left here after completion of "Ladies Courageous" intending to devote herself to the stage, will return next week to do the remaining picture on her Universal contract. She will play a heavy in the Olsen and Johnson murder-mystery farce, "High Spirits."

Evidences that Finland is bending its efforts to get out of the fight and that Turkey is more than ever determined to keep out serve to emphasize an important and cheering change in the wide landscape of the war. At the moment the landscape is dark. The realization that for the Western allies the hardest battles are still to come is hammered home by the bitter fighting on the stony road to Rome.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Refreshed from a three-day rest in observance of Lincoln's Birthday, Congress will return to work this week to resume the fight over soldier voting legislation and with the prospect that the controversy over the Government's Latin-American policies will flare up again, this time in the House of Representatives.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Re-expansion in the circulation of currency, which many regarded as certain after the customary contraction in January, is now taking place. Last week's rise of 2,600,000 was virtually the same as that in the same week of last year, with the difference that it represents an increase on an increase, total circulation now being 162,000,000 higher than a year ago.

The two leading labor organizations of the country, the C.I.O. and A.F. of L., have now made it plain that they are no longer satisfied with the Administration's wage policy. They have made both a flank and a frontal attack upon it. The flank attack has consisted in challenging the accuracy of the Government's index on the cost of living.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Byron Nelson whipped through rain and mud to a par-breaking 68 today to move within one stroke of front-running Johnny Revolta in the battle for the 72-hole, $5,000 Texas open championship.

ON THE HUKAWNG VALLEY FRONT, North Burma, Feb. 10 (Delayed) -- Chinese troops now are firmly in control of the upper third of the Hukawng Valley, and most of the smaller Taro (or Dalu) Valley to the south. In three months of fighting in this area an American-trained and equipped Chinese force has defeated and driven back a good part of one Japanese division and advanced sixty airline miles into Burma.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The stock markets here have managed in the past week partially to shake off the inertia which has gripped them for some time. Just why business has revived moderately and why sentiments have improved is difficult to explain.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Heavy rain and snow in the last six weeks have brought about a marked change in the outlook for the 1944 winter wheat. Crop experts who returned last week from the Southwest report material improvement in the general situation, with sufficient moisture in some areas to carry the plant into May.
Drafting of women for the armed services has been approved by the directors of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women, Dr. Minnie L. Maffett, the president, reported yesterday.
President New York State Industrial Union Council, CIO, Member War Finance Committee for New York

Men and women who have entered the armed services receive special consideration from Uncle Sam when it comes to income taxes this year. More than 95 per cent who were compelled to pay a tax on 1942 income will find their tax liability eliminated under the new tax law.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Price increases ranging from $2 to $10 a ton on four major grades of wood pulp to give producers an additional $12,500,000 a year were announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

The 55,000 Boy Scouts of New York yesterday marked the thirty-fourth anniversary of their organization with special church services, at many of which chaplains who have undergone battle experience delivered messages to the youths.

The proprietor of an unpretentious shop on the East Side has a talent for tracking down unusual, hard-to-find foods. That doesn't mean that at the drop of a hat he will get you a thick, juicy steak or six pounds of butter; on the contrary, he deals in no rationed commodities.

Sal Bartolo of Boston, one of the foremost contenders for the featherweight championship of the world, will meet Frankie Rubino of Williamsburg in the ten-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena tonight. The Infantile Paralysis Fund will receive part of the proceeds of the show.

In connection with the reports of the spoilage of about a hundred tons of butter through failure of the War Food Administration to release it for general use, another news item was, I think, of contrasting interest. This was the account of discussions in the House of Commons, at Ottawa, looking toward the elimination of meat rationing in Canada.

CHUNGKING, Feb. 13 (U.P.) -American fighters and bombers blasted Japanese airdromes, ships and railway installations over a wide area of occupied China and Indo-China on Friday and Saturday, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stillwell's headquarters announced today.

France Forever, Inc., called yesterday on the Governments of the United Nations to supply arms and ammunition to the underground movements of all countries invaded by the Axis. In closing a two-day convention at the Waldorf-Astoria, delegates adopted this resolution:

Acme Decorators, Inc., purchased from the Mutual Life Insurance Company the five-story limestone building at 14 East Sixty-second Street, formerly the Culbertson Club, for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $20,000. The property, which is 25 by 100.5 feet, is assessed at $95,000 and was sold through John J. Blesch, broker.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 13 -- Wendell L. Willkie, who announced three weeks ago that he would not enter the California Presidential preference primary, flew 500 miles from Portland today to have luncheon and "a social visit" with Governor Earl Warren, who will head a delegate slate on the May ballot as a nominal candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.

The Kroger Grocery and Baking Company had net income of $5,009,228 in 1943, equal after preferred dividends to $2.72 a common share, comparing with $4,649,484, or $2.63 a share, earned in 1942, it was announced yesterday by C.M. Robertson, president.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 13 -- A step-up in raw steel output and a heavy volume of new bookings continued last week to reflect a high level of activity in preparation for the invasion of German-occupied Europe. While material for shipbuilding, landing craft and landing mats was in greatest demand, the volume of orders for other war components remained at recent levels.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The office of President Rafael Calderon Guardia announced tonight that early returns in today's Presidential election favored Teodoro Picado, candidate endorsed by the party of the incumbent, who is forbidden to succeed himself.

DES MOINES, IA. -- Ninety-four per cent of Iowa's citizens favor a soldier bonus, THE IOWA POLL found in its current scientific survey of sentiment in a state with 250,000 men and women in the armed services.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Feb. 14 (U.P.) -- The complete bomber arsenal from United States bases in the Solomons was used Friday in a new concentrated attack on the Japanese base of Rabaul, New Britain, as the Allied campaign to destroy completely the once-powerful enemy bastion apparently neared a successful conclusion, it was disclosed today.
ALGIERS, Feb. 13 -- The fighting on the beachhead below Rome flared to a white heat yesterday at a factory a half mile east of Aprilia.

Urging State legislation for enforcement of Federal price ceilings by local authorities, the American Labor party gave credit yesterday to New York City for having used its municipal facilities in the drive against black markets.

LONDON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Turkish radio, evidently referring to the suspension of talks between the Turkish General Staff and a British military mission, quoted the newspaper Aksham today as questioning whether the Allies had provided the amount of arms promised Turkey.

LENINGRAD, Feb. 11 (Delayed) -- Peter Popkoff, President of the Leningrad Soviet, said tonight that total casualties among the civilians from enemy action during the twenty-nine months Leningrad was subjected to artillery shells and aerial bombs numbered 20,000, of whom 5,000 were killed -- an average of fewer than six deaths a day -- and indicated that deaths from starvation during the blockade ran higher.

Cotton prices in the domestic market continued to move upward last week, with spot values at the ten Southern markets reaching the highest level recorded since last July. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the week of 13 to 21 points.
LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Three important new military appointments were announced today by the British War Office.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 12 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Five wounded marine veterans of the Marshall Islands invasion said today that they and their comrades had laughed and sung the marine hymn as they stormed the beach at Namur Island.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 13 -- Three of Finland's leaders, headed by Dr. Juho K. Paasikivi, "the ambassador of peace," were in Stockholm tonight and the world watched for a concrete sign whether Helsinki was moving to an understanding with Moscow.
LONDON, Monday Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Russian Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Every patriotic American would be deeply disturbed if the Fourth War Loan were to fall short of complete success. He would not like to think of the inflationary methods to which we might be driven to pay for the war. He would not like to think of the glee with which such news would be broadcast by the propagandists of Berlin and Tokyo.

ALGIERS, Feb. 13 -- Anyone who expected a lot of lah-de-dah, girlish giggles and a pink cheek atmosphere at the first Wac basketball game in the history of North Africa tonight was in for an exciting awakening.

A split within the Lawyers Committee on Selection of Judges of the First Judicial District came into the open yesterday when former Magistrate Edward C. Maguire, a member, took issue with the majority recommendation that the electorate of any judicial district be permitted to use a modification of the Missouri system of appointment-plus-election in choosing the justices of its constitutional courts.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Establishment of a State-supported and controlled School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell University has been agreed upon, it was disclosed today. The institution will be the first of its kind in the country and will have for its declared purposes a better understanding of industrial and labor relations and a better and more responsible labor and industrial leadership.

In his second recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night, Yehudi Menuhin showed once more how successfully he has made the difficult transition from child prodigy to mature artist. His playing was somewhat uneven, but the intelligent musicianship and sureness of approach bore the touch of the finished performer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (U.P.) -- Joseph W. Martin Jr., House Republican leader, challenged President Roosevelt tonight to make the fight between States' rights and Federal soldier vote advocates an issue in the Presidential campaign. Senate and House conferees are now trying to work out a compromise on differing versions passed by the two houses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Intergration of the victory tax with the regular normal Income tax and surtax and graduation of the withholding tax to collect the exact amount on individual salaries each pay day was advocated today by Representative Disney, Democrat, of Oklahoma, as a simplification move.

A famous champion, in top condition and beautifully shown, gained the highest honors last evening in the thirty-second annual specialty fixture of the Boston Terrier Club of New York at the Pennsylvania Hotel.
Conditions at Cabanatuan prison camp, in the Luzon Island province of Nuevo Ecija, finally brought about two hours so bloody they could be believed only by one who had seen them.

The Arts Council of Japanese-Americans for Democracy, 240 Faith Avenue, through its chairman, Yasuo Kuniyoshi, issued yesterday a public denunciation of "the brutal and depraved act of the Japanese Fascists against every human decency."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation indicated tonight it is ready to make, or guarantee immediate loans to speed the industrial transition from war to peace. It stressed, however, that the program will be in cooperation with private financing.

The League of Composers gave its second program of the season at the Public Library yesterday afternoon. Maria Maximovitch, soprano, was unable to be present. Janet Fairbank and Ethel Luening, substituting, sang numbers by modern American composers.
CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 13 (AP) -- A United States Air Force communique:

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY AT CASSINO, Feb. 13 -- The blood-draining battle for Cassino concluded its twelfth day of street fighting today with American troops in possession of probably only one-fifth of the town. They are still battering away, despite their fatigue, and repulsing strong counter-attacks preceded by heavy shelling.

Current proposals for the Federal support of education, of students and of scientific research and libraries offer a danger of the post-war regimentation of American colleges, Dr. Walter A. Jessup, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, declared in the thirty-eighth annual report of the foundation, made public yesterday.

ABOARD A FRENCH CRUISER, In the Mediterranean, Feb. 10 (Delayed) -- When a fresh supply of American-made brass tubes to be fed to the guns had been stowed in their places aboard this warship, a boat came out from shore with orders to move to a port then known only to the captain.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- The Regional War Labor Board announced today the curtailment of the union privileges of about 900 employes of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, who participated in a two-day work stoppage last November after contending they were "to ill to work."

LONDON, Feb. 13 (Canadian Press) -- A Canadian Army team that sparkled with talent outkicked and outpassed the American Army Pirates and surged to a convincing 16-6 football victory before a roaring crowd of more than 30,000 at White City Stadium today.

BOSTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- As a reward for running the fastest indoor mile in Boston's track history -- a 4:09.5 performance in the Boston A.A.'s famed Hunter event -- Divinity Student Gil Dodds today received the John J. Hallahan Memorial Trophy.

A TRANSIT CAMP NEAR ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Feb. 12 (Delayed) (UP) -- Five escaped Russian war prisoners, who never expected to emerge from their living death under the Germans, reported today that hundreds of thousands of Russians had died of disease and starvation in German prison camps.

A third-period surge that netted them three goals enabled the Boston Olympics to conquer the New York Rovers in the Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The underdog local skaters led their foes early in the final session, but were unable to hold their advantage and were forced to bow to their league-leading rivals by the score of 4 to 2.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 -- News of the death in India of Miss Margaret Woodrow Wilson, eldest of the former President's three daughters, was received today by cable by her sister, Mrs. Eleanor Wilson. McAdoo of West Los Angeles.

MOSCOW, Feb. 13 -- The Germans had set their hopes on retaining Luga and Batetskaya, for after the collapse of the Siverski line along the middle course of the Luga River, their Batetskaya-Luga-Pskov railroad lines had provided the most defensible position on the Leningrad front before falling back on their great base of Pskov.

Mayor La Guardia devoted his entire radio broadcast from City Hall yesterday to a Lincoln Day program. In it he strongly hinted that many present-day officeholders who profess to believe in the Civil War President's philosophy of government were denying one of his principles by assailing the concentration of power in the Federal Government.
MEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 13 -- Charlotte E. Taylor of Upper Montclair, N.J., will receive on Feb. 19 the first degree ever awarded to a woman student by the Tufts School of Engineering.

Beginning the week with a further decline, the stock market recovered later, nearly regaining the losses in price earlier in the month. In particular, Thursday's advance in the railway share average nearly regained the best figure of 1943.

EAST ROCKAWAY, L.I., Feb. 13 -- The family of Lieut. Edmund J. Torpey of the Army Air Forces, former member of the football squad at the Catholic University of America in Washington, were notified here today that he was reported missing in action on Jan. 30 over Germany.

UVALDE, Tex., Feb. 13 -- James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman and Postmaster General during President Roosevelt's first two terms, after a conference with John N. Garner today at the latter's home said:...

The Long Island Lighting Company announced yesterday plans for a comprehensive revision of its capital structure. The purpose, it was announced, is to provide for possible increased depreciation reserves and to facilitate the resumption of dividend payments on the company's outstanding preferred stocks, on which arrears totaled $9,188,431 at the end of 1943.

American industry has accepted the challenge presented by the problem of rehabilitation and training for disabled and medically discharged veterans of the war. Robert M. Gaylord, newly elected president of the National Association of Manufacturers, has made it clear that that organization, which speaks for 80 per cent of American war production, acknowledges its responsibility for rehabilitating all those veterans who want to work and are able to receive training.

Observance yesterday of the twenty-second annual Race Relations Sunday, sponsored by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, brought the reminder from President Roosevelt that the unity of the nations fighting for a free world "includes men of every color and race."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- A soldier's wife has taken up with the War Department her husband's campaign to put down his pen and take up a sword. Without disclosing names, the department released today the contents of the wife's letter.

LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 13 (AP) -- The United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, AFL, representing 600,000 workers, adopted today a statement on the coming campaign and described the New Deal as "incapable" and led by "visionaries."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 -- Alien Chinese may now legally purchase real estate in California after being denied the right to do so for twenty-four years, according to an article in the forthcoming issue of the Journal of the State Bar of California.

A preliminary off-the-record conference of representatives of nearly every economic interest in the nation will meet at Atlantic City Friday and Saturday to explore the possibility of a common post-war program, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers which has called the meeting.

As the Fourth War Loan drive approached its end -- the deadline is tomorrow night -- the War Finance Committee estimated yesterday that 3,540,000 individuals already had purchased bonds and predicted that when all New York State subscriptions are counted the total of individual purchasers would be increased to 4,500,000 and might possibly reach the committee's goal of 5,000,000 subscribers in the State.

The Japanese plan to plunder Thailand of her food supplies and raw materials has been frustrated to a great extent because "they have no ships" to move the spoils, Mani Sanasen, secretary of the Thai Legation at Washington, said yesterday on his arrival at La Guardia Field.

Strong activities were reported in the wholesale markets last week with many buyers in town. Delivery complaints were heard in many instances, taking in both staple and novelty lines, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

In your constructive comments on the tax bill just passed you refer to "excess spending power" and the need for controlling it. Many people regard such a control program as punitive, and the resentment they feel toward it is reflected in the Congress' failure to apply the sound principles so courageously expressed by Mr. Willkie and supported by THE TIMES.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 13 (U.P.) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

Faced with a two-goal deficit in the first period the Toronto Maple Leafs thought nothing of it. They were playing the New York Rangers and they were certain that it would not be long before they would have their rivals' margin erased.

Heavy snow on the ground may have saved the lives of two women employes of the Unexcelled Manufacturing Company, Inc., at 1208 Richmond Avenue, Graniteville, S.I., yesterday after they had been rescued in a fire that destroyed one building and threatened a score of others.

The action of the War Food Administration in providing a support price program for the 1944 pack of food canners at 90 per cent of their net civilian ceilings, while insuring production this year at peak levels, is likely to inhibit further the movement of goods into distributive channels, it was asserted among food traders here yesterday.

A few days ago a National War Labor Board majority consisting of labor and industry members authorized wage increases for truck drivers in St. Louis which exceeded the "Little Steel" formula. The decision was based on the belief of the industry and labor members that "rare and unusual" circumstances justified the increase.

There are few Japanese in the Pacific fighting areas who do not believe that they are the equal of at least five Americans and who won't act on that assumption, Comdr. Gene Tunney, back from a tour of duty in the South and Southwest Pacific, reported yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Lieut. Gertrude Dawson told today of the escape of herself and thirteen other Army nurses, thirteen enlisted men and four crew members of a plane forced down in the German-held Balkans, but for military reasons she omitted the details.

Declaring that the Atlas Corporation had "one of the largest pools of risk or venture capital in this country," Floyd B. Odlum, the president, said yesterday in the annual report to stockholders that the company was ready to participate in "reconstruction, reconversion and development both at home and abroad" in the post-war period if restrictive laws were changed sufficiently to warrant such use of the capital.

When Putnam County passed its $450,000 Fourth War Loan goal over the week-end, a large share of the credit went to Mrs. Faith Dale Voegeli, 21-year-old resident of Cold Spring, N.Y., and youngest War Finance Committee vice chairman in the State.

NAMUR, Kwajalein Atoll, Marshall Islands, Feb. 3 (Delayed) -- A United States postoffice was set up and doing business on this islet yesterday less than twenty-four hours after marines had landed. Today 5,000 letters were packed aboard a Navy plane that left for the States.

CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 14 (AP) -- British and Indian troops were viciously paring down today a Japanese force estimated at 2,000 that counter-attacked on the Arakan front north of Akyab, Burma, ten days ago, filtered through Allied lines and since has been fighting almost constant hand-to-hand skirmishes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 9, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

The preliminary report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation for 1943, released yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $10,894,427, after operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 36 cents a share on the corporation's outstanding common stock, and compares with $10,652,756, or 34 cents a share, in 1942.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Umboi (or Rooke) Island, which sits squarely in the center of Vitiaz Strait between New Guinea and New Britain, was occupied Saturday by American forces, who met no opposition, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

I hope you will allow me to comment on your editorial of this date and to the letter to which it refers, published in the same issue, from Corp. Bernard Bellush on the subject of the Federal ballot plan to enable men in the services abroad to vote in the coming election.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, at Cassino, Feb. 14 -- For almost two weeks house-to-house fighting has been going on in what was once the placid stone-built mountain town of Cassino.

Through Friday, a net total of 20,522 1/2 shares of American Distilling Company had been stamped to indicate the holder had deposited a cheek and issued a buying order for the sixteen cases of whisky which each share is entitled to acquire, which appears more than adequate to cover stock market transactions in the stamped shares to date.

If a will made by the late Sidonia Dach, spinster, is admitted to probate in Queens, as many refugees from Germany as can be accommodated at her 7-room home at 101-44 115th Street, Richmond Hill, will be enabled to stay there free for indefinite periods.

Former Judge alfred J. Talley, counsel for Patrolman James L. Drew, in a brief filed yesterday with Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr. urged the court to dismiss a taxpayer's suit to oust Drew from the police force. He declared that "the private interests that have fostered and fomented this prosecution have had their day in court."

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Feb. 14 -- A buyers' strike throughout the East has tied up the sale of rice and barley sizes of anthracite, clogging railroads and menacing the movement of larger sizes used in households and buildings, it was stated here today.

Who can help admiring that sergeant's wife who complains to the bigwigs at Washington that her husband, six feet high and weighing 190 pounds, is chained to a desk while he longs all the time to get into the fighting? The soldier dissatisfied with his billet is common in all wars.

" TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 14 -Awaiting the reports of the committees on revision of the State Constitution, reorganization of the State's scores of departments into a streamlined setup of not more than twenty, and provision for absentee voting by persons in military service, the Legislature sat for less than ninety minutes today and then recessed until next Monday afternoon.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 14 -- Teodoro Picado, president of the Costa Rican Congress and candidate of the National Republican party, was elected President of Costa Rica today, succeeding Rafael Angel Calderon Guardia.

Because of labor's no-strike pledge for the duration of the war, 8,000 members of the International Fur and Leather Workers Union voted last night at a meeting in Manhattan Center to submit their dispute with the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers Association to the War Labor Board.
LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

A loan exhibition made up of sixty-one nineteenth-century Polish paintings has been installed in Gallery D 8, on the main floor, at the Metropolitan Museum. It opens with a private view from 4 to 6 this afternoon and beginning tomorrow may be viewed by the public through March 19.

Charged with violating Office of Price Administration regulations by selling foods at more than ceiling prices, 284 men and women appeared yesterday in Municipal Term Court before Magistrate Harry G. Andrews, who fined those pleading guilty from $10 to $25 each.

In a sudden reversal of roles Mrs. Edna Hancock, former employe of Brooklyn State Hospital, who had accused Murray Goldman of attempting to rape her in her room at the hospital dormitory last July 1, was arrested yesterday on a charge of perjury and the indictment against Goldman was dismissed.

A triumphal parade of housewives of the Mosholu area of the Bronx, including mothers pushing baby carriages, was held yesterday on Jerome Avenue in celebration of the success of a six-month campaign to force food dealers of the neighborhood to comply with ceiling prices and other regulations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Larger supplies of bed sheeting in the lower-price lines will be made available for civilians as the result of action taken by the War Production Board today, officials of the war agency predicted, WPB directed producers of bed linens to produce the same quantity of bedsheets and sheeting to step production up to the peak levels reached in the first quarter of 1942.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Members of Congress from wool I States fearing a huge stock pile [of the fiber on the American growers' market, were told today by Secretary of Commerce Jesse H. Jones that conferences would be held among Federal agencies concerned to see how the surplus sup-I plies could best be liquidated.

Steel output this week is scheduled at 97.7 per cent of revised capacity, compared with a revised rate of 97.2 per cent last week, and making a new high for 1944 on the new capacity basis, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Two new developments in the Russo-Polish dispute were made known today. Prime Minister Churchill has had another conversation with Premier Stanislaw Mikolajezyk of the Polish Government-in-Exile here, and the Polish Cabinet has asked the underground leaders inside Poland for authority to enter into boundary discussions with the Soviet Union.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Robert R.M. Carpenter Jr. 28-year-old president of the Phillies, became the first major league club president to be accepted for Army service today when he passed his physical examination at the Camden Armory.

The total for the city's general fund for the fiscal year 1944-45 will be $164,529,930, including a carry-over of more than $5,600,000 from collections for the current year, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick estimated in a report made public yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 14 -- J.P. Morgan's heirs are considering razing the forty-one-room mansion on his East Island estate, it was learned today after disclosure that they had served court writs on Nassau County, directing it show cause why the estate's 1944 valuation of $870,152 should not be reduced to $406,698.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -Counsel for Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Emanuel Weiss and Louis Capone, now in Sing Sing's death cell awaiting execution for the murder of Joseph Rosen, a Brooklyn candy store owner, in /936, asked judges of the Court of Appeals today to consider new evidence if they grant a re-argument of the appeal which the defense is seeking.

Notre Dame had the drive, the height and the spirit, each an important asset, in its annual Madison Square Garden basketball game with New York University last night, and all helped bring the Irish a 59-53 triumph over the Violets.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- A ration point program aimed to support capacity production by food processors and plans for an emergency labor force to assist farmers and food processors were disclosed today by Government officials at a conference with food processors.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES CRUISER, Off Italy, Feb. 9 (Delayed) -- Ignoring a 50-knot gale and the shells of German railway guns bracketing her, this ship steamed in to the coast north of Anzio several times today, pouring tons of shells on enemy shore positions.

The immediate reaction to the reports of the terrible treatment of American prisoners by the Japanese appears to have been one of general horror, rage and desire for retaliation; and too many would have it retaliation "in kind," with needless killing and brutality.

The proposed sale of 75 per cent of the Brooklyn Baseball Club to Max C. Meyer, jewelry manufacturer, and several associates, ran into an insurmountable obstacle yesterday and the Dodgers will remain under their present ownership indefinitely.

The fully rented sixteen-story apartment house on a plot 72.6 by 100 feet at 9-11 East Ninety-sixth Street, near Fifth Avenue, has been purchased by Frederick Brown, operator, from the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company through Thomas Moran, broker. This property contains forty-eight suites and has an annual rent roll of about $72,000. It is assessed for $540,000.

In a letter to the faculty warning against dissemination of subversive doctrines, race prejudices and Communist propaganda through the classroom, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, declared yesterday that he would bring charges against any staff member accused of such practices.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 14 -- Immediately after his return by airplane from California this afternoon Wendell L. Willkie announced the selection of Ralph H. Cake, Republican National Committeeman from Oregon, as his pre-convention campaign manager, and smilingly admitted to a group of reporters that this might be taken as formal announcement of his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination.

Dimitri Shostakovich's new Eighth symphony, which is said to depict phases of the present war, will have its Western Hemisphere premiere by the Philharmonic-Symphony on April 2, it was announced yesterday. The symphony, which will be conducted by Artur Rodzinski, the Philharmonic's musical director, will be broadcast over the Columbia Broadcasting System network from 3 P.M. to 4 P.M., Eastern war time, as one of the regular Sunday afternoon broadcasts by the orchestra.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Though almost five months must elapse before the Democrats are to meet at Chicago to select their national ticket and platform for the 1944 campaign, it is taken for granted that every part of the program is prearranged except the choice of the candidate for Vice President.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. Feb. 14 -- Revision of the State settlement law to keep migrants from becoming permanent relief charges of this State after only one year of residence was asked of the Legislature today by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Army had distributed 126,525 decorations among 7,500,000 men up to Jan. 1, while the Navy had awarded 7,073 medals to its 2,800,000 personnel.

Sales of New Fork and Brooklyn department stores declined 17 per cent last week in comparison i with th like period a year ago, i the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reDorted yesterday. The heavy decrease was due: to com/parison with the care buying of the corresponding veek last year, and the snow storm on Friday which cut down week-end volume.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Wayne Chatfield-Taylor, Under Secretary of Commerce, advised Government and business tonight to get together immediately on plans to take full advantage of post-war opportunities in world trade.

The preliminary report of the Union Bag and Paper Corporation for 1943, issued for publication today, shows a profit for the eleventh consecutive year. However, owing to wartime handicaps, an increase in sales failed to produce a corresponding gain in net, according to Alexander Calder, president.

Beginning next month R.H. Macy Co., Inc., will launch an intensive advertising campaign in trade papers on behalf of its new plan to distribute drug items of its subsidiary, Supremacy Products, Inc., on a national scale through selected retail drug outlets.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 14 -- Our assaults on the Marshall Islands have been resumed by a strong carrier force that struck heavily for three successive days at Eniwetok Atoll, staging base to the Marshalls from Truk. And while these blows were falling near the Caroline Islands, other carrier units, Seventh Army Air Force warplanes and Navy search planes blasted six scattered atolls, including Ujelang, also lying near the seat of Japanese Pacific power.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Feb. 15 (UP) -- A communique:

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Virtually final agreement has been reached on settling the controversial question of extension of the ten-year-old mortgage moratorium, and the rate of amortization to be fixed in it for payments on the principal amount of the mortgages affected.

From the report of Dr. Reginald Watson-Jones in The Bulletin of War Medicine and from various articles which have appeared in The Lancet in the latter half of 1943 a picture of Soviet wartime medicine and surgery emerges which testifies to the efficiency of a remarkable organization.

With the establishment on pre-war Polish soil of a Polish "National Council" sponsored by the Russian Government, the problem of Poland has now moved well beyond the old question of frontiers. It has become a more fundamental question of who is to speak for the Polish people in any revision of the frontiers.

Continuance of Regulation W in the post-war period was strongly opposed yesterday by several speakers at the joint Northeastern and Mid-Atlantic Credit and Collection Conference at the Hotel New Yorker. They urged supplanting of the Government restriction on retail credit by self-regulation to insure maintenance of a free economy and sound utilization of credit to buttress consumer demand when hostilities cease.
YORK, Pa., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Two new franchises, enough to form eventually an eight-team loop, were granted today by the Class B Interstate Baseball League at its annual meeting here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- To assist American war correspondents in working out coverage of the European invasion with Army and Navy officials, George H. Lyon, deputy director of the Office of War Information, has gone to London, OWI reported today.

Sal Bartolo, 129 3/4, Boston, won an easy ten-round decision over Frankie Rubino, 129 1/2, Brooklyn, in the feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. A crowd of 2,700 witnessed the program, which was held for the benefit of the Infantile Paralysis Fund.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- While there can be no immediate large-scale resumption of the manufacture of civilian goods, the War Production Board is looking forward to the day when war demands decline, and hopes to be able to ease the transition from a war to a peace-time economy, Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, said today.

In an intensified drive to keep girls of the early 'teen ages off the city streets at night and to reduce an alarming increase in the number of 13 to 15-year-old girls reported missing, the Missing Persons Bureau at Police Headquarters announced yesterday that a new working schedule had been put into effect for the thirty-eight detectives and nine policewomen of the bureau.

BETHEL, Conn., Feb. 14 -- Residents of this town who started out last summer to meet the wartime meat shortage by raising their own cattle and have since been beset by myriad difficulties, were convinced today that the project was jinxed when they learned that 7,332 pounds of beef, outcome of the experiment, had spoiled in the community freezing plant.

The help of the Federal Government in the fight against racial and religious discrimination was pledged by Assistant United States Attorney General Norman M. Littell in an address last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania at a dinner meeting that closed the two-day National Conference to Combat Anti-Semitism.

The egg market is in turmoil these days, for supplies are pouring into town and consumer demand is decidedly small. This lack of demand has prevailed during the last month or more, according to a spokesman for a Manhattan company that independently reports on the trade, and it is believed to be caused by the general availability of meat.

WITH THE JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FORCES, in the Marshall Islands (Delayed) -- United States Marines, traditionally the first to fight, not only launched a major assault in the Marshall Islands but became the first to administer military government provisions set up for the first Japanese Empire possessions to be conquered in the Pacific war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Congressional supporters of the Green-Lucas Service Men's Voting Bill looked today to two Republican conferees, representing the House, as possibly their best hope for a breaking of the deadlock between the Senate and House over the proposed Federal and State ballot programs.

The Gilbert and Sullivan Opera Company, now stationed at the Ambassador, last evening swung into the first of the double bills "Trial by Jury" and "H.M.S. Pinafore." To come right out with it the troupe did very badly indeed by the first of the pair and somewhat better with the second; neither was up to "The Mikado," with which the season opened last Friday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Senator Harry S. Truman, Democrat of Missouri, chairman of the Senate Investigating Committee bearing his name, charged tonight that some Republican leaders were taking advantage of the Administration's policy of bringing mistakes "out in the open so they can be speedily corrected."

A soldier, a sailor and a trusted minor employe of an automobile concern were arraigned yesterday in General Sessions on a twenty-nine-count indictment charging conspiracy to defraud six persons, including a widow and a Harlem night-club bartender, of $26,000, and the attempted theft of $91,000 from the Block International Corporation at 101 West Thirty-first Street.

Herbert Thompson, national champion: Ed. Conwell of N.Y.U., Eulace Peacock of the Coast Guard and Bill Craig of the Army are the stars who have been seeded in preliminary heats of the 60-yard dash to be held in the seventy-fifth anniversary indoor track meet of the New York Athletic Club at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night.

Twenty-two coal dealers, including the major yards of New York City, have made commitments to supply the city's emergency coal dumps for the remainder of the winter, it was announced last night by Brig. Gen. Brice P. Disque, retired, president of the Coal Consumers Protective Association.
MOSCOW, Feb. 14 -- Details of the Red Army's progress along the entire front are being furnished by frontline dispatches to the Soviet press.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Confirming the general knowledge that civilians are becoming fewer, the Bureau of the Census reported today that the civilian population of the United States declined 4,021,220 persons between April, 1940, and last Nov. 1.

A new issue of $15,000,000 of electric plant and refunding revenue bonds was announced yesterday by the Los Angeles, Calif., Department of Water and Power for award on Feb. 24. The issue will be dated Feb. 1, 1944, and will mature serially from Feb. 1, 1945 to 1976, and will be callable on various dates. Bidders are to name the rate of interest.

Fred C. Moffatt, president pro tem of the New York Curb Exchange since July 1, 1942, was reelected yesterday chairman of the board of governors for one year. He has been a member of the Exchange since 1923 and served as president from 1935 to 1939.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt, one of the most respected and brilliant of German generals, pledged today the stoutest possible resistance to an invasion in the west and outlined the measures that would be taken to turn back the Anglo-American armies.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- A warning that psychiatric casualties among fighting men "start right back here in the home territory," and a prediction that medicine based on pills and potions is becoming obsolete were expressed today at the opening session of the annual Congress on Medical Education and Licenses.

Thanks to the valor and determination of the American and British soldier the immediate danger to the Allied beachhead at Anzio appears to have passed. With the return of weather which permits the resumption of air operations the Allies have renewed their offensive.

Bill Dickey, the "Arkansas Traveler," who roomed with Lou Gehrig when the colorful first baseman played for the Yankees, displayed how high sentiment can run in baseball yesterday when he virtually clinched first place for his former team-mate in the Fourth War Loan Sports Popularity Poll.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 14 -- Adroit and Charitable were the winners of the two divisions of the Vista Del Mar purse here at Hialeah this afternoon as the Miami Jockey Club began its last three weeks of the long meeting. The attendance was as high as 9,435, compared with 1942's 10,814, and the wagering ran to $867,950 as against $551,298 two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Personal mail service to Sicily and that part of southern Italy occupied by the Allies will be restored tomorrow or soon thereafter, according to a letter from Maj. Gen. Edwin M. Watson in reply to a plea addressed to President Roosevelt by Representative Vito Marcantonio of New York.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 15 -- The Times of London devoted a column and a half today to its leading editorial, which reviews the importance of American financial and trade policies to the post-war world. The peg on which this discussion is hung is the study recently published by the United States Department of Commerce on international transactions by the United States from the last war to this one.

ALGIERS, Feb. 14 (AP) -- An uproar over a referee's decision marked the opening day of a week-long Allied boxing tourney to determine the North Africa championships in sixteen classes, amateur and professional.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Feb. 14 (AP) -- After two years of combat against the Japanese, the Southwest Pacific has seventy-two fighter aces whose combined bag of enemy planes totals 554, the Fifth Air Force headquarters said today.

A "small fry" fashion show was given yesterday under the auspices of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, 457 Madison Avenue, when twenty-five children of French parentage showed their love for the children of France on St. Valentine's Day by modeling clothes made in the thirdfloor workroom of the Comite des Dames Patronesses, under Mrs. Jean-Pierre Millon.

The State of New York, through Governor Dewey and the Legislature, invested $25,000,000 of its $148,000,000 surplus in War Bonds last night on the eve of the close of the Fourth War Loan Drive. The drive officially ends tonight at midnight.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 14 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The well-known La Guardia gift for epigram was at its best the other day when the Mayor expressed his appreciation of what Deputy Sanitation Commissioner Good Weather has done in meeting the snow-removal problem.
Deputy Police Inspector William M. Kent was sworn in yesterday as Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall. Mr. Kent succeeded John Morris, who is in the armed services.

Large-scale buying operations and renewed price fixing, partially because of expected Government purchases of 332,000 bales of raw cotton in the open market for lend-lease shipments, produced yesterday an improved tone in cotton futures.

Three authors whose first novels have met with wide critical acclaim --Elizabeth Janeway, Betty Smith and John Hersey -- will take part on Wednesday evening, Feb. 23, in the second of a series of book meetings sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES at The New York Times Hall.

Despite greater impetus behind waste paper salvage drives and actions by war agencies to facilitate the output of lumoer and lumber products, a dark outlook for all types of papers was pictured by all speakers addressing the annual convention of the American Paper and Pulp Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

Yesterday the Army Second Service Command, which includes New York, New Jersey and Delaware, began a fortnight's drive to collect 50,000 books. These are to be distributed among camps, embarkation ports, hospitals and rehabilitation centers. It is no mammoth library that is sought.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The United States has taken over more than $375,000,000 worth of alien controlled property, and 30,000 patents which have been made available to American industry, Leo T. Crowley, Alien Property Custodian, reported to Congress today.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Feb. 12 (Delayed) -- For the second successive day an American hospital area near Nettuna has come under fire from German guns. In a twenty-minute shelling that began at 11 A.M. today, a dozen shells screamed over the hospital commanded by Lieut. Col. Frank Y. Leaver of Reno, Nev., and erupted on the south side of the field.

ALGIERS, Feb. 14 -- American troops boring into Cassino penetrated 200 yards farther yesterday, while, two and a half miles to the northwest, the Allies killed at least 100 Germans who attacked the positions around Mount Castellone. On the beachhead below Rome British units of the Allies plunged forward with the aid of tanks and, in a small-scale attack, seized a bridge over a railway just west of Aprilia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The House adjourned today out of respect for the memory of Representative Leonard W. Schuetz, Democrat, of Illinois, who died last night, after devoting its entire meeting to eulogies of him and adopting a resolution authorizing appointment of an eight-man committee to attend the funeral.

Thank you for your fine editorial "The Soldier's Vote." The idea of making partisan capital out of such an issue is utterly unthinkable, and the simple solution which you offer of Federal distribution and collection and counting of the votes by the States should commend itself to the President and to Congress alike.

Among those reported yesterday as having leased residential space was Thomas J. Gilmour, vice president of the Charles Bruning Company, Inc., blueprint papers, who took quarters in 21 East Eighty-seventh Street. Wm. A. White Sons were the brokers. Other leases included:

A comprehensive program for the vocational rehabilitation of disabled service men and women has been set up by the Board of Education, in cooperation with the Veterans Administration, the Selective Service and other interested agencies, it was announced yesterday by George F. Pigott, associated superintendent of schools and head of its vocational division.
ALGIERS, Feb. 14 -- A dramatic episode of the purge campaign in the French Army came to light today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace proposed tonight that instead of selling war plants in the West and South when they are no longer needed for war purposes the Government lease them on terms which will assure their continued independent operation.
I note with pleasure, though not with surprise, that all reports show the American Federation of Labor unions of this State are responding more whole-heartedly than ever to the Fourth War Loan.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 -Alice Faye has been named by Twentieth Century-Fox to star in the proposed comedy "Too Nfany Wives." Michael O'Shea was previously chosen for the male lead. The picture will be based on David Boehm's story about a discharged soldier who is delegated by his former comrades to act as escort for their wives.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A House committee heard today tha men in "high Government places' are being rejected by the Army as "psychoneurotic."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat, of Iowa, registered the only negative vote as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the resolution activating the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, 16 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Supreme Court in a unanimous decision, delivered by Justice Robert H. Jackson, ruled today that Congress "has given discretion to the commissioner (of internal revenue) to prescribe the forms of (income tax) returns and has made it the duty of the taxpayer to comply."
LONDON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

How the American woman can buy her new spring clothes and buy her war bonds too formed the thesis of a fashion show presented yesterday at the New York Dress Institute. At the suggestion of the War Finance Committee, the institute's fashion staff had assembled a group of "War Bond Wardrobes" at prices designed to cut peacetime clothes budgets 50 to 60 per cent without sacrificing style or quality.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who was recently honored by King George, received another signal honor today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 15 -- Russian troops yesterday captured Korsun, main enemy stronghold inside the Cherkassy pocket, while to the southwest the Germans lost 2,000 men killed and seventy-three tanks wrecked in attempting to open an escape corridor from the trap for the remnants of ten divisions now compressed into an area of about 100 square miles.

Germany's wartime shipbuilding program, patterned after American mass-production methods, has proved a failure, and the number of so-called Hansa ships, a smaller version of our Liberty ship, has been disappointingly small London press dispatches report. According to these reports, Germany's entire merchant marine shipbuilding program in wartime has not exceeded 2,000,000 tons, or less than the tonnage reported sunk by the Russians in the Baltic alone.

The first truckload of 1,600 books for service men in this area was carted off in an Army truck yesterday as the drive for 50,000 volumes opened at the Manhattan branch of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office at 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

FIFTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Italy, Feb. 14 -- The German High Command, recognizing the present Allied threat to the entire Italian position, has now brought in new reinforcements from Germany, comprising freshly constituted regiments of replacements, and has built up its strength on this front to a total of seventeen divisions.

The national board of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, yesterday cabled $100,000 to Hadassah's founder, Miss Henrietta Szold, head of the youth immigration bureau of the Jewish Agency for Palestine in Jerusalem, as its part of an international celebration of the tenth anniversary of the Youth Aliyah (immigration) movement.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 14 -- Imperturbable Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., scored a three-under-par 68 today to win the Texas open golf championship and $1,000 in war bonds.

ALGIERS, Feb. 14 -- Jean Politis, Greek member of the Advisory Council for Italy, who has just arrived here, said today that his Government took a limited interest in internal Italian affairs but favored all measures designed to prevent the recdurescence of the Italian aggressive spirit.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Speaking today at a luncheon meeting of the world trade conference here, Philip Young, assistant to the administrator of the Foreign Economic Administration, discussed plans for returning foreign commerce to private initiative and management, which he asserted must depend "on the unfolding military picture."

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations in New Jersey will enter the political field with a revised action committee to be financed by a tax on wages of members, leaders of the labor organization announced after a meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Congressional leaders urged President Roosevelt today not to veto the $2,300,000,000 tax bill, sent to him last week, declaring that Congress would not pass another revenue bill during this election year.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- For the first time since November, prices of hogs advanced above the Government support level today, bringing the top to $13.85 a hundred-weight.

Albert Guerard, whose new novel, "The Hunted," was reviewed in "Books of the Times" yesterday, is now in the Army and is stationed in the Midwest, where he is a trainee in one of the courses of the Army Specialized Training Program.

Nadia Reisenberg, Russian-born pianist, gave a recital last night in Town Hall before a capacity audience which was most enthusiastic in its acclaim of her unusual art. Her program consisted of a group by Rameau, the posthumous B-flat major Sonata of Schubert, Opus 10, and works of Prokofieff, Tchaikovsky, Rachmaninoff and Khatchatourian.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- The stock markets here commenced the week quietly today.

PERNAMBUCO, Brazil, Feb. 13 (Delayed) -- United States Navy fliers have sunk two more German submarines in the South Atlantic without suffering losses, Vice Admiral Jonas H. Ingram's headquarters said today.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, at Cassino, Feb. 14 -- Italian refugees sheltering in the ancient abbey of Mount Cassino were urgently warned today to quit this refuge immediately, as the Fifth Army had finally resolved to shell the historic landmark.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- The United States Strategic Air Forces based in Britain carried out today their fifteenth operation of the past eighteen days with a swift, punishing attack by P-47 Thunderbolt fighter-bombers on the big German fighter airfield at Gilze-Rijen, the Netherlands.

The problem of reintegrating the war veteran into civilian life is not by any means simply one of dealing with disabled and handicapped persons. By far the great majority of our soldiers and sailors can be expected to come home safe and sound.

This week that falls between the birthdays of Lincoln and Washington is observed in the public schools of New York State as Bill-of-Rights Week. In the observance the grown-up citizen may very well join. We all need reminding of the heritage of freedom which the first ten Amendments to the Constitution guarantee to us.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Headed for a generally expected Presidential veto, legislation carrying bans upon the Administration's food-price subsidy programs was sent to conference by the House today.
