Suits were the sole topic at the Saks Thirty-fourth Street showing yesterday afternoon. They were present in many expressions, ranging from bolero to long belted tunic. The cardigan or collarless jacket was predominant. It was noted in a sporty gray flannel and in a dressy raspberry woolen trimmed with soft looped bows at the neckline.

Unless there's a hitch Rhys Williams will withdraw from "Harriet" to enter "Chicken Every Sunday," due here early in April. The management of "Harriet" has granted Mr. Williams permission to make the change if he wants to, but up to last night the actor, who appears opposite Helen Hayes, had not signed a contract for the new play.

Twentieth Century-Fox has acquired screen rights to "A Bell for Adano," the recently published novel by John Hersey, for $100,000. It is understood that the property will be produced by Louis D. Lighton, who is handling Fox's adaptation of "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn."

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Charlie Chaplin walked down a Federal Building corridor today between solid ranks of the curious and formally surrendered as the result of Federal grand jury indictments charging violations of the Mann act and of plotting to deprive Joan Berry, his former protege, of her constitutional rights.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Giving what it termed "the first complete official figures thus far compiled," of production, Government and civilian requirements of processed foods for the last three years, the Office of Price Administration today made public figures to show that 1943 supplies of processed foods were 38,900,000 cases below the 1942 total and 27,700,000 cases behind 1941 supplies.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Wheat showed a heavy undertone from the start today on the Board of Trade and, although there was some buying early in sympathy with strength in rye, commission houses became persistent sellers on reports of additional moisture in the winter wheat belt and a slow Government demand for flour.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Japanese are using better fighter planes, but the quality and aggressiveness of their pilots are declining, Lieut. Comdr. James E. Vose Jr. of Manville, R.I. reported today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 14 -- Hair-triggered Swedish and German telephone censors failed tonight to block completely the news that the Finnish statesmen, Dr. Juho K. Paasikivi, Dr. Leo Ehrenrouth, Minister of the Interior, and Juho Eljas Erkko, Minister to Sweden, have, through Sweden's "benevolent intervention," formally started Finland on a new political course seeking the solution of her war with Russia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -The Agriculture Department estimated cash income from farm marketings for 1943 today at $19,009,000,000, compared with $15,336,000,000 the previous year. Livestock and livestock products contributed the major factor in the rise.

WASHINGTON, Feb. l4 -- Calling attention to the War Department statements that Germany's capacity to produce fighter planes had been reduced by 40 per cent by United States Army Air Forces bombings, Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, asserted today that this country's ability to produce aircraft was gaining momentum while Germany's fell off.

General Chennault won his fame as trainer of the Flying Tigers. Now his cubs fly as the Fourteenth United States Air Force in China. "The Old Man," as they call him, has pinned medals on hundreds of them; in those ranks distinguished service is commonplace. Last week they gathered to see the Air Medal pinned on General Chennault.

Assorted spots of strength kept the stock market on an even keel yesterday with price changes of minor scope. Both demand and selling pressure were at a minimum so far this year as the session only matched the opening one of 1944 in dullness.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The first public and official indication that Britain prefers to work for a postwar world in which the interests of all nations are represented and respected, and is not particularly concerned about a straight Anglo-American alliance was voiced here today by Richard K. Law, Minister of State.

The longer this war lasts the more clearly it is seen to be, in more than one sense, a life-and-death struggle. It is not only a fight for survival. It is also a fight between a theory making for death and a theory making for life. Under any absolutist system human personality dies to the extent of the absolutism.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- A holiday on rationing of all processed foods covered by green stamps between March 1 and June 30 was recommended by the National Canners Association in a program designed to insure maximum production on 1944 of canned goods, approved today.

A return match between Jimmy Herbert, former New York University star, and Johnny Fulton, the Stanford sensation who has been astounding track fans in the East by his versatility, won't be possible Saturday night when the New York Athletic Club holds its seventy-fifth anniversary games at Madison Square Garden, but there'll probably be plenty of action anyway, judging by the lineups announced yesterday for the four feature events.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from Chester Bowles, OPA Administrator, taking exception to an editorial which cited a bewildering range of estimates, all from OPA officials, of the savings that would be achieved by the use of subsidies. We remarked in this editorial that "perhaps these estimates are made on different bases, but there is no clear indication of this."

The hat that hugs the head triumphed at Lilly Daches showing yesterday afternoon. Manikins stepped into a pulpit arrangement against which spring flowers were banked and on which a bright flood light played so that every detail of hat and headdress could be seen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The President conducted his regular news conference and had appointments with Representative Vito Marcantonio of New York; the new Argentine Ambassador, Adrian C. Escobar, who presented his credentials; Donald M. Nelson, Bishop Henry St. George Tucker, Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, John Foster Dulles and the Rev. Luman J. Shaffer.

All indications point to the largest credit volume in the history of retailing during the post-war period, it was stated yesterday by L.S. Crowder, general manager and treasurer of the National Retail Credit Association. This record volume may also be done on the "cheapest credit" ever known, if Regulation W is dropped and steps to adopt and publicize sound credit policies on a cooperative and educational basis are carried out, he said.

Henry Mayer, counsel for various independent labor unions, wrote yesterday to Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, challenging her assertion that it was impractical to give such unions representation on the War Labor Board.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., have formed under Delaware laws Intava, Inc., with a capitalization of $100,000, to supply a full line of petroleum products at any foreign air base that may be served by a private company.

LONDON, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- German tanks and motorized units, striking northeast of Zagreb, have captured the large Croatian towns of Koprivnica, astride the Belgrade- Zagreb railroad, and Ludbrijeg in heavy offensive operations aimed at forcing Yugoslav Partisans from territory along the Hungarian frontier.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The French Army and Navy purge that is being directed from the headquarters of the Committee of National Liberation, a dramatic incident of which was reported in an Algiers dispatch in today's issue of this newspaper, is one of the reasons for the delay in United States recognition of the committee as the provisional government of France.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 15 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

The department of floor procedure of the New York Stock Exchange ruled yesterday that from Feb. 24 up to the close of trading Feb. 26 all dealings in the American Distilling Company common stock, either plain or stamped, shall be for cash, requiring delivery on the day of the contract.

Among those reported yesterday as having leased new commercial quarters was the firm of Pyne, Kendall Hollister, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, which leased the entire Wall Street portion of the twelfth floor in 52 Wall Street through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

Disappointing reports of consumption in January, supplemented by news that the Government had received offerings for lend-lease shipments three times as large as requested, produced yesterday further easiness in cotton futures.

Fifth Avenue is America's fashion center and will continue as such because the retail organizations there interpret fashion trends for the great apparel wholesalers and provide a ready market for displaying and selling their output, Walter Hoving, president of Lord Taylor, declared yesterday after his re-election as president of the Fifth Avenue Association.

General Eisenhower's election as an honorary member of the Athenaeum Club is another evidence of the high regard which his qualities have earned him among our British allies. Whether he is chosen for his eminence in military science or for his public services, he brings distinction to a distinguished company.

Reporting on operations last year of the Continental Can Company, Inc., and wholly owned subsidiaries, Carle C. Conway, chairman and president, said yesterday, in his annual report to stockholders that notwithstanding wartime restrictions total net sales and operating revenues had increased to $125,613,665 from $123,119,130 in 1942.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Under the new British law, which admits not only adultery but desertion, cruelty and insanity as grounds for divorce, there is a marked increase in the number of divorces now being granted in the United Kingdom.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Liquidation by holders of rye futures headed by professional traders carried prices off 1 1/2 to 2 3/8 cents a bushel after a small upturn early, and with stop-loss orders uncovered December sold at a new seasonal low on the Board of Trade and other futures into new ground since early January.
For the first time since 1940 Paul and Lloyd Waner, the famous "Big" and "Little Poison," may play another full season together -- this time with the Dodgers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The recent slump in hog receipts has aided in advancing prices beyond the minimums set by the Government and today's top was the highest since early November. Cattle prices were firm to a shade higher on all classes.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 15 -- The Argentine Trade Promotion Corporation announced here today that it has opened offices in Chicago, San Francisco and New Orleans. Esteban Carbone, president of the organization, said the move is preparatory to initiation of intensive, nation-wide long-term reciprocal trade development programs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during January totaled 819,489 bales of lint and 99,117 bales of linters, compared with 916,785 of lint and 110, 772 of linters during January last year; for the six months ending Jan. 31 consumption was 5,090,896 bales of lint and 652,868 of linters, compared with 5,623,308 and 686,234.

OTTAWA, Feb. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Graham F. Towers, governor of the Bank of Canada, said today in the bank's annual statement that, while the Dominion could not go on indefinitely piling up big increases in the public debt without an intolerable straining of the national economy, debt increases sufficient for war needs and post-war readjustment could be handled without embarrassment.

The emergence of great performers and the comeback of vaudeville after the war were predieted yesterday by Raymond Massey, featured player in "Lovers and Friends," current Broadway attraction. He spoke before 300 members of the Drama League of New York, which held a tea at the Hotel Pierre in observance of the twenty-fourth annual national drama week.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- War Department medals designed for human soldiers will no longer be presented to dogs, the Adjutant General's office has notified William Thomas, Principal here of the Lincoln School and national commander last year of the Military Order of the Purple Heart.

An industry-wide intensive drive for conservation of textile and paper bags, embodying an extensive re-use program, was urged yesterday upon the Textile Bag Manufacturers Association by Jean Zeller, chief, new and used textile bag section, containers division, War Production Board.

Responding to a month-long appeal to "back the attack," the nation last night went over the top in the Fourth War Loan drive. A few hours before the midnight deadline the Treasury Department in Washington announced that the $14,000,000,000 quota had been oversubscribed by $191,000,000, according to The Associated Press.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The Russian-Polish dispute has reached its most critical phase. It now seems certain that, despite all the efforts of the British Government to break the deadlock, the Polish Government in London will refuse to accept the Russian demand that the Russian-Polish boundary be moved westward to the Curzon Line.

The Nazi DNB agency yesterday put out a dispatch for use by the controlled European press in which it quoted a "Japanese Government spokesman" as claiming that "on principle Japan had no objections" to the sending of "gift parcels" to American war prisoners, but that these parcels had been held up by the "somewhat complicated question of a port of exchange accessible to both parties."
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Governor Dewey's Republican following in New Jersey has increased substantially during the past two months, a poll just completed there reveals.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A communique:

Bowing to the inevitable, Finland has apparently entered into direct peace negotiations with Russia in an effort to get out of the war on terms which will permit her continued existence as an independent nation. It is a step which, like the surrender of a defeated and dispirited Italy, foreshadows the defeat of Hitler Germany, and as such it is bound to have a profound effect throughout Europe and the world.
The children at the Walden School, 1 West Eighty-eighth Street, have a "ship of their own," the Booker T. Washington.

On the editorial page of Feb. 3 you listed five varying statements attributed to members of the OPA organization on the extent of the savings to American housewives which will be brought about by the use of subsidies. in connection with the present price-control program.

An eleven-room apartment with four baths at 1100 Park Avenue has been leased to Samuel P. Epstein, vice president of the Bulova Watch Company, through the Payson McL. Merrill Company, Inc., broker, and Frances R. Jaffin agent.
Two foreclosures were filed yesterday in Supreme Court by the New York Life Insurance Company to recover $2,200,000 on mortgages on two units of London Terrace, apartment development.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- A bill to authorize an appropriation of $80,000,000 for the country-wide school luncheon and milk program for the next fiscal year and thereafter, instead of $50,000,000 as now provided, was introduced today by Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democrat, of New York, at the request of the Board of Education of the City of New York and the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations.
Manhattan's champion Minute Man in the Fourth War Loan campaign was a woman -- Mrs. Hilda Kaufman, a housewife of 140 West Seventy-ninth Street, who sold 415 bonds with a total worth of $64,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The soldier vote controversy which has raged for weeks in Washington was fought out here today with the Republicans winning a contest in which a plea for Federal control of soldier voting was defeated.
LONDON, Wednesday Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

SOME of the more famous fights which have occurred during hockey games were recounted in this space the other day, but apparently the granddaddy of them all was overlooked. Coulter F. Irwin of The British Associated Press fills in a large gap in the collection with the following:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- President Roosevelt explained this afternoon that the shelling of the historic shrine of Mount Cassino by American forces was made necessary because the Nazis were using the monastery not only as an observation post but also to house artillery.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Negotiations between the Army and the State Department, on the one hand, and the Netherland and Governments on the other for the restoration of civil administration in those countries have been concluded and sent to London for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's signature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The value of the average motorist's A card gasoline coupon might be 25 per cent higher than it is today if it were not for the flourishing black market, which is draining an average of 2,500,000 gallons of gasoline daily from civilian stocks, Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, asserted tonight in an address broadcast over the Blue Network.

Combined net earnings of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation for the year 1943 were $10,713,208 after deducting $1,000, 000 which has been added to the reserve for contingencies, according to the report released today. These earnings equal $2.94 each on 3,580,948 shares of capital stock, after payment of dividends on the preference stock retired on June 30, 1943.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Despite a decline of nearly 10 per cent in resident civilian population in less than four years and a rise in storage of household goods to the highest volume in many years, New York City's landlords are being forced to turn tenants away because apartment houses are showing the highest rate of occupancy in more than two decades.

Bruno Walter conducted his first New York concert with the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night, and he brought to the organization all the attributes that have made him one of the most distinguished figures in music today.

SPOKANE, Wash., Feb. 15 -- A suggestion that the Pacific Coast should be represented in the Cabinet and would be, if he were elected President, was made today by Wendell L. Willkie in an interview at the Spokane Press Club.

Although she must still face charges of abandoning her 11-month-old daughter, things are beginning to brighten for Mrs. Elinore Stefanski, the wife of an American soldier stationed in England, who told police yesterday that she had deserted her child because her Army allotment was not enough to provide for them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Office of Price Administration today ordered retailers and wholesalers of women's and children's outerwear garments to price such garments under the spring selling season price ceiling beginning March 1.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15 -- Two heavily played favorites, Skytracer and High Fox, took the divisions of the Marine Gardens Purse today at Hialeah Park, where 7,528 persons wagered $617,972. Skytracer is eligible for the $15,000 added Flamingo Stakes and his seven-furlong victory bettered his prospects for that mile-and-a-furlong test on Feb. 26 as he finished in 1:26 4-5 to return $3.50 for $2.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- President Roosevelt was visited today by a delegation from the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, asking assurances that the proposed post-war world organization be "curative and creative, not merely repressive."

Madison Square Garden, scene of various sporting events this season, tonight will expand its list to include roller skating. Five hundred skaters are scheduled to appear for the purpose of raising $10,000 for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the "basic aspects" of a plan of reorganization filed by the International Utilities Corporation and its subsidiary, the Dominion Gas and Electric Company, pending filing by the applicants of certain amendments which the commission found to be necessary.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, At Cassino, Feb. 15 -- The massive Abbey of Mount Cassino, built on the site where St. Benedict founded his holy order of monks, suffered today the worst aerial and artillery onslaught ever directed against a single building.

Most political observers have detected a powerful move toward territorial expansion in Moscow's constitutional amendment that makes it lawful for each of the autonomous republics included in the Soviet Union to possess a diplomatic Service and a military establishment of its own.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Feb. 16 -- American and New Zealand forces occupied the Green, or Nissan, Islands, 250 miles southeast of Kavieng, New Ireland, thus isolating about 22,000 Japanese re maining just to the south on Buka, Bougainville and other islands in the northern Solomons.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The German military position in northern Europe, perilous since the Russian break-through at Leningrad, would be so weakened by the withdrawal of Finland from the war that the evacuation of all German troops from Norway and the surrender of Petsamo and its nickel mines by the Germans are viewed here as "distinct possibilities" arising from peace between the U.S.S.R. and Finland.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 15 -- A group of comparatively junior army officers, alarmed at reports that Argentina was about to declare war on the Axis, took possession of the Foreign Ministry this morning, ousting Foreign Minister Alberto Gilbert and his Under-Secretary, Oscar Ibarra Garcia.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 15 (AP) -- An offer of $1,000,000 for fifty motion pictures more than five years old was made today by Jacques Kopfstein of New York at the annual meeting of stockholders of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Talk of a business man for the Democratic Vice Presidential nomination was relayed to President Roosevelt at a press conference today, but the Chief Executive said he had never heard of it. Such talk has been prevalent here for several weeks.

The recent capture of Kwajalein Atoll in the Pacific, and the continuing Italian campaign with the critical battle for the Nettuno-Anzio beachhead, have provided invaluable case histories for the invasion of Western Europe and for future amphibious operations.
ALGIERS, Feb. 15 -- The bombardment of the Abbey of Mount Casinos was officially announced here at 4:20 P.M. today in the following statement:

Mexico is not in particular need of United States capital but does require American "know how" and will welcome the entrance of our business interests on a "partnership basis" only -- "otherwise we are likely to see the development of a program calling for Latin-American business for Latin-Americans", John B. Walker, assistant to the president, United Air Lines, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The Assembly Ways and Means Committee cleared the decks today for the passage Tuesday of Governor Dewey's budget, amended very slightly. The $371,809,013 total, as submitted by the State's Chief Executive, was increased by $593,959, and the figures were reported out of committee.

Investment and speculative funds, held back during the war loan drive, were unleashed yesterday in considerable volume to give the stock market its widest lift of the year to date. With the average gain at a point, and more in isolated instances, the session was not fully representative, however, since the bulk of the buying was in the railroad issues.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Swedish liner Gripsholm left Jersey City for Lisbon tonight to complete the first direct exchange of United States and German prisoners of war, the State Department announced.

Buffalo, N.Y., awarded yesterday to a banking group headed by the Union Securities Corporation a new issue of $3,000,000 of refunding bonds, dated March 1, 1944, and due serially from March 1, 1948 to 1954. The bankers bid 100.13699, naming the interest rate as 1.10 per cent. Reoffering is being made at prices to yield 0.75 to 1.10 per cent.

The possible appearance of a merchant marine seaman as an important defense witness in the coming trial of Wayne Lonergan for the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, brought on another clash in General Sessions yesterday between the opposing lawyers.

THE tragic plight of refugees who are denied admission to this country for heartlessly mysterious official reasons, which was muffed so wretchedly in Laura Hobson's "The Trespassers" last summer, is the theme of a much less pretentious and far more moving novel published today. It is "Liberty Street,"* by I.V. Morris.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Measures that have been taken in La Paz, Bolivia, by the revolutionary junta have been followed closely here but Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, was not prepared to indicate today whether they improved prospects of the junta's being given diplomatic recognition.

ALGIERS, Feb. 15 (AP) -- American boxers outfought their British Allies in the ring today as the Allied boxing tourney to determine sixteen amateur and professional champions swung into its second day under leaden skies and drenching rains.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 16 -- The great aerial offensive against the doorstep into western Europe in which the United States Strategic Air Forces are playing a leading role continued yesterday with undiminished fury.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 15 -- State governments should not place too great reliance upon such public works as highway and airport development to provide employment for returning veterans after the war, Gov. Raymond E. Baldwin of Connecticut warned here tonight, but should give every aid to private industry to solve the problem.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Fingerprinting of police prisoners before their conviction was vigorously condemned here today in a judgment handed down in the Court of Appeal by Lord Justice Scott, who recommended the matter to the Home Secretary and Lord Chancellor.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 15 -- The hush-hush atmosphere surrounding the movements of Dr. Juho K. Paasikivi, former Finnish Premier, has proved a great handicap to anyone trying to find out what progress, if any, has been made by him in attempting to reconcile Helsinki's viewpoint with whatever ideas are held by Moscow on the subject of a separate peace.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The British Admiralty took new steps today to tighten the blockade against Germany. Most of the enemy blockade runners unload in French ports in the Bay of Biscay. So the Admiralty declared a vast additional area of 150,000 square miles "dangerous" to shipping -- which undoubtedly means that mines have been planted there.

ALGIERS, Feb. 15 -- Allied heavy bombers roared back into action over hundreds of square miles of northern Italy yesterday in their greatest attempt thus far to smash all lines of German supply and reinforcement to the beachhead below Rome.

Persons who eat out will find more unrationed foods on the menu and less of the rationed products after March 1, Kris P. Bemis, chief of the Institutional User Branch of the Food Rationing Division of the Office of Price Administration, declared yesterday.

Christopher Morley, the author, and Frank Morley, his brother, of Harcourt, Brace, will be the guest speakers at the dinner of the Booksellers League of New York this evening at the Brevoort Hotel. Aaron Mendoza, president of the League, will preside.

A friend of the Conrad Library wrote us not long ago offering books and magazines saying, "One seaman who found my name and address on a magazine wrote such a nice letter telling how much it meant to have this literature, and that the books were read until they were in ribbons.

MADRID, Spain, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- Suspension of American gasoline imports to Spain -- already a serious handicap to the nation's economic life -- will be extended through March, it was indicated today.

The report of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for 1943, filed yesterday in the Federal Court by the trustees in reorganization, showed a consolidated balance of income of $10,386,923 after operating expenses and charges but before interest deductions. This compared with $8,603,354 on the same basis in 1942.

Lloyd De Rondi, 49 years old, a narcotic peddler and petty thief, whose police record in this and other cities goes back nearly twenty-eight years, escaped yesterday afternoon from a gang of forty penitentiary prisoners assigned to snow removal in the Bronx
LONDON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15 -- Attorneys for Charles Chaplin and Miss Joan Berry announced tonight that blood tests had shown that the 54-year-old movie producer was not the father of the four-months-old baby of his 23-year-old protegee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Senator Pepper of Florida gave his colleagues today this size-up of the Republican Presidential possibilities:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The activities taking place in Stockholm, Sweden, possibly looking to a basis for peace discussions between Finland and the Soviet Union, naturally are being watched here with interest, it was said today in authoritative circles, but it was insisted that no more is known about them here through official channels than has appeared in the press.
A BOMBER BASE, In England, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- The radio operator turned his blinded, bleeding eyes to the top turret gunner and pleaded: "Thow me out. * * * I'm hit bad-I ly and no use to you now.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 15 -Three youths were placed under arrest here today on charges of homicide by assault as the result of the death early this morning of Norman Jacobus, 22 years old, a high school basketball coach who was injured last Wednesday in a fight that followed a basketball game.

Keeping one's complexion clean -- a process considered by dermatologists as the foremost prerequisite to beauty -- is no longer a simple matter of choosing once for all between the cleansing-cream method and the plain-soap-and-water school of thought.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved the plan of the Electric Power and Light Corporation to make a capital contribution to Mississippi Power and Light Company of 1,493 shares of $6 preferred, 35,000 shares of $6 second preferred, 500,000 shares of common stock and a $190,000 demand note.

An experiment in combatting interracial tensions, now being conducted among English students at Midwood High School in Brooklyn, was described by Dr. Jacob M. Ross, principal, to members of the New York City League of Women Voters meeting yesterday at 90 Riverside Drive.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 15 -- Mixed commissions of French and German members are sitting at present in various parts of France to decide what workers and war employees are not essential for proper operation of any industry or trade and also what employers may be removed without detriment to their business.

The fact that soy is a bean -- and in the minds of many people beans symbolize all that is humdrum in cookery -- may be one reason why it has been accorded a cool reception in some quarters. Another cause underlying its not-too-successful struggle for recognition may be the natural suspicion with which people regard new foods and the resistance they show to efforts to "reform" their eating habits.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national director of selective service, declared here tonight that the manpower needs of the armed forces "must not be placed secondary" to the needs either of industry or agriculture, both of which were praised for operating efficiently at present.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 15 -The cost of living is higher in Shanghai than in Chungking, according to recent arrivals from Shanghai. From Jan. 1 this year, everything has been subject to a 30 per cent retail tax and luxury goods to a 40 per cent levy.

The Citizens Budget Commission, referring yesterday to Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick's report of estimates for New York City's 1944-45 general fund, declared that "the total estimated general fund increase of $9,600,000, taken with a drop of $10,000,000 in gross debt service cost, and the $12,500,000 coming from the State, should be reflected in decreased real estate taxes."

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The stock markets here were cheered today by the war news and business in some sections showed increased activity. The 3 1/2 per cent War Loan was slightly easier and home rails hardened.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, said today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had given "heartiest support" to the theory that plans for the news coverage of the European invasion should be woven into the battle plans.

A large exhibition of modern drawings, one of its major shows of the season, opened with an invitation preview last evening at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. It opens to the public today and will continue through April 16.

Asserting that complete victory over both Germany and Japan "is much closer than most of us imagine," Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming declared here yesterday that it behooves American industry to speed its plans for reconversion to peacetime output.

We wish Sigrid Undset would write more at length about the wild flowers common to Norway and America. My brief visits to her native land, where I saw many of our common field flowers in bloom in the higher altitudes of Norway's mountain meadows, convince me that her list of wild flowers common to our two countries, contained in her recent inspiring letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, can be enlarged.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Differences of opinion were voiced today by spokesmen for a large segment of the country's employers and for trade unions when they argued before the National Labor Relations Board on the question of whether the discharge of a supervisory employe because of his activities on behalf of a supervisors' union was a violation of the National Labor Relations Act.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Dr. Adrian C. Escobar, Argentine Ambassador, revealed in presenting to President Roosevelt today his letters of credence that his government "without the most remote political aim," has proposed to adjacent countries the study and formation of customs unions to facilitate trade.

Lieut. Comdr. Juan Benavides the Peruvian Air Force and Senora de Benavides, who were married on Saturday in Washington, are at the Ambassador. The bride is the former Senorita Teresa Labarthe daughter of Rear Admiral Enrique Labarthe, Naval Attache of the Peruvian Embassy in Washington, and Senora de Labarthe.

" Passage to Marseille," a drama produced by Warner Brothers, will have its local premiere this morning at the Hollywood Theatre. The cast of the topical film, which was produced by Hal Wallis and directed by Michael Curtiz, is headed by Humphrey Bogart, Sydney Greenstreet, Claude Rains, Michele Morgan, Philip Dorn, Helmut Dantine, Victor Francen, George Tobias, Peter Lorre and John Loder.

ON THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, Below Rome, Feb. 11 (Delayed) -- Investigation has established that the bombing of one Red Cross field hospital on Feb. 7 and the shelling of another on Feb. 10, in which thirty persons were killed, were not deliberate.
CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 15 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Senate today adopted a resolution favoring extension of the "Greek experiment" to provide food for the starving population of Axis-occupied countries in Europe.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- A move to go over Mayor La Guardia's head to get wartime pay increases, without strings, for the 25,000 firemen and policemen of New York City was started today as their representatives sought support for a proposal to submit the question to a referendum at the coming election.

WASHINGON, Feb. 15 -- Philip K. Hitti, Professor of Semitic Literature at Princeton University, asserted today at a hearing before the House Foreign Affairs Committee on the Wright-Compton resolutions on Palestine that "political Zionists of New York" were the chief advocates of converting Palestine into a Jewish commonwealth.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 15 -- Ten years ago Miss Henrietta Szold, then 73 years old, was so deeply moved at the Nazis' treatment of Jewish children in Germany that she decided to dedicate the remaining years of her life to rescuing as many youngsters as possible and to train them in the Jewish nationalistic spirit, confirming the traditions of Judaism.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Beau Jack, world lightweight champion, used the veteran Maxie Berger for a punching bag tonight and gained an easy decision over the Montreal welterweight in a ten-round bout before 8,206 spectators in Public Hall.

Fred C. Moffatt started yesterday his seventh year as president of the New York Curb Exchange. Before the institution began its experiment with a paid president in the person of George P. Rea, Mr. Moffatt had served four terms. In 1942, after the departure of Mr. Rea, his post as chairman of the board automatically made him acting president and he has held the office ever since.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -Japanese troops pushing southward behind the Allied lines in western Burma captured a British position early yesterday after a furious night battle in which the enemy suffered considerable casualties, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

President Roosevelt and Wendell Willkie both subscribe to the view that this is One World, and if you want to talk over important matters with a foreigner you step into a plane and fly to Chungking or Teheran. But it will be noticed that when Finns want to discuss peace possibilities with Russians they do not take a plane for Moscow.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 16 --The Russians in the north, moving down along two railroads and a highway, have hammered the Germans farther back toward the great communications center of Pskov, bombing and shelling Nazi retreat lines choked with trucks, carts and infantry, Moscow announced today.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor, told the extraordinary grand jury investigating the Legislature today that it was his purpose to examine, under oath, each of the hundreds of employes whose names appear upon the $2,500,000,000-a-year pay-rolls of the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Sinclair Weeks, appointed a successor to Maj. Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts, was sworn in today as a member of the Senate where his father, John W. Weeks, served a quarter century ago.

In "Die Walkuere," the second of the uncut "Ring" performances last night at the Metropolitan, the prevailing standards were continued and the latent promise of the performance last week of "Rheingold," carried out. George Szell again led the orchestra with a master hand.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Senate and House differences over Federal and State ballots for the armed forces threatened tonight to so deadlock the conferences scheduled to start Thursday as to return the issues to the floors for new voting before the conference report, which is necessary for completion of Congressional action, may be drafted.

A record number of "no heat" complaints for this winter -- 2,340 -- was received by the Department of Health yesterday despite continued mild weather and reports of improved coal supplies. The Health Department disclosed that complaints were accumulating to such an extent that it had been compelled for a second time to increase its staff of inspectors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 15 -- Howard Hughes will return to picture production as financial backer and partner of Preston Sturges, former Paramount writer and director, in a company to be known as Sturges-Hughes, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- The House today completed action on legislation creating a new $9,000-a-year Interior Department post, a wartime assistant secretary, after Speaker Rayburn in a rare appearance on the floor denounced opponents who charged that Secretary Harold L. Ickes was seeking to "grab more power."

The American Theatre Wing War Service hopes to get permission from the War Department to install a high-grade stock company as close to the Mediterranean front line as possible. (Maybe Algiers or Naples.) Already the project, which would be the Wing's thirty-sixth, has received the endorsement of the USO-Camp Shows and is now being considered by the War Department.

In its first investment in Manhattan land in almost a decade, the General Realty and Utilities Corporation has purchased for cash the blockfront on the west side of Third Avenue from Forty-fifth to Forty-sixth Streets.

Preliminary to the establishment of top legal retail prices for fresh vegetables by the end of this month, Daniel P. Woolley, Regional Office of Price Administration Administrator, announced new dollars and cents wholesale ceiling prices yesterday on carrots, snap beans, spinach, peas, egg plant, cucumbers and sweet peppers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- American production of great quantities of weapons of war would have been impossible without materials obtained from Pan-American countries, Nelson A. Rockefeller, coordinator of inter-American affairs, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The State Department's attitude toward censorship is based on free expression of opinion, however unpleasant, between friendly countries, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, said today.

Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs, Independent Republican, warned the City Council at its meeting yesterday that he would not permit it to shelve bills designed to prevent discrimination against any person on account of race, color or creed in the selection of tenants for housing developments with tax exemption.

With the termination of the Fourth War Loan drive last night the investment banking community moved into high speed in preparation for the offering today of two issues of corporate bonds aggregating $44,300,000 and a major-sized issue of common stock.

The eight-story apartment hotel, with stores, known as the San Jacinto, at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Sixtieth Street has been sold by the Greenwich Savings Bank to an out-of-town investor, Middlebrook Sincerbeaux were the attorneys for the bank.

Increasing subway fares to 10 cents, as proposed recently by the Committee of Fifteen, wound not solve New York City's transit eltax problems, the Citizens Union argued yesterday in making public a report entitled "Higher Fares and Bigger Deficits."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- President Roosevelt announced today the resumption of limited mail service between the United States and Sicily, Sardinia and ten Italian provinces occupied by United Nations forces.

Against Vice President Wallace's recent use of the phrase "American Fascists" to describe political opponents with whom he disagrees this newspaper protested. Now two distinguished members of the Republican party have resorted to the same phrase and the same tactics, just as recklessly and just as harmfully.
LONDON, Feb. 15 (UP) -- A (German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

CHUNGKING, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -Fliers of the Fourteenth United States Army Air Force destroyed at least six ships over the weekend, including a 10,400-ton transport, blasted military installations in Indo-China and shot down or damaged fifteen enemy planes, a communique from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters said today.

Wartime "cooperation" between Latin America and the United States is often misinterpreted to give Latin Americans the impression that they are "living on the dole," and naturally, this view is resented in the Latin countries, Dr. Walder Sarmanho, commercial counselor of the Brazilian Embassy, declared yesterday.

The banking and investment division of the New York State War Finance Committee set a goal of 1,000,000 individual sales, regardless of amount, as its quota in the Fourth War Loan Drive, which ended last night. Joseph A. Bower, chairman of the division, which comprises sixteen teams of banks and investment firms, reported last night that the division's score was better than 1,100,000.

Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia reported yesterday that its holdings of United States Government bonds rose $26,223,000 during 1943, exceeding the increase assets for the second successive year and bringing Government security holdings to $124,256,000, or 28.5 per cent of all investments.

Yale's bestowal yesterday of the Howland Memorial prize upon Field Marshal Sir John Greer Dill was more than a recognition of distinguished, of most distinguished, service. It was an act of gratitude. The service of the Field Marshal and of his colleague in arms and in counsel, General Marshall, goes to the winning of the war whose loss would be the end of free opinion and free teaching.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 16 -- The de luxe Hotel Bristol on Unter den Linden was razed in last night's mammoth Royal Air Force assault on Berlin and 200 were killed in a shelter when a blockbuster scored a bullseye, travelers reaching here today said.

The "invasion coast" is ready for the grand assault, says, the German military commander in France. In a dramatic, because unprecedented, statement of a German general to the press, Marshal von Rundstedt has described in detail the wide zone of fortifications the Nazis have built against the expected landings.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- The automobile industry reported today that during 1942-43 it delivered to the Government fighting aircraft valued at more than $5,030,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Military and civilian aircraft are being equipped with new high frequency radio range receivers in preparation for a change-over to improved sending equipment on the country's airways.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Pledges of support, many accompanied by checks or cash, have been arriving at the rate of 200 to 250 daily since the starting here on Feb. 4 of an anti-New Deal movement among Democrats, Robert E. O'Brian, secretary of the American Democratic National Committee, stated today.

A. Karagheusian, Inc., will launch a five-week advertising campaign designed to build postwar sales of its rug and carpet products in New York and Chicago newspapers on Feb. 27, according to Art Funduklian, advertising manager.
The limitations as well as the capacities, of air power have stressed by our recent operations in Italy and in the central Pacific.

The recent wholesale retirements of members of the uniformed force will add $4,179,000 to the Police Department's budget for 1944-45, Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday at a hearing before Budget Commissioner Thomas J. Patterson. The department asked for $37,737,442, an increase of $6,594,820 over the 1943-44 appropriation.

DECATUR, Ill., Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- The Illinois Power Company, formerly the Illinois Iowa Power Company, reported today the highest operating income in its history in 1943 and a net income of $3,276,019, compared with $2,979,769 in 1942.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Short-covering caused today a strong rally in wheat on the Chicago Board of Trade. This followed an early decline of around 1/2 cent a bushel which carried prices to new lows on the current downturn and 4 1/2 to 6 7/8 cents a bushel under the recent tops.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Roosevelt put the War Relocation Authority "in its entirety" under Secretary Ickes tonight as part of the Department of Interior.

The income limitations for admission of tenants to most public housing projects here have been liberalized by the New York City Housing Authority, Edmond B. Butler, chairman of the authority, announced yesterday.

Your editorial "Independent" Schools, appearing in the issue of Feb. 10, seems to rest on the assumption that the Charter of New York City makes no distinction between the school system and the other departments of the city.

Thomas J. Curran, Manhattan Republican leader, made public last night the organization slate of twenty-three delegates, and their alternates, to the Republican National Convention which Republican voters of New York County will be asked to approve at the March 28 primary.

William J. Nolan Jr., 19 years old, of 300 West Fifty-first Street, faces a sentence of five to ten years at hard labor in Sing Sing Prison for stealing 60 cents from a poor-box in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church at Richmond, S. I.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 17 -- The battle of Berlin entered its final and decisive phase Tuesday night when, in the heaviest air assault of history, nearly 1,000 British four-motored bombers dumped more than 2,800 American tons of bombs on the city.
Several hundred representatives of large corporations, banks and mercantile organizations "went to school" yesterday to facilitate the filing of income tax returns for "the average wage earner."

Although sugar stocks seem more than adequate at present so far as the average consumer is concerned, various authorities predict a considerable tightening up of supplies in the months ahead. Just how this will affect housekeepers is a matter of speculation.

Louis G. Padgett, 39 years old, a former investigator for the Federal Bureau of Investigation who was lent to Governor Dewey in 1935 when the latter became prosecutor of rackets in this city, was arraigned yesterday in the Felony Court on a statutory rape charge, lodged against him by a 16-year-old girl, who is about to become a mother.

ON LEDO ROAD in Hukawng Valley, Feb. 12 (Delayed) -- One of the great engineering feats of the war, this spectacular highway through the malarial forests of the Naga Hills, is now "over the hump" and is delivering supplies for the troops fighting in the Hukawng Valley of Northern Burma.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- John A. Collett and Dorothy Hutchinson, although they purportedly resigned from "Peace Now," are still active in the organization, the Dies Committee reported today.

Jacques Maritain will lecture this evening at 8:15 o'clock in the Brooklyn Academy of Music on "Scholasticism and the Immortality of Man." He is the fourth speaker in a series, "Immortality and Western Man," held under the Butterick Foundation of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Brendan Bracken, Minister of Information, rebuked the Church of England newspaper in the House of Commons today for its recent article advocating a fourth term for President Roosevelt and criticizing Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY AT CASSINO, Feb. 16 -- Three waves of speedy fighter-bombers buzzed down on the stark ruins of the Abbey of Mount Cassino this afternoon and touched up the terrible job of destruction done by their big brothers yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Feb. 16 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today declared that Japan, because of her conquests, is no longer predominantly a maritime nation and insisted that the American Army must beat the Japanese Army.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Several thousand United States citizens held by the Japanese in the Orient are facing death from malnutrition, Congress was informed today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- At the suggestion of Donald Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, the American Home Economics Association will start a second survey of civilian scarcities March 15.
LONDON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- A German communiqu, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The Willard Gibbs Medal of the Chicago section of the American Chemical Society, one of the highest distinctions in American chemistry, has been awarded to Dr. George O. Curme Jr., vice president and director of research of Carbide and Carbon Chemicals Corporation, New York, it was announced here yesterday by the American Chemical Society. The award will be formally presented to Dr. Curme at a meeting in Chicago on May 24.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16 -- Signator, Reztips and Scotch Abbot won the Graded Handicaps today in Classes A, B and C, respectively, and it must be stated that each was something of a surprise to the ,169 persons at Hialeah Park who vagered $784,032.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 16 -- In an official communiqu issued from Berlin tonight the Reich Government made an emphatic denial of Allied charges that the Monte Cassino Monastery had been fortified by the German command in Italy or that it had at any time during operations in that sector served the Germans as a fortification or observation post.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Bill Paschal, New York Giants' fullback, sat sullenly on the bench last Nov. 7 and watched his team probe for a footing in the mud against Detroit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- The House by a vote of 140 to 13, approved legislation today authorizing the Government to build and operate three experimental plants to produce synthetic gasoline from coal, shale and other products.

The largest single payment ever made by a distiller anywhere in the United States in settlement of a damage claim for above-ceiling sales of whisky was announced yesterday by the regional Office of Price Administration, which reported that the Park Tilford Import Corporation had turned over to the Government a check for $250,033.29.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The United States Army's orientation program has failed to give our men any clear notion of what the war is about and this failure places the American soldiers under a "terrific disadvantage" against their "madly indoctrinated" Nazi enemies, Rabbi Barnett R. Brickner, here on a Presidential mission, charged tonight.

New explanations for New York City's unusually high level of housing occupancy in the face of a 10 per cent decline in civilian population in less than four years were offered yesterday by real estate men.

The interior of All Saints Episcopal Church, Fortieth Avenue near 214th Street, Bayside, Queens was damaged by vandals Tuesday night or early yesterday morning, Albert Delfyette, the sexton, reported to the police.
Capt. Paul H. Bastedo, USN, and Mrs. Bastedo have come to the Plaza from Washington.
LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Russian supplementary communiqu:

New York City exceeded its Fourth War Loan quota by $37,074,700 and the State exceeded its quota by $68,100,000, according to tabulations completed yesterday including sales on Tuesday, the final day of the drive.

Flooding of the cotton floor coverings market with increasing quantities of inferior quality shag rugs constitutes a definite threat to the otherwise satisfactory wartime output and sales volume of the industry, George E. Mallinson president of the Geo. E. Mallinson Importing Company, Inc., sales agents for Amsterdam Textiles Amsterdam, N. Y., leading producer of better type cotton floor coverings, said in an interview yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 16 -- Victory is now certain, but no one can estimate the time, the effort, or the sacrifice that will be needed to bring Germany and Japan to their knees, Field Marshal Sir John Greet Dill, chief of the British joint staff mission to the United States, declared today as he received the highest special award within the gift of Yale University.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 (AP) -- W.E. Long, president of the United Gas Improvement Company of Philadelphia, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an answer to a petition by stockholders, including Frank M. Booth of Haddon Heights, N.J., which protested U.G.I.'s proposed retirement annuity plan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee sent to the floor today a bill to appropriate $231,304,700 for the State, Commerce and Justice Departments for the fiscal year starting July 1. The State Department would get $44,234,500; Justice, $116,477,200 and Commerce, $70,593,000. The aggregate was $5,987,700 below budget estimates.

If the fishing season isn't exactly just around the corner, it's making steady strides in this direction, so an answer was sought to what a man might expect by looking around the various tackle stores for new equipment.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Expectations of an early end to the Russo-Finn:ish war that have flourished in the past few days in Stockholm, Sweden, and other neutral capitals are viewed with considerable reserve in diplomatic, quarters here. No, information was available in London today to warrant the belief. that the negotiations have gone far, or even that they have actually begun.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 16 -- Perhaps to prod the Finns into making up their minds quicker on the subject of an armistice and peace, Russia introduced an otherwise discordant note into the situation when tonight she attacked Helsinki with a seemingly large number of bombers.

May we supplement your editorial approving of the recommended appointment of some 700 teachers to the New York City schools by urging that readers aware of the importance of public education translate their awareness into effective action.
Confident of victory for the United Nations, Crown Prince Olav of Norway last night urged the necessity for planning the restoration of commercial relations between this country and Norway.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 16 -- The Argentine Government today announced a temporary solution of the Cabinet crisis that was precipitated yesterday by violent action of a group of army officers that ejected Foreign Minister Alberto Gilbert from his post.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 16 -- Far-ranging Army aircraft have pierced deep into enemy territory in the central Pacific to plant tons of bombs on Ponape, in the Caroline Islands. This important island, the largest in the Caroline archipelago and one of the prin...
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Feb. 17 (UP) -- A communiqu:

Representatives of anthracite operators and miners met yesterday in the office of Anthracite Industries, Inc., 101 Park Avenue, to discuss controversial interpretations of the War Labor Board's recent decision affecting wages and working conditions in the industry.

Following published reports yesterday that she sold dresses made in Nazi-controlled Paris a indirectly put money into the pockets of Nazis, Mrs. Elsa Higgins, who owns a dress salon at 757 Madison Avenue, denied the charge.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- The right to appoint justices of the Supreme Court, with a subsequent election at which his nominee could be rejected, was asked of the Legislature today by Governor Dewey. The plan, an outcome of the Aurelio case in New York City, aims to abolish the present system of judicial elections.

OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- Henry J. Kaiser, shipbuilder, and a three-man committee of high officials of the Government of Venezuela jointly announced tonight the success of negotiations for investment of "substantial" American capital in Venezuela development.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 17 -- Soviet troops, driving southward through the forests and lake country of northern Russia in their advance on the big German railroad hub of Pskov, captured more than thirty-five populated places yesterday, including the town of Chudskiye Zakhody, on Lake Peipus three miles from southeastern Estonia.

While New Yorkers with empty coal bins were setting a record yesterday by purchasing 112,975 pounds of coal in 50 and 100 pound lots at the city's emergency depots, the Office of Price Administration let it be known that many fuel oil users -- who have been living in comparative warmth so far this season -- were in for trouble unless they turned down the thermostat.

ALGIERS, Feb. 16 -- While heavy and medium bombers were pounding the fortified Abbey of Mount Cassino into rubbish yesterday, Invader dive-bombers made the first air attacks within Rome since the historic large-scale assaults on the San Vittorio and San Lorenzo railway yards on July 19 and Aug. 13.

The forty-fifth annual report of the American Woolen Company and its subsidiary, the Pocono Company, issued to stockholders yesterday, reveals a net profit in 1943 of $5,475,421 after taxes, provision for renegotiation and for war contingencies.

IN Hackberry, Tex., the scene of George Sessions Perry's "Hackberry Cavalier,"* the townsfolk are either pro or anti Edgar Selfridge. Edgar is the nephew of the pompous town banker, and the trouble with the young man from the point of view of the unco' guid is that he completely lacks his uncle's conventional sobriety. If Edgar had had any great suing to toss around he would have granted credit to anybody, even Polecat Crittenton.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 16 -- Before than 600 "double-duty" soldiers from near-by camps, foregoing the recreations of their spare and furlough time, are working side by side with civilians in some twenty-five factories in this area and they are boosting the morale of the regular employes as well as the production figure, plant managers assert.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- The Japanese, increasing their threat to the almost encircled Allied troops on the Arakan front of western Burma, have captured a hill overlooking Ngakyedauk Pass, gateway to the Mayu mountain range, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.
ALGIERS, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A communiqu:

A gain in millinery sales of 15 to 20 per cent this spring over the same period a year ago was predicted yesterday By Walter A. Krafft, president of the Emporium World Millinery Company, leading millinery syndicate which is holding its semi-annual merchandising clinic at the Hotel McAlpin.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- The first farmer-owned rural electric line in New York State went into operation at Cherry Creek, near here, today at 5 P.M., when nine miles of line were energized at ceremonies held at the sub-station of the Chautauqua-Cattaragus Electric Cooperative two miles north of Cherry Creek.

When the Army called him nearly two years ago, Paul Skobbeko put away the truck with which he had been hauling coal from the Pennsylvania mines and selling it in the Astoria section of Queens and put on a uniform.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- A large volume of Cape and London buying enlivened the Kaffir section of the stock markets here today. West Witwater rose sharply when it was rumored that one of that company's properties was developing favorably.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Chief administrative employes of the Legislature, including William S. King, Senate clerk, and Ansley Borkowski, clerk of the Assembly, were the first witnesses today before the extraordinary grand jury which is investigating the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -Four efforts to oust Harry Slattery, Rural Electrification Administrator, from office and executive action virtually removing his authority were reported by him to a Senate agricultural subcommittee today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The report that the Allied military authorities in Italy, vexed by the gloomy tone of some of the newspaper dispatches from the Anzio beachhead, have ordered more Stringent censorship and delayed transmission of the news comes at a time when public optimism toward the progress of the war is under concentrated attack by other military and civilian authorities.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the plan of the Florida Power Corporation to sell at competitive bidding $16,500,000 of first mortgage bonds and to sell to the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company $4,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent serial debentures.

John Marsh, 20-year-old elevator operator, was held in $10,000 bail yesterday at the Jefferson Market Court on the charge that he had sent threatening letters to Kathryn Grayson, singer and screen actress, and her husband, Capt. John Price, an Army captain, demanding military secrets.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 16 -- German propagandists offered today a new explanation for the weak Luftwaffe raids on London.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Feb. 16 -- The town of Kavieng, New Ireland, was burning brightly yesterday. In its harbor, the Japanese substitute for the much-bombed Rabaul, a 3,000-ton ship, three coastal vessels and smaller craft were sinking.

Radio "soap operas" were denounced as "reeking in so many cases with gush, gore and gutter morals," and defended as affording "an important kind of mental release," in a discussion yesterday in the Bar Building, 36 West Forty-fourth Street, under the direction of Mrs. Joseph E. Goodbar, radio and press chairman of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- The Polish Government in Exile charged today that "Germany's diabolical attempt to exterminate the Polish nation" had resulted in the death of "scores of thousands" of Polish children and complete extermination of all Jewish children in Poland.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 16 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communiqu:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, told the Senate Military Affairs Committee today that a national service act might have "appalling" consequences, because, he said, "millions of American families might be broken up" and "thousands of small business enterprise might have to be abandoned."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, blamed "broken homes and irresponsible parents" today as major contributors to an alarming increase in crime among boys and girls under 21.

ALGIERS, Feb. 16 -- The increasing role of, Pierre Laval's militia and the consequently intensified struggle between the militia and the resistance movements in France were predicted in reports from the underground reaching Algiers.

In connection with the letter of Yugoslav Ambassador Fotitch which was published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 6 I feel compelled to make a few comments as a Serb, as a Yugoslav and also as a representative of the party which precipitated the governmental crisis on the eve of the signing of the Tripartite Pact.

Multiple responsibility for war controls has repeatedly resulted in confusion and unnecessary delays in the formulation and effectuation of policy. Whenever several agencies have been charged with responsibility over the same segment of the economy, conflicts have inevitably developed.

The playing heard from Robert Casadesus, the French pianist, at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall was a masterly exhibition of virtuosity, but, taken in its entirety, his work during the evening was not on a par with the superlative performances to his credit at many a previous appearance in this city.

Three of the leading point-makers in the East, each with 200 or more points to his credit, will be seen in action in tonight's college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden, where St. John's clashes with Temple and CCNY meets St. Joseph's. Both Philadelphia squads are capable of turning this into a sorry night for the local fives, even though St. John's is a decided choice over the Owls.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A prediction that New York's fashion pre-eminence would not fade was made before the Fashion Group today by Clarence G. Sheffield, president of Julius Garfinckel Co., Washington store.
Yesterday's communiqu, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Tammany will send to the Democratic National Convention a delegation unanimously in favor renominating President Roosevelt for a fourth term, it became known last night when Edward V. Loughlin, the new Tammany leader, made public the candidates for delegates that the organization will support in the spring primary.

Approximately 1,360 University of Oslo students were taken into custody and placed in concentration camps by the German Gestapo during November and December, 1943. The figure represents the entire male enrollment of the university except for a small number of students expressing Nazi sympathies.

Secretary Eddie Brannick yesterday announced the Giants had signed Ewald Pyle, southpaw hurler obtained in the draft from Minneapolis of the American Association. Pyle raised to three the number of Giants in the fold, joining Joe Medwick and Bill Voiselle.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, at Cassino, Feb. 14 (Delayed) -- An American colonel whose job it is to take Cassino and whose troops are now fighting in the town where they have been longer than they care to think is truly a remarkable character, but unfortunately he must remain anonymous because of censorship rules.

In the intimate 299-seat theatre of the Blackfriars Guild, 320 West Fifty-seventh Street, "Caukey" will begin an experimental engagement this evening and continue at least through March 12. Wednesday night performances will be omitted.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- In a spirited game played in the Army's big field house today, the cadets, as yet unbeaten, scored their eleventh straight basketball triumph, defeating the University of Pennsylvania, 55 to 38.
A two home run in the ninth, with two out and the bases loaded, sent Mel Ott over the top and to victory over the late Lou Gehrig yesterday in the popularity poll of the War Bond Sports Committee.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk of Poland held a long meeting at 10 Downing Street today as the tension over the Russian-Polish boundary dispute increased.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Dies Committee on un-American Activities asserted in a report today that the "so-called 'Peace Now' movement," with headquarters in New York City, was engaged in treasonable and seditious activities.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan dismissed today a suit brought by Mrs. Muriel Meyers and Sidney Schneiderman of New York, stockholders in the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, to compel the return to the corporation of $3,000,000 alleged to have been lost since 1939 through mismanagement, misrepresentation and fraud.

"Termination financing" seems destined to become another of those meaningless phrases which gather important connotations. It is a pleasant, broad expression, designed to cover all the financial arrangements which the Government may make with industry when war contracts are canceled.

QUEBEC, Feb. 16 (Canadian Press) -- The Quebec Legislative Assembly unanimously adopted today a motion, proposed by Rene Chaloult, Lotbiniere member until recently of the Bloc Populaire, protesting against what was termed Lord Halifax's "new imperialism and dangerous tendencies," and began a debat on a motion proposed by Union Nationale opposition leader Maurice Duplessis, concerning immigration in the Province of Quebec.

BILL CURTIS was an athletic autocrat. He was willing to accept 9.8 seconds as a world 100-yard record but any time under that was dismissed with an emphatic wave of his hand. On seven distinct occasions before the turn of the century Bernie Wefers was clocked in 9.4 seconds, some thirty-five to forty years before Frank Wykoff and Jesse Owens made it official.

An air of mystery surrounded the resignation yesterday from his $6,500 position as regional chief hearing commisisoner of the Office of Price Administration of Harry B. Chambers, a critic of some OPA enforcement policies and a close associate of Edward J. Flynn, Bronx Democratic leader.

Directors of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company, at a meeting held here yesterday, appropriated $9,612,858 out of the 1943 income for interest payment on several bond issues to be payable on March 15. With this distribution all interest made contingent under the modification plan of 1938 and accrued to Dec. 31, 1943, will be paid.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The War Department is paying an average of 20 per cent less for Army equipment and supplies than it paid two years ago, and some items, including machine guns, rifles, tanks and bombers, are being purchased for from one-third to slightly more than one-half of their 1942 price.

After a series or legal clashes the way appeared to have been cleared in General Sessions yesterday for the opening next Wednesday of the first-degree murder trial of Wayne Lonergan, who strangled his young wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan.

Continued reluctance of the paper industry to bid on Army contracts will force issuance of stricter controlling orders which will guarantee prompt delivery of materials for military requirements, Rex W. Hovey, director of the paper division of the War Production Board, declared yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- The Governor's office has vetoed any wholesale revision of the Friedsam formula for State aid for education at this session of the Legislature, but is leaving the door open for additional funds for education, it was indicated today.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Germans have built extensive anti-invasion defenses, including a gigantic anti-tank ditch, along the coastline of Denmark, just about 300 miles across the North Sea from Brtiain, and have increased the Nazi occupation force to seven full divisions, according to reports from the Continent.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Feb. 17 (AP) -- For the first time since he took supreme command in the Southwest and South Pacific, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique dropped the Solomons heading in his communique, a consequence of his assertion yesterday that occupation of the Green Islands had strategically completed the Solomon Islands campaign.

"Phantom Lady," a melodrama produced by Universal starring Franchot Tone, Ella Raines, and Alan Curtis, will have its local premiere this morning at Loew's State. The film marks the debut as an associate producer of Joan Harrison, who formerly was assistant to director Alfred Hitchcock. Among the featured players in the mystery are Elisha Cook Jr., Fay Helm, Regis Toomey and Doris Lloyd.

A loan exhibition of portraits of well-known people of the opera and stage, entitled "Stars of Yesterday and Today," will be held at the Wildenstein Gallery, from March 8 to April 4, for the benefit of the Greater New York Red Cross 1944 War Fund.

The record of Negro fliers of the Ninety-ninth Pursuit Squadron of the Army Air Force in the European combat area was cited yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as an example to twenty-one Negro air navigation cadets whom he received at City Hall

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- "No matter how many nations bind together to give somebody's home to somebody else, it is contrary to the elementary sense of justice," Faris S. Malouf of Boston, president of the Syrian and Lebanese-American Federation of the Eastern States, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today at its hearing on the Wright-Compton resolutions to press for conversion of the British mandate of Palestine into a Jewish commonwealth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Bernard M. Baruch has submitted to the President his report on "War and Post-War Adjustment," which presents detailed recommendations to facilitate the transition of industry from war to peace.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Shipments of manufacturers were at virtually stationary levels during the last quarter of 1943, the Department of Commerce reported today.

A comprehensive plan whereby stockholders of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line (Mokan) Company would be able to exchange their stock for stock in the principal underlying asset of the company, the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, was announced yesterday by W.G. Maguire, president of Mokan.

Almost every type of clothes that might go into a spring wardrobe was represented among the fashions presented by Franklin Simon yesterday during luncheon at the Waldorf. Sportswear, tailleurs and toppers, dresses for day and evening and even raincoats for April showers were included.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 16 -- The tautness of the situation that exists between the Kuomintang party and the Chinese Communists in Yenan and Shensi Province and on the Shensi border region has noticeably relaxed recently, Dr. K.C. Wu, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, said today at a press conference.
Smith, Barney Co. head a group which will offer today 50,000 shares of Hooker Electrochemical Company $4.25 cumulative preferred stock at $100 a share.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE UNITED STATES FOURTEENTH AIR FORCE IN CHINA, Feb. 9 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Captured American fliers, handcuffed and blindfolded, have been herded by the Japanese through the cities of occupied China on planned "tours," apparently for the purpose of ridiculing them to the populace, it was revealed today.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- Heavy fighting is raging in north-central Croatia and northwestern Bosnia, where the forces of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) have smashed two German attempts to pierce the Yugoslav lines, a communique from Partisan headquarters said today.
BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 16 -- Joseph Darnand, Secretary for the Maintenance of Order, has received virtually unlimited authority as chief of the newly created "economic police."

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 16 -- The names of Presidential candidates will not be placed on New Jersey primary ballots unless they themselves file as candidates in the State under a bill to be introduced in the Legislature next Monday, it was announced here today by Lloyd B. Marsh, State Republican chairman.

The stock market was forced yesterday to give some ground when early strength faltered under modest profit-taking in the afternoon. Except in a few cases, fractional price alterations in either direction ruled in the share list, where the railroad issues again dominated the activity.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 16 -- "A positive, vigorous American policy" to assure to this country its share of the world's petroleum resources was recommended today by the Truman committee in a report on the use of petroleum in the war.

Anna Mayer, 21 years old, of 122-67 134th Street, South Ozone Park, Queens, who, for more than a month has been in agony from spasms of hiccups, will have to persuade herself that another skilled surgeon will give her relief from her malady.

It is 165 miles from Leningrad to Pskov. The Germans are rapidly evacuating all the land between. The Russians under General Govoroff are now closing in on Pskov itself. If they take this city, as seems likely, the Nazis will not only have to give up as much ground again in northwestern Russia but will find themselves fighting off envelopment in Estonia and Latvia.

In what is interpreted as an effort to dispel undue optimism regarding a quick victory over Japan, General MacArthur has issued another statement on Pacific strategy which follows similar statements issued by Admiral Nimitz and General Stilwell. General MacArthur rightly emphasizes that Japan is no longer a predominantly maritime Power which can be defeated through blockade or bombing alone.

GREAT FALLS, Mont., Feb. 16 -- Wendell L. Willkie, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, was welcomed here today by 400 party leaders at a "breakfast reception" given by 2,500 townsfolk at a noon meeting in the civic auditorium and by the season's worst snowstorm, which grounded his plane and delayed his departure for Sheridan, Wyo.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared last night that the responsibility for achieving better economic conditions on a world-wide scale and a universal understanding among the peoples of all nations rested on the people of the United States.
