Imagination and ingenuity went into the fashion show that Macy's presented yesterday morning. Besides placing some of the most interesting of the new trends on the runway it demonstrated how much women can do for themselves in making an otherwise unassuming dress interesting.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- A spirited defense of the bombing and shelling of historic or artistic shrines, whenever the requirements of the military situation demand it, was made today in the House of Lords, where it was argued that there is only one way to fight total war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Senate and House conferees reached an agreement today on legislation designed to prohibit most of the Administration's food price subsidies June 30, but the life of the Commodity Credit Corporation, which handles the programs under attack, expired technically before Congressional action was completed.

NAPLES, Feb. 16 (AP) -- American and British troops are winning the second round of the battle of the Anzio beachhead and will ultimately smash on to Rome without assistance from the Cassino front, Gen. Sir Harold R.L. Alexander, commander in chief of the Allies' forces in Italy, declared in a statement released today.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- After forty-six years of married life with one of this generation's most famous Irishmen, the late Mrs. George Bernard Shaw, in a will probated today, left $400,000 to teach the Irish the rudiments of social conduct and to abolish from their lives the social defects of shyness and inarticulate conversation.

Renewed price-fixing in the near positions absorbed yesterday light hedge-selling and liquidation and produced an improved tone in cotton futures. At the close of trading active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 9 to 12 points, or 45 to 60 cents a bale over Tuesday's final quotations.

Testifying yesterday at a Senate hearing on the proposed National War Service Act, William Green, president of the A.F. of L., argued that there have been more wartime strikes in Britain, in proportion to that country's population, than there have been in the United States.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The riddle of the illness and retirement of Lieut. Gen. Andrew G.L. McNaughton is transparent to those who have studied first hand the development of Canada's overseas forces.

Harry Greenstein, chief of the welfare branch of the division of program and requirements of the United Nations Relief and Rehabiltation Administration, declared yesterday that its aid would have to be supplemented by private agencies after the war.

It might almost be called The Mystery of the Congested Desert, or The Affair of the Invisible Tenant. We refer to our front-page story yesterday of how New York City today has three-quarters of a million people less than it had four years ago but it suffers from an acute housing shortage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Special House Committee investigating the Federal Communications Commission announced today that further consideration of the alleged forced sale to Edward J. Noble of Radio Station WMCA in New York would be postponed until the New York Supreme Court had 'reasonable opportunity" to dispose of the suit brought by Donald Flamm, former owner of the station.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, Feb. 16 -- Amphibious landing exercises, involving sizable concentration of warships, special assault vessels and landing craft, as well as considerable numbers of troops, are being conducted with realistic intensity in preparation for the coming invasion of Europe.
Chief City Magistrate Henry M. Curran yesterday created the Wayward Minors Court as a separate entity, parting it from the Women's Probation Court, under which it had functioned since 1936.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16 -- Lauritz Melchior, Metropolitan Opera tenor, has been signed for his first motion picture and will portray an opera singer in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Thrill of Romance," a comedy with music in which Esther Williams, the former swimming champion, will be featured.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Twenty-four members of the crew of forty-four on a 7,244-ton British freighter were lost when the ship ran onto the Boon Island Ledge, about twelve miles off York, Me., in a blizzard on Friday and split in two, the Public Relations Office of the First Naval District disclosed today, with approval of the British Admiralty.

New Yorkers, especially those whose education in roller skating is limited to seeing boys and girls coasting along the streets and sidewalks, got an eyefull of what real skating is last night when the 1944 exhibition for the benefit of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis was held in Madison Square Garden before an appreciative crowd of close to 9,000.

FEA preference ratings under WPB directive No. 27 are apparently not being recognized by manufacturers when materials involved fare destined for export, foreign traders reported yesterday. One exporter attempting to ship a consignment of chemicals said he was informed that even an AA1 priority would not be recognized and that a special directive would be required to insure actual priority.

Leonard Bernstein, 25-year-old assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, has not been re-engaged for the 1944-45 season, but will appear with the orchestra as guest-conductor for one week, the Philharmonic announced yesterday.

Should the present barriers against surface carriers engaging in aviation be lifted, the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad soon would be able to announce the formation of a coordinated rail-air-highway system to serve New England, Howard S. Palmer, president and trustee of the New Haven Railroad, said yesterday at a luncheon at the Advertising Club of New York.

George P. Kennedy, president of the Lafayette National Bank of Brooklyn, announced yesterday that Percy T. Stapleton had been appointed assistant to the president. Mr. Stapleton was chief clerk of the Surrogate's Court of Kings County.
An argument started when two young women entered the wrong box at last night's concert at Carnegie Hall later was carried to the West Fifty-fourth Street police station.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 16 -- The Columbia University basketball team sustained its tenth defeat in a game with the powerful Naval Academy five today, 65 -- 38.

Under the title "Woman as a Citizen," five women prominent in political, literary and social welfare fields will define issues involved in the coming Presidential election at discussions sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES Friday evening, Feb. 25, in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 16 -- Plans for the creation of a "Monroe Doctrine" along socialist lines for the Danubian area under the leadership of the Hungarians are revealed in press dispatches from Budapest tonight. The prime mover behind the scheme seems to be the Hungarian Socialist leader Karol Peyer.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- The War Production Board has allotted 2,000,000 tons of steel, copper and aluminum for domestic transportation during the second quarter of 1944, including metal to build 18,500 freight cars and to roll 550,000 tons of new rail, the Office of Defense Transportation, claimant agency for domestic transport under the Controlled Materials Plan, announced today.

The fourth performance of Verdi's "Rigoletto" in the Metropolitan Opera company's season was given last night with a cast largely different from the previous ones. Interest was focused chiefly on Patrice Munsel in the role of Gilda and Francesco Valentino as Rigoletto.

Further drains were made last week on the nation's supplies of fuel oil, but stocks of gasoline increased moderately, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline stocks at the close of the week amounted to 82,322,000 barrels, an increase of 538,000 over the 81,784,000 a week earlier.

Mrs. Edna Hancock, a former employe of Brooklyn State Hospital, was indicted yesterday by a Kings County grand jury on a charge of first-degree perjury. She was a complainant against Murray Goldman, whose conviction of attempted rape was set aside by Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz after Goldman had submitted to a lie-detector test.
Brown Bomber, Manassa Mauler, Iron Horse, The Bambino and Grand Slam, all famous sobriquets in the sports world, will carry messages of destruction to enemy powers in the not so far future.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- By a roll-call vote of 249 to 118, the House approved and sent to the White House today the bill extending the life of the Commodity Credit Corporation, but carrying a rider prohibiting most of the Administration's food price subsidies.
A communique, as broadcast domestically Thursday by the Finnish radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Two simultaneous OPA news items have in them the making of a nice problem in logic and social expediency. A prominent liquor importing firm has just handed over to the Federal Government a check for a quarter of a million dollars.

OTTAWA, Feb. 17 -- New regulations governing wartime labor relations and providing for compulsory collective bargaining have been put into effect in Canada by an order in council presented to Parliament today by Labor Minister Humphrey Mitchell and affecting directly the 2,500,000 workers in war and allied industries and indirectly another 1,000,000 who may be brought under the scheme.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- One thousand American soldiers have lost their lives in the sinking of a troopship, after an enemy attack, in heavy seas in European waters, the War Department announced this afternoon. Another thousand were saved.

MATLOCK, Derbyshire, England, Feb. 17 -- Marked by some turmoil, considerable confusion and many aspects of a political three-ring circus, one of the most curious and important by-elections Britain has seen in years came to a close today in this agricultural district of West Derbyshire.

When German control comes to an end in Belgium, will King Leopold resume the royal function which he has ceased to fulfill from the day he surrendered to the Germans as the head of his army? Or will he go down in history as a fallen and discredited monarch ?

Al Davis, the Brownsville welterweight who was once suspended for life by the New York State Athletic Commission, will be back in the main bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. He will face Bob Montgomery of Philadelphia in a clash listed for ten rounds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The exportable surplus of several Dominican foodstuffs will be purchased by the United States Government through the Foreign Economic Administration in order to help meet shortages of food in the Caribbean and other areas under an agreement announced tonight, to run to June 30, 1945.

Farm groups contemplating the further use of Italian prisoners of war as seasonal laborers were advised yesterday to eliminate such plans because of a pending change in the status of the Italians, due very shortly, which will take them "out of the category of war prisoners."

Although groceries and butcher shops appear to be virtually bare of certain varieties of meat and fresh produce, they are well stocked -- in some cases flooded -- with other foods, and so present no problem to the week-end marketer. For almost every scarce food there are substitutes that are plentiful and sell for lower prices than they did a week ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 -- Johnny Weissmuller, who for several years has appeared exclusively in "Tarzan" pictures, has been signed by Pine and Thomas for dramatic leads in three films they will make for Paramount during the coming year.

Marking its twenty-sixth season, the series of Yorkville Dinner Dances continued last night with a fete in the ballroom of the Cosmopolitan Club. For many years the dance was given as a semiannual fete, but in recent seasons the sponsoring organization, the Yorkville Community Association, has presented but one of these events each year to aid the support of Camp Yorkville in Harriman State Park.

The railroad issues, basically strengthened by the technical reaction of the previous session, pushed forward yesterday to new high ground while a good portion of the rest of the stock market joined in the rally. Prices were raised 1 and 2 points as orders in thousand-share lots reached the trading floor of the Stock Exchange at the turn of the first hour.

"Art in the Armed Forces" is the title of the Hyperion Press book that Scribners will distribute sometime in April. It will contain reproductions of art work done by professionals as well as amateur artists in the armed forces. Works of the special service projects launched in many Army camps also will be included.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Joan Berry's counsel withdrew today from her paternity suit against Charles Chaplin. A few hours earlier a motion by the actor's lawyer to have the suit dismissed was denied by a Superior Court judge.

Declaring that the increases in railroad expenses are coming too fast, R.W. Brown, president of the Lehigh Valley road, said last night in an address before the New York Railroad Club that it may be necessary for the carriers to seek additional income to cover them.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Two Commerce Department economists estimated tonight that American business as a whole will have from $10,000,000,000 to $20,000,000,000 left for plant and employment expansion after financing its own $36,000,000,000 transition from war to peacetime production.

The Gilbert Sullivan Opera Company last night offered the double bill of "The Pirates of Penzance" and "Cox and Box" at the Ambassador Theatre. And once again large groups of loyal Savoyards were on hand to greet the proceedings warmly. This morning the report is that Mr. R.H. Burnside's troupe is showing considerable improvement over its earlier performances of the famous operettas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Appointment of Brig. Gen. Albert J. Browning as chairman of the War Production Board's procurement policy board was announced here today by Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman. General Browning succeeds Frank M. Folsom, formerly assistant chief in charge of procurement of the Navy Department.

Hearst Magazines, Inc., have sold the fourteen-story apartment house at 471 Park Avenue, southeast corner of Fifty-eighth Street, adjoining the Ritz Towers, to Frederick Brown, operator, in one of the biggest all-cash deals on the East Side in some time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- President Roosevelt was reported tonight as planning to veto the $2,315,000,000 tax bill on the score that it had some crucial loopholes and fell far short of the Treasury's request for $10,500,000,000 in new revenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Acting to put a stop to the practice of over-finishing cotton and rayon finished piece goods, the Office of Price Administration announced today several devices which it predicted would bring back on the market many of the lower price lines of dresses and other goods which had been crowded out.

Mrs. George Bernard Shaw's testamentary gift of $400,000 for Irish uplift, particularly to rectify what she termed Irish "shyness and inarticulate conversation," had created by dawn yesterday a controversial storm unequaled even by Erin's legendary Night of the Big Wind.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel, under whom hundreds of thousands of men will fight for the mastery of western Europe, are in the midst of detailed inspection tours as the days lengthen and the invasion approaches.

Commission house selling, influenced by weakness in the wheat market, caused cotton futures yesterday to surrender most of their early gains. At the close of trading, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 2 to down 8 points.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 17 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

News that the Second Polish Corps has gone into front-line action against the Germans in Italy is more than a reminder that the Allied army moving on Europe is really an International Expeditionary Force, composed of elements from seventeen nations. This in itself puts into high relief the character of the war against the Nazis.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Department store sales for the week ended Feb. 12 were 21 per cent below sales in tile corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight.
LONDON, Feb. 17 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Officials of this city and of New York and neighboring States agreed yesterday in conference here that Federal aid would be needed for post-war highway projects, but expressed divergent opinions on the best methods of apportioning it.

In 1917 and 1941 the United States has found adequate protection in the oceans on its shores but in any future war air power will cut the time for total preparation to a few weeks, F. Lee Talman, executive vice president of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., said last night at the eighteenth annual dinner of the New York Security Dealers Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Feb. 17 (U.P.) -- The 180,000 Jews in the Netherlands have been "completely wiped out" by the Nazis as part of a plan to liquidate 5,000,000 persons in the occupied countries so that more food will be available for Germans, Netherlands official sources disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. l7 -- The Vatican, through its Washington representative, the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, denied today that the papal Willa at Castel Gandolfo, Italy, was "saturated with Germans and therefore subject to bombing."

Seventeen milk concerns, four of them in this State and the others in northern New Jersey, were posted yesterday for violation of their cream sales quotas under the milk conservation program of the War Food Administration.

The Blackfriars' Guild, which is Fifty-seventh Street's most earnest and ambitious bearer of drama's torch, last evening brought in its second play of the season. It was "Caukey," by the Rev. Thomas McGlynn, who as the son of Frank McGlynn has theatre blood in his veins, even if on this occasion he has not written a particularly good play.

DETROIT, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The pace-setting Canadiens showed who is boss in the National Hockey League by rallying in the third period tonight to defeat the second-place Red Wings, 3 to 2, before 13,175 spectators. Maurice Richard scored all three goals for Montreal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The immediate reaction of military authorities here with respect to the OWI's protest was to back up firmly the decision of the commanders on the spot. Asked what he thought of the requirement that news dispatches be sent by courier to Naples for censorship, rather than being transmitted from the beachhead by available radio, Mr. Stimson told a press conference:

Necklines, lowered waists, boleros, short dinner suits and bouffant evening gowns drew the attention of onlookers at Jay Thorpe's showing of custom-made models yesterday afternoon. As is bound to be the case, it is the care paid to details of made-to-order costumes that counts.

Newspaper participation in the drive to salvage 8,000,000 tons of waste paper this year to meet essential military and civilian production requirements resulted in the collection of 200,000 additional tons in December and January, Frank Block, director of the conservation committee of waste paper consuming industries, told a meeting yesterday of paperboard manufacturers in the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Minimum production requirements for deferment as an essential agricultural worker were doubled today by Selective Service Headquarters in a move to increase the number of men available for induction into the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Feb. l7 -- There was little change in the general level of commodity prices during the week ended Feb. 12. Prices for fruits and eggs were seasonally lower and there were further slight advances in market prices for coal as a result of ceiling adjustments to take account of higher costs.
The city's principal wholesale outlets for fruits and vegetables -- the Washington wholesale market, Bronx Terminal market and Brooklyn terminal market -- will close on Saturdays, starting tomorrow.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The United States Army has unwittingly muscled in on Shakespeare by taking over the historic Scala Theatre, where a season of the Bard's repertory was just beginning. The unhappy theatrical impresario is about to protest to Parliament about it.

Despite war claims and manpower shortages, the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company had its biggest year in 1943, according to a report released yesterday. Assets rose $153,420,344, insurance in force rose $602,365,209 to $6,438,540,577 and admitted assets gained 12 per cent to $1,441,468,994.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Delegates from sixteen leading national organizations in the fields of business and industry, finance, labor, agriculture and civic affairs gathered at the Claridge Hotel tonight for the first national post-war conference, opening tomorrow, the purpose of which is to lay the foundation for a "national unity" program after the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Though confronted by a certain veto, Congress sent to the White House today an anti-subsidy bill which President says would "black out" wartime food price stabilization and bring about inflation.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Viscount Wavell, Vice Roy of India, declared today that early self-government for India is "the genuine desire of the British people," but would not come until the Moslem League and Hindu-dominated All-India Congress party settled their differences.
PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 17 -- Truk is under attack by powerful units of the Pacific Fleet.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Feb. 17 -- About 2,500 employes of the Fletcher Shipyard of the Bethlehem Steel Company stopped work at 7:30 tonight in a protest over the suspension of a shop steward of Local 15, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO.

MOSCOW, Feb. 17 -- A statement that numbers of able-bodied Germans released from British captivity under an Anglo-German repatriation scheme are now serving with the Germans on the Russian front in the capacity of medical orderlies wearing sidearms appeared in the columns of Pravda today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The long-awaited Government pronouncement on health was made public today in the form of a White Paper proposing a comprehensive service for all, advice, treatment and care with the best available medical facilities regardless of the patient's ability to pay.

ATLANTA, Feb. 17 -- The Southern Regional Council, Inc., completed its organization at Atlanta University today and began work as an agency for the improvement of economic, civic and racial conditions in the South. At the same time, after twenty-two years of work in the field of race relations, the Commission on Interracial Cooperation was merged with the regional council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The war, as Secretary of Commerce Jones reminded Congress recently, is still to be won and "there are too many postwar plans" already. Yet a master plan of the United Nations for enduring settlements, to begin operation now, is one of the vital requirements of the world; and therefore the diary Col. Stephen Bonsal kept in 1918-20 has immediate importance.

A MYSTERIOUS new figure has moved into the baseball spotlight with the naming of Bob Coleman to manage the Boston Braves. Few persons outside the game know him at all and even the baseball writers, who seem to know everyone, are caught slightly out on the end of a limb. Yet this burly ex-catcher with the minor league background is likely to do surprisingly well.

BOSTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Coast Guard revealed today the heroism of a combat cutter's Negro mess attendant who gave his life to save that of his executive officer and others during rescue operations following the torpedoing of a transport in the North Atlantic last year.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Existing State penalties for "black marketeering" are "tant mount to a license fee," the joint legislative committee on nutrition declared in a report to the Legislature today. It urged that violations of Price ceiling and rationing regulations be made misdeameanors, punishable by a graduated system of stiff fines and jail sentences, so that repeated violations would be discouraged.

Stockholders of the Thatcher Manufacturing Company will be asked to vote at their annual meeting on March 1 on a plan to reclassify 18,000 shares of convertible preference stock, authorized but unissued, into an equal number of common shares.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Creation of a State Commission of Music, Drama and the Fine Arts is asked in a bill offered today by Senator Lester Baum of Manhattan, who declared that adoption of the measure would make Governor Dewey's program of post-war reconstruction "all-embracing in its scope."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate today passed the resolution authorizing a $1,350,000,000 United States contribution to the UNRRA program of war relief:

Harvesting of Victory garden crops and methods of preserving vegetables adaptable for storage through the winter months were discussed yesterday by Thomas Little, superintendent of a Cos Cob estate, in the last of a series of talks on gardening held at The New York Times Hall and sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and the New York Botanical Garden

The novel feature of the concert given by Arthur Rodzinski and the Philharmonic last night in Carnegie Hall was William Schuman's "William Billings Overture," a first performance; the most entertaining was the playing of the Scherzo from Mendelssohn's Octet for strings in the version that the composer orchestrated.

D.W. Figgis, president of the American Can Company, told stockholders yesterday in the forty-second annual report covering operations for 1943 that production of torpedoes and ammunition containers in subsidiary war plants lifted total output to a new high.

Many financial thinkers believe that China will be able to stabilize its currency. The effects of inflation in China are not so far-reaching as is generally imagined, still less as commonly described by foreign correspondents.

Any amendments to the price regulations on fur garments which do not provide for effective control of quotations on raw skins will not be approved by the industry advisory committees, according to a telegram which the chairmen of these committees have sent to James Brownlee, deputy administrator of the OPA, and made public here yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17 -- The seven-furlong Redlands Purse was split into three divisions at Hialeah Park today, the first time at the meeting that this occurred, and the respective winners were Singing Heels and Joe Burger in 1:26 2-5 and Liberty Pan in 1:26 4-5 over a fast track.

A "pin-up" doll that had its origin in G.I. underwear and Guadalcanal took the leading role yesterday in a cast of 20,000 characters opening in the fifth annual American Doll Show at Hearns Auditorium Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street.

The Bari radio said last night that Italian Premier Pietro Badoglio had reorganized his Cabinet, named two new Ministers and promoted others from the rank of under-secretaries to full ministerial status.

With the emphasis now being placed on the sale of E, F and G bonds to small investors, officials of the War Finance Committee of New York disclosed yesterday that additional tabulations have sent the total sales in the Fourth War Loan drive up to almost 105 per cent of the original quotas for New York State and City.

Because next Tuesday will be a holiday, the Treasury will be unable to make its now usual withdrawals from commercial bank war loan accounts on the first three business days of the week. However, in announcing yesterday afternoon a new call on these accounts, effective Monday and Wednesday, the Treasury did not take up this slack by increasing the withdrawals on these two days.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- A proposal that the United States be called upon to cast forty-eight votes at the peace table -- one for each State -- was put before the Legislature today in a resolution urging that the President be named to represent New York State.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY AT CASSINO, Feb. 16 (Delayed) (AP) -- German after German would walk up to the door, click his heels and inquire: "Ist der Herr Hauptmann da ?"

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- "Keep your shirt on," warned the Secretary of War, Henry L. Stimson, in colloquial fashion as he pleaded today for abandonment of the pessimism that some persons have attached to the situation on the Anzio beachhead.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City finished the fiscal week ended Wednesday with no excess reserves but with a reserve deficiency of $30,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. These banks began the week with excess reserves of $5,000,000.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The British Dominions, "desiring millions of immigrants after the war, should absorb Europeans as well as persons from the United Kingdom," Sir Alfred Beit, Member of Parliament, said today in Bristol. It was the first time a public figure here had ventured an opinion on such a touchy subject.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Concentrated selling of September wheat today on the Board of Trade by a commission house that was a large buyer several months ago and which was regarded at the time as against sales of cash grain to Mexico, resulted in a sharp break in prices.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 17 -- German denial of Allied charges that the Monte Cassino monastery was used for military purposes by the Germans was augmented today in a vehement statement by Field Marshal Gem Albert Kesselring, commander of the German forces in Italy.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- American ships now are serving double duty -- bringing home some of the soldiers who have earned a respite from battle.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 17 -- The Argentine Cabinet crisis that was precipitated Tuesday when a group of Army officers forcibly ejected Foreign Minister Alberto Gilbert from his office continues unsolved, for two important political posts in the Government -- that of Foreign Minister and that of Secretary to the Presidency -- have been filled only temporarily.

METUCHEN, N.J., Feb. 17 -- The Raritan Arsenal is under orders to triple its shipment of ordnance overseas within thirty days, thus increasing its consignments from 1,000,000 to 3,000,000 pounds a day, it was disclosed today by Col. Max A. Elser, commander, as he made an urgent appeal for additional workers to handle the "blitz" program, as he termed it.
The Berlin radio said yesterday: "Pope Pius XII's first words as he received news of the wanton destruction of Monte Cassino monastery were:

A few days ago the President stated he "did not have the nerve" to support Mr. Willkie's taxation policy. This shocking admission should rank in history with Prime Minister Baldwin's speech of November, 1936: "Supposing that I had gone to the country and said that Germany was rearming and that we must rearm.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Elements of the United States Ninth Air Force now in Britain under the command of Maj. Gen. Lewis H. Brereton are preparing for the coming invasion of Europe, Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Expeditionary Force announced tonight.

Selected work by members and associates of the Art Students League will be place on view on Sunday in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, and may be seen through March The show is entitled "Veterans Scholarship Exhibition" and is being held for the purpose of raising funds for scholarships to be given to returning service men and women now and at the end of the war.

The Bell Telephone System, through its "outstanding contribution" in the development of special electronic equipment for the armed services, has enabled the Army Air Forces to take the offensive against Japanese shipping in the Pacific at an earlier date than otherwise would have been possible, it was disclosed yesterday in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's annual report to stockholders.

FOLLANSBEE, W. Va., Feb. 17 (AP) -- To "T" or not to "T" may become a problem eventually for the new Navy coach, Swede Hagberg, but he made it clear today that the chances were he'd probably go along with the same system that put the middies among the nation's football topnotchers in 1943.

An item about the unusual migration of a flock of pintail ducks to Palmyra, a small island in the Pacific 1,100 miles south of Honolulu, caught the eye of Arthur Eilenberg of Brooklyn, who got to reflecting on what guides birds over vast distances to their destinations.

AMONG the delegates to the peace conference that met in Paris to formulate the terms of the Treaty of Versailles and the Covenant of the League of Nations none was more long-winded, more insistently repetitious, more annoying and boring to his fellow-delegates than Leon Bourgeois. His speeches often took several hours for delivery; they often repeated re marks he had made only a few days previously.
The influence of air power on our Italian operations has been widely misinterpreted, not only by the public, but possibly also by our military leaders.

The entire educational process in the schools and colleges of this country should be made "tougher," with more emphasis on the mastery of knowledge, it was urged yesterday by Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education. He suggested the extension of the school year to eleven months, with use of the summer holiday period for teaching manual skills to the students.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Roosevelt took steps today to see that adequate facilities were provided for the most complete news coverage by American correspondents of the forthcoming invasion thrusts in western Europe.

The American attack on Truk, announced yesterday in Washington, is the first blow struck at the great base that has always been regarded as the very heart and center of Japanese power in the South Pacific. At that base, certainly in the earlier stages of the war, possibly until a fairly recent date, the main strength of the Japanese fleet was concentrated.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 17 -- Although today produced no signs that the Finns are any nearer that arrangement with the Russians that Dr. Juho K. Paasikivi, former Finnish Premier, is evidently here to negotiate, one remarkable shift in Finnish officialdom occurred this afternoon to indicate that Helsinki is housecleaning for an armistice and ultimate peace.

Skiing enthusiasm is running high in the northeastern snow belt as thousands of devotees looked forward to an enjoyable time running trails and slopes during the Washington Birthday period. While habitues of such accessible centers as Bear Mountain Park, the Catskills and Berkshires have little to be optimistic about, ideal conditions were reported yesterday in the Poconos, Green and White Mountains, Adirondacks and the Laurentians.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The report by Bernard M. Baruch on "war and post-war adjustment," which will set a pattern for industrial transition from war to peace, is likely to be made public tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- "The fact that Truk is Japan's greatest naval base promises a day memorable to that enemy," said Vice Admiral John S. McCain, deputy chief of naval air operations, over the radio tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Virtual elimination of capital goods shipments to Britain under lend-lease is understood to have been agreed upon by British and American supply officials here. The decision is one of many adjustments being made to keep lend-lease exports closely geared to military needs.

Harry C. Steigman has purchased the seven-story loft building at 549 Sixth Avenue, southwest corner of Fifteenth Street, from the Union Square Savings Bank for occupancy by the Harry C. Steigman Equipment Corporation, manufacturers and jobbers supplying interior decorators and hotel.

LONDON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Finland appeared tonight to have made her bid to Moscow for peace, and, although there were indications that her terms were far short of the Soviet demands, heavily bombed Helsinki seemed eager for compromise.

SHERIDAN, Wyo., Feb. 17 -- Warning that resentment against some phases of the New Deal and its assumption of arbitrary power must not be carried too far by the Republican party, Wendell L. Willkie said today that the Federal, State and local governments must work together for the solution of post-war problems.

Robert E. Olson, 39 years old, warrant officer at Hill Field, an Army camp at Ogden, Utah, who formerly resided in Brooklyn, was found guilty of second-degree murder yesterday by a General Sessions jury for having shot and killed Chief Petty Officer William Wilson of the Navy in a quarrel in the Hotel New Yorker on Dec. 23.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The able teamwork of Lieut. Col. Bernice Wilbur of the Army Nurse Corps and Corp. Esther Martin of the Women's Army Corps in routing 2,000 Army nurses and their equipment around the vast North African war theatre was described today by the War Department.

CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 17 (AP) -- British forces held firmly to their Maungdaw-Buthedaung line on the Arakan front of southwestern Burma today while bitter clashes continued in the rear with Japanese forces attempting to cut off the main supply line through Ngakyedauk Pass.

With the utmost respect for Mrs. Bernard Shaw's good intentions, her gift of two-thirds of her fortune to establish after Mr. Shaw's death an institution to "teach the Irish manners and improve their speech" is even more preposterous than if the fund were to found and support a College of Vegetarians.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Feb. 18 -- United States Army and Navy night and day bombers have smashed at a big Japanese convoy attempting to reinforce the enemy's Bismarck Archipelago garrisons and sunk or seriously damaged five cargo ships as well as a destroyer and three gunboats, it was announced today.

Advertising of New York and Brooklyn department stores during January totaled 2,675,852 lines, compared with 2,867,015 in the corresponding month last year, a decrease of 6.7 per cent, according to the monthly breakdown by Media Records.

Local officials of the Internal Revenue Bureau said yesterday that under the present Federal laws they were powerless to take action in instances of the public being solicited to have their tax returns made out for a fee by so-called experts operating in small stores, shoe shine parlors and other "corner establishments."

ALGIERS, Feb. 17 -- After the Germans had slashed into British and American positions in the northern sector of the beachhead below Rome yesterday in their second major attempt to drive the Allies into the sea, the Allied air forces responded today with the heaviest all-out close support of ground troops ever unloosed in the Mediterranean theatre.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 18 -- Gen. Ivan S. Koneff's Ukrainian armies, in a final assault with tanks and massed gunfire, finished the liquidation of ten German divisions yesterday west of Cherkassy, where Adolf Hitler had ordered his men to hold on or die, Moscow announced today, and Germany lost 52,000 front-line troops killed and 11,000 captured in another Nazi debacle resembling Stalingrad on a smaller scale.

Luigi Antonini, general manager of Local 89 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, American Federation of Labor affiliate, largest local in the ILGWU, with a membership of 37,000, was re-elected to his office yesterday over a rank-and-file opposition candidate supported by the Communists.
The three-story apartment and store building at 6210 Park Avenue, West New York, N.J., has been sold by the Prudential Insurance Company to Ernest Moser.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Feb. 17 -- The enemy started again this morning to put pressure on the Allies along the semi-circular Tyrrhenian Sea front below Rome after an over-night lull in the new offensive.

With a discarded shell as their only clue, detectives of the Wadsworth Avenue station traced the killing of Samuel Zadzanick, 45 years old, a candy store proprietor at 1587 St. Nicholas Avenue, to a teen-age hold-up gang and arraigned two boys, one 15 and the other 16, in Homicide Court yesterday as the slayers.

Gen. Henry H. Arnold, chief of the Army Air Forces, and Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, warned industry last night against slackening of production of war materials.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, who auctioned off his famous brown derby for $150,000 in War Bonds on Feb. 5, got the derby back yesterday.

TRENTON, Feb. 17 -- While publican State Chairman Lloyd B. Marsh and E. Bertram Mott, Morris County party leader, continued their conflict over Presidential primary choices in New Jersey, Governor Walter E. Edge went on record here today for an uninstructed delegation to the national convention.
BOSTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Bidding was somewhat irregular today as the Defense Supplies Corporation opened its auction of 30,000,000 pounds of foreign wool.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Conferees on the service men's voting legislation failed at two closed sessions today to reach ground even for discussion of specific proposals for compromise between the Federal ballot and the "States' rights" program.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- It was like this: The Chicago sergeant was sleeping off the effects of his ten-hour train trip into London, so tired he had not even taken his shoes off, when who should walk into his bedroom and wake him up but the King and Queen of England.
Concerning David Anderson's dispatch, "Stateless Worry Allies' Officials," in the issue of Feb. 6, regarding the status of Jewish refugees after the war, I would like to state:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- In assuming jurisdiction over the War Relocation Authority, which was transferred yesterday "in its entirety" by Executive Order to the Department of the Interior, Secretary Ickes said today that the program developed by Dillon S. Myer, WRA director, and his organization would be continued and, he hoped, made even more effective as a unit of his department.

"Life With Father" goes on and on passing new milestones and not paying a great deal of attention to them. Last night, for instance, Producer Oscar Serlin observed the 1,800th performance of the Roward Lindsay-Russel Crouse comedy he brought to the Empire on Nov. 8, 1939.

NYACK, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- Representative Hamilton Fish of the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, which now includes Rockland County, opened his campaign for renomination tonight in a debate on his qualifications with Augustus W. Bennet, Newburgh attorney, before 300 members and guests of the Nyack Republican Club.

The Pennroad Corporation reported yesterday that the net asset value at the close of last year was equivalent to $7.08 each on the 8,300,000 capital shares outstanding, compared with $6.59 a share on Dec. 31, 1942. Net income for 1943 was $1,934,728 after expenses and taxes, equal to about 30 cents a share, compared with $1,717,103, or 25 cents a share, in 1942.

To an amateur churner, who considers herself a top-ranking one, your editorial of Feb. 10 was most interesting. I use a gallon glass contraption with a paddle, of course, a mysterious arrangement of wheels on top and a crank. Not picturesque, but very useful.
"Action in Arabia," a drama of espionage and romance produced by RKO, will be the new attraction today at the Palace.

In the summer of 1942 the Communist weekly, The New Masses, recommended that the American Labor party "draw new strength by including the CIO unions in the membership." Recently Sidney Hillman, as chairman of the CIO Political Action Committee, has proposed that all CIO unions in this State become affiliated with the ALP and be represented on its State Executive Committee in accordance with their respective membership standings.

J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the board of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, has accepted the general chairmanship of the 1944 campaign of the Greater New York Fund, it was announced yesterday by Arthur A. Ballantine, president of the fund, after the annual meeting of the fund at its headquarters, 11 West Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York told the House today that the proposal of Governor Dewey for Gubernatorial appointment of New York judges was "rather brazen," but was met by Republican retorts that Mr. Dewey had a precedent in President Roosevelt's efforts to "pack" the Supreme Court.

Two 12-year-old boys admitted to detectives in Bayside, Queens, that they were responsible for the damage in All Saints Protestant Episcopal Church, Fortieth Avenue and 215th Street, Bayside, which was discovered Wednesday morning.

Bids will be opened on March 13 by Haverford Township, Pa., on $479,000 of refunding bonds. The issue will be dated April 1, 1944, and will mature serially from April 1, 1945, to 1964. The interest rate, to be named by the bidders, is not to exceed 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- After adopting six clarifying and restricting amendments and rejecting as many more, the Senate passed the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration resolution today by a vote of 47 to 14. The opposition was evenly divided between Democrats and Republicans.
An eleven-room apartment at 33 East Seventieth Street has been leased to B.H. Homan through the Tishman Realty Construction Company, agent, and the Apartment Renting Company, Inc., broker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (U.P.) -- Announcement today of the United States troopship tragedy followed by a year the sinking of two American ships in the North Atlantic with a loss of about 850 Army, Navy and Marine personnel and civilians. Those ships were torpedoed and sunk four days apart. Both were described as cargo ships.

A ferocious attack by a crack German fighter group, dubbed by Eighth Air Force airmen "the Abbeville Kids," that killed one and wounded the remaining gunners in his Flying Fortress crew, marked his first introduction to aerial warfare over western Europe and was by far the most exciting of his twenty-five missions, Technical Sgt. Charles E. Vondrachek said yesterday.
Now that we deal in astronomical sums of inconceivable magnitude -- billions, trillions -- a mere half of a cent is not considered money.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The stock markets here today reacted favorably to unexpected announcements of dividend increases by the Southern and the London Northeastern Railways.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Vice President Wallace, just returned from a speaking tour on which he denounced "Wall Street" Americans as "Fascists," defended his remark today with the explanation that there was a little of the Fascist in everyone.

Oscar R. Ewing, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, reported yesterday on his return from a three-week tour of the Pacific Northwest that political sentiment there has swung sharply in favor of the re-election of President Roosevelt.

Lack of a wide assortment of surplus materials and difficulties in acquiring such materials would greatly limit the scope of the War Production Board's test-area plan for the resumption of civilian goods output, small producers stated yesterday.

Aided by several skyscraper players, Temple University sprang an upset by defeating St. John's, New York's leading team, 47 to 44, in the opening game of last night's basketball double-header before 15,252 spectators at Madison Square Garden.

ALGIERS, Feb. 17 -- Eleven officers and guards accused of murdering, torturing and beating prisoners in a Vichy concentration camp at Colomb-Bechar, Algeria, went on trial here today before a special military tribunal with two civil judges sitting.

The American Government has at last decided to give adequate publicity to the fiendish treatment accorded American prisoners of war unfortunate enough to fall into the hands of the Japanese, and to the steps taken to ameliorate their lot. We believe that this is a wise decision.

WITH THE ALLIED FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Feb. 17 -- A traveling laboratory of the newest American weapons, many of which are still entirely secret and others not yet in use on the Italian front, was exhibited today to a large group of United States and British generals and colonels at a makeshift proving ground.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Exports of beverage alcohol to the United States from Cuba will be "frozen" at the levels attained last year, the Foreign Economic Administration revealed today in announcing an agreement with Cuba for the purchase of a minimum of 65,000,000 gallons of blackstrap molasses.
LONDON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday, issued today, showed a decrease of u290,000 in note circulation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The electrical industry, stimulated by future developments in electronics and television, will be a "veritable promised land" for women workers after the war, Secretary Frances Perkins predicted today in an address to women students of Catholic University.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 17 -- Eighty-five bodies had been recovered by noon today from the ruins of Berlin's fashionable Hotel Bristol, in the shelter of which 200 persons died when an RAF blockbuster scored a direct hit on Tuesday night's raid, said a traveler who arrived here aboard the afternoon's plane from Berlin.

KWAJALEIN ATOLL, Marshall Islands, Feb. 4 (Delayed) -- The buddies of Marine Pfc. Stephen P. Hopkins told today how the son of Harry Hopkins, Presidential adviser, died a hero's death on windswept Namur Island.
The New York Stock Exchange membership of John T. Berdan has been transferred to E. Warren Willard of Boettcher Co.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Governor Dewey today appointed Robert L. Garner of New York City, vice president of the General Foods Corporation and a former vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, as a member of the New York State Banking Board to succeed Harold L. Reed, Professor of Economics and Finance at Cornell University, whose term will expire on March 1.

Your Feb. 10 editorial "In Justice to India" was very timely. An additional reason for readmitting the people of India to American citizenship -- a privilege enjoyed by them until 1924 -- is the fact that the Hindus, like the Europeans, belong to the Caucasian race.

Union leaders and Office of Price Administration officials agreed yesterday on a program by which the unions would keep their members, employed in the retail trade, from violating price and rationing rules, and OPA would, in its black market prosecutions, put the major responsibility on employers who, in one way or another, induced their employees to violate regulations.

Assets of the Equitable Life Assurance Society have risen above the $3,000,000,000 level for the first time. Thomas I. Parkinson, president, announced yesterday in releasing the company's report for 1943. Total assets, he said, increased $256,798,026 during the year to a total of $3,189,654,385.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Industry ces continued severe cuts in war ders in the next few months with complete or partial cancellation of large number of contracts, it was stated tonight by Brig. Gen. Albert J. Browning, director of purchases of the War Department, who has just been appointed also chairman of the procurement policy board of the War Production Board. He spoke at a dinner meeting of the Economic Club of Chicago.

"Hitler thinks of everything" the Germans boasted in the years when his war juggernaut was rolling well. If Germans say it today -- those of them who have any judgment at all -- it is only through fear of the eavesdropping Gestapo. For he failed to think of several things.

Twelve thousand men have been commissioned by the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia University since it was established in 1940, Capt. John K. Richards, commanding officer of the school, announced yesterday. All of the men received their training on the Columbia campus or aboard the Prairie State, formerly the battleship Illinois.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 17 -- The story of the marines' flight over Truk, written by First Lieut. Penn T. Kimball of New Britain, Conn., and Second Lieut. William K. Holt of Clarksburg, W. Va., was released here today with the Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's communique.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The stock markets here were mostly quiet today. Home rails eased on profit-taking.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Feb. 19 -- The capture of Staraya Russa, the enemy's westernmost outpost in northern Russia, was announced late last night by the Russians. At the same time they reported the end of the annihilation of the Nazis' Eighth Army in the Cherkassy pocket.

Ever since a state of siege was proclaimed in Argentina in mid-December, 1941, the newspapers of the Argentine Republic have been subjected to rigorous gag laws. If Castillo was a whip Ramirez has been a scorpion. Numerous journals were suspended for their treatment of the Storni-Hull letters.

The editorial "Subsidy Sequence" in your issue of Feb. 14 is erroneous in its implication. The subsidy program for grapefruit juice was instituted by a directive from the Office of Economic Stabilization on Dec. 14, 1943, and Senator Barkley was informed of it in writing prior to the statement quoted in your editorial.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The resignation of Lance Booth, food rationing officer of the Office of Price Administration regional office at New York City, was announced today by Chester Bowles, Federal Price Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Dr. George F. Zook, president of the American Council on Education, said tonight that the cut in Army training would have "a very serious effect" on colleges already hard hit by the war and would bear hardest on those which have no women students and no Navy contracts."

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 19 --The British people would undoubtedly welcome the re-election of President Roosevelt because they look on him as a liberal friend who helped them in the dark days of 1940, but it would be a mistake to assume from this that their Government is "intervening" in our election on his behalf.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The text of President Roosevelt's special message today vetoing the food subsidy bill follows:

Because of the relaxation of dimout restrictions the 1944-45 budget of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity calls for an increase of $1,235,500 for light and power services, Commissioner Patrick Quilty declared yesterday at a hearing before Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson.

The simple, almost waveless coiffures that are becoming a wartime fashion depend for their beauty upon the clean and glossy appearance of the hair itself. And the weekly shampoo, indispensable to this satiny texture, will often have to be administered at home, according to the reports of busy salons.

By now we have the results of the House of Commons by-election in which the Conservative candidate was Lord Hartington, son of the Duke of Devonshire, of the Cavendish family which has represented that particular constituency for 205 years out of the last 210.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Sammy Baugh, the Texas ranchman, today officially roped the 1943 passing championship of the National Football League.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President Roosevelt made public today the Bernard M. Baruch blueprint on how to arm the domestic economy for peace while winning the war. The report said, however, that nothing should come before early defeat of the Axis.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The joint legislative committee to study the use of State prison inmates in war service recommended today immediate adoption of legislation making available any inmate found acceptable to the armed forces. Action on an inmate would require the approval of parole and correction authorities.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- Armour Co. consider themselves amply protected against a repetition of the disastrous inventory losses that followed the first World War, George A. Eastwood, president, assured holders of stock in that meat-packing concern at their annual meeting today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today granted Associated Gas and Electric Corporation permission to submit further evidence at a hearing Feb. 24 on the retainability under the Holding Company Act of four groups which Associated says form single integrated public utility systems. The groups are:

The General Reinsurance Corporation reported yesterday admitted assets of $24,642,440 as at the close of 1943, comparing with $20,652,207 a year before. On the basis of market quotations for securities other than stock of affiliates, assets at the year end were valued at $25,006,491, according to Edgar H. Boles, president.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- Federal intervention in the field of health and hospital insurance would be "an attack" on the individual's constitutional rights and would seriously undermine the effectiveness of medical services offered by American hospitals, Mgr. Maurice Griffin, trustee of the American Hospital Association and vice president of the Catholic Hospital Association, asserted today.

Retail trade here continued "soft" this week and declines under a year ago were general among both department stores and specialty shops. Weather conditions slowed up the sale of early spring offerings and comparison was with the extremely high sales of the scare-buying period of 1943.

The hat that fits the head and the hat with the low, broader crown, were the two silhouettes most emphasized in the new collection of custom millinery viewed in the salon of Henri Bendel, Inc., yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- President Roosevelt is going to send the new $2,315,000,000 tax bill back to Congress Monday or Tuesday -- presumably with a veto.

DALLAS, Tex., Feb. 18 (AP) -- The greatest amount of men, munitions, installations and equipment the world has ever known is being assembled in England for the invasion of the European Continent, which is certain to come, Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell said today.

The heads of two travel agencies, the agencies themselves and two head porters in prominent midtown hotels whose sideline was to handle travel accommodations for guests, were accused yesterday in grand jury informations of violations of the City Administrative Code in overcharging on the cost of special reservations on trains leaving the city.

Representatives of forty-two nationality groups were present at the organization luncheon of the Nationalities Division of the Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York yesterday at the Hotel Brevoort.
Yesterday's Soviet communique, as broadcast by the Moscow radio to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The Dies committee has asked for access to the records of the Congress of Industrial Organizations Political Action Committee, and Sidney Hillman, chairman of the latter, announced yesterday the request had been refused.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The War Production Board reported today that the proposed "equitable distribution order" and other related problems have been discussed with members of the wholesale and retail soft lines advisory committee. The discussions, it added, also included redistribution of service surpluses, future problems of reconversion and other matters, including Inventory Limitation Order L-219.

ALGIERS, Feb. 18 (AP) -- An American lightweight and a French featherweight were crowned champions in the professional division of the Allied Boxing Tournament today as other classes narrowed down to the finalists.

Rossbach Associates, Inc., real estate firm, have leased large additional office space adjoining their present quarters on the eleventh floor of 136 East Fifty-seventh Street from the Tishman Realty Construction Company. The firm recently took over the business of Warren Marks.

Railway issues tired yesterday as the stock market once more conformed to its recent pattern of following a day of strength with a period of congestion. Cashing of profiles among the previously strong rails was not widespread, but demand was limited to special situations.

Post-war attempts to protect obsolete investments will produce an even greater threat to inflation than exists today, Thurman W. Arnold, associate justice of the United States Court of Appeals and former attorney general, warned here yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- One of a shower of German fire bombs that dropped in the grounds of the Houses of Parliament recently burned a hole in the roof of Westminster Hall, one of Britain's most famous buildings, orginally built by William II in 1097.

The Houston Lighting and Power Company filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the issuance of 112,264 shares of new $4 preferred stock and 47,513 shares of common stock.

Prohibitions on the manufacture and sale of military insignia which were imposed by the War Department last July have been lifted by Major Gen. James A. Ulio, adjutant general, according to word received from the War Department yesterday by the Military Suppliers Association of America.

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 19 (U.P.) -- The capture of Staraya Russa and of Shimsk forged an almost unbroken Soviet line curving 165 miles from Lake Peipus on the west to the Staraya Russa area in the east, converging on the German rail junctions of Pskov and Dno.

The only assurance of lasting peace after the defeat of the Axis is through a European federation with a common defense and a bill of rights, Count Richard N. Coudenhove-Kalergi, Austrian author of "Crusade for Pan-Europe," said last night at a dinner of The New York Academy of Public Education in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The sale of 500,000 pounds of butter at black market prices was charged yesterday to A. Quinn's Sons, Inc., 137 Reade Street, and Jacob A. Quinn, president, and Nathan Quinn, secretary and treasurer of the concern. The allegations were embodied in a sixteen-count criminal information filed in Federal court by United States Attorney James B.M. McNally.

A bill to lower the compulsory school age in New York City from 16 to 15 years of age for those students found "incapable of profiting from further instruction" is being sponsored by the High School Principals Association and is scheduled to be introduced in Albany next week, it was learned yesterday.

A panel appointed by the War Labor Board will seek a solution to the wage controversy of 350,000 steel workers with 214 companies, it was disclosed yesterday by Theodore W. Kheel, executive director of the board. Mr. Kheel told 300 business representatives at a meeting of the Commerce and Industry Association at 233 Broadway that the panel would sit either in Washington or Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The United States Maritime Commission announced today the award of its "M" pennant for outstanding production achievement to two shipyards and other "star" and "eagle" awards for continued meritorious production to shipyards already flying the "M" pennant.

J.M. Shields, Inc., has reopened its New Rochelle office at 213 Huguenot Street and will act as management and sales agent for the Home Owners Loan Corporation there, John F. Mahaffey, president of the company, has announced.
Investments in two large apartment properties in the Gramercy Park section were announced yesterday by Netter Netter, attorneys, who bought the houses for clients.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A soldier vote bill defining Federal ballots as "supplementary" to State ballots was proposed to deadlocked Senate-House conferees today by Senator Theodore F. Green, Democrat, of Rhode Island, co-author of the Green-Lucas Federal ballot bill

The Citizens Budget Commission believes that the present proposed appointment of 769 teachers in the New York City schools as a means of meeting the permanent substitute teacher problem would aggravate a serious situation already existing in the schools.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 18 -- With fifteen named for the $7,500 added McLennan Memorial Handicap, the first of Hialeah Park's three climactic stakes will be run tomorrow before a crowd which is expected to be the biggest of the season, perhaps 15,000.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Early appraisals of Britain's national health plan, published yesterday by the Government in the form of a White Paper, agree it is an ingenious compromise between the existing condition and all-out state medical service, fundamentally sound and very provocative.

Bearing a certificate signed by Russian and American Naval officials that attested to the "privations suffered by the men of the 'Forgotten Convoy,' and their shivering through the Arctic winter and nine months confinement in the White Sea," Olympio Nouguerira Vasques, chief cook on the S.S. Bering of the Moore McCormack Steamship Company, declared yesterday that he "had the time of his life" while his ship was anchored there.

This year's harvest of the nations crop of vegetables and fruits will be at least 4 per cent greater than last year -- the largest in the history of the country -- and the major burden of harvesting the increase will fall squarely on the shoulders of the women of the Country and the 'teen age boys and girls.

MEDIA, Pa., Feb. 18 -- Samuel J. Reeves, president of the Phoenix Iron Works at Phoenixville, was killed early today when his automobile left the highway near here and crashed into a stone wall surrounding Media Cemetery. Mr. Reeves, who was 64 years old, was found pinned behind the wheel.

HEADQUARTERS, THE FOURTEENTH UNITED STATES AIR FORCE IN CHINA, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault said today that the Fourteenth Army Air Force was laying the groundwork for collaboration with Admiral Chester W. Nimitz in cracking Japan's Pacific defenses and carrying on the war from China.

Federal Judge Robert A. Inch, in Brooklyn, yesterday accepted plead of guilty from fourteen men am five corporations who had violates Office of Price Administration regulations. It was alleged they had made wholesale purchases of meat at prices higher than the ceiling figures.

Among those reported yesterday as having leased residential space was Paul de Vries, diamond merchant, who took quarters in 1045 Park Avenue through the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, agent, and Wm. A. White Sons, brokers. Other rentals follow:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Among 435 Army and 189 Navy casualties announced today by the War and Navy Departments were the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut: ...

Total national production of all goods and services will have to be maintained at a $200,000,000,000 level, compared to a pre-war "prosperity" level of $100,000,000,000, to provide full employment at present prices and levels of production per employed civilian, Arno Johnson; director of media and research for the J. Walter Thompson Company, stated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Following is the text of the covering letter by Bernard Baruch and John Hancock accompanying their report on war and post-war adjustment policies:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A communique:

Fifteen Wacs, the first group in the Second Service Command to be so honored, received the Army's Good Conduct Medal yesterday at the recruiting and induction district headquarters in Grand Central Palace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- Eric O. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said today that American business was "out of the dog house," but he warned trade leaders that it is "only three jumps from the master bedroom to the kennel."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 1 -- The first national conference o post-war problems, which was opened today in the Claridge Hotel with more than fifty delegates attending from sixteen leading business, labor, agricultural and civic organizations, issued a statement tonight warning that the conflicting interests in the American economic structure, which hitherto usually have acted as pressure groups for their own interests hereafter must collaborate instead of fighting each other.
LONDON, Feb. 18 (UP) -- A German communique broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded by The United Press:

Unidentified hands smeared crude hammer-and-sickle designs and other marks in red paint on doors and walls of St. Patrick's Cathedral, on the Church of the Ascension and on the Church of St. John the Evangelist late Thursday night or early yesterday morning. All are Catholic edifices.

President Branch Rickey yesterday checked in with two items of information concerning the Brooklyn Dodgers. The two tidbits were not necessarily in the order of their importance to the club -- first, the acquisition of another young catcher and second, Manager Leo Durocher is not going overseas on that long projected United Service Organizations tour.

Reflecting a pause in mill buying and more favorable war news, cotton prices yesterday were mixed. The new crop months were relatively easy because of hedge selling against purchases of the near months. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, old contract positions were up 1 to off 3 points and the new contract deliveries were up 2 to off 9 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- By December, 1943, the value of all business inventories totaled $26,800,000,000, representing a decline of $1,200,000,000 under the preceding year, the Commerce Department announced today. The cause of the decline was attributed to "the extraordinary liquidation of retail stocks."
The Studebaker Corporation announced yesterday the completion of arrangements with a group of twenty-five banks for an $80,000,000 line of credit under a VT loan agreement expiring on Dec. 31, 1946.

Increases in "sexual delinquency" among the nation's youth must be combatted by more and better sex education for children and adults in schools and homes, it was agreed yesterday by leaders in medicine, psychiatry, sociology and religion who formed the American Committee on Sex Education and Marriage Counsel.

Supporters of the administration of David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, were disclosed yesterday to have followed up their election victory in Local 89, the union's largest, with clean sweeps in the two next largest locals.

MATLOCK, Derbyshire, England, Feb. 18 -- History repeated itself today when Alderman "Charlie" White, like his popular father before him, defeated a member of the ancient English Cavendish family after a bitter and confused political campaign for the seat in the House of Commons representing West Derbyshire.

THE track season was in its usual hibernation because winter had closed down on the sport. But some New York A.C. foot-racers were restless for competition. Finally someone hit upon the brilliant idea of staging an indoor meet. Gilmore Gardens on Third Avenue near Sixty-fifth Street was the site and thus was board-floor racing introduced on this continent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Assuming continuation of present construction policies and total war through 1944, the volume of construction during this year will amount to $3,700,000,000, which would be 49 per cent of 1943 volume and 28 per cent of 1942's, the War Production Board estimated today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Feb. 19 (U.P.) -- Many men of the Imperial Japanese Navy went down with their ships as American planes finished a fight started Tuesday, when the convoy was spotted off Mussau Island, north of New Ireland.

A study of the rayon and hosiery situations will be conducted in the immediate future by the War Production Board, according to market reports, to explore possibilities of permitting the use of rayon yarns finer than 100 denier in the leg of women's hosiery made on 42 gauge or coarser full-fashioned machines and in the leg of a 300-needle or coarser circular knit stocking.
BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 18 -- Spokesmen for the German High Command today emphatically denied the Russian claims of the annihilation of ten German divisions trapped west of Cherkassy.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 18 -- The vast project of publishing the complete writings and correspondence of Thomas Jefferson was started here today, when the advisory committee appointed to supervise the work held its first meeting.

Robert Gross, 29-year-old violinist, gave his first local recital last night in Town Hall. Mr. Gross was the concertmaster of the American Youth Orchestra, under Leopold Stokowski, on its tour of South America and appeared with that organization as soloist.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 18 (AP) -- An Allied communique:

What became of the smelt that used to swarm into the tributary streams of Lake Michigan and others of the Great Lakes? The mystery goes back a year but its effects will be felt soon when those who seek these small silvery fish will, in all probability, find them missing by the millions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- United States Navy air and sea forces scored a big, smashing victory at Truck, and we will conquer the Japanese or the Pacific Ocean atoll, Franx knox, Secretary of the Navy, assured a news conference today.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- Ben Riley, colorful restaurateur, whose Arrowhead Inns were landmarks in New York night life for more than fifty years, was burned to death early this morning on the second floor of his inn, a two-story brick building at 385 Tuckahoe Road, here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The forty-four-story Board of Trade Building looked as if it were under air-raid attack for an hour today during an explosion and fire in a ground floor cleaning establishment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Reasons of "imperative military necessity" have forced the War Department to slash the Army Specialized Training Program from 145,000 to 35,000 men, it was suddenly announced tonight.

Citing statistics which he asserted should "quiet the fears of some alarmists who have the impression that we have admitted large numbers of refugees," Earl J. Harrison, United States Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, emphasized last night, however, that "probably no other group of immigrants in the twentieth century has been able to adapt itself so readily to our way of life."

" The Uninvited," a melodrama produced by Paramount from the novel by Dorothy MacArdle, will open this morning at the Globe. Produced by Charles Brackett and directed by Lewis Allen, the film's cast is headed by Ray Milland, Ruth Hussey, Donald Crisp, Cornelia Otis Skinner, Dorothy Stickney, Barbara Everest, Alan Napier and Gail Russell.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Long-short-wave radio programs sent to Chungking by the Overseas Branch of the Office of War Information in San Francisco is now a regular daily service and the rebroadcasts wave rebroadcasting in China of are as clear as local programs originating in China's wartime capital, James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today.

A woman's handbag containing $3,000 worth of jewelry, missing since Feb. 10, was traced yesterday to the home of Miss Lucille Lempert, 26 years old, of 1155 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, who told police that she found the bag and had been too busy to turn it over to authorities.

In a report which disagrees sharply with the findings of the League of Nations Committee on Nutrition -- findings which influenced the United Nations Food Conference -- the American Institute of Food Distribution reaches the conclusion that the food shortage in Europe is by no means as critical as it has been pictured and that it will not be necessary for us "to feed everyone in Europe for at least three years."

The May selection of the Book of the Month Club will be Catherine Drinker Bowen's biography of Oliver Wendell Holmes, "Yankee From Olympus." The book will be published by Atlantic-Little, Brown. Other titles placed on the reserve list by the Book of the Month Club are Thomas Mann's "Joseph the Provider," to be published by Knopf, the last in the "Joseph" series, and "The Age of Washington Irving," by Van Wyck Brooks.
The Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York presented awards yesterday to eleven policemen who risked their lives to rescue persons from drowning. The ceremony was held at headquarters.

Father of board-track competition, which has reached the ripe old age of seventy-five years, the New York Athletic Club will stage its annual indoor games at Madison Square Garden tonight with a twenty-five-event program and a field of stars that includes every topnotcher now available.

Basketball and tennis shows at Madison Square Garden and big league baseball games at the Polo Grounds and Ebbets Field are among the events booked by the Red Cross sports committee in connection with the drive of the Greater New York Red Cross committee to raise $22,386,000, during the campaign starting March 1.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 18 (AP) -- An original copy of the Bill of Rights, one of fourteen engrossed in 1789 by order of Congress, legible and in excellent condition, has been found by Miss Mary T. Quinn, Rhode Island archivist, at the bottom of an old filing cabinet in which ancient maps had been stored.

Japanese broadcasts recorded in the United States, Great Britain and China implied Friday that the United States forces that attacked Japan's great naval base of Truk might have tried to land troops there, if only for reconnaissance, The United Press said.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Yugoslav Partisan forces have stabbed across the Slovene border into northern Italy and now are battling the Germans just south of the first World War battlefield of Caporetto, Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] announced today.

Declaring that the spectacular rise in the employment of 16 to 17 year olds indicates the need for strengthening the labor law to prevent exploitation of children, Edward Corsi disclosed yesterday that the Department of Labor had drafted legislation to extend the forty-eight-hour top to all boys and girls in this age group.

The War Department has ruled that appropriate citation may be published in unit general orders, in the case of war dogs performing meritorious service. This seems only a matter of justice. The work of war dogs on many fronts, especially in the islands of the Pacific, has been outstanding.
Al Davis, Brownsville welterweight, returned to the Madison Square Garden ring last night after an interlude of three years, a conqueror.

The release of some 20,000,000 pounds of butter to the civilian trade from the Federal Government's 130,000,000-pound hoard and revamping of the butter-set-aside arrangement are contemplated under plans the Government and trade spokesmen have had under discussion for several days in New York City.

Queens has gone over the top of its over-all quota in the Fourth War Bond drive, figures released yesterday disclosed, to join three other boroughs. Now only Brooklyn remains below the 100 per cent mark with sales of 94.2 per cent. Queens over-all sales on Thursday were $1,751,600, bringing its cumulative total to $67,235,800, or 100.8 per cent of its quota.
