RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 18 -- A West Virginia woodworking corporation, which encouraged the formation of an independent union because of its opposition to the Congress of Industrial Organizations, found itself today in the position of having to offer reinstatement, with back pay, to forty-three of its former CIO employes who had been forced out of their jobs in 1942 through a closed shop won by the independent unit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A strong and continuing voice in decisions, pertaining to war-contract terminations and the post-war disposal of surpluses is reserved for industry under recommendations made today by Bernard M. Baruch, head of the War and Post-War Adjustment Advisory unit of the Office of War Mobilization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President Roosevelt vetoed today the anti-subsidy legislation which Congress sent him yesterday, and within an hour the House of Representatives, as it did last summer on a similar bill, sustained the veto by a vote of 226 for passage of the bill to 151 against.

ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC AIR BASE IN THE SOLOMON ISLANDS, Feb. 18 (AP) -- United Nations airmen shot down at least six Japanese dive bombers on Tuesday during landing operations on Green Island, a survey disclosed today.

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The German air force made one of its most determined attacks since 1940-41 against the London area early today, dumping tons of high explosives and incendiaries that set fires raging in a great ring along the horizon.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 18 -- Unusual patents for treatments of coffee and metals, and a German patent for a new kind of building material, stand out among the 588 issues listed as granted in the current volume of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Feb. 18 -- The Japanese supply line to the South Seas areas has now been cut at both ends -- by the United States Navy at Truk and by Army and Navy bombers in the neighborhood of the Bismarck Archipelago.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 -- The tax system of the country shows signs of degenerating into "a collection of myriad provisions conferring special privileges on numerous minority interests," Roy Blough, Director of Tax Research of the Treasury Department, told the American Philosophical Society's mid-winter meeting today.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill has sent another note to Premier Joseph Stalin in the hope of settling the Russo-Polish dispute, but the general feeling in London diplomatic circles today is pessimistic in the extreme.

The general approval that greeted the Beveridge plan made it a foregone conclusion that it would be adopted in some form. The dispatches now tell us that the first action has been taken in the form of a White Paper, which would commit Great Britain to the expenditure of u146,000,000 annually for the diagnosis and treatment of illness in the entire population.

An exhibition of contemporary Hungarian art in America will be held at the Peikin Galleries, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, from March 3 to 26. The event is sponsored by the Hungarian division of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross and arranged by A. Silberman.
LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 19 (UP) -- The midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

The majority of Polish women serving as "Pestkas," the Polish equivalent of our Wacs, have had dramatic and tragic personal adventures far beyond the experience of most members of the American Women's Army Corps. Yet the Wac is the envy of all Pestkas because the American girls are permitted to go overseas near the scene of fighting.

Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, has received, in effect, a vote of confidence from the membership of that body, which has ratified an amendment to the constitution authorizing the governors to enter into labor contracts with officers.

ANZIO BEACHHEAD FRONT, Italy, Feb. 18 -- German troops, who have suffered in the last two days the heaviest losses since the Allies landed here, called up fresh reserves and launched new attacks today on the Carroceta-Aprilia sector of the beachhead only to be again thrown back by British and American defense units.
PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 18 -- Powerful Amy, Navy and Marine forces have invaded Eniwetok Atoll in the far northwestern range of the Marshall Islands.
Operating results of two leading cigar manufacturers were announced yesterday in annual reports to stockholders covering the year ended with December.

Ending of the fourth war loan drive on Tuesday released the brakes on part of the large backlog of new financing that had accumulated during the campaign, and, as a result, new flotations of securities here rose to $55,782,000 for eight new bond issues in the week ended on Friday, the largest weekly figure in a month.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Feb. 18 -- Urged back to their jobs by union officials who spoke over a public address system set up outside the shipyard, 2,500 night-shift workers of the Fletcher yard of the Bethlehem Steel Company, here, returned to work at 7 o'clock tonight, approximately twenty-four hours after they had staged a wild-cat strike.

WAIKIKI BEACH, Honolulu, Feb. 10 -- Veteran commercial airline pilots who pause here between stages of important duties that are better not discussed in detail are simmering mad about the antics of young service fliers who do daily tricks with their fast war planes at second-story levels along the beaches.

The unpredictability of the movements and tempo of war was strikingly illustrated in yesterday's news from the fronts. For the second time this year the big story was in the Pacific. It is difficult to get a picture of the strength and importance of the group of islands called Truk because few outsiders have had a chance to see this unique and supposedly impregnable fortification since Japan acquired it under mandate in 1919.

Ralph Bellamy, featured player in "Tomorrow the World," and John Moses have purchased "Pretty Little Parlor," a play by Claiborne Foster, with the intention of producing it on Broadway as soon as possible, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The House Military Committee plans to open hearings next week on legislation providing for the establishment of a 5,000,O00-man peacetime reserve army.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Feb. 19 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today that the Japanese convoy caught by our bombers while an route from Truk to the Bismarck Archipelago bases, had been almost completely wiped out. Twelve of fourteen merchantmen, totaling 36,500 tons, a destroyer and two gunboats were sunk in the three-day air attack, the communique stated.

Export traders, concerned about the high cost of rail shipments to Mexico and the congestion and confusion which have arisen at the points of entry since the discontinuance of steamer service to Mexican ports, are planning an appeal to the War Shipping Administration for "immediate" resumption of such service, it was learned yesterday.

The Baruch-Hancock report on "War and Post-War Adjustment Policies" is a formidable document which cannot be summarized adequately in any short space. No one would claim that every one of its proposals is beyond criticism. But it is a statesmanlike document of the first order.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 18 (U.P.) -- It still was uncertain today whether Finland was seriously trying to get out of the war by conferences in this neutral capital, but Finnish circles were openly critical of the Moscow radio for continued anti-Finnish propaganda, which they say has not encouraged the Finns to negotiate.

CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 18 (AP) -- From two fronts in the bitter Burma battling came reports today of Allied successes -- the killing of 1,000 Japanese by the stranded Seventh Indian Division in Ngakyedauk Pass on the west and a strong offensive to the north by Chinese already victorious in twenty-seven of thirty actions against the enemy in three and a half months.

Edward V. Broderick, lawyer for Wayne Lonergan, the 27-year-old former Canadian aircraftsman, accused of murdering his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, filed new papers in General Sessions yesterday which may delay the opening of Lonergan's trial next Wednesday.

Though Congress has once more indicated its opposition to food subsidies, the President has vetoed its bill and Congress has failed to override the veto. Paradoxically, although these subsidies have a dubious legal basis, and the majority of Congress has registered its opposition to them, the failure of Congress to override the President's veto appears to make unlimited subsidies possible.

For the past several months I have viewed with growing alarm the apparent tendency of Congress to make a bigger fool of itself than seems necessary. In its handling of the soldiers' vote it has reached its apex.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

While families in this city search in vain for modern apartments and workers on the West Coast offer bonuses for any type of living quarters, whole villages of new Government housing in some parts of the New York and New England regions stand dark and unoccupied.

As Edwin A. Salmon, City Fuel Administrator, reported yesterday that the Health Department had 4,000 "no heat" complaints still uninvestigated, Brig. Gen. Brice P. Disque, retired, president of the Coal Consumers Protective Association, and Walter J. Dockerill, regional representative of the Solid Fuels Administration, took steps to speed coal deliveries.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 -- Bing Crosby, on loan from Paramount, will be starred by RKO in "Fiesta," a musical with a Latin-American background. The star is to be made available to RKO in payment of a loan to Paramount under which Leo McCarey directed the singer's last picture, "Going My Way."

VANCOUVER, B.C., Feb 18 (AP) -- Four hundred persons were lost, most of them victims of sharks, when the 21,500-ton liner Empress of Canada was torpedoed at midnight by an Italian submarine off Freetown, West Africa, nearly a year ago, survivors told The Canadian Press today.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 18 -- Sporadic strikes, especially in the building and metallurgical trades, broke out this morning in various parts of Argentina, according to reliable information reaching this capital. The strikes have a clear-cut anti-government character, being prompted more by political than by economic reasons.

" Brotherhood Week" will be observed in churches and synagogues, beginning tomorrow, for the eleventh successive year under the auspices of the National Conference of Christians and Jews. Leaders of all faiths have called on their congregations to participate and will use literature distributed by the conference, including the recent message by President Roosevelt endorsing the movement.
MINEAPOLIS, Feb. 18 -- Wendell L. Willkie arrived here tonight on his tour and, at a press conference, took up Vice president Wallace's prediction of a fourth term.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 18 -- The will of Ida M. Tarbell of Easton, noted writer and Lincoln biographer, filed today in Probate Court, leaves her estate in trust for her sister, Sarah A. Tarbell of Easton, and her sister-in-law, Ella Scott Tarbell.
The Italian campaign has been in itself a strategic success but an undeniable political and tactical disappointment.

The dramatic news from the Pacific now makes it clear that the American attack on Truk, whatever else it may have been, was at least a diversionary assault to cover an invasion of one of the most strategically important islands of the whole Marshall group. This island is Eniwetok, at the northwest corner of the Marshalls, less than 800 miles from Truk and within relatively easy striking distance of our own lost island of Wake.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 18 (U.P.) -- Asserting that Japan has lost 2,000,000 men since the start of the war and is facing serious financial difficulties, Chinese spokesman Maj. Gen. Lin Hsiu-lan today urged the Allies to "swoop down on Japan from all sides and hasten her downfall."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Rapid and final settlements of Government contracts with industry immediately on cessation of war production were urged today in the report of the War and Post-War Advisory Unit of the Office of War Mobilization as essential to prevent frozen industrial operations and a depression in the post-war demobilization.

ALGIERS, Feb. 18 -- Surging waves of German infantry stiffened by tanks and reinforced by blazing guns of Luftwaffe fighters and bombers have failed so far to break the Allied lines in the beachhead below Rome and savage fighting is continuing primarily along the axis of the main road running north from Anzio through Aprilia and Campoleone.

Since the Office of price Administration has announced another pork bonus, to be available from now through next Saturday with spare stamp No. 3 in War Ration Book 4, the menus for the coming week include a larger than usual amount of meat.

Hitler's fanaticism against the Jews could be exploited by the Allies. The Three Powers should send a proclamation to the German people through leaflets and to the German Government through neutral countries: threatening that further murdering of Jews would involve terrible retaliation after victory.

Highway officials from eleven States in the northeastern area urged yesterday the preparation of plans and estimates for post-war highway projects as the annual meeting of the Association of Highway Officials of the North Atlantic States closed at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The five-story walk-up containing seventy rooms at 838 Kelly Street, the Bronx, has been sold by a client of Bachrach Bachrach, brokers, to a client of Harold Klipstein, attorney. Albert W. Pross represented the seller.

Next week's calendar of new municipal issues up for award will total $17,496,000, compared with this week's revised total of $6,201,500, the Daily Bond Buyer reported yesterday. The weekly average of new municipal financing for 1943 to date now stands at $19,314,330.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Russia's highest military award, the Order of Suvaroff, First Class, has been awarded to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Commander in Chief, the Moscow radio announced tonight.

Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Froessel in Brooklyn reserved decision yesterday after hearing arguments on a motion by Theodore F. Kuper, former law secretary of the Board of Education, for a summary judgment in a taxpayer's suit that aimed at revision of the custodial system in the city's public schools.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Paying tribute to Fred O. Seibel, cartoonist, whose political limnings over a period of years have been brought together for a showing at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, Arthur Krock, director of THE NEW YORK TIMES' Washington Bureau, said last night that in time of war cartoonists' public service was of "immeasurable value." Mr. Seibel is a cartoonist for The Richmond Times-Dispatch.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 18 -- Continuing shortages of manpower as pointed out by military and Administration leaders has focused attention anew upon the "make-work" policies employed by some unions.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 18 (U.P.) -- Japan may have held the Caroline and Marianna Islands in the Pacific for twenty years, but she has fortified them only within the past ten, Willard Price, traveler and author, said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Following is a summary of recommendations appended to the Baruch report:
ALGIERS, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Allied communique:

After an ownership of three months, the apartment building at 415 Central Park West, northwest corner of 101st Street, has been resold by Cordell Estates Corporation to the Commonwealth Realty Corporation for $20,000 over a first mortgage of $660,000, a second mortgage of $37,500 and a third mortgage of $15,000.

The taxpayer's suit brought by the 276 Realty Company to compel Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine to produce all records of the departmental trial of Patrolman James L. Drew on charges of un-American activities was withdrawn yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien.

The motive of good faith of a violator of the Office of Price Administration's regulations is of no concern in a civil action, the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court held yesterday in a decision written by Justice Bernard L. Shientag and concurred in by Justices Ernest E.L. Hammer and William C. Hecht Jr.

Ski conditions comparable to the best this winter has offered thus far, likely will result in plenty of track cutting up North over the Washington Birthday period. While the metropolitan area was drenched with rain early yesterday morning, powder snow visited the distant skilands, and grand sport awaits the huge outpouring of skiers who started traveling last night.

Thousands of undergraduates of City College have regained their spirit, it became known yesterday at the School of Business, where the photograph of a Mustang fighter plane with the words "Spirit of C.C.N.Y." clearly stenciled on the side has been received from the Treasury Department.

A CHILD'S joy in life, and a child's sorrows, too, remain much the same in any age, and this is perhaps why reminiscences and tales of childhood move as with a more than vivid realization of past modes and landscapes.

A program of rehabilitation work among American merchant seamen, run on an informal basis without any definite plans or methods, is producing remarkable results at the Seamen's House, Young Men's Christian Association, 550 West Twentieth Street.

Unless the democratic elements in Argentina unite and take action against the militarist groups in control of the country, it will become the "Spain" of America, Dr. Sergio Bagu, Argentine educator and author, declared here yesterday.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 19 -- Lend-lease aid is carrying New Zealand along inside its war budget, figures for national finances for the nine months to Dec. 31 reveal.

AKNEE-HIGH envoy in overalls soon will follow in the waddling footsteps of Donald Duck as good-will ambassador to Central and South America. He is Snarky Parker, hero of a series of all-marionette, full-color motion pictures being made for the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs by Bil and Cora Baird, puppeteers.

BY way of Switzerland comes detailed information about the regular postage series which Hungary issued on Jan. 1, 1943. Fragmentary reports had been received in the past, but few facts as to the colors or as to the identification of all the persons whose portraits are presented.

Revision of the War Production Board's general scheduling order will be accompanied by an extensive curtailment in the number of components which require WPB purchase authorizations before they can be bought, Ralph A. Parker, regional deputy director of production and facilities for the agency, stated here yesterday in an interview.

Fashion has focused its attention on several points this spring. For example, the waistline has been lowered by some designers, stressing what is variously called the middy or the long torso silhouette. This does not mean that all must accept it as actually it is flattering only to the slender.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (U.P.) -- Polish partisans are wrecking the efforts of German occupation authorities to send foodstuffs to the Reich, according to an account of recent conditions inside Poland published today in the fortnightly review New Horizons, organ of Wanda Wasilewska, leader of the Union of Polish Patriots in the Soviet union.

PECULIARLY fortunate just now is our opportunity to study drawings. Last week in these columns the "Clouet to Degas" panorama at Wildenstein's, which will be current until March 2, was discussed. Since then the Museum of Modern Art has added a generous chapter addressed to work in this field by artists of our own time.

Frank H. Gervasi, associate editor and Mediterranean correspondent of Collier's Weekly, disclosed last night as he arrived at La Guardia Field from the Cassino front that he had seen 776 American soldiers of an 800-man force fall to German fire because the Nazis were using the Abbey of Monte Cassino as an observation post.

TO THE EDITOR: In THE TIMES Magazine Lord Vansittart lists twelve points he considers necessary for a peaceful Germany. Put these twelve points into effect and you still have a wild horse by the tail. Rather put a twist on his nose and then give him what medicine seems indicated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The War Food Administration will imprint the American flag on canned goods and other food products shipped by the lend-lease division of the Foreign Economic Administration because of a proclamation issued today by President Roosevelt relieving food packers and processors of legal liability for such use of the national emblem.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- British submarines have definitely destroyed nineteen enemy cargo vessels, probably sunk another six and damaged eight others in recent patrols extending from the Arctic Circle to the Indian Ocean, according to an Admiralty announcement today.

LIFE aboard a destroyer is a crowded, busy one and there is little time left over for music, reading or even shooting the breeze. At first glance one would think that music, especially in the creative sense, was totally lacking on a crowded "tin can."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- In commenting here today on the death of Charles E. Bedaux, Attorney General Biddle made public hitherto secret data on his activities during the past few years, including close associations with Joachim von Ribbentrop, Fritz Wiedemann, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Otto Abetz and other Nazi and Vichy French officials.

How does a Mussolini or a Hitler rise to power? Thomas Carlyle answered by asserting that leaders are born, an answer now rejected. The latest approach is that of sociometry, which was developed by Drs. J.L. Moreno and Helen Jennings and which concerns itself with the likes and dislikes, attractions and repulsions of those who constitute a group.
DETROIT, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The first of more than 100 players involved in Commissioner K.M. Landis' famed free agency decision of 1940 returned to the Tigers today.

ALREADY the biggest crop of cabbage in our history has started to arrive in Northern markets from Arizona, California, Florida and Texas. The peak of the movement is expected to be reached during the next fortnight, and to encourage consumption the Government has designated this homely vegetable a Victory Food Selection from Feb. 24 through March 4.

TRAGEDY is passion alone, and rejecting character, it gets form from motives, from the wandering of passion, while comedy is the clash of character. Eliminate character from comedy and you get farce. Farce is bound together by incident alone.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Women's Advisory Committee of the War Manpower Commission, is seeking, as war industry cutbacks increase the establishment of protective policies in the discharge of women workers.

Two doctors, a father and son, and two women were arrested yesterday by detectives from the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan in a raid on an apartment at 993 Park Avenue, and accused of carrying on an abortion practice bringing in $1,500 a day.

ORESTES BROWNSON, son of poor Vermont parents, was one of those Yankees Hawthorne was another -- who combined the hardest of heads with a persistent yearning for mystical experience. For the most part, he educated himself by reading tenaciously and widely.

HAVING somehow neglected to mail its ballot, this department can view with a noble detachment the poll of radio editors recently conducted by The Billboard, which this year took over that nation-wide stint from The New York World-Telegram.

HELEN REILLY'S Inspector McKee ranks high among the police detectives of fiction. He is thorough, he is patient, and he is not taken in by obvious clues. He has need of all these qualities during his investigation of the death of Charlotte Foy, shot dead on a foggy night in one of New York's private parks.

WHAT is probably the first New York performance of Smetana's opera "Dalibor" will be sung in concert form in English at Town Hall Saturday evening under the sponsorship of several high Czech officials.

Reports of a Government request for 7,600,000 yards of Osnaburg cloth to be used by the Army, supplemented by increased local and commission-house demand, produced yesterday further strength in cotton futures. At the close of trading active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were virtually at their highs for the day and showed gains of 7 to 8 points over Friday's final prices.

The War Finance Committee for New York reported yesterday that sales of war bonds to individuals on Friday amounted to $10,228,800 in the city, raising the city's total sales to individuals to $538,785,800, or 77.1 per cent of its quota for the Fourth War Loan Drive. In the State, Friday sales of $15,500,000 lifted the total for individuals to $720,100,000, or 79.1 per cent of the quota.

THE February chore of pruning and training grapevines seems to be a deep mystery to many gardeners. This is unnecessary if a few basic principles are understood at the outset. The first two or three seasons after planting should be devoted to growing a good plant. Of course, fertile soil, plenty of water and plant nutrients are essential.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- The first of four volumes embracing a survey of 1,106 American corporations with total assets of more than $48,000,000,000 to test their final net profit in the years 1936-42 as a per cent of net sales and net worth was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A NEW era in double-talk, right out of the mouths of babes, has begun. And in the past few weeks thousands -- could it be millions? -- of Americans have been murmuring, "Now we've heard everything." "Everything" is the baffling new nursery talk known as "Mairzy."

Labor must "drop its indifference to Government" and take political action now so that "the common people" may fashion their political, economic and social destinies, speakers declared last night at the twenty-third annual workers' educational conference in the Hotel Woodstock.

A committee of hostesses representing many communities in New Jersey has been organized to assist with plans for the ninth annual theatre party to benefit the Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys, a cottage-plan home and school situated in Millington, N.J.

Directors of the Celanese Corporation of America declared yesterday a dividend in common stock to holders of common stock at the rate of one share for each seventy shares held, payable on March 31, with scrip certificates for fractions of shares.
ONE of the most valuable bits of information for the bridge student is declarer's play of certain common suit-holdings at no-trump contracts.

The decision of the Army to abandon its specialized training program in most colleges will not open the way to formal athletic competition in the local institutions that have been associated with the project, it was indicated yesterday.

During the past year Illinois and Pennsylvania joined the ranks of those States that require the teaching of American history in public schools. Illinois went even further, making history mandatory in publicly supported colleges. Under a bill recently introduced at Albany all elementary and high school pupils would be required to take courses in United States history; unless satisfactory grades were received the student's diploma could be withheld.

Italy's gold reserves, amounting to about $120,000,000 are now in the possession of Germany, according to Swiss advices, thus increasing the amount of the metal seized by the Reich from occupied nations to more than $1,000,000,000. If anything, this estimate is conservative.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 19 -- All hopes of coffee speculators who have been maneuvering to induce the United States Government to increase coffee ceiling prices were shattered today by a resolution of the National Coffee Department stating that Brazil would adhere 100 per cent to the American price ceiling on coffee.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, Feb. 20 (UP) -- A communique:

Artists and officials of the Metropolitan Opera Company, representing various Allied nations, will appear at a series of international teas sponsored by the New York Chapter Canadian (Maple Leaf) Division of the British War Relief Society, Inc., through the cooperation of Edward Johnson, general manager of the opera association.

A TELEVISION "development committee" of eight has been appointed in Great Britain. The object, according to a London report, is to put that country "in the lead" in television after the war. On the committee are representatives of the British Broadcasting Corporation, the Postoffice, Treasury, Department of Scientific Research and Ministry of Supply.

MILLIONS of American men in changing over from smart, casual, civilian attire to the more practical garb of the Army have changed as well from sophisticated entertainment to the hurried catch-as-catch-can pleasures of the soldier.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The luckless Polish Government-in-exile now finds itself in the hopeless position where it will be damned if it does anything and doubly damned if it doesn't. As they view it the Poles in exile have two clear fundamental questions to cope with -- and in their opinion each is impossible to solve.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 -- Coward and Dupuy's 8-year-old gelding Marriage won the $25,000 added New Orleans Handicap at the Fair Grounds today, beating William Helis' Rounders by a nose.

WHAT a wealth of wisdom understanding and experience can radiate from the pages of even a small book! Mr. Hancock has given us a star to guide the mind, a sun to warm the heart. The British Empire or (Commonwealth -- he does not recoil from either term -- has here secured a most persuasive interpreter.

SEVERAL members of this society, somewhat bewildered by Mr. Emstein's letter printed in a recent Sunday's TIMES, wonder why, if he has a valid complaint, he does not submit it to the Dramatists' Guild, where it would receive quick action.

With Miss Patricia Potter as chairman, a debutante committee has been formed to assist as junior hostesses at the performance of "Aida," on the afternoon of Feb. 29 at the Metropolitan Opera House, for the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc. The young women, who are stimulating ticket sales, will distribute programs at the benefit matinee.

THE path of the wartime homeowner in search of a simple saucepan or even a modest measuring cup is beset with many and divers difficulties. If she finds the type of utensil she wants, she may not find it in the desired material. If she does unearth the right utensil in the proper metal, it will probably be the wrong size.
LONDON, Feb. 19 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

BY nature the most optimistic people in the world, we Americans have run wild on the subject of the future of aviation. Today the most popular amusement of the hot stove -- in this instance "hot air" -- league is to make fantastic predictions about the number of airplanes which will fill the skies immediately after the war.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- When Mrs. George Bernard Shaw left $400,000 in her will to cure the Irish of shyness and inarticulate conversation, she did so not in an attempt to reprove her husband's nation for bad manners but to show her affection for the Irish people, her friends said today, and a reading of the document's text appeared to bear out their argument.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The crisis precipitated in Argentina by the coup d'etat of the Army colonels that resulted in the ousting of the Foreign Minister and the Secretary to President Pedro P. Ramirez is expected to produce clues to the position that country will finally take toward the war and inter-American solidarity.

FIVE years ago Adolf Hitler's dream child, the immense new Reich Chancellery in the heart of Berlin, was dedicated by the Fuehrer with the remark that it "will outlast many centuries." This was on Jan. 9, 1939. But early last month, when heavy bombers of the RAF struck at Berlin, the grandiose edifice which stood as a symbol of Nazi Germany was reported almost totally destroyed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Allied submarines, ranging from deep in Japanese waters to the Atlantic, Mediterranean and the southeast Asia area, have sunk thirty-two enemy vessels, probably six more, and damaged eight others.

TORONTO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A prediction that "the world is in for very extensive change and renovation" was made tonight by Associate Justice Robert H. Jackson of the United States Supreme Court, but he expressed doubt that his country would swing to extremes of right or left.

Everything yesterday morning at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, was nautical -- the program, the spirit and the frame of mind of the capacity audience of children. The theme was "Ships and Men of the Sea."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Hampered by their own first-half ineptness, during which they were wildly disorganized and dispirited, the Redmen of St. John's tonight staged a whale of a comeback before 7,153 persons at Memorial Auditorium, gained a 37-37 tie with Canisius and the rival quintets went into overtime.

THE early months of the year are a good time for making cuttings of house plants, such as fuchsias, impatiens, ivies or even geraniums. Later these new plants can be used in the garden -- if there is a lightly shaded spot seemingly difficult to fill, impatiens give a good account of themselves -- or may be potted for porch or terrace.

THE scene is the Hudson River Valley, where the patroon system is facing its final break-up. James K. Polk is in the White House; Herman Melville, Fenimore Cooper and Edgar Allan Poe are the current literary lights.

The tide of war has already turned for the United Nations. While the policy of the United States and the other democracies is an open book, America too often thinks about the sphinx in the United Nations family, about Russia. We too often fear her. Several American companies owning and operating tankers have established a cooperative organization whereby tanker experts are now stationed at critical ports throughout the world to serve as expediters, not only in the handling of cargo but also in the quick turnaround of vessels and in speeding such repairs as are needed, according to information from the American Merchant Marine Institute.

Mme. Alexandra Kollontay, daughter of a Czarist general, has had an amazing career. Willkie also announced that he intended to make an active, intensive, organized campaign for the Republican nomination for President.

Patrolman Christian Summonsen, 43 years old, of 564 Forty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, attached to the Elizabeth Street station but assigned to special duty in Harlem, was taken to Sydenham Hospital in a serious condition last night after he had been knocked down and beaten when he went to investigate a crowd on Lenox Avenue between 110th and 111th Streets.

MONTREAL, Feb. 19 -- Sparked by Ray Getliffe, who scored two goals, the National Hockey League's leading Canadiens trounced the lowly New York Rangers, 5 to 2, before 9,135 fans at the Forum tonight in the first game of a week-end home-and-home series.

For the second successive year the total number of doctoral dissertations has declined after eight years of steady increase. NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Neptune Storage, Inc., a moving and storage company, of 369 Huguenot Street, has applied to the Civil Aeronautics Board for an air carrier permit to own or lease six cargo planes and six helicopters after the war for the transportation of household goods, it was announced today by Seymour Fogelson, assistant vice president of the corporation.

They wandered about together sight-seeing, gravely inspecting the Houses of Parliament, Westminster Abbey, the Tower.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- An Army officer back from the battle of Kwajalein reported today that the Japanese there never knew what hit them -- and because of that Tokyo still had no idea of the technique used in the six-day American conquest of that enemy stronghold in the Marshalls.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 19 (U.P.) -- Seizing the initiative on the Arakan front of western Burma, British Imperial troops have made a successful raid on Japanese positions twelve miles south of the Mayu peninsula base of Maungdaw, inflicting casualties on the enemy, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Branches of some shrubs may be forced into bloom indoors if cut at this time. A change in the election law governing the terms of State committeemen of the recognized political parties who are to be elected in the March 28 primary has been drafted by Republican leaders to meet the special situation arising out of the reapportionment of Assembly districts, which takes place this year.

It is always a shock to meet a member of Congress -- he is so unlike a "Congressman." A "Congressman" is a man who buys and sells votes; who spends all his time getting elected and keeping elected; who represents some particular pressure group; who advertises himself and adopts whatever photogenic postures he thinks will appeal to the eye, and who is against "the Administration."

OTTAWA, Feb. 19 -- Discussion of the proposal Viscount Halifax made in a recent speech in Toronto for a better functional organization of the British Commonwealth is still being continued throughout Canada in many speeches and newspaper articles, and out of the discussion there is coming an indication of future issues.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 -- California sunshine and rugged Western scenic effects have been advertised to the rest of the country by go-getting chambers of commerce and by Hollywood for so long and so persistently that the Far West sometimes has been chided for indulging in oversalesmanship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Roosevelt, in a prankish mood, gave William D. Hassett the surprise of his life today. Mr. Hassett is the assistant to Stephen T. Early, White House secretary, and a familiar figure to Washington correspondents in the executive offices for eight years.

A sharp distinction between the type of farm workers who will continue to receive draft deferments and those who will not was drawn before the War Food Administration's regional farm labor conference yesterday by Lieut. Col. James T. Coatsworth of Selective Service.
Close upon Mayor La Guardia's announcement that he was lifting his luncheon butter ban throughout March, butter reappeared yesterday at the midday meal in some chain restaurants.

It was Army and Navy day on Morningside Heights yesterday, the West Point swimming team losing 38 to 37, to Columbia, and the Annapolis wrestling squad downing the Lions, 31 to 5 in the University Hall gymnasium.

GENERAL SIKORSKI was a man of many parts. He fought with distinction on the Austrian side during the first World War. After the armistice he became a general in the newly created Polish Army, and to him belongs much of the credit for the defeat of the Russians before Warsaw in 1920.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19 -- War and the Working Class expressed the opinion today that post-war trade between the Soviet Union and the United States, Britain and Canada would be profitable for all concerned, but made it clear that the Soviet Union must have favorable long-term credits and receive the opportunity to export as well as import goods.

WITH CHINESE FORCES in Northern Burma, Feb. 16 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Chinese troops driving along the Wantuk hills, at the western edge of the Hukawng Valley, have captured the village of Yawngbang after swinging southward of the Tanai River crossing at Tiapha Ga.

MR. BONSAL was one of the most experienced and widely traveled American journalists and observers of the international scene when he was called to act as President Wilson's confidential interpreter at the Peace Conference of Paris. In that capacity he kept a diary, extracts of which, now published for the first time, are of importance far beyond their documentary value.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 19 -- A higher percentage of civilian voters today want the Republicans to win the coming Presidential election than at any other period of time since the 1940 election.

The Solid Fuels Administration urged 100 coal dealers throughout the city yesterday to give priority to applications for emergency deliveries certified by the Department of Health. In his letter to dealers Walter J. Dockerill, regional representative of SFA, suggested that deliveries should be spread out thinly in lots of not more than one ton to ease the plight of as many consumers as possible.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- There will be plenty of meat to eat in the United States this year, but those who want their full share had better like pork.

SALLOW, dark-haired Marie Cappelle, the heroine of Mr. Shearing's fictionized biography, was born in France in 1816. She died in 1852 of emotionalism, a disease that had wracked her all her life. Accused of the murder of her husband, Charles Lafarge, condemned to life imprisonment, she actually spent eleven years of her life in the maison centrale prison of Montpelier.

The annual report of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company and its subsidiaries issued yesterday to stockholders showed for last year a net profit of $4,514,794, or $1.42 a share, after allowing $12,766,308 for Federal and State income taxes and after deducting from this $1,140,575 as the refundable portion.

Five thousand Jews entered Palestine in the four months ended Jan. 31, on the basis of immigration certificates issued by the Jewish Agency for Palestine, it was announced yesterday by Dr. James G. Heller, national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal.

Volume and movements both were small on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Stocks drifted in narrow ranges and closed mixed. Sales were 346,103 shares, against 310,240 on the preceding Saturday. Of the 666 issues traded, 217 rose, 209 fell and 240 were unchanged.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 19 -- Drastic reduction of the milk ration is to go into force in France on March 1. The decision was announced officially yesterday. One immediate consequence must be a rise in the already higher rates of infant mortality.

OUT of knowledge of Poland, past and present, admiration and affection for the Polish people and familiarity with this country's rich store of legend and tradition, Eric Kelly has written an outstanding little book.

SOMETHING new is cooking in the kitchens of ten of the world's largest hotels here in New York City. Patrons won't find it on the menu now, but in a few years dining out undoubtedly will be a greater pleasure because of an apprentice chef system whereby a new crop of potentially great chefs is learning the art from the city's culinary masters.

AS the days begin to lengthen thoughts of spring make the old office desk seem drabber than ever. Holiday time is in the offing. And though plans for a furlough may result in nothiing but plans, the vacation leaven is bubbling.

OSSINING, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Louis (Lepke) Buchalter considers himself to be a "martyr to politics," a visitor to the Sing Sing death house said today. Buchalter and two accomplices in a murder case await execution on March 2.

Accessories were active in retail trade last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. The call for coats and suits was reported "very good."

Anything is now possible in the line of endowment funds; like a bequest for stimulating the shipment of coals to Newcastle; or inculcating in the Chinese people a taste for rice; or encouraging members of Congress to get their undelivered speeches printed in the Congressional Record.

SUNNY Italy, land of rich tourists and eternal bright blue sky, is to the average American doughboy an endless road of sticky mud dotted with minefields, a series of forbidding gray mountain crags filled with almost inaccessible gun pits; murky, freezing rivers rushing past shattered bridges; a collection of barren, gutted villages peopled with tattered scavengers -- all set beneath a gray, cloud-filled sky dripping rain, sleet and more rain.
The Tokyo radio told the Japanese people last night that Premier Hideki Tojo had named three new Cabinet Ministers in a shake-up designed "to cope with the current serious situation."

AFTER the forced situations and paper doll characterization of the run-of-the-mill story for older girls, "Barrie Daughter" is as refreshing as a pine-scented breeze from the hill country of the story.

HOME-COMING for every American in the armed service is the theme of this poignant little book. The publishers call it a novel, but it is actually a collection of vignettes, bound together by the fact that all the returning boys are coming home to the same little Vermont town.

ALGIERS, Feb. 19 -- Despite the intensified campaign against it by Pierre Laval's reinforced and rearmed militia, the French underground movement is stronger today than it was a month ago and is performing incredible acts of resistance against the Germans on a scale that in some places borders on open revolt, according to information that has just reached here from France.

BEWILDERMENT is part of ZaSu Pitts' trade, to the delight of America's movie-lovers. But this day there was no acting about in the amazement that came over her fragile face. She was honestly stumped with the success of "Ramshackle Inn," her first Broadway play.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The bombing of the ancient Benedictine monastery on Monte Cassino by American Flying Fortresses has enabled the Germans to launch a propaganda campaign as vigorous as that which followed the first mass aerial attack on Rome last summer.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- England defeated Scotland by 6 -- 2 in an international soccer match at Wembley Stadium today before a throng of 80,000 that included the King and Queen and Princess Elizabeth.

The naval and air bombardment of Roi and Namur, key Japanese positions in the Kwajalein Atoll, was so terrific that Leathernecks of the Fourth Marine Division, waiting eight miles off shore for the order to storm the beaches, almost felt sorry for the Japanese garrisons, Tech. Sgt. Martin Kivel, Marine combat correspondent and former reporter for The New York Daily News, declared yesterday.

AN American jade merchant discovers that his merchandise has been used to smuggle heroin. To clear his name he goes into occupied China to see the war lord he suspects has placed the drug into hollowed pieces of jade.

THE Red Army of the Soviet Union, which has amazed the world with its prowess against the Nazi military machine is more than a product of the revolutionary regime. It is in direct line of descent from Russian armies that won notable victories in the past and often weighed heavily in the scales of European wars.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 19 -- United States marines have captured the important Engebi air base of the Japanese and several other islands in the northern part of Eniwetok Atoll. This atoll is 759 statute miles from Truk and within land-based bomber range of that major enemy naval base.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Mills engaged in the weaving of denims and chambrays have been directed to increase their production of these essential cotton fabrics, the War Production Board announced today.

THIS reference work suffers from the same fault as many others -- it's too good. Designed to be snatched from the shelf when a single hard fact is wanted, it really is a trap. It answers your questions, to be sure, but it interferes terribly with your work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (U.P.) -- This year will see some production changes as a result of war demands, but reconversion to peacetime production will not be in the cards until Germany is defeated and not in any complete sense until Japan is whipped, according to Donald M. Nelson.
This is the eighth article of the New York designer series.

Use of the retailer's historic margin features the proposed new plan for price control at the retail level, superseding the General Maximum Price Regulation, it was learned here last week. Reports in well-informed quarters indicated the tentative draft of the program has now been completed and will be presented to the Central Council of National Retail Trade Associations within the next ten days.

It was a dirty night of rain and low cloud. Daniel Rautamara sat in his house at Hioge, in Papua. He heard the sound of aircraft. He stepped outside and listened; the motors were missing badly. He called to his neighbors. As they listened the sound ceased, and then they heard an explosion.

Members of the Women's Crews, volunteers aiding in the many enterprises of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, will be the guests of honor at a tea to be given tomorrow afternoon in the apprentices' room at the headquarters of the institute, 25 South Street, by the eleven associations of the central council of the organization.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- National committeemen and women from more than half the States have already been selected by officers of the American Democratic National Committee, the organization formed to wrest control of the Democratic party from the New Dealers, Harry H. Woodring of Topeka, Kan., chairman of the group, announced here today.

AUTHORITIES on acoustics tell us that if a gun is fired in an open space and it isn't heard, the report has made no sound. In other words, sound is something that is heard. If it isn't heard it's no sound. By the same token, a joke is something that's laughed at. If nobody laughs, it's no joke.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 19 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

IN Hollywood, where careers are proverbially brief, Alfred E. Green is a phenomenon. Green has been directing motion pictures without a break for thirty-two years, and that hangs up something of a record in an industry where a man can be -- and has been -- awarded the benediction of an Academy "Oscar" one season and is unable to get a job the next.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Fifty delegates of the sixteen nation-wide business, labor and farm organizations comprising the first national conference on post-war problems ended this afternoon a two-day meeting in the Claridge Hotel here.

" THE VISITOR" proves to at least one inveterate reader of mystery stories that horror and suspense are at their most effective when you find them one sunny day sitting quietly on your own front doorstep arrayed in sheep's clothing.

Some 25,000 British women are currently serving as volunteers or paid staff workers at American Red Cross clubs for American service men in England. Miss Cynthia Waters, recently returned from spending fifteen months in the British Isles as acting club director for the American Red Cross, revealed yesterday that approximately 5,000 of this group are volunteers.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- Charles F. Adams and V.C. Bruce Wetmore announced today the sale of a substantial interest in the Eastern Racing Association, operator of Suffolk Downs, to Gordon B. Hanlon of Weston and a group of Massachusetts associates.

A crude red swastika was daubed on the granite wall adjoining the Claremont Avenue entrance of Riverside Church yesterday, less than twenty-four hours after extra police vigilance had been ordered near all places of worship following the desecration of St. Patrick's Cathedral and two other Catholic edifices.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Favorites for the $25,000 added Widener Challenge Cup on March 4 and the Flamingo Stakes next Saturday were determined today when Sun Again and Director J.E. dominated their opposition before 13,099 persons who wagered the record sum of $1,038,361 at Hialeh Park.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- For the first half of their game in the Drill Hall here this afternoon, Villanova had visions of administering the first setback of the season to Army's basketball team.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Reserves for renegotiation refunds which war contractors may set up and show in their statements and annual reports are not to be regarded by Government renegotiation officials as binding on contractors, according to a ruling by the Joint Price Adjustment Board, representing the six Federal renegotiation agencies, it was announced today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- For the first half of their game in the Drill Hall here this afternoon, Villanova had visions of administering the first setback of the season to Army's basketball team.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Reserves for renegotiation refunds which war contractors may set up and show in their statements and annual reports are not to be regarded by Government renegotiation officials as binding on contractors, according to a ruling by the Joint Price Adjustment Board, representing the six Federal renegotiation agencies, it was announced today.

Friday last, Feb. 18, the President stated in his press conference that he was sending the pending tax bill, Revenue Act of 1943, back to Capitol Hill on Monday or Tuesday. Disquieting as this news is to the nation, there is still a possibility that he will permit the bill to become law without his signature, although the expression of his intention to return the bill to Congress implies the contrary.

Although details of the agreement between the United States Government and the petroleum companies holding concessions in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait have not been worked out, the "principles of the understanding" as signed by Harold L. Ickes, president of the Petroleum Reserves Corporation, and the presidents of the companies show that the Government agency virtually will have a monopoly on the transportation westward of all oil produced in those areas.

Future program testing systems must provide some adequate devices to measure audience reactions to advertising so that sponsors may offer commercials with a reasonable assurance that they will bring satisfactory marketing results, Archibald Crossley, president of Crossley, Inc., said recently at a luncheon meeting of the radio-in-wartime group of the American Marketing Association at the Sheraton.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 20 -- Increased activity in actuals topped off by completion of the purchase of 332,000 bales by the War Food Administration, renewed tightness in the spot position, and private reports that winter preparations for seeding of the new crop were falling further behind schedule because of inclement weather over most of the belt combined to carry cotton futures up to new highs for the season the first part of last week.

DUBLIN, Feb. 20 -- From his See of Armagh in North Ireland, Joseph Cardinal MacRory, octogenarian Catholic primate of All Ireland, issued a Lenten pastoral letter today setting forth vigorously the viewpoint of Catholic Ireland on vital war issues.

USAAF BOMBER HEADQUARTERS, England, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- A skeleton force of Flying Fortresses that pressed on to smash a factory at Brunswick, Germany, in the face of overwhelming odds has received the European theatre's third unit citation, it was revealed today.

What is happening inside France? This question was never so momentous as it is today, not only because the hour of invasion draws near but because the matter of inside help and inside conditions acquires a new importance as the Allies test the determined resistance of the enemy and measure the difficulties of the terrible adventure they face.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. James H. Doolittle, who led the American attack on Tokyo in 1942, today predicted greater Allied assaults on the Japanese capital "in the shortest possible time," but indicated agreement in the Allied High Command that "Hitler must be finished first."

The President's remarks at his press conference last week were taken by most of his listeners to imply that he intended to veto today or tomorrow the tax bill now on his desk. We hope that this interpretation was a mistaken one. A veto of the present tax bill would do more harm than good.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 20 -- Leo Ehrenrouth, Finnish Minister of the Interior, and Juho Eljas Erkko, former Foreign Minister, who were said to have come to Stockholm to prepare the ground for Russo-Finnish peace feelers, have returned to Helsinki.

Proved crude oil reserves in the United States at the end of 1943 amounted to 20,064,152,000 barrels, a decrease of 18,641,000 from the 20,082,793,000 at the close of 1942, according to committee on petroleum reserves of the American Petroleum Institute.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- In a fight that raged for eleven days and nights in connection with what Royal Air Force fliers call the "battle of the strait," British naval planes recently sank three U-boats and damaged a number of others that tried to make individual passages through the Straight of Gibraltar into the Mediterranean from the Atlantic, according to a joint communique issued today by the Admiralty and Air Ministry.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 -- The Los Angeles Stock Exchange is expected soon to reduce the number of its memberships from seventy-five to probably sixty by the cancellation of some fifteen seats held in the treasury. At the time of its annual meeting in January, it had fifty-two members, but three of these were in the armed forces.

Local organizations and institutions that will do the actual work of readjusting and reallocating veterans and war workers are ill-equipped to handle the task, according to a bulletin, "Marching Home," issued yesterday by Teachers College of Columbia University.

To meet the expanding needs of service men for entertainment, the National War Fund has appropriated an additional $4,100,000 for the United Services Organizations, it was announced yesterday. The new donation brings to $65,327,000 the total funds set aside for the USO's work for the period ending Oct. 1, 1944.
Current war need drives have rekindled community consciousness, the Rev. Fred Robert Tiffany of the Richmond Hill Baptist Church, Queens, said yesterday in a morning sermon.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday assumed personal command of the city-wide waste paper salvage campaign. In so doing he accepted a direct challenge to his leadership by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, who charged that the paper salvage drive in New York was producing less than in other large American cities, despite New York's position as the greatest potential source of paper scrap for war use.

TO Comdr. Gene Tunney life has been a constant challenge. Being a man of iron will, the former heavyweight champion has met every challenge as he found it. Harry Greb beat him into a bloody pulp but, before Gene had been helped to his dressing room, the demand for a return bout came from his torn and tattered lips.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Liquidation by tired longs sent wheat prices downward last week on the Board of Trade to the lowest level since late last December, and many speculators who bought previously on the belief that futures would go to the Office of Price Administration ceiling went out of their holdings on the way down.

A traveler who has journeyed much up and down the streets of New York City, and also to such outlying points as Chicago, Kansas City, Albuquerque, Knoxville and station stops in indefinite number south and west, returns to report a certain apparent deterioration in American manners.

It has been announced that many more Wacs and Waves are needed for the armed services to replace young, able-bodied men so they can go into active service. These men, it is said, are now holding jobs in the Army and Navy which can be held just as well or better by women.

Engineering and medicine are the two most important intellectual occupations for the present and the immediate future, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday. He spoke to the mineral industry education division of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at a meeting in the Men's Faculty Club of the university.

Net income of the Long Island Lighting Company for 1943 was $1,928,683, of which $915,000 was placed in reserves by order of the Public Service Commission, it was announced yesterday. This compared with $2,335,737 in 1942, when $1,032,000 was placed in reserves.

Fourteen specific recommendations for eliminating biased and inaccurate statements concerning our Latin-American neighbors from textbooks, motion pictures, visual aids and other teaching materials commonly used in the schools and colleges of this country are contained in a comprehensive report prepared by the American Council on Education, it was learned yesterday.

The Seventh Day, on which we presumably rest, means more to us in wartime, when the other six days are pretty tough going. But Sunday, like a summer vacation, is the better for a little advance planning.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Artur Rodzinski conducting, played two works by Mozart in its concert at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, in addition to two works that had been performed last week, the Scherzo in G minor from Mendelssohn's Octet for Strings and the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto in D major, with Nathan Milstein as assisting artist.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 112.79, a rise of 0.2 per cent from the previous week's level of 112.55. There was an increase of 0.9 per cent in the farm products index and 0.6 per cent in the raw materials index.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Production of lard and hog meats continues unusually heavy and stocks in cold storage increased sharply in January despite large shipments on lend-lease account. Stocks of lard in all positions on Feb. 7 aggregated 1,230,496,000 pounds, an increase of 147,334,000 pounds for the month.

Criticizing Governor Dewey's proposals for changes in the method of selecting Supreme Court Justices as undemocratic and as leading to one-party rule, the American Labor party's State leadership urged yesterday an extension of the direct primary to include Supreme Court nominations.

Several theme shows are on the roster of gallery openings this week, two of them stressing the work of modern artists. The Whitney Museum of American Art, where the exhibition of works selected from the permanent collection is on view, will be closed to the public tomorrow, but will re-open on Wednesday afternoon.

The offerings of faith will always reach the most gifted intellect, the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers said yesterday morning in a sermon in Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, on "Religion's Appeal to the Naive."

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Three American newspapers -- THE NEW YORK TIMES, The Chicago Sun and The Chicago Tribune -- have received facilities for the distribution of their weekly overseas editions to American troops in this theatre, Maj. Gen. John C. H. Lees, deputy theatre commander, announced today.

The Netherlands Purchasing Commission, representing the Kingdom of the Netherlands, is leaving Rockefeller Center in an expansion move and has leased two floors in 41 East Forty-second Street. The new quarters contain about 36,000 square feet of space and will be occupied about May 1, according to Cushman Wakefield, brokers who arranged the lease in conjunction with Horace S. Ely Co., agents of the building.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -There was a special prayer for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on the smiling lips of 9-year-old Patsy Concannon today. Small wonder.

The Brooklyn Hispanos, national champions, defeated Eintracht, German-American League titleholder, 3 -- 0 in the Eastern semifinals of the national challenge cup soccer competition at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday before a crowd of 5,000.

Bishop William T. Manning, preaching yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, praised the heroism and devotion of the chaplains with our armed forces and declared they have earned "our deep and heartfelt gratitude." Many of them, he said, have unhesitatingly given their lives.

With 8,862 daily visits by service men and 16,938 by civilian members to its thirteen buildings, the Young Men's Christian Association of New York City recorded the heaviest use of its facilities in its history. Its ninety-first annual report published yesterday said total visits for the year were 9,418,356.
Optimistic announcements on supplies of butter and meats released from Washington are not justified, Mayor La Guardia declared in his regular Sunday broadcast over Station WNYC yesterday afternoon.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Blue Streak, a leading warplane of the Mediterranean, landed at home today, honorably retired from battle after completing one of the best combat records turned in by bombers in any theatre.
PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 20 -- The greatest carrier-borne air armada ever sent into action on a single objective has delivered a crushing, devastating blow at Truk, big Japanese naval base.
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The Hitler salute, for the past decade so important a part of everyday German manners, is declining in popularity, according to a Duesseldorf newspaper now available in London.

The New York metropolitan area must look chiefly to its industries to provide the full employment that will be needed to maintain the region's pre-eminence, the Regional Plan Association declared yesterday. Completion of a fourteen-month study of the area was announced.

WITH U.S. PACIFIC FLEET AT SEA, Headed for Truk, Feb. 12 (Delayed) -- This fleet, of which the main components are new carriers and battleships, is only part of what we have operating in the Pacific. Yet it is strong enough to do what the Japanese probably think we would not dare to try yet: attack Truk.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 20 (By Wireless) -- The swift attack on Truk, following the domination of the Marshall Islands, without the appearance of the Japanese fleet, opens up the brightest prospects in the Pacific since the beginning of the war against the Japanese.

The smashing blows struck at the enemy in the Pacific, of which the surprise assault on Truk resulting in the sinking of nineteen ships and the destruction or damaging of more than 250 Japanese planes was among the most dramatic, are at last taking the strut and swagger out of the Japanese.

ALGIERS, Feb. 20 -- Charles Laurent, chairman of the Purge Commission, added further details today to the story of the late Capt. Maurice Carre, who was killed in battle in Italy just before the arrival of orders to take him out of the lines for questioning in connection with the purge of the French Army.

At the all-Russian concert given by the NBC Symphony Orchestra, under Leopold Stokowski, late yesterday afternoon at Radio City, "De profundis clamavi," a new orchestral work by Daniele Amfiteatroff, received its world premiere on a program also containing Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Spanish Caprice" and the "Russian Dance," "Kermesse" and "In Petrushka's Cell," from Stravinsky's "Petrushka."

ABOARD A UNITED STATES EXPEDITIONARY FLAGSHIP Off Eniwetok Atoll in the Marshall Islands, Feb. 18 (By Navy Radio) (Delayed) -- United States Marines, attacking under cover of a devastating naval and aerial bombardment, today conquered Engebi Island, site of the key Japanese air strip on Eniwetok Atoll, in exactly six hours, five minutes.

New York State probably will attain its goal of 5,000,000 war bond buyers before the end of the month, when the books close on sales to individuals in the Fourth War Loan drive, W. Randolph Burgess, chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York, said yesterday.

Japan as a nation has never outgrown the "adolescent stage," Bishop Herbert Welch, head of the Methodist Overseas Relief who served as a missionary in the Far East for a number of years, declared yesterday morning in a guest sermon at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- The Flying Fortress, Winnette Lockman, soared aloft at the Lockbourne Army Air Base near this city yesterday -- a tribute to the courage of a girl in Nampa, Idaho, who won a two-year battle against infantile paralysis.

Juvenile delinquency and kindred current social problems require more than education and proper environment for their solution, Mgr. William A. Scully, secretary for education of the Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Three aerial punches delivered in quick succession the morning of Feb. 18 left Rabaul's Vunakanau and Tobera airdromes pock-marked and smoking from damage done by 123 tons of bombs and resulted in the shooting down of thirteen Japanese planes.

Throughout history that ancient battle has set the standard for military encirclement and annihilation. The Russians seem to have achieved a victory of this type twice, once at Stalingrad and now again at Korsun on a somewhat smaller scale.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- Intensified fratricidal fighting in three Yugoslav sectors was reported today in a Partisan headquarters communique twenty-four hours after a broadcast plea by Gen. Dusan Simovitch, Serb leader and former Premier, that rival forces end their civil war and rally behind Marshal Tito (Josip Broz).

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Navy tonight disclosed further details in plans for the European invasion with announcement that Rear Admiral Alan Goodrich Kirk had been named commander of the United States task force operating as part of the combined naval force in England.

Sensing "disturbing evidence that on the home front wartime strain is beginning to exact a toll on the lives of the American people," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street, that only man's "inner resources" will stand against this strain.

MOSCOW, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Miss Kathleen Harriman, with her father, Ambassador W. Averell Harriman in the gallery, placed fourth today in the women's slalom race of the Russian Republican ski championship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Thousands of rejected claims by veterans of this war for disability pensions are being reviewed by the Veterans Administration, the review covering rejections from the time of Pearl Harbor to July 13, 1943, when a "more liberal law" on determination of service-connected disability went into effect.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- The death rate in the State reached an eleven-year high in 1943, with 12,000 more deaths than in 1942, according to the annual report of the Division of Vital Statistics, made public today by Edward S. Godfrey Jr., State Health Commissioner.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The British Board of Trade's index of commodity prices for January, based on 1930 as 100, stood at 164, which equals the high record established last July. It compares with 163.4 in December and in 162.1 in January, 1943.

Despite city-wide police vigilance against a wave of church desecration, vandals in the early morning hours yesterday stained a wall of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America at Broadway and 122d Street with a splotch of reddish-brown paint five inches in diameter.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Feb. 20 -- Airborne rockets were used by American Marine torpedo planes for the first time in the big attack on Rabaul Harbor, on New Britain Island, Thursday, when at least twelve Japanese ships were hit, it was revealed here today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- Pat O'Gorman, the dinghy skipper from Hartford, Conn., who takes time from his war-plant engineering duties to compete in the Larchmont Yacht Club's frostbite program every Sunday, apparently is a firm believer in the double-or-nothing adage.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Prospects that a downward revision of ceiling prices on oats and barley will be announced by the Office of Price Administration within the next few weeks, combined with the break in other grains, resulted last week in lower prices for oats and barley on the Chicago Board of Trade.

The St. John's basketball team, its national invitation tournament bid in jeopardy, following successive defeats by Temple and Canisius, will have to wait until Wednesday night's struggle with N.Y.U. before starting to make amends.

The fifteen-story office building at 80 to 92 Beaver Street has been purchased by Jerome Greene for investment, from the Bowery Savings Bank. The property fronts 122 feet on Beaver Street and 136 feet on Pearl Street and includes a four-story building occupied by the Swan Club.

ALGIERS, Feb. 20 -- The German strength in the beachhead area is now officially reported to be at least nine divisions -- a total of possibly 144,000 men. Six divisions are engaged in the major effort along the Anzio-Albano road.
AT THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, South of Rome, Feb. 20 -- The Germans' mauled divisions weakly relaxed the initiative today and American armored columns scored deep penetrations into the German flank.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 20 -- The output of raw steel of last week advanced one-half point to 97.5 per cent of the newly announced rated capacity, recorded for Jan. 1, 1944. The rate for the week before last on the new basis was 97 per cent. Indications were that output this week would show little or no change.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- Robert Sherwood, director of the Office of War Information, Overseas Section, arrived today and disclosed that a psychological warfare branch had been established in Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's supreme Allied command.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS OF ADMIRAL HALSEY, South Pacific, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- An indication that the Japanese are evacuating their high-ranking officers from Buka Island by plane to escape the death trap drawn around their last Solomons bases by the invasion of Green Island was seen today in a report by a fighter pilot, Lieut. Louis E. Russell of Edgewater Park, N.J.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet press and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

DES MOINES, Feb. 20 -- Wendell L. Willkie told more than 200 representatives of daily and weekly Iowa newspapers today that as a result of many conversations with party groups during his present trip he was convinced that the Republican party, despite some minor differences, would be able to present a united front in the Presidential campaign.
Monday's Southwest Pacific communique, as relayed from Allied headquarters and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:
LONDON, Monday, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Russian Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Held scoreless for the first two periods, the New York Rovers rallied in the third and beat the Brooklyn Crescents, 3 to 1, in the Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The game was the feature of the weekly double-header, and was witnessed by a crowd of 11,201 fans.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 21 -- The German Air Force attacked London twice during the night and scattered incendiaries, oil-bombs and high-explosives over a wide area of the Thames Valley. The first attack occurred late last night and the second early this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Foreign Economic Administration is credited by its supporters with demonstrating in the negotiation of the advantageous Cuban Sugar Agreement, announced a few days ago, what a coordinated foreign economic operation could achieve.

Plans for the conversion of wartime volunteer services to peacetime objectives will be promoted by a national study to be undertaken this spring jointly by the Association of Junior Leagues of America and Community Chests and Councils.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Additional moisture over the winter wheat belt last week further improved the outlook for the crop, and reports indicate that all areas except from eastern Wyoming and Montana westward now have an ample supply of surface moisture.

Conceding that "misunderstandings" have arisen among nurses and their employers since the introduction last fall of a system for classifying nurses as 1A, or eligible for military service, Dorothy V. Wheeler, executive secretary of the New York City Nursing Council for War Service, predicted yesterday that these would not hinder the nursing profession from voluntarily meeting both military and civilian needs this year.

Coming to the Bijou this evening is "Right Next to Broadway," a comedy about Manhattan's garment industry. Written and produced by Paul K. Paley, a certified public accountant when he is not dabbling in show business, the play depicts the obstacles faced by the woman proprietor of a dress-manufacturing concern, with such distractions as love, labor and the OPA contributing to her worries.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- Enactment by the Legislature of a constitutional amendment which would greatly broaden the preference in civil service positions for veterans of the second World War now appears probable. If approved by this Legislature, as is scheduled, the measure would be up for a second passage at the 1945 session and could be submitted to the electorate at a referendum at the 1945 elections.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- There has been no real design or trend in the stock markets as a whole in the past week. Movements here were sometimes upward, sometimes downward, but little that could be called a feature developed.

The O'Neill Supply Company's property at 1819 Flushing Avenue, in Queens, consisting of a heavy concrete and steel industrial building containing 55,000 square feet of space and served by a railroad siding, has been purchased by a client of the Cross Brown Company, brokers.

Mainbocher, American-born disciple of the Paris couture, dedicates his collection for spring 1944 to "intelligent innocence," a quality that stamps his latest wartime creations. His designs are suave. In form they are simplicity itself, in decoration they represent super-craftsmanship.
It would seem that Mrs. Shaw's will has brought down very unfair criticism upon the memory of this estimable lady.

Arriving here last night for a series of conferences with "stop Roosevelt" Democrats from the Eastern States, former Secretary of War Harry H. Woodring said the anti-New Dealers within the party might nominate their own candidate for President, after both major parties have held their conventions, or endorse "one of the major party candidates."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 20 -- The second picture of Olsen and Johnson for Universal this year will be "See My Lawyer," from the Richard Maibaum-Harry Clork play produced in New York four years ago with Milton Berle and Teddy Hart.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, called on trade and other organizations today to abandon plans for any conventions or trade shows unless their officers "are thoroughly convinced that the meetings will help to shorten the war."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Feb. 20 -- There is now every indication that the Japanese fleet will not risk a major battle until our forces are much closer to Japan than they are now. If evidence already at hand is borne out, it is extremely likely that our advance in the Pacific already is far ahead of schedule and will be further speeded up.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- Joseph B. Ely, former Governor of Massachusetts, tonight announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President in an acknowledged attempt to block a fourth term for President Roosevelt.
