The New York County Council of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States held an Interfaith Americanism Rally last night in the assembly hall of Hunter College, in commemoration of George Washington's birthday. Philip Hart, chairman of the group, said the participation of prominent Catholics and Protestants in the meeting was proof that fascist doctrines could not thrive on American soil.

There is no room in the city school system for racial and religoius bigots, Dr. Jacob Greenberg, associate superintendent of schools, said at a rally yesterday afternoon by the Teachers Union at Manhattan Center. The union is Local 555 of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The Kings County District Attorney's office prosecuted 1,272 defendants on felony indictments during 1943, of whom 1,158 were convicted or pleaded guilty, according to the annual report made public yesterday by Acting District Attorney Thomas Cradock Hughes.
Four new films are scheduled to open in Broadway houses this week. The schedule is:
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Feb. 20 -- Pvt. Leo A. Hoelscher, who hails from Garwood, Tex., is perhaps the only soldier on the Fifth Army front who never wants to eat a doughnut again.

Is it not about time that some of our public spokesmen in America began to lay off in our invidious criticism, fault-finding and backbiting of Great Britain in our joint war effort? Such behavior is unbecoming of us on several different grounds.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 20 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

A plot of vacant land in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn has been assembled by a client of Bernard D. Barnett, attorney for a post-war improvement. The buyer bought the southwest corner of Ocean View and West End Avenues from the City of New York and an adjoining parcel from the Sukay Realty Corporation and now controls a plot 180 by 122 feet, assessed at $32,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The 2,000 planes of the United States Strategic Air Forces, based in Britain, winning a major battle in the campaign against German industry, by their bombing today deprived the Nazi enemy of 25 per cent of his fighter plane production capacity, Gen. Henry H. Arnold, commanding general of the Army Air Forces, said here today.

Buyers are looking for greater quantities of sheets and pillow cases as a result of the OPA action last week, and there was a great deal of interest in the market as a result. Some goods have made their appearance already, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 20 -- Infantry and marine troops have landed on Eniwetok Island, captured the western half and now have seized all of Eniwetok Atoll except the Japanese base at Parry Island. The landings at Eniwetok Island, made yesterday, were announced in a communique by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, who said "casualties continue to be light."

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 20 -- The Iron Fireman Manufacturing Company announced today for 1943 net profits of $900,849 after the renegotiation of prices and after setting aside $250,000 in post-war reserves. This compares with $491,646 in the preceding year and amounts to $2.50 a share on the outstanding stock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Four revisions in the price schedule covering carded gray and colored yarn cotton goods were announced today by the Office of Price Administration, but none of them, OPA said, will increase consumer prices.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Action of two labor members of the President's Committee on the Cost of Living in releasing their findings in advance of the whole committee's report was the target of an attack today from the heads of the National Association of Manufacturers and the United States Chamber of Commerce.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The European Advisory Commission has finally agreed to establish effective contact with the representatives of the occupied countries of Europe and consult with them on the surrender and military and economic disarmament of Germany, it was learned tonight.
ALGIERS, Feb. 20 (UP) -- A communique:

After three rounds of the interclub series for the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League the Manhattan and Marshall Chess Clubs are leading in Section A with three victories apiece, the former having won from New World, Bronx-Empire City and Queens for a total game score of 25 1/2 -- 3 1/2. The Marshalls have defeated West Side, New World and Bronx-Empire City and have totals of 18 1/2-7 1/2.

Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung," the fourth and last part of the unabridged "Ring" cycle at the Metropolitan Opera House, will have its first performance of the season next Tuesday night, Feb. 29, with Helen Traubel as Bruennhilde and Lauritz Melchior as Siegfried.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- The light cruiser Oklahoma City, first Navy craft to be named for the capital of Oklahoma, was launched this morning at the yard of the Cramp Shipbuilding Company from a way where construction was started within a few minutes on another $31,000,000 ship of the Cleveland class.
The Italian campaign has been a political and military laboratory in which we have learned many hard lessons.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Japanese forces who broke through the rear of British positions on the Arakan front in Burma are being blasted from their jungle foxholes, but severe fighting remains before the threat to the Allied supply route is erased, Southeast Asia headquarters said today.
A just world order must be established if we are to win the peace, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of Riverside Church, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Behind cafeteria counters, on airplane assembly lines, in other factories and offices in up-State New York, 10,000 jobs are open for women. These are figures on actual positions on file in the offices of the United States Employment Servie of the War Manpower Commission.

Your editorial in THE TIMES Feb. 12 concerning the proposed "flood control" dam in Vermont's West River Valley points out one of the most vital issues facing the American people today -- namely, the extent to which the Federal Government may exercise despotic power over local affairs in defiance of the will of a State and of its sovereignty.

Salvador de Madariaga, biographer of Columbus and Cortez, has chosen Mexico at the time of the conquest as the setting for his forthcoming historical novel, "The Heart of Jade," to be published on March 24 by Creative Age. It is the story of a young Spanish nobleman in the train of Cortez and the daughter of one of the Mexican kings.
Harold Richel of Carstairs Bros. Distilling Co., Inc., has been appointed to the newly created post of assistant metropolitan New York district manager.

The good old-fashioned spanking, administered by the father was recommended yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as an effective way of disciplining a 12-year-old boy who recently committed an act of vandalism in the All Saints Episcopal Church at Fortieth Avenue and 215th Street, Bayside, Queens.

Joint operations of the British and American air forces against Germany are constantly referred to in official communiques as "round-the-clock bombing." In a purely strategic sense, however, the phrase is not quite accurate.

Cotton prices continued to gain ground last week with spot cotton reaching the highest level since last July and with at least one-half of the active future deliveries making new highs for the life of the contracts. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the week of 5 to 24 points, with the strength centered in the nearer positions.

With railway shares in the lead, stock market averages advanced last week. On one day, Tuesday, total transactions crossed the million-share mark for the second time in 1944. The average for railway shares reached the highest since October, 1937, but the industrial share average did not match the achievement, remaining lower than the best price of last January, and far below the highest in 1940 or 1939.

A UNITED STATES HEAVY BOMBER STATION, in Britain, Monday, Feb. 21 -- Employing 2,000 heavy bombers and escorting fighters, the largest American force yet flown against the Nazis, the United States Army Air Forces struck heavy blows yesterday at eight important centers producing aircraft for the Luftwaffe.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Fed 20 -- Flashing the smooth-striding technique that not so long ago made him one of the country's foremost langlaufers, the Royal Norwegian Air Force pilot from Camp Little Norway in Toronto, Bjorn, captured the seven-mile cross-country race which today inaugurated the Lake Placid Club snow birds' twenty-third annual Washington Birthday ski games.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The names of two newspaper men and a former Maryland member of Congress have been assigned to three Liberty ships under construction at the Bethlehem-Fairfield shipyard, Baltimore.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 21 -- The Red Army pushed the Germans back along a 100-mile front in northern Russia yesterday and at two points moved to within twenty-nine miles of the railroad junction of Dno, last enemy stronghold on the westward road to Pskov.

Business will have an opportunity to replenish working capital in the post-war period through "field warehouse receipts," described as a tested but relatively unknown financial device by the National Bureau of Economic Research. In a study released yesterday the organization said the device may help in the disposal of surplus Government supplies after the war.
WITH THE BRITISH FOURTEENTH ARMY, in Burma, Feb. 17 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The Gunga Din of this war today was a 20-year-old barefooted Indian soldier.
LONDON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Central Pacific Area, Feb. 14 (Delayed) -- Veteran infantrymen who have met the Japanese both in the Aleutians and at Kwajalein said today that they were convinced that the majority of Japanese soldiers, at least in the units they have met, would have surrendered easily were it not for their officers and a few Japanese regulars.

MAZATLAN, Mexico, Feb. 21 -- A tall masked man walked into the masquerade ball at Mazatlan's annual carnival today, killed the Governor of Sinaloa with a shot in the neck and escaped amid showering pistol bullets from bystanders that brought death to two American tourists.

Trial of the suit by the Uniformed Firemen's Association to prevent Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh from abolishing the three-platoon system was opened yesterday morning before Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21 -- A cameraman arrived at a Leningrad hospital just as a lieutenant with a shell fragment in his chest was brought in. The cameraman began filming the operation, which was begun immediately by Maj. Yakov Rivlin.

Some two years after Broadway essayed it, the New School for Social Research has revived Ferdinand Bruckner's free adaptation of the Lessing play, "Nathan the Wise." Last night it offered the drama of indictment against racial and religious intolerance at the Studio Theatre on West Twelfth Street.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Enemy shipping seeking to flee heavily bombed Rabaul on New Britain has been tracked down along the New Ireland coast by vigilant American air patrols and sunk by Fifth Army Air Force bombers.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- There is still enough whisky in the Scottish glens to guarantee the world its well earned spree at the end of the war, but both the British distillers and the British Treasury are beginning to worry about the dwindling supply.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 21 (UP) -- State labor officials prepared to halt the income of union locals failing to file financial records with the State before today's deadline, but some union leaders said they would go to jail, if necessary, to protect their secrecy.

Many of the lessons learned in the Italian campaign, now ending another climax with the battle of the Anzio-Nettuno beachhead, may materially aid our invasion of western Europe -- if those lessons are properly appreciated and properly applied.
LONDON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

I believe that on this anniversary of George Washington's birthday your readers would be interested in this letter sent by the Father of His Country to the Hebrew congregation in New Port, R.I., in August, 1790:

The War Production Board's inventory limitation order L-219 will play a more important part in reconversion than it did in providing equitable distribution of decreasing supplies during the period of intense war mobilization, Chester L. Jones, national administrator of the order, stated in an interview yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Dried skim milk went through the Senate's centrifugal separator in triumph today, emerging with three modernistic titles conferred by a 46-to-4 roll-call vote.

OMAHA, Feb. 21 -- The Farm Crops Processing Corporation's grain alcohol plant, second largest of its kind in the world, went into production today. First finished alcohol will be ready in about a week. Miliary and Government officials participated in the opening ceremonies.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The plan of the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company for use of the proceeds from the sale at competitive bidding of the entire re-classified common stock of the Central Illinois Electric and Gas Company was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- At her press conference today Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt praised Red Cross girls who give home comforts to men on leave from the battlefields.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 16, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Feb. 20 (Delayed) -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army receives its motor fuel by pipeline, and gasoline is now being pumped regularly to within enemy artillery distance of the front.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 21 -James Melton, who last appeared on the screen in Warner Brothers' "Melody for Two" six years ago, has been signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for "Ziegfeld Follies." He will arrive here May 10 for rehearsals.

A new issue of $8,330,000 of housing bonds was announced yesterday by the State of New York for award on March 1. The lien will be dated March 2, 1944, will mature on March 2, 1946 to 1994, and will be callable on March 2, 1964. Bidders are to name the interest rate at not to exceed 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Corn ceiling price regulations were amended today by the Office of Price Administration to limit the pricing of corn by formula to locally produced grain, excluding that shipped from outside points.

Judge John W. Freschi denied yesterday in General Sessions the last three defense motions and cleared the way for the opening tomorrow of the trial of Wayne Lonergan for the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan.

AN AMERICAN HEAVY BOMBER STATION, In Britain, Feb. 21 -- The engineer and the navigator of a crippled Flying Fortress lost their lives in a gallant effort to save the plane and the unconscious pilot after the co-pilot had been killed in an air battle during the American attack on Leipzig yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 21 -- Royal Air Force Baltimores destroyed two enemy aircraft over the Aegean Sea yesterday after having beaten off concentrated attacks by two formations of fighters.

The first performance of "grand opera" in the City Center of Music and Drama was given last night. The opera was "Tosca." The performance was of the most refreshing sincerity, competence and dramatic impact. Every one of the three principals, that is to say, Tosca, Scarpia and Cavaradossi, was a singer with a voice and skill and authority in its employment.

Cleo Shans, 135, Los Angeles, won a divided decision over Julie Kogan, 132 1/4, New Haven, in the feature bout of eight rounds before 3,000 persons at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Referee Jed Gahan voted for Kogan, but both judges, John Potter and Fred Brunelli, made the Coast boxer their choice.

After the Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., had acted to bring itself into compliance with the milk conservation program of the War Food Administration, Dr. C.J. Blanford, market agent of WFA in the New York-New Jersey area, withdrew a recommendation for the prosecution of the company for violation of its sales quotas last November and December, he announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Plans being made here to deal with starvation and epidemics in the occupied countries when their liberation starts were outlined today by Dr. James A. Crabtree, acting chief of the Health Division of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.

Except for bursts of strength in the air transports and a few specialties, the stock market adhered yesterday to a middle course. Typical of a pre-holiday session, price changes were narrow and activity was at a lessened pace. Rallying tendencies appeared also in the aircraft industry section, with followers of these issues hopeful that the enactment of the Baruch reconversion program would cushion the transition after the completion of the armament program.

All securities and commodity exchanges in the United States will be closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday. Banks will be closed in every State in the Union except in Arkansas, Idaho, Kentucky and North Carolina, where a majority of the banks will remain open.

The national executive committee of the Social Democratic Federation, in session at 7 East Fifteenth Street, yesterday opposed the passage of a national service act on the ground that it was neither necessary or practicable as a means of assuring maximum production in the war industries.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 21 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

A new unified capital reserve system which would enable the setting up of safe reserves for long-term capital loans on a basis comparable to commercial deposit banking for short-term paper is proposed by Arthur C. Holden, architect, as a means of lowering mortgage interest rates on homes.

ALGIERS, Feb. 21 -- The swift, cutting edge of the greatest German onslaught in the Italian campaign has been blunted and stopped by the Allies on the beachhead below Rome. They have rolled the six-division assault back more than a mile at some places, and what was a veritable cyclone on Saturday had been reduced to a series of minor gusts by yesterday.

Matinee patrons will have thirty-one Broadway attractions to choose from today. All the shows, except "The Two Mrs. Carrolls" and "The Voice of the Turtle," will observe the holiday by giving afternoon performances.

Although the return of warmer weather was hailed yesterday by coal dealers, as well as householders and tenants who have suffered because of the acute shortage of coal, the city's emergency coal stations will remain open today over the holiday to help small consumers.
LONDON, Feb. 21 (U.P.) -- King Peter is a virtual prisoner in his own headquarter in Cairo, private advices said today, after Russian reports of a plot against his life.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Wendell L. Willkie, nearing the end of his transcontinental trip, conversed today withe three members of the Republican National Committee -Harvey Jewett Jr. of South Dakota, William Stern of North Dakota and Roy E. Dunn of Minnesota.
The following points have a bearing on the subsidy controversy and Mr. Bowles' letter in your issue of Feb. 16:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Congressional leaders returned to the Capitol from a conference with President Roosevelt today, expressing the conviction that, in the face of their advice to the contrary last week, he would veto the $2,315,000,000 tax bill and tell why in a message to Congress tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -Rejecting suggestions that the draft age be lowered from 18 to 17, members of the House Military Committee called today for better utilization of existing manpower resources before considering any changes in the Selective Service Act.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- In an attempt to settle difficulties between the legal profession and the standard title insurance companies regarding how far the latter might go in the "practice of law," the New York State Bar Association announced today appointment of a committee to work with members of the New York State Title Association on a statement of policies.

A great new fact of the world today is Soviet Russia. We shall have to live next door to Russia and reckon with her for a long while to come. The more we know about her the better for us and for all concerned.

Governor Dewey has recently asserted that enactment of the Senate bill which provides a Federal ballot for those in foreign service would result in a conflict with certain voting provisions of the New York Constitution. But what of that?

There is a new school of historians whose members every little while must feel like Lord Clive; they are astonished at their own moderation. They are the writers of history who always see the nations as puppets in the hands of a few select families working in cahoots.

Following the plea by Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, to trade and other organizations to cut down on conventions, it was learned yesterday that while 50 per cent of the conventions scheduled in the country had been called off, eighty-seven more were held in New York City in 1943 than in 1942. The increase was from 549 in 1942 to 636 in 1943.

A volume about war from the library of George Washington at Mount Vernon, a book acquired by the Rosenbach Company, 15 East Fifty-first Street, is to be placed on exhibition there for the first time on Feb. 28 in a large and comprehensive collection of American historical documents.

Permission to allow for rent concessions in computing maximum rents has been granted to the New York Defense Rental Area office, Daniel P. Woolley, regional OPA administrator, announced yesterday. The ruling covers only those concessions in leases made in the regular residential leasing seasons. Off-season leases, such as those for short terms, are excluded.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The same convoys which carry to the shores of enemy-occupied territory the troops, tanks and shells for liberation will carry food, agricultural supplies and equipment for the repair of transportation and manufacturing plants, the Assembly was told tonight.

AN ADVANCED SOUTHERN PACIFIC AIRBASE, Tuesday, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Jolly Roger squadron of Navy Corsair fighters filled the Rabaul skies with flaming Japanese planes Saturday and ran the squadron's total to a South Pacific fighter record of 154 planes destroyed in sixty-two days of combat.

In its third concert of the season at the New York Times Hall last night, the Saidenberg Little Symphony, conducted by David Saidenberg, presented two first performances of modern works in a program made up entirely of contemporary scores.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 1 per cent for the week ended Feb. 19, according to the "preliminary" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the previous week the bank had reported a decline of 17 per cent under the like week last year.

A sensational rally by the Washington and Jefferson five in the last two minutes of the game fell short of its mark as the Long Island University Blackbirds gained a 45-to-42 decision over the Presidents in the second game of last night's basketball double-header in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Full acceptance by the Administration of Bernard M. Baruch's proposals for post-war readjustment in the face of rapidly developing Congresssional opposition was indicated today when James F. Byrnes, director of the Office of War Mobilization, filled the two key administrative positions under his office recommended by Mr. Baruch.

The Department of Higher Education submitted a budget request for 1944-45 totaling $10,518,575, an increase of $639,657 over its current one, to Budget Director Thomas J. Paterson yesterday. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, told Mr. Patterson the Government was asking for individualized instruction and treatment for men discharged from the armed forces who must make adjustment in returning to civil life.

AT THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, South of Rome, Feb. 20 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Members of a large Allied patrol walked back into the Allies' lines at dawn today after having fought all night with hand grenades, tommy guns and bayonets, leaving the Germans firing anti-aircraft guns at ground targets and tank-destroyer guns at patrols.
Vandals overturned granite tombstones in the Moravian Cemetery at New Dorp, S.I., some time between sundown Sunday and 7:30 A.M. yesterday, officials of the cemetery reported to the police.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -Senator Maybank proposed today a Senate investigation into the reasons for a slump in cotton textiles production which he said had reached "serious" proportions in recent months. Declaring cotton consumption last month was the lowest since February of 1941, and had declined steadily from a wartime peak in April of 1942, Senator Maybank called for an inquiry to be conducted by a six-member committee which would submit recommendations to the Senate.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- A State medical care plan designed to meet the needs of lower-income groups was placed before the Legislature tonight in a bill calling for approximately equal contributions from the State, employer and the employe.

Possibility that the so-called "joint-area" agreements between the United States and Great Britain might be extended to wartime trade with Italy was seen by exporters yesterday following the recent statement by Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson that although private correspondence with the area would be resumed, regular commercial mail would not be restored until the "completion of agreements now under discussion between the United Kingdom and interested Government agencies of the United States."

"Right Next to Broadway" opened last evening at the Bijou, which indeed is right next to Broadway, but thereafter any connection with events normally taking place in a theatre ended abruptly. For in writing his play, and presenting it, Paul K. Paley stirred memories only to groping for the time there had been anything quite like it; Times Square's latest is not the worst play ever produced, but it is in there trying.

Defending teaching materials on Latin America used in the New York City high schools, Dr. Frederic Ernst, associate superintendent in charge of the academic high schools, said yesterday he doubted that students here have a false picture of our neighbors south of the Rio Grande.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- More than 2,000 American warplanes scourged and blasted the roots of German air power again today and slashed at the thinning Luftwaffe fighter formations defending the inner citadels of Festung Europa in the fourth major assault on Germany since early Sunday morning.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 (U.P.) -- A heavy downpour of rain and gusty winds tonight drenched southern California residents in the second night of the worst snow, hail, rain and wind storm in the region for more than thirteen years.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Paramount "Lady in the Dark," Paramount's adaptation of the musical play by Moss Hart, will have its local premiere. Produced and directed by Mitchell Leisen, the Technicolor film has a cast headed by Ginger Rogers, Ray Milland, Warner Baxter, Jon Hall, Phyllis Brooks, Mischa Auer and Barry Sullivan. . . .

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Baruch-Hancock report was issued at a time when the political duel between the President and Congress was reaching its most intense phase. That was almost enough to assure the attacks that have been made by Congressional leaders against the report's proposal that present executive machinery be used to begin operating its plan to restore the country to a peacetime economy.

BOSTON, Feb. 21 -- Champion Try Cob's Favorite Girl, beautiful black cocker spaniel bred and owned by Mrs. R. Kenneth Cobb of Huntington Station, L.I., and handled by Kenneth Cobb, today won her second Herman E. Mellenthin Memorial Trophy as the Eastern Dog Club began its thirty-second annual two-day all-breed show in the South Armory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- A special agriculture subcommittee of the House approved legislation today which would abolish the Farm Security Administration and change the financing of the Government's farm-tenant program.

Although taxes last year were 3.7 times those of 1942, an increase of 68 per cent in sales enabled the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company to show a net profit of $21,479,048, as compared with $14,370,911 the year before, according to the annual report of P.W. Litchfield, chairman, mailed to stockholders yesterday.

A notable radio program over the week-end brought together John Foster Dulles, Joseph A. Proskauer and Alfred E. Smith to speak for inter-religious and interracial fellowship in this country. Each man representing his own great segment of American life, all three pleaded for recognition of the spirit of tolerance as vital to the unity and the preservation of the nation.

Off the eastern end of Long Island at Montauk, where stripers and weaks and swordfish lured thousands of sportsmen in peace days, "tin fish" now cut through the waters of Fort Pond Bay and race out into Block Island Sound.

In the collection of custom-made clothes designed by Mme. Helene Lyolene for Madame et la Jeune Fille, which was shown yesterday, one had no sense of wartime limitations. The Franco-American designer -- trained in Paris, she is now an American citizen -- handled the materials so as to endow them with a pre-war fluidity of line in daytime and evening styles.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- At least five German lanes out of between fifty and sixty that came over London late last night and early this morning were destroyed, according to figures given out today by the Air Ministry.

One of the principal reasons why a professional shampoo is invariably successful, whereas the home-administered version "never quite seems to get the hair clean," is the rinse. This final step in the average salon shampoo is not just a fancy frill nor a foolish excuse for extra charges.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21 -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda charged today that pro-Fascist officers in the Yugoslav army had Staged a fake assassination attempt against King Peter in Cairo to create favorable conditions for the imposition of "repressions" against Yugoslav officers and men who have made known their desire to leave their present units to Join Marshal Tito's (Josip Broz) Army of Liberation.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Ave. (at 40th St.), through the generosity of the entertainment world offers a partial list of free amusements available today. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M., evening tickets 4, 5:30, 6:30 and 7:30 P.M.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21 -- Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said tonight that this country's contribution to world peace and freedom "can only be made if we are able to use our unparalleled advantages in establishing here, at home, a high standard of prosperity and democracy."

Birthday pennies and other small contributions from Girl Scouts during the past year made up a fund of $26,000, which was distributed to help agencies for children of Great Britain, Russia, China, Greece and Malta, Girl Scout national headquarters announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company has notified the Interstate Commerce Commission that in accordance with its supplemental order of Dec. 31, 1943, authorizing the railroad to purchase 14,857 additional shares, common or preferred, or both, of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway Company that the purchase has been made as follows:
Police detailed to cut potential juvenile delinquents from Times Square's holiday herds found their task complicated last night by swarms that seemed as large as New Year's Eve crowds.

Plans to issue Clipper Air Cheques, which will be acceptable in sixty-three countries and colonies around the globe, were announced yesterday by Pan American World Airways System. According to the company, the cheques will constitute "the first system of world air currency."

The most drastic shake-up of the war in the Japanese High Command, involving the shelving of the chiefs of both the Army and Navy general staffs, was announced by Tokyo yesterday on the heels of official Japanese admissions of heavy losses in last week's great American attack on Truk.

Shortening of the eight-year grammar school course to seven years and of the high school and college courses to a total of seven years, with part of the two years thus saved devoted to military and citizenship training, was advocated yesterday by Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The third and most thorough combing out for military service of men who have been performing jobs that have exempted them because of Britain's need for war production was announced tonight by the Ministry of Labor.

George Bush, Newtown High School center, will remember Monday, Feb. 21, 1944, as a great day. For on that afternoon, which was yesterday, Bush not only sparked his team to the North Shore Queens Division P.S.A.L. championship, but in doing so accounted for a new Madison Square Garden inter-scholastic individual scoring record of 25 points as Newtown overwhelmed Bryant High, 52-39.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21 -- A declaration that the newly created National Council in Poland "has complete right to speak in the name of the nation and represent its interests" was contained in the latest issue (Feb. 8) of Wolna Polska, the publication of the Union of Polish Patriots in the U.S.S.R., which became available to Moscow foreign correspondents today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Feb. 22 -- "Maintaining a close blockade on the Bismarcks," Allied airmen sank nine vessels on Saturday and Sunday, virtually destroying the second convoy in a week, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Discussing "the enormous task ahead, now and at the end of hostilities, involving the lives of millions of human beings" throughout the world, the Most Rev. Francis J. Haas, Bishop of Grand Rapids, declared tonight that he repudiated "'private initiative' alone and unassisted as the formula for reconstructing the post-war world."

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Mayor Erastus Corning 2d, the Democratic Mayor of Albany and 34 years old, revealed today that he had been reclassified from 3A to 1A in the draft. He has two children, Erastus 3d, who is 10, and Elizabeth, 5.

The Citizens Union, in opposing the increased subway fare, stamps the Committee of Fifteen's forecast of increased revenue as mere "guesswork." But what assurance have they that their own predictions are b.ed on more scientific data?

In addition to its announcement of an increased common dividend, E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. released yesterday a preliminary report for 1943 showing earnings of $5.59 a share on the common stock, compared with $5.07 in 1942.

A booklet giving standards for preparation of family budgets by social agencies was presented yesterday to the social welfare and public health department of the New York Home Economics Association at a meeting at the Russell Sage Foundation. Titled "Budget Standards for Family Agencies," the guide is a revision of an edition published in 1938. It was prepared by the New York Budget Council.

LONDON, Feb. 21 (Reuter) -British shipping companies have formed five groups for the organization of air transport: the North Atlantic, South American, South and East African, Eastern, and Coastal and Continental.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 21 -- A winterized tent city was being erected at Raritan Arsenal near here today to house 600 ordnance troops being rushed here from other depots to relieve a shortage of civilian manpower urgently needed to move equipment for the coming invasion of Europe, Col. Max A. Elser, commanding officer, announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of the President's Executive Order establishing the Surplus War Property Administration:

BALTIMORE, Feb. 21 -- Declaring that war and its related problems of peacetime organization for equity and freedom have "at last taught the American people that modern geography is not children's geography, to be finished in the seventh grade," Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of Johns Hopkins University, predicted today that the post-war educational system in this country would include a "thorough-going instruction" in geography.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Governor Dewey recommended to the Legisture tonight the creation of a special commission, composed largely of State Cabinet officers, to coordinate all steps taken by the State for the relief of returning war veterans.
Communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and re ported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Ceiling prices on food have been so complicated in many instances that consumers hardly have known whether they were abiding by them or patronizing black markets. Recently, however, to the gratification of all concerned, the Office of Price Administration has tried to simlify the system.

Women war workers, sometimes accused of spending their "fabulous" salaries on such luxury items as fur coats and orchids, actually are earning an average of less than $30 a week and are finding it difficult to make both ends meet, according to a report made public yesterday by the division of women in industry and minimum wage of the New York State Department of Labor.

The current tenant of the Ambassador, R.H. Burnside's Gilbert and Sullivan Opera Company, to be specific, got around to performing "The Gondoliers" last night. In other quarters, besides this one, it is often agreed that the famous team had an off-day in composing the work.

The Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and its subsidiaries, which were denied permission to consolidate last month by the New York State Public Service Commission, filed yesterday a petition with the commission for a rehearing of the entire matter.

Sir Osbert Sitwell's autobiography will be published by Little, Brown as an Atlantic Monthly Press book April 20. Edward Weeks, editor of the Atlantic Monthly, while in England last autumn visited Sir Osbert and brought the first chapters of the manuscript back to this country then.

Although all manufacturers of domestic electric ranges are entitled to a production quota representing a proportion of the 17,000 ranges to be made quarterly to meet the needs of the Office of Civilian Requirements and the Federal Housing Administration, the War Production Board will allow manufacturers who cannot participate in the program, due to the pressure of war work, two alternatives, agency officials stated yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors endorsed today a bill pending in the State Legislature that would prevent the establishment of tax-exempt playgrounds without the consent of the communities affected.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Applications for export licenses for the shipment of textiles to Latin America are running so far ahead of available supplies that the number of rejections of license applications necessarily has risen, the Foreign Economic Administration asserted tonight in a bulletin sent to foreign traders.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today the sinking of two Japanese vessels and damage to another in scattered American air attacks on Friday and Saturday off the coasts of China and French Indo-China.

FRESNO, Calif., Feb. 21 -- Baron Joseph van der Elst, Chancellor of the Belgian Embassy in Washington, declared today that Belgian patriots, armed with tommy-guns parachuted to them by American fliers, were making a gallant stand in the forests of southern Belgium, while the civilian population was waging a deadly war of sabotage against the Germans.

Mayor La Guardia has found a popular cause. In his radio talk Sunday he announced that he was assuming personal command of the city's paper conservation program, and all yesterday willing hands stretched forth to help him.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Prime Minister Churchill has decided to meet the demand for another war report to the British people, who have not had one of his famous reviews now for five months and who have heard from him since his illness only through the medium of personal letters to Conservative by-election candidates.

ALGIERS, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Guards at the Vichy camp for the interned members of the French Foreign Legion frequently beat their prisoners, and in one case choked a Spanish doctor to death, a special five-man military court hearing charges against eleven camp officers was told today.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 21 -- Passage by the Legislature today of a bill to abolish preferential voting for President in New Jersey primary eletcions, in what seemed to many an obvious attempt to keep the name of Governor Dewey of New York off the Republican ballot in May, threatened tonight to split the party after a year of unprecedented harmony.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY IN BURMA, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Powerful rings of British and Indian troops were being forged today around an isolated but strong Japanese force which for seventeen days has been fighting behind the British forward lines in the Arakan area of Burma.

Tomorrow -- Ash Wednesday -and the entire forty days of Lent which it ushers in will be more widely observed than in any previous year. In every church there will be prayers for our own armed forces and those of our Allies.
ALGIERS, Feb. 21 (UP) -- A communigue:...

With only a week remaining for the sale of bonds to individuals in the Fourth War Loan drive, the city yesterday was short 21.7 per cent of its quota. Tabulation of sales on Saturday of $8,439,600 brought the city's total for individuals to $547,225,400, or 78.3 per cent of the quota of $698,500,000.

Lasting peace will be won only by unconditional surrender and maintained only by continuance of a strong Navy, Capt. John K. Richards, commanding officer of the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia University, declared yesterday at a ceremony honoring the outstanding grad uates of the sixteenth class.
LONDON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 38:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Robert I. Miller, 67, criminal attorney and close friend of the late Vice President Charles Curtis, was held without bail tonight in what police called the slaying of Dr. John E. Lind, psychiatrist, who was shot as he sat at the wheel of his automobile at a downtown street corner.

Somewhat more optimism is being shown in the garment trades that recent WPB and OPA actions will eliminate the bottlenecks which have curtailed greatly the supply of low-end cottons and rayons. The situation on these goods is still extremely tight, however, and real relief may be matter of weeks, if not months, according, to opinions expressed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- The unexpected announcement today that the Commodity Credit Corporation would cease until further notice selling cash wheat for feeding purposes, said to be the result of the failure of Congress to enact legislation extending the life of the corporation, resulted in short covering and professional buying of wheat futures today on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -The House Banking and Currency Committee deferred action today on a bill to continue the Commodity Credit Corporation when the Administration was unable apparently to marshal sufficient committee votes to prevent any limitations from being added to the bill.

The letters of Frederick B. Hodges and of Sigrid Undset in recent issues of THE TIMES are so beautiful and poetic that one hesitates to add anything to them. However, the nostalgia expressed so poignantly by Mme. Undset arouses similar emotions in the writer, since the fears he may never again see the glories of the flowerscapes of our Western mountains.

The difficulty which threatened the lightweight championship situation through the knockout of Bob Montgomery by Al Davis last Friday night in Madison Square Garden, disappeared yesterday. Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C., announced that Beau Jack would defend his lightweight title against Montgomery on March 3, and that Beau Jack would fight Davis March 17. Both matches will be held in the Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (U.P.) -- It may be true that mighty oaks from tiny acorns grow, but what Senator Burnet R. Maybank, Democrat, of South Carolina, wants to know is -- what makes shirt tails grow shorter?

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Stressing the need for mutual trust and tolerance among the Allied Nations, former Ambassador Joseph E. Davies declared today "the Soviet Union, obviously, is as vital to post-war peace as it is to the winning of the war."

Two German generals and Capt. Leon Degrelle, Belgian Nazi leader and Elite Guard "volunteer," were flown to Berlin yesterday and presented at a "reception" of German and neutral reporters by Dr. Otto Dietrich, Adolf Hitler's personal press representative, In an effort to deny that the major part of ten German divisions had been wiped out by the Russians last week in the Cherkassy pocket.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 -- Blind and widowed Mrs. Margaret Stull, 56, all of whose five sons have been drafted, is fearful people may question her patriotism.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Andrey A. Gromyko, the Soviet Ambassador, conferred for a short time today with President Roosevelt under circumstance that led to conjectures that he might have delivered a message from Premier Joseph Stalin.

The Virginia squire who led a revolution of about three million people would doubtless feel himself a stranger in this nation of more than 130,000,000. He might wonder why, after this lapse of time and all the changes that have gone with it, this great mass of humanity should still hold him in respect.

ALGIERS, Feb. 21 -- The "unfavorable progress" of the typhus epidemic among civilians in Naples has been arrested, Brig. Gen. Leon A. Fox, field director of the United States Army typhus commission, told delegates this morning at the opening session of the Allied Medical Congress at the war-conscious University of Algiers.

Going no place at accelerated speed the Rangers tonight in Madison Square Garden tackle the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League struggle that will launch for the Blue Shirts what is known to the trade as "playing out the string."

Capt. Ernest Engerer, 52 years old, an animal trainer, was severely scratched about the forehead and right arm last night by one of five lionesses with which he was staging an act at a benefit circus in the Jamaica Armory, 168th Street and Ninety-third Avenue, Jamaica, Queens.

Though reports from the Anzio front sound a more hopeful note it is too early to assume that we are winning the battle of the beachhead. But at least the Germans are not winning it. Apparently we have broken the hardest blow they have been able thus far to strike. But we have not yet recovered all the ground we were forced to yield around Carroceto.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- The public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission urged today that the Buffalo, Niagara and Eastern Power Corporation be required to recapitalize by substituting a single class of common stock for the presently outstanding $1.60 preferred stock and Class A and common stock.

A new brochure entitled "A Matter of Life and Death," calling for increased advertising support for the Army Medical Department, has been prepared by the War Advertising Council in cooperation with the Army and the Office of War Information arid distributed to business executives throughout the country.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 21 -Skiers from Canada carried off the major portion of the honors as the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' annual Washington Birthday games went through their second day of competition today under perfect weather and snow conditions.

Suits for everyone, for almost every occasion, sounded the keynote of "Spring Indicative," the fashion show presented yesterday by Milgrim at the St. Regis in the Iridium Room. In a collection clearly scheduled for town, the store covered fashions for young and old, for slender and mature figures.

High praise for the military achievements of the Red Army and predictions that it would share with the United States and British Armies in the complete overthrow of Nazi Germany this year were voiced last night by prominent officers of the United States, British and Chinese Armies at a dinner of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship at the Hotel Commodore.

Commercial contracts reported by brokers yesterday included one for a large unit in the General Motors Building, 1775 Broadway, signed by Higgins Brenner, accountants, through the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., broker, and another for additional space in 572 Madison Avenue taken by the National Home Builders Bureau, Inc., through Huberth Huberth, brokers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- They thought the most productive touch-down supply line in football history was broken up last fall when passer Cecil Isbell became assistant coach at Purdue and left his battery mate, end Don Hutson of the Green Bay Packers, groping for tosses from two others.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The stock markets here today were dull, most features having a tendency to decline. London, Midland Scottish was lower in a weak home rail section, and among the Kaffirs, West Witwater also was down.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 22 -Russian Ukraine troops yesterday crashed into the outskirts of Krivoi Rog less than four miles from the heart of that iron ore city in the Dnieper bend, while on the northern front, Moscow said today, other Soviet forces in a sudden strike across the Lovat River toppled the big German base of Kholm, sixty miles south of Lake Ilmen.

William S. Bennet, Republican candidate for Congress in the Twenty-first District special election to be held next Tuesday, received the endorsement yesterday of Wendell L. Willkie, an avowed candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.

The Federal Government is trying "desperately" to move the 138,000,000-bushel carry-over from last year's record-breaking potato crop to avert the necessity for dumping to make way for the new spring crop.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 21 -United States troops have taken Eniwetok Island in Eniwetok Atoll after fighting for about two days against an enemy garrison estimated to consist of a thousand men. Eniwetok Island lies at the southern end of the atoll.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 21 -- With Dr. Juho K. Paasikivi, Finnish diplomat, lingering in Stockholm and nothing definite known about the date of his return to Helsinki to report, political circles in Stockholm are inclined to regard his stay here as a good omen.
LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

"AMERICA," says Archibald MacLeish, "was promises." America also was immigrants, and it can be argued that we first faltered in our optimistic Lincolnian faith when we decided to apply a niggardly quota law to Europeans who wanted to escape the straitened circumstances and the omnipresent militarism of their various old-country homelands.
SALISBURY, England, Feb. 21 -- With their wives in war factories and their servants vanished, Englishmen are beginning to realize that if they want to eat they must learn to cook.

NEVER once in his Seventy-odd years did Bill Klein ever do anything by halves. It was whole loaf or none with the Old Arbitrator. No so long ago an Australian sent him a letter in which he described the difficulties of umpiring Down Under, and timorously suggested that he'd be able to make good use of a "breastplate" (chest-protector to us), if one was available.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- First signs of a break in the Senate-House conference deadlock over srevice men's voting programs appeared today after the conferees accepted for study a proposal designed to eliminate the constitutional issues.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- United States and British air force leaders exchanged congratulatory messages today on the successful, if costly, week-end attacks on Leipzig, home of important German aircraft production factories, blasted by Royal Air Force bombers on Saturday night and again during daylight on Sunday by the United States Army Air Forces.

The large group exhibition that opened formally on Sunday and to the public yesterday at the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, is made up of work by members and associates of the Art Students League. It was organized to raise funds for scholarships that are to be given to service men and women at the end of the war.

ALGIERS, Feb. 21 -- A new Flying Fortress of the United States Fifteenth Air Force was so riddled by flak on its first mission over the beachhead below Rome a few days ago that it was consigned to the scrap heap, it was learned today. Ground crews counted 500 holes, then quit counting.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The United States Government decided today to continue embargo against Spain during March.
Bernardo Segall, Brazilian pianist, gave a brilliant recital before an audience that filled Carnegie Hall last night. He gave many encores.

Renewed price-fixing in the March and May contracts, combined with short covering in advance of the first delivery notice day on Thursday, marked yesterday a quiet, pre-holiday cotton market At the close of trading active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange ranged from losses of 5 to gains of 6 points.

With backlogs of unfilled orders amounting to $3,000,000,000 on Nov. 30, 1943, combined sales of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation as now constituted were $831,295,737 for the fiscal year ended on that date, comparing with $379,022,351 in the preceding year, an increase of nearly 120 per cent, according to the annual report by Tom M. Girdler, chairman, and H. Woodhead, president.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 22 -- Columbia has announced that the contract suspension of Rita Hayworth been lifted and that the actress will return Monday to begin rehearsals of "Tonight and Every Night." Miss Hayworth was suspended the first of the year on her refusal to report to the studio for this part, which in the meantime had been given to Janet Blair.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Approximately 300 recommendations for reducing "burdensome" Government questionnaires have been accepted by the Budget Bureau and subsequently by Federal agencies concerned, including the Office of Price Administration and the War Production Board, the United States Chamber of Commerce announced today.

Going counter to the wartime trend of college enrollments, the registrations for evening sessions of three municipal colleges have shown an average increase of 7.5 per cent over the fall semester of 1943, according to figures made public yesterday by the Board of Higher Education.

First-run Broadway motion-picture theatres played to record and capacity business over the holiday, according to estimates made last night by spokesmen for the various managements. Despite the rain, which began shortly after noon, most of the houses reported standing room only, and, in some cases, long waiting lines outside the theatres in the morning and early afternoon.

A UNITED STATES HEAVY BOMBER STATION, Somewhere in Britain, Feb. 22 -- Standing in the coffee room of this field today and watching American airmen who had just returned from an eight-hour bombing trip to Germany having a cup of coffee or cocoa and a sandwich while waiting to be called for interrogation, this correspondent got two definite impressions.

Holiday throngs swarming through the theatrical district early yesterday morning hampered police seeking juvenile delinquents and potential strays. Only seven were taken. Of these six were between 16 and 21 years of age. One was under 16. In all cases the parents were notified.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 23 -- Very strong formations of American heavy bombers and American and Allied long-range fighters converged on Germany from Britain and Italy yesterday and delivered smashing attacks upon Nazi fighter-plane factories at Bernburg, Aschersleben, Halberstadt and Regensburg in a coordinated effort that opened a new phase of the Allied air effort against the Luftwaffe.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Naples, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Fifteenth Air Force blasted the Messerschmitt factories at Regensburg, fifty miles north of Munich, today, in the first coordinated attack with British-based American bombers on German targets.
The operations in the Marshall Islands may provide much useful case history for the invasion of Europe and for other amphibious operations.

There was an excellent "Siegfried" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, as the third performance in the Tuesday evening Wagner cycle. The audience was an interesting and impressive spectacle: a different audience from the one of the subscription nights, an audience deeply appreciative of the opportunity of such a performance of that music drama which has been appropriately described as the scherzo of "The Ring" and packing the theatre to hear it.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- The Assembly passed Governor Dewey's $372,000,000 executive budget and tax program today after a number of Republican members, who joined in defeating a Democratic amendment to restore the $7,800,000 reduction in State aid for education, announced their willingness to vote later for a separate bill restoring at least a part of that reduction.

Latest figures on Houghton Mifflin's best seller, "The Robe," indicate no slackening in the demand. Total sales in this country to date, excluding the distribution through book clubs, have exceeded 700,000 copies. In Canada sales now stand at 50,000 copies.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has received as a gift from Mrs. Francis Neilson of Chicago a portrait by Rembrandt of "A Lady With a Fan." The painting will go on display at the museum today.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill in a solemn speech before the House of Commons declared today that the United States, Britain and Soviet Russia would remain as united now as they were at the Moscow and Teheran conferences, but warned the United Nations that even with all their strength and all their unity and all their mounting air power they might not be able to defeat Germany in 1944.

LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill urged his countrymen today not to be "unduly concerned" by what may be said about Britain during this election year in the United States and called for Allied unity "in these times of immense exertion and grievous sacrifice."
Patriotic observances marking the 212th anniversary of the birth of George Washington were numerous throughout the city yesterday.
ANZIO BEACHHEAD, Italy, Feb. 22 (U.P.) -- "For gallantry in action and the best inspiration to others * * * "

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- President Roosevelt and Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, both revealed today that the Japanese had suffered heavy losses in the Pacific theatre of war, but behind their disclosure lay a warning that these facts must not carry undue conviction of an early victory in that campaign.

Both the United States and Great Britain have cast their eyes on the oil resources of the Middle East -- we to forestall the imminent exhaustion of our own fields, the British to make sure of their own supply. Our plans are centered on Saudi Arabia, which is probably the largest single undeveloped oil field in the world and one that we already control through leases made to the California Arabian Oil Company.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- According to Reuter dispatches from Stockholm tonight the attacking planes came over the city on a westerly course.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Harold (Jug) McSpaden, rejected today for military service, was returning tonight to the tournament trail, an advocate of revision in the prize system now in use. A change is necessary, McSpaden said, if golf professionals are to continue playing the tournament circuit.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 22 -- "A brisk business" in signing up volunteer civilian personnel to relieve the acute manpower shortage at Raritan Arsenal near here was reported today by Charles Davis, area director of the War Manpower Commission, following appeals by Army and municipal authorities for emergency assistance to speed the shipment overseas of vitally needed supplies.

LONDON, Feb. 22 (U.P.) -midget submarines, specially built for the purpose and manned byI {slueciaUy trained crews, got within{ {200 yards of the German battleship I Tirpitz to torpedo her in the Nor-I iwegian Alten Fjord last Septem-I iber, it was revealed today.

FIFTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Italy, Feb. 22 -- By a profligate expenditure of ammunition that the harassed lines of communition almost certainly cannot keep up, the Germans have now made their front containing the Allies' Anzio beachhead the hottest nest of anti-aircraft fire ever seen in the Mediterranean theatre.

Two hundred more pints of blood were contributed to the American Red Cross blood bank yesterday afternoon when 120 members of Companies I, K and L of the Third Batallion, Fifty-first Regiment, New York Guard, each gave one pint of their blood and eighty civilians, mostly women, donated the same amount at the batallion headquarters on Manor Road, West New Brighton, S.I.

Again yesterday Mr. Churchill proved himself the great historian of the war. The picture he painted of the conflict as it appeared Feb. 22, 1944, is the picture that will go into the record. Whatever may be thought of the Prime Minister as politician, negotiator, architect of the future, he is the unrivaled interpreter of the battle of our time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Senate's Banking and Currency Committee today reported out with a recommendation that it be passed, and without amending the measure, the resolution continuing the Commodity Credit Corporation to June 30, 1945.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The secret weapon that the enemy is preparing to employ against England is a winged bomb controlled by radio, propelled by a rocket or jet and capable of bombing London from bases in northern France, according to reports that have circulated in London for the last two months.

A nutrition course designed to teach planning of meals for low-income families begins at 7 o'clock tonight at the Children's Aid Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street. Planned by the society's nutritionist, Mrs. Katharine Russell, the course also includes care of the kitchen and a lecture on safety hazards.

ALGIERS, Feb. 22 -- The greatest German effort of the Italian campaign so far is now officially interpreted as a failure -- but no one would be so rash as to say that it was the last attempt or that its unprecedented fury would not be exceeded before the battle below Rome was over.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- President Roosevelt vetoed the tax bill today, sending it back to Congress with a sharp message branding it as "relief not for the needy but for the greedy." He called it "wholly ineffective" as a revenue measure.

Drastic post-war control of minerals essential for war-making was advocated yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The question was debated by the war activities, mineral economics and mining geology committees of the institute and the Society of Economic Geologists as well as various Government officials and metallurgical authorities of this country and Canada.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Feb. 23 (UP) -- A communique:

KWAJALEIN, Marshall Islands, Feb. 8 (Delayed) -- Among the Japanese on Kwajalein Island there was less disposition to commit hara kiri in preference to surrender than there had been elsewhere in the Pacific war.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- The Legislature rolled into high gear today for the first time in the current session, with important developments on the floor in both houses, rivaling behind-the-scenes decisions reached by the leaders. With adjournment scheduled for March 16, little more than three weeks away, the highlights were as follows:...

Plans for immediate action to recruit 10,000 volunteer farm workers in the metropolitan area in expectation of a heavy demand for farm labor in the summer were approved yesterday by representatives of the State, city and nation. They met in the office of the United States Employment Service, 44 East Twenty-third Street.
Protestant churches here will participate on Friday in a "World-Wide Day of Prayer," an "intercession for the nations at war."

Operations of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., during the six months ended with January, resulted in a net profit of $6,210,895 after deductions of $10,349,100 for income and excess-profits taxes and $1,000,000 provision for possible future inventory price decline, the report disclosed yesterday.

Secretary Knox's announcement yesterday that ninety-two Japanese ships were sunk in the first three weeks of this month emphasizes the rising tempo of the war in the Pacific. These enemy losses, inflicted by our planes, surface ships and submarines, occurred on four widely separated fronts: the Bismarck Islands, the Caroline Islands, the south China coast and the waters around Japan itself.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission; Dr. Evaline M. Burns, consultant of the National Planning Association, and Lawrence Rogin, national director of education of the Textile Workers Union of America, agreed yesterday that post-war planning must aim at more than a return to a "normal" world.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 22 -- Mrs. John J. Gilligan of 381 South Burnett Street, East Orange, was sponsor today at the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company yard here at the launching of a destroyer-escort named for her son, Pvt. John J. Gilligan Jr., a marine who died of wounds suffered in action in the Solomons.
LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's report to Parliament today:

In your editorial of Feb. 3 entitled "Bewildering Statistics" you listed five estimates attributed to members of the OPA organization relating to the extent of savings from the subsidy program. You implied that these figures are inconsistent and that they have been increased from time to time for purposes of propaganda.

The United States assault on the naval base at Truk has shaken the Japanese people more than any other development of the war, the Japanese Domei agency acknowledged yesterday. At the same time Premier Hideki Tojo told his Cabinet that he was determined to "leave no cause for anxiety on the part of the people from the standpoint of military operations."
LONDON, Feb. 22 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, England, Feb. 22 -- The 212th anniversary of the birth of George Washington was observed today in this village in County Durham, which claims historical associations with the ancestors of the first President of the United States and the man who led the American Revolution against British rule.
The five-story flat for twenty families at 919 Clinton Street, Hoboken, N.J., has been sold by Herman A. Kuehn to Clarence McQueen. It is assessed for $29,200.

As a prelude to the opening of the Red Cross 1944 War Fund drive, 2,000 leaders in business and manufacturing in the city will conduct a mobilization rally at the Hotel Commodore at 4 P. M. on Friday.

HADDONFIELD, N.J., Feb. 22 -- A 13-year-old boy was drowned today in the icy waters of Wallworth Park Lake while three of his companions were rescued when their overloaded skiff was capsized by drift ice. The body of the victim, Thomas Hennessey Jr., was recovered two hours after the tragedy.
The Lenten season, which starts today, is synonymous in a culinary sense with meatless meals. Accordingly, there follows a report on the availability of substitutes for pork and lamb, beef and veal.

Endorsement of a minimum code of social policy for dependent territories by member governments of the International Labor Organization will be sought at its meeting beginning in Philadelphia on April 20, it was announced by the International Labor Office, the administrative agency, in a statement received there yesterday from Montreal.

Establishment of an agency, similar to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, that would deal with the intellectual revival of Nazi-occupied countries was suggested yesterday by Frans van Cauwelaert, former president of the Belgian Chamber of Deputies. M. van Cauwelaert proposed an international conference on intellectual cooperation parallel to the UNRAA sessions already held.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in Mandarin to China and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

HAMILTON, Bermuda. Feb. 22 -- Carrying further its tentative rejection of a definite plan involving payment to the United Kingdom of the cost of United States bases here, the Assembly today threw out a motion calling for raising an interest-free loan of 400,000 plus an undertaking to make contributions when practicable up to 560,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The determination of Congress not to be by-passed in the formulation or application of war demobilization policies was evinced today in an over-all demobilization bill introduced by Senators George of Georgia, Murray of Montana and Hill of Alabama, all-Democrats which embodied recommendations of the Senate's Post-war Planning Committee.

Marilyn Meyer, 17-year-old pianist from Milwaukee, who has studied in this city with Clarence Adler and Simon Barere, gave her third recital last night in Town Hall, where she made her debut on Jan. 6, 1940. She played a program consisting of the Bach-Busoni Toccata in C major, Schumann's Phantasie, Opus 17, the Ballade in F minor and three etudes by Chopin, Ravel's "Oiseaux Tristes" and "Jeux d'Eau" and Liszt's "Rhapsodie Espagnole."

Richmond, the city's smallest county in point of population, ranks tenth among those counties in the State that have exceeded their all-investors' goals in the Fourth War Loan drive, Nevil Ford executive manager of the War Finance Committee for New York, disclosed yesterday.

THERE isn't any aspect about peace-making over which well informed persons of good-will can't disagree violently. What steps should be taken toward greater and more effective international cooperation and what we should do to the Germans are only the two most combustible subjects. No one seems to worry much about what we should do to the Japanese.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22 -- Mayor Fletcher Bowron, admitting failure to end a nine-day strike of electrical employes that halted production at 150 war plants, announced tonight that Army troops would take over operation of the municipal power system tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's message today vetoing the tax bill:

BERNE, Switzerland Feb. 22 -- The "Republican Fascist Government's" decree inflicting the death penalty on all Italians capable of bearing arms who do not report to recruiting centers within the next fifteen days has opened a storm of criticism throughout Italy against the "illegal activities" of that Government, a correspondent of the Swiss Telegraphic Agency said tonight in a censored dispatch from Rome.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The creation of an international economic council to estimate requirements and guide the flow of post-war trade is recommended in a report issued today by the Federation of British Industries. There is an expansionist trend running through the statement, which is accepted as the responsible opinion of a majority of the most influential British manufacturers.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 22 (AP) -- President Roosevelt was described by Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri tonight as the man best able to handle "the solemn responsibilities which will be ours in the post-war world" and urged that he be continued in office.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Prime Minister Churchill, himself a correspondent in the Boer War, complained in the House of Commons today about "alarmist" reports being sent about the Italian bridgehead, some by American newspaper men.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22 -- Red Star, the Army newspaper, published today another attack on the anti-Soviet attitude of the Polish Government in London and its army, charging it is "playing into the hands of Hitlerite Germany" and persecuting Poles who prefer to fight alongside the Red Army in the struggle for the liberation of Poland.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- A formal charge of homicide was filed today against Robert I. Miller, 67-year-old criminal attorney, after a coroner's inquest ordered him held for the grand jury in the shooting of Dr. John E. Lind, psychiatrist of St. Elizabeth's Hospital staff.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Chicago hog-marketing committee announced today that the permission-to-market plan will be suspended here after Saturday and shippers of swine for the remainder of this week will have a 10 per cent rise in quotas. The movement of hogs to market has been reduced in recent days, easing the pressure on killing concerns and agents in maintaining an orderly market.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Finnish port of Aabo was bombed tonight by Russian planes, a dispatch from Finland said.

The apartment house containing thirteen suites and two stores at 3780 Third Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Israel Lazar to the Bowling Real Estate Corporation through Samuel Hurwitz, broker. This property is assessed for $18,000 and was sold for cash.

COLLINGSWOOD, N. J., Feb. 22 -- Second Lieutenant Paul J. Madden, 24 years old, a ferry command pilot, who was reported missing in action on Jan. 31, notified his family today that he had been rescued after eleven days on a life raft, during which two of his companions died.

Declaring that the United States must not again "be found wanting in a realization of the facts of life," Senator Ralph O. Brewster, Republican, of Maine, laid down last night "certain essentials in an American program to establish America in its proper position among the nations of the earth" when peace comes.

By all odds the best matinee day of the year, Washington's Birthday, again came through with flying colors. All but two of thirty-three current Broadway offerings gave afternoon performances, an indication in itself of what was anticipated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- President Roosevelt expressed himself in accord today with Prime Minister Churchill's statement in the House of Commons that he could not guarantee an end of the war in Europe this year.

The late John Macrae was second to none in his fidelity to the creed that a publisher of books is something more than a book merchandiser. Along with books which the public wants, and so testifies by buying them, it is the ancient and honorable tradition of the trade that the public should be taught and persuaded to buy the books that it ought to want.
WASHINGTON, Feb, 22 -- The Maritime Commission awarded contracts to four shipyards today for the construction of 100 small cargo vessels, doubling the number of this type of ship now on order.

Despite the arguments of well-intentioned educators to the contrary, it will prove impossible to impose the American democratic school tradition upon Japan, Germany or any other country, speakers declared yesterday at the regional conference of the American Association of School Administrators, a department of the National Education Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- President Roosevelt said today that he believed Federal authority should be used, if necessary, to maintain an essential municipal service when strikes threaten or disrupt them. He made it clear that he was speaking hypothetically, although he had just been asked at his news conference about the current strike against the Los Angeles municipal power system in which 2,500 of 6,000 workers are out, and about fifty war plants shut down.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22 -- The rank and file of Republican voters in New York State give their Governor, Thomas E. Dewey, an overwhelming "favorite son" vote for the 1944 Presidential nomination.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- Solicitation of proxies in opposition to a proposed retirement annuity plan sponsored by the management of the United Gas Improvement Company was begun today by Victor Frey of this city, an attorney and beneficial owner of 600 shares of the common stock of the holding company.

News of the sale of the Yankee baseball club, reported innumerable times since the death of Col. Jacob Ruppert on Jan. 13, 1939, was revived yesterday in a report that reached THE NEW YORK TIMES from a reliable source. But hours of tracking down an official confirmation were without avail, although several sources involved qualified their denials, justifying the conclusion that the latest report has something more than speculation back of it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Office of War Information said today that more than 740 community recreation centers had been created in 225 critical production areas to help workers maintain efficiency and good work attendance records.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The United States, British and Soviet Governments simultaneously declared today that they would not buy outside their own territories any gold that might have been looted and sold by Axis nations or gold that a country might have been enabled to release as a result of acquisition of Axis gold to replace it.

LANCASTER, Pa., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Aaron H. Martin refused to register for a ration book when war came and points came. He and his wife and five children began making their own shoes, raising and processing their own sugar cane, and doing without what rationed foods they couldn't produce on their own farm.
Reading your "Kitchen Stove" editorial yesterday was like stretching our cold hands to a fragrant wood fire. It made you hear the wood snapping.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22 -- Eight candidates were nominated for two vacancies on the board of trustees of Princeton University at the midwinter meeting of the Princeton Alumni Association here this afternoon. The elections will be conducted by mail.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, head of the Veterans Administration, made public today preliminary plans for carrying on his new duties as retraining and re-employment director to which he was named yesterday by James F. Byrnes, chief of the Office of War Mobilization.
