WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The starving to death of 200 of 1,200 Netherlands soldiers in the German prison camp at Altengrabow because they refused to work in Nazi war plants was revealed today by the Netherlands Government Information Service.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Organized labor joined with the majority of teacher groups today in opposing the Coudert-Wickes bill which would strip the Board of Superintendents in the New York City school system of all its powers and vest it in the Superintendent of Schools.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 22 -- Airplanes of unidentified nationality dropped a number of bombs on Stockholm and the city of Straengnaes, sixty miles due west of Stockholm, on Lake Maelaren tonight. The attack on Stockholm occurred at 8:40 P.M. and was totally unexpected. The city was fully lighted up and there was no alarm in advance, although the dropping of the bombs coincided with the exercise of the city's home guard air section.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, delivering an unscheduled message at the close of the annual Washington's Birthday memorial mass of the Knights of Columbus in St. Patrick's Cathedral, deplored yesterday the bombing of Castel Gandolfo, site of the Pope's summer villa, by American airplanes.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 22 -- "Personally, I think President Roosevelt will be renominated, and I am not averse to that," said Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman at a press conference today in which he stressed that his business was to see that the next Democratic Presidential nominee was elected and not to select him.

United States Attorney James B.M. McNally announced yesterday that he would file in Federal court, when it reopens after the holiday, a suit to restrain two telephone companies and thirty-three hotels from charging above the legal rates for interstate and foreign telephone calls.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Civilian hopes for more dry-cell batteries for their flashlights, radios and other battery-powered electrical equipment were dashed today by the War Production Board in a forecast that heavier military demands will virtually rule out any increase over last year in civilian supplies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Political party lines vanished in Congress today as members stung by President Roosevelt's tax bill veto message retorted hotly with counter-charges that gave promise of reaching far into the political campaign.

ALGIERS, Feb. 22 -- A two-fisted medical agent immunizing against typhus and smallpox simultaneously and the best position for a man in the water to be in to avoid the effects of underwater blasts were described today at the Allied Medical Congress. The gathering also heard Col. Edward D. Churchill of Boston assert that the over-all death rate in field hospitals had decreased 10.5 per cent since 1918.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22 -- The "mystery" of Alsab's condition was partly cleared up today, but the discussion concerning the horse waxes hotter than ever, following an order from the stewards that he be scratched from the featured George Washington Purse.

Wayne Lonergan, Royal Canadian Air Force aircraftman second class, is to go on trial on General Sessions Court before Judge John J. Freschi today for the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, at 313 East Fifty-first Street on Oct. 24.
Wendell L. Willkie returned yesterday from a trip across the continent, satisfied that he had made progress in his campaign for the Republican nomination for President.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- President Roosevelt indicated partiality today to a suggestion he had received that German labor and materials be used to repair damaged historic or ecclesiastical monuments in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Far outbalancing all other reasons for women quitting their war jobs is ill health, principally resulting from fatigue, in the opinion of Mrs. Warwick B. Hobart, who probably has visited more war plants than any other woman in the United States.

The Hygienic Products Company will place advertisements on behalf of the Red Cross drive for war funds in nationally circulated magazines and newspapers with a combined readership of 48,374,584 next month. Total circulation of newspapers is 32,163,956 and total magazine circulation is 16,210,628.

Twenty-five hundred children, representing 60,000 pupils in 518 Jewish religious schools, attended yesterday the second annual Children's Community Assembly, held under the auspices of the Jewish Education Committee of New York, in Hunter College Assembly Hall, Sixty-ninth Street and Park Avenue.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 22 (AP) -- While combined revenues of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiary companies increased $16,110,825 in 1943, net income dropped $639,439.

MILLBROOK, N.J., Feb. 22 -- A four-motored Army bomber bound from Bangor, Me., to Fort Dix crashed shortly after 2 P.M. today in the Kittatinny Mountains near here with the loss of eleven Army officers and men and a Royal Air Force navigator, who was a passenger aboard.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 22 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:
There is an unexpected shift in the attitude of the Turkish Government toward Russia. The Soviet Union is no longer denounced in Ankara as harboring dangerous designs in the Balkans and elsewhere.

Contractors holding inventories as a result of contract terminations have been urged by War Production Board officials to make greater use of the agency's surplus materials redistribution division to speed the settlement of inventory termination claims.

PEORIA, Ill., Feb. 22 -- Condemning what he described as an inefficient, paternalistic, dictatorial and reactionary Administration in Washington, Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, spoke at the annual Creve Coeur Club Washington Day banquet here today.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- The veteran campaigner from Lebanon, N.H., husky Ernest Dion, thrilled a holiday crowd at the Olympic 70-Meter Hill in capturing the spectacular Class A ski jump, concluding event of the three-day Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' twenty-third annual Washington birthday ski games.

As a result of the War Department's curtailment of the Army Specialized Training Program, the United States faces the prospect of a serious shortage of doctors and dentists within the next three years, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the Faculty of Medicine, Columbia University, and chairman of the executive council, Association of American Medical Colleges, warned yesterday.

If the St. John's University basketball team is to realize its hope of receiving a bid to compete in the forthcoming national invitation tournament, tonight is the night when the Redmen will have to assert themselves in no uncertain terms, when they collide with N.Y.U. at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Yesterday's hopes of a compromise in the Senate-House conference on a servicemen's voting program were shattered today when the three House conferees supporting the Eastland - Rankin States' rights plan rejected the proposals through which a meeting ground was believed to have been found, and new ones brought out in its place.

QUINCY, Mass., Feb. 22 (AP) -- The hull o the U.S.S. Pittsburgh, a heavy cruiser of the Baltimore class and third vessel to bear the name of the Pennsylvania city, slid down the ways at the Quincy shipyard of the Bethlehem Steel Company today.

BOSTON, Feb. 22 -- In a brilliant final competition tonight, the award for best in the thirty-second annual bench show of the Eastern Dog Club went to the black standard poodle, Champion Puttencove Impetuous, owned by the Puttencove Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. George Putnam of Manchester, Mass., and handled in the ring by Miss Cecile Ray.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Even those members of Congress who agreed with the President's decision to veto the tax bill and will vote to uphold him came to about the same conclusion as the bill's supporters after reading the text of Mr. Roosevelt's message.

The five-story loft building on a plot 75 by 100 feet, at 231-35 East Forty-second Street, between Second and Third Avenues, has been sold by the Bowery Savings Bank to Jerome Greene, an investor. It is assessed for $295,000 and is fully rented. Hecht Glazer represented the buyer.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 22 -- Two sailors attached to the Lido Naval Station were arrested in Long Beach at 6:50 A.M. today after a chase and charged with stealing a Nassau County police car from in front of the Mineloa Precinct station.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Chilean Government announced tonight the arrest of fourteen persons in a spy ring organized by the German Embassy air attache.

In the prime of devotion to the protective tariff it was a favorite speculation of the high priests of "the American System" that if a couple of inches could be added to the shirt of every Chinese, cotton planting and the textile industry would blossom like the rose. Fact has been brutal to theory.

The Vatican radio last night quoted an article in the newspaper Avvenire di Roma as saying that Pope Pius XII had declared that "it would be an indelible stain on history if, for military reasons, Rome had to be destroyed."
LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Announcement of the winners of prizes in Field and Stream's 1943 fishing contest, contained in the March issue and released to the press yesterday, shows that anglers in New York State waters fared very well.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Although Prime Minister Winston Churchill's speech to the House of Commons today was received well on the stock markets here, it failed to influence business. Further profit-taking caused home rails to decline again, London, Midland Scottish being among those that were marked down.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb, 22 (U.P.) -- For the second time within a week the powerful morning newspaper Prensa carried an editorial today dealing with the relationship between the government and the press. Today's editorial dealt with the question of the registration of journalists.

LONDON, Feb. 22 (U.P.) -- Air crews returning from the United States Eighth Air Force's third straight daylight assault on Germany today reported the most savage attacks by German fighter pilots they have ever experienced. One bombardier of a Flying Fortress said the air opposition was worse than that at Schweinfurt last Oct. 14, when sixty Fortresses were shot down.

Walter J. Dockerill, regional representative of the Solid Fuels Administration, disclosed yesterday that "by far the larger part of the emergency reserve" of 8,000 tons of anthracite held here by SFA had been apportioned to yards in Brooklyn and Queens to help relieve the coal shortage in the city's two largest small-home residential areas.
LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- The Bishops' program of social reconstruction adopted twenty-five years ago, offers the only solution of present-day problems and the maintenance of a democratic form of government, the Rt. Rev. Mgr. John A. Ryan told the Catholic Conference on Industrial Problems tonight.

With a confidence that no longer needs to assert the certainty of victory, but also with a sober appraisal of the strength of the enemy and the difficulties of the great tasks ahead, Mr. Churchill has made another one of his enlightening surveys of the war. It strikes a much-needed balance between undue optimism and undue gloom.

Among those reported yesterday as having leased residential quarters was H. Sidney Morton, a member of the firm of Shields Co., stock brokers, who took an apartment at 28 East Ninety-second Street through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker. Other rentals follow:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- American Mitchell medium bombers raided the once powerful Japanese base of Rabaul on Sunday morning, dropping fifty-two tons of bombs without encountering any interception, a communique, announced today.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 23 -- German planes came over the London area again early this morning in another retaliatory attack on the metropolitan area, dropping high-explosive and incendiary bombs despite heavy anti-aircraft fire.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Heavy rains lashed Southern California today for the fourth consecutive day, while waves pounded the shore and threatened near-by structures.

BRITISH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Western Burma Front, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Scores of demoralized Japanese, abandoned by guerrilla forces behind the British lines, have been wiped out in the northern Arakan jungles in the past forty-eight hours by knife-swinging Gurkhas.

Plans for the Federal Government to release 20,000,000 pounds of butter for civilian consumption from its 130,000,000-pound hoard have struck a snag, it was learned yesterday. The butter and dairy products trade is overwhelmingly opposed because it prefers to deal in fresh rather than in old butter as the country approaches the spring season of flush production.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 23 (AP) -- On the twenty-sixth anniversary of the Red Army today Premier Joseph Stalin triumphantly announced that in one year the Russians had swept the Germans from almost three-quarters of occupied Russia in a westward advance that in places exceeded 1,000 miles.

SACRAMENTO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- An eleventh-hour drive by a sports editor and a care owner, who in forty-eight hours raised $52,000 and fought off a rival bid of more than thrice that amount, has saved Sacramento its Pacific Coast League baseball franchise.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Following is the text of Senator Alben W. Barkley's speech resigning the post of Majority Leader of the Senate:

The "super-destroyer" U.S.S. Moore, named for the late Capt. Samuel N. Moore, USN, who went down with his ship, the cruiser Quincy, in the Battle of the Savo Sea on Aug. 9, 1942, was launched early yesterday morning at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Staten Island yard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The War Production Board disclosed today that a program for allocating cotton duck, to last as long as the fabric is in short supply, will be announced with full details in the near future.

Three field goals within thirty seconds, giving impetus to an incredible spurt that produced eleven points in the final three minutes, brought St. John's a 50-40 basketball victory over New York University before 16,295 persons at Madison Square Garden last night.

Recent defacement of church and synagogue property indicates a new need for vigilance against promoters of religious and racial prejudice, Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday noon in Trinity Church, Broadway at Wall Street.

William L. Batt, vice chairman of the War Production Board, told members of the Bond Club of New York yesterday that when foreign trade was resumed after the war the United States should take payment chiefly through imports of vital raw materials in exchange for the manufactured goods exported.

A possible explanation of the seemingly excessive purchase of scrap steel in this country by the Japanese for at least six years preceding the attack on Pearl Harbor is to be found in a statement made by Walter S. Tower, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers.

" Harriet," the biographical play dealing with the creator of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," will bid Henry Miller's Theatre a reluctant farewell on April 1 after a run of 377 performances. Helen Hayes, who plays the title role, asked Producer Gilbert Miller to end the engagement then so she could spend more time with her ailing husband, Charles MacArthur.

Gilbert B. Geiger of Peoria, Ill., trustee under the American Distilling Company's plan for distribution of whisky inventories to stockholders, announced yesterday that, with the consent of the company, he had extended the time within which stockholders may purchase both sixteen cases of blended whisky and two cases of whisky bottled in bond for each outstanding share until the close of business on April 20.

Reserves for renegotiation refunds which war contractors may set up and show in their statements and annual reports are not to be regarded as binding on contractors, according to a ruling by the Joint Price Adjustment Board, representing six Federal renegotiation agencies, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communiqu:

Prices of post-war automobiles will be at least 25 per cent higher than pre-war levels, Harry M. Williams, president of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York, said yesterday. He pointed out that continuation of high taxes and increased labor and material costs will necessitate a sharp increase in the retail prices of the first models to come off the assembly lines after the war.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

" To ask permission to be free is to confess one's self a slave," says La Prensa, Argentina's great newspaper, quoting Juan Bautista Alberdi, the Jefferson of the Argentine Constitution, to bolster up a strong editorial protest against the Government's proposed new press statutes.

TRENTON, Feb. 23 -- The Republican State Committee today left it to Gov. Walter E. Edge to prevent what might be a disastrous contest for nomination of a candidate for United States Senator in the May primary elections. The party's national committeeman, H. Alexander Smith of Princeton, for whom State Chairman Lloyd B. Marsh reported "overwhelming" sentiment, said he was sure "there will be no row."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Even if the war in Europe is ended by next winter, the rationing of fuel oil will probably have to be continued in the thirty-three States now under a rationing program, the Office of Price Administration warned members of the Fuel Oil Industry Council at a meeting today.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Governor Dewey's executive budget calling for $372,000,000 for 1944-45 became law today when it was adopted unanimously in the Senate after the Democratic minority had failed in a last-ditch effort to force through an amendment pegging State aid for education at $7,800,000, the 1943-44 level.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The latest poem by John Masefield, Poet Laureate, entitled "Ode to the Red Army" and written in honor of the valiant Russian soldiers on the occasion of the twenty-sixth anniversary of the Red Army, was sung publicly today for the first time to music written by Sir Arnold E.T. Bax at a concert in the Albert Hall.

Ella Flesch, Viennese soprano, who joined the Metropolitan Opera company last month, sang her first Santuzza in "Cavalleria Rusticana" at the Metropolitan last night and was acclaimed by an audience that filled the house. Helen Olheim sang the role of Lola and Armand Tokatyan that of Turridu, both for the first time this season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- A showdown fight over the national wage stabilization policy, which has already split the labor members of the National War Labor Board and will probably include the public and industry members also, was regarded as imminent today as a result of recent developments.

The First National Bank of Boston was the successful bidder yesterday for a new issue of $500,00O city of Worcester, Mass., revenue anticipation notes, dated Feb. 24 and payable on Nov. 6, 1944. The bank bid a 0.319 per cent basis.
ALGIERS, Feb. 23 (UP) -- A communiqu:

" No Greater Love," a Soviet importation with English dialogue, will have its local premiere today at the Victoria Theatre. The drama, which stars Maretskaya, deals with a Russian woman who becomes a leader of Partisans after seeing her husband and baby murdered by the Nazis.

Gil Dodds, out to make it four for four in the mile, and the rubber meeting of the red-hot rivalry between Johnny Fulton of the Olympic Club of San Francisco and Joe Nowicki of Rochester, starters in the 1,000-yard run, will get plenty of competition for the public's interest from still another event in the National A.A.U. track and field championships at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Senator Byrd of Virginia read to the Senate today a letter he had addressed to Elmer Davis, director of OWI, asking for a report on an Associated Press dispatch from London that American troops, reaching ports in England, had been circularized with Ministry of Information literature containing alleged election propaganda.

A special meeting of stockholders to vote upon the authorization of 500,000 shares of preferred stock of the company, and the election of Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, as a director were approved by directors of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., at their regular meeting yesterday, Jack I. Straus, president, announced.
LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communiqu, as broadcast from Moscow:

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Bowed tendons were very much to the fore at Hialeah Park today as Curious Coin, who returned to the races this winter after having recovered from a bow, captured the Wildwood Purse, while the Alsab discussions went on and on.

John R. Crews, Brooklyn Republican leader, yesterday announced the county organization's list of delegates and alternates to the national convention to be voted on at the party primaries on March 28. Mr. Crews made no comment in making the list public, but it was apparent that the nominees would support Governor Dewey.
TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 23 -- War veterans are the only class to receive mention in the final legislative committee draft of the proposed State Constitution to be submitted to the Legislature on Friday.

In a recent trip to a Midwestern State I found an interesting viewpoint prevailing quite generally among farmers which might be of interest to readers of THE TIMES. It seems especially important information for any who may accuse farmers of selfishness in their opposition to general food subsidies. Their line of thought can be gleaned from the following, in combination:

BOSTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Details of the largest fire-protection and fire-fighting force ever organized were released today as the Coast Guard observed the second anniversary of its port security operation.

A post-war world in which America can and should, if necessary, accept the responsibility of providing "a quart of milk a day for every Hottentot" was advocated last night by Mayor La Guardia before a meeting sponsored by the Institute on Post-War Reconstruction of New York University.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 23 -- A protest against "Government butting into our affairs" was sent to the White House and to the New Jersey members of Congress today by a group of farmers and business men, who met last night at Washington Crossing, near here.

The housewife who could not always be sure whether the grocer was charging more than ceiling prices -- either because the Office of Price Administration chart was not prominently displayed or because she could not take the time to consult it in a busy store -- will soon have a chance to get a chart of her own.

Less than fifteen months after the laying of her keel on Dec. 15, 1942, the 27,000-ton Essex class aircraft carrier Bennington will be launched Saturday at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by Rear Admiral Monroe Kelly, commandant of the yard.

Their Stanley Cup hopes finally blasted, the Rangers tonight take to the ice at Madison Square Garden against the Red Wings in a game that will bring them that much closer to the end of their Nation Hockey League campaign. Following this skirmish the Blue Shirts will have only nine remaining games and the outcome of these will be of no consequence since Lester Patrick's outfit has been eliminated from the play-offs.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Senator Earle S. Warner, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, issued a call today for a public hearing on March 2 on the three proposals dealing with revision of the system of electing Supreme Court justices proposed by Governor Dewey.

Mayor La Guardia opened some of the New York City watershed lakes and reservoirs to boat fishing in Westchester and Putnam Counties yesterday, thereby satisfying the petitions of sportsmen's organizations for such action.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Office of War Information announced tonight that it is in "vital need" of 450 men for "important and urgent missions overseas in view of impending military operations."

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 23 -- What to do about a flock of crows that have established a "beachhead" somewhere in the vicinity of Police Headquarters and are making forays with highhanded glee is worrying the village constabulary, particularly Police Sgt. Michael Denton, who lives at 14 New Street, in the heart of the happy hunting ground of the thieving blackbirds.

John J. McElligott, former Fire Commissioner, spent the greater part of yesterday as a witness fencing with attorneys at the trial of the suit brought by the Uniformed Firemen's Association, which is seeking to prevent Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh from enforcing an emergency order that would abolish the three-platoon system.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 23 -- Adolf Hitler, in a visit to the north Russian front, ordered a number of high officers shot in his rage at his reverses, and General Lindemann, commanding German troops in the Leningrad area, has committed suicide as a result, usually reliable sources said tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 -- Alice Faye, who is due to report back to Twentieth Century-Fox in April, will have the role of Aunt Sissy in "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," according to a studio announcement. This will be the actress' first non-musical dramatic screen part and will precede her co-starring appearance with Betty Grable in the musical "The Dancing Dollys."

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Chairman F.H. Bontecou of the Senate Excise Committee today reported out a bill designed to clear up obstacles in the way of whisky dividends such as that recently adopted by the American Distilling Company. The measure was introduced last week, reportedly at the request of the State Liquor Authority.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The seventy-ton Mars, giant plane now in service for the Navy, will be dwarfed by its twenty successors now under construction for the Naval Air Transport Service, the Navy stated today.
LONDON, Feb. 23 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

In this newspaper yesterday a dispatch from Washington, England, described the celebration there of the 212th anniversary of the birthday of George Washington. We all know, or are supposed to know, from the books that this little village of County Durham came into the possession of Sir William de Hertburn late in the twelfth century.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The juncture of United States Marines from the north coast and Sixth United States Army troops from the south culminated a campaign that began on New Britain Dec. 15, when the Army landed at Arawe Peninsula and the Marines came ashore at Cape Gloucester on Dec. 26.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The return of King Peter from Cairo, Egypt, to London and an announcement of Yugoslav war unity with Marshal Tito as the dominant military figure were widely predicted today in Britain.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 23 -- High praise for the manner in which American correspondents have been covering the war was voiced by Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla in a speech published today.

Samuel Streicher, principal of Seward Park High School in Manhattan, was named a member of the Board of Examiners yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Education. Mr. Streicher will fill the vacancy left by the death of Dr. Louis Marks in March, 1943.
CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Don Hutson, now on the Green Bay Packers' coaching staff, can look back on 1943 as the most unusual season in his record-crusted football career.

Renewed hedge selling, combined with March liquidation in advance of the first delivery notice day, which is today, caused cotton futures to surrender most of their early gains yesterday and close at the session's lowest prices. At the end of trading, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were mixed, and down 5 to up 4 points, with the gains in the December and January deliveries of the new contract.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23 -- In the first Federal seizure of a municipally owned utility in this war the Army took control of the Los Angeles Water and Power System today to end a strike which had tied up operations of 159 war plants and prevented repair of storm damage that had left tens of thousands of homes in darkness.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The Luftwaffe's Fighter Command, upon which the Nazis depend for primary defense, is sustaining losses so shattering that its potential strength in counter-invasion activities has been seriously weakened.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 (AP) -- R.W. Brown, president of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, announced today that the company will pay on May 1 two deferred coupons on its general consolidated 4, 4 1/2 and 5 per cent mortgage bonds.

The crews of the British midget submarines that sneaked into Alten Fjord, Norway, last September and fired torpedoes into the German battleship Tirpitz put in nearly two years of rigorous training before starting out on their assignment.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- From the moment President Roosevelt turned from economy to the make-work spending policy in 1933, the history of his tax legislation has been stormy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The reaction in diplomatic quarters here today to Prime Minister Churchill's speech in London yesterday was that it was a most important utterance that indicated the wind of British and perhaps of Ango-American foreign policy was blowing in two directions at once.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Spurred by the nation-wide attention surrounding last week's by-election in West Derbyshire, American soldiers stationed in East Anglia are taking a lively interest in a similar contest at Bury St. Edmunds -- to such an extent that as they scoot about the countryside in their jeeps they wave impartial, but hearty, greetings to all candidates when they see them.

ALGIERS, Feb. 23 -- Penicillin has been proved superior to other agents in the treatment of certain bacterial infections, but precise dosage is still impossible to prescribe and it is premature to assess the drug's usefulness in cases of gas gangrene, it was reported to the Allied Medical Congress today in a paper read by Col. Perrin H. Long of Baltimore for Major Champ Lyons of Oxbow, Me.

Today's events: "Le Nozze di Figaro," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 o'clock: "Carmen," New York City Center, 8:15; concert by Philharmonic- Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall@ 8:45; recital by Joseph Bell, baritone, Steinway Hall, $:30; recital, Ralph Kirkpatrick, harpsichord, Frick CollecUon, 3; recital, Marcel Grandjany, harp; concert, Nora Fauchald, soprano, and Josef and Rosina Lhevinne, piano, J,,illtard School, 4:30.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 23 -- Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Brazilian Foreign Minister, in an interview published today in the Sao Paulo newspaper Folha da Manha, stated that Brazil and Russia had much to gain economically in mutual trade and that "even though Russia's political ideology differs from that of Brazil, that does not mean that Brazil and Russia cannot re-establish at least economic relations."

ALGIERS, Feb. 28 -- It is understood that the French Committee of National Liberation will soon submit to the Provisional Consultative Assembly a plan involving the complete abolition of that portion of the Continental French press that collaborated with Vichy after the Allies' landing in French North Africa, pending the creation of new newspapers and the revival of those suppressed by Vichy and those that voluntarily ceased publication rather than collaborate.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended Tuesday were 525, compared with 1,133 in the preceding week and 687 in the like period of last year, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. No arrivals were reported Tuesday, whereas 438 registered the same day of last week.

Attorney General Francis Biddle advocated last night Government assistance for American producers to help them gain access to foreign markets. He declared that the close of the war would show "a striking contrast between the free enterprise system we value and a cartelized Europe."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Roosevelt, in a message to Premier Joseph Stalin today on the occasion of Red Army Day, declared the Russian forces' "magnificent achievements," "together with the collaboration and cooperation which was agreed upon at Moscow and Teheran, assure our final victory over the Nazi aggressors."

ALGIERS, Feb. 23 -- That the days are over when Hitler's inner fortress may expect no air attacks if bombers from Britain do not operate was further emphasized today when large formations of Mediterranean Air Forces Liberators delivered smashing blows on two Nazi aircraft plants at Steyr, Austria, ninety miles west of Vienna.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 23 -- Today's surface moves in the Russian-Finnish peace game took Dr. Juhok Paasikivi and Eero Vuori back to Helsinki, Finland, from Stockholm, presumably to report on Moscow's attitude to the Finnish proposals, including possibly a rough indication of what Moscow's armistice or peace terms might be.

The cotton goods consuming trades, with the exception of the makers of men's, boys' and women's work clothing, reacted favorably to revisions made in the War Production Board's cotton goods conservation order, M-317, issued over the holiday.

Mrs. Edna Hancock, a former employe, of Brooklyn State Hospital, who has been held in the Women's House of Detention because she was unable to raise $25,000 bail following her indictment on a charge of first-degree perjury, was released yesterday in $1,000 bail following a request from her attorneys to Kings County Judge Franklin Taylor.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The mystery of the bombs that dropped on Stockholm last night officially remained unsolved tonight after the Soviet communique announced that no Russian planes had been in the vicinity of the Swedish capital.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Leo Durocher took note today of Branch Rickey's suggestion that he get in shape to return to the Dodger line-up if baseball player shortages make it necessary, and decided that the Brooklyn front-office man had been talking about some other guy.

Despite assurances of the Foreign Economic Administration in its recent Current Controls Bulletin No. 148 that efforts will be made to facilitate shipments, textile exporters indicated yesterday that they were unimpressed by the statement, and in some quarters it was asserted the position apparently indicates a lack of "coordination" between the FEA and other Government agencies concerned with foreign trade.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The twenty-sixth anniversary of the Red Army was observed here today and cordial messages were sent by Prime Minister Churchill to Premier Joseph Stalin and by the British Chiefs of Staff to Marshal Klementy E. Voroshiloff, chairman of the Soviet Defense Council.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 23 -- Allied air attacks on the Berlin area have caused such complete disruption of railroad lines that through expresses no longer run from the capital but from "a secondary station" about thirty miles away, according to a neutral diplomat just returned from Berlin after a forty-eight-hour train journey today.

Small investors of the city, State and nation are continuing to buy Series E bonds in heartening numbers as the time for the final closing of the books on the Fourth War Loan approaches, it was disclosed yesterday as officials of the Treasury announced in Washington that the over-all goal of $14, 000,000,000 has been oversubscribed by $1,884,000,000.

WHEN the boys gather around the cracker barrel for a session in the Hot Stove League and begin picking the greatest baseball players of all time they cannot help but encounter one argument after another. Who was the best outfielder? Was it Ruth or Cobb or Speaker? Was Gehrig a better first baseman than Sisler or did Chase top them both? And so it goes for every position on the field.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 23 -- The action of Governor Dewey of New York in asking that a slate of candidates for delegates to the Republican convention, bearing his name, be withdrawn, caused confusion and surprise in the preliminaries for Wisconsin's primaries April 4.
The abrupt removal of the two highest commanders in the Japanese land and sea forces reveals deep differences of opinion hitherto concealed and a sudden new decision.

Realty owners and managers held a meeting yesterday at the offices of the Real Estate Board of New York to plan opposition to the Steingut bill in Albany, designed to limit commercial rents to 15 above the level of March 1, 1943.

An international office of education should be set up under the peace treaty with powers to supervise the school programs of the Axis countries, Dr. Alexander J. Stoddard, Superintendent of Schools of Philadelphia, declared yesterday at the regional conference of the American Association of School Administrators, a branch of the National Education Association.

It is refreshing to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 18 that Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, is urging the "schools to be more tough." A real educational commando has arisen among us, and it is about time.

An unprecedented defense move yesterday delayed Wayne T. Lonergan's trial in General Sessions Court for the murder of his wife, Patricia.

Quick and decisive reaction by the stock market followed yesterday the revolt within the Administration forces in Washington over President Roosevelt's tax veto message. In one of the swiftest scrambles to buy stocks in recent months, prices were bid up quickly in a broad movement during the last half hour of trading as the strength reserved earlier almost exclusively for the rails, aircrafts and sugars spread to the industrial section.

Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker called on the educators of the United States last night to combat the proposal to lower the draft age to 17 and condemned employers who "in their selfish desire to obtain workers" had hired young men and women away from desks in high schools.

ANZIO BEACHHEAD, Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- A "lost battalion" of Americans fought its way back to the beachhead lines today and told of having been surrounded for a week while the Germans tried in vain to wipe them out with infantry, tanks and dive-bombers.

FROM 1781 to 1944 the Russians have practically never had a government that would meet with the full approval of a majority of American citizens. Czars have been followed by commissars, pogroms have given way to purges. Yet throughout a century and a half the American and the Russian people have never had a serious quarrel, have never gone to war against each other, and have usually taken the same line in foreign affairs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- By a voice vote the Senate adopted today the Bankhead resolution extending the life of the Commodity Credit Corporation through June 30, 1945. The action gives a new lease of life to the Administration's food subsidy program, which officially expired last Thursday through the President's veto of the prior measure, because it curtailed subsidies.

The Republic Steel Corporation, in its annual report for 1943 issued to stockholders yesterday, disclosed a consolidated net income of $12,011,057, equal to $1.77 a share on the common stock. The consolidated net income for 1942 amounted to $17,154,578, or $2.67 a share.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Senator Barkley's resignation from the majority leadership of the Senate was viewed here as marking the break in a record of cooperation between the White House and titular Senate leadership which had seldom been surpassed or was never more conspicuous than during Mr. Barkley's tenure.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 24 -- Soviet troops of the north, pushing the Germans back as much as sixteen miles, yesterday smashed into the streets of Dno, last major Nazi stronghold on the westward road to Pskov, and captured more than 180 towns and settlements along a front moving steadily toward Latvia and southern Estonia.

Predicting that this will be "the bloodiest year of the war for our Navy and other armed forces," Rear Admiral Monroe Kelly, commandant of the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, urged yesterday that ship workers at the yard "hit that production line, and hit it hard."

A new course, designed to prepare citizens for community leadership, will open tonight at 7:30 o'clock at the Washington Irving High School, 40 Irving Place, under the endorsement of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

City Island, outlying area of the Bronx at the point where Long Island Sound meets the East River, went on a temporary war footing yesterday afternoon, to the annoyance of its regular inhabitants and several hundred shipyard workers, because of two seamen who did not want to go to the Navy disciplinary barracks on Harts Island.

In his order of the day congratulating the Red Army on its twenty-sixth anniversary Premier Stalin paid a richly deserved tribute to Russian heroism which has liberated all but a fraction of Soviet territory invaded by the most formidable war machine the world has seen. In that tribute all the world that values freedom joins.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Roosevelt authorized the Secretary of War today to take over and operate the Los Angeles municipally owned water and power system, where a strike has left more than 150 war plants and thousands of homes and businesses without electricity.

The collection of Mme. Lyne, a French designer, shown yesterday afternoon by Chez Ninon, 785 Fifth Avenue, adapted the subtle taste of the Rue de la Paix to New York's needs. Line and color held the stellar roles. Woolen suits were executed with skill.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 24 -- Flying high, fast and singly, an unannounced number of German bombers made a short but sharp attack on London last night -- the fifth in the past four nights and the twelfth this month.

Last year saw a sharp reduction in the losses incurred in marine underwriting, William D. Winter, president of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, declared yesterday in the company's 102d annual report to policy holders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted authority to the Great Northern Railway Company to issue at par a promissory note of $1,501,438 in evidence of the purchase price of three Diesel freight locomotives at a price of $500,479 each, to be purchased from the General Motors Corporation.

The tone even more than the fact of Mr. Roosevelt's veto of the tax bill has precipitated a crisis in the relations between the President and Congress. It has led to the resignation of Senator Alben W. Barkley, who, in his own words, has "carried the flag of the Administration" for the past seven years as majority leader of the Senate.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 23 -- Both of the two greatest Buenos Aires democratic dailies, the Nacion and the Prensa, printed courageous editorials today protesting against the decree of last Dec. 31, which dealt a death-blow to freedom of the press in Argentina.

A city-wide drive to enlist one volunteer price warden for every ten retail food stores was started yesterday by the Office of Price Administration. According to the City Department of Markets, there were 48,000 food stores in 1939, which would set the OPA's goal at 4,800 housewives needed to help retailers abide by price control rulings.

An exhibition of water-colors by members of the California Water-Color Society is to open at the Riverside Museum on Sunday and will remain until April 9. This is the second local exhibition of the society, the first having been held in March, 1940, at which time the Metropolitan Museum purchased several pictures.

Harry H. Woodring, former Secretary of War and Governor of Kansas who is now heading a Democratic movement to block President Roosevelt's renomination, issued the following statement with respect to Senator Barkley's resignation as majority leader:

NAPLES, Feb. 20 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Despite bombs, shells, mines and torpedoes, the crews of American and British landing craft have worked day and night off Anzio since the Jan. 22 landings in one of the most heroic jobs of the war, naval men just back from the beachhead reported today.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 23 -- Backed up by American and British fighters and bombers, Allied troops have forced the Japanese to retreat in northern Burma and on the Arakan front to the west in offensives of the past few days.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Arthur Rank, British film czar, became a hero in a Parliamentary debate on the motion-picture industry today, being pictured as a sort of Saint George challenging Hollywood's dragon.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Battle losses of American bombers based in Britain stand at 3.1 per cent and fighters .7 of 1 per cent since the United States began air attacks on Germany in August, 1942, the Eighth Air Force, now commanded by Maj. Gen. James H. Doolittle, announced today.

ALGIERS, Feb. 23 -- The six-division battering-ram of the German Fourteenth Army was undergoing "repairs" yesterday and the relative lull on the beachhead below Rome continued. But the enemy's forward troops maintained their pressure and German planes and long-range artillery continued to bomb and shell Cape Anzio.

Mrs. John E. Messervey, Republican National Committeeman for South Carolina, has been added to the panel of speakers who will discuss "Woman as a Citizen" at a meeting tomorrow evening in The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 23 -- Allied planes torpedoed a 5,000-ton merchantman and a destroyer in an enemy convoy off Crete yesterday and shot down three German planes protecting the ships.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Nazi organizations, including the Gestapo, are active in American prison camps and already have executed five nonconformist fellow prisoners and threaten post-war democracy in Germany, a former member of the German Reichstag said today.

The Charles F. Rand Memorial Medal for distinguished achievement in mining administration was presented last night at the annual dinner and honors night of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, to Cornelius F. Kelley, chairman of the board of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and an associate in more than thirty companies.

In a written reply to a request for comment on Senator Barkley's resignation as majority leader of the Senate and his attack on President Roosevelt's veto of the tax bill, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday at the City Hall:
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Sweden will protest to Moscow tomorrow in regard to the bombs dropped on Stockholm last night, the Foreign Office said tonight.

Carl Carmer, American poet and novelist, will speak on "The Legends of America" on Sunday afternoon in the Brooklyn Academy of Music, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Feb. 24 -- United States Marines from Cape Gloucester and American soldiers from Arawe have joined forces after having killed 7,000 Japanese of the Sixty-fifth Brigade and the Seventeenth Japanese Division, both of which played a major part in overwhelming the American troops on Bataan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The House rejected today by a vote of 82 to 76 a bill under which past expressions of disloyalty by interned Japanese-Americans would, in effect, be considered a renunciation of citizenship.

NAPLES, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Premier Pietro Badoglio's Government said today that about thirty women, children and old people had been slain by German patrol troops on Monday at the village of Sant' Agata, a few miles north of the German lines on the British Eighth Army's front.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Output of equipment for war, particularly of combat aircraft and landing barges, showed a substantial increase for January, Chairman Donald M. Nelson of the War Production Board reported today.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 23 -- Edward T. Newell, who owned a country home at Halesite and who died Feb. 18, 1941, left a collection of rare old Greek and Roman coins, appraised at $114,710, papers on file in the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court revealed today.

An eight-point program designed to ease the transition from war to peacetime operation to meet future competition from hard goods lines, and retain for sound trade development stabilizing lessons learned during the emergency period was presented last night by Samuel L. Deitsch, president of the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, at the annual meeting of the association at the Hotel Astor.

The amazing success, at relatively small cost, of our Marshall Island operations has been due to thorough logistical planning, the concentration of overwhelming force against the enemy and a combination of strategical boldness and carefully prepared and coordinated tactics.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 23 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, the confident, silent Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet and Pacific Ocean area -- the largest area ever commanded by an American officer -- has never predicted how long the Pacific war will last, and it may be a long time before he does indulge in prognostication, although by now he is in a position to do so with accuracy.

FOURTEENTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, China, Feb. 22 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault said today that the Allies could accomplish the same destruction in Japan that was being achieved in Germany with only one-tenth of the air force used against Germany.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 23 -- American Central Pacific forces plunged hundreds of miles closer toward Tokyo yesterday to rain death and destruction on strong enemy bases in the Saipan and Tinian islands of the lower Marianas.

Carl Friedberg, pianist, and the Both Quartet were the participants in the concert given last night in Town Hall as the sixth event in this season's Town Hall Endowment Series. Mr. Friedberg was heard as soloist in Schumann's "Kinderscenen" and the "Ballade" in G minor of Chopin.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Weakness in rye and a further easing in Premiums on cash wheat in Minneapolis where spring grain is quoted now at 1 cent or more under the permissible maximum except on 12 per cent and under protein, led today to fairly general selling of futures on the Board of Trade.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Eastman, Dillon Co. will offer today $3,500,000 of Food Fair Stores, Inc., fifteen-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures, due in 1959, at 102 and accrued interest. Proceeds from the sale of the issue will be applied to the redemption of $3,150,000 of outstanding notes, with the remainder going into working capital.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The Anglo-American Corporation of South Africa, in addition to a 30 per cent dividend, announced today that it would pay a bonus of 10 per cent, making a total payment for 1943 of 40 per cent. The dividend for 1942 was the same, but there was no bonus.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 23 (AP) -- A soldier vote bill, which its legislative sponsor described as "much more liberal than that of any other State," was signed today by Gov. Walter E. Edge.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- War Production Board officials are at work on a plan for "X" day, when fighting in Europe ceases and the country can begin to slow down on its output of war materials.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans, fighting inside the Italian frontier along the Soca Valley, have "completely destroyed" a German-Italian armored column, killing "scores" of the enemy, a communique from the headquarters of Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] reported today.

Daily and Sunday newspaper advertising in support of Government-endorsed war theme campaigns involved an expenditure of $4,617,600 during December and $25,843,776 for the last five months of 1943, the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday in releasing the third of its new series of analyses compiled by the Advertising Checking Bureau, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP) -- Pacific Fleet communiqu 40:

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 -- All the gasoline coupon books seized here last week from Russell S. Youmans, representing 3,274,646 gallons of gasoline, have been proved counterfeit and a check of dealers' ration banking accounts shows that hundreds of other C-2 coupons, already exchanged for gasoline through dealers, are also counterfeit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The resignation of Thomas K. Finletter, New York lawyer, as special assistant to Secretary Hull was made public today. It was tendered on Feb. 15, and accepted yesterday with regret by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., acting Secretary of State, to be effective on March 9.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Distribution of copies of War Ration Book Four now totals 128,760,419, the Office of Price Administration stated today in making public a tabulation showing the number of books issued in each county throughout the country.

While slight improvement in plastics production is expected by the middle of the year, the supply situation will remain critical throughout 1944, leaving little hope for enlarged civilian allocations, according to Clinton Rector, chief of the plastics section of the War Production Board.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A Middle East air communiqu:

Three author of current best sellers, all of them newcomers in the literary world, discussed last night at a meeting in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, some of the problems that are encountered in writing a first novel and explained the solutions they had employed.

James A. Burke, Borough President of Queens, was accused yesterday by Edwin A. Salmon, city fuel administrator, of having "interfered to a great extent" with the program set up for meeting the city's emergency coal needs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- On the verge of an agreement that they could not agree, conferees on the soldier vote issue decided today to try again Friday as a result of several new proposals for compromise on the differing Senate and House versions being offered.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Governor Dewey withdrew today from the Wisconsin Presidential primary election of April 4, in which his strength as a prospective Presidential nominee would have been tested against the declared candidacy of Wendell L. Willkie.

Captain John E. Ellison, master of the steamship Domino, operated by the American Sugar Refining Company for the War Shipping Administration, received the Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal yesterday for the sinking of a submarine surfaced off the coast of Cuba in June, 1942.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The British Government reserves the right to intervene in the settlement of political affairs in any part of Europe, but the object of its foreign policy is to maintain peace and the rights of small nations with the aid of the British Commonwealth, the United States and Russia, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today.
Sir William and Lady Garthwaite have left the Plaza for Palm Beach.

When the Russians stormed into Krivoi Rog all that was left of the German defense in the Dnieper bend collapsed completely. The Nazi army is apparently in full retreat to the Bug River, the only line in that level steppe-land where it can hope to make a stand.
Following are excerpts from newspaper comments on the Barkley address in the Senate, as gathered by The Associated Press:

Nathan Straus, president of WMCA, announced yesterday that his station would sell time for the discussion of controversial issues providing both sides of a disputed question were presented commercially. The new policy represents a departure from "the code of ethics" of the National Association of Broadcasters, which bars the sale of time for such discussions and calls for their presentation on a sustaining basis.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Assemblyman Robert S. Molinari and Senator Robert S. Bainbridge, New York City Republicans, introduced today a measure to mandate the establishment of child care centers by the State War Council, and appropriate $5,000,000 for the purpose.

You are not the only one, Mr. Churchill, who has that worry; and it applies not only to high strategy and international policy but also to butter and potatoes. Mr. Churchill said that in making public speeches in these critical times he must try to find the "narrow line between reproof of complacency at home and encouragement of the enemy abroad."
An association with the Yankees, going back to the days of the late Miller Huggins as manager, will be suspended at least this season.
LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Force in Europe communiqu:

The interest in the custom hat collection presented yesterday by Hattie Carnegie was not in new silhouettes but in original interpretations of basic hat styles. All the popular hat fashions were present -- sailors, pillboxes, bonnets, and berets -- but in different guises.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley, the majority leader, broke with President Roosevelt today over the tax bill veto message and denounced it in a forty-five-minute speech, in which he said that he would resign as leader tomorrow morning at a Democratic conference which he had called for that purpose.

The recently announced agreement between the United States Government and the American oil companies operating in the Near East for the construction of a pipe line across Arabia has drawn attention to the imperative need for a comprehensive solution of the oil-supply problem, but it has left unanswered several basic questions regarding the future national oil policy, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York asserted in the current issue of The Guaranty Survey.

The Japanese-controlled Manila radio reported yesterday that "a state of national emergency has been declared in the Philippines" following the assumption of new dictatorial powers by Jose P. Laurel, puppet President.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A pattern which may mold the policy for war industries seeking a return to limited production of civilian goods before a final program of reconversion is established was disclosed today by the War Production Board in an announcement said to mark another step toward the manufacture of 2,000,000 electric flatirons for civilian use.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A sharp curtailment of commuter train service in New Jersey areas was ordered by the Office of Defense Transportation today as it sought to free facilities and manpower of the Central Railroad of New Jersey for the record movement of war freight.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Allied troops mopping up Japanese forces in the Ngakyedauk Pass in Burma have all but cleared the pass of the enemy after repulsing one attack at the eastern exit yesterday, a communique said today.

SEAT OF THE ITALIAN GOVERNMENT, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- Premier Pietro Badoglio expressed hope today that Italy would soon be accepted as a full ally and would be permitted to send diplomatic representations to the Allies capitals. At the same time he intimated strongly that he and King Victor Emmanuel proposed to remain in leadership until after the war.

A 2-year-old Scottish terrier, apparently hit by an automobile, went berserk at 9 A.M. yesterday outside the Concourse Plaza Hotel, 161st Street and the Grand Concourse, the Bronx, and bit four women and six young girls about the legs and ankles. Health Department officials warned that the dog might have rabies and appealed to those bitten to report to its nearest office for treatment.

A commendable record of wartime service by the Boy Scouts of Greater New York was made known yesterday in the 1943 annual report of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, which was released at the annual meeting of the councils at the Yale Club.

NOT so very long ago in this space mention was made of the extraordinary Giant-Red night game in which Bucky Walters, leading 4 to 1, was one strike away from victory against four successive hitters in the ninth inning and lost, 5 to 4. Comments on that fray have arrived from an Orleans (Vt.) school superintendent, Charles G. Hapgood, and from a California Seabee, Robert F.X. Meyer.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 24 -- While newspapers throughout the country have carried word of the present wastepaper salvage campaign into a majority of American homes, a tremendous job still remains to be done.

Effective advertising and merchandising are essential to success of the motion-picture industry and exhibitors must institutionalize their theatres and make advertising refreshing, Maurice A. Bergman, eastern advertising director of Universal Pictures, said yesterday before a luncheon meeting of the Associated Motion Picture Advertisers at the Hotel Edison.

In accordance with a recent finding by the Massachusetts Supreme Court that declarations of dividends by a company are mandatory when the dividends are deemed to have been earned and when their payment will not impair the contributed capital of the company, directors of the Waltham Watch Company are expected within the next two months to order dividends on the 6 per cent preferred and class A common stocks.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 24 -- International Pictures has signed Loretta Young to an exclusive term contract and has named her for the co-starring lead in "Home Is the Sailor." The adaptation of the Eric Hatch novel will be produced this summer by David Lewis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, directed his staff today to prepare a memorandum on a proposal that a system of dismissal pay and high postwar priorities be used as incentives to war workers to stick to their jobs as long as they are needed.

The people of Great Britain are a greater people today than they were in 1939, with the war sharpening their finer qualities, Malcolm MacDonald, British High Commissioner to Canada, declared here yesterday.

A proposal from American educators for the training of 1,500 student-specialists from the occupied lands of Europe and Asia has been placed before the State Department. The educators point to the devastation of the cultural centers of European nations and a large part of China.
LONDON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- An Air and Home Security Ministries communique:
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

To take care of growing needs and possible post-war growth, Mary Lewis, Inc., of which Mary Lewis is president and Martin Hession treasurer, has leased the six-story building at 746 Fifth Avenue, between Fifty-seventh and Fifty-eighth Streets, now occupied by Grande Maison de Blanc.

Joe Baksi will get his chance to perform on boxing's "big time" tonight. The Kulpmont (Pa.) heavy- weight, who has been campaigning regularly in rings all over the country for the past three years, will appear in the main bout at Madison Square Garden where he will clash with Tami Mauriello of the Bronx over the ten-round route.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The unceasing drive of Allied air power against the Germans in recent days has accomplished the dual purpose of striking against the Nazi fighter planes and at the sources of future fighter production, Robert P. Patterson, Acting Secretary of War, said today in outlining a weekly review of the war's progress.

A syndicate headed by the Mellon Securities Corporation, Drexel Co., and Harris, Hall Co., Inc., was high bidder yesterday for a new issue of $15,000,000 Los Angeles, Calif., Department of Water and Power electric plant revenue refunding bonds, dated Feb. 1, 1944, and due from Feb. 1, 1945 to 1976.

" Norway Replies" a drama about Norwegian resistance to the Nazis, produced under the aegis of the Royal Norwegian Information Service and written and directed by F. Herrick Herrick, will have its local premiere this morning at the Stanley.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities to have increased $421,878,000 during the week. Note circulation for the entire system showed an increase of $72,467,000.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 24 (UP) -- A provisional permit to the Atlantic City Racing Association to conduct horse racing with pari-mutuel betting at the Atlantic Pines Country Club, was granted by the New Jersey State Racing Commission today.

ARMONK, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- Dr. Charles V. Paterno, New York real estate operator, appeared before the North Castle Town Board tonight and withdrew his application for a rezoning of 200 acres north of here to permit him to establish a $4,000,000 "memorial park" that would provide facilities for baptisms, marriages and burials, a project that has aroused general opposition in the township.

In one of the war's most daring moves a powerful task force of the American fleet has just stabbed some 1,700 miles beyond the outer Japanese defense ring in the Pacific to strike a blow at the principal Japanese air and naval bases in the Mariana Islands. This blow follows on the heels of a similar assault on the Japanese key base of Truk in the Caroline Islands.

The apartment house for twenty-eight families at 2355-57 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, has been sold by the Y.K. Realty Corporation to Luigi Gaudio and Joseph Chiapetta. It is on a plot 45 by 100 feet and is assessed for $50,000. Lewis Steinfeld was the broker. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Charging that the War Labor Board was seeking to coerce it into accepting decisions of the National Labor Relations Board, the Botany Worsted Mills of Passaic, N.J., filed suit today in the United States District Court, seeking to compel the WLB to act on applications for wage increases.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman announced yesterday through his secretary for charities, Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, that the annual appeal of Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, serving 184 welfare agencies, hospitals and other institutions, had been opened this week with the community-wide canvass by the special gifts committee that always precedes general solicitation in all parishes.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 24 -- Shangri-La came out of fiction into a world at war today as nearly 75,000 spectators, many of them workmen who helped build her, roared greeting to the 27,500-ton Essex class aircraft carrier at 10:28 A.M. as she slipped into the narrow Elizabeth River at the Norfolk Navy Yard.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 -- A delegate ticket of fifty persons representing, according to its sponsors, a cross-section of Republicanism and economic interests in California and technically pledged to Governor Earl Warren for President was prepared today for the Presidential preference primary of May 16.

MONTREAL, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Canadiens chalked up their twentieth home game without defeat this National Hockey League season when they beat the Maple Leafs, 3 -- 1, before a capacity house of more than 12,000 tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Valuable military information obtained by German spies in Argentina and Chile and in other American republics has been transmitted to Germany during the past two years by clandestine short-wave transmitters, according to information obtained by the Chilean Government in clearing up Axis espionage agencies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- The War Department is arranging under existing legislation to facilitate the voting by soldiers in eleven State primaries in May, it was announced tonight.

A special meeting of stockholders of Hart, Schaffner Marx has been called for March 17 to consider reclassification of common shares on the basis of two and one-half shares for one. The company expects to file today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the proposed sale of 120,000 of the new shares, with Blyth Co., Inc., as principal underwriters.

Japanese weaknesses undoubtedly contributed to the rapid success, at small cost, of our Kwajalein operation and to the success of our subsequent moves in the Central Pacific. But these factors alone by no means account for the extraordinary nature of these recent victories.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Representatives of twelve national women's organizations joined today in an appeal to President Roosevelt to veto the bill permitting dry skim milk to be labeled "Non-Fat Dry Milk Solids," or "Defatted Milk Solids," on the ground that it threatened the integrity of the Food, Drug and Cosmetics Act of 1938.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The Court of Appeals in ruling today on a motion for reargument of the appeal from the murder conviction hanging over the heads of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Emanuel Weiss and Louis Capone refused to reopen the case, even on the basis of newly discovered evidence which purportedly clears the men.

When we are all living the perfectly adjusted life in the 100 per cent Planned Society, what will prices be like? Well, for one thing, prices may be like the fluctuations in retail clothing prices between mid-December and mid-January as recorded by the Department of Labor.

The buying movement in the stock market that was started on Wednesday by the split in the Administration forces over tax legislation gathered momentum yesterday. With a heavy turnover in low-priced public utility issues the volume on the Stock Exchange was the largest since last Dec. 8, but price increases were moderate except in special cases.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 24 -- The military axiom that land-based aircraft are automatically superior to carrier-based planes has received its final, explicit denial in the thrashing that the United States Navy delivered to the Japanese base on Truk.
LONDON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin radio and recorded by The United Press:

The European war drama may enter its final act this year, but no climax is in sight in the Pacific, Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart Commandant of the Third Naval District, yesterday told 1,160 graduates of the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia University.

Governor Dewey regards himself as pledged not to seek the Republican Presidential nomination, but considers himself free to accept it if the national convention should name him as its candidate. Such is the explanation advanced here yesterday by friends and supporters for his withdrawal from the Wisconsin primary April 4.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 24 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

The Army and Navy need 10,000 more trained nurses by the end of 1944 -- a quota that means "hard work ahead," the New York Nursing Council for War Service was told yesterday at its annual luncheon at the Hotel Delmonico. The figure was given by Dr. Claude W. Munger, director of St. Luke's Hospital and member of the National Committee on Procurement and Assignment of the War Manpower Commission.

Regulations covering collection of waste paper by the Department of Sanitation will be made public today, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday. Earlier in the day all borough superintendents in the department conferred with representatives of the waste paper industry at a meeting called by Commissioner William F. Carey by direction of the Mayor.
IRUN, Spain, Feb. 24 -- American diplomats, newspaper men and relief workers left Germany after thirteen months of internment with this generally expressed opinion:

It is clear from Frederick Graham's dispatch to this newspaper from a heavy-bomber station in Britain that the men who are flying and fighting our aircraft in the round-the-clock onslaught on Nazi Europe are not making the mistake of underrating the enemy.
Mr. and Mrs. Martin von Dehn, who had been staying at the Waldorf-Astoria, have gone to Palm Beach.

STOCKHOLM, Friday, Feb. 25 -- The London correspondent of Dagens Nyheter listed today six Russian armistice demands from unofficial but well-informed non-British sources, who, he said, were very optimistic about Finland's chances of quitting the war.
Three little orphaned sisters started the day yesterday with no home and no relatives but ended it with a half dozen adopted "uncles" doing their best to find them a home.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 24 -- As Admiral Chester W. Nimitz revealed today further carrier plane attacks, these on an atoll in the Marshalls, striking evidence was found that Japanese war industries are unable to match the United States in the quality of their arms.

An export market for American-made popular-price dresses which would help to double the present $250,000,000 annual output was envisioned yesterday for the post-war period at a special meeting of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group at the Hotel McAlpin. Formation of a post-war council for the industry was announced. Louis Rubin, executive chairman of the group, was elected head of the council.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Melvin (Chick) Harbert stole the spotlight from a crack field of professionals today with a four-under-par 68 in a pro-amateur tourney preliminary to tomorrow's $5,000 New Orleans Open.

Wayne Lonergan's trial for wife murder was delayed again in General Sessions Court yesterday -- this time until Monday -- on a second successive motion for adjournment made in absentia by Edward V. Broderick, defense attorney.

WITH GENERAL STILLWELL'S CHINESE FORCES in Hukawng Valley, Feb. 18 (Delayed) -- Headquarters here today released the information that units of two Chinese divisions, the Thirty-eighth and Twenty-second, are fighting the Japanese on this front. Trained by American Army personnel and equipped with American weapons, these two divisions are now rated among the best in the Chinese Army.

Thirty-one concerns, accused by the Office of Price Administration of taking the candy pennies of children without giving them a fair return in goodies, were ordered yesterday to show cause in Federal Court why they should not be restrained from doing business until they comply with Government price regulations.
ALGIERS, Feb. 24 -- The overall lull tended to continue yesterday on all Italian battle fronts, although there was sporadic sharp activity of a limited scope on the beachhead below Rome.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A southwest Pacific communique, relayed from Allied headquarters through the Office of War Information:

Charles I. Stanton, Administrator of Civil Aeronautics, told a joint meeting of the Institute of Radio Engineers and American Institute of Electrical Engineers here last night of the rapidly expanding need for more and better radio communications on the nation's airways. In 1932, he said, radio and communications represented 20 per cent of the total expenses for aircraft maintenance and operation, but that "today they account for 60 per cent of the total."

IRUN, French-Spanish Frontier, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Six hundred and forty-four American repatriates -- including diplomats, newspaper men and relief workers from the United States and Latin America and thirty-seven wounded United States soldiers -- crossed the frontier today from German-held territory on their way to Lisbon and home.
NAPLES, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A communique:

Until recently we had no compelling reason to worry about our oil resources. Now we have. The war has brought us measurably nearer the day, some fifteen or thirty years hence, when we shall have to import much of our oil. The rate at which oil is consumed in this war has so far outstripped the rate of new production that our position is already precarious.
To the manpower shortage on the farm now must be added the horsepower shortage.

An apartment property accommodating 131 families in the Gracie Square section has been purchased by Samuel Knepper, operator. It is the sixteen-story and penthouse building at 430 East Eighty-sixth Street, between First and York Avenues, bought from Hunter L. Delatour, Raymond Reisler and Jerome Thralls, as trustees of the Realty Associates Securities Corporation.

The honorary degree of Doctor of Sacred Theology was conferred at a special interfaith convocation yesterday afternoon by Columbia University upon three distinguished representatives of the Jewish, Catholic and Protestant faiths "in recognition of the growing spirit of cooperation among religious faiths."
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- A German airman who was the only member of his crew to bail out when a bomber was shot down by a nightfighter over England had a hard time surrendering.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 24 -- A trolley car that had caught fire rolled out of control for half a mile down Central Avenue tonight with the motorman trying vainly to stop it and its thirty passengers fighting to get away from the flame and heat.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Congress was asked today by Representative John M. Coffee, Washington Democrat, to go on record as favoring an immediate break with the regime of Gen. Francisco Franco and the granting of support instead to Spanish anti-Fascist forces.

This country will emerge into "the world of tomorrow" after the war with illimitable opportunities for progress and action that will dwarf the achievements of the war period, Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, declared last night at a "World of Tomorrow Dinner" at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria sponsored by the Allied Stores Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order today setting up in the Office of War Mobilization an agency to handle the re-training and re-employment of persons released from the armed forces or civilian war work.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The bond and share markets here were quiet today, but cinema shares again declined. Home rails were steady and gilt-edge issues eased.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' Index of commodity prices in primary markets rose 0.2 per cent during the week ended on Feb. 19. Higher prices for livestock and action of the Office of Price Administration in allowing higher prices for furniture and woodpulp accounted for most of the advance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The House of Representatives voted, 299 to 95, today to pass the $2,300,000,000 tax bill over President Roosevelt's veto. The margin was thirty-seven votes in excess of the two-thirds required to override the White House action.

Those who criticize our Italian campaign, and especially the engagement on the Anzio-Netunno beachheads, have generally noted the failure to bring to bear true "concentration of force." For contrast they point, rightly, to our offensive against the Marshalls and other Pacific islands, where success has been obtained by applying overwhelming strength.
CHESTER, Pa., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Sponsored by the mother of a New Jersey marine killed in action, the oil tanker Esso Portland was launched today at the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company yards.
