These being highly specialized days in track competition, most of those who will go to Madison Square Garden tomorrow night to witness the sixteen-event National A.A.U. championships will be lured by the possibility that Gilbert Dodds of Boston may break the mile record, the clash between Johnny Fulton, Stanford sensation, and Joe Nowicki of Rochester in the 1,000-yard race or the sight of Cornelius Warmerdam soaring over the fifteen-foot bar in the pole vault.

MOSCOW, Feb. 24 -- The Soviet press publishes today the first details of the severe battles that preceded the capture on Tuesday of Krivoi Rog, center of a rich iron-ore mining district, and describes the scenes of devastation left by the retreating Germans, who are estimated to have killed about 17,000 civilians during the two-year occupation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- To help make "practical democrats" of college men in the Army Specialized Training Program, the Army is preparing a new geography text which it expects will be ready for publication in book form by July 1.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Department store sales for the week ended Feb. 19 were 9 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

While some milk concerns may base an appeal to the Office of Price Administration for an increase in retail and wholesale milk prices upon the regional War Labor Board's approval of a wage increase for milk-wagon drivers in the metropolitan area, the industry as a whole has not decided whether to seek permission to increase prices, it was reported yesterday by Edward O. Mather, executive director of the Milk Dealers Association of New York.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- Sammy Adrian Baugh, the Texas calfroper, not only can throw passes -- he can catch them as well.

Women employed in the 341 major war plants in this city in January totaled 134,000, or 27.9 per cent, of the entire working forces of those establishments, Richard C. Brockway, a regional executive of the War Manpower Commission, said last night at a meeting of the New York Chapter of the Society for the Advancement of Management.

Two of three gunmen who, thirteen years ago, participated in the murder of the Rev. Joseph R. Ferraro, a missionary priest, in the attempted hold-up of a steamship ticket office at 191 Sullivan Street were sentenced to State prison yesterday by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions.

A critic, attempting to analyze the charm of the theatrical production "Oklahoma," explains it in terms of the rosy atmosphere that pervades and seems to act as a tonic for war-weary theatre-goers. "Everything about it has a rosy glow," he says, "and even the actresses look 'pink and purty' like the girl in the song."

While all the available detectives of the East Fifty-first Street station and the crew of Emergency Squad 4 searched the area of Second Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street yesterday morning, 6-year-old Richard Naboney, object of the hunt, stalked imaginary bandits up Second Avenue, after spending the night under a hallway radiator next door to his home at 238 East Fifty-eighth Street.

Battling as if the National Hockey League lead were at stake, the New York Rangers held the highly favored Detroit Red Wings to a tie at Madison Square Garden last night. Trailing midway through the final frame, the Blue Shirts came through with a goal that put them at even terms at 3-all and this deadlock remained until the end of play.

A taste of spring skiing, the type of sport that lures thousands of enthusiasts to the higher mountain trails and slopes in late March and April, is currently being enjoyed by those in the North Country. Following the holiday week-end which saw the resorts in the snowbelt playing host to the biggest crowds since pre-war days, the distant ski centers continue to report good snow conditions, while New York City enjoyed summer-like weather.

ABOARD UNITED STATES, FLAGSHIP, Expeditionary Force, Eniwetok Atoll, Marshall Islands, Feb. 23 (Delayed) -- Parry Island, last Japanese stronghold of Eniwetok Atoll, fell to victorious American forces at 7:30 P.M. yesterday, Washington's Birthday, after a battle which added new in luster to American arms.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The uniform contract-termination clause for fixed-price war contracts ordered into use last month on Governmental contracts by James F. Byrnes, Director of the Office of War Mobilization, was amended here today by Mr. Byrnes to specify instances in which the contracting agency may elect not to use the article.

By its vote of 299 to 95 to override the President's veto, the House has made it even more probable than it seemed before that the Senate majority will be great enough to enact the tax bill into law. But whatever the outcome of today's vote, the President's veto, and the manner of it, have already raised a much wider question than the tax issue itself.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- A clique of ultra-nationalistic Argentine Army officers forced President Pedro Ramirez to resign last night and took him prisoner after threatening an armed revolt as the President was about to announce the formation of a liberal government, reports from Buenos Aires said early today.

Those who plan to fish Pennsylvania's streams during the season may be interested in some figures sent out by the State Department of Commerce, indicating that plenty of legal-sized fish will be available.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Prices of wheat had a quick reversal of trend today on the Board of Trade, breaking moderately early on scattered selling and turning strong later in sympathy with rye and on short covering attributed to a large professional trader.
LONDON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Force communique:

According to tabulations made public yesterday by the Citizen's Budget Commission, the 1944-45 budget requests of ninety-four city departments and agencies, directly payable out of local taxes, total $376,991,363, as against $357,310,770 for the same agencies in the 1943-44 budget.
Of four news items emanating from the weekly press conference with President Branch Rickey of the Dodgers yesterday, it is questionable which of two will amaze or intrigue the Flatbush fans most.

On Feb. 29 there will be a special election in the Twenty-first New York District to choose a successor to Representative Gavagan, who resigned to take a seat on the State Supreme Court. The Republicans have nominated William S. Bennet, the Democrats and the American Labor party James H. Torrens.

Despite reports of British trade domination in the Middle East, during the past year or more civilian goods imported into that area have been predominantly of United States origin, Frederick Winant, chairman, Office of Eastern Hemisphere, State Department, declared yesterday at a meeting of foreign traders sponsored by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, at the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Russian troops converging on Pskov captured a village only nineteen miles north of that Baltic gateway, yesterday, Moscow announced, while far to the south a new three-day Red Army offensive shattered the enemy's lower White Russian front by capturing Rogachev.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 24 -- According to reports from Budapest tonight "negotiations" on the German side for Hungarian acceptance of a second group of 500,000 bombed-out persons from Germany have broken down over a question of monetary exchange.

Dr. Louis J. Curtman, Professor of Chemistry at City College, head of the qualitative analysis division of his department, research chemist and author of many articles and books in the field of qualitative analysis, has retired after thirty-seven years of teaching at the college, it was announced yesterday by President Harry N. Wright.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Profits of nearly $7,000,000 have gone to the Army Emergency Relief and $322,100 to British charities from the performances of "This Is the Army," Irving Berlin, creator of the war show, said here today.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- A bid to have Britain take the lead in the development of an economic program to be worked out on an inter-faith basis by Protestants, Catholics and Jews was made here today by Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the Synagogue Council of America.

MOSCOW, Friday, Feb. 25 -- The Soviet High Command announced last night a new Red Army offensive on the White Russian front, where troops swept across the upper Dnieper River, capturing Rogachev, on the road to Bobruisk and Minsk, while the continuing offensive in the north brought the capture of Dno and further tightened the arc around Pskov.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Naples, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Fliers returning from the Fifteenth Air Force attack on the Steyr-Daimler-Puch plant at Steyr today said their bombs left the target ablaze despite strong German fighter opposition.

In a bold step to remove from the rental market the groups of publicly owned war housing left vacant in some parts of the New York region by war production changes or shifting manpower needs, Government housing officials have decided to close thousands of these homes immediately and to open thousands of others to families of service men and honorably discharged veterans, it became known last night.

An increase in the number of applicants for legal aid in matters pertaining to marriage, divorce, custody and adoption was cited in the annual report of the Legal Aid Society, submitted to its members and supporters yesterday at a meeting in the Down Town Association, 60 Pine Street.

Those dreaded casting difficulties having been solved with the signing of Cornelia Otis Skinner, Dennis King, Dudley Digges and Barbara O'Neil, the premiere of "The Searching Wind" was announced yesterday by Herman Shumlin for Tuesday night, April 11.

I have read Mr. Tolischus' article "The Savage Code of Japan" in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Feb. 6 with interest and appreciation. We need to realize the shocking brutality of the enemy and to understand the philosophy which is responsible for a deliberate policy of torture and murder.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Feb. 25 -- A United States destroyer force participating in the Bismarck Archipelago blockade has sunk a Japanese troopship with 400 men, as well as a destroyer, another cargo ship and a number of barges and shelled Kavieng, New Ireland, and Duke of York Island, between New Ireland and New Britain.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 24 -- Considerable doubt is now thrown on the reputed importance of Truk as a strong enemy naval base, as a result of reports from naval fliers who blasted the stronghold last week.

Frank L. Miller, Manhattan attorney, was convicted by a Federal court jury last night on a three-count indictment alleging the interstate transportation and sale of $40,000 in stolen bonds, and conspiracy.

With the Bronx already having achieved 109.1 per cent of its quota for individual investors, officials of the War Finance Committee expressed hope yesterday that Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond would also fulfill their individual goals before the books of the Fourth War Loan are finally closed at midnight Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Council of State Governments said today it was possible that Congress might never reach an agreement on the service-vote question.

With the war now at the "beginning of the end" it behooves us to set up the machinery for carrying into effect those of our war aims about which all are agreed. One of these aims is some form of post-war Anglo-American unity of action in world affairs. But this cooperation, to be successful, must be preceded by the mutual sympathy and understanding that can be firmly founded only on the rock of knowledge.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. will offer today $16,500,000 of the Florida Power Corporation's first-mortgage 3 3/8 per cent bonds, due in 1974, at 104.8257 and accrued interest. Proceeds from this sale and from the private sale of $4,000,000 of serial debentures will be applied with other funds of the company to the redemption of its entire outstanding funded debt.

A city-wide plan to combat juvenile delinquency has already resulted in the formation of Citizens Coordinating Councils in eighty-one patrol precincts of the Police Department, it was learned yesterday.

A first-degree murder indictment was handed up yesterday against 16-year-old Paul Bauer of 575 West 172d Street and Philip Kramer, 20, of 1464 St. Nicholas Avenue, a merchant seaman, in the attempted hold-up and shooting of Samuel Zalazneck in his candy store at 1587 St. Nicholas Avenue soon after midnight last Jan. 25.

Col. Allison Ind, author of "Bataan: The Judgment Seat." which Macmillan will publish March 14, is now on duty at Southwest Pacific headquarters, having been assigned to Gen. Douglas MacArthur's staff after the Battle of Bataan. His book is his observation of Bataan from the vantage point of an intelligence officer, and an aide to three generals, including the late Gen. H.H. George.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Richard Button, Philadelphia, led the field of seven in the men's novice preliminary contests of the national figure skating championships today.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 25 -- The largest number of planes ever dispatched against Germany pulverized industrial targets in Schweinfurt, Gotha and Steyr, Austria, yesterday when the United States Eighth Air Force based in Britain and the United States Fifteenth Air Force stationed in Italy joined to attack the Reich simultaneously from the west and south.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- The War Department said tonight that dogs trained for service with the armed forces were enlisted for the duration and no appreciable number would be returned to civilian life until the war was won.

James McGurrin, deputy county clerk in charge of the division of jurors, New York County, was re-elected president-general of the American Irish Historical Society last night at a meeting in the Society's headquarters, 991 Fifth Avenue.

The premise that every woman can wear a suit was established conclusively at Oppenheim Collins' show yesterday by the variety of suit styles shown and the variety of figure types considered. The store showed suits for the larger woman as well as for those who wear regular or junior sizes.

Trade price-fixing in the nearby positions, supplemented by increased commission house demand, produced yesterday an improvement in cotton futures. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, active old futures contracts showed gains of 4 to 7 points, while deliveries in the new contract were up 4 to 5 points, except March, which closed nominally at 19 points down.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 24 -- Reports from reliable Balkan sources tonight said that mysterious conversations between a group of "Mikhailovitch leaders" and representatives of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) were nearing an agreement that would lead to the solution of present "regional" differences and the fusion of the Mikhailovitch movement with the Tito group.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 19 were 775,692 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 19,750 cars, or 2.5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 23,673 cars, or 3.1 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 1,272 cars, or 0.2 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky carried out today the decision he announced yesterday when he broke with President Roosevelt over the tax bill veto message, and resigned as Majority Leader of the Senate.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 24 -- Berlin today is a city ringed by SS troops [Elite Guards] and its citizens are under the muzzles of SS guns, a Swedish artisan returning here to live after having been bombed out of his shop in the Reich capital, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Preparations by the Government to make a stockpile of winter clothing for expected use in Europe this fall were disclosed today with the announcement to the clothing trade that the procurement division of the Treasury Department will examine sample lines of distress, obsolete or substandard clothing for women, men, children and infants at its New York City office, 76 Ninth Avenue, on Monday.

A drive to enforce compliance with ceilings on restaurant food and beverage prices, forecast three weeks ago by Daniel P. Woolley of the Office of Price Administration, appeared to have been started yesterday when actions against the operators of seven restaurants were filed in Federal court.

Supplies of dressed poultry are decreasing steadily, according to a reliable spokesman for the trade, who says "things will get worse and worse until June." At that time shipments from the West, most of which ceased in January, are expected to start arriving in the city once again.

A very great impression was produced by Richard Strauss' tone poem, "Thus Spake Zarathustra," as it was interpreted by Artur Rodzinski and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. There were other interesting features of the program, but the flaming music of Strauss was the overwhelming sensation of the evening.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The text of Senator Barkley's letter to President Roosevelt was as follows:

As he completed a series of conferences here with Eastern Democrats who are opposed to a Presidential fourth term, Harry H. Woodring, former Secretary of War, announced yesterday that the group he heads plans to set up organizations in every State and to spend about $1,500,000 in an effort to block President Roosevelt's re-election.

The annual report of the Commercial Credit Company, including its subsidiaries from date of acquisition, disclosed yesterday a net profit of $6,357,341 for last year, subject to renegotiation, equal to $3.17 a share of common stock. In 1942 the company had a net profit of $7,068,420, or $3.55 a common share.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 24 -- J. Owen Grundy, a former employe in the Hudson County Bureau of Elections, received today a suspended sentence of one and a half to three years in State prison on a charge of fraudulently altering voting records and was placed on probation for three years.

ONE of the chief delights of fiction is the opportunity it offers for vicarious experience that will widen our horizons, broaden our sympathies and even add a mite to our little store of wisdom about our fellow human beings. Not least among such assets is the occasional opportunity to be found among novels to see and feel the world and all the creatures in it through the eyes of the other sex.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY in Italy, Feb. 24 -- The effects of the manpower shortage on the German Army have been evidenced in the last few weeks in changes in organization, although it must be admitted that they do not appear to have reduced its firing power to any substantial degree.

Study of the Baruch report's proposals covering surplus property disposition by a committee representing every segment of the automotive industry and forceful presentation of the industry's position on methods to be followed in such dispositions was urged yesterday by A.H. Eichholz, general manager of the Motor Equipment Manufacturers' Association in an address before the Overseas Automotive Club at the Hotel Woodstock.

The nation's production of petroleum last week averaged 4,384,500 barrels daily, a decrease of 14,650 from the 4,399,150 daily average in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 34,300 barrels less than the rate of 4,418,800 daily recommended for February by the Petroleum Administration for War.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The House of Representatives passed by voice vote today and sent to the White House the Senate resolution resuscitating the Commodity Credit Corporation and extending it to June 30, 1945. The legislation incorporated the Taft-La-Follette and Butler-Byrd amendments attached to it yesterday in its passage through the upper house.

Edward V. Loughlin, new leader of Tammany, disclosed yesterday that he has requested the resignations of Representative James H. Fay and Charles W. Culkin as chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of the New York County Democratic Executive Committee as a preliminary to a reorganization of that body.

Fruit trees for the small garden with apples, nectarines, quince, apricots, pears, peaches, plums and cherries as the varieties chosen for discussion, formed the topic of an address made last night in New York Times Hall by Arthur W. King of Mount Kisco.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Bethlehem-Fairfield Shipyard, Inc., celebrated the construction of its 300th Liberty ship today with the launching of three more vessels of that type.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Bronze Star, newest decoration for action against the enemy, was introduced to the public today, along with the specification that the only place it cannot be won in an airplane.

The owner of a newly opened cafeteria in Union Square was disclosed yesterday to have signed contracts with two unions covering his cashiers and to have hired an extra cashier, who is paid but does no work, in order to keep a picket line away from his establishment.

A Staten Island meat wholesaler, found guilty of black-market sales yesterday by Magistrate Raphel P. Koenig, was fined a total of $3,300, with the alternative of 660 days in jail. He was sentenced also to serve forty-five days, without alternative, after the court had rebuked him for having failed to cooperate with the Sheriff's investigation into the black market in meat. He paid the fins.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sunday, Feb. 6, 1944, appeared an article entitled "Stateless Worry Allies' Officials." It is stated there that a minimum of 1,000,000 refugees without passport and nationality are to be cared for after the conclusion of this war. Some of them are White Russians, some Armenians, some Spaniards; the majority, however, are central European Jews.

The American Locomotive Company announced yesterday a 25-cent dividend on the common stock for payment on April 1. The previous payment, 50 cents on Dec. 28, 1943, was the first dividend received by common stockholders since 1931.
The twelve-family apartment house at 172 Bay Twenty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Arthur A. Nelson to a client of the Bulkley Horton Company, brokers. It is assessed for $34,000.

Bizet's "Carmen" was presented last night at the City Center as the third offering of the City Center Opera Company. The work had been carefully prepared, reflecting credit on all concerned with the production, and the performance moved with admirable smoothness.

ALGIERS, Feb. 24 -- The plan adopted by the French Committee of National Liberation for the future Government of France is a compromise between the Consultative Assembly's contention that the genuine elections must await the return of prisoners from Germany and Gen. Charles de Gaulle's desire for quick elections to supply some popular foundation for his power, it was learned today.

BAINBRIDGE, Md., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Reports of the transfer of Lieut. (j.g.) John Siegal, former Columbia and Bears' end, to the United States Naval Academy -- presumably to become end coach of the football team -- were confirmed today by Bainbridge Naval Training Station officials.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Senator Barkley, who was the President's spokesman in the Senate and held the title of majority leader, has been succeeded by Senator Barkley, holding the same title but now the spokesman of the Senate against the President on a current conflict of views.

At the semi-annual Bergdorf Goodman collections of custom-made models, one always may expect to pluck at least one star from its fashion zenith. Yesterday afternoon, at the launching of this specialty house's highlights for spring, 1944, the star was the manner in which Bergdof's designers employed linen, linen-weave rayons and shantungs in striking clothes for all hours.

Calling for a balanced educational structure, Dr. George D. Stoddard, New York State Commissioner of Education, declared yesterday in an address before the closing session of the American Association of School Administrators, a branch of the National Education Association, that youth returning from the battlefields and war plants would demand "forthright statesmanship."

JERUSALEM, Feb. 24 -- Permanent standing committees functioning within Palestine and Egypt, will be formed to carry out the decisions taken at the mutual trade exchange talks held in Jerusalem during the past few days under a resolution adopted at the final session, it was learned today.
WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, Feb. 24 -- President Roosevelt made himself incomunicado today with respect to news correspondents.

Among those reported yesterday as having leased apartments was Saul Schwamm, a member of H.L. Schwamm Co., stock brokers, who took an eight-room suite at 1100 Park Avenue through Julius S. Lowenthal, Inc., and the Payson McL. Merrill Company, Inc., co-brokers.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24 -- The outsider won the Paradise Purse at Hialeah Park today to the consternation of many in the crowd of 8,228 who had assumed that the heavily-played Adroit and Silvestra had the race between them. Since there were only four starters, it didn't seem difficult to pick the winner, especially if one were to take two guesses.

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 24 -- Whether or not President Roosevelt and Senator Barkley patch up their difficulties there is no question in the opinion of many Kentuckians that "the Sage of Padukah" has gained in prestige in his native State by the break.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, largest member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, released yesterday an annual statement for 1943, showing net profit of $4,853,874, against $146,608 in 1942. The firm has fifty-three partners.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Banks "must develop the same sense of sales and merchandising which characterizes the manufacturer of the new soap or the new toothbrush," the president of the Financial Advertisers Association declared tonight.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Seventh Indian Division, cut off three weeks ago by a Japanese break-through, has been relieved, although communications with forces still outside the Japanese ring are insecure, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters said today.

The shares of public utilities provided again yesterday the main medium of trading in the stock market, but the movements throughout the list were narrow and final prices were mixed. The market having had its quick reaction to the political upheaval in Washington and, in almost a single session, having discounted the Congressional disapproval of the White House action on the tax legislation, proceeded to settle down and await developments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- "Amazement" was the word that Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, used when he received the details of our success at Saipan and Tinian in the Marianas and learned that despite the fact that the Japanese had detected our forces approaching the islands, the enemy had been unable to sink a single one of our warships.

Elimination of the adverse Government's attitude toward advertising premiums was reported yesterday at a special luncheon meeting of the Premium Advertising Association of America, Inc., at the 400 Restaurant. The industry, described as having a volume of $500,000,000 annually in normal times, was said to face a favorable post-war outlook.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 25 -- A large majority of women workers who are thinking about the postwar period are going to be in the competition for peace-time jobs, judging by first returns of a poll which the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company's family economics bureau has started in all parts of the country.

Federal Judge Robert A. Inch, in Brooklyn, accepted pleas of guilty yesterday in behalf of the Leibmann Packing Company of Green Bay, Wis., and of Edward Leibmann, president of the company, and Nathan Rosenberg, a stockholder, all charged with having sold meat at prices above the maximum set by the Office of Price Administration.

The answer is "Yes" to Elizabeth C. Vogtlaender's query at the end of her letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, "Didn't they wash their butter in the horse-and-buggy days?" They didn't call it "washing" but "working" the butter; and they didn't do it the way your correspondent says she does.

The New York Stock Exchange has an obligation to discipline members for inequitable conduct, but this responsibility does not make the Exchange liable for damages suffered by investors when those damages are not the result of the Exchange's failure to take such disciplinary action, according to a ruling of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has bought the screen rights to "Bad Bascomb," D.A. Loxley's story of a Western outlaw's regeneration through the influence of a child, as a prospective co-starring vehicle for Wallace Beery and Margaret O'Brien. The studio is also looking for a story with which to co-star the young actress with William Powell.

Two Virginia men, who gave the Brooklyn police a busy morning on Jan. 8, were found guilty yesterday in Kings County Court by a jury before Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz on charges of first-degree robbery. They were John Richard King, 23 years old, and David Keith, 24, of Norfolk.

While the men's and boys' clothing industry undoubtedly will benefit through changes made on Feb. 21 in the War Production Board's cotton goods conservation order M-317, converters who have been digesting the various regulations relating to linings such as pants pocketings, coat pocketings and vest linings said yesterday that they believe most producers are unduly optimistic regarding yardage deliveries expected this year.
LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A United States Army Air Force communique:

In connection with the exhibition, "Stars of Yesterday and Today," to be held at the Wildenstein Galleries for the benefit of the 1944 Red Cross War Fund for Greater New York, Mrs. Edward Larocque Tinker, chairman, announced yesterday that thirty-eight artists will paint portraits of winners of door prizes.

The American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation and its United States subsidiaries made $15,193,801 last year before provision for taxes, or $2,813,658 more than in 1942, on the same basis, according to the annual report issued yesterday. The substantially larger earnings reflect the rise in sales to $124,057,703 from the 1942 volume of $114,648,065.

Tami Mauriello, Bronx contender for the heavyweight title, went into eclipse last night in Madison Square Garden, hammered into defeat by Joe Baksi, husky young Kulpmont, Pa., 210-pounder, in ten rounds of furious fighting witnessed by 16,015 fans. The receipts amounted to $50,434.

Francisco (Pancho) Segura, exponent of the two-handed drive from Guayaquil, Ecuador, is returning to America to play for the Red Cross in the benefit tennis matches at Madison Square Garden the night of March 14.
NAPLES, Feb. 25 (AP) -- An Allied communique:

BIARRITZ, France, Feb. 22 (Delayed) -- The much-touted Atlantic Wall designed to protect Europe from an Allied landing is not impregnable and a landing to establish the Western front is possible, the Germans themselves admit.

Members of the Working Mothers Club, composed of employes of the War Manpower Commission in Washington, have proposed that a new clause be inserted in income tax legislation allowing women who have jobs to deduct a maid's salary as a legitimate business expense.

The Brooklyn Savings Bank has sold the seven-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 97 feet at 839 West End Avenue, southwest corner of 101st Street, to Dr. Irving Rothstein through the Wood, Dolson Company. The house is vacant and contains forty-two apartments.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 25 (UP) -- Mrs. Herbert Hoover, wife of the former President, told her two sons they were "lucky boys to have had such a father" in a letter bequeathing her estate to her immediate family. It was written less than two months before her death in January.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The American Palestine Committee will sponsor a national conference here on March 9 to promote "American Christian" support for the opening of Jewish immigration into Palestine, Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democrat, of New York, who is chairman of the committee, said today.

While the copper supply situation has improved to the point where it is in close balance with demand, no general relaxation of curbs on its use "are anticipated for some time," war agency officials stated yesterday. Recent cutbacks in the small arms ammunition program, it was said, have been largely offset by the increase in the artillery program and other demands.

NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- Count Carlo Sforza, Italian Liberal leader, today bitterly criticized Prime Minister Churchill's "sympathetic'' references to the government of Premier Marshal Pietro Badoglio in his speech to Parliament this week and reiterated his demand that "King Victor Emmanuel must go."

Because it is abundant and the current Victory Food Special, cabbage takes the spotlight in our set of menus for next week. In planning for our model family of two sedentary adults and one school-age child, a total of six pounds of the vegetable is used for five appearances in the following forms--creamed cabbage, cabbage and celery salad, cream of potato and cabbage soup, carrot and green pepper cole slaw and Hungarian hot slaw.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

DETROIT, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Jake La Motta of New York gained his third straight ten-round decision over Ossie (Bulldog) Harris by winning tonight before 10,289 spectators who paid $25,527 at Olympia Stadium. La Motta weighed 161 pounds, Harris 159. There was no knockdown.

MOSCOW, Feb. 25 -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, charged today that the newspaper assistants of William Randolph Hearst "are spilling poisoned ink to wreck the great cause of the anti-Hitler coalition and to preserve the bandit Hitlerite nest in Europe."
STOCKHOLIM, Sweden, Feb. 25 -- As travelers from Holland report, the Germans there, in anticipation of an imminent invasion, have flooded certain coastal areas, particularly the Zuider Zee district.

In keeping with the modernists' fondness for furniture pieces that can perform a double role, one of the outstanding designers of terrace furniture has turned a new trick with a group of sofas, chairs and tables that are equally appropriate for the living room or the outdoor terrace.

In the ever-mounting tempo of the air war in Europe we are beginning to see the application of the "two-pronged pincer" to bombing attack. For a series of days our air forces based in Britain have been abetted by those based in Italy to strike mighty blows at the Nazi Reich from the "soft underbelly" as well as the bristling West.

Trade Here Lower in Week Retail trade, while fairly active this week, failed to meet last year's comparative figures. Estimates indicate that department store volume was running about 5 per cent under the high sales totals of 1943 when scare buying of apparel was still a factor. Active trade today would improve the showing for the week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- "We have by no means reached a level of taxation which can be considered adequate for the remainder of the war period," Secretary Morgenthau said today in his report to Congress for the fiscal year 1942-43.

Whisky Distributions A measure intended to prevent some of the complications attendant upon distributions of whisky inventories among stockholders was the order of the Office of Price, Administration yesterday requiring a thirty-day notice by corporations which wish to transfer or distribute packaged distilled spirits or wine to stockholders or members.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Stephen Early, Presidential Secretary, reported today that President Roosevelt was keeping in closest touch with the White House and that any news from him would be given out here, because while he was away he was "strictly off the record."

Few, if any, contests for delegates to the Republican National Convention are expected in New York State. The list of organization candidates has been completed and all but a few are expected to support Governor Dewey for the Presidential nomination.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 25 -- Gen. Edelmiro Farrell, who is to be designated as "vice president in exercise of the Executive power," took possession of his new post this morning without ceremony. He walked straight to the Presidential office, where he was received by his closest collaborators, and then settled down to his duties as Acting President.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- Freed from German internment centers, 312 Americans, including thirty-seven wounded United States service men, arrived here today aboard three special trains from which they are to be transferred shortly to the waiting Swedish repatriation liner Gripsholm in exchange for German subjects brought from the United States.

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 26 -- Hundreds of heavy bombers of the United States Strategic Air Forces, flying from Britain and Italy, smashed deep into Germany yesterday to hammer six vital factories on which the German aircraft industry depends after two smashing blows at Schweinfurt Thursday night by about 1,000 Lancasters and Halifaxes of the Royal Air Force.

Only when President Roosevelt told it himself, in his telegram to Senator Barkley, did the American people know that Mr. Roosevelt was not in the White House on Wednesday. Even then they did not know where the President might be found at the moment; and conceivably they may not know Mr. Roosevelt's whereabouts at this moment, nearly three days later.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Florida's greatest 3-year-old race, the $15,000 added Flamingo Stakes, will be run at Hialeah Park tomorrow, with fourteen entered and Director J.E. the choice. Even with the 122-pound top impost that also is assigned to Alorter, Mrs. Ella K. Bryson's color-bearer, who is named for Director J. Edgar Hoover of the FBI, seems certain to be a heavy favorite.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. will be one of the two special speakers at the fiftieth anniversary dinner of the Men's Bible Class of Riverside Church, of which he is the honorary president, to be held Tuesday evening in the Hotel Commodore. The other speaker will be Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 25 (AP) -- J.M. Withrow of the War Production Board (WPB) told several hundred cotton textile manufacturers here today that any widespread attempt in the industry to do "business as usual at the expense of the other fellow will require much more stringent regulation of production."

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 25--The United States carrier task force that raided the Mariana Islands bombed Guam, destroyed 135 Japanese planes and sank or damaged eleven enemy ships, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz revealed today.

The opera last night at the, Metropolitan was "Il Trovatore" and the melodic wealth and vitality of the score triumphed in the course of a conscientious if not a brilliant performance. The novel feature of the cast was young Miss Harshaw's Azucena.

ALGIERS, Feb. 25 -- News that Gen. Charles de Gaulle has just given the Resistance Cross with a citation to Mme. Gaby Pierre-Bloch draws attention to the heroic part many Frenchwomen are playing in the continuing battle of France.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Paralleling President Roosevelt's arbitral award in the recent railway wage dispute, the National War Labor Board directed today increases of 7 cents in hourly rates and three-tenths of 1 cent in mileage rates for 40,000 midwestern truck drivers.

Donald Lynch, 30 years old, an ex-convict, who gave the address 2672 Marion Avenue, the Bronx, was remanded to the Tombs without bail for a hearing March 2 in Felony Court yesterday on suspicion of the theft of $1,000 in wine, between Wednesday night and Thursday afternoon, from the liquor store of Louis Hirsch at 2440 Amsterdam Avenue.

Clinchfield Coal Directors of the Clinchfield Coal Corporation decided yesterday not to declare a dividend on the common stock at this time. At the February meeting a year ago common dividend payments were resumed for the first time since 1926 with the declaration of 25 cents a share followed by 25-cent disbursements in May, August and December.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Feb. 26 -- Soviet troops increased their pressure on Pskov from two directions yesterday and the High Command reported further progress in Gen. Konstantin K. Rokossovsky's four-day-old offensive on the White Russian front.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, Feb. 25 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Commander of All Invasion Forces, accompanied by Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur W. Tedder, his deputy commander, and Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, head of the British Armies in the operation, have finished a short but thorough inspection of American and British ground units now engaged in pre-invasion training.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- Bombers of the Southwest Pacific forces have dropped 200 tons of explosives on three main target areas in New Britain and New Guinea and other planes have made new attacks throughout the active zone, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 25 -- Political terrorist activity has been showing a marked recrudescence lately in various parts of Palestine, probably in the mistaken notion that it it would bring about pressure on British authorities to change her present policy drastically in favor of extremist Jewish nationalist demands.

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 26 -- Early this morning no German planes had visited the London area, leading to the belief the enemy had had to interrupt his air offensive that has brought down bombs on the British capital every night during the past week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Declaring that the special House committee investigating the Federal Communications Commission under the chairmanship of Representative Clarence L. Lea, Democrat, of California, had degenerated into a "whitewashing affair" to which they were "unwilling to contribute their support," the legal staff of the committee, headed by Eguene L. Garey of New York, resigned in a body today.

Remington has developed a new device by which the sights on rifles may be adjusted quickly and perfectly without firing the gun. Use of the invention has been offered to the Government to be made available to any other manufacturer of small arms on a royalty-free basis.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- An eight-State black-market liquor ring, involving more than 1,000 operators and five distilleries, was revealed to be in operation along the Eastern seaboard today by authorities of three Federal agencies, who have been conferring here on legal steps to prosecute its leaders.

CASSANDRA never delivered a prophecy as utterly incredible as the one James E. Sullivan offered when John Paul Jones broke the world mile record in 1913. The co-founder of the A.A.U. looked at the watches and saw the time of 4:14.4. Then he spoke, awe in his voice and a visionary gleam in his eye.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Merion, Pa., blasted par by four strokes with 32, 36 -- 68 to lead after the first round of the $5,000 New Orleans golf tournament today.

ALGIERS, Feb. 25 -- The German Fourteenth Army on the beachhead below Rome has been reinforced by the 362d Infantry, brought down from north Italy, it was announced today, and the Nazi forces now total at least ten divisions.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The Polish Government in Exile was reported today to have given Britain a firm refusal to accept the Curzon line as the basis for Polish-Russian frontier negotiations, as proposed by Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Canners of fruits and vegetables were advised today by the Office of Price Administration that maximum prices established for the 1943 fruit and vegetable pack will apply also to fruits and vegetables packed up to the time that a 1944 pricing regulation is issued.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Papers filed today in the United States District Court here state that a stockholder's suit to prevent the Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company from giving 160 key employes options on 300,000 shares of unissued stock cost the company $900,000.

The special police patrol established two weeks ago to round up wayward teen-agers in the Times Square area in the pre-dawn hours picked up eight more youngsters yesterday. To date fifty-one have been taken into custody, thirty-seven girls and fourteen boys.

" Lordagskvaller" (Saturday Nights") and "Frun Tillhanda" ("Servant Girls"), comprise the dual Swedish feature film program, starting today, at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. "Servant Girls" is equipped With English titles. The comedies are scheduled for a sixteen-day engagement.

New financing continued at a moderately active pace here this week, with bankers offering to the public bonds totaling $40,000,000 in four new issues, more than half Of which was contained in two public utility loans and the balance in municipal and industrial flotations.
The Home Owners Loan Corporation has sold eight dwellings in the Bronx, through Henry Waltemade, Inc., broker.

DALLAS, Tex., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Robert E. Hannegan of St. Louis, National Democratic Chairman, said today that the Roosevelt-Barkley incident would act as "a stimulus to the promotion of harmony in the Democratic party and the country."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel may be tried for the Pearl Harbor disaster before the war is over, Secretary Knox indicated today as he disclosed that Admiral Thomas C. Hart had been assigned to gather testimony for use at the trial.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Mill buying of May wheat lifted the price of that delivery 1 1/4 cents a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade today to a new high since Feb. 1, but as soon as the support was withdrawn the market started to ease and closing sales were up only 1/8 cent on the day.

In an unusual procedure, reserved only for the gravest crises in Japanese events, the Cabinet of Premier Hideki Tojo met at the Imperial Palace to approve stringent new regulations designed to strengthen the war effort, the Tokyo radio announced yesterday.

Every Wednesday hereafter for the duration of the war the full facilities of the Department of Sanitation will be devoted to the collection of wastepaper and tin, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner William F. Carey, who pointed out that this meant the 10,000 men and 1,000 trucks under his direction would collect no refuse on those days.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today denied a petition by Frank M. Booth of Haddonfield, N.J., a holder of capital stock of the United Gas Improvement Company, which asked that a hearing be held on U.G.I.'s proposed retirement annuity plan prior to a special stockkholders' meeting called for Feb. 29 and that U.G.I. be ordered to postpone voting on the plan.
LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:
FLEMINGTON, N.J., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Drafted here for presentation to the national conventions of both major parties are "four freedoms" of domestic affairs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Before the story by Mr. Crider to which Mr. Early referred was published, the Washington Bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES conferred with the Office of Censorship as to whether any questions of security, which are censorable under the Office of Censorship's Code of Newspaper Practices, were involved.

TRENTON, Feb. 25 -- New Jersey took the first step today toward joining the States that have voted to request Congress to call a Constitutional Convention to consider an amendment restricting income and inheritance taxes to a maximum of 25 per cent.

The Museum of Modern Art will open on March 15 an exhibition of work by modern Cuban painters. It is the first exhibition of its kind to be held in this country. Eighty oils, water-colors and drawings will be included. Among the artists to be represented are Ponce de Leon, Amelia Pelaez, Carlos Enriquez, Mariano, Mario Carrena and Cundo Bermudez.

After an early decline cotton futures yesterday developed steadiness and closed near their best levels of the session. Continued trade price-fixing and the failure of hedge selling to expand were factors in the rise. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts were up 2 to 3 points.

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- Moscow said today that Germans attempting to stem the new Russian offensive aimed toward the Nazi bases of Zhlobin and Bobruisk on the road to Minsk, capital of White Russia, brought up reinforcements and attempted to regain their lost positions. In one sector the Germans were hurled back after making fourteen counter-attacks, while on another they lost 2,500 men killed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Representative Jerry Voorhis of California, Democrat, urged members of the House today in a brief speech to join him in opposing the induction of Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans Affairs, as Director of Demobilization and Re-employment after the war, as envisioned in the Baruch report.

Newest book about Broadway and Broadway characters is Maurice Zolotow's "Never Whistle in a Dressing Room." Dutton's will publish the book March 20. Many of the pieces first appeared in The Saturday Evening Post.

The volume of new issues of State and municipal securities scheduled for award next week amounts to $11,649,200, compared with this week's revised total of $20,196,000, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average or 1944 to date is now $19,424,539.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A Pacific fleet press release:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Transportation described the controls exercised by the Army over part of the Pullman space on trains as unofficial and "a matter of necessity."

Alex Rose, State Secretary of the American Labor party and leader of its right wing faction, was accused yesterday of inspiring the Dies Committee's current attempt to investigate the political activities of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration, reporting the illegal use of 75,000,000 gallons of gasoline in January as a result of black market operations, told today how the fuel was drained from the rationed supply.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 25 -- Lord Moyne, British Resident Minister in the Middle East, revealed today that the Governments of all the Middle East countries will shortly be invited to send representatives to Cairo, where there will be a financial conference the purpose of which, he said, was to "form a common front against profiteering and the high cost of living."

WITH CHINESE FORCES IN HUKAWNG VALLEY, Feb. 21 (Delayed) -- Chinese troops here are now in the closing stages of operations that will clear the Japanese from the entire upper half of the Hukawng Valley. Japanese who formerly held the upper Hukawng Valley are now making desperate efforts to avoid annihilation in Chinese ambushes and encirclements as they fall back toward Maingkwan.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 25 -- Declaring that it is "our rightful duty to our country" to put Governor Dewey of New York before the people as a Presidential candidate, seventeen of twenty-four candidates for Dewey delegates at the April 4 delegation election announced today that they would ignore Mr. Dewey's request that they keep out of the race.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Early surveys on cut-backs show that women, last to enter the labor market, are bearing the brunt of the cut-back with the least cushion of unemployment insurance.

DETROIT, Saturday, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Great Lakes Steel Corporation at Ecorse, which a company spokesman said was the only plant in the country making armor plate for Navy landing craft, reported a spreading strike just after midnight, with the possibility that the entire plant, employing 6,000 men, might close down.

James A. Jackson, a partner in Lazard Freres, investment bankers, will become president of the Continental Bank and Trust Company of New York, it was learned yesterday. Formal announcement is scheduled to be made next week. Since the death in 1942 of F.H. Hornby the presidency of the bank had been assumed by the bank's chairman, Frederick E. Hasler.

Statements presented before the Kilgore Senate subcommittee investigating oil and wax treatment of soles were misleading and erroneous in view of the research made by the boot and shoe industry, the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association declared yesterday in a statement alleging that special interest groups desire the War Production Board to make oil and wax treatment of all leather soles mandatory.

On Sunday, Feb. 13, THE NEW YORK TIMES published extracts from an article printed in The Weekly Digest issued by the American Institute of Food Distribution, New York, on Feb. 12, 1944, regarding food conditions in German-occupied European countries.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Charlie Chaplin's attorneys flied a demurrer today to indictments charging the actor with Mann Act violations, on the ground that the Federal law was intended to prevent commercial vice and traffic in women, and not to govern private acts.

Brooklyn, last of the boroughs to reach its goal, has poked its nose over the top of the all-investors quota in the Fourth War Loan, it was reported yesterday by W. Randolph Burgess, chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York.

MORE than trees grow in Brooklyn; good stories grow there, too. There are ten first-rate stories about Brooklyn people in Michael Seide's "The Common Thread,"* which introduces a new name to the list of those who count in contemporary American fiction.

Teeth were put into the Moreland Act by a decision of the Appellate Division, which yesterday upheld the right of the commission to examine records for kickbacks and held those making the payments liable to jail sentences.

Colleges and universities are already making plans to aid the thousands of war veterans who are expected to return to the nation's campuses when the war ends. At New York University, for example, a Veterans Counseling Service has been established to help returned service men plan educational programs designed to take full advantage of their military or naval occupations.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 24 -- The Republican party's prospects in the coming Presidential election are a lot better than the average Republican voter is inclined to think.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Picking up the Congressional revolt against President Roosevelt's veto of the tax bill where the House left off yesterday, the Senate overrode the Chief Executive today, 72 to 14, or 15 more than the necessary two-thirds, and at 12:49 P.M. made law the measure which he had denounced as one which gave relief not to the needy but to the greedy.

J.J. Reynolds of the home club, playing with minus 3, defeated E.H. Roorbach, plus 1 man, of the Harvard Club, 15 -- 9, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 13, in the third round of the George Cumming invitation handicap squash racquets tournament for the benefit of the Darien Red Cross, at the University Club yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 25 -- The arrest of Arthur B. Reed, 37 years old, a stock selector at the Kearny plant of the Western Electric Company, on a charge of stealing Government property was followed this afternoon by the discovery of 110 vacuum cleaners in his $27-a-month apartment at 226 West Sixteenth Street., New York City, when visited by two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WITH GENERAL STILWELL'S CHINESE FORCES in the Hukawng Valley, Feb. 22 (Delayed) -- A combination of Chinese-American Army medical services is giving the Chinese forces fighting in the Hukawng Valley the best field medical attention the Chinese Army has ever had.

Election machinery of the New York Stock Exchange will start rolling once more on March 8, when the 1944 nominating committee will hold the first of three open meetings to invite suggestions for its new slate. The election in May will choose a chairman of the board, four member-governors, one allied member-governor resident in this district, two out-of-town governors, two trustees of the gratuity fund and a new nominating committee.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:
The German Friday communique, broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Dr. Bertram M. Bernheim, associate professor of surgery at the Johns Hopkins University Medical School and author of "Medicine at the Crossroads," presented last night, before the Physicians Forum, at the Kips Bay Health Center, a program for "tomorrow's medicine," outlining eight vital objectives aiming to place medical practice on a sound foundation.

The overwhelming vote by which both houses of Congress have overridden the President's veto of the tax bill was the only possible response that they could make. The new tax law that Congress has enacted has its shortcomings, but it is incomparably better than no new tax law at all.

John Whitlow Wyatt, ace of the Dodger pitching staff, will not report to the Brooklyn training camp at Bear Mountain on March 15. Whit, who has received his 1944 contract and is pleased with it, doesn't like the Northern climate for training and received permission yesterday to report April 1 instead.

The friendly state of war that has existed between the New York Athletic Club and New York University since last year, when the Violets wrested the team title from the Winged Footers, who had held it five seasons, will flare up again today in the National A.A.U. track and field championships at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- The FBI cut short the life-of-Riley career of two escaped military prisoners who were arrested while posing as Army-officers and while entertaining local citizens at a dinner in a $35-a-day hotel suite equipped with a rented juke box.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Feb. 25 -- Described by their commander as "the best soldiers I have ever seen," the men of the "Puka Puka" battalion from the Hawaiian Islands, made up almost entirely of Japanese, has won distinction in twenty-eight days of steady fighting for Cassino.

The Long Island University basketball team found itself midway through the opening period and went on to a 66-to-48 triumph over Brooklyn College on the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy court last night. The Kingsmen at one stage led L.I.U. by 12 to 5.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A Southwest Pacific communique, as relayed from Allied Headquarters through the Office of War Information:

The New York City Symphony, under Leopold Stokowski, will open its first series of four concerts on March 6, at 8:30 P.M., at the New York City Center, with a program composed of Bach's Fugue in G minor, Beethoven's Seventh symphony, Virgil Thomson's "The Plow That Broke the Plains" and the "Fire-bird" suite by Stravinsky. At the second concert, March 7, at 5 P.M., the program will be repeated.

A fortnight ago yesterday. Henry Pedersen, 11 years old, left his mother's apartment at 17 West Eighty-fourth Street, just off Central Park, with the promise that he would return early from school to clear the sidewalk of snow. His mother is superintendent of the house where they live on the ground floor.

The Radio Corporation of America's production of war materials in the radio, sound and electronics fields, for both the armed forces and the United Nations, increased last year more than 100 per cent over 1942, it was disclosed yesterday in the company's annual report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Quartermaster General of the Army has been instructed to place mandatory orders on certain clothing manufacturers to obtain needed officers' uniforms unless these companies submit bids at once, it has been announced by Robert P. Patterson, Acting Secretary of War.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 25 -- A regiment of Marshal Tito's [Josip Broz's] Dalmatia Brigade has landed on the island of Brac, south of Spalato, in the Adriatic Sea, and attacked the town of Milna, according to today's communique from headquarters of the People's Army of Liberation broadcast over the Free Yugoslavia radio today.

Last night R.H. Burnside's troupe, now firmly ensconced at the Ambassador, finally got around to playing "Patience." As the sixth in the group's repertory of Gilbert Sullivan operettas, it received an agreeable presentation. While the company was to some degree still lacking in the necessary polish and pace required of these works, it managed to do better than on recent occasions.

BOSTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company reported today net income of $9,645,971 for 1943, equal to $6.20 a common share, compared with $9,408,218, or $6.05 a share, in 1942.

Urging that a central planning organization be established in New York City to survey the prospects for post-war economic development of the city, the Savings Banks Committee on Post-War Planning and Reconstruction, headed by DeCoursey Fales, president of the Bank for Savings, issued yesterday a report covering several months of work, stating that thus far there has been little coordination of effort on the part of the various planning groups.

Two youths, "out for a joy ride" in a stolen automobile, were arrested yesterday after a forty-mile chase through north Queens that ended when the fourteenth shot fired by a radio patrolman hit a tire, causing the machine to turn over and burst into flames.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 25 -- American soldiers serving in the Middle East were informed today that they could anticipate returning home after completion of two full years of overseas service as the result of the rotation policy approved by the War Department. The program will become effective March 1.

Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, announced yesterday that the company's net income for 1943 was $44,923,000, or $159,000 under the net of $45,082,000 for 1942. These earnings were equal to $1.56 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, the same earnings a share as shown the year before.
After being closed a year for modernization and redecoration, the Mexican and Central American Hall in the American Museum of Natural History was reopened last night.

Cost of living pay rises and heavier than usual drains upon the pension funds because of recent mass retirements will place an additional burden of about $30,000,000 on the city's budget in 1944-45, Thomas J. Patterson, budget director, announced yesterday.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 25 -- What was described by police here today as Englewood's first wartime case of juvenile delinquency was discovered this morning when janitors arrived at Cleveland Public School to find that the school had been broken into, the contents of ten rooms strewn around the floors, desks overturned, ink splattered over floors, walls and ceilings and a fire smoldering in a closet.

The need for more and larger contributions to the Red Cross than ever before was stressed yesterday at a rally of business leaders in the Commodore, at which the Manhattan Commerce and Industry Committee pledged itself to raise $13,110,000 for the Red Cross 1944 War Fund.

American manufacturers must utilize intensive advertising to overcome Latin-American distrust of the "Yankee big stick," Hector Lazo, assistant to the president of Loose-Wiles Biscuit Company, said yesterday at a luncheon of the Export Advertising Association at the Belmont-Plaza.

The resurgence of the Republican party in the nation, increasingly evident in each election since 1940, can be attributed in large part to the political wizardry with which Charles Linza McNary filled his role as minority leader of the Senate for the past decade.

A temporary truce was effected yesterday by the New York State Mediation Board in the jurisdictional dispute between locals of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations that, according to the owner of a Union Square cafeteria, had for the last three days been costing him the salary and meals of an extra cashier to sit around doing nothing as an appeasement gesture toward the AFL local.

DETROIT, Feb. 25 -- About seventy-five persons, most of them women counselors in war plants here and in half a dozen near-by States, attended today the first of six Friday meetings of "the Employe Counseling Conference."

TRENTON, Feb. 25 -- Senate President Howard Eastwood put before the Legislature today the draft of a new State Constitution prepared by a joint committee of forty-two of the eighty-one members of the Senate and Assembly and will move next Friday for its adoption. With speedy approval by the two Houses assured, the text will be submitted to the voters at the general election in November.

Mrs. William S. Barstow, in 770 Park Ave; Mrs. James Christie, in 530 Park Ave; Mrs. F. Hamilton Merrill, in 850 Park Ave; Virginia Williams, in 112 E 54th St; Charles M. Butler, in 139 E 79th St; John P. Jannotta, in 520 E 86th St., through Douglas Gibbons Co. -- Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, broker.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- With the exception of South African gold and diamond mining shares, the securities markets here suffered a general setback today, although the selling was on the light side. Declines were seen in gas, electric, cinema, radio, brewery and stores shares.
After being closed a year for modernization and redecoration, the Mexican and Central American Hall in the American Museum of Natural History was reopened last night.

A discussion concerning the role of women voters in the coming Presidential election developed last night into a warmly worded debate over the respective abilities of the two major political parties to govern the nation in war and peace.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 25 -- Among the 625 patents listed as issued during the past week is one covering what might be called a "thinking valve" for air-conditioning systems. The patent's number is 2,342,328 and Willis H. Carrier of Syracuse, N.Y., the inventor, has assigned it to the Carrier Corporation.

LISBON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- S. Pinkney Tuck, United States Charge d'Affaires at Vichy, now en route home after being repatriated from Germany along with a group of other Americans, expressed the belief today that an international commission would be formed to fix the responsibility for what he termed Germany's "rape" of American diplomatic missions to Vichy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Joan Langan, aged 10, who has been a pawn in a five-year custody battle between her divorced parents, was taken from her mother, the former British movie actress Joan Manners, this morning by John Langan, her father, while the trio were at breakfast.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The political developments in Argentina were said by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, today to be a cause of concern here. He indicated that they might lead to exchanges of information among the American republics on the question of recognition.

Tonight's performance of "Peepshow" will be the show's last, it was decided yesterday. The comedy, which was written by Ernest Pascal and sponsored by him in association with Samuel Bronston, opened at the Fulton Theatre on Feb. 3 and will have played twenty-eight times.

Kings County Judge Franklin Taylor reserved decision yesterday on the motion of attorneys for Mrs. Edna Hancock, former employe of Brooklyn State Hospital, for an inspection of the grand jury minutes before she goes on trial on a charge of first-degree perjury.

The New York Little Symphony Orchestra, under Joseph Barone, gave a concert last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, at which Erma Erickson, soprano, and Dorothy Holcomb, conductor, were the young American artists granted debut appearances. Anthony Donato's "Elegy for Strings" was the work by a youthful contemporary composer of this country chosen for presentation at this event.

The annual campaign for the Salvation Army's maintenance fund has attained $428,215, it was announced yesterday by Walbridge S. Taft, campaign chairman, at the final luncheon held in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway. Although this represents only 78 per cent of the goal of $550,000, Mr. Taft predicted that additional sums would be received before the close of the organization's fiscal year on Sept. 30.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- A bill was offered in the Legislature today to protect tenants of hotels and rooming houses in war boom towns by bringing them under Office of Price Administration regulations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The seventh meeting today of House and Senate conferees assigned to work out a mutually acceptable soldier-vote bill resulted in another "compromise" proposal which in the end, many observers say, apparently left the members of the armed forces as far from prospective participation in next November's elections as they have been before.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Increased demand for sugar cane molasses for the production of industrial alcohol along with rising needs of the United Nations' armed forces for sugar will cut the amount of sugar available for civilian use this year to 5,074,906 tons, or about 6 per cent below 1943 consumption, the War Food Administration revealed today.

Miss Olive Ruehe, writing in THE TIMES on Feb. 12, criticizes OPA's new price panel program as presaging a "break in national faith" and contributing to "distrust and disruption" in the traditional friendship and understanding between the American storekeeper and his customers.

It is easier to fight the war through than to work it through or think it through. The critical debate on Mr. Churchill's speech in the House of Commons was on foreign policy and this week's revolt in the Congress was on a purely domestic issue, but they were reflections of a political restlessness that is growing in both countries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Draft demands to supply manpower to the armed services will become "tougher and tougher" in the next six months and for an indefinite period after that, Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, told the Senate Committee on Agriculture today.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 25 -- President Ramirez, in a proclamation to the Argentine people, made public at 3:30 o'clock this morning, announced that, being tired and in need of rest, he had delegated the Presidential powers to his Vice President, General Farrell.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has sold the eleven-story store, showroom and loft building at 1255-61 Broadway, at Thirtyfirst Street, to Simon Bond and Leon Fromer for investment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A bill jointly drafted by juvenile judges of many States to reduce juvenile delinquency by using Federal aid- to-dependent-children funds to buy railroad tickets home for interstate runaways, was recommended before a Senate judiciary subcommittee today by two of their number, Judge Walter H. Beckham of Miami, Fla., and Judge Chris Barnette of Shreveport, La.

AGNES ROTHERY is the author of several sparkling, informed, well-written accounts of her expeditions to Scandinavian countries and into South and Central America. In "A Fitting Habitation" Mrs. Rothery turns the tables on herself and her readers and stays at home.

FROM behind the censorship curtain in Asia comes information, by way of a French source in North Africa to Leon Monosson in New York, that Indo-China, a French protectorate under Japanese occupation, has issued twenty-seven stamps with designs largely of historical significance.

WITH an eye on the state of the world, Victor has released an album of selections from Walt Whitman's "Leaves of Grass" (Album M-955, four twelve-inch records). The verses, many of which dramatically represent militant American democracy, are read by Ralph Bellamy, currently of the stage play "Tomorrow the World."

BADEN-BADEN -- The number of Germans put out of action -- killed, badly wounded or captured -- since the beginning of the war reaches a minimum of 4,500,000 to 5,000,000, of whom about 2,000,000 are dead, according to conservative estimates based on information coordinated from several sources in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Statisticians who assay political changes on the basis of mathematical forecasts rather than personalities, think the tide is swinging to the Republicans. Republican analysts count New York as probably returning to that party's candidate next November; they look on Michigan, Indiana and Ohio as Republican certainties and anticipate heavy gains in the "border States" that may lead up to a party landslide comparable to the Democratic victory in 1932.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 26 -- The truce recently effected in Greece between the Elas guerrilla bands and the Edes forces under Gen. Napoleon Zervas continues, according to information available here.

INCREASINGLY earnest are the efforts made by local galleries to present in terms of "theme" exhibitions work by European moderns owned in this country. Imports have been nil for several years, yet it is surprising how much unfamiliar modernist art long resident over here, or arrived before the seas became prohibitively unsafe, can still be summoned for display.

As was expected, ready-to-wear business in some stores is well under the record-breaking figures of February last year, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

The report of the Federation of British Industries, recommending creation of an economic council to guide the flow of the empire's post-war trade under governmental control, was received here by foreign traders last week as a commercial "declaration of war."

Scattered price-fixing in the March and May deliveries, offset by hedge selling and liquidation, produced yesterday an easier tone in cotton futures. At the close of trading, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 1 to 4 points below Friday's final quotations.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas McArthur, speaking over a new radio station opened in New Guinea for entertainment of Allied troops, praised his men today for their "fortitude and fighting efficiency" and promise to afford them "that additional comfort which you so richly deserve."

LISBON, Feb. 26 -- Americans belonging to the Baden Baden and Godesberg diplomatic repatriation group spent their first day in Lisbon accustoming themselves to the thousand and one ways of normal life.

The Sun Oil Company reported yesterday for 1943 a consolidated net income of $13,353,524 after all charges, taxes and reserves, which was equal, after preferred dividend payments, to $4.56 each on the 2,838,928 common shares outstanding. This compares with $8,671,050 for 1942, or $2.91 a common share.

Retail trade was active here last week, but volume fell behind the comparative sales of 1943, which were swollen by the continued scare buying of apparel. Department store volume, it was indicated, ran about 5 per cent behind the like week of last year.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

IT seems impossible today that travelers and students who went among the Indians of the Southwest, and even lived among them, as late as two generations ago reported that they seemed to have no religion. Since Washington Matthews went among the Navaho, of course, we have known how false that was.

The seventh annual United Pacifist Conference brought together yesterday leading advocates of an immediate, negotiated peace, some of whom, however, were critical of methods pursued by certain pacifist groups.

All of us -- consciously or not -- rationalize economic and political belief in terms of the Constitution. So it is with the debate at all levels on the ballot for members of the armed services. Most of the arguments for and against are fathered by the wish, but there is material in our constitutional background for a better understanding of the problem.

In his first broadcast to the people of the United States, Archbishop Bernard W. Griffin, recently installed as Roman Catholic Archbishop of Westminster, warned yesterday that "unless at home our house is in order, we cannot hope to be an influence of good with other nations."

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Buying of May wheat by millers on the Board of Trade gave the market a relatively firm undertone today, although there was a dip in sympathy with rye. The buying is understood to have been removal of hedges against sales of wheat grits to distillers rather than against sales of flour, demand for which remains slow, as the War Food Administration has postponed lend-lease purchases of flour indefinitely.

ALGIERS, Feb. 26 -- The United States Fifteenth Air Force, the strategic heavy bomber component of the Mediterranean Allied Air Forces, revealed its power this week in four consecutive large-scale actions over Germany or Austria, three of them in direct coordination with strategic bombers from Britain.

Retail trade continued active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were busy and apparel departments were crowded.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, Feb. 27 -- American destroyers swept through the northern Bismarck Sea at dawn Friday and bombarded the Japanese supply base at Kavieng, New Ireland, for the third time within a week and Allied bombers dropped 100 tons of bombs on Rabaul, New Britain, Thursday, it was announced today.

ALGIERS, Feb. 26 -- The beachhead battle below Rome went into its fifth week today but the general situation remained unchanged. Patrolling and artillery fire continued but only one small-scale attack was launched by the enemy, despite the maintenance of close contact throughout the front.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The first thirty-two finishers in the fifty-six-team Football League, North, War Cup qualifying competition will enter the cup rounds proper next Saturday, but last year's winners, the Wolverhampton Wanderers, will not be among them.

ASK many stores in town what's new in the furniture field, and the answer will be -- antiques. Antiques, reproductions, period pieces of all kinds have emerged as the very "latest thing" in interior decoration, and a substantial part of every wartime furniture collection.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Capt. Randolph Churchill, 32-year-old son of Prime Minister Winston Churchill, has joined Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) in Yugoslavia, it was learned here tonight. Presumably, Captain Churchill landed by parachute.

For the second time in recent months, a lie detector has been used in a criminal action in Brooklyn, it was disclosed yesterday, and again the result was dismissal of the charges against the suspect who subjected himself to the test. The latest case, which occurred Friday, involved Alfonse Di Lollo, 29 years old, of 143 Sullivan Place, Brooklyn, who was arrested on Jan. 8 on charges of possessing policy slips.
