CONTRIBUTIONS to the fund of $300,000 to meet operating deficits, which the Metropolitan Opera Association is endeavoring to raise by public subscription, amounted on Feb. 25 to approximately five-sixths of the amount required.

Whether the United Nations should assume strict control over the educational systems of the Axis powers after victory came in for spirited discussion this past week by the educators who gathered here for the regional conference of the American Association of School Administrators, a department of the National Education Association.

THAT most Americans do not know their own history as well as they might has been thoroughly established in recent months. Two surveys, one conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES and the other by a committee of prominent historians, have reached the same general conclusion -- we need to know more about our great American heritage, the traditions and ideals that have helped make this nation strong and united.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

IT looks as if busy times are ahead this spring, even before we get to April and the two simultaneous ballet seasons that arrive with the Easter rabbit. Though Broadway theatres are so unavaliable for dance performances as to seem little more than a memory, there are thirteen events on the current week's schedule, a record for the season.

SUCH writers as Hemingway, O'Hara, Cobb, Maugham and Lardner are good to meet in a collection of short stories, no matter under whose sponsorship. In the case of "For Men Only," sponsored by James M. Cain, there is the added inducement of a short story of Mr. Cain's own and his amiable introduction.

I have read with much interest Lyman Beecher Stowe's article entitled "Preparation for Citizenship" in your issue of Feb. 9 and fully agree with him, "to give young people experience in governing themselves."

The German Reich was struck last week by the greatest, perhaps the most fateful, air assault in history. Its objective was the destruction of the Luft-waffe as an effective fighting force. It was aimed to bring the German fighter plane to combat in the skies, to smash Germans fighters on the ground, to obliterate factories where German fighters are made.

A Berlin broadcast of a Tokyo dispatch yesterday said a violent battle had been in progress for several days "for possession of the Pacific isle of Guam," with the Japanese garrison fighting to stave off attacks by an American naval formation, the Associated Press reported.

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 23 (Delayed) -- Despite her small population of only 7,000,000, Australia's war effort, in proportion to her resources and income, is roughly of the same dimensions as those of the United States, the United Kingdom and Canada.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Private advices from Cairo said tonight that King Peter of Yugoslavia had sent an urgent appeal to Prime Minister Winston Churchill to rescue him from what has been called virtual imprisonment there, and to aid his passage to London so that he may confer with Allied leaders.

The report of the American Central Manufacturing Corporation for the year ended on Nov. 30, 1943, mailed yesterday to stockholders, shows a net income of $1,176,441 after all charges and taxes, equivalent to $3.30 each on 349,638 shares of common stock.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Claude (Buddy) Young, Illinois freshman, tied the national 60-yard dash record of 6.1 seconds and captured three events today as Illinois defeated Purdue and Notre Dame in a triangular indoor track meet.

BECAUSE Mrs. Willoughby, a gracious lady in a pale blue housecoat, patters around a thickly carpeted penthouse floor of a fine morning, you must not conclude that she is of the idle rich. Idleness is the enemy she fights most vigorously with all the resources bestowed on her by a fond Providence.
A criminal trial for rape in New York City which attracted country-wide attention raises once more the validity of evidence obtained by means of the so-called lie detector.
ALMOST forty years ago a young naval officer had as his first command a leaky old torpedo boat. One day the leaks began letting in more water than the pumps could take care of.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Baruch-Hancock report on war and post-war readjustment, despite its unfortunate submission at a time when the controversy between the legislative and executive departments of the Government was building up to a spectacular climax, has already been largely placed in execution by the executive department, with an understandable lag in action by Congress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- While representatives of the American Farm Bureau Federation and other agricultural organizations were asking the Senate Agriculture Committee that fewer farm workers be drafted, President Roosevelt today called for an immediate review of 5,000,000 occupational deferments to make good a deficiency of 200,000 in the armed forces.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Big formations of British, Canadian and Australian heavy bombers struck two hammer blows in rapid succession last night at Augsburg, important southeast German production center for airplanes and submarine engines, dropping a total of 1,800 tons of bombs in attacks spaced two and a half hours apart.

Many murmurs from Russia, some from the Dominions and perhaps even an echo from our own shores undoubtedly impelled Mr. Churchill in his speech last week to give the world a reckoning of what the British Isles alone have done in this war. He did not tell it all; he told none of it boastfully.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The Spanish Government has reassured Allied diplomats that it intends to pursue a policy of "honorable neutrality" and some progress has already been made toward limiting the activities of German agents in the Iberian Peninsula, a responsible Allied source indicated tonight.

STRANGELY enough, all eight one-man shows last week brought forward artists who had not previously been thus represented in New York. All of them, what is more, proffered work which for one reason or another may be assigned to the profit side of the ledger.

THE Victory program for 1944 calls for 2,000,000 new gardens which, added to last year's figure, would bring the total up to 22,000,000 plots. This means that many people who did not have gardens last year will be called on to participate in the patriotic effort.

TERESITA'S valley was a happy one, lying quietly, almost forgotten, near the Colorado-New Mexico border, and the Martinez family had called it home for a hundred years. Then Papa lost his land and all his money in a lawsuit and, overcome with humiliation, failed to come home.
The use of red and blue "tiddlywinks" in rationing, which begins today throughout the nation, was heralded yesterday by the Office of Price Administration with praise and poetry.
Lieut. Comdr. William T. Fleming, USNR, and Mrs. Fleming of Harrisburg, Pa., have come to the Ritz-Carlton.

The annual bridge party under the auspices of the Girls' Branch of the Public Schools Athletic League will take place on the afternoon of March 11 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Funds obtained will aid the maintenance of the recreational and athletic activities conducted by the league for girls attending public schools in the city.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 26 -- Despite an acute manpower shortage, Raritan Arsenal reported today that 6,046 separate shipments of ordinance supplies and spare parts weighing 13,665 tons were made during January.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Moving of any trees or large shrubs which is planned for this spring can be undertaken now. . . . It is also time to protect rhododendrons against strong spring sunlight, as damaging as windburn, by putting up a screen of evergreen branches or burlap.

THE "unwritten laws" of bridge -- questions of ethics and sportsmanship -- are far more carefully observed in expert play than in casual bridge games. Misleading hesitations, side remarks, undue emphasis in bidding and histrionics of all kinds, are frowned upon in high-ranking club and tournament play.

Youngstown, Ohio, yesterday was picked as the site of the thirty-second annual National Amateur Baseball Federation championship tournament by thirty-five delegates from various Midwest, Southern and Eastern cities, meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.
NAPLES, Feb. 26 (AP) -- An Allied communique:

OLDER girls who want to know what it is really like to work in a defense plant will find out in "Second Shift." Phyllis Crawford has done a stint in one of them and provides a realistic background for this story of one girl who chose "unskilled, repetitive labor" as her part in the war.
Lippy Leo Durocher, who has devoted most of the off season to helping entertain members of the armed forces in Florida, may make his next move into a St. Louis hospital.

IT'S nice to be a detective; one meets such interesting people. To be sure, some of them play rough, but that is all in the day's work. Within the space of a few days Argus Steele meets a Russian princess, a munitions tycoon, a fabulously rich widow, a dress designer and several glamorous models, to say nothing of the man who falls or is thrown out of a car in Central Park.

SOMEWHERE in Germany nineteen young American veterans of the Tunisian campaign sat in a classroom taking their "finals" in Diesel engineering. Some of the questions they had to answer were pretty stiff: "What is the effect of a negative exhaust lap

OXFORD-EDUCATED East Indian K.M. Panikkar, until recently Foreign Minister and Political Minister of Bikaner State (India), carried through his university studies as Dixon Scholar for Historical Research, taking first class in modern history in 1917.

IT seems strange at first to hear of a class in magic for children who cannot see. However, a magician's powers of deception depend largely on his hands. Here alone is a common basis to work from, for the blind have extremely sensitive fingers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Wood furniture manufacturers were informed by the WPB today that they may produce any type furniture they wish. There was a catch to the seeming liberality of today's announcement, however, since WPB continued its previous limitations as to number of patterns and on lumber consumption for furniture in effect.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- While representatives of the American Farm Bureau Federation and other agricultural organizations were asking the Senate Agriculture Committee that fewer farm workers be drafted, President Roosevelt today called for an immediate review of 5,000,000 occupational deferments to make good a deficiency of 200,000 in the armed forces.

WILL the peace after this war be a permanent one or will it merely pave the way for another war? Dorothy B. Hughes attempts to answer these questions by picturing what might happen if those who love peace are not constantly on the alert.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Miami's most unusual season is rounding into the homestretch, and thousands of visitors have discovered that though getting to Miami was comparatively easy, getting back home is something else again. Mostly it is a matter of train reservations, but automobilists are having their troubles too.

There's a new sound in the wind as February draws to a close, a new feeling in it. Not spring yet, nor even the March wind we think of; but no longer the sleety blast of winter nor the cry of the bitter gale at the doorway. This is the wind of change, the gusty breath of days with earlier sunrise, later sunset, warmer afternoons.

IN April, 1941, with the announcement of the Russo-Japanese nonaggression treaty, Russian-American relationships, which had been improving for some years and then had rocketed downward with the signing of the Soviet-German pact and the Russo-Finnish war, hit bottom.

Edward V. Broderick, defense attorney for Wayne Lonergan, declared at 7:30 o'clock last night that his trip to Canada "and points in the United States" had been "very successful" and that he had obtained "considerable data" with regard to the Lonergan defense "as a result of four stops, the last in Buffalo."

A total of 4,811,628 separate purchasers of war bonds has been tabulated in the Fourth War Loan drive in New York State, so that the goal of 5,000,000 bond buyers is in sight with two selling days remaining, W. Randolph Burgess, chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York, announced yesterday.

WHILE trade volume this month has fallen below the peak sales of the rationing scare period of last year, it now seems likely that February will not turn in the large decline expected. The extra day of leap year, in fact, may reduce the loss in merchandise trade to a mere 3 or 4 per cent.

China once seemed almost as far away and fabulous to most of us as a land on another planet. Now the earth has gone in for reducing and China has suddenly become our close neighbor on the west; our next-door neighbor, in fact. Still more, she is our comrade-at-arms.

NOT often are wartime visitors permitted to see some of the vast program of radio - electronic development going on inside such a plant as the General Electric Company here. Very little can be written except in a general way about the "G.E.," because military censorships are strict and unbending.

THE rights to sell reproductions of paintings that are in the Barnes Foundation have been granted to Arthur W. Colen of the Modern Galleries of Art, Philadelphia. Examples of the work of Titian, Tintoretto, El Greco, Rubens, Daumier, Renoir, Cezanne and others will be reproduced and made available to students, schools, colleges and universities.

Those sportsmen who are interested in pending conservation bills will have an opportunity to air their views on Wednesday when a public hearing will be held on such legislation in Albany, Senator Walter W. Stokes of Cooperstown and Assemblyman Leo A. Lawrence of Herkimer, chairmen respectively of the Senate and Assembly Committees on Conservation, announced the hearing jointly for 2 P.M. in the Senate Chamber at the State Capitol.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce asked today for prompt enactment of legislation establishing policies to govern the disposition of surplus war plants and supplies, warning that if such laws were not passed the country might go into a serious depression after the end of the war.

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School of Brooklyn and Mercersburg Academy of Mercersburg, Pa., each a former titleholder, regained the national A.A.U. interscholastic track and field championship in its respective division yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

STANDING still, The Tallulah somehow gives the impression she's at a destroyer's prow, knifing into a howler. Her long, tawny hair whips into her face with every gesture. She flips it back impatiently every few seconds with a motion almost as regular as breathing. Her speech is a racing torrent, the whisper-in-a-rainbarrel sound of it curiously hypnotic.

THE colorful personality of Mme. Alexandra Mihailovna Kollontay, Soviet envoy to Sweden, keeps coming into the spotlight. Some sixscore newspaper correspondents stationed in the Swedish capital dog her every step because she occupies a key position at the crossroads of the war, where German and Russian diplomatic forces meet.

Last January Prof. Felix Ehrenhaft, an Austrian refugee who used to be director of the Physics Institute of the University of Vienna and who was highly regarded in pre-Hitler Europe, lectured before a local section of the American Physical Society and described some experiments which to him proved that magnetism flows in a current like electricity.

IT was perhaps in the days of the Boxer Rebellion, when troops of several Western powers operated in China, that the ferocity and willingness to die of Japanese soldiers first made a widespread impression on the rest of the world. In the swift Japanese drive Jiro Takahashi -- the typical Japanese private -- proved himself an experienced, well-trained fighter with an almost fanatic zeal to die for his Emperor.

A set of nine Limoges painted enamel plaques, from the French sixteenth-century school of Pierre Reymond, depicting scenes from the Passion of Christ, was included in the auction sale of French and English art objects and furnishings held yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 26 -- The great central Pacific offensive has proceeded so rapidly in the past weeks that the joint Chiefs of Staff in Washington may find it necessary to study a reallocation of Allied shipping tonnage to meet logistics needs in this area.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Southwest Pacific Sunday communique relayed from Allied headquarters through the Office of War Information:
RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Duke upset favored North Carolina tonight and won the Southern Conference basketball championship with a stunning 44-27 victory in the final of the annual tournament.

MONTREAL, Feb. 26 -- The Montreal Canadiens clinched the National Hockey League championship tonight with a 10-2 victory over Boston in a game that dealt another heavy blow to the Bruins' chances of making the Stanley Cup play-offs.

ONE of the largest exhibitions of the season has been arranged by the Art Students League for the Veterans Scholarship Fund and installed in the American Fine Arts Galleries with an overflow in the League Gallery next door.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, which was created in November to set the war-torn countries on their feet again, will within the next week or two receive from the United States and Great Britain their contribution to the $2,500,000,000 fund with which it is to be endowed.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26 -- Stir Up punctured the Director J.E. bubble before 17,262 persons at Hialeah Park today and went on to capture the $20,075 Flamingo Stakes in such convincing fashion that now he is the one talked of as a Kentucky Derby horse.

MARCH may come in like a lion up North, but down South flowers are blooming. And travelers lucky enough to be near some of the famous gardens will see the annual display of blossoms. Though no floral hegiras as in other years are planned for the spring season, most of the gardens will be open to visitors.

EUROPEANS have studied American jazz for the most part with the music detached from its setting. From touring bands or phonograph records they have heard the Cotton Pickers undisturbed by the water nymphs who inhabit river boats, the Original Dixieland Jazz Band without the diversions of Reisenweber's, the first Benny Goodman trio without the distractions provided by jitterbugs rampant.

On the first nice spring day we mean to run up to the Bronx Zoo to see Pearl. This Pearl, we hasten to explain, is a tortoise, and a little one, at that. She weighs only seven ounces in her stocking feet, but some day, with luck, she will be a 500-pounder.

Railway shares led a slight upward movement on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Stocks drifted in narrow ranges and closed irregularly higher on volume of 372,710 shares, the heaviest for a Saturday since Jan. 22, due to activity in low-priced public utilities. On the previous Saturday turnover was 346,103 shares.

LIBERTY STREET is in Brooklyn, but the action of this novel takes place in Santa Rosa, capital of a Central American republic, where Nestor Kerjanian, a refugee, waits for his American visa. His brother lives on Liberty Street, and when the visa comes Kerjanian will join his brother and live in the idyllic bliss of individual freedom which is everyday existence in the United States.

MOSCOW, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- Russian military and naval experts asserted today that the lightning American operations against the Marshall Islands had weakened Japan's strategic position in the mid-Pacific and created a "future threat" to the enemy bastions of Truk and Wake.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Feb. 26 -- The unexpected ease of the "breakthrough" of the Japanese Outer defenses in the Central Pacific is forcing a reconsideration of Pacific strategy. Fading rapidly is the High Command's promise that not much more could be done with the Nipponese than to maintain pressure against them until the war with Hitler is over.

Plans to establish a world training center in tropical medicine at Columbia University's School of Medicine were announced yesterday by Prof. Harry S. Mustard, director of the school's DeLamar Institute of Public Health. The plans call for new building facilities, a greatly expanded personnel and additional laboratories and equipment.

IN the discussions of the question, "Was Shakespeare's Othello a Negro?" which have from time to time appeared in the press since Oct. 19 of last year, I have not as yet chanced to notice the use of certain historical evidence which might be brought forward in justification of the racial appropriateness of Mr. Robeson's selection for this role.

SEVERAL months ago an American censorship officer at an overseas station ran across a passage in a soldier's letter which he thought worthy of passing along to his superior. It read somewhat as follows: "Dear Mom: When you get your next allotment from me through the Government I hope you'll take it downtown and give it to the Red Cross War Fund."

I am delighted with the excellent analysis by Emery Reves in THE TIMES Magazine: "Can We Find the True Path to Peace?" Mr. Reves deduced his views of future democracies from the behavior of individuals in existing democracies.

A 35 per cent increase in the light transmission of binoculars, which enables an observer to see distant targets better in dim light with clearer definition, is made possible by a new method of removing light reflections from glass, reports H.R. Moulton of the American Optical Company's research staff.

The article, "'After Darkness, Light' -- Geneva's Hope" in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine was of particular interest to me as a former student of Geneva University. The Bavaria tavern which was so well described by Mr. Archambault was indeed the meeting place for all of Geneva's illustrious people and visitors.

In the post-war era the United States must plan on a world basis to achieve successful conversion from a war to a peace economy, educators declared yesterday at a panel discussion conducted by the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union in its headquarters, 1710 Broadway.

FIFTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Italy, Feb. 26 -- Definite efforts to facilitate war reporting for correspondents covering the Italian campaign are now being made after the recent small storm concerning censorship and transmission, highlighted by the brief period when the Anzio radio facilities were barred to reporters.
LONDON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Association Press:

Starting three years ago this week, when exemption from Federal taxes was removed from all future issues of Government securities, the municipal bond market has experienced a sharp increase in the demand for State and municipal issues which has carried prices to high records and the yields to investors to low records. Yields of 1 to 2 per cent on medium and long-term municipal issues are now by no means uncommon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Japanese-Americans in the relocation center at Granada, Col., have presented eleven demands on the War Relocation Authority, including a plea that they have freedom to live and travel anywhere in the United States, Dillon S. Myer, WRA director, disclosed today.

One aircraft carrier, 27,500 tons; one aircraft carrier, 27,000 tons; one heavy cruiser, 13,000 tons; one light cruiser, 10,000 tons; one "super-destroyer," 2,200 tons. Thus went the record of launchings for the Navy last week. The carriers were the Shangri-La, launched at Norfolk, Va., and the Bennington, floated in her building dock at Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday.

In the last few months there has been much speculation among students of the steel industry whether or not the strong impetus given by wartime exigencies to an increased range of fabricating and manufacturing activities by steel corporations might not continue after the war.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 26 -- Miss Marcella May and James Lockhead Jr. of the Frisco Skate and Ski Club, San Francisco, Calif., retained their senior dance championship title over two contesting pairs from the New York Skating Club today at the National Figure Skating Association's annual championship meet.

The projected release of some 20,000,000 pounds of butter to the civilian trade from the Federal Government's hoard of 130,000,000 pounds in storage was reported yesterday to have collapsed in the face of determined trade opposition.
LONDON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Sixty-nine United States heavy bombers were lost in Friday's operations against Germany, a record loss for a single day's sorties.

ALGIERS, Feb. 26 -- It now seems certain the Allies will soon reach an accord with the French National Committee of Liberation for its cooperation as the temporary civil authority immediately upon the liberation of any part of continental France.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Records of the Secretary of the Senate show that Congress has overridden President Roosevelt's veto of legislation eight times in addition to yesterday's action on the $2,315,000,000 tax bill.

HERE is an out-and-out love story, unusual in design. There is very little lovemaking in it, yet its primary concern is with love. There are two heroines, kinswomen and close friends -- Augusta, 50, and Lynn, in her early twenties.

NOT even native taste in motion pictures has escaped the widespread Americanization which is going on in South Pacific isles formerly unknown even to the National Geographic Society. Formerly the likings of the New Zealanders ran along fairly well-defined lines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Under the new sugar-ration reduction program of the Office of Price Administration for industrial users, drug and medicine manufacturers will continue to get 100 per cent of the amount of sugar they used in comparable months of 1941 through the first two quarters of this year.

VARIOUS items about Richard Strauss have from time to time passed the censorship. A more recent and uncensored communication as to his present position and whereabouts comes from Robert Breuer, now in America, and formerly of the Foreign Press Association of Vienna, concerning the composer and his relationship with Nazi officialdom.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 26 -- Diplomatic circles today expressed the opinion that either Mexico or the United States might have the task of negotiating establishment of relations between Brazil and Russia.

"NOT very many charter-boats go into the Gulf Stream to fish these days," says Philip Wylie in his introduction to this, the third collection of his Crunch and Des yarns. "The fishing itself, they tell me, is superb."

DETROIT, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Production of armor plate for Navy landing barges was at a standstill today as 6,000 employes of the Great Lakes Steel Corporation in Ecorse remained idle in a strike that began yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration is giving voluntary relief organizations which wish to participate in its work a chance to do so by contributing personnel, Herbert H. Lehman, director, announced today.

IF Anthony Mele, proprietor of the Ruban Bleu, bears a pleased mien these days there is a reason. The night club owner recently signed contracts for Imogene Coca, the funny imp of the Broadway musical stage, to appear at his East Fifty-sixth Street club starting March 8.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes announced today an extensive system for fighting domestic coal shortages next winter.

Sometimes this war seems to spin out farther into the future than one dares look. Sometimes, after a victory, after some revelation of our antagonists' state of mind and spirit, the shining face of peace is visible through the dreadful mists. One can almost hear the bells ringing and the shouting in the streets.

Distribution systems developed around the country's motor-truck and rail transportation lines will require little, if any, overhauling due to strikes made in commercial aviation, Hartley W. Barclay, executive director of the Management Research Institute, declared yesterday.

CHUNGKING, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- Striking at the Japanese lifeline in Central China, Fourteenth United States Air Force fliers successfully raided shipping and other targets along the Yangtze River during the past two days, a communique from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

THREE of the week's group exhibitions reached back into the past with excellent results. THEY are wonderful kids. One who had heard but had never seen them can confess now that he was pretty apprehensive about meeting them, because child prodigies can be fearsome to encounter and are known to have left inferiority complexes that endured for years.

LONDON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- An end to Great Britain's wartime political truce was demanded today by Lady Violet Bonham Carter, daughter of the late Earl of Oxford and Asquith, Britain's Liberal Prime Minister at the start of the first World War.

FROM the American Theatre Wing's farthest-flung beachhead in San Francisco, from its northernmost outpost in Boston, from its stations in Cleveland, Washington, Philadelphia and Newark, representatives of its Stage Door Canteens have begun to entrain and enplane to take part in the celebration of the second anniversary of the daddy of all Stage Door Canteens in New York on Thursday night.

Victory gardeners are thinking now about spring planting. This simple plan for a vegetable garden 20 by 30 feet is a practical one which makes use of every foot of space, throughout the entire growing season. It also includes the crops which do best for amateur gardeners with limited space at their disposal.

COLONIAL sentiment for independence during our Revolution was not unanimous. Many sincere men -- Tories, or, as they called themselves, Loyalists felt that the differences should be resolved within the Empire. Driven from their homes by the aroused rebels, most of them (like Kenneth Roberts' Oliver Wiswell) settled in Canada's maritime provinces after the Revolution.

THE story of Vatican diplomacy since the accession of Hitler is part of the required course for those who aspire to a full view of the weird drama of Europe during the last eleven years. More particularly at this time it delineates some of the snares and pitfalls which lie ahead in the peace, for the Vatican has had, so to speak, been deeply involved from the beginning.

NOTHING could more clearly show the difference between high school age and early college youth today and a generation ago than this booklist "A Goodly Heritage," compiled by a committee of librarians in close touch with the younger readers in the adult department of the Public Library.

WITH "This Happy Breed" ready for showing in a week or two, the Noel Coward production unit is back on the floor at Denham with another of the master's inventions, screened according to the master's own ideas.

THE care and feeding of the strange pets and mascots our service men are bringing home from odd corners of the world constitute the latest domestic front crisis. Think sympathetically of the poor mother whose sailor son left with her when he went back to sea the pet lemur he bought for $17 in a North African cafe.

NINE Chicago artists were awarded prizes in the recently opened forty-eighth annual exhibition of work by Artists of Chicago and Vicinity at the Chicago Art Institute. The list of prize-winners includes Edgar Miller, Margo Hoff, Don Mundt, Thelma Slobe, Mario C. Ubaldi, Clinton King, Wolfgang Behl, Stanley M. Mitruk and Julio de Diego.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A reshuffle of the Senate's Republican organization, with aggressive-minded "Young Turks" in control, seemed in the making today as minority members moved to fill the gap left by the death of Charles L. McNary of Oregon, their leader since 1933.

THIS book begins with Pearl Harbor and ends with the Battle of the Solomons. In between is a history of the United States Naval Academy, told in terms of the men who have gone forth from its classrooms and training ships to make American naval history.

KEEP this under your hat. It's a secret -- such a terrible secret that the fate of the world may depend upon it. Alvin Harmon, a physicist, is the discoverer, and he tells Jim Steele about it, only he does not reveal any details. Steele is a member of a very hush-hush Government agency, and he realizes at once that Harmon is in very great danger.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26 -- Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Philadelphia held his two-stroke lead in the $5,000 New Orleans open golf tournament today, though he slipped from his spanking 4-underpar first-round 68 to a 73 on the second eighteen holes.

DETROIT, Feb. 26 -- R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, made public today details of plans adopted by the international executive board of the union to prevent unauthorized strikes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Congress was angry this week. It put on such a show of passion about this, that and the other that veterans of twenty years' experience could not recall high drama marching the stage of House and Senate in such great intensity.

DESPERATELY in need of help, a Midwest mother recently appealed to me. She wrote in part: "My 16-year-old son, one of millions of restless youth, has become defiant, disobedient, disrespectful, and generally disregards advice and authority from parents and teachers."

PUTNAM'S will publish the report on Japanese atrocities by the late Lieut. Col. William E. Dyess, recently released by the War Department. The book is to appear late next month and now bears the tentative title. "They'll Never Believe You" -- which was General MacArthur's comment on first hearing the accounts of Colonel Dyess and the two officers who escaped with him.

LONDON, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- Thousands of women and children crowded aboard trains leaving London today as a renewal of almost nightly air attacks started the capital's third great evacuation of the war.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- British West African troops have captured the Kaladan valley town of Kyauktaw in western Burma, posing a new threat to the hard-pressed Japanese on the Arakan front, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

IT isn't often these days that motion pictures, for all their obvious appropriateness, are used to explore the realms of fancy or the psychic regions behind beyond. There was a time, in the toddling stage of pictures, when that sort of thing was quite the fad and gay camera men with caps turned backward were forever filming "dreams" and raising ghosts.

Mrs. Eileen Phelan of 28 Harrison Avenue, Montclair, N.J., in services yesterday at the Second Service Command on Governors Island, accepted a Silver Star award for her husband, First Lieut. Lawrence J. Phelan, 28 years old, a German prisoner, who is believed to be confined in a camp in Poland.

JAPANESE "co-prosperity," as applied to the motion-picture trade in enemy-occupied territory, is strictly an all-Japanese affair, according to James E. Perkins, Far Eastern manager for Paramount, who was among the most recent group of repatriated Americans to return home on the Gripsholm.

A MIDDLE-AGED blind man is assembling motors. A 72-year-old veteran is running a glue wheel on a night shift. A housewife is operating a bridge-type overhead electric crane. Women and children are working in the fields, in stores and at almost every other kind of job.

NEW YORK is a monster, or so it seems to Bricky Coleman. It has crushed her and will not let her go. Quinn Williams, too, has been defeated. He knows that within a few hours the police will be looking for him. Bricky and Quinn have come from the same small town in Iowa, but they never meet until both are desperate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, today announced the reappointment of Thomas W. Lamont, New York banker, as chairman of the advisory committee for the Red Cross War Campaign Fund drive for $200,000,000 which will begin on March 1.

Frank Drury of 129 West Eighty-fifth Street, the 15-year-old high school student accused by the police of having killed Henry Pederson, 11, of 17 West Eighty-fourth Street, with a rifle shot two weeks ago, burst into tears as he was being arraigned before Magistrate Anna M. Kross in the Homicide Court yesterday morning.

Alex Rose, State secretary of the American Labor party yesterday unqualifiedly denied the charge of Louis Hollander, president, and Harold J. Garno, secretary treasurer, of the New York State Congress of Industrial Organizations, that he had inspired the Dies Committee's investigation of the political activities of the CIO.

Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, will address the opening session of the two-day conference of the American Retail Federation at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, beginning on Tuesday. Mr. Bowles will discuss "Price Control and the Retailer."

The Grand Cross of St. Sava was presented yesterday to Bishop William T. Manning on behalf of the King and the Royal Yugoslav Government after a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria. He was honor guest of Ambassador Konstantin Fotitch of Yugoslavia.

A dead man unknown to Mrs. Margaret Dwyer gave to the 60-year-old widow of 42 West Sixty-fifth Street the possibility of partly restored vision after seven years of almost total blindness, it was disclosed yesterday at Bellevue Hospital.

A 16-year-old Staten Island schoolboy was saved from going to Sing Sing prison for life yesterday when Judge Thomas J. Walsh in the County Court at St. George, S.I., permitted him to plead guilty to one count in a thirteen-count grand larceny indictment.

The importance of mutual understanding among the nations as a prerequisite for any enduring peace after the war was stressed by Col. Carlos P. Romulo, Secretary of Information and Public Relations of the Commonwealth of the Philippines, in his address at the Opera Victory Rally yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Dr. Frank S. Lloyd, executive director of the physical fitness division of the Federal Security Agency and Professor of Education at New York University, has been appointed chairman of the Hygiene Department of City College, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, the president.

PERHAPS of all creations of man language is the most astonishing. Those small articulated sounds, that seem so simple and so definite, turn out, the more one examines them, to be the receptacles of subtle mystery and the dispensers of unanticipated power.

MR. YARMOLINSKY'S is the third Russian anthology to appear this season. Its distinction is that it confines itself to the nineteenth-century great, to their stories. It contains fifty-three, an immense rich stock.

A shortage of grain for human consumption and livestock feeding and for the production of industrial alcohol can be avoided by utilizing sawdust and other wood wastes available at hundreds of sawmills throughout the United States, says Wilson Compton, executive officer of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association.

Overriding by Congress of the President's veto makes the new excise taxes effective April 1, and retailers yesterday began to complete plans for handling the levies. It was learned that a request has been made to the Office of Price Administration for a ruling which would leave it up to the individual merchant whether to list the taxes as separate items, or include them in the price quoted to the customer.

David Nadien, 17-year-old New York-born violinist who made his debut in Town Hall on Feb. 5, 1941, gave another recital there yesterday afternoon. Despite his youth, Mr. Nadien's performance was the easy, comfortable playing of one thoroughly at home with his instrument.

A TECHNIQUE of food preservation that is arousing no end of interest and speculation is quick-freezing. Victory gardeners who used this process last year in dealing with the fruits of their toil have much to say in its praise, little in disfavor.

OSSINING, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- While Sing Sing authorities notified State Executioner Joseph Francel today to report to the prison Thursday night to put to death five Brooklyn slayers, Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, racket king, one of the doomed prisoners, indicated he still hoped something would happen to save him from the electric chair.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (AP) -- City College of New York avenged a setback suffered earlier in the season by defeating the St. Joseph's quintet, 44-41, at Convention Hall before 4,935 tonight.

WELLINGTON, N. Z., Feb. 25 (Delayed) -- The United States Navy's westward penetration of the Pacific promises more than a military advantage and may be felt as far away as the homes of Europeans liberated from the enemy, it was said today, because the recent successes threaten Nauru and other islands that have been, in the past, the main sources of phosphate for Australia and New Zealand.

An English version of Smetana's opera "Dalibor" was given in concert form, with two pianos replacing the orchestra, last night in Town Hall. This was probably the first hearing of the work as a whole in America, although the opera, the third that Smetana wrote, had its premiere May 16, 1868, on the occasion of the laying of the cornerstone of the National Theatre in Prague.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The pro-Soviet Polish National Council recently established in Russia has offered to discuss the Russian Polish boundary question on the basis of Moscow's "Curzon line proposals" and has isued a decree appointing a new "commander in chief of the Polish armed forces," it was learned tonight.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Twenty blast furnaces and more than ninety open hearth furnaces in Monongahela Valley mills of Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation resumed "nearly full" operation just before midnight tonight following the return of several hundred striking workers to their duties at the corporation's huge Clairton coke works, a company spokesman said.

CAMBRIDGE, England, Feb. 26 (Canadian Press) -- The boat race in which Oxford today defeated Cambridge normally is an annual one, but twice has been dropped during the war. Despite handicaps of a borrowed boat and a strange course, the Dark Blues took the lead at the half-mile mark and held it.

Not all Americans are as yet resigned to the self-denial that the war requires of everyone. Butter still creeps into parlor conversation, the dearth of porterhouse steak is good for at least an hour of grousing, and when these subjects are worn thin there is always the gasoline shortage.

Commemorating its 125th anniversary, Colgate University will sponsor a radio symposium on March 4, on "The American College: Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow." Carried nation-wide through the facilities of the National Broadcasting Company between 2 and 2:30 P.M., the symposium will provide the program for thirty-four Colgate Alumni Clubs meeting in cities throughout the country.

Readers of this department will probably remember our account of the theory put forward by Sir Richard Paget to explain the origin of language. According to this, man learned to talk by way of gesturing. Prof. Alexander Johannesson of the University of Iceland now comes out in the British scientific weekly Nature with an account of his own work along the same line.

ALGIERS, Feb. 26 -- The first full-length play with a cast including USO girls, Wacs, G.I.'s and a Royal Air Force corporal will open a three-night run here Monday night. The show is planned to get away from "one-man shows" by Hollywood stars who have been sharply criticized in this theatre.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Informal consultations with the other American republics regarding the nature and significance of the sudden change of leadership of the Argentine Government on Thursday have begun, it was learned tonight, and it is believed probable that a dissolution of diplomatic relations with Argentina may result.

Thousands of tenants in New York have failed to take steps to get rent savings due them under concession clauses in their leases, either because they do not realize that they are entitled to reductions under a recent ruling of the Office of Price Administration in connection with rent freezing here, or because they are not familiar with the procedure to be followed.

WHEN all is said and done, there are only two distinct ways of writing a novel. There is the way of the spectator who stands outside looking in, and the way of the participant who is inside looking out.

With the Red Cross 1944 War Fund campaign for $200,000,000 officially getting under way on Wednesday throughout the nation, Mayor La Guardia issued a proclamation last night calling upon the citizens of New York City to take part in the campaign and give generously to the fund.
Knockouts featured the boxing card at the Ridgewood Grove S. C., Brooklyn, last night, abbreviating a six-bout program for a crowd of about 3,500.

Here and there a reader may some day be confronted with the job of rounding up a two-thirds majority in the United States Senate to ratify a treaty or organize a two-thirds majority in the House of Representatives to override a Presidential veto.

THE Soviet Far East, the vast, bleak, sparsely settled territory between Lake Baikal and the Arctic and Pacific Oceans, is one of the least known regions of the world, so far as the developments of the last ten or fifteen years are concerned.

NAPLES, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The death of the first American Red Cross woman killed in action in this theatre of war was announced today. She was Miss Esther Richards, 46, a San Francisco hospital social worker, who was a victim of a German bombing of the Anzio beachhead Feb. 7.

Broker-dealers registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission have had more than a year in which to file their financial statements, as required by the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended. Many have done so. Some have not done it, but so far no disciplinary action has been taken against them as the administrators have taken the view that a period of education has been necessary.
LONDON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- An American Air communique:
Two of the most important designers in the New York fashion scene are Philip Mangone and Vincent Monte Sano.

Service on all four bus lines operated by the Queens-Nassau Transit Company was halted at 8 o'clock last night, but with a subsequent arrangement for resumption this morning, in a dispute between the company and a local of the Transport Workers Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations affiliate, over the discharge of a driver.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 26 -- The Naval Academy basketball team completed its home season today by defeating the University of Maryland quintet, 69 to 35.

Two hundred plans for the rehabilitation of the post-war world have been published, but they have been either "too realistic" or "too idealistic," the Rev. Gerald G. Walsh, Professor of History at Fordham University's Graduate School and editor of Thought, the university's quarterly, declared yesterday.

IT seems to have been yesterday -- as matter of fact it was 1918 -- when a bold, bad young composer from Russia came to Boston, Mass., and on being asked by the present observer whom he considered the greatest living Russian composers answered quietly, "Stravinsky, Miaskovsky, and myself."

"THE greatest fighter I ever saw," he said, "was Jack Dempsey. In his prime I'm sure he'd have been able to knock out Joe Louis. While Joe is a hard hitter with either hand, Jack also was a two-fisted slugger -- and a lot faster, too. Dempsey would pound Louis on every clinch, hammering unceasingly on the temple, on the cheek or on the chin.

THE more you know about an art form -- so runs an honored truism -- the more your capacity for its enjoyment increases. This excellent anthology offers a unique opportunity to further your understanding of the cinema -- which is an art form, as Mr. Nichols says in his introduction, no matter who claims it isn't.

THIS is a picture book (and the pictures are magnificent) covering the history of our country from the day Columbus almost set foot upon our shores to Cornwallis' surrender and the rush of migration over the Alleghenies.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26 -- With the Republican Presidential nominating convention less than four months away, Governor Dewey of New York now heads the candidate list in every section of the country.

Warnings against the growth of Federal power at the expense of States' rights were given by Representative Bertrand W. Gearhart, Republican, of California, and Gov. Sumner Sewall of Maine, at a forum yesterday afternoon at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- In a joint statement today, Representatives Richard B. Wigglesworth of Massachusetts and Louis E. Miller of Missouri, the two Republican members of the five-man Special House Committee investigating the Federal Communications Commission, charged that the Roosevelt Administration had from the first sought to "sabotage" the investigation.

Vice President Henry A. Wallace is scheduled to speak on the problems of small business at a dinner meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on March 17, under the auspices of the American Business Congress, 25 West Forty-third Street.
TORONTO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Black Hawks took a step nearer a berth in the Stanley Cup playoffs tonight by beating the Maple Leafs, 3 to 2, in a National Hockey League game.

LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 27 -- The German Army appeared to be retreating rapidly from all of northwestern Russia today as Moscow announced that Soviet forces yesterday had not only captured two railway stations on the roads to Pskov, but had overrun 310 localities and ousted the Germans from 105 miles of a north-south railway less than seventy miles from Latvia.

For the fifth time since the outbreak of the war New York City was shelled accidentally when yesterday at 11:35 A.M. an anti-aircraft gun aboard a United Nations cargo ship at Pier 95, Fifty-sixth Street and the Hudson River, was discharged during a practice session for its crew.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- There is a tendency in some quarters in Washington and elsewhere to call each new dispute between the President and Congress an irrevocable break which means the end of all collaboration between the executive and legislative branches of the Federal Government.

THE NEW YORK TIMES is to be commended for its reporting of maritime affairs and particularly for the comments on American merchant shipping and its decisive importance to the war effort of the United Nations. May I avail myself of the opportunity to review some of the complex shipping problems that are bound to arise?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Jan Ciechanowski, Polish Ambassador to the United States, has left for London to report to his Govern ment there the views of the United States on settlement of the Russo-Polish boundary dispute.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The German fighter air force has suffered its heaviest defeat of the war. Preparation for the Allied invasion of Europe has begun with a resounding success. These are the preliminary results of the Allied aerial offensive of the past week whose effect on Anglo-American strategy will not be realized in full until the great battles of this year are fought

In the last eighteen months the Grace Line has awarded fourteen gold medals for conspicuous bravery in action or for extraordinary feats of navigation and seamanship to officers and men on board Grace vessels, it was disclosed here last week.

Rabbi Louis I. Newman in a sermon yesterday in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, warned that the revolt of Congress, as manifested by its overriding of the President's veto of the tax bill, must not be allowed to create disunity in the effort to win the war and win the peace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Employers are increasingly accepting the principles underlying the National Labor Relations Act and employes are using the National Labor Relations Board's machinery more, rather than resorting to direct action and strikes, according to Dr. Harry A. Millis, chairman, in submitting the board's eighth annual report to Congress today.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, Feb. 26 -- Wendell Willkie visited the Cassino front today -- by proxy. The proxy happened to be his 24-year-old son, Lieut. (j g) Philip Willkie of the United States Navy. "You see," Philip explained, "I want to go somewhere my dad has not already been."

MANY home gardeners who have been able to collect wood ashes this winter wonder how to use them to best advantage. Wood ashes are valuable, for their chief ingredient is potash, one of three important elements for plant growth.

HAD it not been for the Pennsylvania Dutch farmers who sent their grain and meat to Valley Forge instead of selling it for British gold, that dark winter of 1777-78 might have ended differently and so, too, the Revolution.

Seven temporary injunctions against that many restaurants and orders to show cause returnable next Tuesday why they should not be restrained from violating Office of Price Administration price regulations were signed yesterday by Judge William Bondy of the United States District Court.
BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 26 -- The Balkan press today expressed keen interest in reports that a Finnish delegation was en route to Moscow.

BESPECTACLED maidens who have suffered long from allusions to their lack of allure need weep no more. Eyeglasses have "got style." The new frames are like gay, confetti-colored fashion accessories -- so chic in appearance that one is sorely tempted to buy a whole wardrobe in tones of cinnamon and emerald and blue.
CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A communique from the Headquarters of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell:

IT is the belief of this department that there has been no healthier tendency in American creative writing than the re-emergence during recent years of a vital regionalism. It is encouraging to see that tendency being fostered by the publishers, the universities and other effective agencies.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 26 -- A cheerful outlook for Bermuda's tourist trade after the war is taken by representatives of two airlines that will probably have much to do with building it up -- Phil S. Delaney of the Atlantic traffic division of Pan American Airways and W. Sanger Green, manager of the passenger-cargo department of American Export Air Lines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Wartime requirements for industrial alcohol this year will exceed by 39,000,000 gallons the amount which every existing facility for its production plus the new plants which the nation is erecting can produce, the War Production Board has warned the country.

"THE Silence of the Sea" is a small, pale blue book, forty-seven pages of large print, with a pure white gull traced on its cover. It is innocent and frail enough looking to the eye -- like a little book which might be seen lying on a nursery table.

Necessities of wartime are forcing the University of Virginia to turn back, temporarily at least, to Thomas Jefferson's plan for opening the session in the spring and closing it in the fall. The 121st session will open March 3 and will close Oct. 28, according to the revised and speeded-up academic calendar.
Leading contract bridge champions were pacing the field yesterday as sixty-two pairs began play for the Eastern States pair championship and the Julian Goldman trophy at the Park Central Hotel here.

One hundred delegates from the East and Midwest to the third annual conference of the Jewish Council for Russian War Relief, which will be held at Manhattan Center this morning, were guests of honor at a reception yesterday afternoon at the Soviet Consulate, 7 East Sixty-first Street.

DANVILLE, Ill., Feb. 26 (AP) -- A criminal information charging the New York Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and some thirty officers and subsidiaries with violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Law was filed in Federal court today.

Debutantes of this season and recent years have been organized as committee members to assist with plans for the annual benefit opera party of the Grenfell Association of America, Which has taken over the performance of "Tristan und Isolde" for the afternoon of March 14 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Two new records, one by Gilbert Dodds, sensational Boston A.A. miler, and the other by Robert Ufer, University of Michigan star, together with the tying of one by Ed Conwell, New York University flyer, featured the National A.A.U. indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden last night.

While the President's veto of the Revenue Act of 1943 (H.R. 3687) has been overcome by a repassage of the act by better than the required two-thirds vote of both houses of the Congress, the President's veto message will go down in history as an unprecedented executive document. The bill became law Friday last, Feb. 25.

Prints are the bright illustrations of fashion. They are humorous, serious, gay or just beautiful. Sometimes they are even topical, as in the case of the most-discussed lady of the day, the pin-up girl. Again they are just whimsical. A sell-satisfied cat -- probably the pet of some designer -- sits calmly with bristling whiskers on milady's dress.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 26 -- The city of Buenos Aires again has been thrown into a state of expectation, not unmixed with alarm, by the considerable volume of troop movements that occurred early this morning in the near-by military base of Campo de Mayo.

THOMAS MARIO escaped from college after brief incarceration, commenced a satire of campus life, ran out of funds, found work (in his case as a vegetable cook in a Hew York hotel) and has now got out a book.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Governor Dewey sees in what he terms "the fight against Congress in Washington" the very existence of that body "at stake." In a letter written today to former Representative William S. Bennet of New York City, Republican candidate in the Twenty-first Congressional District in a special election Tuesday, he said:
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- Connie Mack finally heard from Buck Newsom today. Big Bobo passed along the word that he was 4-F.
Under bleak gray skies the 27,100-ton Essex class aircraft carrier Bennington was launched at a simple ceremony yesterday at the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn.

Serious financial problems, readjustment of the curriculum, dismissal of faculty members, a general overhauling of the existing academic schedules and in some instances discontinuance for the duration face the colleges and universities of the country as an after-math of the War Department's order curtailing the Army Specialized Training Program.

Retailers are beginning to gird themselves, financially and otherwise, for the post-war period. They foresee increased volume, notably in durable goods; some expansion in units, particularly branch stores to meet decentralization and tap outlying areas; the need for new capital, with many millions to be spent for modernization of existing stores, and greater stress on turnover on smaller, model stocks.

LEIGH WHITE is a keenly intelligent, thoughtful young journalist. Always possessed of a fierce sense of justice, his political convictions have been tempered by the shock and pain of a shattered thigh, interminable surgery and the no less real agony of witnessing at close range defeat of the ideas and the peoples which summoned him to European battlefronts and kept him there until his luck ran out.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sunday, Feb. 27 -- A Russian aerial force variously estimated at 100 to 200 planes attacked Helsinki last night and at least thirty fires were blazing in the Finnish capital, reports reaching here today said.

ROGER BUTTERFIELD'S story of Al Schmid is fresh as green grass. It is the simple story of a kid who went to-war as a marine private with laughter on his lips -- and came home again a hero, blinded, still cheerful.
BADEN BADEN, Germany (Delayed) -- American prisoners of war held by Germany have now become sufficiently numerous to warrant separate camps and at least four are in operation.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 26 -- Surprisingly little notice has been taken thus far in the Farm Belt -- whatever may be the testimony before Congress -- of the Selective Service directive to draft boards to re-examine the status of deferred farm workers and to reclassify those who fail to meet the sixteen-unit farm production test.

HAVING arrived home safely after completing one of the longest USO tours overseas, Joe E. Brown will try his hand at radio with a half-hour quiz program at 10:30 P.M. Wednesday over the Blue (WJZ), beginning with March 23.

A QUICK roll-call of the Playwrights Company the other day brought to light the fact that at least one of them should be closely occupied with the trade for some months to come. That faithful of the moment is Elmer Rice, who is thinking of adapting "Tucker's People," the Ira Wolfert novel depicting the "numbers" or "policy" racket in a big American city.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Instead of any blanket increase in the amount of State aid for education, as requested by teachers and educational groups, the policy of the Dewey Administration will be to give an increase over the amount required by the Friedsam formula to a selected group of communities.

SOUTH OF SHENDEROVKA, on the Second Ukrainian Front, Feb. 23 (Delayed) -- Early in the morning I rode to a village in the Cherkassy-Korsun pocket where a week ago the surrounded German divisions attempted to join the Nazi forces attempting to break through from outside the steel ring.

FEW plantings will yield greater dividends of sheer delight than a bed of sweet violets tucked under a tree or in a semi-shady spot beside a much-frequented path. Even the modest wild variety, while unscented, is often so prodigal of bloom that a few plants cleverly massed will produce in spring a vivid show of color far more decorative than a similar grouping of cultivated perennials.

THE letters DDL, initials of "Det Danske Luftfartsselskab" (Danish Aircraft Corporation), are featured on a 20-ore red dated 1918-43 and illustrating a transport plane. Received by Francis J. Schoendorf, the stamp commemorates the founding of that organization.

With spring just around the corner lovers of the bird dog are looking forward to the opening of the field trial season. Already owners of pointers and setters have been working their charges in preparation for the competition Just ahead.

AFTER spending last week lurking in the suburbs, "Porgy and Bess" is to return to the City Center tomorrow evening, thus resuming a career which had been interrupted by a few days of previously booked grand opera. With no disrespect to "Tosca" and "Carmen" as members of the fine arts, both sides no doubt will be glad to see it back.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Naples, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Port battalions unloading supplies fed into the Anzio beachhead and Cassino front simultaneously during recent weeks were especially lauded today by Gen. Sir Harold L.G. Alexander. He said they had set a new world's record for handling general cargo.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Roving American naval forces of great power, which already have struck the Marianas, 3,800 miles west of Pearl Harbor, today gave Japanese garrisons on scores of Central Pacific islands grave cause for anxiety.

A YEAR before the Mormons started their westward march Samuel Brannan sailed from New York with a shipload of Latter-Day Saints bound for California. He established the first English newspaper in San Francisco, and in 1847 crossed half the continent to meet Brigham Young on Green River and urge that the Pioneer Party find its Zion in California.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 26 -- The Red Army's capture of Vitebsk, whose evacuation was reported yesterday

As the oldest subscriber to the Metropolitan Opera, William P. Stephens, boat maker of Bayside, Queens, who is in his ninetieth year, was honored at yesterday afternoon's performance of "The Tales of Hoffmann" by the gift of a diamond and palladium ring.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor asserted today that the cost-of-living study made by the labor members of the President's Cost-of-Living Committee was "absolutely wrong" in asserting that living costs had risen 43.5 per cent since Jan. 1, 1941, instead of 23.4 per cent as reported by the bureau.

THE series of sixteen concerts to be presented next season by the New Friends of Music will be devoted to chamber music of Mozart and chamber music and songs of France from the days of Louis XIV to the Impressionists. The only exception will be a Beethoven program prepared by Lotte Lehmann for the current series and canceled because of illness.

With the delivery last week of its forty-ninth CVE, familarly known as baby flattops, the Seattle-Tacoma Shipbuilding Corporation, a subsidiary of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, completed on time the yard's construction schedule of the small but deadly escort and combat carriers, according to an announcement by John D. Reilly, president of the Todd organization.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 26 -- Two pardons granted today by the Government created some attention here.

Heinrich Himmler, head of the Gestapo and leader of a private army of 600,000 German, French, Netherland, Norwegian, Belgian, Bosnian and White Russian volunteers, has become the No. 2 man in Germany, succeeding Marshal Hermann Goering, who failed to keep his pledge to protect Germany from air attack, Ralph E. Heinzen of The United Press said last night in a cabled interview from Lisbon

A BABY'S need for "mothering" has been discussed more than once on this page. That babies may droop and die under the most scientific care in spotless hospitals, yet pick up and thrive when "mothered" under foster care in grubby tenements, is a fact well established -- Dr. S. Josephine Baker, to name just one pediatrician, has given it emphasis.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- Leading all the way after the first few seconds, Army's unbeaten basketball team scored its thirtieth successive triumph of the season at the expense of New York University in the drill hall today, 46 to 36.

Only two more berths remained to be filled in the seventh annual national invitation basketball tournament, which starts at Madison Square Garden on March 16, following the announcement by Asa Bushnell, chairman of the tourney, yesterday that DePaul University of Chicago and Muhlenberg College of Allentown, Pa., had accepted bids to take part in the competition.

The long conflict between President Roosevelt and Congress flared into the open last week. Stung by a White House rebuke, Congressmen who had been sniping at Administration policies for months launched a furious counter-attack. Behind the explosion were many old grievances stemming from a growing Congressional resistance to the President's leadership.
President Roosevelt yesterday praised Freda Kirchwey, editor and publisher of The Nation, for her contribution to the welfare of the country and the cause of democracy.

Every so often the imperishable "Porgy and Bess" is in our midst. Tonight the George Gershwin-DuBose Heyward classic of American folklore returns to the City Center for its second visit, marking the fourth time its current sponsors, Cheryl Crawford and John Wildberg, have presented it in New York since January, 1942.

Anxious as we are to see a stable Government in a liberated Italy, we should not forget that this ancient land has in the past known representative systems from early times. The people have their own way of recording their will.

The New York Rovers came through with two third-period goals to defeat the Philadelphia Falcons in the Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The visitors scored first, Bill Stewart tallying in the second chapter, but Doug Carrigan tied matters in the third, and he was followed by Jack Mann, who drove home a long shot that gave the New Yorkers the victory by the score of 2 to 1.

Your London correspondent David Anderson in his report, under date of Feb. 12, of the ceremony at which a new English Lincoln shrine was conceived makes the statement that "only recently * * * was the Swanton Morley property identified with the Lincoln family."

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 27 -- The Industrial Hygiene Foundation of the Mellon Institute announced today the formation of a panel to supply information to business and industry on how it can best meet the problem of placing disabled service men in jobs and "make them happy and useful citizens."
PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 27 -- Fourteen more ships have been added to the score against the enemy in the Central Pacific.

A gathering of 1,300 persons, representing labor and all shades of liberals, that taxed the facilities of the grand ballroom of the Commodore Hotel turned out last night to do honor to Freda Kirchwey, editor and publisher of The Nation, at a dinner marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of her association with the magazine and "in recognition of her services to the liberal cause in America."

DETROIT, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, newly crowned champions of the National Hockey League, ran their winning streak to six games by defeating the Red Wings, 5 to 1, before a crowd of 13,347 tonight at Olympia Stadium.

In the vast expanse of the Americas, stretching from Cape Columbia to Cape Horn and comprising more than a score of different countries and Governments which are solidly united in the war against the Axis Powers for the preservation of their own freedom, there remains one festering spot of trouble which is imperiling the security of all.
