WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The from Allied Headquarters in the Southwest Pacific through the Oflice of War Information:

The Mellon Securities Corporation, Drexel Co., Harris Hall Co. and other underwriters are offer today $15,000,000 of electric plant refunding revenue bonds of the Department of Water and Power of the City of Los Angeles, dated Feb. 1, 1944, and due from Feb. 1, 1945 to 1976.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation will make loans to service men returning to private life to assist them in re-establishing the businesses which they were forced to liquidate or turn over to others on entering the service, it was stated today.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 27 -- Military needs, coupled with strong demand from essential civilian channels, last week kept the steel industry at peak activity. Steel ingot output remained unchanged at 97.5 per cent of the rated capacity recorded for Jan. 1, 1944.

Two Dartmouth men, Aud Brindley and Larry Baxter, and Frank (Chink) Crossin of Penn, were unanimous choices of the coaches in their annual selections of the Intercollegiate Basketball League All-Star team, it was announced yesterday. Bob Gale of Cornell and Mike Shinkarik of Princeton were the other two named for the first five.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 27 (AP) The strong track and field team of the United States Military Academy took six first places to defeat the well-balanced Columbia Midshipmen's School cindermen, 61 to 34, today on the dirt track circling th hug edemy field house.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Feb. 28 -- United States warships have sunk four Japanese ships, including a big cargo vessel, in the Kavieng area off New Ireland Island and have again blasted the Rabaul base on New Britain with a heavy pro-dawn bombardment, which heavy and medium bombers followed with an attack of their own, Gen. Douglas MacArthur reported today.

By issuing $2,305,262,410 of new insurance the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company last year brought its insurance in force to $29,180,396,994 and increased its assets to $6,463,803,551, according to a report for 1943 issued yesterday by Frederick H. Ecker, chairman of the board, and Leroy A. Lincoln, president.

Whittled down by combat and defaults, the eighteenth annual Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament, under the auspices of The News Welfare Association, comes to a close tonight in Madison Square Garden. From an original array of about 2,200 entrants, thirty-six boxers remain to vie for prizes in the eight standard ring divisions in two classifications.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday, in his weekly radio broadcast from Gracie Mansion, the formation of a city-wide Committee on Unity, "to promote understanding and mutual respect among all the racial groups in our city."

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The Germans have made plans for the extensive flooding of large parts of the western provinces in the Netherlands in the event of an invasion by the Allies, according to reports reaching Netherlands Government officials in London.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27 -- Quick stoppage of the first March tenders of cotton, revealing an ever-tightening spot position, inflationary ideas about the Barkley incidents and encouragement gained from the price increases permitted by the Office of Price Administration on denim cloth now produced "at a loss," combined last week to stiffen cotton futures on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange.

On Oct. 20, 1922, John Smith of New York studied the calendar, performed an arithmetical calculation on his desk pad, and said: "I am getting along in years. Some day I'll be too old for a city job. All my life I've been dreaming of a nice, quiet little farm to retire to; a farm with blossoming apple trees on it, and spring lambs and all such delights.
A statement on the raid on Helsinki, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Frank C. Moore, State Controller, made known today that the public debt of New York State and its municipalities had been cut by approximately $160,000,000 during the calendar year 1943. He attributed the decline mainly to wartime restrictions on public works and to a sharp curtailment of refunding operations.

Jesus is more than Jesus, not simply a teacher and a personal ideal but the pioneer of a new age on earth for all mankind, declared the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon yesterday in the Riverside Church.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- The surging Chicago Black Hawks roared into a third-place tie with the idle Toronto Maple Leafs tonight by defeating the New York Rangers, 4 to 2, in a National Hockey League game before a Chicago Stadium crowd of 15,944.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Seven States, during March, will, choose 152 Republican and 120 Democratic delegates to the national conventions. The primaries and ballots, too, may provide some initial tests of strength among Republican Presidential aspirants.

The correspondents who have arrived in Lisbon after more than a year's internment give us the first picture of Germany through American eyes we have had since the United States has been at war. It is, of course, a peep-hole picture.

An appeal for the election of William S. Bennet, Republican nominee for Representative, at the special election to be held tomorrow in the Twenty-first Congressional District, on the ground that it would contribute to Congressional independence of President Roosevelt and the New Deal was issued yesterday by Thomas J. Curran, chairman of the New York County Republican Committee.

YONKERS, Feb. 27 -- Mrs. Edith P. Welty, member of Yonkers Common Council, revealed today that she was preparing an ordinance to carry out City Manager William A. Walsh's recommendation to hire three policewomen to keep track of young girls and enforce the curfew law.

Private industry in New York City has definite plans to spend "several billions of dollars" in the first five years after the war in preliminary steps toward resumption of normal business activities, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.

Romolo De Spirito, tenor, was heard in his first full-length New York recital last night in Town Hall. With Carrington Welch at the piano, he presented a program devoted to offerings in French and English. The songs in the vernacular were by contemporary American composers and featured ten novelties by Paul Bowles.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 27 -- Robert Walker, who has the title role in "See Here, Private Hargrove," has been named by Metro for a lead part in the studio's screen version of Jesse Stuart's "Taps for Private Tussle." The company will borrow Walter Brennan from Samuel Goldwyn for one the top character roles.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27 -- Slugging Sammy Byrd, former New York Yankee outfielder, moved into the lead in the $5,000 New Orleans open golf tournament today by firing a three-under-par 69 in the third round for a total score of 212.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- While the United States doubled its shipments of lend-lease supplies to the Soviet Union in 1943, our losses in ships making these deliveries fell from 12 per cent to 1 per cent, Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, announced today.

Dr. Ivan Wright, Professor of Economics at Brooklyn College, warned yesterday that unless the Baruch-Hancock report is followed transition to peacetime production will be retarded. Declaring that unless Government agencies conform to the spirit, as well as the "letter of the Baruch program," Dr. Wright cited the Vinson directive of Nov. 6 as a "striking example of this threat to the reconversion process."

LONDON, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans have recaptured most of the strategically important islands guarding the Dalmatian coast in a spreading counter-offensive supported by Allied sea and air units, reports from Yugoslav headquarters said today.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- There were two major events for the markets last week -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement on the war situation and the resumption of air raids on Great Britain. Both produced some effect, but neither had much actual influence on prices.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Price Administrator Chester Bowles today formed within the Office of Price Administration a Municipal Affairs Committee, which, he said, would work closely with town and city governments in clearing up problems created by "the impact of OPA regulations" on municipalities.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- Jack Sutphen, who slowly but surely has established himself as king of the Larchmont Yacht Club frostbite dinghy fleet, gained victory in the opening session of the spring series today. Once again with his wife as his crew, Sutphen sailed his Rum Dum to the top position with 45 points, bettering Pat O'Gorman and his Felix, with Miss Barbara Bigelow assisting, after five official races. O'Gorman had 42 points.

The two-story taxpayer containing, twelve stores and bowling alleys at the northwest corner of Second Avenue and Forty-second Street has been bought by Jerome Greene for investment from the Bowery Savings Bank. It is 105 by 100 feet and is assessed at $495,000.
The dime-sized red and blue ration tokens came into their own yesterday as they clicked their way into the purses and pockets of shoppers throughout the nation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Circumstances surrounding a private conference this afternoon between Dr. Adrian Escobar, new Argentine Ambassador to the United States, and Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, suggested that the issue of recognition of the regime now in power in Buenos Aires was focusing on the question whether the regime gained control by force.

Several business organizations turning out a variety of products have placed advertisements in all types of media designed to publicize the superiority of branded products over "anonymous nonentities" and to make consumers realize that freedom of choice would be gravely imperiled by adoption of grade labeling practices.

Prompt and resolute action by the War Refugee Board in the rescue of oppressed minorities will bring substantial results, Senator James E. Murray of Montana told the third annual conference of the Jewish Council for Russian War Relief yesterday in Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue.

The first of the new quarterly test blackouts since the War Department relaxed its wartime restrictions was staged last night in this city and seven surrounding counties. The first blue signal was sounded at 9:21 o'clock and the all clear at 9:56 o'clock.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The American "invasion" of Britain is proceeding at an incredible rate. The Army of the Republic moves silently; its arrivals and departures are carefully and correctly blotted out; but the rise of its strength and influence in this island is unmistakable.

The suggestion that the United States has to play a major role in the post-war re-education of the German people seems to have become a fixed idea in this country. Yet if we assume such a role we shall give life to another dangerous doctrine, for whose possibly fatal consequences we shall have to accept the responsibility if we fail in our self-imposed mission of re-educating the German people.

Three museum shows and a Red Cross benefit headline the list of art exhibitions for the coming week. The Metropolitan Museum will open on Wednesday an exhibition illustrating the mosaics of Hagia Sophia -- the great Byzantine church at Instanbul -- and related Turkish and Islamic art.
Four new films are listed to open in local houses this week. The schedule is:

The Bureau of Labor Statistics has subjected the report on the cost of living prepared by two labor representatives on the War Labor Board to a merciless microscopic analysis. The main charges contained in that report have been examined, and an impressive and convincing array of statistics has been amassed to rebut them.

The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, including the representatives of forty-four nations, is the keystone of international cooperation to assure peace and security in the post-war world, A. H. Feller, newly appointed general counsel to that organization, declared last night at a dinner meeting of the Brooklyn ORT Society in the Brooklyn Jewish Center, 667 Eastern Parkway.

While there were fewer buyers in the market last week, because of the holiday, greater numbers are expected in the current period. Buying declined somewhat as sales to the public dropped, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Mrs. Julia G. Bernneimer, mother of five sons, the eldest of whom fought in the Spanish-American War, will celebrate her twenty-second birthday tomorrow. But there will be ninety-two candles on the cake, for this white-haired woman was born in Philadelphia on Feb. 29, 1852, and believes she is the oldest person alive born on a Leap Year Day.

The wide-ranging naval carrier task force raids and the mopping up of the Marshall Islands in the Pacific, and the unparalleled Allied aerial assault upon Germany were the most important operations of last week.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 26 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- An American Ambulance Corps member repatriated Friday from Germany related today one of the strangest stories of the war -- how he survived three sinkings, two of them on German ships where he was held prisoner, before finally being sent to a concentration camp.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY AT CASSINO, Feb. 27 -- Two famous American divisions have been employed in long, severe battles to take Cassino, breach the Gustav Line and bridge the Rapido River, it may now be revealed. Both suffered heavy casualties.

What is the significance of the legend appearing on the label of certain canned fruits and vegetables: "Packed under continuous factory inspection by the United States Department of Agriculture"? This question, sent to us by a woman who evidently believed well-informed shoppers make the best purchasers, prompted us to do a little investigating.

The "wholeness" of Christian experience, the acceptance of all that life has to give in the mysterious variety of its impacts, is distinctive, the Rev. Dr. Hughell E.W. Fosbroke, dean of the General Theological Seminary, declared yesterday morning in a sermon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
Civic, religious and business leaders and thousands of other volunteer workers will gather today throughout the city as a preliminary to opening of the 1944 Red Cross War Fund appeal on Wednesday.

An American private in an English village pub remarked to one of this newspaper's reporters, Drew Middleton, that he didn't like to hear war "called fancy names." Other soldiers profanely agreed. They just didn't care to be called the "spearhead of democracy" or to be lectured on "honor" and "glory."

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Although the movement of hogs was not excessive last week and the permit system on shipments to the local market will be removed within a few days, there has been a further accumulation in supplies of lard and meats in cold storage, due to inability of the Government to take out the product sold for lend-lease purposes as fast as it is processed.

HEADQUARTERS, THIRTEENTH AIR FORCE, South Pacific, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- The bombardier of a patrolling Liberator, a former divinity student and student pastor, murmured "God bless their souls -- and split them in two!" as his stick of bombs dropped on a Japanese destroyer in the Bismarck Sea Wednesday night, it was disclosed today.

Louis Adamic, author of "My Native Land," published last season by Harpers, will speak at the next Book and Author luncheon, to be held March 7 at the Astor Hotel. John Hersey, author of the new Knopf novel, "A Bell for Adano," and Maj. Peter W. Rainier, author of "Pipeline to Battle," brought out by Random House, will be the other speakers.

The concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Artur Rodzinski, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall featured the Chopin piano concerto in F minor, with Witold Malcuzynski as soloist, and the new "Polonaise Symphonique," Op. 52, by Karol Rathaus. Brahms' Fourth symphony, which had figured on the Thursday night and Friday afternoon program last week, rounded out the offerings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Millions of persons now struggling with complicated income tax returns received this consolation today by Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee: This may be the last tax return they ever will have to file.
Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 112.85, a rise of 0.06 per cent from the previous week's level of 112.79.
LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Sir William Beveridge is not the only person in Britain drawing a new economic blueprint for his country. Nor are men the only ones who have something to say on these matters.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 27 -- Every window in downtown Helsinki was shattered in last night s twelve-hour air attack, the worst pounding the Finnish capital had ever received, according to travelers who arrived in Stockholm from there today. Continuous waves of Soviet bombers, in all more than 600, attacked the city from nightfall last night to shortly after 6 A.M. today.
LONDON, Feb. 27 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast by the DNB agency: ]

The furious tempo of the war in the air both over western Europe and the Pacific suggests that the world struggle may soon enter a new phase of operations. There are indications that enemy defense of the sky, which in modern warfare is a nation's first line of defense, may already have been breached.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- Dr. George F. Zook, president of the American Council on Education, announced formation tonight of a commission on motion pictures in education to study the needs of schools land colleges for motion-picture material.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Uleaborg in Northern Finland was bombed last night and there were alarms in Kotka, Aabo and Tornea.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, revealed today that he had written to all members of Congress urging them not to support the proposed "equal rights" amendment.

ON THE SECOND UKRAINIAN FRONT, Feb. 23 (Delayed) -- During the four days this correspondent spent with the troops of Marshals Ivan S. Koneff and Pavel A. Rotimstroff considerable changes have occurred on their fronts in the Dnieper bend.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- Representative Clarence F. Lea, Democrat, of California, chairman of the House committee investigating the Federal Communications Commission, tonight curtly accepted the resignations of Eugene L. Garey, general counsel of the committee, and three aides who had accused Mr. Lea of converting the inquiry into a political whitewash.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A poll described as "incomplete but substantial" of 1940 Republican convention delegates from forty-six States showed that 65.54 per cent of those reporting would vote for the nomination of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York for President in preference to three other men, James S. Kemper, Chicago insurance executive, said here today.

John Feeney, Irish tenor, assisted by the St. Jude Girl Choir, gave a recital last night before a large audience in Carnegie Hall. The program Consisted mostly of Irish songs, after the opening group of numbers by Handel, Dunhill and Purcell. An exception was the aria Una Furtiva Lagrima from Donizetti's opera "L'Elisir d'Amore.

LONDON, Feb. 27 (AP) -Dispatches from Allied HeadquartersI in Italy today said reconnaissanceI photographs of the Nazis' Prufen-I ing aircraft factory at Regensburg, smashed Friday in coordinated attacks by the Fifteenth and Eighth s Air Forces, showed almost total destruction.

Leopold Teraspulsky, the young American 'cellist who made his debut last season, gave his second recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon and again showed that he is a musician of exceptional promise. He played a well-balanced program with maturity of expression and the unmistakable manner of a genuinely gifted artist.
LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 27 -- Forty per cent of all labor in Germany today is done by virtual slave workers drawn from captured and occupied areas.

Cotton prices continued to move moderately upward during most of last week but eased somewhat in final dealings. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 1 to 7 points for the week. At its peak, the spot month was at its highest levels since the 1928-29 season.

A FLYING FORTRESS BASE, England, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- The pilot of a Flying Fortress told today how he finally "ditched' his ship in the English Channel, after having flown two hours skimming housetops over Germany with two motors gone and a third sputtering.

An amended plan to change the capital set-up of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation n compliance with the Public Utility Holding Company Act, which would distribute to its own stockholders all the stock of its northern group of subsidiaries on a basis of 85 per cent to its preferred stockholders and 15 per cent to the owners of the common, has been made public.

Gil Dodds, Boston divinity student and outstanding miler, yesterday received the Amateur Athletic Union's James E. Sullivan award as the amateur athlete who did the most to advance the cause of sportsmanship in 1943, it was reported by The Associated Press.

Twelve months of reducing distribution costs which have proven their effectiveness are described in an article by Fenton B. Turck and William E. Hill, of the industrial engineering concern of Turck, Hill Co., Inc., in the current issue of Mechanical Engineering, official journal of the American Association of Mechanical Engineers.

OSSINING, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- Reports persisted today that counsel for Louis (Lepke) Buchalter were preparing to go to the Federal courts and raise a constitutional technicality to prevent his execution in the electric chair at Sing Sing next Thursday night. This is their last hope of saving him from the death penalty, outside of executive clemency.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Changes in the maximum import price regulation which affects all importers, distributors and retailers of imported goods will be announced Tuesday, Feb. 29, the Office of Price Administration reported today in disclosing it was inviting members of the import trade to an open meeting at the Hotel McAlpin in New York City on Wednesday, at 2 P.M., to discuss the revisions.

In re-reading Thorstein Veblen's book "An Inquiry Into the Nature of Peace," published in 1917, I am struck by its unusual contemporary relevancy. I call attention to one paragraph as a sample of his cogent understanding of the conditions of a lasting peace.

Wayne Lonergan, former Royal Canadian Air Force aircraftsman second class, will be placed on trial at 10:30 A.M. today in General Sessions Court before Judge John J. Freschi on a charge of murdering his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan.

GREENWOOD, Miss., Monday, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- The second of three escaped convict-kidnappers was captured early today atop a block-long cotton warehouse here as police called in units of the Army's K-9 corps of dogs to help capture the third desperado, who also had taken refuge in the building after running gun battles.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Unfavorable weather conditions tended last week to curtail shelling and the movement of corn from farms to country elevators, and this was reflected in somewhat smaller offerings for deferred shipments. Shortage of freight cars is also a factor in holding down the movement, but the grain held in country houses will be moved to terminals gradually and help swell the visible supply.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A challenge to President Roosevelt's authority to create semi-permanent Federal agencies without resort to Congressional appropriations will be laid before the Senate Appropriations subcommittee tomorrow.

Last week's financial market responded wholly to political movements at home; war news cut a less important figure. On Wednesday news of the revolt of Senator Barkley, Democratic leader in the Senate, against the Administration on the tax bill governed the financial market.
ALGIERS, Feb. 27 -- The battle of Italy remained almost suspended again yesterday.

Once more the board of award of the Daniel Guggenheim medal has shown discriminating judgment. It has selected the late Edmund T. Allen for the posthumous award for 1943 of this notable honor in aeronautics. Mr. Allen was killed in February of last year while testing the great combat weapon, the B-29, big brother of the Flying Fortress.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Post-Dispatch said last night in a story from its Washington bureau that because of inability of California wells to meet demands of the American offensive in the Pacific the Army and Navy have projected pipe lines to pump Texas oil across Mexico to Salina Cruz.
